description: To the Editor:

title: The Counter Revolution
description: Henryville, Pa.

title: Raise High the P.R. Blitz
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: IPad Cant Play Flash Video, but It May Not Matter
description: Correction Appended

title: As the Pressure Rises, Snowboarders Cut Back
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Like several of the worlds top professional snowboarders, Travis Rice will be at the Olympics in Vancouver this month for the mens halfpipe event. He just will not compete.

title: Disney Is Said to Be Seeking a Buyer for Its Beleaguered Miramax Unit
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company has been quietly shopping what remains of its Miramax film unit and has attracted seven to 10 interested bidders, according to a mergers and acquisitions expert with knowledge of the process.

title: Insuring Endorsements Against Athletes Scandals
description: In the wake of the Tiger Woods scandal, insurers are being inundated with inquiries from corporations seeking to protect their investments, their brands and even their sales when their celebrity endorsers suffer public embarrassment.

title: Why the iPad Web Demo Was Full of Holes
description: Adobes Flash will probably not come to the iPhone, iPod Touch or iPad, but for many people with these iProducts, this may prove to be a nonissue, as I report in Mondays Times.

title: Brodeur and Devils Are Tired Out by Kings
description: NEWARK  Long after the Los Angeles Kings swarmed defenseman Drew Doughty, celebrating his last-minute goal and an improbable comeback Sunday, Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur was asked to recount what he saw on the play. He said softly that he did not see much of anything.

title: Showcase: It Couldnt Be, but It Is
description: When it was time for coffee, the newspaper director  a bit embarrassed  had to apologize to the guests assembled in his offices in Cartagena.

title: $100 Billion Increase in Deficit Is Forecast
description: WASHINGTON  The additional tax cuts and public works spending that President Obama has proposed to spur job creation would add $100 billion to this years deficit, bringing it to nearly $1.6 trillion, according to an administration official.

title: Winnable Games Become Empty Words to Knicks
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Shortly after slipping a necklace that resembled rosary beads around his neck, Jared Jeffries jokingly offered a preposterous solution to the funk sinking the Knicks playoff hopes. Perhaps, he said, the Knicks should try voodoo.

title: Word of the Day | deduce
description: deduce \di-ds, de-;\ verb

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include personal income and spending for December, construction spending for December and the Institute for Supply Managements manufacturing index for January (Monday); factory orders for December (Thursday); and unemployment for January (Friday).

title: Biggest Haul at Grammys Goes to Beyonc
description: LOS ANGELES  Affirming her role as one of the reigning queens of pop music, Beyonc was the top winner at the 52nd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, taking six prizes, including song of the year for her inescapable hit Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Tent in Port-au-Prince
description: Three families, with 6 adults and 12 children, share a spot in a tent city in Port-au-Prince. They are fearful of the coming rainy season.

title: Smaller Banks Dont Need $30 Billion From U.S.
description: President Obama's speeches suggest he doesnt dislike all banks, just the big ones. Even though he used much of his State of the Union address last week to bash Wall Street and the money business, he threw a bone to the community banking sector. He pledged to divert $30 billion of money repaid from the Troubled Asset Relief Program to smaller banks to help them make loans to small businesses.

title: Patrick to Confront Heat in the Car and Competition on Nascar Tracks
description: The hottest question going into the 2010 Nascar season isnt whether the fan favorite Dale Earnhardt Jr. can be a contender again, or if impending fatherhood will soften the four-time defending champion Jimmie Johnsons grip on the Sprint Cup.

title: Ben Crane Wins at Torrey Pines, but Is the Last to Know It
description: SAN DIEGO  Ben Crane plotted, plodded and methodically captured his third PGA Tour victory on Sunday at the Farmers Insurance Open, overtaking Ryuji Imada at the third hole and never looking back. He came from two strokes off the pace with a two-under-par 70 that gave him a one-stroke victory over three players.

title: Arena-rock, Auto-Tune and a Michael Jackson Tribute at the Grammys
description: The 52nd annual Grammy Awards placed good intentions at the core of the show, with a Michael Jackson tribute that was also a protest: Earth Song. It was another thank-you from a music business that continues to owe Jackson more gratitude, now for being the best-selling act of 2009. His poised son Prince, accepting his fathers latest Grammy, said his message was simple: love, adding, We will continue to spread his message and help the world. Then his daughter, Paris, added: Daddy was supposed to be here. Daddy was going to perform this year.

title: On the Big Screen
description: Times Square may not be a regular destination for art lovers, but starting today fans of the filmmaker Bruce Conner should brave the neon and swarms of tourists to watch a mini-retrospective of his work on MTV's outdoor screen. Presented by Creative Time at 44 , the showcase will feature three films by the artist, who died in 2008 and whose "ecstatic films  fabricated from bits of old documentaries and educational reels, from mass-cultural snips and snails and recycled movie tales  were at once salvage projects and assertions of individuality in an increasingly anonymous age," wrote Manohla Dargis in an appraisal. See for yourself when "Ten Second Film" (1965), "Crossroads" (1976) and "Easter Morning" (2008) are shown through Feb. 28.

title: The Immigrant Experience
description: What does it mean to be American? Hundreds of years have passed, and the question remains as charged as ever. But instead of watching the talking heads on cable news squawk over the answer, listen instead tonight to the authors Jamaica Kincaid, Gary Shteyngart, and others when they read excerpts from the new anthology "Becoming Americans: Four Centuries of Immigrant Writing" at the 92nd Street Y. The anthology includes letters, stories, and diaries documenting the immigrant experience in this country. The contributors will also share their personal experiences in a conversation moderated by the editor Ilan Stavans.

title: Tap Tap Revolution
description: Whether you're a master at step ball change or a first-time hoofer ready to strut your stuff, head over to The Kitchen tonight where the tap dancer, poet and "Bring in 'Da Noise Bring in 'Da Funk" alum Joseph Webb will be hosting "Shim Sham," a free and open jam tap session. Grab your shoes and join him and some of the city's most talented members of the tap community as they come together to show off their moves. Mr. Webb's quartet will provide the musical accompaniment.

title: 10 Americans Arrested in Haiti Await Charges
description: Ten Americans arrested in Haiti for trying to take 33 children across the border without proper documentation were expected to learn Monday whether they would face criminal charges of child trafficking and kidnapping.

title: News Quiz | February 1, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Do Smaller Banks Really Need $30 Billion From U.S.?
description: President Obamas speeches suggest he doesnt dislike all banks, just the big ones, Breakingviews says. Even though he used much of his State of the Union address last week to bash Wall Street and the money business, he threw a bone to the community banking sector, the publication says.

title: The Places They Go When Banks Say No
description: In the glory days of the digital photo frame business, when his products were still a novelty and shoppers were flush with cash, getting a bank loan to manufacture them was a cinch, Michael Levy says.

title: Spotlight at the Grammys
description: Beyonc was the top winner at the 52nd annual Grammy Awards with six prizes, and Taylor Swift won album of the year.

title: Permira Said to Mull Move on Britains DFS
description: Permira, the British buyout shop, has teamed with the retail executive John Lovering to launch a bid for the British furniture retailer DFS, The Sunday Times reported.

title: Risky Trading Wasnt Just on the Fringe at A.I.G.
description: Ever since the American International Group nearly collapsed, the conventional wisdom has been that the exotic derivatives that drove it to the brink were the product of a lone, unregulated subsidiary in London. The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, called the London branch a hedge fund, basically, attached to a large and stable insurance company.

title: Germany Weighs Purchase of Swiss Client Data
description: An informant is offering to sell the German authorities details of 1,500 individuals who allegedly have untaxed income stashed away in Swiss bank accounts, the Finance Ministry confirmed Sunday, Judy Dempsey writes in The New York Times.

title: Saudi Securities Regulator Fines 6 Investors
description: The Saudi stock market regulator has ordered six investors to pay a total 278.1 million riyals ($74.16 million) for trading violations, it said in a statement on Saturday.

title: Center of Change
description: Images from the International Civil Rights Center and Museum in Greensboro, N.C.

title: When the Saints Come Marching In
description: WHO are crazy because of an event that unleashed a raucous, trombone-blaring, grown-man-weeping, stranger-hugging frenzy in New Orleans recently?

title: Why Do You Play Sports?
description: Thats the question a high school sophomore in Connecticut asked kids in youth leagues all over his town in an effort to update data in a 20-year old scientific study. How would you answer? What do you think was the top response kids  both boys and girls gave this young researcher?

title: Travelport Prices I.P.O. at $1.78 Billion
description: Travelport, the travel reservations company controlled by the Blackstone Group, on Monday announced a price range for its $1.78 billion London listing, valuing the companys equity at between $3.05 billion and $3.45 billion, Reuters reported.

title: Morgan Stanley Said to Plan Hiring Traders
description: Morgan Stanley plans to hire several hundred traders over the next few years to boost its underperforming securities business, the chief executive, James Gorman, said in an interview with The Financial Times.

title: Harrahs Said to Seek Melco Stake in Macau
description: Harrahs Entertainment, the casino company, could try to buy Crowns stake in Melco Crown Entertainment to acquire its Macau gambling assets, David Bain an analyst at Sterne, Agee & Leach, wrote in a note to clients.

title: Volcker: How to Reform Our Financial System
description: President Obama 10 days ago set out one important element in the needed structural reform of the financial system. No one can reasonably contest the need for such reform, in the United States and in other countries as well. We have after all a system that broke down in the most serious crisis in 75 years. The cost has been enormous in terms of unemployment and lost production. The repercussions have been international, Paul A. Volcker writes in an Op-Ed piece in The New York Times.

title: Bravo and Foursquare to Engage TV Fans on Phones
description: Starting Monday, you may have the opportunity to steal a mayorship from Padma Lakshmi, the host of Bravos reality TV show Top Chef.

title: Disney Seeks Buyer for Beleaguered Miramax Unit
description: The  The Walt Disney Company has been quietly shopping what remains of its Miramax film unit and has attracted seven to 10 interested bidders, The New York Timess Brooks Barnes reported, citing a mergers and acquisitions expert with knowledge of the process.

title: All Those Little Stuyvesant Towns
description: When money grew on trees during the late great credit boom, private equity firms plunged headlong into New York City real estate. Not only did these companies snag dazzling Manhattan office towers, they also paid up for thousands of mundane rental apartments across the five boroughs.

title: Citi Said to Plan Sale of Private Equity Unit
description: Citigroup plans to sell or spin off its $10 billion Citi Private Equity unit in order to cut debt, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Most Banks Cut Political Giving, Study Shows
description: Nine of the 10 biggest U.S. banks by assets, including Bank of America, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, reduced their political giving last year, Federal Election Commission reports show.

title: U.N. Leader Seeks Elusive Unity Deal in Cyprus
description: PARIS  After decades of ethnic strife, political wrangling and fruitless diplomacy, leaders of Cypruss divided communities began meetings Monday with the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, months before elections that could further complicate the quest for a settlement.

title: BlueCrests Flagship Fund Said to Near Capacity
description: It appears that things are going so well for some top hedge funds that they are moving to close their best funds to new investors.

title: HCA to Pay Its Owners $1.75 Billion Dividend
description: HCAs private equity owners must be feeling a bit richer.

title: Scandinavia at War
description: OSLO  The NATO secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, must know as a Dane that his fellow Scandinavians wont be contributing much to the troop surge he has promised in Afghanistan. With more than 1,600 soldiers in the fight (or in Afghanistan anyway) the Danish, Swedish and Norwegian militaries say theyre already going full tilt. They will stay  but expect no Viking surge.

title: Bailout Encourages Risk at Banks, Watchdog Says
description: The American taxpayer-funded rescue program set up to save banks from collapse during the financial crisis makes future reckless behavior more likely, the governments bailout watchdog said in a quarterly report.

title: The Financial Crisis, Through Paulsons Eyes
description: When it comes to the collapse of Lehman Brothers, former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. blames the British.

title: JAL Still Neutral on Delta or American Tie-Up
description: The new president of Japan Airlines said the bankrupt carrier had not yet decided whether to stick with a partnership including American Airlines or to defect to Delta Air Lines and its SkyTeam group.

title: UBS Stock Hit by Swiss Ministers Comments
description: Shares in UBS fell on Monday after the Swiss justice minister said the economy would suffer if the Swiss bank collapsed as a result of its United States tax dispute, Reuters reported.

title: HSBC Said to Consider  China Bank Bid
description: HSBC  is considering a bid for a major Chinese bank to reinforce its presence in the country as other foreign lenders retrench, The Sunday Telegraph reported, citing unnamed sources.

title: To All Intensive Purposes
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their most elaborate and awkward malapropisms  or, according to a lady overheard in North London, Mapplethorpisms.

title: Dubai Port Operator Mulls Australia I.P.O.
description: DP World, the port operator that is part of the Dubai World conglomerate, is considering a 1 billion Australian dollars ($884 million) initial public offering by spinning off some of its Australian assets, a media report said on Monday.

title: In Amsterdam, Where Art Meets Wine
description: If the thought of traipsing past the Rembrandts and Vermeers at the Rijksmuseum doesnt inspire you, perhaps the lure of wine tasting will. At Amsterdams Art Vine, you can soak up some culture while sipping a glass of well-selected wine. A gallery in the center of the canal belt, Art Vine pairs specific wines with paintings on display, aiming to enhance the experiences of both the art and the wine through a sensory juxtaposition.

title: In $3.8 Trillion Budget, Obama Pivots to Trim Future Deficits
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama declared in presenting his new 10-year budget proposal on Monday that our fiscal situation remains unacceptable, but he insisted that the country pursue his ambitious domestic agenda despite facing swollen budget deficits for the foreseeable future.

title: Icahn Resigns from Blockbuster Board
description: Carl C. Icahn has given up his seat on Blockbusters board, citing Institutional Shareholder Services guidelines regarding how many directorships he can hold.

title: How Much Do We Spend Caring for Family?
The War Against Suburbia
description: Todays idea: The Obama administrations city-focused, environmentalist war against suburbia helps explain the Democrats recent electoral setbacks from Virginia to Massachusetts, a commentator writes. Urban-dense, smart growth policies may not be smart politics.

title: Tesla Motors Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Tesla Motors, the electric car company in Silicon Valley, said on Friday that it had filed plans to sell shares to the public.

title: Afghan Official Dismisses Taliban Denial of Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan official in charge of reconciliation acknowledged Monday that the government had been in talks for some time with Taliban leaders to bring them into the government and end the war, dismissing the Talibans denials.

title: Scores Killed in Attack on Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A woman who veiled her explosives in a black robe struck a column of Shiite pilgrims on the outskirts of Baghdad on Monday in a suicide attack that Iraqi officials had predicted but could not stop.

title: With Eye on Its Reputation, Toyota Issues Repair for Pedal
description: DETROIT    Toyota, struggling to eliminate questions surrounding millions of its vehicles, announced a repair on Monday to stop gas pedals from possibly sticking and causing cars to speed up unexpectedly.

title: JPMorgan Said to Pass on RBS Sempras U.S. Unit
description: President Barack Obamas proposal to ban banks from engaging in in proprietary trading has thrown a wrench into RBS Sempras plans to sell its global commodities trading business to JPMorgan Chase for 2.5 billion ($4 billion), according to press reports.

title: Clean Energy Poised to Attract Financing
description: From Cezary Podkul at Green Inc.:

title: Swamped With Calls
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, please send them one per comment:

title: Speed Read for Monday, Feb. 1
description: Here are some highlights from Mondays edition of The New York Times:

title: Wall Streets Democratic Defenders
description: Since the onset of the financial crisis, Democrats have been quick to castigate Wall Street for dragging the country down into recession, laying into financial executives for their fat cat bonuses and for the risks they undertook with an implicit government guarantee.

title: Lawmakers Eye Obamas Budget
description: It is budget week on Capitol Hill as President Obama releases his spending blueprint, intensifying the ongoing political battle over fiscal issues.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Tiber Hood | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Man and Machine, Both Beautiful, Meet at Grand Central
description: On an unusually warm day last week, 109 feet beneath Grand Central Terminal, a New York City firefighter was taking his clothes off.

title: Media Equation: iPad is a Bit of a Tabula Rasa Offering a Glimpse of the Future
description: In his Media Equation column Monday morning, David Carr takes a look at Apples ballyhooed iPad and concludes that its future will be determined by the coming flood of new applications and media deals. But even now, without them, it is clear that the new device is a glimpse over the horizon  I couldnt say the future had arrived, but Im pretty sure you can see if from here, Mr. Carr writes.

title: China Rejects Demands for Greater Tibetan Autonomy
description: BEIJING  Chinese officials have rejected demands by the Dalai Lama that Tibetan areas of China receive greater autonomy and be governed as a single region, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Monday.

title: The Early Word: Budget Release
description: The White House releases President Obamas proposed budget for the 2011 fiscal year this morning.

title: Sampler: Sewage in the Bay and a Vietnamese-American Deputy Police Chief in San Jose
description: Sewage in the Bay | During last weeks storms, 630,000 gallons of raw sewage entered the San Francisco Bay at 47 spots, according to San Francisco Baykeeper, an environmental watchdog group. In addition, 170 million gallons of under treated sewage were discharged into the Bay, the group reported. Outdated sewer pipes and processing plants contribute to spills happening when big storms overwhelm the draining systems. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Should CBS Have Allowed the Tebow Ad?
description: Tim Tebow has been criticized for his passing technique recently, but he had no trouble lobbing a political football right into the middle of the Super Bowl:

title: Exxon Grew as Oil Industry Contracted
description: While much of the oil industry contracted last year, Exxon Mobil expanded its oil and gas operations in the United States and around the world.

title: Chinas Smart Grid Investments Growing
description: Chinas overall federal stimulus investments in smart grid projects will surpass the United States in 2010, according to a forthcoming market research report  though not on a per capita basis.

title: After Fire Kills 5, Grief and Questions Multiply
description: In Brooklyn, a Guatemalan immigrant grieved for his wife, killed after their tenement apartment burst into flames as they slept. His eyes red from sobbing, his hand stitched and bandaged beneath a new black funeral suit, the man could do no more than console his toddler son while waiting to see if his infant daughter would live.

title: Red Carpet at the 2010 Grammy Awards
description: Celebrities arriving at the annual music awards ceremony in Los Angeles.

title: WWS 543: Class notes, 2/1/10
description: A brief history of trade policy. (pdf)

title: When Legal Bills Become a Cause for Dispute
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: The Grammy Photo That Pretty Much Says It All
description: Well, maybe next year Ill be seated behind Paul Simon, he said to himself with a sigh.

title: Manufacturing Expanded Last Month
description: Manufacturing in the United States expanded at the fastest rate in five years in January, renewing hope that rising activity at the nations factories may help lead the economy out of its downturn.

title: Judge Ties Italy Secret Service to Clerics Abduction
description: ROME  The Italian secret service was most likely aware of, and perhaps complicit in, the abduction of an Egyptian cleric from the streets of Milan in 2003, a judge in Milan said Monday. But, he added, state secrecy prevented the court from proving this.

title: Ask a Yoga Instructor
description: This week, Bryn Chrisman, a vinyasa flow yoga teacher and kirtan leader in New York City, will be responding to readers questions about her path to yoga, her current job, her practice, kirtan and other matters of interest.

title: Converting Coal Plants to Biomass
description: Coal-powered generating stations retrofitted to run on a mixture of coal and dried wood pellets can produce cost-competitive, emission-reduced electricity even without the advent of a cap-and-trade system, according to a new biomass life cycle analysis published in the Journal of Environmental Science and Technology.

title: Weve Got a Situation: Jersey Shore Culture Invades Manhattan
description: ALTHOUGH the finale of MTVs quasi-reality show Jersey Shore was shown more than a week ago, the after-effects  and spinoffs  are sure to be felt for a while, now that the fist pump (a display of enthusiasm) is creeping into the vernacular. For New Yorkers who found the series far too brief, it is possible to drink and eat your way back to the shore.

title: Another Fire Death Reported in Brooklyn
description: Just two days after five people died in a Brooklyn fire, another fire in that borough claimed a life.

title: Monday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Motorsports Links: F1 Testing Underway in Spain
description: Motorsports news from around the Web

title: The Fight for Paid Maternity Leave
description: During the discussion here last week about Britains new paternity-leave policy, many of you asked who was leading the charge to bring the U.S. in line with other countries.

title: In Lake Placid, Rustic Luxury at a Discount
description: The winter Olympics were held in Lake Placid, N.Y., 30 years ago. And this winter, for those who cannot make it to Vancouver, the Lake Placid Lodge, an Adirondack-style inn, with its ultimate in rustic luxury, is offering discounted packages.

title: Shell to Join Brazils Cosan in Ethanol Joint Venture
description: Cosan, the Brazilian sugar and biofuel giant, said Monday it will merge its ethanol and fuel distribution units with Royal Dutch Shell in a joint venture worth up to $12 billion, extending the trend of growing foreign investment in alternative fuels, Reuters reports.

title: YouTubes Newest Star: President Obama
description: In todays Times, Brian Stelter writes:

title: Kinko's? Yes, Sometimes.
description: In a $1 billion enterprise, some government work is outsourced to the private sector.

title: Protecting the Budget
description: Confidentiality and multiple levels of security clearance prevent breaches of the budget and other government documents.

title: Calvin and Hobbes Creator Speaks
description: Its not quite as impressive as scoring, say, the last known interview with J. D. Salinger, but The Cleveland Plain Dealer has landed what is believed to be the first interview in nearly 20 years with Bill Watterson, the reclusive creator of the comic strip Calvin and Hobbes. Mr. Wattersons newspaper cartoons about a headstrong young boy named Calvin and his stuffed tiger, Hobbes, ran in syndication from 1985 to 1995, until the artist stepped away from the strip at the peak of its popularity, and he has rarely spoken about it since.

title: Boston Scientific to Pay $1.7 Billion to Settle Patent Suits
description: Boston Scientific said Monday that it would pay $1.725 billion to a unit of Johnson & Johnson to settle long-running disputes between the companies over patents for coronary stents.

title: A Tougher A at Princeton Has Students on Edge
description: Update | 1:26 p.m. In nearly 100 comments and counting, reader response on the issue of grade inflation has been fierce. For a sense of how one important arbiter  Yale Law School  interprets undergraduate grades, I draw your attention to this comment, from Asha Rangappa, the dean of Yale Law (and a Princeton graduate.)  Jacques

title: Lazio Criticizes Cuomo for Dithering on Election Plans
description: ALBANY  The message to Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo lately from both Republicans and Democrats, it seems, is: Just declare already.

title: How a Budget Comes Together
description: The Government Printing Office produces the budget, which fills four volumes, in about a week, including last-minute additions from the White House.

title: The Internet Doesn't Stop These Presses
description: The Congressional Record and the Federal Register keep rolling off the presses as the Government Printing Office Web Site -- fdsys.gov -- expands the audience.

title: For Some A.R.C. Loan Borrowers, an Expensive Surprise Caps the Long Wait
description: The Small Business Administrations Americas Recovery Act program  which provides emergency bridge loans created by the stimulus package last winter  continues to founder. To judge by the accounts of Agenda readers, the only thing more frustrating than being declined for an A.R.C. loan may be getting approved for one.

title: Our Lingering Questions About the Grammys
description: It would be too easy  and too cynical  to ask simply, Why have the Grammys at all? Some years the awards program is good, some years its stupendously awful, and anyone who watched Sunday nights show knows in which bin it belongs.

title: Freeneys Ankle Injury Spurs Speculation
description: Dwight Freeney, the Indianapolis Colts Pro Bowl defensive end, has a torn ligament in his right ankle, Adam Schefter of ESPN reported Sunday, an injury that will make it difficult for him to play against the New Orleans Saints in the Super Bowl on Sunday. The most recent word from the Colts, however, was that Freeney had only a low ankle sprain and was still listed as questionable for the game.

title: Question Time
description: There were two remarkable confrontations between a politician and his critics last week: Barack Obamas appearance at the House Republican retreat, and Tony Blairs testimony before Britains Iraq Inquiry. Both were more interesting, informative, provocative and illuminating than any convention speech or State of the Union address. Both suggested the advantages of having forums where our leaders can be publicly cross-examined  and the virtues of having leaders capable of rising to the occasion.

title: Solar Brokering Firm Assesses First Year
description: Its been more than a year now since the debut of the oddly named San Francisco startup One Block Off the Grid  a company that brings together groups of homeowners with solar aspirations and delivers them as a collective to solar installers in the area, earning volume discounts for the customers and referral fees for itself.

title: Infection Persists, Despite Vaccine
description: A vaccine introduced in 2000 has been highly effective in reducing the number of severe lung, blood and brain infections in infants and children. But at the same time, a serious and sometimes fatal complication has become more common.

title: City Fire Department Braces for Cuts
description: New York Citys plans to close as many as 20 fire companies will require the Fire Department to undertake its most radical reorganization since the financial crisis of the 1970s, according to senior department officials.

title: Prevention: An Alternative for Treating Arrhythmia
description: Some abnormal heart rhythms that do not respond to drugs should instead be treated with a procedure that cauterizes the muscle around a vein that carries blood from the lungs to the heart, a new study suggests.

title: Aging: Higher Co-Payments Tied to Costlier Care
description: When Medicare plans raise co-payments for outpatient care, older people cut back on doctors visits, then wind up needing more expensive hospital care, a new study reports.

title: Video: Ten Minutes With the Budget Printer
description: Its budget day in Washington, the annual event when the president submits his spending plan to Congress. For the fiscal year 2011, President Obama sent a proposed budget of $3.8 trillion.

title: The Claim: Heart Attack Rates Rise During the Super Bowl
description: THE FACTS Is the Super Bowl a health hazard for diehard football fans?

title: Williams College Rolls Back No Loan Policy
description: Update | 8:50 p.m. To read an article on The Timess Web site on Williamss scaled-back financial aid policy  with details on how Amherst, Davidson, the University of North Carolina and Haverford intend to continue to offer their no-loan packages  click here.

title: Your Investing Behavior Costs You Plenty
description: Today, we introduce the first of what will be regular dispatches (and back-of-the-napkin drawings) from Carl Richards. Mr. Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: Obamas Remarks on the Budget
description: Following are President Obama's remarks on Monday on the $3.8 trillion budget proposal sent to Congress for fiscal year 2011, as released by the White House:

title: Trial Opens in Concorde Disaster
description: PARIS  Nearly 10 years after a Concorde jet crashed on takeoff from Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris, Continental Airlines and five people went on trial on Tuesday in a French criminal court, accused of manslaughter in the deaths of 113 people.

title: How Are You Responding to the Toyota Recalls?
description: I ran across a hypothetical question on Twitter the other day: Would you turn down a ride from a friend who owns one of the Toyota models that the company stopped selling?

title: Time Inc. Will Handle Some Ad Sales for Smithsonian Magazines
description: Time Inc. will put its ad sales muscle behind Smithsonian Medias magazines, under a deal the two publishers announced on Monday.

title: A Hidden Danger of an Aspirin a Day
description: Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, recently took readers questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham discusses the potential dangers of taking a daily baby aspirin, which doctors often recommend for those at high risk of heart disease.

title: National Portrait Gallery Hangs Painting of Salinger
description: A portrait of the cloistered author J. D. Salinger now hangs in the National Portrait Gallery. Devoted readers of The Catcher in the Rye can see the illustration of Mr. Salinger that was installed on Monday at the Smithsonians National Portrait Gallery in Washington. The portrait of Mr. Salinger, who died on Wednesday at 91, was created by Robert Vickrey for the cover of Time magazine published on Sept. 15, 1961, and is meant to depict the author against a (metaphorical) amber wave of grain. (In that cover story, which was timed to the publication of Mr. Salingers story collection Franny & Zooey, the Time reporter writes that when Mr. Salinger moved to Cornish, N.H., in the early 1950s, he was friendly and talkative; now when he jeeps to town, he speaks only the few words necessary to buy food or newspapers.) A press representative for the National Portrait Gallery said the painting was given to the gallery by Time magazine in 1978 and was last on display there through 1979. Before Mr. Salingers death, the gallery was planning to install the portrait in its permanent collection exhibition in May.

title: Gunmen in Mexico Kill 16 in Attack on a Teenagers Party
description: MEXICO CITY  More than a dozen gunmen sealed off a street in the violent border city of Ciudad Jurez and opened fire on a house where high school students were having a party, killing 16 people, officials said Monday.

title: A Porcine Critique of Bank Profits
description: Decrying bankers as pigs at a trough is a well-worn rhetorical trope. Not that the activist group Americans United for Change seems to mind.

title: In Iceland, Creditors Line Up at Kaupthing
description: Amid the hullabaloo about Davos, it was easy not to notice a second gathering on Friday, taking place almost 1,700 miles away in Reykjavik, Iceland, where creditors from 119 countries gathered to discuss their claims on one of the countrys bankrupt lenders, Kaupthing.

title: Monday Puzzle: The Toiling Antomatons
description: By now youve all seen Avatar, unless the box-office numbers have been inflated by people whove seen it a hundred times. For me, James Camerons blockbuster poignantly reinforced a philosophical dilemma that I had first experienced many years ago while reading a science fiction story by the great Isaac Asimov, That Thou Art Mindful of Him. Well discuss the dilemma later, but in this Asimov story, a robot named George directs the robotization of the earths ecology, creating little positronic robot creatures that fill environmental roles. Todays protagonists might have come out of these sci-fi worlds. They are the antomatons seen in the picture.

title: Readers Solutions to the Carry-on Crunch
description: In response to my Sunday column, Gaming the Luggage System, about the creative ways travelers are trying to dodge new luggage fees, readers weighed in with their own ideas for improving the system.

title: Recalling a Meeting With the Pied Piper of Shea
description: Somehow you never expect to encounter a living legend as an orphan of the storm.

title: Giving the Worst Their Due
description: In the interest of fair and balanced reporting, lets step away from shiny gold statuary for a moment. The Razzies, which honor (dishonor?) the worst of movies, have announced their nominations, and as the Gold Derby blog points out, Sandra Bullock could become the first actress in history to score a Razzie (for All About Steve) and an Oscar in the same year (The Blind Side).

title: Red Devils From Another Dimension
description: Three goals in three dimensions.

title: Indovation & the Fortune at the Bottom of the Pyramid
description: Innovation tailored to the demands and incomes of (poor) consumers in India.[Ind(ia) + (Inn)ovation]

title: Now Showing | Norwegian Good
description: Snhetta is coming to New York. These rock stars of Scandinavian architecture will be featured in Snhetta: architecture-landscapes-interiors, opening Feb. 4 at Scandinavia House: the Nordic Center in America. The exhibition will feature 11 projects by the Oslo firm, which places equal emphasis on architecture, landscape and interiors, and which is known for its innovative, environmentally conscious designs. Founded in 1989, Snhetta won raves for its Bibliotheca Alexandrina in Alexandria, Egypt, which was completed in 2001, and since then has amassed a project list that includes the iceberg-like New Norwegian National Opera and Ballet in Oslo (completed in 2008); the Ras Al-Khaimah Gateway Project, an undulating composition of buildings planned for the United Arab Emirates; and the National September 11 Memorial Museum Pavilion in New York. Until April 3 at 58 Park Avenue.

title: Celebrate Black History Month
description: Updated | February, 2016

title: Featured Recipe: Coconut-Braised Beef
description: Generally speaking, chuck is too tough to eat without braising. (There is an exception: the blade, or flatiron steak, is delicious.) Braise it, however, and it becomes one of the most tender of meats, as in this version of Malaysian rendang, in which browned beef chunks are simmered in coconut milk until tender. At that point the traditional approach is to cook the meat dry, stirring all the while, so it develops a thick, brown crust. I prefer to leave it a little moist, the meat sitting in its gorgeous caramel-colored sauce.

title: Working in the Company of Strangers
description: Although the Internet gives freelancers the ability to work in a cafe, in a library or in their pajamas, some people miss the buzz of the office. Anthony Townsend, a consultant for a research organization in California, is one of them.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Abby Auerbach, executive vice president at the Television Bureau of Advertising, New York, adds the duties of chief marketing officer, a new post at the organization.

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Whos on the Line? It Could Be the C.I.A.
description: Update | 1:38 p.m. Corporate executives might want to think twice before they speak on the next company conference call with analysts. Thats because agents of the Central Intelligence Agency could be on the line scrutinizing their every word to see if they are telling the whole truth. No, the agents arent working on behalf of the government; they are moonlighting for financial firms eager to gain an edge anyway they can.

title: Now Simmering | Momofuku Kos Boozy Broth
description: Its hard to say which was the more surprising occurrence last Sunday: that I got to eat at Momofuku Ko (a last-minute invitation from a suddenly single friend) or that I got to try its daikon tortelloni in oxtail-amaro broth.

title: Who Belongs to Unions?
description: We recently noted that, last year, public sector union members had outnumbered private sector union members for the first time in history.

title: Bruno Is Gone, but His Ride Remains
description: ALBANY  Senator Joseph L. Bruno has left the building  and may be heading to prison  but the Brunomobile remains.

title: Testing, and F1 Season, Begin in Valencia
description: There may not have been a full pit lane of teams, drivers and cars. But the first official day of Formula One testing at the Ricardo Tormo circuit outside Valencia, Spain, today felt like the beginning of the F1 season. In fact, over the last few days there has been more news than ever, with continued car launches  Renault, Williams, Mercedes, Toro Rosso, etc.  and driver announcements  Vitaly Petrov will drive with Robert Kubica at Renault, etc.  and other bits and pieces.

title: Haiti Crisis Prompts Fresh Talk of Pooling U.S. Relief Money
description: Before the earthquake, the American Red Cross had 15 people in Haiti working on projects like malaria prevention and measles vaccines. Partners in Health, a charity based in Boston, had more than 700 doctors and nurses among a staff of almost 5,000 operating a hospital and multiple clinics in the country.

title: Billions for NASA, With a Push to Find New Ways Into Space
description: The ambitious space initiative that President Obama unveiled for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on Monday calls for sweeping changes in mission and priorities for the 52-year-old agency, yet it omits two major details: where the agency will send its astronauts and a timetable for getting them there.

title: Could $70 Million for the Oakland Airport Connector Be Better Spent?
description: The Bay Area Metropolitan Transportation Commission voted last Thursday to go ahead with its ambitious $500 million Oakland Airport Connector project, which would build a 3.2-mile, elevated rail connection from the Coliseum BART station to Oakland International Airport.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff explain why we should expect low growth rates going forward, given the enormity of United States debt.

title: Better Late Than Never? A Booker Prize for Lost Novels
description: Iris Murdoch, Patrick OBrian and J. G. Farrell may no longer be with us, but they  along with 19 other writers  are among the authors eligible for an unusual new British literary award. The organizers of the Man Booker Prize, the prestigious honor given each year to an English-language novel, have announced a new award intended for writers who may have been shut out by a change of rules early in the prizes history. When the award was first handed out in 1969 and 1970, it was given to a novel published in the previous year; starting in 1971, the prize was given to a novel published that same year  meaning that several works published in 1970 were ineligible. The new award, called the Lost Man Booker Prize, will be awarded in May to one of 22 works on a long list that includes Murdochs A Fairly Honorable Defeat; OBrians Master and Commander and Farrells Troubles, as well as Shirley Hazzards The Bay of Noon and Brian Aldisss The Hand-Reared Boy. Peter Straus, the honorary archivist of the Booker Prize Foundation, told The Guardian: I am delighted that, even in a Darwinian way, this year, with so many extraordinary novels, can now be covered by the Man Booker prize.

title: A Homecoming for Richard Brautigan
description: At 7 on Monday night, some of the bartenders at Vesuvio Caf in San Franciscos North Beach district will stop wiping bar tops and delivering drinks to join in an evening of words  read, heard, remembered  honoring the life and work of Richard Brautigan.

title: What Taylor Swift Looks Like When Shes Genuinely Surprised
description: Photographers captured Taylor Swift in a state of astonishment when she dropped and broke one of her four Grammy Awards on Sunday night.

title: Administration Outlines Proposed Changes to No Child Law
description: The Obama administration said on Monday that it would ask Congress to raise education spending by about $3.5 billion, a 7.5 percent increase, for the 2011 fiscal year, even as it sought to limit other categories of domestic spending.

title: New Help for Filling Out the Fafsa Form
description: The student loan giant Salle Mae introduced a new online resource center Monday with tools designed to help college students and parents complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, the cumbersome form required to apply for federal and state aid that the government is trying to streamline this year.

title: Now Trashing | Michael Landys Art Bin
description: The British artist Michael Landy will be destroying hundreds of works of art this year, even though hes gotten in trouble for it before. In his 2001 performance, Break Down, Landy shredded everything he owned  7,227 items in total. Members of the public were most affected by the disposal of his car, his love letters, family heirlooms and the entire archive of his own art. However, he received most criticism from within the art world for destroying his art collection: works by fellow Young British Artists, including Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin, most of which he had received as gifts.

title: Readers Digest Delayed in Leaving Chapter 11
description: The Readers Digest Association, publisher of the Readers Digest, said Monday that it had run into a problem with its reorganization plan that would delay its exit from federal bankruptcy court.

title: From Osage County to Kaufman and Hart
description: The Tony-winning director Anna D. Shapiro (August: Osage County) has signed on to a Broadway revival of You Cant Take It With You this fall, according to the producers of the show, Elizabeth I. McCann and Joey Parnes.

title: Presidential Condolences and Troop Suicides
description: It is a long-standing tradition that presidents send letters of condolence to the families of troops killed at war, whether by enemy fire, accident or illness. But since the Clinton administration at least, one group has not received those hand-signed notes: families of troops who committed suicide, even those who killed themselves while deployed to a war front.

title: Counterinsurgency, One Stuck Truck at a Time
description: Counterinsurgency, in some circles and by some descriptions, can sound like a glamorous military art. More than often it is not.

title: What Does It Mean to Be an Independent Contractor?
description: Hardly a week goes by that I dont receive e-mail messages from readers worrying about workers misclassified as independent contractors.

title: Obama to Travel to Indonesia, Australia
description: President Obama will visit Indonesia and Australia this spring, the White House announced today, a trip that will take Mr. Obama back to the area of the world where he spent several years of his childhood.

title: Father of Terrorism Defendant Is Charged Again
description: Federal prosecutors on Monday brought obstruction of justice charges against the father of the Denver airport shuttle bus driver charged last year in a Qaeda bomb plot.

title: Grammys Attract Biggest Audience in Years
description: Music may not be selling the way it used to, but for one night at least music artists grabbed the attention of the nation. In a dominating performance that exceeded every expectation, the Grammy Awards on Sunday night on CBS attracted its biggest audience in six years, with 25.8 million viewers.

title: 5 Ways to Teach the Super Bowl
description: How can you make this weeks Super Bowl relevant to your curriculum?

title: Red Cabbage: Versatile, Economical  and Tasty
description: I dont know why its taken me so long to write a column about red cabbage, also known as purple cabbage. Its always been one of my favorite vegetables, lending itself readily to raw shredded salads, to long-cooked braises  and to everything in between. You can sear red cabbage in a hot pan for five minutes on a side or quick-cook it in a stir-fry. With each cooking method, your red cabbage will gain a unique flavor and texture. This vegetable is also incredibly economical. The big ones I buy at my supermarket weigh about 4 1/2 pounds, enough to use for at least four different dishes.

title: So, Virginia, Whats the Story?
description: A campaign now under way is asking consumers to consider something revolutionary in this economy: spending money on leisure travel.

title: G.M.s Hummer Sale Is Delayed
description: General Motors plan to sell its Hummer brand to a Chinese heavy equipment maker has been delayed by a month, The Associated Press reports.

title: U.S. Will Reimburse Hospitals That Treat Haitians
description: WASHINGTON The federal government announced on Monday that it would reimburse American hospitals who treat Haitian earthquake victims with life-threatening injuries, making it possible for more hospitals in states outside Florida to consider taking those patients.

title: Bus Museum Honors Negro League Baseball Teams
description: In honor of Black History Month, the Museum of Bus Transportation in Hershey, Pa., will display photos, films, and items related to the Negro league baseball teams beginning on Monday. Willie Fordham, 84, once a pitcher for the Harrisburg Giants, will be at the museum Monday through Friday through the month to chat with visitors and sell memorabilia.

title: Trials of the Century, Then and Now
description: As the likelihood of a downtown trial for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed dims, several spots in the New York area are now being considered as alternatives. Mayor Nicholas Valentine of Newburgh, N.Y. has engaged in one of the more aggressively public bids, arguing on Fox News on Friday that his perennially struggling Hudson River town of 28,000, about 70 miles north of ground zero, would benefit from the economic boost provided by hosting a major federal trial.

title: The Nifty 50 | David Benjamin Sherry, Photographer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Bonus Miles Expand, but Flight Upgrades Are Squeezed
description: This is usually the time of year when frequent fliers who earned elite status in the previous year can stop obsessing about qualifying miles and enjoy the fruits of all their travels: complimentary upgrades.

title: Wholl Design the New N.E.A. Logo? It Could Be You
description: Got something you want to express to Rocco Landesman and the National Endowment for the Arts  in a constructive, artistic way? Nows your chance: on Monday, the N.E.A. and Mr. Landesman, its chairman, announced that they were seeking proposals for a new logo to represent the phrase Art Works, which Mr. Landesman has previously described as the agencys guiding mission. In a statement Mr. Landesman said the logo, which will be used in print and online promotions, should represent the three meanings of the phrase: the creation of artists; the effect of art on audiences; and the contribution of artists to the economy. Proposals for the design must be submitted by email to the agency by 5 p.m. Eastern time on Feb. 26, and the selected proposal will receive a government grant of approximately $25,000. A complete list of instructions and requirements for submitting a proposal can be found here at the arts.gov Web site.

title: Obamas 2011 Budget Proposal: How Its Spent
description: President Obama's proposal for the 2011 budget.

title: 'The Park' | Episode 1
description: In the debut episode of our newest original series, "The Park," a school-aged ambler is betrayed by her friend and retreats into poetry.

title: Bachs Music as a Blank Canvas for Guitarists
description: A small-waisted, double-strung version of the guitar flourished in France, Italy and Spain in Bachs day, though not in Germany. Bach never composed for it, but that has not stopped guitarists from drafting Bach into their repertory. His lute music  four suites and other pieces  has long been the foundation for guitarists. Virtuoso players have transcribed the unaccompanied violin and cello works as well.

title: Officer Jabbed Man Between Buttocks, Colleague Testifies
description: A Brooklyn police officer testified Monday in a police-brutality trial that he saw a colleague jab a retractable baton between a suspects buttocks until more than half an inch of it disappeared from his view.

title: Congress Worries About Commercial Real Estate
description: There is growing concern in Congress that the shaky $6.7 trillion commercial real estate market could implode, delivering a major blow to the economic recovery. A bipartisan group of 79 House members led by Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Representative Ken Calvert, Republican of California, sent a letter to the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve on Monday urging them to take a more active role in keeping the commercial real estate market from turning into a disaster.

title: A New Resource to Untangle the Fafsa
description: Regular readers of The Choice know that we have been tracking efforts to streamline the Fafsa (or Free Application for Federal Student Aid), a form that has proved time-consuming and confusing to college applicants in years past. As families of this years high school seniors set about tackling the form in earnest, Mark Kantrowitz of finaid.org, spent a week last month dutifully answering a laundry list of questions from readers on our blog. For further assistance, we direct you to the new February Resource Center on the Web site of Sallie Mae, where there are instructional videos, links and information on a coming Q&A. Our sib-blog, Bucks, has more details here.

title: Now Showing | The Park, Episode 1
description: In the debut episode of our newest original series, The Park, a school-age ambler (Qorianka Kilcher) is gently betrayed by her friend and then retreats into poetry. Can you guess the poet? Log on each Monday for more of The Park, directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and starring New Yorks mostly green dream machine, Central Park.

title: Hummer Sale Is Delayed
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: One on One: T.J. Creamer, Astronaut (Currently in Space)
description: Of the more than 500 astronauts and cosmonauts who have been into space, only one has connected to the Internet and Tweeted from 250 miles above Earth: T.J. Creamer, a flight engineer and NASA science officer.

title: Shopping With Brad Ford
description: The Manhattan interior designer picked out eight blankets that can be  that finishing touch on a room.

title: Answers to Questions About Toyotas Repair Plans
description: Toyota said on Monday that its dealers in the United States would begin repairing later this week 2.3 million vehicles e involved in a recall for accelerator pedals that could potentially stick. Here are some details about the situation.

title: Super Bowl Stress and the Heart
description: In this weeks Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores whether the heart-pounding action of a football game can put spectators at risk for heart attacks.

title: Wrapping It Up
description: WHEN it comes to putting the finishing touch on a room, Brad Ford, a Manhattan interior designer, often reaches for a blanket. Its a great accessory because its an opportunity to bring in color, texture or pattern, he said. And its so much easier to change out a blanket than it is to reupholster a piece of furniture.

title: Children: Quality of Life With Cochlear Implants
description: Children with the surgically implanted hearing aids called cochlear implants rate their quality of life as highly as children with normal hearing, according to one of the first studies that looked at children as well as their parents.

title: A Lasting Gift to Medicine That Wasnt Really a Gift
description: Fifty years after Henrietta Lacks died of cervical cancer in the colored ward at Johns Hopkins Hospital, her daughter finally got a chance to see the legacy she had unknowingly left to science. A researcher in a lab at Hopkins swung open a freezer door and showed the daughter, Deborah Lacks-Pullum, thousands of vials, each holding millions of cells descended from a bit of tissue that doctors had snipped from her mothers cervix.

title: Growing Pentagon Focus on Energy and Climate
description: The Pentagon released its Quadrennial Defense Review on Monday, a wide-ranging report laying out rising priorities for keeping the peace and, when needed, waging war. For the first time, the report  at the request of lawmakers  considered the significance of climate change for national security, both as a potential source of conflict and a factor in military operations.

title: If You Swat, Watch Out: Bees Remember Faces
description: A honeybee brain has a million neurons, compared with the 100 billion in a human brain. But, researchers report, bees can recognize faces, and they even do it the same way we do.

title: 10 Americans Arrested in Haiti
description: Ten members of a U.S. church group were arrested for trying to take 33 children out of Haiti. (Video: NBC)

title: Case Stokes Haitis Fear for Children, and Itself
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  God wanted us to come here to help children, we are convinced of that, Laura Silsby, one of 10 Americans accused of trafficking Haitian children, said Monday through the bars of a jail cell here. Our hearts were in the right place.

title: Health Care and the Deficit
description: Against the backdrop of trillion dollar deficits, Ezra Klein argues that President Obamas call for a short-term discretionary spending freeze is a sign that the White House has lost the argument about health cares relationship to the national debt. From the perspective of long-term deficits, Klein notes, a temporary cap on discretionary spending is insignificant. Thats why Obama spent the last year trying to persuade Americans that the deficit problem is a function of health-care spending. Unfortunately, he failed:

title: Toads on the Brink
description: Jim Breheny, director of the Bronx Zoo, describes the effort to save the Kihansi spray toad from extinction. (Video footage from the Wildlife Conservation Society; audio interview by Thomas Lin/The New York Times)

title: Budget Forecasts vs. Reality
description: Something to keep in mind when reading about the presidents budget projections: They are almost always wrong. And not surprisingly, the estimates usually err on the side of optimism.

title: Travel Deals: Organized Tours to South Africa
description: Lion World Tours, a company that specializes in group and individual tours to southern Africa, is offering several organized trips to Cape Town and the surrounding area.

title: The Nifty 50 | Leidy Churchman, Artist
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Saving Tiny Toads Without a Home
description: This is a story about a waterfall, the World Bank and 4,000 homeless toads.

title: When the Low Tide Gets Carried Away
description: No, fellow landlubbers, it did not mean that New York Harbor was about to run dry.

title: Reitmans Very Personal Gut Test
description: Jason Reitman, an early man to beat in the Oscar race, appeared on The Oprah Winfrey Show recently, during which she urged people to see his film Up in the Air. (Lee Daniels, the director of Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire, of which Oprah is an executive producer, groused good-naturedly about this at the Directors Guild Awards. Oprah, who is my executive producer, says you gotta go out and see his movie? he said from the stage. Oprah Winfrey, executive-produce him.)

title: Recalling a Meeting With the Pied Piper of Shea
description: Over on the City Room blog, Glenn Collins recounts a meeting with a woman who made music that countless New York baseball fans heard and who also had her own somewhat subversive agenda to make Muzak better. Mr. Collins writes:

title: Road From Haiti Was Paved With Good Intentions, American Baptists Say
description: Last Updated | 6:37 p.m. Ten American Baptists sit in a Haitian jail on Monday, accused of child trafficking for what they say was a hastily conceived attempt to rescue orphans by quickly removing them from Haiti  before getting official permission or even checking to determine that the children really were orphans. In Haiti and on the Web, the arrests have led to fresh accusations that some religious groups may be guilty of a kind of spiritual trafficking, by mixing the help they offer to victims of last months earthquake with proselytizing.

title: Obama Takes Questions on YouTube
description: Its been more than six months since President Obama held a prime-time press conference at the White House. A new study finds that places him on par with Herbert Hoover for the number of times he has held formal news conferences with reporters.

title: Why You Shouldnt Trade In Your Toyota Now
description: If you own a Toyota model and are considering trading it in because youre worried about accelerator pedal problems, you may want to wait at least three months and focus instead on getting your vehicle fixed.

title: Coaches Still Vexed by Going for Two
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Long before Peyton Manning shredded the Jets defense with a two-minute drive in the American Football Conference championship game on Jan. 24, the Indianapolis Colts coaches had considered one of the most vexing decisions they face each game.

title: Using a Cello and a Piano to Trace Beethovens Path
description: Beethovens five sonatas for cello and piano represent his three major creative periods. Performed consecutively and in order, as they were by the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening, they provide a vivid snapshot of his artistic development.

title: Readers Say Love, and Leave, Your Dog at Home
description: For owners who are obsessed with their dogs, it seems only natural for their pets to go where they do. After all, some see New York City as one giant dog park. For these people, its a comfort to be accompanied by their pooch. For others, however, the sight of a furry being brings to mind allergies, and bacteria makes others uncomfortable.

title: Meeting the Heat
description: Q. What causes hot flashes in menopausal women?

title: Paternity Claim Challenges Zumas Stance on AIDS
description: JOHANNESBURG  Jacob Zuma, the polygamous president of South Africa, was upbraided Monday by commentators and political rivals after a newspaper reported that he had fathered his 20th child, the mother being a much-younger family friend and not one of his three wives.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Facebook, Cellphones and Samples of Movement
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Lula Washington has an eye for dancers. There is much to savor in Eboni Adamss supple charms, or the poised, steely strength of Keisha L. Clarke Gray, whose experience with the choreographer Garth Fagan shines through in long extensions and rock-solid balances.

title: Gates Shakes Up Leadership for F-35
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that he was replacing the general in charge of the Pentagons largest weapons program  the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter  and withholding $614 million in award fees from the contractor, Lockheed Martin.

title: Abstract Thoughts? The Body Takes Them Literally
description: The theory of relativity showed us that time and space are intertwined. To which our smarty-pants body might well reply: Tell me something I didnt already know, Einstein.

title: The Real Body Language
description: In this weeks Basics column, Natalie Angier notes that while the brain may do the thinking, the body experiences and processes information in a physical, somewhat literal fashion.

title: The High Low | Bensimon Sneakers, $55
description: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.

title: Elton John Gets Behind Next Fall
description: Following Oprah Winfrey (The Color Purple) and Jay-Z, and Will and Jada Pinkett Smith (Fela!) in lending their names to favorite Broadway shows, Elton John and his partner, David Furnish, have signed on to the producing team of the upcoming Broadway transfer Next Fall, a new play about the happiness, strains and religious differences between two gay men over the course of their five-year romantic relationship. The publicists for the production announced the arrangement on Monday.

title: Intramural Rooting for Kathryn
description: Since the Directors Guild anointed her with its top prize on Saturday, Kathryn Bigelow has become the frontrunner in the best director sprint. Even in an industry in which multiarmed back-patting is the cost of doing business, Ms. Bigelow seems to have an unusual level of support from her presumptive co-nominees.

title: Point Omega
description: Chapter 1

title: Make War. Make Talk. Make It All Unreal.
description: Richard Elster, the central character of Point Omega, Don DeLillos slender new novella, is a scholar who helped the Pentagon conceptualize an intellectual framework for the Iraq war. He is being courted by a filmmaker named Finley, who wants to make a documentary with him talking about the war. Picture Paul Wolfowitz, Condoleezza Rice and some American Enterprise Institute thinkers put in a Cuisinart along with Robert S. McNamara as he appeared in Errol Morriss movie The Fog of War.

title: Why Asexual Organisms Are on Their Last Legs
description: Scientists who study how organisms reproduce know that asexual reproduction is more efficient  for one thing, its about twice as fast as sexual reproduction, since every offspring can produce more.

title: Sometimes, It Takes a Woman to Solve a Murder
description: Be careful how you judge Trifles, as performed by the experimental troupe Theater of a Two-Headed Calf. What initially feels foolish could, on reflection, prove to be more powerful, and what is frustrating may later gel into something intriguing. While not all of the productions missteps are absolved by time, not everything here is what it first seems, either.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Feb. 1
description: The immediate trauma of the event itself, and of the aftershocks, may have passed. But as Damon Winters photograph makes plain, Haitis toughest journey could be the one ahead. The report also touches on Iran, Lebanon, Pakistan, India, Iraq, Spain and Thailand; Washington and Miami.

title: Whole Orchestra Shines, Nurtured by a Deft Touch
description: Pierre Boulez seemed a lion in winter on his latest visit to Carnegie Hall, over the weekend, and not only because of the bitter cold and wind outside. Once feared as a sharp-tongued advocate for modernist revolution, Mr. Boulez, who turns 85 in March, has mellowed in recent decades, embracing a broader repertory that includes works by composers he once dismissed, like Bruckner and Janacek.

title: Paul Ehrlich, 1908
description: Paul Ehrlich, the discoverer of the magic bullet cure for syphilis, was first mentioned in The New York Times in connection with something other than his best-known accomplishment.

title: How Seabirds Follow Fishing Boats Routine
description: Its a typical sight in fishing areas: a trawler or other boat being followed by seabirds eager to gulp down the unwanted fish the crew throws back. Research has shown that the supplemental food such discards provide can affect bird populations, in some cases improving reproductive success.

title: Rules Worth Following, for Everyones Sake
description: In the more than four decades that I have been reading and writing about the findings of nutritional science, I have come across nothing more intelligent, sensible and simple to follow than the 64 principles outlined in a slender, easy-to-digest new book called Food Rules: An Eaters Manual, by Michael Pollan.

title: Rules to Eat By
description: In this weeks Science Times, the Personal Health columnist Jane Brody reviews Michael Pollans latest book, Food Rules: An Eaters Manual, which offers a collection of simple ways to improve eating. And she even changes one of her own eating habits as a result. She writes:

title: A Depressing Budget
description: I havent gone through the budget proposal in detail yet. But theres no escaping the sense that this is a tremendous comedown from the hopes of a year ago.

title: No Place Like Foam for Tropical Frogs
description: Around the tropics, there are hundreds of species of frogs that build their nest out of foam, as a home for eggs or larvae.

title: From Jazz-Rock Fusion to Progressive Metal, With a Virtuosic Accompaniment
description: Instrumental virtuosity is like any kind of power on earth, corruptive and constructive in equal measure. Its a handicap, in a strange way: the musician must acquire one more level of refinement to turn it toward the good. If you can sing through your instrument  particularly if you can do it very, very speedily  you can make a music that seems lordly, pinched and gloating. Or you can spread a generous feeling through a room and somehow transcend your own gifts.

title: The Miracle of Vitamin D: Sound Science, or Hype?
description: Imagine a treatment that could build bones, strengthen the immune system and lower the risks of illnesses like diabetes, heart and kidney disease, high blood pressure and cancer.

title: Footballs First Family
description: NEW ORLEANS  Archie and Olivia Mannings galleried Greek Revival home is well known in this legendary city. It is a recommended site for visitors touring the citys famed Garden District. While the building, a tan house with a front porch swing, is storied for its architecture, it may be most famous for being the childhood home of the N.F.L. quarterbacks Peyton and Eli Manning.

title: Vitamin D, Miracle Drug: Is It Science, or Just Talk?
description: Imagine a treatment that could build bones, strengthen the immune system and lower the risks of illnesses like diabetes, heart and kidney disease, high blood pressure and cancer.

title: Homeless, Shoeless, Even Nameless
description: When the police brought Jane to 3East, the soles of her feet were blistered. Young and pretty beneath a layer of urban grime, she had been picked up for wandering barefoot around Portland, Ore., on a 90-degree August afternoon. She wouldnt give her name and carried no identification, but went willingly with the young officer.

title: The Party of Look, You Know, I Was, Uh, Yeah
description: Last week Mike Pence, the third-ranking Republican in the House, was asked what compromise he would agree to on health care. His answer, word for word, was

title: With Bill Stalled, What if Talks Reopen?
description: For all the handwringing among Democrats about the fate of their health care legislation following the Republican victory in the Massachusetts special election for United States Senate, one thing party leaders have not said is that they would use the political setback as an opportunity to write a better bill.President Obama and Congressional Democratic leaders have floated the idea of a smaller bill or bills: breaking apart the legislation into parts that might have a better chance at passage. They have also raised the prospect of House Democrats simply adopting what almost everyone agrees is a flawed Senate bill, including a number of shortsighted provisions stuck in to win the votes of individual senators.

title: The Times Best Sellers API: From Washington to WorldCat
description: Our series of posts about external uses of Times APIs continues. Today were highlighting the University of Puget Sounds use of the Times Best Sellers API.

title: Will Second-Chance Chuck Keep Incisors in Check?
description: Chuck has been training hard for months now. Hes put on a few pounds of what might conceivably be muscle. Hes in the shape of his life.

title: Tea Party Conventions Keynote and Other Events Will Be Televised
description: The revolution will be televised.

title: Things That Make You Wonder
description: One comment on my confrontation with Roger Ailes says,

title: Seattle Group Paying F.D.A. for Work on a Pneumococcal Disease Vaccine
description: A nonprofit organization is paying the Food and Drug Administration to help develop a better vaccine against pneumococcal disease in poor countries.

title: Russians Rally Around a Falling Enclave
description: MOSCOW  The bulldozers came at night, flanked by armor-clad riot police officers, to clear the houses of a small neighborhood here at the behest of Moscows mayor, forcing residents out into subzero temperatures.

title: Hair Has New Way to Spread the Love
description: That most precious of Broadway marketing tools  favorable word of mouth among theatergoers  is being transformed for the Facebook generation.

title: Photographing the Real Macondo
description: Within hours of his arrival in Colombia, Stephen Ferry had already been exposed to the magic realism expressed so exquisitely by Gabriel Garca Mrquez in One Hundred Years of Solitude. Then he had the chance to seek out the source, to photograph the real Macondo. Read the full post and view the audio slide show.

title: Teachers Union and N.A.A.C.P. Sue to Stop School Closings
description: The citys teachers union and the N.A.A.C.P. filed a lawsuit on Monday to block the closing of 19 schools for poor performance, charging that the city studiously ignored provisions of state law as it moved forward in its process to shutter the schools.

title: Up in the Air, and Down, With a Twist
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The first time you watch skiers hurtle off a curved ramp at 30 miles per hour, soaring six stories in the air while doing three back flips and up to five body twists, you cant help but think:

title: Portrait Gallery Hangs Painting of Salinger
description: Devoted readers of The Catcher in the Rye will be able to see a portrait of its author, J. D. Salinger, that was installed on Monday at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. The painting of Mr. Salinger, above, who died on Wednesday at 91, was created by Robert Vickrey for the cover of Time magazine published on Sept. 15, 1961, and is meant to depict the reclusive Mr. Salinger against a (metaphorical) amber wave of grain. (In that cover story, timed to the publication of Mr. Salingers story collection Franny & Zooey, the Time reporter writes that when Mr. Salinger moved to Cornish, N.H., in the early 1950s, he was friendly and talkative; now when he jeeps to town, he speaks only the few words necessary to buy food or newspapers.) A press representative for the National Portrait Gallery said Time gave the painting to the gallery in 1978, and the work was last on display there through 1979.

title: Media Day Is Moved Indoors
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  A forecast of rain has forced the N.F.L. to move Tuesdays media day inside for the first time in memory. The event, which is usually held on the playing field at the host stadium, will instead be staged on the club level of Sun Life Stadium, a more compact environment for the annual theater of the media absurd.

title: Who Will Design the National Endowment for the Arts Logo? It Could Be You.
description: Got something you want to express to Rocco Landesman, right, and the National Endowment for the Arts  in a constructive, artistic way? Nows your chance. On Monday the N.E.A. and Mr. Landesman, its chairman, announced that proposals are being sought for a new logo to represent the phrase Art Works, which Mr. Landesman has previously described as the agencys guiding mission. In a statement Mr. Landesman said the logo, which will be used in print and online promotions, should represent the three meanings of the phrase: the creations of artists, the effect of art on audiences and the contribution of artists to the economy. Proposals for the design must be submitted by e-mail to the endowment by 5 p.m. Eastern time on Feb. 26. The author of the proposal selected will receive a government grant of about $25,000. Instructions and requirements for submissions are at arts.gov.

title: Elton John Signs on as Broadway Producer
description: Following Oprah Winfrey (The Color Purple), Jay-Z and Will and Jada Pinkett Smith (Fela!) in lending their names to Broadway shows, Elton John and his partner, David Furnish, have signed on to the producing team of the forthcoming Broadway transfer Next Fall, a new play about the happiness, strains and religious differences between two gay men during their five-year romantic relationship. As producers Mr. John and Mr. Furnish have put money into the show  on Monday no one involved in the production would say how much  and will lend their names to publicity and other material in hopes of drawing attention to the play. Written by Geoffrey Nauffts and directed by Sheryl Kaller, the Naked Angels production of Next Fall  which drew critical acclaim during an Off Broadway run at Playwrights Horizons last summer  is moving to the Helen Hayes Theater without a star performer, director or playwright, a risky proposition on Broadway today. It is scheduled to begin previews on Feb. 16 and to open on March 11.

title: Obama Calls Health Overhaul My Greatest Hope
description: President Obama, in a question-and-answer session posted on YouTube, the online video-sharing site, said that it is my greatest hope that health care legislation be adopted not just a year from now, but soon. Yet he also referred to the effort in the past tense: We came extremely close, he said  a sign that the fate of the health care measure is now highly uncertain.

title: Tale of an Unsung Fossil Finder, in Fact and Fiction
description: Mary Anning was one of the few women to make a success in paleontology and one of the fewer still whose success was not linked to that of a paleontologist spouse (or any spouse: she was single). She made five major fossil discoveries from 1811 to her death in 1847, and many lesser ones.

title: The Possibilities and Perils of Retelling a Masterpiece
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last week I attended performances by American Ballet Theater (in Washington), New York City Ballet (in New York) and San Francisco Ballet (in San Francisco). Observing the San Francisco company, I saw that in many ways it stands with the other two as one of Americas three most internationally prestigious ballet troupes.
