But all three performances I watched of the companys new Swan Lake at the War Memorial Opera House here made me want, not for the first time, someone to make the troupe blaze. Instead it looks polite, veiled, embryonic, unfulfilled.

title: Citibank, in Settlement, Extends Free Checking
description: The Citibank EZ checking account is going to remain free a while longer for many bank customers.

title: A Little Chip Designed by Apple Itself
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sure, the screen is nice. But the iPads most important component, at least for Apples future, may be the A4, the fingernail-size chip at the tablets heart.

title: Sundance: Snow and Stars vs. Twitter and Google Alerts
description: PARK CITY, Utah  An uncomfortable question surfaced at this years Sundance Film Festival: In the digital age, is trekking to this mountain town each January becoming less necessary?

title: Extra Money for Science in Obamas Budget
description: Calming fears that scientific research would be hurt by the Obama administration, the budget request for the Department of Health and Human Services was $81.3 billion, up from $79.6 billion a year ago. And the National Institutes of Health saw its budget request rise by $1 billion, to $32 billion, more than was requested last year.

title: President Obama's Budget Proposal
description: David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent for The Times, discusses President Obama's budget proposal.

title: As Marines Move In, Taliban Fight a Shadowy War
description: KARARDAR, Afghanistan  The Marine infantry company, accompanied by a squad of Afghan soldiers, set out long before dawn. It walked silently through the dark fields with plans of arriving at a group of mud-walled compounds in Helmand Province at sunrise.

title: Russias Evolution, Seen Through Golden Arches
description: MOSCOW  Viktor A. Semenov was growing lettuce on a collective farm outside Moscow in 1990 when a representative of McDonalds stopped by. The company had just opened a restaurant. Could he sell it a few boxes of lettuce each week?

title: Face Off | When Alexis Met Alexis
description: Eye of the Tiger was blaring from the speakers as I walked into the photo studio. It seemed an appropriate entrance for my meeting with Joan Collins, a woman known for draping herself in animal prints, and who has in recent years come to be heralded as the original cougar. Try as she might, she cannot escape the association with Alexis Carrington, the perfectly bitchy character she portrayed for almost a decade on the prime time soap opera Dynasty. And on this day, Alexis  oh, sorry  Joan was being photographed for the jewelry designer Alexis Bittars spring ad campaign. Alexis the legend, donning bold, 80s-inspired costume jewelry designed by another Alexis who, hard to believe, had never seen the show.But I had, and I was about to meet the woman who, as Alexis, devoured anyone who stood between her what she wanted, and did so sporting big hair, red lips and shoulders galore  whether bare or padded. She did it so well that today people have trouble distinguishing her character from the real person who was now seated in front of me, wrapped in her own Michael Kors leopard-print trench coat and clutching a decidedly unglamorous white Styrofoam cup of coffee. I would never go out to lunch in a tracksuit, she said about her insistence on keeping up appearances. But I might pop out to the supermarket in one  but only in L.A.

title: News Photos, on the Move, Make News
description: In the middle of December two trailer trucks left New York City bound for Austin, Tex., packed with a precious and unusual cargo: the entire collection of pictures amassed over more than half a century by the Magnum photo cooperative, whose members have been among the worlds most distinguished photojournalists.

title: In Closing, Competing Portrayals of Defendant in Afghan Shooting Trial
description: Aafia Siddiqui was not in court on Monday. Had she been, Ms. Siddiqui, the Pakistani neuroscientist accused of trying to kill United States soldiers while in custody in Afghanistan, would have heard herself portrayed in two sharply different ways.

title: Reading (Rifle) Magazines
description: How do Taliban fighters operate and sustain themselves as an effective force in the field?

title: How Big Will Blankfeins Bonus Be?
description: Its Wall Streets favorite guessing game: How big a bonus will Goldman Sachs give Lloyd C. Blankfein, its chief executive?

title: Obama Budget Doesnt Thrill School Lunch Advocates
description: President Obamas budget proposal is getting mixed reviews among the people watching over the quality of public school lunches. Some say its too little to make any meaningful change, while others are relieved school food programs are getting anything when other agricultural programs have been cut.

title: At Hot Contest, Cool Beyonc Is a Dynamo but Never a Diva
description: LOS ANGELES  Whats good for Beyonc is good for the Grammys.

title: New Budget Assumes Passage of Health Care Bill
description: President Obama says he has not given up on major health care legislation, and his new budget backs him up. The $3.8 trillion budget released by the White House on Monday includes $150 billion in deficit reduction over 10 years on the presumption that a health care bill will be adopted.

title: Obamas Figure for 2011 Arts Budget? The Same as His 2010 Request
description: President Obama proposed on Monday that the National Endowment for the Arts receive $161.3 million in his fiscal year 2011 budget request to Congress, the same level he proposed last year. The agency was ultimately allotted more: $167.5 million. Americans for the Arts, a national advocacy group, criticized the the proposed budget, saying it is a $6 million decrease from what Congress appropriated for fiscal year 2010.

title: For Young Superstar Taylor Swift, Big Wins Mean Innocence Lost
description: For Taylor Swift, the jig is up.

title: The Morning Skate: Trading Floor Opens, Lightning Sale Not Closed
description: The Maple Leafs-Flames and Maple Leafs-Ducks deals on Sunday enlivened a trading scene many had characterized as moribund.

title: In Brooklyn, Paying Tribute to a Fixture of Court Street
description: Panhandlers in this city are often ignored, stiffed, even reviled, but sometimes, if they hang around long enough and take the right approach, they can work themselves not only into the wallets, but also into the hearts of those they solicit.

title: Countries Submit Emission Goals
description: WASHINGTON  The climate change accord reached at Copenhagen in December passed its first test on Monday after countries responsible for the bulk of climate-altering pollution formally submitted their emission reduction plans, meeting the agreements Jan. 31 deadline.

title: Ratings for Grammys Top Globes and Emmys
description: In a dominating performance that exceeded expectations, the 52nd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night attracted its biggest audience in six years, with ratings that dwarfed other recent awards shows, according to the Nielsen company. The 25.8 million viewers who tuned in to the Grammys on CBS represented a 35 percent increase over last years show (which drew 19 million), and surpassed audiences for the Golden Globes (17 million) and the Emmys (13.5 million). The Grammys this year were more popular than all the N.F.L. Sunday night prime-time football games this season on NBC as well as Game 4 of the World Series, which was played on a Sunday night. CBS won the night over all, and ABC ranked second with its usual lineup of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (8.5 million), Desperate Housewives (11.4 million) and Brothers & Sisters (7.7 million). Fox was third with new episodes of its animated comedies, while NBC finished in fourth place.

title: Weighed Down by All the Memories
description: WHEN my brother Jack, who used to be a long haul mover, was over for dinner the other day, he told me something about myself that even now, as I sit typing, appalls me.

title: Israel Rebukes 2 for U.N. Gaza Compound Shelling
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military confirmed Monday that it had reprimanded two senior officers, a brigadier general and a colonel, for the firing of artillery shells that hit a United Nations compound during the Gaza war last winter. It was a rare admission of high-level wrongdoing at a time when Israel is battling accusations of possible war crimes.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Groundhog Day'
description: A. O. Scott revisits Harold Ramis's existential comedy starring Bill Murray.

title: Carlsen Conquers Corus
Haitis Children and the Adoption Question
description: Updated, Feb. 2, 4:20 p.m. | Darron Smith, a researcher on issues of interracial adoptions, joins the discussion.

title: Critics Picks Video: Groundhog Day
description: This week, A. O. Scott celebrates Groundhog Day by watching the 1993 comedy Groundhog Day. The film, which stars Bill Murray as a TV journalist who is forced to live the same day over and over again, has a winning, mainstream appeal. But on subsequent viewings, Mr. Scott notices the film explores a very simple, stark, existential situation that has many complicated philosophical ramifications. Please share your thoughts on Groundhog Day. Have you seen it multiple times?

title: The Song Remains the Same
description: With less than 12 hours to go until the Bagger tames her bedhead for the Oscar nomination announcement, lets take a trip through everybodys final predictions. Guess what? Theyre almost all the same!

title: Illinoiss Daddy Problem
description: Illinois voters go to the polls Tuesday to vote in a whole mess of important primaries. Barack Obamas Senate seat on the line! Republican moderates vs. Tea Partyists! And once again, we are in the world of the angry voter.

title: Specter Gives Refunds, Loses Bragging Rights
description: Update | Feb. 2, 4:22 p.m.  Arlen Specters party switch has cost him some cold hard cash.

title: Big Chill Hit the Deal Market in January
description: The year started off exceptionally slowly for mergers and acquisitions in the United States. There was only $34.2 billion worth of announced deals in January, according to Standard & Poors Capital IQ, making it the slowest first month of the year since 2003.

title: From the Archive: Magnums Moving Images
description: In the middle of December two trailer trucks left New York City for Texas, carrying the entire collection of pictures amassed over more than half a century by the Magnum Photos cooperative. In News Photos, on the Move, Make News, Randy Kennedy of The Times describes where more than 180,000 press prints are going  and why theyre going there. Here on Lens, we pay a small tribute to the remarkable Magnum legacy with 14 images, accompanied by the agencys own captions.

title: Europe Weighs Oneworld Plan to Assure Flight Competition
description: BRUSSELS  Europes antitrust regulator said Monday that it was reviewing an offer by British Airways, American Airlines and the Spanish flag carrier Iberia aimed at preserving competition on long-haul routes if their proposed joint venture is approved.

title: Yahoo Renews Deal to Use A.P. Material
description: Renewing a longstanding link, The Associated Press and Yahoo said Monday that they had reached a new agreement for A.P. articles, photos and videos to appear on the Yahoo News site.

title: Living Well With Diabetes, and Showing Others How
description: I LOVE flying. Im a former physics professor who taught at Carleton College and at M.I.T. The most flying I did then was going to a seminar or meeting once or twice a year.

title: Google Planning Store for Business Apps
description: Google is developing an online store where it will sell business software from its partners in an effort to ramp up sales of Google Apps, its own suite of business applications, according to a person familiar with the project.

title: Study Finds a Tree Growth Spurt
description: Forests in the eastern United States appear to be growing faster in response to rising levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, a new study has found.

title: Economies in Asia Continue to Show Strong Rebound
description: A range of economic data released on Monday underscored the Asia-Pacific regions rebound from the global turmoil of last year, but also highlighted the challenges facing governments as they sought to solidify that growth while reining in nascent inflation.

title: In Europe, Challenges for Google
description: Google has a problem in China. But it may have bigger headaches in Europe.

title: Speaking Freely Where Fear Rules
description: BAGHDAD  At the end of a week that included two spectacular bomb attacks, Ali al-Nijar left his home to talk about poetry. Mr. Nijar, a retired professor of agriculture, was squeezed in among 60 others at a weekly literary salon on Baghdads Mutanabi Street, one of about a dozen salons that have sprung up around the city in the last two years as violence has dropped.

title: A Rankings Shake-Up in Mens Tennis
description: After the mens singles event at the Australian Open notable for Roger Federers dominance and Rafael Nadals knees, the  new rankings that came out Monday reflected both story lines.

title: A Bond Issue at McClatchy
description: The McClatchy Companys prospects are looking up, just a year after investors seemed to expect the newspaper publisher to go bust. The company is marketing $875 million of bonds this week. But investors should be cautious. McClatchys recent performance will be tough to maintain.

title: New Meetings Industry Emerges After a Boom and Bust
description: BACK in the boom years, I used to attend many of the major travel industry trade shows, which were always held in places with monstrous convention centers like Las Vegas, New Orleans and Orlando, Fla.

title: Paulsons Final Days at Treasury: Still More Bailouts
description: Bear Stearns had long been sold to JPMorgan Chase, Lehman Brothers had already fallen and the American International Group had been all but nationalized by an unprecedented government rescue. But the final months of Henry M. Paulson Jr.s tenure as Treasury secretary were almost as tense as the weeks during the height of the financial crisis.

title: Development at Railyards Is Delayed
description: The developer selected to build a $15 billion residential and commercial complex over the railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan has once again delayed signing a formal contract for the project and making a down payment. The developer, the Related Companies, also lost its partner, Goldman Sachs, which unexpectedly pulled out of the project last week.

title: Government Priorities, Across the Decades
description: Along with the presidents proposed budget for 2011, the Office of Management and Budget today released updated historical figures.

title: Vermont Power Plant Continues to Leak Radiation
description: Technicians seeking the source of a leak of radioactive tritium at the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant have found concentrations in groundwater there that were three times higher than what was discovered last week, a plant spokesman said Monday.

title: Like St. Vincents Itself, Missing Wall Means Much
description: By now, many people who walk along West 11th Street and see the sign on the south portico of St. Vincents Hospital must wonder what it could possibly mean. The Wall of Hope and Remembrance, it reads.

title: Deficits May Alter U.S. Politics and Global Power
description: WASHINGTON  In a federal budget filled with mind-boggling statistics, two numbers stand out as particularly stunning, for the way they may change American politics and American power.

title: Teenagers Speak Up on Salinger
description: Last week, Room for Debate published a discussion on whether J.D. Salingers Catcher in the Rye resonates with teenagers today. We asked writers and teachers about Holden Caulfields kind of alienation in a world of Facebook and Twitter.

title: Sony Pictures Plans More Job Cuts
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment, which last year cut 250 jobs or about 3.5 percent of its workers, said it was a planning a new round of job reductions that could total an additional 6.5 percent of its global workforce.

title: Somalia: Islamist Groups Join Forces With Al Qaeda
description: Two militant Islamist groups announced Monday that they were joining forces and that they were now part of the international jihad of Al Qaeda. The militants, the Shabab and a much smaller outfit called the Raskamboni Rebel Group, also pledged allegiance to Osama bin Laden. The Raskamboni rebels control territory near the Kenyan border and used to be allied with another rebel group known as Hizbul Islam. The Shabab remain the most potent threat to Somalias weak transitional government.

title: Palin Endorses Paul  the Kentucky One
description: Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor, has waded into another Republican primary, this time endorsing Rand Pauls Kentucky Senate campaign.

title: Panel Suggests 100 Ways Buildings Can Be Greener
description: A panel of experts convened by the mayor and City Council issued more than 100 recommendations Monday on how to make New York Citys building codes more environmentally sound by imposing energy-saving requirements on construction and renovation work.

title: Williams College Will Bring Loans Back to Aid Packages
description: Williams College, which two years ago replaced all loans in its student financial aid packages with direct scholarships that did not have to be repaid, is rescinding the policy amid the fallout of the economic downturn.

title: Cloudy Future for Fannie and Freddie
description: The Great Bailout is mostly over for the banks. But for those troubled behemoths of the nations housing bust, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the lifeline from Washington just keeps getting longer.

title: Ethics Panel Fines Ex-Aide to Speaker
description: A former deputy chief of staff to Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn who recently served as a top aide to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs re-election effort has been fined for violating city law by soliciting campaign contributions for Ms. Quinn while working for her.

title: Hacking for Fun and Profit in Chinas Underworld
description: CHANGSHA, China  With a few quick keystrokes, a computer hacker who goes by the code name Majia calls up a screen displaying his latest victims.

title: Wall of Junk Debt Maturities Looms, Moodys Says
description: The boom in the high-yield debt markets has bought time and breathing space for companies needing extra financial flexibility. But that has come at a cost, according to the latest annual report by Moodys Investors Service: more than $700 billion will come due between 2012 and 2014.

title: Bankers in Davos Seek a United Message on Volcker Rule
description: Davos, Switzerland

title: Hospitalization Halts Trial in Cheshire Family Killings
description: NEW HAVEN  Jury selection was abruptly halted Monday in the triple-murder trial of one of the men accused of a 2007 home invasion after the defendant was found unconscious in his cell and taken to a hospital, where he was placed in a medically induced coma.

title: Close Encounters
description: The goal of the European artist Tino Sehgal is to create something (a situation) from virtually nothing (actions, words) and then let that something disappear, leaving no potentially marketable physical trace, writes Holland Cotter. His rule may be unenforceable in this day and age. Still, it turns the museum into a zone of sort-of secrecy. It piques both the voyeur and the skeptic in us. Mr. Sehgal, who lives in Berlin and studied political economy and dance, has cleared out the Guggenheim for his self-titled exhibition, which runs through March 10. Yet the space isnt empty. On the rotundas ground floor, a man and woman entwine in a changing, slow-motion amorous embrace and on the ramps above, people walk and talk in pairs or clusters at a leisurely pace, with new participants periodically joining conversations as others drop away. Mr. Sehgals art is made up almost entirely of such balletic tableaus and social encounters; its bare-bones but addictive and makes you want to return for more.

title: Guitar Hero
description: Compared to, say, JVC Jazz or CMJ, the New York Guitar Festival doesn't get much attention from the city's music community, but that doesn't it mean it should be overlooked. The series, which runs through Feb. 4 has been "examining virtually every aspect of the guitar's musical personality" since 1999. Tonight, head to Le Poisson Rouge to listen to Marc Ribot's contribution. "Mr. Ribot is a fount of pithy commentary," writes Nate Chinen. "In Ceramic Dog, his punkish band with the bass guitarist Shahzad Ismaily and the drummer Ches Smith, he pursues a more messily ecstatic agenda; the name of the group's most recent album, 'Party Intellectuals,' captures it perfectly." Mr. Ribot will be performing songs off that album as part of the festival with Skeleton$.

title: An Advocacy Ad Stirs a National Debate
description: FOR 43 years, Super Bowl viewers have watched all kinds of commercials from companies that are famous (Coca-Cola) or otherwise (Cash4Gold.com), peddling everything from automobiles to Xerox copiers. But never has there been a Super Bowl spot that took sides on a contentious social issue  until now.

title: Kell on Earth
description: If youve ever indulged in a marathon of MTVs The Hills or The City, then you know who Kelly Cutrone is. The fashion publicist and founder of the P.R. company Peoples Revolution, is a backstage figure propelled by the synergy of the celebrity industry into her own version of stardom, writes Alessandra Stanley. She has succeeded with the arrival of Kell on Earth, which began on Monday, and is the latest addition to the Bravo universe, a reality show that follows Ms. Cutrone, as she bullies and cajoles her way through the underbelly of the New York fashion world. Though she is more of an earth mother  no make up, sloppy dress  than a glitzy, size zero Rachel Zoe type, she still makes assistants quake in their Louboutins. Spot her minions tonight at Barnes & Noble where shell be reading from the book she co-authored, If You Have to Cry, Go Outside: And Other Things Your Mother Never Told You.

title: Sony Studio Plans to Cut More Jobs
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment, which last year cut 250 jobs, or about 3.5 percent of its workers, said on Monday that it was a planning a new round of job reductions that could total an additional 6.5 percent of its global work force.

title: Officers Testimony Supports Abuse Accusation
description: At first, Officer Kevin Maloney kept it all to himself.

title: Near Quakes Epicenter, a City Ready for Business
description: LOGNE, Haiti  Commerce was thriving at the warrenlike shantytown that has sprung to life on what was once this citys main square. Shoeshines and hairstyles, coal and soap, Casino brand chocolate and Comme Il Faut cigarettes, even new homes constructed from salvaged wood and sheet metal  each could be had for a price.

title: Flock Is Now a Fight Team in Some Ministries
description: MEMPHIS  In the back room of a theater on Beale Street, John Renken, 37, a pastor, recently led a group of young men in prayer.

title: Terror Suspects Father Is Accused of Obstructing Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors on Monday charged the father of a Denver airport shuttle bus driver accused of plotting a terrorist bombing with conspiring to obstruct the investigation.

title: Curveball Alters Talks on Wall St. Reform
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas proposals to tax and curb the activities of Wall Street have thrown an unpredictable element into the debate over financial regulatory reform. They also have touched off an intensive new round of lobbying and raised questions in Congress over whether his plan will add urgency or merely bog things down.

title: What Is the First Amendment For?
description: Citizens United v. Federal Election commission  the recent case in which the Supreme Court invalidated a statute prohibiting corporations and unions from using general treasury funds either to support or defeat a candidate in the 30 days before an election, and overruled an earlier decision relied on by the minority  has now been commented on by almost everyone, including the president of the United States in his state of the union address.

title: Slow Going for Broadway Experiment
description: It has been hailed as New York Citys most radical civic experiment in a generation: cars would be barred from driving along two sections of Broadway in the heart of Midtown. The aim was to reduce congestion in Times and Herald Squares, two of the worst areas for drivers in the city.

title: Lottery Numbers
Iran, With Opposition Protests Continuing, Executes More Prisoners
description: Every Thursday since last April, Davoud Rahmanipour traveled to the notorious Evin prison in northern Tehran for a weekly visit with his son, Arash, 19, who was being held there while his lawyer appealed his death sentence.

title: Suit Points to Guest Worker Program Flaws
description: Immigration authorities worked closely with a marine oil-rig company in Mississippi to discourage protests by temporary guest workers from India over their job conditions, including advising managers to send some workers back to India, according to new testimony in a federal lawsuit against the company, Signal International.

title: Experience in Sports Optional for New Leaders
description: On March 8, David Brandon will become the athletic director at the University of Michigan. He will assume one of the most coveted positions in college sports, and yet Brandon has no experience in the field. He made his name instead in fast food  since 1999, Brandon has been the chief executive of Dominos Pizza.

title: Georgian TV Channel Says Russian Company Elbowed It Off the Air
description: MOSCOW  In an echo of the cat-and-mouse game of signal jamming in the Soviet Union, a Russian-language television station in Georgia is accusing a Russian company of blocking its broadcasts into Russia by buying out the spectrum on a French-operated television satellite.

title: Trial of Opposition Leader Could Reshape Malaysian Politics
description: BANGKOK  During more than three decades in Malaysian politics, Anwar Ibrahim has spent a good share of his time behind bars  from his detention during his days as a rabble-rousing student leader in the 1970s to his imprisonment a decade ago for sodomy and abuse of power.

title: Killer, 89, Hoping for Mercy, Dies in Prison
description: Eddie Jones, the 89-year-old inmate who was poised to become the first prisoner to be freed under New Yorks expanded compassionate-release law, died Monday morning in his hospice bed in a state prison, according to corrections officials and a niece. He was nine days away from his parole hearing, at which he hoped he would be released into his familys care.

title: Progress Is Slow on Moving Surplus Swine Flu Vaccine to Countries That Need It
description: There is now so much unused swine flu vaccine in the world that rich nations, including the United States, are trying to get rid of their surpluses. But the worlds poorest countries  a few still facing the brunt of the pandemic  are receiving very little of it.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Health Reform Dead?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Conn Carroll of the Heritage Foundation debate the chances of passing health care reform.

title: At Issue: Counting the Jobs Created
description: As the Obama administration begins talking to Congress about a new jobs bill, it is still having trouble saying with precision how many jobs have been spurred so far by last years effort, the $787 billion stimulus package that was designed to create or save 3.5 million jobs over two years.

title: Since 1964, on the Beat and Forever Learning
description: This fellow started at The New York Times as a City College stringer in 1962 and joined the reporting staff two years later. He reported from the city and suburbs, Germany, Vietnam, Cambodia, Texas and points in between, until December when, at 68, he laid down his quill pen to become a freelance contributor. We turned the tables and finally caught up with the writer of this biweekly feature, Ralph Blumenthal.

title: St. Louis Blues
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I can predict some of the reaction to todays puzzle. I didnt see the theme until I was finished solving. This will be uttered with a dismissive wave, as if thats the measure of the puzzle. On the other side will be admirers. Where you end up probably depends on your skill and experience.

title: Fire Fatal to 5 Was Revenge, Police Theorize
description: Detectives investigating the fire that killed five people in a Brooklyn apartment building on Saturday believe that it was set by someone with a vendetta against a building occupant, a police spokesman said on Monday.

title: Guatemalans, in Brooklyn for Work, Keep Bonds of Home
description: In Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, they wait on corners for odd jobs, sending as much money as they can back home to Guatemala. They gather at the small churches that double as community centers. They sleep in apartments crowded with friends and family.

title: As Sponsors Fall Away, the Iditarod Tightens Its Belt
description: WASILLA, Alaska   Most days, a handful of devoted fans pay their respects in a tiny museum here dedicated to the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, which has been run across Alaskas punishing wilderness for the last 37 years. And in March, spectators will come in droves to watch along the more than 1,000-mile course.

title: Bullying Complaint in California Primary
description: LOS ANGELES  A tiny dab of drama was injected Monday into a heretofore somnolent race to succeed Arnold Schwarzenegger as governor of California.

title: Sienas Success Is the Story of Three Recruits
description: After getting off to a typically rocky start in the non-conference portion of their schedule, the Siena Saints are now once again steamrolling through the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, winning all 12 league games to date by an average margin of 13.3 points.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the United States temporarily suspending the medical evacuation of critically injured Haitian earthquake victims misstated, in some editions, the circumstances of the political campaign currently being waged by Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida. Mr. Crist, a Republican, is running to replace United States Senator George LeMieux  not Mel Martinez, who retired from the Senate last year. (Mr. LeMieux, who was appointed to the seat by Mr. Crist, is not seeking a full term.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a new requirement by Massachusetts that many day-care centers add toothbrush time to their routines misspelled the surname of the director of the First Path Day Care in Watertown, Mass. She is Alexandra Pikus, not Picus. The article also misstated the number of preschoolers at First Path. There are 55, not 60. And because of an editing error, the article misstated the name of a Boston.com blog that posted many opinions about the toothbrush requirement. It is Moms Are Talking About  not Moms Nation.

title: Mr. Obamas New Budget
description: President Obama got his priorities mostly right in the new $3.8 trillion budget for the fiscal year 2011. It calls for increased spending on education and clean energy technology, shows some restraint on the defense budget, and, most importantly, calls for more spending on job creation. It also rightly lets the Bush-era tax cuts for high-income Americans expire as scheduled at the end of 2010.

title: The Not-So-Safe Euro Zone
description: The euro is facing the most serious crisis in its 11-year history. Greece, one of 16 European Union members that uses the currency, must raise $76 billion this year  more than $50 billion of it before June 30  or default. A default would threaten the euros global credibility, scare investors away from other struggling European economies and likely reverse Europes fragile recovery.

title: A Verdict Against Vigilantism
description: On Friday, a Kansas jury convicted an anti-abortion extremist of first-degree murder for the shooting death of a Wichita abortion provider, Dr. George Tiller. It was a just verdict, but it was not only the judgment of guilt that mattered in this case.

title: Grappling With Pythons
description: The Internet is full of ads: clean, smooth, hypoallergenic is the pitch for boa constrictors on one breeders site. Other snakes can be delivered to your home the next day. The problem is that owners often tire of these living conversation pieces.

title: Moving the 9/11 Trial Out of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Vincents Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 19 about a public protest by the Guatemalan government over the arrest of three Guatemalan men at a Florida office of a shipping company gave an outdated name for the company. It is FedEx, not Federal Express. The article also misstated the name of the FedEx division that shipped a package containing a Guatemalan passport for one of the men arrested. It is FedEx Ground, not Federal Express.

title: Failed T.S.A. Nomination
description: To the Editor:

title: How Many Parents?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ways to Reduce Corporate Influence in Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: The Geezers Crusade
description: We like to think that in days gone by, the young venerated the elderly. But that wasnt always so. In As You Like It, Shakespeares morose character, Jaques, calls old age second childishness and mere oblivion. Walt Whitman hoped that the tedium and pettiness of his senior years would not infect his poetry.

title: Jim Crow Policing
description: The New York City Police Department needs to be restrained. The nonstop humiliation of young black and Hispanic New Yorkers, including children, by police officers who feel no obligation to treat them fairly or with any respect at all is an abomination. That many of the officers engaged in the mistreatment are black or Latino themselves is shameful.

title: Playing to Learn
description: New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about J. D. Salingers last known address in New York City, 300 East 57th Street, misspelled the surname of his best-known literary character. He is Holden Caulfield, not Caufield.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about Internet-based language courses misstated part of the name of Britains public service broadcaster. It is the British Broadcasting Corporation, not the British Broadcasting Service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the ramifications of a possible expansion of the Big Ten Conference misstated the name of the organization to which all Big Ten members belong. It is the Association of American Universities, not the American Association of Universities.

title: Colts Face a Shuffle if Freeney Cannot Play
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  The Indianapolis Colts are preparing to play the Super Bowl without Dwight Freeney, their All-Pro defensive end, who has not practiced since severely spraining his right ankle in the American Football Conference championship game.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Bobby Bragan, the veteran baseball player, manager and executive, misstated the date of his death. It was Thursday, Jan. 21  not Thursday, Jan. 28.

title: Stephen Huneck, Artist of Dogs, Dies at 61
description: Stephen Huneck, an internationally known artist, woodcarver and furniture maker whose most famous work was the Dog Chapel, a hand-built church in Vermont to which dogs and their owners can go for quiet reflection and spiritual renewal, died on Jan. 7 in Littleton, N.H. He was 61 and lived in St. Johnsbury, Vt.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Tuesday about the jazz drummer Ed Thigpen erroneously attributed a distinction to him. While he was a drummer with the Oscar Peterson Trio, he was not the first. At least one other drummer, Gene Gammage, preceded him.

title: Google Puts New Focus on Outside Research
description: Google, like other leading technology companies, funds university research in fields where its interest and the interest of science coincide. Until now, the company has done that mainly with lots of smaller grants, typically $50,000 or so.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Howard Zinn, the author of A Peoples History of the United States, misidentified the department of Boston University where he taught for many years. It was the political science department, not the history department.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 24 about Bob Noorda, a graphic designer who helped modernize the signs in the New York City subway system, misidentified the agency that commissioned his work in 1966. It was the New York City Transit Authority, not the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. And because of an editing error, the M.T.A.s name was rendered incorrectly as the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

title: Smooth Transition as Obama Joins the Crew
description: President Obama has called for a college football playoff, appeared on last years Super Bowl pregame show for NBC and charted his 2009 March Madness bracket picks on ESPN with Andy Katz.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the lawyer Robert D. Joffe misspelled one of the names of the firm where he was a partner. It is Cravath, Swaine & Moore  not Cravath, Swain & Moore.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sunday, about the first year of the Nixon administration, misstated the medal President Nixon bestowed on Duke Ellington. It was the Presidential Medal of Freedom, not the Medal of Honor.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 959 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: Australian Figure Skater Is Helped by Israels Rules
description: In what could amount to an unusual gift from Israels Olympic committee, a 16-year-old Australian figure skater appears to be on her way to the Vancouver Games.

title: California: Housing Ban Reviewed
description: The State Supreme Court called for new hearings to consider whether an initiative restricting where sex offenders can live imposes vague and unreasonable parole conditions. The law bans released predators from living within 2,000 feet of schools, parks and other sites where children gather; the restrictions leave many former prisoners homeless. Last week the court ruled that an initiative allowing indefinitely extended sentences for sexually violent predators might violate constitutional guarantees of equal protection; it ordered a new hearing to explore that issue.

title: Louisiana: Recusal in Landrieu Phone Case
description: Jim Letten, the United States attorney for New Orleans, recused himself from the case involving four men arrested last week on charges of interfering with the phones in Senator Mary L. Landrieus office. Mr. Letten said that after consulting with Justice Department officials, and in consideration of various relevant factors, he was allowing his first assistant attorney to handle the case. Ms. Landrieu, a Democrat, has requested that Mr. Letten, who was appointed by President George W. Bush, be reappointed. In addition, one of the four men arrested is the son of the acting United States attorney for the Northern District of Louisiana.

title: McGwire Is Testing a Loyal Baseball Town
description: ST. LOUIS  The night Mark McGwire slugged his record-breaking 62nd home run, Bob Beumer was cheering from the upper reaches of the old Busch Stadium. That ticket stub is on display in his basement, where it joins some photographs, a few autographed baseballs and other McGwire mementos from the home run chase in 1998 that gripped the nation and revived the sport. Now, though, for Beumer and many other Cardinals fans, those days seem a bit less triumphant.

title: Reliever Putz Faults Mets Handling of His Elbow Injury
description: The Mets want nothing more than to forget their injury-filled 2009 season, but their players will not let them. Reliever J. J. Putz, one of the many Mets to spend more time on the disabled list than on the field, has questioned the teams handling of an existing elbow injury that eventually required surgery.

title: Military Airlifts From Haiti Resume
description: Military airlifts of wounded Haitians began again after a controversial suspension of the flights.

title: Winfreys Cable Channel to Bring Viewers Backstage
description: How will Oprah Winfrey show up on her new cable channel when it makes its debut next January? On a show about the end of The Oprah Winfrey Show.

title: On Winfreys Channel, a Show About Her Show
description: When Oprah Winfreys cable channel makes its debut in January, she will still be the host of her syndicated talk show on local stations. Contractual agreements will prohibit her from appearing in something similar on OWN, which is short for the Oprah Winfrey Network, until the syndicated show ends in September 2011.

title: Horses Die, Jockeys Boycott and Owner Blames a Track
description: Michael Gills competitive drive has often served him well. The owner of a mortgage brokerage company based in New Hampshire, he won 370 races in 2009, more than any other racehorse owner. But with those victories has come controversy, and Gill now finds himself the target of an unusual protest in which jockeys at Penn National Race Course are refusing to ride in any race in which a Gill-owned horse is entered.

title: Anticipation and Precipitation Combine for Super Bowl Week
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  A forecast of rain has forced the N.F.L. to move Tuesdays Super Bowl media day inside for the first time in memory.

title: David Brown, Film and Stage Producer, Dies at 93
description: David Brown, an urbane New Yorker whose publishing background was the foundation of a producing career in Hollywood, with films like The Sting, Jaws, and The Verdict, and on Broadway, died Monday at home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Word of the Day | repository
description: repository \ri-p-z-tor-e\ noun

title: Earl A. Barth, a Master of Plaster, Dies at 87
description: Earl A. Barth said that plastering and music sort of rhyme. Perched on a scaffold, he would burst into arias from Carmen or growl like Muddy Waters when installing a ceiling medallion.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on the death of Charles Mac Mathias on Jan. 27 misspelled the name of a Republican representative from Ohio who helped pass the Civil Rights Act of 1964. He was William McCulloch, not McCullough.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Jan. 31 about where to try the alleged mastermind of the 9/11 attacks inaccurately described the history of military tribunals at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. There were two convictions in 2008.

title: EU Weighs Oneworld Plan to Assure Flight Competition
description: Europes antitrust regulator said Monday that it was reviewing an offer by British Airways, American Airlines and the Spanish flag carrier Iberia aimed at preserving competition on long-haul routes if their proposed joint venture is approved, The New York Timess James Kanter reported.

title: Tom Brookshier, 78, an N.F.L. Star and Voice
description: Tom Brookshier, a star defensive back who helped lead the Philadelphia Eagles to the 1960 National Football League championship and later teamed with Pat Summerall as CBSs No. 1 pro football broadcasting duo, died Friday at a hospital in the Philadelphia suburb of Wynnewood, Pa. Brookshier, who lived in West Conshohocken, Pa., was 78.

title: News Quiz | February 2, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Buyout Shops Said to Be in Race for China Bank Stake
description: Three American private equity firms are on a short list to submit final bids for Morgan Stanleys $1 billion-plus stake in Chinas top investment bank, three sources briefed on the bidding process told Reuters on Tuesday.

title: Investors Help Whitman Line Coffers for Campaign
description: Donations from a host of hedge fund managers and venture capitalists helped Meg Whitman, the billionaire Republican California gubernatorial candidate, raise more than $10 million in campaign contributions, The Associated Press reported.

title: Davos Bankers Seek One Message on Volcker Rule
description: Debates raged for most of Davos about the merits and possible harm of President Obamas Volcker Rule, which would limit banks size and ability to engage in proprietary trading, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

title: China Brokerage Firms I.P.O. Aims for $2.4 Billion
description: Huatai Securities, the mid-sized Chinese brokerage firm, will introduce an initial public offering in Shanghai this week that could raise 16.5 billion renminbi ($2.4 billion) in Chinas largest offering this year, braving a mainland market straining under a large number of new share offerings and tightening liquidity, Reuters reported.

title: Feng Shui Master Is Denied Billionaires Estate
description: HONG KONG  A judge in Hong Kong ruled Tuesday that the estate of the billionaire known as Little Sweetie will not be going to her feng shui master.

title: Google Extends Research Financing
description: From Steve Lohr from Bits:

title: Is It More Fair to Share?
description: WHO are both for and against the idea of pooling disaster relief funds for use by multiple aid organizations?

title: Are You Happy?
description: In recent years, a few books have been published on the subject of happiness  including arguments against simple pleasure and surface-level complacency. What does happiness mean to you?

title: Merkel Set to Buy Bank Data, but Party Hesitates
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel said the German government would be willing to buy stolen information relating to Swiss bank accounts to crack down on tax dodgers, sparking discord in her coalition and criticism in Switzerland, Bloomberg News reported.

title: New Look, a Fashion Retailer, Announces I.P.O.
description: New Look, the British budget fashion chain, announced its long-awaited initial public offering on Tuesday, hoping to take advantage of a tentative recovery in new issues and banish the ghosts of the last big British retail I.P.O., Reuters said.

title: China Warns U.S. on Meeting With Dalai Lama
description: BEIJING  A senior Chinese official strongly warned President Obama on Tuesday against meeting with the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, saying it would damage relations between China and the United States.

title: A Bond Issue at McClatchy
description: The McClatchy Companys prospects are looking up, just a year after investors seemed to expect the newspaper publisher to go bust, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Burkle Moves on Barnes & Noble
description: The investor Ronald Burkle is seeking permission from Barnes & Noble to nearly double his stake in the book seller and become its largest shareholder.

title: Cloudy Future for Fannie and Freddie
description: The Great Bailout is mostly over for the banks. But for those troubled behemoths of the nations housing bust, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the lifeline from Washington just keeps getting longer, The New York Timess Charles Duhigg writes.

title: Yodle Has Investors Singing Its Tune
description: Yodle, a start-up that helps local businesses advertise online, has received $10 million in a fourth round of funding, Venturebeat said.

title: Korean Pension Fund Buying Stake in Gatwick
description: South Koreas National Pension Service announced Tuesday that it would buy a small stake in Gatwick Airport in London as it sought to increase its investments abroad.

title: Bush Legs
description: Russian nickname for American chicken products.

title: A Twist in Wall St. Reform Talks
description: Update | 9:46 a.m. A spokeswoman for Senator Christopher J. Dodd denied a report by dealReporter that the senator planned to quietly modify or drop the so-called Volcker rule for separating proprietary trading from commercial lending. The senator stands by the proposal, the spokeswoman told DealBook.

title: KDDI Said to Be Scrutinized Over J:Comm Bid
description: Japans Financial Services Agency is looking into the $4 billion bid by KDDI, the Japanese telecommunications operator, to buy 38 percent of Jupiter Telecommunications from John Malones Liberty Global, according to news reports.

title: China Begins Emergency Check of Dairy Products
description: BEIJING  China has begun a 10-day emergency inspection of dairy products because of reports that tainted items the government ordered destroyed during a food safety scandal in 2008 were still on the market, the official newspaper China Daily reported Tuesday.

title: Schwarzman Sees Buyout Chill in Australia
description: Australia will find it very difficult to attract new private equity investments while a tax dispute remains unresolved, Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chief executive of one of the most powerful private equity firms, the Blackstone Group, warned.

title: Federer Dismisses Notion of Taking a Long Break
description: On Monday, the day after winning his 4th Australian Open and 16th major over all, Roger Federer practically gushed about being able to share the victory with his 6-month-old twin daughters.

title: Putting London to Paper
description: Pumped up after taking a 2003 course called Drawing the City at the Princes Drawing School in London, a few members of the class decided to branch out on their own. Dubbing themselves the Drawing London Group, they started exploring all facets of London life  alleyways, cathedrals, cafes, pubs, markets  depicting the capital through sketches and watercolors.

title: White House Watches Illinois Primary
description: President Obama is heading to New Hampshire on Tuesday, but his eye is on Illinois.

title: Is Leap Wireless Considering a Deal With MetroPCS?
description: Could Leap Wireless International and MetroPCS Communications finally be headed for a courtship, more than two years after Leap rejected an unsolicited proposal from its rival?

title: Madoffs Ex-Finance Chief to Give Up New Jersey Home
description: The man who served as Bernard Madoffs finance chief has agreed to give up his New Jersey home so it can be sold for the benefit of those cheated by his jailed former boss.

title: Rio Tinto Sells Alcan Units to Amcor for $1.95 Billion
description: Rio Tinto said Tuesday it had completed the almost $2 billion sale of some divisions of its Alcan business to Amcor, taking another step toward cutting its debt load.

title: Europe Feels Snubbed by Obama
description: PARIS  President Obamas decision to skip a United States-European Union summit meeting scheduled for Madrid in May has predictably upset European officials, who suggested Tuesday that the summit meeting itself would now be postponed, possibly to the autumn.

title: Maybe the Moon Can Wait, but the S.E.C. Cant
description: President Barack Obama is seeking a 12 percent budget increase for the Securities and Exchange Commission, including $419 million for more than 100 new enforcement staff members to work on the agencys growing fraud and market manipulation caseload, The Associated Press reported.

title: For the Unscathed Banks, China Beckons
description: Several Western banks that have escaped the worst of the financial crisis are seizing the opportunity to increase their presence in China in the hope of profiting from the sectors rapid growth, Reuters reported.

title: Should Banks Get Out of Our Markets?
description: Slates Daniel Gross has a message for the bankers balking at proposals to rein in the size and scope of financial institutions and other changes aimed at forestalling a repeat of the panic of 2008: If the banks want us out of their business, they should get out of our markets.

title: Macklowe Sells Three N.Y. Towers to Zell
description: Harry Macklowe has agreed to sell three Manhattan apartment towers to Sam Zells Equity Residential for $475 million, as the New York developer leaves the residential market, Crains New York Business reported.

title: Cognitive Fluency
description: Todays idea: Cognitive fluency  a measure of how easy it is to think about something  shapes what we believe, how we invest, and who and what we think is beautiful, psychologists say.

title: R.B.S. Said to Make Bonuses Convertible Into Cash
description: Royal Bank of Scotland Group is to allow its top performing employees to convert a large part of bonuses given in shares into cash within 12 weeks, The Daily Telegraph reported, citing a letter sent to investors Monday.

title: What If You Could Wear Your Smartphone Like a Bracelet?
description: For all the hype over the Apple iPad last week, its size and shape  a tablet  is hardly radical. Other PC makers have been making tablet computers for years.

title: Lawmakers Ask Toyota to Prove Fix Solves Problem
description: DETROIT  Lawmakers and the Transportation Department stepped up pressure Tuesday on Toyota, seeking proof that problems that could cause its cars to speed up unexpectedly were limited to floor mats and sticking pedals.

title: Protest Mars U.N. Leaders Visit to Cyprus
description: PARIS  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, ended a three-day visit to Cyprus on Tuesday with reports saying his talks there in quest of a unity deal had been overshadowed by a diplomatic gaffe.

title: Funds Face Tax Increase in Obamas Budget
description: The hedge fund and private equity industry may not have been too pleased with some of the proposals put forth by President Obama in his 2011 budget blueprint Monday, Reuters says.

title: Do the Saints Play Dirty?
description: Many Fifth Down readers have objected to the Saints mauling of quarterbacks  Kurt Warner, then Brett Favre  during the postseason. A few days after the battering of Favre, the Saints defensive coordinator, Gregg Williams, went on a Nashville radio station and took verbal aim at the Colts Peyton Manning:

title: Sampler: Political Bullying, Dangerous Surf and Sebastapol Tackles Teenage Drinking
description: Accusations of Bullying | Steve Poizner, the states insurance commissioner and a candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, accused his rival in the primary, Meg Whitman, of criminally trying to bully him out of the race. In a complaint with federal and state authorities, Mr. Poizner said that Mike Murphy, an official in the Whitman campaign, sent him an e-mail message urging him to leave the race and run for the Senate in 2012. Mr. Murphy, in a statement, did not deny claim. After reading the ridiculous charges made by Steve Poizner during todays strange press conference, Mr. Murphys statement said, all I can say is that Im starting to worry about the commissioners mental condition. [The New York Times]

title: Sorting Chocolate Bunnies, Thinking of the Dead
description: It is a surreal experience these days to visit Madelaine Chocolate Novelties, a huge chocolate factory in the Rockaway section of Queens.

title: F1 Testing and Season Begin in Spain
description: From our colleagues at Formula One:

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Feb. 2
description: Here are some highlights from Tuesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Bank of New York to Buy PNC Unit for $2.3 Billion
description: Bank of New York Mellon said Tuesday that it would buy the global investment servicing unit of the PNC Financial Services Group for $2.31 billion in cash, bolstering its back-end offerings for fund managers and financial advisers.

title: Agnilux? It Means Wont Say a Peep
description: If youre a reporter, theres only one thing more frustrating than a stealth start-up, and thats a stealth start-up run by former Apple employees. Youre basically dealing with people who refuse to confirm or deny anything, including what they ate for breakfast.

title: Of Dr. Seuss and Coal Gasification
description: Post updated 2/10; 11:55 a.m.

title: The Nifty 50 | Jennifer Lawrence, Actress
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: The 82nd Annual Oscar Nominations
description: Below is the full list of the 82nd Annual Oscar Nominations, which were announced Tuesday morning:

title: Agnilux? It Means, Wont Say a Peep
description: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

title: YouTubes Take From Movie Rentals: $10,709.16
description: UPDATE 12:45 pm Clarified next steps for YouTube rental business.

title: High Bacteria Levels Found in Packaged Greens
description: Its no secret that its not a good idea to eat bagged salad greens straight out of the bag, but Consumer Reports this month indicates just how bad an idea it is.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: Bonus Miles Expand, but Flight Upgrades Are Squeezed More elite fliers are competing for fewer seats in the front of the plane.

title: The Early Word: Jobs and Elections
description: A day after his latest budget proposal was released, President Obama heads to New Hampshire to discuss  what else?  the economy. And in his home state of Illinois, voters go to the polls for primaries in several state and federal races.

title: Fiscalizing Failure
description: If you read much of whats being said these days by respectable people, youd believe that deficits are always and everywhere the main source of economic problems. But, you know, thats not really true.

title: Academy Award Nominations Are Announced
description: The Ten have been revealed. The 10 movies that will be contending for best picture honors at the Academy Awards next month include anticipated front runners like Avatar, The Hurt Locker, Precious, Up in the Air and Up, dark horses like The Blind Side, An Education, Inglourious Basterds and A Serious Man, and one surprise popcorn movie, the science-fiction hit District 9.

title: Avatar and Hurt Locker Lead the Oscar Field
description: Update | 9:41 a.m. Avatar and The Hurt Locker narrowly led the Oscar nominees, with nine nominations each, including best picture and best director, as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences scattered its honors among an unusually wide field of contenders on Tuesday.

title: Candidates Set in Race for Obamas Old Senate Seat
description: CHICAGO  Representative Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican, and Alexi Giannoulias, the Illinois treasurer and a Democrat, won primary elections for the United States Senate here on Tuesday, setting up the pair for a contest in the fall over the seat once held by President Obama.

title: David Furnish Talks About Next Fall
description: When Elton John and his life partner, David Furnish, went to see the Naked Angels production of Next Fall last June, they were struck by how their own concerns as a couple were reflected in the play about the love story of two gay men  and the barriers they face when an accident leaves one of them in a coma and the other without legal rights to care for his partner.

title: Resort Ready | Packing for Heat
description: Dreaming of trading in your tights for a two-piece? Ts fashion department picks its favorite beach-ready fashion from the current womens resort collections.

title: Waiting for a Decision on the Broadway Experiment
description: It has been hailed as New York Citys most radical civic experiment in a generation: cars would be barred from driving along two sections of Broadway in the heart of Midtown.

title: Canada Tweaks Emissions Reduction Targets
description: In a pledge made as part of the Copenhagen Accord, Canada has officially notified the United Nations that it intends to establish national greenhouse gas emission targets that precisely correspond with the United States goal of a 17 percent reduction from 2005 levels by 2020.

title: Suspect Arrested in Fatal Brooklyn Fire
description: Updated, 1:01 p.m. | The police have charged a man with setting the  fire in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, that killed five people on Saturday, the authorities said.

title: S.E.C. Admits It Received Galleon Wiretaps
description: Update | 1:17 p.m. The Securities and Exchange Commission conceded in court filings that federal prosecutors mistakenly sent the agency confidential wiretap information from the criminal insider-trading case against Galleon Groups founder, Raj Rajaratnam.

title: 2 Decisions Reshape Inquiries Into Madoff Case
description: Authorities on both sides of the Atlantic have made decisions that shape the investigations into Bernard L. Madoffs long-running Ponzi scheme.

title: CBS Says Grammys Rap Didnt Meet Our Broadcast Standards
description: No details yet from the Recording Academy about what led to the, shall we say, aggressively dissonant duet between Taylor Swift and Stevie Nicks during the Grammy Awards on Sunday night. But CBS, which showed the awards ceremony, has provided a brief explanation of why it censored a rap performance that featured Eminem, Lil Wayne and Drake. The audio from the performance, which combined the rap songs Forever and Drop the World, was frequently cut from the live telecast, leading many viewers to wonder if their television sets simply werent working. In an interview with The Associated Press, Chris Ender, a spokesman for CBS, said: It was a rousing musical performance, but words were edited from the live telecast that didnt meet our broadcast standards. We have great respect for artists creative freedom, but there are certain things you cant say, or sing, on television.

title: Carpetbagger: The Oscar Nominations are Unveiled
description: The Oscar nominations were announced at dawn on Tuesday. The full story and the complete list of nominees are on the Carpetbagger blog. Bottom line: Lots of love for James Cameron, Quentin Tarantino and The Hurt Locker  not so much for Clint Eastwood. Check in with Carpetbagger throughout the day for Oscar updates.

title: Meeting on Labor Talks Is Added
description: The N.F.L. players union last week requested a meeting with the owners labor committee before the Super Bowl with the start of an uncapped year looming. The owners agreed, so the sides will meet early Saturday, before a previously scheduled meeting of team owners. The meeting is unusual because it will involve the full labor committee of owners and players on the unions executive committee, and is not a meeting of the regular negotiating teams for both sides.

title: Players Win a Ruling on Revenue Sharing
description: A special master ruled Monday that N.F.L. owners may not dismantle its supplemental revenue program, as it had planned to do at the start of the 2010 league year, a victory for the players union on the eve of the uncapped year. The pool is worth about $200 million and is divided among 8 to 12 lower-revenue teams. Owners had contended that the pool was only required during years with a salary cap and that with the disappearance of the cap, the pool was no longer necessary.Stephen Burbank, the special master, ruled that the owners could not unilaterally dismantle the program, and that the collective bargaining agreement demanded that the union approve of any changes to supplemental revenue sharing.

title: Reasons for Separation
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: This is unfortunate. I heard that John Edwards and his wife Elizabeth have legally separated. Under the reasons for separation, Elizabeth Edwards just wrote, See news.

title: Four More Years
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: President Obama got out of jury duty. No word yet about getting us out of Afghanistan.

title: Terrorists Out of Manhattan
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: The Obama administration has reversed itself and is now considering moving the trial of the 9/11 terrorists out of Manhattan after protests from Congress and the mayor of New York. See, theyre going to do an Off Broadway version first, see if people like it. See, then if it does well, then theyll bring it into the city.

title: Leno Remakes a Legendary Car Movie
description: Cetait un Rendez-Vous, the nine-minute film of a car speeding through Paris at dawn, with only the cars revving engine as soundtrack, is a cult classic. Produced in 1976 by the French director Claude Lelouch, the film has inspired numerous remakes and spoofs, including Nissans promo for the 350Z several years ago.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused articles appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Value of Pell Grant Awards Would Rise Under Obama Budget Plan
description: As President Obama and his aides unveiled the administrations fiscal 2011 budget with lots of talk about reining in discretionary spending, the Web site Inside Higher Ed wrote Tuesday morning, they largely exempted programs important to higher education from the budget restraint they urged.

title: Lawyer for Steven Tyler Warns Aerosmith Over Replacement Singers
description: When he announced in December that he was entering rehab, the Aerosmith front man Steven Tyler said that he was eager to be back with his band mates as soon as possible. Perhaps to illustrate that point, his lawyer has sent a cease-and-desist letter to the bands management, saying that its efforts to seek a replacement singer could destroy the group, Billboard reported. In a letter to the bands manager, Howard Kaufman, Mr. Tylers lawyer, Skip Miller, wrote that the strategy was playing band members off against one another and engaging in acts and conduct to the harm and detriment of the singer and the band. Aerosmith without Steven Tyler is like the Rolling Stones without Mick Jagger, or U2 without Bono, Mr. Miller wrote. While this management strategy may get the band on the road a few months sooner, it ultimately could destroy Aerosmith.

title: Malaysian Figure to Call Premier in Sodomy Case
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  There may have been little progress inside the courtroom on Tuesday, but there was no shortage of drama outside on what was to have been the first day of the new sodomy trial of the opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim.

title: The 82nd Annual Oscar Nominations
description: The Academy scattered its honors among an unusually wide field of contenders.

title: Blind Side Forever
description: There was a wave of cheering in the press room when The Blind Side was announced as a best picture contender on Tuesday morning. In a year tailor-made for surprises, the Oscars delivered some, with the box-office hit nabbing a lead spot and a nomination for its star, Sandra Bullock. District 9, the sci-fi feature set in South Africa, also did well, with a best picture nomination and nods for editing, visual effects and best adapted screenplay.

title: The Decline of St. Vincents Hospital
description: For more than 150 years, St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan has been a beacon in Greenwich Village, serving poets, writers, artists, winos, the poor and the working-class, and gay people.

title: The Great Abstinence Debate
description: In yesterdays column, I argued for an empirical modesty about what works and what doesnt in sex education, and suggested that wed be better off leaving decisions about whether to emphasize contraception or abstinence to states and localities, rather than trying to set a sex-ed policy at the national level. At Slates XX Factor, Hanna Rosin disagreed:

title: WWS 543: Class Notes, 2/3/10
description: The one-minute trade policy theorist. (pdf)

title: An Oscar Show of Firsts
description: Adam Shankman and Bill Mechanic are the odd couple of Oscar producers: during the announcement on Tuesday in Beverly Hills, Mr. Shankman was bejeweled and jumpy, Mr. Mechanic beige and calm. Though they have been working for months to build a show with populist appeal based on this years expanded field of 10 best picture nominees, they admitted they have no idea how the new voting system for that category works.

title: Another View: New Prism for Post-Crisis Deal Terms
description: Michael Weisser and Christopher Machera of Weil, Gotshal & Manges analyze the importance of acquisition agreements in corporate deals made in the wake of the financial crisis.

title: Grammys Fill-In
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first five paragraphs of this article about the Grammy Awards, Biggest Haul at Grammys Goes to Beyonc. Use your own words and phrases, or click read more to choose from a scrambled list of the words/phrases that were removed.

title: Visual Learning: The Theater Posters of Fraver
description: Last week we introduced you to the artwork of Robert Rodriguez, who designed the poster for the coming Broadway revival of Lend Me a Tenor.

title: A Couple of Additional Budget Thoughts
description: 1. The administration projects debt of 77.2 percent of GDP in 2020. Without the non-security discretionary spending freeze, this number would, by my reckoning, be 78.7 percent. But hey, the freeze is crucial to demonstrating fiscal responsibility

title: India Issues Terrorism Alert Over Hijack Plot
description: Airline passengers across India went through extra security screenings Friday and sky marshals were placed on flights as the government put its airports on high alert amid reports that al-Qaida-linked militants planned to hijack a plane. Read the full story.

title: Fidelity Cuts Trading Fees and Waives Commissions on 25 E.T.F.s
description: The competition is heating up in the online brokerage world.

title: Night Rides, Part 2: Your Photos
description: Last week, we put out a call for photos of the city captured during the course of a late-night ride. Many people answered, including one reader in Montreal, and most of the snaps  on bridges and bike paths, of strewn trash and a sleeping drunk  illustrate the feeling of peacefulness and quiet that riders described to us.

title: More Government Debt, Please
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Once Again, We Are the World
description: There comes a time when musicians heed a certain call and come together as one, and that time came on Monday evening as more than 70 performers joined up to record a new version of We Are the World to benefit Haitian earthquake relief organizations, Reuters reported. The all-star session took place in the same Hollywood studio where the original song, written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and produced by Quincy Jones to raise money for African famine victims, was recorded, and was overseen by Mr. Richie and Mr. Jones. Among the artists who can be heard on the new single are Barbra Streisand, Celine Dion, Tony Bennett, Snoop Dogg, Lil Wayne, Drake, LL Cool J, and will.i.am of Black Eyed Peas, as well as Justin Bieber, who sings the songs opening line, and Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-American performer who has largely served as the celebrity face of the earthquake relief effort. None of the performers on the original We Are the World recording are involved in the new single, nor was Lady Gaga, who was widely rumored to be on the producers wish list. Randy Phillips, the AEG Live executive, told Reuters that a video for the song would have its debut on Feb. 12 during the Winter Olympics, and that proceeds will go to a newly established charity foundation.

title: 'Hair' Dance Party
description: A look at the onstage dancing at end of a performance of the Broadway revival of "Hair." (Video courtesy of HMS Media)

title: Banning Junk Food in Public Schools
description: The blogger Jill Richardson notes some encouraging school lunch news from Massachusetts  read more here and here.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Italians Will Fine Athletes Who Test Positive in Vancouver
description: The Italian Olympic Committee isnt fooling around with its intent to take a drug-free team to the Vancouver Games. The organization announced Tuesday that it would fine any Italian athlete $140,000 if he or she was caught doping at the Winter Games.

title: Avista Hires Ex-Bush Official to Advisory Board
description: Avista Capital Partners, a private equity firm specializing in energy, healthcare and media investments, said on Tuesday that it had hired the former Bush administration official Jim Nussle to serve on its advisory board.

title: The Super Bowl From Every Angle
description: In a way, it is fitting that Groundhog Day falls during Super Bowl week, both being ritualistic and absurd. Perhaps we should stage our own sports version of Punxsutawney Phils yearly peek, with John Madden emerging from his cruiser to see his shadow, meaning we get six more weeks of hearing about Dwight Freeneys ankle.

title: Homeownership Rate Falls Back to Pre-Boom Level
description: The American homeownership rate in the last quarter of 2009 fell back to its level from a decade ago, according to the Census Bureau.

title: Britain Wont Pursue Legal Action Against Madoff
description: Britains Serious Fraud Office said Tuesday that it would not pursue legal action against the British operations of Bernard L. Madoff, the ex-financier now in jail in the United States.

title: Goldilocks Devices
description: Web-browsing gadgets  like the iPad  which are positioned somewhere between smartphones and laptops.

title: The Nifty 50 | Eric Daman, Costume Designer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Nike Makes Environmental Strides and Abandons Carbon Offsets
description: A new corporate responsibility report issued by the shoe and apparel manufacturer Nike highlights the progress the company has made in reducing its environmental footprint and the ways in which its climate change strategy is evolving  including its decision to abandon carbon offsets and renewable energy certificates as means of achieving carbon neutrality.

title: Tasting Report: Oregon Pinot Gris With Distinct Personality
description: Anne Amie Willamette Valley 2008

title: Some Good News for the Indies
description: A day after Sony Pictures Entertainment announced another round of layoffs, its indie division, Sony Pictures Classics, earned a company record of 13 Oscar nominations for seven films on Tuesday, including An Education, The Last Station, The White Ribbon, Coco Before Chanel and The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus. (The latter two were nominated in categories like costumes and art direction.)

title: Obama to Explain Small-Business Lending Proposal
description: President Obamas Jobs for Small Business 2010 United States Tour continues. Tuesdays stop: Nashua, N.H., where he is to flesh out his State of the Union proposal to facilitate lending by community banks to the tune of at least $30 billion.

title: Pairings: Warm Deconstructed Caesar Salad
description: A crisp yet grapey pinot gris can be the default wine for dishes that are notoriously hard to please. Salad, for starters, and eggs.

title: Corporation Says It Will Run for Congress
description: Following the Supreme Court decision implicitly granting corporations the right to free speech (by determining that political spending is a kind of speech), a corporation has decided to take what it believes to be democracys next step: It is running for Congress.

title: Win a Stay at Norman Mailers House! (If Youre British.)
description: If youre going to spend several weeks crashing at Norman Mailers place, its probably for the best that the master of the house is no longer around. The British edition of GQ magazine is offering young writers an opportunity to stay for a month at the disheveled if singularly productive authors former home in Provincetown, Mass., where Mailer lived from the 1990s until his death in 2007, and which has since been turned into a writers retreat. The Guardian reported that Dylan Jones, the magazines editor, announced on Tuesday the start of an annual nonfiction writing competition, open to undergraduates and post-graduates at British universities who are over the age of 18. The contest will be judged by a panel that includes GQ editors and the pop singer Lily Allen; its winner may be published in GQ, and will for certain receive a prize of about $1,600 and a July stay at the Norman Mailer Writers Colony, whose activities include writing workshops, seminars and not getting beaten with a hammer by Rip Torn.

title: What Should $20 Get You?
description: Pinot gris is a most unusual grape. Unlike, say, sauvignon blanc, which is pretty much identifiable as sauvignon blanc wherever it comes from regardless of varying expressions of terroir, pinot gris offers completely different guises depending on whether it hails from Alsace, Italy (as pinot grigio) or Oregon, which is the subject of my column.

title: Top Defense Officials Seek to End Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top two defense officials called Tuesday for an end to the 16-year-old dont ask, dont tell law, a major step toward allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the United States military for the first time.

title: A Look Under the Hood of Tesla Motors
description: In his typical style, Elon Musk, Tesla Motors chief executive, laid out grand ambitions in a government filing Friday: He wants to make all-electric sport utility vehicles, vans and coupes once he is done with Teslas sports car and sedan.

title: Panel Cites Preflight Crew Errors in Crash Near Buffalo
description: WASHINGTON  Even before the plane took off, a critical error had been made. Because the captain and first officer of the Colgan Air turboprop had entered contradictory information into cockpit computer systems, a false alarm was later triggered, startling the captain into yanking a control the wrong way and leading to a crash outside Buffalo that killed 50 people last Feb. 12.

title: Toyotas Sales Fall as G.M. and Ford Gain
description: DETROIT  Toyota Motor on Tuesday estimated that it lost about 20,000 vehicle sales in the week since it halted sales and production of some of its most popular models.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Flames Lose Again, Then Trade Again
description: Four games on Monday night, including Calgary Flames, seeking only their second win in 11 games. Spoiler alert: they lost again, prompting them to pull the trigger on a trade with the Rangers just two nights after they made a big trade with Toronto. Meanwhile, some big Olympic names made an impact  including Teemu Selanne, who suffered a broken jaw on Jan. 13 and was feared lost to Finland for the Winter Games. Home teams listed first:

title: Paul Taylor Dance Foundation Downsizes by One
