description: On the eve of moving into its new home, the Paul Taylor Dance Company said on Tuesday that it had eliminated an executive position to save money and was expecting to finish with a balanced budget this season, as it celebrates Mr. Taylors 80th birthday. The Paul Taylor Dance Foundation, which runs the company, said its executive director, Martin I. Kagan, resigned on Friday. He was effectively replaced by the companys general manager, John Tomlinson, who was given the title of managing director of the foundation. Mr. Tomlinson said that construction work was complete on the companys new studios and offices on the Lower East Side and that it was just waiting for permits to move in. He said he hoped that would happen before the start of the companys season at City Center on Feb. 24. The company lost the lease on its old home in SoHo in late 2008.

title: Emanuel Apologizes, in Wake of Palin Slam
description: Update | 8:44 p.m. Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, apologized for using the word retarded to describe liberals at a closed-door meeting last year.

title: The False Prophets of Autism
description: When Dr. Andrew Wakefield  the British doctor who linked vaccines to autism  was found to be dishonest, irresponsible and acting contrary to the clinical interests of a child by a medical-misconduct panel last week, and when the respected medical journal The Lancet officially retracted its publication of Wakefields 1998 study earlier today, those were but the most recent controversial moments in the medical mystery that is autism.

title: Kraft Seals Deal for Cadbury
description: Kraft Foods declared victory on Tuesday in its pursuit of Cadbury, announcing that it had won widespread support from the British confectioners shareholders.

title: Inside Out | Shopping the Palm Beaches
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

title: Obama Photos and Pinkney Paintings at Schomburg Center
Q&A: Where to Study in Spain
description: Q.

title: What Were Reading
description: Barry Estabrook says the Atlantic albacore may be going the way of the Atlantic bluefin. Catches have dropped from 60,000 tons to 20,000, since the 1980s, but ICCAT  the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna  still sets an annual limit that, at 32,000 tons, is more than 50 percent higher than the annual take.

title: Galileo Sets Up LGBT Capital for Gay Market
description: Carving out a niche in the crowded investment banking world is tough, with boutiques focusing on nearly every sector of the economy from autos to green technology. But the partners at Galileo Capital Management may have done just that with the start-up of LGBT Capital, a specialist corporate advisory and investment management unit that will focus exclusively on the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender consumer market.

title: Teachers Union and City Drift Apart
description: It seemed a fairly straightforward request: a principal asked teachers to outline their goals for students as part of a school plan. But for the United Federation of Teachers, the request for written student goals amounted to an increase in the workday. So last April, the union filed an official grievance, claiming that the Education Department had refused and/or failed to provide sufficient time during the workday for U.F.T.-represented teachers to perform the goal setting.

title: By Playing It Safe, Will They Be Sorry?
description: OREGON pinot gris is a stealth wine. It occupies a secure spot in the marketplace, but few crave Oregon pinot gris or give it much thought. Yet on the occasions when I spot it on an otherwise unfriendly wine list, I am relieved to have found a somewhat safe haven.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Recessions increase inequality. That is primarily because households in the bottom percentiles of the earnings distribution suffer the largest earnings declines during economic downturns.

title: We Suppose, Technically, They Are the World, Too
description: The first annual ArtsBeatie prizes for people we least expected to see involved in the new recording of We Are the World are hereby awarded to:

title: Galleon Case Informant Faces S.E.C. Charges
description: Update | 2:21 p.m. David R. Slaine, a former Wall Street hedge fund manager and former head of Nasdaq trading at Morgan Stanley who secretly recorded conversations for the government in the Galleon Group insider trading case, was accused of insider trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday.

title: Murtha Hospitalized in I.C.U.
description: Representative John P. Murtha, a longtime Democrat from Pennsylvania, is in a Washington-area intensive care unit following complications from gall bladder surgery.

title: Vain Glorious | Apot.Care Irido-radiant Cream
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Living in the Post-Cancer Moment
description: Having cancer is like being kidnapped, being harried to a dark and deadly place by an unexpected assailant who has pressed the cold barrel of a gun to your skull. You might be strong enough or lucky enough to escape, to survive. Then again, you might not.

title: Shrine to a Special Ship Is Given to a Public Display
description: Wednesday is when the movers will show up, ready to pack box after box and load everything onto the truck and leave Mario J. Pulices landlocked apartment looking less like a ship.

title: Some News Outlets Ready to Try Charging Online Readers
description: Extracting payment from online readers has been called everything from the next great folly of print journalism to its salvation, but to get a glimpse of how it really looks, head to Lancaster, Pa.

title: Guess Whos (Possibly) Coming to the Oscars?
description: Its been a minute since we checked in on our old pal Adam Lambert, but that provocative American Idol finalist could end up back on our radar  and ABCs  very soon.

title: Italians to Electrify Cruise Ships in Port
description: Post corrected 2/3; 12:19 p.m.

title: Its the Economy, Undergraduate
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  One day last summer, in the back of a bug-like armored truck in southern Afghanistan, an American infantryman my own age asked me a question, one Ive heard countless times from countless soldiers when they learn that at home, I study at an Ivy League college: What do they think of all this back there, in your world?

title: OKeefe Talks to Fox About His Landrieu-Office Arrest
description: James OKeefe, the young videographer who caused an uproar last year by surreptitiously recording himself and an associate, posing as a pimp and prostitute, getting business advice from workers at Acorn, has given his first TV interview after his arrest at Senator Mary Landrieus office in New Orleans last month.

title: British Motor Industrys Setting Sons
description: The British motor car industry looks decidedly less British these days, with the announcement last month that Jaguar Land Rovers British chief executive, David Smith, was being replaced by an executive from India.

title: In Senate Panel, Concern Over Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas budget came in for sharp criticism on Tuesday from both Republican and Democratic lawmakers who said the White House was not doing enough to reduce the deficit in the medium and long term.

title: In January, CNN Overtakes MSNBC
description: Proving again that it still thrives when there is real news to cover, CNN staged a comeback of sorts in January, a month dominated by coverage of the earthquake in Haiti.

title: Puzzling Over a Red, White and Blue Iran
description: Recent images of Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, standing before backdrops prepared for official ceremonies  in which the colors of Irans flag appear to have been changed from red, white and green to red, white and blue  have observers asking: Are Iranian graphic designers trying to tell us something? And if so, what, exactly?

title: Macmillan Books Still Mostly Absent From Amazon.com
description: On Sunday, Amazon.com appeared to wave the white flag of surrender in its war with book publishers over e-book prices. But as it turns out, the battle is still raging.

title: Ads That Promote Health, Not Appetite
description: New anti-smoking ads in delis and bodegas are the latest in a long line of gross-out public health campaigns by the city. As McBrooklyn describes, one such poster hanging in Montague Street Bagels in Brooklyn Heights is practically dripping with cancer and is so appetite-suppressing that the restaurant was forced to annotate the image with an apologetic note: We are very sorry, but by order of NYC DOH we are required to post this sign or face a $2,000 fine.

title: The Morning Skate: The Jokinen Trade and the May Rant
description: Heres todays question. Why would Darryl Sutter, the Flames general manager, trade Olli Jokinen, a proven goal scorer (although he has under-performed this season) who is an unrestricted free agent after this season, and rugged Brandon Prust to the Rangers for Ales Kotalik (who cant even make the Ranger lineup), with two years left on a three-year, $9 million deal, and Chris Higgins (whose lack of finish around the net is a chronic condition), who is also about to be an unrestricted free agent?

title: Carpetbagger: Oscar Nominations
description: The Bagger rises early to report from the 2010 Academy Award nominations ceremony.

title: Ingredients You Wont Find in a Store
description: To find unusual ingredients from farms around the country, Print, the restaurant in the new Ink 48 hotel at 48th Street and 11th Avenue, has an in-house forager.

title: Video: The Bagger at the Nominations
Stumping for Jobs Plan, Obama Pushes Health Bill
description: NASHUA, N.H.  President Obama hit the road again Tuesday to promote the new job-creation program he described as his No. 1 priority, but he refused to abandon his embattled health care legislation, vowing to punch it through resistance in Congress.

title: Officials Visit Russian City Amid Protests
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials this week have been shuttling between Moscow and Kaliningrad, where antigovernment protests over the weekend drew thousands of people in one of Russias most strategically important cities, seemingly catching the authorities off guard.

title: Opposition Hardens Line Inside Iran
description: Mir Hussein Moussavi, the Iranian opposition leader, made some of his harshest remarks to date against Irans rulers on Tuesday in an interview on his Web site, calling their behavior dictatorial and terrifying.

title: USA Curling Wants You to Donate and Sweep Your Way to Vancouver
description: The word is out: USA Curling wonders if you would make a good skip in the Vancouver Olympics.

title: Ukraine and Russia Trade Spying Charges
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraine has detained a Russian intelligence officer and expelled four others, breaking up what it said Tuesday was a spy ring that intended to steal military and state secrets.

title: Bits: Macmillan Books Still Largely Absent on Amazon
description: On Sunday, Amazon appeared to surrender to Macmillan in a dispute over the pricing of e-books. Macmillan, like other publishers, wanted more control over prices for their digital books. At first, Amazon responded by removing Macmillan titles, both digital and paper, from its site, except when bought through third-party vendors. Then, Amazon seemed to back down. But the talks are continuing, and Macmillan titles are still mostly absent from the Amazon site. Read the full story here.

title: Oscar Thoughts
description: I remain skeptical of the Academy Awards decision to expand the Best Picture pool to 10, but this years list makes the decision look like a qualified success. Without the expansion, its probably safe to assume that the roster of nominees would have consisted of Avatar, Up in the Air, Inglourious Basterds, The Hurt Locker and Precious. That means the additions are An Education, District 9, Up, A Serious Man, and The Blind Side. The first four are solid or even inspired choices, and if  as people seem to think  the alternative to The Blind Side was Invictus, then Im glad the Academy went with Sandra Bullocks hit instead.

title: Volcker Takes Tough Line on Trading by Banks
description: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, pushed his plan on Tuesday afternoon to tighten the investment activities of large banks in order to avoid future bailouts, telling the Senate Banking Committee that there was no rationale for public funds  taxpayer funds  protecting and supporting essentially proprietary and speculative activities.

title: Senators Warned of Terror Attack on U.S. by July
description: WASHINGTON  Americas top intelligence official told lawmakers on Tuesday that Al Qaeda and its affiliates had made it a high priority to attempt a large-scale attack on American soil within the next six months.

title: Why a Duck? Because He Escaped
description: Leslie Day, author of Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City and resident of a houseboat docked at the 79th Street Boat Basin, had a rather distinguished guest Saturday morning: a mandarin duck, Aix galericulata, paddling with the usual gang of mallards outside her boat. I have no idea where he came from or where he was going, but what a gift on a freezing NYC morning, Ms. Day wrote.

title: Skiers Raise $90,000 for Haiti in Online Auction
description: World Cup Alpine skiers have raised more than $90,000 for Haitian earthquake relief with an online auction of autographed race bibs from the most storied races on the World Cup circuit, the United States Ski Team announced Tuesday.

title: Can White Roofs Battle Global Warming?
description: A forthcoming study in Geophysical Research Letters reinforces the idea that painting urban rooftops white  a tactic that would reflect sunlight  could have a cooling effect on the planet.

title: The Joy of the First-Timers
description: While the Bagger blogs away in Los Angeles, the Baguette has been working the phones in New York. Here are how some of todays best actresses, all first-time nominees, reacted when they heard the Oscar news:

title: (Climate) Information Wants to Be Free
description: in 1984, when Stewart Brand mused at the first Hackers Conference on how information wants to be both expensive and free, he was talking about monetary value.

title: Taps
description: The Marines of Bravo Company left their patrol bases early Saturday morning. To their west were the Taliban pickets who defend the outer limits of Marja, an insurgent enclave in Helmand Province. The Marines turned in the opposite direction, heading to Forward Operating Base Spin Ghar, their company command post.

title: Avatar and Hurt Locker Lead Oscar Field
description: LOS ANGELES Avatar and The Hurt Locker took narrow leads in the Oscar race on Tuesday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences scattered its honors among an unusually wide field of contenders. Each film received nine nominations, including best picture and best director for James Cameron (Avatar) and Kathryn Bigelow (Hurt Locker).

title: We the People: Considering Howard Zinns Approach to History
description: Overview | What was Howard Zinns approach to history, and what values are inherent in it? What issues does his work raise about the purpose and significance of studying history? What are the benefits and drawbacks of his method? In this lesson, students examine Mr. Zinns work by comparing his writing with a typical American history textbook. They then write a reflection or select a document from American history to perform.

title: Grass Fed | The Peel Sessions
description: Grass Fed features the culinary ramblings of the food writer Peter Meehan, the co-author of the Momofuku cookbook with David Chang and an all-around good eater.

title: Biden Endorses Avatar
description: Today was a big day for Avatar  not only was it nominated for nine Academy Awards including best picture, but as Anna Holmes noted at Jezebel.com, it also got an all-important thumbs-up from Vice President Joeseph R. Biden Jr. during an interview Tuesday with Andrea Mitchell on MSNBC.

title: Proposals to Reduce Mortgage Principal
description: The Treasury Department announced Friday that it was simplifying the paperwork required to apply for its Making Home Affordable loan modification program in hopes of increasing the number of successful and permanent modifications.

title: Nokia Gets Its Manos
description: Mike Manos comes as close as you can get to a data-center celebrity. And he has just taken a job at Nokia.

title: Islanders to Hold Part of Training Camp in China
description: The Islanders will spend nine days in China next September as part of their training camp, the teams owner, Charles Wang, confirmed Monday in an interview.

title: War, Peace and Oscars
description: Apocryphal history and bombastic entertainment are strange bedfellows, as Quentin Tarantino showed in Inglourious Basterds, but not as strange, perhaps, as the twin interests of Lawrence Bender, a producer of that movie. Mr. Bender was in Paris at a nuclear disarmament conference when he heard the news that Basterds had nabbed eight Oscar nominations, via a phone call from his mom.

title: Welcome to Your Condo. Please Dont Stay.
description: The condo in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., has three bedrooms, three bathrooms and sweeping ocean views. It can be yours for just under $2.6 million.

title: Sanchez to Have Surgery on Knee
description: Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez will undergo surgery on his left knee sometime in the next few weeks, the team said on Tuesday. He is expected to miss some off-season workouts but be ready for training camp in July.

title: Blair Called a Liar in Iraq Inquiry
description: LONDON  Only days after Tony Blair offered an impassioned defense of his decision to take Britain to war in Iraq, a cabinet minister who resigned over the war delivered a blistering condemnation of the former prime minister on Tuesday, accusing him of conning her and of deceiving his cabinet, the Parliament and the public in his resolve to have Britain join the United States in the invasion of 2003.

title: Looking for a Job? Watch This TV Show
description: Maybe you should think twice about watching the season premiere of Lost on Tuesday night. If youre unemployed, or looking for a better job, you should consider watching a new series starting at 9 p.m. called Job Hunt, on Channel 25.

title: Underused Therapy for the Heart: The Gym
description: She shows up promptly at 8:30 each Monday, Wednesday and Friday morning with a smile and a hello for everyone. She walks on the treadmill first, then climbs onto the seated elliptical trainer, followed by stints on the rowing machine, a stationary bike, a Stairmaster  seven machines in all, five minutes apiece. She checks her pulse to be sure it stays in the target range of 80 to 95 beats per minute.

title: U.S. Drones Said to Strike Along Border in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In another exceptionally heavy barrage, eight American drones fired at least 17 missiles at suspected militants along the border with Afghanistan on Tuesday, Pakistani security officials and residents said.

title: A Bus Tour of Gay Hollywood
description: Sure, everyone knows that West Hollywood is a gay-friendly neighborhood, with rainbow flags flying from restaurants and bars. But did you also know that the phrase lipstick lesbian originated at Peanuts, a femme bar on Santa Monica Boulevard? Or that there was a riot against police brutality in Silverlake on New Years Eve 1966, years before Stonewall?

title: Frank Wants Banks to Disclose All Top Paychecks
description: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, the Democratic chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, contends that regulators should force companies to disclose the compensation for their best-paid employees, potentially forcing Wall Street to reveal how much top traders and money managers earn.

title: The Only Prepared Statement We Will Run*
description: Were all tremendously thrilled to get this nomination, writes Armando Iannucci, the writer and director of the satire In the Loop, a nominee for best adapted screenplay. In The Loop was just a simple little film about how Tony Blairs an idiot, so its nice to see Tony Blairs idiocy get such international recognition.

title: Madoff-Related Fraud Complaint Is Dismissed
description: In an opinion released on Tuesday, a federal judge in Manhattan dismissed all of the Securities and Exchange Commissions civil fraud complaints against Cohmad Securities, a small brokerage firm that the S.E.C. said had played a role in Bernard L. Madoffs long-running Ponzi scheme.

title: What You Get for ... $1 Million
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA.

title: Properties for $1 Million
description: Homes in Charlottesville, Va.,Sarasota, Fla., and Los Angeles.

title: Fashion I.Q. | Twitter Quiz
description: Calling all fashion know-it-alls. Starting tomorrow, The Moment gives you a chance to flaunt your fashion I.Q., when we post a daily multiple choice quiz on our Twitter account. Answers will be posted at the end of each day and, for non-Tweeters we will also run highlights here on The Moment. Time to start cramming.

title: Surprising Strength in Long Islands Warehouse Market
description: RONKONKOMA, N.Y.  Landlords dont typically expect to set leasing records in a severe economic downturn, but the Long Island industrial real estate market is proving to be a welcome anomaly.

title: 'Daphnis et Chlo,' Suite No. 2
description: An excerpt from a performance of the work by Ravel, with James Levine conducting the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

title: After Massacre, Guinea Sees Hope of Lifted Chains
description: CONAKRY, Guinea  Something rare has happened in a region often given to brutal autocracy: power has been peacefully transferred to a civilian, just four months after an army massacre that recalled the worst of Africas past.

title: A Maestros Reunion, Ripe With Ravel
description: New Yorkers are spoiled by manifold opportunities to hear James Levine in action. Though sidelined by health issues sporadically during this season in particular, Mr. Levine has somehow managed to seem ubiquitous. We saw him twice at Carnegie Hall in December, with the Met Chamber Ensemble and the Met Orchestra, and again with the orchestra a little more than a week ago. He has also been leading performances of Simon Boccanegra at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Obamas Budget Includes Cobra Extension
description: The new year may not bring an end to unemployment woes, but many workers who get laid off in 2010 will receive a helping hand with paying for health insurance, if a little-noticed proposal in President Obamas budget for the fiscal year 2011 is adopted.

title: Rolling Out the Yoga Mat
description: LIKE Wi-Fi, on-demand movies and fitness centers, yoga is becoming an amenity many hotels and resorts just cant do without.

title: Lawyer for Steven Tyler Warns Aerosmith
description: When he announced in December that he was entering rehab, the Aerosmith front man Steven Tyler said he was eager to be back with his band mates as soon as possible. Perhaps to illustrate that point, his lawyer has sent a cease-and-desist letter to the bands management, saying its efforts to seek a replacement singer could destroy the group, Billboard reported. In a letter to the bands manager, Howard Kaufman, Mr. Tylers lawyer, Skip Miller, wrote that the attempt was playing band members off against one another and engaging in acts and conduct to the harm and detriment of the singer and the band. Aerosmith without Steven Tyler is like the Rolling Stones without Mick Jagger, or U2 without Bono, Mr. Miller wrote. While this management strategy may get the band on the road a few months sooner, it ultimately could destroy Aerosmith. Aerosmith played its last show on Nov. 1 in Abu Dhabi, where Mr. Tyler, 61, fell from a stage. The bands guitarist Joe Perry said in November that Mr. Tyler had quit the band, only to reunite with him at a concert in New York a few days later. In December Mr. Tyler entered a rehabilitation center to treat an addiction to prescription painkillers.

title: Reid Sees His Shadow; Its McConnell
description: With Senate Republicans this week looking to welcome Senator-elect Scott Brown and to emerge from the deep-freeze of their 40-vote, filibuster-short minority, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada could not miss the opportunity to enlist a groundhog in the political ground-game.

title: Stay at Mailers House! (if Youre BRITISH.).
description: If youre going to spend several weeks crashing at Norman Mailers place, its probably for the best that the master of the house is no longer around. The British edition of GQ magazine is offering young writers an opportunity to stay for a month at the former home in Provincetown, Mass., of the sometimes disheveled if singularly productive author. Mailer, above, lived in the house from the 1990s until his death in 2007, and it has since been turned into a writers retreat. The Guardian reported that Dylan Jones, the magazines editor, announced on Tuesday the start of an annual nonfiction writing competition, open to undergraduates and postgraduates at British universities who are over the age of 18. The contest will be judged by a panel that includes GQ editors and the pop singer Lily Allen; its winner may be published in GQ, and will receive a prize of about $1,600 and a July stay at the Norman Mailer Writers Colony, which, since 2009, has offered activities like writing workshops and seminars.

title: Paul Taylor Troupe Downsizes by One
description: On the eve of moving into its new home, officials of the Paul Taylor Dance Company said on Tuesday that it had eliminated an executive position to save money and expected to finish with a balanced budget this season, as it celebrates Mr. Taylors 80th birthday. According to John Tomlinson, the companys former general manager, Martin I. Kagan, the executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Foundation, which runs the company, resigned on Friday. He was replaced by Mr. Tomlinson, who has been given the title of managing director of the foundation. Mr. Tomlinson said that construction work was complete on the companys new studios and offices on the Lower East Side and that it was waiting for permits to move in. He said he hoped that would happen before the start of the companys season at City Center on Feb. 24. The company lost the lease on its old home in SoHo in late 2008.

title: One More Time, We Are the World
description: There comes a time when musicians heed a certain call and come together as one, and that time arrived on Monday night as more than 70 performers joined up, above, to record a new version of We Are the World to benefit Haitian earthquake relief organizations, Reuters reported. The all-star session took place in the same Hollywood studio where in 1985 the original song  written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and produced by Quincy Jones to raise money for African famine victims  was recorded, and this time was overseen by Mr. Richie and Mr. Jones. Among the artists on the new single are Barbra Streisand, Celine Dion, Tony Bennett, Snoop Dogg, Lil Wayne, Drake, LL Cool J, and will.i.am of the Black Eyed Peas, as well as Justin Bieber, who sings the opening line, and Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-American performer who has largely been the celebrity face of the earthquake relief effort. None of the performers on the original We Are the World recording are involved in the new single, nor was Lady Gaga, who was widely believed to be on the producers wish list. Randy Phillips, the AEG Live executive, told Reuters that a video for the song would have its debut on Feb. 12 during the Winter Olympics and that proceeds would go to a newly established charity.

title: CBS Says Grammys Rap Didnt Meet Standards
description: No details yet from the Recording Academy about what led to the, shall we say, aggressively dissonant duet between Taylor Swift and Stevie Nicks during the Grammy Awards on Sunday night. But CBS, which televised the awards ceremony, provided a brief explanation of why it censored a rap performance that featured, above from left, Drake, Eminem and Lil Wayne. The audio from the performance, which combined the rap songs Forever and Drop the World, was frequently cut from the live telecast, leading many viewers to wonder if their television sets werent working. In an interview with The Associated Press, Chris Ender, a spokesman for CBS, said: It was a rousing musical performance, but words were edited from the live telecast that didnt meet our broadcast standards. We have great respect for artists creative freedom, but there are certain things you cant say, or sing, on television.

title: CBS Wins Over Fox
description: CBS earned a narrow ratings victory on Monday as its comedies Two and a Half Men and The Big Bang Theory drew the largest audiences in prime time, 16.5 million and 15.4 million viewers, respectively, according to Nielsens estimates. In addition to CBSs sitcoms leading the 9 p.m. hour, the network won the 10 p.m. time slot with CSI: Miami (13.3 million), but lagged behind at 8 and 8:30 with How I Met Your Mother (9.4 million) and Accidentally on Purpose (8.5 million). Fox ranked a close runner-up on the night, earning 13.4 million at 8 for House and 9.8 million at 9 for 24. ABC finished not far behind Fox in third with The Bachelor from 8 to 10, which delivered a season high 11.7 million viewers, followed by a rerun of Castle (8 million). In fourth place, NBC struggled as Chuck attracted the networks best ratings of the night (6.8 million). NBCs Heroes drew 4.4 million at 9, while The Jay Leno Show garnered 3.9 million viewers at 10.

title: An Ensemble of Their Own, Beyond the Great White Way
description: Concept counts for a lot these days, and Joshua Rosenblum, a composer, conductor and pianist, has an interesting one. Having spent much of his career conducting Broadway and Off Broadway shows, Mr. Rosenblum knew that some of the pit musicians he worked with were first-rate performers with an interest in new music. He gathered 10 of them  a string quartet, with clarinet, trumpet, horn, piano, bass and percussion  named them the Pit Stop Players and led them in a debut concert at the Thalia Theater at Symphony Space on Monday evening.

title: Ford and Gillibrand in Dueling TV Appearances
description: She talked about Britains experience with gay soldiers in the military. He talked about how cute Matt Lauer looked in a photo.

title: Coupons Ease Chaos in Efforts to Feed Haitians
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Four days into a new food distribution program from the United Nations that aims to repair a faltering aid effort, paper coupons that can be redeemed for 55 pounds of rice have become more valuable than Haitian money.

title: Stewart to Appear on OReilly Factor
description: Fake news meets Bill OReilly this week, when Jon Stewart, the host of The Daily Show, appears on The OReilly Factor on the Fox News Channel.

title: Silicon Valleys High-Tech Jobs and Wages Decline
description: For the Silicon Valley workforce, the 2000s was a decade book-ended and reshaped by the twin shocks of the Dot-Com Bust and the Great Recession. Thousands of manufacturing jobs were irreversibly shed and real wages steadily declined.

title: House Hunting in ... Amsterdam
description: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-BATH LOFT APARTMENT IN CENTRAL AMSTERDAM

title: A View of a Canal
description: A two-bedroom two-bath loft apartment in Central Amsterdam is on the market for 995,000 euros (about $1.4 million).

title: A.I.G. Taps Lehman Alumnus for Its Top Lawyer
description: The American International Group, which was saved from collapse by a $180 billion government bailout, said Tuesday that it had named a former top lawyer from Lehman Brothers as its general counsel.

title: Eavesdropping on the Harpers Shake-Up
description: Last week was a tumultuous one at Harpers Magazine. On Monday morning, as the editor, Roger Hodge, finished a croissant, he was fired by the publisher, John R. MacArthur. On Tuesday, Mr. MacArthur, who goes by Rick,  told Media Decoder that Mr. Hodge had chosen to resign: Its his choice, and its personal, he said. By that afternoon, Mr. MacArthur acknowledged he misspoke, after Harpers editors said that was untrue.

title: A Womans Undying Gift to Science
description: The best book blurb Im aware of came from Roy Blount Jr., who said about Pete Dexters 1988 novel, Paris Trout: I put it down once to wipe off the sweat. Im not sure I know what that means. Was the sweat on Mr. Blounts forehead? On the dust jacket? On the inside of his fogged-up reading glasses? But I like it.

title: Credit Haggling, Oscar-Style
description: When The Hurt Locker was nominated as one of the 10 best movies on Tuesday morning, there were no names attached to receive the kudos officially. Greg Shapiro, one of four producers of the film, told the Bagger that his team was appealing the Academys rule that only three people may take proper credit. The other producers are Kathryn Bigelow, the director and a nominee; Mark Boal, the screenwriter and a nominee; and Nicolas Chartier, the financier.

title: Mens Fashion | The Joy of Sets
description: Mens designers in Europe went all out when it came to staging their fall 2010 runway shows. Why settle for the ordinary when you can have flames, boxing matches, film screenings and makeup worthy of the Rocky Horror Picture Show? From Milan and Paris, here are the sets that will have you singing Lets do the time warp again!

title: Dot-Com Crash Catches Up With Venture Capitalists
description: Silicon Valleys venture capitalists and their investors are finally feeling the full effect of the dot-com crash a decade ago, thanks to the industrys long-term approach to tracking returns.

title: M.T.A. Fails to Honestly Rate Contractors Work, Report Says
description: Outside contractors working on the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys biggest projects are routinely given positive evaluations despite mediocre work, in part to preserve business relationships, an investigation by the authoritys inspector general has found.

title: Alice Is Everywhere, Including a Brooklyn Church
description: Clearly, Alices Adventures in Wonderland is having a moment: in December Syfy broadcast the mini-series Alice, a reworking of Lewis Carrolls classic; Tim Burtons cinematic take arrives in March; and in Midtown Manhattan, Firecat Productions is offering an adult twist. In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the Irondale Ensemble Project is presenting alice ... Alice ... ALICE!, a modest production capitalizing on the troupes home, a former Sunday school space in the magnificent Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Shopify, a Start-Up, Starts Its Own Business Competition
description: It is routine, of course, for start-ups to participate in business plan competitions and related events. It is virtually unheard of, however, that a start-up would hold its own competition to foster start-ups  especially one offering a first-place prize of $100,000. But that is precisely what a start-up called Shopify is doing.

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
description: Prologue: The Woman in the Photograph

title: Judge Dismisses S.E.C. Fraud Case Tied to Madoff
description: In an opinion released on Tuesday, a federal judge in Manhattan dismissed all of the Securities and Exchange Commissions civil fraud complaints against Cohmad Securities, a small brokerage firm that the S.E.C. said had played a role in Bernard L. Madoffs long-running Ponzi scheme.

title: An Israeli Tale of Communal Mistrust, Without the Finger-Pointing
description: The Israeli movie Ajami, one of the five Oscar nominees for best foreign-language film, takes its name from a rough neighborhood in Jaffa, a mostly Arab city just south of Tel Aviv. This particular urban conflict zone may be unfamiliar to most American viewers, but it bears a definite kinship to mean streets we know very well, at least from movies and television. Crime is endemic, bonds of family and friendship can be both sustaining and fatal, and the urge to escape is no match for the gravitational pull of the place itself.

title: Spyker Reveals Plan for Saab
description: Spyker Cars released a statement on Tuesday to offer details before its planned shareholders meeting on Feb. 12.

title: Why Not Prairie Dog Day, Activists Ask
description: This Groundhog Day, Punxsutawney Phil has a little furry competition.

title: X Initiative Goes Out With a B.Y.O.A. (Art, That Is)
description: After almost a year of exhibitions, performances, panels and screenings, the X Initiative, a nonprofit art consortium that took over the old Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, will cease and desist on Friday, as planned. But it is going out with a bang and, in contrast to its rather austere exhibition program, with a stark lack of curatorial oversight. The farewell event is a 24-hour marathon titled Bring Your Own Art (BYOA) that starts Wednesday at 11 a.m. and ends 24 hours later, at 11 a.m. on Thursday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Feb. 2
description: The five American Muslim men who were arrested last month in Pakistan on suspicion of plotting terrorist acts shouted to reporters that they were being tortured. Slide 10 is by Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press, whose work was briefly profiled on Jan. 29.

title: Spreadsheets Are Us
description: Another film that could benefit from the buzz of its Oscar nomination is The Cove, about a secret dolphin slaughter in Japan. The documentary has struggled with a reputation that its subject matter is difficult to stomach, which its makers refute.

title: Defying the Groundhog
description: So Chuck the groundhog made it through his paces Tuesday morning at the Staten Island Zoo without incident. Unlike last year, he did not bite the mayor.

title: Rex Ryan Is Fined for Obscene Gesture
description: Coach Rex Ryan was fined $50,000 by the Jets on Tuesday for making an obscene gesture at a fan or fans Saturday. Ryan was attending a mixed martial arts event (above) in Sunrise, Fla., in which he bantered with the crowd (as only he can). The N.F.L. may also fine Ryan.Update | Wednesday, 12:40 p.m.  The N.F.L. decided not to further fine Ryan.

title: Streetcar to Take a New Route
description: The theater producer who holds the rights to mount A Streetcar Named Desire on Broadway has decided not to try to transfer the Sydney Theater Company production starring Cate Blanchett, which was a critical and audience favorite in late 2009 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: MetLife Confirms Talks Over A.I.G. Unit
description: MetLife on Tuesday confirmed that it was in talks with the American International Group to buy a major life insurance unit, commonly known as Alico.

title: Obamas Remarks on His Small-Business Plan
description: Following is a transcript of President Obama's speech and question-answer session in Nashua, N.H., on his plan to revitalize small businesses, as released by the White House:

title: Broadway Traffic Redo Yields Mixed Results, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged on Tuesday that the citys ambitious re-engineering of the Midtown street grid had a mixed impact on traffic in the area, although he seemed to express general support for the pilot project, which barred automobile traffic along two sections of Broadway.

title: Morgan Stanley Evaluates Hedge Fund Holdings
description: Morgan Stanley is evaluating its investments in hedge funds including FrontPoint Partners and Lansdowne Partners of London, its chief executive, James P. Gorman, said Tuesday.

title: Rabbit Hole Redux in Wonderland
description: The guy who plays the Gryphon (Geoffrey Parrish) is good. Jeri Batzdorffs costumes are inventive, especially the Queen of Heartss roses-and-gewgaws headwear. The little guinea-pig puppets (operated by Stephanie Bashall) are cute for about five seconds. Otherwise, the musical Alice in Wonderland Thru the Looking Glass, at the Actors Temple Theater, is likely to leave you colder than the winter of 2010.

title: Australias Drug Wars, Seething and Savage
description: For the last two years the satellite carrier DirecTV has been giving its in-house 101 Network a PG-13, 10 p.m.-drama feel: Friday Night Lights, Wonderland and The Nine, serious shows shared with or scavenged from the broadcast networks, have all joined the lineup.

title: Trailer: Mass Effect 2
description: The "role-playing shooter," a sequel to the original from 2007, was developed by BioWare for Electronic Arts.

title: New Play Puts an Old Face on Race
description: The first image in the new play Neighbors, which opens at the Public Theater on Feb. 16, is a family of five hooting, hollering, joking as they carry boxes into their new home, according to the stage directions. What makes this unlike a usual move-in day is that the family, the Crows, is made up of black actors in blackface.

title: Slimmer Doesnt Always Mean Fitter
description: IN his new book, Racing Weight: How to Get Lean for Peak Performance, Matt Fitzgerald, a sports nutritionist, writes about an amazing running experience. He worked out on a special sort of anti-gravity treadmill, the AlterG, which uses a cushion of air to lift the body, allowing you to effectively decrease your body weight as you run.

title: Dragging Out a Galaxy Rescue
description: The original Mass Effect was my favorite game of 2007. At the time, back at the dawn of the high-definition gaming era, Mass Effect was a revelation in its embrace of more powerful technology not only in the service of bigger and badder explosions but also in the service of portraying some of the most natural, realistic characters and stories yet seen in interactive entertainment.

title: Reuters Retracts Taxes to Hit Middle Class Article
description: Some mistakes are about small matters and go unnoticed. Unfortunately for Reuters, reporting on the White House is not one of those things.

title: Fearless
description: Among biologists, the Galpagos Islands  an archipelago of volcanic islands that straddle the equator about 600 miles from the coast of mainland Ecuador  are legendary. For when the young Charles Darwin sailed around the world in the 1830s, he visited these islands, and was struck by five things.

title: Religion and Private Passion Fight Their Good Fight
description: The tug of war between the spirit and the flesh is as old as religion and has inspired countless plays, novels, operas, ballets and paintings. Few have examined the conflict as exhaustingly as Paul Claudels Satin Slipper, a theological debate of a play that is being given a fervent if ultimately tedious revival by the Blackfriars Repertory and Storm Theater at the Church of Notre Dame in Morningside Heights.

title: Bankruptcy Complicates Deal for Roosevelt Papers
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama signed a law on Monday to clear the way for the largest privately held archive of papers relating to President Franklin D. Roosevelt to be donated to Roosevelts presidential library, it was to be the culmination of a five-year effort to finally make the documents available to the public.

title: Virginia Closer to Banning Insurance Requirement
description: As if the message from Massachusetts were not clear enough, the Virginia state Senate passed a measure on Monday  with Democratic help  that would attempt to block any effort to make health insurance mandatory for citizens, a centerpiece of the Democratic overhaul now stalled on Capitol Hill.

title: G.O.P. Links Jobs Plan to Tax Increase on the Wealthy
description: By mid-afternoon, Republicans seemed to have settled on their talking point in opposition to President Obamas jobs plan, including the $30 billion loan package formally announced today. The new watchword: uncertainty.

title: Crumbling Movie Palace Finds an Angel
description: The building bears little resemblance to the extravagantly sumptuous wonder theater that wowed audiences in 1929.

title: If Meals Won Medals
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

title: Take That, You Jackanapes
description: A lot of business journalism is, well, polite. I think it should be. Still, it can be fun to watch a master of impoliteness go after his opponents.

title: For the Big Game? Why, Pigskins
description: BEFORE we return to the regularly scheduled cooking portion of our program, it is important to note that pigskins were never used to make American footballs.

title: Dodd Calls Obama Plan Too Grand
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee warned on Tuesday that the Obama administrations new proposals to rein in Wall Street firms ran the risk of derailing months of delicate negotiations over overhauling financial regulations.

title: PNC to Repay TARP Money After Sale of Unit
description: The PNC Financial Services Group, one of the largest regional banks, said late Tuesday that it would pay back $7.6 billion in government bailout money to the Treasury Department.

title: Helping Small Businesses Help Themselves
description: President Obama promoted his plan on Tuesday to increase lending to small businesses. The proposal would create a fund that provides capital to smaller community banks in hopes of making it easier for them to lend to small businesses.

title: Google Adds Multi-Touch Features to Nexus One Phone
description: On Tuesday, some Nexus One owners began receiving updates to their smartphones that will enable multi-touch for some applications, fix 3G problems and otherwise tweak the software on the Google devices.

title: Sharp Drop Is Seen in Gifts to Colleges and Universities
description: Gifts to colleges and universities declined almost 12 percent in the 2009 fiscal year, to $27.85 billion, according to the Council for Aid to Educations annual survey of voluntary support of education. It was the steepest decline in the surveys 53-year history.

title: App of the Week: Free Calls, if You Dont Mind Ads
description: We have all long known how to make cheap (or free) VoIP calls from the iPhone, provided you had a Wi-Fi hot spot nearby. And we knew that someday we would be able to make VoIP calls over the 3G network  Apple and AT&T said so.

title: Opening the Door to Gays in the Military
description: Taking a major step toward allowing openly gay men and women to serve in uniform, Defense Secretary Robert Gates and Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on Tuesday that it was time to end the militarys decades-old dont ask, dont tell law. This change, Admiral Mullen said, would be the right thing to do.

title: Senate Jobs Bill to Include Tax Credit
description: In the big jobs legislation that they are developing, Senate Democratic leaders have to decided to include a proposal to waive the 6.2 percent Social Security payroll tax for any private-sector employer that hires a worker who had been unemployed for at least 60 days, Senate aides said.

title: At a Queens Chocolate Factory, Grief After Haitian Earthquake
description: It is a surreal experience these days to visit Madelaine Chocolate Novelties, a huge chocolate factory in the Rockaway section of Queens.

title: When Theater Shocks
description: Neighbors, a new work by the playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, may come as one of the most sustained shocks of this theater season, writes Patrick Healy.

title: Rosensweig Lands at Textbook Renter Chegg.com
description: The veteran Silicon Valley executive Dan Rosensweig is leaving his job as president and chief executive of Activision Blizzards Guitar Hero franchise to take the same title at Chegg.com, a well-financed start-up that is applying the online rental model pioneered by Netflix to college textbooks. Previously, Mr. Rosensweig served as chief operating officer of Yahoo under Terry Semel, then the chief executive.

title: Nani Elevates His Play in Match Shown in 3-D
description: Three goals in three dimensions.

title: Avatar Bolsters News Corp.s Earnings
description: Buoyed by the success of Avatar, the science fiction blockbuster that has become the highest-grossing movie to date, the News Corporation reported a quarterly profit on Tuesday that surpassed the expectations of Wall Street analysts.

title: California Sets Up Statewide Network to Monitor Global-Warming Gases
description: SAN FRANCISCO  California is preparing to introduce the first statewide system of monitoring devices to detect global-warming emissions, installing them on towers throughout the state.

title: Chinas Defiance Stirs Fears for Missing Dissident
description: BEIJING  A year ago this week, Chinese security agents made a midnight visit to the home of Gao Zhisheng, one of Chinas most high-profile human rights lawyers, and led him away. They told his family he was wanted for a brief chat.

title: No Help in Sight, More Homeowners Walk Away
description: In 2006, Benjamin Koellmann bought a condominium in Miami Beach. By his calculation, it will be about the year 2025 before he can sell his modest home for what he paid. Or maybe 2040.

title: Official Says Terrorism Suspect Is Cooperating
description: WASHINGTON  Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the Nigerian man accused of trying to blow up a jetliner bound for Detroit on Dec. 25, started talking to investigators after two of his family members arrived in the United States and helped earn his cooperation, a senior administration official said Tuesday evening.

title: Straddling Political Fault Lines in the Middle East
description: GHAJAR, Golan Heights  In this far-flung village that straddles a tense international border, location is not just a real estate issue. It determines in which country you reside.

title: $100 Million Bonus Plan at A.I.G. Draws Fire
description: The American International Group has agreed to cut employee bonuses by $20 million and will distribute about $100 million on Wednesday, according to people with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Freeneys Ankle Still Hurts; Other Answers Must Wait
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  An hour before media day festivities began, six television cameras, two dozen reporters and Deion Sanders, a Hall of Fame cornerback turned analyst, gathered at Station 2.

title: The Who, and the Super Bowls Evolving Halftime Show
description: Once upon a time, a Super Bowl halftime show meant Carol Channing, college marching bands, Up With People and salutes to Louis Armstrong. These days, headliners like the Rolling Stones and Paul McCartney happily line up to play a 12-minute set.

title: An Unlikely Super Bowl Celebrity
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Jimmy Lafont was at work Tuesday in the bayou town of Cut Off, La., where he manages a business that operates boats and barges that run up and down the Mississippi, when he looked up and saw himself on television.

title: Inquiry Into F.B.I. Raid That Killed Cleric
description: CHICAGO  The Justice Department has opened an investigation into an F.B.I. raid near Detroit last fall that left a Muslim prayer leader dead with 21 gunshot wounds, officials said Tuesday.

title: Riverton Houses in Harlem to Be Sold in Foreclosure
description: A state judge on Tuesday ordered the foreclosure sale of the storied Riverton Houses, a middle-class Harlem enclave that ran into trouble a year ago when its new owner failed to make good on optimistic revenue projections and defaulted on his mortgage.

title: The Saints Linebacker Who Speaks His Mind
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  New Orleans Saints linebacker Scott Fujita addresses hot-button issues the way he might meet an opposing running back: directly.

title: Racehorse Owner Barred From Competing at Pennsylvania Track
description: Michael Gill, a controversial racehorse owner accused of running infirm horses at Penn National Race Course, has been barred from competing at the track by the Pennsylvania Racing Commission.

title: Jets Fine Ryan $50,000 for Obscene Gesture
description: The Jets fined Coach Rex Ryan $50,000 on Tuesday for the obscene gesture he made last weekend at a mixed martial arts competition in Sunrise, Fla.

title: War: What Is It Good For?
description: Good God yall. Protectionists and pacifists may find each other to be strange bedfellows.

title: A.I.G.s $100 Million Bonus Payout Draws Fire
description: The American International Group has agreed to cut employee bonuses by $20 million and will distribute about $100 million on Wednesday, according to people close to the negotiations. But the reductions may not be enough to appease the companys critics, who do not accept the companys argument that it has to honor contracts signed before its government bailout, The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh and Sewell Chan report.

title: Pigskins in Play
description: A salty, crunchy layer of fried pork skin gives heft and flavor to the Super Bowl party menu.

title: In Helping Haiti, Pierre Garcon Wins Fans in Miami
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  At Pierre Garcons feet Tuesday sat a cooler containing six bottles of Gatorade, an N.F.L. sponsor. Arranged on the round table in front of him was a Gatorade tea towel, another bottle of Gatorade and the official Reebok Super Bowl XLIV baseball cap, its bill pointing toward the cameras so the game logo was in clear view.

title: The Internet vs. Obama
description: Could we give Barack Obama a break?

title: Senate Race in New York Is a Tug of War Over Donors
description: Moments after arriving at an Upper West Side duplex for a gathering of Democrats two weeks ago, Orin Kramer, a hedge-fund manager, was surrounded by angry supporters of Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand. One by one, they demanded to know why he was encouraging Harold E. Ford Jr., the former Tennessee congressman, to run for Senate in New York.

title: Israel: Coast Is Searched After Explosives Wash Ashore
description: Security forces searched Israels coastline and closed beaches in the south on Tuesday after two barrels of explosives washed up on the shores of Ashkelon and Ashdod, north of Gaza. A police spokesman said that the explosive devices, discovered Monday, were apparently intended for attacks on ships or beachgoers. In Gaza, a spokesman for the Popular Resistance Committees, a militant group, said that many more such explosives were still in the ocean and that they were intended to avenge the death of Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, a veteran Hamas operative killed last month in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates. Hamas blamed Israel for his death. Israeli security officials said that two devices exploded more than a mile off the Gaza coast on Jan. 29. Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, blamed Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, and said Israel would respond.

title: Gates Tries to Get F-35 Program Back on Course
description: WASHINGTON  The Joint Strike Fighter was supposed to be the program that broke the mold, proof that the Pentagon could build something affordable, dependable and without much drama.

title: For Some Survivors, Polio Wont Fade Into the Past
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The polio virus, and its reign of terror in the American psyche, is faded history now. After a vaccine was introduced in the mid-1950s, millions of people sighed, turned the page and moved on. Many polio victims, often struck in childhood, tried to leave the story behind and forget, too.

title: Journal Retracts 1998 Paper Linking Autism to Vaccines
description: A prominent British medical journal on Tuesday retracted a 1998 research paper that set off a sharp decline in vaccinations in Britain after the papers lead author suggested that vaccines could cause autism.

title: In Super Bowl City, a Hero for Haitians
description: Members of the Little Haiti community near Miami are proud to have Colts receiver Pierre Garcon waving their country's flag.

title: Heel. Sit. Whisper. Good Dog.
description: Nestl barks when Mike Marder and his wife come home, and he barks when they leave. He barks at delivery boys, he barks at the doorbell, and he barks at the Marders new puppy, Truffle.

title: Four Saints From Louisiana Can Finally Dare to Hope
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.

title: In Court, Impassioned Challenges of Madoff Trustees Plans
description: No one would ever mistake the cramped, unadorned Manhattan courtroom of Judge Burton R. Lifland for King Solomons court.

title: Gregg Williams Defends Saints Defensive Approach
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Gregg Williams, the Saints defensive coordinator, clarified the comments he made last week about giving Peyton Manning some hits to remember in Super Bowl XLIV.

title: Bonbons With Truffles, Roses or Fireworks
description: The sleek Park Avenue shop Borne Confections is now importing chocolates by Oriol Balaguer, a chef from Barcelona who worked with Ferran Adri. Mr. Balaguers signature is a chocolate bonbon in the shape of a cacao pod, filled with often exotic ganache flavors.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: With Raw Recruits, Afghan Police Buildup Falters
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The NATO general in charge of training the Afghan police has some tongue-in-cheek career advice for the countrys recruits.

title: Blocks of Pressed Caviar for Building Canaps
description: In the old days, before sturgeon were at so much risk, pressed caviar was for those with czarist tastes but peanut butter budgets. It is an assertive black paste made from damaged sturgeon roe that cannot be sold as fine caviar. Russians love it to smear on bread.

title: A Basketful of Sweetness, Wrapped in Thoughts
description: Making the most of their season, tiny cupids decorate the red wrappers on Good Karmals buttery caramels, which sit in a beribboned basket for Valentines Day. The wrappers bear quotations from authors including Henry Miller, Aesop and Maya Angelou, and even a Zen proverb, Leap and the net will appear.

title: Child Pornography, and an Issue of Restitution
description: When Amy was a little girl, her uncle made her famous in the worst way: as a star in the netherworld of child pornography. Photographs and videos known as the Misty series depicting her abuse have circulated on the Internet for more than 10 years, and often turn up in the collections of those arrested for possession of illegal images.

title: Ask About Canine Devocalization
description: Sharon Vanderlip, a doctor of veterinary medicine, will be responding to readers questions about the process, the ethics, the after-effects and other concerns relating to the debarking procedure. Readers who would like to ask Dr. Vanderlip a question should do so in the comments box below. Her responses will be published on the blog later this week.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Recurring Themes

title: Northern Spy Food Company
description: THE pigs foot at Northern Spy Food Company may be the friendliest in town.

title: Things Get Messy When Bartenders Crack an Egg
description: WHATEVER happened on the evening of Jan. 19 at the Pegu Club, the high-end cocktail hangout in Manhattan, the perpetrator was a specialty of the house: the Earl Grey MarTEAni.

title: McCarron Apologizes for Accusing Mickelson of Cheating
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif.  Scott McCarron stepped in front of the klieg lights and microphones in the late evening light Tuesday and apologized, falling on his sword to silence the lingering echoes from last weeks uproar over his accusation that Phil Mickelson was cheating by using a square-grooved club.

title: Sharing Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency Takes a Fresh Look at Electronics in Toyota Recall
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has begun what it calls a fresh look at electromagnetic interference in modern auto throttle systems as a possible cause of the unintended acceleration problem that promoted the recall of millions of Toyotas.

description: To the Editor:

title: Parental Orders
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  You dont suppose todays constructor has children, do you?

title: Injuries of Man Claiming Police Abuse Are Detailed
description: A doctor who supervised Michael Mineos care at Brookdale University Hospital testified on Tuesday that when Mr. Mineo arrived shortly after his confrontation with the police in a Brooklyn subway station 15 months ago, he had anal skin lacerations, a small amount of anal bleeding and symptoms of an internal inflammation, including a high white blood cell count.

title: Beco
description: 45 Richardson Street (Lorimer Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 599-1645; becobar.com.

title: Russia: No Plans for Moon
description: The Russian space agency has no plans to fly to the Moon and will not be shifting this position now that President Obama has asked NASA to abandon a second American Moon program, the head of the agency suggested in comments to Interfax. The exploration goals of the two space agencies would fully coincide if America drops its Moon program, the director, Anatoly N. Perminov said. Our near-term program has not included any plan for settlement on the moon, he said. We shouldnt rush from side to side. No longer rivals, the two space programs are closely entwined through work on the International Space Station and will become more so when Russian rockets will become, at least for some time, the only means of putting American astronauts into orbit if the space shuttle fleet is retired as expected this year.

title: Russia: Railway Bombed
description: A bomb exploded on the tracks beneath a railroad maintenance engine in St. Petersburg on Tuesday, slightly wounding the vehicles operator, the Prosecutor Generals office said in statement. The blast produced a crater over three feet wide, but caused little other damage, the statement said. Anatoly Kvashnin, the head of the regional investigation unit covering transportation, told the Interfax news agency that the bombing was probably a terrorist attack. In November, a bomb exploded beneath a luxury train traveling between Moscow and St. Petersburg, killing over 25 people. Officials have named no suspects in that attack.

title: At a Neglected Movie Palace, Cobwebs Are Given Notice
description: The building bears little resemblance to the extravagantly sumptuous wonder theater that wowed audiences in 1929.

title: Aretskys Patroon
description: 160 East 46th Street (Lexington Avenue), Midtown; (212) 883-7373, patroonrestaurant.com.

title: Pitt and West Virginia: Two Teams Going in Different Directions
description: No. 22 Pittsburgh (16-5, 6-3 Big East) at No 6 West Virginia (17-3, 6-2)The Panthers are falling; they were 5-0 in the Big East but have lost three of their last four and are struggling to score. They averaged 74 points in their first five games, but that dropped to 62.7 in the past four. Not surprisingly, guard Ashton Gibbs is struggling, too. Gibbs averaged 20 points in the 5-0 start, shooting 51 percent. Hes down to 14 points and 30 percent in the slump. Hes still getting his shots (28 for 55 in the 5-0 start, 16 for 55 in the slump); hes just not making them.

title: A Taste of Shanghai
description: 39-07 Prince Street, 1A (Roosevelt Avenue), Flushing, Queens, (718) 888-1636.

title: Interior Secretary Sees Little Hope for Consensus on Wind Farm
description: ABOARD THE IDA LEWIS  Weighing the future of a controversial wind farm project, Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar toured Nantucket Sound on a Coast Guard cutter Tuesday, surveying the 24-square-mile area where the proposed project would loom.

title: Obama Continues Policy Outreach to Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  Emboldened by the response to President Obamas face-off with House Republicans last week, the White House is intensifying its push to engage Congressional Republicans in policy negotiations as a way to share the burden of governing and put more scrutiny on Republican initiatives.

title: Ethics Lapse? Welcome Aboard!
description: On Monday afternoon, a City Hall political operative by the name of Maura Keaney was given a $143,000 job at the citys Department of Education.

title: Craving Scorer, Rangers Acquire Flames Olli Jokinen
description: Center Olli Jokinen, who was having a subpar season in Calgary and has been traded three times in the past two years, became the latest piece of a Rangers makeover that does not seem to end.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about testimony in the federal corruption trial of Leona Beldini, the former deputy mayor of Jersey City, misspelled the given name of the mayor of Jersey City, who appears in videos that were introduced as evidence. He is Jerramiah T. Healy, not Jeremiah.

title: Victims Roommate Charged With Setting Fire That Killed 5 Guatemalans
description: The fire that killed five Guatemalan immigrants in their home above a restaurant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, was ignited by one of their roommates, who drenched a roll of toilet paper in an accelerant and tossed it into a baby carriage at the bottom of the tenements stairs, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: A Clean Break With Staid Detergent Ads
description: ONE of the biggest  and dullest  categories in consumer marketing is showing signs of life.

title: Paterson Vetoes Ethics Bill, Saying It Isnt Real Reform
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday vetoed the Legislatures attempt to create new ethics panels to monitor elected officials and to require greater financial disclosure by lawmakers, halting for now an overhaul of the rules meant to curb political corruption.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about lingering aviation safety problems a year after the fatal crash of a commuter plane near Buffalo misidentified the airline for which Randy Babbitt, the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, was once a captain. It was Eastern, not Northwest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the absence of the multimedia software Flash in Apples new iPad tablet computer referred incorrectly to the Web language HTML5. While HTML5 can support video, it is not itself a video format. The article also misstated the ownership of HTML5 patents. HTML5, like other versions of Hypertext Markup Language, is open source; it is not owned by a group of companies, including Apple. (Many Web sites that are starting to use HTML5 are using a particular video encoding program called H.264, which has shared patent pool, of which Apple is a part.)

title: Corrections
description: The Popular Demand listing in the Most Wanted chart on Monday about the best-selling books of 2009 misstated the publication date of Where the Wild Things Are by Maurice Sendak. The book was published in 1963, not 1988. (Harper Collins released a 25th anniversary edition in 1988.)

title: Parents Tell of Children They Entrusted to Detained Americans
description: FERMATHE, Haiti  Guerlaine Antoine pushed aside a tub full of laundry, wiped her soapy hands on her T-shirt and rushed barefoot to bring out photos of the 8-year-old boy she entrusted to 10 American Baptists.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the Walt Disney Companys efforts to sell its Miramax film unit reversed the identifications of two films and their leading actresses in some copies. The Queen, with Helen Mirren was at bottom left and Chicago with Rene Zellweger was at bottom right.

title: In Response to Irans Nuclear Program, German Firms Are Slowly Pulling Out
description: BERLIN  German companies, long Irans biggest trading partners in Europe, are finding it increasingly difficult to do business there as the United States, Israel and others campaign for tougher United Nations sanctions in response to the countrys nuclear program.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about the effect on seabird movements when commercial fishermen discard unwanted fish misstated the type of fishery in the study location, off Spains Mediterranean coast. Trawlers in the area obtain hake and other fish that are at or near the bottom, not sardines and squid.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about David Brown, a Hollywood and Broadway producer, gave an erroneous credit for the movie The Player and misstated the year it was made. While Mr. Brown was a producer of The Player, his longtime producing partner Richard D. Zanuck was not. The movie was made in 1992, not 1994.

title: American Idol 9 on 9: The Denver Auditions
description: The last official American Idol audition show of season nine was a warm, wet kiss with an unusually high percentage of treacle. Maybe its the law of averages, but after several straight dud-thick shows this was Idol easing into its comfort zone, nudging viewer support in its preferred directions.

title: Foursquare: Share, and You Can Be the Mayor
description: Waisum Tam has a secret. Though she may look petite, and may glide unnoticed among the many bearded and fashionable patrons of Henry Public, a new cocktail-and-hamburger joint in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Cobble Hill, Ms. Tam, a 34-year-old marketing consultant, has outsize status there. She is the mayor of Henry Public.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 962 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: In Insider Trading Inquiry, Old and New Cases Linked
description: Federal prosecutors unsealed criminal charges on Tuesday against an informant who had secretly recorded conversations with people charged in the insider trading case involving the Galleon Group hedge fund.

title: Palin to Headline Tea Party Rally
description: Sarah Palin will trade the frozen tundra of Alaska next month for the parched terrain of Searchlight, Nev.  and probably not for the ice fishing.

title: No Live TV of a Trial on Marriage, but a Replay
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Considering all the media hoopla surrounding the trial on Proposition 8, Californias voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage, it was bound to get the Hollywood treatment. But this fast?

title: Quick Response to Study of Abstinence Education
description: A study of middle-school students that found for the first time that abstinence-only education helped to delay their sexual initiation is already beginning to shake up the longstanding debate over how best to prevent teenage pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: After Aqueduct Deal, Governor and Pastor Talk Politics
description: ALBANY  Three days after awarding a lucrative state contract to a company connected to the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, one of New Yorks most influential black pastors, Gov. David A. Paterson summoned Mr. Flake to his Harlem office Monday morning and sounded him out about his political support.

title: Appeals Court Throws Out Sentence in Bombing Plot, Calling It Too Light
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday threw out the 22-year prison sentence imposed in 2005 on Ahmed Ressam, known as the Millennium Bomber, who plotted to set off explosives at Los Angeles International Airport on New Years Eve in 1999. The court said the sentence was too light.

title: Equality in the Military
description: History was made on Capitol Hill on Tuesday. More than 16 years after their predecessors helped impose the odious dont ask, dont tell policy, the nations two top defense officials called on Congress to repeal the law that bans gay men and lesbians from serving openly in the military. The principled courage of the defense secretary and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is a major step forward for civil rights.

title: A Trial for City Police
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City and Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly have a right to brag about lower crime rates in the city. But they still have work to do when it comes to the behavior of some police officers.

title: The Royalty Boondoggle
description: In 1995, when oil prices were very low, Congress tried to encourage deep-water drilling in the Gulf of Mexico by giving oil companies relief from some of the royalties they incur for producing oil and gas on public land.

title: Calorie Counters
description: This might come as an unpleasant surprise for the fast-food industry, but when people can read how many calories there are in their fast food, they do cut back. In a study of millions of transactions at several hundred Starbucks outlets, economists from Stanford University found that consumers in New York City responded to required calorie postings by cutting almost 15 calories off their average purchases, a calorie reduction of 6 percent.

title: When Economics Meets Politics
description: Doha, Qatar
