description: Houston

title: U.S. Expands Medical Care for Haitians
description: The United States military airlift of Haitians who were severely injured in the earthquake is expanding this week to deliver patients to hospitals in and around Tampa, Fla., and Atlanta, federal health officials said Tuesday.

title: Phys Ed: How to Overcome Fear on the Slopes
description: Peter Olenick, a 25-year-old freestyle skier and gold medalist in the Big Air skiing competition at last weekends 2010 Winter X Games, vividly recalls the first time he tried the Whiskey Flip, his self-invented marquee trick, a twisty, somersaulting double flip executed 20 feet or so above the halfpipes lip. It was terrifying, he says. I didnt even know if it could be done. But Id been doing it over and over in my head, so I figured I could make it go right. Some deep breaths, some mental finger-crossing and I just kind of hucked it, he says, landing cleanly, exhilarated. A second attempt was even scarier. Now my body knew what was happening. But I did it. Fear kind of keeps all of us going.

title: Showcase: Out of Line
description: On the right-angled grid of New York City streets, curves can be downright subversive.

title: In Texas, Resistance Over Stricter U.S. Smog Limits
description: HOUSTON  Environmentalists squared off against business groups and Texas state officials on Thursday at a hearing on the Obama administrations proposal to tighten standards for smog-producing pollutants, a change that could improve the health of millions but would impose burdensome costs on industry and local governments.

title: A Winning Deal for PNC Investors
description: Bank of New York Mellon, the giant trust bank, is growing but at a price. The bank agreed Tuesday to buy the back-office operations of PNC Financial Services for $2.3 billion. That works out to 23 times annualized fourth-quarter 2009 earnings of the unit. That is a heady multiple for only a marginal increase in market share.

title: 5.7 Million Get Weekly Food Assistance
description: The number of Americans getting help from soup kitchens, shelters and food pantries each week rose 27 percent in the past four years, to 5.7 million, according to a survey by Feeding America, an association of food banks. About 37 million Americans, one in eight, got assistance over the course of a year, an increase of 46 percent.

title: California: Suit Over Day-Laborer Law
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California and other civil rights organizations sued Costa Mesa in federal court, saying a city ordinance unconstitutionally prevents day laborers from soliciting work. City leaders in Costa Mesa, a Los Angeles suburb, have increasingly taken a hard line on dozens of immigrants, mostly from Latin America, who stand on streets soliciting work. Mayor Allan Mansoor has said the ordinance helps keep streets safe and appeases residents who complained about immigrants loitering in neighborhoods, sometimes littering and urinating in public.

title: Word of the Day | retrench
description: retrench \ri-trench\ verb

title: Theater of War
description: For a long time it seemed like films made about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan just weren't clicking with critics or audiences. But with "The Hurt Locker" tied at the top of the pack of Oscar nominations with "Avatar" and a win at Sundance for the Afghanistan documentary "Restrepo," movies are finally catching up to the stage, which has fared better in tackling the past eight years of conflict. There was "Stuff Happens," "Black Watch" and now "Time Stands Still," which stars Laura Linney as a photojournalist recuperating from severe injuries suffered while she was covering the war in Iraq and Brian d'Arcy James as her partner who suffered a breakdown there. The "thoughtful drama by Donald Margulies," writes Charles Isherwood, which also stars Alicia Silverstone and Eric Bogosian, "explores the relationship between two couples at a crucial juncture in their lives, when the desire to move forward clashes with the instinct to stay comfortably  or even uncomfortably  in place." The "flawless Manhattan Theater Club production" is directed by Daniel Sullivan, "with the leads giving performances of "complementary sensitivity and richness."

title: See a Nominee
description: In keeping with the golden statue theme, "Ajami," an Israeli film, one of five Oscar nominees for best foreign-language film, opens today in New York. The movie, takes its name from a rough neighborhood in Jaffa, a mostly Arab city just south of Tel Aviv. "This particular urban conflict zone may be unfamiliar to most American viewers, but it bears a definite kinship to mean streets we know very well, at least from movies and television," writes A.O. Scott. "We could almost be in the Los Angeles of 'Colors' or 'Boyz N the Hood,' the Baltimore of 'The Wire' or the Rio de Janeiro of 'City of God.' " The movie, written and directed by Scandar Copti, an Israeli Arab, and Yaron Shani, who is Jewish, "is acutely insightful about the social divisions within Israel, but it examines them without scolding or sentimentality. There is no finger-pointing here, and no group hugging either. Instead there is an acute sense of just how deep and wide the schisms are, not just between Jews and Arabs, but also between Christians and Muslims, rich and poor, farmers and city dwellers, men and women, young and old and so on."

title: Down-Home Cooking
description: The menu at Northern Spy Food Company "reads like a roster of favorite snacks and midnight feasts, albeit executed with a precision honed in high-end kitchens," writes Ligaya Mishan. The East Village restaurant, which opened in November, is run by the chef Nathan Foot, who "has done time in fine dining, but seems to have a soft spot for down-home cooking." Look for comfy dishes like pickled eggs and corned beef hash. Polenta "engorged with crme frache substitutes for grits, its country cousin, as a bed for baked eggs. It's a voluptuary's dish." There is also exotic risotto, sandwiches stuffed with salty country ham and a kale salad with cubes of roasted squash for all the non-meat eaters. "The dining room is charming, referencing a country store without the glaze of irony."

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Monday about the Haitian earthquake misspelled the name of a Haitian-American consultant. He is Jocelyn McCalla, not McCallan.

title: Aaron Ruben, TV Producer, Dies at 95
description: Aaron Ruben, who was a producer, writer and director for some of the most popular television comedies of the 1960s and 70s, notably The Andy Griffith Show, Gomer Pyle, U.S.M.C. and Sanford and Son, died Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 95.

title: James H. Quello, Ex-Member of F.C.C., Dies at 95
description: James H. Quello, who as a generally pro-business member of the Federal Communications Commission from the 1970s to the 1990s helped propel the drive to deregulate broadcasting, died on Jan. 24 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 95.

title: Pakistan: Note From 5 American Muslims in Custody Claims Torture
description: Five American Muslims in custody in Sargodha threw a handwritten note to reporters from a police vehicle while on their way to a court hearing on Tuesday, stating: Since our arrest, the U.S.A., F.B.I., and Pakistani police have tortured us, according to their representative, Khalid Khawaja. A Pakistani relative of one of the men also claimed that the police had threatened to give them electric shocks. A spokesman for the American Embassy in Islamabad, Richard W. Snelsire, said that the United States categorically rejects those allegations. Mr. Khawaja, whose organization provided the young mens lawyer, said a bail hearing would be held Feb. 8. The authorities have not yet brought charges against the men.

title: New Olympus PEN E-PL1 Is Aimed at Everyday Users
description: Olympus has announced a new version of its slick-looking PEN Micro Four Thirds camera that targets everyday users with intuitive features and a lower price. The new PEN E-PL1, priced at $600, will include a built-in flash, faster autofocus and graphical interface that will enable casual snap-shooters to easily achieve more sophisticated results.

title: 2 Decisions Reshape Inquiries Into Madoff Case
description: Authorities on both sides of the Atlantic have made decisions that shape the investigations into Bernard L. Madoffs long-running Ponzi scheme.

title: News Quiz | February 3, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Hershey Defends Decision Not to Pursue Cadbury
description: Hershey defended its decision to back away from a Cadbury bid and a bigger stake in the global confectionery market, saying it remained confident about its growth prospects and was raising its dividend.

title: China Heavy I.P.O. Reflects Slipping Demand
description: China First Heavy Industries set the share price for its $1.67 billion initial public offering in Shanghai below the top of its range, the first to do so since China resumed I.P.O.s last June, and a sign of growing realism as markets have weakened and regulators have demanded more rational pricing, Reuters reported.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Case: The Movie
description: It has been almost one week since testimony ended in Perry v. Schwarzenegger, the federal trial in San Francisco over the constitutionality of the state ban on same-sex marriage, and some of you may be experiencing withdrawals.

description: No one would ever mistake the cramped, unadorned Manhattan courtroom of Judge Burton R. Lifland for King Solomons court.

title: Dodd Calls Obama Plan Too Ambitious
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee warned on Tuesday that the Obama administrations new proposals to rein in Wall Street firms ran the risk of derailing months of delicate negotiations over overhauling financial regulations, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: A Brighter Tomorrow for Goldman Sachs Partners in Britain?
description: It looks like Goldman Sachss London-based partners have just got to have faith, at least when it comes to getting compensated.

title: Moodys Says U.S. Rating Might Sink Under Deficit
description: Moodys Investors Service said Tuesday that unless the United States makes more efforts to cut its budget deficit or the economy improves more than anticipated, the governments Aaa bond rating will eventually be put under pressure.

description: Warning: This post contains spoilers. Big ones.

title: British Regulator Said to Play Hardball on Bonuses
description: The Financial Services Authority of Britain has told banks in the City of London to cooperate in deferring 60 percent of all pay, regardless of contractual obligations, or risk having their banking licenses withdrawn, The Telegraph reports, citing unidentified sources.

title: Is PNC Deal a Winner for Bank of New York?
description: Bank of New York Mellon is growing, but at a price, Breakingviews says. The the giant trust bank agreed Tuesday to buy the back-office operations of PNC Financial Services for $2.3 billion. That works out to 23 times annualized fourth-quarter 2009 earnings of the unit. That is a heady multiple for only a marginal increase in market share, the publication says.

title: Soldier Deaths Draw Focus to U.S. in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The deaths of three American soldiers in a Taliban suicide attack on Wednesday lifted the veil on United States military assistance to Pakistan that the authorities here would like to keep quiet and the Americans, as the donors, chafe at not receiving credit for.

title: Istithmar Said to Shop Port Unit
description: Dubai Worlds investment arm Istithmar has put its port and shipping agent Inchcape Shipping Services up for sale for $600 million to $700 million and has attracted interest from private equity groups, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

title: Malaysian Opposition Leader Goes on Trial for Sodomy
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The sodomy trial of the opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim finally began on Wednesday afternoon with a heavy police presence outside the Kuala Lumpur High Court and with crowds of supporters cheering him on. There had been no shortage of drama at the court on Tuesday, on what was to have been the first day of Mr. Anwars trial on charges that he sodomized a former campaign worker. Mr. Anwar, a former deputy prime minister, said he planned to subpoena the incumbent prime minister of Malaysia, Najib Razak, and his wife.

title: Power Broker in Japan Is Unlikely to Be Indicted
description: TOKYO  The kingpin of Japans governing party is not likely to face charges in an investigation into campaign finance, major Japanese newspapers reported on Wednesday. But it remains unclear whether he will be forced to step down over the scandal, which threatens to derail his partys reformist agenda.

title: Odyssey Nabs Wencor, Maker of Aircraft Parts
description: Odyssey Investment Partners said Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire  Wencor Group, a commercial distributor and maker of aircraft parts.

title: What Do You Think of the Oscar Nominations?
description: The list of Oscar nominees was released on Tuesday. What do you think of the list? Which films and actors did you want to see on it?

title: Friedman: When Economics Meets Politics
description: One of the few pleasant surprises of 2009 was that the worlds biggest economies were able to concentrate on healing themselves without any major wars or world-shaking political or geopolitical disruptions, Thomas Friedman writes in The New York Times. What are the odds that 2010 will be so benign?

title: Schott Op-Chart: U.S.A.A.A.
description: Countries, like individuals and corporations, have credit ratings. These ratings offer forward-looking opinions about risk  will a country be able to pay back its debts in full and on time?

title: A Word of Caution on New Russian I.P.O.s
description: Russian initial public offerings are set for a comeback, Breakingviews says. Some $20 billion of Russian share sales are forecast this year, including dozens of I.P.O.s. With plenty of options, investors should be able to drive a hard bargain, the publication suggests.

title: Denham Capital Injects Vulcan Power
description: Denham Capital said Tuesday that it had invested an additional $108 million in Vulcan Power, a developer of geothermal energy projects.

title: Iran Sends Some Animals, and Some Ambitions, Into Space
description: PARIS  In what seemed intended as a display of technological advance, Iran said on Wednesday that it had fired a rocket into space carrying living organisms  a rat, two turtles and worms, according to the state-run Press TV.

title: Shares Gain on Earnings Reports

description: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japans top bank, swung to profit in the quarter ending Dec. 31, buoyed by trading gains and an improvement in its stock portfolio, and maintained its full-year forecast, Reuters reported.

title: Geithner Says Banks Must Pay Fully for Bailout
description: The Obama administration is prepared to impose fees on financial firms for as long as necessary to ensure that every cent spent on bailing out banks is repaid, the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, said on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

title: In Berlin, Wagner Revisited

title: Britain Wants a Say in E.U. Mobile Merger

description: George Packer usually writes about foreign affairs, politics and books for The New Yorker, but this week he decided to attack Twitter in a blog post that ironically got much of its attention because a link to it was reposted more than 700 times on Twitter.

title: U.S. Lawmaker to Push for Crackdown on Speculation

title: Fords Challenge to Gillibrand Splits Donors
description: Moments after arriving at an Upper West Side duplex for a gathering of Democrats two weeks ago, Orin Kramer, a hedge-fund manager, was surrounded by angry supporters of Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand. One by one, they demanded to know why he was encouraging Harold E. Ford Jr., the former Tennessee congressman, to run for Senate in New York, The New York Timess Michael Barbaro writes.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Lauren Grodstein
description: Lauren Grodstein is the author of a story collection and two novels, most recently A Friend of the Family. She teaches creative writing at Rutgers, where she helps administer the M.F.A. program.

title: I Am Overwhelmed
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, please send them one per comment:

title: Of Volcker, Private Equity and Hedge Funds
description: Does former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A. Volcker know the difference between private equity firms and hedge funds?

title: An Inquiring Mind Tracks a Reporter Named Hemingway
description: Barry Levine, the executive editor of The National Enquirer, reaches into an old bookcase in his Upper East Side apartment and pulls out a tattered first edition of For Whom the Bell Tolls.

title: Car Seat Recall Nearly 10 Years in the Making
description: Consumer advocates say Dorel Juvenile Groups new recall of four million child car seats comes so late it doesnt matter anymore. Many of the children who once used those seats could have drivers licenses by now, as the company and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration fought over the recall for almost a decade.

title: Two U.S. Soldiers Killed in Southern Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Two United States soldiers were killed Tuesday by an improvised explosive device in southern Afghanistan, a focal point of the fight between international troops and Taliban militants, NATO officials said.

title: Sampler: Alameda Voters Say No to Development at Former Naval Air Station
description: Hikers Mothers Want to Go to Iran | In an interview, Nora Shourd, the mother of one of the three graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, who are detained in Iran, said she and the two other mothers have applied for visas to travel to Iran to plead the case of their jailed children. On Tuesday, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad told state television that the three Americans may be exchanged with Iranians jailed in the United States. Were still at ground zero here, and nothing has happened, said Ms. Shourd, of Oakland, whose daughter, Sarah, has been imprisoned in Iran since she and two friends crossed the Iranian border from Iraq. I cant even begin to tell you what this feels like to us. [The Oakland Tribune, Reuters]

title: Paulson & Co. Said to Receive Inquiry From S.E.C.
description: The hedge fund Paulson & Co., run by John A. Paulson, has received an information request from the Securities and Exchange Commission, The Financial Times reported, citing unidentified sources.

title: Eating Vancouver
description: In the Dining section I have an article about the Vancouver eating scene that I hope will make life a little more enjoyable for anyone heading to British Columbia for the 2010 Winter Games. It has around a dozen restaurant recommendations for both Vancouver proper and its close suburb, Richmond. But of course there are thousands of restaurants in and around Vancouver. Some number of them deserve to be shouted about from the top of Whistler, or at any rate in the comments field below. (What about Lumiere, Sifton? What about Japa Dog?)

title: Lazard Posts 4th-Quarter Loss on Compensation Charges
description: Lazard, the independent investment bank, reported a $54.9 million loss for its fourth quarter, as the firm took charges related to changes in its compensation policies and stock payouts tied to the death of its former chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein.

title: Prius Brake Inquiry May Be Another Blow for Toyota
description: NAGOYA, Japan  The Prius, a centerpiece of Japans cutting-edge technology, fell victim to Toyotas widening quality crisis on Wednesday after Japanese authorities told the automaker to investigate reports of faulty brakes on the gas-electric hybrid.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Feb. 3
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Tracing a Hospitals Long Decline
description: For more than 150 years, St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan has been a beacon in Greenwich Village, serving poets, writers, artists, winos, the poor and the working class, and gay people.

title: In Obamas Budget, Help for Caregivers
description: The people who work for advocacy groups representing older Americans and their families are doing happy Snoopy dances this week.

title: Another Attack on Pilgrims in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  At least 21 people were killed Wednesday in Karbala when a bomb was detonated only miles from a sacred Shiite shrine during a week in which millions of pilgrims are converging on the holy city.

title: Households Enter Voluntary Carbon Market
description: Last month, Tami and Randy Wilson of Harrisburg, Pa., may well have become the first homeowners to ever sell a carbon credit theyd generated at home. The family saved one metric ton of carbon by reducing their energy use and installing solar panels on their roof.

title: The Early Word: Busy Day on Capitol Hill
description: Capitol Hill looked to be the center of attention in Washington on Tuesday, with testimony on high-profile issues like terrorism, dont ask, dont tell and financial regulatory reform from plenty of administration heavyweights.

title: Do Small Businesses Want More Credit?
description: Our colleagues at the Economix blog have published a post that questions whether or not small business really wants the credit that President Obama is trying to get banks to extend to them.

title: Economic Measures by North Korea Prompt New Hardships and Unrest
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas sweeping attempts to revive socialist central economic planning and crack down on private markets appear to have set off runaway inflation and perhaps caused the countrys reclusive leaders to reconsider some of their own measures, according to South Korean news reports and intelligence officials.

title: What Were Reading
description: More bad news for high-end California winemakers, even Robert M. Parker tells them to get real as sales have plummeted. Sadly, far too many proprietors of high-end Napa wines are in denial, and have failed to recognize the dramatically changing parameters in the wine world of the consumer, he says.

title: The Arrangement | Flower Lessons in Red Hook
description: Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen discovered each other the way everyone does these days: online. Ryhanen owns Saipua, a flower shop in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where she also sells beautifully packaged soap made by her mother. (Saipua is Finnish for soap.) Owen runs her own Williamsburg-based flower biz focusing on private events. They are kindred spirits, who make stunning flower arrangements in the style of Oh, these wild things I just cut out back? Of course, the flowers are particularly chosen and arranged  and not cheap.

title: Explaining New Yorks Jobless Rate
20,000 Reasons Not to Hire Someone
description: After my last post, some readers suggested that I was exaggerating the potential cost of paying unemployment insurance when you hire the wrong person. Fred from Florida wrote, Payroll tax rates that fund unemployment insurance are affected by the companys history, but its not a dollar for dollar payout. Actually, in Illinois, its even worse.

title: Is the MacGruber Movie Blowing Up Already?
description: Usually, incendiary devices dont blow up on MacGruber until hes had some time to work on them (and then ignore them). But a coming movie starring that recurring Saturday Night Live character could be in jeopardy of detonating before it reaches theaters.

title: The Uses and Abuses of Poison Pills
description: Ronald Burkle, notable friend of Bill Clinton and the head of Yucaipa Investments, a private investment fund, issued a warning letter this week to Barnes & Noble, the beleaguered bookseller.

title: Concerned Over Jobs and Revenue, Wall St. Wanders
description: Investors were cautious on Wednesday as concerns over high unemployment and the ability of businesses to bring in revenue resurfaced, tempering some of the zeal that had marked Wall Street earlier this week.

title: Ban on Hundreds of Iraqi Candidates Overturned
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs political crisis deepened on Wednesday after an appeals court overturned a ban on hundreds of candidates in next months election for having ties to Saddam Husseins Baath Party, and Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki then disputed that ruling.

title: American Idol': Something Kinda Hmmmm
description: Hold onto your hats, people: theres a possibility that a reality show may not be presenting an accurate depiction of reality  or, at least, isnt being completely candid about the background of one of its contestants.

title: Obama Discusses Small-Business Credit
description: At a Town Hall meeting in Tampa, Fla., President Obama addressed a small business owner about how the Small Business Administration works with bank lenders.

title: N.Y. Haitians See Chance for Clout
description: After a week of watching news coverage of the Haiti earthquake, Nadege Fleurimond, a Haitian-American event planner in New York, fired off an e-mail message to about three dozen friends and associates. Though she was moved by the outpouring of help from local Haitians, she was frustrated that the effort had not coalesced into something larger and more visible.

title: I, Cassandra
description: Brad DeLong digs up my initial reaction to the Obama stimulus proposal, more than a year ago.

title: Wind Power in Europe Grows, but Credit Remains Tight
description: For the second year in a row, more wind power capacity was installed in the European Union than any other power technology, according to data compiled by the European Wind Energy Association.

title: What Small Government Looks Like
description: Via TAPPED, turning out the lights  literally  in Colorado Springs.

title: Chinese Mercantilism
description: According to Gideon Rachman and Martin Wolf, Larry Summers gave a talk at Davos in which he warned that free trade would become politically, and maybe even intellectually, hard to defend in the face of mercantilist policies by unnamed parties at a time of high unemployment.

title: Can Foods Contribute to Infertility?
description: Can you explain the link between celiac and infertility? Are you more likely to be infertile if you have celiac?Melanie

title: Freeney Cant Sidestep Questions About His Ankle
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Dwight Freeney limped into the Colts meeting with the media on Wednesday morning and responded to another round of questions about his ankle with the same answers he gave on Tuesday:

title: A Glimpse of Haiti Before the Catastrophe
description: Since life in Haiti was not a common subject in international news reports until the country was devastated by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake three weeks ago, it is something of a shock to view the short video embedded below, which was shot just over a month ago by a Haitian photographer named Frederic Dupoux to document New Years Eve in the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Lost, Nearing End, Nods to the Beginning
description: There are many different reasons to love Lost. But if youre still watching the series, its likely you can be (very roughly) sorted into one of two groups based on the nature of your love.

title: $100,000 Poetry Prize Is Awarded
description: In its continuing unofficial mission to prove that a poetry career need not condemn an author to a life of destitution, Claremont Graduate University has announced the winners of its highly lucrative Kingsley and Kate Tufts Poetry Awards. The Kingsley Tufts Award, which comes with a prize of $100,000, will go to D. A. Powell for his collection Chronic (Graywolf Press), the university said in a news release. Mr. Powell, a poet from the San Francisco Bay Area, is a finalist for the National Book Critics Circles poetry award, also for Chronic; his previous collection Cocktails, was also a finalist for that same honor. The Kate Tufts Discovery Award, a $10,000 prize that is given to a first book by a poet, was won by Beth Bachmann for her collection Temper (University of Pittsburgh Press). The awards will be officially handed out at a ceremony on April 22 at Pasadena Museum of California Art.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Giguere Deal a Hit for Leafs; Jokinen Deal a Dud for Rangers
description: Nine games on Tuesday, and so many of them involved streaks: Washingtons 10-game winning streak was on the line, as was Vancouvers seven-game streak, Los Angeless six-game streak and Antero Niittymakis personal 15-game streak vs. Atlanta. Then there was the chance that the Capitals might overtake the Sharks as the N.H.L.s overall leader.

title: Dressed Like the Mayor
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Today, by the way, is Groundhog Day. And this morning, the groundhog known to humans as Punxsutawney Phil was ripped from his hole by men dressed like the mayor in Monopoly. The animal rights group PETA has asked the organizers of this ridiculous event to replace Punxsutawney Phil with a robot groundhog. You create one robot groundhog, and before you know it, they take over the planet, you have to send people back in time to exterminate them and then we have no governor anymore. Its not a good idea.

title: Checking In | Erwin Olaf
description: The Dutch photographer Erwin Olafs latest photo and video series, Hotel and Dawn & Dusk, opened last week at New Yorks Hasted Hunt Kraeutler. The somewhat surreal exhibit reminds us of the artists gift for highly detailed but ambiguous storytelling. I want to trigger something in your head, so that youre going to make up your own story, he says. While the images of Dawn & Dusk are series of mirror images rendered alternately in black and white and then in color, the photographs that make up Hotel provide plenty of room for interpretation.

title: Planning Huge Changes
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Well, the Oscar nominations were announced today, you guys. Best-actor nominees included George Clooney for Up in the Air, Jeremy Renner for The Hurt Locker, and President Obama for the State of the Union.

title: In Images of Haiti, Tools for Recovery
description: When the founders of 25CPW took a former supermarket near Columbus Circle and turned it into an alternative space for exhibits and lectures, they knew they would have to move out one day when the landlord found a commercial tenant.

title: Updated: Obama Urges Democrats Forward on Health Care
description: Update | 12:51 p.m.

title: The Oscar Men Weigh In
description: Nobody call sexism, please. Though we mostly heard from actresses in the aftermath of the Academy Awards announcements on Tuesday, the Baguette also spoke with a few actors, Christoph Waltz and Jeremy Renner, who were each nominated for playing a dedicated (and in one case, very evil) military man.

title: Prius Adds to Toyotas Woes as Stock Drops in Tokyo
description: The hybrid-electric Prius has long been Toyotas green car, the symbol of the automakers engineering prowess and its big bet on the kind of car consumers will want to buy for decades to come.

title: Powell Favors Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, who as the nations top military officer in the 1990s opposed allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military, switched gears today and threw his support behind efforts to end the dont ask, dont tell law he helped shepherd in.

title: Cadburys Chairman and C.E.O. to Step Down
description: Following the success of Krafts pursuit of Cadbury, the British confectioner said that its chairman, its chief executive and its chief financial officer will step down.

title: High Art Meets High Jinks Onstage
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Good Wife Watch: Use Your Allusion
description: The O.J. Simpson case was a model for last nights episode of The Good Wife, and so was the Sunny von Blow scandal. But what does Kenneth L. Lay have to do with it?

title: Desserts in the Desert: Magnolia Opens Branch in Dubai
description: Its no secret that cupcake culture has already arrived in the Middle East. And now Magnolia Bakery, one of New Yorks most popular (and divisive) purveyors, is joining the fray.

title: For Vance, a Modest Start as District Attorney
description: Cyrus R. Vance Jr.s crackdown on crime started with something quite simple: a purse snatching.

title: Measuring Greenhouse Gases Locally
description: In Wednesdays New York Times, I wrote about Californias move to set up what is believed to be the worlds first statewide greenhouse gas monitoring network.

title: Obama to Democrats: Dont Play It Safe
description: President Obama urged Democrats not to be defeatist about the loss of their supermajority in the Senate, declaring: If anyone is searching for a lesson from Massachusetts, I promise you, the answer is not to do nothing.

title: Lost Ratings Up in Season Premiere
description: Oceanic Flight 815 didnt crash in the Lost episodes that opened the shows final season on Tuesday night, and ratings for this ABC serial stayed aloft as well. The Live Feed blog of The Hollywood Reporter said that the two-hour Lost premiere drew 12.1 million viewers, up from the 11.4 million viewers who tuned in for the debut of the shows fifth season in 2009. The Hollywood Reporter said that the Lost premiere also beat a new episode of NBCs reality show The Biggest Loser, which was rescheduled at the last minute to go head-to-head with Lost.

title: Generic Analysis, Cheap and Fast
description: Now that everyone has had a day to suck in the Oscar news, and process the snubs and surprises, the Bagger would like to weigh in with her own analysis. Well, wed like to, but its a lot easier to link to this generic analysis, written a la Steven Soderberghs Schizopolis (generic greeting).

title: Why Sydney Theater Companys Streetcar Wont Stop on Broadway
description: A Broadway run for the Cate Blanchett-led Streetcar Named Desire would have probably overcommitted her Sydney Theater Company at a time that it is approaching an extremely full artistic program in 2010 and deep into planning for 2011, a spokesman for the company said, explaining why a Broadway transfer is now off.

title: A Personal Perspective on Obamas Pell Grant Infusion
description: As I moderated comments Tuesday on a post about President Obamas proposal to increase Pell Grant awards, one dispatch stopped my cursor cold. It read: This is absolutely the right direction and in keeping with my grandfathers original vision for the program. It was signed, Clay Pell.

title: In Bay Area, Free Speech Means Scolding Strangers
description: Next to the elevators on the first floor of the Berkeley Public Library is a typed, well-written, unsigned note from a library patron.

title: Hamlet, Keats and Now Off Broadway
description: BEN WHISHAW threw a series of jersey tops and skinny jeans on and off his wiry body like a juggler tossing scarves in the air. He stood before a full-length mirror, head cocked, his petite frame topped by an explosion of thick black hair, a boyish yet chiseled face and the eyes of a pixie.

title: Nickeled-and-Dimed, and Quartered, Too
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled his $63 billion budget last week, most of the attention was devoted to his proposals to squeeze the teachers union, close 20 fire companies and increase the caseloads for social workers.

title: Apple Co-Founder: My Prius Has a Problem, Too
description: So far, the Prius is not on the list of models that Toyota is recalling for sticking accelerators, though one high-profile owner of a 2010 Prius  Steve Wozniak, co-founder of Apple  says he has had acceleration issues, too.

title: Rich People Feel More Well Rested
description: Rich people are more likely to say they feel well rested than poor people are, according to the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being survey.

title: Clash of the Titans and Harry Potter Get 3-D Upgrades
description: You cant in any way discern this from the 2-D picture above, but Clash of the Titans will soon be coming at you in temple-rumbling, Medusa-decapitating, Kraken-battling 3-D. Capitalizing on audiences renewed interest in the 3-D format that has helped boost ticket sales and revenue for Avatar, the James Cameron sci-fi film released by 20th Century Fox, Warner Brothers announced that several of its coming films will be shown in 3-D screens. In a news release, the studio said that its coming remake of Clash of the Titans, starring the Avatar veteran Sam Worthington as the Greek hero Perseus and directed by Louis Leterrier (The Incredible Hulk), will be its first film to get the 3-D treatment. Its release will be delayed by one week, to April 2 from March 26 as a result. The first part of Harry Potter and Deathly Hallows, the two-film finale of that boy wizard franchise, will also be shown in 3-D in November, Warner Brothers said. Both movies will also receive traditional 2-D releases.

title: Make Your Own Hotel Bed and Save
description: How dirty are you willing to let your hotel room get to save a few bucks?

title: Composers Intent? Get Over It
description: WHEN the Vienna Philharmonic visited Carnegie Hall recently, it brought three programs that largely avoided the orchestras usual mandate. Haydn and Mozart were missing, and the Romantic canon was represented only by a pair of Beethoven symphonies, some Wagner excerpts and a movement of Mahler.

title: Recruits Scramble on Signing Day
description: Because we have clearly not reached our limit on absurdity in sports this week, Wednesday is national signing day. Once, this meant a top prospect gathered some folks at his high school, put caps from two schools on a table and grabbed one, while his family members squealed and wielded camcorders. Now, it means someone named Seantrel Henderson is flying to New York to announce his college choice on national television, and if we later hear tales that he complained his lobster thermidor was too salty, we will not bat an eyelash.

title: Super Bowl Snacks
description: Not only am I doing a lovely scallop gumbo for this weeks Minimalist column, but check out Andrews jambalaya (were both pulling for the Saints).

title: A Bargain at Half the Price
description: I had to laugh the other day when I received an e-mail circular from a wine merchant promoting February Red Burgundy Sale! Meo Camuzet Richebourt 2007 $495 a bottle! Dujac Chambertin 2006 $650 a bottle! Rousseau Clos St. Jacques 2006 $285!

title: Bankrupt Air Americas Creditors Include Rachel Maddow, Ron Reagan
description: When Air America Media, the liberal radio network, went bust last month, it left several of its better-known contributors, including Rachel Maddow and Ron Reagan, holding i.o.u.s.

title: Correction
description: A Theater entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday about the City Center Encores! revival of Fanny misidentified the actor who plays Panisse, the man whom Fanny is forced to marry. Fred Applegate plays Panisse  not George Hearn, who plays the father of Fannys true love.

title: Publicy
description: When the public, not the private, is the default.(Publi[c] + [Priva]cy)

title: Putting the Wrongs of History in Paint
description: DURING a visit to New York late last fall, the Belgian painter Luc Tuymans sat on a couch in the dimly lighted lounge of the Bowery Hotel and recounted a disturbing childhood memory. One evening when he was 5, he said, his family was gathered around his paternal grandparents dinner table. His mothers brother was leafing through a picture album when a photograph of one of his fathers brothers  his own namesake, Luc  fell to the floor. The photo, Mr. Tuymans said, showed this uncle as an adolescent performing the Hitler salute.

title: Illinois Senate Race Worries Democrats Anew
description: CHICAGO  Alexi Giannoulias, the treasurer of Illinois and a basketball-playing friend of President Obamas, won the Democratic primary here on Tuesday for the Senate seat once held by Mr. Obama. But his victory was hardly the free throw some had expected, setting off a new round of worrying among Democrats that the reliably Democratic seat might be picked off by Republicans in November.

title: Answers From a Yoga Instructor
description: Following is the first set of responses from Bryn Chrisman, a vinyasa flow yoga teacher and kirtan leader in New York.

title: View on Signing Day: Florida and Texas Win
description: Update | 8:45 p.m. A day of fax machines humming and die-hards sweating ended somewhat predictably Wednesday.

title: The Least-Trusted Banks in America
description: Customers of the biggest banks in the United States are the least likely to believe their financial institution does whats best for them as opposed to whats best for the bottom line, according to a new report from Forrester Research.

title: Scattered migrs Haiti Once Shunned Are Now a Lifeline
description: MIAMI  Since leaving Haiti in 1974 and becoming a successful engineer here, Fritz Armand has often felt that his skills were unwelcome in his native country.

title: Graphic Content | Film at First Sight
description: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the MFA Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

title: Run Extended for Venus in Fur
description: The critically acclaimed Off Broadway production of the new play Venus in Fur, at the Classic Stage Company, will be extended for two additional weeks to meet audience demand and accommodate theater producers who are eyeing it for a commercial run, perhaps on Broadway, executives involved in the production said on Wednesday.

title: Stranger in a Familiar Land
description: Its often said that people who live near great tourist attractions are the least likely to have ever seen them. More than common experience, this phenomenon has actually been shown to be the case in at least one academic study, bearing the wonderfully direct and scolding title Procrastination of Enjoyable Experiences. [pdf] (Who says academics never study anything useful?)

title: Ferrari Stays on Top in Valencia
description: On the third and final day of the first test session of the season, the Ferrari again set the fastest lap, this time with Fernando Alonso driving. In fact, Alonso set the fastest lap of the week. And in doing so, he led not only a cohort of a total of three Spanish drivers  Jaime Alguersuari at Toro Rosso and Pedro de la Rosa at BMW Sauber Ferrari  through an exciting test session, but he and they led the entertainment for the close to 40,000 Spanish fans who showed up to watch the test.

title: Marcia Bullard Retires from USA Weekend
description: Marcia Bullard is retiring after 14 years as president and chief executive of USA Weekend, Gannetts weekend magazine insert, the company announced on Wednesday. The magazines publisher, Charles Gabrielson, will also take on the title of president.

title: Jail for Solow
description: Jamie Solow, the broker whose ample fortune ended up under his wifes control and tucked away in a Cook Islands trust by the time a judgment against him for securities fraud became final, has gone to prison.

title: Paul Ryans Moment
description: Across the first thirteen months of the Obama era, Wisconsins Paul Ryan, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, has been one of the few conservative politicians offering detailed alternatives to the Democratic agenda. When Obama released his initial budget, Ryan responded by issuing a sweeping fiscal roadmap that envisioned bringing the U.S. budget back into balance across the next three decades. While many of his fellow Republicans were greeting Obamas health care push with Medicare demagoguery, Ryan was busy co-sponsoring (with Tom Coburn, among others) the Patients Choice Act, an imperfect but impressive alternative to the Democrats approach. And now, with the release of Obamas second budget, which projects deficits as far as the eye can see, Ryan has updated his fiscal roadmap as well  and suddenly, people are paying attention to him.

title: Car Talk
description: The Times reports today on the problems of the latest Defense Department procurement program to go awry, the Joint Strike Fighter:

title: Before Grammys Kick In, Lady Antebellum Tops Charts
description: This has been a big week for the country trio Lady Antebellum. On Sunday night it performed at the Grammy Awards and took home a prize for best country performance by a duo or group. Now Lady Antebellum has a blockbuster No. 1 album with its second release, Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), which sold an impressive 481,000 copies in its first week in stores, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (Since SoundScans sales week ended Sunday, the full effect of the Grammys traditional sales bump will not be felt until next weeks chart.)

title: Shoptalk: Vignettes
description: Photography may be a storytelling medium above all else, but it can also be an extremely technical one as well. Against the gravity of the Haitian catastrophe, it has seemed inappropriate to dwell on details like f stops and shutter speeds  even though such details underlie every image. But a reader named Ed asked a question on Tuesday that goes to a broader issue in photojournalism: to what degree do technical imperfections inhere in an image?

title: Hargrove Is Single-Minded: Smear the Guy With the Football
description: MIAMI  The Saints and Colts are playing nice in the lead-up to Super Bowl XLIV, and none of the players was more good-natured on Wednesday than Saints defensive tackle Anthony Hargrove.

title: Editor Janice Kaplan Is Out at Parade
description: The editor in chief of Parade magazine, Janice Kaplan, has stepped down, the latest in a series of changes at the Cond Nast-owned publication.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) A tax court has ruled that gender reassignment surgery is a deductible medical expense.

title: Whats Next for Swiss Bank Secrecy?
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Quote Unquote | Cat Couture
description: -Jean Paul Gaultier exclaims to The Telegraph about his recent epiphany. No wonder couture is doing so poorly.

title: Nepal Waits as 2 Armies, Former Foes, Become One
description: JHYALTUNGDANDA, Nepal  Up in the foothills of the Himalayas, the soldiers of Nepals onetime rebel army have spent more than three years in camps monitored by the United Nations. Mornings begin with exercise, breakfast and drilling. Afternoons often mean political education sessions on their Maoist agenda for restructuring Nepals government.

title: Wall St. Revenue Falls, So States Deficit Rises
description: ALBANY  New York States revenue collections keep coming up short.

title: Remixing Regional Flavors in Houston
description: RARE is the city where a chef can set up tables inside a former car dealership and pack the house nightly. But on a recent evening in Houston, I sat inside that space, which has been reborn as Reef, a bustling, hyper-inventive seafood restaurant, and thought about the unusual fish on my plate: a Gulf of Mexico wahoo, to which the chef and co-owner Bryan Caswell had done unexpected, and unexpectedly delicious, things.

title: How Safe Is Safe Enough?
description: Gail Collins: David, how safe is safe enough?

title: Bank Data May Unveil German Tax Evaders, Finance Official Says
description: BERLIN  Germanys finance minister warned German tax evaders Wednesday that they risked punishment if their names were found on a CD the government is buying that contains information about Swiss bank customers.

title: The High Low | YMCs Basic Line
description: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.

title: Time Warners Movies Help It Swing to a Profit
description: TIME WARNER, the media conglomerate that has spun off some of its major businesses over the last year, said on Wednesday that its revenue and profits had improved, providing more evidence that traditional media businesses may be pulling out of a prolonged downturn.

title: Out-of-Step Ice Dancing Routine
description: ASTON, Pa.  A pair of figure skating costumes, meant to be aboriginal, have been denounced instead as abominable.

title: For Scots, a Scourge Unleashed by a Bottle
description: COATBRIDGE, Scotland  What is it about Buckfast Tonic Wine that makes it so alluring to consumers and yet so repulsive to politicians?

title: Coats Eyes Return to Indiana Senate Seat
description: Former Senator Daniel R. Coats announced on Wednesday that he is taking steps toward making a bid for his old seat in Indiana, potentially giving the G.O.P. a top-tier challenger in its bid to unseat Democratic Senator Evan Bayh.

title: Drugs and Alcohol Cited in Death of Musician Jay Reatard
description: A medical examiner said that cocaine and alcohol contributed to the death of Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., the punk rock musician better known as Jay Reatard, The Commercial Appeal of Memphis reported. After an autopsy, Dr. Karen E. Chancellor, the medical examiner of Shelby County, Tenn., told The Commercial Appeal that Mr. Lindsey died from cocaine toxicity, and that alcohol was a contributing factor in his death. Mr. Lindsey, a prolific musician whose recent albums included Watch Me Fall and Blood Visions, was found dead in his home in the Cooper-Young section of Memphis on Jan. 13. He was 29.

title: Snowboarder Davis Released From Utah Hospital
description: Snowboarder Danny Davis was released from the Utah hospital where he had been recovering from injuries sustained in an early morning all-terrain vehicle accident in Park City on Jan. 17.

title: Taking It Literally: Testing How the Body Processes Information
description: Overview | What is embodied cognition, and how does research in the field describe the way our bodies and minds process language and metaphors? How might this research provide insight for teaching and learning? In this lesson, students act out common metaphors that convey abstract ideas. They consider embodied cognition research on how we process information and abstract ideas, then design and conduct their own cognition experiments. Finally, they present their findings and reflect on how their research might be applied.

title: A Visit to the Orphans of Haiti
description: Dr. Jane Aronson is back from visiting orphanages in Haiti. She was still there last Friday when 10 Americans were detained at the border of the Dominican Republic, trying to leave with 33 children who may or may not be orphaned. And she was there during the resulting debate in the United States about whether adoption by Americans is the best way to help Haitis children.

title: A New Way to Comment on Pogues Posts
description: Get psyched! As of today, the Pogues Posts blog abandons the Eisenhower-era Comments system its been using from the beginning.

title: A New Face at the Briefing
description: For the last year, Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, has stood in the White House briefing room, taking questions and engaging in a back-and-forth with reporters nearly every day that President Obama is in Washington.

title: As St. Vincents Flounders, Readers Weigh In
description: In 1983, Norma Millay of Austerlitz, N.Y., wrote a letter to The New York Times Book Review that is certainly one of the more romantic tributes to St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village. Addressing what some more realistically minded souls assumed must be the apocryphal story that her sister, Edna St. Vincent Millay, the famous poet, got her middle name from the hospital, Norma Millay assured the book review: The reason why the story that my sister was named for New Yorks St. Vincent Hospital has been bandied about is that it is true.

title: Travel Deals: Flight Sale to Denver and $5 Buses to Philly
description: Looking to travel to Denver or Philadelphia? Youre in luck. Two cities, two affordable deals.

title: Referee on Sunday Has Felt Glare Before
description: The N.F.L. announced the officiating crew for the Super Bowl, and one member will revive bad memories for Giants fans.

title: Researcher on Climate Is Cleared in Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  An academic board of inquiry has largely cleared a noted Pennsylvania State University climatologist of scientific misconduct, but a second panel will convene to determine whether his behavior undermined public faith in the science of climate change, the university said Wednesday.

title: The Sour Notes of Irans Art Diplomacy
description: GENEVA  Late last month  around the time the Iranian government executed two more political prisoners, charging nine others with waging war against God, a capital offense  the Tehran Symphony Orchestra was sent on a government-sponsored tour across Europe, which just ended this week.

title: Iran Opposition Leaders Urge Rally on Anniversary
description: Throwing up a challenge to the increasingly violent tactics of Irans ruling elite, the countrys two leading opposition figures are urging protesters to defy the government and take to the streets in an antigovernment rally on Feb. 11.

title: Household Pesticide Is Finding Its Way Into California Rivers, Study Suggests
description: Pyrethroids, a common home pesticide, have been found in California rivers at levels toxic to some stream-dwellers, according to a new study.

title: Creative Destruction: Car Dealership Edition
description: What happens to old car showrooms after auto dealerships shut down? They turn into catwalks, galleries, schools, theaters, churches and yoga studios.

title: Ackmans Confidence Bolsters Borders Shares
description: Shares of the Borders Group jumped as much as 50 percent on Wednesday after its largest investor, William A. Ackman, said there was little likelihood that the struggling bookseller would file for bankruptcy and that it could even be part of an industry consolidation.

title: Pakistani Scientist Convicted of Attempted Murder
description: A Pakistani neuroscientist was convicted on Wednesday of attempted murder for trying to kill American soldiers and F.B.I. agents in Afghanistan.

title: Billie Jean': Literal Video Version
description: Video | With the new lyrics, the video makes a lot more sense now:

title: A Personal Perspective on Pell Grants
description: Over at The Choice blog, a grandson of the late Senator Claiborne D. Pell talks about President Obamas plans for what are known as Pell grants.

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 7
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: BMW Picks Jeff Koons for Next Art Car
description: At a sparkly art world party in Manhattan last night, BMW announced that artist Jeff Koons would create the next car in the companys Art Car series.

title: Superficial Seductions in a Rock Operas Return
description: The choreographer David Parsons creates modern-dance works that are apparently designed to be accessible, appealing, inoffensive and  often enough  both sexy and athletically exciting. Certainly he has an audience that finds them so. How many other choreographers today can present their company (11 dancers in this case) for a three-week season in New York, as he is doing this month? And his company tours extensively.

title: Capitalizing on Oscar Buzz
description: As the sheen settles from nomination day on Tuesday, Hollywood types are taking stock of what really matters: money.

title: Lincoln Center Festivals Are On, but Great Performers Remain a Mystery
description: Lincoln Center on Wednesday announced its Great Performers programming for next season and the big news included no news: programmers will mount two festivals, but officials declined to release the themes, subject matter, performers or even all the genres being presented. A spokeswoman said in an e-mail that the festivals, one in the fall and one in the spring, would be announced when all of the information is confirmed/finalized. A news release from Lincoln Center did say that the festivals will incorporate productions of genre-crossing works, innovative collaborations and premieres, and diverse music presentations. Lincoln Center also said that two groups, the chorus Accademia Chigiana Siena, and the Belgian wind ensemble I Solisti del Vento, would be making their New York debuts during the season.

title: The Strip Is the Saints Not-So-Secret Weapon
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  When Gregg Williams arrived as the New Orleans Saints defensive coordinator this season, he brought with him the mantra of attacking the football. Against the Minnesota Vikings on Jan. 24, the Saints provided a clinic in Williamss intentions and produced a highlight reel of one of footballs most important and popular tactics: the strip.

title: Geithner Urges Bank Fees to Recoup A.I.G. Bonuses
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Wednesday that the American International Groups contracts to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in bonuses were outrageous and appealed to Congress to help recoup the payments. He said Congress could help recover the deeply irresponsible bonuses by passing an Obama administration proposal to levy fees on large financial firms.

title: A Quiet, and Abrupt, Exit From McDonalds
description: Few McDonalds franchisees have ever been as prominent or daring as Irwin S. Kruger. In the 37 years since he opened the companys first outlet in Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Kruger has spoken out about changes in the McDonalds menu and has even done a little tinkering of his own.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Feb. 3
description: Children, unfortunately, are all too often the perfect subject for photojournalists, since they embody  in their innocence  the grievous damage of wars, disasters and civil strife. Today, their faces run through the show. To fathom the trauma of the school bombing in Pakistan, take a moment to study Slide 2, by Ali Shah of Reuters. As your eyes accustom themselves to the strong contrast of light and shadow, you will begin to see more of the human toll. In visiting the children at the makeshift clinic in a soccer stadium in Port-au-Prince (Slides 3 and 4), Ruth Fremson of The Times finds contrasting emotions. Slide 10 by Dar Yasin of The Associated Press seems at first to be a more benign view of curious boyhood  until you read the caption.

title: Giacometti Bronze Breaks World Record Auction Price
description: Update | 6:29 p.m.

title: Best Cameras for $300 or Less
description: In 2001, I conducted a search for the best camera with a street price under $300. Ive repeated the experiment every year since.

title: Sudans Leader May Be Accused of Genocide
description: The president of Sudan, who is already facing an international arrest warrant, came under new legal scrutiny on Wednesday when appeals judges at The Hague reopened the possibility that he may be charged with genocide.

title: Warm and Fuzzy Dept. | Rodartes Flying Colors
description: New York fashion week, which runs Feb. 10 to 18, will face some stiff competition this time around in the form of the 21st Winter Olympic Games, which kick off Feb. 12. Sure, Ralph Lauren designed Americas official opening ceremony attire and village wear, and Vera Wang is outfitting the figure skater  and top gold medal hopeful  Evan Lysacek. But for a truly breathtaking Olympic fashion mash-up, check out Ryan McGinleys portfolio of athletes dressed by Rodartes Kate and Laura Mulleavy.

title: Amazon Said to Buy Touch Start-Up
description: In a sign that Amazon wants to upgrade its Kindle e-reader to compete head-on with the Apple iPad, Amazon has acquired Touchco, a start-up based in New York that specializes in touch-screen technology, a person briefed on the deal said Wednesday.

title: Bernanke Takes Oath at Fed, Quietly
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke stepped into the imposing two-story marble atrium at the Federal Reserves headquarters and took the oath of office from his deputy. The president lauded Mr. Bernanke as an economists economist who had earned the respect of the global financial community. A cabinet secretary, members of Congress and two former Fed chairmen looked on.

title: Europe Leans Toward Bluefin Trade Ban
description: PARIS  European officials are increasing pressure for an international ban on the commercial fishing of bluefin tuna, a threatened species whose fatty belly is prized for sushi. But they are facing a delicate balancing act as they try to weigh economic interests of a Mediterranean fishing industry, a sushi-loving Japan, and a species that some experts say is on the verge of extinction.

title: Controversy Is a Trans-Atlantic Affair
description: Our colleague Lynn Zinser, looking for a distraction from the American brand of football in her Leading Off column today, writes:

title: New Elementary School for the Upper East Side
description: After a year in which a surge in demand led to waiting lists of young children seeking spots in their local elementary schools  not to mention crowds of irate parents  the Upper East Side will be getting a new public elementary school, the Department of Education said Wednesday.

title: Comparison Chart: Cameras Under $300
description: A comparison chart of nine new point-and-shoot cameras.

title: Bernanke Takes Oath at Fed, Quietly
description: Ben S. Bernanke stepped into the imposing two-story marble atrium at the Federal Reserves headquarters and took the oath of office from his deputy. The president lauded him as an economists economist who had earned the respect of the global financial community. A cabinet secretary, members of Congress and two former Fed chairmen looked on.

title: Manns Fate in Climategate
description: Michael Mann, the climatologist from Pennsylvania State University who has been under attack by foes of restrictions on greenhouse gases and critics of the dominant view that human-driven warming is occurring and dangerous, has been cleared on three points of inquiry by a faculty review panel at the university, John Broder of The Times reports. A fourth question will be investigated further.

title: Workers Treated After Exposure to White Powder
description: Updated, 6:25 p.m. | Nine people were being decontaminated after they were exposed to a white powdery substance on the 40th floor of 26 Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday, according to the police. Initial tests performed by authorities on the substance determined that it was not hazardous.

title: Hut-One, Hut-Two! Pizza Hut Devotes Pregame Ad Buy to New Campaign
description: The unveiling of the first work for Pizza Hut from its new agency is getting a big stage: the pregame hours on CBS on Sunday before Super Bowl XLIV.

title: Amazon Is Said to Buy Touch-Screen Company
description: In a sign that Amazon wants to upgrade its Kindle e-reader to compete head-on with the Apple iPad, Amazon has acquired Touchco, a start-up based in New York that specializes in touch-screen technology, The New York Timess Nick Bilton and Brad Stone reported Wednesday, citing a person briefed on the deal.

title: Inside the Action: Luge
description: Mark Grimmette, a doubles luge athlete for the United States Olympic team, describes the sled and how to steer it going 90 miles an hour.

title: Nifty 50 | Emily Pilloton, Humanitarian
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Bringing a Little More Cowbell to the Olympics
description: If you ever thought the Olympics couldve used a little more cowbell, there is now an iPhone app rushing to the rescue.

title: Freeney Strolls in the Sand for Therapy
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Dwight Freeney has been walking on the beach behind the Indianapolis Colts hotel this week, but not in the relaxing, vacation kind of way. Walking on the sand is part of Freeneys hell-try-anything efforts to get his right ankle feeling well enough to play in Sundays Super Bowl.

title: Bar Association Backs Greater Transparency in Albany
description: When the State Legislature passed a package of reform to New Yorks ethics laws, one big criticism was that it would exclude lawmakers who were also lawyers from having to disclose the names of their clients. Revealing outside business interests is considered one crucial step in bringing transparency and, perhaps, greater accountability to Albany.

title: Zap or Chill? Targeting Fat Without Surgery
description: REDUCING fat around ones midriff and thighs has become a defining quest of the modern age. It has brought us Zone Diet delivery, the ThighMaster and liposuction, which involves surgically vacuuming fat out of your body.

title: A New Set of Wheels for the Big Show?
description: With the news that thousands of Toyotas are being recalled because of acceleration and brake problems, and the federal transportation secretary, Ray LaHood, Wednesday morning asking people not to drive the cars at all, the Bagger has a pressing question: What will celebrities drive to the Oscars if not their precious Priuses?

title: Obama Takes a Tough Question on S.B.A. Lending
description: One nice thing about our president is that he has the intellectual self-confidence to take questions from anyone who cares to ask, regardless of whether the interlocutor agrees with him. And so it happened that once more, an entrepreneur had the opportunity to pose to President Obama a question that Agenda readers have raised more than once. If banks arent willing to loan to small businesses, asked Steve Gordon at a town hall in Tampa last week, and Washington is seemingly willing to loan to practically everybody else, why doesnt the Small Business Administration make loans directly to small firms?

title: Ciscos Profit Surges 23 Percent
description: John T. Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco Systems, prides himself on forecasting technology and economic shifts ahead of his companys peers and competitors.

title: Facing Scandal, Keeping Faith
description: Heres a sign of the times: when Jenny Sanford sat down to tell her young sons that their father, Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina, was having an affair, one of them reacted in an unusually worldly way.

title: Getting to Manning Is Still the Key for Saints
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Many of the Saints defensive players are already running out of creative ways to say that there is no good way to prepare for Colts quarterback Peyton Manning.

title: More Casting Announced for La Cage Aux Folles and Fences
description: The producing teams for the coming Broadway revivals of the musical La Cage Aux Folles and the play Fences announced more casting choices for those shows on Wednesday, including several theater veterans in plum roles.

title: A Small-Business Owner Takes His Case to the Top
description: Last week, one entrepreneur had the opportunity to ask President Obama a question that no doubt has been on the mind of many others. The venue was a town hall meeting in Tampa, Fla., on Thursday, the day after the presidents State of the Union address. "Im frustrated because I can create 500 jobs," began Steve Gordon. Ive gone to the banks, I cant get a loan. You lent directly to Wall Street, you lent directly to the automakers, you lent directly to the banks  why cant the government make [small-business loans] available directly to us?"

title: Lindsey Vonn at the Summit
description: On the November day last year when Vail opened for the winter season, the base area was a swarm of skiers and snowboarders, a mass that swelled with the approach of a tall, 25-year-old blonde carrying ski boots and poles. As she walked into the resorts plaza, a gaggle of young children trotted in her wake, shouting her name. Many of those waiting to board the nearby gondola recognized Lindsey Vonn as well and surged toward her.

title: State Must Pay Farmers Legal Fees
description: ALBANY  New York State picked the wrong farmer to fight.

title: Trace of Thought Is Found in Vegetative Patient
description: He emerged from the car accident alive but alone, there and not there: a young man whose eyes opened yet whose brain seemed shut down. For five years he lay mute and immobile beneath a diagnosis  vegetative state  that all but ruled out the possibility of thought, much less recovery.

title: Justice Defends Ruling on Finance
description: WASHINGTON  In expansive remarks at a law school in Florida, Justice Clarence Thomas on Tuesday vigorously defended the Supreme Courts recent campaign finance decision.

title: Frances Buss, Pioneer of Early Television, Dies at 92
description: Frances Buss, who at the dawn of commercial television parlayed a job as a temporary receptionist into a pioneering career as a director whose work helped establish the talk show, the game show and the cooking show as television staples, died on Jan. 19 in Hendersonville, N.C. She was 92.

title: New Theater: Lincoln Center Raises the Roof
description: In the early 1960s Hugh Hardy worked as an assistant to Jo Mielziner, the theatrical designer. Mr. Mielziner was collaborating with Eero Saarinen on the design of the Vivian Beaumont Theater for the new Lincoln Center, and part of Mr. Hardys job was to mediate between his boss and the great architect.

title: Pretzel Logic
description: Lately, every chance I get, I have been working whole grains into the meals we serve our sons, Dexter and Elliot. The cabinets and the freezer are stockpiled with farro, oatmeal, wild rice, polenta and bags of not-white flour: whole wheat, spelt and buckwheat. The change in our diet is most noticeable on Saturday and Sunday mornings, when Dexter and I usually make pancakes or waffles. Just six months ago, we were following a white-flour-dominated recipe that either one of my grandmothers would have recognized. Our most recent batch of pancakes incorporated whole-grain rye flour and cornmeal along with half a cup of cooked quinoa. If my goal was to transport my sons back to the kitchen of some Nixon-era communally owned radical-feminist vegetarian tea parlor without anybody figuring out that we had left 2010 Brooklyn, then the pancakes were a wild success.

title: Great Performers a Great Mystery
description: Lincoln Center on Wednesday announced its Great Performers programming for next season and the big news included no news. Programmers will mount two festivals, but officials declined to release the themes, subject matter, performers or even all the genres being presented. A spokeswoman said in an e-mail message that the festivals, one in the fall and one in the spring, would be announced when all of the information is confirmed/finalized. A news release from Lincoln Center did say that the festivals would incorporate productions of genre-crossing works, innovative collaborations and premieres, and diverse music presentations. Lincoln Center also said that two groups, the chorus Accademia Chigiana Siena and the Belgian wind ensemble I Solisti del Vento, would make their New York debuts during the season.

title: La Cage and Fences Add Cast Members
description: The producing teams for the coming Broadway revivals of the musical La Cage aux Folles and the play Fences each announced more casting choices on Wednesday, including several theater veterans in plum roles. La Cage, starring Kelsey Grammer as Georges and Douglas Hodge as Albin (a role for which he won an Olivier Award last year in London), will also include the Tony Award nominees Veanne Cox (Company) in two roles as the uptight mother and a cafe owner, Robin de Jesus (In the Heights) as the butler and personal assistant Jacob, and Christine Andreas (the William Hammerstein revival of Oklahoma! in 1980) as the owner of Chez Jacqueline. Preview performances are to begin April 6 at the Longacre Theater, with an opening night on April 18. Fences, one of August Wilsons Pulitzer Prize-winning plays, already had its two major star attractions on board: the Academy Award-winning actor Denzel Washington as Troy Maxson (played by James Earl Jones in the original 1980s run) and the Tony winner Viola Davis (King Hedley II) as his wife, Rose, played by Mary Alice in the original run. In addition, the producers announced the casting of Chris Chalk (Ruined) as Cory; Stephen McKinley Henderson (Ma Raineys Black Bottom), above left, as Jim Bono; Russell Hornsby (HBOs In Treatment), right, as Lyons; and Mykelti Williamson (Foxs current season of 24) as Gabriel. Casting for the role of Raynell will be announced later. Directed by Kenny Leon, this Fences  its first revival on Broadway  is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26.

title: Why Streetcar Revival Wont Stop on Broadway
description: A Broadway run for the Cate Blanchett-led Streetcar Named Desire would have probably overcommitted her Sydney Theater Company at a time that it is approaching an extremely full artistic program in 2010 and deep into planning for 2011, a spokesman for the company said, explaining why a Broadway transfer is now off. The spokesman, Tim McKeough, wrote in an e-mail message on Tuesday night that he could confirm that the company  where Ms. Blanchett is co-artistic director  received several inquiries from commercial producers about a transfer of the critically acclaimed show, which was a very difficult ticket to get during its limited run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music late last year. Stephen C. Byrd, the Broadway producer who had been interested in possibly transferring this Streetcar, starring Ms. Blanchett as Blanche DuBois, above, said through a spokesman on Tuesday that he was instead planning a new revival of this Tennessee Williams play with a multiracial cast on Broadway in spring 2011.

title: A Big Week for Lady Antebellum
description: Lady Antebellum, the country trio that won the Grammy Award for best country performance by a duo or group on Sunday night, now has a blockbuster No. 1 album. The bands second release, Need You Now (Capitol Nashville), sold an impressive 481,000 copies in its first week in stores, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (Since SoundScans sales week ended Sunday, the full effect of the Grammys traditional sales bump will not be felt until next weeks chart.) Hope for Haiti Now, the download-only album of performances from the Haiti telethon on Jan. 22, fell one spot to No. 2 with 143,000 sales (proceeds from it benefit various Haiti relief groups); The Fame (Interscope) from Lady Gaga holds at No. 3 with 68,000; and Susan Boyles I Dreamed a Dream (Syco Music/Columbia) is No. 4 with 59,000 sales. Other high-ranking new releases on this weeks chart include Barry Manilows new album, The Greatest Love Songs of All Time, (Arista) at No. 5 with 57,000, and The Sea (Capitol) by Corinne Bailey Rae, at No. 7 with 53,000.

title: $100,000 Poetry Prize Goes to D. A. Powell
description: In its continuing unofficial mission to prove that a poetry career need not condemn an author to a life of destitution, Claremont Graduate University has announced the winners of its highly lucrative Kingsley and Kate Tufts poetry awards. The Kingsley Tufts Award, which comes with a prize of $100,000, will go to D. A. Powell for his collection Chronic (Graywolf Press), the university said in a news release. Mr. Powell, a poet from the San Francisco Bay Area, is a finalist for the National Book Critics Circles poetry award, also for Chronic; his previous collection Cocktails, was also a finalist for that honor. The Kate Tufts Discovery Award, a $10,000 prize that is given to a first book by a poet, was won by Beth Bachmann for her collection Temper (University of Pittsburgh Press). The awards will be officially handed out at a ceremony on April 22 at the Pasadena Museum of California Art.

title: Drugs and Alcohol Cited in Death of Jay Reatard
description: A medical examiner said that cocaine and alcohol had contributed to the death of Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., the punk rock musician better known as Jay Reatard, The Commercial Appeal of Memphis reported. After an autopsy Dr. Karen E. Chancellor, the medical examiner of Shelby County, Tenn., told The Commercial Appeal that Mr. Lindsey, above, had died from cocaine toxicity, and that alcohol was a contributing factor in his death. Mr. Lindsey, a prolific musician whose recent albums included Watch Me Fall and Blood Visions, was found dead in his home in the Cooper-Young section of Memphis on Jan. 13. He was 29.

title: Lost Finds Viewers
description: Oceanic Flight 815 didnt crash in the Lost episodes that opened the shows final season on Tuesday night, and ratings for this ABC serial stayed aloft as well. According to Nielsens estimates, the two-hour Lost averaged 12.1 million viewers, up from 11.4 million last year. Still, Foxs American Idol remained dominant as usual, leading prime time with 24.4 million total viewers. Fox won the night over all although CBS finished close behind with NCIS (19.1 million), NCIS: Los Angeles (16.4 million), and The Good Wife (12.7 million). ABC ranked third and NBC finished fourth with a lineup that included The Biggest Loser (9.4 million).

title: Is Amazon Building a Superkindle?
description: Update | 6:26 p.m.  Correcting details about Sonys first touch-screen e-reader.

title: Democrat Jumps Into Delaware Senate Race
description: In a not unexpected move, Chris Coons, a Democrat and the New Castle County executive, announced on Wednesday that he would run for the Senate in Delaware, setting up a possible face-off with Republican Representative Michael N. Castle.

title: Playing to the (Broadway) Crowd
description: Betty Buckley was at the very top of her game in Tuesdays opening-night program of a four-week engagement at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. The title of her show, For the Love of Broadway!, reflects a slightly chagrined recognition that the majority of her fans, not to mention the managers of Feinsteins, where she appears almost every year around this time, demand theatrical showstoppers, not experiments in pop-jazz, soft-rock and pop-country fusion. For New York audiences at least  Ms. Buckley moved back to Texas, her home state, six years ago  a Broadway diva is whats expected.

title: Oakland Tries to Take On Guns
description: After Tuesday nights City Council meeting, Oakland is one step closer to approving stricter gun control laws.

title: At London Sale, a Giacometti Sets a Record
description: One of Alberto Giacomettis best-loved bronzes, Walking Man I, has broken the world record price for a work of art at auction, selling to an unidentified telephone bidder for $92.5 million, or $104.3 million with fees, at Sothebys in London on Wednesday night. The previous record was $104.1 million, paid for a 1905 Picasso, Boy With a Pipe (The Young Apprentice), at Sothebys in New York in 2004.

title: What Game? Ski Deals for Super Bowl Sunday
