description: One of the best days to hit to slopes may be Super Bowl Sunday. That is because the slopes can be relatively empty. A number of North American ski resorts are now offering discounted passes and ski-and-stay packages. Liftopia, an online ski discounter that acts as a Priceline of sorts for the ski industry, has rounded up 44 deals on resorts across the country, from Copper Mountain out west ($54.99 day pass) to Killington out east ($54.99 day pass).

title: U.S. to Help Banks in Distressed Areas
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department will invest up to $1 billion from the federal bank bailout fund in small banks and credit unions that make loans to small businesses in some of the communities most ravaged by the economic downturn, officials announced on Wednesday.

title: Don DeLillo, a Writer by Accident Whose Course Is Deliberate
description: Don DeLillo, whose new novel, Point Omega, came out on Tuesday, is not exactly a Pynchonesque recluse. He travels, sees friends, gives readings occasionally. People know what he looks like: a slight, reserved man, now going gray, with an intense, serious expression. I only smile when Im alone, he said recently, not smiling.

title: To the Right? The Left? Tough Questions Now for Democrats
description: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats groping for a new strategy on major health care legislation, one crucial question is whether the way forward is to the right or to the left  or would it perhaps be better to just stand still?

title: Emanuel Meets With Disability Groups
description: The White House chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, told advocates for the disabled today that he would sign a pledge to end the use of the word retarded, and promised that the administration would consider legislation to remove the word from federal law, the advocates said.

title: Have a Medical Question? Text a Group of Doctors
description: Patients, journalists, financial analysts, pharmaceutical executives and doctors could at times benefit from having a panel of physicians to whom they could pose questions. Truth On Call, a San Francisco start-up, assembles such a group virtually, by letting people text questions to physicians and then collecting the doctors responses.

title: A Noteworthy Uppercut for a Piece of a Record
description: World records are made to be broken. But some cannot, they can only be equaled. East-West tied a world record in the diagramed deal from a team match.

title: Muscular Moodiness, Paired With Reflection
description: The pianist Radu Lupu appears to have cultivated an unflamboyant, even deliberately unglamorous approach to performing. He sits on a straight-backed chair rather than a piano bench, and his physical gestures at the keyboard are economical and focused, almost matter-of-fact. But Mr. Lupus placidity is deceptive: as an interpreter he is thoughtful and inventive, and given to reconsidering balances, tempos and dynamics in ways that make his readings highly personalized, though never to the point of distorting the music.

title: The Tech Savvy Lend a Hand in Haiti
description: People around the world have been yearning for meaningful ways to help the people of Haiti  and up to now, most have felt powerless to do much more than open their wallets.

title: Memoir of the Sanford Wife
description: Book critic Janet Maslin reviews the new memoir by Jenny Sanford, the estranged wife of Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina.

title: The Camera Is Less Sleek, but the Price Tag Is More So
description: Olympus has announced a new version of its slick-looking PEN Micro Four Thirds camera that is aimed at everyday users with intuitive features and a lower price. The new PEN E-PL1, priced at $600, will include a built-in flash, faster autofocus and graphical interface that will enable casual photographers to easily achieve more sophisticated results.

title: IPad: A Perfect (if Pricey) Plaything for Children
description: Heres why Apple may have created the ultimate plaything:

title: App of the Week: The Phone Call Is Free, but Keep It Short
description: We knew that some day wed be able to make VoIP phone calls over the iPhones 3G network  Apple and AT&T said so.

title: A Rockwell Illustrating a Street-Lit World
description: When Jason Claiborne was a third grader at Public School 187 in Washington Heights, the teacher scolded him for drawing a picture of a naked woman.

title: Is My Windows 32 Bit or 64 Bit?
description: Is My Windows

title: President Touts His Alternative Fuels Plan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama moved on Wednesday to bolster the nations production of corn-based ethanol and other alternative liquid fuels and ordered the rapid development of technology to capture carbon dioxide emissions from the burning of coal.

title: Monster Is Buying HotJobs From Yahoo
description: Monster Worldwide said Wednesday afternoon that it was buying HotJobs, a rival employment Web site, from Yahoo for $225 million in cash. The deals price represents a significant discount from the $439 million that Yahoo paid for HotJobs in 2002.

title: The Pluses, and Oddities, of 3-D TV
description: John Skidmore doesnt care about 3-D TV. Should you?

title: Taking the Initiative
description: It sounded like the makings of a wild scene: For 24 hours, anyone and everyone could show their art, at a major exhibition space in Chelsea (Dias former home, no less). To participate in Bring Your Own Art (B.Y.O.A.), the closing event of the yearlong, not-for-profit X Initiative program, all you had to do was bring your work in anytime after 11 a.m. Wednesday, grab a spot in the galleries, install it, and remove it by 2 p.m. the following day. The description on the X Initiative Web site conjured images of American Idol auditions, or at least of half of Bushwick pitching tents along West 22nd Street.

title: Video Using Riefenstahl Footage Is Withdrawn
description: The organizers of the Vancouver Games withdrew an official video for their Olympic torch relay after the Canadian Jewish Congress and others questioned its use of footage from Olympia, Leni Riefenstahls film of the 1936 Olympics in Berlin.

title: Letterman Show Adds a Female Staff Writer
description: Ending what had been a somewhat embarrassing drought at the big late-night comedy shows, CBSs Late Show with David Letterman has added a female writer to its staff.

title: A Manufacturers Debt to Haiti
description: Nearly 20 years ago, Rawlings Sporting Goods closed its baseball assembly plant in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and completed a move to its other factory in Costa Rica. Rawlings cited Haitis political instability for idling about 1,000 workers.

title: Space: Its Still a Frontier
description: That quote is 40 years old, but I continue to be amazed by the extent to which we havent begun to address the problem Fuller highlighted. Theres a staggering glut of empty space around the country right now, unused space thats not doing anyone much good. That in itself isnt new; what is unprecedented is our ability to visualize that data in an entirely new ways.

title: Poll: Americans Doubtful Health Overhaul Will Pass
description: Most Americans think health care legislation is doomed, according to a survey released Wednesday by the Pew Research Center. But a growing, if still small, percentage of people are becoming more optimistic that it may pass.

title: Correction: Designing to an Afro Beat
description: An article on Dec. 31 about African elements in fashion misstated the date that Yves Saint Laurent introduced a collection of dresses made from raffia, shells and wooden beads. It was 1967, not the 1970s. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Jan. 2; this correction was delayed because editors and the reporter did not follow through on the complaint.

title: Zac Posens Journey
description: New York, before the recession, was a breeding ground for young designers, a phenomenon that can largely be traced to the example of Zac Posen.

title: Sports and SNL Among Muses for Film Festival
description: LOS ANGELES  Apparently the energy level is up in Austin, Tex.

title: Questions for Baptists, Praise for Scientologists in Haiti
description: Last Updated | 10:30 p.m. On Wednesday, as a Haitian judge continued to question 10 Americans whose faith-based mission to Haiti has landed them in legal trouble, the work of volunteer ministers from the Church of Scientology was lauded in a report on American television.

title: Colombian Paramilitaries Successors Called a Threat
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Criminal armies that emerged from the ashes of the Colombian governments attempt to disband paramilitary groups are spreading their reach across the countrys economy while engaging in a broad range of rights abuses, including massacres, rapes and forced displacement, a human rights group said Wednesday.

title: Drawing on Rhythms of Resistance, Adding Resolve
description: Prayers, protests, appeals to conscience and pleas for love filled Nnekas set at S.O.B.s on Tuesday night. Shes a petite firebrand with serious intentions: Its very important that you pay attention to the lyrics, she insisted as one song began. Her message is steadfastness above all: You cant take my soul away, she sang. You cant make me go astray.

title: Moving the Deck Chairs
description: This is a useful and timely book. Joseph E. Stiglitz is one of the two or three score pundits, economists and historians who more or less predicted the disasters that have overtaken the American economy. And as a member of the presidents Council of Economic Advisers under Bill Clinton, he has the political credentials to criticize the new Democratic administration as well.

title: Mexico: Leader of Attack Reported Killed by Soldiers
description: The man who led a weekend attack on teenagers at a birthday party in Ciudad Jurez that killed 16 people was himself killed the next day in a gun battle with soldiers, Chihuahua State officials said Wednesday. The man, who went by several nicknames, including 12, apparently intended to kill everybody in a rival drug gang but shot the wrong people, the state attorney general, Patricia Gonzlez, said in a television interview. One man, who the authorities said acted as a lookout, has been arrested in the attack.

title: Research Groups Report Urges Radical Changes in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A liberal-leaning policy organization that advises President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Wednesday recommended a startling agenda of long-term changes, including restoration of elections for governors, an end to censorship of the news media, Russian membership in NATO and dissolution of the Federal Security Service, successor to the Soviet-era K.G.B.

title: An Eagle That Carefully Plucks Its Feathers
description: I HAVE no problem with the guy riding a horse while wielding a mallet. The crocodile is a gimme, as is the tiger. I can stomach the dangling sheep and the equestrian knight. On a weak day, I can tolerate the crow. I wont even entertain the idea of the skull.

title: U.S. Report Details Money Laundering
description: A suitcase containing $1 million in shrink-wrapped bills, hand-carried into New York by the former president of Gabon for his daughter to buy a Manhattan apartment. Purchases of a stretch Hummer H2 armored limousine and C-130 Hercules military transport planes for a civil war in Angola. And a shell company named Sweet Pink used to funnel millions of dollars into the United States from Equatorial Guinea.

title: Northern Ireland: Minister in Scandal Resumes Post
description: A month after he became embroiled in a sex scandal involving his wife and her teenage lover, Peter Robinson, Northern Irelands first minister, resumed his post on Wednesday. Mr. Robinson, 61, said an investigation by an independent counsel had cleared him of any wrongdoing. The investigation focused on allegations that he had failed to properly report the actions of his wife, Iris, 60, also a prominent lawmaker, in raising $80,000 in loans from property developers to help her 19-year-old companion open a cafe. Mr. Robinsons return to office after a three-week suspension came as the political party he leads, the Democratic Unionists, the majority grouping among the provinces Protestant majority, faces a bitter internal rift over an outline agreement Mr. Robinson reached earlier this week with Sinn Fein, the leading party among Catholics, to transfer power over the provinces police and courts from British officials to the power-sharing government in Belfast.

title: CBS News Lays Off Dozens in New Round of Staff Cuts
description: Dozens of employees at CBS News were laid off in recent days amid a new round of budget cuts at the third-place networks news division.

title: Pfizer Misses Estimates, and Shares Slide
description: Pfizer, the worlds biggest drug maker, said fourth-quarter profit missed analysts estimates on costs from its acquisition of Wyeth and projected lower-than-expected earnings in 2010.

title: Victims From Haiti Arrive in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  One after another after another, the five bright yellow medical stretchers rolled off a C-130 cargo plane and into waiting ambulances. Each carried a severely injured evacuee from Haiti. All were bound for hospitals in the Atlanta area.

title: Defaults Could Fall by Half This Year, Altman Says
description: The good news in the high-yield credit markets is that default rates could fall by as much as half of 2009s near-record levels, Edward I. Altman, the New York University professor who specializes in debt studies, told an audience of restructuring professionals on Wednesday.

title: France: Nationality to Be Denied Over Veil
description: Prime Minister Franois Fillon said Wednesday that he would sign a decree denying French nationality to a man who ordered his French wife to wear the full Islamic veil. This case is about a religious radical: he imposes the burqa, he imposes the separation of men and women in his own home and he refuses to shake the hands of women, Mr. Fillon told Europe 1 radio. If this man does not want to change his attitude, he has no place in our country. In any case, he does not deserve French nationality. The government is examining a ban on the full veil. The mans name was not released.

title: South Africa: Zuma Acknowledges Paternity
description: President Jacob Zuma admitted Wednesday that he was the father of a girl born last October. Mr. Zuma, a polygamist, has three wives, but this baby was born out of wedlock, and allegations that the president had fathered a 20th child have preoccupied the news media in South Africa since the story broke on Sunday. The country has one of the worlds worst H.I.V. infection rates, and Mr. Zuma was criticized for undermining his own governments campaign against unprotected sex and multiple partners. In a statement, Mr. Zuma said he remained dedicated to the H.I.V. and AIDS campaign and sharply criticized the news media for revealing the names of his new daughter and her mother.

title: House Panel Sees Pros and Cons in NASA Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional reaction to President Obamas budget for NASA was divided more along geographical than political lines Wednesday, as members of a House subcommittee debated the merits of scrapping the agencys plans to return to the moon by 2020 and shift, instead, to developing new launching technologies.

title: Rivals Await Blankfeins Bonus at Goldman Sachs
description: Voice-mail boxes inside Goldman Sachs lit up on Jan. 21 with an unusual message from the banks chief executive  a bit of Wall Street speak that sounded like the makings of a book on Zen and the Art of Money-Making.

title: Rebuilding Effort in Haiti Turns Away From Tents
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Shifting tactics in the race to shelter an estimated one million Haitians displaced by the earthquake, aid groups on Wednesday began to de-emphasize tents in favor of do-it-yourself housing with tarpaulins at first, followed by lumber.

title: Shockey Hopeful Burress Will Play Again
description: MIAMI  Twenty minutes into the New Orleans Saints news media availability at their team hotel Wednesday, one question was threatening to drown out any other: Where is Jeremy Shockey?

title: Plenty of Nuts for Sale, but the Roasters Are Vanishing
description: We Are Nuts About Nuts, the awning proclaims, as the classic stainless-steel roaster spins in the window, churning out seven-pound batches of hot almonds, cashews and pistachios, up to 10 times a day. Beyond the glass, bins of macadamias, raisins and pumpkin seeds nestle amid containers of dried fruit, store-made snack mixes and black licorice.

title: Military Officials Say Afghan Fight Is Coming
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO and the Afghan military are about to launch their biggest joint offensive of the war, and they appear to be making sure the Taliban know they are coming.

title: The Morning the Milking Was Finished
description: COPAKE, N.Y.

title: Currency Dispute Likely to Further Fray U.S.-China Ties
description: WASHINGTON  To the growing list of grievances between the United States and China, add one more: the Obama administration is reviving American pressure on China to stop artificially depressing its currency, a policy that fuels its persistent trade gap with the United States.

title: Cutbacks on Wall St. Are Burden for Albany
description: New York State officials staring at holes in the budget this time of year generally have had a trusty cushion to fall back on: a mattress stuffed full of Wall Street bonus money.

title: Pakistani Scientist Found Guilty of Shootings
description: A Pakistani neuroscientist was convicted on Wednesday of trying to kill American military officers while she was in custody in Afghanistan, capping a trial that drew notice for its terrorist implications as well as its theatrics.

title: Few News Conferences, but Still Taking Questions
description: WASHINGTON  Over the last two weeks, President Obama has taken questions from unemployed workers in Ohio, students in Florida and a cancer survivor in New Hampshire. He took questions from YouTube users, Senate Democrats and even House Republicans. Almost everyone, it seems, but the White House press corps.

title: Judge Says State Must Pay Farmers Legal Fees
description: ALBANY  New York State picked the wrong farmer to fight.

title: With Bated Breath, Rivals Await Blankfeins Bonus
description: Voice-mail boxes inside Goldman Sachs lit up on Jan. 21 with an unusual message from the banks chief executive  a bit of Wall Street speak that sounded like the makings of a book on Zen and the Art of Money-Making, Graham Bowley and Zachery Kouwe of The New York Times report.

title: A Street Artist's Home in Offenburg, Germany
description: In his one-bedroom apartment, Stefan Strumbel surrounds himself with the work of other street artists.

title: Yale, With $150 Million Deficit, Plans Staff and Research Cuts
description: Yale University announced on Wednesday that it planned a number of steps to close a remaining $150 million budget gap, including cutting staff, freezing salaries for deans and officers, reducing the number of graduate students  even turning down all thermostats to 68 degrees.

title: Highlights from the Youre the Boss Blog
description: 20,000 Reasons a Company Might Not Want to Hire

title: The Trials of a Former Boy Wonder
description: IT was late into the night last April 30, after a lavish dinner at La Grenouille honoring the 100th anniversary of Cartier, when Zac Posen, the precocious designer, took a seat next to Glenda Bailey, the editor of Harpers Bazaar and the evenings hostess.

title: New-Age Owner Brings the Colts Old-Style Success
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The recording that answers Jim Irsays cellphone is not a standard voice message. It is Irsay singing Singin in the Rain, an allusion to the Super Bowl played in a downpour here three years ago, when Irsays Colts defeated the Chicago Bears.

title: Argentine Bank President Is Formally Dismissed
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina formally dismissed the president of Argentinas central bank on Wednesday and vowed to follow through with her plan to tap $6.59 billion of the countrys reserves to pay down foreign debt, a demand that the bank president had refused to heed.

title: Ex-Leader of Honduras Says Successor Must Hasten Purge
description: MEXICO CITY  At the end of his first week in exile, former President Manuel Zelaya of Honduras said Wednesday that his newly inaugurated successor had done nothing to remove those who carried out the coup that overthrew him in June.

title: National Prayer Breakfast Draws Controversy
description: For more than 50 years, the National Prayer Breakfast has served as a prime networking event in Washington, bringing together the president, members of Congress, foreign diplomats and thousands of religious, business and military leaders for scrambled eggs and supplication.

title: A Big Tent to Benefit a Big Cause
description: WHEN Naomi Campbell calls, designers answer.

title: Mickelson Removes Club, but Is Still Critical of Rule
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif.  The controversy over the use of square-grooved golf clubs, which came to prominence with accusations of cheating and threats of sanctions, began to simmer down Wednesday as the PGA Tour commissioner outlined options for solving the rules loophole that started it all.

title: U.S. Keeps North Korea Off Terror List
description: WASHINGTON   President Obama announced Wednesday that he would not put North Korea back on the State Departments list of state sponsors of terrorism, after a classified study determined that the country does not meet the statutory criteria for that designation.

title: Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra Could Meet at Oaklawn
description: Oaklawn Park officials will announce plans for what they are calling a Race for the Ages at a news conference Thursday.

title: Dick McGuire, a Fixture With the Knicks for More Than Half a Century, Dies at 84
description: Dick McGuire, whose deft ball-handling and passing wizardry led the New York Knicks to three straight National Basketball Association finals, and who then coached and scouted for them in a Hall of Fame career that lasted more than half a century, died Wednesday in Huntington, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Terra Firma Considers Investing More in EMI
description: The British private equity firm Terra Firma is considering asking investors to invest up to an additional 120 million ($191 million) in EMI, the troubled record label it owns, to avoid defaulting over the next year, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Ski Cross Team Takes Hard Bumps Before the Olympics
description: First Casey Puckett aggravated his separated left shoulder. Then Daron Rahlves dislocated his right hip. Suddenly, any chance the United States would win a medal in the debut of ski cross at the Vancouver Games appeared unhinged.

title: Officials Bar Shackling of Juvenile Offenders
description: ALBANY  State officials issued an order this week prohibiting the shackling of the vast majority of juvenile offenders held in state custody after a court ruling that staff at New Yorks youth prisons were routinely violating rules.

title: St. Vincents Gets Loans for a Four-Week Reprieve
description: The financially ailing St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village got a months reprieve on Wednesday, as Gov. David A. Paterson met with hospital officials, elected officials and others to try to keep the hospital from closing.

title: Rye Pretzels
description: 1 (1/4-ounce) package active dry yeast

title: Shockey Supports a Return by Burress
description: MIAMI  Twenty minutes into the New Orleans Saints news media availability at their team hotel Wednesday, one question was threatening to drown out any other: Where is Jeremy Shockey?

title: Dress Codes: Custom
description: Men go for bespoke, from suits to surfboards.

title: City Seeks to Close 15 Day Care Centers in Budget Cut
description: More than a half-dozen gentrified neighborhoods in Brooklyn would lose subsidized day care centers for low-income families under proposed city budget cuts, Bloomberg administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Grifters Tale
description: Judson Phillips is a Tennessee lawyer, specializing in personal injury lawsuits, drunk-driving cases and men who get into trouble beating their wives. It was his idea to incorporate Tea Party Nation as a money-making venture and charge $349 to hear Sarah Palin talk about whats wrong with America over steak and lobster this weekend in Nashville.

title: In an Illinois Primary Race, Victory Is Self-Declared
description: CHICAGO  At a downtown train station where he had been thanking voters for their support, Gov. Patrick J. Quinn accepted a congratulatory call from President Obama and declared victory, even though his challenger in Tuesdays Democratic primary for governor had not conceded defeat and the race was deemed too close to call.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 963 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Custom-Made Is Spreading Far Beyond Savile Row
description: WHEN you think of the man who buys custom-made clothing, you might think of the kind of guy embodied by James Spader in David Mamets new play, Race  that is, a silver-templed lawyer who goes to a custom tailor once a year and buys a couple of new suits, a half-dozen shirts, and calls it a day. You might not think of Mr. Spader himself. So it is a surprise to hear Mr. Spader say he had bonded with Mr. Mamet over custom clothing of a different stripe  specifically, the leather jackets Mr. Mamet had made for the cast and crew of Race by the storied Langlitz Leathers Inc. of Portland, Ore.

title: Riefenstahl Footage In Video Causes Stir
description: The organizers of the Vancouver Games withdrew an official video for their Olympic torch relay after the Canadian Jewish Congress and others questioned its use of footage from Olympia, Leni Riefenstahls film of the 1936 Olympics in Berlin.

title: G.O.P. Group to Promote Conservative Ideas
description: WASHINGTON  A group of prominent Republicans is forming an organization to develop and market conservative ideas, copying a successful Democratic model and hoping to capitalize on the fund-raising and electioneering possibilities opened up by a recent Supreme Court ruling.

title: Obama Offers Pep Talk to Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged Senate Democrats on Wednesday to move beyond a demoralizing defeat last month in Massachusetts and to draw a lesson for their own campaigns as they navigate the difficult headwinds of a midterm election year.

title: Stevensons Misanthrope
description: Special note: The answers to the combined Across clues are anagrams of each other. The order in which the answers in each pair are to be entered in the grid is for you to discover.

title: A Veritable Vision in Five-Inch Heels
description: NEAR dusk on a recent winter Sunday, in a glossy and compact one-bedroom in Hells Kitchen, Michael Lisbona was drying the toe box of a Louis-style mule with a blow dryer. The upper part of the half-made shoe, which had been cut from black kid leather embossed with a delicate silver lace pattern, curled back like the petal of an exotic flower. Llorraine Neithardt, a full-time psychic and part-time shoe guru, clapped her hands and exclaimed: Boy, does that beat mowing the lawn. Look how beautiful  like a little tortellini.

title: Massachusetts Senator-Elect Asks to Speed Swearing-In
description: BOSTON  Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts will probably be sworn into office on Thursday afternoon in Washington, after requesting that his installation be moved up a week.

title: A Bit of Paris in a Brooklyn Bedroom
description: A look inside the bedroom that two designers completely redecorated on a budget of $1,500.

title: Restoration of Loews Kings Theater
description: The lost luster of Loews Kings Theater in Brooklyn, a local film palace, will be restored.

title: A Vision in Five-Inch Heels
description: A Jungian-inspired clairvoyant teaches the art of shoemaking.

title: LaHood Backtracks on Stop Driving It
description: WASHINGTON  Ray LaHood testified before a Congressional panel on Wednesday morning, something he had done many times before, and made points that  he thought  he had made many times before.

title: Admirals Opposition to Gay Policy Was Years in the Making
description: WASHINGTON  As Adm. Mike Mullen had written it, he would tell the Senate committee that allowing homosexuals to serve openly would be the right thing to do.

title: Ex-Senator May Seek Old Seat
description: Former Senator Daniel R. Coats announced on Wednesday that he was taking steps toward making a bid for his old seat in Indiana, potentially giving Republicans a top-tier challenger in the partys bid to unseat Evan Bayh, a Democrat. Mr. Coats authorized supporters to start collecting signatures to put his name on the ballot. Mr. Bayh, a former two-term governor, was elected in 1998 to succeed Mr. Coats, who chose not to seek re-election that year.

title: A Pesky Bedroom, Tamed by Pattern
description: FOR Judith HoSang, a travel industry publicist, redecorating the bedroom she shares with her husband, Robert HoSang, a media buyer for a marketing company, had been an exercise in frustration.

title: Pinstriped Emissaries Seek Fans in China
description: BEIJING  Guo Shuofeng, a 10-year-old fourth grader, is serious about baseball. Since joining his school team two years ago, he spends more than 20 hours a week during the season at practice, sacrificing his weekends and winter vacation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about some evangelical churches that have turned to mixed martial arts to attract young men misstated the age of John Renken, the founder XTreme Ministries, a church near Nashville that doubles as a fight academy. Mr. Renken is 37, not 42.

title: Guru Indicted in 3 Deaths at Arizona Sweat Lodge
description: LOS ANGELES  A New Age motivational speaker who led a sweat lodge ceremony in Arizona last year in which three people died was indicted Wednesday on manslaughter charges despite his claims he did nothing wrong.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about the Detroit Shrine Circuss loss of its home on the grounds of the Michigan State Fair misstated the history of the fair and erroneously attributed a distinction to it. It is 16o years old, not 106. And while it is the oldest continuously operating state fair in the nation, it is not the oldest. At least one other state fair, New Yorks, began earlier but was closed for several consecutive years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in The Caucus column on Tuesday about an announcement by the National Tea Party that it will broadcast the main parts of its convention live on cable television and the Internet misspelled the surname of the writer. She is Kate Zernike, not Zernicke.

title: Chaplain Is Found With Blades at City Jail
description: A Muslim chaplain for the citys Department of Correction showed up for work on Wednesday as he routinely does  entering the city jail in Lower Manhattan to minister to some of the roughly 900 male inmates there.

title: In a Prius Preserve, Shaken Fans
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Here in the countrys environmental hotbed, where plastic bags are banned, composting is mandatory, and even some Yellow Cabs run green, Thursday will dawn with at least eight fewer Toyota Priuses  the eco-friendly status symbol of the hybrid set  on the roads.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Wednesday with an article about an archive of papers that belonged to Grace Tully, Franklin D. Roosevelts last personal secretary, was published in error. While the full photograph does show Ms. Tully, the part that was published showed Roosevelt with another secretary, Marguerite LeHand, known as Missy; Ms. Tully was not shown.

title: Given a Shot, Hughes Gives the Knicks a Boost
description: While assessing his teams recent poor form, Coach Mike DAntoni pointed to the Knicks lack of energy and their defensive neglect as the primary problems.

title: Court Told of Possible Origin of DNA on a Police Baton
description: A baton that the authorities seized from Officer Richard Kern contained a trace of blood in a mix of genetic material that possibly included that of a Brooklyn man he is charged with sexually abusing in 2008, an expert witness testified on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A music column in some copies on Monday about the Grammy Awards ceremony misidentified the song Pink was singing while suspended on a slinglike trapeze. It was Glitter in the Air, not Speechless. (As noted elsewhere in the column, Speechless was performed by Lady Gaga and Elton John.)

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Monday about a program of songs written by Michael Friedman, part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series, misstated, at one point, the title of one of the musicals for which he wrote songs. As noted elsewhere in the review, it is This Beautiful City, not The Beautiful Life.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column last Thursday about the Nielsen estimates of prime-time television audiences on Jan. 26 misstated the difference in the number of viewers of American Idol, on Fox, and NCIS, on CBS. American Idol had about four million more, not three million.

title: Corrections
description: The Second Opinion column on Tuesday, about Henrietta Lacks, who unknowingly contributed cancer cells to medical researchers before her death in 1951, misstated the surname of one of her children at one point. As noted elsewhere in the column, she is Deborah Lacks-Pullum, not Pullum-Lacks.

title: Health Official Cant Guarantee Openness in Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, told Congress on Wednesday that she could not guarantee greater openness in negotiations over legislation to remake the nations health care system.

title: American Lisa and Congolese Lisa
description: My Thursday column is about the war in eastern Congo, looking at the work of Lisa Shannon and her Run for Congo Women. Readers sometimes ask why I often write about outsiders, like Lisa, rather than about the innumerable local people who are doing extraordinary work  often at greater risk. Its certainly true that Congo, for example, has a vibrant and admirable civil society, full of Congolese women themselves organizing against rape and war.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about James H. Quello, a longtime member of the Federal Communications Commission, misstated the given name of the executive director of the communications and society program at the Aspen Institute, who commented on Mr. Quellos tenure on the commission. He is Charles Firestone, not David.

title: Reactionaries? Make That Collectors
description: Beijing

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: On the Schedule for Thursday: More Carolina Blues
description: North Carolina (13-8, 2-4 Atlantic Coast) at Virginia Tech (16-4, 3-3)The hard times have hit Chapel Hill.

title: The Clockmakers Retreat
description: OFFENBURG, Germany

title: Old Dogs, New Tricks
description: Donna Wilson, a British designer, has given Staffordshire ceramic dogs  popular in the 19th century, and still collectible today  a contemporary face-lift. Working with traditional forms from a factory in Stoke-on-Trent, in Staffordshire, she paints a patterned Fair Isle-style sweater on each dog by hand. Her objective is to bring an old design back to life, she said, but with my own kind of handwriting. The dogs, above, which come in pairs (for about $400), can be bought through the Future Perfect  as can some of Ms. Wilsons latest textile designs, which are on display until Feb. 26 at the Future Perfect Manhattan, as part of Friendly + Fresh, a show of furniture and accessories from SCP, a British company. Her contributions include Treecloud knitted lambs-wool poufs ($393 to $723), Nos Da wool throws ($295 each) and the Wilma bench ($875). Information: (877) 388-7373 or thefutureperfect.com.

title: Dwell Gets a Gag Gift on Its Birthday
description: The earnestly modern habitats extolled in Dwell magazine, which celebrates its 10th birthday this year, veered into parody last week, pushed there by a mischievous blog called Unhappy Hipsters (unhappyhipsters.tumblr.com). With its deadpan captions (example below), it ricocheted in the blogosphere like a shuttlecock, as Twitterers like Matthew Yglesias, a political blogger, Andrew Sullivan of The Atlantic and Michele Posner, Dwells own managing editor, thwacked it onward and upward. Original Dwell cast members gleefully sent it back and forth. We did brand the dispassionate hipster, didnt we? wrote Maren Levinson, a former photo editor, to Karrie Jacobs, the departed founding editor.

title: A Different Sort of Bowl Game on Super Bowl Sunday
description: As all you rabid home-furnishing fans know, were just three days away from the big event that will keep you glued to your television this Sunday: the DIY Network Toilet Bowl. One full day of shows like 10 Killer Bathrooms and BATHtastic! hosted by Matt Muenster, a 32-year-old contractor  plus, a sneak preview of Bath Crashers, in which Mr. Muenster, above, waylays shoppers at their local home improvement stores and offers to redo their bathrooms. Mr. Muenster, who once worked in a residential design firm in St. Paul, is clearly the m.v.p. of the Toilet Bowl, and we called him to find out how he got there.

title: Hes 93; Sit Where He Tells You
description: THERE are any number of challenges at a furniture gallery opening: signs on the tables reading, Please Do Not Rest Glass, signs on the chairs reading Please Do Not Sit. And you had better believe there are no price tags hanging off the chairs. These are collectibles, sweetheart.

title: Bowls That Could Double as Hats
description: Michelle Jaff, an artist and designer in Manhattan, makes sculpture from aluminum and steel, plastic and vinyl. She also makes hats out of felt. I take planar, flat materials and make them volumetric, she said. When she designed her first home accessories, the Fjord Collection of nesting bowls, above, she was thinking of going with metal, she said, but decided on felt instead, not just for its warmth, but also for its rich color palette. Ms. Jaff recommends using the little one for small pieces of jewelry, the medium-size one for necklaces and bracelets and the big one for mail. They range in size from 3 to 4 3/4 inches high and come in two color combinations (graphite, gray and orange, left, or navy, lavender and magenta) for $250 a set. Artware Editions, 327 West 11th Street (Greenwich Street), (212) 463-7490 or artwareeditions.com.

title: Cookware and Brown Bags
description: Broadway Panhandler is taking up to 70 percent off selected cookware Feb. 10 to 15 (a 12-inch stainless-steel fry pan with lid by All Clad, originally $180, will be about $80); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434.

title: How to Speak Nanny
description: THE mother was annoyed with her nanny, and she went on the Web to vent. The nanny had fed the children a casserole that the mother had intended to serve for dinner. Now I have to come up with something else, she wrote on a popular site for mothers, exasperation radiating from the computer screen.

title: Saluting Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: For Love of a Bachelor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nations Top Recruit Commits to U.S.C., Then Thinks Again
description: After pondering his college future all day Tuesday, Seantrel Henderson, an offensive lineman who is considered by most analysts to be the nations top high school football recruit this year, lay in the bed of his hotel room in Midtown Manhattan, reflecting on his options. Dozing off after 9 p.m., he was Southern California dreaming after deciding he would play for the Trojans.

title: Top U.S.C. Recruit Is Not Signed Yet
description: Seantrel Henderson, the highly recruited offensive lineman who announced Wednesday that he was going to Southern California, has not signed a letter of intent to play for the Trojans.

title: An American in Congo
description: Five years ago, Lisa Shannon watched the Oprah show and learned about the savage, forgotten war in Congo, played out in atrocities such as mass rape. Today, she's rebuilding lives there.

title: Bloggingheads:  Abortion Kills Reform?
description: Jonathan Cohn, left, of The New Republic and Timothy Noah of Slate discuss the role of abortion in a potential health care compromise.

title: Lee A. Archer Jr., Tuskegee Fighter Pilot, Dies at 90
description: Lee A. Archer Jr., a pioneering black fighter pilot who was credited with shooting down four German planes, three in a single day, when he flew with the Tuskegee Airmen of World War II, died Jan. 27 in Manhattan. He was 90 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Europeans Revitalize Plants to Save Jobs
description: BERLIN  The soaring glass and iron Siemens factory here opened almost exactly a century ago. At first, it churned out electricity turbines, then munitions during World War II before being looted by the Soviets, which required it to be rebuilt at the dawn of the cold war.

title: Safety Group Questions Dodge Dakotas Air-Bag Choice
description: When the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety conducted its most recent tests for roof strength and side-impact protection on five small pickup trucks, the 2010 Dodge Dakota gave the institute a couple of unwelcome surprises.

title: Russia Plans to Promote Technology Innovations
description: MOSCOW  The Russian finance minister on Wednesday floated a new approach to catching up with the West in technology, a problem that has bedeviled the economy here for decades in spite of the countrys rich tradition in science.

title: Essay: A Family History Needs a Family
description: Lance Cpl. Edwin Marrero, U.S.M.C., your past beckons.

title: SXSW Film Festival Lineup
description: This years installment of the South by Southwest film festival in Austin, Tex., once again is promising a diverse mix of films, some from Hollywood, others far from it. Michael Cieply writes about some of the offerings in here. Below is a partial list of the other 119 features showing from March 12-20. Visit the SXSW Web site for a complete list.

title: Health Cares Share of U.S. Economy Rose at Record Rate
description: The recession has increased the nations health care bills, forcing Americans to spend 5.7 percent more for health services and drugs in 2009 than they spent in 2008, according to new projections in a report by the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

title: Microsofts Creative Destruction
description: San Juan Island, Wash.

title: The Defense Budget
description: The cold war has been nearly banished from the Pentagons latest review of military challenges. The Quadrennial Defense Review, released this week, finally catches up with the current world, one where the United States confronts a host of different adversaries on a variety of different battlefields.

title: A Bitter Guest Worker Story
description: A federal agency appears to have collaborated in an effort to silence foreign workers who claimed they were lured here under false pretenses and abused by the company they worked for. The role of Immigration and Customs Enforcement  reported in The Times by Julia Preston  is being investigated by the Department of Homeland Security and the Justice Department.

title: An Unreasonable Delay
description: More than a year into his presidency, President Obamas nominee to lead the Justice Departments Office of Legal Counsel still has not been confirmed by the Senate. Dawn Johnsen, a law professor at Indiana University, is a highly qualified choice, but Republicans have been raising baseless objections and delaying. They owe Mr. Obama a vote on this nomination, and Democratic leaders have a duty to get it done quickly.

title: Some Wine With That?
description: You can get everything you need to make dinner in a New York grocery store, but not the wine to go with it. This is not because grocers are puritanical. They sell beer, wine coolers (a misperceived brew made with malt) and a sugary low-alcohol wine product. You might think its wine, but drink it and you will not make that mistake again.

description: windfall \win(d)-fol\ noun

title: For Vilified Banks, a Pay Cut Might Be the Best Case
description: Bankers have earned themselves a cut in pay. The industry lost credibility because of its crass approach to bonuses last year. For banks to get back on the right foot, compensation in the current financial year needs to be much lower. Its time for governments and regulators to make this happen  and quickly.

title: Communicating with the Unconscious
description: David Corcoran of The Times discusses a new study by The New England Journal of Medicine that suggests it is possible to communicate thoughts while in a vegetative state.

description: Jonathan Schwartz, the last chief executive of Sun Microsystems, has become the first Fortune 200 boss to tweet his resignation.

title: News Quiz | February 4, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: For Vilified Banks, a Pay Cut Might Be the Best Case
description: Bankers have earned themselves a cut in pay, Breakingviews says. The industry lost credibility because of its crass approach to bonuses last year, the publication argues. For banks to get back on the right foot, compensation in the current financial year needs to be much lower. Its time for governments and regulators to make this happen  and quickly, according to Breakingviews.

title: U.S. Report Details Money Laundering
description: A suitcase containing $1 million in shrink-wrapped bills, hand-carried into New York by the former president of Gabon for his daughter to buy a Manhattan apartment. Purchases of a stretch Hummer H2 armored limousine and C-130 Hercules military transport planes for a civil war in Angola. And a shell company named Sweet Pink used to funnel millions of dollars into the United States from Equatorial Guinea.

title: Going to the Dogs?
description: WHO did not renew their sponsorship of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race this year?

title: U.S. to Help Banks in Distressed Areas
description: The Treasury Department will invest up to $1 billion from the federal bank bailout fund in small banks and credit unions that make loans to small businesses in some of the communities most ravaged by the economic downturn, officials announced on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Starts Inquiry Into Brake Problems on Prius
description: DETROIT  No sooner had Toyota dealerships begun to repair accelerator pedals on millions of recalled vehicles than the carmaker said it was considering yet another major recall, this time for problems with the brakes on its Prius hybrid.

title: Pakistan Arrests 35 in U.S. Soldiers Deaths
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani officials said Thursday that they have arrested 35 suspects as part of their investigation into a bombing that killed three American soldiers and four Pakistanis on Wednesday in northwest Pakistan.

title: If the Shoe Fits
description: "If your devotion to the shoe resembles a form of worship ... this will be your temple," writes Llorraine Neithardt on her Web site, "and you, a disciple of the art of shoe making." There's no doubt many women in New York would find divine inspiration in these words. Ms. Neithardt is a full-time psychic  a Jungian-inspired clairvoyant, to be more precise  and a part-time shoe guru. "Since learning the craft," Penelope Green writes, "she has had a shoe art show at Art Basel Miami Beach, inspired the shoe-making subplot of a movie, 'P.S. I Love You,' starring Hilary Swank, and, for the last five months, directed workshops." In her classes, students learn the intricate craft of hand-making footwear, unleashing, as Ms. Neithardt put it, "the shoe within." The results "are fantastical creations of fig bark and rooster feathers, spotted python and blood-red kid leather." A beginners course on mules starts tonight and runs through Feb. 7. Give it a go before moving on to intermediate pumps and the master class in boots. You must bring your own heel, shank and leathers. Basic soles, of the material sort, are provided.

title: Bring It
description: The farewell event for the X Initiative, a nonprofit art consortium that took over the old Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, is a 24-hour marathon titled Bring Your Own Art (BYOA) that started Wednesday at 11 a.m. and ends 24 hours later, at 11 a.m. Thursday. Tell your boss you have a dentist appointment and stop by to see the hodgepodge of an installation or even contribute a creation of your own. As Roberta Smith writes, the rules are easy enough, despite sounding like a recipe for bedlam. Any artwork that anyone brings to 548 West 22nd Street, X Initiatives temporary home, will be displayed in 'BYOA.' A few conditions apply. Small artworks can be carried up the stairs. Bulkier ones must be able to fit  whole or in parts  into Xs passenger elevator. X will provide two ladders; otherwise participants should bring their own tools. One imagines lots of running with hammers. X will be open for the entire run, with bands, musicians and D.J.'s playing in 30-minute segments throughout.

title: Unsound of Music
description: The opening event of the Unsound Music Festival indicates the expansive terrain the series covers, writes Steve Smith: "The Finnish electronica musician Vladislav Delay collaborates with Lillevan, a German video artist; and Sebastian Meissner, a German electronic musician also known as Klimek, joins the exciting Polish new-music quartet Kwartludium in a project inspired by the seminal American punk-rock record label SST." Sound hip enough for you? The experimental-music festival, founded in 2003 and based in Krakow, Poland, presents its first New York incursion Thursday night with the help of several local partner organizations, including Wordless Music, the Bunker, Issue Project Room and the Goethe-Institut New York. It starts at 8:30 p.m. at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center and it's free.

title: Deutsche Bank Reaffirms Rebound With Profit
description: Deutsche Bank reinforced its position as one of the survivors of the global financial crisis Thursday, posting its fourth straight quarterly profit after a record loss a year earlier.

title: Should the Military End Dont Ask, Dont Tell?
description: The nations top two defense officials are  calling for an end to the dont ask, dont tell law, a major step toward allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the United States military for the first time. What do you think?

title: Concerned Over Jobs and Revenue, Wall St. Wanders
description: Investors were cautious on Wednesday as concerns over high unemployment and the ability of businesses to bring in revenue resurfaced, tempering some of the zeal that had marked Wall Street earlier this week.

title: Cutbacks on Wall St. Are Burden for Albany
description: New York State officials staring at holes in the budget this time of year generally have had a trusty cushion to fall back on: a mattress stuffed full of Wall Street bonus money.

title: Data May Unveil German Tax Evaders, Official Says
description: Germanys finance minister warned German tax evaders Wednesday that they risked punishment if their names were found on a CD the government is buying that contains information about Swiss bank customers, The New York Timess Nicholas Kulish reported.

title: A Small-Business Owner Takes His Case to the Top
description: Last week, one entrepreneur had the opportunity to ask President Obama a question that no doubt has been on the mind of many others, The New York Timess Robb Mandelbaum writes. The venue was a town hall meeting in Tampa, Fla., on Thursday, the day after the presidents State of the Union address.

title: Somali Pirates Seize Libyan Vessel
description: A Libyan-owned merchant ship flying the North Korean flag has been hijacked by Somali prates in the Gulf of Aden, according to the European Union naval coalition in the gulf.

title: Bluewashing
description: The accusation that some purveyors of fish are making misleading claims as to the eco-credentials of their wares.

title: President Touts His Alternative Fuels Plan
description: President Obama moved on Wednesday to bolster the nations production of corn-based ethanol and other alternative liquid fuels and ordered the rapid development of technology to capture carbon dioxide emissions from the burning of coal, John M. Broder reports in The New York Times.

title: China Rejects U.S. Complaints on Its Currency
description: BEIJING  A senior Chinese official said on Thursday that China would not bow to pressure from the United States to revalue its currency, which President Obama says is kept at an artificially low level to give China an unfair advantage in selling its exports.

title: Britain Studying High-Frequency Trading
description: The British government is studying the growth of high-frequency share trading to see if regulatory action is needed, the financial services minister, Paul Myners, said on Wednesday.

title: ICE Staff Under Strain to Regulate Itself, Commission Says
description: A review by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission found that the compliance staff at IntercontinentalExchange Futures U.S. was under notable strain that hindered its ability to regulate itself.

title: Imperial Capital Yanks I.P.O.
description: Imperial Capital Group, a boutique investment banking firm, pulled its planned initial public offering Wednesday after failing to drum up enough interest from investors.

title: Movie Gallery Files for Bankruptcy
description: Movie Gallery, the operator of the Hollywood Video rental chain, plans to close 805 poorly performing U.S. stores after falling sales and mounting losses led to its second bankruptcy in three years, Reuters reported.

title: A Parisian Street Artist Comes Indoors
description: Graffiti doesnt belong in museums, says Andr Saraiva. Its all in the act, the result is meant to disappear.

title: China Renews Opposition to Iran Sanctions
description: PARIS  Reflecting a growing catalog of disputes between Washington and Beijing, a senior Chinese official said Thursday that pressure for tighter sanctions against Iran over its nuclear program could block chances of a diplomatic settlement on the issue.

title: Ironwoods I.P.O. Disappoints
description: It may have been one of the most anticipated initial public offerings of a biotechnology stock in years, but Ironwood Pharmaceuticals debut on the public markets was unconvincing, The Boston Globe says.

description: It seems that for the Blankfeins, Goldman Sachs is a family affair.

title: Online Payment Said to Draw Start-Ups
description: The Facebook games FarmVille and Cafe World have Silicon Valley startups racing to create new ways to pay for virtual goods, a market that may reach $3.6 billion by 2012, Bloomberg News writes.

title: British Hedge Manager Banned for Inflating Returns
description: A former hedge fund manager at Britains BlueBay Asset Management has been slapped with a 140,000 ($223,000) fine and banned from the industry for inflating his performance figures.

title: Artificial-Limb Envy
description: Todays idea: Technology and the marketplace have transformed the artificial limb from emblem of hurt and loss into paradigm of the sleek, modern and powerful, an article says. Prosthetics now provoke envy, and a desire for further tissue removal for self-enhancement.

title: Tech Giants Said to Eye Security Acquisitions
description: As tech spending stages a comeback, industry giants like Hewlett-Packard and IBM are expected to scour the security software market for acquisitions that will bolster their share of corporate IT budgets, Reuters reported.

description: Many hedge funds have been enjoying a recent rebound in their fortunes, but it seems the industrys start-ups didnt get the memo.

title: Bank of America Hiring Said to Include Asia-Pacific
description: Bank of America has embarked on a major hiring spree across Asia, aiming to expand in the fast-growing region and revive the investment banking franchise that Merrill Lynch built before the financial crisis.

title: Trump Moves Against Icahns Casino Plan
description: The battle between Donald Trump and Carl C. Icahn over the future of the bankrupt Trump Entertainment Resorts continued Wednesday, as Mr. Trump and his daughter, Ivanka, asked a judge to allow them to vote on Mr. Icahns restructuring plan.

title: Santander Posts Profit on U.K. and Brazil Units
description: Banco Santander, the biggest Spanish bank and one of the largest in Europe, reported a solid rise in year-end profit Thursday, helped by growth in Brazil and Britain and a turnaround at its U.S. unit, Sovereign.

title: For Agent as Famous as His Clients, a New Base of Operation
description: Every month, 13,536 people move out of New York. Bobby Zarem says that this is the month he will be one of them.

title: Sampler: Bottle Boat Sets Sail and Prius Lovers Wonder Whats Next
description: The Death of a Bay Area Philanthropist | Evelyn Haas, whose philanthropy touched many aspects of life in the Bay Area, died Wednesday in San Francisco. She was 92. The widow of Walter A. Haas Jr., Mrs. Haas led the family foundation, the Evelyn and Walter Haas Jr. Fund. It has contributed more than $364 million to a range of community and cultural organizations, including the San Francisco Symphony, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the restoration of Crissy Field. Mrs. Haas wanted to make a tangible difference to peoples lives, said Ira Hirschfield, president of the foundation. It was about leveling the playing field so that all families could live and raise their families with equality and dignity, to make sure all families had an equal chance to enjoy their lives, he said. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Bank of England Calls Halt to Bond Purchase Program
description: Faced with rising inflation and evidence that the country has finally emerged from recession, the Bank of England announced Thursday that it would not extend its massive buying spree of government bonds that was intended as an economic stimulus, Matthew Saltmarsh and Jack Ewing report in The New York Times.

title: Kraft Said to Be Poised for $4 Billion Bond Sale
description: Kraft Foods is planning to sell a minimum of $4 billion in bonds in four parts on Thursday to help finance its $18.7 billion acquisition of the British chocolatier Cadbury, IFR said on Wednesday.

description: Two weeks ago, Charles Isherwood answered readers questions about what makes a good revival, monologue plays and other theater topics. This week Mr. Isherwood tackles questions about the critics responsibility, rude audience members and one of his favorite new playwrights. Here are his responses.

title: Regret Me Nots
description: Buyers remorse is the pits. These days especially, theres nothing worse than seeing that rash purchase collect dust in your closet. So if youre going to fork over some serious fashion dollars, you want a sure thing. For pre-fall, a lot of designers are revisiting 70s classics, which, far from feeling dated, strike me as timeless. 24:7, Tamara Mellons new collection of iconic styles for Jimmy Choo, delivers the perfect wedge  and in cherry red, it feels plucked from the world of Slim Aarons. Salvatore Ferragamos simple frame bag in brown croc manages to be both minimal and luxe  the very definition of understatement. And scarves, an accessory usually reserved for ladies of a certain age, turned up at Lanvin and other pre-fall shows. I love the American folk feel of the pheasants and peacocks on this one from Herms.

title: Investors Fear Europes Woes May Extend Global Slump
description: Just as Americas recession begins to ebb, trouble is brewing in Europe that may prolong a downturn on the Continent and ricochet through the global economy as it struggles toward a recovery.

description: As big solar power plants planned for the desert Southwest remain bogged down in environmental disputes, utilities increasingly are turning to so-called distributed solar rooftop arrays and small photovoltaic farms that can be built close to transmission lines.

description: We Are Nuts About Nuts, the awning proclaims, as the classic stainless-steel roaster spins in the window, churning out seven-pound batches of hot almonds, cashews and pistachios, up to 10 times a day.

description: Daniel Alpert, managing director of Westwood Capital, considers Paul A. Volckers plan for financial regulation and offers this view on how prudential regulation could work.

description: Most of the nations major chain stores began the year on the right foot, with retailers both high-end and low posting better results than a year ago.

title: In Defense of Taylor Swift
description: She may be only 20 years old, but Taylor Swift woke up from her Grammy night celebration with an unpleasant hangover. Though she won four Grammy Awards on Sunday, including one for album of the year for her Fearless, Ms. Swift, the country-music star, was also roundly criticized for her uneven performances on the show, including an out-of-tune duet with Stevie Nicks on the Fleetwood Mac song Rhiannon.

title: Updated: Meeting for Obama and Democrats
description: Update | 11:26 a.m.  The meeting between President Obama and Democratic Congressional leaders is on for 3:45 p.m., and White House officials are stressing that the discussion will be about the overall agenda for 2010, not just about health care.

title: Struggles in the World of Food
description: The Times reports that European officials are increasing pressure for an international ban on the commercial fishing of the endangered bluefin tuna.  In New York,  stores that roast nuts have all but disappeared. And, from Columbia County, Peter Applebome writes a moving Our Towns column about a dairy farmer in financial straits who shot his cows and then himself.

title: Manning Is O.K. With Wearing the Black Hat
description: The Indianapolis Colts may be favored to win Super Bowl XLIV on Sunday, but the sentimental favorite, for obvious reasons, is the New Orleans Saints.

title: Weekly Popcast: The Grammys, Lil Wayne, Orrin Evans and More
description: This week: Jon Pareles reviews Lil Waynes Rebirth; Ben Ratliff discusses Faith in Action by Orrin Evans; and Ben Sisario recaps the 2010 Grammy Awards. Sia Michel is the host.

title: The Abstinence Debate, Cont.
description: As a complement to Hanna Rosins critique of my sex-ed column from the left, heres Maggie Gallaghers critique from the right:

title: Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Read Faster: Libraries Cutting Back Hours
description: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | Lean budget times have hit the New York Public Library in a big way. On Wednesday, the library announced it would reduce hours at two-thirds of its 87 locations in Manhattan and the Bronx and on Staten Island after having its financing from the city chopped by $5.9 million in the mayors latest round of budget cuts. Such a drastic move has not occurred since 2001.

title: Winter Wonder Brand
description: After the Super Bowl, the next sports spectacular to take over television screens will be the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver. Super Bowl Sunday is imperial Rome, all armor and battle formations, while the Olympics are still classical Greece: all torches, wreaths and moral uplift. The Super Bowl is a unique display of American exuberance. The Olympics have a more solemn function: to channel the lethal energies of modern nationalism into a peaceful competition for gold medals.

title: New York Observer to Help Create Las Vegas Weekly
description: The New York Observer is very much a creature of its home town, devoted to telling knowing tales of the citys power structures. When it branched out with a new publication last year, it was not to another city, but to another slice of the Apple  real estate. So whats next?

title: Doctor Demonstrates Dialogue With Vegetative Patients
description: As my colleague Benedict Carey reports in Thursdays New York Times, a team of medical researchers has succeeded in communicating with some patients in what is called a vegetative state, in which they are unable to make any physical motion to indicate that they are conscious.

title: Super Bowl Q. and A. With Judy Battista
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answered from readers on Thursday in the comments box below.

title: Obama Calls for Civility at Prayer Breakfast
description: President Obama urged Democrats and Republicans to not question one anothers motives and to make an effort to move beyond the cynicism and skepticism that has weighed down the politics of Washington, saying: Civility is not a sign of weakness.

title: Big News for Big Love': A Fifth-Season Order
description: Break out the carrot raisin salad and feel free to plant a big wet kiss on the oldest child of your polygamist husbands first wife: HBO has renewed Big Love. The Hollywood Reporter said that the cable channel has officially ordered a fifth season of Big Love, its hit drama about the familial entanglements of a Mormon patriarch (Bill Paxton) and his three wives (Jeanne Tripplehorn, Chlo Sevigny and Ginnifer Goodwin). Now in its fourth season, the show saw ratings for its premiere episode rise 49 percent over that of Season 3 and has maintained its viewership despite competition from the National Football League playoffs and the Grammy Awards. The shows creators, Mark V. Olsen and Will Scheffer, told The Hollywood Reporter that the current season will get deeper and darker, while Season 5 will settle into the storytelling and take the temperature of the marriages. Does that mean well get the old opening credit sequence back too?

title: C.I.C. Approved to Buy Stake in Apax Partners
description: The China Investment Corporation, the sovereign wealth fund that is investing some of the countrys huge foreign currency reserves, has won approval from a British regulator to buy a stake in the private equity firm Apax Partners, an Apax spokesman said Thursday.

title: An Accent on Authenticity
description: The not-so-surprising surprise addition to the best actress Oscar list, Sandra Bullock, has won a bunch of awards this season for playing a sassy Southerner with a heart of gold and hair of platinum in The Blind Side. As Leigh Anne Tuohy, a real-life Memphis matriarch who takes in a near-homeless black teenager and helps him be all he can be, Ms. Bullock sports a lot of jewelry and a bit of twang. The Academy, of course, loves physical transformation. But not all sassy Southerners were enamored with Ms. Bullock. Just for the record, those of us here in Memphis are not necessarily impressed with Ms. Bullocks accent, Susanne Nan Bayes Koenig wrote to the Bagger recently to register a complaint. She sounds like she is from Georgia, where the film was shot. Lovely woman, great work, two states off.

title: Settlement Plan Drafted for Sept. 11 Lawsuits
description: With a firm trial date looming for thousands of lawsuits brought by workers at ground zero against the city, lawyers for both sides are engaged in intensive talks aimed at settling some or all the cases.

title: Organic or Authentic? The Sauls Deli Debate
description: Whats not to like about Berkeleys favorite deli? Why all the kvetching?

title: A Teachers Primer on Climate Action
description: Off and on Ive invited Dot Earth readers to open discussions on books exploring core issues discussed on this blog, and heres the latest, from Anna Haynes, a blogger and longtime Dot Earth comment contributor. (If theres a book out there youd like to discuss, post a comment here or send your pitch to dotearth@nytimes.com.) Below, please read Annas thoughts on a book by Greg Craven, best known for his series of popular videos deconstructing the climate challenge.

title: The Lightness of Being an Olympian
description: While many of the athletes at the Vancouver Olympic Games will count on gravity to do its work as they try to get to the bottom of their racecourses, others will be going in the opposite direction -- up in the air.

title: London Philharmonic Wins a $3.7 Million Judgment in Fraud Case
description: The London Philharmonic, which said it was stung in an embezzlement scam by its finance director, lost far more money than was originally reported. The official, Cameron Poole, was accused in November of taking 357,000, or $570,000, over four years. The Times of London reported on Thursday that a High Court judge had awarded the orchestra a judgment of 2.3 million, or $3.7 million, against Mr. Poole. The police are investigating the case, The Telegraph reported.

title: Vain Glorious | Beyoncs Sweet Smell of Success
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: BofA Sued By Cuomo, but Strikes Deal With S.E.C.
description: Update | 11:54 a.m. More from The New York Timess Louise Story here.

title: Readers Respond to Giacometti Sale
description: What is the value of art? Yesterdays record-breaking sale of Walking Man I, a bronze by Alberto Giacometti for $104.3 million with fees, has revived the age-old question and our readers had plenty to say about it. Most, like snesich from Seattle, were outraged that during a recession an individual would pay such a huge sum for a sculpture. Am I the only one who finds it morally and ethically repugnant that an unidentified telephone bidder has the disposable income to pay $92 million for a work of art in a world where almost half of the human race lacks decent drinking water and sanitation? A few, like John from Westport, Conn., countered, Its worth what someone is willing to pay. And others, like suzing from Baltimore, tried, with a little humor, to put the price in context: A steal at half the price of Avatar. Whats that tell you? Read more remarks from readers below and share your own.

title: Pulled From Festival, Chinese Film Disappears From Film Forum
description: Update | 2:52 p.m.  Planned showings of a Chinese movie that was abruptly pulled last month from the lineup at the Palm Springs International Film Festival have been canceled at Film Forum, which will instead show a documentary about the Dalai Lama that provoked the other movies withdrawal in Palm Springs.

title: Room for Debate: Federal Role in College Costs
description: Room for Debate, a Times forum that describes itself as a running commentary on the news has taken up a subject on which The Choice has focused all week: federal education aid for low-income college students and the potential impact of the Obama administrations proposals on higher-education costs (as well as the ability of families to pay them).

title: Dungy Says Super Bowl Wont Be Close
description: MIAMI  As predictions pour in, it should come as no surprise that Tony Dungy, the former Colts head coach, is choosing Indianapolis.

title: House Passes Cybersecurity Bill
description: Update | 12:46 p.m.  The House today overwhelmingly passed a bill aimed at building up the United States cybersecurity army and expertise, amid growing alarm over the countrys vulnerability online.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Last-Minute Wins for Senators and Oilers
description: On Wednesday the Columbus Blue Jackets, languishing in next-to-last place in the West, fired head coach Ken Hitchcock. The Jacks were idle on Wednesday, but 10 other teams played, led by Sabres-Senators in a northeastern battle. Home teams listed first:

title: With Three Letters, a New Name for Cyclones Home
description: Sports traditions die easy these days. Hardly had Brooklyn Cyclones fans developed a sentimental attachment to their home field of KeySpan Park in Coney Island when KeySpan, the utility formerly known as Brooklyn Union Gas, got gobbled up by a British power superpower, National Grid.

title: Israeli Minister Adds Heat to Exchange With Syria
description: JERUSALEM  Israels blunt-talking foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, warned Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, on Thursday that the Assad family would lose power in any war with Israel, ratcheting up bellicose exchanges between the countries in recent days.

title: Gerard Schwarz to Wear Many Hats in Farewell Season at Seattle Symphony
description: Gerard Schwarz will bow out after 26 years as music director of the Seattle Symphony with a bang. The orchestra said on Thursday that next season, his last, would open with Mr. Schwarz conducting a concert featuring his son Julian playing the world premiere of a cello concerto by Samuel Jones and a work by the conductor himself, The Human Spirit. The program also includes Gerard Schwarzs own arrangement of a suite from Der Rosenkavalier by Strauss. And the 2010-11 season will close with a performance of Mahlers Symphony No. 2, The Resurrection.

title: India Offers to Resume Talks With Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI  India has proposed high-level talks with Pakistan, the first of their kind since the attack on Mumbai by Pakistani militants in November 2008, but Pakistan has not yet accepted the invitation and is seeking clarification about what will be up for discussion.

title: Dont Go Buying a Boat
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: President Obama is getting more angry criticism today. Boy, this guy cant get a break. Apparently, though, he told a group of high school kids in New Hampshire, and I quote: When times are tough, you tighten your belts. You dont go buying a boat when you can barely pay your mortgage. You dont blow a bunch of cash in Vegas when youre trying to save for college. You prioritize. And needless to say, people in Vegas are extremely upset. In fact, the mayor of Las Vegas said the president is not welcome in Las Vegas. I happen to agree with the mayor. How dare the President tell high school kids not to blow their college money in Las Vegas. Were in a recession right now. What about Siegfried? What about Roy? What about their tigers? The tigers cannot survive on eating magicians alone. They need money.

title: Think Twice About Unlimited Calling Plans
description: Last month, Verizon and AT&T announced that they were cutting the prices on their unlimited cellphone calling plans to $70 a month from $100.

title: Just About Scoring Points
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: During a town hall meeting in New Hampshire yesterday, President Obama said that using stimulus money to help schools is not sexy, but its making a difference. Oddly enough, thats the same way he describes Nancy Pelosi.

title: Get Them to Pass the Dip
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: President Obama is having a big Super Bowl party. This is very shrewd. He has invited a group of Republicans to come to the White House for his Super Bowl party. Hes going to seat the you lie guy next to the not true guy.

title: Her Whole Ordeal
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: President Obama has announced his administrations plan to build a new $8 billion high-speed rail system. Have you ever ridden on Amtrak? We cant figure out how to keep a low-speed rail system from crashing, O.K. Do you really want to go off the track at 150 miles an hour?

title: Cuomo Sues Bank of America, Even as It Settles With S.E.C.
description: The legal drama surrounding the controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch by Bank of America, one of the pivotal moments of the financial crisis, took a fresh turn on Thursday as the attorney general of New York leveled civil fraud charges against Kenneth D. Lewis, the former Bank of America chief who masterminded the deal.

title: Democrats Sketch Outline of Jobs Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democratic leaders unveiled a new jobs agenda on Thursday morning, and said they hoped to hold a first vote on the legislation early next week. But they offered no details, and presented only a scant outline of proposals they might pursue, some of which echo initiatives they failed to include in last years stimulus bill.

title: Answers About Canine Devocalization
description: Following are the responses from Sharon Vanderlip, a doctor of veterinary medicine, who answered readers questions about the procedure.

title: A Little Love for Short Films
description: Amid the excitement of the Oscar nominations announced on Tuesday, the animated and live action short film nominees may have escaped your attention, but not that of some movie executives, who are taking their commercial possibilities very seriously. At the IFC Theater in New York, last years program of Oscar Shorts holds the record for the biggest single-screen, opening weekend revenues, bringing in $24,006.

title: Crumbling Europe?
description: The worry du jour is the Iberian peninsula  Spain and Portugal. Greece is at least temporarily set aside. Watch for Ireland and Italy to join the list at some point.

title: Operatic Style Designed to Suit Your Living Room
description: AT the end of La Bohme, as Puccini envisioned the opera, the frail seamstress Mimi dies in bed in a garret overlooking the rooftops of Paris, attended by only her five bohemian cronies. As seen live on Swiss television in September, she boarded an empty bus from a curb outside a shopping mall, leaving not only her friends but an indeterminate number of onlookers. Then the bus pulled away, pursued for a time by her stricken lover Rodolfo until he collapsed on the pavement.

title: The Saints Turnaround
description: In the chronology of pre-Super Bowl hype, apparently Thursday is All Saints Day, or at least Mostly Saints Day. Perhaps it is in reaction to three solid days of obsession over the swollen appendage of Colts defensive end Dwight Freeney (Hes walking on the beach!), and we are restoring some sort of cosmic balance. You will need to hide in a cave with no wireless access to avoid analysis of the Saints entire legacy.

title: Sales of the Smart Fortwo Plummet
description: When it comes to plunging car sales, all eyes have been on Chrysler. Car sales at the company now managed by Fiat dropped 44 percent in 2009 compared with 2008.

title: Fund Manager Led Investigators to Galleon Informant
description: Prosecutors revealed at a sentencing hearing for a former hedge fund manager on Thursday that he helped investigators turn David R. Slaine into a key informant in the Galleon Group insider trading case.

title: Thumb Tribe
description: Term used in Asia to describe avid users of cellphones and other handheld gizmos.

title: Q&A: A Fall Family Gathering in Italy
