description: Q.

title: Top U.S. Commander Sees Progress in Afghanistan
description: ISTANBUL  The senior commander of American and allied forces in Afghanistan offered a guarded but unexpectedly upbeat assessment of the war effort on Thursday, saying that while the situation remained dangerous it was no longer deteriorating, and that the stage was set for real progress.

title: Nine Oscar Nods for The Hurt Locker? Tell Us What You Think
description: A movie set in Iraq, The Hurt Locker, has been nominated for nine Academy Awards. It leads the Oscar field alongside James Camerons 3-D blockbuster Avatar, about a paraplegic ex-Marine waging war on the distant moon Pandora.

title: Dodd Denounces Pace of Banking Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  Executives at Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase expressed misgivings on Thursday about the Obama administrations new proposals to restrict the size and risk-taking of the countrys largest financial institutions.

title: Kids, Divorce and a Move
description: Sandy is moving in a few months. She and her longtime companion have run out of job options in their relatively small hometown and have decided to leave for a larger city, where they will each have better odds.

title: The Nifty 50 | Paul Schneider, Actor
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: When the Patient Cant Afford the Care
description: During my training, I took care of a man in his 50s with a devastating surgical complication: His abdominal incision had split open a week after an emergency operation. Even after we had taken him back to the operating room, sewn the deepest layer of his abdominal wall closed and treated the infection that had caused his wound to fall apart in the first place, he still had a three-inch long crevice along the middle of his belly. Until the edges contracted and the gaping expanse filled in on its own, he and his wife would have to pack damp gauze into the wound every day to keep it clean and help it heal.

title: Britain Mulls Energy Market Reforms
description: Britain has unveiled a menu of sweeping policy proposals that could see the government nationalizing its energy sector in an effort to meet renewable energy portfolio standards and attract more investment in energy supplies over the next decade.

title: Why We Make Home Videos
description: From time to time, I write about data rot: the distressing tendency of our recordings and computer files to become inaccessible as it's orphaned by new technology.

title: When Patients Cant Afford Their Care
description: In todays Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the economic reality of medicine, and the fact that sometimes, patients cant afford to do whats best for them. She tells the story of a patient who had been cleaning a wound less frequently than prescribed because he couldnt afford the necessary supplies.

title: Why We Make Home Videos
description: Update | 4:28 p.m. Correcting source of the quotation on the unexamined life. (Thanks to my erudite readers.)

title: Jacksons Doctor Is Negotiating Surrender
description: Conrad Murray, the personal doctor who was with Michael Jackson when he died, may soon surrender to the authorities in Los Angeles to face charges related to the singers death. Dr. Murray injected Jackson with the anesthetic propofol and the anti-anxiety drug lorazepam, causing his death, according to the Los Angeles County Coroners office, which has ruled it a homicide. Although prosecutors have not announced any charges against Dr. Murray, his lawyer, Ed Chernoff, said in a statement on Thursday that he is negotiating with the District Attorneys office the surrender of Dr. Murray. Details have not yet been agreed on, the statement said. Randal C. Archibold has more here.

title: The Flash Bangs Are Stilled
description: On a policy note, the Police Department has basically stopped using concussion grenades.

title: Concession in Illinois Governor Primary
description: CHICAGO  With his primary challengers concession, Gov. Patrick J. Quinn became the undisputed Democratic nominee for governor on Thursday, and said he wanted to get past the campaigns negativity and work together with fellow party members toward victory in November.

title: Brazils Romi Offers to Buy Rival for $90 Million
description: The Brazilian machine tool maker Industrias Romi submitted an unsolicited all-cash offer on Thursday to buy Hardinge, a rival based in Elmira, N.Y., for $90 million, saying it is prepared to take its offer directly to Hardinges shareholders.

title: Playing With Pictures
description: Images from an exhibition of Victorian photocollage at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Hackers Hit Europes Carbon Market
description: The latest setback for carbon trading has come from cyberspace.

title: Haiti Charges Americans With Child Abduction
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Ten Americans who tried to take 33 Haitian children out of the country last week without the governments consent have been charged with child abduction and criminal conspiracy, as Haitian officials sought to reassert judicial control after the Jan. 12 earthquake.

title: Former Assemblyman Sentenced to Six Years
description: Updated, 1:49 p.m. | Former State Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio of Queens, who prosecutors said took hundreds of thousands of dollars in payoffs from people and organizations that had business with the state, was sentenced Thursday morning to six years in prison by a federal judge in Manhattan.

title: Fall Out Boy Decaying in Public
description: At a presentation for MTV on Tuesday afternoon, Pete Wentz, the telegenic bassist of the rock band Fall Out Boy, cracked a few jokes about his marriage to the pop singer Ashlee Simpson-Wentz and his status as a Mr. Mom. Now it looks like he may have even more free time on his hands as public squabbling among his bandmates suggests the group has gone on hiatus or broken up all together.

title: U.S. Scientists Given Access to Cloud Computing
description: The National Science Foundation and the Microsoft Corporation have agreed to offer American scientific researchers free access to the companys new cloud computing service.

title: A Plug of the Leak
description: Theres good news for the Academy on the piracy front. (Boy. How long have we been waiting to write that sentence?) Andy Baio, a technology guru and writer from Portland, Ore., has been tracking the availability of digitally ripped copies of Oscar-nominated movies since 2003, and reports that this year the tide may be turning.

title: Heskey, the England Striker Who Doesnt Score
description: Commentators in the English media often bemoan the national teams lack of elite strikers. Manager Fabio Capello has tried Jermain Defoe, Peter Crouch, Gabriel Agbonlahor and Darren Bent as partners to the mercurial Wayne Rooney. And then there has been the long-running saga about whether or not to recall Michael Owen for the World Cup in South Africa.

title: Explaining the Power of Open-Book Management
description: Let me tell you about Ellen Rohr, whom I had a chance to speak with recently. As Ms. Rohr would tell you herself, it wasnt that long ago that she didnt know how to balance a checkbook  even though she finished at the head of her class when she graduated from college with a degree in business administration.

title: 36 Hours in Istanbul
description: FROM a skyline featuring both minarets and church spires to the call to prayer competing with lounge music in a hip cafe, Istanbul is the only major city to span two continents. While it is known for sights dating back thousands of years, it also has a fascinating, and often ignored, contemporary scene that is finally receiving international attention. As a 2010 European Capital of Culture, the city is showcasing local artists in both historic areas and new museums  yet another example of how Istanbul is among the worlds most visually stimulating cities.

title: No Pun Aptly Describes Fiorinas Sheep Ad
description: Within the last day, some people in political circles have watched and mocked this video ad by Senate candidate Carly Fiorina slamming her primary opponent, Tom Campbell. A demon sheep, other odd imagery and creepy music have prompted many to ask whether this isnt the worst campaign ad so far in this midterm cycle. (Of course, its only early February.)

title: Coroner Says Brittany Murphy Died of Pneumonia
description: Brittany Murphy, the Clueless and 8 Mile actress, died of pneumonia, though anemia and prescription drugs factored into her death, the Los Angeles County Coroners office said on Thursday.

title: Questions for Pippo Delbono
description: PARIS  The Italian actor and director Pippo Delbono has long had a cult fan base in Europe and South America - a following that expanded last year when he won the prestigious European Prize for New Theater. (Previous recipients have included Peter Brook and Ariane Mnouchkine.)

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) The best places to die in 2010, based on which states have estate and/or inheritance taxes. Residents in New Jersey and Maryland who are the brink might want to think about moving.

title: State Street to Pay $313 Million in Bond Case
description: State Street said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $313 million in penalties and restitution to settle charges by federal regulators and Massachusetts officials that it had misled investors about their exposure to subprime mortgage-backed securities in one of its bond funds.

title: Dangerous Books
description: I was one of those dads who snatched up The Dangerous Book for Boys a few years ago, seduced by its nostalgia for a simpler time, when kids climbed trees and tied knots and made drone aircraft out of paper. The authors, Conn and Hal Iggulden, grew up in the 1970s and 80s, but the world of their book felt more like the 1950s, or the 1850s. (Maybe you know: Were there paper airplanes before there were airplanes?)

title: The Art of Being Santa Fe
description: I CANT remember how or why it came to be dawn when I first saw Santa Fe from a bus window. It was my first time in New Mexico, the fulfillment of a long-held dream: to visit the land that had inflamed my imagination when as a teenager Id read D. H. Lawrences paeans to the state.

title: Now Visiting | Museum of Small Things
description: When Chicago-born Harry Gordon Selfridge opened Selfridges department store in London in 1909, he wasnt thinking small  the original architect drawings show the Oxford Street shop topped with a dome that rivals that of St. Pauls. (It was nixed before construction began, but a colonnade of impressive looking Doric columns adorns the buildings facade). A pioneer of the shopping-as-entertainment school of retailing, Selfridge was all in favor of using culture to get shoppers through his doors. So while the latest exhibit to go up in the stores gallery space, the Museum of Small Things (MOST), may sound like, well, small potatoes, he would no doubt have approved. Conceived of in collaboration with the artist and designer Kit Grover and POCKO, MOST celebrates the tiny and the trifling. We left the definition of small up to the artists, Grover says. So it can mean something minuscule or something thats generally ignored or thought of as insignificant. The exhibit is arranged in the form of a labyrinth, with a rotating eight-foot head created by the Japanese artist Kin Pro at the center. Kind of like a Macys float, but not from this planet, Grover says. We wanted to play with scale. You cant see all of it as you approach it, so you feel like youre being peered in on by someone very large  and youre miniature. Also included in MOST are a bag by Grayson Perry (limited-edition replicas are available at the exhibit pop-up shop), a Richard Wentworth dictionary (of small, of course) and several films, including I Met the Walrus, which features a soundtrack of an interview a teenage fan did with John Lennon in the 1960s paired with animation by James Braithwaite.

title: Off the Menu: The Meatball Shop
description: Andrew Carmellini made it safe for chefs to crank out meatballs. But it took Michael Chernow and Daniel Holzman, childhood friends who ended up working in restaurants, to open a cafe on the Lower East Side that revolves entirely around meatballs.

title: Obamas Aunt Returns to Court; Fights Deportation
description: Updated, 6:45 p.m.: BOSTON  An immigration hearing that could lead to the deportation of Barack Obamas aunt ended without a resolution today.

title: Jacksons Doctor Negotiating With Prosecutors
description: LOS ANGELES  A lawyer for the doctor who was treating Michael Jackson at the time of his death said Thursday that the doctor planned to surrender to face charges.

title: Annual Sub-$300 Camera Roundup
description: David Pogue tests nine point-and-shoot cameras that cost less than $300.

title: Honda Opens New Solar Hydrogen Station in California
description: When it comes time to refuel Hondas FCX Clarity fuel-cell car with hydrogen, the company is letting the sun shine in.

title: Evidence Builds on Color of Dinosaurs
description: Until last week, paleontologists could offer no clear-cut evidence for the color of dinosaurs. Then researchers provided evidence that a dinosaur called Sinosauropteryx had a white-and-ginger striped tail. And now a team of paleontologists has published a full-body portrait of another dinosaur, in striking plumage that would have delighted that great painter of birds John James Audubon.

title: Indianapolis Mayor Reflects His City and Its Team
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.

title: Sweat Lodge Leader Is Indicted in Deaths
description: LOS ANGELES  A New Age motivational speaker who led a sweat lodge ceremony in Arizona last year in which three people perished appeared in an Arizona courtroom in handcuffs and waist chains on Thursday to face charges of three counts of manslaughter. His attorney said he would plead not guilty.

title: Shani Davis, on Edge
description: As Shani Davis approached the starting line for a World Cup race in November, at an ice oval in the Dutch town of Heerenveen north of Amsterdam, a marching band that was circling the arena stopped playing, and the festive crowd  many of them dressed from head to toe in orange, the national color  roared in anticipation. Davis, who is 27 and poised to become one of the most decorated Winter Olympians ever to compete for the United States, is like an American jazzman in the 1950s  little known and poorly compensated at home but beloved in certain parts of Europe. Here, they understand his sport and perhaps, on some level, even Davis himself, who accumulates grievances and clings to them as if they were first-place medals. We can see that Shani is someone who lives for speed skating, and we dont care so much about all the rest of it, Irene Postma, a Dutch journalist who covers the sport, told me as we waited for the race to begin. And he is so perfect, so beautiful when he races. I would know him just by his silhouette.

title: Seeing Things | Welling and Whiteread In L.A.
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

title: Google Asks Spy Agency for Help With Inquiry Into Cyberattacks
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has turned to the National Security Agency for technical assistance to learn more about the computer network attackers who breached the companys cybersecurity defenses last year, a person with direct knowledge of the agreement said Thursday.

title: Photo of the Week
Finding College Spirit, Off the Quad
description: Ah, college. A time when your most pressing engagement was getting to a game of flip cup before the last keg was tapped. New York has some of the best universities in the country, though urban campuses sprawled across apartment buildings just do not seem to have that collegiate feel. But with a little resourcefulness, visitors to Morningside Heights, the home of Columbia University, can relive their college days  as jock, prep or even nerd  without any hefty tuition.

title: Podium
description: Heres one safe prediction for the Winter Olympics: Competitors and commentators will use podium as a verb, as in, She can definitely podium here today. And just as predictably, some observers will shudder at the word.

title: The Morning Skate: Hitchcock Fired and Witt Waived
description: Every Wednesday evening in Columbus, Ohio, the local sports radio station 97.1 The Fan broadcasts The Coachs Show, featuring Blue Jackets Coach Ken Hitchcock. Last weeks show (audio), with Kings Coach Terry Murray, was quite interesting. I think our philosophies are similar, Hitch said of Murray, who was his assistant coach in Philadelphia. We both believe in structure and discipline, we both believe in accountability with the players, and I think both of us feel like the game should be played a certain way.

title: Take 5: Independent Films, a Childrens Performance and a Saxophone Quartet
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered:

title: Inside the List
description: GATORS GONE WILD: Punxsutawney Phil, the celebrated groundhog meteorologist of western Pennsylvania, may be predicting a long winter, but Tim Dorseys Gator A-Go-Go, new at No. 16 on the hardcover fiction list, is already off on spring break. Dorsey is a Hawaiian-shirted former reporter and editor for The Tampa Tribune. Gator A-Go-Go is the first of his 12 acid-splashed Florida crime capers (Atomic Lobster, Nuclear Jellyfish) to make the list. This time, the discerning serial killer Serge Storms (his credo: People need to be killed, but not randomly) cruises from Panama City to Daytona Beach to Fort Lauderdale filming a Girls Gone Wild-style documentary as dead bodies pile up along the way. I love everything about spring! Serge exults. Reeks of hope, new lease on another year, blooming possibilities, lush beds of violet wildflowers along the Interstate, natures annual spring migration: whooping cranes, manatees, Canadians.

title: G.O.P. Leader Questions Obamas Outreach
description: Almost a week after President Obama and House Republicans had their therapy session in Baltimore, its fair to say relations still seem a bit strained.

title: The Streets Are Safe (From Whimsical Bike Racks)
description: Back in August of 2008, the Department of Transportation unveiled nine site-specific bicycle racks designed by the artist, musician and seemingly ubiquitous cyclist David Byrne. There was a dollar sign for Wall Street, a red high-heeled shoe for outside the Bergdorf Goodman department store on Fifth Avenue, a coffee cup for the Upper West Side near the Hungarian Pastry Shop and others at least as quirky.

title: Should the Sex Offender Be Invited?
description: I am thinking about organizing a 30th reunion for my elementary-school graduating class. One classmate is a registered sex offender whose presence may discourage other people from attending, especially with their kids. Should I invite him? Make the event adults only? Inform others of his offense? Public records show that his misdeed was committed 13 years ago. He received probation, and theres no indication of any subsequent crime. I would regret excluding him or violating his privacy, but Id feel bad withholding information that other classmates might want. What to do? NAME WITHHELD, TEXAS

title: Manhattan, as Seen From Hollywood
description: WITH the new season of 24, which is set in New York, Hollywood is again redrawing the map of the city, extending the longstanding practice of indulging in addresses that cant be real, juxtapositions that dont exist and police precincts that are pure fiction (the 12th of Barney Miller, the 15th of NYPD Blue, the 27th of Law & Order).

title: On Amazon, Buy Buttons Still Off for Some Macmillan Titles
description: Talk about a drawn out surrender.

title: Into the Wild in Lush Guyana
description: WEARING both hiking boots and nightclothes, blearily rubbing the sleep from our eyes, we jerked and bumped our way by jeep across the Rupununi savannah of southwestern Guyana. As the sun rose over the Kanuku Mountains, we passed sinewy cattle, plump black vultures and giant Jabiru storks hunched like skinny old men.

title: Throwback Skiing: No Heated Gondolas
description: A HALF-DOZEN children were waiting to hang onto a rope tow that would pull them up Mount Prospect, a small ski hill in Lancaster, N.H. I watched them scoot along before I, too, grabbed onto the rope, which, despite temperatures in the teens, felt hot from the friction.

title: Hotel Review: The Kensington Hotel in London
description: THE BASICS

title: Restaurant Review: Derrire in Paris
description: Derrire, a clandestine restaurant in the heart of the Marais, may be the only spot in Paris where nonsmokers will want to steal away for a puff. Its second-floor fumoir  made necessary by a two-year-old smoking ban  is also hidden, like a tobacconists speakeasy, behind a false door (more on that later).

title: Axels of Evil
description: If dreams dont express repressed emotions, maybe YouTube does. Remember those online videos from 2006 that added the Brokeback Mountain score to clips from movies like Titanic and Fight Club? You can still find many of them on YouTube. They seem to uncover a hidden gay love story in nearly every American blockbuster.

title: White House Unveils Plan to Double U.S. Exports
description: WASHINGTON  The administration on Thursday unveiled its new strategy to make good on President Obamas promise to double American exports in the next five years. The approach included pledges to pursue more trade agreements, increase pressure on trading partners to open markets and the creation of an export promotion cabinet.

title: The Regulatory Landscape for Private Equity
description: The time for regulatory reform is nigh. The bulk of attention is directed at financial institutions and addressing systemic risk, but private equity is being caught in the regulatory wave. Current regulatory proposals have the potential to change the way private equity conducts business both domestically and internationally. Here are some of the significant issues:

title: Hospital Chain Withdraws St. Vincents Offer
description: A large hospital chain that offered to take over the nearly bankrupt St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village has formally withdrawn its offer, further harming the hospitals prospects for survival.

title: An Ethnic Mix Keeps It Funky in Chicago
description: HOW does Rogers Park, a neighborhood on the northern edge of Chicago, stay funky? The secret is geography. The area lies beyond the end of Lake Shore Drive; most east-west streets dead-end into beaches, and theres no quick way to get downtown.

title: Dodd Assails Bankers Opposition to Overhaul
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee told Wall Street representatives on Thursday that the financial services industry had sent an army of lobbyists whose only mission is to kill the common-sense financial reforms needed by the public.

title: The Best Weight for the Best Workout
description: In her latest Personal Best column, Gina Kolata explores how what you weigh can affect your workout. She writes:

title: Seeking Your Inner Federer, if the Muscles (Groan!) Allow
description: Wesley Chapel, Fla.

title: An Inn Is an Oasis From Environmental Affronts
description: Adams, Mass.

title: Is This Headline Clear? Learning About Ambiguity and Clarity From Headlines
description: Overview | What is the purpose of headlines? What factors sometimes render them ambiguous, confusing or misleading? What role does grammar play in clarity? In this lesson, students review and revise ambiguous headlines to make them clearer, consider what makes headlines effective and generate tips and guidelines. Various related activities are provided for journalism, English language arts and English language learning.

title: Answers From a Yoga Instructor, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Bryn Chrisman, a vinyasa flow yoga teacher and kirtan leader in New York City.

title: South Ossetians Warn Against Rearming Georgia
description: MOSCOW  Residents of South Ossetia, the tiny separatist enclave at the center of the August 2008 war between Georgia and Russia, petitioned United States Senator Richard G. Lugar on Thursday to warn against supplying the Georgian government with weapons, saying they could be used against civilians.

title: Communicating With a Patient in a Vegetative State
description: This week, The New England Journal of Medicine reports on a fascinating study involving a car accident victim who remains in a persistent vegetative state. Using magnetic resonance imaging technology, doctors have been able to communicate with him.

title: Dreaming of a White Olympics
description: As a novelist and social critic who lives in Vancouver and whose guidebook, City of Glass, chronicles such local concerns as Highway 99, cruise ships, drug addiction and homelessness, were you surprised when you were asked to contribute an essay to the official Olympics brochure? I was surprised, because Im not an athlete. I thought there must be someone who is a super athlete as well as a writer.

title: Answers About Roth I.R.A. Conversions: Part 8
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Answers to Questions About Prius and the Toyota Recalls
description: Here are some answers to questions about the recent problems at Toyota:

title: Democrats Question Comcast on NBC Deal
description: Concerns about fair access to TV programming dominated the first day on Thursday of Congressional hearings on the proposed combination of Comcast and NBC Universal.

title: Romanians Accept Plan for Basing of Missiles
description: MUNICH  Romanias top defense body approved an American proposal to base missile interceptors there, the countrys president said Thursday in a hastily arranged announcement.

title: Berkshire Loses Last Triple-A Rating
description: Standard & Poors stripped Berkshire Hathaway of its last triple-A credit rating on Thursday after Warren E. Buffett, the companys chief executive, agreed to buy the railroad operator Burlington Northern Santa Fe.

title: Finding College Spirit, Off the Quad
description: Ah, college. A time when your most pressing engagement was getting to a game of flip cup before the last keg was tapped. New York has some of the best universities in the country, though urban campuses sprawled across apartment buildings just do not seem to have that collegiate feel. But with a little resourcefulness, visitors to Morningside Heights, the home of Columbia University, can relive their college days  as jock, prep or even nerd  without a hefty tuition.

title: Life After a Child Dies
description: There is no word in the English language for a parent who loses a child. When our parents die we are orphans. When our spouse dies, we are widowed. When a child dies we are speechless.

title: Mamets Life in the Theater Getting New Life on Broadway
description: For an anti-establishment guy, David Mamet is certainly getting comfortable with Broadway. Revivals of his plays Speed-the-Plow, Oleanna and American Buffalo have recently been presented there (some lasting longer than others), his latest work, Race, continues to run there, and now a revival of his early play A Life in the Theater is headed to the Great White Way. On Thursday, the producers Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Steve Traxler (who were also behind Race) said that a new staging of A Life in the Theater would come to Broadway this fall. Neil Pepe, the artistic director of the Atlantic Theater Company, is to direct; Mr. Mamet is a founder of the company. The play, about the evolving relationship between a young actor and his older mentor, was first performed in 1977 at the Goodman Theater in Chicago in a production that starred Mike Nussbaum and Joe Mantegna and was directed by Gregory Mosher. That same year it played off Broadway at the Lucille Lortel Theater, where it starred Peter Evans and Ellis Rabb and was directed by Gerald Gutierrez. Cast members and a theater for the Broadway revival have not been announced.

title: Off the Menu: Bistro Vendme
description: For many years, Pascal Petiteau was the chef at Jubilee, a popular bistro near Sutton Place that is known for mussel dishes. His wife, Virginie, was a manager there. Following their dream, they left last year. Now, on Monday, they will open their own place, Bistro Vendme, nearby, in the multilevel townshouse space that had been March and Nish when Wayne Nish owned it, and was home to Robert Pritskers Brive before that.

title: Layering On a New Flavor
description: As a New Yorker born in the middle of the 20th century, I come from a place and time where lasagna was without fail made of dried pasta layered with red meat sauce and ricotta, along with the inevitable mozzarella and parmesan. It wasnt until I first visited Italy, in my 20s, that I encountered lasagne (note the shift from lasagna in the singular, describing the whole dish in Little Italy fashion, to lasagne in the plural, referring to the sheets of pasta that are its defining ingredient) based on egg pasta, rag bolognese and bchamel sauce. It seemed very sissified at the time, but somehow it came to be my standard, perhaps simply because it is a more satisfactory dish. I still occasionally make ricotta/red sauce lasagna, but most of the time the lasagne that come out of our oven are more in a Bolognese than a Calabrian vein.

title: Democrats Question Comcast-NBC Universal Deal
description: Update | 7:57 p.m.  Concerns on Thursday about fair access to television programming dominated the first day of Congressional hearings on the proposed combination of Comcast and NBC Universal, The New York Timess Brian Stelter reports.

title: U.S. Mens Hockey Team Adds Whitney and Gleason to Defense
description: Ryan Whitney of the Anaheim Ducks and Tim Gleason of the Carolina Hurricanes, both defensemen, were added Thursday to the United States mens Olympic team roster.

title: Springsteen Says He Is Not Suing a New York Bar
description: Bruce Springsteen wants to make something clear: he is not suing any bars where bands might be playing his songs.

title: Woman Detained in Haiti Also Due in Idaho Court
description: Last Updated | 9:30 p.m. Laura Silsby, who led a Baptist group on a mission to Haiti that resulted in all 10 members of her team being charged with kidnapping on Thursday by Haitian authorities, also faces legal troubles back home in Boise, Idaho, in the form of two lawsuits.

title: Point Guard Shuffle: Robinson In, Duhon Out
description: Nate Robinson will start at point guard for the Knicks on Friday, completing a stunning turnaround in his fortunes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Feb. 4
description: There is something importantly reassuring  and balancing  about seeing everyday life proceed in areas known only to outsiders for their turbulence. Musadeq Sadeq of The Associated Press provides such a tableau from Afganistan (Slide 6), as he did on Tuesday and on Oct. 29.

title: Morality and Salvation
description: The rap on Academy members is that most of them are older folk who dont get out much. Sort of like future bloggers. Anyway, perhaps theyd still be interested in R.S.V.P.ing to Movieguides Best 2009 Movies for Mature Audiences  awards event, which honors moral and spiritual principles along with cinematic achievement. The nominees this year include The Blind Side, Invictus, Julie & Julia, and of course, that high point of inspirational ethics, Terminator Salvation.

title: Mr. Haydn, if You Please, Come Meet Mr. Ellington
description: Anyone as prolific, pragmatic and busy as Haydn could hardly afford the luxury of dwelling on a project once it was completed. You would assume that once he had delivered The Seven Last Words of Christ, an orchestral work commissioned during the mid-1780s for Good Friday services in Cdiz, Spain, he might have considered his job done and moved on.

title: Love and Sorcery in a Religious War
description: Sometimes slight flaws in an otherwise great opera  say, a convoluted plot twist or impractical vocal demands  can account for the works neglect. That Glucks magnificent 1777 Armide, a seemingly flawless masterpiece, continues to be a rarity is inexplicable.

title: Coyote on Ice
description: Veryl Witmer, an amateur photographer who lives on the Upper West Side, was walking past the pond in Central Park on Tuesday afternoon when he noticed something unusual: a coyote. The animal came out of the Hallett Nature Sanctuary and walked across the frozen pond several times, Mr. Witmer writes. It seemed timid and skittish and kept retreating back to the sanctuary  avoiding humans? It kept a watchful eye on me. The coyote did, however, find a moment to pose for a more formal portrait.

title: Feeling for  Spring Break
description: To help our fashion peeps battle the winter blues and make those days at the beach seem a bit closer, Ive decided to highlight a couple of summery lines. Orlebar Browne is a young company based in Britain that makes a very focused range of quick-dry nylon swim shorts based on traditional surf jams. Its tailored shapes come in a few different lengths and flatter even the skinniest shanks. The Bulldog is a midlength trunk with metal side tabs and angled pockets that help it pass as normal shorts post-swim; the Beagle is a more traditional surf short with a drawstring waist. These leaner, cleaner, Gidget-era togs are far more flattering than those oversize, below-the-knee psychedelic printed things that you see in Cancn.

title: Where Singing Means More Than Hip Shaking
A Former Prosecutor Suits Up Again
description: It began as a 1992 suburban drug bust, but it snowballed into a major crisis of confidence that pulled the lid back on years of failed warnings about corruption in New York Citys Police Department.

title: Gibbs Seeks Apology From Senator Bond
description: Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, said today that Senator Kit Bond, the ranking Republican on the Intelligence Committee, should apologize for suggesting that the administration leaked information in the investigation of the Nigerian man accused of trying to blow up a jetliner on Christmas Day.

title: Beneath Brown Bags, Saints Had Loyal Fans
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Before Buddy Diliberto came along, brown paper bags held groceries, became art projects or covered the Led Zeppelin album In Through the Out Door. Diliberto spawned another use: decorative headwear for suffering sports fans, like those who followed his New Orleans Saints.

title: $5 Million Is Offered if Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra Meet
description: In an attempt to bring Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta together for the first time, Oaklawn Park in Arkansas announced Thursday that it would increase the purse of the April 3 Apple Blossom Invitational to $5 million if the two female stars competed in the race.

title: The Free Verse Is in Aisle 3
description: There are 15 or 20 better poets in America than Tony Hoagland, but few deliver more pure pleasure. His erudite comic poems are backloaded with heartache and longing, and they function, emotionally, like improvised explosive devices: the pain comes at you from the cruelest angles, on the sunniest of days.

title: Action Star Learns Merits of Tenderness
description: WHAT the hell was all that stupid noise in the background? Why  what was it about? What were those silly lights for?

title: A Taylor Swift Defense Catches Kelly Clarksons Eye
description: And the Taylorgate debate expands. First Taylor Swift gave a shaky vocal performance at the Grammys, leading to plenty of thumbs-downs from tweeters and critics, including Jon Pareles of The New York Times, who called her painfully out of tune. Then, in defense, Scott Borchetta, president of Ms. Swifts record company, said in an interview with The Tennessean that maybe shes not the best technical singer, but shes probably the best emotional singer, and he told The Associated Press: This is not `American Idol. This is not a competition of getting up and seeing who can sing the highest note. This is about a true artist and writer and communicator. Its not about that technically perfect performance.

title: Back to the Grindstone
description: Ive been home from Hawaii less than a week, and Ive almost adjusted to being back at work (the 30 degree temperatures are a different story). I came back from my trip with a ton of energy, a great tan and so many wonderful memories. I also came back with some unexpected realizations about my business and my role as chief executive.

title: Fox Files More Suits Claiming DVD Piracy
description: Escalating its efforts to crack down on DVD piracy, Twentieth Century Fox on Thursday filed six lawsuits against several dozen people that the company said had sold DVDs containing an unfinished version of X-Men Origins: Wolverine and other counterfeit Fox titles.

title: Essay: Too Many Angles on Suffering?
description: Update | 4:00 p.m., Monday, Feb. 8: The following post, written by The Timess international picture editor, raises engaging, important and contentious questions. And, frankly, it has touched more than one nerve. Ron Haviv of the VII agency and Christopher Anderson of Magnum sought a chance to elaborate publicly on their quoted remarks. And Damon Winter, one of five photographers who were working in Haiti on assignment from The Times, also thought there was more to be said on the subject. We welcome their essays, which will be found at the end of the post. We believe theyll broaden this already vital discussion.

title: A Novel Gatsby: Stamina Required
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  What happens between a novel and a consenting reader is usually a deeply personal activity, occurring behind the closed doors of individual minds. It is arguably more intimate and subjective than sex. And if someone asked you, Want to watch me read a book for the next six or seven hours? you would probably  and wisely  decline.

title: McGuires Understated Greatness
description: Spencer Ross is a longtime New York sports broadcaster, who grew up idolizing Dick McGuire and came to know him as a Knicks broadcaster starting in 1972. Ross is a member of the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Life in the Theater to Get Broadway Run
description: For an anti-establishment guy, David Mamet is certainly getting comfortable with Broadway. On Thursday the producers Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Steve Traxler (who also brought Mr. Mamets new play Race to Broadway) said that a new staging of A Life in the Theater would come to Broadway this fall. Neil Pepe, above, the artistic director of the Atlantic Theater Company, is to direct; Mr. Mamet is a founder of the company. The play, about the evolving relationship between a young actor and his older mentor, was first performed in 1977 at the Goodman Theater in Chicago. Cast members and a theater for the Broadway revival have not been announced.

title: London Philharmonic Wins Fraud Judgment
description: The London Philharmonic, which said it was stung in an embezzlement scam by its finance director, lost far more money than was originally reported. The official, Cameron Poole, was accused in November of taking 357,000, or $570,000, over four years. The Times of London reported on Thursday that a High Court judge had awarded the orchestra a judgment of 2.3 million, or $3.7 million, against Mr. Poole. The police are investigating the case, The Telegraph reported.

title: AOL Snags a Google Executive to Oversee Content
description: AOL said on Thursday that it had named David Eun president of AOL Media and Studios, overseeing the companys content sites and its new Seed.com publishing platform. Mr. Eun, who will begin at AOL on March 1, most recently was vice president of strategic partnerships at Google, where he oversaw the often tense relationship that Google and its YouTube unit had with media companies.

title: Defending Taylor Swift
description: Though Taylor Swift, above left, won four Grammy Awards on Sunday night, including one for album of the year for Fearless, she was also roundly criticized for her uneven performances at the awards ceremony, including her out-of-tune duet with Stevie Nicks, above right, on the Fleetwood Mac song Rhiannon. Now the head of the record label Big Machine, which released Fearless, has spoken up on Ms. Swifts behalf. In an article in The Tennessean of Nashville, Scott Borchetta, the labels president and chief executive, said that Ms. Swifts critics are not getting it. Mr. Borchetta added: The facts say she is the undisputed best communicator that weve got. When she says something, when she sings something, when she feels something, it affects more people than anybody else. Defending Ms. Swifts performance at the Grammys, Mr. Borchetta said, Maybe shes not the best technical singer, but shes probably the best emotional singer because everybody else who gets up there and is technically perfect, people dont seem to want more of it. Mr. Borchetta told The Associated Press that Ms. Swift had a technical problem during her duet with Ms. Nicks and was unable to hear the complete mix of the song as she performed it.

title: Chinese Film Falls Off Film Forums Schedule
description: Planned showings of a Chinese movie that was abruptly pulled last month from the Palm Springs International Film Festival have been canceled at Film Forum, which will instead show a documentary about the Dalai Lama that provoked the other movies withdrawal in Palm Springs. In January City of Life and Death, a film about the 1937 Nanking massacre featuring Liu Ye, above, was pulled from the festival, along with Quick, Quick, Slow, at the direction of Chinas ministry of foreign affairs and its film bureau. Festival representatives said that the withdrawals were to protest another film screening at Palm Springs, The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibets Struggle for Freedom, which chronicles a year in the life of the Dalai Lama. On Thursday Mike Maggiore, a representative for Film Forum, the Manhattan movie house, said the decision to pull City of Life and Death had been made by its distributor, National Geographic Entertainment. A representative for National Geographic said the company was still in negotiations with the Chinese film board about the movies American release. Film Forum said The Sun Behind the Clouds would run from March 31 through April 13.

title: Studios Lose a Downloading Case in Australia
description: Hollywood studios lost a copyright court case against an Australia Internet service provider on Thursday, Reuters reported, when a court ruled that the provider, iiNet, could not be held responsible for unauthorized downloads of movies using its service. The suit was filed by a group of studios including Universal Pictures, Warner Brothers, Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures Entertainment, 20th Century Fox and Disney. A federal court in Sydney ruled that it was impossible to hold iiNet responsible for users who might infringe copyright. iiNet contended that it was not required by law to act on allegations of copyright infringement; that customers were innocent until proven guilty; and that the case was comparable to suing a power company for the activities clients use electricity to engage in.

title: Pneumonia Cited in Actresss Death
description: Brittany Murphy, the Clueless and 8 Mile actress, died of pneumonia, though anemia and prescription drugs factored into her death, the Los Angeles County Coroners office said on Thursday. The Associated Press said that a report from the coroners office gave Ms. Murphys cause of death as community acquired pneumonia, with contributing factors of iron deficiency anemia and multiple drug intoxication. Craig Harvey, a spokesman for the office, told The A.P. that the drugs involved were all prescription medications but did not specify what they were. Ms. Murphy, an alternately upbeat and offbeat actress who worked in films including Girl, Interrupted and the cartoon television series King of the Hill, collapsed in the bathroom of her Hollywood home on Dec. 20 and was taken to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead. She was 32.

title: Smaller Audience Still Wins for Idol
description: A final audition episode of American Idol drew 20.8 million viewers on Wednesday night, a modest audience for the show but enough to lead the evenings ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox won the night with Idol but earned just 7.8 million viewers for Human Target, a new action series. CBS was second with a lineup that included Super Bowls Greatest Commercials (11.2 million), the largest audience the annual special has seen in three years. ABC ranked third with a comedy lineup that included The Middle (7.3 million), Cougar Town (6.2 million), Modern Family (9.1 million) and Ugly Betty (4.1 million). NBC finished fourth.

title: A Busy Farewell Season for Seattle Conductor
description: Gerard Schwarz, below, will bow out after 26 years as music director of the Seattle Symphony with a bang. The orchestra said on Thursday that next season, his last, would open with Mr. Schwarz conducting a concert featuring his son Julian playing the world premiere of a cello concerto by Samuel Jones and a work by the conductor himself, The Human Spirit. The program also includes Gerard Schwarzs own arrangement of a suite from Der Rosenkavalier by Strauss. And the 2010-11 season will close with a performance of Mahlers Symphony No. 2, The Resurrection.

title: Passion and Identity Crisis in a Pious Community
description: Eyes Wide Open, the quiet and confident feature debut of the Israeli director Haim Tabakman, explores the conflict between sexual desire and religious obligation. Set in an ultra-Orthodox neighborhood of Jerusalem, the film, written by Merav Doster, gives nearly equal weight to both sides in that struggle. It does not sensationalize lust or treat piety with condescension, but rather treats these two basic, often antithetical human impulses with respect and compassion. Faith can console as well as constrict, and sex can bring confusion along with intimacy and pleasure.

title: Little Richard
description: Chapter 1: Early One Morning

title: A Vanished Arcade in Times Square
description: Playland, catnip for aficionados of pinball and Skee ball, had multiple locations.

title: Ankle May Not be Freeneys Only Podiatric Issue
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Given the awards and sponsorships that are a part of Super Bowl week, its a little surprising that the N.F.L. doesnt give out a Mr. Congeniality award for the player who handles himself best with the media (sponsored by Prozac, perhaps?). But if there was such an award, the Colts Dwight Freeney surely would deserve consideration.

title: Saxon State Operas Music Director Quits
description: In a story of opera house intrigue with nationalist overtones, the Italian general music director of the Saxon State Opera and its celebrated orchestra, the Dresden Staatskapelle, has abruptly resigned, leaving the house without a conductor for this months Wagner Ring cycle.

title: Gansevoort to Open Second New York Hotel
description: Though lenders recently took possession of the Gansevoort South in Miami, the hoteliers behind the budding boutique chain are proceeding with their next project: the 249-room Gansevoort Park Avenue, scheduled to open in June.

title: The Estates at Keswick Hall
description: WHAT Resort community with new house design options.

title: Vancouvers Floating Hotel Pulls the Plug
description: Hundreds of visitors to the Olympic games in Vancouver are scrambling to find alternative accommodations following the last minute cancellation of a plan to use a cruise ship as a floating hotel.

title: Allowances Were Squandered Here
description: Q  As a Long Island kid who visited the city most weekends, I spent a lot of time in a penny arcade near Times Square. Of course, there was Skee ball, and there was also a pinball baseball game that displayed the names of the 55 or 56 Yankees and Dodgers who played in the World Series. Could you identify this place? It was magical to a kid back then. ... Seth Wittner, Henderson, Nev.

title: Ordinary Thunderstorms
description: Chapter 1

title: Americans Spark the Gunfire in the City of Light
description: A conservative estimate of the escalating body count in Pierre Morels gleefully chaotic action-adventure comedy From Paris With Love is two dozen a day, boasts John Travoltas trigger-happy character, Special Agent Charlie Wax. But as you watch Mr. Travolta, twirling a weapon in each hand, dispatch the members of a Chinese drug gang in a Paris restaurant and later in a nearby apartment, it could be a hundred or a thousand. In a rare moment of contemplation, Wax remarks that there are a billion more to be disposed of.

title: Scan Artist | Nature Calls
description: Scan Artist copies the latest fashion trends so you can, too.

title: No Charges Against Safir in Driving Incident
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office will not charge Howard Safir, the former New York City police commissioner who backed his sport utility vehicle into a pregnant woman on the Upper East Side last month and drove away, a law enforcement official said Thursday afternoon.

title: St. Louis Bulks Up in W.P.S.
description: St. Louis Athletica of Womens Professional Soccer waltzed away with three quality players on Thursday in the dispersal draft of talent from the defunct Los Angeles Sol.

title: Letters: Visiting the Vatican
description: To the Editor:

title: For $2, a Wine for Those Who Cant Be Bothered With a Cork
description: It almost sounds fancy, especially when its said in its native Scottish brogue  Buckfast Tonic Wine, as if it cures the drinker of any ailments besides their wits and sobriety. A potent mix of alcohol and caffeine, it has come under attack in Scotland for making people drunk and disorderly, and empty bottles of the stuff have a way of showing up at crime scenes and brawls.

title: Pearce Moves to Brain Rehab Hospital in Colorado
description: Snowboarder Kevin Pearce, a likely Olympian before sustaining a severe head injury Dec. 31 during training in Utah, has been transferred to a brain-rehabilitation hospital in Colorado.

title: Men and Terror Run Wild
description: The blood that runs through the Red Riding trilogy  three movies based on four crime books by the British author David Peace  begins as a river that races and then rages until it floods this dank, dark, pitiless world in misery. By the time the third movie finishes, some half dozen young girls will have been murdered, along with more than a dozen women. Men will have died as well, tormented by other men wearing smiles and sneers, and wielding fists, drills, lighted cigarettes, the usual guns and even a rat that ends splattered against a wall.

title: What Is Printmaking Today? Philadelphia Dares to Ask
description: PHILADELPHIA  The fine art of printmaking is not what it used to be. To produce printed images using tools more sophisticated than potatoes and rubber stamps once required the esoteric knowledge of an alchemist and the manual skills of a surgeon. Today anyone with the right software and a good color printer can make infinitely reproducible images that are hard to distinguish from professionally made drawings, paintings, montages, commercial illustrations and other sorts of pictures. Which raises the question: What should a major, international exhibition devoted to contemporary printmaking entail?

title: Skiing Downhill With Lindsey Vonn
description: Lindsey Vonn, the gold medal favorite in alpine skiing in Vancouver, hit the slopes with the reporter Bill Pennington to discuss speed, crashing and recovery.

title: Questions Raised About JPMorgan E-Mail on M.&A.
description: An internal JPMorgan Chase e-mail message from 2008 describing a meeting involving Jamie Dimon, the banks chief executive, and Emilio Botin, Banco Santanders chairman, has been obtained by TheStreet.com, which says the message raises antitrust questions because it suggests that the two men possibly discussed divvying up the banking market.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Navigating the Sea of Data on the Internet
description: In this weeks Tech Talk podcast on NYTimes.com, Nick Bilton talks about the notion of controlled serendipity and how he aggregates and curates the information he finds on the Internet.

title: Mystery Men of the Financial Crisis
description: Now that we have pulled back sufficiently far from the near destruction of the modern financial system  as the former Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson described the events of 2008 in his new memoir, On The Brink  to focus on how to prevent such a calamity from recurring, the time has come to hear from those players in the drama who really know what happened and why.

title: Brown Is Sworn In as the 41st Republican
description: Scott Brown took his place in the Senate this evening, ending the 60-vote Democratic supermajority and placing a Republican in the seat that Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts  that most Democrat of Democrats  held for nearly half a century.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: How Toyota Can Find Its Way Back
description: Toyota, long considered the gold standard for reliability, faces an ever broadening crisis with federal regulators opening an investigation into  faulty brakes on the latest Prius hybrid. The company is scrambling to fix  2.3 million vehicles recalled for unintended acceleration and 4.2 million for design flaw that trapped gas pedals under the floor mat. On Wednesday, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood said the department was considering a civil penalty against Toyota over the handling of the recalls.

title: North Korea Appears to Ease Markets Crackdown
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Facing food shortages, severe price increases and social unrest, North Korea appears to have relaxed, at least temporarily, its broad crackdown on private markets by allowing them to reopen with price caps, news reports and officials in Seoul said Friday.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: To Protect Manning, Colts Line Adjusts
description: For all the Saints talk about trying to hit Peyton Manning and disrupt his game, the Colts say it hasnt quickened their pulse.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: I.P.O. Market Shows Growing Signs of Trouble
description: Two initial public offerings that had been expected to start trading on Thursday were delayed as world financial markets continued to decline on concerns about the pace of the global economic recovery  yet another sign of trouble for companies looking to sell shares to the public.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: U.S. Players Who Arent Injured or Otherwise Occupied Get the Call-Up
description: Coach Bob Bradley of the U.S. national team has called in a roster of 23 players, all who play domestically, for a training camp in advance of a friendly match against El Salvador at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla., on Feb. 24. Bradleys list includes four uncapped players: Kevin Alston (New England), Geoff Cameron (Houston), Omar Gonzalez (Los Angeles) and Chris Pontius (D.C. United).

title: Gingrich Plans Speech at Catholic Gathering
description: Newt Gingrich, who converted to Catholicism last year, plans to share his conversion story with business executives at a Catholic conference in California this weekend.

title: The First Wave of iPad Gadgets
description: Cue blare of trumpets: Apple has a new device, which can mean, among other things, one certainty: a brand new bunch of accessories.

title: Truth or Dare
description: Asked why so many of his poems seemed animated by unhappiness, Philip Larkin once told an interviewer, Deprivation is for me what daffodils were for Wordsworth. A supremely cynical thing to say  but also backhandedly romantic, isnt it? A dreadful muse is still a muse. Like Larkin, Tony Hoagland seems to draw inspiration and fluency as a poet from his disappointment and frustration as a human being. And like Larkins, Hoaglands poems, though chock-full of grousing, are so fully alive to the rich, dark depths of their grumpiness that they constantly threaten, against their authors gimlet-eyed better judgment, to become beautiful.

title: Uncle Pirate
description: UNCLE PIRATE

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Overstock Restates, Again
description: Those who recall how Overstock.com thundered about its horror that Grant Thornton, its former auditing firm, changed course and wanted it to restate profits may be surprised by how meekly Overstock went along with that idea on Thursday.

title: Theater Listings: Feb. 5  11
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: The Tao of Temple
description: ON Sunday afternoon, in subfrigid temperatures, Henry, Scout and I headed to the farm near our house expecting that no other humans or dogs would be crazy enough to be outside. I knew Scout would be disappointed by an empty landscape, so I lit up at the sight of her bounding out of our car as she caught sight of two of her regular dog friends, Ikey and Kaboo. In nasty weather, when my children were toddlers, I often fretted the playground would be empty, just as I was doing now.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Winter Jam NYC
description: Some of us are surely grumbling about recent low temperatures and swirling winds in New York City, but at least one person is probably quite pleased with the chilly air: Adrian Benepe, the parks commissioner. Mr. Benepe has big plans for this weekend, when a portion of Central Park is to be blanketed in snow for the annual Winter Jam NYC, a daylong event on Saturday that will allow visitors to play around in the white stuff and experiment with cross-country skiing or snowshoeing. (Equipment and lessons will be available.)

title: Behind Films Drama, a Tale Like a Country Song
description: LOS ANGELES

title: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art Raises Funds for Expansion
description: Update | 10:21 a.m. Bucking the downward trend that has plagued the boardrooms of most museums during the recession, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art announced Thursday that it has raised $250 million over the last several months, allowing it to double the size of its endowment and put $150 million toward an ambitious expansion.

title: Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Do the 10 Top the 5? Oscar Promoters Say Yes
description: LAST year the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the bestower of Oscar gold, took a calculated risk  some would say a cynicalized risk  by announcing that there would be 10 best picture nominees instead of the usual 5. Cue months of grumbling and grousing from armchair critics who said the expansion devalued the award, from directors who were miffed that there wasnt a parallel doubling of their category, and from Academy members who couldnt think of 10 good movies, period.

title: The Pastime of Victorian Cutups
description: Breakthroughs arent always all theyre cracked up to be. Collage, one of riverheads of modernism, is usually thought to have been introduced around 1912, when Braque and Picasso began gluing pieces of newsprint and wallpaper to their Cubist drawings.

title: Phillips to Appear on Today
description: Steve Phillips, who was fired by ESPN last year as a baseball analyst after his affair with a network production assistant became public knowledge, will be interviewed Monday by Matt Lauer on NBCs Today show.

title: A Name Change in Brooklyn
description: The stadium formerly known as KeySpan Park will now be MCU Park, for the Municipal Credit Union.

title: Art in Review
description: FROM THE GOTHIC TRADITION TO THE EARLY RENAISSANCE

title: Microsofts Innovation Versus Dick Brass
description: More than a decade ago, Dick Brass, then a Microsoft vice president, worked with a stealth team on a visionary project. The teams goal was to build a computer that looked less like a computing device and more like a pad of paper  a tablet PC to be precise.

title: Honoring an Inventors Passion for Plastic
description: A clapboarded 1890s barn in Yonkers was the unlikely setting, in 1907, for a leap in polymer technology. The barn contained the home laboratory of Leo Baekeland, a Belgian-born inventor who experimented with heating and pressing plastics to maximize durability. He patented his favorite formaldehyde compound, Bakelite, and eventually ran factories that molded the syrupy resin into colorful scientific equipment, housewares, toys and tchotchkes.

title: A Quadruple Return for a Man Doubly Missed
description: For a certain breed of New York jazz fan the alto-saxophonist Wess Anderson is the one that got away. Nearly twice. Mr. Anderson, a Brooklyn native, emerged in the late 1980s as a sideman with Wynton Marsalis, and later a charter member of Mr. Marsaliss efforts at Jazz at Lincoln Center. Fondly known as Warmdaddy, he was on board there until about four years ago, when he joined the jazz faculty at Michigan State University.

title: Ancient Sphere Where Cultures Mingled
description: In 1988 the art historian Nancy Tingley, then a curator at the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco, went to Vietnam to talk with museums about borrowing examples of the countrys ancient art for the first major United States exhibition. It was a bold idea. To most Americans, Vietnam still meant little more than the memory of a nightmare war. And who knew it had a great art tradition, never mind museums that preserved it?

title: Unrolled, Unbridled and Unabashed
description: In the 18th century Casanova referred to them as English frock coats and made prodigious use of the little preventive bag invented by the English to save the fair sex from anxiety. In 1709 the English literary journal The Tatler alluded to their supposed invention by an eponymous doctor of eminent Quality; the success of his Engine eventually made it an Immodesty to name his Name.

title: Is It Ever O.K. to Name Rape Victims?
description: Some readers have asked, in the context of my recent Congo columns, why I have named rape victims, including the name of a 9-year-old girl. Let me say at the outset that its the policy of the Times not to name rape victims and that making exceptions requires consultation with a senior editor. Thats a policy that makes sense to me; I didnt consult but should have (and will in the future). In any case, let me explain my thinking here.

title: Young Love Caught in the Grips of 9/11
description: Go ahead and cry. You know you want to. Why else would you read a book by  or, in keeping with our purposes here, see a movie based on a book by  Nicholas Sparks?

title: Britain: 390 M.P.s Ordered to Repay Expense Claims
description: Nine months after the House of Commons was plunged into crisis by news accounts of extravagant expense claims by hundreds of lawmakers, the official appointed to audit the claims ordered 390 members of Parliament on Thursday to repay $1.8 million  about $60,000 less than the cost of the review. The costliest of the repayment demands fell to Barbara Follett, a Labour minister and the wife of the spy novelist Ken Follett: $67,000 for security surveillance of her country home. The smallest was 63 cents, for an accounting error.

title: Japan: 3 Charged in Campaign Finance Investigation
description: Prosecutors on Thursday charged three former aides of a top governing party official with misreporting $4.4 million in political funds. But they said they did not have enough evidence to charge the official, Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the Democratic Party. The opposition Liberal Democrats called for Mr. Ozawa to resign.

title: Collider to Operate Again, Though at Half Power
description: The worlds biggest and most expensive physics experiment will finally be going into regular operation later this month, but it is going to operate at only half power for the next two years, CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, said Thursday.

title: Bring Back the Draft
description: WASHINGTON  Lt. Col. Paul Yingling became a pivotal figure in the Iraq debate when he wrote an article three years ago that faulted the performance of American generals. It was a hard-hitting commentary that broadcast out loud the sort of misgivings that many of the Armys younger officers had been keeping to themselves.

title: Medical Group Urges New Rules on Radiation
description: The leading professional organization dedicated to radiation oncology has called for enhanced safety measures in administering medical radiation, including the establishment of the nations first central database for the reporting of errors involving linear accelerators  machines that generate radiation  and CT scanners.

title: Fraying at the Edges
description: We must hang together, Benjamin Franklin once said of the colonies that formed the United States. Else, we shall most assuredly hang separately.

title: Peering Into a Mind Thats Different, but Not Less
description: In her autobiography, Thinking in Pictures: My Life With Autism, Temple Grandin explains that she values positive, measurable results more than emotion. The HBO movie Temple Grandin honors its heroines priorities, stressing deeds over tearful setbacks and joyous breakthroughs.

title: Vietnam Enlists Allies to Stave Off Chinas Reach
description: HANOI, Vietnam  The archipelago called the Paracel Islands lies in the South China Sea 250 miles off the east coast of Vietnam, a series of rocks and reefs and spits of land that, to the undiscerning eye, appear as valuable as broken coral washed up on a beach.

title: Two European Banks Post Strong Profits
description: Deutsche Bank reinforced its position as one of the survivors of the global financial crisis Thursday, posting its fourth consecutive quarterly profit after a record loss a year earlier.

title: Bouncing and Soaring, With Mayhem in Mind
description: The otherworldly bodies in District 13: Ultimatum fly over, and sometimes against, walls like hard rubber balls. They bounce and soar and only occasionally go thwack as flesh meets concrete. One of the two bounciest in the movie belongs to Cyril Raffaelli, a sculpted specimen with a bald head, a thrusting jaw and steeply sloping shoulders who suggests a cross between the American comic Chris Elliott and a cue ball. The spiky-haired David Belle, meanwhile, who is often credited as the inventor of parkour, the crazy-beautiful French-born physical discipline he and Mr. Raffaelli practice here, is sui generis and probably part monkey.

title: Justice Dept. Criticizes Latest Google Book Deal
description: In another blow to Googles plan to create a giant digital library and bookstore, the Justice Department on Thursday said that a class-action settlement between the company and groups representing authors and publishers had significant legal problems, even after recent revisions.

title: Jobs Report Preview
Love Takes a Holiday
description: After living together in Europe the last four years, I broke up with my girlfriend over Christmas, and Im moving back to New York around Valentines Day.

title: Mayoral Primary Gives New Orleans Another Contest This Weekend
description: NEW ORLEANS  Politics may not be the main topic of conversation in this football-addled town right now, but there is a mayoral election on Saturday, the day before the Super Bowl, and its outcome could be historic.

title: Not Exactly a Danish Grovers Corners
description: Henrik Ruben Genzs diabolical comedy Terribly Happy assures us that yes, something is definitely rotten in the state of Denmark, or least in the rural Danish county of South Jutland. From the moment the camera surveys the dirty brick buildings in Skarrild, a desolate backwater in the countys soggy flatlands, you sense that this is a village of the damned.

title: For Hollywood, Stand-Ins Play Californias Part
description: LOS ANGELES  Shooting day for night is one thing. Shreveport for Santa Monica is quite another.

title: New York City Names Winners of Apps Contest
description: The winners of the first NYC BigApps competition, which invited the public to develop applications using raw sets of municipal data, were announced at an event in New York on Thursday evening.

title: Even Where Pakistani Law Exists, Taliban Find a Porous Border
description: CHAMAN, Pakistan  The thick brown sack that a man named Abdulmalek carried over his shoulder on a recent afternoon might have contained anything: weapons, drugs or explosives. But crossing back and forth between Afghanistan and Pakistan was no problem, he said.

title: Compliant Witness Gets Probation in Galleon Case
description: In the end, it was a close call for a former hedge fund manager who was sentenced on Thursday after two years as a cooperating witness in the governments expanding investigation into insider trading on Wall Street.

title: Graffitis Story, From Vandalism to Art to Nostalgia
description: Eric Felisbret stood by a chain-link fence, watching three men spraying graffiti on a backyard wall in Upper Manhattan. One man smiled and invited him over.

title: Did Salinger Leave a Word for Posterity?
description: With J. D. Salingers death, many people have turned to the possibility that unpublished works, perhaps a novel or two, will emerge from the shadows of his long seclusion. Stephen Enniss has his eye on something else.

title: When Windmills Dont Spin, People Expect Some Answers
description: For those who suspect residents in places like Minnesota of embellishment when it comes to their tales of bitterly cold winter weather, consider this: even some wind turbines, it seems, cannot bear it.

title: State Street Gave Some of Its Clients Better Data
description: BOSTON  The State Street Corporation told some preferred investors in 2007 that one of its bond funds was almost entirely invested in subprime mortgage securities, allowing them to get out. Others were kept in the dark, costing them millions of dollars.

title: Houston Bus Companies Were Links in Illegal Immigrant Network
description: HOUSTON  Raids on 14 illegal bus companies here have shed light on a seedy underground system that transported illegal immigrants all over the country and that sometimes held them captive until their relatives paid exorbitant fares, federal law enforcement officials said Thursday.

title: Facing Re-election, Schumer Draws Breath
description: The usually unavoidable-for-comment, if-its-Sunday-here-is-my-press-release senior senator from New York is being a little tetchy about going on the record.

title: New York State Labor Chief Is Confirmed to Federal Post
description: The Senate voted 60 to 37 on Thursday to confirm M. Patricia Smith, the New York State labor commissioner, for the Labor Departments No. 3 post.

title: Vindication Now Arrives After a Battle of 28 Years
description: He had proclaimed his innocence, to no avail, at his trial and sentencing and in his five years behind bars.

title: In the Shadow of the Olympics
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In this urban oasis widely considered one of the most livable places in the world, the Downtown Eastside is about 15 square blocks of something else.

title: City to Bronx Community About a Homeless Shelter: Not in Your Backyard
description: In the perpetual battle against homelessness in New York, the Kingsbridge Heights Community Center in the Bronx was only a bit player, with about 10 beds in its gym. But offering space for even a handful of destitute people meant something to those who benefited from a warm, safe place to sleep, as well as to those who helped provide it.

title: Bond Investors Hungry for Kraft
description: If Krafts stock is any indicator, shareholders are ambivalent about the purchase of Britains cherished candy maker, Cadbury. Yet debt investors handed over $9.5 billion to the food conglomerate on one of the gummiest days in the markets for ages. Irene Rosenfeld, Krafts chief, shouldnt take this confidence, however, as a robust validation of her acquisition strategy.

title: A Latino Bronx Tale
description: Like a thousand other coming-of-age-in-an-ethnic-family dramas, Falling Awake puts good intentions and appealing performances into the balance against clichs of dead-end neighborhoods and rebellious (but sensitive) youth.

title: Ex-Police Official Wont Be Charged in Driving Mishap
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office will not charge Howard Safir, the former New York City police commissioner who backed his sport utility vehicle into a pregnant woman on the Upper East Side last month and drove away, a law enforcement official said Thursday afternoon.

title: Hans L. Trefousse, Historian and Author, Dies at 88
description: Sometimes the least prepossessing American presidents are the most enduringly interesting. That is certainly the case for Andrew Johnson. His impeachment trial of 1868 was in the news again in the late 1990s, during the impeachment proceedings against President Bill Clinton.

title: In California, a Rebuke to Toyota
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Wary of the expanded Toyota recall and still stinging from a recent decision by the Japanese automaker to close a major manufacturing plant in California, the State Assembly turned patriotic on Thursday, adopting a Buy American policy for all future vehicles bought for its fleet.

title: The Virtues of a Slow-Moving Dad
description: WHEN a man has a child late in life, it helps to have thick skin. People come right out and say, Whyd you wait so long, youre too old, said Rob Vichnis, 54, whose son Sergei is 7.

title: G.O.P. Senator Is Sworn In, and Democrats Regroup
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Congressional Democratic leaders sought to reset their agenda as they lost their 60th vote in the Senate on Thursday, trying to push ahead with measures to spur more job creation even as they grasped for ideas to keep alive their health care legislation.

title: A Nightmare on a Ski Lift
description: A minimalist setup delivers maximum fright in Frozen, a nifty little chiller that balances its cold terrain with an unexpectedly warm heart.

title: The Dozens of Computers That Make Modern Cars Go (and Stop)
description: The electronic systems in modern cars and trucks  under new scrutiny as regulators continue to raise concerns about Toyota vehicles  are packed with up to 100 million lines of computer code, more than in some jet fighters.

title: Ex-Assemblyman From Queens Gets Six-Year Term for Influence Peddling
description: The former assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, who prosecutors said took more than $1 million in payments from people and organizations doing business with the state, was sentenced to six years in prison by a federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday.

title: Super Elegant Bowl
description: Tired of spending the Super Bowl slipping on beer-soaked floors and fighting over congealed seven-layer dip? City Winery is offering a slightly more elegant way to watch the pigskins fly with its first Super Bowl party on Sunday. Watch the game on a projector and 150-inch screen or on one of the multiple 50-inch HD flat screens. Entry is free, and the Winery is offering an all-day happy hour with $5 glasses of wine and $15 carafes, as well as discounts on beer and alcohol. Wings, slow-braised ribs, burgers and more are on the menu, and the best part  especially for those nonfootball fans  everyone who attends will be entered into a raffle to win two V.I.P. tickets to the Music of the Who tribute at Carnegie Hall on March 2. The festivities kick off at 4 p.m.

title: Celebrate Winter
description: Grab your sled, snowboard, skis, snowshoes and whatever other cold-weather gear you've got stacked in the basement and head this Saturday to Central Park for Winter Jam 2010. The annual winter sports festival is presented by the New York City Parks Department and the Olympic Regional Development Authority. Channel your inner Shaun White while testing out a backside 180 at Switch Academy Rail Jam, where the professional snowboarder Pat Moore will serve as a judge. The less daring can play in the snow at the Lake Placid Snow Field or watch a screening of "Project X," a short film documenting Mr. White's Olympic training. The high-flying Skyriders will perform trampoline tricks on skis and snowboards. Free samples from Pride of New York Winter Market will keep participants warm and toasty. The event begins at 11 a.m.; enter at West 72nd Street and head south toward the Sheep Meadow to join the festivities.

title: Asias Aesthetic Crossroads
description: The exhibition "Arts of Ancient Vietnam: From River Plain to Open Sea," now on view at the Asia Society Museum, took over 20 years to produce. Is the show worth the wait? It is, according to Holland Cotter. "From the moment you enter the galleries you're seeing things you won't find anywhere else and certainly not in this combination: a bronze drum as hefty as a hot tub; a wooden Buddha, tall, dark, and Giacometti-thin. Avid-eyed Hindu deities keep company with contortionist dancers. A tiny serpent of beaten gold basks in a spotlight. Ceramic plates and bowls crowd a room just as they had once filled the hold of a ship that went down in the South China Sea." As a trade hub, Vietnam absorbed cultural influences from China, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and more, and these disparate influences are reflected in the show. "Once you've made your way through the society's suave installation, you've seen treasures from 10 Vietnamese museums. You've time-traveled from the first millennium B.C. to the 17th century A.D. And you've style-traveled through dozens of cultures both inside and outside Vietnam itself."

title: American Charged in Haiti Had Some Troubles in Idaho
description: MERIDIAN, Idaho  The leader of the group of Americans charged on Thursday with abducting children in Haiti is an Idaho businesswoman with a complicated financial history that involves complaints from employees over unpaid wages, state liens on a company bank account and lawsuits in small claims court.

title: LOL at Some of This Recruiting Stuff
description: The differences in how universities pursue a recruit is always a fascinating aspect of the recruiting process.

title: Lottery Numbers
Insulin Study Could Lead to New Dosage Devices
description: The results of a new study on managing juvenile diabetes may give hope to millions of parents in this country and abroad who typically wake up several times a night to make sure their childrens blood sugar levels have not dropped into the danger zone.

title: Queens Is Losing Hangout It Has Loved Since 1950
description: Have you seen Colorado? Rocco Ortiz asked the bartender at the Cavalier Restaurant and Lounge around lunchtime on Wednesday. The bartender promptly told him that the man known within the restaurants walls as Colorado does not come by on Wednesday afternoons because that is when he does his laundry.

title: City to Review Hiring of Chaplains After an Attempt to Carry Blades Into Jail
