description: It was not clear what was more surprising initially to city officials: that one of the Department of Corrections chaplains was accused of taking scissors and metal blades into a jail, or that the same chaplain had been convicted of murder.

title: Lobbying Imperils Overhaul of Student Loans
Illinois Court Overturns Malpractice Statute
description: In a case that could resonate in Washington, the Illinois Supreme Court on Thursday overturned the states five-year-old medical malpractice law because it limited compensation to injured patients for pain, suffering and other non-economic harms.

title: Bit of a Stir as Clinton Strays From Script on Mideast Peace
description: WASHINGTON  With an inadvertent bit of shorthand, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton set off a buzz in diplomatic circles on Wednesday, and may have offered a glimpse into how the Obama administration hopes to revive the stalled peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Volunteers Fly Supplies Into Hard-to-Reach Areas
description: LOGNE, Haiti  On a good day, a stray cow might be the only obstacle to landing the small planes bringing oxygen, crutches, baby formula and other supplies that will be put to immediate use at a hospital set up in a nursing school dormitory here.

title: Lorene Yue and Wai Gen Yee
description: WHEN Lorene Yue first saw Wai Gen Yee, she said she assumed he was an F.O.B.  a Fresh Off the Boat immigrant.

title: Hospital Network Withdraws Proposal to Take Over St. Vincents
description: A large hospital network that had offered to take over the nearly bankrupt St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village has formally withdrawn its offer, further clouding the hospitals prospects for survival.

title: Haitian Quake Brings More Money and Scrutiny to a Charity
description: Virtually unknown by Americans before an earthquake struck Haiti last month, the tiny charity founded by the performer Wyclef Jean stands to be one of the biggest winners in the fund-raising bonanza that is the hallmark of the Internet age, when tapping a keyboard is all that is required to unleash a torrent of donations.

title: No, Not That Tom Dempsey
description: If Tom Dempsey had a bead for every time hes asked, when checking into a hotel or renting a car, if hes any relation to the former Saints kicker, hed have enough for a double-strand Mardi Gras necklace that hangs down to his feet.

title: Election Panel Puts Off Start of Iraq Parliament Races
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs independent elections commission announced Thursday that the parliamentary elections campaign, scheduled to start Sunday, would be postponed for five days, as confusion reigned over an appeals court decision that overturned a ban on hundreds of candidates.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 965 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Rebuffing Scholars, Germany Vows to Keep Hitler Out of Print
description: MUNICH  In Germany, an author is granted an ironclad copyright for 70 years after his death, apparently even if he is subsequently regarded as one of the greatest mass murderers in history and a dark stain on the national character.

title: An Advocacy Ad Elevates Interest in All the Ads
description: VIEWERS look forward to the commercials shown during a Super Bowl because they know the spots will almost always be different from  and better than  the everyday ads they typically deride or ignore. For Super Bowl XLIV on Sunday, the anticipation may be more keen than usual.

title: California: Jackson Doctor Is Expected to Surrender
description: A lawyer for the doctor who was treating Michael Jackson at the time of his death said Thursday that the doctor planned to surrender to face charges. We are presently negotiating with the District Attorneys office, Ed Chernoff, a lawyer for Dr. Conrad Murray, said in a statement. What charges the doctor would face and when were unclear  a spokeswoman for District Attorney Steve Cooley said there would be no comment unless the case went forward. Dr. Murray, 57, has maintained through his lawyer that nothing he gave Mr. Jackson should have caused his death.

title: Stored Something for Future Use
description: With its innumerous circlets, sank absorbed,Safe in the cloud  O naked Moon full-orbed!   Browning

title: Mid-Atlantic Braces for Another Winter Storm
description: A major winter storm stretching from the Midwest to the Mississippi Valley was headed for the East Coast on Thursday, threatening to dump two feet of snow on the Mid-Atlantic and potentially paralyze Washington for the second time this season.

title: Lawsuit Over a Crash Adds to Toyotas Difficulties
description: FLINT, Mich.  The trip was one that Guadalupe Alberto had made many times before, just a few miles through her neighborhood to the small grocery store her family had owned for years.

title: Employer Wellness Programs Asking Fewer Questions
description: Both the Senate and House health care bills propose incentives to boost corporate wellness programs that aim to help employees stay healthier and to keep a lid on a companys insurance costs. But those programs have hit a legal speed bump with the recent enactment of a law that generally prohibits employers and insurers from asking workers about their family medical history.

title: Correction
description: A headline on Thursday about deliberations by the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff over the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy for gays and lesbians misstated his rank. As the article noted, the chairman is Adm. Mike Mullen; he is not a general.

title: MasterCard Posts Profit That Misses Expectations
description: MasterCard posted a 23 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, but the results fell short of analysts estimates and the company lowered its long-term forecast, contributing to a 10 percent decline in its share price.

title: Sony Returns to a Profit and Raises Its Outlook
description: After several quarters of losses, Sony said Thursday that it had returned to profit during the last three months of 2009 and raised its outlook, providing the latest evidence of how the global economic recovery was filtering through to corporate earnings.

title: When Generations Collide: The Who at the Super Bowl
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  As Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend left their Super Bowl news conference Thursday, Daltrey carried a Saints helmet and Townshend one for the Colts.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about an Obama administration initiative to increase production of biofuels misstated the projected decrease in annual oil consumption if the nation meets its biofuels target by 2022. It would fall by 328 million  not billion  barrels, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 15 about Stan Kroenke, who owns multiple sports teams and is close to taking control of the English soccer club Arsenal, misidentified the organization that would require him to make a bid for the entire team if he reached 30 percent ownership. It is a rule of Britains Takeover Panel, not of the English Premier League.

title: China Escalates Trade Fight Over European Shoe Tariff
description: China complained to the World Trade Organization on Thursday about antidumping duties imposed by the European Union on Chinese-made shoes, raising tensions between the trading giants.

title: Correction
description: An article on Wednesday about an archive of papers that belonged to Franklin D. Roosevelts last personal secretary, using information from the National Archives, misidentified the auction house that tried to arrange a sale of the papers in 2005. It was Christies, not Sothebys.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Escapes pages last Friday about purchases of vacation homes in various ski areas in the United States, including Telluride, Colo., misstated the origin of the name of Element 52, a condominium project under construction in Telluride. It is named for the element tellurium, No. 52 on the periodic table  not for telluridium, a form of gold ore. (There is no ore of that name.) The article also referred incorrectly to the mining of gold ore. It was not mined in Telluride.

title: Secretary General Reports on Gaza Inquiries
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said in a report to be released Friday that Israel and the Palestinians took steps toward independent investigations of possible war crimes committed during the Gaza campaign last winter, but that neither was far along enough to draw conclusions. A United Nations fact-finding mission reported in September on what it said was widespread evidence that Israel and to a lesser extent Hamas had committed war crimes.

title: 'Welcome to the Downtown Eastside'
description: By bidding for the Olympics, Vancouver invited the world to visit. Now city officials are trying to redirect the international news media spotlight from a blighted neighborhood called the Downtown Eastside.

title: Correction
description: An article on Tuesday about efforts by the Wildlife Conservation Society to preserve Kihansi spray toads referred incorrectly to a course on amphibian husbandry to be offered at the Toledo Zoo this year. It will be the zoos 10th such course, not its 3rd. The article also quoted incorrectly from a comment by Jennifer Pramuk, a herpetologist at the Bronx Zoo, on species loss in South America. She referred to amphibian fauna, not amphibious.

title: Making No Child Better
description: Like most ambitious federal reforms, the No Child Left Behind Education Act of 2002 will need to be revised, perhaps several times, before it reaches maximum effectiveness. Without formally announcing them, the Obama administration has made clear that it wants changes in the law, which could be reauthorized this year. For starters, it would like more effective mechanisms for intervening in failing schools and ways to reward schools that make rapid improvements.

title: Get On With Iraqs Election
description: Iraqs fragile democracy stepped back from the brink this week only to have Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki push it toward the edge once again.

title: What Price Politics?
description: A binge of special interest money seems inevitable unless Congress acts quickly  before this years election  to repair the damage from the Supreme Court ruling that ended restraints on campaign spending by corporations and unions.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Thursday about Dick McGuire, the former New York Knicks player, coach and scout, misidentified the area of Queens where he grew up and where his parents owned a bar. It is Rockaway Park, not Far Rockaway. The obituary also omitted a survivor  a daughter, Leslie Dwyer, of Glen Rock, N.J.

title: Living and Dying in Albany
description: For a concrete measure of how New Yorkers are hurt by Albanys chronic dysfunction, consider the State Legislatures prolonged dithering over the Family Health Care Decisions Act: a relatively small but vital statutory fix to allow family members to make health decisions for incapacitated loved ones.

title: What Do the Elderly Owe the Young?
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Look at Annuities
description: To the Editor:

title: DuPont in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bipartisan Plan for a Tax Break to Create Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiscal Scare Tactics
description: These days its hard to pick up a newspaper or turn on a news program without encountering stern warnings about the federal budget deficit. The deficit threatens economic recovery, were told; it puts American economic stability at risk; it will undermine our influence in the world. These claims generally arent stated as opinions, as views held by some analysts but disputed by others. Instead, theyre reported as if they were facts, plain and simple.

title: The Sporting Mind
description: After Hitler came to power, the sociologist Eugen Rosenstock-Huessy emigrated to the United States.

title: Will Science Take the Field?
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Fade to White
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Friday about Howard Zinn, the author of A Peoples History of the United States, erroneously included an award among his many honors. His book La Guardia in Congress received an honorable mention in the competition for the American Historical Associations Albert J. Beveridge Award; it did not win the award itself.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: A Death Prompts an Inquiry
description: An accident that killed Guadalupe Alberto, a former autoworker, is adding to the push for a broader inquiry into problems with acceleration in Toyotas.

title: Can Republicans Capitalize on Democrats Worries?
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: The Chicago Way: Aldermens Furloughs Arent Quite So Painful
description: Chicago aldermen often insist that their job is so demanding that they never really get a days rest. Now, that assertion is being confirmed by an official policy of Mayor Richard M. Daleys administration.

title: Hyde Park-Style Politics Are Evident in Preckwinkle Victory
description: As chants of Toni, Toni, Toni washed over her on Tuesday night, Alderman Toni Preckwinkles pearl necklace glistened in the bright glare of televised victory. She had just become the Democratic nominee for Cook County Board president.

title: Stalled Health Care Bill Leaves Drug Makers in Regulatory Limbo
description: With the possible demise of health care legislation, getting back to business as usual may not be the best thing for the nations drug makers.

title: With Daughters Struggle, a New Role for Dempster
description: Pro athletes are easily typecast as societys chosen ones, an exalted class of millionaire performers with the financial means to enjoy a worry-free life and the sense of entitlement to expect as much.

title: Bucks Rookie With Plenty to Prove Isnt Focusing Only on Points
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  After the worst game of his brief N.B.A. career, Brandon Jennings tucked himself into a wooden locker stall, wrapped in oversize towels and frustration. His head was low and his voice lower.

title: More Ways to Torture Mets Fans
description: For Mets fans, Oct. 19, 2006, is a date which will live in infamy, to borrow a phrase from Franklin D. Roosevelt. The place: Shea Stadium. The scene: Bases loaded in the bottom of the ninth of Game Seven of the National League championship series. The moment: Carlos Beltran watched a curveball from Adam Wainwright cross the plate for strike three. Game over. The St. Louis Cardinals beat the Mets and advance to the World Series.

title: North Korea Says It Will Release U.S. Missionary
description: SEOUL  North Korea said Friday that it would release Robert Park, a Christian missionary from the United States who illegally entered the country on Christmas Day to urge its leader, Kim Jong-il, to shut down its concentration camps, free all its prisoners and resign.

title: In Haiti, Help From Above
description: As wide-scale challenges of aid distribution persist, owners of private aircraft are delivering small-scale assistance.

title: The Eyes of Texas Werent Upon Him
description: Nearly every elite college football program tried to recruit Seantrel Henderson, an offensive lineman from Minnesota who is considered by most analysts to be the nations top high school football recruit.

title: Muni, Food, Busybodies
description: Here are excerpts from the most-viewed posts on this weeks Bay Area blog.

title: Clinic Works to Include Ex-Inmates in Health Cares Embrace
description: The inadequacy of prison health care in California was one reason for the federal court decisions that will reduce the prison population by 40,000 inmates, starting this year. As the former prisoners, and their illnesses, move back into communities, they will struggle to overcome a new set of obstacles and find a way to better care.

title: Vermouth Takes Its Place on the Rocks
description: About a year ago I started drinking vermouth. I discovered it one evening when I didnt feel like a beer, a cocktail would be too strong and uncorking a bottle of wine seemed extravagant.

title: In Internet Era, an Unwilling Lord for New Age Followers
description: Raj Patels desk sits in a dusty, cement-floored nook in his garage, just beyond a parked gray Prius, near the washer and dryer. They are humble surroundings for a god.

title: Rangers Surrender Game and Stage to Ovechkin Show
description: The hockey world knows how great Alexander Ovechkin is and how dangerous he makes an already strong Russian Olympic team at the Vancouver Games later this month.

title: Devils and Czech National Team Await Eliass Return
description: NEWARK  As birds in the rafters at Prudential Center heralded his arrival, Patrik Elias rejoined his teammates for practice Thursday morning  a positive development for the struggling Devils, as well as the Czech Republic national team.

title: Correction
description: An article on arguments over the use of artificial turf on playing fields around the area in last Fridays Bay Area report misstated the number of fields in San Carlos where artificial turf may be installed. It is one, not two.

title: Robinson Is Set to Start
description: Nate Robinson will start at point guard for the Knicks on Friday, completing a stunning turnaround.

title: A Personal Assistant on Your iPhone
description: The pop-culture record shows that most artificially intelligent assistants dont work out too well for their human masters.

title: U.S.D.A. Plans to Drop Program to Trace Livestock
description: Faced with stiff resistance from ranchers and farmers, the Obama administration has decided to scrap a national program intended to help authorities quickly identify and track livestock in the event of an animal disease outbreak.

title: Ionas Resurgence Keeps Others Off Balance
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.  Nearly 2,500 fans filled much of the stands on both sides of the court. The cheerleaders in maroon stretched across one baseline, while the dance team in gold tops sparkled across the other. And in the middle of it all, Iona was conducting mens basketball business as usual.

title: Devils Land High-Scoring Kovalchuk in Deal With Thrashers

title: Northern Ireland: Deal Is Reached on Police Powers
description: EUROPE

title: Air Products Said to Offer $5.1 Billion for Its Rival Airgas
description: Air Products and Chemicals, a producer of industrial gases, has made an unsolicited $5.1 billion offer for a rival, Airgas, after having been rebuffed for months, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

title: Frances Reid, Actress of Stage and Daytime TV, Dies at 95
description: Frances Reid, one of daytime televisions most enduring performers, who played the family matriarch Alice Horton on the soap opera Days of Our Lives for more than 40 years, died Wednesday in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 95.

title: San Franciscos Charter an Obstacle to Muni Budget Fix
description: Of all the problems facing San Franciscos cash-strapped City Hall, nothing has more immediate political and financial impact than the financial crisis at the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency.

title: Bill Dudley, Slow, Small, but an N.F.L. Star, Dies at 88
description: Bill Dudley, who had a Hall of Fame career as one of college and professional footballs most dynamic running backs in the 1940s and early 1950s despite a small frame and a lack of speed, died Thursday. He was 88 and lived in Lynchburg, Va.

description: Graffiti artist Eric Felisbret records the history of graffiti in New York City in a new book.

title: From Hepburn to Mickelson, Riviera Embraces Hollywood and Golf
description: LOS ANGELES  Among all the opening holes in championship golf, many are more difficult and some are easier than the opening hole at the Riviera Country Club. But as an introduction to everything that makes the course one of the most revered in golf, the first tee is the perfect portal into another world and time.

title: Toyotas Top Executive Under Rising Pressure
description: NAGOYA, Japan  When Akio Toyoda took control last summer of the company started by his grandfather, his challenge was to lead Toyota out of its worst financial crisis in half a century.

title: Leader Shows Touch and Power in First Round of the Northern Trust Open
description: LOS ANGELES  Dustin Johnson, generally regarded as the best athlete and one of the longest hitters on the PGA Tour, showed his mastery of the total game on Thursday. On a relatively calm day at Riviera Country Club, the 25-year-old Johnson used superior iron play and a deft putting touch to shoot a bogeyless seven-under-par 64 and grab the first-round lead in the Northern Trust Open.

title: Marta Moves Up California Coast in W.P.S. Dispersal Draft

description: drudgery \drj-re, dr-j-re\ noun

title: Ewing Has New Ally in Coaching Bid
description: Patrick Ewing will have a team of his own to coach next weekend, albeit for only one day, and for a simple exhibition game. Symbolically, at least, its a nice start.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about John A. Larkin, who twice proposed constructing the tallest buildings in the world in New York City, misstated the year he died. It was 1955, not 1959.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Thursday about a Mississippi company apparently enlisting a federal agencys help to silence complaining guest workers referred incorrectly to investigations prompted by the complaints. The Justice Department is reportedly investigating the company, Signal International. It is not investigating the agency, Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

title: Devils and Czechs Await Eliass Return
description: NEWARK  As birds in the rafters at Prudential Center heralded his arrival, Patrik Elias rejoined his teammates for practice Thursday morning  a positive development for the struggling Devils, as well as the Czech Republic national team.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Thursday about the delay in confirming Dawn Johnsen to lead the Office of Legal Counsel, misidentified the university where she teaches. It is Indiana University, not the University of Indiana.

title: Offering Grim Picture, Union Chief Says Teams Are Preparing for 11 Lockout
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  About 72 hours before Super Bowl kickoff, the rivals blocking and tackling and eye-gouging broke out, if only rhetorically, in dueling presentations from the union and the league over the N.F.L.s looming labor situation and games that might be lost some 19 months from now.

title: Obama Maps a Way Forward for a Health Overhaul
description: Speaking to enthusiastic supporters at a fund-raiser here, President Obama on Thursday evening presented his clearest plan yet to move forward with comprehensive health care legislation, saying that he wanted to meet with Democrats, Republicans and independent experts, lay out the facts for the American people and then, he said, I think that we have got to move forward on a vote.

title: News Quiz | February 5, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Bay Area Report Highlights: Health Care for Ex-Inmates and Vermouths New Appeal
description: Help With Health Care When Prison Doors Open | As former prisoners, and their illnesses, move back into communities, they will struggle to overcome a new set of obstacles and find a way to better care. What happens in the prison system isnt isolated in the prison system, said Dr. John Stobo, senior vice president for health sciences and services for the University of California system. It spills over into the free world. But some Bay Area counties are looking to the Transitions Clinic in San Francisco as a possible model for ensuring that this group gets health care. The clinic is the first in the country specifically for parolees, combining aggressive outreach  like recruiting prisoners before their release  with a nonjudgmental approach.

title: Are You There, God? Its Me, Scott
Art Auction Record May Not Be End, Experts Say
description: After a Giacometti statue smashed the art auction record late on Wednesday, fetching $104.3 million, experts are predicting there may be even higher numbers to come, Reuters reported.

title: Phillips Was Treatedat Sex Clinic, Agent Says
description: Steve Phillips, whom ESPN fired last year as a baseball analyst after his affair with a production assistant became public knowledge, spent 45 days in a sex addiction clinic in Hattiesburg, Miss., said his agent, Steve Lefkowitz. Phillips, a former Mets general manager, was treated at the Gentle Path clinic, which Tiger Woods reportedly attended. Phillips is attending after-care therapy; his wife, Marni, is also in therapy in Arizona, Lefkowitz said. Lefkowitz said Phillips expected to discuss his affair, his therapy and his perspective on Woodss infidelities in an interview Monday with Matt Lauer on the Today show.

title: Bond Investors Hungry for Kraft
description: If Krafts stock is any indicator, shareholders are ambivalent about the purchase of Britains cherished candy maker, Cadbury. Yet debt investors handed over $9.5 billion to the food conglomerate on one of the gummiest days in the markets for ages. Irene Rosenfeld, Krafts chief, shouldnt take this confidence, however, as a robust validation of her acquisition strategy, Reuters Breakingviews warns.

title: Norris: Fraying at the Edges

For instance, do you believe that Its not food if it comes to you through the window of a car or that One should always leave the table a little bit hungry? Journalist Michael Pollan has recently written a book that outlines 64 simple principles for eating that will both keep you healthy and help the planet.

description: When Bank of Americas board met to approve the acquisition of an investment bank on Sept. 15, 2008, members thought they were going to buy Lehman Brothers Holdings, not Merrill Lynch, according to New Yorks attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, Bloomberg News reports.

description: Federal prosecutors filed court papers Thursday indicating a former Intel executive charged in a huge insider trading case has agreed to waive indictment, a necessary step before a guilty plea can be entered.

description: Korea Development Banks grand dream of breaking into the league of top global banks seems to have gotten harder to achieve, after its bid for an international foray was scuttled this week, Reuters reported.

title: Bill Dudley Dies; He Was a  Star of a Different N.F.L.
description: An intriguing obituary today by the Timesman Frank Litsky on Bill Dudley.Dudley died Thursday at age 88. He was not big or speedy, but managed to become an N.F.L. star in the 1940s and early 1950s. A quotation from Sammy Baugh: We always wondered how he gained as much yardage as he did. But he had that instinct. He would do things that always amazed me, how he could get out of trouble.

description: Carnevale, the festive season before Lent, is celebrated around the world, and Rome is no exception. In fact, over the last couple of years, the city has taken the revelry up a few notches.

title: Blackstone and Resolution Said to Eye R.B.S. Branches

description: Not all the derivative contracts the American International Group wrote on complex securities backed by now-toxic mortgages have ended up being a disaster.

title: Deal Saves N. Ireland Government
description: LONDON  Ending months of dispute that threatened to bring down Northern Irelands power-sharing government, the prime ministers of Britain and Ireland on Friday hailed a breakthrough agreement to transfer the provinces police and justice system from Britain to local control on April 12.

title: S.E.C. Drops Action Against Broadcom Execs
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it will not pursue a civil action for stock-option backdating filed against four of Broadcoms former executives.

title: How to Survive a 6-Mile Fall
description: Todays idea: If youre going to plummet 35,000 feet from a plane without a parachute and live to tell the tale, its probably best to ride a piece of debris on the way down.

description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

description: Elizabeth Hawes is the author of New York, New York: How the Apartment House Transformed the Life of the City, 1869-1930 and, most recently, the biography/memoir Camus: A Romance.

title: A Perfect Day to Name a Fish Restaurant
description: That my first name for my restaurant was Bananafish was only natural, if ill-fitting, since all the names I think of have something to do with J.D. Salinger. My first dog was named Seymour, An Introduction.

title: Dimon Gets $10 Million in JPMorgan Shares
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, received roughly $10 million worth of shares in the bank he runs after exercising expiring 10-year-old stock options, according to regulatory filings.

title: Keeping Track of Super Bowl Trucks
description: Its fair to say that when Pete Townshend and Roger Daltrey of the Who arrive in Miami to prepare for their halftime performance at the Super Bowl, many people will probably be watching over them.

title: Speed Read for Friday, Feb. 5
description: Here are some highlights from Fridays editions of The New York Times:

title: Sampler: Demon Sheep Ad and More Would-Be Lawyers
description: Segregation at Charter Schools | Charter schools nationwide are racially segregated, according to a study from the Civil Rights Project at the University of California, Los Angeles. About three out of four black students who attend charter schools are among student populations that are at least 90 percent minority. The pattern of racial isolation is similar in Bay Area and California charter schools. These are the very kind of schools that decades of civil rights struggles fought to abolish in the South, researchers said. Charter school supporters criticized the study. The civil rights issue here is the persistent achievement gap and high dropout rates for these students when they are left to languish in traditional schools that fail to meet their academic needs, said Jed Wallace, chief executive and president of the California Charter Schools Association. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Pakistan Blasts Kill Shiite Worshipers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A huge bomb blast tore apart a bus carrying Shiites to a religious procession in the southern city of Karachi on Friday afternoon, and barely two hours later another lethal explosion struck a hospital where many of the wounded had been taken, police and hospital officials said.

title: Berkshire Sells $8 Billion in Bonds
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of billionaire Warren E. Buffett, has sold $8 billion in bonds to help finance its acquisition of the Burlington Northern railroad company, Bloomberg News reported, citing an unnamed source.

title: Behind the Scenes at Crazy Heart, a Saga Worthy of Its Own Country Song
description: The Oscar-sleeper Crazy Heart, which this week earned three Oscar nominations  one for Jeff Bridges highly praised lead performance as a down-and-out country singer, one for Maggie Gyllenhaals supporting performance as an admiring journalist and one for its music  is also the source of a poignant, back-stage saga worthy of its own country song.

title: Head of A.I.G. Jet-Leasing Unit Steps Down
description: The American International Group said late Thursday that Steven Udvar-Hazy, director and chief executive of its plane-leasing arm, the International Lease Finance Corporation, would step down effective Friday.

title: Anticipating Federal Rules, New Power Plant Requests Carbon Dioxide Limits
description: A Texas company that builds power plants around the country said Thursday that it had been granted a federal permit for a new one near San Francisco that, at its own request, sets a limit for carbon dioxide output.

title: UBS Begins Reorganizing U.S. Wealth Management Unit
description: UBS, the troubled Swiss bank that has been battered by a tax evasion investigation in the United States, is reorganizing its Americas wealth management division in an attempt to stem outflows, Reuters reported.

title: Four British Lawmakers Charged Over Expenses
description: LONDON  In the latest twist of a scandal that has stained the reputation of British Parliament members with claims of widespread fraud on their expense accounts, the countrys chief prosecutor said Friday that criminal charges, including false accounting, would be brought against four legislators.

title: The Spanish Tragedy
description: As Europe is roiled by sovereign debt fears, its important to realize that the crisis in the largest of the PIIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece, Spain) has nothing to do with fiscal irresponsibility. On the eve of the crisis, Spain was running a budget surplus; its debts, as you can see in the figure above, were low relative to GDP.

title: Jobless Rate Falls to 9.7%, Giving Hope Worst Is Over
description: The unemployment rate unexpectedly dipped to 9.7 percent in January, from 10 percent in December, the government reported Friday, buoying hopes that the worst job market in at least a quarter-century is finally improving.

title: We Three Things | Cherry Picking
description: The Moment is proud to introduce We Three Things, by Leanne Shapton, a roundup of three items from the current visual landscape that share a common theme. Shapton, a former art director of the New York Times Op-Ed page as well as an author (Important Artifacts and Personal Property From the Collection of Lenore Doolan and Harold Morris, Including Books, Street Fashion, and Jewelry), illustrator and publisher, connects the dots.

title: Explosions Amid Crowds of Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq Kill at Least 27 and Wound Scores
description: BAGHDAD  At least two explosions tore through crowds marching to the burial place of Shiite Islams most revered martyr Friday in the culmination of ritual mourning that has drawn millions to the holy city of Karbala in one of the worlds largest pilgrimages. At least 27 people were killed and dozens more were wounded.

title: The Early Word: Unemployment Rate Dips to 9.7%
description: The unemployment rate has fallen to 9.7 percent after employers shed 20,000 jobs in January.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Newcomer Lands at No. 1
description: Our manga list tends to be filled with double-digit volume numbers, making it a little scary to jump on board and try a series for the first time. This is not the case for Black Butler, published by Yen Press, which lands at No. 1 this week. This is the books first volume. It centers on Sebastian, the trusted aide to a 12-year-old English noble. The publishers Web site describes Sebastian as all capable, whether hes called to save a dinner party gone awry or probe the dark secrets of Londons underbelly. There are also hints that Sebastian, perhaps, may not be completely human. Volumes 2 and 3 will go on sale in May and October.

title: Jackson Heights Loses Its Living Room
description: Have you seen Colorado? Rocco Ortiz asked the bartender at the Cavalier Restaurant and Lounge around lunchtime on Wednesday. The bartender promptly told him that the man known within the restaurants walls as Colorado does not come by on Wednesday afternoons because that is when he does his laundry.

title: Wall Street Takes a Dip and Then Comes Back
description: Wall Street indexes swung wildly on Friday but ended the day higher as investors tried to look beyond fears that Europes debt crisis would choke off global growth.

title: Jobs Are Up! I Mean Down! Whatever
description: A confusing employment report this morning: employment down, but unemployment also down. Nor is this a story about workers dropping out of the labor force; the report shows an increase in the employment-population ratio, the percentage of adults who are working. What?

title: Obama Statue to Leave Indonesia Park
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A recently erected statue of President Obama as a 10-year-old boy will be removed from a public park here, city officials said Friday, bowing to vociferous criticism on Facebook just a month before Mr. Obama is scheduled to visit Indonesia.

description: Professors Steven M. Davidoff and Peter J. Henning have teamed up to analyze the latest trials and tribulations of Bank of America in its acquisition of Merrill Lynch:

title: Cue the Directors Adrenaline
description: MARTIN SCORSESES dark, twisty detective thriller Shutter Island is set in 1954, in the full flowering of what W. H. Auden had, just a few years earlier, called the Age of Anxiety. I dont know, maybe Im stuck in that time, Mr. Scorsese said recently, sounding a little weary as he talked about a film that started out as an entertainment, though I guess I dont really know how to do that, he said. It always seems to become something else.

title: Lobbying by Banking Industry Threatens Student Loan Overhaul
description: Weve been talking all week on The Choice about President Obamas plans for financial aid, including his proposal to phase banks out of the student loan business and to use hundreds of millions in dollars in government savings to boost the Pell Grant program.

title: East Coast Is Hit by Potentially Epic Snowstorm
description: WASHINGTON  One of the largest winter storms the Mid-Atlantic region has seen in decades swept into Washington and Baltimore on Friday, grounding flights, closing schools and government offices, and sending residents racing to stock up on groceries and rock salt before the snow accumulated to what are expected to be record-setting depths.

title: Finding Hope in the Jobless Numbers
description: If you were worried the job market was starting to deteriorate again, todays employment report lets you stop worrying. The job market is still improving.

description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: On Dont Ask, Dont Tell': Debating a Proposed Repeal
description: Overview | Should gays and lesbians be allowed to serve openly in the military? What issues are at stake in this issue? In this lesson, students consider the law and the arguments for and against repealing it, then engage in a structured academic controversy about whether or not the dont ask, dont tell policy should be repealed.

title: Academy Bends Its Rules for Hurt Locker
description: The producers of The Hurt Locker and The Blind Side can start figuring out who theyre going to elbow out of the way at the podium on Oscar night. Though it normally allows only three producers to accept credit for a film, the Academy has ruled that all four from The Hurt Locker  Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal, Nicolas Chartier and Greg Shapiro  had fully functioned as genuine producers of the film, according to a statement, and bent its rules according to a clause which permits it to do so under extraordinary circumstances. The decision follows an appeal by the Hurt Locker team. The three producers of The Blind Side  Gil Netter, Andrew A. Kosove and Broderick Johnson  were also deemed acceptable, if one person short of extraordinary.

title: Lessons From the History of Childbirth
description: After completing medical school and giving birth to four children, physician Randi Hutter Epstein knew a thing or two about childbirth. Even so, she remained intrigued by the wonder of it all.

title: Salvaging a Famous Rust Bucket
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J.

title: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Losses
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: JPMorgans Dimon Gets $17 Million Bonus

title: The Senate Becomes A Polish Joke
description: So, heres the news from the Senate. Martha Johnson was nominated to head the General Services Administration, and was confirmed by a nearly unanimous vote  but only after having had her nomination held hostage for nine months by Senator Kit Bond, who wanted more pork for Kansas City. And now Senator Richard Shelby has placed a hold on  are you seated  all, all, Obama administration nominees, until he gets some pork for Alabama.
