title: What Were Reading
description: Slice reports that Totonnos in Coney Island will reopen on Wednesday, after being shut by a fire almost a year ago.

title: A Serial Plaintiff and His Loyal Opposition
description: Draw the ire of James C. Couri and youll know it. He is hardly shy about taking people to court - an Internet search showed that he has filed more than 60 lawsuits in New York; by his count, he has filed 105 over the last 40 years.

title: Heavy Metal Rooster
description: Video | No peace in the farm yard when this roosters home:

title: Inside the Action: Luge
description: Mark Grimmette, a doubles luge athlete for the United States Olympic team, describes how to steer the sled going 90 miles per hour.

title: Hello, White House. Is Anyone Home?
description: What Jonathan Cohn said. Health care reform is achingly close, but it needs a push from Obama.

title: Electric Motors, Made to Order
description: THE electric motors that drive todays hybrids and electric vehicles are not so different from those pioneered by Nikola Tesla and George Westinghouse a century ago.

title: Jamaican Bobsled Fails to Qualify for Games
description: There will be no Cool Runnings this time around in a Canadian Olympics.

title: Its Prediction Friday
description: Weve known for days which team the former Saints quarterback Archie Manning wants to win on Sunday, but on Prediction Friday everybody else gets into the action.

title: The Motivation Is Perfection
description: DELANCO, N.J.

title: Hes So Vain
description: Reporting on the entertainment business is one of the most bewildering tasks in journalism: no one talks, or people want a favor first, or they suddenly become very curious about the reporters ideas for a screenplay  and even then the unburdening is selective, always with an eye toward concealing the truth. Perhaps the only more distasteful task in the industry is slaving away at a 627-page biography of a celebrity who has mastered these kinds of games, and Peter Biskind must at least be commended for pushing through to completion on Star, his unlovely but ultimately satisfying book about Warren Beatty. Biskind was never under any illusions about his status vis--vis Beatty in Hollywoods peerage  he writes about the thrill he felt when Beatty first acknowledged his existence on the set of Dick Tracy by balling up a piece of gum and shooting it in his direction  but he surmised, since the notion of collaborating on a book partly belonged to the actor, that on this project he had been greenlighted. By reversing himself and denying significant access, Beatty has done a disservice to them both.

title: A Broad U.S. Push to Ease Credit for Small Businesses
description: The Federal Reserve and other financial regulators prodded banks on Friday to ease financing to small businesses, while President Obama proposed expanding two loan programs run by the Small Business Administration.

title: Quote Unquote | For Whom The Belle Tolls
description: -Model Dree Hemingway tells V Magazine that she prefers Harry Potter to her great-grandfathers famous novels. Looks like she chose the right career.

title: Talks With G.O.P. on Financial Bill at Impasse, Dodd Says
description: Two months of Senate negotiations over legislation to rewrite financial regulations  a top priority of the Obama administration  fell apart on Friday amid wrangling over a proposal to create a consumer financial protection agency that would oversee credit cards, mortgages and other products.

title: How Do Parents Pay for College?
description: Now that my son is a college freshman, I see everything in terms of tuition payments. I know that our monthly mortgage is less than our monthly college bill. That a certain freelance assignment will or will not cover a month at school. That the anemic levels of our 529 accounts have rebounded enough to pay for a few months more.

title: Barton Silverman: "Super Bowl"
description: Photographer Barton Silverman on covering the Superbowl.

title: The No(w)osphere
description: As the human population heads toward nine billion and simultaneously becomes ever more interlaced via mobility, commerce and communication links, the potential to shape the human journey  for better or worse  through the sharing of ideas and experiences has never been greater. (My own sense is that the upside will dominate.) From Darwin through Havel, theres been a vision of breaking down tribal and other barriers and enveloping the planet in what some have called noosphere.

title: One More Reason for Denials of Loan Modifications
description: Several distressed homeowners who may be eligible for loan modifications were denied by Chase for a reason that violates the Treasury Departments rules, according to a recent report from ProPublica, a nonprofit news organization.

title: Celebrities for Cuomo
description: It is not just real estate moguls who like Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Hollywood types dig him, too. An article in The Times last week revealed that about 20 percent of Mr. Cuomos donations come from the real estate industry.

title: The Wild, Musical West
description: A Bagger pal has pointed us to an incredible artifact of the early collaboration between Oscar frontrunners James Cameron and Kathryn Bigelow, back when they were Mr. and Mrs. Its a music video  the only one Mr. Cameron directed, apparently  for a shortlived band in the 1980s, Martini Ranch, formed by the actor Bill Paxton  who appeared in Ms. Bigelows Near Dark  and the musician Andrew Todd Rosenthal. The group released only one album, Holy Cow, but it had guest appearances from members of Devo (who had a little something to do with the track called How Can the Labouring Man Find Time for Self-Culture?) and the B-52s, as well as Bud Cort (Harold and Maude) and Judge Reinhold. Good god, the Internet is just fantastic.The video, for Reach, includes cameos by Mr. Reinhold, Paul Reiser and actors from Aliens and Terminator, and is, of course, set in the Wild West. Ms. Bigelow stars as the leader of an outlaw band of female gunslingers who manage to persuade a few good-time gals to join them. Theres also a mariachi band that plays through a hanging and a guy buried up to his neck in sand, trying to get at a martini glass with his tongue. (Reach!) Its over seven minutes long and the music doesnt start until nearly three minutes in, but thats for the best.

title: White House Blasts Shelby Hold on Nominees
description: The White House fired back this morning at a move by Senator Richard Shelby, Republican of Alabama, who placed a blanket hold on dozens of President Obamas nominees awaiting confirmation before the Senate.

title: Weekend Competition: Famous Last Words
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to suggest the final words they would like history to attribute to them.

title: BAE Settles Corruption Charges
description: BAE Systems, Europes largest military contractor, agreed on Friday to plead guilty to two criminal charges and pay nearly $450 million in penalties in the United States and Britain to end long-running investigations into questionable payments made to win huge contracts overseas.

title: Harry Reid Is Complicated
description: Quite frankly, after reading about Harry Reids intolerance for fat people in the profile by Adam Nagourney, I really had no interest in reading any more about him, despite the column inches devoted to his supposedly complicated character.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Ovechkin Shines on Night of Kovalchuk Trade
description: Nine games on Thursday, but the big news was New Jersey nabbing Ilya Kovalchuk from Atlanta for a package of young players who may or may not pan out. Kovalchuk, whose 328 career goals makes him the N.H.L.s top goal scorer since entering the league in 2001, turned down the Thrashers $101 million 12-year contract offer. So Atlanta G.M. Don Waddell dealt him and defenseman Anssi Salmela to the Devils. In return, Devils G.M. Lou Lamoriello gave up slumping Swedish Olympic defenseman Johnny Oduya, slumping rookie forward Niclas Bergfors, disgraced prospect Patrice Cormier (banned for the season by the Quebec junior league for deliberately elbowing an opponent in the head) and the clubs No. 1 draft choice next June.

title: An Offensive Tackle Named Shlomo
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Nikola Tesla, an Inventive Namesake
description: ODD, isnt it, that the people at Tesla Motors named their company after a man who spent years trying to invent a death ray.

title: James Patterson Inc.
description: Although Ive never read a James Patterson book, I bridle at some of the remarks in Jonathan Mahlers article criticizing Patterson and his readers for not measuring up to some vague standard of literary worthiness. As an English teacher for more than 40 years, I know that some people  probably the vast majority  will never be enticed to read works by the likes of Joyce, Faulkner or Updike. If millions choose to read more accessible material, and Patterson chooses to make it available to them, who is in a position to decry those choices? Why do self-appointed critics allow for popular taste in television, music and movies but drift into almost religious solemnity when discussing books? If we can look back at Charles Dickens (maligned by many in his own time) as one of the great 19th-century British novelists, how far-fetched can it be that 50 years from now people will have a similar evaluation of Patterson?

title: Colts Defense Looking to Emerge From Peytons Shadow
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  A lot has been made this week of the New Orleans Saints defense, with its remember me hits and its ability keep the opposing teams offense off the field by any means necessary. But lurking behind Peyton Manning is the Colts defense, a group that has been impressive in Indianapoliss two playoff victories.

title: Complaint Box | Online Insults
description: Who are these people? Seriously. I want names.

title: Power-Sharing Agreement in N. Ireland
description: France24 reports from Ulster where a deal between Northern Ireland's biggest parties for a transfer the provinces police and justice system from Britain to local control on April 12.

title: Chevy Cobalt Is Investigated for Steering Failure
description: After receiving more than 1,100 complaints over several years  including about 750 in the last six months  the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened an investigation into failures of the electric power steering on about 900,000 Chevrolet Cobalts.

title: Ukraines Premier Stumps for Her Turn at the Top
description: IVANO-FRANKIVSK, Ukraine

title: Time for a New Generation at Super Bowl Show?
description: Ever since Janet Jacksons wardrobe malfunction in 2004, Super Bowl halftime shows have tended toward older stars unlikely to generate much controversy, like Bruce Springsteen, Tom Petty, the Rolling Stones and Paul McCartney. (As well as Prince, who until his religious conversion was all about controversy.)

title: Have Your Hours Changed?
description: One bright spot in the January jobs report is that more employers appear to be converting their part-time employees back to full-time workers.

title: Making a Landing Without the Plane
description: What do you do if you find yourself free-falling from a plane without a parachute? In this months issue of Popular Mechanics magazine, Dan Koeppel offers a survival guide, based on simple physics and the stories of a few people who have found themselves in that situation and survived.

title: History, Distilled
description: People dont travel like they used to. The Associated Press reports that five crates of Scotch whisky and two of brandy have been recovered by a team restoring a hut in the Antarctic that was used a century ago by the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton.

title: Air Products Offers $5.1 Billion for Rival Airgas
description: Air Products and Chemicals, a producer of industrial gases, made an unsolicited $5.1 billion offer on Friday for a rival, Airgas, after having been rebuffed for months.

title: Terry Loses England Captaincy
description: It would be nave to say the drama is over, but the John Terry affair has taken a turn toward a conclusion, of sorts. After almost four years as captain of the England team, Terry was stripped of the armband Friday after a meeting with Manager Fabio Capello in London.

title: More to Read
description: Roger Cohen weighs in on Chinas controversy over whether to continue to allow dogs and cats to be eaten. Im happy China eats dog, he writes on The Timess opinion Web site. It so proclaims both a particularity to be prized in a homogenizing world and its rationality. Anyone who doesnt want China to eat dog must logically embrace pigs as pets. He tried some, too. The meat was tender, unctuous, blander than pork, but stronger than chicken.

title: If the Climate Accord Works, Will the Climate Notice?
description: Trevor Houser, who just left the American climate change negotiating team to return to the Peterson Institute for International Economics, has taken a close look at the greenhouse gas emissions reductions pledges of the 92 countries that submitted plans this week under the Copenhagen Accord. Heres the report.

title: The Book of Self-Love
description: In Game Change, the recent tell-all book about the 2008 presidential campaign, the authors blame John Edwardss narcissism for his downfall and describe Bill Clinton as a narcissist on an epic scale. Do a Google search on Tiger Woods and narcissist and you get tens of thousands of references. Try it with the Salahis and you get thousands more. Rush Limbaugh calls President Obama a narcissist, it seems, every 24 hours, while a writer on The Huffington Post recently declared that advanced stages of narcissism thrive on the Right these days.

title: Tales Out of School
description: Of the top 20 universities in the world, according to one 2008 reckoning, just three were outside the United States. Of the top 50, just 14 were. American colleges and universities are unquestionably pre-eminent in teaching and research, attracting students and faculty members from around the world. We may no longer be the nation that exports cars. But we are the nation that exports higher education.

title: Required Viewing | Paris, Texas
description: After screening this German New Wave tear-jerker, you might be surprised to find yourself coveting locally sourced heirloom denim. Paris, Texas (1984) isnt just an epic drama that won the Palm dOr at Cannes; nowadays it feels curiously in step with the current cultures ongoing American heritage trip. Shot largely in the Southwest, the film is a paean to America the Authentic: ghost towns, cuffed jeans, the highway, the mustache, the desert landscape, Marlboros, leather boots, chamois shirts, motels, Super-8 home movies, railroad tracks. How convenient then that the Criterion Collection has just remastered the film under the supervision of its director, Wim Wenders, and packaged it stylishly for DVD and Blu-ray. The film, written by Sam Shepard, comes across like a sumptuous coffee-table book inhabited by Harry Dean Stanton, Dean Stockwell and Nastassja Kinski, haunted by the melancholy vibrato of Ry Cooders slide guitar. As the writer Nick Roddick laments in the accompanying essay, The world to which Wenders pays homage is vanishing fast  cellphones have replaced photogenic phone booths, McDonalds franchises have gobbled up roadside diners. No amount of limited-edition Red Wings can turn back that tide, as watching the film makes ravishingly and heartbreakingly clear.Paris, Texas, DVD or Blu-ray ($31.96), available at Criterion.com.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE LOST CITY OF Z: A Tale of Deadly Obsession in the Amazon,  by David Grann (Vintage Departures, $15.95.) Percy Harrison Fawcett, Grann writes, was the last of the great Victorian explorers who ventured into uncharted realms with little more than a machete, a compass and an almost divine sense of purpose. He became obsessed with rumors of a sophisticated lost civilization in the Amazon, which he called the City of Z; he disappeared while searching for it in 1925. Grann pairs this tale with the story of his own sometimes comical pursuit of Fawcett. This evocative rendering of the vanished age of exploration, Michiko Kakutani said in The Times, has the pace and excitement of a movie thriller.

title: Editors Choice
description: JUST KIDS,  by Patti Smith (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.) The downtown rockers memoir of her early career and her relationship with Robert Mapplethorpe is a spellbinding, diverting portrait of funky-but-chic New York in the late 60s and early 70s.

title: From Russia, No Love
description: About 40 years ago, a British teenager named Kevin visited Leningrad with a group of high school students. He managed to form a special friendship with Lena, one of their young English-speaking guides. At his carefree suggestion, they separated from the group and roamed the majestic avenues, rode the metro (he was stunned by its palatial elegance) and even tried to take daringly unflattering photographs of women waiting in line at a shop, just about escaping the attention of a stern policeman. Before saying goodbye, Kevin took a snapshot of 14-year-old Lena and presented her with a silver bracelet from the exclusive Beriozkashop for foreigners theyd visited on the tour  though she might have preferred a forbidden book by Bulgakov, displayed near equally unattainable tins of shrimp and expensive French Cognac.

title: Eternal Life
description: From the very beginning there was something uncanny about the cancer cells on Henrietta Lackss cervix. Even before killing Lacks herself in 1951, they took on a life of their own. Removed during a biopsy and cultured without her permission, the HeLa cells (named from the first two letters of her first and last names) reproduced boisterously in a lab at Johns Hopkins  the first human cells ever to do so. HeLa became an instant biological celebrity, traveling to research labs all over the world. Meanwhile Lacks, a vivacious 31-year-old African-American who had once been a tobacco farmer, tended her five children and endured scarring radiation treatments in the hospitals colored ward.

title: Shackletons Whisky Dug Up in Antarctica
description: Updated | 12:37 p.m. As my colleague Eric Asimov notes on The Pour blog, three crates of Scotch whisky and two crates of brandy left beneath the floorboards of a hut by the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton in 1909, at the end of a failed expedition to the South Pole, have been unearthed by a team from the Antarctic Heritage Trust.

title: Slice of Lives
description: He simply had to follow his instincts  he had to be true to himself, William Boyd writes in the turbulent first chapter of his new novel. The self in question here is an unremarkable young academic named Adam Kindred, who has become, with awful suddenness, a victim of dire circumstance, a puzzled plaything of fate: he is the only suspect in the murder of a man he barely knows, and the instinct he follows, blindly, is the one that tells him to run like hell. Since Adam is completely innocent, this impulse seems, at first blush, rash and stupid, just the sort of irrational, spontaneous bad choice people in thrillers so often make, to seal their author-destined doom. But Ordinary Thunderstorms isnt a thriller, exactly, and Boyd isnt the kind of author who punishes his characters too severely for their spasms of unreason. His instinct, rather, is to put them through their paces, let them sweat a bit and then, in recognition of their services to his fiction, leave them in exhausted peace.

title: Faith-Based Defiance
description: In 1995, one million black men  give or take a couple of hundred thousand  gathered on the National Mall in Washington. The Million Man March bested the March on Washington of 1963 in turnout but otherwise fell far short of that historic benchmark. It was a rebellion without a cause, lacking any specific political agenda, and its organizer, the notorious demagogue Louis Farrakhan, was as repellent as the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was inspiring. Perhaps worst of all, the Million Man March announced its chauvinism in its very name, deliberately excluding half the black community.

title: Dodd Sees Impasse on Financial Overhaul
description: The senator who is shepherding the Obama administrations package of Wall Street reforms through Congress said on Friday morning that talks with his Republican counterpart had broken down, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: Owner of Langston Hughes Home in Cleveland Weighs Options
description: Langston Hughes has a block named after him in New York: Langston Hughes Place, East 127th Street between Madison and Fifth. But the house where Hughes lived, at No. 20 East 127th, is no longer open to the public. In 2008 the owner evicted tenants who had been running an informal Hughes museum there and now the only trace of Hughes is a plaque in front of the building, which was designated as a landmark in 1981.

title: Some Fun Tonight
description: David Kirbys brief biography of Little Richard reads the way Richards shows of the past few decades have played. Its an engaging, intermittently exciting but ultimately frustrating mix of assertion, reminiscence, free association, repetition, clowning and showing off, with just enough talent on display to keep you from walking out. Kirby, a poet and critic who teaches English at Florida State University, has plenty to say about the rock n roll originator, as Little Richard likes to call himself. Its carving the good bits out from everything surrounding them thats the problem.

title: When Maintenance Is Long in Arrears
description: Q.

title: Outwaiting a Picky Board
description: Q.

title: Bill Clinton, in Haiti, Emphasizes Urgent Need for Sanitation and Health Care
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Former President Bill Clinton, who is the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, returned here on Friday to meet with government and aid officials, visit a health clinic and deliver medical supplies, computers and generators.

title: A Wrinkle in Time
description: Don DeLillos spectacular career seemed to have reached some kind of omega zone almost 20 years ago. After the red-hot streak of The Names, White Noise and Libra, his 10th novel, Mao II, was so self-derivative that one wondered how much he had left in the tank. The answer came in the form of Underworld, an epic rejoinder that left the reader doubly pummeled: both by the scale of the undertaking and by the sustained intensity with which it was achieved. After such titanic exertions, DeLillos next novel, The Body Artist, felt like a warm-down, but it was followed, disastrously, by the high-concept self-karaoke of Cosmopolis. Even Falling Man, although a partial return to form, failed to satisfy completely: the 9/11 subject matter demanded more. So longtime admirers will approach DeLillos new novel, Point Omega, with as much anxiety as excitement.

title: Sellers Responsibility After the Closing
description: Q.

title: French Contentions
description: The Dreyfus Affair is timely again, more than 100 years after the exoneration of Alfred Dreyfus from trumped-up charges. Convicted of high treason by a military court that based its verdict on a bogus secret document, Dreyfus, a Jewish army captain, spent more than four years in the hellhole of Devils Island before his case was revised in 1899. During those years France itself was divided as it had not been since the Revolution, with party lines rigidly drawn, old friendships broken and families rent asunder between Dreyfusards and antis.

title: Feb. 7  13
description: Film

title: The Scoundrel and the Bride
description: A prominent historian once asked if I didnt get tired of the sort of research novelists often feel obliged to pursue. Must we really know how 19th-century Latvian lumberjacks brushed their teeth? Arent you tempted to make things up? Coming from a historian, this sounded like heresy  or perhaps the historians dream vacation. Of course Im tempted, I said. I fudge, I make things up, but I also pounce on arcana. Moreover, to work under the constraints of historical fact can spur the imagination, just as working with rhyme and meter does for poets.

title: Drinking and Grieving
description: They travel to St. Kitts for winter breaks and to Florence for their 20th wedding anniversaries. They play CDs of Joan Sutherland in their car radios. When crises arise they take to bourbon in the midafternoon and snack on olive tapenade. Romes air pollution is a likely subject of conversation over their dinners, which might feature gnocchi in basil cream sauce and radicchio and orange salad, washed down with a St.-Amour Beaujolais. They read The Economist and go to psychiatrists who subscribe to Paris-Match. Readily dropping foreign phrases, they flatter a woman by saying that she looks like a Balthus or that she has a lot of chien.

title: New York Plans to Topple Public Housing Towers
description: Philadelphia tore down 21. Chicago leveled 79. Baltimore took down 21 as well, and when 6 of them came down in one day in 1995, it threw a parade.

title: A Touch of Evil
description: The beauty of Roberto Bolaos slender mystery novel Monsieur Pain, originally published in 1999 and now translated from the Spanish by the estimable Chris Andrews, is that it doesnt behave much like a mystery novel. By the end of the book, which Bolao wrote in either 1981 or 1982, the mysteries remain unsolved, the ostensible victim may or may not have suffered from foul play and the protagonist intent on figuring out who done it (if anyone did anything at all) appears incapable of doing so.

title: Bored Into Submission
description: To the Editor:

title: The Case Against Yoo
description: To the Editor:

title: Up Front: Vanessa Grigoriadis
description: Vanessa Grigoriadis, who has written magazine articles about movie stars as well as pop stars, seems to have a clear preference.

title: Cruel Love
description: The first lurch comes four lines in. A woman named Irene America is writing in her diary  or, rather, in one of her diaries. She is keeping two: one real, one fake. You gave me the first book in order to record my beginning year as a mother, she writes. It was very sweet of you.

title: Banks Prodded to Ease Lending to Small Firms
description: The Federal Reserve and other financial regulators, which have faced strong pressure from the White House and Congress to stimulate lending to small businesses, prodded banks on Friday to ease such financing, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: New Deputy in San Jose May Foster Good Will With Vietnamese
description: At 2 p.m. on Friday, the San Jose Police Department will take a significant step toward improving the departments contentious relationship with the citys Vietnamese community. In a ceremony at San Joses Family Community Church, the police chief, Rob Davis, will swear in Capt. Phan S. Ngo as the departments first Vietnamese-American deputy chief.

title: The Twitter Train: George Packer Responds
description: Ah, the reverberating beauty of the Internet.

title: Cooking From the Cabbage Patch
description: Few foods are as tasty, versatile and good for you as red cabbage, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Is Everyone a Critic?
description: In SFWeekly.com, Jonathan Kaufman takes in Robert Sietsemas and Francis Lams recent pieces on the future of professional restaurant criticism in the face of crowdsourcing and other Web innovations, and asks, Cant we all just get along?

title: Swap Till You Drop | Art Book Edition
description: Do I really need four Ben Shahn books? If youve ever asked yourself a question like this, pay attention. At the MoMA library on Saturday afternoon, you can swap your unloved art and photography books for new or gently used ones supplied by publishers like D.A.P., area art galleries and fellow swappers. Whatevers left at the end of the day will be donated to the Prison Readers Encouragement Project.

title: Still Mad They Stiffed Him
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Here in California, our governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, spoke about our states infrastructure yesterday. Or tried to. His English still isnt very good.

title: Correction
description: The Diagnosis column on Jan. 24, about a man who became dizzy while swimming and had other reactions to cold temperatures, misspelled the name of the disease for which he was tested. It is Raynaud's syndrome, not Reynaud's.

title: Corned Beef for Breakfast
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: This morning, President Obama spoke at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C. Obama told the crowd that no one should go broke when they get sick in the richest nation on earth, which, I think, is his way of saying were going to start exporting sick people to China.

title: Liquidators Say $370 Million Is Found in Stanford Account
description: Funds and property valued at about $370 million traced to R. Allen Stanford, who is suspected in a Ponzi scheme, have been found, but disputes over control of the assets are holding up disbursement, liquidators for Mr. Stanfords offshore bank said on Friday, according to Reuters.

title: Doppel-Gangs of New York
description: Well, its been about a week, but friends are still transforming into celebrities on Facebook, part of the latest fad to hit the social media site.

title: What Could Be More Fun?
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: A couple of days ago, there was the annual race, people come from all over the world, and they race up the stairs of the Empire State Building. Wait a minute. You want to get your heart racing, you really want to get it pump pumping? Do what I do. Drive to work in a Toyota.

title: A Place of Excess
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Have you heard the new slogan? Toyota, just try and stop us.

title: Living in Belmont, the Bronx
description: Belmont is known as the Little Italy of the Bronx -- or, to some, "the real Little Italy."

title: Ask an Elder Law Attorney
description: Craig Reaves, immediate past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, will field legal questions from readers on occasion. You may submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your inquiries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot offer personal legal advice.

title: FriendFinder Networks Pulls Its I.P.O.
description: Sex may sell, but not necessarily as an initial public offering.

title: Turncoats Who Become Heroes
description: ARE you tired of Avatar yet? Not necessarily the movie itself, which shows no sign of fatigue in its march to global box-office and Oscar-broadcast domination, but the urgent questions that keep popping up in its wake. How much money will this blockbuster make? How many Academy Awards will it win? Will it change the way movies are made, ushering in a new era of 3-D, motion-capture, hybrid spectacle?

title: Now Ordering | Ill Have What Shes Wearing
description: After dinner at Vinegar Hill House a few weeks ago, the chef and co-owner Jean Adamson worked the room not in her whites but in a dress. What grabbed the attention of the women at my table was her belt, a sexy, prizefighter-width twist of mahogany leather that was a mix of 70s craft fair with 80s YSL.

title: Chinese Firm Claims Apple Stole iPad Design and Name
description: When it came to naming its new tablet computer, the iPad, Apple was hardly coining an original term. As The Times outlined in a story last week, a number of other electronics companies already sell products that use the iPad name.

title: A University President Advocates Tweaking Tenure
description: Readers of The Choice who are still in high school may not yet realize a critical way in which their professors will be evaluated. Typically, professors are awarded tenure  in many ways a job status as secure as that of a Supreme Court justice  based on formulas that may value their writing published in scholarly journals over that in mainstream publications, to say nothing of their work in the classroom.

title: Books, Readers and Teachers: A Wrap-Up
description: Last week we asked students and teachers about the books they love to read and teach, and weve been delighted by the response.

title: Gates Offers Equipment to Allies
description: ISTANBUL  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pledged Friday that the United States would help protect foreign troops in Afghanistan by offering them armored transport vehicles, surveillance systems and electronic equipment to guard against roadside bombs. Such bombs have claimed more lives than any other weapon in the war.

title: Dummy in the Car-Pool Lane
description: Another daily commute on the Long Island Expressway, another dummy in the high-occupancy-vehicle lane.

title: The Super Bowl of Auteurs
description: Video | If the football classic were brought to you by famous directors:

title: Niles Channels the Black Eyed Peas
description: We know were late to the party on this, but weve been on such a roll posting YouTube videos and its the Friday before a snowstorm (which means people are even lazier than normal), so why not? Here is a video of David Hyde Pierce performing the Black Eyed Peas Boom Boom Pow at the closing festivities of the Sundance Film Festival, alongside the festivals director, John Cooper. There is some synchronized dancing and crotch-grabbing, but lets just say that, in the realm of white rap, Ke$ha is still safe.

title: The Morning Skate: The Kovalchuk Breakaway
description: The Atlanta Thrashers trade of Ilya Kovalchuk surprised no one in the hockey world. The fact they traded him to the New Jersey Devils surprised almost everyone.

title: The Challenge of Pricing Surgery Ahead of Time
description: Dont know how much your hospital surgery will cost you? Well, calling ahead may not help.

title: Boy Found Dead in Midtown Hotel
description: Police detectives are investigating the suspected killing of a 9-year-old boy who was discovered dead in the Peninsula Hotel in Midtown Manhattan on Friday afternoon along with a severely incapacitated woman relative, the authorities said.

title: Toyota President Apologizes
description: Toyota's president Akio Toyoda apologizes to customers about recent global recalls but says the customers' trust in the world's biggest automaker will return.

title: Travel Deals: AirTran Flights From $44
description: AirTran is offering discounted tickets to the warmer climate of your choice, with flights starting as low as $44 one way.

title: Madoff Family Members Agree to Asset Freeze
description: Editors Note Appended

title: How Could I Embrace a Village?
description: AGAINYE and I met in Ibadan, Nigeria, a metropolis of more than two million people in the southwest part of the country, where he was a graduate student in linguistics and I was on a grant researching Nigerian literature.

title: The Reading Life: From London, Personal Ads With Bite and Style
description: The London Review of Books has been running personal ads since 1998, and theyve slowly become a comic institution, unlike any personal ads youll find anyplace else. Absurd, self-deprecating and sometimes excellently kinky, theyre worth the price of an LRB subscription alone.

title: Under Siege in Europe
description: Fortress Europe is now under attack by the market.

title: A Reluctant Return to the Spotlight
description: LONDON

title: Iraqis: Adjusting to America, or Not
description: I work for a doctor in Michigan. Since I arrived in America from Iraq last year my job has shifted from being on the front desk of his clinic to being the person who processes the forms for other people who undergo the immigration medical exam for their green cards.

title: In a First, Women Surpass Men on U.S. Payrolls
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Jennings Is Ready for Showtime
description: The last thing Brandon Jennings said, before finishing off his caramel Frappuccino and concluding our interview Wednesday morning, was about Fridays game between his Milwaukee Bucks and the Knicks: It should be a show, he said, smiling.

title: Answers From a Yoga Instructor, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Bryn Chrisman, a vinyasa flow yoga teacher and kirtan leader in New York City.

title: Book Review Podcast: Amy Bloom and Lee Siegel
description: This week: A conversation with Amy Bloom about her new story collection, Where the God of Love Hangs Out; Lee Siegel discusses Christopher Laschs classic, The Culture of Narcissism; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Trucking and Oil Industries Protest Fuel Mandate in California
description: Californias new mandate for cleaner, low-carbon fuels is being met with resistance by the trucking and petroleum industries.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: What Were Watching
description: Vice TV put up a video today, a kind of interview and travelogue with Frank Falcinelli and Frank Castronovo, the bearded wise men behind the Frankies restaurants in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and Prime Meats in Brooklyn. Its remarkable and not simply because theyre relaxed and totally unmediated, drinking beer at Robertas then kidnapping the chef at Motorino and heading back to Carroll Gardens to make meatballs. The program  one of Vices Munchies broadcasts  shows the Franks at their vested, bearded best. More of these, please.

title: Danger on Tracks: Two Are Hit at Same Station
description: Updated, 4:53 p.m. |It has been a dangerous 24 hours at the Nostrand Avenue subway station in Brooklyn.

title: A Recovery Thats Factory-Built and Gaining Speed
description: A GLOBAL recovery in manufacturing appears to be accelerating. Most manufacturers around the world are reporting an increase in output and new orders, both of which plunged in late 2008 and early 2009 as a credit crisis spurred fears of a new Depression.

title: S.E.C. to Consider Ways to Curb Short-Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will consider adopting short-selling curbs in coming weeks as well as ways to improve market surveillance, Mary L. Schapiro, the S.E.C. chairwoman, said on Friday, according to Reuters.

title: Now Showing | Plastic Fantastic
description: Bakelite, the 20th centurys first plastic, was invented in 1907, 60 years before The Graduate suggested the industry was on the cutting edge. Bakelite in Yonkers: Pioneering the Age of Plastics, an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the Hudson River Museum, showcases 300 objects from the 1910s to the early 21st century that exploit the unique properties of Phenol-formaldehyde: brilliant color, heat resistance and strength. Bakelite is still used today in car parts, plywood and pan handles (Revere Ware, for example), but the earliest pieces in the exhibition show its decorative side.The early Bakelite objects have a very 19th-century form, said Bartholomew F. Bland, curator of exhibitions at the museum. The designers were consciously trying to mimic marble, ebony and burled wood. By the 1920s and 1930s, the age of streamlining made moldable plastics appealing in their own right. Star designers like Raymond Loewy exploited the range of possible colors and shapes, and the exhibition includes a camera he designed in 1937, along with toys, bangles, radios, typewriters, dominoes and intercoms, all of which were culled from the Amsterdam Bakelite Collection, the holdings of Hugh Karraker, a great-grandson of Bakelites inventor, Leo Baekeland, and the Yonkers Historical Society.

title: A 'Little Palace'
description: Filipp and Raya Katz live in a red brick and beige stone house in Bath Beach, Brooklyn.

title: Russia Cool to U.S. Plan for Missiles in Romania
description: MOSCOW  Russian officials reacted coolly on Friday to the news that Romania had agreed to host American missile interceptors starting in 2015, with a top envoy saying that the announcement could directly affect Moscows position as negotiations to replace the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or Start, reach their conclusion.

title: At Pearl Paint, Rumors Flow as Stores Close
description: For years the cluster of Pearl Paint stores in Lower Manhattan  one in a cast-iron building on Canal Street and two in the next block, on Lispenard Street  have been the supply depots where artists found their next blank canvas, that extra tube of cerulean blue or another quart of turpenoid, an odorless substitute for turpentine.

title: An Early Look at Some Super Bowl Auto Ads
description: A recent survey by the research firm Nielsen Homescan confirmed what many of us have long suspected: many people enjoy the Super Bowl television ads more than the game itself.

title: The House of Open Arms
description: THE journey that took Filipp and Raya Katz to the red brick and beige stone house that Ms. Katz calls my little palace began more than half a century ago in the Ukrainian city of Mukachevo, near the Hungarian border. The Katzes, now both in their mid-50s, grew up on the same street, and knew each other as children. A particular bond was the fact that all four of their parents were Holocaust survivors.

title: The Bigger Little Italy
description: THE other day in the Belmont section of the Bronx, two women carrying shopping bags conversed excitedly as they ambled down Crescent Avenue. One wore black winter gear from head to toe; her companion had on jeans and stylish black boots. Something marked their conversation as unusual: half was in Italian and the other in Spanish. But they clearly understood each other.

title: Hadron Collider Set for Half Power
description: The worlds biggest and most expensive physics experiment will finally rumble into regular operation later this month, but it is going to operate at only half power for the next two years and then shut down for a yearlong repair session, CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, said this week.

title: Cory Gubner
description: Mr. Gubner, 43, is the president and chief executive of RHYS Commercial, a full-service commercial real estate company based in Stamford, Conn., that he founded last fall.

title: New Uses for Military Treasures
description: East Garden City

title: A Holiday Gift That Keeps on Giving
description: A SHAPELY 76-foot-high Norway spruce that grew up in Easton, Conn., won a beauty contest, traveled to the bright lights of the big city and served briefly as the holiday diva of Rockefeller Center, is returning to its home state in a humbler but no less significant role  as lumber.

title: Teacher Q | How Has N.C.L.B. Affected Your Teaching?
description: The Obama administration announced this week that it was pursuing a rewrite of No Child Left Behind, and would seek to replace the laws much-criticized system for rating schools based on student test scores, according to an article by education reporter Sam Dillon.

title: Restaurateurs Beg City to Drop Report Card Plan
description: Letter grades are nothing more than a scarlet letter that will keep people from eating out, Geoff Kravitz, a spokesman for the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, said at the first public hearing Friday considering the citys proposal to rate restaurant cleanliness with letter grades.He was not the only one to invoke the stigma of an upper-case A. In point of fact, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene would assign a bright-blue letter A to New York restaurants that have passed inspection. But still, many in the restaurant business objected as if the city had likened them to Hester Prynne at a public shaming.

title: Is He or Isnt He the Messiah?
description: The leader of a New Age movement is taking issue with some of his own followers who have declared a San Francisco man their messiah.

title: A Search Engine That Relies on Humans
description: A report this week laying out a strategy for social search has been getting a good deal of attention in tech circles. The paper, Anatomy of a Large Scale Social Search Engine, was written by Damon Horowitz and Sepandar Kamvar of Aardvark, one of several companies working on creating social search engines. As of October 2009, Aardvark had about 90,000 users.

title: Index Funds, Dowdy to Some, Get a Notable Endorsement
description: FOR the wealthy, index funds have an image problem. They are considered the economy cars of the investing world: theyll get you there but not in style and youre always worried they may break down. Anyone at a serious level of wealth, the thinking goes, needs the equivalent of a luxury sedan, with strategic stock choices, hedge funds, private equity, real estate.

title: An Urban Alternative
description: ENTICED by notions of buying a home to grow into, Erica Brembos and her husband, Satya Maganti, thought about getting a big house and a big yard in the suburbs of northern New Jersey. After all, Ms. Brembos said, it was common wisdom that people got more space for your money in the suburbs.

title: Outsider Art Fair 2010
description: The Outsider Art Fair begs the question, what exactly is an Outsider artist?

title: Book Review Podcast: Amy Bloom and Lee Siegel
description: This week: A conversation with Amy Bloom about her new story collection Where the God of Love Hangs Out; Lee Siegel discusses Christopher Laschs classic, The Culture of Narcissism; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Loans for Green Homes
description: BORROWERS looking to make energy upgrades in their homes that will lower utility bills, along with their environmental impact, may soon find additional options available to them.

title: Sick and Tired of Treading Water
description: Yonkers

title: The Bonus Bounce
description: IF the mix of optimism and uncertainty that pervades the New York residential real estate market right now can be symbolized by one property, a leading candidate may well be the penthouse at 1055 Park Avenue.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Feb. 5
description: Three photographs that stand out in Fridays show do so because of elements that dominate, while occupying only a small portion of the frame: a food coupon in Slide 2, a boys head emerging from a sea of men in prayer (Slide 4) and the agonized face of a bombing victim (Slide 5).

title: One Costly Condo
description: IN the contest for Brooklyns priciest condo, a Brooklyn Heights triplex with sweeping Manhattan and harbor views has just taken the prize, with an $8.495 million sale price.

title: At Top City Schools, Lack of Diversity Persists
description: Just seven black students were admitted to Stuyvesant High Schools incoming freshman class, down from a dozen last year, according to numbers released Friday by the citys Education Department. The number of Hispanics also dropped incrementally, with 17 being admitted this year, compared with 24 last year. A total of 958 students were admitted last week for next years freshman class at Stuyvesant, long regarded as the crown jewel of the citys schools.

title: Signs of Damage to Public Trust in Climate Findings
description: CBS News has run a report summarizing fallout from the illegal distribution of climate scientists email messages and files and problems with the 2007 report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The conclusion is that missteps and mistakes are creating broader credibility problems for climate science.

title: Chicken Soup for the Post-Salinger Soul
description: Last month in the Book Review, Katie Roiphe blamed the weak literary libidos of the current crop of Great American Male Novelists on the influence of feminism.

title: But Does It Have a Garage?
description: JIMMIE JOHNSON, who made history last year when he won his fourth consecutive Nascar Sprint Cup Series championship, has just sold his 3,200-square-foot loft in Chelsea for $4 million.

title: Pelosi: We Will Pass Health Insurance Reform
description: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, predicted on Friday that Democrats would succeed in winning passage of major health care legislation this year, and she described the bill as a core component of her partys effort to improve the economy.

title: The Unedited Version
description: The Unedited Version

title: Gheorghiu Pulls Out of Carmen Completely
description: First it was eight, then two and now zero.

title: Tomatoes Tossed at Plan to Post Restaurant Grades
description: Restaurant owners and their friends jammed a hearing Friday to speak against the citys proposal to require them to display the letter grades they receive on their regular health inspections. Letter grades are nothing more than a scarlet letter that will keep people from eating out, said Geoff Kravitz, a spokesman for the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce. Read the whole story at Diners Journal.

title: Obama Pays Tribute to Fallen C.I.A. Officers
description: President Obama paid tribute today to the seven Americans killed in a suicide bombing late last year in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, the single deadliest attack in the history of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Closer Scrutiny for School Lunches
description: USA Today has been doing great work digging into the safety of school food. This is the latest. The Department of Agriculture announced measures to tighten requirements on companies that supply ground beef to schools and require more frequent and thorough testing of the safety of the meat, a subject Michael Moss has been reporting on.

title: Breess Colleagues See an Amazing Athlete Within
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  As Drew Brees carried the New Orleans Saints to their first Super Bowl appearance, he was described as a humanitarian, a thinker, an overachiever and an underdog.

title: Weekend Track Work Called on Account of Snow
description: If you can brave the snow and wind this weekend, youll actually have an easier time getting around town by mass transit than usual.

title: In Ads, Veterans Push for Energy Bill
description: A Democratic-leaning group, VoteVets, has begun a campaign involving $2 million in advertisements to pressure lawmakers to pass clean energy legislation, saying that the countrys dependence on foreign oil endangers troops and enables terrorists.

title: Testing Your Internet Speed: Advanced Edition
description: After reading my article about testing the quality of an Internet connection, several readers wrote with other suggested software. These tools are all a bit less user-friendly than the Web pages described in the article, but they can offer more information and a better understanding of whats working and not working.

title: From the Nevada Desert to Roads Less Traveled
description: Gonjasufi

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
