description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti Hospitals Fight Against TB Falls to One Man
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  At a fly-infested clinic hastily erected alongside the rubble of the only tuberculosis sanatorium in this country, Pierre-Louis Monfort is a lonely man in a crowded room.

title: Freeney Sits Out Practice
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Dwight Freeney, whose right ankle sprain has been one of the biggest story lines of Super Bowl week, did not practice Friday, and remains questionable for Sundays game.

title: Chic in Review | Stealing Is So Last Season
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Santa Fe is celebrating its 400th anniversary this year. But as Henry Shukman writes in this weeks cover story, the citys heart and soul  including its artistic, spiritual, culinary and architectural facets  are in a state of constant renewal.

title: Snowcapping the Weeks End
An Interview With Gary Locke
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Commerce Secretary Gary Locke.

title: Convention Is Trying to Harness Tea Party Spirit
description: NASHVILLE  As they opened their inaugural national convention here, Tea Party advocates from across the country declared that they would turn the grass-roots anger that burst onto the streets a year ago into real political power, wielding money and campaign infrastructure as well as sheer energy.

title: In Visit to Fox News, Jon Stewart Faults Fox News
description: Jon Stewart, who already had a reputation for lobbing word grenades at media personalities and outlets that displease him, this week delivered one of the most sustained criticisms of Fox News ever heard on Fox News.

title: Ars Longa, Restaurant Brevis
description: Before you contemplated the offerings on the menu at Chanterelle, you would pause to contemplate the menu itself.

title: Justice, Parades and Gaelic in Northern Ireland
description: As my colleague John Burns reports, after extremely protracted negotiations, an agreement has been reached in Belfast to put Northern Irelands power-sharing government in charge of the criminal justice system in the province.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 5
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Blankfein Gets Bonus of $9 Million in Stock
description: Update | 6:09 p.m. The New York Timess Graham Bowley provides more details about Lloyd C. Blankfeins bonus.

title: Jacksons Doctor to Face Charges Monday
description: LOS ANGELES  The doctor who was treating Michael Jackson when he died suddenly in June will face charges on Monday, the Los Angeles County district attorneys office announced Friday, after a week of news leaks portraying the police and prosecutors as at odds over how his arrest should come about.

title: Saving Money, and the Soup
description: WHEN I was growing up, my parents always bought shrimp in the shell. Why buy them peeled when the shells, boiled into an intense shrimpy glaze, add such great flavor to risotto and bouillabaisse?

title: Rustic Shrimp Bisque
description: 1 pound medium or large uncooked shrimp, shelled, shells reserved

title: Gillibrand Seeks to Stop Funding for Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: In an apparent effort to court a voting bloc in her home state, Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand is preparing to introduce legislation that would withhold funding to enforce the dont ask, dont tell law.

title: Questions to Ask Before Buying Disability Insurance
description: Given how confusing disability insurance is, my column on the odds of needing it didnt have room to list all of the questions you should ask an insurance company before signing up for a policy. (If you get disability insurance for free from your employer, making similar queries is crucial to understanding the limits of the coverage.)

title: Euro Debt Crisis Is Political Test for Bloc
description: PARIS  What began with worries about the solvency of Greece in the face of high deficits, fake budget figures and low growth has quickly become the most severe test of the 16-nation euro zone in its 11-year history.

title: Fund-Raising Soars at San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
description: Its been a good year for the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: Volpe to Lead Labor Talks at the Met
description: Joseph Volpe, the one-time carpenter and Metropolitan Opera lifer, rose to become the Mets general manager. Sixteen years later, in 2006, Peter Gelb, a former record company executive, succeeded him. As their paths crossed, there seemed to be no love lost. They traded barbs, and stories of behind-the-scenes friction circulated.

title: Philagrafika 2010
description: Images from a printmaking festival in Philadelphia.

title: Goodell Not Budging on Fines for Fashion Missteps
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Earlier this week, Saints safety Darren Sharper was not shy about criticizing the N.F.L. for its fines on things like uniform violations.

title: Bison Basketball: Fun on the Road
description: Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 senior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. As he did last season, he will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

title: South African Show of Pride, Big Cats Included
description: Times are hard, theaters are struggling, and institutional money is drying up fast. Creative solutions are to be applauded.

title: One Professional Opinion: Freeney Will Play
description: Ralph Reiff is the director of St. Vincent Sports Performance in Indianapolis, which works with many elite athletes on performance and rehabilitation. Reiff has more than 25 years experience as an athletic trainer and was manager of athlete care at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics.

title: Some See Restraint in Goldman Chiefs Bonus
description: Once again, a bonus at Goldman Sachs has all of Wall Street talking  only this time, over how small it is.

title: A Survey of a Field Hard to Define
description: The Outsider Art Fair is running this weekend, which makes this as good a time as any to ask, what exactly is an outsider artist? Judging by those represented by the fairs 38 dealers, the answer isnt simple. They are an exceedingly diverse bunch.

title: Blind Side Finds a Path to the Oscars by Running Up the Middle
description: LOS ANGELES  The whoops and giggles, heard at 5:42 a.m. on Tuesday as Anne Hathaway announced that The Blind Side was in the pool of 10 best picture nominees at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, were the sound of Hollywood surprising itself.

title: San Francisco Museum Raises $250 Million
description: Bucking the downward trend that has plagued the boardrooms of most museums during the recession, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art announced Thursday that it had raised $250 million over the last several months, allowing it to double the size of its endowment and put $150 million toward an ambitious expansion. The expansion is necessary partly because the museum is to be the home of the extensive art collection of Don and Doris Fisher, co-founders of the Gap clothing chain. The Fishers announced in September, shortly before Mr. Fishers death, that they would lend their works to the museum instead of placing them in a museum that they had planned to build in the Presidio in San Francisco. The modern art museum, which celebrated its 75th anniversary last month, also announced Thursday that the agreement for the Fisher loan would be extended from 25 years, as initially announced, to at least 100 years. The works will be presented in a new wing along with works from the museums permanent collection and will also be interwoven throughout the museums other galleries beginning in June. A search will now begin for an architect for the expansion and the museum will continue to work toward raising a total of $480 million for it and the endowment.

title: Poets Home in Ohio May Carry Legacy
description: Langston Hughes, in Harlem, above, has a block named after him in New York: Langston Hughes Place, East 127th Street between Madison and Fifth. But the house where Hughes lived, at No. 20 East 127th, is no longer open to the public. In 2008 the owner evicted tenants who had been running an informal Hughes museum there and now the only trace of him is a plaque in front of the building, which has been a landmark since 1981. The Hughes legacy may have a better chance of taking hold in Cleveland, where a nonprofit development group has bought a foreclosed house in that citys Fairfax neighborhood, where Hughes lived for about two years starting in 1917. Hughes was in high school, living with his mother, and when she moved away he stayed on and rented an attic room at 2266 East 86th Street. According to Arnold Rampersads biography of Hughes, he said of his time at East 86th Street: I couldnt afford to eat in a restaurant, and the only thing I knew how to cook myself in the kitchen of the house where I roomed was rice, which I boiled to a paste. Rice and hot dogs, rice and hot dogs, every night for dinner. Then I read myself to sleep. The developer, Fairfax Renaissance Development Corporation, hasnt decided what to do with the property, which it picked up for $100 in November. One option, according to Jay Gardner, the groups community development director, is to fix it up for a private owner; another is to create a museum devoted to Hughes and his work.

title: Footnotes
description: David Wilson Barnes, who drew strong reviews for his performance last season as the acidic friend in the Off Broadway run of Becky Shaw, will play the husband of Megan Mullallys character, Chloe, in the Roundabout Theater Companys coming revival of Lips Together, Teeth Apart. Patton Oswalt and Lili Taylor are the other couple in the Terrence McNally play, which is scheduled to begin preview performances on Broadway on April 9.... Fresh off winning a Grammy Award on Sunday night for best musical show album, the producers of the current Broadway revival of West Side Story announced on Friday that a touring production of North America would begin in Detroit in October, with other cities to be announced.

title: The Odds of a Disability Are Themselves Odd
description: You have an 80 percent chance of becoming disabled during your working years.

title: Springsteen Had No Role in Lawsuit, He Says
description: Bruce Springsteen, below, wants to make something clear: he is not suing any bars where bands might be playing his songs. In response to reports saying that he and Ascap, the royalty collection agency, had sued Connollys Pub and Restaurant, a chain in Midtown Manhattan, for copyright infringement because it did not pay licensing fees, Mr. Springsteens publicity firm said in a statement that Ascap had filed the suit without his involvement or permission. Ascap was solely responsible for naming Bruce Springsteen as a plaintiff in the lawsuit, the statement said. Bruce Springsteen had no knowledge of this lawsuit, was not asked if he would participate as a named plaintiff, and would not have agreed to do so if he had been asked. According to the lawsuit, the bars branch on West 45th Street near Times Square, did not pay fees for public performances of two Springsteen songs when a band played there in August 2008. A spokesman for Ascap declined to comment in response to the Springsteen statement.

title: Mentalist Pulls Ahead
description: The Mentalist attracted the largest audience in prime time on Thursday as CBS led the night over all, according to Nielsens estimates. The 10 p.m. crime show drew 14.7 million viewers, just a bit more than CBSs CSI during the 9 p.m. hour (14.6 million). Fox earned first place during the 8 p.m. hour, posting its highest ratings in three years for Bones (12.3 million), which won the time slot ahead of the CBS special Surviving Survivor (8.3 million). For the night, Fox edged past ABC for second place. ABC broadcast The Deep End (5.1 million), Greys Anatomy (12.5 million) and Private Practice (9.3 million). NBC was fourth.

title: A Would-Be Carmen Announces She Wont Be
description: First it was eight, then two and now zero. Those are the number of Angela Gheorghius appearances this season in Carmen, a production created for her at the Metropolitan Opera. It was to be her first Carmen. The Met on Friday said she had withdrawn from her two remaining scheduled performances of the work, directed by Richard Eyre. In a statement from her relayed by the Met, Ms. Gheorghiu implied that she was not ready for the role. To make so important a debut as Carmen, I want to be as prepared dramatically as I am musically, she said. Therefore, I will postpone my role debut until a later date when I can work intensely with the Richard Eyre production. Ms. Gheorghiu withdrew from the first six performances, in which she was to have starred with her husband, the tenor Roberto Alagna, because of marital troubles. The tenor role (Don Jos) had been assigned to Jonas Kaufmann for the final two performances, on April 28 and May 1.  Kate Aldrich, above, who has performed in Carmen at the Bavarian State Opera in Munich and the Deutsche Opera in Berlin, will take Ms. Gheorghius place, the Met said. Elina Garanca was assigned to replace Ms. Gheorghiu in earlier performances.

title: Describe Your Experience With Disability Insurance
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I examine the odds of becoming hurt or sick enough that youd want to make a claim on a long-term disability policy.

title: A Mousy App From Logitech
description: Now heres a really useful app from the Apple app store: a program that turns an iPhone or iPod Touch into a wireless computer trackpad and touch-screen keyboard.

title: New Coolpix Cameras Are Big on Zoom
description: Nikon has unwrapped seven new Coolpix point-and-shoot cameras that include a performance model with a 26X optical zoom and a slim compact camera that packs a 10X optical zoom.

title: A Road to Redemption (Hint: Be Polite)
description: IN 1993 Amongst Friends, a film about spoiled Long Island kids turned would-be gangsters, generated strong buzz and positive press at the Sundance Film Festival. That low-budget indie, shot for $900,000 in 24 days, didnt earn much at the box office, but the raw and vibrant energy of the debut by the writer and director Rob Weiss left audiences and insiders wondering what hed do next.

title: On Assignment: Sideline Scrimmage
description: Its like everybodys trying to jump on each other, said Barton Silverman of The New York Times, when recalling the Super Bowl. Its a very competitive game.

title: The Cost of a $499 iPad: $290
description: If a 43 percent profit margin sounds about right to you, then Apple Computer has priced its new iPad tablet fairly.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 5
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include a fatal fire in Brooklyn, Groundhog Day, and a graffiti writer.

title: The Beauty of Pulses, the Glory of Drones
description: The Unsound Festival New York claims a shrewdly amorphous domain: a zone in a virtual Europe (including Eastern Europe and Scandinavia) where electronics; arty, multimedia experiments; chamber-music meticulousness; punk impulses; and D.J. dance beats may all appear amid clouds of noise.

title: You-Caught-My-Eyes as Creative Kindling
description: SINCE its start in May, the Metropolitan section has occasionally published collections of found poems  more specifically, love poems found in the remarkable Missed Connections section of Craigslist New York, generally on a theme like neighbors or eye contact or on two wheels.

title: Sounds Forged to Sharp Edges
description: The Jazz Standard wasnt nearly full for the tenor saxophonist David Snchezs early show on Thursday night, so its important to get the word out that his current band  new as of two years ago  has settled into its music, swapped out a drummer and become quite great.

title: NATO's Imminent Offensive in Marja
description: Alissa J. Rubin describes NATO's imminent offensive on the city of Marja in Helmand Province, an insurgent stronghold in the Afghan war.

title: For iPhone Users, TV Over 3G
description: IPhone owners, your TV is going 3G.

title: Artifacts | Pillow Talk
description: For the performance artist Marina Abramovic, the staff of life is endurance. Her appearances, which have involved fasting, cutting her belly with a razor, kissing till she faints, and staring into the eyes of a stranger over extended periods of time until she  and her audience  experience a cathartic levitation of the spirit that requires intense concentration and enormous strength of character. The well from which she draws her strength of purpose will soon be available to everyone. To accompany her career retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, opening March 14, Abramovic collaborated with the non-profit outreach organization, More Art, to produce the Energy Blanket. Available next month from either More Art or MoMA, it comes with fourteen magnets and a drawing of Abramovics body indicating where they ought to go before climbing under it. $460 is a small price to pay for inner peace  or, come to think of it, for a wearable piece of art.

title: Macmillan Books Return to Amazon After Dispute
description: Electronic and paper books from the publisher Macmillan were returning to Amazon.com on Friday evening, ending a weeklong public conflict as the parties negotiated over the future price of e-books.

title: Pass the Squishy
description: OF all the supplies at Haven Academy, a charter school in the South Bronx, none matter as much as the squishy. Like any elementary school, Haven has pencils, books and desks. But it is the squishy  a colorful rubber ball with dozens of tentacles that can withstand the strength of any young student  that daily absorbs a fit of anger or a mess of tears.

title: Behind the Scenes: The Product Specialist
description: Once again, models are ready to strut and designers take their bows in the latest reenactment of the emperors new clothes. The back story of New York Fashion Week is far more interesting: an industry in turmoil, the drastic loss of local factories and suppliers, the manufacturing dominance of China and other countries, the gradual decline of technical expertise in the face of apparent consumer indifference about fit and quality. As usual, the story goes well beyond the limited world of runway collections.

title: Super Bowl XLIV Apps to Load Before Kickoff
description: This Super Bowl weekend, whether you are rooting for the New Orleans Saints or that other team, there is a dog pile of apps to enhance the game, although I will acknowledge not as many as I would like for some handsets.

title: Journalist Whose Article Was Retracted Leaves Reuters
description: The journalist who wrote an article on Monday that turned into an embarrassment for Reuters has left the wire service, the company said Friday. A Reuters spokeswoman declined to say whether the journalist, Terri Cullen, left voluntarily, or why. I cant really go into any detail, said the spokeswoman, Courtney Dolan.

title: With These Pancakes, No Sleeping In
description: Margaret Chin, a longtime housing and immigration rights advocate who grew up on Mott Street, is the first Asian-American woman on the New York City Council and the first Chinese-American to represent Chinatown, a feat achieved after three losing bids for the Council. She taught for 14 years in  LaGuardia Community Colleges Division of Adult and Continuing Education, and in 1974 helped establish Asian Americans for Equality, an advocacy group.

title: More on Online Language Learning
description: Last weeks article on online language learning apparently hit a nerve; not only was it widely e-mailed, but a number of people told me about other language courses that I had missed in my research.

title: The Opera in an Opera Overcomes Illnesses
description: This is the season of colds. And illness has certainly taken a toll at the Metropolitan Opera this winter, as it did on Thursday night for the first performance of Strausss Ariadne auf Naxos in a revival of Elijah Moshinskys slightly surreal 1994 production.

title: A Godsend, Except When Its Not
description: Jean Ryan is the kind of New Yorker who makes everyone else feel lazy. She has two masters degrees and a black belt in tae kwon do. She serves on her local community board. You know the type? Try this one: When she had eye surgery two weeks ago, she refused sedation.

title: Retrieving Fleeting Wisps in the Miasma of Memory
description: Dance suffers or thrives, depending on your point of view, from impermanence, yet a sense of fleeting changeability, good or bad, is difficult to pin down in Kimberly Bartosiks Materiality of Impermanence. During much of the work, first performed on Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop, Ms. Bartosik juxtaposes the hazy ambiguities of memory with formal structures.

title: Do We Need to Know Whats in Junk Food?
description: In the continuing effort to fight obesity in the U.S., the Food and Drug Administration is reviewing its nutrition labeling guidelines. The agency is re-evaluating serving sizes and considering the placement of calorie and nutrition labels on the front of food packages, from cereals to soups to candy.

title: Debt Problems Chip Away at Fortress Europe
description: Fortress Europe is now under attack by the market. For months, the conventional wisdom in Europe was that the speculative aims of bond traders and hedge fund investors would remain largely focused on Greece, Europes chronic problem child.

title: A Clomp Back in Time
description: Marooned on the cobblestones of a Brooklyn neighborhood so cozily forlorn that you could easily imagine the clomping of a night coach passing by, Vinegar Hill House is one of those vintage joints wherein certain elements  distressed-wood furniture, roaring fireplace, bartenders with Reconstruction-era facial hair  conspire to give a feeling of homey, antique cheer. Located at 72 Hudson Street, not far from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, it has been the only restaurant in the immediate area. Not for long. A few nights ago, the brain trust of a soon-to-open spot came by to sample the competition.

title: Where Do You Volunteer?
description: We recently noted that volunteer rates edged up last year. Between September 2008 and September 2009, 26.8 percent of the population volunteered through or for an organization; the previous year, 26.4 percent of the population did so.

title: One-Man Band (and a Few Surprises)
description: Were you to guess in advance which instrument Dayve Hawk  the one-man band Memory Tapes  would be playing during what he described as his first American live show, the answer probably wouldnt have been guitar. But there it was on Wednesday night at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, slung around his neck, an unexpected accent piece.

title: Excerpt: 'Undercover Boss'
description: "Undercover Boss," a CBS reality show, turns the tables on management.

title: Hes Good at Pushing Paper, but Can He Pick Up Trash?
description: Undercover Boss, a CBS reality show that turns the tables on management, seems tailor-made for the anticorporate rancor of the times, but if anything, it paints too rosy a picture of white-collar benevolence.

title: Oh, What a Lovely Mess!
description: You may be among the e-mailers who have written, in effect, Let us hear what Dick has to say about this. Hes in a unique position to comment on it.

title: Some Super Bowl Winners Are Already Known
description: Food is so powerful, the right menu can even help decide the outcome of the Superbowl.

title: Toast of the Bronx Will Soon Be Toast
description: Before 7 every morning, Federico Toro, 49, strides down a long lane into the giant bakery run by Old London Foods, a little-known but mighty presence in the northeast Bronx, off Eastchester Road. This has been his routine for 27 years. Maria Cruz, 71, comes in around 2 in the afternoon. She has made that trip for 34 years. And with just three years on the job, Mubbushir Uzair, 26, swings to any shifts that need him.

title: Andrea Wong Steps Down as Chief of Lifetime Entertainment Services
description: In a move that had been expected for some time, Andrea Wong is leaving her position as chief executive of Lifetime Entertainment Services, of which the Lifetime cable channel is the flagship. Her departure was jointly announced Friday by Lifetime and the A&E Networks, which had become the parent of Lifetime in a deal concluded last August.

title: A Fascination With Time (and Nakedness)
description: Listen: with all this talk of the 10-horse race and sensational Internet videos, the art and craft of cinema, the whole reason people make movies, can get lost. And even though Sundance feels like a million years ago, it is still generating deals (and, um, Internet videos) that people are talking about. Or at least, that is the excuse we are going to use to post this stuff now.

title: When Parks Must Rely on Private Money
description: A majestic staircase of granite rises some 30 feet above the Brooklyn edge of the East River, revealing a panorama that sweeps from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Midtown Manhattan. A salt marsh lined in limestone offers a contemplative look at the river as ecosystem. Along paths winding up manufactured hills and ridges are hundreds of trees that outline velvety fields of green.

title: Newspaper Guild Files Labor Complaint Against Reuters Over Compensation Cuts
description: The Newspaper Guild accused Reuters of wrongly cutting the pay and benefits of 420 employees, in a complaint filed on Friday with federal regulators.

title: Pel Is My Co-Pilot
description: Lost, perhaps, in the avalanche of soccer news from around the world (John Terry, more injuries to U.S. national team players, Manchester United thrashing Arsenal, Togos banishment in Africa) was the triumphant return to Brazil of Robinho.

title: Portrayal of Ann Landers Captures Societys Changes
description: When Christopher Buckley interviewed Eppie Lederer, better known to millions of newspaper readers as Ann Landers, at her Lake Shore Drive apartment in Chicago, It was like visiting an attentive, rich grandmother, he wrote in his 1995 New Yorker profile.

title: Seasons of the Wolf
description: A timeline of movie werewolves, from Lon Chaney to Benicio Del Toro, complete with trailers and clips. "The Wolfman" is now on DVD and Blu-ray.

title: Amour and Song Return to Marseille Waterfront
description: Is that the salty air of Marseille stinging your eyes, or the bittersweet finale of the musical Fanny, which arrives at an improbably happy climax even as one of its central characters succumbs to death?

title: Finding Your Way Can Mean Getting Lost
description: As Danspace Projects Platform series, i get lost, continues, we have more a sense of what has been found. On Thursday night Ralph Lemon, who organized the programming, introduced two more choreographers: Judith Snchez Ruz, who was born in Havana, and Souleymane Badolo, who hails from Burkina Faso.

title: A Committed Salesman of Chopin Does His Thing
description: Schumann, whose compositional gift for description extended to words, aptly referred to Chopins music as a cannon buried in flowers. A powerful tension often simmers beneath the surface of Chopins aristocratic, elegant works, like the Prelude in D flat (Op. 28, No. 15). In that piece, performed by Garrick Ohlsson on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, a serene melody is underpinned by a repeated note that becomes angrily more insistent until the calm is shattered, then seamlessly restored.

title: Goodell Is Hopeful for Peace With Union
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  A year from now, Commissioner Roger Goodells state of the N.F.L. address may be held weeks before the labor deal expires and a lockout begins.

title: Size, Scale and Detail in Creations of Steel
description: It is easy to be impressed by the Albert Paley retrospective at Grounds for Sculpture, the 35-acre sculpture park and museum on the former site of the New Jersey State Fairgrounds in Hamilton. The size and scale of the metal sculptures in this indoor exhibit are mind-blowing; some pieces are around 15 feet high, while others weigh up to a ton. They are monumental.

title: The Melody and Lyrics of Black History
description: LAST spring Paul Hefner, a bandleader and composer from Floral Park, had the idea of spotlighting Tara Nova, a longtime vocalist with his group, in a concert with a local twist: It would feature music by his colleagues in the Long Island Composers Alliance, which has more than 50 members.

title: A Revolution Indeed, and Bathed in Smoke
description: If you are interested in images of industry, then you will enjoy At the Heart of Progress: Coal, Iron, and Steam since 1750, a miscellaneous group of 76 works from the John P. Eckblad Collection at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College. But if pictures of factories, steel mills, cooling towers, pipe bridges, shipyards, foundries, forges and coal mines leave you cold, then you will probably be less enthusiastic.

title: Dowdy Index Funds Win a Notable Endorsement
description: For the wealthy, index funds have an image problem. They are considered the economy cars of the investing world: theyll get you there but not in style and youre always worried they may break down. Anyone at a serious level of wealth, the thinking goes, needs the equivalent of a luxury sedan, with strategic stock choices, hedge funds, private equity, real estate.

title: Direct Latin Flavors With a Sweet Finish
description: SOME of us have sworn off all things glazed and jelly-filled, but if you call a doughnut a buuelo, as they do at Caf Barcel, and make a plump, cinnamon-laced confection that belongs in the deep-fried hall of fame, well, you will probably cause more than a few former doughnut addicts to fall off the wagon.

title: Love, Wine and Chocolate
description: For wine-loving locavores, Millbrook Vineyards and Winery, in Dutchess County, has a Valentines Day gift that might be more welcome than the usual heart-shaped box of chocolates.

title: The New Math on Campus
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

title: A Live Music Capital Is Hearing Less Music These Days
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The closing of storied music sites, often accompanied by protest, fund-raising and other exercises in futility, has become a recurring spectacle in this growing city, where the official stationery carries the legend Live Music Capital of the World.

title: Charleston Chews and Sugar Babies: Fistfuls of Nostalgia
description: ALTHOUGH penny candies havent cost a cent for a long time, they are still relatively cheap treats. That may be one reason that retro-themed candy shops have been opening around the state, defying the difficult economy.

title: Legal Broadsides Kick Off Air Products-Airgas Battle
description: Less than 24 hours after Air Products and Chemicals announced an unsolicited $5.1 billion takeover offer for its smaller rival, Airgas, the lawsuits began flying.

title: A Deuce Takes Another Shot at Tying a Record
description: There are times when you do not see the rain forest for the copse. Thursdays column had a very bad error in it. I was so involved in altering the original deal, effecting an uppercut by a deuce, that I made an oversight.

title: Hamas Insists Rockets Were Not Aimed at Civilians
description: JERUSALEM  Hamas insists that it did not intentionally aim rockets at Israeli civilians during the Gaza war last winter, according to a report submitted this week to a United Nations office in Gaza.

title: Savory Routes From Taste Buds to the Heart
description: THIS Valentines Day, couples may find themselves doing a cost-benefit analysis when planning a romantic evening. It isnt easy to manage the perfect balance, largely because restaurateurs traditionally see the day as one of the few occasions when diners are willing to splurge  so the menu is often priced accordingly. But maybe not in 2010. Here are a few places that offer good value, fine wines and at the same time provide the possibility of a dreamy evening getaway.

title: Where the Boys Arent
description: The University of North Carolina, with a student body that is nearly 60 percent female, is just one of many large universities that are starting to feel eerily like womens colleges.

title: His Hairs Not Always Perfect
description: IT has been nearly 70 years since this ominous rhyme was first recited to an antsy Lon Chaney Jr. in the 1941 film The Wolf Man: Even a man who is pure in heart and says his prayers by night/May become a wolf when the wolfbane blooms and the autumn moon is bright.

title: Most Americans Think Swine Flu Pandemic Is Over, a Harvard Poll Finds
description: Most Americans do not intend to get the swine flu vaccine, assume the pandemic is over and think the flu threat was overblown, according to a poll released Friday by the Harvard School of Public Health.

title: First Profit in Year for Airline in Britain
description: A big cost-cutting campaign at British Airways helped lift the company to its first quarterly operating profit in more than a year. But the airline said Friday that it still expected to record an annual loss amid a broad industry slump.

title: Southern Discomfort
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.

title: Auspicious Entrees to Start the Year Right
description: MANHASSET

title: Women Now a Majority in American Workplaces
description: For the first time in recorded history, women outnumber men on the nations payrolls.

title: As Shuttle Flights Dwindle, a Series of Lasts Begins
description: The space shuttle Endeavour, carrying the last major piece of the International Space Station, is poised for launching before sunrise on Sunday, the last planned nighttime liftoff of a shuttle ever.

title: Arts Patron Is Sentenced to 9 Years for Fraud
description: In his years as a prominent patron of the arts, Alberto W. Vilar sat in red velvet seats in the first row at the Metropolitan Opera, where he watched performances he had helped finance.

title: Dismissal of a Guantnamo Case Is Sought
description: The Obama administration asked the Supreme Court on Friday to consider dismissing a case on the rights of prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, after the Swiss government said it would accept transfer of two inmates involved in the dispute. The solicitor general said that the transfer agreement, which involves two Chinese Uighurs, eliminates the factual premise presented in this case. The court is scheduled to hear arguments March 23 about whether judges can order release of nondangerous Guantnamo prisoners into the United States. The federal government has said the Uighurs do not pose a threat to the United States.

title: From a Home Court in Queens to the N.B.A.
description: They called it the Rockaway Game, basketball the way it was played in the 1940s on blacktop courts along the Atlantic Ocean in Rockaway Beach, Queens.

title: Colorado: Air Force Academy Criticized
description: The Air Force Academy, which recently set up a worship area for followers of Wicca, Druidism and other Earth-centered religions on its Colorado Springs campus, has been criticized by some cadets as being too slow to address vandalism at the area on Jan. 17. Mikey Weinstein, a 1977 academy graduate and founder of the Military Religious Freedom Foundation, said that it took the academys dean 10 days to speak to faculty about the incident, and that it was not until Wednesday, after Mr. Weinstein said he alerted the Pentagon, that the vice commandant spoke to cadets. Officials said the incident was being investigated. Leadership has been very responsive, said Lt. Col. William Ziegler, the cadet wing chaplain. I know that Lt. Gen. Michael Gould, the superintendent of the academy, has made it very clear that this type of behavior is not appropriate and will not be tolerated.

title: Assassinating Americans, Killing the Constitution?
description: Think about this sentence for a moment: Im not even slightly surprised to find out that the Obama administration has some kind of process in place to assassinate American citizens who its decided are in cahoots with terrorists.

title: Profit at Tyson Foods Tops Estimates
description: Tyson Foods, a processor of chicken, beef and pork, posted a quarterly profit that topped analysts estimates amid higher revenue at its chicken and beef divisions.

title: Ex-Financial Adviser Is Sued by Wesleyan
description: As the economy eroded college endowments around the country, money managers in academia worked tirelessly to contain the damage. Everywhere, that is, but at Wesleyan University, at least according to a lawsuit that the university has brought against its former chief investment officer.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Anti-Abortion Ads Split Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  Anti-abortion groups have erected scores of billboards here with an alarming message: Black children are an endangered species.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Iran May Be Near Uranium Deal
description: MUNICH  Iran might be close to a deal to have uranium enriched abroad, the countrys foreign minister said Friday. But he proposed a condition that might not be acceptable to the United States and other governments that have been trying to negotiate a compromise over Irans nuclear program.

title: Democrats Ask, Can Health Care Bill Be Saved?
description: WASHINGTON  For a moment, President Obamas pledge to keep fighting for major health care legislation got personal on Thursday night as he told supporters at a fund-raiser about a former campaign worker in St. Louis without health insurance who had died of breast cancer.

title: Seeking a Safer Way to Securitization
description: Can the world be made safe for the return of securitizations?

title: Russia: Putin Warns His Party on Promises
description: After a week that brought a rare show of mass dissent in Russia, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Friday warned the members of United Russia, the party he leads, that they must win back the loyalty of the people. You cant, of course, promise everything to everyone right away, he said. You cannot turn into Mr. Promises, who makes promises just to pull the wool over peoples eyes, to break into positions of power, and then goes about solving his own personal problems without thinking about fulfilling your promises. Mr. Putins remarks came a week after an antigovernment rally in Kaliningrad drew 6,000 to 10,000 people, the largest turnout Russia has seen in years. He told party members that it was completely obvious, and right, that citizens turn to us with complaints about various aspects of our activities, and instructed them to pay close attention to those complaints.

title: Carnal, Gum-Crackin and Dangerous to Know
description: ITS easy to recognize the Bad Girl. Shes usually a bottle blonde, stuffed into a tight sweater that outlines her oddly conical breasts. Her mouth is wide, painted and clamped on a cigarette. Her eyes burn a little too brightly, and her legs, planted in a pair of high-rise pumps, go on forever.

title: Russia: 5 Soldiers Are Killed in Chechnya
description: At least five soldiers were killed and as many wounded in a fight with rebels that began late Thursday night in Chechnya, said Maryam Nalayeva, a spokeswoman for the Chechen prosecutors investigative committee. At least five militants were also killed in the fighting, which continued into Friday, she said. Soldiers and rebels have fought sporadically in Chechnya and other parts of Russias North Caucasus as the authorities seek to eliminate the last remnants of a simmering Islamic separatist movement. On Thursday, at least six rebels were killed by military forces in Chechnya in another operation, according to the Chechen presidents Web site.

title: Obama Gets His Groove Back
description: Where has this Obama been?

title: Bruised Maid Dies at 12, and Pakistan Seethes
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The death already seemed like a bitter injustice. A maid died after unexplained injuries she got in the house of her rich employer. But one detail in particular has outraged Pakistanis: she was 12.

title: Could Vick Be Headed to the Rams?
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  St. Louis Rams Coach Steve Spagnuolo visited the media center Friday and he did not close the door on the Rams (1-15) acquiring Michael Vick in the off-season.

title: Palin, Visible and Vocal, Is Positioned for Variety of Roles
description: WASHINGTON  Without leaving home, Sarah Palin will be able to reach much of her political base, courtesy of a soon-to-be-built television studio in her living room paid for by her newest media patron, Fox News. From her house in Wasilla, Alaska, Ms. Palin also sends missives to 1.3 million Facebook fans, writes newspaper columns, Tweets and signs copies of her book for donors.

title: Serving Size Sleight of Hand
description: William Neuman talks about how the F.D.A. and food companies make labels for serving sizes that bear little reality to the way people eat.

title: With Taliban Leader Reported Dead, New Pakistani Figure Emerges
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  News that the leader of the Pakistani Taliban was most likely killed by an American drone strike, while not yet confirmed, may already be setting off jockeying among his potential successors. One was seen in a video circulated this week and shown on a private television channel flogging two men and a teenage boy.

title: Defendant Not in the Station Has Low Profile at Police Trial
description: In two weeks of trial testimony, his name has hardly been mentioned. When witnesses take the stand, his lawyer seems to ask the fewest questions. This defendant, Officer Andrew Morales, never even stepped inside the Brooklyn subway station where, prosecutors say, a body piercer named Michael Mineo was sodomized by a police officer in October 2008.

title: Out of Cash, St. Vincents Is Set to Close
description: A few days after receiving a $6 million state loan to make its payroll, St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan is making contingency plans to close if it does not get another bailout, according to people who attended an emergency meeting about the hospital on Friday.

title: 2 Bronx Communities Are Accused of Preventing Blacks From Buying Homes
description: The people of Edgewater Park have described their home as a Shangri-La, a tightly knit and idyllic community sitting on Long Island Sound in a hidden pocket of the Bronx.

title: College Sports as Emotional Hubs
description: In case you missed it, New York Times columnist David Brooks addressed the subject of college sports on Friday.

title: Mother Held in Death of Boy, 8, at Luxury Hotel
description: The call came in to the 20th Precinct station house in Manhattan on Friday morning from Belgium: A woman was reporting that her niece had sent her a rambling e-mail message indicating she planned to kill her 8-year-old son and herself. Officers rushed to the nieces apartment building on Central Park West, then were directed to a luxury hotel in Midtown.

title: After Unemployment Ends, Pain and Trauma May Linger
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Antje Newby went back to work in September, but she has still not escaped the burden imposed by nine months of unemployment.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: One Bowl = 2 Servings. F.D.A. May Fix That.
description: Seeking a new weapon in the fight against obesity, the Food and Drug Administration wants to encourage manufacturers to post vital nutritional information, including calorie counts, on the front of food packages.

title: Downtime on Tour
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Corrections
description: A report in The Caucus column on Friday about President Obamas remarks to lawmakers and religious leaders at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday rendered incorrectly part of a quotation by Mr. Obama about the current political debate. In noting that we become absorbed with our abstract arguments, our ideological disputes, our contests for power, he went on to say, And in this Tower of Babel, we lose the sound of Gods voice. He did not say this tower of babble.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a House subcommittee hearing on President Obamas budget proposal for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration used an outdated name for an auditing arm of Congress. It is the Government Accountability Office, not the General Accounting Office.

title: Panoramas: Tuberculosis Patients
description: In a small room in the only tuberculosis sanatorium in Haiti, a lone nurse attends to the remaining patients.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a request by Senator-elect Scott Brown of Massachusetts to move up the date of his swearing in by a week misstated the middle initial of the Massachusetts secretary of state, who certified the results of the election. He is William F. Galvin, not William M. (Mr. Brown was sworn in on Thursday.)

title: When the Final Game Really Meant Something
description: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Its Mellow Upstairs, With a Party Below
description: FOR the last two years, Deity, a club on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, has attracted a mostly local crowd just as interested in listening and dancing to an eclectic mix of underground hip-hop, reggae and jazzy instrumental mixes as they are in settling in at the bar and mingling.

title: More Members of Madoff Family Agree to Freeze of Assets
description: Several members of Bernard L. Madoffs family have agreed to a freeze of their assets pending the outcome of a $200 million lawsuit filed by the court-appointed trustee in charge of recovering money for the victims of Mr. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: In Idaho, Questions on How Aid Mission Went Awry
description: MERIDIAN, Idaho  Paul Thompson sent an urgent e-mail message to a group of friends last month as he rushed to prepare for a trip to Haiti.

title: 1,576 Steps (Heaven Help Me) to Clarity
description: If only King Kong had known about the Empire State Building Run-Up, where for one miraculous if masochistic morning each year people are allowed to climb the inside of the landmark building, he and Fay might have lived happily  if asymmetrically  ever after.

title: Lottery Numbers
Learning What Food Looks Like Before It Goes Into the Package
description: About 20 high school students stood behind the butcher counter, staring at a 160-pound piece of meat from a recently slaughtered cow.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Wednesday with an article about the evolution of Super Bowl halftime shows was published in error. The photograph showed Carol Channing at a college football game in 1977  not at Super Bowl IV in 1970 at Tulane Stadium in New Orleans. (The picture, which was courtesy of Ms. Channing, was also published in error on Jan. 31, 2004, with a similar article about glitzy halftime shows.)

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 968 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Job Growth Tops Forecasts in Canada
description: Canada gained almost three times as many jobs as expected in January, led by part-time positions for youth, pushing the unemployment rate down to the lowest level since September. Employment rose by 43,000 last month, Statistics Canada said, and the unemployment rate fell to 8.3 percent. The median forecast of 22 economists surveyed by Bloomberg was for a 15,000 gain in employment and a jobless rate of 8.5 percent. The gain is very much in line with the moderate recovery were seeing, said Doug Porter, deputy chief economist with BMO Capital Markets in Toronto. While the details of the report were not as friendly as the overall gain would suggest, its notable that the unemployment rate fell.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the sentencing of Mark E. Lenowitz, a former hedge fund manager and a cooperating witness in an insider-trading investigation involving the Galleon Group, erroneously attributed a distinction to the investigation. While the inquiry represents the first time federal investigators have used confidential informants to secretly record meetings between suspects in an insider trading inquiry, it is not the first time confidential informants have been used to gather evidence in such cases.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the grand history of golf and show business at the Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles, which is currently host to the Northern Trust Open, referred incorrectly to the silent screen star Douglas Fairbanks, whose picture with Mary Pickford hangs on a wall in the golf courses clubhouse. He was Ms. Pickfords second husband, not the first. (That was Owen Moore.)

title: O.K., Russia, Time to Work It
description: MOSCOW

title: The Lady in Red
description: What gives a girlPower and punch?Is it charm, is it poise?No, its hairspray!  Corny Collins

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the author Don DeLillo misidentified the maker of the manual typewriter he uses. It is an Olympia, not an Underwood.

title: Corrections
description: A music column on Friday about the Metropolitan Operas new production of Carmen, using information from the Met, misstated the age of the tenor Brandon Jovanovich, who plays the role of Don Jos in some performances. He is 39, not 29.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in the Escapes pages on Friday about the Topia Inn in Adams, Mass., misstated the given name of one of the owners. She is Nana Simopoulos, not Nina.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: After Penn States Season of Firsts, Losses Come in Bunches
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  The Penn State mens basketball coach, Ed DeChellis, often described his teams record-setting 2008-9 season as one of many firsts.

title: Bernhard in the Daimler Spotlight Again
description: Wolfgang Bernhard, a rising star at Daimler before he abruptly left in 2004, is returning to the companys management board and taking on responsibilities for Mercedes-Benz cars.

title: Bloggingheads: Twittering Away
description: Susan Orlean of The New Yorker and Kurt Andersen of Studio 360 discuss writers using Twitter.

title: Leaving the Familiarity of Home, a Japanese Skater Finds Solace
description: SIMSBURY, Conn.  The ice rink in this sleepy corner of Connecticut is a long way from Nagoya, Japan, Miki Andos hometown. But Ando, one of the worlds top figure skaters, has found solace here as she prepares to take on her rivals at the Olympics in Vancouver in a few weeks.

title: A Lot to Fix
description: Toyota has a lot of work to do to recover drivers trust. The company has now recalled about three times the number of cars it sold in the United States and Canada last year. This hardly inspires confidence in its much-vaunted manufacturing and design prowess.

title: Looks Sleazy to Us
description: For years now, New York State has been trying to upgrade the facilities at the deteriorating Aqueduct raceway in Queens. Then last month, Gov. David Paterson suddenly handed the lucrative contract for video lottery terminals to a company called Aqueduct Entertainment Group. The company has promised jobs, a $300 million bonus for the state and a casino concept that celebrates New York.

title: A Welcome Retraction
description: For a decade, many parents have worried that vaccines might somehow be causing autism in children. Repeated assurances from respected experts that there is no link have failed to quiet those fears. Now The Lancet, a prestigious British medical journal that published the paper that first gave wide credence to those fears, has retracted it, saying that the papers authors had made false claims about how the study was conducted.

title: Ad Follies of the Super Bowl
description: Just the other day, CBS took the forthright stand in the face of political pressure and accepted an evangelical groups anti-abortion commercial. That makes it all the harder to accept its timid rejection of a gay dating services sendup of couch-potato machoness.

title: What Went Wrong With My Toyota?
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Ways to Remake the Banking System
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast-Food Calories
description: To the Editor:

title: Portrayals of Italian-Americans in the Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Wisdom of Grandparents?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Holds Barred
description: Washington was immobilized by snow on Friday. This is highly unusual. Normally, Washington is immobilized by senators.

title: Time Is Running Out
description: Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Toyotas Blind Spot
description: Los Angeles

title: Devils Organist Remains Part of Arenas Rhythm
description: NEWARK  At 5:30 on a Devils game night, the main bowl of the Prudential Center is cold and empty, but it is not silent. As the first fans amble to their seats, Pete Cannarozzi, the Devils organist, plays a bright overture. The atmosphere in the big building becomes warm and expectant.

title: Kovalchuks Presence Puts Smiles on the Devils
description: NEWARK  Zach Parise has played for the Devils for less than five years, but he knows how it works around here. The Devils have been mentioned in trade rumors about other elite players, but the players always end up elsewhere. If the Devils are named in a rumor, he said, it must not be true.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Kovy Trade, Day 2  Devils Win, Thrashers Lose
description: Five games on Friday, one night after the big Ilya Kovalchuk trade. Kovalchuk and Anssi Salmela were in action for the Devils; Niclas Bergfors and Johnny Oduya were on the ice for the suddenly diminished Thrashers. Home teams listed first:

title: Early Signs That Barbaros Brother Is Ready to Run
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  Had Lentenor been related to any other horse, his victory on Jan. 20 at Gulfstream Park would have gone largely unnoticed. It came, after all, in a maiden race, which is an event exclusive to horses who have never won. But Lentenor, a 3-year-old, won impressively, is eligible to run in this years Kentucky Derby and, most important, is Barbaros full brother.

title: Whole Wheat Muffins
description: Mark Bittman cooks a recipe he learned from Grandma Starchild of the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood in San Francisco.

title: Whole Wheat Muffin, the Remix
description: THE problems with most real whole wheat muffins are multiple: theyre heavy, dense and even slightly bitter, unless they contain a ton of sugar. Which explains why many whole wheat recipes call for wheat and white flour.

title: With Patrick in Foreground, Other Women Chase Stock-Car Glory
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Leilani Munter once worked as a photo double for the actress Catherine Zeta-Jones, but that is not the celebrity she most often passes for now. Munter has been approached by fans here who ask if they can pose with her for a photograph and afterward gush, Thanks so much, Danica!

title: Imari Obadele, Who Fought for Reparations, Dies at 79
description: Imari Obadele, a teacher and writer whose commitment to black empowerment fired a militant, sometimes violent effort to win reparations for descendants of slaves and to carve out, however quixotically, an African-American republic in the Deep South, died on Jan. 18 in Atlanta. He was 79.

title: Knicks Booed for Their Play and Their Picks
description: The point guard the Knicks could have had visited Madison Square Garden on Friday, on the same night the Knicks turned to the point guard they once shunned. There was discontent in the air even before tipoff.

title: Toms Eloy Martnez, Argentine Author Who Merged Fact With Fancy, Dies at 75
description: Toms Eloy Martnez, a distinguished Argentine writer whose fiction mingled journalistic and novelistic techniques to conjure an Argentina more authentically strange and elusive than either fact or fiction alone might allow, died on Sunday in Buenos Aires. He was 75 and had homes in Buenos Aires and Highland Park, N.J.

title: Colts Defense Could Emerge From Shadow
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  A lot has been made this week of the New Orleans Saints defense, with its remember me hits and its ability to keep the opposing teams offense out of the end zone by any means necessary. But lurking behind Peyton Manning is the Colts defense, a group that has been impressive in Indianapoliss two playoff victories.

title: Margaret Dale, Director of Dance for the BBC, Dies at 87
description: Margaret Dale, an illustrious dancer who went on to become an important producer and director of dance for British television, died in London on Jan. 28. She was 87.

title: Jamaican Bobsled Team Falls Short in Qualifying
description: There will be no Cool Runnings this time in a Canadian Olympics.

title: Lydia Csato Gasman, Picasso Scholar, Dies at 84
description: Lydia Csato Gasman, an art historian known for her groundbreaking scholarship on the work of Picasso, died on Jan. 15 in Charlottesville, Va. She was 84 and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Stricker Gets Out of Rain With a 65
description: LOS ANGELES  Ignoring the steady downpour that drenched the Riviera Country Club, the early starter Steve Stricker posted a six-under-par 65 for the low round of the day Friday, then headed to his hotel to watch the rest of the field try to match his 36-hole total of 10-under 132.

title: Son of U.S. Hockey Teams G.M. Dies
description: The youngest son of Brian Burke, the general manager of the United States Olympic ice hockey team and of the Toronto Maple Leafs, has died in a car crash.

title: Brendan Burke, Son of Leafs and U.S. Olympic G.M., Dies in Car Crash
description: The youngest son of Brian Burke, the general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs and the United States Olympic ice hockey team, has died in a car crash.

title: Polishing Some Tulsa History in New Jersey
description: When the people of Tulsa, Okla., buried a Plymouth Belvedere in front of the courthouse in 1957, it was a huge event for the city as it marked the states centennial. Now, watching video of that event, and the citys glee over its whimsical decision to bury a new car as a time capsule, its hard not to be charmed by the city and by the times. I write about the car and the efforts of a New Jersey company to save the car in Sundays Automobiles section.

title: Voting for the Hall Today: Wholl Join Jerry and Emmitt?
description: Programming note: The 2010 Hall of Fame class will be announced later today, and as part of the ceremony, the NFL Network will show a two-hour special and final installment of the Road To Canton series at 5 p.m. Eastern.

title: Classic Ads: Super Bowl Edition
description: With the annual feast of Super Bowl commercials just a day away  interrupted by small helpings of football now and then  this seems an apt time to look back at some of the best car commercials from Super Bowls past. And yet despite more than four decades worth of candidates, the pickings turn out to be pretty slim.

title: Brains  Brains
description: John Quiggin, who has a book in progress on Zombie Economics  ideas that should be dead, but arent  worries about

title: Yes, Were Poland
description: Ezra Klein helpfully explains how a hold works: basically, the normal running of the Senate requires unanimous consent on procedural matters, so any individual senator can stop everything by threatening to withhold that consent.

title: The Saturday Word: Blizzard
description: President Obama is scheduled to speak at the Democratic National Committees winter meeting today at the Capitol Hilton in Washington, but with inches of snow fast becoming feet, the blizzard will likely keep many of the Democratic rainmakers at home.

title: On the Street | Dash
description: The streets of New York, with their wide range of sartorial fantasies, also suggest the return of the peacock to everyday life and provide a contrast to the sedate mood of the mens collections last month in Europe.

title: Their Featured Speaker
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: The first ever Tea Party Convention is going on right now in Nashville. The tea partiers are a group of Americans who think the government is too big and also like to party and have tea.

title: Improve Our Math
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama was busy holding two fundraisers in D.C. last night. During one of his speeches, Obama told the crowd, We cant be afraid of the future. Most Americans agree with him, mainly because they are so busy being afraid of the present.

title: Very Ecologically Minded
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know anything about the new senator from the great state of Massachusetts? Senator Scott Brown. Comes out of nowhere, this guy. And he used to be, like, a go-go boy. Thats where he got his start. And then he was a nude model, and now, hes a senator. Have you seen the guy? Terribly good-looking. He looks like one of those guys in an adult film who would describe his work as tasteful.

title: Part Human, Part Pig
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: For the second time since he became president, Barack Obama has slammed Las Vegas by saying, You dont blow bunch of cash in Vegas. Hey, the way government is spending money, Id rather take the odds in Vegas. Wouldnt you? At least you might win something!

title: Gay Marriage Puts Mexico City at Center of Debate
description: MEXICO CITY  Angela Alfarache and Ivonne Cervantes met at a party 16 years ago and have been a couple ever since, filling their lives with books and writing and friends. After their daughter, Constanza, was born six years ago, they became a family.

title: Spains Problem, Illustrated
Notes From the Tea Party Convention
description: NASHVILLE  Yes, there were the handful of Revolutionary War re-enactors with their powdered wigs and tri-corner hats. And a guy with the T-shirt proclaiming himself a proud member of the Tennessee MOB  a poke back at politicians who dismissed tea partiers as an angry mob. And one of the speakers did insist that Jesus birth was better documented than President Obamas.

title: Rules Do Little to Hinder Iraq Parliament Race
description: BAGHDAD  The campaign for Iraqs parliamentary elections does not officially begin until next week. But for the crowd gathered beneath a tent sponsored by the Sadr movement in the southern neighborhood of Dora, it was well under way.

title: Afghan Police Kill 7 Mistaken for Insurgents
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Seven civilians were shot dead on Friday as they were apparently mistaken for a group of insurgents trying to cross the frontier from Pakistan, an Afghan police official said Saturday.

title: Obama Rallies the Party Faithful
description: President Obama said this morning that the Democratic Party should not simply regroup, lick our wounds and try to hang on during a challenging political season, pledging to press forward this year to deliver results on health care and job-creation measures.

title: People Should Travel In Trains As God Intended
description: I cant find the reference, but I believe it was an English matron who declared that airplanes were an invention of the devil, that people should take trains as God intended.

title: A Storm Part Crippling and Part Enchanting
description: A blizzard that had forecasters reaching for superlatives engulfed the nations capital and the mid-Atlantic states on Saturday with record snowfalls that paralyzed transportation, commerce and all but emergency services. But it transformed the weekend into an enchanted snowbound adventure for millions.

description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Reggie Bush said he rode an elevator at his teams hotel with someone who kind of recognized him.

description: MUNICH  As Irans foreign minister met with the chief of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency here, the United States and Germany rejected Irans assertion that it was close to accepting an international compromise on its nuclear program.

title: Its Up, and Its Good
description: In his 17th season, Mark Brunell will be on the sideline Sunday for his first Super Bowl. Brunell, 39, drafted in 1993 by Green Bay in the fifth round out of Washington, was a backup to Brett Favre with the Packers, then spent nine years with the expansion Jacksonville Jaguars, four with the Redskins and two with New Orleans as the backup to Drew Brees. Brunell, selected to the Pro Bowl three times, led the Jaguars to the A.F.C. championship game in the 1996 and 1999 seasons, and was the N.F.L. comeback player of the year in 2005. He was the holder for Garrett Hartley on Hartleys 40-yard field goal in overtime that vaulted New Orleans over Minnesota for a berth in the Super Bowl. CARL NELSON Q. What did you say to Garrett Hartley before the snap?

title: For Saints Vilma and Shockey, Title Would Be Symmetry
description: MIAMI  Jonathan Vilma and Jeremy Shockey formed a bond during their first few weeks of college that has become almost familial, their football careers a double helix intersecting here and in New York and in New Orleans.

description: This article is by James Kanter, Micheline Maynard and Hiroko Tabuchi.

title: Saints Arent the First to Call on Fleur Power
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The fleur-de-lis will be showcased in Sundays Super Bowl as the symbol of the Saints.

title: Peyton Mannings Case for Being the Best Ever
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  The Indianapolis Colts were trailing Houston, 17-0, when the Texans rookie linebacker Brian Cushing glanced up to see Colts quarterback Peyton Manning looking in the direction of the defenses huddle. In those few seconds of quiet before the chaos at the line of scrimmage, Cushing saw Manning nodding his head. Up and down. Up and down.

title: Time Rarely Runs Out on Colts
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Near the end of each half, when the clock creeps below two minutes, the Indianapolis Colts offense somehow becomes more dangerous.

title: Rebecca Mark and David Bernfeld
description: Rebecca Lee Mark, a daughter of Laurie B. Gelles of Brooklyn and Steven C. Mark of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to David Nicholas Bernfeld, the son of Virginia Pepe and Lawrence D. Bernfeld of Manhattan. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in Manhattan, where he is senior rabbi.

title: Its About the Quarterbacks, and It Always Has Been
description: More than any of their Super Bowl teammates, Peyton Manning and Drew Brees will duel for the property rights. One will be considered to have won, the other to have lost. Such is the quarterbacks bonanza and burden. Coaches also deserve ownership or censure, but other players are mostly remembered for having earned, or having missed an opportunity for the ring.

title: Lauren Waisbren and Adam Nathanson
description: Lauren Elizabeth Waisbren, a daughter of Jill Waisbren and Dr. Burton A. Waisbren of Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Adam Ian Nathanson, a son of Jane F. title: Charter School Founder Faces Scrutiny, and Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Compensation Is Questioned | The founder of a public charter school in the East Bay that provides a comfort zone for Muslim students is under attack in the wake of a state audit that uncovered questionable financial practices, including lavish payments to her. In 2007, compensation for the founder and director of the FAME school in Fremont, Maram Alaiwat, was more than $240,000. This was roughly the same as the total compensation of the Fremont Unified Schools superintendent, who oversees 38 schools. On Tuesday, officials of the Fremont schools are expected to raise concerns during an Alameda County Board of Education meeting.

title: Retired Officers Raise Questions on Crime Data
description: More than a hundred retired New York Police Department captains and higher-ranking officers said in a survey that the intense pressure to produce annual crime reductions led some supervisors and precinct commanders to manipulate crime statistics, according to two criminologists studying the department.

title: Alesina On Stimulus
description: I notice that commenters keep citing this paper by Alesina and Ardagna as if it were a definitive rejection of Keynesian economics. So I guess I should explain why Im not convinced.

description: YOU know were in trouble when were told that the economic problems in Greece, Portugal and Spain, the most indebted countries in the euro zone, are likely to remain safely contained in those nations.

Smyth, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Basilica of the Sacred Heart on the campus of Notre Dame, where the bride and bridegroom met and from which they both graduated.

title: A Voting Result That Faulkner Could Drink To
description: NEW ALBANY, Miss.  There was a vote here last month. It was hard-fought, with dueling newspaper advertisements and yard signs, tableside debates in restaurants, a prayer rally and a fusillade of last-minute phone calls.

description: Angela Kirsten Hurley and Eric Christian Rahe were married Saturday by the Rev. Gary Braun, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

description: This interview with Susan Docherty, who leads the United States sales, service and marketing team at General Motors, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Iraqi Group Says It Captured American
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi militant group said it had abducted an American contractor, a day after the United States military reported that a contractor had been missing since Jan. 23. It would be the first reported kidnapping of an American in a year in Iraq.

title: Audacitys Shape, From Outer Space
description: You may think Dubai is an odd place  an ostentatious and architecturally spectacular member of the United Arab Emirates that has teetered on the brink of a real estate collapse. So perhaps a change in perspective is in order  from outer space. Heres the Dubai coast, seen from the International Space Station. At left are the man-made Palm Jumeirah islands. At right is a development of 300 private man-made islands shaped like a global map. (Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt were said, at one point, to be thinking about buying a faux Ethiopia.) Like Dubai, the project may not be thriving. NASA could see little infrastructure.

title: For Tony Hawk, the Skateboard Is a Canvas
description: I STARTED skateboarding because I never fit in with team sports. I was so energetic as a kid, and skating became my outlet. It was like finding a blank canvas.
