And the man with the T-shirt proclaiming himself a proud member of the Tennessee MOB  a poke at politicians who dismissed Tea Party members as an angry mob. And one speaker did insist that Jesus birth was better documented than President Obamas.

title: Quotation of the Week
description: No matter how I look at the issue, I cannot escape being troubled by the fact that we have in place a policy which forces young men and women to lie about who they are in order to defend their fellow citizens. Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, calling for an end to the dont ask, dont tell law.

title: When Shes Ready to Retire, Shell Know
description: I HAVE what I consider the ideal job: providing confidential advice to small businesses and working to create jobs in western Massachusetts. Its a position Ive had for over 17 years.

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: Freedoms Dominoes
description: I was in Mikuyu Prison in Malawi when Nelson Mandela was released. Hearing the news, whispered to me by a daring prison guard, I instantly thought back to the day, a year earlier, when the same guard had told me the rumor that President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa was holding secret talks with Mr. Mandela. Rumors played a critical, if therapeutic, role for us; they were more reliable than the clippings from local newspapers that were smuggled into prison.

title: Biathlon Program Finds a Home in Northern Maine
description: FORT KENT, Me.  The thermometer read 15, and night had fallen on this intrepid little border town in northernmost Maine.

title: A Few Ashes Here, a Few Ashes There
description: About 30 years ago, only 4 percent of American families chose cremation over burial. Now that number is nearly 40 percent, and families increasingly are choosing to scatter their loved ones ashes widely and without permission, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Prime Number
description: 120: The number, in millions, of electric bicycles humming along the roads in China, up from a few thousand in the 1990s. Now Chinas booming electric-bike industry is spurring interest and sales in India, Europe and the United States. From virtually nothing a decade ago, electric bikes have become an $11 billion global industry. The most popular models in the United States are similar to standard bicycles with pedals, but they come equipped with electric motors that engage on command or when a cyclist pedals. Prices typically range from $1,500 to $3,000.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 7
description: Super Bowl XLIV competes with foreign policy, the economy and the Tea Party on this weeks talk shows.

title: Buy Now, Pay Later (Maybe With Your Allowance)
description: BUSINESSES dont let 13-year-olds pay for purchases with a promise. At least they didnt before last week.

title: Better Loving Through Chemistry
description: IF finding true love were an exact science, we wouldnt need matchmakers, singles bars or, of course, online dating services.

title: Is the Market Priced for Perfection?
description: THE stock market has changed considerably since early 2000, when the Standard & Poors 500-stock index traded at a record high valuation.

title: Terrorism and the Pocketbook
description: SHORTLY after Sept. 11, 2001, a soon-to-be familiar figure appeared in the news media. He was a young Muslim who wanted nothing more than to strap on a belt laden with explosives and blow himself up in an area crowded with infidels. He thought his reward would be eternity in paradise with 72 virgins.

title: No Walk-Through for Freeney
description: Defensive end Dwight Freeney did not participate in the Colts final walk-through on Saturday, according to the pool report. Freeney, who did not practice all week because of a torn ligament in his right ankle, spent the time on a golf cart although his ankle was not wrapped. Freeney was listed as questionable on Fridays injury report.

title: Why Politics Is Stuck in the Middle
description: MARKET competition, under the proper circumstances, has the power to make a business better serve its customers. Cellphone companies, for example, compete via cheaper prices, clearer connections and better apps. Political competition, though no less vigorous, is conducted on very different terms  and often ends up stifling innovation instead of encouraging it.

title: Not Quite Saying Super Bowl, but Cashing In on It
description: Every year shortly before the Super Bowl, advertisers exhort fans to get ready for the Big Game (with a new HDTV), stock up for the Big Game (with pizza and ice cream) and score some Big Game Savings (on Doritos).

title: Letters: New Demand for Adjunct Professors
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Stuck in Neutral? Reset the Mood
description: The Economic View column last Sunday, about pessimism during a recession, misidentified the university where Rachel Kranton, co-author of the coming book Identity Economics, is a professor. Although she was previously at the University of Maryland, she is now at Duke.

title: Cut, Snip, Slash, the Deficit Is a Hardy Survivor
description: When President Obama proposed a commission to come up with ways to bring the deficit under control, Republican opposition was summed up by Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin. The idea, he said, simply punts on the critical budget decisions that members of Congress got elected to make.

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: Silly Men, Sharp Knives
description: Nine months before Nelson Mandela was released from prison in South Africa, the Chinese police cracked down on demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, and in August 1989 I was sent to Hebei Prison for incitement to overthrow state power. My cellmates, like so many Chinese people at the time, were pessimistic about Chinas future. Why do you persist? they would ask me. Democracy and freedom are good, but there is not much hope for them in China. The prison guards would tell me, We have guarded many political prisoners before. The smarter ones have been promoted by the Communists to ranks as high as political consultant; the ones who persisted in defiance never ended well.

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: Path of Most Resistance
description: It was back in the 1970s, when I was doing diabetes research in Britain, that I first learned of the political drama surrounding Nelson Mandela. At the time I never would have predicted that one day I, too, would be imprisoned by a repressive regime for advocating human rights and democracy.

title: Reading File
description: How to Survive a Very Long Fall

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: The Radios Song of Liberation
description: Nelson Mandela has won the battle, I said to myself in my cold, tiny cell in the military prison in Bandung, West Java, Indonesia. Thank God, at last justice and freedom win.

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: My Hero, Page by Page
description: News of Nelson Mandelas release dominated the radio broadcasts by the BBC and Voice of America on Feb. 11, 1990. I felt I understood why he had resisted so long, because in Burma, as in South Africa at the time Mr. Mandela was in jail, the majority of people were struggling to make their voices heard. Within three months, the military junta would refuse to recognize the results of our national election  and I would be locked up in Rangoons Insein Prison for leading a demonstration.

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: Ray of Light
description: During the dictatorship of Hissne Habr in Chad, I was wrongfully accused of political activity and imprisoned. Our jail was infested with insects, and the heat was nearly unbearable. Packed in our cells, we had to take turns to sleep, often on top of the corpses of other prisoners who had died from torture, disease or malnutrition. We were forbidden to pray aloud. And every night, President Habrs political police took away prisoners who never returned.

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience: A Smile to Remember
description: Twenty years ago, I was in Qincheng, the most well-known of Chinas political prisons, along with several hundred other students and intellectuals who had taken part in the student movement of the previous summer. On a particularly cold winter morning, I sat on my bed and picked up my copy of The Peoples Daily, the government newspaper we were allowed to read, and saw that Nelson Mandela had been released from prison.

title: The Riddle of Consciousness
description: The assorted mystics, philosophers, theologians and, most recently, neuroscientists who have burned a candle searching for the essence of consciousness all started with a simple presumption: Consciousness must begin where unconsciousness ends.

title: Battle of the Bands: Citigroup Is Up Next
description: AFTER the Grammy Awards last Sunday, the stars came out for EMIs party at the W Hollywood Hotel. The country music hunk Keith Urban arrived with his wife, Nicole Kidman. Katy (I Kissed a Girl) Perry sparkled in a form-fitting dress that would become gossip fodder on the Internet. There were also rappers (Cypress Hill), guitar heroes (Slash and Dave Navarro) and a coffeehouse darling (Norah Jones).

title: Nelson Mandelas Captive Audience
description: On Feb. 11, 1990  20 years ago this Thursday  Nelson Mandela walked through the gates of a South African prison after 27 years of confinement. His release was celebrated the world over. But it had a particular effect on those who were being held as political prisoners by other repressive regimes. The Op-Ed editors asked seven of these former captives to describe what it was like when they heard the news of Mr. Mandelas liberation.

title: In a Young Season, Its Younger Players Who Are Standing Out
description: LOS ANGELES  It began two weeks ago in the desert, kept coming last weekend at Torrey Pines Golf Course and has continued this weekend at the Northern Trust Open here. Golfs youth movement, popping up like a hint of spring through the snowy shroud of winter, has broken the surface during the PGA Tours California swing, and is showing staying power.

title: A Globe Still in Need of Steel
description: The steel industry, though buffeted by crises in past decades, remains a core part of the economy. We may now be in the information age rather than the industrial age, but people still need steel for things like cars, buildings, pipelines, machinery and appliances.

title: The Big Whistle
description: The highest compliment you can pay an N.B.A. referee sounds something like this: Oh, you officiated the game last night? I didnt notice. A seasoned veteran will smile and say thank you.

description: WASHINGTON  For decades  through political upheaval and wars and wild bouts of deficits or inflation  the debt of the United States has always been rated AAA, the gold standard of creditworthiness by which all nations are compared.

description: NASHVILLE  The first National Tea Party convention here is not over  Sarah Palin speaks tonight  but organizers are already saying they will hold another one this summer.

title: Paying for the Olympics: The Toughest Course
description: WHEN the first Olympic athletes hit the slopes and ice this week in Vancouver, the 343-member staff of the United States Olympic Committee will probably breathe a collective sigh of relief. Last year was a tough one for this nonprofit group, which is charged with running the Olympic movement in the United States  and is one of the few among the 205 national Olympic committees to receive no government support.

description: Stacey Lynn Widlitz, a daughter of Patricia M. Widlitz and Gary Widlitz of Guilford, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Roger Murray Thomson, a son of Margaret and Murray Thomson of Dundee, Scotland. Goldin and the late Dr. Gurston D. Goldin of New York. Rabbi Andrea Myers officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Oh, What a Feeling: Watching Toyota Flunk for Once
description: Life, goes the clich, is just high school writ large, and in the senior class of automakers, Toyota was the straight-A student who wrecked the curve for everyone. Name the test  Consumer Reports ratings, customer satisfaction surveys, sales figures  and the company aced it, year after year. The performance didnt just make Toyota look great; it made rivals look daft. When Americans tsk-tsked the product rolling out of Detroit, they pointed like disappointed parents to Toyota and asked the Big Three, Why cant you be more like that?

title: England Beats Wales on Opening Day of Six Nations
description: LONDON  England celebrated a centenary by donning retro uniforms and rediscovering a winning form, as it beat Wales, 30-17, at Twickenham on Saturday on the opening day of the Six Nations competition.
