description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Apolitics and the War Film
description: Last Tuesday, the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences bestowed nine nominations on  The Hurt Locker, Kathryn Bigelows nerve-racking, formally astonishing tour de force about a squad of United States Army bomb disposal specialists plying their hazardous trade in Baghdad. After seven years in Iraq, eight in Afghanistan, and dozens of feature films touching  sometimes gingerly, sometimes allegorically  on both conflicts, this recognition seems both timely and overdue. At last, attention is being paid to a tough, uncompromising drama (which is also a doozy of an action movie) about the realities of combat on the ground.

title: The Dechoukaj This Time
description: Los Angeles

title: Addicted to Haiti
description: Dallas

title: Bleak Portrait of Haiti Orphanages Raises Fears
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The floors were concrete and the windows were broken.

title: Major Storm Hits Mid-Atlantic States
description: "Snowmaggedon!" President Obama declared to officials of the Democratic National Committee on Saturday morning at the Capital Hilton hotel. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Spending Cuts Meet Selective Support
description: WASHINGTON  While Senator Saxby Chambliss, Republican of Georgia, said he was all for slowing federal spending, he has no appetite for the substantial cuts in farm programs proposed in President Obamas new budget.

title: A Scrubbed Toe in the Race
description: Between bites of an egg-white garden omelet at a bistro in his Union Square neighborhood, Harold Ford Jr. defended himself on pedicures and flip-flops.

title: In a California Town, Birth Defects, Deaths and Questions
description: KETTLEMAN CITY, Calif.  State and federal officials are scrambling to determine what caused the deaths of three children in this Central California farming town, which shares a ZIP code with the largest hazardous waste treatment site west of the Mississippi.

title: League and Union Hold a Negotiating Session
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  The N.F.L.s labor committee and the players union held a 90-minute negotiating session Saturday, on the eve of the Super Bowl and a month before the 2010 season begins without a salary cap. The team owners then held a three-hour meeting.

title: Smoke the Bigots Out of the Closet
description: A funny thing happened after Adm. Mike Mullen called for gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military: A curious silence befell much of the right. If this were a Sherlock Holmes story, it would be the case of the attack dogs that did not bark.

title: Sinatra Song Often Strikes Deadly Chord
description: GENERAL SANTOS, the Philippines  After a day of barbering, Rodolfo Gregorio went to his neighborhood karaoke bar still smelling of talcum powder. Putting aside his glass of Red Horse Extra Strong beer, he grasped a microphone with a habitus self-assuredness and briefly stilled the room with the Platters My Prayer.

title: Nurse to Stand Trial for Reporting Doctor
description: KERMIT, Tex.  It occurred to Anne Mitchell as she was writing the letter that she might lose her job, which is why she chose not to sign it. But it was beyond her conception that she would be indicted and threatened with 10 years in prison for doing what she knew a nurse must: inform state regulators that a doctor at her rural hospital was practicing bad medicine.

title: Retired Correction Officer Wounds 2 in Queens Shooting
description: A retired New York City correction captain working security at a Queens bowling alley shot and wounded two men during a violent confrontation early Saturday morning outside the alley, the authorities said.

title: The World Capital of Killing
description: BUKAVU, Congo

title: After Summer Olympics, Empty Shells in Beijing
description: BEIJING  If you build it, he will come, Ray Kinsella, the farmer in the 1989 film  Field of Dreams,  hears, mystically, as he walks through his cornfield. So at seemingly ruinous cost, he razes the cornfield and builds a ball field, and is rewarded with an endless stream of ticket buyers stretching to the rural Iowa horizon.

title: A Valentines Day Sampler as Famous New Yorkers Kiss and Tell
description: New Yorkers can be quite creative when they want to put their affection into words. Some leave Post-it notes on the bathroom mirror. Some take out billboards in Times Square.

title: The Football Fan
description: Youre nothing but a pack of cards!  Alice

title: Postcard From Yemen
description: Sana, Yemen

title: Rice and Smith Lead Latest Class Into Hall of Fame
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  As expected, wide receiver Jerry Rice and running back Emmitt Smith were elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday. Linebacker Rickey Jackson will join them in Canton, Ohio, along with defensive tackle John Randle, guard Russ Grimm, running back Floyd Little and the cornerback and longtime coach Dick LeBeau.

title: Riding the Rails, Until the Weather Caught Up
description: When the powerful Mid-Atlantic winter storm grounded all flights and shut down highways in the Mid-Atlantic region, Amtraks Capitol Limited, bound for Chicago from Washington, seemed to offer 115 passengers the perfect cozy alternative as it sped through the snow-swept countryside on Friday night.

title: Obama Pledges to Press Ahead on Goals
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Saturday that the Democratic Party should not simply regroup, lick our wounds and try to hang on during a challenging political season, pledging to find a way for health care and job-creation measures to be passed this year.

title: Q and A With Kenny Smith: All-Star Musings
description: This years N.B.A. All-Star Game is going up against the Olympics and Valentines Day. So the basketball fan who has a love of international sports or a significant other could feel a little conflicted about their plans Sunday night.

title: States Look to Forestall Hypothetical Mandate
description: Health care legislation in Washington may be stalled, but that has not stopped legislatures in more than two-thirds of the states from objecting to one of its central planks: a requirement that everyone buy health insurance.

title: Worlds No. 1 Player Widens Lead Over His Biggest Rivals
description: History will record 1990 as a great year for chess players: it was when three of the current top 25 players in the world were born.

title: Too Close to Home
description: LATE last month, a Web site called the Electronic Intifada reported that Ethan Bronner, the Jerusalem bureau chief of The Times, has a son in the Israeli military. Others, including Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting, a liberal media watchdog group, demanded to know if it was true and, if so, why it did not create an unacceptable conflict of interest for Bronner and The Times.

title: The Two Worlds of the Citizen-Soldier
description: Preparing for my part-time National Guard training, I am transported into a former life. Getting my old number two on the sides and back, trim the top haircut and putting on my digital camouflage uniform is like going through a time warp. Looking in the mirror, I feel as if I am staring at a person I used to be. Like a rusty foreign language speaker, I struggle to talk like a soldier. Once second nature, the clipped sentences and vocabulary of sirs, maams, rogers, hoo-ahs, acronyms, four letter words and colorful expressions now take effort. I also return to a world where the conflicts in Afghanistan and Iraq are an impending reality, not a distant abstraction.

title: A High-Tech Alternative for Hollywood Hopefuls
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: News Analysis: After the Primary, Its Not Politics as Usual
description: Terrence OBrien got his start in Chicago Democratic politics like so many of his peers and the generations that came before him, dutifully ringing doorbells to solicit votes for his state senator on the far North Side. He rose to coordinating other precinct captains for such candidates as a young Cook County states attorney and mayoral hopeful named Richard M. Daley.

title: New Chef Will Help Pastry Level to Rise
description: Chicago has long attracted ambitious immigrants from all corners of the world. World champion bakers from tiny Alsatian villages are not usually among them.

title: The Pulse: Kick Back and Relax as a Cafe Returns
description: Two years ago, when the grungy Wicker Park icon Filter Cafe was ousted from its prime location in the Flat Iron Arts Building by a bank, its clientele was forced to seek other venues in which to lounge while drinking the occasional cup of coffee.

title: The Pulse: If You Get a Parking Ticket, a Prayer May Not Help
description: In a conflict between churches and the state of affairs with the citys new parking meters, a group of black ministers is circulating petitions designed to end the ticketing of parked cars during church events.

title: The Pulse: Citys Public Schools Seek a Bit of Serenity
description: Ron Huberman, the chief executive of Chicagos public schools, is looking to hire a Culture of Calm coordinator to improve conditions in schools deemed most at risk for student violence.

title: Officer Shoots and Wounds Man Holding BB Gun in Brooklyn
description: A 61-year-old man was shot and wounded by a police officer early Saturday after, officials said, he refused to drop what looked like a pistol on a dark street in Brooklyn.

title: A Practiced Politician Who Doesnt Look It
description: Joe Simitian has spent nearly half his life in elective office, having served on the Palo Alto school board, the City Council, as mayor, on the County Board of Supervisors and in the State Assembly. Now he is in his second and final term in the State Senate. He is married to his political consultant.

title: Charter School Founder Faces Financial Scrutiny
description: The founder of a public charter school in the East Bay that provides a comfort zone for Muslim students is under attack in the wake of a state audit that uncovered questionable financial practices, including lavish payments to her.

title: The Truth About the Deficit
description: When the White House released its new budget last week, including more spending to create desperately needed jobs, Republican leaders in Congress denounced President Obama for driving up the deficit and demanded that the Democrats halt their reckless ways.

title: Time to Catch Up With Herself
description: Alice Waters, 65, opened her bistro Chez Panisse on Shattuck Avenue in Berkeley at 27. It became the cradle of a culinary revolution that swept across the state and introduced a neat, understated approach to traditional kitchens of the East Coast. An abiding devotion to simple cooking and fresh ingredients in the kitchen are part of Ms. Waterss broader slow food philosophy, of buying and eating local and organic. (Her words have been edited and condensed.) GERRY SHIH

title: Two Cities, One Lasting Cultural Exchange
description: To many people who have never been to China, myself among them, San Franciscos Chinatown  the oldest and one of the largest districts of its kind in North America  still largely represents Chinese culture, despite the popularity of films like Zhang Yimous Hero; international tours by the countrys top ballet, opera and circus companies; and the fame of Chinese composers like Tan Dun. Most Bay Area residents see beyond the usual representations of Chinese New Year parades, dragon dances and Ming Dynasty vases gathering dust behind glass in museums. But even so, when lipstick-colored pagodas, soggy dim sum and mass-produced, paw-waving porcelain cats come to represent an entire civilization, its time to take a step back and look beyond the Disneyland view.

title: The Tea Partiers Court the Foreign Press
description: NASHVILLE  Organizers of the National Tea Party Convention here were not happy about the media coverage leading up to their event  the stories about how convention sponsors and participants were pulling out and accusing the convention of profiteering, and about one organizers past bankruptcy.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column last Sunday, about long-suffering pro football fans in New Orleans who could use some good times, misstated, in some editions, the birth order of the sons of former Saints quarterback Archie Manning. Peyton Manning is his second son, not his oldest son. (Cooper is the oldest and Eli is the youngest.)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Serena Williamss victory over Justine Henin in the Australian Open womens final the previous day erroneously attributed a distinction to Li Na and Zheng Jie. They became the first two Chinese players to advance to the semifinals in singles at the same Grand Slam tennis tournament; they did not become the first Chinese to make it to a Grand Slam semifinal. (Zheng played in the semifinals at Wimbledon in 2008.)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about Sam Sullivan, a former mayor of Vancouver who caught the worlds attention when he waved an Olympic flag from his wheelchair at the close of the 2006 Games in Turin, Italy, misidentified, in some copies, the woman shown with him and misstated the location of the picture. She is a member of a group that seeks to aid drug users in Vancouver  not Mr. Sullivans fiance, Lynn Zanatta. And the picture was taken in the Downtown Eastside, a neighborhood in Vancouver; it was not taken at the Eastside Association.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a high school sophomore who surveyed young athletes in Darien, Conn., to find out why they played sports misidentified the sport his father is involved with. Mike Barston, who encouraged his son Peter to update and localize a 20-year-old national study, serves on the board of a youth baseball  not football  league.

title: Peyton Manning, and Speed-Reading a Defense
description: Is the Colts Peyton Manning the greatest quarterback in N.F.L. history?

title: Patrick Avoids Disasters and Wins Praise, if Not the Race
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The crowd around Danica Patrick swelled as she walked toward her trailer Saturday night after finishing sixth in her stock car debut behind Bobby Gerhart, a six-time winner here.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column on Jan. 24 about points of interest in Los Angeles misstated the location of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. It is midway between downtown and Santa Monica; it is not in downtown.

title: Bill Keller Takes Exception to Too Close to Home
description: Because todays Public Editor column takes the unusual step of recommending that a respected Times journalist be reassigned, I thought it only fair to offer Bill Keller, the executive editor, an opportunity to respond in full. Here is what Keller had to say: Much as I respect your concern for appearances, we will not be taking your advice to remove Ethan Bronner from the Jerusalem Bureau. Im happy to explain my thinking.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an item in the Globespotters column on Jan. 31 about places offering affordable massage and reflexology in Mumbai, India, misidentified the type of massage offered by Aura Thai Spa. It is traditional Thai massage, not Keralan ayurvedic.

title: Corrections
description: SPORTS

title: Maine Town Suits Biathlon Perfectly
description: The Maine Winter Sports Center is attempting to create an international center for biathlon in northern Maine.

title: Tearful Rice and Smith Lead Class of Seven to Hall of Fame
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Weeping tears of joy, Jerry Rice and Emmitt Smith led a class of seven inductees into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday.

title: Vows: Caitlin & Corey
description: Caitlin Allen and Corey Wilson met five years ago in Chicago. When Caitlin had the opportunity to join a Broadway show, Corey quit his job, left everything behind, and followed her to New York.

title: Your Comments on my Sunday Congo Column
description: My Sunday column is again from Congo, through the lens of a doctor (Denis Mukwege) and his patient (Jeanne Mukuninwa). They are both extraordinary figures, and Dr. Mukwege is sometimes mentioned  most deservedly  as a candidate for the Nobel Peace Prize. His Panzi Hospital is an oasis in South Kivu, just as the Heal Africa Hospital is in North Kivu.

title: Weather, and Wildcats Surges, Cant Deter Hoyas
description: WASHINGTON  The weather was horrible. The No. 2 team in the country was in town. And Georgetown was coming off a disappointing midweek loss.

title: Geoffrey Burbidge, Who Traced Life to Stardust, Is Dead at 84
description: Geoffrey Burbidge, an English physicist who became a towering figure in astronomy by helping to explain how people and everything else are made of stardust, died on Jan. 26 in San Diego. He was 84.

title: Jack Block, Who Studied Young Children Into Adulthood, Dies at 85
description: Jack Block, a prominent psychologist of personality who in 1968 began studying a group of California preschoolers and for decades kept watch as they moved from childhood through adolescence and into adulthood, died on Jan. 13 at his home in El Cerrito, Calif. He was 85.

title: Kovalchuk Creates Offense and Interest
description: That the Atlanta Thrashers traded Ilya Kovalchuk last Thursday surprised no one in the hockey world. That they traded him to the Devils surprised almost everyone.

title: A Doctor and His Patient
description: Dr. Denis Mukwege and his young patient try to assert humanity and dignity in war-torn eastern Congo, Nicholas D. Kristof reports.

title: Eleven Madison Park Chef Will Compete at Bocuse dOr
description: James Kent, sous chef at Eleven Madison Park in Manhattan, will represent the United States in the Bocuse dOr International Culinary Competition, to be held in Lyon, France next January.

title: Landrieu Takes Mayoral Seat in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  Riding a wave of discontent with political corruption, high crime rates and the slow pace of the citys recovery, Lt. Gov. Mitch Landrieu was elected mayor of this city by a landslide on Saturday, the first white man to hold the position since his father, Moon Landrieu, left office in 1978.

title: Josh Smith Brings a New Look to Shot Blocking
description: The image of a shot blocker in the N.B.A. is, and probably always will be, a plodding 7-footer piling up huge amounts of blocks in spurts. Doing his best to change that stereotype, the Atlanta Hawks Josh Smith, at an athletic 6 feet 9 inches, became the fastest player to reach 1,000 career blocks in a loss to Oklahoma City last Tuesday.

title: Snowstorm in Washington
description: One of the largest winter storms in decades swept into Washington and Baltimore, and continued up the northeastern United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
N.H.L. Scoreboard: On Sad Night, Leafs Snap Senators Streak
description: Fourteen games on Saturday. Home teams listed first:

title: Sarah Palin at the Tea Party
description: Sarah Palin's speech, the climactic moment of the National Tea Party Convention in Nashville, was closely watched as a potential signal of her political future.

title: Stricker Leads by Five When Rain Halts Northern Trust Open
description: LOS ANGELES  The field did not finish the third round of the Northern Trust Open on Saturday at the soggy Riviera Country Club, but Steve Stricker did his best to ensure that the tournament was almost over.

title: Rangers Maintain an Edge Against the Devils
description: The Devils may be the new glamour team in the metropolitan area, and they may be headed to a 13th straight season of finishing ahead of the Rangers in the standings, but in head-to-head meetings none of that seems to matter.

title: Jamess 47 Points, Including 35 by Halftime, Are Too Much for Knicks
description: CLEVELAND  LeBron James does not talk much about free agency anymore, having grown either bored or irritated by the subject. But if a person could scoff with a jump shot, then James just soaked the Knicks in contempt.

title: Cloudy Weather Halts Shuttle Launch
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The launching of the space shuttle Endeavour was postponed a day because of thick clouds that moved in during the last few hours of the countdown.

title: Detained Health Workers Denounce Philippine Government
description: MANILA, Philippines  The families and colleagues of 43 health workers detained over the weekend denounced the Philippine government on Sunday and accused the police and military of framing the suspects.

title: Dan Shaughnessy: Manning Is Better Than Brady
description: In his column on Monday morning, Dan Shaughnessy of The Boston Globe will tell the children of New England that Santa Claus doesnt exist.

title: Out With the Ox, in With the Tiger
description: The Chinese New Year, or Spring Festival, will soon be upon us (and with it, the Year of the Tiger), and Hong Kong has one of the most elaborate celebrations in the world. Heres a quick guide to the festivities in the city.

title: How to Spot a Winner in a Squares Pool
description: Carlton Chin, a fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. Don LaFronz contributed reporting.

title: Super Bowl vs. Champions League
description: If its the ultimate game, how come theyre playing it again next year?  Duane Thomas, Cowboys running back

title: Foyer of Patience Orphanage
description: The same room in the orphanage serves as a classroom and a bedroom for the children, who sleep on the floor with minimal bedding.

title: Opposition Leader Declares Victory in Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The opposition leader Viktor F. Yanukovich declared victory on Sunday in presidential elections in Ukraine, claiming what appeared to be an unlikely comeback from his humiliating defeat in the 2004 Orange Revolution, when he was shunned as a bumbling Kremlin sidekick.

title: Palins Tea Party Speech
description: Former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin gave a 40-minute speech at the Tea Party convention in Nashville on Saturday night, when she took several jabs at President Obama and deflected a question about her own political future.

title: Is Google Running a Super Bowl Ad?
description: Updated 6:52 PM Confirming Google is running ad to promote its brand during the Super BowlOver the weekend, the tech blogosphere was abuzz over the expectation that Google, a company that build its brand almost entirely through word of mouth, was going to air an ad during the Super Bowl. John Battelle, the author of The Search, the 2005 book about Google, wrote on his blog that Google plans to hit the branded advertising big leagues this Sunday, citing an unnamed source.

title: Irans President Moves Ahead on Uranium Processing
description: CAIRO  Irans president ordered his atomic scientists on Sunday to begin enriching their stockpile of uranium in order to power a medical reactor, a move that accelerated Irans brinkmanship over its nuclear program by moving the country closer to producing weapons-grade fuel.

title: Second Wave of F1 Testing
description: This week the Formula One teams will test in Jerez, Spain  weather permitting. The second wave of testing will help to define a little better whats really happening this year, hopefully. Ferrari, the fastest team and car last week, played down the idea that it is the team to beat.

title: 5 Dead, Dozens Hurt in Connecticut Power Plant Blast
description: A power plant under construction in central Connecticut exploded with earthquake force that shook homes across much of the state on Sunday as workers purged natural gas lines in preparation for the plant to open this year. At least five people were killed and more than two dozen were injured as a section of the plant collapsed and burned.

title: Iraqi Court Given Time to Review Candidates
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq staggered toward a resolution of its election crisis on Sunday as the countrys leaders gave an appeals court time to reconsider a ban on hundreds of candidates barred from next months election because of alleged links to Saddam Husseins Baath Party.

title: Is the Colts Running Game Better Than It Looks?
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  If the Saints want to increase their chances of getting to Peyton Manning, they might want to start with stopping the Colts running game.

title: Why Do You E-Mail Times Articles?
description: If youve ever e-mailed a New York Times article, there are some researchers at the Wharton School at Penn who would like to hear from you. Click here to take a brief survey on your e-mailing habits. After you fill it out, youre welcome to add any additional comments on the questions here at the blog.

title: Home-Field Advantage for Saints?
description: MIAMI  Arriving at Sun Life Stadium Sunday afternoon, it was much easier to spot a Saints jersey than a Colts one as fans streamed in.

title: Cleaning Up After a Snowstorm as Another One Looms
description: WASHINGTON  Road crews, power company workers and plain old homeowners with shovels struggled in gleaming sunshine on Sunday to clean up from a weekend of record snowfall here, but they faced little hope of returning to normalcy soon because five or more inches was forecast within days.

title: Sapp Released After a Night in Jail
description: Warren Sapp, the former Tampa Bay and Oakland defensive tackle who is now an NFL Network analyst, was released on bond Sunday morning after spending the night in jail following his arrest for allegedly choking a woman.

title: Super Bowl Final: Saints 31, Colts 17
description: New York Times reporters and editors, including Judy Battista, Greg Bishop, Tom Jolly and Justin Sablich, provided live analysis from Miami Gardens, Fla., of Super Bowl XLIV between the Colts and the Saints. Richard Sandomir, contributing from New York, added commentary on the CBS telecast. The Media Decoder blog commented on the Super Bowl ads here.

title: Explosion at Plant in Connecticut
description: Dozens of fire trucks and ambulances are headed to a huge explosion at a power plant in Middletown, Conn. MSNBC's Melissa Rehberger reports. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Transit-Plan Prescription for Disappearing Detroit
description: The biggest jolt in Blueprint America: Beyond the Motor City comes as the director of Madrids subway and light-rail system talks about the importance of infrastructure. (Maybe jolt is too strong.) Discussing Spains ambitious high-speed rail system, he says countries that neglect their infrastructure experience a slow decline in importance and their weight in the world. Cut to Detroits imposing Michigan Central Station, sitting in abandoned, broken-windowed splendor. It doesnt look like decline  it looks like whatever comes next.

title: Medical Technology Dominates at the Olin Cup
description: The Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis announced the winners of its commercial business plan competition, the Olin Cup, on Thursday night with a $50,000 seed investment offer going to a top team. The competition, now in its 22nd year, received 45 initial submissions; of 17 eligible semifinalists, seven advanced to the finals.

title: Ex-Vice President May Avoid Run-Off Vote in Costa Rica
description: MEXICO CITY  Early results in the Costa Rica presidential elections held Sunday gave a decisive lead to Laura Chinchilla, a former vice president who was on the verge of becoming the countrys first woman president.

title: Love (and Arias) With a Proper Swine
description: The British composer Jonathan Dove has written theater and film scores, orchestral and chamber works, and operas: most notably operas for children. He had a solid success in London in 2006 with The Enchanted Pig, a childrens opera based on a Romanian folk tale, with a libretto by Alasdair Middleton.

title: Storm Prompts Senate to Postpone Votes
description: The Senate has been stalled by partisanship much of the past year and now Mother Nature is getting in on the act.

title: Circling for Two Years, Rivals Are Set to Race
description: VALENCIA, Spain  After a 30-month legal fight that seemed at times as if it might never end, a funny thing happened on the waters of the Western Mediterranean on Sunday: two teams led by rival billionaire yachtsmen got ready for a sailboat race.

title: Obama Plans Bipartisan Summit on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Sunday that he would convene a half-day bipartisan health care session at the White House to be televised live this month, a high-profile gambit that will allow Americans to watch as Democrats and Republicans try to break their political impasse.

title: The Next Great Big Man?
description: SOUTH KINGSTOWN, R.I.  Andre Drummond doesnt turn 17 until August. Because hes 6-foot-11 and 270 pounds, he said people mistake him for a grown-up all the time. And by grown-up, he means an 18-year old.

title: Another Look at Uppercuts and Getting Partner Involved
description: We have been looking at uppercuts that generate extra trump tricks for the defense. Sometimes this can take persistence  as in the diagramed deal.

title: A Chronicler of the World Now Looks Inward
description: In one of the short personal reminiscences that the historian Tony Judt has been writing for The New York Review of Books he mentions that he was part of the lucky generation born in the affluent West after World War II, free to indulge in daydreams and passions.

title: Super Bowl Ad Watch: Blogging the Commercials
description: Stuart Elliott, The Timess advertising columnist, is taking a running look at some of the evenings Super Bowl commercials:

title: Local Stop: Morningside Heights
description: A visit to the urban campus of Columbia University, sprawled across Upper Manhattan.

title: Back From the Depths, Rebuilding a Career
description: Sitting in the Off Broadway theater where he has begun to put his career back together, in the new play Venus in Fur, the actor Wes Bentley takes a deep breath, leans forward in his seat, and starts answering the obvious question: What happened to him after the film American Beauty?

title: A British Bands Cerebral Electronics
description: Hot Chip could make things easy on itself. The band knows how to get a crowd of New York indie-rock fans, like the ones at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Saturday night, dancing and waving their arms. It simply deploys a four-on-the-floor dance-club thump under bouncing, pinging synthesizer parts and pop choruses.

title: Altidore: A Tremendously Well-Taken Goal
description: With one well-timed swing of his right foot, Jozy Altidore on Saturday helped to ease the pain in his personal life and the pressure in his professional.

title: New CDs
description: MASSIVE ATTACK Heligoland (Virgin)

title: Ambient Techno Gets the Improvised, Live Touch
description: No one minded that the Moritz Von Oswald Trio had five members when it made its American debut on Saturday night at Le Poisson Rouge, part of the Unsound Festival New York and the Wordless Music series at the club. The trio is an alliance of techno and ambient disc jockeys and programmers doing what they dont do in D.J. booths or remix studios: playing instruments together in real time.

title: 20 Across: Equipment in Craps
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Paula Gamache has consulted her dictionary and come away with a cool theme revolving around the multiple meanings of HOT. Thieves, cooks, bartenders, subway conductors and Victorias Secret catalog subscribers will all find something to relate to.

title: Just Me and My (Murderous Soviet Agent) Shadow
description: As the dark comedy Duet for Solo Voice begins, Leonard Pelican, its only character, recounts his personal chronology: published a novel at 24, married a chorus girl at 26, entered a mental institution for the first time at 30. Now, years later, hes the night manager of the quintessential seedy Times Square hotel in 1969.

title: Know Your Deficits
description: Brad DeLong catches Ryan Avent, unusually, making a whoopsie, confusing current account deficits with fiscal deficits. When I say that the problems of the euro do not, in fact, have much to do with fiscal irresponsibility, heres the picture I have in mind:

title: Between the Musical Gems, Suburbs-vs.-Hollywood Asides
description: Christine Ebersole materialized like a goddess formed out of the ectoplasm in screwball heaven at Wednesdays opening-night performance of her new show at the Caf Carlyle. From what other celestial realm could this dizzy, curly headed blonde with a soprano whose wheeling vibrato evokes Jeanette MacDonald with a whiff of helium have originated?

title: Scrapping a Program, Breaking Into Solos
description: Preparation and poise, consideration and conviction: these are fundamental qualities in any successful classical-music performance. But occasionally thinking on the fly is required. Musicians From Marlboro, the touring arm of the prestigious Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, planned to include vocal duets by Haydn and Schumann in a concert presented at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night. But when the soprano Hyunah Yu fell ill, Nicholas Phan, a tenor, was left to carry on by himself.

title: Romping Couples, Brazilian Rhythms and Strobe-Light Suspension
description: The Joyce Theater was sprinkled with children on Saturday afternoon when Parsons Dance performed a family-friendly matinee. Yet so many of the qualities we associate with youngsters  their sense of play and wonder, of honesty and discovery  were missing from the nearly two-hour program of slickly surfaced, content-thin works.

title: Neo-Classical Stravinsky Joins Bachian Rhythms
description: Neo-Classicism comes in many varieties, and the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra explored several in its concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening. It is a style well-suited to this conductorless orchestra. Though it plays large-scale Romantic and contemporary works persuasively, Orpheus is at its best in music where the orchestration is focused, and the contours are tightly defined.

title: Ambitious Banker, Not to the McMansion Born, Ascends the Ladder of Class
description: In Union Atlantic an immensely talented young writer attempts to write a big, splashy novel with Tom Wolfeian ambitions  a novel set mainly in the early years of this millennium and flirting with issues like Wall Street corruption and class warfare. The result is a lumpy, disappointing book: at times, gripping and keenly observed, but more often strangely implausible and contrived.

title: A Quartet Illuminates the Passion of Beethoven
description: Beethoven, inspired by the tomb scene from Romeo and Juliet, wrote les derniers soupirs (the last breaths) in his sketch for the Adagio of his String Quartet in F (Op. 18, No. 1). The Brentano String Quartet played the work with the requisite passion and tenderness at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening.

title: Intrigue at the Annies
description: Animators can be a tricky bunch. On one hand, they are generally dorky and polite, guys (and overwhelmingly so) who offer an aw-shucks counterbalance to the preening of the rest of Hollywood. But animators can get really, really cranky when it comes to the public lauding  or not  of their work.

title: Donizetti Returns, Offering Plenty of Chemistry and Nine High Cs
description: The Argentine composer Ginastera made an unlikely appearance in Donizettis Fille du Rgiment when Laurent Pellys lively and broadly comical 2008 production returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday evening.

title: Iron Checkbook Shapes Cultural Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Every American city has its power brokers, but only Los Angeles has an Eli Broad.

title: The Reach of Eli Broad in Los Angeles
description: Eli Broad, the billionaire philanthropist, wields an influence in Los Angeles that is unparalleled in any other American city. An interactive map reveals his vast imprint.

title: Rock Groups
description: Like anything else, arithmetic has its serious side and its playful side.

title: Will Americans Really Learn Chinese?
description: The Times recently reported on the rise of Chinese-language instruction in American schools, a push supported by aid from the Chinese government. While language fads come and go  there was Russian during the cold war, then Japanese in the 1980s, then Arabic after 9/11  thousands of public schools have stopped teaching foreign languages in the last decade. Is the boom in Chinese language education going to last?

title: Plentiful Content, So Cheap
description: Last Wednesday, I met with an executive from Demand Media, a company that generates content based on popular Web searches and other data. Since then, Ive spent about 20 hours reading past articles, calling people for background, doing interviews, writing my column, and working on the copy with editors Sunday afternoon.

title: Romance Overtakes Avatar
description: Moviegoers turned their attention to a mushy Nicholas Sparks adaptation over the weekend as Dear John ended the seven-week run of Avatar as the No. 1 movie in North America. Starring two of Hollywoods ascending young actors, Channing Tatum and Amanda Seyfried, right, Dear John (Relativity Media) sold an estimated $32.4 million in tickets. The movie  which received mixed-to-negative reviews and was based on Mr. Sparkss best-selling novel about a soldier and his sweetheart back home  performed sharply better than expected; box office analysts pointed to successful countermarketing to women on Super Bowl weekend. Avatar (20th Century Fox) was second with about $23.6 million for a domestic total of $630.1 million. John Travolta suffered another dud with From Paris With Love. This crime thriller (Lionsgate) entered the market in third place with a soft $8.5 million total, according to Hollywood.com, which tracks ticket sales. Mel Gibsons Edge of Darkness (Warner Brothers) was fourth with about $7 million for a total of $29.1 million. Tooth Fairy (Fox) was fifth with an estimated $6.5 million for a total of $34.3 million.

title: Footnotes
description: The country-singing mother-daughter duo the Judds are reuniting for one last tour, Wynonna Judd announced on The Early Show: Saturday Edition on CBS. Before performing live from Miami on the networks pre-Super Bowl XLIV show, Ms. Judd announced plans for a tour, as well as plans to record new music with her mother, Naomi Judd, for a fall release. ... Henry Winkler has joined the cast of the USA networks drama Royal Pains, Variety reported. Mr. Winkler, who first became famous as a star on Happy Days, is to appear in the shows new season as the absentee father of Hank and Evan, played by Mark Feuerstein and Paulo Costanzo. The expanded second season, from 12 to 18 episodes, is set to begin this summer.

title: In the Wings
description: The Goodman Theater in Chicago has announced casting for the world premiere of A True History of the Johnstown Flood by Rebecca Gilman. Robert Falls is to direct a cast that includes the Broadway actors Cliff Chamberlain (Superior Donuts), Sarah Charipar (One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest) and Randall Newsome (Inherit the Wind), as well as Janet Ulrich Brooks, Stephen Louis Grush, Cedric Mays, Heather Wood and Lucas Hall, Playbill reported. Previews will begin on March 13. ... The national tour of The Phantom of the Opera, Andrew Lloyd Webbers musical that never dies, will end its run in November at the Pantages Theater in Los Angeles, after more than 7,000 performances, the producers Cameron Mackintosh and The Really Useful Theater Company announced.

title: For New and Healthy Recipes, a Magazine Turns to Leftovers
description: When Health magazine promoted Your New Favorite Dinners in its December issue, there was just one problem: the dinners werent exactly new.

title: New Role for Taylor Lautner
description: The Twilight heartthrob Taylor Lautner has been cast as the hero of Universal Pictures coming Stretch Armstrong, Variety reported. This Hasbro-branded adventure movie, based on the toy of the same name, was scheduled for release in April 2011 but producers announced on Friday that it has been pushed back to March 2012 to allow the film to be shot in 3D. The delay will also accommodate Mr. Lautners prior commitments, which include two more Twilight films and Paramounts Max Steel, also based on a toy, this one from Mattel, in which a 19-year-old extreme-sports enthusiast is recruited by a secret agency after an accident renders him superhuman. Brian Grazer and Hasbro will produce Stretch, with a screenplay by Steve Oedekerk (Bruce Almighty).

title: Broadway at the Y
description: As part of its cultural programming the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan will begin holding a new series of one-on-one conversations about theater next month, called Broadway Talks. The moderator will be Jordan Roth, above, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns five Broadway houses. According to publicists for Jujamcyn and the 92nd Street Y, the first guests will be Liev Schreiber (A View from The Bridge) on March 1 and Laura Linney (Time Stands Still) on March 28. In May, Mr. Roth is to interview two actors who are scheduled to star in Broadway musicals this spring: Nathan Lane of The Addams Family on May 23, and Sean Hayes of Promises, Promises on May 24. The 92nd Street Y proposed the series to Mr. Roth after his appointment to lead Jujamcyn last fall, and he has been the one responsible for inviting the guests as well as interviewing them, according to the Y. Tickets are $27 for each panel. Information: 92y.org.

title: Rare Lincoln Items at Historical Society
description: On Monday the New-York Historical Society will display two new artifacts in its Lincoln and New York exhibition: a handwritten text of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, which outlawed slavery, and an 1864 printing of the Emancipation Proclamation, both signed by Lincoln. According to a statement from the museum the copy of the amendment being displayed is one of only six or seven known Congressional copies, which were signed not only by Lincoln, Vice President Hannibal Hamlin and the speaker of the House, Schuyler Colfax, but also by the members of the House and Senate who voted for the measure. There are no more than 14 copies of the amendment bearing Lincolns signature, according to the museum. The copy of the Emancipation Proclamation on display, above, was signed by Lincoln and his secretary of state, William Seward, and authenticated by John Nicolay, the presidents private secretary. They will remain on view through March 25, when the exhibition closes.

title: Leonard Cohen Tour Delayed by Injury
description: Leonard Cohen, below, the singer-songwriter has postponed a European tour after hurting his back while exercising, his representatives said in a statement, Reuters reported. The tour, which was to begin March 1 in Caen, France, will be delayed by more than six months to allow for an extended regimen of physical therapy on advice from Mr. Cohens doctors. Shows are now planned to begin on Sept. 15 and to continue through Oct. 7. Mr. Cohen, 75, returned to performing in May 2008 after a 15-year absence. He was taken to the hospital in September after collapsing onstage in Valencia, Spain, during a performance. Tour promoters said he had suffered from a stomach complaint and was released the next day. Mr. Cohen received a Grammy Award on Jan. 31 for lifetime achievement.

title: Super Bowl Merchandise and the Bets Behind It
description: LONG before the opening kickoff of Super Bowl XLIV, the New Orleans Saints had already beaten the Indianapolis Colts in one important category: merchandise.

title: Obamas Balancing Act on U.S. Trade Policies
description: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania challenged President Obama last week on behalf of steel workers, and helped underscore the administrations ambivalence about trade.

title: Obamas Balancing Act on Trade
description: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania challenged President Obama last week on behalf of steel workers, and helped underscore the administrations ambivalence about trade.

title: Undersized Point Guard Makes a Big Impact at Siena
description: LOUDONVILLE, N.Y.  In December 2005, Jim Donofrio, the basketball coach at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School in suburban Philadelphia, sent an e-mail message to Siena Coach Fran McCaffery about his point guard, Ronald Moore. Upset at the dearth of recruiting attention Moore was receiving, Donofrio felt McCafferys team would be a good fit. A reply came within hours.

title: Britain Plans to Cut Flow of Foreign Students
description: LONDON  In the face of mounting concern about abuse of student visa rules by migrant jobseekers and potential terrorists, Britain said Sunday that it was planning an immediate tightening of its border controls that could reduce the flow of people entering the country as students by tens of thousands a year.

title: Kindle Books in Snack Sizes
description: Who has time to read a whole book anymore?

title: Americans Held in Haiti Are Divided Over Leader
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Divisions emerged within the group of 10 Americans jailed in Haiti on child abduction charges, with eight of them signing a note over the weekend saying that they had been misled by Laura Silsby, the leader of the group.

title: A Federal Effort to Push Junk Food Out of Schools
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will begin a drive this week to expel Pepsi, French fries and Snickers bars from the nations schools in hopes of reducing the number of children who get fat during their school years.

title: For Students at Risk, Early College Proves a Draw
description: RAEFORD, N.C.  Precious Holt, a 12th grader with dangly earrings and a SpongeBob pillow, climbs on the yellow school bus and promptly falls asleep for the hour-plus ride to Sandhills Community College.

title: Have Faith in Love
description: Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Cry for Self-Rule by Tamils Is Muffled by Reality
description: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka  Jaffna is a city of ruins. Some are physical, like the overgrown jumbles of mold-streaked concrete where graceful buildings used to stand. But perhaps the biggest ruin of the Tamil Tiger insurgency against the Sri Lankan government is the very thing the Tigers wanted most: any hope of self-rule.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: The Fight Over Who Sets Prices at the Online Mall
description: Wheres the price?

title: Sucking the Quileute Dry
description: Los Angeles

title: Palin in 2012? She Says Run Is Possible
description: NASHVILLE  Sarah Palin said in an interview broadcast Sunday that she would consider a run for the White House in 2012 if I believe that that is the right thing to do for our country and for the Palin family.

title: UEFA Sets Qualifying Groups for Euro 2012
description: UEFA held the qualifying draw Sunday for the 2012 European Championship, which will be played in Poland and Ukraine.

title: How the Letterman-Oprah-Leno Super Bowl Ad Came Together
description: Jay and Dave together? Could it be true?

title: America Is Not Yet Lost
description: Weve always known that Americas reign as the worlds greatest nation would eventually end. But most of us imagined that our downfall, when it came, would be something grand and tragic.

title: The Road to Jalalabad
description: Drivers take hairpin curves at dizzying speeds along an Afghan mountain road.

title: On Afghan Road, Scenes of Beauty and Death
description: SAROBI, Afghanistan  Even in a nation beset by war and suicide bombings, you would be hard-pressed to find anything as reliably terrifying as the national highway through the Kabul Gorge.

title: The Highway From Kabul to Jalalabad
description: Driving along the hairpin bends, ravines and mountain tunnels of the narrow riverside highway that links the Afghan capital to Pakistan and the Khyber Pass.

title: Video: A Front-Seat View of the Highway
description: The scenic but hazardous road from Kabul to Afghanistans southern gateway Jalalabad is described by Dexter Filkins in The New York Times today. Here is a video of a drive along the same highway, past the jagged peaks, erratic trucks and sheer precipices along that narrow mountain lifeline to the Khyber Pass.

title: In Nordic Combined, Americans Close In on a Quantum Leap
description: Americans are used to being the scrappy underdog in Nordic combined, a sport that involves cross-country racing and ski jumping and has traditionally been dominated by Norwegians, who originated the sport.

title: After Turmoil at Merrill, Thain Will Lead the Lender CIT
description: Over his 30-year career, John A. Thain has risen to top executive positions at Goldman Sachs, the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch.

title: Super Bowl XLIV
description: The Indianapolis Colts and the New Orleans Saints met in Miami Gardens, Fla,. to decide who would be the winner of Super Bowl XLIV.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a lawsuit over an automobile crash involving a Toyota not subject to either of the companys recent recalls misstated the surname of a Transportation Department spokeswoman. She is Olivia Alair, not Adair.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an academic inquiry that largely cleared a Pennsylvania State University climatologist, Michael E. Mann, of scientific misconduct misattributed an e-mailed comment about a trick used in combining temperature data. Phil Jones, a climatologist of the University of East Anglia, sent the e-mail message, not Dr. Mann. (The inquiry board found that Dr. Manns use of the data was legitimate and noted that trick is a term used by scientists to refer to an insight that solves a problem.)

title: A Well-Written War, Told in the First Person
description: WASHINGTON  Brian Turner was focused on staying alive, not poetry, when he served as an infantry team leader in Iraq. But he quickly saw that his experience  a year of complete boredom punctuated by these very intense moments  lent itself to the tautness of verse.

title: After Turmoil at Merrill, Thain Will Lead CIT
description: Update | 7:32 a.m. Over his 30-year career, John A. Thain has risen to top executive positions at Goldman Sachs, the New York Stock Exchange and Merrill Lynch.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Indias proposal to resume high-level talks with Pakistan misidentified Indias foreign secretary, who is expected to meet with her Pakistani counterpart, Salman Bashir, if talks resume. She is Nirupama Rao  not S. M. Krishna, who is the foreign minister.

title: Toyota Is Expected to Add 2010 Prius to Recalls
description: TOKYO  Toyota plans to recall at least 311,000 of its 2010 Prius hybrid models after receiving a flurry of complaints about the vehicles brakes, a person briefed on the decision said late Sunday.

title: Ex-President of Argentina Undergoes Cardiovascular Surgery
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Former President Nstor Kirchner of Argentina underwent successful emergency surgery on Sunday to unclog his right carotid artery, Argentine news outlets reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about possible connections between Anwar al-Awlaki, a fugitive American-born cleric accused of terrorist ties, and Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the Nigerian suspect in the Christmas Day plot against an American passenger jet, paraphrased incorrectly from comments by a Yemeni journalist about the relationship between the two men. The journalist, Abdulelah Hider Shaea, said that Mr. Awlaki told him he had communications with Mr. Abdulmutallab last fall, not that the two men had met in person.

title: Push to Force Monserrate Expulsion Vote in the Senate
description: A group of Senate Democrats, concerned about efforts within their party to block the removal of a senator convicted of domestic violence, say they will attempt to force a vote to expel him this week even if they cannot win the support of State Senate leaders.

title: Corrections
description: The Cornish Journal article last Monday, about the New Hampshire town where the writer J.D. Salinger lived for many years before his death there on Jan. 27, referred incorrectly to Mr. Salingers wife Claire, who married him in 1955. She was his second wife, not his first. (He was married briefly in the mid-1940s to a German doctor named Sylvia.)

title: In a Message to Democrats, Wall St. Sends Cash to G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  If the Democratic Party has a stronghold on Wall Street, it is JPMorgan Chase.

title: Quake a Defining Crisis for Two Priests in Queens
description: The Rev. Robert Robinson was sitting at his office computer when he got a call from Linda Freebes, the principal of the parish school. Down the hall, the Rev. Jean-Moise Delva was counseling a couple preparing for marriage when the bride-to-bes cellphone rang.

title: In Super Bowl Commercials, the Nostalgia Bowl
description: AS dangerous as it may be to generalize, it is probably safe to say that few folks think of Marcel Proust as they watch the Super Bowl. But for the advertising bowl that took place inside Super Bowl XLIV on Sunday, it was one long remembrance of things past  with candy bars, mobile phones and beer bottles standing in for madeleines.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 29 about the author J. D. Salinger referred incorrectly to one element in the plot of his short story A Perfect Day for Bananafish. The character Seymour Glass commits suicide while on vacation with his wife, not while on his honeymoon. (The error also appeared in a news article on Aug. 31, 2000; a book review on Oct. 8, 2000; and in essays on March 23 and Dec. 31, 2008.) The obituary also misstated the name of the yearbook at Valley Forge Military Academy in Pennsylvania, for which Mr. Salinger was literary editor when he was a student there; it was Crossed Sabres, not Crossed Swords. And the obituary referred incorrectly to a work he had written while at Valley Forge. It was a poem that was later set to music; it was not a school song.

title: Scenes From a Ruined Boulevard
description:
A view of the destruction along a quarter-mile stretch
of Boulevard Jean-Jacques Dessalines, one of the main commercial arteries in the heart of Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

title: Halftime at the Super Bowl
description: For 12 minutes, it was a Who concert for the ages. Or the aging.

title: To Survive, Dairy Farmers Go Co-op
description: PLEASANT VALLEY, N.Y.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: As Gillibrand Gathers Endorsements, Ford Calls It Underhanded
description: Former Representative Harold E. Ford Jr. accused Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand on Sunday of using underhanded tactics to try to keep him off the ballot, and he urged New York City Democratic Party officials to delay an endorsement amid intense wrangling over how to handle his potential candidacy.

title: Forget Police Data; New Yorkers Rely on Own Eyes
description: As the crime rate in New York continues to decline, the Police Department has credited the use of a sophisticated crime database that pinpoints the frequency and location of murders, burglaries and other crimes. That database, known as CompStat, has also served as evidence of the departments successes.

title: Former Commander Recalls Pressure to Alter Reports
description: He was a police executive in three boroughs during the CompStat era, the years after 1995, when New York Police Department precinct commanders used computer-generated statistics to track and respond to crime.

title: Lottery Numbers
Paterson Gives St. Vincents Hospital Another Loan
description: Gov. David A. Paterson provided the second cash infusion in a week Sunday to St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village, but said concessions from unions and physicians would be needed to keep the hospital open.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 16 about the evangelist Oral Roberts referred incorrectly to the Pentecostal and charismatic movements. Collectively they had become the fastest-growing Christian movement in the world by 2000, not the largest Christian movement. A reader pointed out the error shortly after the article was published; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Project Renews Downtown, and Debate
description: SALT LAKE CITY  For many devout Mormons, Utahs capital city is important mainly as a setting for the jewel that really matters: Temple Square at the citys center. Brigham Young, the pioneer leader of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, laid out the urban grid with street numbers starting at the temple. The secular world was thus defined by the sacred core.

title: Some Toyota Owners Voice an Eroding Loyalty
description: LIBERTYVILLE, Ill.  Car shoppers can choose from 25 brands at 13 dealerships along a short stretch of Milwaukee Avenue in this northern Chicago suburb.

title: Victory at Riviera Moves Stricker to No. 2 in World
description: LOS ANGELES  On his best days, Steve Stricker seems as consistent as a metronome. Everything he does, on the golf course and off, has the reliability of an engineering blueprint.

title: Obama Challenges Terrorism Critics
description: WASHINGTON  The White House pushed back Sunday against Republican criticism of its approach to terrorism, calling it not anchored in reality as a national security debate that was largely muted in recent years roared back to center stage with an angry intensity.

title: European Central Bank in a Squeeze
description: FRANKFURT  Whether he likes it or not, Jean-Claude Trichet is not just the president of the European Central Bank. Mr. Trichet, 67, is also the de facto president of Europe, at least for the 16 nations that rely on the euro as their common currency.

title: Asia Sails Smoothly Through Debt Waters
description: MUMBAI, India  While rising government debt is a growing concern in Europe and the United States, Asias economies remain remarkably resilient, even buoyant, underscoring how economic might is shifting from West to East.

title: New Orleans Picks Mayor With Show of Support
description: NEW ORLEANS  At forums during the mayoral campaign here, candidates were frequently asked what they would do about the racial divide in the city, the dysfunctional stalemate that has often bogged down the citys recovery from Hurricane Katrina.

title: In Halftime Show, the Who Exhibits Flashes of Age and Familiarity
description: Lasers, lights and fireworks were flashing full-tilt through the Whos halftime show Sunday at Super Bowl XLIV. It looked as if the producers were worried that the rock geezers at the center  the guitarist and songwriter Pete Townshend, 64, and the singer Roger Daltrey, 65  might not look heroic enough to the camera. Townshend, in a porkpie hat and shades with a black suit hanging off his lanky frame, was grizzled. Daltrey, in a striped neo-Mod jacket and a scarf, revealed a voice that was raspy and thick. But the Who still had the stadium shouting along on choruses Townshend wrote decades ago: Who are you and We dont get fooled again!

title: The Dream of Zero
description: MUNICH

title: Champs? The Saints, Dats Who
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The New Orleans Saints almost left when their city flooded and their stadium had been turned into a shelter, a disaster seeming to provide the perfect escape route for a team in search of a better stadium and a bigger market.

title: With Federal Stimulus Money Gone, Many Schools Face Budget Gaps
description: Federal stimulus money has helped avoid drastic cuts at public schools in most parts of the nation, at least so far. But with the federal money running out, many of the nations schools are approaching what officials are calling a funding cliff.

title: Title Decided, but Labor Battle Is Just Beginning
description: Miami Gardens, Fla.

title: A City Rejoices, but the Focus Is Elsewhere
description: The final act of CBSs Super Bowl broadcast Sunday night left me wondering how prepared the network was for a New Orleans victory. This was not an ordinary city whose Saints upset the Indianapolis Colts, 31-17. This was the team representing Hurricane Katrina survivors and the team that had not been to the Super Bowl in a lifetime dating to 1967.

title: Abstinence Education Done Right
description: The ongoing debate over sex education has been rekindled by a provocative new study suggesting that teaching abstinence can delay the start of sexual activity among inner-city youngsters  if it is freed from the moralistic overtones and ideological restrictions that were the hallmark of abstinence-only programs under the Bush administration.

title: Lobbyists and Students
description: The private lending companies that earn billions of dollars in undeserved profits from the federal student loan program are working overtime to kill a bill that would stop their gravy train once and for all  and should have been enacted long ago. The House stood up to the powerful lending lobby last fall and passed a student loan reform bill. The White House has been pushing the Senate, but it is having trouble finding its spine and has yet to introduce a bill.

title: Pay Up
description: Claimants are still looking for their money, more than a decade after the federal Department of Agriculture reached a landmark settlement for having cheated generations of black farmers through indifference and blatant discrimination. The 1999 agreement on what is known as the Pigford class-action lawsuit was hailed as the biggest civil rights settlement in American history. The judge estimated a swift $2 billion payout  or $60,000 each  for victimized black farmers.

title: The Privilege to Serve
description: Albany needs a strong ethics reform bill. The one vetoed by Gov. David Paterson had a lot of flaws, including its failure to require state legislators who also work as lawyers to publicly disclose who is paying for their professional services.

title: Using Talk and Play to Develop Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: Holocaust Remembrance
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Health Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Bases in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex Education and Freedom of Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: David V. Becker, Expert on Thyroid Disease, Is Dead at 86
description: David V. Becker, a pioneer in using radioactive materials to diagnose and treat thyroid disease and an expert on the thyroid damage caused by the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident in 1986, died Jan. 31 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 and had continued his research work until last year.

title: Before Blast, Few Safety Problems as Energy Project Rose at Abandoned Mine Site
description: What began more than a decade ago when one of Connecticuts largest trash haulers bought a water-soaked, abandoned mine near Middletown, Conn., ultimately became one of the largest power plant construction projects in the country.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include wholesale trade inventories for December (Tuesday); the trade deficit for December (Wednesday); retail sales for January and business inventories for December (Thursday); and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

title: Accounts, People & Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Goodell Stresses a Culture of Safety
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  One of the iconic images of football is of linemen preparing to square off, face mask to face mask, with one hand dug into the turf in a three-point stance, but Commissioner Roger Goodell said Sunday that it was conceivable such showdowns could be prohibited.

title: Desperate Search for Victims of Explosion in Connecticut
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  Search and rescue crews braved icy weather late into the evening Sunday to look for possible survivors who might be buried in the wreckage at the site of a power plant where hours earlier an explosion rocked this central Connecticut college town.

title: Unfamiliar Turf for Manning: A Comeback That Is Thwarted
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  This was new territory for Peyton Manning and he hesitantly made his way. His path from the interview tent at Sun Life Stadium to the waiting buses brought Manning, the Colts quarterback, face to face with New Orleans Saints players who were on their way to talk to about their 31-17 victory in Super Bowl XLIV.

title: An S.& P. Scoop Was a Blunder
description: Standard & Poors could use a break. Instead, the credit-rating agency has committed another blunder. Last week, it revealed that PNC Financial was raising capital to help repay the government under the Troubled Asset Relief Program hours before the bank did so. As a party to the deal, S.& P. shouldnt be grabbing such scoops.

title: On Assignment: Haiti at the Homefront
description: Of course, all of us would like to run to Haiti and photograph, said Michelle Agins of The New York Times, but some of us have to stay here and cover it on the local level.

title: Piniella Says He Forgives McGwire
description: Mattingly, Winfield, Randolph, Henderson, Baylor, Griffey.

title: After 43 Years, a Party in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  The city descended on Bourbon Street. New Orleanians, as a general rule, do not like to go there. It is a tourist trap, too crowded and cheap. But on Sunday night it was a beating, living, pulsating mass of people, like a capital city of some country after a dictator has been overthrown.

title: A Growing Appreciation for Cents Off
description: When the history of coupons finally gets written, 1992 will go down as the Year of the Coupon, a time when consumers redeemed about 7.9 billion of them. But every year since, that figure has shrunk, whittled down by years of relative prosperity, changing demographic trends and manufacturer policies that shortened each coupons redemption period, among other changes.

title: Pass Wasnt the First Thing Porter Cut Off
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Without a helmet, Tracy Porters artwork could be seen by all. On the left side of his almost-shaved head his remaining hair said SB 44 in honor of Super Bowl XLIV.

title: Bundling Hardware and Software to Do Big Jobs
description: In data-center computing, the big trend today is to move from building blocks to bundles.

title: Word of the Day | quorum
description: quorum \kwor-m\ noun

title: Playing Precisely, Brees Answers Critics
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  This was the moment Drew Brees had longed for, the reason he came back from a shoulder injury so severe that doctors initially said it could not be repaired. This was for all the critics who said he was too short, for all the teams that passed on him as a free agent.

title: A New Kicker in New Orleans
description: Tom Dempsey, the most famous kicker in Saints history until last month, took a phone call Sunday night during his drive home from the French Quarter, where he spent the day mingling with fans and watching the Saints 31-17 victory over the Colts in Super Bowl XLIV.

title: Officer Is Shot and Suspect Is Killed in Newark
description: An Essex County Sheriffs officer was hospitalized Sunday night after a fatal firefight with a man in Newark, the police said. The suspect, who was not identified, died in the exchange of gunfire.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Jan. 24 about the extensions of copyrights in the United States gave the wrong date for the publication of Arthur Conan Doyles last Sherlock Holmes adventure. The last stories were published in 1927, not 1914.

title: Seymour B. Sarason, Leader in Community Psychology, Dies at 91
description: Seymour B. Sarason, a psychologist whose groundbreaking work on social settings and their influence on individual problems helped establish the field of community psychology, died on Jan. 28 in New Haven. He was 91 and lived in Hamden, Conn.

title: Analyzing Sean Paytons Gutsy Calls
description: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

title: Brokerage Hopes for $2.5 Billion in Shanghai I.P.O.
description: Huatai Securities plans to raise as much as 17.26 billion renminbi ($2.5 billion) in an initial share sale in Shanghai, where two companies that went public in the past month fell on their first trading day, Bloomberg News reported.

title: News Quiz | February 8, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Kirin Ends Merger Talks With Suntory
description: A potential mega-merger in the food and beverage sector fell apart on Monday after Kirin Holdings of Japan said it had ended talks with its smaller rival Suntory Holdings about a deal that would have created a company on a par with Kraft Foods and Pepsico in terms of global sales, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Saints Coachs Pair of Bold Bets: One Miss, One Turning Point
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  At halftime, while the Who sang Wont Get Fooled Again, the New Orleans Saints plotted to fool the Indianapolis Colts with the biggest trick of Sundays Super Bowl.

title: The Colts Drive 96 Yards, and Most of Those Come on the Ground
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The drive that matched the longest one in Super Bowl history started 96 yards from the end zone covered in blue paint.

title: Barclays Hires 3 Bankers From UBS
description: Barclays Wealth, the private banking arm of Barclays, has hired another three bankers from UBS, adding to the 10 who were recruited in August last year.

title: Food for Thought
description: WHO are the students in this photo?

title: Erica Wodas Tenacity Helps to Get Children Off the Couch
description: In spiteful cold on a recent Saturday morning in the Washington Heights neighborhood of New York City, three 27-year-olds stood outside a hushed school, two of them lured uptown by the uncommon inner furnace of the third.

title: Irked, Wall St. Hedges Its Bet on Democrats
description: If the Democratic Party has a stronghold on Wall Street, it is JPMorgan Chase.

title: Morgenson: This Crisis Wont Stop Moving
description: You know were in trouble when were told that the economic problems in Greece, Portugal and Spain, the most indebted countries in the euro zone, are likely to remain safely contained in those nations.

title: Iran Nuclear Plans Start New Calls for Sanctions
description: PARIS  Iran told the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency on Monday that it would begin enriching its stockpile of uranium for use in a medical reactor, prompting officials from the United States, France and Russia to call for stronger sanctions against Tehran.

title: Conflict With Goldman Helped Push A.I.G. to Edge
description: Billions of dollars were at stake when 21 executives of Goldman Sachs and the American International Group convened a conference call on Jan. 28, 2008, to try to resolve a rancorous dispute that had been escalating for months.

title: Deutsche Telekom and Investors: Stuck Together?
description: Deutsche Telekoms foray into the United States has been costly for shareholders, Breakingviews says. Its T-Mobile USA unit ranks a distant fourth in the cellphone market. Its network needs upgrading and its reach remains limited.

title: There Will Be Dragons
description: Perhaps no role-playing game has provoked more controversy or more devoted followers than Dungeons and Dragons. In his documentary, The Dungeon Masters, Keven McAlester follows two men and one woman who devote their lives to D&D. One is an evil drow elf displaced by Hurricane Katrina, another is a sanitation worker who lures friends into a Sphere of Annihilation, and the third is a failed super-villain who starts a cable-access show involving ninjas, puppets and a cooking segment. Their fantasy lives clash with their real ones in this movie, which is being shown as part of the Tribeca Cinemas Presents: Doc Series. The screening begins Monday at 7:30. Stick around after to grill the director on druid spells.

title: Help Haiti
description: News about Haiti is quickly moving off the front pages, but that doesn't mean relief efforts are slowing down. Mary J. Blige, Andr Balazs, Donna Karan and Andre Harrell are hosting a benefit on Monday night to remind New Yorkers of the people still in need. The event, "A Night of Humanity" at the Urban Zen Center, is followed by a "Relief Party" at the Standard Hotel and includes appearances by P. Diddy, Russell Simmons, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and others. Soledad O'Brien will act as master of ceremonies, Wyclef Jean will be the featured speaker, Whoopi Goldberg will be the night's auctioneer and Ms. Blige will perform. All proceeds from the evening will go to Habitat for Humanity, Partners in Health and Yle Haiti.

title: Power Trio
description: Them Crooked Vultures is unswervingly faithful to its pedigree, writes Nate Chinen. Along with Josh Homme, best known as the front man of Queens of the Stone Age, it features Dave Grohl, the former drummer in Nirvana, and John Paul Jones, the former bassist in Led Zeppelin. That their output delivers a punch to the gut can only be seen as the fulfillment of a promise. The band doesnt feel like naked derivation, but its parentage is hammered home with every fat and bruising riff.

title: Doostang Lands $1.25 Million
description: Doostang, a jobs Web site, has raised $1.25 million of a planned $2.1 million in its latest round of funding, VentureBeat reported, citing a filing with Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: For Kremlin, Ukraine Election Cuts Two Ways
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The apparent victory of Russias preferred candidate in the Ukrainian presidential race may be a relief to Vladimir V. Putin, who has long sought to discredit his neighbors raucous democracy and its drift to the West.

title: What Makes an Athlete Great?
description: With the Super Bowl just ending and the Winter Olympics just beginning, The Times is full of stories about individual athletes, from skier Lindsey Vonn to quarterback Peyton Manning to the youngest skater on the American Olympic team, 11-year-old Polina Edmunds. Who do you think are the greatest athletes? What does it mean to be great? How much of these athletes dominance comes from natural physical ability and how much from other elements such as ability to practice, mental focus, character or upbringing?

title: Owners of Conn. Power Plant Cooperating in Probe
description: Energy Investors Funds says it is fully cooperating with authorities investigating the fatal explosion of the Kleen Energy Systems plant in Middletown, Connecticut.

title: Wielding Iron Checkbook to Shape Cultural L.A.
description: Every American city has its power brokers, but only Los Angeles has an Eli Broad.

title: Scrapbook Site Raises $2.5 Million
description: Scrapblog, an online scrapbooking site, has received another $2.5 million in financing.

title: Shuttle Blasts Off for Space Station
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The space shuttle Endeavour thundered into orbit before dawn Monday morning, briefly turning darkness into daylight.

title: I.P.O. Said to Value Turkish Miner at $1.4 Billion
description: An initial public offering for the Turkish gold mining company Koza Altin has put the market value of the business at 2.2 billion lira ($1.4 billion), one of the banks mandated with the issue told Reuters.

title: Bonuses Canceled, Swedish Bank Raises Salaries
description: After announcing that it was canceling its 2009 bonuses, Swedbank, the lender based in Stockholm, is backtracking in the face of employee uproar.

title: Citi in Talks Over $3 Billion in Car Loans, Report Says
description: Citigroup has held talks with private equity groups and hedge funds over the sale of $3 billion in car loans in a move to clear troubled assets from its balance sheet, The Financial Times reported.

title: Toy Mogul Said to Buy Madoff Penthouse
description: Alfred R. Kahn, the marketing mogul behind such hits as the Pokemon and the Cabbage Patch Kids franchises, has reportedly snapped up another high-profile asset: the Manhattan penthouse that once belonged to Bernard L. Madoff.

title: Disney Eying Bus Advertiser Stake in China
description: A consortium led by Walt Disney is in advanced talks to buy into Chinas largest digital media and advertising company operating inside buses, a deal that could offer the American entertainment giant a new platform to promote Mickey Mouse in China, three sources told Reuters.

title: Saab Dealers Said to Put Money Up Backing Spyker
description: Swedish Saab dealers have made an unsolicited offer of $24 million dollars to help Spyker raise the funds it needs to buy the carmaker from General Motors, Dagens Industri reported.

title: Battle of the Bands: Citigroup Is Up Next
description: After the Grammy Awards last Sunday, the stars came out for EMIs party at the W Hollywood Hotel. The country music star Keith Urban arrived with his wife, Nicole Kidman. Katy (I Kissed a Girl) Perry sparkled in a form-fitting dress that would become gossip fodder on the Internet. There were also rappers (Cypress Hill), guitar heroes (Slash and Dave Navarro) and a coffeehouse darling (Norah Jones).

title: Private Equity Firms Brace for Tax Battle
description: Private equity firms are again being threatened with higher taxes, as a long-running debate over how to classify their profits again becomes a focus for governments desperate for cash.

title: Sumitomo Mitsui Reports Strong Quarter
description: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japans third-largest bank by assets, posted its biggest profit in seven quarters on Monday, helped by an improvement in its stock portfolio and a decline in bad loans, but stuck to its full-year forecast, Reuters reported.

title: Buyout Shops Said to Circle Lloyds Unit
description: Lloyds Banking Group of Britain is in talks with private equity firms to sell a controlling stake in its Integrated Finance unit, according to The Mail on Sunday.

title: Ex-Financial Adviser Is Sued by Wesleyan
description: As the economy eroded, college endowments around the country, money managers in academia worked tirelessly to contain the damage. Everywhere, that is, but at Wesleyan University, at least according to a lawsuit that the university has brought against its former chief investment officer.

description: Creativity equals capital. Thats the vision of Surface to Air, a multidisciplinary company combining efforts in fashion, film, photography and music. Now the group has a flagship retail location in the Marais, which opened late last month; their new spring/summer collection, on display in the back gallery, went on sale this week.

description: When Kraft Foods took over Cadbury, they got a deal, and one reason is because they had no serious competition from other bidders.
