description: Ocado, the British online grocer, is close to appointing advisers for an initial public offering which could value the company at between 1 billion and 1.2 billion ($1.6 and $1.9 billion), according to press reports.

description: Banco Santander, the Spanish banking giant, is considering the sale of a minority stake in its British arm through a stock market flotation, though there is no detailed plan yet, Reuters reported, citing industry sources.

One of the bloggers, the conservative columnist Michelle Malkin, argued that the scarf was inappropriate because the keffiyeh, for the clueless, is the traditional scarf of Arab men that has come to symbolize murderous Palestinian jihad.

title: A.I.G. Hires Finance Veteran to Oversee Risk
description: The American International Group said Monday that it had hired Peter D. Hancock, a veteran financial services executive, as an executive vice president overseeing the insurers finance and risk.

title: Sampler: El Cerrito and San Jose State University Receive Federal Money
description: Big Signature Collectors Shun Constitution Petitions | In California, it is almost always planting season and almost always signature-gathering season. Like big farmers, the major signature-gathering companies can determine what measures they want to plant on the statewide ballot  and what they do not. Kimball Petition Management does not want anyone to plant initiatives promoting a constitutional convention. Fred Kimball, who runs the petition firm, said he opposed such ballot initiatives and said he had warned independent managers that he would blacklist them if they work with Repair California, the Bay Area group promoting constitutional reform. One issue: the state constitutional convention, if it materializes, might remake the ballot initiative process. John Grubb, a spokesman for Repair California, said signature-gathering firms had blacklisted their petitions and shouted at their volunteers. Repair California has sent cease-and-desist letters to the major signature gathering firms. In the meantime, while those gathering signatures to put measures on the ballot usually carry multiple proposed propositions, some will not carry those two initiatives. [The Economist, The Contra Costa Times]

title: What Did You Think of the Who?
description: Love The Who, my favorite band ever. But the last halftime show they should have done was around SB X. Next year Beethoven, perhaps? A reader comment from Ray on the live blog of the game

title: Quebecs Vehicle Emission Law Is Disputed

title: Buying Spree Nets China Stakes in Top U.S. Firms
description: Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, Chinas sovereign wealth fund quietly snapped up more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citigroup.

title: Crime Statistics May Be Fudged, but Drop Feels Real
description: In the wake of a survey of retired police captains and other high-ranking officers in which most said that the pressure to reduce crime numbers led to fudged statistics, one retired commander detailed techniques he used to reclassify reported felonies as misdemeanors. Every week, we had meetings, and I knew I would be called up to be grilled and embarrassed, if my numbers were not good, in front of my peers and commanders, he said. [NYT]

title: Can Airgas Ride Out Air Products Gale?
description: Air Products and Chemicals $5.1 billion bear-hug offer on Friday to acquire Airgas is a nice burst of activity in an otherwise sluggish takeover market. The unsolicited offer has the added luxury of being more than hot air.

title: What Theyre Saying: The Aggressive Team Won
description: It can almost be a curse to have a halftime lead in a big game. The Chargers had one against the Jets. The Jets had one against the Colts. The Colts had one against the Saints.

title: Dow Industrials Close Below 10,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, a closely watched barometer of the economys health, dipped below the 10,000 threshold on Monday, delivering a psychological setback as investors braced for more market volatility.

title: Fed Said to Prepare Plans for Eventual Tightening
description: As much as the Federal Reserve is trying to ease credit for small businesses, it is already looking ahead to a time when it will bring its policy closer to what it knew before the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Super Bowl Ads Get Lost
description: Theres not much more we can say about the Super Bowl television commercials that our colleagues at Media Decoder didnt already get to: Stuart Elliott live-blogged the advertisements here, and Bill Carter revealed the back story of the surprise Letterman-Oprah-Leno commercial here.

description: This week, Laurie Davis, the founder of eFlirt Expert,responded to readers questions about finding a mate online, using technology to flirt and dating offline.

description: JR Motorsports announced Monday morning that Danica Patrick will follow her strong performance at the ARCA race on Saturday with her Nationwide Series debut at Daytona International Speedway.

description: Warning: this post may contain spoilers and/or things that never happened.

title: Studios Man Up for Super Bowl
description: Amid all the not-so-subtle man messaging in this years Super Bowl commercials, there was room for a few movie spots. Starting around the kickoff and just into the postgame show, there were eight ads, down from nine last year.

title: Liberty Global Said to Scour Europe for Deals
description: The chief executive of Liberty Global, the communications company controlled by John C. Malone, told a Dutch financial daily that the company had $3 billion in its war chest and was considering takeovers in Europe.

title: Magazines Newsstand Sales Fall 9.1 Percent
description: 10:40 Updated with responses from magazines.

title: Monday Reading
description: Each weekday morning, we gather consumer-focused articles from The New York Times and items from our blogs so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Case Against Zero
description: My column today makes the argument that the quest for nuclear abolition, which has gained traction in the Obama era (and which is clearly dear to the presidents heart), shouldnt be linked to the quest to forestall proliferation. Iran would still be seeking nuclear weapons even if America didnt have a vast nuclear arsenal  and right now, at least, our arsenal tends to prevent local arms races, rather than encouraging them.

title: Theyre Closing In
description: In the wake of last weeks coyote sighting in Central Park, the following memo was sent out Sunday from the chief of public safety at Columbia University, James F. McShane. Lewisohn Hall is at Broadway and West 116th Street.

title: Searching for Role Models
description: When Alabamas Mark Ingram won the Heisman Trophy he made sure to mention his father, Mark Ingram Sr., a former N.F.L. receiver who was an important member of the Giants 1991 Super Bowl victory and a role model to him.

title: Monsters Ball
description: Vampires are so last decade  these days, its all about monsters. At the center of this scary trend is Lady Gaga, whose stage performances feature Thriller-style choreography and ghoulish costume changes. (Even Filipino prisoners helped push the trend with their famous YouTube video.) Alexander McQueen, who has cited Lady Gaga as an influence, recently showed an otherworldly collection accented with prosthetic makeup and podlike 10-inch reptilian platforms. Gareth Pugh also unleashed a legion of threatening, heavily powdered models in a broodingly romantic zombie romp, and Lanvins disturbing new ad campaign stars the photographers Vinoodh Matadin and Inez van Lamsweerde  the latter in full-body makeup that makes her look as if shes been skinned alive.Perhaps the house should consider a partnership with the jewelry designer Emily Miranda, whose chunky pieces feature flesh-ripping animal claws. The film world is also right on trend. Spike Jonze got things going with Where the Wild Things Are, which was followed by remakes of The Wolfman and, in theaters soon, A Nightmare on Elm Street. Natalie Portman has signed on for Pride and Prejudice and Zombies, and Tim Burtons dark directorial oeuvre is being celebrated in a career retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art through April 26. From a pop-psych perspective, this macabre obsession reads as a projection of the collective anxiety were dealing with, given a glossy sheen to make it less scary. Wouldnt it be nice if instead of financial crises and terrorist attacks, all we had to worry about were things that go bump in the night?

title: New Hawaii Five-O Makes Its First Booking
description: While his Lost co-stars prepare to pack up and leave Hawaii, Daniel Dae Kim can plan to remain in that real-life locale for at least a few more months. Mr. Kim, who plays the time-traveling tough guy Jin on Lost, has been the first actor cast in a coming remake of the crime drama Hawaii Five-O, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Kim will not be playing Danno or the other guy (our knowledge of Hawaii Five-O extends only to its famous catchphrase and its surf-rock theme song). He has been cast as Chin Ho Kelly, a detective played by Kam Fong in the original 1968 series. No casting has been announced for the roles of Danny Williams (the Danno in Book em, Danno) or Steve McGarrett (the lead character played by Jack Lord), though The Hollywood Reporter said that Alex OLoughlin (Moonlight) was in talks for the McGarrett role. The Hawaii Five-O revival is being developed by the screenwriters Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci (Star Trek, Fringe) and Peter Lenkov, an executive producer of CSI: NY.

title: Once Again, Seeing the Shadow of Madoff
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Best Voice-Over in a Car Commercial
description: In other movie-ad news, that was indeed Jeff Bridgess voice you heard in those Hyundai commercials during the Super Bowl, in which that best-actor nominee for Crazy Heart plugged the Sonata and its amazing warranty. Though the nitpicky Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has a longstanding rule against its nominees being featured in ads within one hour of their appearance on the Oscar telecast, it has still decided to work with Hyundai, its largest advertiser this year, reports Steve Pond at TheWrap.com. (Hyundai will have nine commercial spots on the Oscars next month, at an estimated $1.4 million for each 30-second ad.)

title: Investigators to Sift Power Plant Rubble for Evidence of Criminal Negligence
description: Investigators will look for evidence of criminal negligence in the rubble at a Middletown, Conn., power plant that exploded on Sunday, killing five people, officials said Monday.

description: For many of us, eating more whole grains requires learning about foods rarely seen in the traditional American diet.

description: WASHINGTON

description: Get ready for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver by doing our newest crossword. You can find the answers here.

description: Always two N.H.L. games on Super Bowl Sunday  the early game on a U.S. broadcast network, and the Canadiens matinee. Home teams listed first:

description: PBS NewsHour had a segment last week on economic humor, focusing on a special session from this years American Economic Association conference. Enjoy.

title: Feinberg Says He Talked With Blankfein on Pay
description: Update | 12:24 p.m. Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Treasury Departments special master on executive compensation, said Monday that Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, consulted with him on the firms pay plans and adopted his prescriptions.

title: Nurse on Trial After Reporting Doctor
description: In Sundays New York Times, Kevin Sack reported on the unlikely prosecution of a nurse who informed state regulators about a doctor she believed was practicing bad medicine.

title: An Approach That Draws Students Into the College World
description: For high school students who might not even be thinking about college, early college high schools offer a potentially life-changing option. My colleague, Tamar Lewin, reports that such schools are growing in popularity around the country.

title: Turning to Albany to Preserve a Smoke-Filled Room
description: When Nat Sherman, the venerable Midtown tobacconist, opened its new showroom on 42nd Street showroom a few years ago, it quickly ran into a problem. The showroom included a private smoking lounge, known as the Johnson Club Room, where members and guests could enjoy a drink or a snack along with their cigars, pipes, and cigarettes. But under New York law, smoking is forbidden wherever food or beverages are served to the public.

title: Retracting a Medical Journals Autism Study
description: Last week, the highly regarded medical journal, The Lancet, retracted a much debated 1998 study that had linked the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine to autism.

title: Film and Television Stars Align for Olivier Awards
description: Its not only the New York theater scene that has come to be dominated by film and television celebrities: the roster of performers nominated on Monday for the Laurence Olivier awards, among the highest honors of the London stage, is rich with actors well known for their work outside the theater, The Guardian reported. Contenders in the best actress category include the X-Files star Gillian Anderson for A Dolls House, Rachel Weisz for A Streetcar Named Desire and Imelda Staunton for Entertaining Mr Sloane. Best actor nominees include James Earl Jones (Cat on a Hot Tin Roof), Jude Law (Hamlet) and James McAvoy (Three Days of Rain), and Keira Knightley (The Misanthrope) was nominated in the best supporting actress category. The dramas Enron by Lucy Prebble and Red by John Logan, both headed to Broadway, were nominated for best new play. The winners will be announced on March 21.A complete list of Laurence Olivier Award nominees can be found here.

title: And the Oscar Goes to  Old Dogs?
description: In a sure sign that the Academys switch to 10 nominees for best picture is getting traction beyond awards-season bloggers, check out this past weekends Saturday Night Live, in which the expanded field went even further. Among those making the new, more liberal cut: Old Dogs and Jersey Shore.) The show also poked fun at Avatar, with Sigourney Weaver reprising her role as a smoking scientist and Bill Hader playing Sam Worthington, really making the most of his Navi body.

title: Investing Is Not Entertainment
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

title: In Praise of the Saints
description: This one time, its perfectly acceptable to switch bandwagons after the Super Bowl. If you were rooting for the Colts, or rooting for no one, or simply hoping Tim Tebow would stop finding ways onto your television screen, feel free to cheer for New Orleans. You dont even have to cheer for the Saints  particularly if you remember how close their owner, Tom Benson, came to ditching the city in its worst moment in 2005  but go ahead and feel good for a city that almost drowned four and a half years ago.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Which organs can you live without, and how much cash can you get for them?

title: Joey Campanaro to Be Chef at Kenmare
description: Joey Campanaro, the owner of Little Owl, will be the chef at Kenmare, a new restaurant that will replace Civetta at 98 Kenmare Street in NoLIta in the spring.

title: A Gift From the Makers of Valentines Day': A Ready-Made Sequel
description: Whether you dislike Valentines Day, the coming romantic comedy whose ensemble cast features roughly every third actor in Hollywood, or only begrudgingly accept it, you can expect to see more movies like it in the months ahead. Variety reported that New Line Cinema, the studio behind Valentines Day, is already preparing a sequel-cum-spinoff called  wait for it  New Years Eve. (Evidently, Arbor Day and Administrative Professionals Day arent sufficiently exciting to sustain their own movies, and someone already had the foresight to claim Groundhog Day.)

title: Risks, and Perhaps Rewards, in Obamas Health Summit
description: One big question about President Obamas bipartisan health care summit, scheduled for Feb. 25, is whether American voters will really get a full and open competition of ideas and emerge with a clearer sense of whether they support or oppose the various proposals put forward by Republicans and Democrats.

title: Royal Shakespeare Company Announces New York Residency
description: Shakespeare savants, get thee to the Armory: The Royal Shakespeare Company will hold court in Manhattan in the summer of 2011 for an unprecedented six-week, five-play residency in a newly constructed theater inside the Park Avenue Armory as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, officials from the three organizations announced Monday.

title: The High Low | Sonia Rykiel for H&M Sweater and Shoes, $29.95 and $59.95
description: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.

title: Off of Antarctica
description: Its five a.m., and outside my window the sky is low, the wind is howling, the temperature is sub-freezing. You could say this about New York, of course, and many other places right now. But can you say this? The sky is light, and there are countless icebergs, some a mile long and a hundred feet high.

title: China Announces Arrests in Hacking Crackdown
description: HONG KONG  The police in central China have arrested three people and seized money and equipment worth hundreds of thousands of dollars in a crackdown on the countrys biggest commercial operation to train computer hackers, state media reported Sunday and Monday.

title: Risks: Study Looks at Serotonin and SIDS Deaths
description: Babies who die of sudden infant death syndrome may have low levels of serotonin, a brain chemical involved in regulating breathing and other vital functions, a new study suggests.

title: Costa Rica: Female Leader Elected
description: MEXICO CITY  Costa Ricans elected a former vice president, Laura Chinchilla, as the countrys first female president, giving the ruling party a resounding victory.

title: Perceptions: Doctors, Patients and a Clash of Priorities
description: High blood pressure is often a top priority for doctors. But pain and depression may be more pressing to their patients.

title: In Tough Times, a Library Branch Reopens
description: In the midst of a budget cut that is forcing it to cut back hours at two-thirds of its locations, the New York Public Library has found something to celebrate: the reopening of the St. Agnes branch on Amsterdam Avenue and 81st Street. The long-languishing three-story stone building with the arched windows has been restored to its former glory, thanks to a $9.8 million makeover.

title: The Claim: 3-D Movies Can Induce Headaches and Sickness
description: THE FACTS The epic science-fiction film Avatar has broken box-office records. But it has had some unwanted side effects.

title: Shakespeare Troupe Plans Residency in New York
description: Shakespeare enthusiasts, get thee to the Armory: the Royal Shakespeare Company will hold court in Manhattan in the summer of 2011 for an unprecedented six-week, five-play residency. The troupe will occupy a newly constructed theater inside the Park Avenue Armory as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, officials from the three organizations announced on Monday.

title: A Story Line Straight to Oscar
description: Over at New York magazine, Mark Harris takes a spin through two exhausting weeks of Oscar campaigning. (Try doing it for three months, buddy.) And he gives a nice summation of what produces a victory: story line.

title: Hazards: A Warning on Mixing Herbs and Medicine
description: Researchers are warning that popular herbs and supplements, including St. Johns wort and even garlic and ginger, do not mix well with common heart drugs and can also be dangerous for patients taking statins, blood thinners and blood pressure medications.

title: Job Postings Hint at Amazons Plans for the Kindle
description: It looks as if color screens and Wi-Fi might be the next additions to Amazons Kindle.

title: Yanukovich on Track to Win Election
description: Ukraine's opposition leader Viktor Yanukovich appeared on Monday to have won a narrow victory in Ukraine's presidential election, according to nearly complete results.

title: Monday Puzzle: Back to the Future
description: Today is a special day in the history of the United Federation of Planets. Monday, February 8, 2010 is the date to which space adventurer Bert Stein made a heroic unidirectional leap backward into time from the 23rd century. He spent (is spending?) about six months in our time, before returning with his cargo of dilithium which helped jump-start the Federation. This day will always be known as The Beginning of the Federation, and we will unravel its mystery by means of a puzzle. But before we do so, heres a warm-up question.

title: After the Parade, Saints Face Many Decisions
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Sean Payton wore Mardi Gras beads and the look of a man who had channeled the Bourbon Street party after the New Orleans Saints completed their stunning resurrection for themselves and their city at the Super Bowl.

title: Margulies Bumps Himself as Time Stands Still Extends
description: The Manhattan Theater Clubs production of Time Stands Still by Donald Margulies, starring Laura Linney and Brian dArcy James, will extend performances for a second time to accommodate audience interest, the theater company announced on Monday.

title: Passengers Must Pay for Blankets on American
description: American Airlines quietly announced last week that it would eliminate free blankets in coach on domestic flights and sell an $8 packet that includes a pillow and blanket starting May 1.

title: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Will Your Employer Restore Its 401(k) Match?
description: In the darker hours of the financial crisis, some employers cut their matching contributions to workers 401(k) retirement accounts.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The California Milk Processor Board, San Clemente, named Santa Susana High School, Simi Valley, as the winner of the grand prize in a contest to create video clips centered on an online rock opera that is part of the White Gold campaign for the milk board. The school won $20,000 for its arts programs. Pioneer Technical Center, Madera, won the second prize of $10,000.

title: All-Day Pajama Syndrome
description: Dubiously scientific name for the trend of wearing pajamas all day long, and in public.

title: BMW to Introduce the New X5 in Geneva
description: Can it be true that BMW has been building S.U.V.s for more than a decade now?

title: Interlopers, Short Term and Long
description: While New Yorkers are generally more welcoming to tourists than your average French waiter, apartment dwellers become prickly when those same tourists move in next door. This has been an issue around the city for years, most publicly on the Upper West Side, where the owners of several single-room occupancy hotels  S.R.O.s  have tried to bring tourists in against the will of the permanent residents. The issue is not without its collection of advocates willing to stage protests at City Hall, especially before the summer tourist season kicks off (seen here in 2008).

title: The Insider | Anne Pearson
description: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the Vancouver-based Anne Pearson shares her essentials. Pearson is a former architect who now owns Vancouver Special, a design store named after a local architectural style. She is currently planning a lecture series at the store for the spring and her own wedding for this summer.

title: Sri Lanka Arrests Defeated Candidate
description: NEW DELHI  The retired general who sought unsuccessfully to defeat his onetime ally in Sri Lankas presidential election last month was arrested late Monday by the military police, raising concern that the country was veering into political vengeance and autocracy after having barely emerged from a quarter-century of war.

title: Survey Raises Questions on Data-Driven Policy
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, an engineering major in college, has never been shy about proclaiming an unerring faith in statistics.

title: Royal Shakespeare Company
description: The company will come to Manhattan in the summer of 2011 for an unprecedented six-week, five-play residency.

title: Two Stars: The QB, and His Little Man
description: Who would have predicted that the most memorable image of a very memorable game would be a little boy  wearing headphones, trying to catch confetti and looking awed but secure in his fathers arms?

title: This Campaign Is Wet (and Wild)
description: The feats of Casanova were formidable, especially when you consider that he was bereft of Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and the rest of the social media by which to pursue his conquests. Now, a campaign for a line of personal products seeks to make up for that.

title: The Morning Skate: Capitals, Ovechkin Looking Good
description: Who dat? Who dat? Who dat say they goin beat the Caps?

title: Russia Names New Leader for Republic of Dagestan
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday made one of the most complex regional appointments of his presidency, nominating Magomedsalam M. Magomedov to be the next president of the combustible southern republic of Dagestan.

title: Defendant in Brokers Killing Is Barred From Changing Lawyers
description: Sparks flew Monday morning in the trial of the woman accused of murdering Linda Stein, the celebrity real estate agent, after the defendants family shouted down the judges decision not to let her change her lawyers.

title: Gunmen Open Fire on Former Official in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan Three people were killed when unidentified gunmen opened fire at the election office of a former federal minister and opposition leader Monday evening in the garrison city of Rawalpindi, police and rescue officials said. At least five people were wounded.

title: 2 More Firms Settle in N.Y. Pension Fund Inquiry
description: Two more firms on Monday reached a settlement with Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York over a broad investigation into a pay to play scandal involving New York States pension fund.

title: FAME Charter School: Audit Questions and Answers
description: An article in Sundays Bay Area report focused on a critical state audit of the financial practices of  FAME,  an East Bay charter school that has a large population of Muslim students.

title: Brian Turner in Home Fires
description: In todays story, A Well-Written War, Told in the First Person, The Timess Elisabeth Bumiller surveys some of the first-rate writing by veterans about the Iraq war, including that of Brian Turner, a contributing writer to Home Fires. Turner, who is the recipient of the Amy Lowell Traveling Scholarship, will continue to write dispatches for Home Fires about his travels in Cambodia, Vietnam and several other countries.

title: Researchers Get Grant for DNA Factory
description: It is the idea that paved the way for Legos, rifles and the Industrial Revolution: standardized parts. Now Bay Area researchers are applying it to the field of bioengineering. With a new $1.4 million grant from the National Science Foundation, scientists from Stanford University and the University of California, Berkeley are now designing, making and testing thousands of pieces of DNA in an Emeryville facility which hopes to standardize these parts for the first time.The Bay Area is one of the countrys biggest hubs for synthetic biology  a multidisciplinary field that aims to create new biological systems  so it is fitting that it will house the first lab dedicated to churning out standard DNA parts, a lab known as Biofab.

title: Daniel Ellsberg, Movie Buff
description: You bet! Daniel Ellsberg told us by e-mail when we asked if he would be heading to the Oscars in March. The man who leaked the secret history of the Vietnam War is the subject of the documentary The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers. Directed by Rick Goldsmith and Judith Ehrlich, the film has been nominated for a best documentary Oscar.

title: Fake Food Coupons Spread in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The United Nations said Monday that counterfeiters had begun printing fake tickets to gain access to free rice distributions, complicating giveaways that are meant for the hungriest Haitians.

title: Liquid Sky | Carry-on Beauty Products
description: Who: Kate Duff and Alexi Mintz

title: In Haiti, Practicing Medicine From Afar
description: In the desperate days soon after the earthquake in Haiti last month, foreign medical volunteers relied on improvised, low-tech devices for consultations and coordination. But American doctors are switching to more sophisticated technology to help improve public health in Haiti, one of the worlds poorest nations.

title: Gainey Reportedly Resigning as Canadiens General Manager
description: TSN is reporting that Bob Gainey, who has been the Montreal Canadiens general manager since 2003, is stepping down. The Canadiens have called a press conference for 4 p.m.

title: Risks and Rewards of Health Care Summit
description: At Prescriptions, David M. Herszenhorn weighs the risks and possible benefits of the health care summit set for Feb. 25.

title: Travel Deals: Flight Sale to 16 European Cities
description: Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, is having a European Spring Sale on flights from New York or Boston to 16 European cities. Fares start at $209 each way for travel from April 13 to April 30, and $229 for flights from May 1 to May 31. Book by Feb. 10 (7 p.m. E.S.T.).

title: For Obama, Nuance on Race Invites Questions
description: WASHINGTON  The civil rights movement will come alive in song at the White House on Wednesday night, when President Obama plans to celebrate Black History Month with a star-studded concert.

title: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie Sue Murdoch Paper in Britain
description: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, the stars of the 20th Century Fox hit Mr. and Mrs. Smith, are gunning for one of the studios corporate cousins.

title: Doctor Is Charged in Death of Jackson
Congressman Murtha Dies
description: Representative John P. Murtha, the longtime Democratic congressman from Pennsylvania, has died at age 77.

title: Guggenheim Settles With Malevich Heirs
description: The foundation that runs the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum said on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the heirs of the artist Kazimir Malevich over the ownership of an untitled work by him that the museum plans to include in an exhibition this month. In a joint news release, the foundation and the heirs of Malevich, the Russian Suprematist, said they had reached an amicable settlement over an oil painting on canvas made by the artist around 1916, which was acquired by Peggy Guggenheim in 1942 and has been part of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. The painting is one of about 70 Malevich works that were presented at an exhibition in Berlin in 1927, during which the artist was called back to the Soviet Union and entrusted the works to several friends. Malevich died in 1935 and his work was subsequently banned by the Nazis, but his paintings, drawings and other art have since become part of the collections of museums and private owners, setting the stage for efforts by his heirs to reclaim ownership of these works.

title: Making the Abstract Concrete: Creating Skits to Explain Math Concepts
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Says Pika Not Imperiled by Climate Change
description: The Obama administration has determined that the American pika, a small rabbit-like mammal, is not threatened by climate change.

title: Recovery Matches a Marathon Operation
description: Robert Collison has a lot to do. He wants to teach his grandchildren to play the guitar, piano and trumpet. His house needs work. His 96-year-old mother is counting on him to help take care of her house, too. There are trips to take. And he has a business to run.

title: Beachhead Established in One Mans Parking War
description: The signs go back more than 50 years, forbidding parking in much of the Rockaway Beach-front communities of Belle Harbor and Neponsit on summer weekends and holidays.

title: 10th Person in Galleon Insider Case Pleads Guilty
description: A former executive of Intel became the 10th person to plead guilty in the Galleon Group insider trading case after admitting in court on Monday afternoon that he had passed confidential corporate information to Galleons founder, Raj Rajaratnam.

title: Now Collaborating | Levis and Opening Ceremony
description: Looking for a new version of your favorite all-American classics? Opening Ceremony and Levis have joined forces to create corduroys in spring colors like lavender, curry and teal. Josh Katz, a designer from Levis, tells us he began with a treasured pair of classic Levis cords that you can wear in the spring and then cut into shorts for summertime. From there, the collection grew into a rainbow of corduroy  trucker jackets, classic 505s and shirts. The design team was inspired by Ryan McGinleys photos of his friends hanging out in upstate New York wearing 70s-style vintage denim, so its only fitting that McGinley should have shot the campaign (above). The Levis + Opening Ceremony clothes go on sale tomorrow, but the collaboration will be an ongoing project, evolving as each season progresses.

title: UEFA Considers Politics in Euro Draw
description: As European soccers bureaucratic elite huddled through a sub-zero Warsaw dawn and into the Palace of Culture and Science on Sunday morning, a small white plastic ball was about to make history. For the first time, the proceedings of international tournament was about to be willingly  and publicly  manipulated.

title: Gates Voices Concern About Warship Sale to Russia
description: PARIS  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told French officials Monday that he was concerned about their plans to sell Mistral-class amphibious assault ships to Russia, although there is little if anything the United States could do to block the deal, officials said.

title: Nuclear Power Giant Buys Solar Firm
description: Areva, the giant French nuclear company, has bought Ausra, a small manufacturer of solar thermal systems that can be used for electricity production or industrial steam.

title: A Nation Awaits Gold in Figure Skating
description: The South Korean superstar Kim Yu-na's carefree approach, and her unlikely coach, help her manage soaring expectations back at home.

title: Lansing Mayor in Michigan Governors Race
description: In Michigan, the mayor of Lansing, Virgil Bernero announced today that he will seek the Democratic nomination for governor.

title: The Most Dangerous Road?
description: The North Yungas Road in Bolivia is widely considered the most dangerous road in the world. According to this BBC report, it claims between 200 and 300 lives a year.

title: For Human Spaceflight, Can Measured Beat Bold?
description: Ever since Apollo astronauts flew to the Moon four decades ago, expert task forces and political leaders have, from time to time, pondered what to do next in human spaceflight. They came up with new directions and new visions, set new goals. Some of their hopes rested on machines that never made it to a launching pad. Others got off the ground but never really soared.

title: Nooks Will Be Available at Barnes & Noble Stores Beginning Wednesday
description: Barnes & Noble, the countrys largest book-selling chain, said that its Nook electronic reading device would be available for purchase in its stores starting Wednesday.

title: In Toyota Mess, Lesson for Japan
description: TOKYO  When Toyotas president, Akio Toyoda, apologized for the recalls that have marred Toyotas reputation, he talked not just about his companys fate, but also his nations.

title: Reality Check on Old Ice, Climate and CO2
description: Richard Alleys name has been thrown around a bit by bloggers asserting that ice-core records from Greenland show that carbon dioxide has scant, if any, influence on climate. Dr. Alley, a glaciologist and climate scientist at Penn State, is a longtime contributor to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, author of a nice history of ice and climate, The Two-Mile Time Machine, and  as many Dot Earth readers are aware  a teacher with musical and terpsichorean talents (see the YouTube video below for his orbital dance explaining how ice-age cycles help show the amplifying power of greenhouse gases).

title: VF Cover Creates Online Bonfire of Comments at Yahoo, Including a Threat
description: Although no one would dispute there there is a serious political divide in America, many assumed that the election of Barack Obama was the beginning of a period of post-racialism, a time when the politics of identity had lost some of its corrosiveness.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Feb. 8
description: Beyond the grief expressed so keenly in the opening photograph, Mondays show offers some pleasures as well: a view of a security training exercise that verges on the comic (Slide 6) and of a space shuttle launch in which human effort seems momentarily to dwell on a cosmic plane (Slide 11). Michael Kamber, now in Iraq for The Times, has just finished an eye-opening  if frustrating  assignment in Yemen. He will describe it in a Lens post on Tuesday.

title: Colleges Where Men Are in Short Supply
description: Heres yet another issue for high school seniors  particularly girls  to factor into their college choices: the ratio of women to men on a particular campus.

title: The Peninsula, the Small Town and High-Speed Rail
description: Tonight, the Burlingame City Council will host a study session for residents to discuss the plan to build a high-speed rail line from San Francisco to San Jose. The idea is for it to swoosh through the Peninsula on the existing Caltrain tracks.

title: 'The Park,' Episode 2
description: In the second installment of our original Web series, two strangers discover that a moment's peace can be elusive, , even in the woods.

title: Ally for the Poor in an Unlikely Corner
description: Andrew Witty is not quite as young or as buff as Anderson Cooper, but he does do interviews in shirtsleeves from the slums of Nairobi and rural hospitals in Uganda.

title: Paying People Not to Walk Away
description: Many homeowners are so far under water on their mortgages that theyre tempted to walk away and rent elsewhere, even if they can afford the monthly payments on their current mortgage. Now, one company is trying to persuade banks to give those homeowners money in exchange for staying put.

title: Cant Employees and Bosses Get Along?
description: In my last post, I talked about the fact that in Illinois its possible for a business owner to be forced to pay for six months of unemployment benefits for someone the owner employs for no more than 30 days. My point was that this doesnt do much to motivate employers to enlist someone they may be on the fence about hiring.

title: In Defense of Trolls (and Other Online Meanies)
description: What is the cost to civility exacted by unfriendly online commenters?

title: A Call for Stronger Sanctions
description: New York Times chief Washington correspondent David E. Sanger reports.

title: When to Worry if a Child Has Too Few Words
description: There is nothing simple about speech, and there is nothing simple about speech delay  starting with the challenge of diagnosing it.

title: A Walking Magnet for Odd, Minor Ills
description: At 38, I officially declare myself Queen of Minor Ailments No One Has Ever Heard Of.

title: Ukraines Voters Speak, in Two Voices
description: Last Updated | Tuesday | 12:15 p.m. Ukraines presidential election on Sunday seems to have reversed the results of the countrys Orange Revolution, putting Viktor Yanukovich, the man who was defeated in 2004 after street protests forced a vote that he lost, into office, and handing defeat to Yulia Tymoshenko, who helped lead the campaign against him five years ago.

title: Judge Presses S.E.C. on BofA Settlement
description: Update | 4:31 p.m. A federal judge put a lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission on the defensive on Monday afternoon over a $150 million settlement resolving the S.E.C.s civil charges that accused Bank of America of misleading investors when it acquired Merrill Lynch.

title: 2 Coasts and 2 Troupes: Contrasting Visions of a Well-Trod Ballet
description: The threads that bind movement to music are nowhere more various or more subtle than in The Sleeping Beauty. This cooperation between the ballet master Marius Petipa and Tchaikovsky has always been held up  rightly  as a yardstick (even though before the 1890 premiere Tchaikovsky by no means followed Petipas requirements to the letter, and Petipa made small and large cuts in Tchaikovskys music, giving up some of his own original ideas for the ballet).

title: Paterson Says Cuomo Has Avoided Unpopular Decisions
description: Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday addressed concerns that his low approval ratings would make it difficult for him to prevail in the general election, saying that his likely challenger for the Democratic nomination, Andrew M. Cuomo, enjoys high popularity only because voters know so little about his politics.

title: Google to Add Social Features to Gmail
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google is trying once again to capture some of the momentum surrounding social networking companies like Facebook and Twitter by adding new features to Gmail, its popular e-mail service.

title: Seeing How Far $100 Can Go
description: Andrew Marantz paid strangers to walk through Bryant Park holding hands and sharing secrets. Joshua Krafchin walked up and down a B train begging people -- to take his money.

title: Developer Is Accused of Fleecing Clients and Friends
description: A man who once was one of the citys high-flying real estate moguls was arrested Monday morning on charges that he stole $2.5 million from business associates and friends, including the best man at his wedding, by fooling them into believing he was making deals to buy hotel properties in upstate New York and Colorado.

title: Hair Recedes at Box Office
description: The Broadway production of Hair, winner of the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, dipped below the $500,000 mark in box-office grosses last week for the first time since it opened last March. It was one of several shows with middling or poor ticket sales for the first week of February.

title: Do You and Your Doctor Have the Same Priorities?
description: New research shows that doctors and patients often dont agree on which health issues are the most important.

title: Now Showing | The Park, Episode 2
description: In the second installment of our original Web series, two strangers (Emilio Delgado from Sesame Street and Mary-Beth Peil) discover that a moments peace can be elusive, even in the woods. Log on each Monday for more of The Park, directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and starring New Yorks mostly green dream machine, Central Park.

title: A World of Words Reinvented in Pictures
description: Look! Up in the sky! Its a prose author moving a ton of graphic novels!

title: New Hawaii Five-O Makes First Booking
description: While his Lost co-stars prepare to pack up and leave Hawaii, Daniel Dae Kim, below, can plan to remain there for at least a few more months. Mr. Kim, who plays the time-traveling tough guy Jin on Lost, has been the first actor cast in a coming remake of the crime drama Hawaii Five-O, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Kim will not be playing Danno or the other guy. (Our knowledge of Hawaii Five-O extends only to its famous catchphrase and its surf-rock theme song.) He has been cast as Chin Ho Kelly, a detective played by Kam Fong in the original series, which began in 1968. Casting has not been announced for the roles of Danny Williams (the Danno in Book em, Danno) or Steve McGarrett (the lead character played by Jack Lord), though The Hollywood Reporter said that Alex OLoughlin (Moonlight) was in talks for the McGarrett role. The Hawaii Five-O revival is being developed by the screenwriters Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci (Star Trek, Fringe) and Peter Lenkov, an executive producer of CSI: NY.

title: Bundesliga Keeps Financial House in Order
description: The German Bundesliga wants the world to know that even in these trying economic times, it is solvent and competitive  a soccer island in Central Europe that exudes diligence, steady growth and smart management.

title: Correction: One Noodle at a Time in Tokyo
description: The cover article on Jan. 31 about ramen shops in Tokyo described the reconstruction of a street scene at the Shinyokohama Raumen Museum incorrectly. The museum occupies a basement done up to resemble a 1958 scene, with branches of famous ramen shops, not a scene set in the 1930s. The article also misstated the age of Ivan Orkin, a New York City native who runs a shop called Ivan Ramen. He is 46, not 43.

title: Super Bowl Lifts Undercover Boss Debut
description: A preview episode of CBSs new series Undercover Boss attracted a sizeable audience on Sunday with its coveted time slot after the Super Bowl. According to Nielsens estimates that new reality show, in which corporate executives disguise themselves to work alongside employees at their companies, earned 38.6 million viewers, making it the largest audience ever for a post-Super Bowl series debut, and the third most-watched program to follow the game, after a special episode of Friends (in 1996) and the premiere of the second season of Survivor (in 2001). Opposite CBS the other networks struggled to find viewers. ABC averaged 2.9 million with comedy repeats, finishing about even with repeats of Foxs animated comedies. NBC was fourth with back-to-back repeats of The Biggest Loser.

title: Movie Not Out Yet, but Sequel Is Eyed
description: Whether you dislike Valentines Day, the coming romantic comedy whose ensemble cast features roughly every third actor in Hollywood, or only begrudgingly accept it, you can expect to see more movies like it. Variety reported that New Line Cinema, the studio behind Valentines Day, is already preparing a sequel-cum-spinoff called  wait for it  New Years Eve. (Evidently Arbor Day and Administrative Professionals Day arent sufficiently exciting to sustain their own movies, and someone already had the foresight to claim Groundhog Day.) The new film is expected to retain much of the creative team behind Valentines Day, including its director, Garry Marshall, and its screenwriter, Katherine Fugate. Cast members would be culled from the 20-odd performers starring in Valentines Day, who include Jessica Alba, Julia Roberts, Bradley Cooper and Anne Hathaway, though no stars for New Years Eve have been officially named yet, with shooting to take place later this year in preparation for a 2011 release. No matter how you feel about it, Valentines Day is planned to open on Friday.

title: Ownership Settled for Malevich Painting
description: The foundation that runs the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum said on Monday that it had reached an agreement with the heirs of the artist Kazimir Malevich over ownership of an untitled work by him that the museum plans to include in an exhibition this month. In a joint news release the foundation and the heirs of Malevich, the Russian Suprematist, said they had reached an amicable settlement over an oil painting he made around 1916, below left, which was acquired by Peggy Guggenheim in 1942 and has been part of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. The painting is one of about 70 Malevich works presented at a Berlin exhibition in 1927, during which Malevich was called back to the Soviet Union and entrusted the works to several friends. He died in 1935, and his work was subsequently banned by the Nazis, but his paintings, drawings and other art have since become part of the collections of museums and private owners, setting the stage for efforts by his heirs to reclaim ownership of these works.The Guggenheim, which will show the untitled painting in an exhibition called Malevich in Focus: 1912-1922, said in a statement that the terms of the settlement were confidential. A representative of the Malevich heirs said in a statement that the family is gratified that this matter has been resolved in a way that acknowledges Malevichs legacy and his contributions to the history of 20th-century art and keeps his artwork on public display.

title: Film and TV Stars Align for Olivier Awards
description: Its not only the New York theater scene that has come to be dominated by film and television celebrities. The roster of performers nominated on Monday for the Laurence Olivier Awards, among the highest honors of the London stage, is rich with actors well known for their work outside the theater, The Guardian reported. Contenders in the best actress category include the X-Files star Gillian Anderson (above, far left) for A Dolls House, Rachel Weisz (second from left) for A Streetcar Named Desire and Imelda Staunton for Entertaining Mr. Sloane. Best actor nominees include James Earl Jones (third from left, for Cat on a Hot Tin Roof), Jude Law (far right, for Hamlet) and James McAvoy (Three Days of Rain). Keira Knightley (The Misanthrope) was nominated in the best supporting actress category. The dramas Enron by Lucy Prebble and Red by John Logan, both headed to Broadway, were nominated for best new play. The winners will be announced on March 21.

title: Buying More Time for Time Stands Still
description: The Manhattan Theater Clubs production of Time Stands Still by Donald Margulies, starring Laura Linney and Brian dArcy James, will extend performances for a second time to accommodate audience interest, the theater company announced on Monday. As a result the next production coming into the companys Samuel J. Friedman Theater  Collected Stories, also by Mr. Margulies  is now scheduled to begin preview performances on April 9, three days later than originally scheduled. The opening night for Collected Stories is still set for April 28. Time Stands Still, about the turbulent relationship between a war photojournalist and her reporter boyfriend, opened on Jan. 28 to mostly positive reviews. Directed by Daniel Sullivan, the production was scheduled to close on March 7 but was extended early on to March 21. This second extension is set to conclude on March 27.

title: Updated: Sebelius Asks California Insurer to Explain Rate Increase
description: Update | 5:30 p.m.

title: Up in the Air, With Frayed Safety Nets
description: We know from the movies that commercial airplanes are full of venomous snakes and pandemic-inducing viruses, but you may prefer those in-flight hazards to the ones documented in Flying Cheap, Tuesdays Frontline on PBS.

title: Available Soon at a Barnes & Noble Near You: The Nook
description: Our colleague Motoko Rich reports on the Media Decoder blog that Barnes & Noble stores will finally have the Nook e-reader in stock starting Wednesday.

title: Critics' Pick: 'My Son the Fanatic'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at this 1997 film about a young British man's journey from assimilation to radical Islam.

title: Publishers Win a Bout in E-Book Price Fight
description: Could book publishers suddenly be in the position of telling Google what to do?

title: Less Invasive Hip Surgeries Make Inroads
description: Hip replacement is one of the most successful operations in all of medicine, which prompts many orthopedic surgeons to think, as one leader in the field put it, Why change something that doesnt need fixing?

title: Improving on the Hip Replacement
description: I Feb 26. 4:34 p.m. | Updated Thanks for all your comments. See Dr. Meeres responses in the Comments section, below.n this weeks Science Times, Jane Brody, the Personal Health columnist, reports on less invasive techniques for hip replacement that reduce complications and speed recovery. Minimally invasive operations like anterior hip replacement and the PATH technique are allowing patients like Jack White, a 71-year-old personal trainer from Arizona, to walk without a walker or even a cane on the morning after surgery. On Day 5, I walked a mile and a half, and in Week 4, I taught my aerobics class and played 18 holes of golf with no pain and no problem, Mr. White told Ms. Brody.

title: High Tech on the High Seas
description: Shuffle boards and snorkeling are two ways to play at sea. Toying with technology is another, thanks to social media networks and mobile apps that are popping up on cruises.

title: Both Parents Ages Linked to Autism Risk
description: Older mothers are more likely than younger ones to have a child with autism, and older fathers significantly contribute to the risk of the disorder when their partners are under 30, researchers are reporting.

title: H.I.V. and Herpes: Treating Herpes Doesnt Reduce Chance That AIDS Virus Will Spread, Study Finds
description: Treating herpes in people who are also infected with H.I.V. does not reduce the chances that they will pass on the AIDS virus, according to a new study.

title: Representative John P. Murtha Dies at 77; Ex-Marine Was Iraq War Critic
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania, a gruff ex-Marine who used his immense power in military spending to funnel hundreds of millions of dollars to his hard-luck district and who became an outspoken critic of the Iraq war, died on Monday. He was 77.

title: Q&A | Martin Brudnizki, Designer
description: Hes a household name in London  where his designs include the Club at the Ivy and a redo of the venerable seafood restaurant Scotts  but on this side of the pond, Martin Brudnizki remains relatively unknown. His American projects  Cecconis in Los Angeles and Le Caprice at the Pierre in New York  opened to positive design reviews, prompting T to meet with the elegant ex-model to discuss whats next.

title: Records Set in 44th Super Bowl
description: A listing of the records set in the Super Bowl on Sunday ties a bow around the story lines discussed (rehashed) in the last two weeks.

title: Is Avatar Giving You a Headache?
description: In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores the link between 3-D movies and headaches.

title: Paperwork Hinders Airlifts of Ill Haitian Children
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Private medical evacuations of critically injured Haitian children to the United States for treatment have largely stopped because aid workers, doctors and government officials are worried about being accused of kidnapping if they transport the children without first getting paperwork that is slow to arrive or is unavailable.

title: Film Criticism From the Boots on the Ground
description: As Elisabeth Bumiller reports in Mondays New York Times, more soldiers are ready and willing to tell their stories now, mostly in written form. But they are also weighing in on this seasons military movies, namely The Messenger, which has received a positive response from veterans, and The Hurt Locker, whose makers have worked with a memorial group for explosive ordnance disposal experts.

title: Super Bowl by Decades
description: Ive been working on a new Super Bowl relationship with the stock market. Unfortunately, it is a coincident indicator, not a forecasting one. But it does show that all bullish shareholders should be pleased by the Saints victory last night.

title: When Your Toddler Doesnt Talk
description: In todays 18 and Under column, pediatrician Dr. Perri Klass explores the difficulty of diagnosing speech delays in young children.

title: Liberals and the Ryan Roadmap
description: As I suggested last week, there are plenty of reasonable ways to criticize Paul Ryans blueprint for a more solvent America. You can say that its too austere. You can say that its too radical. You can say that it would never pass Congress. You can wonder, with Tyler Cowen, whether Medicare vouchers could actually work.

title: You Read It in Class; Now You Can Play It on Your Console
description: One of the nice things about basing an entertainment product on a 700-year-old epic poem like Dantes Divine Comedy is that you dont have to pay anything to use the basic intellectual property  a convenience that was surely not lost on the executives at Electronic Arts who approved the budgets for Dantes Inferno, a new game scheduled to be released on Tuesday.

title: Thirty Knots, With the Wind at Your Wings
description: VALENCIA, Spain  USA-17, the challenger for the Americas Cup, and Alinghi 5, the defender, may be stripped-down, lean racing machines, built purely for speed. But both are fully loaded.

title: How Flexible Are You? This Bachs a Good Test
description: The Juilliard School started its historical performance program in the fall and quickly established its bona fides with a performance of Bachs Musical Offering by its nine-player faculty ensemble, Juilliard Baroque, led by the violinist Monica Huggett. That performance, at the Juilliard School in October, was surprisingly relaxed, given the current fashion for speedy, sharp-edged playing in Baroque works.

title: Imaginary Soundtracks for Two Silent Warhol Films
description: There are plenty of ways to kiss, this Andy Warhol knew. In his film Kiss, which was screened at the Walter Reade Theater on Friday night, there was nibbling, munching, sucking, swallowing, biting and more. Each intimacy had its own peculiar rhythm.

title: Charting an Earnest Course Between the Rah-Rah and the Reflective
description: Hectoring and uplift enjoy an uneasy truce in the music of Delta Spirit. This five-piece indie-rock band from San Diego makes an earnest racket, with songs built around singalong choruses and roughed up mainly around the edges. On Thursday night at Pianos on the Lower East Side, the group was preaching to the converted  all those choruses had their intended effect  but that didnt diminish the force of the preaching.

title: Lou Reeds Machine: Now More Strings, Less Metal
description: A real-time, chamber-music performance of an inhumanly generated composition: that was Lou Reeds Metal Machine Music as played by the Fireworks Ensemble at Miller Theater on Friday night.

title: 2 Singers, One Experienced and One Not
description: Various music competitions and programs offer promising young singers a means to be heard above the fray. One important contest is the George London Foundation awards competition, named for the renowned American bass-baritone, which recognized singers like Joyce DiDonato and Rene Fleming early in their careers.

title: Sticky Sweets | Say It With Caramel
description: You were expecting maybe chocolate?

title: Video of the Shackleton Whisky Cache
description: Since news seems to move slowly out of Antarctica, this video, from the team that dug up five crates of whisky and brandy left beneath a hut there in 1909 by the explorer Ernest Shackleton, only made it to YouTube on Sunday, two days after we discussed the find on The Lede:

title: Delivering Bad News and Bearing It
description: Is there any hope for a novel that begins as The Postmistress does? In the fall of 1940 a 40-year-old spinster named Iris James goes to visit a Boston doctor. She wants a written document attesting that she is, as the book says, intact. The lucky recipient of the letter will be Harry Vale, a mechanic who smells of axle grease and Old Spice and has a crypto-sexual fetish of his own. It concerns the height of the flagpole in Franklin, the small Cape Cod town where he and Iris both live.

title: A Floating Safari in Botswana
description: Ever since Katharine Hepburn declared I never dreamed that any mere physical experience could be so stimulating!, African river boating has been a booming industry.

title: Identity Found: On West Side via West Bank
description: Najla Saids Palestine, a one-woman Off Broadway show that began previews on Saturday, is a coming-of-age story about Ms. Saids journey to become an Arab-American on her own terms.

title: PNCs Bailout Warrants May Fetch $253 Million
description: The governments warrants for the PNC Financial Services Group, acquired in the banking bailout, may raise $253.3 million for taxpayers if they go up for auction, according to Pluris Valuation Advisors.

title: Samurai Shopper | Seeing Red
description: Theres no greater challenge to Samurai shopping than Valentines Day, when love fills your airspace and makes some of us see red. Hearts on boxer shorts may be quite a bodice ripper, but not for me. And a red thong wrapped as a rosebud is not exactly a brain tease.

title: Exxon and the Climate Fight
description: When the Heartland Institute held its gathering in New York City last year celebrating climate skepticism, Exxon Mobil made a point of saying it had stopped contributing money to that group, explaining that it did not want to support groups whose position on climate change could divert attention from the important discussion about how the world will secure the energy required for economic growth in an environmentally responsible manner.

title: A Move to Expand Falters as Kirin Ends Talks With Suntory
description: A potential merger in the food and beverage sector fell apart on Monday after Kirin Holdings of Japan said it had ended talks with its smaller rival Suntory Holdings. A deal would have created a company on a par with Kraft Foods and PepsiCo in terms of global sales.

title: Newsstand Sales and Circulation Fall for Magazines
description: In another tough stretch for the magazine business, newsstand sales and subscriptions declined in the last six months of 2009. The only good news: the rate of decline is getting less steep for newsstand sales.

title: Report Says Value of Media M.&A. Fell 49%
description: The value of mergers and acquisitions in the media and entertainment industry fell 49 percent in 2009, according to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers.

title: Innovations in America's Cup Sailing
description: America's Cup rivals USA-17 and Alinghi 5 are built of carbon fiber and have towering masts and enormous multihulls.

title: Critics Picks Video: My Son the Fanatic
description: This week, A.O. Scott returns to the 1997 film My Son the Fanatic, the story of a British Muslim, the son of a cab driver, who goes from being a guitar-playing university student to a life of religious extremism. The film, directed by Udayan Prasad and written by Hanif Kureishi, didnt receive much attention when it was released, but its themes have become much more topical, prophetic and urgent, Mr. Scott says. Its filmmakers, he adds, are interested in real people and the essential messiness of human life. Please share your thoughts on the film.

title: House Republicans Urge Democrats to Scrap Health Bills
description: The top two House Republicans, Representatives John A. Boehner of Ohio and Eric Cantor of Virginia, sent a letter to the White House on Monday urging Democrats to scrap their existing health care legislation ahead of President Obamas bipartisan summit meeting.

title: More Infighting Among Tea Partiers
description: The Tea Party war  the internal one  continues.

title: Where to Hold Hands
description: Parks and gardens have been places of romance since the very first garden, says no less an authority on the fig leaf than the city parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe.

title: A List No Hotel Wants to Be On
description: THE reviews of the worlds dirtiest hotels are in, and only Max Bialystock, the character in The Producers who makes a shady living bringing big theatrical flops to Broadway, would welcome notices like these:

title: Special Election to Fill Murtha Seat
description: The death of Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania puts another Democratic House seat in play for the midterm elections and forces a special election that will likely draw the strong interest of both parties.

title: Will You Be E-Mailing This Column? Its Awesome
description: Sociologists have developed elaborate theories of who spreads gossip and news  who tells whom, who matters most in social networks  but theyve had less success measuring what kind of information travels fastest. Do people prefer to spread good news or bad news? Would we rather scandalize or enlighten? Which stories do social creatures want to share, and why?

title: Reincarnated, and Now the Detective Work Begins
description: Theres morbid, and then theres prime-time morbid. Add up the shows that involve communicating with dead people or investigating how they died and youll find that just under half of the dramas on the big-four networks are predicated, week in and week out, on death.

title: Does Awe, or Something Else, Move You to E-Mail Articles?
description: Do you like to share awe-inspiring articles with your friends, like the many Times readers whose habits are analyzed in a new study? Or do you have other motives?

title: Ketchup That Doesnt Need to Pour
description: The Diners Journal has in its possession what may be a ketchup game-changer: The Heinz dip and squeeze package.

title: CIT Group to Repay $750 Million of Debt
description: Fresh off announcing its new chief executive, the CIT Group said Monday that it would repay $750 million of its $7.5 billion first-lien loan, debt that the company described as high cost.

title: Gregg Proposes Starting Points for Bipartisan Talks
description: Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, praised President Obamas call for a bipartisan summit meeting on health care legislation and suggested that there are two plans that could serve as a basis for compromise: a proposal that he developed called Coverage, Prevention, Reform  C.P.R., for short  and a bill put forward by Senators Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, and Bob Bennett, Republican of Utah.

title: Do-It-Yourself Super Ads
description: BE afraid, Madison Avenue. Be very afraid.

title: Race to Avoid a Death by Red Tape in Haiti
description: Updated | 7:07 p.m. My colleague Ian Urbina reports on Monday that medical evacuations of critically injured Haitian children have slowed down in part because of concerns that not completing the proper paperwork beforehand could expose medical personnel to charges of kidnapping.

title: Weiner on Bipartisanship: Good Luck With That
description: Throughout the health care debate over the last year, Representative Anthony Weiner, Democrat of New York, needled President Obama and Democratic leaders in Congress for not sticking to their liberal ideals and being too willing to compromise on the idea of a government-run health insurance plan, or public option.

title: Battle of Billionaires Has to Wait as Fickle Wind Delays the Race Start
description: VALENCIA, Spain  The grudge match will have to wait a little longer.

title: Impending Storm Postpones House Votes
description: With Washington still digging out from the weekend snow and expecting more snow beginning Tuesday afternoon, the House leadership put off votes set for Tuesday night, leaving the Congressional schedule for the week uncertain.

title: Excerpt: 'Past Life'
description: The new Fox drama follows a psychologist who uses information from people's past lives to solve murders.

title: Reading Palins Palm
description: Ask conservatives why they love Sarah Palin so and theyll often say its because shes so authentic.

title: Shopping With Granger and Robert Moorhead
description: The Moorhead brothers, who own an architecture and design firm, looked for Valentine's Day gifts that would have an element of the unexpected.

title: Heartwarming
description: MANHATTAN is getting a temporary gift for Valentines Day  the Ice Heart, a 10-foot-tall frozen sculpture at 46th Street and Broadway. Built from Lego-like blocks of ice, the piece was designed by the brothers Granger and Robert Moorhead, the owners of the New York architecture and design firm Moorhead & Moorhead.

title: Judge Questions Bank of Americas New Deal With S.E.C.
description: A federal judge left open the possibility on Monday that he might reject a new $150 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America over the banks controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, a move that could force the case to go to trial.

title: Low LDL Levels
description: Q. Can my LDL, my bad cholesterol, get too low?

title: Hungarian Dry Whites? Forge Ahead
description: COMFORT zone? Believe me, I understand. At restaurants, Im always fighting the impulse to order a beloved dish again and again. I have to struggle against sticking to customary territory in music, books and, especially, in wine.

title: Some Insects Are Picky About What Wind to Ride
description: For a high-flying insect, long-distance migration must be easy. The bug just ascends to a height where the air is zipping along  about 500 to 2,500 feet  and heads whichever way the wind blows.

title: A Complicated History for the Humble Turkey
description: Turkey may be an uncomplicated food, but the history of the bird is far from simple.

title: Figuring Out How Toads Endure All That Hopping
description: About 40 years ago, researchers discovered that when humans jump, they activate their ankle muscles before landing as protection against the force of impact. Furthermore, the intensity of this muscle-tensing depends on the size of the jump  the bigger the fall, the more electrical activity in the muscles  and activation occurs at a fixed interval before landing no matter how big the jump.

title: A Neuroscientist Studying the Structure of Dog Brains
description: At his Princeton laboratory, Samuel Wang is searching for basic information on how the brains of humans and dogs work. Dr. Wang, 42, an associate professor at the university, also spends time popularizing breakthroughs in his specialty  neuroscience. His book, Welcome to Your Brain, was named 2009 Young Adult Science Book of the Year by the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Next semester, he will offer a first for Princeton: an undergraduate course called Neuroscience and Everyday Life. Here is an edited version of a four-hour conversation.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 969 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American last week:

title: Euro perspective
description: Big problems in Europe, no doubt. But its easy to lose perspective on the size of the Greek problem. So heres a chart showing 2008 shares of eurozone GDP:

title: S.E.C. Enforcers Focus on Avoiding Madoff Repeat
description: WASHINGTON  Bernard L. Madoff haunts these corridors like the He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named of Wall Street.

title: Do Supplements Work? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Science and Gender (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviewing the 2010 Hall of Fame Selections
description: Andy Barall, who writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down, offered a few thoughts on some of the players who made it to the Hall of Fame on Saturday, and some of those who didnt.Jerry Rice, Emmitt Smith, Rickey Jackson, Russ Grimm, John Randle and the two senior nominees  Dick LeBeau and Floyd Little  made it.

title: The Cove Breaks Into Japan
description: Update | 10:07 a.m. The filmmakers behind The Cove have been open about their goal: not to win an Oscar  though they wouldnt mind  but to stop the dolphin slaughter that the documentary depicts. They may have moved one step closer to that goal with the news that the Oscar-nominated film, which shows a secret dolphin-killing field in Taiji, Japan, will now be distributed in Japan. The Japanese company Medallion Media is planning a tentative release date of April 2010, according to a statement released late Monday by the filmmakers representatives. The director, Louie Psihoyos, considers the move a coup because the film had drawn the threat of legal action in Japan.

title: New Hampshire: Dartmouth Announces Layoffs
description: Dartmouth College announced Monday that it would lay off 38 non-teaching staff members this week and a similar number in April to help close a projected recurring annual budget gap of $100 million. An additional 33 non-teaching employees will be asked to work reduced hours. At a weekend meeting, the Board of Trustees approved a 4.6 percent increase in undergraduate tuition, room and board and fees for next year, to $52,275 a year.

title: Japanese Split on Exposing Secret Pacts With U.S.
description: TOKYO  They were Tokyos worst-kept diplomatic secrets: clandestine cold war era agreements with Washington that obligated Japan to shoulder the costs of United States bases and allow nuclear-armed American ships to sail into Japanese ports.

title: Spring Planning
description: Several weeks ago, during a severe cold snap in the northeast, I didnt have my usual anxiety about whether my hives would survive the bitter chill. I already knew the answer: No way  they havent got a chance.

title: San Francisco Joins the Club of Green Financiers
description: It was an idea born in the Berkeley mayors office in 2007, tried out in that city in 2008 and then implemented in eastern Riverside County in one of those parched towns strung along Interstate 10 known for little beyond the occasional music festival, the sprawling desert and 350 days a year of sun.

title: The Tamil Question
description: Far from Colombos shimmering seaside skyscrapers, the hollowed-out city of Jaffna, Sri Lanka, seems stuck a generation behind the rest of the country.

title: Bills Stalled, Hospitals Fear Rising Unpaid Care
description: President Obama says he aims to keep trying. But what happens if the health care legislation cannot be revived, and tens of millions of uninsured Americans continue without coverage?

title: Second Wave of Snowfall Is in Forecast
description: While they dig out from an epic snowstorm on Friday and Saturday, road crews and utility workers across the Mid-Atlantic States may be facing a Sisyphean struggle. They are likely to be digging out all over again after another heavy snowfall that is forecast to start Tuesday afternoon.

title: Republican Senator Lifts Some Holds on Obama Nominees
description: Senator Richard Shelby, a Republican from Alabama, today lifted many of his holds on nominations to administration posts by President Obama that require Senate confirmation.

title: Paytons Path Was Winding, His Confidence Never Wavering
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  While the bulk of attention after the New Orleans Saints Super Bowl victory over the Indianapolis Colts focused on quarterback Drew Brees and cornerback Tracy Porter  two Saints with improbable journeys whose career performances came in the most important game either had ever played  the path of Sean Payton was just as, if not more, unlikely.

title: Lawyers Back Creating New Immigration Courts
description: Responding to pleas from immigration judges and lawyers who say the nations immigration courts are faltering under a crushing caseload, the American Bar Association called Monday for Congress to scrap the current system and create a new, independent court for immigration cases.

title: In City Real Estate, Old Clans Are Shrewd Again
description: At the height of the boom, the Dursts, the Rudins, the Roses, the LeFraks and other members of New Yorks royal real estate families were treated like slow-moving dinosaurs on the verge of extinction.

title: Insiders Admission Deepens Galleon Case
description: A former executive of Intel admitted in court on Monday that he had leaked confidential corporate information to his close friend Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund. He adds to a list of cooperating witnesses that federal prosecutors are using to build a case in a wide-ranging insider-trading scandal.

title: In Northern Iraq, a Vote Seems Likely to Split
description: QARAQOSH, Iraq  There was a hope, not long ago, that democracy would mean peace and stability for Nineveh, a place where cultures and armies have clashed since biblical times. Instead, democracy is hardening divisions  of people, of resources, of land  in ways that threaten the future of Iraq itself.

title: Shareholders Deciding a Dividend
description: Wouldnt it be great if we could turn back the clock to 2007?

title: A Powerful Pennsylvania Congressman
description: Representative John P. Murtha, an ex-Marine who became an outspoken critic of the Iraq war, has died.

title: Bloggingheads: Repealing Dont Ask
description: Journalist Ana Marie Cox and Rich Lowry of National Review debate repealing Dont Ask, Dont Tell.

title: Optimism Persists in a Kentucky Town Where a Carmaker Brought Jobs
description: GEORGETOWN, Ky.  Before Toyota arrived here more than two decades ago, Georgetown was a sleepy town of 10,000. Its population has since swelled to 25,000, and most of those people owe their livelihood to the sprawling Toyota plant outside of town on Cherry Blossom Way.

title: U.S. Asks Keriks Judge to Send a Stern Message
description: Federal prosecutors on Monday painted a damning portrait of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, as a corrupt official whose egotism and hubris led him to commit crimes that would upgrade his lifestyle.

title: One Womans Journey
description: In the way of many immigrant kids, Najla Said recalled in a recent interview with Felicia R. Lee, I just wanted all the questions about identity to go away. For Ms. Said, an actress, writer and the daughter of Edward W. Said, the Columbia University professor who died in 2003, the questions, however, persisted. And so she created Palestine, a one-woman off-Broadway show produced by the Twilight Theater Company in association with New York Theater Workshop, that began previews on Saturday. It is, as Ms. Lee writes, a coming-of-age story about Ms. Saids journey to become an Arab-American on her own terms. The show, which blends the personal with the political, covers her teen years as a self-described politically agnostic Upper West Side princess to her vision of herself today, a 35-year-old woman who is deeply moved by the very word Palestine.

title: Love Stories
description: In her latest, erotically charged, highly explicit collection of short stories, Where the God of Love Hangs Out,  Amy Blooms characters think and speak in a cheeky if not impudent manner, writes Francine du Plessix Gray. This upbeat sassiness of tone is one of the many treasures of the new collection, which consists of two sets of linked narratives, each consisting of four stories, as well as several free-standing stories. Janet Maslin has also called the book beautifully astute. The onetime psychotherapist and best-selling author will read from the collection, well-timed for Valentines Day, at Book Court tonight beginning at 7 p.m.

title: A Ran Rerun
