description: Akira Kurosawa's centenary doesn't arrive until March, but Film Forum has given devotees of the great Japanese director an early reason to celebrate his work with a tribute series, which runs through Feb. 18. Tonight, catch a screening of "Ran," the 1985 film is a transposition of "King Lear" to 16th-century Japan. The movie, Kurosawa's final epic production, is returning for its 25th anniversary in a print made from the original camera negative. "Tatsuya Nakadai plays the Lear figure, a feudal lord who divides his lands among his three disputatious sons, with predictably disastrous results," writes Dave Kehr. Go especially to watch the battles scenes, "filmed with great flair and bold color."

title: How the First Amendment Works
description: One of the respondents to my column on United Citizens, the corporate campaign funding case, declares, Professor Fish is obviously an apologist for this bad decision (Mark), while others are just as confident that I tip my hand in the other direction when I refer to the majority as the usual suspects.

title: Immigrants Claim Wal-Mart Fired Them to Provide Jobs for Local Residents
description: SILVERTHORNE, Colo.  A small group of West African men who came to the Rockies in search of economic opportunity are embroiled in a dispute with Wal-Mart, accusing it of a raft of discriminatory actions. Most say they were dismissed because supervisors wanted to give their jobs to local people in need of work.

title: Skeptics Find Fault With U.N. Climate Panel
description: Just over two years ago, Rajendra K. Pachauri seemed destined for a scientists version of sainthood: A vegetarian economist-engineer who leads the United Nations climate change panel, he accepted the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize on behalf of the panel, sharing the honor with former Vice President Al Gore.

title: Influx of Youth Has U.S. Ski Jumping Looking to Future
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  One does odd jobs for his fathers property development company. Another washes dishes at a pub. The other scoops ice cream at a shop called Mountain Mist. This is the United States ski jumping team, in all their boyish glory.

title: Colts Approach Leaves Room for Second-Guesses
description: Miami Gardens, Fla.

title: As Data Flows In, the Dollars Flow Out
description: John Anderson and Sharon Rapoport estimate they spend $400 a month, or close to $5,000 a year, keeping their family of four entertained at home.

title: 49 Down: Black Key Material
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Whats not to like about this theme? Its a simple yet clever idea that makes for a light, fun puzzle thats perfect for a Tuesday.

title: Beep! Chime! Buzz! Now, Juggle!
description: ID like to stay and chat, because I have something important I want to talk about this week. But Ill have to get back to you after I check on a few things upstairs, where an army of people is helping me prepare my house to sell here in Northern California.

title: On Health Bill, G.O.P.s Road Is a New Map
description: WASHINGTON  When Republicans take President Obama up on his invitation to hash out their differences over health care this month, they will carry with them a fairly well-developed set of ideas intended to make health insurance more widely available and affordable, by emphasizing tax incentives and state innovations, with no new federal mandates and only a modest expansion of the federal safety net.

title: Blast Victims Served Their Communities
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  Their obituaries will call them pipe fitters, and they will not be wrong, but they certainly will not be exactly right. The work these men did went far beyond threading and brazing, welding and rigging  they were coaches and leaders, self-appointed statesmen of the cities where they lived. They were tradesman-citizen throwbacks who gave of their time after work the way they gave of their backs on the job.

title: The Venting of Gas From Pipes Has Been Fatal in the Past
description: In 1999, workers taking a boiler out of service at a power plant in Dearborn, Mich., mistakenly blew natural gas from the surrounding pipes into the boiler, where it built up, met with something hot and exploded. Six workers died and 38 were injured.

title: With Shake-Up, SAP Seeks Better Customer Relations
description: SAP, the German software maker, said Monday that it would focus on restoring its damaged customer relationships after a surprise management shake-up that cost the chief executive his job.

title: Not All Teams Are Looking to Trade Solely for Talent
description: Last month the New Orleans Hornets payroll was hovering a little above the $69.92 million luxury tax threshold. They were slated to owe approximately $500,000 in tax when the league does its end-of-season accounting, and would forgo the $4.3 million tax distribution that goes to non-taxpaying teams.

title: Super Bowl Dethrones M*A*S*H as Most-Watched Show in U.S. History
description: New Orleanss 31-17 victory in the Super Bowl on Sunday on CBS generated more viewers  an average of 106.5 million  than any other television program in United States history, defeating the 1983 broadcast of the final episode of M*A*S*H.

title: What to Do With Senator and Slasher?
description: Pity the State Senate. It is struggling mightily over what to do about one of its lesser lights, Senator Hiram Monserrate of Queens, whose main claim to fame is that he assaulted his girlfriend.

title: From Right of Radio Dial, a Challenge to McCain
description: PHOENIX  J. D. Hayworth is a large man, and to compensate for his indulgences, he hits the elliptical trainer every morning at 4, zipping along to an incongruous soundtrack of Elvis Costello, Frank Sinatra and old advertising jingles.

title: A Chefs Ingredients, and His Hopes, Run Afoul of a Border Inspection
description: I ENJOY flying because its a time when I can work in peace, without the interruption of a cellphone or computer.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about a snowstorm that blanketed Washington and much of the Middle Atlantic region on Saturday misstated the amount of snow that fell on Long Island. While residents of some communities on the South Shore reported a slight amount of snow, no location received 3 to 6 inches.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about programs that allow students to earn high school diplomas and up to two years of college credit in five years at no cost misstated the name of one of the countrys first early-college high schools, which is now a private liberal-arts college in Great Barrington, Mass. It is Bard College at Simons Rock, not Simons Rock at Bard College. The article also misstated the given name of the president of Sandhill Community College in Raeford, N.C., which has an early-college high school. He is John R. Dempsey, not Rick.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 31 about intensive searches in the St. Louis area to find long-lost relatives of teenagers who are languishing in foster care misstated the name of a suburb across the Mississippi River from St. Louis. It is Fairview Heights, Ill.; there is no Fairview, Ill.

title: A New Space Program
description: President Obama has called for scrapping NASAs once-ambitious program to return astronauts to the Moon by 2020 as a first step toward reaching Mars. That effort, begun by former President George W. Bush, is behind schedule and its technology increasingly outdated.

title: Music Inc. Gets Bigger
description: President Obama has made a welcome break with the Bush administrations disregard for enforcing antitrust law. The Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission have become more aggressive about questioning mergers and challenging monopolies and anticompetitive behavior.

title: The Hudson Cleanup
description: The first phase of the long-delayed dredging of toxic chemicals from the Hudson River is over. The polluter, General Electric, and the Environmental Protection Agency have issued separate reports evaluating the six-month cleanup, which was designed as a trial run for a much larger second phase that will finally rid the river of PCBs, industrial lubricants that have poisoned its mud and fish for generations.

title: How to Reduce the Federal Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Tea Partiers and Republicans, in Battle Mode
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Drilling Royalties
description: To the Editor:

title: A Word From Harpers
description: To the Editor:

title: Controlling Radiation Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: The House of Tranquillity
description: During the presidential campaign, Barack Obama and Joe Biden had a Felix and Oscar air about them. Obama was disciplined and professorial while Biden was tactile and approachable. Biden would make an off-color joke, while Obama would put on a contemptuous grimace. Biden would bound friskily onstage to the roar of the crowd. Obama would glide gracefully and even ask Joe to hold his coat.

title: The Worst of the Pain
description: There is a great tendency in this country to refuse to see what is right in front of everybodys eyes.

title: Irans Two-Edged Bomb
description: Maxwell Air Force Base, Ala.

title: Making Solar Power Portable
description: Last year, when Jonathan Smith was still the president of Earth911.com, a Web site dedicated to recycling, he said he would often board a plane after a speaking engagement or a day of meetings with a dead cellphone in hand.

title: China Lists $9.6 Billion in Shares of U.S. Companies
description: SHANGHAI  Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, Chinas sovereign wealth fund quietly bought more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citigroup.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the history of St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan, which is struggling to survive, misspelled the name of the founder of a Roman Catholic religious order whose nuns were at the hospital in late January. She is Mother Teresa, not Theresa.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions on Jan. 31 misstated the hours for the Montclair Art Museum. It is open from noon to 5 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Monday, about Super Bowl commercials, referred imprecisely to the career of Christopher Guest, who directed an ad for the Census Bureau. While Mr. Guest has been both writer and director for films, he was only a writer for the 1984 film This Is Spinal Tap. An accompanying picture caption misstated the age of The Simpsons animated television show, some of whose characters appeared in a Coca-Cola ad. The shows first episode was shown on Dec. 17, 1989, and it is now in its 21st season; it does not turn 20 this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about British Airways quarterly earnings referred incompletely to the airlines efforts to downsize its service. In addition to reducing the number of flights, it is also using smaller planes and replacing business and first-class seats with economy seats on some routes in order to cut capacity.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about Health Magazines revising recipes from Real Simple, a sister Time Inc. magazine, misstated the issue in which the revised recipes appeared. It was the December 2009 issue, not the February 2009 issue. (The original recipes appeared in Real Simple in its February 2009 issue.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Monday about a pair of risky plays called by Coach Sean Payton that helped the New Orleans Saints win the Super Bowl on Sunday misidentified, in some copies, the team for which Chris Reis plays. It is the Saints, not the Colts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 31 about Coach Jim Barons efforts to improve the Rhode Island mens basketball program misspelled the universitys location. It is in South Kingstown, R.I., not South Kingston.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday with a report in the Arts, Briefly column about plans for the actor Taylor Lautner to star in the movie Stretch Armstrong misidentified the creature he plays in the The Twilight Saga: New Moon. He is a werewolf, not a vampire.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Saturday about the soprano Angela Gheorghius withdrawal from the Metropolitan Operas current production of Carmen misspelled the surname of the tenor scheduled to play Don Jos in the final two performances, on April 28 and May 1. He is Jonas Kaufmann, not Kaufman.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: French Identity Debate Leaves Public Forum
description: PARIS  Prime Minister Franois Fillon of France announced a few symbolic measures on Monday to provide concrete results from Frances bitterly contentious debate over national identity.

title: Roadblock to the American Dream in the Rockies
description: Members of a community of West African immigrants in Colorado saw their efforts to make it in the United States stall after Wal-Mart fired them earlier this year.

title: To Ace This Interview, Palin Keeps Notes Close
description: Ask conservatives why they love Sarah Palin so and they will often say it is because she is so authentic.

title: Speedskatings Olympic Rewards Fail to Pay the Bills
description: Tears welled in Kip Carpenters eyes last fall as he addressed the Wisconsin Speedskating Association board at the Pettit National Ice Center. One of the athletes he coaches, Jilleanne Rookard, had an abundance of talent, desire and grit, he explained, but a cash deficit threatened to derail her bid to make the 2010 United States Olympic team.

title: Burmese-American Awaits Verdict in Myanmar Case
description: BANGKOK  At last count there were more than 2,100 political prisoners in Myanmar, according to human rights groups that track the opaque workings of the penal system in that country, formerly known as Burma. Among them is Nyi Nyi Aung, who spent years campaigning for Burmese democracy in exile before obtaining American citizenship.

title: Pakistani Military Retakes Key Town in Tribal Belt From Taliban
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military has retaken the key town of Damadola, in the Bajaur area of the tribal belt, where the army has been fighting Taliban militants for more than a year, military and local officials said Monday.

title: Protecting Banks in the Boardroom
description: Bank regulators havent exactly covered themselves in glory. But an earlier defense against bank excesses ought to be their boards. Its not an easy job, but directors could try harder to control risk-taking. Uncomfortable questions are welcome.

title: Early Run by Kansas Keeps Texas in a Tailspin
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The preseason No. 1 team, Kansas is accustomed to expectations.

title: N.C.A.A. Fails to Stop Licensing Lawsuit
description: A district court judge in San Francisco on Monday denied the N.C.A.A.s motion for dismissal in a class-action lawsuit headed by the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed OBannon. The ruling leaves the N.C.A.A.s licensing contracts open to discovery.

title: Keep the Lawyers, Judge Tells Murder Defendant
description: The woman accused of killing Linda Stein, the celebrity real estate agent, asked for new lawyers at her trial on Monday, but the judge turned her down, leading to shouts of protest from her family.

title: Patersons Ethics Veto Survives Override Vote
description: ALBANY  The Legislature failed Monday to override Gov. David A. Patersons veto of legislation intended to require greater transparency and accountability in public office.

title: Leno on His Old Friend Letterman
description: Jay Leno on his show Monday night told his audience that the Super Bowl ad with David Letterman was a chance to get laughs with his old friend again. He also shared with the audience how the commercial, which he said was Mr. Lettermans idea, came to be.

title: Scott P. Brown: America's Newest Senator
description: In January, Brown won a special election in Massachusetts to fill the remainder of Senator Edward Kennedy's term. His supporters know him as a "regular guy," but he has a colorful past and a mixed political record.

title: A Federal Climate Service Is Created to Provide Data
description: WASHINGTON  The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will create a new climate change office to gather and provide data to governments, industry and academia as part of a broad federal effort to prepare for long-term changes to the planet, officials said Monday.

title: Hendricks Racing Dynasty Shows No Sign of Slowing Down
description: Four championships in four years is enough to breed a sense of invulnerability in a race team.

title: On Assignment: Minders, Fixers, Troubles
description: Its New Years Eve in Dakar when the call comes from the editor in New York. A Nigerian man, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, tried to blow up an airliner headed to Detroit six days earlier. Im told hed studied in Yemen. Steven Erlanger, chief of The Timess Paris bureau, is already there filing stories. Im to join him immediately. I fly to Paris, pick up money and gear at the bureau, then rush back to the airport to catch a flight to Dubai. Thirty-six hours after leaving Senegal, Im in Yemen.

title: Republicans Have Eyes on House Seats in Northeast in Midterm Races
description: WASHINGTON  Republican candidates are showing surprising financial strength in Congressional districts held by Democrats in the Northeast that party leaders have singled out as ripe for what could be critical gains in the November election.

title: Developer Is Accused of Fleecing Investors
description: A man who once was one of the citys high-flying real estate moguls was arrested Monday morning on charges that he stole $2.5 million from business associates and friends, including the best man at his wedding, by fooling them into believing he was making deals to buy hotel properties in upstate New York and Colorado.

title: Foursquare Signs a Deal With Zagat
description: Update | 1:43 PM Adding information about a new content partnership between Foursquare and The New York Times, inconjunctionwith the Winter Olympics.

title: Illinois Democrats Look to Fill Sudden Ticket Gap
description: CHICAGO  A coveted high-profile position was unexpectedly available Monday morning: the job of Democratic nominee for lieutenant governor of Illinois.

title: Senator Lifts Holds on Most Nominees
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, on Monday night lifted most of the nearly 70 holds he had placed on President Obamas nominations to posts that require Senate confirmation.

title: U.S. Officials Plan $78.5 Million Effort to Keep Dangerous Carp Out of Great Lakes
description: CHICAGO  Federal authorities on Monday presented a $78.5 million plan intended to block Asian carp, a hungry, huge, nonnative fish, from invading the Great Lakes.

title: For Haitian Children, a Crisis Escalates
description: After 10 Americans tried to take children out of Haiti last month, medical evacuations for critically wounded children have slowed dramatically because of paperwork requirements.

title: Word of the Day | agnostic
description: agnostic \ag-ns-tik, g-\ noun and adjective

title: Theres No Eyebrow She Cant Tame
description: Unibrows meet their match in Salima Rajwani, a 28-year-old threader at Unique Threading Salon in Chelsea, who has been making New Yorkers scraggly eyebrows lovely for the last two years. Threading, not to be confused with sewing, entails twisting taut cotton threads together and rolling them along the skin to wrest hairs at the roots. Sound painful? It is! Except Ms. Rajwani, who lives in Rego Park, Queens, says threading is easier on the skin than waxing and more precise. And the salon where she works charges just $6 per pair of brows. CARA BUCKLEY

title: With Snow an Issue, Practices Are Curtailed
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Olympic organizers continued to use heavy-lift helicopters, dump trucks and a fleet of snow-grooming machines Monday to deal with the meltdown at the resort hosting the snowboarding and freestyle skiing events at the Vancouver Games. As the United States moguls team set off in the afternoon for the first practice runs of the Games, questions loomed over the state of the site.

title: Aparicio Lets White Sox Unretire His No. 11 So Vizquel Can Wear It in Tribute
description: Omar Vizquel had a team, but someone else had his number.

title: Dueling Priorities as the Knicks Rebuild
description: As the Knicks slogged through another too-little, too-late rally Saturday night, the franchises confused priorities were on full display.

title: Saints Risky Decisions Were Both Calculated and Crucial
description: Coach Sean Payton made daring decisions on the way to New Orleanss first Super Bowl victory. Toward the end of the first half on Sunday night, trailing by 10-3, he called for a run on fourth-and-goal from the 1.

title: A Dance of Beauty and Death
description: WHO have been killed driving through the Kabul Gorge, pictured above?

title: In Midst of Recession, Bundesliga  Thrives
description: The German Bundesliga wants the world to know that even in these trying economic times, it is solvent and competitive  a soccer island in Central Europe that exudes diligence, steady growth and smart management.

title: News Quiz | February 9, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Foursquare Signs a Deal With Zagat
description: Go to item from Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Developer Is Accused of Fleecing Investors
description: A man who once was one of New York Citys high-flying real estate moguls was arrested Monday morning on charges that he stole $2.5 million from business associates and friends, including the best man at his wedding, by fooling them into believing he was making deals to buy hotel properties in upstate New York and Colorado.

title: Japan: Official Says Hell Keep Job
description: Japans most influential political leader, Ichiro Ozawa, said Monday that he would keep his formal job as the No. 2 leader of the governing Democratic Party after prosecutors decided not to charge him in a financing scandal. Mr. Ozawa, left, who was the architect of his partys election victory last summer, said that the prosecutors decision proved his innocence. But recent polls show that about three-quarters of Japanese think he should resign.

title: Canada: Air Force Official Charged
description: The commander of the largest air force base in eastern Canada has been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of two women from eastern Ontario and with the sexual assault of two others. Col. Russell Williams, 46, commander of Canadian Forces Base Trenton, was arrested Sunday in Ottawa, the police said Monday. He was charged with the first-degree murder of Jessica Lloyd, 27, of Belleville, and Marie Comeau, 38, an air force corporal, of Brighton. Ms. Lloyds body was found Monday and Corporal Comeaus was found in November.

title: Vatican: Child Abuse Condemned
description: Pope Benedict XVI on Monday condemned the abuse of children by members of the clergy. Speaking to Pontifical Council for the Family members, the pope said that while the church has defended childrens dignity and rights throughout the centuries, in some cases, members of the clergy had violated those rights. The church, he said, hasnt and wont ever stop deploring and condemning such behavior.

title: The S.E.C.s Enforcers
description: Bernard L. Madoff haunts these corridors like the He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named of Wall Street.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Ducks Snap Kings 9-Game Streak, but Lose Getzlaf
description: Five games on Monday, including a big freeway derby in which the Kings put their nine-game winning streak on the line. Home teams listed first:

title: International Judges Dismiss Charges Against a Sudanese Rebel
description: International judges dismissed a war crimes case against a Sudanese rebel leader on Monday, saying there was not enough evidence to try him on charges that he played a key role in the killing of 12 African Union peacekeepers in Darfur in 2007. Bahr Idriss Abu Garda, a leader of the United Resistance Front, voluntarily traveled to the International Criminal Court in The Hague last year to attend hearings in the case. The courts prosecutor had accused him and two others of organizing an attack in which about 1,000 rebels stormed a peacekeeper base in Darfur, and fled with equipment and vehicles.

title: Protecting Banks in the Boardroom
description: Bank regulators havent exactly covered themselves in glory. But an earlier defense against bank excesses ought to be their boards, Breakingviews says. Its not an easy job, but directors could try harder to control risk-taking. Uncomfortable questions are welcome.

title: Chief of Albany Firm Charged With Securities Fraud
description: The president of an Albany investment firm has been accused of selling fraudulent securities to investors across the country.

title: Arrests by Iran Are a Bid to Quell Wide Protests
description: CAIRO  In recent weeks, security officials have unleashed an epidemic of arrests across Iran in an effort to neutralize the political opposition, silence critical voices and head off widespread protests when the nation observes the anniversary of the revolution on Thursday, Iran analysts inside and outside the country said.

title: Judge Questions Bank of Americas New Deal With S.E.C.
description: A federal judge left open the possibility on Monday that he might reject a new $150 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America over the banks controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, a move that might result in the case going to trial, Louise Story reports in The New York Times.

title: UBS Swings to Profit, but Clouds Linger
description: UBS, the Swiss bank that became a symbol of ravages of the subprime crisis in Europe, failed to stem an outflow of client funds even as it posted its first quarterly profit in over a year on Tuesday, Julia Werdigier reported in The New York Times.

title: QuinStreet Called Beacon of Hope in Lousy I.P.O. Market
description: QuinStreet, an Internet marketer, is the one beacon of hope in this weeks crop of initial public offerings as the market contends with jitters spurred by concerns about the economy, and I.P.O.s from companies with more than their fair share of debt, The Associated Press writes.

title: In City Real Estate, Old Clans Are Shrewd Again
description: At the height of the boom, the Dursts, the Rudins, the Roses, the LeFraks and other members of New Yorks royal real estate families were treated like slow-moving dinosaurs on the verge of extinction.

title: BSkyB Sells 10.4 Percent Stake in ITV
description: BSkyB, the British Pay-TV group, sold a 10.4 percent stake in the commercial broadcaster ITV for around 196 million ($306 million) on Monday, to finally bring an end to a long-running legal battle.

title: Nuclear Power Giant Areva Buys Solar Firm
description: From Matthew L. Wald at Green Inc.:

title: The Tiger Recession
description: The potential economic consequence of Tiger Woods withdrawal from professional golf.

title: What Have You Been Taught About Sex and Abstinence?
description: A new study shows that some types of abstinence education can work in certain ways. What kind of sex education have you had? Do you think it is effective?

title: Shareholders Deciding a Dividend
description: HCAs announcement last week that it was paying its private equity shareholders a $1.75 billion special dividend brought back memories of 2007, when buyout shops, riding a booming market, routinely paid themselves huge dividends, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Fund Wins Auction for Terminator Franchise
description: Pacificor, a hedge fund based in Santa Barbara, beat out Lionsgate and Sony in the auction for the rights to the Terminator movie franchise, Nikki Finke reported on her Deadline Hollywood blog.

title: Redpoint Closes $400 Million Fund Aimed at Start-Ups
description: Redpoint Ventures said Monday that it had closed a new $400 million fund aimed at early stage investments in social networking, mobile products, cloud computing and clean technology.

title: Motorola Invests in TuneWiki
description: Motorola Ventures took the lead in a new round of funding for TuneWiki, a social music start-up, PaidContent reported.

title: Dow Industrials Close Below 10,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, a closely watched barometer of the economys health, dipped below the 10,000 threshold on Monday, delivering a psychological setback as investors braced for more market volatility.

title: Music Inc. Gets Bigger  but Should It?
description: The New York Timess editorial board has a bone to pick with the Obama administration over the merger between Ticketmaster and Live Nation.

title: Swedbank Reports Loss After Tough Year
description: Swedbank, the banking group based in Stockholm, posted a fourth-quarter operating loss that was bigger than market expectations on Tuesday but said a profit for the full year in 2010 was feasible.

title: NYSE Euronext Returns to Profit in 4th Quarter
description: NYSE Euronext, the trans-Atlantic stock exchange operator, said Tuesday it returned to profit in the fourth quarter as cost-cutting helped offset a drop in revenue from falling global share trading volumes, The Associated Press reported.

title: Sri Lankan President Dissolves Parliament
description: NEW DELHI  Sri Lankas president dissolved Parliament on Tuesday, clearing the way for elections to choose a new legislature even as a bitter dispute raged over the fate of the main challenger in last months presidential election.

title: MGM Mirage Seeks to Divest Stake in Atlantic City Casino
description: MGM Mirage is moving to divest itself of its 50 percent stake in an Atlantic City casino in a move to settle questions raised by New Jersey regulators over its ties to a controversial Chinese casino family.

title: SAS to Issue Shares and Cut Jobs After 2009 Loss
description: SAS, the Scandinavian airline group, said Tuesday that it would issue new shares to raise capital and cut about 650 jobs after reporting a loss for 2009  but the worst may not be over.

title: Japan Airlines Decides to Stick With American
description: Japan Airlines confirmed on Tuesday that it would maintain its partnership with American Airlines and the Oneworld airlines alliance, dashing Delta Air Lines hopes of partnering with the troubled Japanese carrier, The New York Timess Bettina Wassener reported.

title: Macquarie Cautious on Outlook
description: The Macquarie Group, Australias top investment bank, startled investors on Tuesday with a lukewarm outlook, warning them about weakening markets and sending its shares down 6 percent.

title: At Tate Modern, Gorkys Power and Poetry
description: Starting tomorrow, fans of Arshile Gorky should head straight to the Tate Modern (Bankside, SE1; 44-207-887-8888; www.tate.org.uk/modern/), which is hosting the first major retrospective of the enormously influential artist to be seen in Europe in about 20 years.

title: D.E. Shaw Said to Form Distressed-Assets Team
description: D.E. Shaw, the big U.S. hedge fund, has put together an in-house team that will focus on buying portfolios of distressed assets, in particular those belonging to rival hedge funds, The Financial Times reported.

title: Americas Wars Without Decisive End
description: Todays idea: America has an impressive record of starting wars, but lately, a dismal record of ending them well, a historian says  so best to heed cautious generals.

title: Manhattan Madam Claims Hedge Fund Ties
description: While it may surprise some to hear that Kristin Davis, the Manhattan Madame who claims Eliot Spitzer, the former New York governor, was a client, is now gunning for Mr. Spitzers old job, her credentials might also have some in the hedge fund industry checking their roster of former employees.

title: F.S.A. Chief to Step Down This Year
description: Hector W. Sants, the chief executive of Britains financial services regulator, said Tuesday that he would leave the agency by the end of the summer, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

title: Britain Told It May Sell Bank Stakes in 5 Years
description: A committee of British lawmakers is publishing a report Tuesday saying that the government may sell its stakes in Royal Bank of Scotland Group and Lloyds Banking Group in five years, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Keeping China (Relatively) Green
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Sampler: City to Change School Assignment System and Berkeley Bathroom Thieves
description: San Francisco to Rethink School Assignment System | The San Francisco School Board will consider proposals at its meeting on Tuesday night to replace its complex and controversial school assignment system with a new system that could take into account a familys proximity to a school. In place since 2002, the current system uses a diversity index, which looks at factors like family income, but not race, in an effort to ensure a racial mix. Parents have complained that the system is complex and often assigns their children to undesirable schools far from home. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Feb. 9
description: Highlights from todays media coverage:

title: Mobile Data Traffic Expected to Surge
description: As I reported last month, there is a coming tsunami of mobile devices, from tablets to smartphones, that will guzzle data and consume scarce bandwidth.

title: Tangled Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Tangled Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

title: Opel Plans to Cut Jobs and Reduce Its Capacity
description: Adam Opel, the European unit of General Motors, announced an ambitious turnaround plan on Tuesday, vowing to become profitable in 2012 by cutting capacity by 20 percent and reducing its work force by 8,300, while introducing new models, including the battery-powered Ampera.

title: Warren: Banks Sabotage of Overhaul Will Hurt Them
description: In a scathing op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, Elizabeth Warren, a professor of law at Harvard and the chairwoman of the TARP Congressional Oversight Panel, denounced the deception that she said had become routine in the practices of U.S. banks.

title: Good Energies Invests in Massachusetts Clean Energy Firm
description: Amid a state-wide feud over the job creation spin-offs of President Obamas stimulus package, a Massachusetts clean energy design and construction company announced Tuesday that it has raised $6.5 million in venture financing to help underwrite a national expansion strategy.

title: Super Return: Black Sees Better Days Ahead
description: Rhea Wessel for The New York Times Leon D. Black of Apollo Management (right) predicts happier prospects for the private equity industry in 2010.

title: Editor Reviewing China Quake Deaths Is Sentenced
description: BEIJING  The sentencing of an outspoken literary editor to five years in prison for subversion showed that the Chinese government will not relent in its ongoing crackdown against critics and dissidents, supporters of the editor said Tuesday.

title: Toyota Dealers Pull Ads on ABC for Excessive Stories on Recalls
description: Brian Ross, chief investigative correspondent for ABC News, says hes undaunted that 173 Southeastern Toyota dealers have pulled their ads from ABC-affiliated stations in response to his persistent reporting on the companys sudden unintended acceleration problems.

title: The Early Word: More Snow?
description: The Washington area now expects more snow later today and on Wednesday, complicating votes on Capitol Hill and canceling work for thousands of federal employees.

title: Haute Economics
description: Backstage after their spring show, the designers Viktor & Rolf explained that because of the credit crunch, they had decided to crunch their couture  literally, burrowing tunnels and cutting away slices in their extravagant tulle dresses. In the spirit of fashions new D.I.Y. ethos, they offered this simple guide to reproducing their results. Have fun.1. Purchase 149 yards of fine tulle for the skirt, 44 yards of stiffer tulle for the underskirt and 2.3 miles of very thin yarn, which you will use to sew the garment by hand.

title: Talk of Assistance for Greece Propels Markets
description: Hopes that the wealthy nations of Europe would come to the aid of Greece galvanized financial markets on Tuesday and, for a day at least, soothed fears that the economic troubles on the fringes of the Continent might spread.

title: White Stripes Protest Super Bowl Ad for Air Force Reserve
description: Update | 2:55 p.m.  In song, at least, the band the White Stripes has boasted that it can hold off a seven-nation army. But now that rock group is taking on an entire branch of the United States Armed Forces, contending that it misused one of the bands songs in a commercial that was promoted as a Super Bowl Sunday ad.

title: Does the N.F.L.s Going to the Ground Rule Need to Be Changed?
description: The Saints pass attempt to Lance Moore for a 2-point conversion with 5:42 left in the fourth quarter was one of the biggest plays in the Super Bowl. When the referee Scott Green changed the on-field ruling of an incomplete pass to a completion after a video review, it gave the Saints a lead of 24-17 instead of 22-17.

title: Home Fires: Shaking All Over
description: PHNOM PENH  Its mid-afternoon. From my hotel room at the Bright Lotus Lodge  only a block from where the Tonle Sap converges with the Mekong River  I can hear the keyboard strains of The Doors Light My Fire drifting out from one of the bars on the riverfront.

title: Nigerian Parliament Names Acting President
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Nigerias National Assembly voted Tuesday to make Vice President Goodluck Jonathan the acting president, filling a power vacuum that has unsettled Nigeria, Africas most populous nation, since President Umaru YarAdua left the country for medical treatment in November.

title: Philippine Clan Patriarch Charged in November Killings
description: MANILA  Prosecutors here in the Philippine capital on Tuesday indicted the patriarch of a powerful political clan and 196 others in connection with the November massacre of 57 people, the worst case of political violence in the nations history.

title: Councilman Seabrook Faces Fraud Charges
description: Updated, 1:02 p.m. | City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook surrendered to city and federal authorities in Manhattan on Tuesday to face a 13-count indictment accusing him of money laundering, extortion and fraud in a series of schemes that included helping a close associate win a contract to install boilers in the new Yankee Stadium.

title: A Better Future (or Typeface) for the Navi
description: The Bagger is considering instituting an equal-play policy when it comes to the biggest horse race in the Oscars: for every post about The Hurt Locker we need one about Avatar. So voila: there has been a nerd-storm brewing for weeks over the typeface that the master of all media James Cameron used in subtitling the Navi language he helped create in his box-office-busting film. The futuristic blue aliens words, you see, are rendered in a dowdy old font, Papyrus. It is the only unimaginative visual aspect of the movie, Allan Haley, a type design master, wrote on a font blog. If the choice were mine, the subtitles would have been original calligraphy.

title: For Private Equity, a Time for Wary Optimism
description: BERLIN  Its time for paranoid optimism about the economy as the world maneuvers its way into a new balance of power, John Micklethwait, editor in chief of The Economist, argued here at the Super Return 2010 conference on Tuesday.

title: Obsessions | The Delilah Complex
description: Im grappling with a small but puzzling question of motherhood. When it comes to child rearing, there is an array of controversies to pick from thats almost dazzling  breast or bottle, stay at home or work, stay at home and work  but this one seems to be much less vital. O.K., here goes: It might be time to cut off my hair.Every man I have consulted on the issue believes it is a bad idea. And the experts seem to agree that there are historical and biological links between long hair and sexual desirability. (But what are these guys thinking? That well go on a date? Im married.) On the other hand, every mother I talk to has either cut her hair or wishes she was brave enough to do so. Iconic images of mothers principally show women with their hair up, or short. Dorothea Langes Migrant Mother had seven children and hair  from what we can tell in the photographs  no longer than her shoulders. Mary Cassatts painted mothers always have their hair tied up in a bun or a topknot.

title: Opels Strategy Has Fewer Jobs and Less Capacity
description: Adam Opel, the European unit of General Motors, announced an ambitious turnaround plan on Tuesday, vowing to become profitable in 2012 by cutting capacity by 20 percent and reducing its work force by 8,300, while introducing a raft of new models, including the battery-powered Ampera, The New York Timess Jack Ewing reports.

title: Americans Jailed in Haiti Plead for Aid From U.S.
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The 10 Americans detained on kidnapping charges are pleading for the United States government to do more on their behalf and for the news media to focus on them less.

title: China Report Shows More Pollution in Waterways
description: BEIJING  Chinas government on Tuesday unveiled its most detailed survey ever of the pollution plaguing the country, revealing that water pollution in 2007 was more than twice as severe as was shown in official figures that had long omitted agricultural waste.

title: Avalanches Kill Dozens on Mountain Highway in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Heavy winds and rain set off 17 avalanches that buried more than two miles of highway at a high-altitude pass in the Hindu Kush mountain range, entombing hundreds of cars and cutting off Kabuls heavily traveled link to northern Afghanistan, officials said Tuesday.

title: Jimmy Fallon and Stephen Colbert Wrestle Late-Night Wars to a Close
description: For a time on Monday night, it looked as if the great late-night war of 2010 might finally be winding down. As Derrick Henry and Bill Carter report on Media Decoder, Jay Leno used the penultimate episode of his Jay Leno Show to thank his old frenemy David Letterman for the invitation to join him and Oprah Winfrey in a much buzzed-about commercial that ran during the Super Bowl. No matter what animosity there is among comedians, Mr. Leno told his audience, a good joke is a good joke. A short while later on the Late Show, Mr. Letterman showed his gratitude by thanking the actors who played Oprah and Jay Leno in the ad.

title: Jean Todt, FIA President, Speaks
description: Jean Todt met with a few members of the media in Paris and answered questions about his first 100 or so days as president of the FIA. It was a wide-ranging talk and I still havent transcribed my full recording, but there were a few interesting points Ill return to.

title: Written on Her Hand
description: Monologue |  Monday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Did everybody watch the Super Bowl? Everybodys happy for New Orleans. In fact, FEMA announced plans to congratulate them in about two weeks.

title: A Moving Ceremony
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Congratulations to the New Orleans Saints. They defeated my Indianapolis Colts. So all I can say is, Dont worry, Indianapolis, FEMA is on the way.

title: Headed to Jail
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Well, congratulations to the world champion New Orleans Saints for winning the Super Bowl. Thats the best thing to happen to New Orleans since George Bush left office.

title: 59% of U.S. Haitians Lost Loved Ones in Quake, Poll Finds
description: Giving hard numbers to the devastating impact of the Haitian earthquake on Haitians in this country, a poll released Tuesday found that 59 percent of Haitians in the United States had lost loved ones in the Jan. 12 earthquake, and an additional 10 percent still did not know whether they had when the survey was conducted, from Jan. 22 to Jan. 24.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Another Not So Great Moment in Chicago Politics
description: As my colleague Susan Saulny reports in Tuesdays New York Times, Democrats in Illinois once again find themselves having to fill an opening in their statewide slate after a bizarre news conference by an embattled politician. This time it was their candidate for lieutenant governor, who went to a Chicago bar on Sunday night to announce that he was withdrawing from the race.

title: Delayed Grants From Foundation Start to Come Through
description: The Judith Rothschild Foundation has paid at least some of the grant money that it had neglected to award to 17 arts groups last year, according to one recipient. Im glad I got it because it pays for the catalog and some printing costs, said Natalie Edgar, the director of the Philip Pavia Trust in New York, which had been awarded $7,000 toward a book about the works of Mr. Pavia, a sculptor.

title: When to Worry if a Child Has Too Few Words
description: Every pediatrician knows the frustration of trying to quantify the speech and language skills of a screaming toddler. How many words can he say? Can she put two or more words together into a sentence? Can people besides you understand him when he talks? Questions like these, put to the parents, are the quick and somewhat crude yardsticks we often use.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: A List No Hotel Wants to Be On This years lists singled out the 10 dirtiest hotels in each of six regions  the United States, Asia, Canada, France, Italy and Britain.

title: Looking for Lessons in Others Rejection Letters
description: The more I hear of surprising early decision and early action results, the more skeptical I get. One amazing kid after another has been rejected or deferred from a college that seemed like just the right fit.

title: Quote Unquote | Hair Apparent
description: -Donatella Versace reveals her beauty, er, secrets to Love Magazine. As if.

title: Chuck Norris and Henry V in Port-a-Johns. With Armored Penguins.
description: ALI AL-SALEM AIRBASE, Kuwait  Like many who have spent time in Iraq and Afghanistan, I have come to consider latrine graffiti as something of an art form  the only interesting entertainment to be found on many dismal patrol bases and outposts.

title: Siemens Touts Growth in Renewables and the Value of the American Market
description: Since acquiring the Danish wind turbine company Bonus Energy in 2004, the German industrial giant Siemens AG has become one of the larger players in the wind power game with roughly 7 percent of the market.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Taxi Swap Keeps Historic Meters Running
description: Clanking through the crowded city streets one recent afternoon, the old New York Checker cab provoked looks of disbelief, and not just because the well-loved, almost comically bulky car disappeared from commercial use long ago.

title: EBay Asks Its Users for Help Building New Search Tools
description: When eBay makes changes big or small, a very vocal group of buyers and sellers react. Now, eBay is trying to involve its users earlier in the process by getting their input before new features are introduced.

title: Pipe Fitters, Yes. Statesmen, Too.
description: Their obituaries will call them pipe fitters, and they will not be wrong, but they certainly will not be exactly right. The work these men did went far beyond threading and brazing, welding and rigging  they were coaches and leaders, self-appointed statesmen of the cities where they lived. They were tradesman-citizen throwbacks who gave of their time after work the way they gave of their backs on the job.

title: Todays Jets Parade, and the Favorite in  2011
description: We didnt forget. Today was supposed to be the Jets parade.

title: Inside Out | Depth of Field
description: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.I find that one of the keys to giving a living room a feeling of depth and substance is to have something  like a piece of furniture  visible behind the sofa or chairs. It leads your eye into the distance, giving the room that third dimension it so often lacks. I spent last Friday with a client, moving furniture around. The newly upholstered furniture was arriving in her living room, the first phase in the transformation of a room that has been long-unused into one that can be enjoyed on a daily basis. Behind the new pair of club chairs, we put a chest of drawers between two windows. The room immediately felt substantial in a way it hadnt before, as well as very cozy and warm. (This is also an excellent way to use a piece of furniture that your parents gave you, and which has sentimental value but which is not necessarily to your own taste. Not every piece in a room needs to be your absolute favorite thing; in fact, it is usually preferable for at least one thing not to be.)When chairs or sofas just sit in front of a wall, the space behind them can look rather sad. At home, I have been struggling with the depressing nest of cables and air of general neglect behind my club chair. But what was putting a monkey wrench in the decorating works was that I didnt need a table there  there is already a desk nearby  so I left it until finally it came to me. What I wanted, I realized as I put the last of a small stack of logs on the fire, was a really big log basket. I love log baskets, and it has been something I have wanted for a long time. They look so good in rooms, and, in the same way that bookcases and drinks trays do, they imply civilized living is going on!

title: A Smoothie That Hits the Spot
description: Mike Fachetti, who lives in the East Village, often feels as if he is being pulled to Xoom, a new smoothie shop on East Seventh Street, for the simple reason that he is. Mr. Fachettis dog, Harley, an English bulldog who is 80 pounds of determined tug, knows that what awaits is not the mere biscuit proffered by many dog-friendly businesses but an actual menu item.

title: Vancouvers Warm Welcome
description: Now that folks are shaking their real or proverbial Super Bowl hangovers  well, except those in New Orleans still eagerly fomenting theirs  it is time to swing our attention to a new sporting event: the Spring Olympics. This is what happens when you throw a Winter Olympics in Vancouver the year it decides not to have a winter. This becomes a problem unless you are willing to move the halfpipe competition to the Rose Garden, which apparently stole all of Vancouvers  white fluffy stuff, or you want to spawn the new Olympic event of tulip bulb planting.

title: Anatomy of a Euromess
description: Most press coverage of the eurozone troubles has focused on Greece, which is understandable: Greece is up against the wall to a greater extent than anyone else. But the Greek economy is also very small; in economic terms the heart of the crisis is in Spain, which is much bigger. And as Ive tried to point out in a number of posts, Spains troubles are not, despite what you may have read, the result of fiscal irresponsibility. Instead, they reflect asymmetric shocks within the eurozone, which were always known to be a problem, but have turned out to be an even worse problem than the euroskeptics feared.

title: Schools Closed Tomorrow
description: Updated, 2:47 p.m. | New York City public schools will be closed on Wednesday, the Department of Education announced on Tuesday in a pre-emptive decision one day before a significant winter storm is due to hit the region.

title: K.K.R. Continues Greening Its Portfolio
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the private equity giant, has expanded an initiative it started with the Environmental Defense Fund to green up the operations of its portfolio companies.

title: Samsung Gets the Amoled Out
description: Samsung created a whole bunch of fuss at Januarys consumer electronics extravaganza with its prototype laptop that displayed stunning OLED images on a clear see-through screen. It all seemed a bit sci-fi-ish, but reports are that the Korean brand will bring Amoled (active-matrix organic light-emitting diode) devices to market in the next year.

title: Pearlstein/Held
description: Images from the exhibition at the Betty Cuningham Gallery in Chelsea.

title: Republicans Have Their Disagreements, Too
description: For anyone who spent months watching the Democrats family feud over a proposed government-run health insurance plan, or the more recent intraparty battle between House and Senate Democrats over a proposed tax on high-cost, employer-sponsored insurance policies, it might have seemed as if Republicans were much more unified on the issue of health care.

title: App of the Week: Weather Anywhere
description: Anyone who has had to abandon a car during snowmageddon has learned the value of being weather-aware. There are a dozen or so very good weather apps, most specialized for one phone or another. But in the interest of getting critical weather information to as many people as possible, I suggest using Weather Undergrounds mobile Web page.

title: Clock Is Ticking on Possible 24 Movie
description: Question No. 1: Will it be 24 hours long? Question No. 2: Will it still have short breaks roughly every 15 minutes so that its viewers  and, presumably, its protagonist  can go to the bathroom? Fans of the Fox action series 24 may soon learn the answer to these and other pressing questions now that a feature film version of the television show is in the works. Variety reported that the motion-picture division of 20th Century Fox has hired the screenwriter Billy Ray (State of Play, Shattered Glass) to write a script for a movie-length adventure for Jack Bauer, the secret agent (played by Kiefer Sutherland) whose world-saving exploits always take exactly one day to unfold. The Variety report said that Mr. Rays screenplay would likely be set in Europe (where clocks are already set to 24-hour time). 24 is now in its eighth season on Fox, which has not yet officially ordered a ninth season of the show; Variety cautioned that a possible movie could be put on hold if the Fox network passes on the television series.

title: German Church Faces Child Abuse Charges
description: BERLIN  The Roman Catholic Church faces yet another child abuse scandal, this time in Pope Benedict XVIs native Germany.

title: A New Norm for Unemployment?
description: The January jobs report had some mixed messages. One thing seems clear, though: The position of the already unemployed is looking more and more desperate.

title: Philanthropy Fill-In
Snowboard Videos: Send Us Your Tricks
description: Perhaps the most defining characteristic of snowboard halfpipe riding is that it is always changing. The riders call this progression. And for the athletes competing in the Vancouver Olympics, progressive runs mean the difference between ending up on the podium and ending up empty-handed.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Ugly people are more likely to turn to crime.

title: Whats in a Name?
description: Joe Sharkey reports in todays paper on TravelAdvisor.coms list of dirtiest hotels. That got me curious and I went to the list of the dirtiest hotels in the United States. Then I looked around the site, and found their list of best hotels in the country.

title: Splinternet
description: A fragmented Internet  the consequence of proprietary hardware and software, private networks, and content gated behind logins.[Spl(inter)+Internet]

description: Q.

title: When Coal Flows Between Countries, Who Owns the CO2?
description: [Nov. 24, 2010, 12:15 p.m. | Updated A news story in the Beyond Fossil Fuels series by The Times has explored the issues raised in this post in some depth: Nations That Debate Coal Use Export It to Feed Chinas Need.]

title: The Rise of Green Modular Homes
description: Kevin Clayton, the chief executive of Clayton Homes, a modular home manufacturer based in Maryville, Tenn., predicted last year that his companys i-house  a solar modular home  would command 10 percent of its profits.

title: Without Fanfare, Lenos Prime-Time Show Ends
description: The Jay Leno Show will end quietly on Tuesday night, only five months after it had its premiere in prime time to great fanfare on NBC.

title: Salzburg Easter Festival Roiled by Financial Scandal
description: It seems you just cant celebrate Wagner anymore without at least a little bit of behind-the-scenes intrigue. The Salzburg Easter Festival in Austria may be in for a lot of it, as state prosecutors there have announced that they are investigating eight people involved with the event on suspicion of deception and embezzlement, The Independent of London reported. We expect our inquiries to take months, a spokesman for the prosecutors told The Independent. It involves non-existent companies and offshore bank accounts. The announcement follows the dismissal in December of the festivals executive director, Michael Dewitte, who is now being sought by the police on charges that he misused its funds and put its money into foreign bank accounts. Last week, The Independent said, the festivals technical chief, Klaus Kretschmer, was found unconscious under a bridge in Salzburg, and is believed to have attempted suicide after being accused of charging the festival for non-existent services. Over all, the festival may have been defrauded of as much as $2.75 million. It is scheduled to open on March 27, and feature Simon Rattle conducting a production of  what else?  Gtterdmmerung.

title: Horsing Around With Herms
description: Starring Channing Hill and Richard Wright

title: European Debt Issues Top Agenda for Meeting
description: STRASBOURG, France  With the European Unions single currency in the grip of the worst crisis in its history, the blocs new president is expected to use the growing alarm over debt levels to argue for a new form of economic government in Europe.

title: Ford Unveils New Transit Connect Electric and Taxi Version
description: Ford unveiled an electric version of its Transit Connect work van ahead of the Chicago Auto Show, which opens to the press on Wednesday.

title: You Got Deferred. Now What?
description: Sally Rubenstone recently posted an open question on College Confidential that boils down to this: What might an applicant who was deferred by a college in its early decision or early action round do to improve his or her chances of admission now, as colleges are weighing final decisions?

description: Who is the Marc Jacobs of South Korea? Is it Demoo Parkchoonmoo? Or Juun.J? Maybe Andy & Debb?

title: A Bay Area Parents Quest for the Cheap and Easy Snow
description: Snow is elusive when you live here. Sure, sometimes it comes tantalizingly close to us, and Mount Diablo gets a white frosting like a British judges wig. When it rains here, the snow people start wearing ski hats and talking about the powder. But the Sierra snow pack, for many of us, remains an abstraction  a number that may indicate whether we should expect another year of water restrictions.

title: A Teacher Terror Alert Phenomenon?
description: Michael Mulgrew, the head of the citys teachers union, loves nothing more than to get under the citys skin. And he has a theory that, he believes, proves he does.

title: Skier Turned His Life Around but Kept Eyes on Olympic Gold
description: At the 2006 Turin Olympics, there was no avoiding the spectacle that was Jeret Peterson, the American freestyle aerialist known as Speedy.

description: Updated | 1:40 p.m.

description: There is nothing like plans for new bipartisanship to create an argument over, well, bipartisanship.

title: Michelle Obama Leads Campaign Against Obesity
description: Michelle Obama kicked off a sweeping initiative today aimed at reshaping thediet and exercise habits of American children  from thefat in their school lunches, to the playgrounds they frequent andthe measurements their pediatricians take at check-up time with the ambitious goal of eliminating childhood obesity within a generation.

title: The Case of the Fake Pinot, or Thousands of Cases of It
description: Did E & J Gallo, the huge California wine producer, buy millions of gallons of French red wine fraudulently labeled as pinot noir? According to The Independent, a French court is now hearing the case of 13 people in the French wine trade who have been charged with selling Gallo 3.57 million gallons of wine from the Languedoc-Roussillon region that was labeled as pinot noir but was in fact made from cheaper grapes.

title: Senates Vote on Labor Nominee
description: With the Senate still expected to take a vote later today on President Obamas nomination of Craig Becker, a labor lawyer, to a seat on the National Labor Relations Board, its time to take stock of the chatter online about Mr. Becker and the growing opposition to his nomination.

title: The New Math of Oscar Advertising
description: In addition to the new math of voting, this season Oscar campaigners have new math for budgeting and timing. To accommodate the Olympics, the telecast has been pushed back two weeks later than normal, to March 7th. Which gives studios and their acolytes extra days to spend and woo.

title: S.&P. Issues Negative Outlooks for BofA and Citi
description: Standard & Poors lowered its credit rating outlooks on Bank of America and Citigroup to negative from stable on Tuesday, saying the government appeared less likely to provide a further bailout if either bank needed it in the future.

title: Saints Go Marching in New Orleans, at Last
description: On Tuesday, Campbell Robertson reported on the New Orleans Saints victory parade. His news article on the event is published elsewhere on our site, but below are some updates on the parade he filed to The Lede before the festivities got underway.

title: Obama Urges Setting Aside Petty Politics
description: President Obama declared today that a sense of purpose that transcends petty politics must be forged by Democrats and Republicans to create more jobs, reduce the deficit and find at least some common ground on health care.

title: Google Gets More Social With Buzz
description: Feeling overwhelmed by the bevy of social networking services? Google wants to help  by adding one to the list. On Tuesday the company unveiled Google Buzz, another way for people to tell other people what theyre doing, thinking and feeling.

title: Haitian Mans Four-Week-Survival Story Draws Amazement and Some Skepticism
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The case of a Haitian man said to have been pulled alive from rubble nearly a month after the earthquake here amazed doctors on Tuesday, but his story of survival also drew a note of skepticism.

title: Google Offers Phone Help for Nexus One Owners
description: As my colleague Miguel Helft and I recently reported, new owners of the Nexus One, the touch-screen smartphone developed by Google, have found themselves at a loss when it comes toreceivingcustomer support for the device.

title: Digital Chirps in Subway Tunnels
description: When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority redesigned its Web site last month, in addition to real-time updates and color-coded service information, the authority also threw itself more aggressively into social media, starting several accounts on Twitter and Facebook.

title: Would You Pay $895,000 for This Business?
description: Despite the tough economic times, conventional wisdom in the small-business marketplace holds that there is always a market for good businesses. One such business is this niche manufacturer of specialty lighting and related products that has continued to post profits right through the recession.

title: Learning to Drive a Manual? Try the Dodge Ram 3500
description: Knowing how to operate a manual transmission is an increasingly arcane art  Ferraris newest car, the 458 Italia, doesnt even offer a stick shift. Still, I think its a useful skill for anybody to learn. Fun aside, what if you had to get to the hospital and the only vehicle at your disposal was a 2001 BMW M5? Exactly. Knowing how to drive a stick shift just might save your life.

title: Indie Distributor New Yorker Films Gets a Second Reel
description: Update | 1:29 p.m.  New Yorker Films, the 44-year-old film distributor that abruptly announced last year that it was shuttering its doors, will live on as a new owner has been found for its estimable movie library. On Tuesday, Aladdin Distribution LLC of Marina del Rey, Calif., said that it had purchased more than 400 foreign and independent titles that comprise the catalog of New Yorker Films, which previously handled the release of movies like Jean-Luc Godards Breathless and Claude Lanzmanns Holocaust documentary Shoah, as well as films by Bernardo Bertolucci, Federico Fellini, Akira Kurosawa and numerous other directors. The revived New Yorker Films, which was originally founded in 1965 by Dan Talbot, will be run by Jose Lopez, a business partner of Mr. Talbots and former vice-president who will now serve as president of the company. In a statement, New Yorker Films said that it intends to acquire six to eight films a year for theatrical release, and will continue to seek movies for its non-theatrical and home video divisions.

title: Kelley Blue Book Values for Toyota Prius Drop
description: Consumers are apparently scooping up bargains on the newly recalled 2010 Toyota Prius.

title: Whats the Best Age to Have Children?
description: In the hunt to explain the increase in diagnoses of autism, the conversation has once again come back to parental age.

title: Globetrotters Show That Ice Is No Obstacle

description: Michelle Obama kicked off a sweeping initiative today aimed at reshaping the diet and exercise habits of American children  from the fat in their school lunches, to the playgrounds they frequent and the measurements their pediatricians take at check-up time  with the ambitious goal of eliminating childhood obesity within a generation.

title: White House Reschedules Concert to Beat the Snow
description: With another round of wintry weather threatening Washington, the White House announced that it would hold a concert featuring Bob Dylan, Smokey Robinson, Joan Baez and Jennifer Hudson a day ahead of schedule.

title: Air Force Reserve Responds to White Stripes
description: The Air Force Reserve said on Tuesday that the music used in a television commercial shown during the Super Bowl was created by an outside company, and was not meant to sound like a song by the White Stripes.

title: The Jihadist Next Door
description: For Muslim-born Americans, there really is no great mystery in the radicalization of certain Muslim-Americans. Reading Andrea Elliotts article reinforces my contention that many of the most fundamentalist Muslim-Americans are converts. Most religious converts, be they Muslim or born-again Christians, convert in times of confusion,turmoil or uncertainty. Typical converts are rebellious by nature, shun traditional societal beliefs and

title: Indie Film Distributor Gets New Life
description: New Yorker Films, the 44-year-old film distributor that abruptly announced last year that it was shuttering its doors, will live on as a new owner has been found for its estimable movie library. On Tuesday, Aladdin Distribution LLC of Marina del Rey, Calif., said that it had purchased New Yorker Films catalog of more than 400 foreign and independent titles, including Jean-Luc Godards Breathless and Claude Lanzmanns Holocaust documentary Shoah, as well as movies by Bernardo Bertolucci, Federico Fellini, Akira Kurosawa and numerous other directors. Read more on the revived New Yorker Films on ArtsBeat.

title: Is There an Ecological Unconscious?
description: Daniel B. Smiths article deepens our understanding of the psychological aspects of climate change. The article gives pioneering examples of how the stress of climate change can be incorporated into psychotherapy. Emphasizing the unconscious as an influence is crucial, since

title: Giant Steps
description: I first encountered the music of Fred Hersch when his CD Evanessence: A Tribute to Bill Evans, was released in 1998. I was intrigued by this pianist who reminded me so much of Bill Evans  not so much that he sounded like him, but that his approach to the melody of the music was much the same.

title: A Charitable Use for Leftover Gift Card Funds
description: When Darren Cannao first heard the statistic three years ago that merchants and banks collect billions of dollars each year in unredeemed gift card funds, as covered in this recent Your Money column, his jaw dropped and he had an idea.

title: Crash Blossoms
description: In Ben Zimmers On Language column, he mentions the telegram HOW OLD CARY GRANT? to which Grant (allegedly) replied, OLD CARY GRANT FINE. HOW YOU? In a period from 1981 until Grants death in 1986, he made appearances in large performing-arts centers throughout the country for unrehearsed question-and-answer sessions with audiences. As agent and manager for these evenings, I accompanied him and his wife, Barbara, and would like to say that Zimmer is correct in his assumption that the story about the telegrams is apocryphal. Grants response to audience questions about this famous telegram was: It never happened, but its one of the things I wish I had said.

title: The Morning Skate: Red Ink in Dallas, a Vote in Hempstead
description: In another troubling sign of how the N.H.L. is faring in the poor economy, Tom Hicks, who is selling the Dallas Stars, said his team was losing money and doesnt believe the economy will allow the new owner to spend to the cap.

title: A Sondheim-Tinted Perspective on Life
description: To borrow the words of the English novelist Anthony Powell, Stephen Sondheims Night Waltz, from A Little Night Music, might be described as a dance to the music of time. A little giddy, with one foot off the ground and the other perilously perched on tiptoe, the song is the thematic thread in an unfurling Sondheim medley that is the centerpiece of the jazz pianist Barbara Carrolls new show at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Two Wheels + Two Seats = Love
description: For some, the tandem bicycle is as close as it gets to love on a bike. The machines with two seats and one pair of wheels have often conjured thoughts of everlasting bliss and pedaling in union.

title: A Certain Uncertainty, With Lieder and Gospel
description: Waiting for a recital by the soprano Kathleen Battle to begin on Monday night at Carnegie Hall felt a bit like riding an unfamiliar roller coaster for the first time. There was a giddy expectancy heightened by the presence of gabby spectators snapping photos. But there was also the kind of apprehension that steadily builds during the slow ascent toward the rides first vertiginous dip.

title: For L.B.O.s, the Key Is Less Risk, Not None
description: BERLIN  For leveraged buyouts, the issue isnt necessarily avoiding risk. Its sticking to a modest level of risk.

title: Storm Closes Schools and Grounds Planes Along East Coast
description: A major snowstorm charged in from the Midwest late Tuesday night toward major East Coast cities, forcing pre-emptive school and office closures and grounding hundreds of flights for the second time in less than a week.

title: House Closes for 2 Weeks; Senate In and Out
description: House Democrats have decided to call it a snow day, or a snow week. Or, actually, make that two.

title: North Jersey Finds Popularity as Home for Data Centers
description: The boxy three-story building at 5851 Westside Avenue in North Bergen, N.J., attracts as much attention from passing motorists as a cornfield by the side of an interstate in Iowa.

title: Inside the Salang Pass
description: At War's chief blogger Stephen Farrell traveled through the high-altitude pass in Afghanistan months before a series of 17 avalanches buried more than two miles of highway.

title: Changing a Culture by Removing Walls
description: In November, after 45 years in cloistered offices at 777 Third Avenue, the advertising giant Grey Group moved to an open-plan layout in the International Toy Center building at 200 Fifth Avenue.

title: Study: Short-Sale Disclosures Could Disrupt Market
description: A new study commissioned by the hedge fund industrys chief lobbying group has concluded that forcing investors to disclose their short positions in certain stocks could lead to less liquidity and wider price spreads, ultimately making trading more expensive.

title: Russia: Chechen Leader Drops Suits
description: MOSCOWChechnyas powerful president, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, backed down from a conflict with human rights defenders and journalists on Tuesday, withdrawing several libel suits at the request, aides said, of his mother.

title: Blizzard Looming, House Cancels Votes
description: House Democrats, seeking to move forward with at least a component of their health care legislation, had planned to vote this week on a bill to repeal the limited exemption from federal antitrust laws long enjoyed by insurance companies. But after a huge snowstorm over the weekend, and with another one rolling in on Tuesday afternoon, the House canceled all votes this week.

title: Google Tries to Get Some Good Buzz
description: Today Google announced it was introducing a new social-networking product called Google Buzz.

title: Agency Co-Founder Bond Leaves
description: Jonathan Bond, who helped remake the New York City advertising scene with a upstart spirit, has left the agency he co-founded 23 years ago.

title: Canon Improves Entry-Level Rebel D.S.L.R.
description: Canon has extended the capabilities of its EOS Rebel consumer D.S.L.R.s with the new EOS Rebel T2i, which brings some of the features of the midrange EOS 7D to the starter camera space.

title: Correction: Into the Wild in Lush Guyana
description: An article on Feb. 7 about an eco-tour in Guyana misidentified the type of monkey seen by the writer in the rain forest. The error also appeared in a picture caption accompanying the article. The monkeys in the treetops were black spider monkeys, not squirrel monkeys, and the photo was of a black spider monkey, not a squirrel monkey.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra, After Leadership Vacuum, Faces Financial Straits
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra suffered unexpectedly weak ticket sales in the fall, a keyorchestra member said  yet another blow in a spiraling financial crisis that has been coupled with a leadership vacuum at one of the worlds elite orchestras.

title: Can Republicans Win?
description: Daniel Larison has been writing a a series of withering posts on Republican self-delusions about this November, and beyond. Heres a passage from the latest one:

title: Love in the Time of Recession
description: Money doesnt buy love and it doesnt buy happiness, as we should all know by now. But money woes can certainly cause problems for couples, especially during the economic downturn. The bottom line: Its complicated.

title: Did Belarus Rip Off The Big Bang Theory?
description: Plenty of television producers would surely love to duplicate the success of the prolific comedy creator Chuck Lorre, and someone (or someones) in Belarus may have figured out how to do it  by ripping off his hit CBS series The Big Bang Theory in its entirety.

title: A City Apartment in Lodz
description: A two-bedroom apartment in the city center of Lodz, Poland, is on the market for 910,000 Polish zlotys ($306,000).

title: The Subject of the Sibling
description: I began dreading my son Maxs college-application process even before his senior year began last fall. I didnt want to hear the stories about his ultracompetitive peers or come into contact with their crazed berparents. I wasnt looking forward to the endless essays, the almost-missed deadlines. But mostly I just felt an amorphous sadness. Its not that he wasnt ready to go; it was as if there were something more that I needed to do or say before I could let him.

title: Does an Old Climate Critique Still Hold up?
description: Two years beforetheFourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was released in 2007,this comment about an early draft of the report came in from Andrew Lacis, a physicist at the Goddard Institute for Space Studies, the NASA lab led for decades by James Hansen:

title: Video: New Media Saving Old
Ground Is Broken on San Francisco Subway
description: On Tuesday, city officials gathered to break ground on San Franciscos Central Subway, the project that will provide rail access for the first time along a north-south axis running through some of the citys most densely populated areas.

title: Commercials Are the Culprit in TV-Obesity Link
description: Too much time in front of the television has long been linked to childhood obesity. Now, new research suggests its not the TV but the commercials that are making kids fat.

title: House Hunting in ... Poland
description: A TWO-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN LODZS CITY CENTER

title: Wheels: Toyota Dealers in Five States Pull Ads from ABC
description: Our sister blog, Wheels, has a piece up about how Toyota dealers in five Southern states  Alabama, Florida, Georgia and both Carolinas  have pulled their ads from ABC because they are upset with the coverage the network has given to the auto companys recent recall woes. Brian Ross, ABCs chief investigative reporter, says ABC is not letting the protest divert them from covering the story. Read more here.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Feb. 9
description: As the aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti moves from its acute to its chronic stage, a second wave of photojournalists has arrived to document the tentative steps forward. Lynsey Addario of The Times visited a makeshift dental clinic in a police station in Port-au-Prince (Slide 4), while John Moore of Getty Images accompanied members of the U.S. Army 82nd Airborne into areas of Port-au-Prince where aid had not yet reached (Slides 5 and 6).

title: Freeze-Frame Flamenco Hints at the Mystique of a Fast, Fiery World
description: In time for New Yorks annual Flamenco Festival, which starts on Thursday, an exhibition has just opened, split between two places. It shows flamenco in photographs, some of them dating to the 19th century.

title: A New Owner for Montenapo
