description: Montenapo, the Italian restaurant in the New York Times building that has been closed for a month, has a new owner, Gennaro Sbarro, who also owns Salute! on Madison Avenue and several steakhouses on Long Island.

title: Gibbs Plays a Palin Hand
description: After President Obama left the White House briefing room today, his press secretary, Robert Gibbs, held up a surprise of his own, literally: a scribbled list of items on his hand, in an obvious mocking of Sarah Palins weekend crib sheet at the Tea Party Convention.

title: Unauthorized Immigrant Population Declines
description: The population of unauthorized workers in the United States declined in the year ending January 2009, according to a new report from the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Kalup Linzy in Performance
description: Linzy's exclusive music videos for T: "Labisha's Bonus Track (Turn It)" and "Sit Down Child."

title: Flushings New Flavors
description: A look at northeast Chinas rich and warming food, which can now be found in Queens.

title: Galleon Defendants Ordered to Turn Over Wiretaps
description: Federal District Judge Jed S. Rakoff on Tuesday ordered Raj Rajaratnam and other defendants in the Galleon Group insider trading case to turn over wiretap recordings to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has brought a parallel civil complaint against Mr. Rajaratnam and other individuals.

title: Disneys Cable Results Offset Parks and Studios
description: LOS ANGELES  Cost-cutting in movies and an uptick in television profit helped the Walt Disney Company overcome continued weakness in its theme parks in its most recent quarter.

title: Longhorns New Look Starts With Loss
description: The new uniforms didnt help.

title: O Canada! Considering the Impact of Hosting the Olympics
description: Overview | In this lesson, students consider their associations with and knowledge of Canada. They then explore how hosting the Olympic Games contributes to and expresses national brands and do further research into Canada and the impact of hosting the Olympics.

title: Just This Once, Its O.K. to Kiss and Tell
description: He was an Englishman in New York; I was a native besotted with how he pronounced the phrase May I help you? as I shopped at the store he worked at on Madison Avenue. After Id returned my third vest in as many weeks, I mustered up my courage and offered to show him around my city.

title: A Driving Resource for a Snow Day
description: If you have to decide which vehicle to take on a road trip this week, Weather Underground can help you pick between, say, your sedan and your dog sled.

title: And the Recaps of the Super Bowl Spots Just Keep on Coming
description: The post-game scrutiny of the commercials that ran during Super Bowl XLIV on Sunday continues with a bumper crop of surveys, polls and opinions about the spots.

title: An Island Retreat
description: Drawn to the history of the region, Stein-Gunnar Sommerset bought a home on a island that is a favorite summer retreat for Istanbuls non-Muslim minorities.

title: In Turkey, Keeping the Antique Intact
description: BUYUKADA, ISTANBUL  Istanbul may no longer be the polyglot cosmopolitan hub it once was during the Ottoman empire, when it was home to large Greek, Armenian and Jewish communities. But Stein-Gunnar Sommerset, the owner of a 100-year-old wooden house here on Buyukada, a leafy island about an hours ferry ride from Istanbul, is trying to keep the spirit of that multicultural era alive.

title: Lincoln Center's New Restaurant
description: A rendering of the chef Jonathan Benno's restaurant, which is under construction at Lincoln Center. (Video courtesy of Diller Scofidio + Renfro.)

title: Philadelphia Orchestras Ticket Sales Add to Woes
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra suffered unexpectedly weak ticket sales in the fall, an orchestra member said, yet another blow in a spiraling financial crisis that has been coupled with a leadership vacuum at one of the worlds elite orchestras.

title: Pugnacious Apparent Loser in Ukraine Remains Silent
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the apparent loser in Sundays presidential election, remained out of sight on Tuesday and provided no strong hints about whether she would concede or try to overturn the results.

title: Avalanches in the Salang Pass
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Our colleague Rod Nordland writes today that 17 avalanches  have buried more than two miles of road along Afghanistans high-altitude Salang Pass, killing perhaps dozens of people on the main highway north from the capital Kabul.

title: Paulson Reassures Buffett on TARP Repayment
description: Former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., responding to a question from the billionaire financier Warren E. Buffett, said on Tuesday that the United States government would be repaid in full for the bailout money it gave to the nations financial firms.

title: Hungarians Worth Knowing
description: My column this week is on the wonderful dry white wines of Hungary. It was a column I had to think twice about writing.

title: An Annual Report on One Mans Life
description: At the end of 2005, Nicholas Felton decided to publish a report that would chronicle his life over the previous year. He looked through his music archives to see how many songs he had listened to. He checked his airline ticket stubs to see how many miles he had flown. He aggregated the number of books read and photos taken. He compiled those and myriad other data points into his first annual report about his life, aptly titled, The Feltron Annual Report. (The r in Feltron was added to include a subtle pseudonym component to the report.)

title: USA-17s Wing Presents a Challenge to Its Crew When the Wind Kicks Up
description: VALENCIA, Spain  With 19th-century rules forcing the Americas Cup to wait a day for another shot at beginning the match, both teams kept their boats tied up Tuesday.

title: She Can Have It All, Cant She? The Answers in Her Eyes
description: The question mark in the title of Lucinda Coxons play Happy Now? suggests the jittery tone that underlies much of this trenchant comedy about the emotional hurdles of midlife.

title: The Nifty 50 | Kalup Linzy, Artist
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Republicans Block Confirmation of Labor Lawyer
description: Senate Republicans late this afternoon blocked the confirmation of labor lawyer Craig Becker to fill a vacancy on the National Labor Relations Board. The vote was 52-33, eight short of the 60 votes needed to force final consideration of Mr. Beckers appointment.

title: Cruise Bargains Harder to Find
description: LOOKING for a bargain cruise? Better get booking. Deals in 2010 promise to be harder to come by than they were last year, when cruise lines introduced a wealth of bargains, and passengers benefited from deep discounts, waived booking deposits, free upgrades, onboard credits and other perks.

title: Genocides Many Horrors, With a Romantic Subplot
description: Jasmina, a political refugee, is definitely coming on to her lawyer. Then she demonstrates her tender feelings by buying him a gift: a book about genocide grave sites.

title: Air Force Reserve Ad Angers White Stripes
description: In song, at least, the band the White Stripes has boasted that it can hold off a seven-nation army. But it is taking on an entire branch of the United States armed forces, contending that one of the bands songs was misused in a commercial shown in some markets during the Super Bowl. At issue is a commercial for the Air Force Reserve, set to an instrumental track that the White Stripes say is an unauthorized version of their song Fell in Love With a Girl. At the Web site of its record label, Third Man Records (thirdmanrecords.com), the band juxtaposed the video for that song with a link to the commercial, inviting listeners to judge for themselves. In a statement posted Monday evening, the White Stripes wrote: We believe our song was re-recorded and used without permission of the White Stripes, our publishers, label or management. The White Stripes take strong insult and objection to the Air Force Reserve presenting this advertisement with the implication that we licensed one of our songs to encourage recruitment during a war that we do not support. The Air Force Reserve said in a statement that its ad agency, Blaine Warren Advertising, had hired Fast Forward Music of Salt Lake City to score original music for its commercial and that there was never any intention to utilize any existing music or to sound like any music by the band White Stripes or any other musical performer. Any similarity or likeness to any other music is completely unintentional.

title: Performers Named for Bonnaroo Festival
description: Coming to the Bonnaroo mud this summer: Dave Matthews Band, Jay-Z, Weezer, John Fogerty, LCD Soundsystem, Jeff Beck and the Flaming Lips playing Pink Floyds Dark Side of the Moon. They, along with the Dead Weather, Phoenix, the Zac Brown Band, the National, Steve Martin, Kris Kristofferson, the Melvins and about 100 others, including, clockwise from top left, Stevie Wonder, Norah Jones, Kings of Leon, and Regina Spektor, are booked for the ninth annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival. The event is scheduled for June 10 to 13 at its regular home, a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn. Most peculiar pairing so far: Daryl Hall with the hipster party rockers Chromeo. (Their common denominator: 1980s pop.) Most prominent success story: Kings of Leon, who, according to the festivals announcement, are the first band to work its way up from a tent stage to a headlining slot. Full schedule and ticket information: bonnaroo.com.

title: 24 Film in the Works
description: Question No. 1: Will it be 24 hours long? Question No. 2: Will it still have short breaks roughly every 15 minutes so that its viewers  and, presumably, its protagonist  can go to the bathroom? Fans of the Fox action series 24 may soon learn the answer to these and other pressing questions now that a film version of the television show is in the works. Variety reported that the motion-picture division of 20th Century Fox had hired the screenwriter Billy Ray (State of Play, Shattered Glass) to write a script for a movie-length adventure for Jack Bauer, the secret agent (played by Kiefer Sutherland, above) whose world-saving exploits always take exactly one day to unfold. 24 is now in its eighth season on Fox, which has not yet ordered a ninth season of the show; Variety said that a movie could be put on hold if the Fox network passes on the series.

title: CBS Comedies Win
description: The comedy lineup on CBS led Monday nights ratings as Two and Half Men delivered the evenings largest audience with 17.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox placed second with House (13.5 million) and 24 (10.2 million). ABC finished close behind in third as The Bachelor (12.3 million) delivered another season high, marking the fifth consecutive week that shows audience has grown. NBC ranked a distant fourth.

title: Mcsweeneys Namesake, an Artist, Dies
description: Timothy McSweeney, who inadvertently donated his name to the San Francisco publishing venture founded by the novelist Dave Eggers, died on Jan. 24. Mr. McSweeney, 67, was a painter who fell victim to alcoholism and mental illness and spent much of his later life in hospitals. The death was disclosed on the McSweeneys Web site, mcsweeneys.net. Mr. McSweeney began writing letters to Mr. Eggers, then a boy, and his mother, whose maiden name was McSweeney, believing they were all related. Mr. Eggers did not know whether someone named Timothy McSweeney actually existed but was fascinated by the mystery of those letters, and the feeling stayed palpable enough that in 1998 he named his new literary journal Timothy McSweeneys Quarterly Concern. Since then Mr. Eggerss enterprise has grown to be a publisher of books, magazines and online content in addition to the original journal, known collectively as McSweeneys. A few years after the journal began, a young man, Ross McSweeney, came to work for Mr. Eggers as an intern. He turned out to be Timothys nephew. Knowing that the journal bore the name of a real person who had endured years of struggle threw melancholy shadows over the enterprise, Mr. Eggers wrote on the McSweeneys site. But the McSweeneys insisted that the use of the name was acceptable, even appropriate, given Timothys background as an artist and search for connection and meaning through the written word. Since 2000 weve implicitly dedicated all issues to the real Timothy.

title: Arts Foundation Resumes Grants
description: The Judith Rothschild Foundation has begun to pay at least some of the grant money it promised to 17 arts groups last year. Im glad I got it because it pays for the catalog and some printing costs, said Natalie Edgar, the director of the Philip Pavia Trust in New York, which had been awarded $7,000 toward a book about the works of Mr. Pavia, a sculptor. Ms. Edgar was among those who had filed complaints with the New York State attorney generals office after failing to receive their grant money. Wendy Snyder, director of the Sam Glankoff Collection in New York, said she had received the $10,000 she had been promised toward the conservation of works on paper by Mr. Glankoff, a painter. The Drawing Center in New York has also received its grant of $7,000. Ms. Edgar said she received a handwritten note from Harvey S. Shipley Miller, the foundations sole trustee, apologizing for the delay. Mr. Miller said in January that he had been unable to pay the grants because he had had a serious accident. His attorney, Erik Stapper, did not respond to messages left at his office on Tuesday. The foundation was established 15 years ago under the terms of the will of the abstract painter Judith Rothschild who died in 1993.

title: Sales Slip for Musicals
description: The Broadway production of Hair, which won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, dipped below the $500,000 mark in box-office grosses last week for the first time since opening last March. It was one of several shows with declining ticket sales during the usual midwinter doldrums on Broadway. In the Heights, the 2008 Tony winner for best musical, has also been sliding recently  its grosses were only 39 percent of the possible maximum last week, compared to 81 percent during New Years week  but it has a cash advance of $2.7 million and another $1 million in group reservations, said the producer Jeffrey Seller. In the Heights was one of five major musicals  along with Fela!, Memphis, Next to Normal and South Pacific  that had declines of 10 percent or more in their grosses last week, though a cold snap and Super Bowl Sunday were probably factors. While Rialto gossip has speculated about finances for Hair, the show has already recouped and has a $2.5 million advance with tickets on sale through Labor Day, said Jeffrey Richards, one of the lead producers. Hair is also close to signing new leads, and is hoping to get a box-office boost by hiring the former American Idol sensation Ace Young to play Berger. Berger is now played by Will Swenson, who is opening the London production of Hair next month with other members of the original Broadway cast.

title: Hair in Good Shape Despite Box Office Dip, Producer Says
description: Jeffrey Richards, one of the lead producers of the Broadway musical revival Hair, said in an interview Tuesday afternoon that he was pleased with the shows financial shape, disclosing that it has never had a losing week at the box office since opening in March.

title: Hoofing It | Clogs on the Runway
description: Once reserved for nurses and vegans, clogs were seen stomping all over the spring runways. For Chanel, it was Green Acres complete with aprons, flower baskets and hopsack clogs with bold CCs  a nod to the thick-soled footwear favored by Dutch and Swedish farmers. Marc Jacobs outfitted his sportier, colorful clogs with kitten heels, tassels and a mustache-like fur. (A buxom Lara Stone wears them in the new Louis Vuitton ad campaign; she is surrounded by moss, trees and white doves in a bucolic scene of innocence and luxury.) Meanwhile, Miu Miu took clogs the 70s route with huge platforms and kitschy prints of dogs, birds and daises.

title: Musician Apologizes for Advertising Track That Upset the White Stripes
description: The composer of an instrumental track used in a Super Bowl commercial for the Air Force Reserve, and which the White Stripes said was an unauthorized copy of their song Fell in Love With a Girl, apologized to the band and said that the similarities between his composition and the bands song were coincidental.

title: An Interview With Ai Weiwei
description: Ai Weiwei, a prominent artist and friend of political dissident Tan Zuoren, speaks about a police raid in the city of Chengdu in response to Mr. Tan's criticism of the government following the 2008 earthquake.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: WALLINGFORD, PA.

title: More Charges Filed Against Rajaratnam
description: Federal prosecutors brought new charges against Raj Rajaratnam in the Galleon Group insider trading case on Tuesday, expanding the number of stocks that they say were traded based on inside information.

title: Bad Blake, Post-Modernist Country Crooner?
description: To the surprising list of people who benefit from Oscar nominations  stylists, make-up artists, awards consultants, bloggers  lets add Thomas Cobb, author. Mr. Cobb, 62, wrote the novel Crazy Heart, which was the basis of the movie thats meant to give Jeff Bridges his long-overdue Academy Award. First published 23 years ago, the book was well received but sold only about 11,000 copies; re-released on Feb. 2 by HarperCollins  complete with photo of Mr. Bridges on the cover  it has already racked up five times that in sales and pre-orders. The film, too, has received more of an Oscar box office boost than its fellow nominees, according to The Los Angeles Times.

title: Campaign Against Obesity
description: Michelle Obama kicked off a sweeping initiative today aimed at reshaping the diet and exercise habits of American children.  (Video: MSNBC)

title: Where to Find Free Wi-Fi at the Airport
description: Before heading out to the airport for your next trip  especially during the next few weeks, when there are bound to be plenty of winter-related weather delays and thus plenty of time to kill  you may want to check out the travel site Jaunted, which has a constantly updated map of which airports offer free Wi-Fi service.

title: Airgas Formally Rejects Air Products Bid
description: Airgas on Tuesday formally rejected a $5.1 billion takeover offer from its rival, Air Products and Chemicals, saying the proposal significantly undervalues the industrial gases company.

title: Properties for $500,000
description: A home in Wallingford, Pa., and an adobe in Albuquerque.

title: Friends for Whom Space Was the Place
description: Despite an extreme difference in artistic styles, the New York painters Philip Pearlstein and Al Held were friends for nearly 50 years. A fascinating show that pairs examples of their work from five decades suggests at least one idea why. Both artists were obsessed with pictorial space, the visual illusion that could be created on a flat canvas.

title: In Albany, a Rumor of a Rumor Catches Fire
description: Albany  long a place of scandal, the rumor of scandal and the echoing talk about the rumor of scandal  has had a week a bit unlike any other. Newspapers, blogs, reputable outfits and fringe gossip sites have worked themselves into a frenzy about a purported article in The New York Times that would be so scandalous as to compel Gov. David A. Paterson to resign.

title: Feinstein Blasts Calif. Insurer Over Rate Increase
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, sharply criticized Anthem Blue Cross of California on Tuesday over its plans to raise health insurance premiums by as much as 39 percent, and she said that the move provided a vivid example of why major health care legislation is needed.

title: A Studio Head Slowly Alters the Warner Way
description: LOS ANGELES  Jeff Robinov, president of the Warner Brothers Pictures Group, arrived at the fashionable Tower Bar here on a recent weekend. Other members of Hollywoods A-list were quickly ushered to tables in the dining room, but Mr. Robinov had to wait  and wait. He finally ordered off the bar menu.

title: Genealogy for a Nation of Immigrants
description: Eva Longoria and Yo-Yo Ma have a common ancestor.

title: Job Openings Still Scarce
description: While layoffs have been declining, companies are still reluctant to hire, a new report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows.

title: Fraunces Tavern to Close Briefly
description: Fraunces Tavern, which has been serving up food and drink on and off since the early 1760s, is about to go dark yet again, albeit briefly, according to the owners of the complex, which includes the restaurant and an associated museum.

title: Where Produce Is Scarce, Supermarkets Will Grow
description: In Randys Grocery, the small bodega above the Tremont Avenue subway station in the Bronx, the fresh produce pickings are slim. A dozen shriveled green peppers and a tray of limes and tomatoes sit under a dimly lighted glass counter next to a crate of browning bananas.

title: Like an Early Christmas, and Just as Welcome
description: The call was made during English class.

title: Room for Schwarzenegger in Torch Relay
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Olympic organizers invited Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California to carry the torch on Friday as it makes its way to the opening ceremony that night. He appealed to Olympic officials for this role, they said, because of his concern for the environment and his relationship with British Columbia. His use of steroids in building his iconic persona as a champion bodybuilder was apparently no concern.

title: Hitting Broadway, Punching and Slapping
description: LOSING control and making it seem real is one of the most difficult challenges an actor can face. Those who succeed are generally seasoned artists like Geoffrey Rush, who portrayed the traumatized pianist in the film Shine or Vanessa Redgrave, who played the morphine-addicted mother in the 2003 Broadway revival of Long Days Journey into Night. Children, lacking both life experience and training, can have a harder time  which is why the role of Helen Keller, the blind and deaf 6-year-old-turning-7-year-old at the heart of William Gibsons play The Miracle Worker, is one of the most difficult in drama; the character must be chiefly expressed through physical action.

title: A Calculus of Writing, Applied to a Classic
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Zachary Masons critically praised first novel comes with a largely self-explanatory title: The Lost Books of the Odyssey purports to be a compilation of 44 alternate versions of Homers epic. What that title cannot possibly convey, though, is the unusual journey of Mr. Masons manuscript on its way to publication by Farrar, Straus & Giroux last week.

title: Unorthodox
description: When it comes to sex and reproduction, mammals are ultra-orthodox and, frankly, rather dull. Individuals are either male or female, no one changes sex and there are never more than two sexes in a species. No mammal reproduces asexually  by budding off a small piece of itself, say, or by splitting down the middle and growing a new individual from each half. Nope: among mammals, offspring are always produced by sex. That is, an egg fuses with a sperm to produce a child that is genetically distinct from both parents.

title: Honda Expands Air Bag Recall to 378,000 More Cars
description: Honda is recalling 378,000 additional vehicles because the drivers side air bag may deploy too forcefully, causing an injury or death. The company had announced the recall of 440,000 vehicles for that reason last year.

title: A Rising Directors Medium-Security Side Project
description: AT 31, Arin Arbus, the associate artistic director of Theater for a New Audience, is already something of an Off Broadway luminary. She made her Off Broadway directing debut last year with a critically acclaimed production of Othello, which the theater plans to revive commercially next season. And her latest production, Measure for Measure, which features Jefferson Mays, Rocco Sisto and Elisabeth Waterston, opens at the Duke on Sunday.

title: Is Manned Spaceflight Obsolete?
description: The Obama administration has scrapped NASAs plan to return humans to the Moon by 2020, which was behind schedule because of technical and budgetary problems. Instead, the administration will focus on  developing new technologies to make long-distance space travel cheaper and faster, with astronaut trips to the Moon, asteroids and Mars possible in the future.

title: Goodluck Jonathan Addresses Nigeria
description: As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports, on Tuesday Nigerias National Assembly made Vice President Goodluck Jonathan the countrys acting president, in the absence of President Umaru YarAdua, who left the country for medical treatment in Saudi Arabia in November.

title: Death of Kerrigans Father Ruled Homicide
description: BOSTON  The death of the father of the former Olympic figure skater Nancy Kerrigan has been ruled a homicide, the office of the states chief medical examiner said Tuesday.

title: A Nice Guy in a Perfect Baseball World
description: In his 1979 movie, Manhattan, Woody Allen made a list of the things that make life worth living. At the top sat Groucho Marx. But just behind Groucho  and before the second movement of Mozarts Jupiter Symphony, Louis Armstrongs recording of Potato Head Blues and those incredible apples and pears by Czanne  came Willie Mays.

title: Willie Mays
description: Prologue

title: Pakistan Is Said to Pursue Role in U.S.-Afghan Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan has told the United States it wants a central role in resolving the Afghan war and has offered to mediate with Taliban factions who use its territory and have long served as its allies, American and Pakistani officials said.

title: Novi-wha?
description: This weeks restaurant review is of Novit, an Italian trattoria on East 22nd Street thats been around for a long time, a neighborhood favorite that operates under the radar. Its a very good restaurant. And there are many of those in New York, restaurants that dont receive regular attention in magazines, newspapers or blogs. Tell us about your favorite, below.

title: Jobs Bill Is Sidetracked by Snowstorm
description: With snow quickly accumulating around the Capitol again Tuesday night, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, gave up on his hope of advancing a jobs-creating bill by the end of this week.

title: Canadas Medal Quest: Gold, and Lots of It
description: No Canadian has ever won an Olympic gold medal on home soil, not even at the Winter Games, where one would think Canadians might have a bit of an advantage. But all that may be about to change if the organizers of the Vancouver Games, which begin Friday, have their way.

title: As Champions March In, Their City Parties Harder
description: NEW ORLEANS  This citys two simultaneous parties  Mardi Gras season and the unending Saints Super Bowl victory celebration  came together in one big blowout Tuesday evening as the returning football champions paraded through the downtown streets amid an ecstatic, swaying throng of black and gold.

title: Philosopher Left to Muse on Ridicule Over a Hoax
description: PARIS  For the debut of his latest weighty title, On War in Philosophy, the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Lvy made the glossy spreads of French magazines with his trademark panache: crisp, unbuttoned white Charvet shirts, golden tan and a windswept silvery mane of hair.

title: Virgil Strikes Back
description: Theres a scene in David Maloufs Ransom  a novel based mainly on Homers Iliad  in which King Priam of Troy is slaughtered by Neoptolemus, the son of the Greek hero Achilles. That episode, which is not described in the Iliad, ultimately derives from a lost archaic Greek epic, the Iliou Persis, or Sack of Troy. But the best-known surviving version of the death of Priam appears in the second book of Virgils Aeneid, and Latinists took me to task for not mentioning it in my review of Ransom published in the Book Review last month.

title: Rothschild to Appoint First Non-Family C.E.O.
description: For centuries, Rothschild was led by scions of its eponymous founding dynasty, members of perhaps the most gilded clan in global finance.

title: Councilman Charged With Money Laundering
description: City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, a fixture in Bronx Democratic politics for more than two decades, was charged on Tuesday with money laundering, extortion and fraud in a series of schemes that included helping a close associate win a contract to install boilers in the new Yankee Stadium and siphoning hundreds of thousands of dollars in city money to himself, friends and family members.

title: A Court Date After a Kiss, and Chaos, at Newark
description: Take away the first word in their names and there are not many similarities between Newark Liberty International Airport and Newark Municipal Court. One of them sends airplanes all over the planet. The other is a few blocks from a business that calls itself New Jerseys largest pawn broker. Amelia Earhart led the dedication of the first terminal at one of them. People fight tickets for illegal dumping and peddling at the other.

title: Baseball Considers Plan to Curtail Age Fraud
description: Major League Baseball is studying a series of initiatives, including the fingerprinting of youths under the age of 16, as it attempts to gain control of the age and identity problems it has encountered in signing players in the Dominican Republic, according to several people with knowledge of the situation.

title: Everything Is in Place in Vancouver, Except Snow
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The steady roar of a helicopter dumping snow on the Olympic snowboard halfpipe and a caravan of trucks hauling more snow from hundreds of miles away are creating a defining image of the Vancouver Games before the competitions even begin.

title: Mets Make Minor Change to Center Field Wall
description: The Mets have seemingly made more changes to Citi Field this off-season than to their roster. All were cosmetic  think more blue and orange in and around the ballpark  but none were about to affect the course of a game. At least until Tuesday, when it was revealed that the Mets will chop in half the 16-foot wall that shields a sliver of straightaway center field  otherwise known as the area that houses the Home Run Apple. When the Mets begin the 2010 season April 5 against Florida, that fence, 408 feet from home plate, will stand 8 feet high. The modification was first reported by The Daily News.

title: Passing the Torch: An Evolution of Form
description: A collection of Olympic torches from 1936 to today.

title: Do You Believe in Comebacks?
description: This week is the fourth anniversary of one of the weirdest trades in sports history.

title: Trail of Disquieting Reports From Hospitals of Select Medical
description: Some of the most worrisome reports about Select Medicals hospitals are largely hidden from the public.

title: Long-Term Care Hospitals Face Little Scrutiny
description: No one at the hospital noticed that Tina Bell-Jackman was dying.

title: Northeast China Branches Out in Flushing
description: CHINESE cuisine has eight great traditions, including Cantonese, Sichuanese, Hunanese. Dongbei cai, or the food of the Northeast, is not among them.

title: U.S. Eyes New Sanctions Over Iran Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is working on a series of sanctions that would take aim at the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps of Iran, publicly singling out the organizations vast array of companies, banks and other entities in an effort to curb Tehrans nuclear ambitions.

title: F.D.A. to Increase Oversight of Medical Radiation
description: The federal Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it would take steps to more stringently regulate three of the most potent forms of medical radiation, including increasingly popular CT scans, some of which deliver the radiation equivalent of 400 chest X-rays.

title: Kings of Leon, Jay-Z and Stevie Wonder on the Bill for Bonnaroo
description: Coming to the Bonnaroo mud this summer: Stevie Wonder, Dave Matthews Band, Kings of Leon, Jay-Z, Weezer, John Fogerty, Norah Jones, LCD Soundsystem, Jeff Beck and the Flaming Lips playing Pink Floyds Dark Side of the Moon. They, along with Regina Spektor, the Dead Weather, Phoenix, the Zac Brown Band, the National, Steve Martin, Kris Kristofferson, the Melvins and about 100 others, are booked for the ninth annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, scheduled for June 10 to June 13 at its regular home, a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn.

title: Clamping Down on the Kaleidoscope of Rios Beaches
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Luis Fernando Bensimon beamed as he looked away from the crystalline waters of Rios famed Ipanema Beach, away from the beautiful bodies perfecting their caramel-mocha tans just days before the city explodes with its annual Carnaval celebration.

title: The Chef Enters, Center Stage
description: STANDING at the brink of the rude trench where his 60-foot-by-25-foot show kitchen will gleam someday, Jonathan Benno studied an oddly twisting raw-concrete space littered with construction junk. Two captive pigeons flapped noisily indoors among the fireproofed steel beams.

title: Canadian Luge Gets Offer It Cant Refuse
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Just a year ago, members of the Canadian national luge team wore For Sale decals on their helmets to attract corporate sponsors.

title: A Viagra Alternative to Serve by Candlelight
description: COUPLES hoping to bring Valentines Day dinner to a satisfying conclusion may be tempted by the special menu offered by One if by Land, Two if by Sea in Manhattan and, in particular, the Black Forest dessert. Its a chocolate pistachio brownie bar with chocolate meringue sticks, crme frache ice cream, cherry gel and sweet cherries. But beware! One study found that the scent of cherries significantly decreases sexual arousal in women.

title: China Passes Germany as Worlds Top Exporter
description: HONG KONG  China announced late Wednesday morning that its exports climbed 21 percent in January from a year earlier, while imports surged 85.5 percent. It was the latest sign that world trade is starting to recover from the financial crisis.

title: Chanterelle Sells Its Art  la Carte
description: IF you dined at Chanterelle during its three-decade run, before opening the menu to contemplate its offerings you very likely paused to contemplate the menu itself.

title: Small Step in Irans Nuclear Effort Suggests Ambitions for a Weapon, Experts Say
description: Irans stated intention to enrich uranium to higher levels is in one sense another incremental act of brinkmanship in a standoff with the West. But nuclear specialists say it also suggests that the country is striving to make real technical progress toward producing a bomb.

title: For Hughes, Gold Medal Never Trumped Family Life
description: Sarah Hughes rarely looks at the video of her marvelous four minutes. She does not have to. It was implanted in her mind, a permanent chip that contains the crowds reaction to her near perfection.

title: Crispy Lamb With Cumin, Scallions and Red Chilies
description: Adapted from Northeast Taste

title: Novit
description: NOVIT is a designer shoe box of a restaurant around the corner from Gramercy Park, a basement room on East 22nd Street, a perfect neighborhood trattoria.

title: With Buzz, Google Plunges Into Social Networking
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google and Facebook are on a collision course in the increasingly competitive market for social networking services.

title: Carolina-Duke Reflects a Changing Landscape
description: The annual matchups between North Carolina and Duke serve as mile markers during the mens college basketball season.

title: Knicks Lose the Game and the Crowd
description: The malaise that has gripped the Knicks for the last six weeks might have finally claimed their last shred of hope  for a revival, for a playoff berth, for anything positive to come of this season.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Dipped in Chocolate

title: In India, Many Top Athletes Work on the Railroad
description: NEW DELHI  Cricket is a national obsession in India. Its stars dominate the headlines and devour almost all the sponsorship deals. Aspiring Olympians can find financial support harder to come by.

title: Papaye
description: FINGER FOOD at the Ghanaian restaurant Papaye may challenge your expectations as well as your dexterity, but it can be deeply satisfying.

title: For St. Johns, Detours on a Long Road Back
description: Some of the legends from St. Johns journey to the national semifinals in 1985 will step off the history pages and onto the court at Madison Square Garden during halftime of the Red Storms game against Louisville on Thursday night. Lou Carnesecca, Chris Mullin and Bill Wennington are among those expected for the 25th anniversary celebration.

title: Rules Are Bent a Little, and Olympic Torch Visits the U.S.
description: PEACE ARCH STATE PARK, Wash.  The Olympic torch has spent the past four months touring North America, spanning its coasts, crossing its heartland and scaling its mountains in a 28,000-mile route to the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: Listen to the Iranian People
description: Thursday promises to be another dramatic day in Iran, and to lift hopes here in the West. Its the 31st anniversary of the 1979 revolution, and opposition leaders have scheduled rallies of the sort that the increasingly repressive government has had trouble gracefully repressing. As we watch reformers once again face off against the black-clad motorcycle-riding Basij militia, it will be tempting to hope that maybe, somehow, the good guys will win this time; and with a new, liberal regime ascendant, maybe the Iran problem  in particular, the nuclear standoff, which took a turn for the worse this week  can at last be solved.

title: Mets Start Tutoring Session at First
description: Given their many question marks these days, the Mets might wish that Keith Hernandez could suit up again in orange and blue. Alas, Hernandez now spends his days in the television booth, writing books and shuttling between his homes in Florida and Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Foolproof? No, but I.O.C. Is Confident in Antidoping System
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A team of nearly three dozen scientists assembled by the International Olympic Committee will conduct more than 2,000 doping tests on athletes competing at the Vancouver Games. But I.O.C. officials say athletes who cheat still might get away with it  at least for a while.

title: Lenos Last 10 P.M. Monologue
description: Jay Leno closed the least successful chapter of his long comedy career Tuesday night  a rather abrupt midweek stop to what had been trumpeted as a new paradigm for prime-time television. Instead the show lasted only five months, cut short by ratings deemed unacceptable by NBCs affiliated stations, which saw their late local newscasts damaged by low lead-in audiences from Mr. Leno.

title: Making the Rounds With a New Grater
description: What goes around comes around in more ways than one. Microplane, the company that added slender ultra-sharp vertical graters to kitchens years ago, now has a rotary grater for hard cheeses.

title: A Menu of Meatballs
description: Its no stretch to go from burgers to meatballs, which is what two young chefs have done with their singularly focused storefront cafe, Meatball Shop.

title: Let Them Eat Cake (Theres a Prize Inside)
description: Along with gumbo and jambalaya, a New Orleans-style Mardi Gras celebration requires a king cake. Like the galette des rois, a European pastry thats usually served on Epiphany, it has a lucky charm baked inside.

title: Sauerkraut With a French Twist
description: Sauerkraut has personality to spare on its own, but it also benefits from additions like wine, spices and fat. A collection of artfully seasoned sauerkrauts from Andr Laurent, a company in the Champagne region of France, has landed at Fairway.

title: Europe Watches as Portugals Economy Struggles
description: LISBON  Along the hilly, cobbled streets of this moody Atlantic city, known for its melancholy even in good times, people seem to be holding their breath, unsure if Portugals foundering economy will improve  or worsen, and weaken Europes overall financial health.

title: Safety Agency Scrutinized as Toyota Recall Grows
description: In November, top auto safety officials made an unusual request of Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood. After reviewing complaints about Toyota vehicles, the regulators said they believed the automaker was stalling their inquiries and wanted to go to Japan to stress just how serious their concerns had become.

title: Duke-Carolina Is at Head of Rivalry Class
description: College basketball has some wonderful rivalries.

title: Two Parties Join Together, Then Resume Divided Ways
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Republican leaders, each eager to show they can put aside partisanship, agreed Wednesday that they had pinpointed a handful of areas  most of them related to jobs creation  where the two sides might be able to work together.

title: 1 Across: Tasseled Topper
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Love is just a four-letter word. So says Bob Dylan, Joan Baez and todays puzzle. In the case of Ed Sessas theme, however, a little decoding is required.

title: Airgas Rejects Takeover Bid From Its Rival, Air Products
description: Airgas, the industrial gases company, formally rejected a $5.1 billion takeover offer from its rival, Air Products and Chemicals, on Tuesday saying the proposal significantly undervalues the company.

title: Buon Appetito
description: Sam Sifton is blowing the cover on Novit. The perfect neighborhood trattoria on the corner of Gramercy Park would sit atop of the heap in many other cities, but, thanks to the surplus of great restaurants here, goes unnoticed in New York, that is, until now. The chef Marco Fregonese, who has been at the helm of Novit since it opened in 1994, has been steadily improving it since then, and his new, simpler approach is worth noting. Go for the pastas, which are just ridiculous: perfectly prepared, full of flavor, a rejoinder to low expectations. Try a plate of gramigna alla carbonara, for instance, thin strands of curled pasta with eggs, pecorino romano, guanciale and black pepper. It arrives on the table as a riot of simplicity, a four-member noise band. It is outstanding, firm and pliant, salty and sweet, slick and sticky and rich. The breaded baby eggplant baked with tomato, mozzarella and Parmesan is like something out of a Bensonhurst fever dream. Bring an appetite: You wont go away hungry from Novit ; the plates are food, not art.

title: All That Jazz
description: Why cant there be a new jazz trio that does it all  one thats flexible, intuitive and strategic, not lugubrious, arid or jammy-boring, and a repository of postwar piano-trio lessons, from Ahmad Jamal to free jazz and beyond? Well, there is, and it can, and it did. Ben Ratliffs enthusiastic words were inspired by Vijay Iyers trio and album Historicity, which topped Mr. Ratliffs list of best jazz albums of 2009. Mr. Iyer hasnt slowed down since then and his latest fusion project can be heard Wednesday at Harlem Stages. Holding It Down is a work in process by Mr. Iyer and the jazz poet Mike Ladd. It takes on the stress associated with race and war through music and draws from the poems and experiences of an African-American former Marine. It features the musicians and spoken-word artists Pamela Z, Guillermo E. Brown, Liberty Ellman and Okkyung Lee. A discussion of the evolving piece follows the show.

title: Baile!
description: The Flamenco Festival in New York doesnt officially begin until Thursday, but fans of the flamboyant Spanish art form can get an early taste tonight at the Guggenheim where Works & Process is presenting Dressed to Dance. The program, sponsored by the regional government of Madrid, features a performance/runway show with dancers dressed in historic costumes by Spanish artists including Pablo Picasso and Salvador Dal. The choreography is by Carlos Chamorro and the dancers include Roco Molina and Company, Manuel Lian, and others, who will also appear at City Center. The program begins at 9 p.m. with a pre-performance lecture at 8:30 p.m. by Roger Salas, a dance critic for El Pas and a Spanish dance and costume historian. Also check out the exhibition No Singing Allowed: Flamenco and Photography on view through April 1 at Aperture Gallery and Bookstore, which features images of flamenco on stage and off, some of them dating to the 19th century, and where as Alastair Macaulay writes, you see flamenco both as a source of pride and as a claim to fame.

title: Saints Go Marching In
description: The Saints' Super Bowl victory celebration and Mardi Gras season came together in one big blowout in New Orleans.

title: Leaks Trouble Nominees for Nuclear Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Tritium leaks like the one that threatens the future of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant are undermining confidence in other reactors around the country, three experts nominated by President Obama to join the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Tuesday at their confirmation hearing.

title: Finance Regulatory Chief in Britain Will Step Down
description: LONDON  Hector W. Sants, the chief executive of Britains financial services regulator, said Tuesday that he would leave the agency by the end of the summer.

title: The Politics of Fear
description: An election is coming, so the Republicans are trying to scare Americans by making it appear as if the Democrats dont care about catching or punishing terrorists.

title: Times Up
description: Over the last four years, the United Nations Security Council has repeatedly demanded that Iran stop producing nuclear fuel. Iran is still churning out enriched uranium and has now told United Nations inspectors that it is raising the level of enrichment  moving slightly closer to bomb-grade quality.

title: Medical Justice, West Texas-Style
description: A nurse is on trial in a West Texas criminal court after she submitted an unsigned complaint to a state medical board expressing concern about the quality of care provided by a doctor in the county hospital where she worked. The nurse, Anne Mitchell, has been accused of misuse of official information, a third-degree felony in Texas that carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine.

title: Hungry in America
description: More Americans are going hungry in hard times and are increasingly dependent on private charity, according to a new study by Feeding America, a national network of food banks. The study found that 37 million people  roughly one in eight Americans  had sought emergency food assistance from the network last year, a 46 percent increase from 2006.

title: Precious, in Black, White and Gray
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Grocers Be Allowed to Sell Wine in New York?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutting Defense Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: The Zero Parallax View
description: How much does Phil McNally love 3-D?

title: Its All About Schools
description: Sana, Yemen

title: Disorder Out of Chaos
description: Washington

title: More Troubles for Toyota
description: Adam Bryant, deputy business editor of The Times discusses Toyota's crisis and its latest recall, the Prius hybrid.

title: Canada Aims for Gold
description: The organizers of the Vancouver Games want to rewire the Canadian national mind-set and come away with not just a couple of golds but the most medals over all.

title: The Politics Behind a Downfall in Albany
description: ALBANY  Very last chair, back row, right-hand side, chamber of the New York State Senate.

title: Athletes in Low-Profile Sports Savor Spotlight
description: Most of the time, athletes who compete in low-profile Olympic sports pursue their passion with few perks. They work part-time jobs, borrow money from parents, and get used to traveling in coach class as they circle the globe attending international competitions.

title: Fed to Reveal Its Strategy for Raising Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, having survived a surprising challenge to his second term as Federal Reserve chairman, now faces the delicate task of beginning to pull the central bank out of its extraordinary effort to prop up the economy.

title: Judge Orders Galleon Defendants to Release Tapes
description: The defendants in the Galleon insider trading case were ordered Tuesday to provide more than 14,000 hours of conversations secretly taped by investigators to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Childhood Obesity Battle Is Taken Up by First Lady
description: WASHINGTON  The White House, led by Michelle Obama, announced a sweeping initiative on Tuesday aimed at revamping the way American children eat and play  reshaping school lunches, playgrounds and even medical checkups  with the goal of eliminating childhood obesity within a generation.

title: Calling a School Snow Day Against a Clear Blue Sky
description: The sun was shining brightly in a bluebird sky on Tuesday morning when the announcement landed like a single, early snowflake in e-mail in-boxes around the city. No school tomorrow. Snow!

title: Lottery Numbers
Stress Relief Online, Aromatherapy by Mail
description: ABOUT a decade ago, when Johnson & Johnson, whose baby products include powders, oils and diaper rash creams, was conducting focus groups, marketers noticed that mothers would bring up not just what to put on their babies skin, but also what got under their own.

title: Congress and Country: Behold the Differences
description: Members of the United States Congress do not look much like the public they are elected to represent.

title: Q&A With the Editor in Chief of CruiseCritic.com
description: Back in 1996, if you were going to pick someone to cover the cruise industry, you might not immediately have thought of Carolyn Spencer Brown. A cruise virgin, Ms. Brown got easily seasick and was dumfounded by things like preset dining times. She described her attitude back then as, "Frankly, it's not my style of travel."

title: Q&A With Carolyn Spencer Brown, Editor in Chief of CruiseCritic.com
description: Back in 1996, if you were going to pick someone to cover the cruise industry, you might not immediately have thought of Carolyn Spencer Brown. A cruise virgin, Ms. Brown got easily seasick and was dumfounded by things like preset dining times. She described her attitude back then as, Frankly, its not my style of travel.

title: Throwback Player, Robinho, Returns Home
description: The return home of Rbson de Souza, universally known as Robinho, and Roberto Carlos does not signify the end of an exodus of so many Brazilians  almost 900 every year  who fly away to make their fortunes in Europe, yet these are significant homecomings. Brazilian fans deserve to see their fine performers in the flesh, however fleeting these rare returns may be.

title: Arsonists Blamed for Series of Texas Church Fires
description: HOUSTON  Arsonists are to blame for a series of fires that has left at least seven churches in ruins in small East Texas towns over the last five weeks, federal investigators said Tuesday.

title: UBS Reports a Profit, but Clients Are Still Taking Out Cash
description: LONDON  UBS, the Swiss bank that became a symbol of ravages of the subprime crisis in Europe, failed to stem an outflow of client money even as it posted its first quarterly profit in more than a year on Tuesday.

title: Illegal Immigrant Population Drops
description: The number of illegal immigrants in the United States declined to 10.8 million in January 2009, a drop of one million since a peak in 2007, according to an estimate Tuesday by the Department of Homeland Security. Demographers said the figures, based on census data and the most recent estimate by the department, showed the largest two-year drop in the population of illegal immigrants since 1990, after which it began a period of rapid growth. Homeland Security Department researchers noted that the decline coincided with the recession, while Steven Camarota, a demographer at the Center for Immigration Studies in Washington, said that stepped-up enforcement was also a factor. About 62 percent of illegal immigrants are from Mexico, the report said.

title: New Hampshire: Dartmouth Resumes Student Loans
description: Two years after announcing that it was eliminating all loans from its financial-aid packages, Dartmouth College is re-instituting a loan requirement for many financial-aid recipients. Under the policy, which takes effect with the class entering in the fall of 2011, Dartmouth will expect financial-aid recipients from families with incomes above $75,000 to take out loans of $2,500 to $5,500. Williams College ended its no-loan guarantee last week.

title: No Cause Found for Cluster of Birth Defects
description: SAN FRANCISCO  State health officials said Tuesday that there was no evidence of a single cause for a series of birth defects in a central California farming town that is adjacent to the largest hazardous waste landfill in the West.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a deadly explosion at a power plant under construction in central Connecticut, and a second article in some editions about the effort to find out how many workers were on the job at the time of the explosion, misstated the age of one of the five people killed, Raymond Dobratz of Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 58, not 57.

title: Averbuch: Im Going to Portugal With U.S. Womens National Team
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, the Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team last week by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog before, during and after her trip to Portugal.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about successful emergency surgery performed on Nstor Kirchner, the former president of Argentina, misidentified the procedure he underwent. Doctors unclogged his right carotid artery, which carries blood from the aorta to the head; they did not perform heart surgery.

title:
Peril for Products
Tied to Mortgages
description: Investors in collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.s, were badly burned by increases in interest rates in 1994. Some of the factors are again present. Banks and other investors in the little-known trillion-dollar market could be set for a spill.

title: Frank Magid, Creator of Action News, Dies at 78
description: Frank N. Magid, a marketing consultant who was widely credited, for good or ill, with standardizing the face of local television news, introducing the fast-paced, user-friendly Action News format in markets nationwide, died on Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 78 and had homes in Santa Barbara; Cedar Rapids, Iowa; and Montana.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a survey that raised questions about the integrity of crime reduction statistics compiled by the New York Police Department referred incorrectly in some editions to sanctions by the current police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, for manipulation of the statistics. A police spokesman said Mr. Kelly had meted out discipline in 11 cases, 4 of which involved precinct commanders; not all 11 involved precinct commanders.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing accompanying the Big City column on Tuesday, about New Yorkers who gave away $100 in creative ways, referred imprecisely to the occupation of Helen Coster, one of the donors. She is a journalist at Forbes magazine, not Forbes.com

title: Ian Carmichael, Comic British Actor, Dies at 89
description: Ian Carmichael, a debonair actor who made a specialty of playing the well-meaning buffoon in British films of the 1950s and who went on to star on television as Bertie Wooster, P. G. Wodehouses oblivious twit, and Lord Peter Wimsey, Dorothy Sayerss aristocratic detective, died Friday at his home in Grosmont, in northern England. He was 89.

title: New York Senate Expels Monserrate Over Assault
description: ALBANY  The State Senate on Tuesday expelled a senator convicted of domestic assault, the first time in nearly a century that the Legislature has forced a member from office.

title: Corrections
description: The continuation of an article on Tuesday about the reaction of Georgetown, Ky., the home of a major Toyota plant, to the carmakers recent troubles reversed the second and third columns of type in some editions. A corrected version can be found at nytimes.com/business.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an effort by Oaklawn Park to bring together the female horses Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta in a race for the first time by offering a $5 million purse if they both compete in the Apple Blossom Invitational erroneously attributed a distinction to the $10 million Dubai World Cup. Depending on exchange rates, a few other races, in France, Australia and Japan, can be worth more than the proposed purse in the Apple Blossom; the Dubai World Cup is not the only race worth more.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the organist who entertains fans at New Jersey Devils home games at the Prudential Center in Newark misspelled the surname of the teams director of game presentation. He is Gene Szucs, not Szuch.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about Falling Awake referred imprecisely to the area of the Bronx where the Soundview neighborhood, a setting of the film, is located. While it is in the southeast part of the borough, it is not the South Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 29 about new restaurants in art museums referred incompletely to the title of an expandable wall sculpture by Liam Gillick in the Wright, a new restaurant at the Guggenheim Museum. While the work, created last year, has been informally referred to as The Horizon, its full title is The horizon produced by a factory once it had stopped producing views.

title: Revising Book on Disorders of the Mind
description: Far fewer children would get a diagnosis of bipolar disorder. Binge eating disorder and hypersexuality might become part of the everyday language. And the way many mental disorders are diagnosed and treated would be sharply revised.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Showcase: Coffin Nails
description: There are few wide-open frontiers in this city, but the streets have long given New Yorkers a little extra room to maneuver around social stricture. Streets are public, yet not really civic (as parks and plazas are). So, unless youre way out of line, no one is likely to challenge whatever it is you happen to be doing.

title: Rabbis in Training Receive Lessons in Real-Life Traumas
description: After four years of training, most rabbinical students can speak fluent Hebrew, give a passable exegesis on any Biblical passage and deliver a fine sermon.

title: Smaller Conferences, but Big Games
description: With teams in the Pacific-10 and Southeastern Conference having poor seasons, there has been plenty of speculation that six Atlantic 10 Conference teams could earn bids to the N.C.A.A. tournament. Four of them play Wednesday night.

title: Connecticut Town Chafes at Return to the Spotlight
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  There was the college-wide ban on students sidewalk scribblings, which set off a First Amendment debate at one of the countrys more progressive campuses. There was the faculty-led seminar, Pornography: Writing of Prostitutes, which raised questions over the role of sex in undergraduate curriculums.

title: Music That Changed History and Still Resonates
description: WASHINGTON  Half a dozen legislators sat a few feet away, under the crystal chandeliers of the East Room of the White House, as Bob Dylan sang The Times They Are A-Changin, poker-faced.

title: Experts for Defense in Police Brutality Case Say Evidence Is Not Consistent With Claims
description: Defense witnesses testifying in a police brutality trial said Tuesday that neither the hole in Michael Mineos boxer shorts nor his injuries were consistent with his claim of being sodomized by a police officers baton.

title: Word of the Day | torque
description: torque \tork\ noun

title: Room for the Motorless in a Chaotic Traffic Circle
description: Theyre called roundabouts in Britain and traffic circles or rotaries elsewhere. But whatever the name, they are so rare in New York City that when they do appear  in Brooklyns Grand Army Plaza, say, or Columbus Circle in Manhattan  some motorists may find them whimsical.

title: How G.O.P. Worker Got Bloomberg Money Is Investigated
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office is investigating the circumstances surrounding a $750,000 payment that ended up in the hands of a Republican political operative who helped with Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs campaign last year, a political insider with knowledge of the investigation said on Tuesday.

title: No Indictment for Jail Chaplain
description: A grand jury declined on Tuesday to indict a Muslim chaplain for the citys Department of Correction who was accused of trying to smuggle a pair of scissors and several metal blades into a Manhattan jail.

title: A Slow Reaction to Toyota Illustrates Gaps in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  The first problems with sticking accelerators in some Toyotas surfaced more than a year ago in Britain and Ireland. But it was only Friday, long after a global recall began, that the European Commission issued its first consumer alert.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, some copies last Wednesday omitted a line from an article about restaurants in Vancouver, British Columbia. The passage should have read: The most ravenous visitors to this marvelous, temperate city will begin their culinary touring almost from the moment they land at Vancouver International Airport on Sea Island in suburban Richmond, where a vast Asian enclave is growing. The complete article can be found at nytimes.com/2010/02/03/dining/03note.html?ref=dining.

title: Lost Watch: Claire, First Blood
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: News Quiz | February 10, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Temasek Said to Plan New Global Fund
description: Temasek Holdings, the sovereign wealth fund backed by the government of Singapore, has set up a global investment company run by Charles Ong, its chief strategist, which will concentrate on stocks and bonds.

title: Russia: Missile Defense Delaying Arms Talks, Top General Says
description: Gen. Nikolai Makarov, the chief of Russias general staff, said Tuesday that Russian discontent over the planned American missile defense system was holding up negotiations to replace the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, or Start. Despite official statements that the missile defense system will ensure our security, this is far from the truth, General Makarov, above, told Vesti, a television news channel. It is natural that we view this very negatively, because this to some extent can weaken our missile capability.

title: Russia: Cargo of Bear Paws Seized
description: In what Russian news agencies described as the largest such interdiction of its kind in recent years, Russian border guards seized 447 bear paws from a truck in the Jewish Autonomous Region, near the frontier with China, on Monday. Smuggling wildlife body parts for use in traditional Eastern medicine and cuisine is rampant along the border between China and Russia.

title: Fed to Reveal Its Strategy for Raising Interest Rates
description: Ben S. Bernanke, having survived a surprising challenge to his second term as Federal Reserve chairman, now faces the delicate task of beginning to pull the central bank out of its extraordinary effort to prop up the economy, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

title: Talk of Assistance for Greece Propels Markets
description: Hopes that the wealthy nations of Europe would come to the aid of Greece galvanized financial markets on Tuesday and, for a day at least, soothed fears that the economic troubles on the fringes of the Continent might spread, Javier C. Hernandez and Jack Ewing report in The New York Times.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Shootouts, the Russian Roulette of Hockey
description: Seven games on Tuesday night, and a depressing four of them end with bonus points awarded through shootouts. Its quite likely at least one teams regular-season fortune will be made or broken because of these postgame penalty-shot contests. Home teams listed first:

title: Investors Said to Pressure Morgan Stanley on Pay
description: Morgan Stanleys move to cut the firms pay ratio followed prodding by large investors who questioned the firms high pay levels, and the firm is preparing to take further steps to address shareholder concern, The Wall Street Journal Online reported on Tuesday.

title: Commonwealth Bank Reports Record Profit
description: Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the nations biggest lender, forecast strengthening demand for loans and fewer bad debts after posting record profit in its fiscal first half as the financial crisis abates, Bloomberg News reports.

title: iFollo, a Celebrity Site, Takes $1 Million
description: iFollo, a site that allows members to share stories about their celebrity encounters, has landed $1 million from Robert Trump, a real estate investor, PaidContent reported.

title: Twilight in Pictures
description: WHOM do you know who is a Twilight fan? WHO will print 350,000 copies of a graphic-novel adaptation of the book? WHO will illustrate it?

title: Goldman Said to Have Helped Greece Hide Debt
description: As Europe tries to resolve the problem of Greek deficits and debt before the struggling southern economy puts the euro in the tank, more shenanigans have come to light, and this time, they are said to involve Goldman Sachs.

title: On American Idol, the Ellen Era Begins
description: Even if American Idol ends this week, there will officially be an Ellen Era. In just one episode, the new judge Ellen DeGeneres displayed why its no stretch for her to step into Paula Abduls chair. She was witty both in her praise and her take-downs. So this is it, huh? she asked Simon Cowell. I come on, you leave. Its not as unfair a trade as it once seemed.

title: The Least-Trusted Banks in America
description: From our colleagues at Bucks:

title: DotNetNuke Nabs $8 Million
description: DotNetNuke, a developer of an open-source platform for building Web sites based on Microsoft, has landed $8 million.

title: How Would You Give Away $100?
description: Seeing How Far $100 Can Go describes a woman who decided to give some of her money away by handing nine thoughtful friends each $100 to then give away themselves. A month later, they all gathered to describe what they did and why. If you were one of these friends, what might you do with the money?

title: Solar Capital Shares Drop in Trading Debut
description: Shares of the investment company Solar Capital dropped in its market debut Tuesday after it raised less money than it had hoped for in a weak market for initial public offerings.

title: Nordea Reports Profit Drop for Quarter
description: Nordea Bank, the largest banking group in the Nordic region, reported a nearly 30 percent drop in fourth-quarter net profit on Wednesday, due mainly to rising costs and loan losses.

title: Myanmar Sentences American to Prison
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  A court in Myanmar sentenced an American citizen on Wednesday to five years in prison and hard labor on charges of carrying a forged identity card and two other offenses.

title: Graham Packaging Delays Pricing of I.P.O.
description: Blackstone Groups Graham Packaging has become the latest company to hit a snag on its way to an I.P.O.

title: Nasdaq Chief Says Congress Has to Find Different Path
description: The heads of the top U.S. stock exchanges have poured cold water on the Obama administrations plan to bar banks from proprietary trading, Reuters reported.

title: Toll Grows in Afghan Avalanche
description: SALANG PASS, Afghanistan  Rescuers atop this treacherous mountain pass dug through piles of snow on Wednesday to extract more bodies from cars, buses and trucks buried in snow as the death toll from possibly the worst series of avalanches in Afghanistans history climbed to 166. Officials are predicting that they will find more victims.

title: MetLife May Buy A.I.G. Unit With Stock and Cash
description: MetLife plans to pay the American International Group in stock and cash for its American Life Insurance unit, as the two sides negotiate what could be a roughly $15 billion deal, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter.

title: Hooters on the Block?
description: Hooters anyone?

title: A Big Tent, Moving On
description: Since 1993, the big tent in Bryant Park has changed the worlds perception of American fashion.

title: Micron Buys Numonyx for $1.27 Billion
description: Micron Technology announced late Tuesday that it was acquiring Numonyx Holdings in an all-stock deal worth about $1.27 billion, a move that may help it challenge Samsung and Toshiba.

title: Morningstar Buys Footnoted, a Research Blog
description: Morningstar, the financial research firm, has purchased Footnoted.org, a financial blog that digs through Securities and Exchange Commission filings to uncover buried news items.

title: Fashion Jury
description: Sitting in on the GQ contest for mens designers.

title: Fund in Talks to Sell Terminator Rights, Report Says
description: After a reportedly contentious auction for the Terminator movie franchise, the hedge fund that beat out Lionsgate and Sony to win the rights is now in discussions to sell them back to the two firms, The Los Angeles Times reported, citing people familiar with the process.

title: Obama Strikes Softer Note With Wall Street
description: President Obama took a more conciliatory stance toward the financial sector in an interview with Bloomberg BusinessWeek, saying he did not begrudge people success or wealth, as it was part of the free-market system.

title: Raw Onion for Saints Skeptics
description: With this headline, the Onion poked fun at N.F.L. analysts, Saints skeptics and stat-crunchers who cant be bothered to watch a game:

title: In Rome, Contemporary Art Times Five
description: At the moment, it might feel like Rome is swimming in contemporary art. Late last year saw the opening of the Zaha Hadid-designed Maxxi. And on Jan. 22, five new shows simultaneously opened at Macro, a contemporary art museum housed in a former brewery, where theyll be on view until April 5.

title: European Lawmakers Seek Clampdown on Speculators
description: European Union lawmakers are calling for a clampdown on speculators and short-selling ahead of a meeting next week between the E.U. financial markets chief, Michel Barnier, and E.U. finance ministers to discuss the issue.

title: Sick at Work
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Ex-Cadbury Chairman Calls for Takeover Protections
description: Roger Carr, chairman of Cadbury until the British confectioner was taken over by Kraft just weeks ago, said Tuesday that Great Britain needed to change its takeover rules to give companies at home more protections.

title: Portrait of Peyton Manning After Defeat
description: What was it like to be Peyton Manning in the moments after defeat? After losing a Super Bowl that many had conceded to him  then facing reporters who wanted to talk about the one thing he probably wanted to forget?

title: Small Earthquake Hits Near Chicago
description: A small earthquake in northern Illinois set off car alarms, knocked books off the shelves and jolted scores of people awake at 4 a.m. Wednesday, but otherwise caused no serious damage, officials said.

title: The Great Unemployment
description: Todays idea: The Great Recession may be over, but this era of high joblessness is probably just beginning, and its effects will be profound, an article says. Were looking at a recovery from which a generation of Americans will not soon recover.

title: European Fund Plan Seen Threatening Economy
description: The European Unions plans to regulate managers of hedge funds and other alternative investments need changing to avoid damaging Europes economy and curbing investor choice, a British parliamentary report said on Wednesday.

title: No Gold Rush for Paulsons Fund
description: It seems that investors arent convinced that John Paulson has the Midas touch. The hedge fund manager has been having a hard time getting investors to pony up for his gold fund, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Whole Wheat Muffins
description: Most muffins we see are a far cry from the harmless little tidbits they once were; now each one is about the size of half a pound cake, and just as sweet. The whole-wheat babies in this weeks Minimalist are different, and worth trying.

title: Parade? That Could Have Been the Vikings
description: What must Minnesota fans be thinking? The Vikings outgained and outmuscled the Saints in the N.F.C. title game, but made too many mistakes to capitalize.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Marisa Meltzer
description: Marisa Meltzer is the author of Girl Power: The Nineties Revolution in Music and a co-author of How Sassy Changed My Life.

title: Barclays Chief Tells Parliament That Rules Hurt Prosperity
description: John Varley, chief executive of Barclays, told the House of Commons Treasury Select Committee that certain regulations could hurt British consumers and the wider economy, The Telegraph reports.

title: Hillbilly Palm Pilot & Telepalmter
description: Aides-memoires written on the palm of ones hand.

title: Pull Up a Chair
description: and send us your snow pix,  using this form or e-mail by cell phone at pix@nyt.com.

title: Sampler: Brentwood Says No to Chickens, and Youll Need a Permit to Stand on Half Dome
description: Stanford to Cost More than $50,000 Annually | The cost of attending Stanford University next year will surpass $50,000 after the universitys Board of Trustees voted to approve a 3.5 percent tuition increase to $38,700. Room and board fees will also rise, by 3.6 percent, to $11,876. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: The Gloves Are Off
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: After a Slow Start, a Snowstorm That Exceeds Expectations
description: For all the warnings and the ominous-looking colors on the television weather maps, for all the jokes about a snowpocalypse, only light snow was falling when most New Yorkers turned out the lights and went to bed on Tuesday.

title: Editor Appeals Sentence in China
description: A literary editor sentenced by a Chinese court to five years in prison gave a defiant handwritten appeal to the court on Wednesday.

title: Shares Toss and Turn for Most of the Day
description: A heap of uncertainty greeted Wall Street on Wednesday, setting the stage for an up-and-down day that left investors searching for a sense of direction.

title: China Indicts Rio Tinto Staff on Bribery Charges
description: SHANGHAI  A Chinese prosecutor handed down indictments on Wednesday against an Australian citizen and three Chinese employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, charging them with accepting bribes and stealing trade secrets.

title: Fruit of Kaboom
description: Animation | Apparel quarrel in stop-motion (promotional credits at end):

title: Oaktrees Chairman Urges Faith  and Restraint
description: BERLIN  Howard Marks may be cautiously optimistic about the economic recovery, but he still warned fellow private equity executives to exercise restraint on leverage and to see the current market rally for what it is: cyclical.

title: Now Mapping | New York Fashion Week Highlights
description: View T Fashion Week Hot Spots in a larger map

title: Vestas Earnings Shy of Projections for 2009
description: In financial results released Wednesday, the worlds largest maker of wind turbines, Vestas of Denmark, reported that earnings for the 4th quarter 2009 exceeded expectations  though its $8.8 billion in revenues for the full year fell short of the $9.9 billion projected.

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Feb. 10
description: Highlights from media coverage in todays New York Times:

title: The Early Word: Snow Shutdown
description: Washington is pretty much shut down for the day,   again, but there will be signs of life at the White House and the Federal Reserve.

title: Studio Visit | George McCracken
description: After a few seasons of relatively quiet success, the mens-wear designer George McCracken will be showing for the first time during New York Fashion Week, this Thursday. A few days before the big debut, T stopped by his casting to preview the line and check out the models. Heres a sneak peak.

title: AOL Cracks Open AIMs Door and Lets in Facebook
description: AOL is finally opening up AOL Instant Messenger, its popular chat network.

title: Times Company Reports Profit for Quarter and Year
description: The New York Times Company stayed ahead of the continued decline in advertising with deep cost-cutting in the fourth quarter, the company reported on Wednesday, as it posted net income of $90.9 million, up from $27.6 million in the period a year earlier.

title: British Court Summary of Secret Documents Says U.S. Mistreated Detainee
description: Updated | 10:58 a.m. On Wednesday, the British government was forced to release a seven-paragraph summary of secret documents that were shared by American intelligence officials with their British counterparts. The documents detail the mistreatment of a British resident who had been subjected to extraordinary rendition by American authorities after his arrest in Pakistan in 2002. The summary, written by a British judge, concludes:

title: Extinct New York Taxis Ply London Streets
description: Clanking through the crowded city streets one recent afternoon, the old New York Checker cab provoked looks of disbelief, and not just because the well-loved, almost comically bulky car disappeared from commercial use long ago.

title: Alls Well That Ends Well
description: A look back at final words that will endure through the ages.

title: Asked & Answered | Kelly Cutrone
