description: When Kelly Cutrone moved to New York in the mid-80s, she didnt have much more than a nursing degree and a dauntless attitude. Today shes a scandalously outspoken publicist who reduces young girls to tears on shows like The City and The Hills. Her ruthless work ethic is the result of hard-learned lessons. In the mid-90s, she divorced her first husband, gave up half of her PR firm, tossed her party wigs and fled to Topanga, Calif., where she conquered her drug addiction and became a spiritual warrior. After reading tarot cards in Santa Monica and working for the Psychic Network, she gradually made her way back to PR.

title: A Small Bank Finds a Way to Make a Troubled Loan Program Work
description: Regular readers of this column know that The Agenda has followed closely the progress of the Americas Recovery Capital program, the business stabilization loan program created by the stimulus bill and carried out by the Small Business Administration. The news, in general, has not been good: relatively few banks find the loans profitable or otherwise worthwhile enough to embrace. Borrowers and bankers alike are finding that A.R.C. requires a lot of effort for not a lot of money.

title: Behind the Scenes: On the Road With a VJ
description: Reporter. Camera operator. Sound technician. Lighting technician. Writer. Narrator. Editor. Those arent seven jobs. Theyre one. Mine. Oh, yes, I also carry up to 100 pounds of gear. (Thats right: add Sherpa to the job description.) Im a VJ; a video journalist.

title: Latest Data Hints at a Recovery in World Trade
description: Export and import statistics released Wednesday for the United States and China offered the latest signs that world trade was starting to recover from the global financial crisis.

title: The Case of the Vanishing Unwelcome Mats
description: This is a now-you-see-it-now-you-dont story about something the size of a floor mat in a car. Except that it wasnt in a car; it was stuck to the sidewalk outside a subway station.

title: Renewables Industry Promotes Its Potential
description: Funds from the $787 billion stimulus package and other federal assistance kept growth in the renewable energy sector strong in 2009, a trend that will probably persist as federal investment continues to pay off over the coming year, industry leaders said in a teleconference Tuesday.

title: Iraqi Elections  The View From Kurdistan
description: ERBIL, Iraq  A senior Kurdish leader here told me recently that anyone who aspired to become the next prime minister of Iraq needed the blessing of the Kurds. He said it was a simple fact.

title: K.K.R. and Premier to Join for Energy Investments
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Wednesday that it was teaming up with Premier Natural Resources, a nearly four-year-old oil and gas investment firm, to look for new investment opportunities in North America.

title: Ferrari Prepares Hybrid for Geneva Auto Show
description: You dont buy a Ferrari expecting the latest in green technology, but there are signs of environmentally friendly evolution in Maranello.

title: Dental Malady Delays Lil Wayne Sentencing
description: It was the kind of tense courtroom scene that John Grisham would have wrestled Scott Turow to the ground for: a high-profile defendant. A long-anticipated sentencing. A judge ready to bang the gavel. And then: a three-week postponement for dental surgery.

title: The First Star: Q. and A. With Lars Anderson
description: Known as the Galloping Ghost, Red Grange was, in the Roaring Twenties, the first true superstar of professional football. In The First Star: Red Grange and the Barnstorming Tour That Launched the N.F.L., Lars Anderson, a writer for Sports Illustrated, recounts the story of how Grange, at the height of his popularity, dropped out of the University of Illinois and signed on to be the marquee player of George Halass cash-strapped Chicago Bears.

title: Around the World in 119 Days
description: It took Francis Drake almost three years to circumnavigate the globe, and its safe to say that the 16th-century voyage wasnt exactly a pleasant one. But times have changed. Next January, the Silver Spirit, the newest addition to the Silversea cruise line, will embark on a 119-day cruise hitting destinations around the world  and amenities on the 540-passenger ship will be decidedly more ambitious than on Drakes vessel.

title: Bernankes How-To on Rate Increase Lacks a When
description: WASHINGTON  At some point. At the appropriate time. When the time comes.

title: F1 Testing Begins Again  Sort Of
description: The long awaited look at the true strength of the major teams in Formula One will have to wait a little longer, as testing resumed in Spain today but under a steady drizzle of rain that made it impossible to see who looks strongest.

title: A Voting System to Dethrone the King
description: Two more Oscar prognosticators have taken a look at the Academy and found that this years race comes down to the voting processes. (If the Bagger were a different kind of blogger, we would say: TOLDJA.) At The New Yorker, Hendrik Hertzberg says that the new instant-runoff system might give The Hurt Locker a boost over its most likely competitor. Avatar is polarizing, he writes. So is James Cameron. He may have fattened the bank accounts of a sizable bloc of Academy members  some three thousand people drew Avatar paychecks  but that doesnt mean that they all long to recrown him king of the world. (As he has admitted, his people skills arent the best.) These factors could push Avatar toward the bottom of many a ranked-choice ballot.

title: Bernankes How-To on Rate Increase Lacks a When
description: At some point. At the appropriate time. When the time comes.

title: The Nifty 50 | Rashaad Newsome, Artist
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Spinning Wheels in Harlem
description: By 9 a.m., even the streets that were plowed retained a slick sheet of slushy icy cover that made driving treacherous. This was especially the case on sloping streets like the ascending stretch of Broadway just north of 125th Street.

title: FIA Clarification on Teams Participation
description: Yesterday I reported what Jean Todt and his spokesman had said during a meeting with the media in Paris concerning the right of Formula One teams to skip races. The two men had qualified what they said by saying that it was their understanding, but that they were not sure, that it was possible for the teams to skip up to three races and not be penalized. They said they would verify this and inform the media later. Somehow, some reports from that meeting came out saying this was in fact a fait accompli, that teams could skip up to three races. In fact, the FIA has just reported back to the media and will later publish the following statement:

title: Shin Injury Threatens Lindsey Vonns Quest
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Three times since early last week, alone with her husband and far from the crowds expecting an Olympic medal haul, the American skier Lindsey Vonn has stuck her right foot into her ski boot.

title: Tracking the Campaigns of 2010
description: A remarkable mid-term election campaign is under way, with Democrats fighting to hold their majorities in both chambers of Congress and keep governors seats across the country, while Republicans are seeking to upend the balance of power in Washington.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an earlier version of this article incorrectly stated quarterly per-share results as revenue rather than earnings.

title: Having It Both Ways on Medicare
description: One of the truly amazing things about the health care debate is the way Republicans have managed to pose as defenders of Medicare. The death panel thing has been absolutely central to their argument. For example, when I was debating Roger Ailes on This Week, his response to my Massachusetts comparison  that the Senate bill was basically the same as Romneycare  was to start blustering that Mitt Romney didnt slash Medicare benefits.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: South Park Episode Is Pulled in Mexico
description: If South Park teaches us nothing else, it shows how rigid broadcast standards are in countries outside the United States. Mexico has become the latest nation to pull a South Park episode from its airwaves, at least temporarily, The Associated Press reported. The episode, called Pinewood Derby, in which a traditional racing competition accidentally leads to the discovery of extraterrestrial life, caricatures numerous world leaders, including the British prime minister Gordon Brown, the Chinese president Hu Jintao, and Felipe Caldern, the president of Mexico. MTV, which was scheduled to broadcast the episode in Mexico on Monday, said it pulled the show not because it makes fun of Mr. Caldern, but because it depicts the Mexican flag. Mexican law says that its the flag and other national symbols must be treated respectfully. A spokesman for Mexicos interior ministry told The A.P. that it hadnt received a request from MTV for permission to broadcast the episode.

title: Britain Discloses Data on Ex-Detainee
description: LONDON  The British government lost a protracted court battle on Wednesday to protect secret American intelligence information about the treatment of a former Guantnamo Bay detainee, and immediately published details of what it called the cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment administered to the prisoner by American officials.

title: Clueless
description: Im with Simon Johnson here: how is it possible, at this late date, for Obama to be this clueless?

title: Share Your Snow Day With Us
description: So heres the deal, snow angels. We want to put together a running portrait of an enwhitened city today.

title: What Do Kids Really Think About Their Working Parents?
description: I will be chatting on blog radio this afternoon with Ellen Galinsky, president of the Families and Work Institute, and Joshua Coleman, author of The Marriage Makeover and The Lazy Husband. Hes also co-chairman of the Council on Contemporary Families as part of the Fem2.0 Wake Up! blog radio series that has been underway this week.

title: Some Car Buyers Are No Longer Considering Toyotas
description: As Toyota increases itsrecalls, a growing number of consumers are taking the carmakers vehicles off their shopping list.

title: Patient Voices: Tourette Syndrome
description: Sudden jerking movements, uncontrollable tics and strange vocalizations. Seven men and women talk about living with Tourettes syndrome.

title: 2009: A Banner Year for Bankruptcies
description: For bankruptcy and restructuring professionals, 2009  especially the first half of the year  could hardly have been busier.

title: Expansion of A.P. Tests Also Brings More Failures
description: The College Boards Advanced Placement program is expanding in American high schools, but as it moves from being a program primarily for elite students, the number of test-takers who fail A.P. exams is growing  although not as much as the number of those who pass.

title: A Calculated Move
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Did you see Sarah Palin at the Tea Party Convention on Saturday? Well, this is  Im starting to love her, really. She mocked President Obama for using a teleprompter and then, someone noticed she had notes written on her hand. And she had the words energy, budget, with the word cuts crossed off, tax, and lift American spirits written on her palm. It lifted my spirits, so  mission accomplished, I guess.

title: The Distracting Debate Over Climate Certainty
description: Anyone tracking the long fight over curbing greenhouse gases can see the tendency of the most passionate advocates on either side to try to build their cases around certainty.

title: Monthly Bipartisan Meeting
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: President Obama just held his first monthly bipartisan meeting and said that working together on jobs would be a good place to start. You know where else would have been a good place to start? A year ago.

title: Staying Sane During Snow Days
description: In an IM chat on Tuesday night, a friend declared: Snow days are so lame. We are having snow weeks.

title: Something That is Mighty Helpful
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: I started doing a little something that is mighty helpful. When I come out here to tell the jokes, I have them all written in the palm of my hand.

title: Stymied Projects: On the Map, and Under Scrutiny
description: Ever wonder about the status of a development project that seems to have stalled, or of a vacant lot that is threatening to become a permanent blight on your neighborhood?

title: Be Glad Youre Not Back East
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Jay Leno Show on NBC: Hey, be glad youre not back East. Huge snowstorms. I dont think Washington has seen a snow job like this since that last stimulus package.

title: Tempting Fate at the Winter Games
description: Every winters day, or so it seemed, brought a fresh report of an Olympic medal hopeful knocked out of contention for the Vancouver Games. From skiers to bobsledders, snowboarders to skaters, a startling number of athletes became part of an agony-of-defeat montage of injuries.

title: Valentines Day Across the Curriculum
description: Updated | Feb., 2017

title: Video of Rescue Effort in Afghanistan
description: As Americans joke about what to call the snowstorm that has blanketed the East Coast  Snowpocalypse or Snowmageddon  Afghans are racing to dig out survivors trapped in a series of deadly avalanches in the Salang Pass, north of the countrys capital, Kabul.

title: Outspoken Hurricane Expert Sues Over Dismissal
description: Last April, Ivor van Heerden, an internationally known hurricane expert, was told he was losing his job at Louisiana State University. He and other experts said it was because of his outspoken criticism of the federal governments flood protection of New Orleans; the university would not comment.

title: Good Wife Watch: A Homecoming of Sorts
description: Tuesday nights episode of The Good Wife, which ended with Alicias bad husband coming home from jail, felt like a season finale and it sort of was: This CBS series goes into repeats until March to avoid competition with the Olympics.

title: Airline Snowstorm Guide
description: Be sure to check with your airline before heading to the airport in the next few days.

title: Racing Fear and the Clock in the Downhill
description: Behold the downhill racer, the fearless daredevil oblivious to the dangers of skiing 80, if not 90, miles an hour.

title: Understanding the Tics of Tourettes
description: A stand-up comedian, a ventriloquist who performs for children and a high school sophomore are among the people who share their stories about living with Tourettes syndrome in the latest installment of Patient Voices. The often misunderstood condition can cause a range of tics, including sudden jerking movements, grunting, snorting and clearing the throat, which typically first appear during childhood.

title: Diamond Junk
description: CORRECTED at 4:40 p.m. See below for details.

title: Obama Says He Doesnt Begrudge Bank Executives Bonuses
description: President Obama channeled the anti-populist side of his character, telling Bloomberg/BusinessWeek in an interview on Tuesday that he didnt begrudge Wall Street executives their big bonuses.

title: New Knife Skills at Warner Brothers
description: The Baggers pal Brooks Barnes takes a close look at Warner Brothers, for many years the gold standard of Hollywood studios because of its corporate gentility and stability in an unstable business.

title: Private Equitys Tough Fund-Raising Test
description: Rhea Wessel for The New York Times Guy Hands of Terra Firma (left) and David Rubenstein of the Carlyle Group warn private equity colleagues that their investors are in control.

title: Viewing a College Through 3-D Lenses
description: More than two years before moviegoers would don 3-D glasses to watch Avatar on movie screens, administrators at Hobart and William Smith Colleges gathered to contemplate new ways to get the attention of 16- and 17-year-old potential applicants.

title: Google Set to Showcase Fast Internet
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Wednesday that it would offer ultrahigh-speed Internet access in some communities in a test that could showcase the kinds of things that would be possible if the United States had faster broadband networks.

title: Alameda Education Board Expected to Renew FAME Schools Charter
description: The FAME charter school in Fremont appears to be heading toward a five-year renewal of its charter in March, after the Alameda County Board of Education voted unanimously at a meeting on Tuesday to continue offering its provisional support.

title: Some Buyers Are No Longer Considering Toyotas
description: From our colleagues at the Bucks blog:

title: Longtime Michigan Congressman Retires
description: Representative Vernon Ehlers, a Michigan Republican who entered Congress in 1993, announced today that he would not seek re-election in November, making him the 17th Republican to decide not to run for the House again this year.

title: Do-It-Yourself Genetic Engineering
description: IT ALL STARTED with a brawny, tattooed building contractor with a passion for exotic animals. He was taking biology classes at City College of San Francisco, a two-year community college, and when students started meeting informally early last year to think up a project for a coming science competition, he told them that he thought it would be cool if they re-engineered cells from electric eels into a source of alternative energy. Eventually the students scaled down that idea into something more feasible, though you would be forgiven if it still sounded like science fiction to you: they would build an electrical battery powered by bacteria. This also entailed building the bacteria itself  redesigning a living organism, using the tools of a radical new realm of genetic engineering called synthetic biology.

title: Winter Games Rest on Vonns Tender Shin
description: First, we have a Winter Olympics with no snow (memo from New York: come take ours) and now we have a seriously dented cover girl, skier Lindsey Vonn. This is not a positive trajectory considering the Games havent even started yet. At this rate, the snowboard icon Shaun White will announce hes retiring to become a full-time Harry Potter impersonator and Sidney Crosby will declare its really not all THAT important for the Canadian mens hockey team to win a gold medal.

title: The Mets Are (Officially) Junk
description: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

title: A Snow Day for Grown-Ups
description: Katherine Brodie jumped up and down and high-fived her neighbor when she got an e-mail message on Tuesday afternoon granting her that rarest of respites, an adult snow day.

title: The Short Happy Fiction of John Hughes
description: When he died in August of a heart attack, the filmmaker John Hughes left behind a legacy of decade-defining 1980s teen comedies, from The Breakfast Club to Pretty in Pink to Sixteen Candles. But after a prolific screenwriting run that continued through the 1990s, Mr. Hughes had stopped submitting scripts to the studios by the early 2000s, and his output seemed to have slowed to a crawl.

title: The Insider | Daniel Peddle
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the casting director Daniel Peddle lets us in the back door on fashion week, street-level talent scouting and everything in between. Peddle began his modeling reconnaissance while a grad student at N.Y.U. film school, eventually founding his own agency. This season, he and his fellow scouts will discover the fresh faces for Givenchy Men, 3.1 Phillip Lim Men and Women, Ports 1961 and Chado Ralph Rucci. Peddle is a man with many hats (all fashionable) and next month, he will show a new series of paintings at the Envoy Gallery entitled, appropriately enough, Backstage.

title: When Defendants Speak Out, Problems Begin
description: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and follows them for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Suicide Attack Kills 17, Mostly Police, in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In one of the bloodiest days for Pakistani security forces, at least 17 people, including 13 police officials, were killed Wednesday when a suicide bomber attacked a convoy in the northwestern tribal area of Khyber, local news outlets reported.

title: Snowed In
description: David Brooks: Gail, there I was watching the snow drift down on the Brooks estate in suburban Maryland last Saturday, when suddenly, after some spluttering and coughing, I was without power. Now I know how the Republicans feel.

title: Indias Central Bank Stops Some PayPal Services
description: NEW DELHI  Thousands of small companies here are facing a cash crunch after Indias top bank regulator suspended some PayPal services in the country.

title: SXSW Announces Film Panels and Shorts
description: In March, Quentin Tarantino will again be dissecting his craft on one of more than 80 panels announced for the film conference portion of the South by Southwest festival. Hell be joined by the directors Eli Roth (Hostel), Ruben Fleischer (Zombieland) and Ti West (The House of the Devil) to speak about directing genre films. Michel Gondry, whose film version of The Green Hornet has been generating a good amount of buzz, will talk with Elvis Mitchell about Mr. Gondrys filmography. Panels on how to sell graphic novels to Hollywood and how to simultaneously master the television and film production worlds will also be highlights. The film conference runs March 12 to March 16.

title: Words for Seniors Facing Loss
description: My father is a relentlessly upbeat guy. Up and around! he reports when I call. Keeping busy! He tells me about his volunteer work, his card game winnings, the (seated) yoga class he enrolled in at the library. His favorite refrain is, I cant complain. (And yes, yes, yes, my sister and I do know how lucky we are.)

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Anne Rice Takes a Stab at Her First Vook
description: A quarter-century-old short story by Anne Rice, the author of Interview With a Vampire and the Songs of the Seraphim series, will soon become a video-enhanced digital book to be sold for viewing and reading on iPhones, personal computers and other Internet-connected devices.

title: The Snow Goes On but So Do the Shows
description: Updated | 3:13 p.m.  Todays Broadway parlor game, blizzard edition: how much money is Broadway going to lose today because day-of-show patrons arent going to the theater because of the weather?

title: For Queens Neighborhood, a Step Toward Landmark Status
description: Addisleigh Park, an upper-middle-class enclave in St. Albans in southeast Queens, is distinguished by its elegant homes, one-way streets and the large number of notable African-Americans who made their home there.

title: Are You Better Off Than Your Parents Were?
description: American dreams be damned. It appears that the United States has less intergenerational social mobility than many other industrialized countries.

title: Leader Faulted on Using Army in Iraqi Politics
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  The Iraqi Armys Fourth Division cordoned off the provincial council building here overnight on Tuesday and showed no sign on Wednesday of leaving. It was the latest in a series of actions by the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki that have infuriated his political opponents, while raising doubts about the strength of the countrys laws and democratic institutions.

title: Low I.Q. Predicts Heart Disease
description: Smoking, obesity and high blood pressure are well-known risk factors for heart disease, but now British researchers have identified a powerful new predictor of heart problems: low intelligence.

title: Champions League Final on Fox  in HD
description: The UEFA Champions League final: same time, different channel.

title: Ancient Man in Greenland Has Genome Decoded
description: The genome of a man who lived on the western coast of Greenland some 4,000 years ago has been decoded, thanks to the surprisingly good preservation of DNA in a swatch of his hair so thick it was originally thought to be from a bear.

title: Broadening Makeups Spectrum
description: NOT every woman has the confidence to paint her lips a metallic cornflower blue, even if Doo.Ris models walked the runway with Everest-cold pouts during the last New York Fashion Week. But some of the unusual colors that professional makeup artists routinely use to create an unforgettable eye or lip dont have women running scared anymore.

title: The Mountaintop, Play About Martin Luther King Jr., Planned for Broadway
description: The Mountaintop, a new two-character play that imagines a surprising turn of events for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the night before his assassination, is aiming for Broadway in the fall, the producers Jean Doumanian and Sonia Friedman announced Wednesday.

title: Wall Streets Snow Day
description: Brendan McDermid/Reuters A New York Stock Exchange employee clears out snow, as Wall Street employees find themselves distracted by the blizzard.

title: Politics A to Z: Bipartisanship, Blizzard Edition
description: The word of the week in Washington seems to be bipartisanship. President Obama hosted the first in a series of monthly meetings at the White House, and a health care summit for leaders in both parties is set to take place later this month.

title: Nissan Juke: An Offbeat New Crossover
description: When Nissan unveiled the Qazana concept crossover at the Geneva auto show last year, it was described by reporters as bizarre, zany, a Pufferfish Murano and a dune buggy for downtown dwellers.

title: Fire Your Relatives. Scare Your Employees. And Stop Whining.
description: ITS not the economy, stupid, its you. So says George Cloutier, author of Profits Arent Everything, Theyre the Only Thing (HarperBusiness, 2009). Mr. Cloutier, the 63-year-old founder and chief executive of American Management Services, specializes in advising small and midsize businesses and turning troubled companies around.

title: Taming Twitters Streams With Automated Web Sites
description: Unlike Facebook, whose builders strive to make it an ever more organized social network, Twitter seems to thrive on being a jumble. It is an egalitarian sort of mess: Twitter does not sort its users into categories, does not tag some as celebrities, does not map out who does lunch with whom in the real world. You and Shaquille ONeal are Twitter equals, only he has an extra 2.8 million followers.

title: Guares Free Man of Color Moves to Lincoln Center Theater From Public Theater
description: John Guares new play, A Free Man of Color, which endured a much-publicized cancellation at the Public Theater last season, will be given a production uptown at Lincoln Center Theater this fall, according to two theater artists involved with the project.

title: What Do Ice Dancers Do for Fun? Play Hockey Video Games
description: People who happen by the room of American ice dancers Charlie White and Evan Bates at the Olympic Village might hear cheering or screaming.

title: 36 Hours in Vancouver, British Columbia
description: NO wonder Vancouver is often heralded as one of the worlds most livable cities. It is blessed with a snowcapped mountain backdrop and crystal blue harbors. It is also a gateway to the Inside Passage  the marvelous maze of glacier-carved fjords and forested islands that are a cruise lovers delight. But what really sets Vancouver apart is its urban density. With sprawl kept in check by geography, the city thinks vertically. Neighborhoods overlap, apartments rise. That seems to heighten the citys international mix, and not just when the Olympic Games are in town.

title: Goldman Hasnt Set Its 2010 Pay Plans
description: Goldman Sachs, which held down executive pay last year, has no magic formula for setting compensation in 2010, its chief financial officer said on Wednesday.

title: Is This What It Takes to Run a Small Business?
description: Today were publishing an interview with George Cloutier, who is founder of American Management Services and who specializes in advising small and midsize companies. He is the author of Profits Arent Everything, Theyre the Only Thing, and he favors a take-no-prisoners approach to running a business. Among other things, he suggests firing all family members, using fear to motivate employees, micromanaging and not whining about the recession. He also tells business owners to love their businesses more than they love their families  a message, he acknowledges, that his current wife (his third) doesnt fully endorse. He has no children, about which he says:

title: A Hollywood Player Inspires a Broadway Play
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Robert Evans has long been good theater. Now comes the actual stage play.

title: When Private Equitys Geniuses Fail
description: BERLIN  In the halcyon days of 2007, the private equity industry liked to pat itself on the back for its smartness.

title: Behind the Challenge to the Galleon Case Wiretaps
description: As the Galleon Group insider trading case moves forward, a lawyer for Raj Rajaratnam, the leading figure in the sprawling investigation, is taking the first steps to try to suppress the wiretap evidence that prosecutors say iscrucial to proving the largest hedge fund insider trading case in history.

title: Into the Abyss With Werner
description: If youve ever wanted to be locked in a hotel room with Werner Herzog for four days and, other than Klaus Kinski, who hasnt?  nows your chance. Mr. Herzog has announced that the second installment of his Rogue Film School will take place in New Jersey on June 11-14, 2010, with a maximum class size of 65 students/disciples. The curriculum once again includes: the art of lock-picking. Traveling on foot. The exhilaration of being shot at unsuccessfully. The athletic side of filmmaking. The creation of your own shooting permits. The neutralization of bureaucracy. Guerilla tactics.

title: Officials See Slander in Uzbek Photos, but Artists See Censorship
description: MOSCOW  How can a photographer defame her country?

title: Now Baking | Beyond Red Velvet Cake
description: Lately, some of the best sweets have been the color of love  and vegetables. With Valentines Day around the corner, these comforting red confections made from ingredients not usually associated with homey desserts gave me an idea: a new trademark treat for the holiday. I craved something in a Valentine-worthy hue that was easy to make, easy to love, but not so easy to recognize. Thered be an element of playful surprise  a beet, perhaps, or some beans.

title: The Voices of Tourettes Syndrome
description: Tourettes syndrome is an odd and little understood disorder, characterized by sudden jerking movements and uncontrollable tics and vocalizations.

title: A Debate for the Snowbound
description: We will never forget the wintry fury that was inflicted upon us in February 2010, reads the epigraph to one of the many snowmaggedon pages that have cropped up in the last few days on Facebook. This one has a few thousand fans, a modest but respectable number considering this: Who wants to be a fan of snowmaggedon?The word could be the most annoying new portmanteau to be widely adopted by the mainstream media. Watch out, staycation, snowmaggedon is a trending topic for the New York area on Twitter (#snowmaggedon) and has already appeared in the first few paragraphs of Wikipedias entry on Armageddon, to wit:

title: Blizzard Pummels East Coast
description: From Virginia to Connecticut, more than a foot of snow is expected to fall. (Video: NBC)

title: Is This How Cleopatra Felt?
description: STROLLING onto the roof deck of the Sun Boat IV, a 40-cabin river vessel, as it churned slowly up the Nile in early January, I relished the scene before me. Lounging on white chaises and overstuffed couches, swimming in the heated pool, reading and sipping drinks were dozens of people from various parts of my life. To my right was a childhood friend posing for a photo with a parent from my sons school. To my left, my mother shared a joke with her friend of 70 years, while nearby a work colleague of my sisters discussed Egyptian pharaohs with my daughters godfather.

title: Travel Deals: STA and Southwest Offer Winter Sale
description: Need a late winter getaway? STA Travel and Southwest Airlines are offering discounted fares.

title: Photos of the Moment | Chanel Rouge Coco Dinner Party
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: Cup Still Delayed, but Meteorologist Is Doing Fine
description: VALENCIA, Spain  So far in the Americas Cup, it is weather forecasters 2, sailors 0.

title: Let It Snow! Let It Snow! Let It Snow! Its Good Business
description: Treacherous road conditions infuriate drivers, but they bring smiles to the tire shop owners along Jerome Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Offering Whatever Floats Your Boat
description: DESPITE rough economic seas, the cruise industry is staying the course this year with new destinations far and near, activities for young and old and amenities that seem to appeal to every niche.

title: Universal Music Names Grainge as Its Next Chief
description: The Universal Music Group, the worlds largest music company, announced Wednesday what had been expected for months: that Lucian Grainge, the head of the companys international division, will become chief executive.

title: Playing With Tofu Skins
description: Kerri Conan visited me a couple of weeks ago and we decided to shop and cook instead of going out to dinner. I took her to Chinatown for a walk, and we shopped, basing our purchasing decisions on what looked good and might be fun and challenging. Originally we thought wed buy fish but decided, for two reasons, to go vegan. (The first reason: I dont know a reliable fish market down there right now  ideas?  and I didnt feel like poking around much. The second: more challenging.)

title: What to Look For in an Online Broker
description: Charles Schwab fired the first shot when it cut its trading commissions last month, and now Fidelity and E*Trade have followed with price cuts of their own.

title: Now Showing | Contemplating the Void at the Guggenheim
description: Frank Lloyd Wrights Guggenheim, with its seemingly endless spiral ramp and its relatively minuscule galleries, has long been the museum that artists, curators and visitors (particularly those in high heels) loved to hate. Most of the prime real estate in the place is consumed by a central rotunda  or, in other words, dead space.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Romeo in Naples, Italy
description: THE BASICS

title: In Honolulu, Chinatowns Revival
description: HONOLULUS Chinatown is livelier than ever, thanks to the street cred that has come along with the neighborhoods latest reinvention as an arts hub and a gritty, up-and-coming place to shop and eat. A handful of older shops have closed their doors in the last year, but a spate of cafes, boutiques and bakeries have sprung up in the last few months to take their place.

title: Store Review: Strangelets in Singapore
description: The first thing youll probably notice in this design boutique is a hollowed-out, painted grand piano displaying handmade soaps, delicate jewelry and illustrated T-shirts proudly declaring designerd. This piano-turned-display-case is a fine example of the stores championing of unique products that combine function with a healthy dose of whimsy.

title: Forr Raises Pulse of Parisians
description: ON a recent dank and wintry Wednesday evening in Paris, couples jostled for every inch of an overcrowded dance floor at BizzArt, a dining and dancing club on the fringes of the chic Canal St. Martin quarter. They were there to dance the forr, a rustic country dance from northeastern Brazil that has fired the romantic imaginations of Parisians young and old, at a weekly gathering devoted to the dance.

title: Touring the Prado at Warp Speed
description: HOW much time do you need for a museum visit? Some might say that they could spend an entire day at any of the worlds great museums, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Louvre in Paris or the Prado in Madrid, without even coming close to experiencing all their riches. Others, like those museumgoers with short attention spans, get itchy after a half-hour or so, and just make a mad dash to see a few favorites and maybe peek in at a new exhibition before heading back out into the sunlight and away from the crowds.

title: Answers From an E-Dating Expert
description: Following is the first set of answers from Laurie Davis, the founder of eFlirt Expert. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: Letters: Gaming the Luggage System
description: THE SCRUM FOR BIN SPACE

title: Weather Could Keep Belbin, Agosto From Ceremony
description: Ice dancers Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto, the 2006 Olympic silver medalists, are waiting out the second winter storm to hit the East Coast in the past week, hoping that the airports will reopen in time for them to fly to Vancouver on Thursday.

title: NBC Video: Vonn Reveals Injury
description: Olympic skier Lindsey Vonn bruised her shin during training last week, which threatens her run at five medals.

title: Wall Street Damage Control
description: So, via Greg Sargent and Sam Stein, the White House is trying to limit the damage from those Obama remarks about bankers compensation, providing more context. I wish I could say that it helps a lot; but it doesnt.

title: Fela!: Dance Tells a Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Envisioning Shakespeare at Home in New York
description: The news that the Royal Shakespeare Company will install a classical theater inside the Park Avenue Armory for a six-week residency in the summer of 2011 inspires both gratitude and chagrin.

title: A Commercial Arrival
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Paulus: Shakespeare as a Draw
description: To the Editor:

title: Jon Robin Baitz Play Announced for Broadway
description: Jon Robin Baitz (A Fair Country, The Substance of Fire) will have his first commercial production on Broadway during the 2010-11 season, its lead producers, Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel, said.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the singer Sade misidentified the civilization that created the structures in the backdrop of the cover of her new album. They are Zapotec ruins, in Monte Alban, Mexico; they are not Mayan ruins.

title: Correction
description: A Pop entry in the Week Ahead report on Jan. 31 misstated Andy Warhols background. Warhol was the son of immigrants from Czechoslovakia; he was not Polish-American.

title: Getting Physical: The Physics and Other Science Behind Winter Olympic Sports
description: Overview | What is the science behind the sports in the Winter Olympics? In this lesson, students explore how two laws of physics are involved in the sports of aerial skiing and figure skating. Then, through demonstrations, science videos and articles, they learn about the physics concepts connected to other Winter Olympic sports. Students showcase their knowledge by writing and performing a physics-savvy sportscast that explains the science behind their favorite sports. Take the lesson further with ideas for investigating other scientific aspects of these sports.

title: Stars and Gripes: Tea Party Protests Captain America Comic
description: Over his 70-year history, Captain America has often vowed that his duty is to the American dream  and not to any political party. Its a lesson that has hit home for Marvel Comics, Captain Americas longtime publisher, which said it would amend a recent issue of his comic-book series after it upset members of the Tea Party movement.

title: Financial Crisis Deepens in Greece
description: Germany is considering bailing out Greece and other troubled European countries.

title: Despite Snow, Business as Usual in Brooklyn
description: The snow didnt seem to bother commuters and residents in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, this morning. Around 9 a.m., the buses with chains on their tires were grinding down DeKalb Avenue at a healthy pace, and a BMW truck sent out a foot-long spray of gray slush as it barreled down the street, almost unaware that snow was on the ground.

title: Tempting Fate
description: Over two decades, the International Olympic Committee has updated the Winter Games with sports containing more elements of danger and risk.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Feb. 10
description: Yes, the snow was bad in the East. It was far worse along the Salang Pass in Afghanistan, where two miles of highway were buried under avalanches, killing dozens. Moises Saman, on assignment for The Times, reached the pass and transmitted remarkable photographs (Slides 3 and 4). The first summons the sheer brutality of the moment. The other  not easy to look at  captures the dimension of human loss.

title: From D.J. to Olympian: Ladwig at Ease With Microphones
description: Amanda Evora and Mark Ladwig, one of the American pairs figure skating teams, were not expected to make the U.S. Olympic team. Still, Ladwig came to Vancouver prepared for all the media attention.

title: Patriot Risk Catches the I.P.O. Chill
description: Wall Street may be getting smacked by a severe snowstorm on Wednesday, but the really big chill remains in the I.P.O. market, where Patriot Risk Management became the latest company to postpone its initial public offering.

title: Hockey Heaven in a Backyard
description: There's nothing like stepping out your back door to drop the puck, as families who have installed ice rinks in their backyards have come to realize.

title: Case Study | Love Potion No. 50
description: On the list of odious propositions, creating a Valentines cocktail has to be right up there with consuming one. Why do restaurateurs and other guilty parties assume that simply because it is a Hallmark holiday, we all lose our minds and are compelled to throw back Irish Cream and chocolate-laced confections masquerading as drinks? But its that time of year, and create a Valentines cocktail I must.

title: Cables With Extras
description: Cables

title: Chicago Auto Show: All Eyes (and Ears) on Toyota
description: CHICAGO  The redesigned 2011 Toyota Avalon was unveiled this morning at the Chicago Auto Show, complete with a complement of new technologies.

title: 1950s Sophistication, Current Dynamics
description: The pianist Gerald Clayton played the first set of his first night of his first week at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday, and prefaced it with a familiar speech, the kind thats been heard there on many first-night Tuesdays in the past. He talked about the rooms historical importance, its sound, the great records that have been made there. Then he played a tasteful and sufficiently modern set with his trio  arrangements full of broken or stuttered rhythm, pinpoint dynamics, classically ordered introductions  and the music cleanly slipped by.

title: Pittsburgh Brings New York 2 Staples
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra came to a sold-out Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night as an ensemble with something to prove. This was the orchestras first New York concert with its new music director, the Austrian conductor Manfred Honeck. When Mr. Honeck took charge in the fall of 2008, he brought boundless enthusiasm and artistic authority to an institution in need of both.

title: Vail International Dance Festival Lineup Announced
description: The 22-year-old Vail InternationalDance Festival, a summer destination in the mountains of Colorado for dance lovers, has announced its program for this year.The festival, which runs from July 27 to Aug. 10 and is under the direction of Damian Woetzel,willpresentthree premieres and11 performances. In addition there will be an artist-in-residence and a company residency.Some highlights:the Vail debut of BeijingDance/LDTX; the Americanpremiere of Natalia Hills and Gabriel Misss tango show, Romper el Piso; and a new work by Larry Keigwin, the festivals first artist-in-residence, who will also perform during the festival.The Pacific Northwest Ballet will be in residency for a week, and the Paul Taylor Dance Company will perform in honor of the choreographers 80th birthday. Herman Cornejo, Wendy Whelan, Daniil Simkin, Carla Krbes, Matthew Rushing and Tiler Peck are among the dancers scheduled toappearas part of the International Evenings of Dance,whenartistsfrom companies around the worldperform.Ticketsare available beginningFriday, Feb.12 at 11 a.m. MST onthe festivalsWeb site: vaildance.org

title: Motorola Ventures Invests in Zenverge
description: Motorola said Wednesday that it had invested in Zenverge, a privately held chip maker, through its venture capital arm, Motorola Ventures.

title: Post-Minimal to the Max
description: TO paraphrase Jerry Lee Lewis, there is a whole lot of art making going on right now. All different kinds. But youd hardly know it from the contemporary art that New Yorks major museums have been serving up lately, and particularly this season.

title: Reaganomics Revival in San Francisco?
description: Update | 11:33 p.m. Pacific Time

title: The Desperate Quest for Talk Show Outlets
description: As we bravely soldier forth into a Conan-less world, and a Leno-less one (if only, and unfortunately, for just a few weeks), Oscar campaign publicists may be facing a drought of acceptable showcases for their clients. A chat-show stop is a necessary part of the final weeks of campaigning, to convince viewers, and, ideally voters, that the nominee is still relatable and, more importantly, fulfills the requisite storyline, like Cinderella or Huh, Never Thought It Would Happen To Me  see: Sandra Bullock on Late Show With David Letterman and Gabourey Sidibe as one of Mr. Lenos final guests.

title: Report Warns Silicon Valley Could Lose Its Edge
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valleys economy is sputtering and risks permanently stalling, according to an annual report by a group of researchers in the region.

title: Audi A1: Mini-Size Car, but Not for America
description: Small, in automotive terms, has always been associated with the word cheap. But it seems those terms may be parting ways as automakers experiment with the idea that small could successfully be associated with luxury.

title: What Kind of Coffee Do You Get for $18,000?
description: First off, some myth-busting: the $18,000 price tag for the Slayer  now in use at RBC  (71 Worth Street, 212-226-1111) is normal for a high-end three group espresso machine.

title: Wilson and Murtha, Together in Arms
description: The death of former Representative Charlie Wilson of Texas is the loss of the second legendary member of the House Appropriations Committee in a week, coming just days after his one-time colleague, Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania, passed away.

title: Vonns at Ease, but Never Far From the Edge
description: Lindsey Vonn, the defending World Cup ski champion and multiple Olympic medal favorite, tried other sports as a child. Figure skating was a struggle, and she was not very accomplished at gymnastics, either.

title: The Delicate Act of Dealing With Regulators
description: BERLIN  Private equity executives preparing to deal with regulators and heightened regulations face a balancing act, Richard Thornburgh, the vice chairman of Corsair Capital, said here at Super Return 2010 on Wednesday.

title: Better Calling for Less, by Skipping the Cell Network
description: Few people care whether their calls are carried over a data network, a voice network, copper wires or a piece of string tied to two Dixie cups. Unless, of course, the method doesnt really work.

title: I Saw the Snow Raining Snow
description: Wednesday was the first day he woke up in America. The first time he looked down at the Bronx street before dawn. And as a winter storm began to swirl outside, the very first time that Aung, a 37-year-old Burmese refugee, saw real snow.

title: Why the Winter Games Get a Chilly Reception
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Pssst.

title: A.I.G. Rolls Out New Pay Plan
description: The American International Group said Wednesday that it plans to roll out a new compensation system that grades its employees performance numerically and ties the new scheme to the size of their annual bonus payments.

title: Anne Rice Tries Her First Video-Enchanced Book
description: A 26-year-old short story by Anne Rice, right, the author of Interview With a Vampire and the Songs of the Seraphim series, will soon become a video-enhanced digital book to be sold for viewing and reading on iPhones, personal computers and other Internet-connected devices. Ms. Rice has sold the multimedia rights to make a so-called vook of The Master of Rampling Gate, a vampire story, to Vook, a multimedia company that has joined with publishers and authors to make enhanced editions of electronic books. The story was originally published in Redbook magazine in 1984. I think the whole idea is very exciting, Ms. Rice said in a telephone interview. Were in the midst of some kind of revolution here. Bradley Inman, chief executive of Vook, said the special edition, which is to be released on March 1, will include a video interview with Ms. Rice and a tour of New Orleans led by her son, Christopher Rice, an author in his own right.

title: Baitz Play Announced for Broadway
description: Jon Robin Baitz (A Fair Country, The Substance of Fire) will have his first commercial production of a new play on Broadway during the 2010-11 season, its lead producers, Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel, said. The play, Love and Mercy, concerns a former matinee idol turned ambassador, his wife (a screenwriter) and their daughter (a novelist), Mr. Richards said. Mr. Baitz, whose Fair Country was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1996, has had a long career Off Broadway and is also the creator of the ABC television series Brothers & Sisters. Mr. Richards said he and Mr. Frankel were aiming for performances to begin in the late fall or early winter. The two have produced together before, including David Mamets Race, now on Broadway, and Tracy Lettss Pulitzer Prize-winning August: Osage County.

title: World Trade Center Aerial Photos
description: Newly released aerial photos of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center capture the dramatic collapse of the towers.

title: Play About King Planned for Broadway
description: The Mountaintop, a two-character play that imagines a surprising turn of events for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., above, on the night before his assassination, is aiming for Broadway in the fall, the producers Jean Doumanian and Sonia Friedman announced Wednesday. The play, by Katori Hall, received a critically praised production in London last summer, and the producers said in a statement they were eager to capitalize on its success by moving ahead on Broadway. They said they were in negotiations with Kenny Leon to direct; he is directing the forthcoming revival of August Wilsons Fences on Broadway. Ms. Hall has said in interviews that her inspiration for the play came partly from her mother, who grew up near the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, where Dr. King was assassinated, and regretted not going to hear him speak on the day before he was killed. (He delivered his Ive Been to the Mountaintop speech.) The plays characters are Dr. King and a woman who at first seems to be a hotel maid. Casting, performance dates and a theater are yet to be announced.

title: Degeneres in, Leno Out
description: The introduction of Ellen DeGeneres as a judge on Foxs American Idol gave the competition a slight ratings bump, as 27.7 million viewers tuned in to see Ms. DeGeneres take over the chair once occupied by Paula Abdul. Whatever curiosity her debut generated was quickly squandered by Past Life (9 million), a new Fox crime series that lost more than three million viewers from its first half-hour to its last. Fox won the night over all, and CBS was second with a lineup that included NCIS (19.7 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles (17.8 million). NBC was third as 5.9 million people tuned in to bid farewell to The Jay Leno Show.

title: Guare Play May Move to Lincoln Center
description: A Free Man of Color, the new play by John Guare, below, which had a much-publicized cancellation at the Public Theater last season, is to be given a production at Lincoln Center Theater this fall, according to two theater artists involved with the project who spoke on the condition of anonymity because an official announcement has not been made.  George C. Wolfe is expected to direct the play, about the Louisiana Purchase, as he was scheduled to do at the Public. The Public canceled its production in November 2008. At the time its artistic director, Oskar Eustis, issued a statement saying that the current harsh economic climate means we cannot produce Free Man this season within the Publics fiscal parameters. Asked about losing the production, Mr. Eustis replied in an e-mail message on Wednesday: John Guare has written a beautiful and important play. I am very happy its being produced; audiences should get a chance to see it.

title: How Oscars Voting System Really Works
description: O.K., folks. Everyone in the world  or at least everyone on the East Coast  has been crowing about a snow day. (Not the Bagger: weve been blogging.) Also, everyone in the world  or at least Oscarologists  has taken a crack at explaining how the Academys new preferential voting system will change this years awards. In the spirit of combining the two, we are going to take the snow day, a.k.a lazy, way out of a post and just throw to Mark Lisanti of Movieline, who a few days ago gave a killer rundown of how the tabulations will proceed:

title: Dental Malady Delays Lil Wayne Sentencing
description: On Tuesday a Manhattan judge gave the rapper Lil Wayne permission to put off his sentencing on a weapons possession charge so that he could undergo dental work in Miami, The Associated Press reported. Lil Wayne, the multiplatinum-selling performer whose real name is Dwayne Carter, appeared in State Supreme Court, where he was to be sentenced on charges stemming from a July 2007 incident in which a loaded .40-caliber semiautomatic gun was found on his tour bus. He pleaded guilty to attempted criminal possession of a weapon in October. But a lawyer for Lil Wayne said on Tuesday that Lil Wayne needed to be treated for a medical situation that could not be attended to sooner, because his dentist had been out of the country performing charity work. Judge Charles Solomon granted an adjournment and rescheduled the sentencing to March 2. Lil Wayne could face a sentence of one year on the gun charge, and is scheduled to go on trial March 30 on felony drug possession and weapons charges in Arizona.

title: New Yorker Films Gets a Second Reel
description: New Yorker Films, the distributor that abruptly announced last year it was shuttering its business, will live on: a new owner has been found for its estimable movie library. On Tuesday, Aladdin Distribution of Marina del Rey, Calif., said it had purchased the more than 400 foreign and independent titles of the New Yorker Films catalog. New Yorker handled the releases of movies like Jean-Luc Godards Breathless and Claude Lanzmanns Holocaust documentary Shoah, as well as films by Bernardo Bertolucci, Akira Kurosawa and other directors. The revived New Yorker Films, which was founded in 1965 by Dan Talbot, is to be run by Jose Lopez, a business partner of Mr. Talbots and former vice president of the company who will now serve as its president. In a statement New Yorker Films said it intended to acquire six to eight films a year for theatrical release, and seek movies for its nontheatrical and home video divisions.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Why E-Books Will Cost More
description: This week on Tech Talk, The New York Timess podcast about the world of technology, Bettina Edelstein talks to Brad Stone, The Timess technology reporter covering Amazon and Apple. He describes how the e-book price war that has pitted Amazon against book publishers will result in consumers paying more for the e-books they want to download from Amazon or other vendors.

title: Recipe Redux: Chocolate Caramels, 1881
description: A few weeks ago, I gave Stuart Brioza and Nicole Krasinski, a husband-and-wife team of San Francisco chefs, a 19th-century recipe for simple chocolate caramels made with molasses and vanilla and asked them to use it as inspiration for an entirely new dish.

title: American Team Picks Honorary Curler
description: There are more curling fans in the United States than just Stephen Colbert.

title: Snow Day? For Some, It Means Extra Work
description: Not everyone got a snow day Wednesday. For many in the city, the forecasted foot of snow meant extra work scraping, salting and standing in the city streets.

title: Is It Time for Apple to Retire the Cats?
description: Its the snowpocalypse here on the East Coast, and many of you are having a quiet day at home or the office. So lets play a little game.

title: Photos of the Moment | Tuesday, Feb. 9
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Rachel Chandler.

title: Redford Honors Activism at Berkeley Center
description: Without much fanfare, the Redford Center opened its headquarters last May in the David Brower Center in downtown Berkeley. On Thursday night at the Sundance Kabuki Theater in San Francisco, the center held its first Art of Activism program, part of its series featuring prominent people and honoring local activists.

title: Eye-Opening Beds
description: The beds on display at a furniture show in Las Vegas offer the consumer much to be excited about.

title: 2010: Black-Sugar-Glazed Medjool Dates With Pecorino and Walnuts
description: For the glaze:

title: Big Grammy Ratings, but Less Impressive Sales
description: The Grammy Awards show on Jan. 31 drew its biggest television audience in six years, with nearly 26 million viewers, according to Nielsen. With those ratings you might expect huge increases in album sales the next week, but the bump was not substantially greater than in previous years.

title: Now Showing | Galerie Slott, Paris
description: When Paola Bjaringer returned to Paris after a career in London as a TV news correspondent, she had art on her mind. The French were really longing for a welcoming, generous place, she says, referring to the many young artists and designers that have come home to Paris  from places like Stockholm, Berlin, New York and London  and were looking for galleries that were open to showing emerging talent. So she decided to create one herself. After two years of searching for the a location, plus another year of gut renovations done with the architect Joseph Caspari, she recently unveiled the gallery Slott in the 10th arrondissement.

title: Pooch Party
description: Dogs dressed in their finest hit the Muse Hotel for a book party benefiting the Humane Society.

title: Mark Twain: Man in White
description: Chapter 1: Ragtime on Tap

title: Mark Twain: A Public Image as Tailored as His Snow-White Suits
description: In 1907 Mark Twain, Americas best-loved living author, visited England in a blaze of glory. Among the fellow literary lights he met there were Rudyard Kipling, who described the camera shutters around Twain click-clicking like gun locks, and George Bernard Shaw. He is in very much the same position as myself, Shaw said of Twain. He has to put matters in such a way as to make people who would otherwise hang him believe he is joking.

title: Samba Queen, 7, Approved for Rio Carnival
description: A family court judge in Brazil ruled on Wednesday that 7-year-old Julia Lira will be allowed to dance at the head of a drum corps in this years Rio Carnival as the queen of the one of the countrys best-known samba schools, Viradouro.

title: Americas Bandy Heroes, Back From Moscow
description: As the United States mens and womens hockey teams count down the last days and hours to the Olympic tournament, we heard from an official of another national team, Chris Middlebrook, coach of the mens bandy team that competed late last month in the world championship in Moscow.

title: Gundlach Sues TCW for $1.25 Billion in Damages
description: A star bond fund manager, Jeffrey Gundlach, took aim at his old employer Wednesday, accusing the TCW Group in a lawsuit of breaking a 2007 oral agreement that cost him and his team as much as $1.25 billion.

title: U.S. Lugers See Medals With Tunnel Vision
description: SAN DIEGO  Mark Grimmettes duty for the day was more appropriate for a mannequin than an Olympian.

title: CME to Buy Control of Dow Jones Index Unit
description: Dow Jones & Company is selling a 90 percent stake in its stock-market index unit to the CME Group for $607.5 million, The Associated Press reports.

title: Faulkner Link to Plantation Diary Discovered
description: The climactic moment in William Faulkners 1942 novel Go Down, Moses comes when Isaac McCaslin finally decides to open his grandfathers leather farm ledgers with their scarred and cracked backs and yellowed pages scrawled in fading ink  proof of his familys slave-owning past. Now, what appears to be the document on which Faulkner modeled that ledger as well as the source for myriad names, incidents and details that populate his fictionalized Yoknapatawpha County has been discovered.

title: You Can Have Lindsey; Ill Take Kwame
description: The headline was big, bold and beautiful.

title: A Toyota Timeline
description: In recent months, the Japanese automaker has recalled about eight million cars worldwide over gas pedals that could stick or become caught on floor mats.

title: No Need for Music When the Rhymes the Thing at a Webster Hall Concert
description: Forever Harlem by Juelz Santana, Jim Jones and the singer Tobb Cobain  a remake of Forever, last years song by Drake, Kanye West, Lil Wayne and Eminem  is the rare mixtape version of Forever that challenges the original in audacity.

title: Plushenko, the Quad King, Is Back for More
description: TALLINN, Estonia  Yet another gold medal was in his possession, and with a sly smile, Yevgeny Plushenko extended his right arm and let his hand tremble.

title: Miracle? Depends Where Youre From
description: The Miracle on Ice is not the only miracle on ice in the history of Olympic hockey, although Americans can be forgiven for thinking otherwise. That stirring victory in 1980 by a ragtag group of collegians from Minnesota and Massachusetts in Lake Placid, N.Y., is often revisited in articles, books, ads and in two full-length film re-enactments. (Karl Malden played Herb Brooks in 1981; Kurt Russell in 2004.)

title: The Margiela Sale to End All Margiela Sales
description: Starting tomorrow, Resurrections 20 Years of Maison Martin Margiela: The Marcia Berger Collection will be on view at One Jackson Square in downtown Manhattan. The more than 1,000 mint-condition accessories and garments will then go up for auction, in a collaboration between the vintage clothing resource and 1stdibs. There has been a fair amount said about Bergers collection, which includes some 40 one-of-a-kind artisanal pieces, like a top made from vintage opera gloves, a dress-form top and a sweater made from military socks; the collection spans the designers career from 1989 up until the time he was rumored to be phoning his work in from Ibiza, Spain. But just who is the woman who assembled  and never wore!  this Margiela trove? A quick search yields little on Berger, who is occasionally described as a fashion doyenne. This is a fair enough assumption for someone who in her lifetime (she died in 2008) amassed enough high-end and avant-garde clothing to fuel multiple sales. (Resurrection already sold off her stash of shoes  Alaia, Yohji, Louboutin, Manolo Blahnik, etc.  in 2008. She was a size 8/8.5 in case you were wondering.) Yet, to hear Resurrections Mark Haddawy describe her, she was anything but doyenne-ish. Quite the opposite in fact. Like most L.A. women, Berger was typically dressed-down and favored a uniform of jeans, a Margiela AIDS T-shirt and flip-flops. She drove a Ford Taurus. Unlike the python-clad L.A. fashion cowboy Jim Goldstein, Berger was not a front-row fixture on the show circuit. Yet, no doubt when she walked into stores like Laura Urbinati or Maxfield or Mameg, her salespeoples eyes would light up. Its an amazing collection put together in real time, says Haddawy, who with Katy Rodriguez was responsible for organizing and cataloging the contents of Bergers closets. To the untrained eye, he adds, many of the pieces looked like they should have been tossed in the trash. They were ripped, burned, wrinkled or otherwise damaged. Intentionally of course.

title: Good Chemistry for Some Household Sprays
description: It has been nearly a year since S. C. Johnson & Son, the maker of products like Windex, Glade and Drano, agreed to begin disclosing all the ingredients in its home-cleaning and air-care products sold in the United States, giving consumers unprecedented access to information about the chemicals they squirt and spray throughout their homes. And earlier this month, a lawsuit brought by a consortium of health and environmental groups with the aim of forcing other household cleaning-product manufacturers (like Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive) to do the same, inched closer to resolution when a New York State Supreme Court judge announced at a hearing that he will soon rule on whether the case can move forward.

title: Finally, Good-Looking Nontoxic Paint?
description: The Process

title: Concerns as Canada Balances Protests and Civil Liberties
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Christopher A. Shaw, a middle-class, middle-aged professor of ophthalmology at the University of British Columbia, seems an unlikely target of police interest. But Shaw is also the author of Five Ring Circus: Myths and Realities of the Olympic Games, a book highly critical of the Olympics and his hometowns decision to host them.

title: A Training Center for Medals, From Chandelier on Down
description: PARK CITY, Utah  At the Center of Excellence, a three-story training complex for Olympic hopefuls, not even the entrance entertains the possibility of failure. A larger-than-life metal sign displays the unmistakable address in gold: 1 Victory Lane.

title: Win or Lose, Its Good Curling
description: Every four years, Americans who watch the Winter Olympics on television see an odd game in which the players, some with brooms, slide heavy granite stones down a thin strip of ice. They hear sudden, piercing cries  Hard! Hard! or Off! Off!  then a thunking collision of stones in a large, round target painted on the ice, and a huge ovation from thousands of people in the stands.

title: Vudu Lives (Outside the Box)
description: We like to think of ourselves as rational creatures. But if thats true, why do we eat stuff we know isnt good for us, fall for people who treat us badly and text while we drive?

title: An Ode to Snow, in Pictures, Prose and Verse
description: We asked readers to share with us their photos from the great white city and beyond. Above is a tableau of the hundreds of snapshots we received. Scroll through using the toolbar, or click on the photos for a larger view. If youd like to submit your own, heres how.

title: Riga Mortis
description: Meanwhile, things could be worse. And in Latvia, they are: real GDP down 18 percent. Unlike Spain, which Ive been obsessing about, Latvia isnt in the eurozone. But its determination to keep a fixed exchange rate against the euro lies behind the catastrophe.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Somebody tell Madonna: Materialism is highly correlated with self-esteem.

title: From That Instant Thrill, Enduring Art, Now for Sale
description: In the 1960s about half of all American households owned a Polaroid camera, according to the companys own estimates. And while the instant thrill of having a tangible record of first birthdays, prom nights, vacations and Christmas dinners was the driving force behind the companys success, its revolutionary product also changed forever the way many artists worked. Ansel Adams captured some fabled images of Yosemite National Park using a Polaroid; Andy Warhol and Chuck Close took Polaroid portraits  of themselves, friends and celebrities  and William Wegman used a Polaroid to shoot his beloved Weimaraners.

title: Ellen Jackson, Who Helped Establish Barrett-Jackson Auction, Dies at 90
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Ellen Jackson, wife of Russ Jackson, who co-founded the Barrett-Jackson collector car auction, died on Wednesday at the age of 90.

title: For Mets, Its an Issue of Junk
description: The Mets have made a number of changes to Citi Field this winter  a new team Hall of Fame, more images of their stars, and even planters with orange and blue flowers.

title: Virginia Advances Legislation Against Insurance Requirement
description: Virginia took another step on Tuesday toward becoming the first state to enact legislation to exempt its residents from a central feature of President Obamas health care plan: a requirement that everyone buy health insurance or pay a penalty.

title: Is This a Man Who Sheds Light, or Simply Sets Fires?
description: American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein is a cautiously respectful documentary portrait of a political firebrand who presents himself as a beacon of moral truth in the murk of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. A scholar, author and passionate advocate of the Palestinian cause, Mr. Finkelstein, 56, is a thorn in the side of the Israel lobby.

title: Strikes and Lockouts at Record Low
description: Reflecting both the waning influence of organized labor and a dismal economy, there were just five major work stoppages in 2009. That is the lowest number of events since the Labor Department began keeping records in 1947.

title: Reinventing Prokofiev, to an Extent
description: New Yorks major conservatories have such large footprints in the concert world  the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music with their opera productions and new music programs, and Mannes College the New School for Music with its parade of summer festivals  that you might think the market for student and faculty performances is saturated. But the Yale School of Music has established a formidable presence with its Yale in New York series at Carnegie Hall these last three seasons, mainly by presenting inventive programs of mostly new or unusual works.

title: Kirkus Gets a New Owner  From the N.B.A.
description: Looks like Kirkus Reviews will live another day to praise  and skewer  authors, but with some rather unorthodox owners for a publication with a long literary pedigree.

title: Iran, Beacon of Liberty?
description: ON Thursday, the birthday of the Islamic Republic of Iran, we will see whether the democratic opposition movement has been driven underground by the increasingly brutal harassment from the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Iranian society has become like molten rock under high pressure: more eruptions are inevitable. And if the dissidents can take to the streets, they will.

title: They Bark, They Rule
description: THERE was a brief confrontation on the coat-check line  some growling, a bit of pushing  but otherwise the guests at an event held Tuesday night in the basement of the Muse Hotel on West 46th Street were extremely well behaved. Part book party, to celebrate the publication of Its a Dogs World: The Savvy Guide to Four-Legged Living, by Wendy Diamond, chief pet officer of Animal Fair, the pet lifestyle magazine, and part benefit, for the Humane Society of New York, the Yappy Hour welcomed dogs and their humans from 6 to 8 p.m.

title: A Move Gives Modern Furniture Its Space
description: We had a chance to almost triple the size of our space, said Michael Manes, president of M2L, explaining the decision to move his showroom from East 58th Street, where it had been for a decade, downtown to 31st and Madison. The new space feels like it could be in Milan or Paris, Mr. Manes said. And were on the second floor, so we have some presence from the street. The 11,500-square-foot showroom, designed by Richard Kronick, of Gerner Kronick + Valcarcel Architects, will carry modern furniture brands like Artifort, Montis and Walter Knoll, and is open to consumers as well as the trade. M2L, 135 Madison Avenue (31st Street), (212) 832-8222, m2lcollection.com.

title: New York Streets Under Your Bare Feet
description: The Streets of New York, a new collection of rugs designed by Tracey Sawyer of the Nought Collective and Frank Carfaro of Desiron, makes it possible to have your own neighborhood underfoot at home.

title: More Than a Place to Rest
description: Las Vegas

title: The Four-Bedroom Kibbutz
description: REBECCA KARP, Brian Cohen, Danielle Hardoon and Alissa Worly, all of whom are in their 20s, share a spacious red-brick house in Philadelphia. It rents for $3,200 a month.

title: Chandeliers That Sing Their Own Praises
description: Foscarini, the Italian lighting company, introduced Allegro, a collection of chandeliers intended for hotels and restaurants, in 2007. Designed by Atelier O, a Swiss architecture firm, they were made from aluminum rods suspended from wire, so they moved and made a gentle tinkling noise if you touched them. (As Carlo Urbinati, the managing director of Foscarini, put it, They can sing.) But they were all too big for residential use  the largest was 53 1/2 inches wide and tall. Now Foscarini has come out with Allegretto, a line of smaller versions of the original fixtures. Allegretto Vivace ($2,438), below, one of three new pieces, is 20 inches in diameter and 27 1/2 inches high. Information: (212) 685-0800 or ddcnyc.com.

title: Markdowns Everywhere You Turn
description: Home furnishings will be discounted as much as 70 percent at Aeros winter sale, Feb. 12 to 27 (the Chelsea Side Chair by Thomas OBrien for Hickory Chair, below, regularly $2,250, will be $425); 419 Broome Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 966-1500 or aerostudios.com.

title: A Roomy 178 Square Feet
description: THE tins of seasoning on top of Zach Motls refrigerator  Old Bay, Hungarian paprika, Madras curry powder  are for show only, chosen for their graphic punch and nifty typefaces. Living in a room thats only 178 square feet, you dont want to cook much, Mr. Motl said; its just too odoriferous. He once made French onion soup, and the apartment smelled for four days. It was gross, he said.

title: Do School Libraries Need Books?
description: Keeping traditional school libraries up to date is costly, with the constant need to acquire new books and to find space to store them. Yet for all that trouble, students roam the stacks less and less because they find it so much more efficient to work online. One school, Cushing Academy, made news last fall when it announced that it would give away most of its 20,000 books and transform its library into a digital center.

title: Meeting the Treadmill Challenge
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team last week by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog before, during and after her trip to Portugal.

title: From the Archive: Instant but Timeless
description: Ansel Adams captured some fabled images of Yosemite National Park using a Polaroid; Andy Warhol and Chuck Close took Polaroid portraits  of themselves, friends and celebrities  and William Wegman used a Polaroid to shoot his beloved Weimaraners.

title: Half-Century at Daytona, Off the Fourth Turn
description: They were heading to watch cars race at Daytona at very high rates of speed.

title: With Toyota in Trouble, Rivals Gain
description: DETROIT  With Toyota stumbling as it recalls more than eight million vehicles for problems, its rivals are seeing a rare opportunity to take back some market share.

title:
Mets Hope
Frustrating
Off-Season
Ends Well
description: It was an old spring training farmhand for the Mets, Garth Brooks, who sang about thanking God for unanswered prayers. Maybe, eventually, the Mets will say the same thing about their frustrating off-season.

title: Finding Parents in Haitis Rubble Was Easy Part
description: Jean-Paul Coffy arrived in darkness at the three-story house he grew up in, in the Nerette neighborhood of Port-au-Prince, a concrete-and-tin home where his parents still lived and he visited each year.

title: Binghamton Audit Nears Completion
description: The four-month-long audit of Binghamton Universitys athletic department appears to be coming to a close, and a report was expected to be released on Thursday.

title: Iran Disrupts Internet Service Ahead of Protests
description: In an effort to disrupt communications and head off huge opposition demonstrations planned for Thursday, the Iranian authorities on Wednesday drastically slowed Internet service in Iran and shut down text messaging services, and an official said that Gmail, the Google e-mail service, would be blocked.

title: In Canada, Complete Coverage Is Not Hyperbole
description: The Olympics are in Canada for the third time, and the countrys broadcasters are planning a live media overload unlike anything seen over the United States border.

title: Europe Agrees to Aid Greece, but Is Unsure of How to Help
description: BRUSSELS  The crisis in Greece brought Europes leaders together on one issue Wednesday: The need for emergency action to keep the problem from infecting Europes other weak economies. But an accord on who will take the lead  and how  appeared uncertain.

title: U.S. Penalizes Companies Tied to Iran Corps
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on Wednesday on a commander and four companies linked to the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps of Iran, underscoring the Obama administrations determination to single out the elite corps as a way to curb Irans nuclear program.

title: At New-Look Pebble Beach, Early Peek at U.S. Open
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  There is a palpable buzz on the cliffs above the Pacific at the annual party that is the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. Whether it rains or shines  and the optimistic forecast is for four days of the latter  this tournament knows how to put on a show.
