title: Carl Braun, an All-Star With the Knicks, Dies at 82
description: Carl Braun, a former All-Star guard for the Knicks and one of the finest shooters in the first decade of the National Basketball Association, died on Wednesday in Stuart, Fla., where he lived. He was 82.

title: Rachel Alexandra Wont Race at Oaklawn
description: Rachel Alexandra, the Horse of the Year, will not be ready to face her rival, the undefeated mare Zenyatta, in the Apple Blossom Handicap in April at Oaklawn Park in Arkansas. Her trainer, Steve Asmussen, said his filly needed more time to return to racing shape after a six-month layoff.

title: Wall St.s Biggest Bonuses Go to Not-So-Big Names
description: The list of the biggest earners in finance usually reads like a Whos Who of Wall Street. But these days, it reads more like a Whos That?

title: Wang and Nationals Near Deal, and Damon Weighs Braves Offer
description: Two prominent former Yankees could land in the National League East this season, with Chien-Ming Wang closing in on a deal with the Washington Nationals on Wednesday and Johnny Damon receiving a one-year offer from the Atlanta Braves.

title: Rinks Become Backyard Entertainment Centers
description: BUFFALO  Dennis Weppner and his wife, Kathy, did not want a big bash for their 25th wedding anniversary last summer. Instead they chose to landscape their backyard. With the youngest of their five children now 15, they took down the playground and told the landscaper to create a Kansas-flat section measuring 80 feet by 40 feet.

title: Let the Debate Begin
description: "What is love?" Besides a catchy 1993 dance track by the singer Haddaway, it is a perennial question around Valentine's Day. Thursday night, head to the Algonquin Hotel, where Harper Perennial books is hosting "Love: The Debate." Moderated by Ben Greenman of "The New Yorker," the event will feature commentary and conversation on all things Eros from Ariel Leve, the author of "It Could Be Worse, You Could Be Me," Rachel Shukert, the author of "Everything Is Going to Be Great," and Simon Van Booy, the author of "The Secret Lives of People in Love." There will be wine and appetizers, so bring your sweetheart. It begins at 7 p.m.

title: Sister Act
description: It may be impossible to get a seat at their shows, but you can still admire the work of the designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy starting today at Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. The exhibition "Quicktake: Rodarte" features clothes by the sisters from Pasadena, which can be bought at department stores and appreciated "as 21st-century wearable art," writes Carol Vogel. Their designs can also be found in the permanent collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute and the Fashion Institute of Technology. The show, the second in a series of installations featuring emerging names, will include many of Rodarte's most inventive designs. "Like sculptures on mannequins, the pieces in the exhibition will highlight the unusual level of detail and workmanship that goes into every garment. It will also illustrate the sisters' imaginative use of traditional materials." It's a great opportunity to get a close-up look at their clothes this fashion week, minus the flashing lights and pushy fashion editors. Also on Feb. 20, the Vogue editor Sally Singer will interview Laura Mulleavy at the museum; the exhibit is on view through Mar. 14.

title: My So-Called Life
description: There should be a word for it in German. The feeling you get when you hear someone read from her long lost diary about her middle school crush. Thursday night, you can revel in that unique form of humiliation at the 92YTribeca where Comedy Below Canal is presenting a heartbreak edition of "Mortified." The show is a comedic "excavation of teen angst artifacts" including journals, letters, poems, lyrics, home movies and more as shared by their original authors before total strangers. This show is hosted by Anne Altman and features Adam Wade, Jenn Wehrung, Jasmin Singer, Brooke Van Poppelen, Todd Rosenberg, Julia Wright, Boni Joi and Julianna Forlano.

title: Finding a Stage
description: The fashion shows in Bryant Park put American designers on a global stage.

title: A History of Food Stamps Use and Policy
description: After a U-turn in the politics of poverty, a program once scorned as "welfare" enjoys broad support and a new identity as "nutritional aid."

title: Once Stigmatized, Food Stamps Find Acceptance
description: A decade ago, New York City officials were so reluctant to give out food stamps, they made people register one day and return the next just to get an application. The welfare commissioner said the program caused dependency and the poor were better off without it.

title: E-Book Price Increase May Stir Readers Passions
description: In the battle over the pricing of electronic books, publishers appear to have won the first round. The price of many new releases and best sellers is about to go up, to as much as $14.99 from $9.99.

title: A Message for the President
description: Nicholas D. Kristof talks to Congolese rape victims and social counselors, who ask President Obama for help in ending the conflict in eastern Congo.

title: Germany, Forced to Buoy Greece, Rues Euro Shift
description: BERLIN  As Europe edges toward emergency guarantees to stem market panic over one of the most profligate members of the euro bloc, the country that the region turns to for leadership, Germany, is suffering from growing doubts about the European experiment it long championed.

title: Vonn May Wish Her Dream Could Be Deferred a Bit Longer
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  For the last several months, when Lindsey Vonn talked about the 2010 Winter Olympics, she was happy that her strongest events were bunched in the early part of the schedule.

title: Needing Some Good News, the L.P.G.A. Adds a Sponsor
description: The L.P.G.A. said Wednesday that Kia Motors America would sponsor its newest tournament next month, welcome news after a rough 2009, when the tour lost events, sponsors and top management.

title: Slumburbia
description: LATHROP, Calif.  Drive along foreclosure alley, through new planned communities that look like tile-roofed versions of a 21st century ghost town, and you see what happens when people gamble with houses instead of casino chips.

title: Dusty N.B.A. Treasures in the Attic
description: Its the idea that got eBay started, as well as swap meets and flea markets: whats junk to you might be treasure to someone else.

title: The Torchs Path
description: The Olympic torch touched American soil for a brief moment on its quiet way to Vancouver.

title: Small Fund-Raisers for Victims Start to Add Up
description: Devin Greene celebrated his seventh birthday on Saturday. His party raised $1,025 for Mercy Corps to support its charity work in Haiti.

title: Obama Takes Several Gambles in Bid to Defuse Nuclear Standoff With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama adds economic pressure and military containment to force Irans leadership to negotiate on its nuclear program, he is taking three big bets on his ability to defuse an increasingly tense confrontation.

title: At Least 30 Athletes Fail Tests
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  More than 30 athletes who were expected to compete in the Vancouver Games were barred from competition after failing pre-Games testing, David Howman, the director general of the World Anti-Doping Agency, said Wednesday.

title: Motorola Considers Merging Units for a Spinoff
description: Motorola is considering changing its reorganization strategy by merging its mobile handset unit with its set-top boxes business in order to spin it off into a publicly traded company, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Bloggingheads: New York and Harold Ford
description: Dayo Olopade of The Root and David Weigel of The Washington Independent discuss Harold Ford's potential Senate candidacy.

title: Right to Free Speech Collides With Fight Against Terror
description: WASHINGTON  Ralph D. Fertig, a 79-year-old civil rights lawyer, says he would like to help a militant Kurdish group in Turkey find peaceful ways to achieve its goals. But he fears prosecution under a law banning even benign assistance to groups said to engage in terrorism.

title: For Detained Youths, No Mental Health Overseer
description: Edwina G. Richardson-Mendelson has been the administrative judge of the New York City Family Courts for nine months, in charge of the judges responsible for the detention of dozens of young people charged with crimes, the vast majority of whom suffer from some form of mental illness.

title: Blagojevich Wants Tapes Played in Court
description: CHICAGO  When his corruption trial begins in June, Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, wants jurors to be allowed to hear all of the audio recordings  some 500 hours worth  that federal authorities secretly made of his telephone conversations.

title: New Option for the States on Inmates in the Census
description: For decades, predominantly rural and Republican districts have had extra clout in state and local legislative bodies because their large inmate populations were counted as local residents in apportioning representation. Now, the Census Bureau has agreed to give states a tool that could dilute the political power of those districts.

title: Storms Had Romance, Once
description: KATONAH, N.Y.

title: Child Obesity Risks Death at Early Age, Study Finds
description: A rare study that tracked thousands of children through adulthood found the heaviest youngsters were more than twice as likely as the thinnest to die prematurely, before age 55, of illness or a self-inflicted injury.

title: Knicks Find That Talent Is Hard to Beat
description: The temptation, upon watching the Knicks blow a 15-point fourth-quarter lead, on their home court, against a nondescript team, is to wail and groan and wonder how and why  all reasonable reactions for a tormented fan base.

title: Slumping Rangers Lose for 8th Time in 10 Games
description: Michael Del Zotto, the Rangers 19-year-old defenseman, skated ever so slowly across the ice from the penalty box to the bench after the Nashville Predators scored a power-play goal Wednesday night. Perhaps Del Zotto thought wasting time might get Coach John Tortorella to forget his mistake.

title: Snowed In
description: New Yorkers began digging out from the the second blustery snowstorm to sweep across the Northeast in less than a week.

title: One Last Time, Fashion Under a Tent
description: GEOGRAPHY has always been a convenient form of branding in Manhattan, where Madison Avenue, Broadway and Wall Street are shorthand for career tracks as much as they are addresses.

title: A.I.G. Will Use a Grading System for Bonuses
description: The American International Group said on Wednesday that it would introduce a compensation system that grades its employees performance numerically. The rankings would then be used to determine the size of their annual bonus payments.

title: Climate-Change Debate Is Heating Up in Deep Freeze
description: WASHINGTON  As millions of people along the East Coast hole up in their snowbound homes, the two sides in the climate-change debate are seizing on the mounting drifts to bolster their arguments.

title: 20 Across: Tropical Trees
description: Heres the clue for 62 Down: Nickname of the man (born 2/12/1809) who gave the address at 18A, issued the 28A/45A, was the first elected president of the 60A Party, and whose name can be found in this puzzles main diagonal

title: After 10 Months, Chief of MySpace Steps Down
description: Owen Van Natta, the chief executive of MySpace, abruptly stepped down on Wednesday night, the News Corporation said, in another setback for its beleaguered social networking arm.

title: NBC Commits to Keeping Ellen Show
description: The Ellen DeGeneres Show will stay on stations owned and operated by NBC for the next four years, the shows distributor said late Wednesday. The move ends speculation that Ms. DeGeneres would replace Oprah Winfrey on stations owned by ABC.

title: Enviable Access Given Top 10 Donors to New York Lawmakers
description: There are thousands of them throughout New York, politically engaged citizens who contribute donations, large and small, to candidates each election.

title: Mayors Grow Attuned to the Politics of Snow Removal
description: WASHINGTON  Mayor Adrian M. Fenty, whose city has been overwhelmed by record snowfall, knows the clock is ticking. While residents have been relatively understanding  so far  about delays in plowing roads and clearing sidewalks, he recognizes the perils for politicians who do not get their cities cleaned up quickly.

title: Sanofis Profit Rises on Vaccine Sales
description: Sales of more than 100 million doses of swine flu vaccine spurred higher fourth-quarter revenue and profit for the French drug giant Sanofi-Aventis, the company said on Wednesday in a report that exceeded some analysts expectations.

title: Ukrainian States Plan
description: MOSCOW  Viktor F. Yanukovich, the presumed winner in Ukraines presidential election, outlined his priorities on Wednesday, saying that he wanted to restructure the countrys debt, improve relations with Russia and create new links to the European Union.

title: Black Leaders Push Obama for Jobs Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama promised civil rights leaders on Wednesday to push hard and work with Congress to address the high unemployment rate, particularly among the urban and rural poor.

title: Russian View of Visa Process
description: MOSCOW  How do Russians view the visa process with the European Union? The New York Times posted that question to a Russian blog about visa issues on livejournal.com. Here are some of their responses, translated by the Moscow bureau of The Times.

title: Journey Through Paperwork Greets Russians Hoping for a European Getaway
description: MOSCOW  The winter holidays have only just ended here, but many Russians are already planning their next European getaway, buying plane tickets and reserving hotels.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Canadas all-out effort to win the most medals over all at the Vancouver Games misstated John Furlongs title with the Vancouver Organizing Committee. He is chief executive, not president. (The committee has no president.)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a report in the Reuters Breakingviews column about the costs of Toyotas recent recalls misidentified the auto part being repaired on a Toyota Camry. It is the gas pedal, not the brake pedal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 31 about the promotional hype before the first Super Bowl, in 1967, erroneously attributed a proper name to the trophy presented to the winner. The award, which is now called the Vince Lombardi Trophy, was initially inscribed with the words World Professional Football Championship and was referred to generically as the world championship trophy; it was not called the Titletown Trophy. The article also referred incorrectly to the origin of the term Super Bowl. While the game was informally referred to as the Super Bowl from the beginning, Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, did not adopt the name right away.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the actor Ian Carmichael misidentified the role he played in the play Simon and Laura and the subsequent film version. He played David, a supporting character, not Simon.

title: Oregon: Judge Finds Salmon Plan Flawed
description: A federal judge told the Obama administration on Wednesday that its plan to help endangered salmon in the Pacific Northwest was technically flawed, and he urged it to revise the proposal before he rules on its broader merits. Judge James Redden of United States District Court in Portland said the plan, an effort to modify but not replace one from the Bush administration, was procedurally improper. He gave the administration until next week to decide whether to modify its plan, and urged it to do more to protect salmon.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about the physicist Geoffrey Burbidge misidentified one of the places where he and his wife, E. Margaret Burbidge, worked in the 1960s. It was the University of Chicagos Yerkes Observatory in Williams Bay, Wis.  not the University of Wisconsin.

title: Pennsylvania: Harrisburg Bond Rating Is Lowered
description: Harrisburg, the state capital, has been downgraded to five levels below investment grade by Moodys Investors Service, as the city considers bankruptcy in the face of $68 million in debt service payments. Moodys lowered its grading on Harrisburgs general obligation bonds to B2 on Tuesday, from Ba2. Harrisburg officials have said Chapter 9 bankruptcy is one option under consideration.

title: Museum Creates New Jerusalem Divide
description: JERUSALEM  In a dispute that reflects the religious and political divides in this contested city, representatives of long-established Palestinian families petitioned the United Nations on Wednesday for help in trying to stop Israel and the Simon Wiesenthal Center from constructing a museum on part of a centuries-old Muslim cemetery.

title: Campaigns Big Enough to Open With Olympics
description: TO say that the folks on Madison Avenue who create television commercials have been busy lately is like saying New Orleans was pleased when the Saints won the Super Bowl. The debut of scores of campaigns, tied to the start of the Olympics on Friday, is part of what may be the most concentrated period of big-budget, big-name marketing efforts in years.

title: West Bank Attack Kills Israeli Soldier
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli soldier was killed Wednesday in the northern West Bank by a Palestinian police officer, the Israeli military said. It was a rare instance of violence that occurred at a delicate time, with the Israeli and Palestinian security forces trying to build mutual trust.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 24 about the actress Jean Simmons referred incorrectly to the movie Footsteps in the Fog, in which she starred with her husband, Stewart Granger. It was a British film, not an American one.

title: 2 Ex-Workers Accuse Blackwater Security Company of Defrauding the U.S. for Years
description: WASHINGTON  Two former employees of Blackwater Worldwide have accused the private security company of defrauding the government for years by filing bogus receipts, double billing for the same services and charging government agencies for strippers and prostitutes, according to court documents unsealed this week.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Collections: Frivolous Obsessions
description: I love dropping by workrooms before the shows, and few are more absorbed in the small details than the dedicated folks at Ralph Ruccis shop. He is located in SoHo, where his show will be on Thursday night. Thats a first for hima kind of salon presentation for about 225 people. Isnt it the best way to see clothes?

title: Clash Over Plans for a Brooklyn Park
description: The way Marty Markowitz sees it, the rundown nine-acre park where Coney Island and Brighton Beach meet is ripe for a sparkling transformation.

title: Chinese Producer Prices Jumped Sharply in January
description: HONG KONG  The rate of inflation at factories and other producers more than doubled last month in China, with producer prices climbing at the fastest pace in 15 months while the money supply continued to grow briskly.

title: The Challenge of China
description: Relations between the United States and China have turned chilly in recent months as the two countries wrangle over Taiwan, Tibet, Iran and Chinas continued manipulation of its currency.

title: Unfit for Office
description: For the first time in nearly a century, the New York State Senate has ousted one of its members. Tuesdays 53-to-8 vote to expel Hiram Monserrate, a Democrat from Queens, was the right thing to do. Mr. Monserrate was convicted last year of violently abusing his companion, Karla Giraldo.

title: Sensible Rules for Ethanol
description: Despite pressure from farm state politicians, the Environmental Protection Agency has taken an important step to ensure that biofuels help rather than hurt the environment. Under new guidelines, biofuels produced at new facilities  including ethanol from corn, sugar, plants and other sources  must achieve at least a 20 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions compared with conventional gasoline.

title: Prisons, Redistricting and the Census
description: The Census Bureau struck a blow for electoral fairness recently when it decided to speed up publication of its data on prison populations to ensure it is available for the next round of redistricting. We hope this new data, which will be released in the spring of 2011, will bolster the efforts of reformers who are trying to end prison-based gerrymandering  the cynical practice of drawing legislative districts with populations inflated by inmates who do not have the right to vote and whose actual residences are often far away.

title: No Child Left Behind, Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mortgage Crisis: Suggestions for Some Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Evidence of Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: The Biggest Losers
description: Our question for today is, who has the most awful political culture, Illinois or New York?

title: The Grotesque Vocabulary in Congo
description: BUKAVU, Congo

title: Motorola Considers Merging Units for a Spinoff
description: Motorola is considering changing its reorganization strategy by merging its mobile handset unit with its set-top boxes business, then spinning the combination off into a publicly traded company, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

title: The Politicians Wife Claims No Baggage
description: SINCE early January, when Harold E. Ford Jr. announced he was considering a bid for a Senate seat from New York, his wife, Emily Ford, has been hounded. Her friends call almost daily to ask if she has read the latest gossip about the couple. Mr. Ford cant seem to stop talking about his wife, either, recently telling a columnist that he walks her favorite Chihuahua, Fabby.

title: Trying On Shoes in Someone Elses Dream
description: TWAS a dreary day south of Houston Street: slush on the streets, a sky the color of wet socks, an old, irreparable sadness throbbing in the heart like a migraine. Theres not enough light in the sky these days, not enough love in the world and not enough fluidity in the economic bloodstream.

title: Another Wrinkle in the A.I.G. Bailout
description: The plot thickens again for the American International Group bailout. The rescued insurer is in discussions to sell its American Life Insurance, or Alico, unit to MetLife. But A.I.G. might get MetLife stock as part of the potential $15 billion deal. As a result, the government could end up owning stock in yet another company, bringing further delay and uncertainty to the bailout repayment effort.

title: Charlie Wilson, Texas Congressman Linked to Foreign Intrigue, Dies at 76
description: Charlie Wilson, a 12-term Texas congressman who was best known for his playboy ways until he masterminded a covert effort to funnel billions of dollars in arms to Afghan rebels fighting the Soviets in the 1980s, died Wednesday in Lufkin, Tex. He was 76.

title: Rowleys Instant Gratification
description: WITH today marking the beginning of yet another Fashion Week, as hundreds of designers prepare to show their fall collections, let us take a moment to consider how the immediacy of information in the Internet era has created a disconnect for consumers. Images from the fall shows will be streaming online as they happen, at the same time that the spring collections, which were shown last September, are arriving in stores.

title: New Hampshire: Inquiry Sought at Nuclear Plant
description: Gov. John Lynch asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Wednesday to investigate the Entergy Corporations Vermont Yankee nuclear plant. Mr. Lynch said he wanted an inquiry into elevated levels of tritium in groundwater monitoring wells at the site in Vernon, Vt., which is across the Connecticut River from New Hampshire. Vermont Yankee reported finding the tritium, a radioactive form of hydrogen, to the Vermont Department of Health on Jan. 7.

title: New Jersey Added to Trial to Cut Health Insurance Paperwork
description: As part of the discussion last year over how best to overhaul the nations health care system, the insurance industry promised to do its part by tackling the burdensome paperwork involved in paying medical claims.

title: In Hockey, It Cant Hurt to Hit the Ice Early
description: WHEN Jenny Potter first learned to play hockey as a child on an outdoor rink in Edina, Minn., she had no idea that she had already given herself a huge edge.

title: China Rejects Dissidents Appeal
description: HONG KONG  A court in Beijing on Thursday denied an appeal by one of Chinas best-known democracy advocates and upheld his 11-year prison sentence, human rights activists said.

title: John Dankworth, a Leader of British Jazz Scene, Dies at 82
description: John Dankworth, one of the leading lights of the British jazz scene for more than a half-century, died Feb. 6 in London. He was 82.

title: Brooks Thomas, Publishing Executive at Harper & Row, Dies at 78
description: Brooks Thomas, who led Harper & Row Publishers during a period of turmoil and consolidation in the publishing industry and who was its chief executive when it was acquired by Rupert Murdochs News Corporation in 1987, died Friday in San Diego. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan; Essex, Conn.; and Vail, Colo.

title: Tell Us Why You Deserve Fame (You Have 30 Minutes)
description: IT is commonplace among Serious Fashion Insiders to decry as an outlandish caricature the version of the rag trade seen on reality programs like Project Runway. Still, when a group of real designers prepares to be judged before a panel of distinguished industry leaders, the urge does strike to call out, Make it work!

title: Ankles With Attitude
description: BLAME it on tourists, aging hippies, Del Boca Vista retirees or the boys of Jersey Shore, but in the great pantheon of fashion faux pas, the socks-and-sandal combo is perhaps the most egregious. Nevertheless, it showed up on quite a few spring runways, looking decidedly adorable.

title: Phil Harris, Crusty Captain on Deadliest Catch, Dies at 53
description: Phil Harris, the bearded, cantankerous captain of the Cornelia Marie, one of the small fleet of crab-fishing boats that have plied the perilous waters off the coast of Alaska for five seasons on the hit reality television show Deadliest Catch, died on Tuesday in Anchorage. He was 53 and lived in Seattle.

title: Citys Courts Get Snow Day, Too, but Not Everyone Got to Go Home
description: The snowstorm caused countless cancellations, from city schools to commercial flights on Wednesday. But among those cancellations, the decision to close courthouses in New York stood out  both for its infrequency and the complications it caused.

title: Concern Aired Over Banks Real Estate Loans
description: WASHINGTON  A huge wave of mortgage failures on commercial real estate could hit next year, causing banks to lose as much as $300 billion, imperiling lending for small businesses and hindering the economic recovery, a Congressional panel is warning.

title: Bagel-nomics: For $177, You Also Get the Kitchen Sink?
description: It would be difficult to order a nearly $200 bagel sandwich at Bits Bites & Baguettes  difficult, but certainly not impossible. You would have to get creative. The bagel would have to get messy.

title: SEB Squeaks By With Quarterly Profit
description: SEB, one of the Swedish banks with a major presence in the Baltic states, reported a fourth quarter operating profit on Wednesday of 564 million kronor ($77 million), a seventh of its 4 billion kronor profit a year earlier, as loans in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania hurt its bottom line.

title: The Last of my Congo Columns
description: just went up, with a bit more of a look at what can be done. Theres no magic bullet, but the four steps I outline seem to reflect a common view about what would help. And theres a risk in writing about eastern Congo that readers think that the whole country is a catastrophe. In fact, most of the country has stabilized and is much better off. On my first visit to Congo in 1997, I drove from Kisangani all the way to the east (it took a week), and for years that was then impossible for security reasons. Now it can be done again, and the road has improved enough that the route takes just two days.

title: Two Charities Start Fund to Help Haitians in New York
description: It will be years before the impact of Haitis earthquake on Haitians in New York can be fully measured. But as the local population rushes to respond  increasing remittances to relatives in Haiti, welcoming others who are fleeing the destruction, or mourning the dead  two of the citys major charities are pitching in to help.

title: U.S. Told to Review Files on Terror Case Detention
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ordered prosecutors to review Justice Department files concerning the governments decisions to detain a terrorism suspect for nearly five years in the C.I.A.s secret jails and later at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, before moving him into the civilian court system last year.

title: Figure Under Scrutiny in Inquiry Into Charity Was on Senate Payroll
description: A figure under scrutiny in the federal investigation into a charity set up by State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and United States Representative Gregory W. Meeks was placed on the Senate payroll by Mr. Smith in 2002 shortly after he lost his job as a Queens prosecutor for lying to a judge, officials said Wednesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Audit Raised Concerns About a Union Administrator Before Charges Were Filed
description: In December, federal prosecutors charged a benefits administrator with pillaging $42 million from the employee benefit funds of the union representing the construction workers known as sandhogs, who dig the citys giant water tunnels.

title: Greek Civil Servants Strike Over Austerity
description: ATHENS  Striking civil servants brought public services to a halt across Greece on Wednesday, in a largely peaceful one-day protest against the tough austerity measures that officials have said are necessary to stave off a mounting financial crisis.

title: Kashmir: India Talks About a Shooting
description: Indias Border Security Force admitted that one of its soldiers might have shot an unarmed youth whose death set off ferocious protests across Kashmir. The youth, Zahid Farooq, 17, was shot when security forces stormed a playground in Kashmirs capital, Srinagar, on Friday. The circumstances of the attack are unclear. Another boy, Wamiq Farooq, 14, died after being struck by a tear gas canister on Jan. 31. The protests shut down life across much of the Kashmir Valley for several days, though many businesses reopened Tuesday. Kashmiris chafe at the heavy military presence in the valley, which both India and Pakistan claim.

title: News Quiz | February 11, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Terreno Realty Shares Tumble in Debut
description: Terreno Realty saw its shares tumble in the companys stock market debut, following a scaled-back initial public offering, The Associated Press said.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Caps 14-Game Streak Ends in OT
description: Eight games on Wednesday night, and the biggest one was in Montreal, where the Capitals put their 14-game winning streak  tied for the third-longest in N.H.L. history  on the line. Home teams listed first:

title:
East Coast Confronts
Storms Aftermath
description: The blustery storm, as forecasters had predicted, walloped the Northeast, dropping a foot of snow in some places as it crawled up the eastern seaboard and then churned to oblivion over the Atlantic early Thursday.

title: North Koreas Wayne Rooney
description: Jong Tae-Se is a promising striker for one of the top clubs in Japan, the country where he was born and has lived his entire life.

title: Piedmont Office Shares Rise in Debut
description: Piedmont Office Realty Trust stock is rising after its pared-back initial public offering raised $174 million.

title: Opinion: Letter From Foreclosure Alley
description: Our editorial page colleague, the columnist Tim Egan, visited the San Francisco Bays exurbs to see the detritus left behind by the foreclosure crisis. He found some ghost suburbs, and other areas he calls suburban slums.

title: Iran Boasts of Capacity to Make Bomb Fuel
description: CAIRO  Irans president boasted Thursday that his nation had the capacity to make weapons-grade nuclear fuel if it chose to, in a speech intended to rally the nation as it marked the 31st anniversary of the Islamic Revolution.

title: Grimmette to Lead U.S. Into Vancouver Games
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Mark Grimmette is a five-time Olympian; he slid his way to a silver medal in luge in 2002 and a bronze in 1998; hes ahigh-tech test pilot, of sorts; and now hell lead his countrymen into the B.C. Place for the 2010 Vancouver Games.

title: Wall St.s Biggest Bonuses Go to Not-So-Big Names
description: The list of the biggest earners in finance usually reads like a Whos Who of Wall Street. But these days, it reads more like a Whos That?

title: After 10 Months, Chief of MySpace Steps Down
description: Owen Van Natta, the chief executive of MySpace, abruptly stepped down on Wednesday night, the News Corporation said, in another setback for its beleaguered social networking arm.

title: Report Warns Silicon Valley Could Lose Its Edge
description: Silicon Valleys economy is sputtering and risks permanently stalling, according to an annual report by a group of researchers in the region, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

title: Travelport Scraps $1.7 Billion London I.P.O.
description: Travelport, the private equity-backed airline ticketing firm, called off its $1.78 billion London listing on Wednesday, citing poor market conditions, the latest in a slew of failed initial public offerings across Europe.

title: Snowed In
description: WHO are the mayors of Baltimore and Washington, D.C.?

title: Another Wrinkle in the A.I.G. Bailout
description: The plot thickens again for the American International Group bailout. The rescued insurer is in discussions to sell its American Life Insurance, or Alico, unit to MetLife.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about the designer Zac Posen referred incorrectly to Glenda Bailey, the editor of Harpers Bazaar. She did in fact attend his runway show in September.

title: Cowboy Adoptions
description: Adoptions that disregard formal domestic or international processes.

title: What News Stories Are Awesome?
description: A research team has studied the NYTimes.com most e-mailed list and discovered that certain kinds of content increase the likelihood that readers will share these articles with friends and family. What kinds of news reports do you like to tell your friends about? What kinds of news stories do you prefer and enjoy most?

title: Shares Toss and Turn for Most of the Day
description: A heap of uncertainty greeted Wall Street on Wednesday, setting the stage for an up-and-down day that left investors searching for a sense of direction.

title: Autonomy Builds Deal Warchest
description: Fresh off its $55 million acquisition of MicroLink, British software company Autonomy received approval from shareholders to make a $1 billion acquisition after backing a 500 million ($758 million) convertible bond issue, The Financial Times reported.

title: Concern Aired Over Banks Real Estate Loans
description: A huge wave of mortgage failures on commercial real estate could hit next year, causing banks to lose as much as $300 billion, imperiling lending for small businesses and hindering the economic recovery, a Congressional panel is warning.

title: Background Check Office Opens in Europe
description: A United States-based company that does financial background checks is opening a European office, in a tangible sign investors like funds of hedge funds are paying more than just lip service to risk management in the post-Madoff world.

title: New Trial in Milkshake Murder
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kongs highest court overturned on Thursday the murder conviction of an American woman who allegedly spiked her husbands strawberry milkshake with a date-rape drug and then bashed him in the head with a brass figurine.

title: Regulators Tackle Carry Trades
description: As governments seek to root out and smother what they see as excessively risky and questionable financial market activity, the world of currency carry trades has found its way onto their radar, Reuters writes.

title: 3i Mulls Bids for State Assets
description: The 3i Group is considering bidding for assets being sold by the government, its chief executive said Wednesday.

title: Chinese Court Denies Appeal by Jailed Activist
description: HONG KONG  A court in Beijing denied an appeal by one of Chinas best-known democracy advocates on Thursday and upheld his 11-year prison sentence, human rights activists said.

title: Thailand to Deport Crew of North Korean Arms Plane
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Thailand will deport the crew of an aircraft that flew into Bangkok two months ago laden with North Korean weapons, a Thai official said Thursday.

title: N. Korea Said to Apologize Over Currency Changes
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean government has made a rare apology for a policy blunder and lifted a ban on using foreign currency, South Korean news organizations said Thursday.

title: Matalan Calls Off Sale
description: Matalan, the British discount fashion retailer, has taken itself off the block. The company said it had closed down the potential sale process for the business, without giving a reason.

title: AMG Acquires Pantheon for $775 Million
description: Corrected | 11:08 a.m. Continuing its shopping spree, Affiliated Managers Group said Wednesday that it had snapped up Pantheon Ventures, a London private equity fund-of-funds, for $775 million in cash.

title: Repossessions in Britain Hit 15-Year High, and Look to Rise
description: The British Council of Mortgage Lenders said Thursday that 46,000 properties had been repossessed last year, a 15-year high that was nonetheless slightly under the 48,000 it had predicted, as the rate of repossession fell by 13 percent in the fourth quarter from the third.

title: Citi Names New Head of Global Commodities
description: Citigroup said on Wednesday it has named Stuart Staley to replace the retiring head of global commodities, a unit that the bank, the third-largest in the United States, aims to expand by 30 to 40 percent over the next three years, Reuters said.

title: Brown Says World Is Ready to Move on Bank Tax
description: In an interview with The Financial Times, Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Great Britain said he thought the world was moving toward a global bank tax.

title: Twitter Taps Pixar Executive as C.F.O.
description: Twitter named a chief financial officer on Wednesday, as the microblogging service, now two-and-a-half years old, steps up its efforts to make money.

title: At Hong Kong Mall, the Ultimate Collision of Commerce and Art
description: Billing itself as the worlds first art mall, K11 opened in mid-December, with 340,000 square feet of retail space and 13 permanent installations by prominent Hong Kong artists. Though the worlds first tag is a bit of a stretch  many modern malls feature bits of artistic flare  K11 highlights local artists in a city that tends to be all business. The new shopping center (18 Hanoi Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon; www.k11concepts.com) is the brainchild of Adrian Cheng, the retail specialist who also happens to be the grandson of Cheng Yu-tung, the head of New World Development, which developed the mall.

title: Barclays Buys Citis Italian Credit Card Unit
description: Barclays is buying Citigroups Italian credit card business, as the British bank accelerates its push in certain European countries.

title: Pereira Says the N.F.L. Has It Wrong on Pass Interference
description: Pointing you to a radio interview by the N.F.L.s outgoing vice president for officiating, Mike Pereira. He talked to Mike Felger and Tony Massarotti of The Sports Hub in Boston before the Super Bowl. The interview was discussed on a Patriots message board and found its way to Mike Florio of ProFootballTalk.com.

title: European Leaders Agree to Rescue Greece
description: European leaders, facing a crucial test for the credibility of their common currency, said Thursday that they had reached an agreement aimed at persuading jittery bond market investors that Greece would not be allowed to default on its government debt, Stephen Castle reports in The New York Times.

title: Building a Better Bunker-Buster
description: Todays idea: The science of aerial bombardment is evolving to try to make bombing campaigns safer for civilians  and more dangerous for bunkers deep underground.

title: Ex-Corruption Chief in Indonesia Sentenced in Murder Plot
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  An Indonesian court on Thursday found the countrys former anticorruption czar and three other men guilty of orchestrating the murder of a prominent business executive, although the court backed off from demands by prosecutors that the men be sentenced to death.

title: Air Products Begins Tender Offer for Airgas
description: Air Products on Thursday officially turned hostile with a $5.1 billion tender offer for Airgas, taking its $60-a-share all-cash proposal directly to its targets shareholders two days after being rejected again.

title: Word of the Day | squander
description: squander \skwn-dr\ verb

title: White House Moves to Clear Up Comments on Bankers
description: It seems the White House was none too pleased with the fallout from an article in which President Obama appeared to take a more conciliatory stance toward the financial sector, telling Bloomberg BusinessWeek that he did not begrudge people success or wealth, as it was part of the free-market system.

title: Is Summers Ready to Get Tough on Big Banks?
description: Simon Johnson, a fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, and James Kwak are the authors of the forthcoming book 13 Bankers.

title: Europe Commits to Action on Greek Debt
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders on Thursday promised to safeguard their common currency by backstopping Greece during its debt crisis. But they offered no immediate aid to Athens and remained silent on how they would respond if markets resumed their attacks on the weaker nations that rely on the euro.

title: Chicago Auto Show: Kia Ray Plug-In Hybrid Concept
description: CHICAGO  The Kia Ray plug-in hybrid concept, which was shown at the auto show here on Wednesday, is a study in aerodynamics: a blunt front end and long tail, low roof, skinny tires and an emphasis on being eco-friendly. Even the audio system  Infinitys GreenEdge  is designed to draw less electricity.

title: Cedar Fair Sets Date for Apollo Vote
description: It seems that March 16 will be the date that Apollo Management will find out if its plan to buy Cedar Fair Entertainment will be a go.

title: Sampler: Asian Surnames Top Homebuyers and a Plan to Restore Bay Area Marshes
description: Silicon Valleys Economy at Risk | A new study says that Silicon Valley lost 90,000 jobs in 2009, compared with the same period in 2008. The drop in the number of midlevel jobs, like engineers, has been the sharpest, as employers hire contractors instead of regular employees or hire people abroad, according to the annual report produced by the Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network and the Silicon Valley Community Foundation. But the report says the regions troubles go beyond the current job picture and the area could lose its competitive edge. Let me give you a few snapshots in despair, wrote Chris OBrien, in a column in The San Jose Mercury News. The venture capital industry is collapsing. Our educational system is failing. State government is dysfunctional. Other regions are cleaning up on federal funding for green-tech jobs. And immigrants who have kept our innovation economy humming are feeling less and less welcome. [The New York Times, The San Jose Mercury News].

title: Credit Suisse Sees Gains at Expense of Rival UBS
description: Credit Suisse reported a fourth-quarter profit that came in under analyst expectations Thursday, but said it was gaining market share in the important wealth management business as its rival, UBS, suffers.

title: In $4.7 Billion Deal, FirstEnergy of Ohio Is to Buy a Pennsylvania Utility
description: FirstEnergy of Ohio agreed on Thursday to buy Allegheny Energy of Pennsylvania for $4.7 billion in stock, creating a giant electricity provider with customers spread across the Midwest and mid-Atlantic.

title: Feb. 11: Updates on Demonstrations in Iran
description: On Thursday, The Lede is tracking news of demonstrations in Iran posted online, as the country officially celebrates the 31st anniversary of the Islamic Revolution. Readers are encouraged to share any first-hand accounts of the protests in the comments thread below or by writing to lede@nytimes.com.

title: No Parking, Even When Sign Is Snow-Covered
description: The snow that blanketed the city also left many street parking signs under a layer of white, obliterating the various regulations. This caused confusion among drivers and left them wondering whether the city could enforce rules that were impossible for motorists to discern.

title: California Congresswoman to Retire
description: Democratic officials say Representative Diane Watson, a Los Angeles Democrat, is scheduled to announce today that she will not seek a return to the House in November.

title: FirstEnergy to Buy Allegheny in $4.7 Billion Merger
description: FirstEnergy of Ohio agreed on Thursday to buy Allegheny Energy of Pennsylvania for $4.7 billion in stock, creating a giant electricity provider with customers spread across the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic.

title: Once Upon a Mattress Pile
description: Sight Gag | A reader calls this bachelor padding:

title: The Nifty 50 | Sara VanDerBeek, Photographer
description: This month, T celebrates the Nifty 50: Americas up-and-coming talent.

title: Tri-Artisan Strikes Merger Agreement with Jesup
description: The private equity firm Tri-Artisan Capital Partners has reached an agreement in principle to combine with the Wall Street brokerage firm Jesup & Lamont, in a sign that consolidation among investment boutiques continues.

title: Europe Rejects U.S. Deal on Bank Data
description: BRUSSELS  The European Parliament on Thursday broadly rejected an agreement with the United States on sharing information about bank transfers that was aimed at tracking people suspected of being terrorists.

title: President Obama Sings! (Bob Dylan, Too)
description: If heavy snow  or, say, the lack of an invitation  kept you from In Performance at the White House: A Celebration of Music from the Civil Rights Movement, a concert that took place on Tuesday (and which Jon Pareles reviewed here), the event will be broadcast Thursday night on PBS. In the meantime, the Web site of The Washington Post points us to some video clips from the concert, including the highlight reel above, which includes portions of performances by Smokey Robinson, Bob Dylan, Jennifer Hudson and even President Obama, who joined in a final singalong of Lift Every Voice and Sing.

title: The Early Word: Digging Out
description: The snow has stopped falling in Washington  for the moment, at least, although gusting winds have been shifting the drifts a bit throughout the early morning.

title: Speed Read For Thursday, Feb. 11
description: Highlights from media coverage in Thursdays New York Times:

title: Prospect of Aid for Greece Gives Wall Street a Boost
description: A promise by European leaders to come to the aid of their weaker brethren calmed American markets on Thursday, helping stocks overcome an early wave of pessimism.

title: How the Recession Made Us Stronger
description: As it did with most companies out there, the recession hit SRC like a brick. But, as Ive discussed a few times, it was a number of decisions that helped us pull through. Now that the results are in for 2009, its clear that those decisions didnt just help us survive  they made us stronger.

title: O Brother, Where Art Thou?
description: High on the list of stuff that drives caregivers berserk, along with Medicare regulations and nursing home staff shortages, is the behavior of brothers and sisters.

title: Report  on Green Business Practices Pits Perception Against Reality
description: If truth is only a matter of perception, then brands like Wendys, Levis and Amazon.com may be a bit luckier than, say, Nike or GE  at least as it relates to their environmental credentials.

title: How to Keep a Warm Halfpipe Alive
description: VANCOUVER  Of the six events scheduled for the snow-deficient Cypress Mountain, the most difficult logistical challenge probably involves the halfpipe for snowboarding.

title: John Mayer Says Hes Sorry for Racially Charged Interview
description: Update | 10:11 a.m.  In what may be a new record for the shortest time elapsed between a performer giving a candid interview and apologizing for its contents, the musician John Mayer apologized on Wednesday for the contents of a candid interview he gave to Playboy magazine.

title: P.E. Should Forget Financial Engineering
description: BERLIN  To succeed when cheap debt isnt as available as it once was, private equity firms should refocus on their traditional task, turning around companies, two industry veterans said here at the Super Return conference on Thursday.

title: Thanks to the Snow, Intimacy at the Orchestra
description: To look at the sparse audience for the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, you would think that a full-fledged blizzard had dropped a couple of feet of snow on the city. Outside Lincoln Center it was a bit slushy but navigable; the subways were running and cabs were plentiful. (Admittedly, for Philharmonic subscribers outside Manhattan, getting into the city was a messier, more complicated matter.) But the orchestras press spokesman said the phones had been ringing all day with questions about whether the concert (reviewed here) would be canceled, and at 7:30  curtain time  most rows in the hall seemed to have more empty seats than full ones.

title: Ristretto | My Caffeinated Valentine
description: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why its never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

title: Is Summers Ready to Get Tough With Big Banks?
description: From Simon Johnson and James Kwak at Economix:

title: The Unlikely but Not Impossible Bagel
description: Updated, 10:37 a.m.| It would be difficult to spend nearly $200 on bagel sandwich at Bits Bites & Baguettes  difficult, but certainly not impossible. You would have to get creative. The bagel would have to get messy.

title: Europe Rejects U.S. Deal on Bank Data
description: The European Parliament on Thursday broadly rejected an agreement with the United States on sharing information on bank transfers that was aimed at tracking suspected terrorists through their finances, James Kanter reports in The New York Times.

title: How Christian Were the Founders?
description: LAST MONTH, A WEEK before the Senate seat of the liberal icon Edward M. Kennedy fell into Republican hands, his legacy suffered another blow that was perhaps just as damaging, if less noticed. It happened during what has become an annual spectacle in the culture wars.

title: Weekly Popcast: Sade, Lionel Loueke and Cedric Watson
description: This week: a review of Soldier of Love, the new album from Sade; the African jazz guitarist Lionel Loueke; and, just in time for Mardi Gras, Cedric Watson plays Cajun music in our studio.

title: A.I.G. Lines Up Underwriters for A.I.A. Offering
description: The American International Group has called upon virtually every major bank in Hong Kong to underwrite the initial public offering of its Asian life insurance unit, Reuters reported Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Another View: Why Privacy Matters to the Swiss
description: James Nason, head of international communications at the Swiss Bankers Association, gives his personal view of why the Swiss remain so attached to privacy in banking.

title: Aqua Makes a Splash in London
description: The much buzzed-about Aqua London, which recently opened atop the former Dickins & Jones department store in Londons Soho, is really three venues in one.

title: David Cromer Isnt Giving Up
description: It was a Monday in late October,  a week before Neil Simons Brighton Beach Memoirs was to open in its first Broadway revival since the original 1983 production. David Cromer, the plays director, stood near the entrance to Barneys New York. He looked partly excited, because this was his big break, his Broadway debut, coming on the heels of his Off Broadway triumph: the imaginatively staged, emotionally transcendent production of Our Town. At the same time he looked partly miserable, because that is what David Cromer does for a living when hes not directing. There was no particular reason for misery  at this juncture of his life, at least. But old habits die hard, so there he was, on the outside looking in, a gray knit cap pulled over his hair, wearing a well-worn tweed jacket, gray corduroy pants that had never seen an iron and Pumas. Though these clothes came from J. Crew and the Gap, Cromers wardrobe tends to span a palette of odd colors  rare shades of mustard or something that is not quite brown, the sartorial equivalent of mystery meat  so its no surprise to learn that he has long shopped at secondhand stores.

title: The End of the Space Age
description: The apparent end of manned spaceflight, under the Obama administrations budgetary scalpel, has produced reactions from some interesting quarters. (Who knew, for instance, that James Cameron wants us to go into space? Doesnt he know that well either end up despoiling the flora of an alien world, or being devoured by its megafauna?) On the merits of the decision, I suppose Im in reluctant agreement with John Derbyshires Room For Debate contribution, in which he argues that in a time of cratering public finances, the stupendous costs of manned spaceflight  half a billion dollars per shuttle launch  cannot be justified. On what it says about our civilizations relationship to space, though, I sympathize with Christopher Caldwells point of view:

title: Reading Between the Sheets
description: Over the years, as a parade of powerful male figures (mostly politicians, with the exception of one particular golfer whom we treat like a world leader) have been caught with women who were usually younger and always less powerful than they, the question has often been raised: Why dont women gamble their political and personal futures like this? Is it because powerful women dont cheat? Or is it just that they dont get caught? Is it because the May-December equation sizzles only when hes December? Or because there are not yet enough women out there yet with real clout?

title: Sprite Recast as Spark in a Bottle
description: A soft-drink brand that could use a spark to reignite its once-strong growth in its home market is getting a new campaign based on that concept.

title: After the Beer Summit
description: Youre a Harvard professor and a scholar of African-American literature; what led you to undertake your new PBS series, Faces of America, in which you research the ancestry and genetic makeup of a dozen mostly white celebrities, including Meryl Streep and Stephen Colbert?  In 2006, when we first aired the series African American Lives, I got a huge response. A woman wrote to me and said, I like the series, but why dont you trace someone like me, who is of Russian-Jewish descent? I thought that was a great idea.

title: Cellar Door
description: Words like mother  and love often appear on lists of beautiful English words. But so do defenestration and lollygag. Obviously, they are not all chosen for the same reason. Some words tug at the heart, some pique the mind and others are simply euphonious. Perhaps the strangest member of the last category, the purely harmonious, is the otherwise ordinary phrase cellar door.

title: Oscar Chases the Youths of Today
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, whose stodginess rivals a meter maids, is joining the social media era. No Google Buzz just yet, but it is unveiling an iPhone app for the Oscars. It lists all the nominees with valuable insider information and allows you to see trailers for the best pictures and others, and to make and share your predictions for the winners.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Philip Morris to Buy Back $12 Billion in Shares
description: Philip Morris International said on Thursday that it would buy back $12 billion of its own shares, as it reported strong fourth quarter and full-year earnings.

title: On Arms Sales to Taiwan, China Sends Mixed Signals
description: HONG KONG  China sent contradictory signals on Thursday about its policies toward the United States two weeks after the Obama administration enraged the Chinese by approving the sale of $6.4 billion worth of arms to Taiwan.

title: The Google Alphabet
description: If you have asked Google to show suggestions in your browser toolbar, you know the keen comfort of discovering youre not alone in asking the Internet questions its not quite equipped to answer, including, Am I pregnant? and Am I crazy? You start typing Am I   and like an impatient therapist Google Suggest interrupts you with a drop-down list of concepts seemingly culled from the unconsciousness of the human race. Google doesnt let you wallow in your eccentricities. Whats that? Are you  oh, lemme take a wild guess here  crazy? Well, now, thats original. . . .

title: A Closing on Broadway Becomes Permanent
description: Updated, 2:03 p.m. | The citys ambitious re-engineering of the Midtown street grid, which closed parts of Broadway to vehicular traffic last spring, will become permanent, despite few improvements to the areas traffic flow.

title: Q. and A. With Times Journalists in Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER  A day before the official start of the 2010 Winter Games, New York Times editors and reporters in Vancouver will answer your questions.

title: Dodd Kick-Starts Financial Reform Talks
description: Updated: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said today that talks over legislation to overhaul the nations financial regulations had resumed, although whether a bipartisan agreement could be reached remained far from clear.

title: Darth Vader, William Kristol and the Khaki Pants Ethos
description: Hang around politics long enough and you will notice a guy who is always blowing past the people with the clipboards and diving into the thick of it, all back claps and bon mots. After seeing him talk both smack and wonk in his native Beltway environment, you might be tempted to ask, Who is this guy?

title: Mets Agree to a Deal With Another Japanese Pitcher
description: Since 1997, when they signed an obscure reliever out of the Japanese minor leagues, the Mets have had more players from Japan than any other major league team. That international connection remains strong as the Mets added their second Japanese pitcher of the off-season on Thursday.

title: Live From New York, Could It BeBetty White?
description: After 88 years of traveling down that road and back again, are things finally starting to look up for Betty White? Ms. White, known to some as the longtime Mary Tyler Moore and Golden Girls actor, to others as a perennial game-show and talk-show panelist, and to still others as the breakout star of the Sandra BullockRyan Reynolds comedy The Proposal, now finds herself the beneficiary of an online campaign to have her host Saturday Night Live. A Facebook page called Betty White to Host SNL (please?)! has compelled more than 182,000 members of that online social network to sign on as fans, and the movement has gained momentum from Ms. Whites recent appearances at the Screen Actors Guild Awards (where she received a lifetime achievement honor) and in a popular Super Bowl commercial (with fellow octogenarian Abe Vigoda).

title: Baucus, Grassley Propose New Jobs Bill
description: The top Democrat and Republican on the Senate tax-writing committee today unveiled the main elements of a new jobs and economic recovery measure, hoping to put some rare bipartisan momentum behind major legislation.

title: In the Calculations of Online Dating, Love Can Be Cruel
description: Heidi Funai sat perched at the swank bar at Circa in San Franciscos Marina district, the citys mecca for straight singles. As men sidled up, she noted which ones might be there to mingle and which wore wedding bands.

title: YouTube, the G-Rated Edition
description: Today marks the debut of YouTube Safety Mode, a subtle but potentially reassuring parental control that can be found onthe bottom of every YouTube screen, from this day forward. Now you can locka filter onto what YouTube displays, and your YouTube account password actsas the key. Heres how to turn it on:

title: War Rooms
description: Christiane Amanpour Age: 52 Occupation: Journalist Current Project: "Amanpour," a weekly program on CNN that investigates international news stories.

title: Columbia River Salmon Dispute Continues
description: The federal government is being given one last chance to develop a plan that would allow endangered salmon and hydroelectric dams to co-exist on the Columbia River.

title: Florida Republican Congressman to Retire
description: Updated Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Florida Republican, announced today that he will not seek another term this year, making him the 18th House Republican to decide not to run for re-election.

title: Inside the Rings
description: On the eve of the Winter Games, a look at how increasingly dangerous the Olympics have become and what topics will dominate coverage from Vancouver.

title: At the Center of Vancouvers (Lack of) Storm: John Furlong
description: VANCOUVER  In his role as chief executive of the Vancouver Organizing Committee, John Furlong is the man ultimately held responsible for how the Winter Olympics are run, and how they are perceived.

title: Brooklyn School Receives Grant to Perfect Its Chinese
description: In speeches on education, President Obama has praised Medgar Evers College Preparatory High School in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, for pushing its students to master reading, writing and math. So what does an inner-city school that garners a shout-out from the countrys leader do for an encore?

title: Quote Unquote | Project Runway
description: Hamish Bowles tells the Guardian how he used to sneak into runway shows. Thanks for the tip!

title: Lucky Hires People StyleWatch Publisher
description: Cond Nasts Lucky magazine has a new publisher, Michelle Myers, the founding publisher of the hot magazine People StyleWatch.

title: Transformer Blast Damages Building in Chelsea
description: A Con Edison transformer in a vault below the sidewalk at 641 Avenue of the Americas in Chelsea exploded in a fireball seven stories high on Thursday morning, badly damaging stores and offices in a building at the corner of 20th Street. There were no injuries reported.

title: Citi Still Has Competitive Pay, C.F.O. Says
description: Citigroup isnt at a disadvantage when it comes to paying employees, the banks chief financial officer, John Gerspach, said on Thursday, according to Reuters.

title: The Home of the British Grand Prix
description: The home of the British Grand Prix, the Silverstone Circuit, today announced that it had received approval from Formula One Management to use the new arena track during the Formula 1 race in July this year.

title: Blind Side Couple Will Write Book
description: The spirit of generosity encouraged by the hit movie The Blind Side is continuing to pay dividends to the real-life couple depicted in it, who will write a new book about the power of giving. On Thursday the publisher Henry Holt and Company said it had acquired a book by Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy, the Tennessee couple who adopted the future Baltimore Ravens player Michael Oher, and whose story is told in the Michael Lewis book The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game as well as its recent film adaption. In a news release Holt said that in the as-yet untitled book, the Tuohys would tell their story from their perspective for the first time and that they hope to inspire and challenge individuals to turn around and see the needs in their own community. The book, which was acquired by Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Holt, is planned for a summer release; terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Alexander McQueen, Designer, Is Dead at 40
description: Alexander McQueen, the renegade British fashion designer known for producing some of the most provocative collections of the last two decades, was found dead on Thursday morning in his London home, the police there said. He was 40.

title: Theater Talkback: I Feel Your Cellphone Pain
description: For years I have felt that people whose cellphones ring during live theater performances should be regarded and treated as criminals. Not as capital offenders, of course, though there have been moments  like the time an Eine Kleine Nachtmusik ring tone broke a stark silence near the end of A View From the Bridge  when hanging seemed like an appropriate punishment.

title: Blind Side Couple Will Write New Book
description: The spirit of generosity encouraged by the hit movie The Blind Side is continuing to pay dividends to the real-life couple depicted in it, who will write a new book about the power of giving. On Thursday the publisher Henry Holt and Company said it had acquired a book by Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy, the Tennessee couple who adopted the future Baltimore Ravens player Michael Oher, and whose story is told in the Michael Lewis book The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game as well as its recent film adaption. Read more on ArtsBeat

title: More Tools for Sifting Through Government Data
description: In a blog post on Wednesday, Clay Johnson, director of Sunlight Labs, discussed the data flood coming out of Washington and the need for more applications to deal with the new era of government information.

title: Facing Flight Cancellations
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: The entire East Coast is covered with snow banks and snow drifts, or as Toyota drivers call them  cushions.

title: Republican Medicare Cuts
description: So, Newt Gingrich and John Goodman say,

title: Working and Working and Working
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: What are you folks doing here? Its a snow day, for heavens sake. I got up this morning, the first thing I did, I turned on the radio and listened for the talk show closings  darn! And then I get a call from the guy at the office here, and I think, right away, somebody is calling me at home. Theyre not supposed to do that, must be trouble. And I said, Whats wrong? Has the show canceled? And the guy said, No, just checking in on the elderly.

title: Featured Recipe: Bay Scallops With Sesame Seeds and Scallions
description: Fans of seasonal, local foods have little to celebrate in the depths of winter, especially those of us in the Northeast. Among the notable exceptions is the bay scallop, harvested between the south shore of Cape Cod and the north shore of Long Island. Though they are less sweet, the common sea scallop  which is also less expensive can step in as a substitute, especially if this much larger scallop is halved or quartered. In this recipe, where the scallops are treated almost as simply as possible, theyll do fine.

title: Winter Olympics Fill-In
Syfy Enters the Childrens Programming Business
description: NBC Universal is dipping its toe into the enormous childrens entertainment business through its Syfy cable channel.

title: Officer Testifies He Used Baton to Subdue Suspect
description: Testifying in his own defense, Officer Richard Kern acknowledged Thursday that he used his retractable baton to subdue Michael Mineo in a Brooklyn subway station, but denied that he shoved it between Mr. Mineos buttocks, as prosecutors contend.

title: Does Pregnancy Affect Memory?
description: When I was pregnant with my first child, I went off to the mall one day to buy baby things. All went smoothly at the first stop, but at the second I left the package I was carrying from store one. I remembered to take my purchase from store two, but then forgot that purchase at store three. This went on about half a dozen times with me retracing my steps across The Galleria for much of the afternoon.

title: BrightSource Alters Solar Plant Plan to Address Concerns Over Desert Tortoise
description: The developer of Californias first new solar power plant in 20 years has proposed revamping the project in an attempt to defuse concern over its effect on the imperiled desert tortoise.

title: Alexander McQueen, March 17, 1969  Feb. 11, 2010
description: What can we really say? The news of Alexander McQueens suicide is as sad as it is tragic; the fashion world is poorer without him. Wed like to remember him full of life and energy, as he seemed to be in this sitting with Cathy Horyn, which appeared in the fall 2009 mens issue of T. R.I.P., General Lee.

title: Sealing Shift, Chvez Gives Contracts to Western Oil Companies
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  After clashing with foreign oil companies in recent years, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela has shifted strategy and awarded contracts to Western oil companies, hoping to increase his nations flagging oil production and pull the country out of a sharp economic downturn.

title: The Tar Heels and Vonns Shin
description: There is a fabulous debate to be had over who is undergoing a more precipitous fall: North Carolina Coach Roy Williams or the Olympic skier Lindsey Vonn. Yes, it is a highly unusual competition because Vonn probably has little grasp of the box-and-one and Williams (thankfully) has never appeared in a swimsuit issue, thanks to his resemblance to Deputy Dog.

title: Vonn Gets Back on Skis and Likes the Results
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The first step for Lindsey Vonn came Wednesday night when she slipped her right foot into her ski boot and did not yelp. In recent days, trying on her boots had been so painful she had refused to try.

title: Take Five: Heist Films, Yiddish Culture and a Dance Benefit for Haiti
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered:

title: Unsealed Letters Offer Glimpse of Salinger
description: The letters, a total of 11, were written between 1951 and 1993, from one buddy, or Buddyroo, to another. In sharp and familiar prose, laced with humor and biting wit, the writer gives an intimate peek into his life and thoughts at precise moments in time. Read so many years later, they are filled with surprises.

title: G.E. Disputes Incident in Paulsons Book
description: When it comes to Henry M. Paulson Jr.s new book, On the Brink, it seems theres a little bit of disagreement over some of the particulars  and should make for an interesting conversation with Jeffrey R. Immelt next week.

title: Photos of the Moment | John Bartlett
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.See all of Ts Fashion Week coverage.

title: Davis, Colbert Can Laugh Together Now
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  Although he was initially reluctant to draft off the comedian Stephen Colberts popularity, speedskater Shani Davis said he enjoyed crossing lanes with Colbert in a skit that aired last month on The Colbert Report.

title: Chicago Auto Show: Limited Editions From Chrysler and Others
description: CHICAGO  Its not Panther Pink, the famous Chrysler color of yore (and yes, named after the crafty cartoon character). In fact, the bright hue of the 2010 Dodge Challenger R/T Classic and SRT8 commemorative editions that celebrate the Challengers 40th anniversary is more of a cross between blueberry and pomegranate.

title: Celine Dion Is Heading Back to Vegas
description: Her last show employed some 50 dancers and musicians, featured Cirque du Soleil-style theatrics with one of the largest indoor LED screens, celestial imagery and trapezes, and spawned its own perfume. It also grossed more than $400 million during its five-year run. Who knows what Celine Dion will bring to Las Vegas this time? On Wednesday Ms. Dion, the Canadian singer and five-time Grammy winner, announced that she would return to the strip, and the Colosseum at Caesars Palace that was originally built for her, in March 2011 for a three-year engagement, Reuters reported. Her previous show, A New Day, drew nearly 3 million people. This time Ms. Dion, who finished a worldwide tour in 2009, will stage a new show inspired by classic Hollywood films, and it will feature a full orchestra. Tickets for the first 54 shows, which are to begin on March 15, 2011, go on sale Friday through ticketmaster.com.

title: Thinking Outside the Void
description: THE dominant architectural exhibition of the past year was the Museum of Modern Arts recent Bauhaus show, with its eminently utilitarian, practical ethos.

title: The Temptation to Cheat in Computer Science Classes at Stanford
description: In January, on the first day of the Computer Science 106A: Program Methodology course at Stanford University, Eric Roberts, the professor, began with his customary admonition: Cheat, and you will be caught. And, he added: Cheat, and your classmates will suffer. More weight will be given to the final exam when calculating the final grade.

title: A Song to Celebrate Spider-Man in 3-D
description: In honor of the recent news that the next Spider-Man movie will be shown in 3-D, ArtsBeat has composed the following song, set to the tune of the swingin Spider-Man theme song from the wall crawlers classic 1960s cartoon:

title: Taking Questions on Freelancers and Taxes
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Afghans Try to Reassure Tribal Elders on Offensive
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With a military operation looming, Afghan leaders met Thursday with tribal elders from the southern city of Marja to tell them that, indeed, government and NATO forces would soon rid the area of Taliban fighters and that Afghan police officers and soldiers would stay behind after the fighting was over.

title: Cost-Cutting Helps Profit at Viacom
description: For the major media conglomerates that were hampered by both the economic recession and technology-driven changes in consumer habits, the world is starting to look brighter. Viacom, the media conglomerate, became the latest to show improvement when it reported a surge in quarterly profit on Thursday.

title: Q&A: A Low-Cost Weekend in the Sun
description: Q.

title: Facebook and Twitter Compete for Olympic Glory
description: Each Olympics brings one or two novel new events. At the 2010 Olympic Winter Games, which start in Vancouver on Friday, there is Ski Cross, in which four skiers plunge down a mountain at the same time.

title: Battle of the Oscar Contenders
description: The 10 best picture nominees are not just shaking up the Oscar telecast. (A F.A.Q. for the Bagger: How are they going to fit in all those clips? A: Search us. Er, well find out!) The AMC movie theater chain, which has a tradition of holding a yearly best-picture marathon, is suffering some scheduling pains with all the extra films, according to an announcement on its Web site.

title: Sterling Rubys Caged Heat
description: Best in Show follows the peregrinations of critic and novelist Linda Yablonsky, author of The Story of Junk, and a front-line chronicler of art-world events and exhibitions.

title: Waiting for the Latest Stop-and-Frisk Figures
description: A panel of analysts, academics and former police officials is poised to debate one of the New York Police Departments most controversial policies  Stop, Question and Frisk  at a summit at the citys Bar Association offices.

title: Akhtar Nawab to Be Chef at Sandovals Zengo
description: Akhtar Nawab will be the chef de cuisine at Zengo, the restaurant Richard Sandoval is opening next month in the former Wild Salmon space on Third Avenue and 40th Street.

title: European Leaders Support Greece
description: European leaders reach deal to support Greece, in an unprecedented move to stave off a broader crisis in the 16-nation bloc that shares the euro single currency.

title: Jamie Oliver Wins TED Prize for Obesity Efforts
description: Jamie Oliver, the chef who prodded the British government to overhaul the nations school lunch program, was awarded the $100,000 TED Prize on Wednesday at the annual TED conference, a series of lectures by experts from a wide range of fields including science, religion, and economics.

title: Obama to Meet Dalai Lama Next Week
description: President Obama will meet the Dalai Lama at the White House on Feb. 18, Robert Gibbs, White House spokesman, said Thursday.

title: Selectarian
description: One who exercises meticulous choice over the food they eat.

title: The Loss of Alexander McQueen
description: Alexander McQueens death is just incredibly sad. That is the only word for it. Im sad for him, said the milliner Philip Treacy, a friend of McQueens for the last 20 years. Creativity is a very fragile thing, and Lee was very fragile. He was a fragile person with a front of whatever you want to call it. Its not easy being Mr. McQueen. Were all human. His mum had just died. And his mum was a great supporter of his talent. I dont really know what happened.

title: Adviser to Detained Americans in Haiti Is Investigated
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The police in El Salvador have begun an investigation into whether a man suspected of leading a trafficking ring involving Central American and Caribbean women and girls is also a legal adviser to the Americans charged with trying to take 33 children out of Haiti without permission.

title: Designer's Studio: George McCracken
description: The men's wear designer prepares for New York fashion week.

title: The End of Cedar Fairs Ride?
description: Update | 5:08 p.m. At least one New York law firm was working through the severe snowstorm on Wednesday.
