Right after the stock market closed, the amusement park operator Cedar Fair filed its definitive proxy statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. This is the proxy for the shareholder meeting that will be held to approve or disapprove Cedar Fairs agreement to be acquired by Apollo Management.

title: Lawmakers Want to Reinstate Barriers on Campaign Spending by Corporations, Others
description: House and Senate Democrats outlined legislation today aimed at rebuilding some of the barriers to political advertising by corporations, unions and other third-party groups that the Supreme Court just struck down.

title: Five Finalists Picked in Condom Wrapper Contest
description: One way to promote safer sex is to make it more attractive.

title: Getty Bronze Must Be Returned to Italy, Judge Rules
description: An Italian judge ruled on Thursday that the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles must hand over a rare bronze statue, Victorious Youth, that has been at the heart of a four-decade-long dispute.

title: Report Faults Binghamtons Leaders in Scandal
description: What began at Binghamton University as a dream of basketball success and culminated in its first trip to the N.C.A.A. mens tournament last March came crashing down on Thursday. A four-month investigation detailed just how far administrators were willing to go in pursuit of athletic glory.

title: New Poll Shows Support for Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: As the Obama administration proposes repealing the policy known as Dont Ask, Dont Tell, a new New York Times/CBS News poll finds that a majority of the public support allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the military.

title: Mid-Atlantic States Dig Out, Again
description: The winds stopped howling and the sun emerged again on Thursday, as residents in the mid-Atlantic states began the slow, and often self-defeating process of digging out yet again from record-breaking back-to-back blizzards.

title: When the Nurse Is a Bully
description: It was the end of my shift, and I listened as one of my co-workers was being hassled over the phone for the second time that day. The computer wouldnt release a patient record, and a nurse in another department was blaming her.

title: Reprising the Olive
description: In 2008, Tom McCarthy wrote about Jean-Philippe Toussaints novel Camera in the Book Review:

title: SunPower to Acquire Europes SunRay
description: SunPower, a leading Silicon Valley solar company, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire SunRay Renewable Energy, a European photovoltaic power plant builder, in a $277 million deal.

title: Tot Couture | Bergdorfs for the Under-6 Set
description: Is personal style a product of nature or nurture? Certainly it cant hurt to give the lady goo-goo in your life a nudge in the right direction, lest she grow up to think that its perfectly acceptable to go out in public in a onesie and no pants. A good place to start would be Bergdorf Goodmans brand- spanking-new childrens department, Little BG, where she can outfit herself  from head to toe  in grown-up fashion labels like Philip Lim, Chlo, Little Marc Jacobs, Baby Dior, Charvet and Loro Piana. For truly precocious size-zero fashionistas, there are hand-embroidered footies, cashmere booties and receiving blankets, not to mention a slew of handmade toys from around the world.

title: Dawn Blalock and Craig Goodwin
description: THE romance of Dawn Blalock and Craig Goodwin almost seems woven from the threads of an international thriller.

title: The Morning Skate: Cuban Circles the Stars and the Caps Streak Ends
description: The Dallas Morning News reports today that Mavericks owner Mark Cuban has entered into discussions to buy a piece of the Dallas Stars, along with an unidentified group of investors, from current owner Tom Hicks.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1) Do you work longer on rainy days? (What about snowy ones?)

title: American Idol': Towards a Unified Theory of Group Day
description: Youd think after Conan told me not to be cynical, I would have learned my lesson. In the post about Tuesday nights episode of American Idol, I insinuated that there might have been some chicanery in regard to Big Mike Lynche: Wasnt there just the tiniest bit of Jonny Fairplay (the Survivor contestant who lied about his grandmother dying), in the timing of Big Mikes wifes contractions?, I asked. The original question Id posed, and deleted, was different: They can send a camera to capture Vanessa Wolfes first airplane flight but not simulcast Big Mikes wife as she goes into labor? I was suspicious.

title: Schwarzman Defends Bankers
description: The economy may be improving at last, but Stephen A. Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group argues that we should be careful not to strangle that recovery in its crib.

title: Designer's Studio: George McCracken
description: The men's wear designer prepares for New York fashion week.

title: Global Warming and Weather Psychology
description: How does extreme weather affect the publics understanding or misunderstanding of global climate change?

title: Whistle-Blowing Nurse Is Acquitted in Texas
description: A West Texas jury took but an hour Thursday to acquit a nurse who had been charged with a felony after alerting the state medical board that a doctor at her hospital was practicing unsafe medicine.

title: Express Yourself: Crafting Social Location Maps and Identity Monologues
description: Overview | What is identity and where does it come from? How can we convey our identities with others? In this lesson, students map their social locations, reflect on their identities and the dramatic purpose of monologue, and craft speeches that explore defining aspects of their lives.

title: Answers From an E-Dating Expert, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of answers from Laurie Davis, the founder of eFlirt Expert.

title: Battle of Weight Versus Gain in Ski Jumping
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  One by one, the Olympic ski jumpers launched themselves in training for Fridays opening competition, lifting off the ramp at nearly 55 miles an hour, floating more than the length of a football field, hands tucked at their side, their skis flared in a V-shape.

title: To Cut Debt, Obama Shifts on No Tax Vow
description: President Obama, still seeking to get Congressional Republicans to join in a bipartisan commission to reduce the federal debt, suggested he would be willing to break his campaign promise against raising taxes on households with less than $250,000 annual income.

title: In Wine, Celebrating Differences
description: In my last post, I took a moment to celebrate the wonderful diversity of wines to which we are lucky enough to have access today. Coincidentally, over on his blog Saigne, Cory Cartwright posted a thoughtful essay on the fragility of this diversity.

title: Burlington Northern Investors Approve Berkshire Deal
description: Burlington Northern Santa Fe shareholders have approved the railroads sale to Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by Warren Buffett, paving the way for the Oracle of Omaha to complete his biggest acquisition.

title: Mumps Outbreak in Brooklyn Jewish Communities
description: More than 1,500 people in the metropolitan area, mostly Orthodox Jewish boys and young men in Brooklyn, have contracted mumps in the worst outbreak in the United States since 2006, city and federal health officials said Thursday.

title: The Gods of Irony
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: After the Whiteout, a Return to Normal?
description: The sun is out, the air is cold, and the 8 to 17 inches of snow on the ground is rapidly turning into icy, foot-shaped hazards on the sidewalk or melting into slushy gray pools by the curb.

title: Author, 17, Says Its Mixing, Not Plagiarism
description: BERLIN  It usually takes an author decades to win fawning reviews, march up the best-seller list and become a finalist for a major book prize. Helene Hegemann, just 17, did it with her first book, all in the space of a few weeks, and despite a savaging from critics over plagiarism.

title: Och-Ziff Posts Strong Results for Fourth Quarter
description: The Och-Ziff Capital Management Group said its assets under management ballooned by $500 million in the last six weeks, according to its fourth-quarter earnings report released Thursday.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A girl plays on the beach in San Sebastin, Spain.

title: Now Collaborating | YSL and Atelier
description: Another day, another fashion collaboration  except that this is a particularly cool one. The Yves Saint Laurent designer Stefano Pilati has teamed up with Atelier, the downtown mens store known for its broody, moody aesthetic. The 129 special pieces include cool drop-crotch trousers, long knits and gabardine jackets in Ateliers signature shades of gray and black. Prices range from $595 for drawstring pants, to $3,695 for a cashmere jumpsuit.

title: After Two Postponements, the Crews Still Receive a Day of Rest
description: VALENCIA, Spain  This is what happens when 19th-century legal language governs a 21st-century race.

title: What Caring for Immigrants Costs
description: Medical care for immigrants who are in the country illegally has long been a sore subject. Emotions boiled over last fall when Representative Joe Wilson, Republican of South Carolina, shouted You lie! after President Obama, in a speech before Congress, denied that undocumented immigrants would receive free coverage under the Democrats proposed health care legislation.

title: Obama Congratulates Ukraines Election Winner
description: MOSCOW  President Obama on Thursday congratulated Viktor F. Yanukovich on winning Ukraines presidential election, increasing the pressure on his opponent, Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, to concede.

title: 2 Pension Funds Sue Morgan Stanley Over Pay
description: Two pension funds sued Morgan Stanley on Thursday, accusing the Wall Street firm of overpaying its employees and calling the payouts unjust enrichment.

title: A Different Kind of Love Triangle
description: Once upon a time, not so very long ago, there were two sisters who lived in Manhattan. One was wildly emotional, the other smartly sensible. The sisters found love, as lovely women do, and they lost love, but no matter where love went they always worked hard and had rich lives. Now these sisters also had a sweet, beloved mother, whose own fairy tale of a life suddenly came apart when one day her sweet, beloved husband came home and announced that he was divorcing her. She was 75 years old. She was banished from her handsomely appointed Central Park West apartment. Her daughters rushed to her rescue. But their lives were falling apart, too. One was broke and disgraced, the other lonely and worried.

title: A Visit to London
description: Ive been thinking more about the interviews I did with Alexander McQueen last July, a conversation spread over two days and conducted at his rented flat in Mayfair, at the fashionable restaurant Scotts nearby, and at his design studio on Clerkenwell Road. He was very confident, clear, mature and certainly eager to talk about his ideas about the Web. All that fascinated him  its conceptual possibilities fascinated him, as well as its commercial realities. I think we saw that in his October show in Paris.

title: Excerpts from Natavia Lowery's Statement
description: Natavia Lowery gave this videotaped statement to police confessing to the murder of Linda Stein, which was presented in court. Ms. Lowery is accused of killing Ms. Stein, but she has since recanted the confession.

title: Another Teenage Woe: The Hounds of Hades
description: Greek mythology barges into the sanitized ethos of High School Musical in the frenziedly busy screen adaptation of Rick Riordans popular 2005 novel, The Lightning Thief. Because it is the first in the five-book Percy Jackson & the Olympians young-adult series, can a franchise be far behind?

title: Suicide Bombers Attack Police Compound in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers attacked police officers in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, killing 15 people and wounding 20 others in the second attack on Pakistani police officers in as many days, the authorities said.

title: BMW Hopes to Catch the Upswing
description: ESTORIL, Portugal  There was not much sign of Portugals debt crisis as a fleet of shiny gray BMW sedans set out one by one from an elegant seaside hotel near here Thursday morning. As the cars sped through whitewashed coastal villages, the sun broke through low clouds and gray-green Atlantic swells rolled lazily to shore.

title: Why Banks Are Offering You Cash
description: You may want to open the next pitch you get from a bank because theres a chance it will offer you a generous amount of cash.

title: Ones to Know: Bode Miller
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: New Life, but Still a Small-Town Feel
description: The elevated train rattles overhead, drowning out the sidewalks Irish brogues, Spanglish exclamations, and Vietnamese and Albanian chatter. New blood has changed the Kingsbridge neighborhood, in the northwest Bronx, which sits in a valley between Riverdale and the Major Deegan Expressway. But its small-town character remains strong  waiters know how customers like their meat cooked, and barbers pick up conversations with customers where they left off. Stroll down Broadway to check out the new life in the area and pay respect to the old.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Feb. 11
description: Some of the most compelling photographs from Afghanistan last year were made by David Guttenfelder of The Associated Press. He has returned there (Slide 4 today and Slide 2 in Mondays show), bringing his skill for portraying the armed forces in the context of the vast land they are trying to calm. Or tame. Or just survive.

title: Its Hard to Be Refined as You Howl at the Moon
description: The title character in The Wolfman, an English squire turned actor turned howling, moonstruck lycanthrope, suffers from a vexing identity crisis, and so does the movie. Lawrence Talbot, the hairy hero, broodingly played by Benicio Del Toro, is torn between his human and his bestial impulses, and this new version of the 1941 creature-feature classic struggles to stay true to its pulpy B-movie roots while fulfilling the commercial imperatives of a modern, large-scale commercial entertainment.

title: The Scene: Day One
description: Scenes around the tents at Bryant Park during New York Fashion Week.

title: Subway Takes Ambush Marketing Complaints in Stride
description: The chief marketing officer for the Subway sandwich chain has a cheeky rejoinder to complaints that his company is engaged in ambush marketing surrounding the Vancouver Games.

title: Karen Finley Wears Pearls, Not Chocolate
description: The prospect of Karen Finley doing dinner theater sounds as remote as her singing God Bless America at a memorial tribute to Senator Jesse Helms. Yet Ms. Finley  who achieved national notoriety two decades ago when she drew the wrath of Helms for her publicly financed activities as a performance artist  can now be found on Saturday nights practicing her very personal brand of drama before an audience of scallop- and steak-consuming patrons.

title: Wyden on Insurance: We Can Expand Competition
description: The Voice for Choice is feeling upbeat  at least, he is on the issue of selling health insurance across state lines.

title: Whats Next for Binghamton?
description: The audit of the Binghamton mens basketball program was released on Thursday. Conducted by Judith S. Kaye, a former chief judge of New York, the investigation painted a vivid picture of the trade-offs the administration was willing to make in pursuit of success on the basketball court. You can read Pete Thamels article, and the full report.

title: Inside the Rings: Dropping Kilos to Fly Farther
description: VANCOUVER  With so many athletes competing in so many different events, it can be difficult to keep track of the different story lines of the 2010 Winter Games. To help you understand what is happening and why, reporters and editors for The New York Times will provide their insight and analysis on the athletes and issues making news  or about to make news  in Vancouver.

title: Owner of N.B.A. Team Buys Kirkus Reviews
description: It looks as if Kirkus Reviews will live another day to praise  and skewer  authors, but with some rather unorthodox owners. Herb Simon, the owner of the Indiana Pacers and chairman emeritus of Simon Property Group, a shopping mall developer, has bought the venerable journal of prepublication book reviews from the Nielsen Company, which announced in December that it was closing the magazine. Terms were not disclosed. Mr. Simon, who is also a co-owner of an independent bookstore in Montecito, Calif., has appointed Marc Winkelman, chief executive of Calendar Holdings, which owns several chains of seasonal retailers, to be chief executive of what will be renamed Kirkus Media. Mr. Winkelman is also taking a small stake in the company. Mr. Winkelman, who also owns Tecolote Books with Mr. Simon, said by telephone that the company would retain its current editorial leadership, with Elaine Szewczyk as editor and Eric Liebetrau as managing editor. Mr. Simon, also in a telephone interview, said: I always admired the publication. I thought it was honest and interesting, and for a book reader its an incredibly helpful tool if you buy a lot of books.

title: Celine Dion Is Heading Back to Las Vegas
description: Her last show employed about 50 dancers and musicians and featured Cirque du Soleil-style theatrics with one of the largest indoor LED screens, celestial imagery and trapezes. It also grossed around $400 million during its five-year run. Who knows what Celine Dion, above, the Canadian singer and five-time Grammy winner, will bring to Las Vegas this time? On Wednesday she announced that she would return to the strip, and the Colosseum at Caesars Palace that was originally built for her, for a three-year engagement beginning in March 2011, Reuters reported. Her previous show, A New Day, drew nearly three million people. This time Ms. Dion, who finished a worldwide tour in 2009, will stage a new show inspired by classic Hollywood films and will feature a full orchestra. Tickets for the first 54 shows, which are to begin on March 15, 2011, go on sale Friday at ticketmaster.com.

title: Getty Must Return Work, Italian Judge Rules
description: An Italian judge ruled on Thursday that the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles must hand over a rare bronze statue that has been at the heart of a four-decade dispute. Judge Lorena Mussoni decreed that the statue, Victorious Youth, left, must be confiscated from the museum and transferred immediately to the Italian government, which the ruling said was its rightful owner. Maurizio Fiorilli, a lawyer for the government, said the ruling was a confirmation that the Getty had not acted in good faith when they bought the statue, which was found by Italian fishermen in the Adriatic in 1964 and bought by the Getty in 1977 for almost $4 million. The Italian justice ministry must now make a formal request to American authorities to execute the court order. The work, a second- or third-century B.C. sculpture of an athlete, known as the Getty Bronze, had been excluded from a 2007 agreement between Italy and the Getty for the return of 40 artifacts that Italy said had been looted, pending the court decision. The Italian culture ministry said on Thursday that it hoped the Getty would now review that accord and that it would return the statue in light of this ruling. The Getty said a statement that the court order was flawed both procedurally and substantively. The museum said it would appeal to Italys highest court and vigorously defend its legal ownership of the statue.

title: Blind Side Couple to Write a Book
description: The spirit of generosity encouraged by the hit movie The Blind Side is continuing to pay dividends to the real-life couple depicted in it, who will write a book about the power of giving. On Thursday the publisher Henry Holt & Company said it had acquired a new book by Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy, the Tennessee couple who adopted the future Baltimore Ravens player Michael Oher, and whose story was told in the Michael Lewis book The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game. In a news release Holt said that the Tuohys would tell their story from their perspective for the first time in the as-yet-untitled book, and that they hope to inspire and challenge individuals to turn around and see the needs in their own community. The book, which was acquired by Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Holt, is expected to have a summer release; terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: The Inspirational Movie That Keeps On Giving
description: Like a cross between two Kevin Spacey movies (bonus points if you know which ones), The Blind Side has been paying it forward for everyone involved: Sandra Bullock got an Oscar nomination; the Tuohys, the Memphis family at the center of the story, got their own book deal, and Michael Lewis, the author of the account that started it all, got to see his movie career re-ignite after an adaptation of his baseball movie Moneyball wiped out last year. In fact Mr. Lewis, a contributing writer for Vanity Fair and The New York Times Magazine, should be riding twice as high right now: not only is Moneyball apparently back on track  with Brad Pitt still set to star and Bennett Miller (Capote) to direct  but, according to New York magazine, Mr. Pitt has optioned Mr. Lewiss next book, The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine, about the housing bubble. None of this has absolutely anything to do with this years Oscar race, by the way. And the answers are: Swimming with Sharks and K-Pax.

title: Vail Dance Festival Announces Lineup
description: The Vail International Dance Festival, a summer destination in the mountains of Colorado for dance lovers, has announced its program for this year. The festival, which will run from July 27 to Aug. 10 under the direction of Damian Woetzel, will present 3 premieres and 11 performances. In addition there will be an artist in residence and a company residency. The Pacific Northwest Ballet will be in residency for a week, and the Paul Taylor Dance Company will perform in honor of Mr. Taylors 80th birthday. Herman Cornejo, Wendy Whelan, Daniil Simkin, Carla Krbes, Matthew Rushing and Tiler Peck are among the dancers scheduled to appear as part of the International Evenings of Dance, a performance of artists from around the world. Some other highlights: the Vail debut of Beijing Dance/LDTX; the American premiere of Natalia Hills and Gabriel Misss tango show Romper el Piso; and a new work by Larry Keigwin, above, the festivals first artist in residence, who will also perform. Tickets are available beginning Friday at 1 p.m. Eastern time on the festivals Web site, vaildance.org.

title: Its a Girl, and a Win, for American Idol
description: While the wife of the American Idol contestant Michael Lynche, a k a Big Mike, was delivering a daughter, the show continued to deliver in the ratings, attracting 25 million viewers on Wednesday night, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: So Thats What Too Big to Fail Means
description: The White House released the annual Economic Report of the President today. Most of it is contains data and trends that economists already knew about, but it has some fantastic charts. (And you know how we feel about those around here.)

title: Pierce Is Out as Giants Turn Page
description: The Giants released linebacker Antonio Pierce on Thursday, jettisoning a key player who helped them win a Super Bowl three seasons ago but who came to symbolize the defenses downfall last year.

title: Mother Natures Lost Children, Up Close
description: T. Coraghessan Boyle loves to write about people in extremis: people who are odd, obsessive, strangely gifted, bizarrely damaged or just plain mad. A Hungarian circus performer who clambers up a skyscraper and ties himself to the wing of an airplane. A primatologist who decides to retire to Connecticut along with one of her chimpanzees. A bond trader who makes a Faustian pact with the Devil. A former hippie who tries to make a go of a marijuana farm in the California hills. A survivalist holed up in a cabin in Montana with his family.

title: A Whole Lotta Interconnected Love, and a Whole Lotta Movie Stars
description: The best and really only sensible thing to say about the dire romantic comedy Valentines Day, which is neither romantic nor remotely comedic, is that it makes you appreciate and long for the breeziness, acting and basic competency  the decent lighting, focused cameras and choreographed action  of Love Actually, the ingratiating British movie it transparently and ineptly rips off. What else? The movie poster for Valentines Day that features more than a dozen performers is something of a bait and switch: Ashton Kutcher seems to get more face time than anyone else, including actually good performers like Julia Roberts and Anne Hathaway.

title: Good Dharma: Lost Served 60s-Style
description: Hey, as long as were on the subject of swingin 1960s theme songs: remember that vintage television show about the castaways who couldnt seem to get off that crazy island no matter how hard they tried? Were talking, of course, about Lost:

title: A Renegade Whose Talent Taunted Convention
description: As news of Alexander McQueens death rippled through the tents of Bryant Park, where the fashion world was gathered Thursday on the first day of the New York collections for fall, there was shock at the loss of a designer of outsize talents, perhaps even genius.

title: Leon Wieseltier vs. Andrew Sullivan
description: Theyre not exactly fight clubs, but intellectual grudge matches do have their fans. One long-running feud, between Leon Wieseltier, the longtime literary editor of The New Republic, and Andrew Sullivan, a former New Republic editor who now blogs for The Atlantic, exploded this week. Mr. Wieseltier started the smackdown with a 4,000-plus word article accusing Mr. Sullivan of anti-Semitism.

title: Bauble-icious
description: 1. Gaia Repossi tapped her friend Eugnie Niarchos to be co-designer of Nre, a collection for her familys eponymous jewelry house. The Asian-inspired pieces include a ring that looks like a carving of Chinese jade and earrings that resemble Japanese floral prints.

title: Excerpt: 'The Ricky Gervais Show'
description: The new HBO show adapts Gervais's popular podcasts into an animated series.

title: Programmer Indicted in Goldman Code Theft Case
description: Federal prosecutors said Thursday that Sergey Aleynikov, a former computer programmer at Goldman Sachs, had been indicted on charges that he stole proprietary software that the firm uses to make rapid-fire trades in the financial markets.

title: Bill Clinton Undergoes a New Heart Procedure
description: Updated Former President Bill Clinton was taken to a New York hospital today after experiencing chest pains, and underwent a heart procedure, his office said.

title: Wild Child
description: La Conchita

title: Motorola Confirms New Plan to Split Itself
description: Motorola confirmed on Thursday that it planned to reorganize itself into two independent companies by the first quarter of 2011, with its mobile handset unit to be combined with its set-top boxes in order to be spun off into a publicly traded company.

title: On Assignment: Up for the Downhill
description: To photograph subjects wholl be moving past him in a flash, Doug Mills spends weeks of preparation.

title: Green Cards for Green Cars
description: Some entrepreneurs are counting on a lot of support from China for making hybrids in the United States. Why? Because supporting green technology can mean a green card for an entire family.

title: Chicago Auto Show: IndyCar of the Future?
description: CHICAGO  Hot Wheels at the Chicago Auto Show? The concept racer from DeltaWing Racing Cars is just that: a Batmobile for this years show.

title: American Indians and the California Dream
description: As a fifth-generation Californian who was raised in San Francisco, I thought I knew a lot about state history. After all, I recently wrote a book about my great-great-grandfather who settled in Los Angeles in 1859  when it was more dusty pueblo than American city then moved to San Francisco in 1890.

title: On Assignment: Up for the Downhill
description: To photograph subjects wholl be moving past him in a flash, Doug Mills spends weeks of preparation.

title: Nationwide Borrows a Page From the Department of Redundancy Department
description: Another spokescharacter is joining a crowded category, but in this instance with a large dollop of parody.

title: Jury Views Confession Video in Stein Murder Trial
description: Jurors on Thursday watched a crucial piece of evidence in the trial of the woman accused of killing the celebrity real-estate broker Linda Stein: the confession video.

title: A Frigid Hamptons Market Thaws to Lukewarm
description: PRESIDENTS DAY weekend is when New Yorkers typically take advantage of the three-day break to: a) fly somewhere warm; b) hit the slopes; or c) look at houses in the Hamptons.

title: New Life, but Still a Small-Town Feel
description: The elevated train rattles overhead, drowning out the sidewalks Irish brogues, Spanglish exclamations and Vietnamese and Albanian chatter. New blood has changed the Kingsbridge neighborhood, in the northwest Bronx, which sits in a valley between Riverdale and the Major Deegan Expressway. But its small-town character remains strong  waiters know how customers like their meat cooked, and barbers pick up conversations with customers where they left off. Stroll down Broadway to check out the new life in the area and pay respect to the old.

title: Carrying a Torch, Studiously
description: Prefacing her impeccable performance of The Folks Who Live on the Hill on Wednesday evening at Birdland, Hilary Kole remarked that the approach singers take to this dream of wedded bliss, composed by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II, tends to depend on age and experience.

title: Sea Turtles Saved from Florida Frost
description: Last month, when bitter cold struck the entire state of Florida, not only did tourists suffer; turtles did, too. Thousands of sea turtles,chilled into catatonic states, floated helplessly throughout shore waters, inland waterways and shallow brackish waters from the Panhandle all the way down to the Keys.

title: Financial Pressures Grow for Public and Private Colleges
description: I wanted to draw your attention to two articles on the Web site of The Chronicle of Higher Education that, collectively, further illuminate the financial squeeze on public universities and private colleges.

title: Try Disarming
description: My brother and sister-in-law were married shotgun a year ago. They have a beautiful baby, and the marriage seems happy. But my sister-in-law keeps trying to claim that they didnt know she was pregnant until after their engagement.

title: Guard Your Health Insurance Card
description: You may want to make sure you know where your health insurance card is.

title: Finding Emotions Stark and Intimate in Works New and Familiar
description: Looking at what must have been a dispiritingly empty Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, Alan Gilbert took a moment before leading the New York Philharmonic in works by Mozart and Christopher Rouse to thank listeners who had braved the snow, and to encourage those in the halls far reaches to move toward the front. Most took him up on this informal seat upgrade, and that made the storms toll even clearer: the balconies were virtually empty and only three quarters of the orchestra seats were full.

title: Financial Perversions Sold During Credit Boom
description: Would you buy a XXX security?

title: Inside the List
description: NEVER SAY DIE: Rebecca Skloots much praised Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5  not bad for a serious work of narrative nonfiction from a first-time author who spent 10 years working on the book, bouncing among four editors and three different publishing houses.

title: On Mandelas Release Anniversary, Zuma Seeks High Ground
description: JOHANNESBURG  It was the 20th anniversary of Nelson Mandelas release from prison, a high point in South Africas history, but for the current president, Jacob Zuma, who delivered his state of the nation address on Thursday, the moment arrived at a low point in his own 10-month-old tenure.

title: Countdown to an Afghan Offensive
description: As American, NATO and Afghan forces engaged in final maneuversbefore the imminent offensive in Marja, a Taliban stronghold in Helmand Province, Afghan leaders met with tribal elders in the area to discuss the goals of the operation  the biggest joint offensive of the Afghan war.

title: Days After Game, Rankings of Super Bowl Commercials Continue
description: Several additional surveys and polls have added to the debate over which commercials during the Super Bowl on Sunday worked  and which did not.

title: The Negative Buzz Around Googles New Social Network
description: Update | 11:11 p.m. Google implemented changes to Buzz late Thursday that make it easier to adjust settings.

title: Bill Clinton Released From Hospital
description: Former President Bill Clinton left a New York hospital on Friday morning after undergoing what his cardiologist called a successful procedure to clear a blocked artery.

title: Programmer Indicted in Theft of Goldman Software
description: Federal prosecutors said Thursday that Sergey Aleynikov, a former computer programmer at Goldman Sachs, had been indicted on charges that he stole proprietary software that the firm uses to make rapid-fire trades in the financial markets.

title: What Were Reading
description: Danny Meyer, whos taken over the food operations at the Whitney Museum of American Art, will set up a pop-up cafe at the museum, Sandwiched, during the Whitney Biennial, starting Feb. 25. Chefs from Mr. Meyers restaurants will create the sandwiches. But hes hit a bit of a roadblock for his Shake Shack plans downtown, with neighbors objecting to the restaurants liquor license application.

title: A Mountain Getaway Is Lavish by Design
description: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif.

title: ...And Theres Skiing Too
description: Until the 1960s only wilderness surrounded 7,160-foot Whistler Mountain and 7,494-foot Blackcomb Mountain, part of the Coast Mountains. No road connected the area to the nearby town of Squamish, and there was no infrastructure. That began to change in 1962, when three Vancouver businessmen set out to develop a ski resort in the area with the goal of hosting the 1968 Winter Olympics. Grenoble, France, won that bid, so residents like to joke that being a co-host of the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games with Vancouver has been a 40-year dream.

title: In Vermont, a Bid to Legalize Physician-Assisted Suicide
description: SHELBURNE, Vt. - The next showdown over physician-assisted suicide could be in Vermont, where a group of citizens has begun an effort to pass a bill patterned on Oregon's seven-year-old law allowing doctors to prescribe suicide drugs for terminally ill patients who request them.

title: The Dream, Without the Drive
description: Entourage written backward doesnt quite spell garmento, but that is the gist of How to Make It in America, a new series on HBO beginning Sunday that comes from the producers of Entourage. Here they have reversed the premise to look at guys from the neighborhood who havent left the neighborhood.

title: Sparse U.S. Listings Prompt Rush on China I.P.O.s
description: SHANGHAI  Last April, when global financial markets were collapsing, a Chinese Web site named Sohu.com made a bold move to spin off its online gaming unit and list it on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

title: Stanford Finds Computer Science Students Cheat More Than Others
description: Our colleagues on the Bay Area blog report on Stanford Universitys troubles with cheating in computer science classes.

title: Afghan Avalanche
description: A series of avalanches killed about 150 Afghans, and buried hundreds of vehicles along a highway in the Hindu Kush mountain range in northern Afghanistan.

title: Ones to Know: Armin Zoeggeler
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Vain Glorious | Ralphs Heart of Gold
description: Who: Ralph Lauren fragrances

title: Giants Lose a Leader in Pierce
description: The Giants released middle linebacker Antonio Pierce this afternoon, cutting a tie to their Super Bowl season and losing a vocal leader. At 31, he had slowed in the last year or two, and a herniated neck disk ended his 2009 season.

title: The Life of a Death Penalty Lawyer
description: Toward the beginning of The Autobiography of an Execution, David Dow relaxes after a speech with the celebrated death penalty abolitionist Sister Helen Prejean. (It was the first time I went drinking with a nun.) Prejean tells Dow, who has represented more than 100 death row inmates over 20 years, that support for the death penalty is a mile wide, but just an inch deep. Dow responds: Well, Sister, I believe you can drown in an inch of water. This book is Dows effort to drain the puddle.

title: Up Front: Dahlia Lithwick
description: In her 10 years covering the Supreme Court for Slate, Dahlia Lithwick has established herself as one of the wittiest observers of the American legal scene.

title: Stars and Gripes Forever: More Controversial Captain America Protests
description: On Wednesday, ArtsBeat reported on a controversy stirred by a recent issue of Captain America comics, in which that star-spangled superhero and his ally the Falcon appear to be dismissive of protesters at an apparent Tea Party rally. (The sequence did not go over well with real-life members of that political movement, and Marvel Comics said it would alter the protest signs depicted in that scene when it reprints the comic.)

title: With a Call, John Berry Shuts Down Government
description: WASHINGTON  Dressed in flannel-lined blue jeans to guard against the chill, John Berry was in the second-floor bedroom of his Dupont Circle townhouse, about a mile from the White House, when he picked up the phone to make a call, minutes before the Super Bowl kickoff on Sunday evening.

title: Some Democratic Senators Want to End Filibusters
description: Filibuster  the parliamentary maneuver that allows senators to block bills that lack 60 votes  has become a dirty word in Washington. Democrats are especially furious about it, now that Scott Brown, the new Republican senator from Massachusetts, has deprived them of their 60-vote super-majority, leaving President Obamas health legislation and many of his nominees in limbo.

title: Melancholy Dwelling in an Enchanted Life
description: Swan Lake, at least the New York City Ballet way, is not a tale for those who relish happy endings, or even ambiguously happy endings. You wont find such nonsense at this lakeside view.

title: Wheeldons Ghosts, Haunted by Dead Choreographers Society
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Very few ballet makers today create movement that is as completely dancy as Christopher Wheeldon does. Ghosts, his new creation for San Francisco Ballet, abounds in the felicities that for nine years have placed this still young choreographer in high national and international demand. Audiences at War Memorial Opera House here respond happily to them. This is Mr. Wheeldons fifth premiere for this company, and both the first performance on Tuesday and the second on Wednesday were heartily cheered.

title: Theater Listings: Feb. 12  18
description: THEATER

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Remembering Alexander McQueen
description: The editors of T recall their favorite memories of Alexander McQueen, who was found dead in his London home on Thursday.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 5 through 10 with 1,084 adults throughout the United States.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: Credit Suisse Sees Gains in Wealth Management
description: PARIS  Credit Suisse reported a fourth-quarter profit that was below analysts expectations on Thursday, but said it was gaining market share in the coveted wealth management business while its rival UBS suffered.

title: Dance Listings
description: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

title: Poll Finds Edge for Obama Over G.O.P. Among the Public
description: WASHINGTON  At a time of deepening political disaffection and intensified distress about the economy, President Obama enjoys an edge over Republicans in the battle for public support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Bryant Park, Finding a Stage
description: By centralizing their shows under one tent in Bryant Park, New York designers put American fashion on a global stage. Includes interviews with Diane von Furstenberg, Nanette Lepore and other industry insiders.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: A Snowy Celebration of Schumann and Chopin
description: New York music lovers can be an intrepid bunch. Despite Wednesdays snowstorm, a sizable audience made it to Carnegie Hall for a recital by the estimable pianist Emanuel Ax, the second in a series of three programs celebrating the 200th birthdays of Chopin and Schumann.

title: Flowing Along With Loves Chemical Forces
description: Although it has its share of lovey-dovey moments, This Thing Called Love, Eric Comstock and Barbara Fasanos Valentines Day show at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel does not succumb to the usual seasonal clichs of throbbing hearts and flowers and kissy-poo cuteness. The program is a witty, his-and-hers exploration of romantic chemistry by a couple whose musical portrayal of their five-year marriage goes out of its way to celebrate each partners individuality.

title: A Master Improviser Is Remembered With Masterly Improvisation
description: Joe Maneri, who died last August, was the sort of musician who leaves a deep and tangled impression. During his 37-year teaching career at the New England Conservatory in Boston  and a longer but more intermittent run as a multireedist and composer  he put his stamp on generations of improvisers, along with some perplexedly enchanted audiences.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Celestial Navigations: The Short Films of Al Jarnow
description: You remember the images: hand-drawn and sort of wobbly, with dusty primary colors and slightly psychedelic perspectives; they taught letters or numbers or shapes, animals and geography. If you watched Sesame Street or The Electric Company, the childrens educational shows, in the 1970s to the mid-1990s, you saw dozens of short animated films, including Cosmic Clock, above, that no doubt helped to shape your view of the world, or at least your aesthetic sense. But you probably didnt know that they were chiefly the creation of one artist, Al Jarnow.

title: A Menu for Feeding 9 Billion
Swagger and Sideburns: Bad Boys in Galleries
description: Judging from a number of overbearing, obstreperous and generally large works by male artists that command gallery space right now, it seems to be bad-boy week on the New York art scene. Isnt every week, you ask? Maybe, but some are more emphatically so than others.

title: Greek Troubles Are More Than Fiscal
description: Right now all the focus is on the budget, which is the action-forcing event. But Greece, like Spain, experienced a large real appreciation during the years of bubble finance  and now it faces a prolonged era of grinding deflation as it works its way back to competitive costs.

title: A Ski Home in Mammoth Lakes, Calif.
description: Richard Landry's three-level house offers unimpeded vistas of the Sierra Nevada mountains.

title: New Times/CBS Poll on Obama, Economy
description: In the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News, The Timess Adam Nagourney and Megan Thee-Brenan note that President Obama still holds an advantage over Republicans in terms of public support.

title: An Aging Hotel Row
description: The stretch of Broadway from 26th to 31st Street, between the Shake Shack and Herald Square, gives a foretaste of what promises to be a hip new hotel center.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100211

title: When Elmo Grows Up
description: Elmos concerned about adulthood? Hasnt anyone told that fuzzy little red dude that hes already over 30?

title: Today in Exquisite Insults
description: Jonathan Chait, on the revelation that Paul Ryan is an Ayn Randite*:

title: Movie Listings
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

title: See It, Feel It, Touch It, Climb It
description: In the 12 years that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has presented exhibitions on its roof, visitors have seen sculptures by Jeff Koons, Ellsworth Kelly, Roy Lichtenstein and Roxy Paine. They have glimpsed more unusual projects too, like miniature black smoke shells that resembled inkblots bursting into the sky every afternoon, the work of the Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang. Now for the 13th installation, Gary Tinterow, the Mets curator of 19th-century, Modern and contemporary art, has decided to try something more ambitious.

title: Miss Him Yet?
description: Thats the question on a Minnesota billboard featuring George W. Bushs smiling face. This back-and-forth between Keith Hennessey and Jonathan Chait (with follow-ups here and here), on the question of whether Barack Obama is shaping up to be more profligate than Bush, is a reminder of why the answer should be no.

title: Home for the Holler Days: Visit Dad, Add Girlfriend
description: There is a lot of hurting in the family melodrama The Vicious Kind, and a lot of healing too. An inquiry into the harm that men do to themselves, one another and of course women, the movie, which has been motoring on the festival circuit after its premiere at Sundance last year, is the second feature directed by Lee Toland Krieger, now 27. Mr. Krieger, who also wrote the screenplay, has obvious ambitions and his film has a nice feel for lifes quieter moments. Working with the cinematographer Bradley Stonesifer, he has made the most of his modest Connecticut locales, including the lived-in home that functions as the storys heart and, during its more cumbersome moments, its group-therapy rec room.

title: An Ogling Subversive With a Homemade Camera
description: The photographs are blurry, skewed, badly printed and in terrible condition: dog-eared, scratched, spotted and encrusted with who knows what. They all show girls and young women, in streets and public parks, going about their business and mostly unaware of the camera.

title: Yemens Government Agrees to a Cease-Fire With Rebel Forces
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemens government agreed to a cease-fire with the Houthi rebels late Thursday, saying it hoped to put an end to a six-year war that has drawn in neighboring Saudi Arabia and diverted resources from the struggle against Al Qaedas growing presence here.

title: Art in Review
description: ROY NEWELL

title: Two Centuries of Books in a Pennsylvania Barn
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa.  You can see your breath this time of year in some uninsulated aisles at Baldwins Book Barn, a used-book store between farms here near the Delaware border. The science-fiction section is particularly breezy; uncaulked gaps are visible in the wooden walls of this 1820s barn.

title: Prime Minister, Primo Mogul
description: There are moments in Videocracy, a queasy-funny and unapologetically biased look at the televisual world that the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, has created, when it feels as if you were watching a transmission from another planet. A media mogul who has a monopoly hold on Italian television and was elected for a third term in 2008, Mr. Berlusconi helped put the boob (and lots of them) on the Italian tube and is often in the news himself for his political machinations, outrageous observations  Mussolini sent people away on holiday; President Obama is suntanned  sexcapades and persistent charges of corruption.

title: Rakoff Prods BofA and S.E.C. for Information
description: Its question time for Bank of America and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Judge Jed S. Rakoff wants some answers.

title: Will the Great One be The One?
description: VANCOUVER Wholl light the Olympic cauldron? That question is swirling around Canada today, and the most frequent answer is Wayne Gretzky, although the Great One himself is not answering.Gretzky would be the default choice, a figure admired by all Canadians and in many countries around the world, most notably Russia and the United States. But it somehow doesnt seem surprising enough. Could it be Gretzky and Gordie Howe, who met him when Gretzky was a small boy and was a present, guardian angel-like, at all the key points in his career? Or could it be Gretzky and a woman, perhaps Canadas greatest female player, Hayley Wickenheiser, even if she will be playing these Games as well?Clues are offered by some of the torchbearers on Thursday and Friday. The beloved Vancouver Canucks of yesteryear, Richard Brodeur and Stan Smyl are among them, as well as iconic players for the British Columbia Lions and Vancouver Whitecaps. So is Rolly Fox, father of Terry Fox, who enthralled the nation by almost making it all the way across Canada in a cancer benefit run before succumbing to the disease. Walter Gretzky, the countrys iconic hockey dad, will carry the flame  an especially poignant torchbearer, in that a 1991 brain aneurysm left him without 20 years of memory, including that of his sons incredible early hockey successes, until intensive therapy enabled him to recover.

title: An Olympic-Size Marketing Dispute
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The United States Olympic Committee is continuing to feud with the sandwich chain Subway over the companys television commercials featuring swimmer Michael Phelps.

title: Swiss-American Adventurer
description: How you feel about the odd little documentary Barefoot to Timbuktu will depend to an unusually large extent on how you feel about its subject, a Swiss-American artist named Ernst Aebi, who made a killing in SoHo and TriBeCa real estate and has spent much of the time since as a globe-trotting adventurer. The director Martina Egi, a Swiss television producer making her first feature film, isnt reverent toward Mr. Aebi. (She gives screen time to people whose feelings are clearly mixed.) But neither is she critical. She manages the neat trick, intentional or not, of shaping no point of view whatsoever, leaving us to choose along a spectrum that, based on the evidence here, could run from charismatic Renaissance man to tyrannical narcissist.

title: A Hip Replacement for a Down-at-the-Heels Hood
description: BY day its the Canal Street of Midtown, a blurry tumble of frantic shop fronts in an epic half-mile panorama, Perfume-Hairpieces-Jewelry-Sweatshirts-Sunglasses. But by night the stretch of Broadway from 26th to 31st Street, between the Shake Shack and Herald Square, gives a foretaste of what promises to be a hip new hotel center.

title: You Want a Piece of Giants Stadium?
description: Yankees and Mets fans bid adieu to their stadiums in 2008. Now, Giants and Jets have said their good-byes. In this memorabilia-obsessed age, that means they can buy just about any salvageable scrap from their stadium in the Meadowlands.

title: Questions About Biofuels Environmental Costs Could Alter Europes Policies
description: BRUSSELS  A top European farm official has suggested that yet-to-be-released studies by the European Commission could be used to kill heavily promoted and subsidized biofuels by focusing on their total environmental impact.

title: Atop the Market
description: THE super high-end of Manhattan real estate doesnt seem to be doing all that badly, if you judge by the recent $23.98 million sale of a lavish penthouse at the Park Laurel, a 40-story condominium at 15 West 63rd Street in Lincoln Square.

title: Sold by Rey Curtis, Er, Benjamin Bratt
description: BENJAMIN BRATT, whom you may know as Detective Rey Curtis on  Law and Order  and for having dated Julia Roberts in the late 1990s, has just sold a three-bedroom two-bath loft in Greenwich Village for $2.5 million.

title: The Mobsters of Palermo
description: Imagine the Bada Bing as a gay disco where Tony Soprano and his cohort  flaunting platform boots and diamant belt buckles  shimmy in homoerotic abandon. Add a singalong called We Are Mafia, and youve pretty much captured the spirit of To Die for Tano, a bizarre musical comedy in which, amazingly, the actual severed swordfish heads are not the ugliest things on screen.

title: No Need to Buy Artwork
description: DOROTHY LICHTENSTEIN, the widow of the Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein, recently closed on a two-bedroom two-bath apartment at 25 Central Park West, an Art Deco landmark building, for $1.85 million.

title: An Evening of Anguish, Control and Radiance
description: Since 1961, the Young Concert Artists series has offered a platform for promising musicians, presenting them in debut concerts in New York and elsewhere. Under the leadership of Susan Wadsworth, its founder, the organization has promoted prominent ensembles and soloists early in their careers, among them Dawn Upshaw, Richard Goode, Murray Perahia and the St. Lawrence String Quartet.

title: China Alarmed by Security Threat From Internet
description: BEIJING  Deep inside a Chinese military engineering institute in September 2008, a researcher took a break from his duties and decided  against official policy  to check his private e-mail messages. Among the new arrivals was an electronic holiday greeting card that purported to be from a state defense office.

title: Saved by the Swiss
description: Did President Obama have to promise to outfit the Swiss Navy to induce Switzerland to take two of the last Uighur detainees at Guantnamo Bay off our hands?

title: A Coaching Heritage
description: Mark Johnson, who scored two goals in the United States hockey teams Miracle on Ice victory against the Soviet Union, is here, but not in a ceremonial position associated with the 30th anniversary on Feb. 22 of the 1980 Olympic Gamess most indelible moment.

title: Model Apartments
description: IT may just be another sign of how weak the rental market has become, but its apparently quite the vogue to give away a New York City rental apartment as a prize for contestants in national reality TV shows  and even in a local art competition.

title: A Family in Need of a Generation Gap
description: October Country, which sometimes seems like a Joyce Carol Oates novel rendered as a documentary, takes place in a stretch of the Mohawk Valley in upstate New York. Directed by Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher, a couple collaborating on their first feature together, the movie rests its probing, sympathetic gaze on members of Mr. Moshers family, who speak forthrightly about the misery and frustration that seems to afflict them, from one generation to the next, like a curse.

title: SunPower to Acquire SunRay of Europe
description: From Todd Woody at Green Inc.:

title: Google Agrees to Buy Social Search Service
description: Google has agreed to acquire Aardvark, a San Francisco-based start-up that taps a users social network to find someone who can answer their questions, according to representatives of the companies.

title: Ones to Know: Apolo Anton Ohno
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Arizona Quits Western Cap-and-Trade Program
description: Citing financial worries, the State of Arizona has backed out of a broad regional effort to limit greenhouse gas emissions in the West through a cap-and-trade system.

title: Democrats Try to Rebuild Campaign-Spending Barriers
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats outlined legislation Thursday aimed at undoing a recent Supreme Court decision that allows corporations and interest groups to spend freely on political advertising.

title: European Rules Draw Heated Debate
description: BERLIN  The temperature rose among the snow drifts here on Thursday as executives of the private equity industry squared off against regulators and representatives of unions at the Super Return 2010 conference to air their differences about pending regulation of the industry.

title: Appreciated, Certainly, but Not Appreciating
description: HOW much are they worth?

title: Gambling Revenue Rises in Las Vegas
description: Las Vegas Strip gambling revenue rose 5.9 percent in December, a second consecutive monthly gain and a fresh sign that the casino slump might be easing.

title: Vette Set: An Artists Dream Collection Relocates
description: AS I carried the recyclables from my Brooklyn apartment to the buildings basement garage one recent Sunday morning, I noticed that my Corvettes were gone. All 36 of them.

title: What You Get for $199 a Month
description: THE ad is tantalizing, aimed at pulling you through the showroom door: a brand-new midsize sedan for just $199 a month, plus tax, after youve put $2,199 down.

title: Health Reform in Limbo, Top Drug Lobbyist Quits
description: Billy Tauzin, one of Washingtons highest-paid lobbyists, is resigning as president of the drug industry trade group Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America amid internal disputes over its pact with the White House to trade political support for favorable terms in the proposed health care overhaul.

title: A Tata Nano Takes Manhattan
description: THE Tata Nano, which caused a sensation when it went on sale in India last year with a base price of about $2,200, has been seen by relatively few people in the United States. New Yorkers will get their chance to view a brilliant yellow example of the podlike peoples car beginning next Thursday, when the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum puts the car on display in its Great Hall at 2 East 91st Street in Manhattan.

title: Senate Confirms 3 to Treasury Posts
description: The Senate confirmed three assistant Treasury secretaries on Thursday, helping to fill out President Obamas economic team more than a year after the start of his administration.

title: New York Traffic Experiment Gets Permanent Run
description: New Yorks ambitious experiment that closed parts of Broadway to vehicles last spring will become permanent, city officials said on Thursday, even though it fell short of achieving its chief objective: improving traffic flow.

title: A Fatal Ending for a Family Forced Apart by Immigration Law
description: WEST BABYLON, N.Y.  Elizabeth Drummond was a single mother from a hardscrabble family whose roots go back to the Mayflower and an American Indian tribe. The man she married, Segundo Encalada, was a relative newcomer to the United States, sent illegally by his parents from Ecuador when he was 17.

title: Response to Beating Stirs Anger
description: SEATTLE  The surveillance video is vivid and brutal. Over and over, one girl kicks another in the head as she lies on her back on a transit station platform. The girl on the ground is not moving as the other girl steps away and then returns to stomp her head one more time.

title: Senate Confirms 27 Obama Nominees
description: Updated Before leaving for the Presidents Day break, the Senate tonight confirmed  by unanimous consent  27 of President Obamas nominees to federal positions, under a threat made earlier this week by the president that he might make recess appointments not requiring Senate votes. None of these seemed controversial; the senators approved these amid a backlog of presidential nominations and holds on some.

title: DeGeneres Is a Rising Star in Daytime
description: Executives at Warner Brothers have long believed that Ellen DeGeneres is the heir apparent to Oprah Winfrey in daytime TV. Still, they were startled by the news that a media research firm delivered to them last spring.

title: A Good Time to Buy a Toyota?
description: A BARRAGE of bad news about Toyota, including safety recalls for unintended acceleration and for a braking problem with the 2010 Prius, may be a boon for contrarian consumers seeking deals from an automaker that doesnt ordinarily offer deep discounts.

title: A Reversal on Food Stamps
description: The food stamp program, once seen as a form of welfare, now enjoys an identity as nutritional aid.

title: "Take a Look" Commercial
description: A new campaign from G.E., which begins running during the Olympics, emphasizes its health care business.

title: Single Mother Is Spared Court-Martial
description: Specialist Alexis Hutchinson, a 21-year-old Army cook and single parent, was days from deploying to Afghanistan last fall when her mother backed out of an agreement to take care of her 10-month-old son for the duration of her one-year tour.

title: "Doctors" Commercial by G.E.
description: A new campaign from G.E., which begins running during the Olympics, emphasizes its healthcare business.

title: Officer Testifies He Used Baton to Subdue, Not Abuse
description: Sitting forward in his chair, his face untroubled as he gave matter-of-fact answers, Officer Richard Kern spoke publicly for the first time on Thursday about his 2008 confrontation with Michael Mineo in a Brooklyn subway station. He testified that he had placed his expandable baton on Mr. Mineos legs to help subdue him, but had never put it between Mr. Mineos buttocks, as prosecutors have charged.

title: Flag-Waving Canadians
description: Canadians historically havent been big on flag waving or other overt acts of patriotism. On Thursday Prime Minister Stephen Harper urged them to change their ways during the Vancouver Olympics.

title: Transformer Explodes, Blasting Fire Into the Air
description: A transformer beneath a sidewalk exploded in a roar of flames and smoke on Thursday, charring the light stone face of an office building and showering debris over a half-block stretch of Avenue of the Americas. The authorities said that no one was injured.

title: Wi-Fi Turns Rowdy Bus Into Rolling Study Hall
description: VAIL, Ariz.  Students endure hundreds of hours on yellow buses each year getting to and from school in this desert exurb of Tucson, and stir-crazy teenagers break the monotony by teasing, texting, flirting, shouting, climbing (over seats) and sometimes punching (seats or seatmates).

title: For G.E., a Human Face on Its Role in Health Care
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC, for one, still believes in advertising.

title: Year of the Tiger
description: This Sunday kicks off the beginning of the Chinese lunar calendar. Celebrate the year of the tiger with a visit to the China Institute with your friends and family for a dumpling-making class beginning at 1 p.m. on Saturday. After you've mastered the culinary art, pay a visit to Sara D. Roosevelt Park on Sunday for a traditional firecracker ceremony at noon. Don't stop there though  continue the celebration next Friday when the institute hosts a big New Year's party at Gotham Hall. It will include a cocktail reception, multi-course family style dinner, an awards ceremony, the traditional lion dance, a special performance by the Princeton Tigertones and lots of dancing. Xin Nian Kuai Le!

title: Dinner and a Movie
description: Skip the celebrity-infested "Valentine's Day" movie, which Manohla Dargis calls "a disaster," and instead head to BAM on Sunday night to share one of the best romantic comedies of all time with your love. In the original 1934 review, Mordaunt Hall called "It Happened One Night," "a screen feast." The Frank Capra directed screwball stars Claudette Colbert and Clark Gable on a madcap cross-country romp. Colbert is the spoiled rich girl on the run from a forced marriage and Gable is the poor newspaper reporter with charm to spare. Delightfully, you know how it all ends. Stick around after for a special Valentine's dinner. On the menu: wild mushroom fettuccine, lobster risotto, duck confit crepes, slow baked lemon scented Dover sole and warm chocolate fondant cake, and a slew of other dishes.

title: Something to Yak About
description: "If you watched 'Sesame Street' or 'The Electric Company,' the children's educational programs, in the 1970s to the mid-1990s, you saw dozens of short animated films that no doubt helped to shape your view of the world, or at least your aesthetic sense," writes Melena Ryzik. "But you probably didn't know that they were chiefly the creation of one artist, Al Jarnow." Mr. Jarnow, 62, is a Brooklyn-born painter, sculptor and filmmaker who now lives in Northport, N.Y., and is an expert in the design of children's museums. He is also the man probably most responsible for why you associate Y with Yak. Mr. Jarnow made "Yak," "the minute-long film in which the titular animal introduces himself and then overuses the words 'you' and 'yes'  in a whimsical, educational fashion, of course, for Sesame Street." That film and many others that Mr. Jarnow made over a 30-year affiliation with "Sesame Street" and others children's shows are part of a new hourlong DVD, "Celestial Navigations: The Short Films of Al Jarnow," which will screen twice on Friday at the 92Y Tribeca. A question-and-answer session with Mr. Jarnow will take place after the first showing.

title: Airstrike Kills Palestinian Militant
description: A Palestinian militant was killed on Thursday in an Israeli airstrike, according to Israeli officials. The militant was identified as Fares Jaber, 26, by Israeli and Palestinian officials. The Israeli military said that he was active in the Global Jihad organization, and that he was part of a squad preparing to attack the Karni border crossing.

title: Maestro Behind Scenes Keeps U.S. Team Humming
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  One of the most indispensable members of the United States Olympic team will not set foot on an ice rink or in a ski gate this month. But if not for her, the teams athletes would not be in Vancouver at all, let alone competing for gold.

title: Motorola Outlines Plan to Split Into Two Companies
description: Motorola confirmed on Thursday that it planned to reorganize into two independent companies by the first quarter of 2011, with its mobile handset unit and its television set-top box division being combined and spun off as a separate publicly traded company.

title: Georgia Schools Inquiry Finds Signs of Cheating
description: ATLANTA  Georgia education officials ordered investigations on Thursday at 191 schools across the state where they had found evidence of tampering on answer sheets for the states standardized achievement test.

title: Bollywood and Politics Collide in a Red-Carpet Standoff
description: MUMBAI, India  In this capital of Indias Hindi film industry, Fridays release of the latest blockbuster by Bollywoods biggest star, Shah Rukh Khan, is not shaping up as the usual red carpet and starlets affair. Police officers, fearing violent protests, are being stationed at theaters, while nearly 2,000 people have already been arrested as a precaution.

title: Snowboarder Hawks Undies for her Pet Causes
description: VANCOUVER  Gold medalist Hannah Teter is not shy: The U.S. snowboarder shed her Burton snow gear for Sports Illustrateds swimsuit issue; an outspoken vegetarian, she condemned the hunting of baby seals for PETA; and at a news conference Thursday with her teammates, she shamelessly plugged the energy drink Amp, one of her sponsors.

title: A U.S. Analogy for a Greek Solution
description: Is Greece a sovereign version of Bear Stearns? The world had better hope not. But its tempting to draw parallels between an incipient Hellenic bailout and the rescue of Wall Streets biggest outlier.

title: Deal on Jobs Shows Limits of Push for Bipartisanship
description: WASHINGTON  Key Democrats and Republicans in the Senate reached a rare bipartisan agreement on Thursday on steps to spur job creation. But Democratic leaders said they would move ahead on only some elements as the two parties maneuvered to address both the struggling economy and voter unrest over gridlock in Washington.

title: Of Bagel Larry, Term Limits And Panache
description: An old newspaper story, probably apocryphal but falling under the heading Too Good to Check, tells of a foreign correspondent who was headed to a cold-weather assignment and bought a new coat. He put it on his expense account, only to have the bosses bounce it back. You cant expense a coat, they said.

title: Gay Guardsman Has Returned to Drills With His Unit
description: WASHINGTON  In a sign that the dont ask, dont tell policy may be weakening under pressure from the White House and the Pentagons top leadership, Lt. Dan Choi, who is facing discharge from the New York Army National Guard because he publicly announced that he was gay, took part in a drill last weekend with his Guard unit at what he said was the encouragement of his commander.

title: Greeces Woes May Give Pause to Euro Zone Candidates
description: RIGA, Latvia  The tiny Baltic states have pursued closer integration with Europe with enormous zeal. But the price of monetary union may be giving them pause.

title: Hiding a Hollywood Symbol, to Make It More Visible
description: LOS ANGELES  Decades ago, Howard Hughes bought a bunch of land behind the world-famous Hollywood sign with the intent of ensconcing his lover Ginger Rogers in a mansion in its hilltop shadow.

title: Administration Rejects Insurers Defense of Rate Increases
description: Anthem Blue Cross, the California health insurance company that was criticized by the Obama administration for raising its premiums, said Thursday that the increases of up to 39 percent were driven by rising health care costs.

title: Nice Buses, With One Hitch
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Several of the buses being used to transport athletes and officials up the mountain hosting the freestyle skiing and snowboarding events have an obvious shortcoming: they cant climb hills.

title: Administration Rejects Health Insurers Defense of Huge Rate Increases
description: Anthem Blue Cross, the California health insurance company that was criticized by the Obama administration for raising its premiums, said Thursday that the increases of up to 39 percent were driven by rising health care costs.

title: Obama Advisers Predict Unemployment of 8.2% by 2012
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration projected Thursday that the unemployment rate would fall this year by only a little, if at all, and would remain well over 6 percent until 2015.

title: New Guest-Worker Rules Seek to Increase Wages
description: Labor Secretary Hilda Solis announced new rules on Thursday for the temporary immigrant farm workers program, saying they would raise wages and strengthen labor protections for foreign and American workers.

title: Terrorism Fight Creates Battle Over Prosecution
description: John Walker Lindh and David Hicks were both young Muslim converts who traveled to Afghanistan to join the Taliban and were captured there in 2001 by American troops. But then their cases diverged  in ways that might surprise anyone following the fierce political debate over how the Obama administration should treat terrorism suspects.

title: Western Union to Pay in Border-Crime Deal
description: Western Union will pay $94 million to settle a long-running battle with Arizona over whether the company turned a blind eye to the use of its services in border-related crime.

title: 32 Down: One of the Palins
description: Sarah Palin with members of her family after she was announced as Senator John McCains running mate in 2008. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

title: Ones to Know: Chad Hedrick
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Bursting Pipes Lead to a Legal Battle
description: State and local governments across the country may have to replace their water systems because of defective pipes, according to a whistle-blower lawsuit unsealed this week.

title: Jewish Youths Are at Center of Outbreak of Mumps
description: More than 1,500 people in the New York area, mostly Orthodox Jewish boys and young men in Brooklyn, have contracted mumps in the worst outbreak in the United States since 2006, city and federal health officials said Thursday.

title: Jury Views Recanted Confession to a Killing
description: Jurors on Thursday watched a crucial piece of evidence in the trial of the woman accused of killing the celebrity real estate broker Linda Stein: the confession video.

title: Florida Congressman Wont Run Again
description: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island, has told Democratic leaders that he will not seek re-election this year, a party official said Thursday evening. Once he leaves office, it would be the first time in a half-century that a Kennedy would not be serving in Congress. Three Democratic officials confirmed the decision on condition of anonymity. Mr. Kennedy recorded a video announcement that was to be released on Sunday, a party official said. It outlines the reasons for his decision, including the death of his father, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and a long struggle with addiction. He would be the 14th House Democrat to decide to retire or seek another office. Earlier Thursday, Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Florida Republican, announced that he would not seek another term, making him the 18th House Republican to decide not to run for re-election this year.

title: California: Newspaper Shifts From Print to Web
description: The Berkeley Daily Planet newspaper announced Thursday that it would shift to an online-only edition at the end of the month. In a letter posted on the papers Web site, the editor, Becky OMalley, and publisher, Mike OMalley, cited falling advertising sales, absentee business owners, and a continuing boycott by a group that accuses the paper of being overly critical of Israel. The campaign against the Planets free-speech policy by a few misguided zealots who represent themselves as friends of Israel has certainly contributed to our advertising problems in some measure, the OMalleys wrote.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Posts Profit, but Slow Sales Depress Shares
description: Alcatel-Lucent, the struggling French-American network equipment maker, on Thursday reported its first real quarterly profit since its 2006 merger. But its stock fell sharply amid concerns over declining sales.

title: $4.2 Billion Loss in 2009 Is Reported by Renault
description: PARIS  Renault, the French automaker, posted a 3.1 billion euro  annual loss on Thursday on a sharp decrease in sales. It also declined to offer a 2010 earnings forecast, saying conditions would remain difficult.

title: Judge Denies Monserrates Request to Block Expulsion
description: A federal judge on Thursday denied a request by former Senator Hiram Monserrate, the first member of the New York State Legislature forced out of office in nearly a century, to temporarily block his expulsion and halt the special election that will determine his replacement.

title: Ex-Nominees Troubles Stain Pawnbrokers
description: Illinois is no stranger to odd, larcenous or rough-and-tumble elections. But only here, it seems, has a candidate collapsed so ingloriously that he brought dishonor on what many consider a shame-proof industry: pawnbroking.

title: Atomic Agency Views Irans Stepped-Up Enrichment of Uranium as a Violation
description: Irans surprise move this week to begin enriching its uranium to a level closer to weapons-grade violated an agreement with atomic inspectors in Vienna, diplomats said, very likely providing the United States with another piece of evidence that Iran is not living up to its international commitments on its nuclear program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 18 about the role of faith in Haiti in the aftermath of the Jan. 12 earthquake misstated the year of construction for the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Assumption, which was among the churches destroyed. The cathedral, identified in the article only as the main cathedral in Port-au-Prince, was built in 1914, not 1750.

title: For James, Game-Day Quirks Evolve Into the Ritual
description: CLEVELAND  It is known simply as the Ritual.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the Democratic primary for Illinois governor misstated the surname of a spokesman for the secretary of state of Illinois. He is David Druker, not Druken.

title: Patrick Kennedy Wont Seek Re-election to Congress
description: Representative Patrick Kennedy, the son of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has told Democratic leaders that he will not seek re-election this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the American Bar Associations recommendation to Congress for the creation of a new independent immigration court misstated the length of a report by the associations immigration commission on the state of existing immigration courts. The report is 510 pages, not 1,500 pages.

title: Landlord to Pay $1 Million Over Treatment of Tenants
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said Thursday that he had reached a $1 million settlement with a large New York City property owner that became a lightning rod for complaints about landlords treatment of tenants in rent-regulated apartments.

title: Federal Monitor Rejects Westchesters Plan to Address Segregation With Fair Housing
description: Six months after Westchester County signed a landmark housing desegregation agreement, a federal monitor has rejected the countys plan to create hundreds of homes for people with moderate incomes in predominantly white communities as vague and lacking in accountability and enforcement.

title: Health Reform in Limbo, Top Drug Lobbyist Quits
