description: Billy Tauzin, one of the highest paid lobbyists in Washington, is resigning as president of the pharmaceutical industrys trade group amid internal disputes over its pact with the White House to trade political support for favorable terms in the proposed health care overhaul.

title: Marshall High School Moves Closer to a Sweeping Overhaul
description: On an April morning last year, more than 200 juniors took their seats at Marshall High School for the Prairie State Achievement Examination, a measure of whether their school had prepared them to meet basic state learning standards.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Wednesday about New York Citys decision to declare a snow day for its public schools well before any snow had fallen misstated the date of the last snow day, in 2009. It was March 2, not March 8.

title: Subpoena Seeks Senators Records on Funds He Directed to Community Groups
description: Federal prosecutors investigating a nonprofit group linked to State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and Congressman Gregory W. Meeks have subpoenaed records from Mr. Smiths Senate office that detail all monies he has directed to community groups for a decade, a person with knowledge of the subpoena said Thursday.

title: A Cinderella Emerged, Then Quickly Lost Its Way
description: Dont trust Cinderella.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the lineup for the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., referred incompletely to an act scheduled to perform. The full Kings of Leon band is to appear, not just Nathan Followill, the drummer.

title: Zenyatta vs. Rachel Alexandra Will Happen After All
description: The showdown between the undefeated mare Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra, the unbeaten 2009 Horse of the Year, is once more on at Oaklawn Park in Arkansas. The tracks president, Charles J. Cella, agreed Thursday to move the date of the Apple Blossom Invitational back nearly a week, to April 9, and restored the $5 million purse if both Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta show up.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Thursday about American Radical: The Trials of Norman Finkelstein misstated a word in a comment Mr. Finkelstein made in a television interview shown in the documentary. He said, A handful of American Jews have effectively hijacked the Nazi Holocaust to blackmail Europe and divert attention from what is being done to the Palestinians  not divert attention to what is being done to the Palestinians.

title: Olympic Athletes Fare Well in Marist Poll
description: While few Americans have a favorite athlete competing this month in Vancouver, Olympic athletes are considered good role models for children, according to a recent Marist Poll.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the philanthropist Eli Broads influence on the cultural scene in Los Angeles misstated his role in the founding of the SunAmerica financial services firm. He was the sole founder, not a co-founder.

title: Cowardice and Courage
description: Irans autocrats were determined to use Thursdays anniversary of the 1979 Islamic Revolution to show that they are still in control and have the support of Irans people. Their ruthless campaign of violence and intimidation against a largely peaceful  and extremely courageous  opposition proves just the opposite.

title: The Pulse: Possible at DePaul: An Obama Link
description: The First Brother-in-Law has raised his hand for the DePaul University basketball coaching job.

title: Seeking to Raise His Game, Donald Chose to Lift Weights
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Making birdies while the sun shone, the big hitters in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am spread out across the Monterey Peninsula on a mild, breezy Thursday, pounding all three courses into submission while they could.

title: Corrections
description: Schedule information on Monday with a music review of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the date of the orchestras next Carnegie Hall concert. It is March 20, not March 10.

title: The Pulse: Mayors Furlough to Grow to 29 Days
description: After learning that he and Chicagos other elected officials received favorable treatment in a cost-cutting program requiring city workers to take unpaid days off, Mayor Richard M. Daley decided to take 29 furlough days before the end of this year, said his press secretary, Jacquelyn Heard. That is five more than other city workers must take.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Greece, Word of E.U. Support Provides Little Solace
description: ATHENS  Even with the statement of political support from European Union leaders on Thursday, Athens still faces a struggle to reassure jittery markets and overcome investor skepticism after Greece underestimated its enormous deficit.

title: Remembering Alexander McQueen
description: Cathy Horyn reflects on Alexander McQueen's talent, his career and his contributions to fashion.

title: A Fashion Statement Designed to Grab Gold
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  Look at that figure streaking into view on the Richmond Oval. Is it a crossing guard? Is it a backpacker?

title: At Pop-Ups, Chefs Take Chances With Little Risk
description: Lung Shan is an unremarkable Chinese restaurant in the Mission District. But on Thursday and Saturday nights its rocked by an invasion of diners and chefs with much more than sweet and sour pork on their minds.

title: How Not to Write a Jobs Bill
description: The jobs bill emerging in the Senate is pathetic, both as a response to joblessness and as an example of legislation deemed capable of winning bipartisan support.

title: Cellphones and Privacy
description: Cellphones have long been a fixture of life, becoming more powerful and more aware of their locations every year. Phone companies and software developers jump on each advance to provide new services. But the law is behind the technology.

title: Binghamtons Scandal
description: College presidents who dream of building powerhouse sports teams should read the new report on the basketball program at Binghamton University. Based on an investigation overseen by Judith Kaye, New York States former chief judge, it shows how a runaway sports program can poison campus life, make a mockery of academic values and leave the administrations reputation in ruins.

title: If Iran Gets Nuclear Weapons ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Stories Like Precious Need to Be Told
description: To the Editor:

title: An Election Sets a Record, and Not a Good One
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Changing New York States Law on Wine Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Renews Bipartisan Talks on Overhaul of Financial Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said Thursday that talks over a bipartisan bill to overhaul the nations financial regulations had resumed, but the outcome of a major point of contention  whether to create an independent consumer agency to regulate financial products like credit cards and mortgages  remained unclear.

title: Republicans and Medicare
description: Dont cut Medicare. The reform bills passed by the House and Senate cut Medicare by approximately $500 billion. This is wrong. So declared Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, in a recent op-ed article written with John Goodman, the president of the National Center for Policy Analysis.

title: Whats Next, Mr. President?
description: By 2008, Americans were disgusted with their government. They were sick of partisan gridlock and general incompetence. Along came Barack Obama offering to usher in a new era. It was time, he said, to put away childish things.

title: Tribunal and Error
description: SINCE Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York announced that he no longer favored trying Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed 9/11 mastermind, in a Manhattan federal court because of logistical concerns, the Obama administration has come under increasing attack from those who claim that military commissions are more suitable for prosecuting terrorists. These critics are misguided.

title: Plan for Casino in Richmond Raises Fears of a Bad Precedent
description: A plan to build a Las Vegas-style casino complex on an isolated promontory on San Francisco Bay has drawn broad support in Contra Costa County, but detractors fear that its approval will unleash a new round of gambling places in urban areas.

title: Lee, Replacing Iverson, Is Knicks First All-Star Since 2001
description: Amid another miserable season, the Knicks received some good news on Thursday: David Lee is an All-Star.

title: Economics and School
description: Below are excerpts from some of the most provocative posts on The New York Times Bay Area blog this week:

title: After Losing to St. Johns, Pitino Denies Talk of Nets
description: When Louisville Coach Rick Pitino returned to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, he maintained that he had not had contact, directly or indirectly, with the Nets.

title: Patrick Kennedy Wont Run Again
description: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island, has told Democratic leaders that he will not seek re-election this year, a party official said Thursday evening. Once he leaves office, it would be the first time in a half-century that a Kennedy would not be serving in Congress. Three Democratic officials confirmed the decision on condition of anonymity. Mr. Kennedy recorded a video announcement that was to be released on Sunday, a party official said. It outlines the reasons for his decision, including the death of his father, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and a long struggle with addiction. He would be the 14th House Democrat to decide to retire or seek another office. Earlier Thursday, Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Florida Republican, announced that he would not seek another term, making him the 18th House Republican to decide not to run for re-election this year.

title: Senate Confirms 2 Dozen Obama Nominees
description: WASHINGTON  Before leaving for the Presidents Day break, the Senate on Thursday night confirmed  by unanimous consent  more than two dozen of President Obamas nominees to federal positions.

title: John Furlong, Games Organizer, Feels Heat About the Weather
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In his role as chief executive of the Vancouver Organizing Committee, John Furlong is the man ultimately held responsible for how the Winter Olympics are run, and how they are perceived.

title: Jimmie Heuga, an Early U.S. Ski Medalist, Dies at 66
description: Jimmie Heuga, one of the first two American men to win an Olympic medal in Alpine skiing, and later a pioneering advocate of exercise and activity to combat multiple sclerosis, the disease that curtailed his athletic career, died Monday in Boulder, Colo. He was 66 and lived nearby in Louisville, Colo.

title: How Do I Love Thee? Let Me Count the 233 Ways
description: Theres an old saying about online dating: The odds are good, but the goods are odd. This column examines just how odd things have become.

title: Kennedy, Feeling Fathers Absence, Steps Aside
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Patrick J. Kennedys life has been a public testament to the blessing and burden of his family name. It afforded him a big head start in his political career and also caused his personal struggles  with mental illness, substance abuse, the law  to play out in public view.

title: 2010 Olympics Tracker
description: Use this personalized event schedule to follow your favorite sports and countries throughout the Games.

title: Word of the Day | putrid
description: putrid\py-trd\ adjective

title: Corrections
description: An entry on the On the Market page last Sunday, about a co-op for sale at 165 Carroll Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, misstated its price and maintenance fees. The price is $819,000, not $869,000, and maintenance is $899 a month, not $831.

title: Ones to Know: Kim Martin
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Living In article last Sunday, about Belmont, the Bronx, misstated the residency status of Puerto Rican residents of the area. Because Puerto Rico is a commonwealth of the United States, they are citizens  not immigrants.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the In the Region article in New Jersey copies on Jan. 17, about the challenges of dual-agency representation by real estate brokers, misstated the affiliation of Roberta Plutzik Baldwin, a broker cited in the article. She is with Keller Williams Towne Square; she is no longer with Re/Max.

title: Corrections
description: The Living In article on Jan. 31, about the Civic Center area of Manhattan, misstated the historical relationship of Columbus Park, which opened in 1897, to the Five Points neighborhood. The park replaced the heart of Five Points, not an area adjacent to it.

title: News Quiz | February 12, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Pop-Up Restaurants: An Experiment in Experimental Cooking
description: Think of it as the foodie version of cuckoos, who take eggs from other birds nests. Young, eager chefs take over some other restaurants kitchen for an evening and go wild.

title: Correction
description: An article on the favorite view of Bruce Horton, a bar pilot in San Francisco Bay, included a quotation that gave the wrong conversion from knots to miles per hour. Fifteen knots is about 17 m.p.h., not 12 m.p.h.

title: Correction
description: An article last Friday about Toni Preckwinkles victory in the Feb. 2 Democratic primary for Cook County Board president referred incorrectly to the position of Dorothy Brown, one of Ms. Preckwinkles opponents. Ms. Brown is clerk of the Circuit Court of Cook County, not Cook County clerk.

title: Sparse U.S. Listings Prompt Rush on China I.P.O.s
description: Last April, when global financial markets were collapsing, a Chinese Web site named Sohu.com made a bold move to spin off its online gaming unit and list it on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

title: 5 U.S. Soldiers Injured in Afghan Suicide Attack
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber wearing the uniform of an Afghan border police officer, who wounded five American soldiers on Thursday, was in fact a border police officer working for the Taliban, a Taliban spokesman said Friday.

title: M.L.S. Talks to Continue
description: Major League Soccer and the players union said they had agreed to continue to negotiate on a new collective bargaining agreement through Feb. 25. Negotiations scheduled for this week were postponed because of snowstorms.

title: Zenyatta vs. Rachelwill Happen After All
description: The showdown between the undefeated mare Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra, the unbeaten 2009 Horse of the Year, is once more on at Oaklawn Park in Arkansas. The tracks president, Charles J. Cella, agreed to move the date of the Apple Blossom Invitational back nearly a week, to April 9, and restored the $5 million purse if both Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta show up.

title: Helping His Family in Haiti
description: WHO is Jean-Paul Coffy?

title: Norris: Financial Perversions Sold During Boom
description: Would you buy a XXX security?

title: Madoff Family Said to Be Target of Tax-Fraud Cases
description: The brother and sons of imprisoned swindler Bernard Madoff are the subject of criminal tax-fraud cases by federal prosecutors in Manhattan, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Senate Renews Bipartisan Talks on Finance Change
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said Thursday that talks over a bipartisan bill to overhaul the nations financial regulations had resumed, but the outcome of a major point of contention  whether to create an independent consumer agency to regulate financial products like credit cards and mortgages  remained unclear.

title: What Are the Most Meaningful Relationships in Your Life?
description: Valentines Day is this Sunday, and in honor of it were asking you about the relationships that are most important in your life right now, whether theyre with family, friends, a romantic partner or anyone (or thing) else. How, if at all, do you plan to use the occasion of Valentines Day to show these people what they mean to you?

title: 3 I.P.O.s Come to Market After Price Cuts
description: Three companies, including QuinStreet, an Internet marketing company whose fast-growing sales made it a standout among this months crop of I.P.O.s, managed to go public Thursday after slashing prices on their offerings, The Associated Press said.

title: Greenlight and Elliott Said to Help Ross Raise $1.1 Billion
description: Stephen Ross, the billionaire investor, and two partners raised about $1.1 billion from investors, including David Einhorns Greenlight Capital, to help their SJB National Bank acquire a seized American lender, a person with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: Alcon Profit Rises as Novartis Takeover Looms
description: Alcon, the eye-care products maker being acquired by Swiss drug maker Novartis, reported higher fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by double-digit sales increases in the United States. and emerging markets, Reuters reported.

title: Super Return Delivers Testy Sound Bites
description: It seems the tone turned rather testy Thursday during a panel discussion at the Super Return conference for the private equity industry taking place in Berlin.

title: United Tech Considers Bigger Bets in Clean Energy
description: United Technologies is interested in making bigger investments in alternative energy, possibly including a majority stake in wind turbine maker Clipper Windpower, a top executive at the diversified United States manufacturer said on Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: Ones to Know: Emily Brydon
description: The Canadian Alpine ski team has been decimated by injuries this season, but Emily Brydon is one great ski racer still lurking in the field with her eyes set on a home-snow upset. She is funny and has just enough spirit to vault past the favorites to land on the medal podium. She is also good friends with Julia Mancuso of the United States and spent the most recent New Years Eve with her in an Austrian mountainside hut. Mancuso knows about Olympic surprises.

title: Schott Op-Chart: Let the Games Begin
description: Being a collection of statistical curiosities pertaining to the Winter Olympics.

title: Investor Seeks Trustee for Six Flags
description: An investor holding  Six Flags preferred shares asked a federal judge to appoint a trustee to run the bankrupt theme park operator because current management has breached its fiduciary duty and suffers conflicts of interest.

title: Mixpanel Raises $500,000
description: Mixpanel, the developer of tools to track how users engage with Web sites in real time, said Thursday that it had landed $500,000 in seed funding.

title: Prospect of Aid for Greece Gives Wall Street a Boost
description: A promise by European leaders to come to the aid of their weaker brethren calmed American markets on Thursday, helping stocks overcome an early wave of pessimism.

title: Is FirstEnergys Deal Really Worth It?
description: At first blush, the FirstEnergy Corporations $8.5 billion all-stock purchase of Allegheny Energy looks to be a winner, with huge cost savings to harvest. But factor in the pounds of flesh that regulators will extract, and investors would be forgiven for questioning whether its worth the bother, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Parallels Between Greece and Bear Stearns?
description: Is Greece a sovereign version of Bear Stearns? The world had better hope not. But, Breakingviews says, its tempting to draw parallels between an incipient Hellenic bailout and the rescue of Wall Streets biggest outlier.

title: Google Agrees to Buy Social Search Service
description: From Miguel Helft at Bits:

title: Lloyds Sells Esure Back to Founder
description: Lloyds Banking Group has sold its majority stake in Esure, one of Britains largest providers of home and car insurance, as part of its plan to offload non-core units after a merger with rival lender HBOS.

title: Webvisible Receives $20 Million in New Financing
description: Webvisible, which develops tools to help businesses manage their online advertising, has received $20 million in a third round of funding, PaidContent reported, citing a regulatory filing.

title: G.I.C. May Book 70% Loss on UBS Conversion
description: The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation will convert 11 billion Swiss francs ($10.33 billion) worth of UBS notes into shares next month at a price that may erode the value of its stake in the bank by 70 percent, Reuters reported.

title: Appeals Court to Weigh Galleon Wiretap Issue
description: Raj Rajaratnam, facing criminal and civil charges in a multimillion dollar insider-trading investigation involving his hedge fund firm,Galleon Group, won an emergency order relieving him from having to immediately turn over wiretap recordings in the civil case.

title: For Private Equity, I.P.O. Exits Proves Elusive
description: If the board of New Look decides to shelve plans to bring the British fashion retailer to market, it will mark the third time this week that a private equity firm has seen its hopes for an exit dashed.

title: Manager Scores Dinner With Buffett, His Treat
description: One way to score a meal with Warren E. Buffett is to cough up $1.68 million, like a Canadian wealth management firm did to win a charity auction of a steak lunch with the famed investor.

title: Nortel Sees $1 Billion More From Asset Sales
description: Nortel Networks, the bankrupt telecommunications equipment maker, said it was expecting about $1 billion more from the sale of some of its remaining businesses, including the Optical Networking and Carrier Ethernet service.

title: The Town Busybody Is Now Us
description: Todays idea: The archetypal neighborhood busybody peeking over the backyard fence is a vanishing breed. Say hello to the new busybodies: you.

title: Volcker Speaks on the Volcker Rule
description: In a video interview with The Financial Times, Paul A. Volcker, former head of the Federal Reserve, explained his thinking behind the package of reforms that includes the Volcker Rule, which would ban banks from engaging in proprietary trading.

title: Taking the Flamenco Train to London
description: Londoners, get ready to kick up those heels: the city will host its seventh annual Flamenco Festival from Feb. 13 to 27 at Sadlers Wells (Rosebery Avenue, EC1R; 44-844-412-4300; Angel tube stop), featuring a roster of new shows performed by a variety of dancers from across Spain.

title: Was Polian Out of Line in Criticizing His Offensive Line?
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Kohn Has Experience, but Not in Whistler
description: VANCOUVER Many bobsled drivers who have steered the Whistler Sliding Centres sharps turns marvel at the treks speed and need to be technically sound.

title: Payouts for London Bankers Surge, Survey Says
description: Bankers in London have received average bonus increases of 40 percent this year and most have also received a jump in base salary, according to a survey, signaling that attempts to restrain payouts are failing, Reuters reported.

title: Do E-Readers Cause Eye Strain?
description: The admonition offered by legions of mothers  Dont sit so close to the TV  isnt really an option when it comes to e-reading devices. You have to get close to the screen to use it.

title: KDDI Changes Deal Terms for Jupiter
description: KDDI Corp., one of the largest Japanese wireless operators, said Friday that it had changed the terms of its agreement to buy Liberty Globals stake in Jupiter Telecommunications, after the Japanese financial regulator objected to the deal announced last month.

title: Stray Questions for: Philip Hoare
description: Philip Hoares new book, The Whale: In Search of the Giants of the Sea, has just been published.

title: Taking the Bait: Playing a Fishy Name Game
description: Once again, you have risen, dear readers, en masse, to the occasion. A restaurant without a good name is like a meal without a fine wine, a man without a faithful dog, a boat without a trusty rudder. Your thoughtfulness and honesty are appreciated more than you know, and if The Times didnt have ethics (or lawyers), I would love to buy you each a drink at my soon-to-be-named restaurant. What a great bunch of bananas you are!Red Fish Blue Fish  jodik, New York

title: Air Products Revises Its Airgas Lawsuit
description: While the takeover bid by Air Products and Chemicals for Airgas officially went hostile only on Thursday morning, the companys aggressive legal action against its target heated up on Thursday evening with a new set of allegations.

title: Lloyds Said to Be Inflating Cap Market Salaries
description: Stockbrokers in the City are said to be complaining to the British government that Lloyds, the bank it nationalized, is chasing talent a bit too hard to build its capital markets unit, according to The Daily Telegraph.

title: Yes, Those Were Peter Maxs Corvettes in the Basement
description: In this weeks Automobiles section, I wrote about a collection of 36 Corvettes, spanning 1953 to 1989, that were stored for years in the basement garage of my apartment building. When I first saw the cars, I turned to the Internet to try to figure out why they were there and quickly came across an article on New York magazines Web site that explained the basics of the story.

title: What Is Affordable Health Care?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Goldman Server Accused of High-Speed Voting
description: A group leading a campaign to implement what it calls the Robin Hood tax, which would single out bankers, says that an online poll it held on the levy was hit by artificial opposition, with 5,000 votes pouring in against it in the space of 20 minutes, The Guardian reports.

title: Sampler: Water Wars in Washington and a Plan for the Former Oakland Army Base
description: Update | 12:28 p.m.  Sampler will be off on Monday in celebration of Presidents Day. Well be back on Tuesday.

title: Equity Firms Acquire Web-Based Training Company
description: A consortium of private equity firms has agreed to buy SkillSoft, a Web-based business training company with headquarters in Ireland, in an all-cash deal valued at $1.1 billion.

title: SkillSoft to Sell Itself in $1.1 Billion L.B.O.
description: SkillSoft, an Irish provider of electronic education services, said on Friday that it agreed to sell itself to a consortium of private equity firms for $1.1 billion in cash.

title: Trump Wants the W.T.C. Site (Sort Of)
description: Update | 2:04 p.m. It seems that Donald J. Trump thinks he wants to buy 1 World Trade Center, but, then again, he isnt really sure. And he may be too late.

title: STUPID
description: An acronym for Spain, Turkey, the United Kingdom, Portugal, Italy and Dubai  countries that are expected to fare badly if the Greek economy collapses.

title: Ones to Know: Robel Teklemariam
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Tighter Curbs on Lending in China
description: For the second time in less than five weeks, Chinas central bank has moved to limit lending to consumers and businesses by ordering big commercial banks to park a larger share of their deposits at the central bank, Keith Bradsher reports in The New York Times.

title: Happy Birthday, Abe. Youre Fired.
description: Think Lincoln and New York and the juxtaposition would most likely conjure up the tunnel or the performing arts center. Until this year, it also would have evoked the majestic Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street. No longer.

title: NASA Scientist Adds to Views on Climate Panel
description: Andrew Lacis, a climate scientist at NASA, flashed around the skeptic blogosphere after A.W. Montford found Dr. Laciss 2005 critique of early drafts of an important chapter in the 2007 reports from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Earlier this week I wrote a piece examining Dr. Laciss views as well as the wording of the final version of that report section, which dealt with the tough question of detecting the human climate influence amid all the various forces creating climate patterns.

title: Biblio File | When Hair Could Fly
description: Back before fashion became a global corporate enterprise, it was a haven for deviants from the norm. Fey boys, gawky girls, misfits in their own homes and their own hometowns, they left their backgrounds behind and emigrated to the land of Style, where they were welcomed into the business of making and marketing illusion. In time, they landed jobs as designers, photographers, display directors, makeup artists, hairdressers, stylists, editors, arbiters.

title: Speed Read for Friday, Feb. 12
description: Highlights from todays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: The Early Word: Open for Business
description: The federal government will open two hours late this morning, after its longest continuous closing since the late 19th century.

title: Eleven Tantalizing Glimpses of Salinger
description: The letters, a total of 11, were written between 1951 and 1993, from one buddy, or Buddyroo, to another. In sharp and familiar prose, laced with humor and biting wit, the writer gives an intimate peek into his life and thoughts at precise moments in time. Read so many years later, they are filled with surprises.

title: Eurostar Criticized for Winter Breakdowns
description: An independent review of the December train breakdowns that stranded thousands of travelers in Britain and France blamed Eurostar and the operator of the tunnel beneath the English Channel for being unprepared for severe winter weather and rebuked their emergency responses as slow and uncoordinated.

title: For Venture Capital, Efficiency Is in Vogue
description: Venture capital investments in cleantech companies plunged by 50 percent to $2.6 billion last year as investors put their money in energy efficiency projects instead, according to a report released this week by Ernst & Young.

title: Happy Valentines Day, No One!
description: If you absolutely had to pick one moment to remember all of Thursday night television by, which would you go with? An eerily well-timed joke about John Mayer on Parks and Recreation? Jon Bon Jovi sending up his inexplicable status as NBCs artist-in-residence on 30 Rock or its welcome supporting performances from Elizabeth Banks and Horatio Sanz?

title: Using Lasers to Zap Mosquitoes
description: Can consumer electronics be used to combat malaria?

title: Thin Line Between Politics and Treason in Sri Lanka
description: On Friday, Sri Lankas supreme court ruled that Sarath Fonseka, the retired general who was arrested Monday night after his defeat in the countrys presidential election, will be allowed to challenge his detention in court. After the ruling the Web site Lanka Truth posted this video of one of General Fonsekas representatives telling reporters that the court had scheduled a hearing for Feb. 23:

title: Swiss Not Ready to Extradite Polanski
description: Update | 10:54 a.m. The filmmaker Roman Polanski can safely remain in his Alpine chalet for the time being: the Swiss Justice Ministry has said it will not extradite him to the United States until a California court rules that the director must appear in person to face sentencing on his longstanding sex crime, The Timess Doreen Carvajal reports. Rudolf Wyss, the ministrys deputy director said Friday that it made no sense to remove Mr. Polanski from his house arrest in Gstaad as long as the question is still open.

title: Vain Glorious | A Razors Edge
description: With Vain Glorious, T Magazines beauty/style editor, Sandra Ballentine, breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

title: Yassky May Head Taxi Agency
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is seriously considering the appointment of former City Councilman David Yassky as the next head of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, according to people told of the plans.

title: Ones to Know: Sophie Muir
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers
description: Novelists continue to be captivated by the world of graphic novels. Given how warmly they are received, who can blame them? This week our hardcover list has three graphic novel adaptations of Stephen Kings Dark Tower novels. The Fall of Gilead and The Long Road Home enter at No. 1 and No. 5, and join Dark Tower: Treachery (at No. 6), which has been on our hardcover list for 17 weeks.

title: What Were Reading
description: Marion Nestle takes note of studies on the effects of commercials and other food branding on the way children eat.

title: Polanskis Visions of Victimhood
description: THE GHOST WRITER, the 18th feature by Roman Polanski, opens this week, and, not for the first time in Mr. Polanskis career, the movie itself is likely to be overshadowed by the man who made it.

title: Chinese Contestant Enters Worldwide Gay Pageant
description: BEIJING  He is 25, Muslim and comes from a part of China recently known for deadly ethnic rioting. This weekend, he is competing for the title of Worldwide Mr. Gay.

title: Secret Agent Men, Accountant Division
description: Mark it down: Never again will the Bagger make fun of the accountants involved in the Oscar tabulation. Those fine, kind briefcase-toters are often the brunt of nerd jokes or, even worse, simply ignored in favor of, Hey, is there any more beer left? They havent even gotten to appear on the awards show for the last two years, their 15 minutes relegated to a few seconds on the red carpet, where even the briefcases get a star turn. But this year, the year of the 10 best picture nominees and the complicated preferential voting system, the folks at PricewaterhouseCoopers may actually get the attention they so richly deserve. Well, were writing about them anyway.

title: Broken Spokes? Roadside Help for Bikes
description: Biking in unfamiliar terrain just got a little more convenient.

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Guns N Roses Plays Surprise Fashion Week Show
description: There is apparently nothing that New York Fashion Week cannot do. It can compel important, sophisticated people to herd themselves like cattle under a tent in frozen Midtown Manhattan, and it can evidently persuade Guns N Roses to perform a live show.

title: Happy Birthday, Abe. Youre Fired
description: At our sib-blog, City Room, colleague Sam Roberts details the slight delivered in New York to Abraham Lincoln:

title: For Further Reading
description: A Parents Guide to Childhood Obesity: A Road Map to Health by the American Academy of Pediatrics and Sandra G. Hassink

title: In Progress: 'The Ricky Gervais Show'
description: The animatic, or moving storyboard, provides a rough draft for the sequence.

title: When Children Are Overweight, Changes for the Whole Family
description: AS Michelle Obama reminded us this week, the forces behind childhood obesity are insidious.

title: The Cost of Changing Family Eating Habits
description: In this weeks Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman explores the cost of family lifestyle changes, ranging from shopping for more healthful foods, paying for a dietitian or signing up for a fitness program. She writes:

title: Weekend Competition: Define Love
description: This Valentines Day weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting definitions of love:

title: State of the Rams: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

title: Oregon to Reduce Clean Energy Incentives
description: Oregons House of Representatives Wednesday passed a bill that will rein in a business energy tax credit that was designed to help strengthen the citys states renewable energy industry.

title: Swiss Not Ready to Extradite Polanski
description: PARIS  The Swiss ministry of Justice announced Friday that authorities will not extradite the film director Roman Polanski to face criminal charges in California until Los Angeles courts determine whether he must face sentencing in person on charges of having sex with a 13-year-old girl in 1977.

title: A Pediatricians Advice on Green Parenting
description: Since 1995, the pediatrician Alan Greenes popular Web site, DrGreene.com, has offered information about everything from potty training to picky eaters. Dr. Greene was also an early advocate of environmentally conscious parenting, an issue he explores in his latest book, Feeding Baby Green: The Earth-Friendly Program for Healthy, Safe Nutrition During Pregnancy, Childhood, and Beyond (Jossey-Bass, 2009). I recently spoke to Dr. Greene about the effect green parenting can have on a childs lifelong eating habits. Heres our conversation.

title: Nissan Leaf Electric Car Comes to New York
description: Nissan had originally planned to bring its Leaf electric car concept to 22 American cities, but requests from Atlanta and Boston made it 24. They asked and we couldnt say no, said a grinning Carlos Tavares, the chairman of Nissan Americas. He estimated that 100,000 people saw the companys lithium-ion battery car, which will go on sale late this year, during its cross-country jaunt.

title: Louisiana Museum Confronts Segregation
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  When Eddie Robinson was growing up here in Louisianas capital city about 80 years ago, he discovered the only way a black person infatuated with football could attend a game at the state university: He showed up at 5 a.m. on Saturdays to clean the stadium.

title: Racial Roots Underlie Debate on Felons Voting Rights
description: At the New York constitutional convention of 1821, legislators from around the state debated a particularly explosive topic: voting rights for blacks.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Streaking Sens Edge Formerly Streaking Caps
description: Seven games on Thursday, highlighted by a clash between hot teams from North Americas two capital cities. Home teams listed first:

title: Now Carrying | A Revamped Classic
description: In 1829, a year before Belgium gained independence from Holland, Charles Delvaux founded what would become the worlds oldest luxury leather-goods company. Now pushing 200, Delvaux continues to make bags in small runs signed by master craftsmen. Which doesnt mean the label isnt looking toward the future. It has forged bag collaborations with the designer Bruno Pieters, the model Hannelore Knuts and the Belgian avant-gardist Natalia Brilli, who wraps watches and objects in taut lambskin. But Delvauxs biggest score to date was hiring Veronique Branquinho as artistic director. Its a legendary brand with a great history, says Branquinho, who in addition to reworking existing classics is introducing several new bag styles for spring  most notably a deep-blue duffel and a buttery beige envelope (right). Many years ago, I received my first Delvaux from friends who purchased it at a vintage store, she says. Its still contemporary and beautiful after all these years.

title: 2010 Winter Olympics Teaching and Learning Extravaganza
description: 11:09 a.m. | Updated  Weve added a half-dozen new activities to our list, below, of Olympics teaching and learning activities. See our new suggestions on ice skating scoring (math section), minority Olympians (social studies), analysis of winners tactics and video interviews with athletes (journalism) and a look at dangerous conditions (science and health)  and have students join the conversation on the athletes and events they are most interested in.

title: Secret of Kells Gets U.S. Release Dates
description: The Secret of Kells, the film that grabbed a surprise Academy Award nomination for best animated feature earlier this month, wont be a secret to American audiences for much longer. On Thursday, the distributor GKIDS said that it would show the movie at the IFC Center in New York on March 5, two days before it vies with Coraline, The Princess and the Frog, Up and Fantastic Mr. Fox for Oscar honors. Directed by Tomm Moore, The Secret of Kells tells the story of a boy living in a Celtic abbey, whose adventures with fairies, she-wolves and barbarians lead to the creation of the Book of Kells, the 1,200-year-old illuminated manuscript. The film was already planned to be shown in Boston on March 19, but after its Oscar nomination gave it a little extra shine, it will now receive a wider national release in cities including Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago starting April 2.

title: Officer Free Rider
description: A retired New York City police officer, I take the subway to and from work four days a week. When I show my ID and shield to station clerks, some of whom know Im retired, they let me ride free. (Bus drivers do, too.) The public gets the added safety of having a retired police officer ride with them  I still carry a firearm and have at times aided conductors and uniformed officers. I never sit, so I do not take a seat from a paying rider. What do you think? GEORGE KAVANAGH, NEW YORK

title: Secret of Kells Gets U.S. Release Dates
description: The Secret of Kells, the film that grabbed a surprise Academy Award nomination for best animated feature earlier this month, wont be a secret to American audiences for much longer. On Thursday, the distributor GKIDS said that it would show the movie at the IFC Center in New York on March 5, two days before it vies with Coraline, The Princess and the Frog, Up and Fantastic Mr. Fox for Oscar honors. Directed by Tomm Moore, The Secret of Kells tells the story of a boy living in a Celtic abbey whose adventures with fairies, she-wolves and barbarians lead to the creation of the Book of Kells, the 1,200-year-old illuminated manuscript. Read more on ArtsBeat

title: The Carpetbagger in 3-D
description: Melena Ryzik reports from the headquarters of RealD, the Los Angeles company that helps bring 3-D films like "Avatar" to theaters.

title: Pride and Avarice
description: When the first wave of novelists began to tackle the post-9/11 world, many critics marveled (and some jeered) that theyd done it so soon. In 2005, Jonathan Safran Foers Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close and Ian McEwans Saturday were in the vanguard. Since then, new works touching on our jittery times have appeared with increasing frequency. And yet, almost a decade after the cataclysm, it can still strike a reader as portentous or premature when the somber shadow of that day falls across the pages of contemporary fiction. So its with surprise, even incredulity, that you grasp, as you read Adam Hasletts first novel, that this book, set chiefly in 2002, not only tucks 9/11 into its narrative in an uncowed, offhand way but, to an extent, leaves it behind. Instead, Haslett tracks a different calamity: the global economic crisis that accelerated after 2001, propelled by bad mortgages, bad financial instruments, bad regulations and bad faith. As Doug Fanning, the protagonist (in no way a hero) of Union Atlantic, curtly observes, recapping the trajectory that made him rich, the attacks on 9/11 only sped the trend. So much for the halcyon pre-9/11 mind-set. This novels narrative history doubles as news analysis.

title: Figure Skaters Ready to Mount Vancouvers Stage, With No 6.0s in Sight
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: Man of Constant Sorrow
description: The German word Einfall, meaning a sudden notion or fancy, contains the image of something dropping precipitously into the mind. Don Juan, in this whimsical tour de force by the Austrian writer Peter Handke, is not a man but an Einfall, and the mind into which he drops, with a crash, is that of a French innkeeper and chef who (unlike the world-renowned Handke) has lost his customers and is living in solitude, reading Pascal and Racine in his overgrown garden. The legendary lover comes hurtling over the garden wall, narrowly escaping an angry semi-nude couple on a motorcycle whose alfresco lovemaking he has not only disrupted but, in effect, criticized with a sigh.

title: A Sublet Tenant Faces Eviction
description: Q.

title: Andrew Youngs Memoir of John Edwards
description: In Mark Twain and Charles Dudley Warners satirical and pioneering Washington novel, The Gilded Age, published in 1873, the beautiful frontierswoman Laura Hawkins accepts an invitation from Senator Dilworthy to visit the nations capital. Reinventing herself as an heiress, she swiftly conquers Washington high society and schemes with Dilworthy and other worthies to ensure Congressional passage of a sleazy Tennessee land bill that would appropriate millions to buy a large property deeded to her impecunious family and supposedly build a university dedicated to educating the newly emancipated slave population on it. Only her acquaintance Philip Sterling is disgusted by the deceit and hypocrisy that pervade Washington, which he views as the maddest Vanity Fair one could conceive, a feverish, unhealthy atmosphere in which lunacy would be easily developed.

title: HBO Gets the Point
description: David Gonzalez/The New York Times A mural outside The Point, a community center in Hunts Point. A version of the mural appears in the credits of the 2002 HBO documentary Hookers at the Point, which HBO decided to stop showing after years of complaints.

title: Chinas Central Bank Hits Brake on Hot Economy
description: HONG KONG  As most countries agonize over how to keep their barely reviving economies growing, China is already looking to slam on the brakes.

title: Couples Cut Back Valentines Day Gifts
description: This Valentines Day, couples plan to spend less on each other than in the past.

title: Time Limits on Condo Lawsuits
description: Q.

title: Photos of the Moment | Chadwick Bell Fashion Show, Mr. Brainwash Party
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: Video: The Carpetbagger in 3-D
Empire of Savagery in the Amazon
description: The 19th-century doctrine of progress held slavery and capitalism to be incompatible. Coercion, liberals believed, violated the ideals of natural rights and free labor. Wage work, Marxists thought, was more profitable than forced work, and that alone would doom slavery. Then in 1904, nearly four decades after Appomattox, Roger Casement, an Irish-born career diplomat in the British Foreign Office, wrote his Congo report, revealing that King Leopold of Belgium had enriched himself by presiding over a rubber trade founded on pure cruelty. What has civilization itself been to them? Casement asked of Leopolds Congolese victims, 10 million of whom, by some estimates, had perished in but two decades. He himself had the answer: A thing of horror.

title: Muhly and Lucass Opera First Met-Lincoln Center Project
description: The composer Nico Muhly and the playwright Craig Lucas have crossed the finish line first.

title: Ones to Know: Alex Ovechkin
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Well Crafted | D.I.Y. My Valentine
description: The consuming frenzy around this Hallmark holiday ultimately inspires me to create something unique  or at least personalize something I buy my Valentine. Here are three projects that will mean more than a box of chocolates or a pair of Louboutins. (Okay, maybe not the shoes.)

title: Odysseus Remixed
description: The hero of Homers Odyssey is a modern man in ancient times, an eloquent outfoxer whose life is one long, furious act of self-invention. The embodiment of metis, or cunning intelligence, Odysseus adopts false identities fluidly and fully, invites a gods wrath rather than let an act of cleverness go unknown, risks death to hear the ruinous songs of the Sirens because he cannot bear to let the opportunity pass.

title: In Progress: 'The Ricky Gervais Show'
description: The first step in production is to turn the podcast audio into a working script for the episode.

title: Marja 50 Years Ago: Model Villages and American Money
description: Marja, an area of Afghanistans southern Helmand Province, is the focus of an imminent NATO military operation. Tribal elders are being assured that government and NATO forces will rid the area of Taliban fighters, and that they will be consulted on the appointment of local officials and development project proposals.

title: Complaint Box | Online Class Reunions
description: DEAR K.,

title: Start Date of Banana Shpeel Slips Again
description: Has the Allman Brothers Band put some sort of Southern-fried hex on the Canadian clowns of Cirque du Soleil? On Friday Cirque du Soleil said that it would again delay the start of its coming show Banana Shpeel at the Beacon Theater  the same show that pushed the Allmans band out of its longtime March residency at the Beacon. In a news release, press representatives for Banana Shpeel said it would now begin preview performances on March 17; back in December, the show had moved its first performances to Feb. 25, from an original date of Feb. 4. In the release, the press representative said the latest delay had occurred because the rehearsal period at the theater has been extended to integrate new performance elements. An official opening date at the Beacon has not yet been announced. A Chicago production of Banana Shpeel was presented last year, and disapproving critics more or less tied it to the whipping post.

title: Jews and the Burden of Money
description: The question of why so many Jews have been so good at making money is a touchy one. For hundreds of years, it has been fraught with suspicion, denial, resentment, guilt, self-hatred and violence. No wonder Jews and gentiles alike are so uncomfortable confronting Jewish capitalistic competence. Still, in his slim essay collection Capitalism and the Jews, Jerry Z. Muller presents a provocative and accessible survey of how Jewish culture and historical accident ripened Jews for commercial success and why that success has earned them so much misfortune.

title: China Sees Growth Engine in a Web of Fast Trains
description: WUHAN, China  The worlds largest human migration  the annual crush of Chinese traveling home to celebrate the Lunar New Year, which is this Sunday  is going a little faster this time thanks to a new high-speed rail line.

title: Written on Coffeehouse Walls
description: In 1981, Raymond Carver advanced a literary genre with What We Talk About When We Talk About Love. The movement wasnt dirty realism or minimalism, but vaguely titled fiction: stories concealing their intensity and anxiety behind titles full of pronouns and ennui, signifying nothing much about their narratives. The device is now well established, thanks to Joshua Ferriss Then We Came to the End, Miranda Julys No One Belongs Here More Than You, Maile Meloys Both Ways Is the Only Way I Want It and the Everest of the genre, Lorrie Moores People Like That Are the Only People Here.

title: What to Expect When Youre Abducting
description: Most good novels have veins of engaging questions running through the bedrock of their narratives, tempting readers to become miners, apt to strike it rich with enough digging. Too visible and obtrusive, such questions turn a book into a bully or an eye-roller; hidden or absent, they leave the story hollow. Geoffrey Beckers fantastic Hot Springs works hard to conceal its own scope and ambition, but the books coyness (not to mention its humor) only heightens the uncanny, moving power of the question at its core: When it comes down to it, how far will people go for love?

title: Discover Settles With Morgan Stanley for $775 Million
description: Discover Financial Services paid Morgan Stanley $775 million to settle claims related to sharing proceeds from an antitrust suit against the credit card networks Visa and MasterCard, according to a regulatory filing on Friday.

title: A Dance King, Secure in His Domain
description: NOT to take anything away from the other kings, as the dancers in the touring show Kings of the Dance are known, but the Brazilian Marcelo Gomes is the complete package of dancer, actor and partner. Ballet is an art, after all, but waiting to see what Mr. Gomes, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, will do next in a performance almost borders on sport.

title: Home Alone
description: Lori Gottlieb offers herself up as Exhibit A  thats A for Alone  in this unsparing exploration of the contemporary mating scene. Part cautionary memoir, part field study, her account of her own stalled search for a husband is honest and darkly comic.

title: Dogma No More: Anything Goes
description: IN its modest, underground way a concert that the young musicians of the Ensemble ACJW gave on a brisk night in December at Le Poisson Rouge, the Greenwich Village club for all kinds of contemporary music, was one of the most liberating programs I have heard in years.

title: A Historian Looks Back at the Climate Fight
description: Amid a prolonged exchange of e-mail messages Thursday with a heap of authors from past and future reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, along with some stray experts, the climate historian Spencer Weart chimed in with a history of the recent flare-up in the two-decades-and-counting climate wars.

title: Cold Mountains
description: Dont be misled by the dreamy pastoral image on the dust jacket of Amy Greenes first novel. Bloodroot takes place in Appalachia, and, yes, Greene lovingly describes its mountains and hollows, its waters filled with bluegills. Theres also much talk of healing and magic and backwoods folk wisdom. But this story is really about the fraught, sometimes dangerous, bonds between children and their mothers, and the appalling spillover of violence from one generation to the next.

title: Riot Prevents Courtney Love From Reaching Hole Concert
description: In other erratic-rock-star news, a reunion show for Hole, the band led by Courtney Love, was postponed in London on Thursday night, and for once it doesnt appear to be Ms. Loves fault. RollingStone.com reported that Hole was scheduled to perform at Proud Galleries in the North London neighborhood Camden but was unable to reach the performance space because of a riot occurring near where the band was staying.

title: Writing and Rocking
description: Fan, advocate, judge, dissector, dissenter  a critic can be any or all of these things. But a friend? No.

title: Obama Appears, Then Disappears, in Financial Aid Ad
description: The online ads on behalf of a Web site that calls itself classesandcareers.com beckon potential college students to go back to school and get your share of the stimulus money at stimulus friendly schools.

title: A Shadow Over Fashion Weeks Start
description: The death of Alexander McQueen, the British fashion designer, cast a pall over Bryant Park on Friday, as New York Fashion Week opened there for its last run before a planned move to Lincoln Center in the fall.

title: Freedoms Laboratory
description: To say that the scientific frame of mind has played an important part in the rise of the West is not exactly controversial. Science always gets its moment in the spotlight in Whig history, as historians (dismissively) call grand narratives of political and material progress. In The Science of Liberty, the veteran science writer Timothy Ferris makes a more extravagant claim, assigning not a mere supporting role but top billing to the celebrated experimenters and inventors of the past several centuries. As he sees it, the standard account of the history textbooks  with the Renaissance giving rise to the Scientific Revolution and thus preparing the way for the Enlightenment  fails to identify the primary causal relationship. Democratic governance and individual rights did not emerge from some amorphous brew of humanistic and scientific thinking, he argues, but were sparked by science itself  the crucial innovative ingredient that continues to foster political freedom today.

title: Why Orwell Endures
description: In Sutton Courtenay churchyard about 10 miles south of Oxford, near the imposing tomb of H. H. Asquith, the prime minister 100 years ago, a much simpler gravestone reads Eric Arthur Blair. It was to that grave a friend and I recently made a pilgrimage for a sad anniversary. Blair died of tuberculosis on Jan. 21, 1950, at the age of 46, just when he had found fame and fortune under the name by which the world knows him, George Orwell.

title: Spirit Airlines Shows Fuel Costs
description: Paul Sakuma/Associated Press Fuel costs directly impact airline ticket prices.

title: A Readers Ode to the iPad
description: As longtime Pogophiles know, Im fond of writing new lyrics (about the tech industry) to old melodies. But today, Ive got some competition. Heres a clever song parody by reader Peter Weisz

title: Photos of the Moment | Bryant Park
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alec Holst.

title: Free-Range Villains
description: With the possible exception of James Patterson, genre authors arent robots, so you have to marvel at the strategies they use to keep their series heroes on their toes. James W. Halls loner sleuth, who goes by the prickly name of Thorn, has long flourished in the backwaters of the Florida Keys, tying bonefish flies and composing poetry in his modest shack on a secluded lagoon. Now here he is in SILENCER (Minotaur, $24.99), held captive on Coquina Ranch, a private hunting preserve in the pinelands north of the Everglades where beer-drinking good ol boys with their cheeks full of chaw go to bag themselves a Watusi bull, a blackbuck antelope or some other helpless exotic beast.

title: On N.B.A.s Big Night, Stadium Is the Show
description: Basketball players, as a general rule, are tall  some of them freakishly so. They are accustomed to standing out in a crowd, commanding a room and absorbing curious stares. On Sunday, the N.B.A.s best players will be dwarfed by the room itself. And they might be the ones doing the gawking.

title: A Love Song Rapped in Japanese
description: Kendall Graham, 31, met Miki Mitsumoto, 24, in Times Square four years ago. They tied the knot at the Marriage Bureau in Brooklyn Borough Hall this week, in time for Valentine's Day.

title: Hating Congress, a National Occupation
description: Updated, Feb. 12, 6:20 p.m. | Lorenzo Morris of Howard University joins the discussion.

title: Weekend Links
description: The seven Americas of Facebook.

title: Bunny Love
description: Little Bunny on the Move, Peter McCartys first picture book, from 1999, was a tale of a single-minded bunny who lets nothing stall him on the way to his mysterious destination. The storys spare, insistent prose and the illustrations, evoking a surreal pastoral, build a delicious suspense. It offers a lovely metaphor for holding to ones inner vision in spite of naysayers and obstacles, and like all McCartys stories shows fidelity to the emotions of young children.

title: A Room With One Heck of a View
description: Astronauts on board the International Space Station, including T.J. Creamer, the astronaut I interviewed a couple of weeks ago, added an extension to their home Friday.

title: Morbidity and Hilarity
description: You could say that this years winner of the Michael L. Printz Award for young adult literature, announced last month by the American Library Association, begins with an off-putting premise. The narrator, Cameron, a self-proclaimed slacker (Im a drifter  right downstream and over the falls with the rest of the driftwood), learns that he has contracted a fatal condition: Creutzfeldt-Jakob, or mad cow, disease (as its known in animals). Who wants to read a 480-page novel about a 16-year-old who has four to six months to live and suffers from progressive muscle weakness, dementia and delusions?

title: Game Face
description: Charlie Popovich is a former linebacker for two National Football League teams who still loves to hit, even at age 54. He craves the pop, the sound of brutal, body-on-body, bone-jangling contact. But that alone does not make him a memorable character. Charlie, who is immensely likable, has Alzheimers disease, the central fact of Pop.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: THE HUMBLEBEE HUNTER  Inspired by the Life and Experiments of Charles Darwin and His Children.  By Deborah Hopkinson. Illustrated by Jen Corace.  Disney-Hyperion. $16.99. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: The Reading Life: Out of Israel, a Tantalizing Peek at a Graphic Novel
description: In most large bookstores these days, the graphic lit section is overflowing with big, floppy, well-pawed paperbacks  the abundance is a sign of how far the genre has quickly come. But as the excellent Web magazine Words Without Borders makes plain in its February 2010 issue, theres still a bounty of fine graphic work being done in other languages, work that most American readers have no idea about.

title: From Harlem to Albany
description: Milestones in the life and career of David A. Paterson, the new governor of New York.

title: Editors Choice
description: SHADOW TAG,  by Louise Erdrich (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.) Erdrichs new novel is a portrait of an iconic marriage on its way to dissolution, and it appears to be seeded with deliberate allusions to her own marriage with the writer Michael Dorris.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE NORTHERN CLEMENCY,  by Philip Hensher (Anchor, $16.95.) This big novel, a finalist for the 2008 Man Booker prize, follows two not quite upper-middle-class families, neighbors in the northern English city of Sheffield, from the 1970s through the 90s. Full of detail and Dickensian minor characters, the novel suggests that the British obsession with domestic correctness is underscored by a desire for violence. Although the book contains no surprises, our reviewer, Sophie Gee, said it is tremendously adroit and reminds us of what its like to sink luxuriously into the great novels of an earlier era.

title: The Moviegoer | Sex, Lies and Videotape
description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Shaw, a Cable Operator, to Buy Canwests Television Assets
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Shaw Communications, a regional cable television operator, agreed on Friday to purchase the television assets of Canwest Global Communications, a major Canadian media company that was in bankruptcy.

title: A Permanent Suspension
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Today is the 31st anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran. President Mahmoud Amembersonlyjacket celebrated by declaring that Iran is now a nuclear state. So thats good news. Mazel tov to them.

title: Security and Eager Crowds Greet Bollywood Film
description: MUMBAI, India  With thousands of police officers providing security, the latest blockbuster from Bollywoods biggest star opened Friday, despite threats and protests from a radical political party that had vowed to block the film in this capital of Indias movie industry.

title: With Masdar Institute, Abu Dhabi Seeks Reputation as Clean-Tech Research Hub
description: As the United Arab Emirates looks to diversify its oil- and gas-dominated economy, the royal family is hoping that its Masdar Institute of Science and Technology will lead the way  and it is aggressively recruiting students and researchers toward that end.

title: Too Far Out There
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on NBC: Joe Biden was interviewed on Larry King last night. And he said that some of Sarah Palins recent comments are just too far out there. He doesnt know where they came from. He was like, Who the hell is she, me?

title: Love in a Hard Place
description: Invulnerable and Free as Only Youth Can Be

title: Kenyan Police Disperse Gay Wedding
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyan police officers broke up a gay wedding on Friday and arrested several wedding guests, saying they had to intervene before an irate mob could stone the wedding party to death.

title: Did What He Needed to Do
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: The big blizzard hit the East Coast. Washington, D.C., probably hit hardest of all. Two storms, back-to-back. The bad news is Washington, D.C., is entirely shut down. The good news is Washington, D.C., is entirely shut down.

title: Valentine Ideas From T
description: Ts Moment blog gets all sweet for Valentines Day.

title: Wieseltier vs. Sullivan, the Sequel
description: Round 2. After receiving a lot of criticism for his 4,300-word take-down of Andrew Sullivan for his comments on Israel and Jews, Leon Wieseltier, literary editor of The New Republic, has written another piece, titled A reply to Andrew Sullivans reply. Mr. Sullivans M.O. is to make offensive remarks and then apologize for his remarks being taken the wrong way, Mr. Wieselter writes. If I should be more careful about the question of anti-Semitism, so should Sullivan. He complacently says that on this score I did my best. No, he did not. There is a lot of this prejudice in the world right now, and this is really no time to be sloppy.

title: Lonely Hearts
description: Even people who dont like poetry tend to make an exception on Valentines Day. But what about people who do like poetry, and dont like valentines? If your plans for this Sunday include being depressed and embittered and alone, may I recommend the anthology Its Not You, Its Me: The Poetry of Breakup? The editor, Jerry Williams, has had some experience with romantic disappointment, as he details in his slightly painful introduction: Bitter humor aside, he says after one girlfriend leaves him for a chemistry major, this new development opened the door to that dim, airless room of anguish just down the hall. Yikes.

title: Weather Disrupts Athletes Training
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Sloppy, foggy weather continued to disrupt Winter Olympic training schedules Friday, turning carefully groomed ski courses to mush in Whistler and on Cypress Mountain a day before competition was scheduled to begin.

title: Dell Moves Aggressively With Kace Deal
description: Dell is expanding aggressively into systems management for small to midsize businesses with its acquisition of Kace, a company that it has been working with over the last several years.

title: Aging: Hospital Type May Play Role in Decision on Feeding Tubes
description: When nursing home residents with advanced dementia are sent to the hospital, many are given feeding tubes, even though the practice is not believed to help them live longer. Now a new study finds that it is much more prevalent at some hospitals than others.

title: Chart: Joanna Newsoms Kingfisher
description: On Feb. 23, the experimental indie-rock singer and harpist Joanna Newsom will release her third album, Have One On Me, on the Drag City label. The artist Andrew Kuo charts her new song Kingfisher, nine minutes of weirdness.

title: Shaw to Buy Control of Canwest TV Business
description: Canwest Global Communications said Friday that Shaw Communications had agreed to acquire a 20 percent equity stake and 80 percent voting interest in its television business, Reuters reports.

title: Stuffed Envelopes and Other Fun Oscar Facts
description: During our conversation with the lovely briefcase-toters from PricewaterhouseCoopers, we learned some fascinating facts about the Oscars. Here they are, courtesy of our favorite accounting firm:

title: Rep. Price Derides Health Care Summit
description: In some of the harshest criticism yet of the effort by Democrats to overhaul the nations health care system, Representative Tom Price, Republican of Georgia and chairman of the conservative Republican Study Committee, on Friday dismissed President Obamas bipartisan health care session as simply an attempt by the president to use the White House as a political tool to intimidate his way into a government takeover of health care.

title: Nothing Says Love Like a Borough Hall Wedding
description: It was just another Saturday night on Queens Boulevard two years ago when Eddie Ellis and Gladys Corcino pulled up beside each other at a red light near 65th Street.

title: What Was the Airgas Chief Thinking?
description: Updated | Feb. 14, 6:06 p.m. and Feb. 12 6:18 p.m. and 3:50 p.m. This post is by Steven M. Davidoff and Peter J. Henning.

title: Recessions Silver Lining: U.S. Trade Deficit Is Down the Most on Record
description: AFTER years of being told by Asians and Europeans that it had to find a way to reduce its trade deficit, the United States did find a way in 2009. A global recession did the trick, producing the largest decline ever in the deficit.

title: Europe Approves H.P.s Takeover of 3Com
description: The technology giant Hewlett-Packard won approval from competition regulators in the European Union on Friday for its takeover of the 3Com Corporation, reinforcing its presence in the network equipment market, Reuters reports.

title: Hanson to Replace Vento With a Dos Caminos
description: Stephen Hanson will be closing Vento after dinner on Sunday, and at the end of April will reopen the space as Dos Caminos Meatpacking, the fourth of those Mexican restaurants in New York.

title: Ones to Know: Wang Bingyu
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: From Bachelor Pad to Family Dwelling
description: Joel Hinman has lived in the same NoHo apartment since 1979. He now lives there with his wife and year-old son.

title: Afghan Offensive Is New War Model
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For all the fighting that lies ahead over the next several days, no one doubts that the American and Afghan troops swarming into the Taliban redoubt of Marja will ultimately clear it of insurgents.

title: Olympics Often Plagued by Whims of Weather
description: Donna de Varona, who won two gold medals in swimming at the 1964 Olympics, is a writer, producer and an Emmy Award-winning broadcaster. She is currently a member of the International Olympic Committees Women and Sport Commission.

title: Head of Goldmans Asset Management Leaves
description: Marc A. Spilker, the head of Goldman Sachs Asset Management and a member of Goldmans management committee, has abruptly left the Wall Street firm, according to internal memorandums obtained by DealBook.

title: The Domestication of a Dive
description: THE 1970s and 80s are on thrilling and sometimes terrifying display in the fifth-floor apartment in NoHo where Joel Hinman has lived for the past 35 years.

title: Ill Take Frugal Traveler for $2,000
description: Yesterday evening, as I was playing with my daughter, Sasha, and waiting for her mother to come home, I heard an odd sound coming from the TV: my name. Or not my name exactly  it was Alex Trebek announcing a category on Jeopardy!: The New York Times Frugal Traveler. Wow!

title: Conditions Are Iffy, but Downhill Skiers Still Expect the Best to Win
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  From the moment Vancouver was chosen to host the 2010 Winter Olympics  with the Whistler resort 75 miles to the north named the site of the Alpine events  the ski racing community has been debating how the regions unpredictable weather might affect the 10-event Alpine competition.

title: The Benefits of Bulgur
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman explores new ways to cook bulgur, an ancient grain from the Middle East thats especially suitable for todays busy cook.

title: Travel Deals: 2011 Holland America Cruises
description: Holland America announced its lineup of Europe voyages for 2011, with rates starting at about $140 a day, and early booking bonuses ifreservations are made by June 1.

title: Three Mates Laughing (Well, Two Are)
description: ASK the British comedian Ricky Gervais the secret of his success, and he will either tell you its trying very hard or not trying at all. It was some combination of effort and dumb luck that connected him to his longtime collaborator Stephen Merchant and that brought the two men to the BBC, where they created the hit comedy The Office, which led to their follow-up series, Extras, on the BBC and HBO. All of which was merely a prelude to their meeting Karl Pilkington.

description: LOS ANGELES

description: Mr. Beck performs "Where Were You," taken from the DVD "Jeff Beck, Performing This Week: Live at Ronnie Scott's" (Eagle Rock Entertainment).

description: If youre having trouble figuring out how to raise financially responsible children, youll be thrilled with this news: Congress is stepping in to help you set some limits.

description: What: A cocktail party celebrating the opening of NY 11-18-02-10, Dunhills deluxe pop-up shop in the meatpacking district.

title: Luge Athletes Death Casts Pall Over Games
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Vancouver Olympics were set to open with the most daunting and dangerous collection of events the Winter Games had ever seen, but before the competitions even began, a luge athlete died in a high-speed crash that overshadowed Friday nights opening ceremony and intensified concerns over the safety of the Games.

title: Theyd Like to Keep It That Way
description: AN outpost 30 miles from the city where children walk to school on sidewalks lined with trees; where lovingly refurbished Victorians have old-fashioned front porches; where shopkeepers greet longtime customers by name: The 1.8-square-mile village of Pleasantville pretty much lives up to the qualities implied by its name.

title: Book Review Podcast: Cathleen Schine and Andrew Young
description: This week: the novelist Cathleen Schine tells us about The Three Weissmanns of Westport; Andrew Young, a former aide to John Edwards, discusses his new memoir, The Politician; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Ethiopian Hydro Plant Suffers Setback
description: A tunnel collapse has closed the largest hydropower plant operating in Ethiopia, only 10days after its inauguration.

title: David L. Picket
description: Mr. Picket, 47, is the chief executive of Gotham Developers and the president of its parent, the Gotham Organization, which is run by his father, Joel.

title: Lobbying in 2009: A Final Tally
description: We have been watching for several months now as the dollars pile up for Congressional health care lobbyists.

title: New Good Faith Takes Hold
description: FEW mortgage borrowers have had the fortitude for a thorough reading of all their loan paperwork, often feeling intimidated or overwhelmed by the legalese and numerical complexities in the disclosures. But some mortgage brokers say that such passivity is declining.

title: Teacher Q | How Do You Handle Cheating and Plagiarism?
description: In my first year teaching, I discovered that a student had copied part of an essay from something he found online. I went over the passages with the student and discussed with him why it had violated school policy on academic integrity, and what he could do to make up the assignment. Reluctantly, I called his parents to tell them what had happened. What I hadnt expected was the fathers verbal shrug: Well, the president doesnt write his own speeches. Nonplussed, all I could think to say was, We both know thats a different situation.

title: Amid Postponements, U.S. Mens Downhill Team Is Selected
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The womens training run in advance of Sundays super combined event was canceled Friday to let course workers better prepare the downhill course for Saturdays mens downhill and for the final scheduled training run for the women, which is also Saturday.

title: Detroit Symphony Music Director to Work Four Weeks for Free
description: Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, has agreed to donate four weeks of concerts next season to help out with its financial difficulties, the orchestra said Friday.

title: Got 500,000 Clams? The City Is Your Oyster
description: NEW YORK is one big sprawling city, full of people who are proud to call themselves New Yorkers. But sometimes it seems as if that were where the sameness ended. Just try to find a taxi on Staten Island or a gas station in Manhattan and you will quickly learn that there are big differences among the boroughs.

title: Photos of the Moment | Native Son
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Eric Ray Davidson.

title: Plan for Baltic Sea Pipeline Clears Last Major Hurdle
description: MOSCOW  A Russian-German plan to build a pipeline on the floor of the Baltic Sea and detour natural gas around the disruptive politics of Eastern Europe cleared a last major hurdle on Friday.

description: CHICAGO  Amid all the recalls, finger-pointing and apologies, Toyota received MotorWeeks Best of the Year award for its 2010 Prius. The announcement at the Chicago Auto Show raised a few eyebrows.

title: Should College Students Have Credit Cards?
description: Starting later this month, people under the age of 21 will no longer to be able to apply for credit cards unless they have a source of money that they can document (say, a part-time job) or a co-signer on the account (presumably a parent).

title: Plugged In and Happy
description: FOR an entire year, Joe Foxton and his then-partner looked in vain for an East Village condominium. It needed to be a dog-friendly two-bedroom with outdoor space for well under $1 million.

description: Francesco Vezzolis black-tie-soiree-as-performance-art, Ballets Russes Italian Style (The Shortest Musical You Will Never See Again), featuring Lady Gaga and Prada-clad dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet, was undoubtedly one of the highlights on last years contemporary-art calendar. If you missed the spectacle of spectacles, created for MOCAs 30th anniversary gala, the Swedish filmmaker Jonas Akerlund captures the extraordinary night in this exclusive new video, Ballets Russes, Italian Style  Coming Soon.

description: TERRI LALIBERTE and her husband, Mark, have been trying to save their Thomaston home since they found foreclosure papers stuck in their garage door one day after Christmas 2008.

description: The death of the Georgian luger Nodar Kumaritashvili in a training-run crash on Friday was the fifth fatality connected with the Winter Olympics over the years, but no athlete has died during official competition at the Games, according to the Olympic historian David Wallechinsky.
