description: EARLIER this month, the W Hoboken Hotel and condominium tower offered itself as a host location for a speed-dating event that drew almost 400 would-be sweethearts  a number to be recorded by Guinness World Records, according to its organizers.

title: McQueens Outer Child
description: COMMENTATORS were not to be blamed for defaulting to clich when characterizing Alexander McQueen, who died on Thursday, apparently by suicide. And they were not altogether mistaken in referring to him as fashions designated bad boy, a reliable pain in the neck.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) Fox is piloting a comedy about the Internal Revenue Service. I (and the many accountants in my family) cant wait.

title: Arrest May Be Linked to Jewelry Store Killing
description: The police arrested a man who they said had 40 pieces of jewelry that they believed were stolen two weeks ago during a robbery and killing at a jewelry store on Manhattans Upper East Side, the authorities said.

title: Chic in Review | Saint Laurent, the Musical!
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Some Rowdy Realism, but Dont Forget Nascar
description: Whos real? Whos not? The youngish country singer Eric Church shares some ideas on the matter on Lotta Boot Left to Fill, which decries country musics death by a thousand polishes: boy bands, one-hit wonders that dont stick, a focus on television over music.

title: David Gelbaum, Clean Energy Investor, Remains Bullish Despite the Downturn
description: When the news emerged in December that David Gelbaum, the wealthy former hedge fund manager, conservationist and philanthropist, had suspended his annual $20 million bequest to the American Civil Liberties Union, as well as high-dollar contributions to other organizations, a shudder ran through the renewable energy world.

title: Fake Psychic and Friend, Trying the Stage
description: QUICK, what is the name of the Monk sidekick? Technically, yes, its Sharona (or Natalie, depending on the season), but the answer could well be Psych, the detective series that has reliably followed Monk on the USA Network from 2006 until Tony Shalhoub hung up his sanitized crime-scene gloves last year. Psych has recently returned from its Season 4 hiatus as a headliner, the Wednesday night offering of original programming.

title: Spending Less in a Recession, and Talking About It, Too
description: THREE years ago this month, I wrote a column about the secrecy, envy and anxiety that surrounded talk of money. While most of us were perfectly happy to speculate back then about how a friend, neighbor or colleague could afford that new addition to the house, the trip to Europe and luxury car, most of our private financial lives were shrouded in mystery.

title: Ah, Love (Statler Brothers Included)
description: TRYING to piece together a Valentines Day playlist without confronting loves dark side is a fools task. There are so many ways to write a love song, and most of them involve suspicion. Ambiguity and uncertainty pervade the songs listed below, which are drawn from some impressive recent and forthcoming releases. But even the ones that end in failure still radiate hope.

title: From the Department of Oscar Odds and Ends
description: Its Friday afternoon and all anybody wants to do is watch cool Winter Olympics videos. Here is a grab-bag of Oscar-world odds-n-ends that should only distract you briefly:

title: Barbies Next Career? Computer Engineer
description: Barbie has come a long way since 1992, when the blond bombshell of a doll was programmed to say, Math class is tough.

title: On Being a Woman, From Cradle to Grave
description: The Victorian arts of mourning are alive in Kiki Smiths latest work, as they have been in much of what she has produced since she emerged in the 1980s. Ms. Smith has always operated in close proximity to death; she lost a sister and many friends to AIDS, and has worked as an emergency medical technician.

title: Endless Motion, Sharply Defined: From Gawky to Sleek and Back Again
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Wayne McGregors Entity begins and ends with a video of a greyhound seeming to run in place. The reference is significant: as entities, these slim animals are at once refined and fidgety, highly flexible and, of course, able to devour space at great speed. For Mr. McGregor, those are key physical ingredients that his dancers, also entities, must possess to have a solid grasp of his movement. In this world of glossy distortion, there isnt a place for hazy shapes.

title: New Rule on Cargo Is Shaking Art World
description: Collectors and dealers of fragile, phenomenally expensive art have never wanted for reasons to stay awake at night. A piece could plunge from a wall. Somebody could stumble into it or step on it or add a new color to it with a splash of red wine. Contemporary art, sometimes made to resemble trash, has occasionally been mistaken for it and thrown away.

title: Slatkin Aids Detroit
description: Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, has agreed to donate four weeks of concerts next season to help with its financial difficulties, the orchestra said on Friday. Mr. Slatkin will perform for 16 weeks in 2010-11 and will reduce his salary by an undisclosed amount. The orchestra also said Mr. Slatkin would extend his contract by two more seasons, through 2012-13. The orchestra said it ran a deficit of about $3.8 million last season.

title: Sunday Preview
description: A private cruise down the Nile with 78 of your closest friends? Its not just for Wall Street C.E.O.s and hedge fund managers, as Jennifer Conlin, a frequent contributor to the Travel section, learned when she turned an idea hatched over dinner into a floating party last month. The trick? It involves early planning, someone good with money and a little help from Facebook.

title: Flamenco, Past and (Very) Present
description: February in this city belongs increasingly to  no, not fashion  but to flamenco and all its attendant regalia: the ruffles, the clickety-clack of castanets, the oohs, the ahhs and the very tentative attempts by New Yorkers at exclaiming, Ol! A 10-day New York extravaganza kicked off last night with a gala presentation at City Center, and more flamenco performances are planned throughout the month in Vancouver, Miami and London, which should give English-speaking audiences around the world a fresh taste of this very old dance style.

title: Report: Mort Zuckerman Mulling Senate Bid
description: Michael Barbaro and Tim Arango write:

title: Guns N Roses Plays Fashion Week Show
description: There is apparently nothing that New York Fashion Week cannot do  even persuade Guns N Roses to perform a live show. The rock band led by the superlatively erratic frontman Axl Rose, right, played a surprise set at the John Varvatos store in the East Village. (The location, appropriately enough, is the former site of the music club CBGB.) The Web site BrooklynVegan.com reported that Mr. Rose and his band appeared early Friday morning after a Thursday night performance by the New York rock group Alberta Cross and proceeded to play 17 songs over 90 minutes. The set list provided by BrooklynVegan.com heavily favored tracks from the bands hit 1987 album Appetite For Destruction and largely avoided songs from its 2008 follow-up, Chinese Democracy. No roster was given for the band, which has changed its lineup more than a few times under Mr. Roses direction.

title: Coalition Troops Storm a Taliban Haven
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  Thousands of American, Afghan and British troops attacked the watery Taliban fortress of Marja early Saturday, moving by land and through the air to destroy the insurgencys largest haven and begin a campaign to reassert the dominance of the Afghan government across a large arc of southern Afghanistan.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 12
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Banana Shpeel Date Has Slipped Again
description: Has the Allman Brothers Band put some sort of Southern-fried hex on the Canadian clowns of Cirque du Soleil? On Friday, Cirque du Soleil said that it would again delay the start of its coming show Banana Shpeel at the Beacon Theater  the same show that pushed the Allman band out of its longtime March residency at the Beacon. In a news release, representatives for Banana Shpeel said it would now begin preview performances on March 17; back in December the show moved its first performances to Feb. 25 from an original date of Feb. 4. The release said the latest delay had occurred because the rehearsal period at the theater has been extended to integrate new performance elements. An official opening date at the Beacon has not yet been announced. A Chicago production of Banana Shpeel was presented last year, and disapproving critics more or less tied it to the whipping post.

title: Survivor Endures
description: The premiere of Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains, the 20th edition of the reality series, averaged 14.2 million viewers on Thursday, helping to lift CBS to No. 1 in the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. The two-hour debut earned more viewers than last Februarys premiere of Survivor: Tocantins (13.6 million) but finished second on the night to The Mentalist on CBS, the most-watched show with 15.7 million viewers at 10 p.m. ABC ranked second with The Deep End at 8 (5.7 million), Greys Anatomy at 9 (12.7 million) and Private Practice at 10 (9.1 million). Fox was third with a repeat of Bones (8.1 million), followed by Past Life at 9 (5.3 million), while NBC finished in fourth place with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 followed by reruns of The Office in the 10 p.m. hour (3.1 million).

title: Secret of Kells to Open in U.S.
description: The Secret of Kells, above, the film that grabbed a surprise Academy Award nomination for best animated feature this month, wont be a secret to American audiences much longer. On Thursday the distributor Gkids said it would show the movie at the IFC Center in New York on March 5, two days before it vies with Coraline, The Princess and the Frog, Up and Fantastic Mr. Fox for Oscar honors. Directed by Tomm Moore, The Secret of Kells tells the story of a boy living in a Celtic abbey whose adventures with fairies, she-wolves and barbarians lead to the creation of the Book of Kells, the 1,200-year-old illuminated manuscript. The film was already planned to be shown in Boston on March 19, but after its Oscar nomination gave it a little extra shine, it will now receive a wider national release, including in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago, starting on April 2.

title: Paranoia in Polanski
description: Dennis Lim narrates a look at the Roman Polanski films that deal with paranoia, including his latest, "The Ghost Writer."

title: A Riot Keeps Love From Hole Concert
description: In other erratic-rock-star news, a reunion show for Hole, the band led by Courtney Love, below, was postponed in London on Thursday night. RollingStone.com reported that Hole had been scheduled to perform at Proud Galleries in Camden, a North London neighborhood, but was unable to reach the performance space because of a riot occurring near where the band was staying. On her idiosyncratic Twitter feed, Ms. Love wrote: a MASSIVE riot tonight putside my HOUSE the cops wouldsnt let me leave. The Times of London reported that the riot, in the Mayfair neighborhood, had begun when the police were called to break up a squat party held at an abandoned building and some of the estimated 2,000 partygoers began throwing bricks and bottles at the officers. Barring future riots, Hole is scheduled to play its next concert in London on Feb. 17.

title: Swiss Arent Ready to Extradite Polanski
description: The Swiss ministry of Justice announced on Friday that the authorities would not extradite the film director Roman Polanski, below, to face criminal charges in California until courts determine whether he must face sentencing in person on a charge of having sex with a 13-year-old girl in 1977. That decision rises from the latest legal wrangling in Los Angeles, where a State Superior Court judge insisted in a January hearing that Mr. Polanski must return to the United States before his case can be concluded. A California appeals court had suggested a few weeks earlier that Mr. Polanski could be sentenced in absentia.  Rudolf Wyss, a spokesman for the Swiss ministry, said the authorities were waiting for a clear decision on the question of an in absentia trial. Bart P. Dalton, one of Mr. Polanskis American lawyers, said only that any new appeal would have to be filed by March 24. In a statement, the Los Angeles County district attorneys office said it was reviewing news reports from Switzerland, and added: At present, this rests with the Swiss courts. We will comment after a ruling by the courts there, not before. Mr. Polanski, 76, remains under house arrest in his Swiss chalet. On Friday Mr. Polanskis new political thriller movie, The Ghost Writer is to be shown at the 60th Berlin International Film Festival.

title: Luge Accident Claims Life
description: Nodar Kumaritashvili was killed in a crash in training on the Olympic track at the Whistler Sliding Center on Friday.

title: Bad Boys
description: Images from exhibits in New York that exemplify different stages of bad-boyness.

title: White House Invites Congressional Leaders to Summit
description: With some Republicans attacking President Obamas health summit as nothing more than political theater, the White House extended formal invitations to lawmakers on Friday afternoon and promised to post a text of the Democrats bill online before the Feb. 25 gathering.

title: Two Crime Tales, but Similarities End Right There
description: THE LADYKILLERS

title: A New Look for Paterno
description: Dont look now, but Joe Paterno doesnt need his glasses anymore.

title: An Enigmatic Land of Great Expectations
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  It is unlikely that anything resembling the impressive Levine Museum of the New South would exist anywhere else. A museum of the New North or the New East would be merely peculiar, but here the term New South has a venerable heritage, recalling unrealized hopes and great expectations. There is also much at stake in trying to understand just what the term really means.

title: A Pocket Detective for Daters
description: Is romance dead? If not, this should kill it.

title: Ones to Know: Tim Burke
description: A look at some notable athletes who will take the stage at the Vancouver Games.

title: Muscling In on the Front Row
description: IF designers are not terribly, terribly worried that Snooki and Pauly D will show up and spoil their party  dont be alarmed, dears, its only Fashion Week  it may be because they have excellent gatekeepers like Billy Daley of Michael Kors.

title: A Month After the Quake, Haiti Takes Stock
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  And on the 32nd day, Haiti rested.

title: Doctors Haunted by Haitians They Couldnt Help
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The foreign doctors who performed the first amputations after the earthquake used hacksaws. They relied on vodka for sterilization, substituted local numbing for general anesthesia, jury-rigged tourniquets from rubber gloves. Working around the clock in improvised operating rooms, they sacrificed limbs and lost patients to injuries that are no longer supposed to be disabling or deadly.

title: Levine Museum of the New South
description: The museum attempts to explore a concept that means different things to different people.

title: Violations at Building Where 5 Died
description: The city is charging the owners of the building in Brooklyn where five people died in a fire last month with illegally subdividing apartments to create extra dwellings, officials said.

title: Google Co-Founder Hopeful About Uncensored Search in China
description: Sergey Brin, a Google co-founder,speaking publicly for the first time about the hacking attacks on Google in late 2009, said Friday that the company still hoped to find a way to continue operating its Google.cn search service in China, which it has blamed for the attacks.

title: Creamy Polenta With Parmesan and Sausage
description: Mark Bittman shows how much easier it is to make polenta than most people expect.

title: A Hero Begins His Quest, and Then the Trouble Starts
description: The message of My Name Is Khan, an effective exercise in Bollywood high emotionalism, is less political than movie-ish: there are two kinds of people in the world, good and bad, a distinction more important than any other differences, like those between Hindus and Muslims.

title: Taking the Fear Out of Polenta
description: Polenta is such a natural base for so many savory foods  more flavorful than either pasta or mashed potatoes, but somehow just as forgiving  that its hard to pick a favorite topping. Having said that, I know what mine is: sausage. The fatty succulence of a banger combined with the lean graininess of the cornmeal is somehow perfect.

title: Getting Faster With Age: Sam Shepards New Velocity
description: When Sam Shepard directed the original 1985 Off Broadway production of his play A Lie of the Mind, about emotionally scarred young men and the damaged women in their lives, the production ran six hours at first. His latest play, Ages of the Moon, about two emotionally scarred men in their 60s (the damaged women remain offstage) lasts about 80 minutes.

title: Creamy, Mushroomy Pizza, at Home
description: Nowadays in New York, you can hardly order anything in an upmarket pizzeria without cream or bchamel sauce on it. I exaggerate, of course, but cream does seem to be the new marinara sauce. Maybe it started with Gabriel Kreuthers amazing version of Alsatian tarte flambe in the Bar Room at The Modern.

title: A Look at the Locked Up, and the Locked In
description: What gets your sympathy juices flowing? An abandoned puppy? Sure. An American Idol contestant whos receiving a Simon Cowell tongue-lashing? Maybe. But for a real test, see if you can work up any supportive tears at all for the spouses in Prison Wives, a reality series that has its debut on Sunday  aw, Valentines Day; aint that sweet  on Investigation Discovery.

title: Waking, a Second Time, to Birdsong
description: Bill T. Jones, 57, has not performed in three years, but dance remains his main muse. He has created more than 140 works for the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, which has performed in more than 30 countries. His choreography for the 2006 musical Spring Awakening won a Tony Award and led to his immersion in the acclaimed Fela!, which he co-conceived, co-wrote, directed and choreographed. He lives in Valley Cottage, in Rockland County, with Bjorn Amelan, 54, a sculptor who is the creative director of the company. ROBIN FINN

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 12
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include New York real estate families, a snowy day in New York, and an explosion on Avenue of the Americas.

title: In the Loop, in Its Own Choice Words
description: If youve ever wanted to see a bunch of profanities, obscenities and other choice words strung together in wildly inventive (and literary, of course) ways, youll be happy to know that IFC Films has just posted the Oscar-nominated screenplay for Britains In the Loop. Its a challenge to print any excerpts on the blog, but you can head here to read the whole raucous thing. As A.O. Scott wrote in his review last July, If Anglo-Saxon epithets were armaments, Britannia would rule the waves.

title: The San Francisco Bay Area Celebrates the Year of the Tiger
description: This years Chinese New Year marks the year of the tiger. While the lunar New Year is this Sunday, the San Franciscos Chinese New Year parade will be held on Feb. 27th, two Saturdays after the New Year, to coincide with the Lantern Festival, which occurs the 15th day of the new year. The parade, which began in the 1860s in Chinatown, is one of the few remaining night parades in the country, according to the organizers website.

title: Battle Over the Bailout
description: THE critical lawsuit challenging that mystery of finance known as the Bailout started, oddly enough, with a casual newsroom chat.

title: El Bulli to Close Permanently
description: Ferran Adri, the Catalan chef who for two decades has been the leading catalyst and inspiration for avant-garde cuisine, has decided to permanently close his restaurant El Bulli, considered by many to be the worlds greatest, and to replace it with an academy for advanced culinary study, Mr. Adri said in an interview on Friday.

title: Haitian Child Moved to Britain for Surgery
description: Inigo Gilmore of Britains Channel 4 News reported on Friday that a British doctor has finally succeeded in arranging a medical evacuation for a three-month-old Haitian girl who needs treatment for head injuries that can not be offered in Haiti.

title: Studio Visit | Joseph Altuzarra
description: The up-and-coming designer Joseph Altuzarra will be showing his much-anticipated fall collection Saturday night at Milk Studios. T was lucky enough to be let into Altuzarras intimate studio, where we got a glimpse of his all-star team, including the makeup artist Tom Pecheux, the hairstylist Laurent Philippon and the stylist Melaine Huynh (from French Vogue). As for the clothes, they are under tight wraps  literally! But stay tuned for more!

title: Honoring a Departed Player With a Pair Event and Wine
description: David J. Morrow, a former editor in chief of TheStreet.com and a New York area player, died of pancreatic cancer on Feb. 2 . A two-session memorial game was held four days later at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan. The proceeds were donated to the Dave Morrow Prize for Audacious and Talented Financial Journalists, which will be sponsored by the Society of American Business Editors and Writers (S.A.B.E.W.) in cooperation with Morrows family.

title: Small Business Incentives Face a Hard Road in Congress
description: President Obamas incentives for small business to create jobs appear to be foundering at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue. Those proposals  tax credits for hiring and investment and initiatives to spur lending to small firms  all face strong resistance, and not all of it comes from the Senate. Each chamber has embraced separate elements of the administrations agenda, and, for the moment, none of those elements overlap.

title: Save the Pigs Head for Later
description: MAKING an authentic pozole  the fragrant Mexican hominy stew  has been on my list of things to do for years, but it can be very labor intensive. One recipe by Diana Kennedy, the author of Mexican cookbooks, calls for trimming hominy and boiling a pigs head. Just reading about it causes my enthusiasm to wane.

title: Turkey and Hominy Chili With Smoky Chipotle
description: 4 tablespoons olive oil

title: Photos of the Moment | Jason Wu
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: Their Goal: To Regain Oscars Old Luster
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Only a few months ago, Bill Mechanic and Adam Shankman, the producers of this years Oscar ceremony, didnt even know each other. Now they show up wearing the same shoes.

title: Delahunt on Kennedy (and Delahunt?)
description: Representative William Delahunt, Democrat of Massachusetts, was speaking by phone Friday about the decision of his colleague Patrick Kennedy not to seek re-election in Rhode Island. In doing so, Mr. Delahunt, who has yet to say whether he will seek re-election himself this year, might have signaled a hint about his own future.

title: MetroPCS and Leap Wireless Hire Advisers
description: Facing ever-tougher pressure from bigger rivals, MetroPCS Communications and Leap Wireless International have hired advisers to evaluate a possible merger of the two prepaid cellphone service providers, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: The Continuing Assault
description: Thousands of American and Afghan troops encircled and descended on the town of Marja for a major military offensive.  The initial attack was from air, with Hellfire missiles and Apache helicopters. Cordons were set up to capture fleeing Taliban fighters, and Marines stormed a central bazaar.

title: The Time-Honored Exaltation of Chocolate
description: KENT

title: Experiments That Work
description: A new Bedell white sparkling wine and a Channing Daughters red dessert wine illustrate innovative directions at these cutting-edge wineries. Both whet the appetite.

title: A Start With Chocolate; Now Room for Dinner
description: Huntington

title: An Introduction to Portugal
description: My markups are very low, Manuel Ferreira says about the prices in Chaves a Portugus, his modest corner market. I dont expect to make a lot of money. I want to introduce people to the food and culture of Portugal.

title: A Wide-Ranging Menu to Start the Year 4708
description: FOR many Westchester residents, there is a lot more than love and romance to celebrate this weekend. Feb. 14 marks the start of the Lunar New Year 4708, the year of the charismatic, take-charge Tiger. This longest and most festive of Chinese holidays, which ends with the Lantern Festival on Feb. 28, gives celebrants 15 days to party. And Jade Garden in Hartsdale, a new addition to Westchesters few authentic Cantonese restaurants, has opened its doors in time to provide more feasting space.

title: Truth Lies Somewhere in Between
description: WHEN is a documentary not a documentary? That question hovered in the freezing air at the recent Sundance Film Festival, where documentaries are often justly celebrated, and which this year made room for a few movies that had uneasily found a place in the gray zone between fact and fiction. After watching Exit Through the Gift Shop, an entertaining feature about an unlikely street artist that was said to have been made by Banksy, the mysterious British street artist and world-class prankster, audiences were left wondering: Was this a documentary? A goof? A movie as performance art? Or something different?

title: At a Cuban Hideaway, Big Portions and Flavors
description: PUSHING aside the thick curtain at the entrance to A Little Bit of Cuba, you leave behind the winter darkness for a hub of ebullient festivity, where lights are soft, and shutters on the walls frame views of Cuba. The curtain is only a windbreak separating the vestibule from the elements, but it seems like a secret door to a delightful hideaway.

title: For This Day and 364 Others
description: Last-minute gifts for Valentines Day are easy to come by at David Bradley Chocolatier, which makes its confections at a factory in Windsor and sells them at an adjoining store.

title: North Carolina as It Was, Split and Seething
description: WHETHER or not North Carolinians are more inclined than other Americans to follow Thomas Wolfes injunction to look homeward, some past the age of 50 have personal reasons to cast a retrospective glance on the state of their youth. It was a time when a century of Jim Crow laws and segregation were being challenged by the advocates of civil rights in a struggle that was often more bitter and bloody than popular history likes to admit.

title: Dreaming of a White Olympics
description: Much has been said about the lack of snow in some of the venues at Vancouvers Winter Games and efforts to cover the barren slopes.

title: Quirky Marriage of Art and Text
description: Right by the train station in Croton Falls is an old factory that once serviced forklifts and trucks. Today it houses artists studios and an exhibition space  not so much a gallery as a place where artists and independent curators can put up temporary exhibits. It is called Lift Trucks Project.

title: Mad Hatters
description: I remember the veteran pitcher Mike Jackson telling me that by the time you finish with this game, you will have worn a lot of hats. I heard him, but it didnt really sink in because I hadnt yet been in that annual free agency vortex that can force you to play for a different team every year. At the time, I had been traded once and was wearing only my second major league hat, which I was confident would be the last of my career.

title: Works That Testify to the Nurturing of Black Artists
description: At its most creative and inspired, philanthropy can alter lives, or even a society. That is the message of A Force for Change: African American Art and the Julius Rosenwald Fund, a thoughtful show at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: Harry Reids Bipartisan Oblivion
description: Remember the Golden Age of Bipartisanship? The one that lasted from approximately 11 a.m. on Thursday  when Senators Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, released their Hiring Incentives to Restore Employment Act  to 4:00 that afternoon, when Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid crumpled it into a small ball, lit it on fire and tossed it in a garbage can?

title: Bengals Are Apparently Still Trying to Save Souls
description: Cornerback Pacman Jones  remember him?  recently worked out for the Cincinnati Bengals. Another Jones with a checkered past, the former Jaguar first-round receiver Matt Jones, could also be going to the Bengals. (Matt Jones faced felony drug charges for cocaine possession in 2008; he avoided trial by agreeing to enter drug court.) Both players were out of football in 09.

title: In Rhode Island, a Political Earthquake
description: Representative Patrick Kennedys decision not to seek re-election sent shock waves through the Rhode Island political establishment Friday, and set off a scramble to fill his seat.

title: The Women of the Ring Are Back for a Rematch
description: Watching artists as they burrow into and out of material over an extended period is one of the pleasures of being a critic  or any dedicated audience member, for that matter.

title: A War Over an Agency That Built a Honey Pot
description: The foot of Manhattan Island has grown by 92 acres over the past four decades, the shoreline expanded with dirt from the excavation for the World Trade Center and tons of sand dredged from the harbor.

title: The Unthinkable as a Tolerance Lesson
description: GLEN COVE

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE UNDERGROUND LOBSTER POUND began a few months ago, when Ben Sargent, 32, a Bostonian who is writing a book on chowder, started inviting friends over to his basement apartment on Lorimer Street to taste and discuss his cooking. It got so I was laying out so much money that I started asking for donations, Mr. Sargent recalled. The suggested donation for a lobster roll was $14. Word spread, and Mr. Sargents operation became the darling of local foodie bloggers. Soon, he was handling several seatings a night on the foldout couch in his apartment, which resembles a New England fishing shack. Everything was great until the Fire Department showed up on Monday, the day after a profile appeared in The Daily News. Mr. Sargent was told he could not use a propane stove. Then his landlord told him to stop having all those dinner guests.

title: Teamwork Means Secrecy When It Comes to Vonn
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  When Lindsey Vonn was injured while training in Austria last week, several of her teammates were on the mountain at the time or became aware of her crash a short time later. While Vonn tried to recover in Austria, they continued to train and then went home to the United States for a few days before heading to the Vancouver Olympics. Other members of the womens team were already in the United States and training. They, too, knew about Vonns injury. But for a week, the secret of Vonns injury went unrevealed, until she announced it in a Today show interview on Wednesday.

title: Dancing in the Street
description: Radio 1, Satan 0

title: Violations Are Found at Building in Brooklyn Where 5 Died in Fire
description: New York City is charging the owners of a building in Brooklyn where five people died in a fire last month with illegally subdividing apartments there to create extra dwellings, officials said.

title: A Ride With the Czech Bobsled Team
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia Beyond walking, buses are the primary means of transportation for both athletes and the media at the Winter Olympic Games.

title: Lincoln Loses a Tower, but He Still Has the Tunnel
description: Think Lincoln and New York, and the juxtaposition would most likely conjure up the tunnel or the performing arts center. Until this year, it might have also evoked the majestic Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street.

title: Two Florists Fight Back as Sweet Smell of Success Turns Sour
description: They came to New York from places a half-world apart: Jorge Calle is from Ecuador and Seung Yoon Park, known as Justin, is from Korea. But they followed similar paths in this city of immigrants, marrying, working, saving money and eventually buying flower shops 15 blocks apart in Queens.

title: Paying Tribute to Mormon Churchs Ohio Roots
description: KIRTLAND, Ohio  Tim Powell remembers when the Utah Mormons first came to town with their plans in the early 1990s.

title: Toyota Says More Models Might Get Fix for Acceleration
description: Toyota said on Friday that it might expand the number of models that will receive a braking override system designed to prevent sudden acceleration, a problem that led the company to recall millions of cars.

title: Saving a Place to Bump Into People
description: On Wednesday afternoon, as the snowstorm rested between squalls, all seemed as it should at Bread Stuy, a coffeehouse on Lewis Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Professor Said to Be Charged After 3 Are Killed in Alabama
description: Three faculty members at the University of Alabama in Huntsville were shot to death, and three other people were seriously wounded at a biology faculty meeting on Friday afternoon, university officials said.

title: Business Comes First for Knicks Lee
description: DALLAS  David Lee was supposed to be in Houston on Saturday for a wedding. In fact, Lee, the Knicks star forward, was supposed to be in the wedding party. He had bought a tuxedo and had gone as far as negotiating ways to circumvent the snow that hit Texas.

title: U.S. to Back Loans for Reactors
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is to announce on Tuesday a loan guarantee to allow construction of two nuclear reactors in Georgia, according to administration officials.

title: No-Win Situation: Too Much Snow or Too Little
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It is one of the most counterintuitive notions at the Winter Olympics: When it comes to skiing, no natural snow is a good thing. That is why more than 1,200 people have been working in round-the-clock shifts the last few days, largely removing snow from the Alpine ski courses.

title: University and Pickens Sue Over Fund-Raising Plan
description: Oklahoma State University and T. Boone Pickens, an alumnus and one of its largest donors, have sued a life insurance company over a fund-raising plan that took out policies on alumni with the aim of raising hundreds of millions of dollars for the university.

title: Experts Say Schools Need to Screen for Cheating
description: ATLANTA  This week, Georgia officials said they had found evidence that cheating might have occurred on standardized tests at one in five public elementary and middle schools around the state. What was extraordinary, however, was not so much the extent of the problem, but the decision of the state to screen for cheating at all.

title: Lilly Pressured as Its First New Drug in 4 Years Falters
description: Eli Lilly had billion-dollar hopes when the blood thinner Effient was approved by the Food and Drug Administration last summer.

title: El Bulli to Close Permanently
description: Ferran Adri, the Catalan chef who for two decades has been the leading catalyst and inspiration for avant-garde cuisine, has decided to permanently close his restaurant El Bulli, considered by many to be the worlds greatest, and to replace it with an academy for advanced culinary study, Mr. Adri said in an interview on Friday. Read the full story at Diners Journal.

title: U.S. Envoys Head Out on a Mission to Rally Irans Neighbors
description: WASHINGTON  With tensions over Irans nuclear ambitions hitting new levels, the United States is mounting a diplomatic full-court press in the Middle East, sending four top diplomats, including Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, to confer with Arab and Israeli leaders.

title: Obama Didnt Endorse This Billboard, Either
description: The online advertisements for the Web site classesandcareers.com beckon potential college students to Go back to school and get your share of the stimulus money.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Obama Making Plans to Use Executive Power
description: WASHINGTON  With much of his legislative agenda stalled in Congress, President Obama and his team are preparing an array of actions using his executive power to advance energy, environmental, fiscal and other domestic policy priorities.

title: For a French Imam, Islams True Enemy Is Radicalism
description: DRANCY, France

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Ralph Rucci Adds Some Strut
description: Could Ralph Rucci be a rock star designer?

title: Tiger Farms in China Feed Thirst for Parts
description: GUILIN, China  The crowd-pleasing Year of the Tiger, which begins Sunday, could be a lousy year for the estimated 3,200 tigers that still roam the worlds diminishing forests.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: A Writer Seared by Anne Frank
description: Rinne Groff likes complexity, and her newest play, having its world premiere at Yale Repertory Theater, offers it up in spades.

title: A Performance Artist and Her Greatest Hits
description: Performance art is undergoing a revival in New York. Marina Abramovic, a veteran performance artist, has a retrospective opening at the Museum of Modern Art in March, and Performa, an every-other-year performance art festival held in November, drew record crowds. Not to be left out, the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase has an exhibition that surveys the work of Tania Bruguera, a Chicago performance and installation artist who was born in Cuba in 1968.

title: In California, Governor Vows to Fight for Nominee
description: LOS ANGELES  Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers attempt to appoint a fellow Republican as lieutenant governor, a post left vacant when the Democratic incumbent was elected to Congress, has sent Sacramento into political meltdown.

title: Simple Boxes to Beam You Up
description: HARTFORD  Between 1975 and 2007, the Matrix series at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art presented the work of 157 contemporary artists, including Willem de Kooning, Andy Warhol and Cindy Sherman. Sol LeWitt had three Matrix exhibitions. The Matrix exhibitions of Gerhard Richter, Nancy Spero and Keith Haring, among others, were their first solo shows in the United States.

title: Amid Protest, Torch Takes a Detour
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Organizers quickly changed the Olympic torch relays zigzagging route through Vancouver on Friday morning to avoid a small protest.

title: Injured Vonn Is Given Reprieve as Rain Leads to Postponements
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Lindsey Vonn happily welcomed another canceled training run Friday and was buoyed by the postponement of Sundays womens super combined, which should give her injured right shin more time to heal.

title: Journal Entries Describe Time Spent in Captivity
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Prosecutors in the case of Jaycee Dugard, who was abducted as a girl and held against her will for 18 years, have released three snippets of journals she kept during her captivity. The writings show anxiety, fear and despair over her condition.

title: NBC Poised to Outperform 06
description: Four years ago, American Idol and several other shows exposed how susceptible NBCs taped broadcasts of the Turin Olympics were to strong counterprogramming by rival networks.

title: Working Hard News Into Script Full of Fluff
description: An Olympic opening ceremony is usually a televised exercise in fluff and world geography, a three- or four-hour pageant without news. But Fridays death of Nodar Kumaritashvili, a luger from the Republic of Georgia, in a training accident at the Whistler Sliding Center on Friday, changed the dynamics.

title: Airlines Cancel Flights Before Storms Arrive, and E-Mail the Passengers
description: Airlines have two choices when a snowstorm is predicted: they can wait and see what happens or cancel flights based on the forecast.

title: Artistry at Root of Latest Controversy
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Figure skating has yet to begin at the Winter Olympics, and already strange things are happening. O.K., not as strange as Lindsey Vonn wrapping her ailing shin with Austrian cheese curd, but strange nonetheless.

title: Arizona: Quayles Son Seeks Office
description: Ben Quayle, the 33-year-old son of former Vice President Dan Quayle, plans to run for Congress representing a Phoenix district. The announcement came from the former vice president, who told Fox News that his son would file papers Friday to run for the seat being vacated by Representative John Shadegg, an eight-term Republican who is retiring. In a telephone interview, Ben Quayle, a lawyer and businessman, said the economy and stopping the out-of-control spending would be the top issues. At least four other Republicans, most of them former state legislators, have indicated they plan to run for what is considered a generally safe Republican seat.

title: A Glimpse Inside a Troubled Youth Prison
description: THE guard made Edwin a deal.

title: California: Convention Bid Set Aside
description: An effort to call a constitutional convention has been put in abeyance as its organizing group has run out of money. John Grubb, a spokesman for Repair California, said Friday that his group did not have enough money to make payroll, and would need some $3 million to get two measures on the ballot. Mr. Grubb said a decision would be made by March 1. Angels do exist, Mr. Grubb said. We just need them to come to our church.

title: Goldman Picks New Leader in Asset Management Unit
description: Marc A. Spilker, the co-head of the Goldman Sachs Asset Management division and a member of Goldmans management committee, abruptly retired from the Wall Street company on Friday.

title: A Young Outsider, on the Doorstep
description: LaQuan Smith has no studio, no eager assistants  not even a super-strength sewing machine. He stitches up his designs on a modest Kenmore in his bedroom, a tidy diminutive space in his grandparents house in the St. Albans section of Queens. I do everything here but eat, Mr. Smith said as he sprawled on his grandmothers rose-patterned quilt, the rooms single nod to tradition.

title: Arkansas: Migrants Win $2.75 Million
description: An Arkansas tree-planting company has agreed to pay $2.75 million to settle a lawsuit in which foreign guest workers accused it of often paying less than the minimum wage and not paying for all hours worked. The money will go to 2,200 workers from Mexico and Central America in one of the largest settlements ever reached under the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act. The workers, who planted pine seedlings throughout the Southeast, entered the country under a guest worker visa program.

title: Nascar Wants to Reintroduce a Bit More Action
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  In the face of sagging television ratings, drops in attendance and a sense that Nascar is losing some of its core fans, series officials have decided to embrace good-ol-boy racing once again.

title: Swine Flu Deaths Rise Slightly
description: About 11,700 Americans died from swine flu from its emergence in April until mid-January, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimated on Friday. That was up slightly from its estimate of 11,000 a month earlier, indicating how much the pandemic has slowed. About 257,000 people have been hospitalized, the agency estimated, and between 41 million and 84 million have caught the virus. With about 70 million people vaccinated, that means well over a third of the country should be immune  either from having had the disease or a shot. Most of the hospitalizations and deaths have been among those aged 18 to 64. In a typical year, 36,000 people die of seasonal flu, the C.D.C. estimates. There has been very little seasonal flu so far this year.

title: St. Patrick Out of Tourney After Coachs Rule Violation
description: Kyrie Irving, a star senior guard at St. Patrick High School in Elizabeth, N.J., received a phone call Friday afternoon from his father informing him that the schools boys basketball team would not be eligible to defend its state title.

title: New Pasture Rules Issued for Organic Dairy Producers
description: The Department of Agriculture issued new rules on Friday meant to settle a dispute in the organic agriculture industry over how much time cows at organic dairies must spend grazing on pasture.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 5 about the student lending industrys lobbying against changes to the loan system, using information from the Center for Responsive Politics, a private campaign-finance research group, misstated the amount of money the student lender Sallie Mae spent on federal lobbying in recent years. Sallie Mae reported having spent a total of $3.48 million in federal lobbying in 2009, an increase from $3.2 million in 2008. It did not spend $8 million in 2009.

title: Luge Crash at the Olympics
description:
Nodar Kumaritashvili, a luge athlete, was killed during a training
run Friday on the Olympic track in Whistler, British Columbia. The track is the fastest in the world.

title: In the Cold of Morning, Descending Into Conflict
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  The helicopter was filled with men and dark in its cabin when a voice cut over the whir of the rotors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the dateline of the Ghajar Journal article on Feb. 3, about the uncertain future of the residents of Ghajar, a far-flung village that straddles the border convergence of Israel, Lebanon and Syria, misstated the location of the village. It is Ghajar, Golan Heights  not Ghajar, Israel. (Israels claim to Ghajar has not been accepted internationally because Ghajar is part of the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the 1967 war and annexed in 1981.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about efforts to raise money to protect the hilltop land around the Hollywood sign above Los Angeles from development misstated, in some editions, the amount that the Trust for Public Land agreed to pay a group of Chicago investors for a 138-acre parcel. It is close to $12 million, not $12.

title: Johnson and Kahne Win Qualifiers
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Nascar interrupted the Danica Patrick reality show under way here long enough to run two qualifying races on Thursday that set the grid for the season-opening Daytona 500.

title: Pierce Is Out as Giants Turn Page
description: The Giants released middle linebacker Antonio Pierce on Thursday, jettisoning a player who helped them win a Super Bowl three seasons ago but who came to symbolize the defenses downfall last season.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about ways to find specific Twitter members referred incompletely in some copies to the options for searching members on the companys site. Besides a list of unsorted staff favorites, the site also recently introduced a list of users categorized by topic.

title: Questions of Propriety and Safety
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Winter Olympics have had regular flurries of adversity and controversy through the decades  from weather challenges to doping and corruption scandals  but genuine tragedy has been exceedingly rare.

title: Rangers Acquire an Enforcer, Then Win
description: With almost everyone besides Marian Gaborik in an offensive funk, the Rangers would seem to need more players who can score goals. Instead, before their victory at Pittsburgh on Friday, they traded for an enforcer to replace Donald Brashear, who was waived by the team Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz entry in the listings pages on Friday misstated the location of some concerts that are part of the Charles Mingus Festival this weekend. On Sunday, a high school jazz band competition and performances by the Manhattan School of Musics Mingus Jazz Combo and the professional-grade Mingus Dynasty Band will be held at the Manhattan School of Music, at 122nd Street and Broadway, Morningside Heights  not at St. Bartholomews Church, at Park Avenue and 51st Street. (As the listing correctly noted, the Mingus Orchestra concert on Saturday at 7 p.m. is at St. Bartholomews.)

title: Looking for a Date? A Site Suggests You Check the Data
description: Looking for love on an online dating service?

title: One Man Creates Ultimate Duel
description: Circle April 9 on the calendar; make your travel plans to Hot Springs, Ark., and keep good thoughts in your heart that Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta remain healthy. You dont want to miss their showdown that Friday in the Apple Blossom Handicap at one of the most charming, best-run racetracks in the nation.

title: 30 Across: Make Plans to Tie the Knot
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Take a bow. This puzzle is about you. You and others actually.

title: 'Operation Moshtarak' Begins
description: Thousands of coalition forces began their assault on Marja, Afghanistan, a Taliban stronghold in Helmand Province, and a centerpiece of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystals counterinsurgency strategy.

title: Still a Quarter to Call
description: Even in the age of the cellphone, a pay phone across from a Queens courthouse remains a lifeline for many people.

title: Showcase: The Best in the World
description: Before we say anything about this years World Press Photo Contest winners, please: go the Full Screen button above, immediately to the right of the slide counter, and look at these pictures as they are meant to be seen.

title: One Grand Deal Too Many Costs Lobbyist His Job
description: WASHINGTON  After about two dozen years in Congress, Representative Billy Tauzin of Louisiana was after bigger game  the giant, 200-pound whitetail deer that run through the area of south Texas that hunters call the Golden Triangle.

title: Listening In on a Pay Phone in Queens
description: Benjamin Patir called his son because he was lonely and, perhaps more important, because he had a quarter. Robert J. Covelli called his son, too, to find out if, at some point during the more than 24 hours he spent in custody, he had become, for the first time, a grandfather. Frank Federico, fresh from a courthouse jail cell, called his mother, who spared him any lectures and asked him if he needed a ride home.

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times for Children entry on Friday about screenings of A Town Called Panic, at the Museum of the Moving Image, referred incorrectly to admission for the film. It costs $10, which includes museum admission; the film is not free. The listing also omitted the recommended viewing age. It is for audiences 8 and older.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music entry in the listings pages on Feb. 5 about the Metropolitan Operas production of Donizettis Fille du Rgiment and schedule information with a music review of the performance on Monday misstated the phone number of the opera companys box office. It is (212) 362-6000.

title: Critics Say Google Invades Privacy With New Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Google introduced Buzz  its answer to Facebook and Twitter  it hoped to get the service off to a fast start. New users of Buzz, which was added to Gmail on Tuesday, found themselves with a ready-made network of friends automatically selected by the company based on the people that each user communicated with most frequently through Googles e-mail and chat services.

title: Doctors Haunted by Haitians They Couldnt Help
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The foreign doctors who performed the first amputations after the earthquake used hacksaws. They relied on vodka for sterilization, substituted local numbing for general anesthesia, jury-rigged tourniquets from rubber gloves. Working around the clock in improvised operating rooms, they sacrificed limbs and lost patients to injuries that are no longer supposed to be disabling or deadly.

title: Haiti May Delay Release of U.S. Detainees
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The release from jail of the 10 Americans accused of taking Haitian children out of the country without government approval may be delayed because of legal problems surrounding an adviser to the group, the judge in the case said Friday.

title: He Breaks for Band Recitals
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Muted Celebration Opens the Olympics
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  For about an hour, a parade of athletes poured into B.C. Place for the opening ceremony of the Vancouver Olympics on Friday, but only two nations received a full standing ovation.

title: Dealing With the Nightly Grind
description: A FEW weeks ago, Tom Lelievre, 46, who owns a home renovation business in Westford, Mass., noticed that hed chipped a back tooth and so he visited his dentist, Dr. Thomas Connelly.

title: St. Vincents in the Village Lays Off 300
description: St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan began laying off more than 300 workers on Friday and asked other employees for temporary pay cuts of 10 percent to 25 percent in an effort to stave off closing.

title: Families See a Utopia Turn Into an Ugly Legal Fight
description: The Hello Living condo project in Brooklyn was marketed as an urban utopia, a collection of low-rise apartments designed for young families without large inheritances or bonuses.

title: The Marrying Kind
description: Would you like bottled water or tap? asked the waiter as Lori Gottlieb and her friends settled into a booth at the Upper East Side restaurant Rouge Tomate on a recent evening.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 40 this weekend about synthetic biology misstates the cause of stomach ulcers for which a possible vaccine was being produced a team of Slovenian students. The vaccine would treat ulcers caused by bacteria, not by a virus.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Explaining the Irrational: Here Goes ...
description: LOVE it or dread it, here we are again: Valentines Day. Why does such a holiday exist? One story is that back in the third century, a saint named Valentine, who faced execution for officiating illegal marriages, fell in love with his jailers daughter. Somehow he wrote and delivered a card to her that he signed, From your Valentine. Then he was killed.

title: Commonwealth
description: In this poem, Tato Laviera explores the political and emotional limbo created by Puerto Ricos nebulous status as neither state nor sovereign:

title: Poet Spans Two Worlds, but Has a Home in Neither
description: His poems, in countless anthologies and five of his own collections, are considered part of the Latino literary canon. His plays and lectures have earned him honors etched in flowery superlatives on plaques. But Tato Laviera would rather possess a more prosaic document, written in legalese.

title: Man Charged After Police Find Gems From Robbery
description: The police have arrested a man they said had about 40 jewels that were stolen two weeks ago during a robbery and fatal shooting at a store on the Upper East Side, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Bluster on Twitter, and Off It, Too, From Russias NATO Envoy
description: MOSCOW  Normally the formality of European diplomacy would be shattered if, say, an ambassador suggested that his country might kick its opponents posterior.

title: Letters
description: Dating on Campus

title: Wal-Mart Agrees to Sell Live Nation Tickets
description: Wal-Mart Stores reached an agreement with Live Nation Entertainment to sell tickets to concerts and other events at about 500 stores. The service will be introduced in the next few months in cities including Chicago and Los Angeles, according to Irving Azoff, executive chairman of Live Nation. The new accord will let Wal-Mart shoppers buy tickets for concerts, sports and other events at cash registers in the retailers entertainment department, Mr. Azoff said. Live Nation also sells tickets at Blockbuster stores.

title: Transsexualism No Longer Viewed as Mental Illness in France
description: France has removed transsexualism from an official list of mental illnesses, according to an order issued by the French Ministry of Health reported Friday by French news media. The order issued Wednesday removed gender identity disorders from an article of the social security code related to long-term psychiatric diseases. According to media reports, France is the first country in the world to do so.

title: Afghanistan: Different Accounts Offered About Civilian Deaths
description: Several civilians were killed in Paktia Province on Friday when a joint Afghan-NATO force went to investigate a report of militant activity, but NATO and the Afghan police gave varying accounts of what happened. A NATO statement said the joint force went to a compound in the village of Khatabeh, in the Gardez district, where insurgents opened fire on them from a residential compound. Several insurgents were killed and a large number of men, women and children fled and were detained by the NATO force. Inside the compound, soldiers found the bodies of three women who had been tied up, gagged and killed, the NATO statement said. The Paktia Province police chief, Aziz Ahmad Wardak, confirmed the episode but said the dead in the house were two men and three women, who he said were killed by Taliban militants. He said the killings took place while the residents were celebrating the birth of a baby.

title: Israel: Work Begins to Reroute Barrier
description: More than two years after a Supreme Court ruling, Israel has started work to reroute its security barrier near Bilin, a Palestinian village in the West Bank, Israeli officials and activists in the village said Friday. The village became a symbol of the Palestinian struggle against the barrier because of its legal battle and because of the weekly protests held by activists near the fence line. Israel says the barrier is essential to preventing Palestinian suicide bombers from reaching its cities, but Palestinians oppose it because much of it runs through West Bank territory. The Supreme Court ruled that the barrier should be moved away from the village and closer to an Israeli settlement to take in less of Bilins agricultural land.

title: A Spot to Raise Cheers and Glasses
description: IT may not be Vancouver, but if youre looking for a congenial New York spot to share the excitement of the Olympics, Warren 77, a sleek sports bar in TriBeCa, is a good bet. For the next two weeks, the bars six TV screens will be steadfastly tuned to the 2010 Winter Games.

title: Japan Calls Hummer H3 Fuel-Efficient
description: TOKYO  Hummer and fuel-efficient are rarely mentioned in the same breath.

title: Europes Recovery Comes to Near Halt
description: Europes economic recovery almost ground to a halt in the last quarter of 2009, according to data released Friday, capping a week of worries about the ability of some countries to deal with their outsize budget deficits.

title: At Officers Trial, No Show of Blue, but Plenty of Dark Suits
description: It has not been terribly difficult to find a seat in the Brooklyn courtroom where three police officers are on trial on charges of abusing Michael Mineo or helping to hush it up.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Washingtons Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: Somber Scene at Venue Designed to Celebrate Victory
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  When an athlete gets hurt during competition, and it appears serious, you can hear the air go out of a crowded stadium or packed arena. Remember, even if watching on TV, how eerily quiet Ralph Wilson Stadium in Buffalo was on September 2007 after the Bills Kevin Everett was injured, paralyzing him from the shoulders down, in a game against the Broncos?

title: Bloggingheads:  Helping New Mothers
description: Liza Mundy, left, of The Washington Post and Randi Hutter Epstein, author of Get Me Out, discuss home visits for new mothers by nurses.

title: Live Updates From Opening Ceremony
description: The opening ceremony for the 2010 Winter Olympics is scheduled to begin tonight at 9 p.m. ET at the downtown Vancouver arena B.C. Place, which is otherwise the home of a Canadian Football League team. It will be the first indoor opening ceremony in Olympic history. Several New York Times reporters will provide live-blogging throughout the ceremony: Juliet Macur, Katie Thomas and Ian Austen. Use your refresh button for the most current updates.

title: Lost in Transit
description: Here is chilling news for the eight million commuters who ride New York Citys railroads, buses and subways each day and the businesses that depend on them. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the system, is facing a budget shortfall of about $800 million.

title: Dying of Red Tape
description: The case of 10 Americans jailed for trying to take a busload of children out of Haiti has done more than spark anger and fears about international kidnappings. Doctors and aid workers in Haiti say it is making it much harder to arrange medical evacuations to the United States for badly injured Haitian children, endangering their lives.

title: Mr. Malikis Dangerous Ambition
description: To resolve a dispute with the Tikrit provincial council this week, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq did what any good autocrat would do: He sent in the army. The problem is, Mr. Maliki isnt supposed to be an autocrat. And the United States didnt train Iraqs Army so it could be used for political coercion.

title: A Blue-Ribbon Look at Criminal Justice
description: The nations criminal justice system is in need of an overhaul. This is particularly true of its incarceration policies. Too many people are being put behind bars who do not need to be there, at great cost to the states, and not enough attention is being paid to helping released prisoners re-enter society.

title: Watching China Run
description: It was primarily a symbolic gesture. Way back in 1979, in the midst of an energy crisis, Jimmy Carter had solar panels installed on the roof of the White House. They were used to heat water for some White House staffers.

title: Crucible of Change
description: President Obama wanted to change Washington. It changed ... for the worse. And its now holding his agenda hostage. The question is: How much is he willing to change himself in order to save it?

title: Haiti Lessons: A Search and Rescue Corps ...
description: A S the one-month anniversary of Haitis earthquake passes, one inspiring memory of the rescue effort stands out: after a Los Angeles search and rescue team pulled another survivor from the rubble, bystanders in Port-au-Prince chanted, U.S.A.! U.S.A.! President Obama recounted the scene in his State of the Union address, and now policymakers should make sure that such successes can be repeated, more frequently, in future disasters by expanding our urban search and rescue capacity.

... And One for Doctors, Too

title: Three Steps to Demystifying Online Dating
description: OkCupid, a free dating site based in New York, has been analyzing the habits and patterns of its members to figure out what does and doesnt work, as I report in an article on Saturday.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about dating on campuses where women outnumber men misattributed a quotation. It was Janitra Venkatesan, a student at the University of North Carolina  not Mitali Dayal, another student there  who said: My roommates parents met here. She has this nice little picture of them in their Carolina sweatshirts. Must be nice.

title: Frederick C. Weyand, Vietnam Commander, Dies at 93
description: Frederick C. Weyand, who served as the commander of American forces in Vietnam in the final year of the war, a duty he carried out despite having become convinced as early as 1967 that the war was a hopeless venture, died on Wednesday at his home in Honolulu. He was 93.

title: Fred Morrison, Creator of a Popular Flying Plate, Dies at 90
description: Walter Fredrick Morrison, who at 17 sent the lid of a popcorn tin skimming through the air of a California backyard and as an adult remade the lid in plastic, in the process inventing the simple, elegant flying disc known today as the Frisbee, died Tuesday at his home in Monroe, Utah. He was 90.

description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The crash that resulted in the death of the luge athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili was caused by his errors on the course and not a deficiency in the Whistler Sliding Centre course, the Olympic organizing committee and the sports international governing body said in a joint statement issued late Friday.

title: My Home, a Mortal Peril? What the Childproofers See
description: First she balances; then comes a huge grin. After that its one foot, a wobble, another foot, some momentum, and then shes off to the races. With all the pleasures of seeing my 13-month-old daughter learn to walk came one disappointing realization: it might be time to think about childproofing.

title: New York Fashion: Wooing Penn and More
description: Last evening I went to Grand Central, boarded a train and went home. The past 36 hours had been depressing because of Alexander McQueens death, and absurdly disconnected because of the shows and the chattering. If there is an answer to Mr. McQueens death  and no doubt there will be some thoughtful attempts at an explanation in the coming weeks it will have to begin with his work. Looking at photographs of some of his great shows  the dance marathon show, the glass box and Girl in the Tree shows and of course last seasons spectacular Web presentation  I think the keys are all there. Its one thing to have the vision and technical ability to realize those kinds of expressions; it is a more difficult burden to also constantly live with the emotions and ideas that those expressions embrace. And Mr. McQueen didnt just have three or four exceptional shows in his career; he had a steady run of them, and the last few seasons really saw him reaching further.

title: Mens Downhill Race Is Postponed
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The mens downhill skiing competition, the marquee Alpine race of the Winter Games, has been postponed to Monday from Saturday because successive days of rain and warm weather have created slushy conditions on the course at Whistler Creekside. Combined with the previous postponement of Sundays womens super combined, the opening weekend of the Vancouver Olympics will be without its featured events.

title: Valentines Day  Down the Pub, at the Stadium
description: What to do you when Valentines Day falls on a game day?

title: Mens Downhill Pushed to Monday
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The mens downhill competition, one of the marquee events of the Winter Games, has been postponed from Saturday to Monday because successive days of warm weather and rain have created slushy conditions on the course at Whistler Creekside.

title: A Tasteful Way to Start the Olympic Games
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Even the death of the 21-year-old Georgian luge athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili did not do much to deflate the opening ceremony for the Vancouver Olympics a few hours later. There was a moment of silence for Kumaritashvili, and the audience at B.C. Place stood and applauded when the grief-stricken Georgian delegation marched in, but mostly Vancouverites got on with the show. They cheered, they waved, they walked around town in red hockey jerseys. It was like New Years Eve, but a tasteful, well-behaved New Years Eve.

title: China Looks Strong in Pairs Again
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: The Saturday Word: Recess
description: With the District of Columbia still resembling a polar ice cap with infrastructure, Congress is out for another full week.

title: Allied Troops Seize Taliban Posts; Fighting Is Sporadic
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American, Afghan and British troops seized crucial positions across the Taliban stronghold of Marja on Saturday, encountering intense but sporadic fighting as they began the treacherous ordeal of house-to-house searches.

title: Tragedy Hits at Heart of Olympics
description: Hours before the opening ceremony in Vancouver, the worst kind of Olympic accident occurred, casting a sorrowful shadow on the start of the Games. A crash on the luge track, which has been described as the fastest and most dangerous in the world, claimed the life of Nodar Kumaritashvili of the Republic of Georgia. Ranked 44th in the world, the 21-year-old Kumaritashvili lost control of his sled, went airborne and hit an unpadded vertical support that holds a canopy and lights over the course. He was pronounced dead at the hospital.

title: Changes Made to Luge Competition
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  While insisting that the track at the Whistler Sliding Center was safe, Olympic and luge officials announced at a news conference here Saturday morning that the mens competition would start lower on the track, at the current womens start, to limit speeds. They also said that the wall around Curve 16 had been raised.

title: Model-morphosis | Richard Chai Love
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Alana Zimmer of Supreme Model Management before (above, bottom) and after makeup by Gucci Westman and hair by Kevin Ryan. (Drag the orange bar down to reveal the full transformation.)

title: A Previous Death at the Hand of Alabama Suspect
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  The neurobiologist accused of killing three colleagues at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, on Friday fatally shot her brother in 1986 in suburban Boston, and the police there are now questioning whether their department mishandled that case when it let her go without filing charges.

description: Alexis Beth Offen and Aaron Matthew Beim are to be married Sunday evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Rabbi Adam Feldman is to officiate.

title: Anna Grossman, Jess Diaz
description: Anna Jane Grossman and Jess Diaz were married Wednesday at the Marriage Bureau in Manhattan. Blanca Martinez of the Office of the City Clerk officiated.

title: Gillian Scouler, Adrien Weindling
description: Gillian Margaret Scouler, a daughter of Cynthia Scouler of Fairfield, Conn., and Daniel Scouler of Kamuela, Hawaii, was married Saturday to David Adrien Weindling, the son of France-Hlne Weindling and Ralph E. Weindling of New York. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Fast and Risky, Sledding Track Drew Red Flags
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The crash that killed a luge athlete at the Winter Olympics on Friday followed warning signs and a drumbeat of concern conveyed by athletes and officials since the opening of the Whistler Sliding Centre in 2008.

title: Kimberly Solow, Adam Pomeranz
description: Kimberly Ann Solow, a daughter of Barbara and Stanley Solow of Plainview, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Adam Jason Pomeranz, the son of Ilene Zaretzky of Southfield, Mich., and Jerry Pomeranz of Brentwood, Calif. Cantor Morris Wolk is to officiate at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: For Saving Saints, Tagliabue Deserves a Place in the Hall
description: Over the Super Bowl weekend, the sentimental story was how the Saints had finally fulfilled their romantic return to New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina. The ignored story was that Paul Tagliabues name was not even in the discussion when the Pro Football Hall of Fame selectors met.

title: In Detroit, Is There Life After the Big 3?
description: DETROIT

title: Letters to the Editor: At Binghamton, Continuing to Pay the Price for Athletic Woes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Let Your Heart or Coach Guide You
description: ITS Valentines Day, and the pressure is on for men everywhere to step up their game and not just the single ones. Those who are married or in long-term relationships are advised to revisit and refresh many of the skills they once used on the dating scene.

title: A Test for the Meaning of Victory in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Midway through the rancorous debate inside the Obama administration last fall over how to redefine Americas goals for the war in Afghanistan, Secretary of Defense Robert Gates told his colleagues that they did not need to kill off the Taliban in every city and town in the country.

title: Afghan Attack Gives Marines a Taste of War
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  The helicopters landed before dawn Saturday in a poppy field beside a row of mud-walled compounds. The Marines ran into the darkness and crouched through the rotor-whipped dust as their aircraft lifted away.

title: These Battle Lines Are Drawn in Yellow
description: JASON COWIE, the owner of Kingpinz Skateboard and Snowboard Shop in Houston, has done a pretty good job of getting his business noticed on the Web. Just type skateboards in Houston on a search engine, and his store will be among the first listed.

title: A Lineup of Intriguing Story Lines to Watch as Spring Training Nears
description: Nine things to watch as spring training begins this week.

title: Jeters Next Contract Is About More Than Money
description: It is, all at once, the biggest issue and the biggest nonissue that will hover over the Yankees this season: Derek Jeter is in the final year of his contract.

title: Hospital-Clean Hands, Without All the Scrubbing
description: HOSPITAL workers often have to wash their hands dozens of times a day  and may need a minute or more to do the process right, by scrubbing with soap and water. But new devices could reduce the task to just four seconds, cleaning even hard-to-reach areas under fingernails.

title: In Black Caucus, a Fund-Raising Powerhouse
description: WASHINGTON  When the Congressional Black Caucus wanted to pay off the mortgage on its foundations stately 1930s redbrick headquarters on Embassy Row, it turned to a familiar roster of friends: corporate backers like Wal-Mart, AT&T, General Motors, Coca-Cola and Altria, the nations largest tobacco company.

title: Whats Sustainable About This Budget?
description: PRESIDENT OBAMAS 2011 budget, released this month, bears the title A New Era of Responsibility.

title: Sketchy Past
description: Animation | Artists line-drawn story of the world is short but padded:

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Now Its Really About the Olympics
description: Seven games on Friday night, which coincided with the opening ceremony at the Vancouver Olympics, featuring Bobby Orr helping to carry the Olympic flag and Wayne Gretzky helping to light a malfunctioning Olympic cauldron.

title: Falk Says N.B.A. and Players Headed for Trouble
description: DALLAS  This is the part where David Falk can smirk, say I told you so and upbraid everyone who ignored his warnings. But Falk is not in a gloating mood.

title: A Balance Between the Factory and the Local Farm
description: INDUSTRIAL food production is not very fashionable right now.

title: Joey Porter Looking for Place to Land
description: The Miami Dolphins appeased disgruntled linebacker Joey Porter by releasing him Friday. However, it was determined that the move would cost the Dolphins $4.8 million against the salary cap, sending them $600,000 over the limit. So, barring an unlikely trade, Porter will remain on the roster until the cap disappears March 5. (Think of it as a couple breaking up, only to realize that its easier to live together another few weeks until the lease on their apartment expires.)

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Valentines Day
description: Its an executive showdown on Sunday morning, as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his predecessor, Dick Cheney take to the airwaves.

title: Soda: A Sin We Sip Instead of Smoke?
description: Is soda the new tobacco?

title: One Compliment, but Two Complaints
description: IN this episode, the Haggler trains his immense and blazing Spotlight of Justice on Samsung, the electronics giant. But before we deploy our discomfiting glare, we pause to note that Samsung is a member of a very small group: corporations that readers have written the Haggler to praise.

title: Sobriety Checkpoints Catch Unlicensed Drivers
description: Bernardinos wife began to sob as soon as she saw the signs warning sobriety checkpoint ahead.

title: Making Yourself Indispensable
description: Q. Your company went through layoffs and you survived, but you want to do more than just hold on. How can you make yourself more valuable to your company and improve your chances of a future promotion?

title: Church Adviser May Face Warrant
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Two days after a group of 10 Americans were taken into custody in Haiti last month, a man who has emerged as a suspect in a sex trafficking ring and who has an array of other legal charges against him called up the Idaho church where 5 of them attend, portraying himself as an attorney who could help free the group at no cost, interviews show.

title: Reforming the Student Loan Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: The Encouragement Factor
description: I WAS 28 when my family realized that my 88-year-old grandmother couldnt live alone anymore. She had gotten progressively weaker and could hardly get out of a chair.
