title: Unlicensed Drivers Are Caught in Net for Drunken Ones
description: In Sundays Bay Area Report, Ryan Gabrielson, a fellow with the Investigative Reporting Program at the University of California, Berkeley, writes about how sobriety checkpoints have increasingly become profitable operations that are far more likely to seize cars from unlicensed  and often illegal immigrant  motorists, than to catch drunken drivers.

title: R.I. Democrats Bid for Kennedys Seat
description: BOSTON  Two prominent Rhode Island Democratic politicians announced today that they are running for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Patrick J. Kennedy.

title: A Rookie Stars Mom Is With Him All the Way
description: DALLAS

title: Somebody Elses Rumor
description: NINE days ago, John Koblin, a reporter for The New York Observer, posted this tweet: anyone hearing about NYT bombshell on Paterson? Heard big, damanging [sic] story comin. been working for weeks, but still not published yet.

title: Motors Have Muscled Out the Grinders
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Brian MacInnes is a longtime sailor with the BMW Oracle team that is challenging for the Americas Cup for the third time, having sailed on its two previous boats, in 2003 and 2007.

title: Drew Brees, a Man in Demand
description: In the past week, Super Bowl XLIV M.V.P. Drew Brees has been the most wanted interview in America. The demand has just been tremendous, Breess agent, Chris Taylor, said Saturday. My phone has been ringing off the hook, really since the interception, referring to Tracy Porters interception of Peyton Manning.

title: Washington Shivers, Moscow Laughs
description: MOSCOW  Even in Russia, the recent blizzards that have hit Washington have been noticed. Though not always sympathetically. Were Congress and other powerful institutions really closed, not to mention the schools? Did panicked residents actually strip stores of food, making the bare shelves resemble something from the Soviet era?

title: Small Ideas Wont Fix It
description: When Republican Congressional leaders come to the White Houses health care summit meeting on Feb. 25, dont expect them to bring any big ideas with them. Instead, they will press President Obama to scrap his ambitious health care reforms and focus on modest proposals.

title: East German Sports Machine Shadows Vancouver Olympics
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, Germany is still coming to terms with its divided past in sports as well as in society and politics.

title: Toyotas Wrecked Image Needs the Right Bodywork
description: A Japanese leader in the auto industry is accused of negligence, causing car accidents and dragging its feet with investigators. A giant recall is ordered, top executives are hauled in front of Congress, and losses snowball. Consumers flee in droves, trial lawyers lick their chops, and analysts say the companys brand is permanently tarnished.

title: Why Do Sled Dogs Run?
description: At 10 degrees, the Minnesota air is just cold enough for the dogs with heavier coats, like the left wheel-dog, who dips his snout in the snow more often than the dogs ahead of him. I am seated in the basket of the sled, as stiff as a quartered moose. Behind me, riding the runner, is the musher, Kelly Murphy. We slow now and then to let the teams behind us stay close, and when we do, the dogs  seven of them, right and left of the gangline hooked to their harnesses  look impatiently at us, haunches quivering, ready to pull and pull again.

title: Icicles, Inside and Out
description: WASHINGTON

title: Johnson Focuses on the Road, and Soon a Baby on Board
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  After an unprecedented fourth consecutive championship in Nascars top series, and all of the prestige and accolades that came with it, Jimmie Johnson finds himself in search of new vistas in 2010. Johnson, a part-time New Yorker, recently sold his Chelsea loft to move to an $8.3 million condominium in Manhattans West Village.

title: For Players, Charity Begins on the Course
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Before Chris Smith said anything else on Friday, he wanted to tell every player on the PGA Tour how grateful he was. And before Ken Green could talk about how he intended to write each player on tour a letter of thanks, he had to pause, clear his throat and compose himself.

title: Contemplating the Future of the European Union
description: In 1870, the French novelist Victor Hugo had a vision. Planting an oak tree in his yard, he predicted that by the time it matured, a United States of Europe would have sprung up, strengthened by a common currency that would one day make the Continent a force to be reckoned with.

title: Olympic Hopes Rest With Skating Favorite Kim Yu-na
description: TORONTO  The megastar of figure skating, Kim Yu-na, lives with her mother in a Korean neighborhood here, a world away from her life of fame in Asia.

title: Stiffening Political Backbones for Fiscal Discipline
description: SPINELESS and shortsighted.

title: Study Suggests More Veterans May Be Helped by Talking About Killing
description: The act of killing is as fundamental to war as oxygen is to fire. Yet it is also the one thing many combat veterans avoid discussing when they return home, whether out of shame, guilt or a deep fear of being misunderstood.

title: Palins Cunning Sleight of Hand
description: Liberals had a blast mocking Sarah Palin last weekend when she was caught addressing the Tea Party Convention with a cheat sheet scrawled on her hand. Even the presidents press secretary, Robert Gibbs, couldnt resist getting into the act and treated a White House briefing to a Palin hand gag of his own.

title: Crib Notes on Canada, From a Canadian
description: Welcome to Canada. Bienvenue au Canada! We want you to enjoy your stay here at the 2010 Winter Olympic Games in Vancouver but we also hope youll take this opportunity to travel beyond the Olympic village. Canada, you know, is the second-largest country by area in the world  almost a third larger than your United States. Fortunately, most of it is empty so youre not missing much. But what there is to see may surprise you.

title: Our Politics May Be All in Our Head
description: We all know that liberals and conservatives are far apart on health care. But in the way their brains work? Even in automatic reflexes, like blinking? Or the way their glands secrete moisture?

title: India on Alert After Explosion Kills 9 at Bakery in Western City
description: NEW DELHI  Indian authorities on Saturday issued a national alert after 9 people were killed and at least 57 were wounded when a bomb exploded at a bakery in a neighborhood popular with foreign tourists in the western Indian city of Pune.

title: Border Towns Across Rio, Worlds Apart in Drug War
description: EL PASO

title: Videos of Congressional Black Caucus Foundation Events
description: The Congressional Black Caucus Foundation  a charity dedicated to internships, public policy research and healthy living among African Americans  spends more on its special events than it does on scholarships, internships and its health and education programs, according to an analysis byThe New York Times. Money is donated to finance the Annual Legislative Conference by corporations and labor unions that often also turn to the members of the black caucus for support on their issues in Congress. But the donations to the foundation are not subject to limits, like contributions to political campaigns are.

title: Quotations of the Week
description: There are many so-called orphanages that have opened in the last couple of years that are not really orphanages at all. They are fronts for criminal organizations that take advantage of people who are homeless and hungry. And with the earthquake they see an opportunity to strike in a big way.Frantz Thermilus, the chief of Haitis National Judicial Police

title: Millionaire Wants Heart of Gold, and Nothing Else
description: Karl Rabeder has been rich and poor. Poor is better, he says. The Austrian millionaire, who made his fortune from an interior furnishings and accessories business, is giving away his nearly $5 million fortune and planning to repair to a small wooden hut in the mountains, The Daily Telegraph of London reports. My idea is to have nothing left, he said. Absolutely nothing. Money is counterproductive  it prevents happiness to come. Mr. Rabeder, 47, has sold his business and is selling his villa in the Austrian alps and his farmhouse in Provence. The money will go to charities he set up in Central and South America. But Mr. Rabeder said he did not judge those who keep their wealth. I was just listening to the voice of my heart and soul.

title: A Forever Fad
description: The man who gets the credit for inventing the Frisbee, Walter F. Morrison, died last week at 90. Here are excerpts from an article by Gay Talese in The New York Times on Aug. 11, 1957, not long after Mr. Morrisons whirling object made its debut.

title: Some Clues for Finding New Tax Breaks
description: OPPORTUNITIES to save money on 2009 taxes abound, thanks to incentives enacted by Congress last year. Whats more, taxpayers can still act to claim one of the biggest prizes: a credit of up to $8,000 for buying a home.

title: Changes on Luge Track Could Offset Canadian Teams Advantage
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Canada was criticized for granting foreign athletes only limited training access to the Olympic sliding center before the Winter Games. Now its luge team will have to quickly adjust to the course along with everyone else.

title: This Year, the Tax Code Is My Friend
description: TAX time has come around again, with its glorious blend of trepidation, tedium and loss. But theres no need to get all gloomy about it. Lets celebrate!

title: 1977 vs. 1979
description: Visiting Yemen and watching the small band of young reformers there struggle against the forces of separatism, Islamism, autocracy and terrorism, reminded me that the key forces shaping this region today were really set in motion between 1977 and 1979  and nothing much has changed since. Indeed, one could say Middle East politics today is a struggle between 1977 and 1979  and 1979 is still winning.

title: Prime Number
description: 42: The number of high-speed rail lines recently opened or set to open by 2012 in China. By contrast, the United States hopes to build its first high-speed rail line by 2014, an 84-mile route in Florida linking Tampa and Orlando. How fast are the Chinese bullet trains? They average speeds of up to 215 miles an hour. The train that connects Guangzhou, the southern coastal manufacturing center, to Wuhan, in the interior, takes a little more than three hours to travel 664 miles, roughly the distance between Boston and southern Virginia.

title: Short of Stature, but Not Fortitude at Central Florida
description: A.J. Rompza, the starting point guard for Central Florida, is the author of A Little Guy in a Big Mans World.

title: Should Tax Bills Be Public Information?
description: MANY people are phobic about letting others see their tax information. Perhaps they shouldnt be.

title: Dont Overlook the Rewards for Thinking Green
description: ITS one thing to favor clean energy and to want to reduce your carbon footprint. It may be quite another to put together enough cash to buy energy-efficient products like hybrid cars or electricity-efficient refrigerators  or to pay for an all-out home energy upgrade.

title: The Myth of the One-Term Wonder
description: Washington

title: Big-Wave Surfing, With Danger
description: Spectators were injured during the Mavericks Surf competition, a big-wave event in Half Moon Bay, Calif.

title: An Idea of F1 Team Strength?
description: Just as I was looking at the lap times of todays final F1 test in Jerez and realizing that we had a yet another different order of strength, I suddenly felt that perhaps the answer as to the individual team strengths is sitting right in front of our noses after all. That is to say, unlike last year when Brawn GP dominated testing and then dominated the season, it could be that because no one has been able to figure out who has the strongest car at the moment, it is because there is no one team that will dominate this year.

title: A 1040 Close-Up
description: A line-by-line walk through the 1040 to help taxpayers understand the changes in 2009.

title: Protesters Smash Windows and Vandalize Cars in Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaA small group of demonstrators smashed two large plate glass windows of the official department store of the Vancouver Olympics Saturday morning as protests disrupted downtown traffic for the second consecutive day.

title: A U.N. Betrayal in Beirut
description: Beirut, Lebanon

title: Is Soda the New Tobacco?
description: Check out my Week in Review article exploring the possible dangers of drinking too much (or maybe any) soda, the response of the beverage companies to criticism and the new nationwide push for steep taxes on S.S.B.s (sugar-sweetened beverages) as a way to cut consumption and fund campaigns against obesity and for healthier eating.

title: Ruggiero Has Map to Future: First Stop, Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  How to live life after hockey is a question elite female hockey players must face a lot sooner than elite male players, given the absence of a professional womens league. At 30, the four-time United States Olympian Angela Ruggiero is already preparing for it, even if some of the work she has done may come back to haunt her.

title: A Side-by-Side Look at Tax Software
description: TAXES can make people do silly things, like investing in chinchilla and ostrich ranches or, over the last several years, buying a second home  which was a bad move just about anywhere in the United States.

title: With Rules in Flux, Its a Tough Time for Tax Strategies
description: WASHINGTON

title: That Fog Still Hasnt Lifted From the Estate Tax
description: THE estate tax isnt dead. Its resting.

title: Paying the Price for Survival Tactics
description: FOR some people, the recession was only the first part of a one-two economic punch. Tax time delivers the second blow.

title: U.S. Envoy Is to Be Link to Muslims
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has appointed Rashad Hussain, a deputy White House counsel, to be his representative to the Muslim world, White House officials said Saturday.

title: The Case For Higher Inflation
description: Olivier Blanchard, normally at MIT but currently the chief economist at the IMF, has released an interesting and important paper on how the crisis has changed, or should have changed, how we think about macroeconomic policy. The most surprising conclusion, presumably, is the idea that central banks have been setting their inflation targets too low:

title: Top Judge Suspends Presidents Judicial Appointment in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A simmering power struggle in Pakistan erupted into open confrontation on Saturday, when the countrys top judge clashed with President Asif Ali Zardari over a judicial appointment.

title: Greek Statistician Is Caught in Limelight
description: ATHENS  As the head of a once obscure Greek agency churning out government data, Manolis Kontopirakis never sought the limelight that has suddenly come his way, after his countrys financial woes touched off a global storm that threatens to tear the euro zone apart.

title: Chinese Women Battling Back in Ice Hockey
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  There is no parity in Olympic womens hockey. Canada and the United States are all but in a league of their own, and everybody else is struggling for respectability. Even the American teams surprising loss to Switzerland at the 2006 Games, which cost them a chance at the gold or the silver medal, did not do much to alter the balance of power.

title: Miller, Skiing on His Terms, Says Olympics Lured Him Back
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  In the buildup to the 2006 Turin Olympics, Bode Miller, then the worlds best skier, seriously contemplated skipping the Winter Games. Miller feared he was being set up for a fall, especially considering his deeply rooted contrarian attitude and his centerpiece role in the boundless pre-Olympic hype.

title: Marines Battle Taliban Fighters in Offensive
description: Much of the expected resistance in Marja, Afghanistan, failed to materialize, but the hardest fighting may lay in the days to come.

title: Wall St. Helped to Mask Debt Fueling Europes Crisis
description: Wall Street tactics akin to the ones that fostered subprime mortgages in America have worsened the financial crisis shaking Greece and undermining the euro by enabling European governments to hide their mounting debts.

title: Education Was Also Leveled by Quake in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Christina Julme was scribbling notes in the back of a linguistics class at the State University of Haiti when, in an instant, everything went black.

title: Thats Amore
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  The meaning of love has been pondered for ages. Those in possession of it rhapsodize. Those without have long lists of questions. Those who can write put it into words.

title: Same-Sex Couple Stir Fears of a Gay Agenda
description: BLANTYRE, Malawi  Tiwonge Chimbalanga looked like a man but said he was a woman. He helped with the cooking and dressed in feminine wraparound skirts. Steven Monjeza was a quiet, sullen man often intoxicated on sorghum beer. He said he had never been happy until he finally met the right companion.

title: Myanmar Frees a Pro-Democracy Leader
description: BANGKOK  An 82-year-old leader of Myanmars main pro-democracy party was freed Saturday after nearly seven years of house arrest.

title: China Hints at Trials for 20 Seeking Asylum
description: BEIJING  The Chinese Foreign Ministry has indicated that 20 Uighur asylum seekers who were deported from Cambodia to China in December are being or have been put on trial for what China considers criminal activities.

title: Future Bailouts of America
description: AS Washington spins its wheels on financial reform, its becoming painfully clear that the problem of entities that are too interconnected or too politically powerful to fail is also too hard for our policy makers to tackle.

title: Premature Exit
description: While looking at the Economic Report of the President, I was inspired to make this chart, which actually doesnt come from the ERP (more ERP blogging in a day or two). It shows the contribution of the ARRA, aka the Obama stimulus, to the deficit  a rough measure of the amount of stimulus  with the CBOs projection of the unemployment rate, by fiscal year:

title: Hes Not Bill Gates, or Fred Astaire
description: This interview with Vineet Nayar, chief executive HCL Technologies, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Ohno Begins Bid at Olympic History
description: Update | 10:44 p.m. Apolo Anton Ohno won a silver medal in the 1,500 meter short-track speedskating event for his sixth Olympic medal, matching Bonnie Blair as the most decorated United States Winter Olympian.

title: Results Unproven, Robotic Surgery Wins Converts
description: At age 42, Dr. Jeffrey A. Cadeddu felt like a dinosaur in urologic surgery. He was trained to take out cancerous prostates the traditional laparoscopic way: making small incisions in the abdomen and inserting tools with his own hands to slice out the organ.

title: Revised Alpine Schedule Could Benefit Vonn
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Olympic organizers Saturday announced the revised Alpine race schedule for the first week of competition. The mens downhill is to be held Monday at 10:30 a.m. local time with the mens super combined slated to go off as originally scheduled on Tuesday at 10 a.m. Wednesdays featured event will be the womens downhill at 11 a.m. On Thursday, the womens super combined, originally scheduled for Sunday, will be contested beginning at 10 a.m. Thursday had been a day off in the Alpine schedule.

title: Southern Oregon Historical Society Looks to the Past for a Future
description: JACKSONVILLE, Ore.  They say economic collapse is what froze this place in time, a gold rush relic all but abandoned when the railroad passed it by. Decades later, that chance preservation positioned Jacksonville to benefit from new interest in the past. Boutiques moved to quaint California Street. Californians soon moved to town.

title: The Perfect Pairing of Roommates
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Tanith Belbin, the American ice dancer, arrived at her two-bedroom suite at the athletes village and found it looking like someone had been living there for weeks.

title: American Speedskater Shani Davis Belongs to the World
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  In the serpentine mixed zone at the Richmond Olympic Oval, the young Dutch speedskater Arjen van der Kieft turned a corner after a training session last week and came upon a half-dozen journalists from the Netherlands, who nodded benignly in his direction. A few minutes later, two female Dutch skaters walked past. The journalists acknowledged them, but their pens remained still.

title: Insurer Delays Increase for California Customers
description: Under intense pressure from Washington and Sacramento, Californias largest for-profit health insurer delayed a double-digit rate increase by two months on Saturday, but expressed confidence that its new premiums would pass state scrutiny.

title: Patrick Crashes, and the Lessons Pile Up, Too
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Danica Patricks first career Nascar race ended with a jolt of reality for those who believed the IndyCar Series star could become a competitive stock car driver right away.

title: Wahhabi Fanatics Reported on the Afghan Frontier Feb. 13, 1872
description: The more things change, the more they stay the same. Here, from nearly a century and a half ago, a stark warning of the emergence of a mischievous nest of fanatical conspiracy  a nest whose beliefs are similar to those of the Taliban and Al Qaeda  around the northwestern frontier of British-ruled India and Afghanistan. That is to say, modern Pakistan.

title: We Are the World 25 for Haiti': Big-Name Karaoke With Good Intentions
description: When We Are the World was recorded in 1985, to benefit famine relief in Africa, Bob Dylan sang some pivotal lines with his usual wayward phrasing. Now Lil Wayne shows up in the same spot, using Auto-Tune on his vocal, in We Are the World 25 for Haiti, the remake to aid earthquake victims that had its video premiere on Friday night during the Olympics. Similarities aside  scratchy voice, gift for free association  Lil Wayne, youre no Bob Dylan. Its one measure of the slippage between the original and the remake, which can be seen on You Tube or downloaded from iTunes.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,367 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 970 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: White House Press Secretary Joins Twitter
description: Updated |  Robert Gibbs has become the first White House press secretary to join Twitter, sending out his first dispatch  a concise 14 words  on Saturday.

title: F, 18, Seeks Victorian Gentleman
description: VALENTINES DAY 2010: Singles search for love by creating profiles on dating Web sites or posting ads on Craigslist or connecting to a far-flung network via social media. It sounds so ... futuristic. Except its not.

title: Corrections
description: The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about Kwedit.com, a provider of payment systems for online games, referred incorrectly to its new payment option for people without credit or debit cards. It is available to those who are 13 or older, not to everyone. The column also misspelled, at one point, the surname of Kwedits vice president for marketing. She is Loree Hirschman, not Hirshman.

title: Battle of the Bands
description: An article last Sunday about the music publishing and recording company EMI misstated the given name of the wife of Guy Hands, chairman of Terra Firma, the private equity firm that bought EMI in 2007. She is Julia, not Julie.

title: Letters: The Adjunct Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: David Morrow, Business Journalist, Dies at 49
description: David J. Morrow, a prominent financial journalist and a former editor in chief of TheStreet.com, died on Feb. 1 in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 49 and lived in Reno, Nev.

title: Quick to Blame in Luge, and Showing No Shame
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Olympic officials treated the death of Nodar Kumaritashvili, the Georgian luge athlete, less as a tragedy than as an inconvenience.

title: New Challenges Await on Adjusted Luge Course
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The modifications and adjustments that officials made to the Whistler Sliding Center after the death of Nodar Kumaritashvili after a crash during a training run presents luge sliders with a new set of challenges.On average, the elite mens singles lugers lost about 6 to 7 miles per hour off their peak speeds from their normal starting position. The men will now start from the womens starting ramp, and their first curve will now be what would have been their third on the course.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the trial of an administrative nurse who was charged with a felony after alerting the Texas Medical Board that a doctor at her hospital was practicing unsafe medicine reversed the identifications of the two women shown. Anne Mitchell, the defendant, is at the left and Vickilyn Galle, arms folded, is at the right. (Ms. Mitchell was acquitted on Thursday.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about the election of Lt. Gov. Mitch Landrieu of Louisiana as the mayor of New Orleans overstated the turnout. It was relatively low compared with recent mayoral elections; the turnout was not high. (Turnout early in the day was high.)

title: Facing Tall Expectations, Dutchman Sets a Record
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The strain was not evident in the days before his first event of these Winter Olympics, even though Sven Kramer was carrying the weight of the Netherlands immense expectations.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the success of young players so far this season on the PGA Tour misspelled, in some copies, the surname of a twenty-five-year-old golfer. He is Alex Prugh, not Pugh. The article also misstated, in some copies, the ages of two players. Michael Allen is 51, not 50, and Andrs Romero is 28, not 27.

title: From Long Track to Short Track, an Unprecedented Journey
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  His 5,000-meter race was done but Haralds Silovss day of competition had just begun.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions on Jan. 31 misstated the hours for the Montclair Art Museum. It is open from noon to 5 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday, not from noon to 5 p.m. Tuesday through Sunday and from 5 to 9 p.m. Thursday.

title: Climate Change Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: All Politics Is Local
description: To the Editor:

title: Missed Warning Signs of the Financial Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis in a Stoic Land
description: Athens

title: Finding Her Name in the Program and on the Menu
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Mirai Nagasu, the 2008 United States figure skating champion, had a special honor bestowed on her when she qualified for the United States Olympic team last month.

title: Nothing Magical in Mix, Just a Hard-Earned Gold Medal
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The Harry Potter connection, like the series of books itself, is firmly part of the past for Simon Ammann.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday described concerts by the Long Island Composers Alliance in honor of Black History Month to be held today at Park Avenue United Methodist Church in Manhattan and next Sunday at South Nassau Unitarian Universalist Congregation in Freeport. Todays concert has been canceled because the vocalist is ill. A decision has not yet been made about next Sundays concert.

title: Challenges at the Luge Course
description: A look at the challenges of the Olympic luge course in Whistler, British Columbia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 40 this weekend about synthetic biology misstates the cause of stomach ulcers for which a possible vaccine is being produced by a team of Slovenian students. The vaccine would treat ulcers caused by bacteria, not by a virus.

title: A Big Hitter and a Short One Are Dueling at Pebble Beach
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Dustin Johnson and Paul Goydos each shot a 64 on Saturday and were tied for the lead at 18-under par after three rounds of the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. That is the long and short of it, which nicely sums up this final-round pairing.

title: Rhode Island Democrats to Campaign for House
description: Two prominent Rhode Island Democrats announced on Saturday that they would run for the Congressional seat held by Patrick J. Kennedy.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the music publishing and recording company EMI misstated the given name of the wife of Guy Hands, chairman of Terra Firma, the private equity firm that bought EMI in 2007. She is Julia, not Julie.

title: Let Health Insurance Cross State Lines, Some Say
description: As Republicans and Democrats claim to be searching for common ground in the health care debate, one idea that lawmakers on both sides seem to agree on is that health insurance should be sold across state lines.

title: A Real Scoring Race
description: The N.B.A. seems to be in an ideal situation coming out of the All-Star weekend with its brightest stars locked in a tight race for the scoring title: LeBron James, Kevin Durant, Carmelo Anthony and Kobe Bryant are separated by a total of 1.9 points a game.

title: Premier Says Fraud Tainted Ukraine Vote
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the apparent loser in Ukraines presidential election, declared Saturday night that she would not concede, denouncing the results as having been tainted by widespread fraud.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Frank F. Fasi, 89, Mayor of Honolulu for 22 Years, Is Dead
description: Frank F. Fasi, the outspoken, streetwise six-term mayor of Honolulu whose muscular remake of the citys governance and infrastructure included personally mounting a bulldozer to turn a City Council parking lot into a park, died on Feb. 3 at his home in Honolulu. He was 89.

title: Is There a  Physiology of Politics?
description: My Sunday column looks at whether political differences may be rooted partly in personality differences, possibly even fundamental physiological differences. In particular, as described in the column, theres some evidence of variations in our sense of fear of threats. Presumably we have evolved to be wary of enemies (that seems to be the biological basis of suspicion of out groups, including racism), and some people are more wary than others. These days, that wariness isnt directed at sabertooth tigers or enemy clans but at, say, Iranians  or even the French. And those who register higher in sensitivity to threats tend to be more conservative. For example, one study that I didnt have space to talk about in the column presented people with images of faces with ambiguous expressions. Those who thought that the facial expressions were more conservative.

title: Islanders Victory Over the Lightning Keeps Tavares Happy in His Goal-Scoring Drought
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  John Tavares, the Islanders 19-year-old center, has not scored a goal in 13 games, or four long weeks, but who is counting? The drought did not seem to matter as much to him Saturday as a hard-earned 5-4 victory against the Tampa Bay Lightning.

title: Slower Speeds and Snowy Conditions as Luge Begins
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  A day after tragedy struck the Olympic sport, the mens singles luge competition began in a wintry mix at the Whistler Sliding Center on Saturday evening.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Pierre Zimmermann, a chef from Alsace who is joining the faculty of Chicagos French Pastry School, misstated the timing of the American premiere of the documentary Kings of Pastry. It will premiere in the spring, not in the fall.

title: William Tenn, Science Fiction Author, Is Dead at 89
description: William Tenn, who wrote satirical science fiction at a time when few writers in the genre displayed a sense of humor, died at his home in Pittsburgh on Feb. 7. He was 89.

title: Fighting a Four-Alarm Fire in Jackson Heights
description: Saturday morning, a four-alarm fire that officials believe broke out at a furniture store quickly spread to neighboring storefronts in Jackson Heights, Queens. An emergency call came in just before 10 a.m., and it took 168 firemen to get the blaze under control at around 1:30 p.m. The occupants of 54 apartments were evacuated.

title: Opening Ceremony Scores High Ratings
description: The opening ceremony on NBC Friday night attracted an average of 32.6 million viewers, the second most for a non-United States Winter Olympics carried by an American network. The figure exceeded by 14 million the opening ceremony viewership of the Winter Olympics from Turin four years ago.

title: Enthralled at the Oceans Edge
description: Karen Luks family of doctors and engineers assumed she would follow their lead. But after she discovered comic books as a child, she opted for art and storytelling. Ms. Luk creates manga comics  pocket-size tales about flecks of life most of us barely notice. She eschews digital drawings, preferring pencil, ink and watercolors. She takes people into her imaginings, where children ride giant crows and a rain puddle is as deep and mesmerizing as the sea. She finds inspiration at Seabright State Beach in Santa Cruz. (Ms. Luks words have been edited and condensed.) -- CAROL POGASH

title: At Berkeley, Yoo Tackles California Constitution
description: In the rest of the country, John Yoo is a hero to the right, a war criminal to the left and a deeply controversial figure in the legal field. But at the University of California, Berkeley, of all places, Mr. Yoo is a tenured law professor, quietly leading a seminar on how best to overhaul the states Constitution.

title: Canadian Women Put on Record-Breaking Display for the Home Fans
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  They filled Canada Hockey Place on Saturday night, a record 16,496 fans from as far away as Smiths Falls, Ontario, the Siksika Nation in Alberta and Nunavut in the Arctic.

title: A Small Business Finds a Catch in Federal Aid
description: When Barbara Wright learned last year of a federal program to aid struggling small businesses like her South Side uniform company, she jumped at the chance to apply for the Small Business Administration loan.

title: A Neighborhood Transformed From Residences to Restaurants
description: My great-grandfather passed through Ellis Island in 1902, a 22-year-old laborer with $18 in his pocket and a brother at 111 South Morgan Street in Chicago. The ships manifest listed many other men from his poor village of Achladokambos, most destined for the same neighborhood on Chicagos Near West Side, then the biggest Greek immigrant community in the country.

title: Wildcats Standout Raises Hope for Tourney
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Police Checkpoints: Safety or Profit?
description: In California, sobriety checkpoints target unlicensed drivers. Is the motivation safety or profit? A report by the Investigative Reporting Program at the University of California, Berkeley, and PBS NewsHour.

title: Ohnos Silver, His 6th Medal, Ties a Record
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Inside the mixed-zone maze at Pacific Coliseum, Apolo Ohno wore his blue bandana and trademark soul patch as he let loose a scream that bounced and echoed down the hallway. His body appeared to follow suit, ping-ponging with energy, as if gravity had allowed for a short break.

title: NBC Shelves Accident Footage
description: NBC made a decision Saturday night not to replay the video of Nodar Kumaritashvili, a luge athlete from the Republic of Georgia who died Friday during a training run at the Whistler Sliding Center. When Bob Costas introduced a report on the changes made to the luge track  intended to make it safer and slower  he said that NBC would not play the video of Kumaritashvilis accident for the rest of the Olympics.

title: Google Alters Buzz to Tackle Privacy Flaws
description: Google moved quickly to contain a firestorm of criticism over Buzz, its new social network, taking the unusual step of announcing changes to the product over the weekend to address privacy problems.

title: Arrest in Olympians Death
description: The authorities in Oxnard, Calif., arrested the wife of an Olympic medalist who was gunned down in his back yard last summer. The Oxnard police issued a statement saying that Jane Laut, 52, had been arrested in connection with the homicide of her husband, the shot-putter David Laut, and was being held in Ventura County Jail on $3 million bail.

title: Grieving Burke Expected to Be at Games
description: Brian Burke, the general manager of the United States mens hockey team, was scheduled to arrive in Vancouver on Saturday, eight days after the death of his 21-year-old son, Brendan, in a car accident.

title: A Carnival Artist Without a Carnival
description: Onel Bazelais, a Haitian mask maker from the city of Jacmel,  struggles to showcase his vision and make a living now that Carnival has been canceled throughout the earthquake ravaged nation.

title: After the Cohen Debacle, a Chance to Show Skill
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Report
description: Art and Storytelling | After Karen Luk discovered comic books as a child, she decided to pursue her passion for art and storytelling. Ms. Luk creates manga comics  pocket-size tales about flecks of life most of us barely notice. She eschews digital drawings, preferring pencil, ink and watercolors. She finds inspiration at Seabright State Beach in Santa Cruz.

title: Dallas Gets Caron Butler as Part of 7-Player Deal
description: DALLAS  With the spotlight already trained on their city, the Dallas Mavericks seized a little more attention on Saturday by acquiring the former All-Star Caron Butler in a multiplayer trade with the Washington Wizards.

title: American Wins Gold in Womens Moguls
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On a dismal, drizzly evening at Cypress Mountain, Canada failed to pry loose the monkey clinging to the back of its Olympic fortunes. Jennifer Heil, who had been favored to win the womens mogul skiing competition and become the first Canadian to claim a gold medal on home soil, finished second, behind the American Hannah Kearney. Shannon Bahrke, another American, was third.

title: Vows: Bailey & Eric
description: Bailey Kindlon and Eric Johnson got to know each other when they were working on a commercial for Oreo cookie in 2008. At the moment they met each other, they were both hit by the love bomb.

title: Cornell Bounces Back by Beating Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Twenty minutes before Cornells game against Princeton tipped off on Saturday, five Tigers football players, wearing black masks with matching body paint and tights, stepped onto Carril Court by the basket where the Big Red was warming up.

title: Documentaries and More at Turkeys !f Festival
description: The documentary film sector is booming in Turkey and the !F International Independent Film Festival (2010.ifistanbul.com/en), now through Feb. 21, is a great way to survey its breadth  with the rare, added benefit of English subtitles.

title: Vicks Admission on Marijuana Use Raises Question
description: Michael Vicks admission that he didnt always give his best effort in Atlanta is nothing new. Vick had been dropping hints since returning to the league (most notably in his 60 Minutes interview). What is new is Vicks acknowledgment of how marijuana use affected his Falcons career.

title: Looking for a Souvenir? Look No Further
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The white terra cotta Hudsons Bay Company store in downtown Vancouver was targeted by protesters Saturday who smashed two display windows.

title: Yzerman Tries to Deflect Pressure Off Canadian Team
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  There has probably never been more pressure on an Olympic team to win as there is on the Canadian mens hockey team at these Winter Games. But Steve Yzerman, Team Canadas general manager, will not concede that point.

title: Blue Marbles Soft Side
description: Jennie Dundas and Alexis Miesen never thought they would sell soft-serve when they opened Blue Marble ice cream in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, in 2007 or at their second shop in Prospect Heights.

title: After Gruesome Injury, a Satisfying Finish for J.R. Celski
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia - On almost any Olympic night, including this one, J.R. Celski would make for a remarkable story. Instead, Apolo Ohno made history - personal history, short-track history, Winter Olympics history - and Celski became an interesting footnote.

title: Is Robotic Prostate Surgery Really Better?
description: In todays New York Times, health reporter Gina Kolata explores the marketing and the science behind robot-assisted prostate cancer surgery.

title: Green Eyes, Pretty Mouth and a Strangers Kiss
description: They shared a mutual distaste for phonies, an interest in the arts and a turn on the dance floor. The year was 1946, she was a sheltered 20-year-old, and he was seven years her senior and embroiled in a divorce.

title: Bharti Airtel Bids for Zains African Phone Customers
description: NEW DELHI  Bharti Airtel, the Indian mobile phone company, has offered to buy the African operations of the Kuwaiti telecommunications company Zain in a deal valued at about $10.7 billion.

title: Police Officer Is Charged After a Crash
description: An off-duty police officer was charged with drunken driving after his car hit a garbage truck and flipped onto the sidewalk in Midtown Manhattan early Saturday, knocking down a tree and scratching the marble-and-granite facade of Tiffany & Companys flagship Fifth Avenue store, according to the police.

title: Errant U.S. Rocket Strike Kills Civilians in Afghanistan
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  An errant American rocket strike on Sunday hit a compound crowded with Afghan civilians in the last Taliban stronghold in Helmand Province, killing at least 10 people, including 5 children, military officials said.

title: In Georgian Village, Plans to Honor Luge Athlete
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Some personal details emerged Saturday about Nodar Kumaritashvili, the luge athlete from Georgia who died Friday in a training accident.

title: Running for Top Dog
description: More than 3,000 dogs competed last month in the Rose City Classic Dog Show in Portland, Ore.

title: India Pursues a Possible Terror Link to Bomb Blast
description: PUNE, India  A day after a bomb blast ripped through a crowded cafe in this western Indian city, the Indian authorities were trying to determine Sunday whether the attack was linked to any known terrorist groups and to a man charged in the deadly 2008 assault on Mumbai.

title: Inside the Rings
description: Bill Pennington discusses why the men's downhill at Whistler for the 2010 Vancouver Games is so compelling.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Slovakias Hossa, Swedens Holmstrom Hurt on Eve of Olympics
description: Eleven games on Saturday night, and the last action before the Olympic break for the Sabres, Sharks, Canadiens, Flyers, Hurricanes, Devils, Panthers, Bruins, Blues, Capitals, Red Wings, Senators, Coyotes, Stars, Thrashers, Flames, Avs and Kings.

title: Now Screening | Ohne Titel
description: The fall 2010 collection from Ohne Titel.

title: An Art Historical Tour of Istanbuls Quakes
description: Artwork from the Collection Kozak in Prague depicting historic earthquakes in Istanbul.

title: New Olympic Sports Have History With Danger
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Four at a time, the racers barrel down the mountain, navigating banked turns, long jumps, washboard bumps and  if they can help it  one another. The concept is simple: first one to the bottom wins.

title: Photos of the Moment | Alexander Wang
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: Now Screening | Joseph Altuzarra
description: The fall 2010 collection from Joseph Altuzarra.

title: Photos of the Moment | Model Expression
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Inside the Rings: Drama and Delay in Alpine Skiing
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Just before dinner time on the eve of every Alpine race or training session, there is a meeting of race officials called the captains meeting, which is another term for coaches meeting. Ground rules and schedule for the event are discussed at the meeting, the start order is drawn and often a weather report is delivered.

title: Now Screening | Alexander Wang
description: The fall 2010 collection from Alexander Wang.

title: Dueling Vice Presidents Trade Barbs
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and former Vice President Dick Cheney engaged in the latest round of their war of words on Sunday in dueling television appearances, in which each offered sharply different positions on national security and forceful defenses of their administrations policies.

title: The Curling Lords of Argyle
description: After the Norwegian mens curling team unveiled its new look for the Vancouver Games in 2010, other teams soon took notice.

title: Quick-Change Artist | Liu Wen
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York fashion week. Here, the model Liu Wen of Marilyn gets reinvented six times. For previous models, click here.

title: Food for Thoughtless
description: Incoming | An American has an Internet chat with a starving African boy about the virtual game Farmville (from Ninjapirate.com).

title: Speedy Legs
description: Alyson Dudek, 19-years-old Wisconsin native, is making her Olympic debut in short track speed skating.  Learn the rules and tricks of one of the most dangerous sports represented at Vancouver.

title: The Way the Cookie Crumbles
description: Sight Gag | Just your luck, an hour later and youll still be broke:

title: Model-morphosis | Joseph Altuzarra
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Sigrid Agren from New York Models before (left, right) and after makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Laurent Philippon for Bumble and bumble. (Drag the orange bar down to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Early Chance at Cubs Tickets Comes With a Price
description: Pitchers and catchers report to spring training in just a few days, which means diehard fans are gearing up for an annual ritual: the start of ticket sales for individual games.

title: The Curling Lords of Argyle
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  For the record, it was Christoffer Svaes idea.

title: Technical Achievements
description: The opening look in Italo Zucchellis fall mens collection for Calvin Klein, shown on Sunday, suggested, at first blush, a minimalist interpretation of an omnipresent style among guys who take the easy route to dressing. A sharply tailored dark blazer over clean dark-wash jeans is passable in most restaurants, clubs and the offices of creative types, though it doesnt say much on a runway.

title: Something Personal
description: Roberta Smith on artists whose work deserves more attention.

title: A Twist on Getting Dressed: Try Doing It While Dangling
description: BEACON, N.Y.  I always feel sorry for the parts of the stage that arent being used, the choreographer Trisha Brown said once. I have in the past felt sorry for the ceilings and the walls. Its perfectly good space, why doesnt anyone use it?

title: Palestinian President Suspends Aide in Sex Scandal
description: JERUSALEM  Facing a corruption scandal that has rocked the highest echelons of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank, the Palestinian president suspended his chief of staff on Sunday while a committee investigates accusations that the aide sought to trade influence for sex.

title: Baghdad Is Red, Clerics Are Blue: Valentines Back, Roses for You
description: BAGHDAD For the first time since the war, the sales of red roses here have reached pre-war levels. Red teddy bears and plastic roses filled the fronts of shops in Baghdad days before Valentines Day.

title: Interpreting Balanchine Connections
description: SAN FRANCISCO  San Francisco Ballets latest program consists of three ballets that George Balanchine choreographed in America between 1934 and 1972: all classical, Romantic and modernist. The more you look (I attended the opening performance on Thursday night), the more you see that the very connections shared by the three ballets are also where they begin to be most dissimilar.

title: Twists Multiply in Alabama Shooting Case
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  On Friday, this city of rocket scientists and brainy inventors was stunned when a neuroscientist with a Harvard Ph.D. was arrested in the shooting deaths of three of her colleagues after she was denied tenure.

title: At Carnival Time, a Joyless Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Oh, what a party there would have been. Sound trucks with towering speakers. Dancers in eye-catching outfits. Three days of rum-fueled, dusk-to-dawn debauchery.

title: Temporary Suspensions for High Hemoglobin Levels
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A cross-country skier from Estonia and a Nordic combined athlete from Russia were temporarily barred from competition at the Winter Olympics because tests conducted before the Games showed that their hemoglobin levels were above acceptable limits.

title: Tracing the Path to Chinese Finesse
description: Copying is bad; originality is good. Thats what we learn from toddlerdom on. In art as in life, be yourself. Dont pretend. Nobody likes phonies, fakes or frauds. Forgery is illegal. Authenticity is holy.

title: The Enemy of My Enemy
description: Its traditional to teach kids subtraction right after addition. That makes sense  the same facts about numbers get used in both, though in reverse. And the black art of borrowing, so crucial to successful subtraction, is only a little more baroque than that of carrying, its counterpart for addition. If you can cope with calculating 23 + 9, youll be ready for 23  9 soon enough.

title: Seventh Avenue Drive-Through
description: This afternoon, before Diane Von Furstenbergs show, I popped up to Oscar de la Rentas showroom for a preview and, lo, the burgers and fries were inbound. No kidding: Mr. de la Renta and the crew, including the stylist Alex White, had ordered a delivery. They had extra. We sat around a table in the studio eating burgers off paper plates and talking about movies and this and that. Mr. de la Renta said he watched Pretty Woman last night. I gave him a hard time about that, naturally.

title: For Haiti, They Are the Remake
description: When We Are the World was recorded in 1985, to benefit famine relief in Africa, Bob Dylan sang some pivotal lines with his usual wayward phrasing. Now Lil Wayne shows up in the same spot, using Auto-Tune on his vocal, in We Are the World 25 for Haiti, the remake to aid earthquake victims that had its video premiere on Friday night during the Olympics. Similarities aside  scratchy voice, gift for free association  Lil Wayne, youre no Bob Dylan.

title: A Tree Climber Grows in the Bronx
description: Young New Yorkers training for jobs in landscaping, horticulture and arboriculture learn to work out on a limb.

title: The Void
description: Images from Contemplating the Void: Interventions in the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Damages: Bill Clintons Legal Mess
description: At the end of The Death of American Virtue, Ken Gormleys tough, labyrinthine account of the legal nightmare that beset Bill Clintons presidency and led to his impeachment trial, Paula Jones takes stock. Ms. Jones, the woman who accused Mr. Clinton, then governor of Arkansas, of sexual harassment and saw her lawsuit snowball its way to the Supreme Court and take on constitutional ramifications, complains about the mud theyd drug me through and about being called trailer-park trash. I never lived in a trailer in my life, she says.

title: Dirty Person
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Lynn Lempel is back with another fine Monday puzzle. Not everyone can make a puzzle simple enough for a Monday but charming and clever enough to amuse jaded longtime solvers. Ms. Lempel makes it look easy. This is a lovely puzzle. Did you notice there are a lot of Ds in the finished grid? That seems to make it fun too, for some reason.

title: Beethoven, a Refined Classicist of Vienna
description: Beethovens music abounds in Romantic fervor, especially the breakout pieces of his middle years. And the otherworldly mysticism of his late works transcends historical period.

title: U.S. Missiles Kill 6 in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two missiles fired from an American drone aircraft killed at least six militants in North Waziristan on Sunday, Pakistani security officials said.

title: Clarinet Gets Acrobatic Workout
description: In his brilliant Clarinet Concerto, Magnus Lindberg exploits myriad facets of what the instrument can do, from playing soaring melodic lines to making almost rude-sounding noises. He composed the work in 2002 for the remarkable clarinetist Kari Kriikku, who performed its United States premiere with the New York Philharmonic, led by Alan Gilbert, on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: A Poignant Trail of Broken Hearts, All on Display
description: ISTANBUL  Among the many curious objects on display at a new exhibition in an upscale shopping mall here is an old Nokia cellphone with a rugged plastic skin, accompanied by a tag from an anonymous donor that reads: It lasted 300 days too long. He gave me his mobile phone so I couldnt call him anymore.

title: Russian Ballet in Cuba
description: As part of an effort to improve relations after the fall of the Communist-ruled Soviet Union, Russian-Cuban cultural ties were on full display in Havana last week. On Saturday night six members of the Bolshoi Ballet, including Anna Antonicheva danced in Cuba, the first time the company appeared there since 1980, alternating performances with the Cuban National Ballet at the Karl Marx Theater, Reuters reported. Cuba has a strong ballet tradition; a number of major dancers in the West have emerged from it. On Thursday the annual Havana International Book Fair opened, with an emphasis on Russian literature. Russias foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, gave the inaugural speech at the fair, the news agency said.

title: 2 Basquiats Sell at Auction
description: Two works by Jean-Michel Basquiat from 1984 and a sculpture by Donald Judd were the big sellers at a Phillips de Pury & Company auction in London on Friday. The Judd piece went for $1.15 million, Bloomberg News reported. An untitled Basquiat collage that features a skull and an oil landscape called Cash Crop each went for $1.12 million, Bloomberg reported.

title: U.S. Wins Its First Medal in Nordic Combined
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  One by one, the Americans in the Nordic combined had their chance Sunday at reversing a history of futility.

title: Lang Lang Jumps to Sony
description: Lang Lang, the celebrity pianist, has left the Deutsche Grammophon label and signed on with Sony Classical. Sony said that his first album would be a live concert performance at the Musikverein in Vienna. While no other details of the contract, including what Mr. Lang is being paid, were released, Sony said it would collaborate with him on a number of other projects showcasing cutting-edge technologies, exploring opportunities for 3-D video and Web-based music education initiatives. Mr. Lang already has an endorsement deal with Sony Electronics.

title: Sidewalk Verse in St. Paul
description: Its practically Twitter in cement. The city of St. Paul, Minn., has announced the third year of a sidewalk poetry contest. Residents can submit entries through March 28; the winners will have their verses stamped on sections of sidewalk. While Twitter has room for 140 character spaces, the poems are a bit more generous, with 250.

title: Moseley Interprets Moguls for Viewers
description: Jonny Moseley, a gold medalist in freestyle skiing at the 1998 Nagano Winter Games, showed Saturday night during the womens moguls competition that he could use the sports jargon and not confuse viewers. He ably mixed the language of back flip full twists, great big helis, and kickers with clear explanations of skiing technique.

title: Valentines Day Is No. 1
description: A trio of high-profile new movies  and a still-solid Avatar  brought in large crowds at North American theaters over the weekend. Valentines Day (Warner Brothers/New Line) was a strong No. 1 with $52.4 million. The comedy, directed by Garry Marshall, succeeded partly because its ensemble cast of 18 stars, including Julia Roberts, Ashton Kutcher and Shirley MacLaine, appealed to all ages. Most date films primarily attract teenagers. Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief, based on the young-adult novels by Rick Riordan, was second with about $31.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Some critics said that film, a fantasy from 20th Century Fox, was a knockoff of the Harry Potter franchise, but Fox played up the similarity in advertisements, a decision that box-office analysts said probably paid off. The Wolfman (Universal Pictures) was third with about $30.6 million, a weak opening for such an expensive endeavor  budget estimates range from $110 million to $150 million  but better than some analysts had anticipated given negative chatter on the Internet. Avatar (Fox) was fourth with about $22 million for a new domestic total of $659.6 million, while the tear-jerker Dear John (Relativity/Sony) was fifth with about $15.3 million ($53.2 million total).

title: Strike at London Museum
description: Employees at the National Gallery in London plan a two-hour strike on Tuesday in a protest over salaries, according to the BBCs Web site bbc.co.uk. Staff who protect important artworks and assist the public are sick and tired of working 50- to 60-hour weeks and having to take second jobs to earn a living wage, said Mark Serwotka, general secretary of the museum workers Public and Commercial Services union. A spokeswoman for the National Gallery said officials were hopeful the museum would stay open. The gallery will do all it can to keep disruption to the public to a minimum, the BBC quoted the unidentified spokeswoman as saying.

title: From the Pope to Pop: Vaticans Top 10 List
description: So many records, so little time. But the Vatican can help. The official newspaper of the Holy See, LOsservatore Romano, has published what it called a semi-serious guide to the Top 10 pop albums of all time. In first place was the Beatles Revolver. The next was If I Could Only Remember My Name, David Crosbys first solo album, followed by Pink Floyds Dark Side of the Moon. The newspaper published its list on Saturday, before the start of the San Remo festival, an over-the-top Italian competition of pop music that is widely watched on television. The rest of the list: Rumors by Fleetwood Mac; The Nightfly by Donald Fagen of Steely Dan; Thriller by Michael Jackson; Paul Simons Graceland; Achtung Baby by U2; (Whats the Story) Morning Glory by Oasis; and Carlos Santanas Supernatural. The writers of the article ended with a shot at Bob Dylan, praising his great poetic vein but saying he was excluded from the list for a major fault: paving the way for generations of dilettante singer-songwriters who have harshly tested the ears and patience of listeners, thinking that their tortured meanderings might interest somebody.

title: Celski Pauses to Look Back, but Not for Long
description: VANCOUVER, B.C.  The day after J. R. Celski secured the bronze medal in short track speedskatings 1,500-meter race, he met with reporters at the media center here and admitted that five months ago, when he removed his left skate from his right knee at U.S. Nationals, he wondered if he would die.

title: New CDs
description: JAHEIM

title: The Library, Through Students Eyes
description: After a Room for Debate discussion last week, Do School Libraries Need Books? the comments from readers included some first-hand views from students. Below are excerpts of their observations on how studying has changed, how they use libraries (if at all) and how to use the space differently.

title: Averys Goal on Penalty Shot Sparks a Rangers Rally
description: Sean Avery had been done wrong, and, as in the past, he let the officials know it immediately after play was stopped in front of the Tampa Bay goal Sunday. He pointed animatedly toward center ice at Madison Square Garden, making his case for a penalty shot. He got one.

title: Champions League Returns to Recapture European Sports Fans Attention
description: Most people in Europe may be focused on womens biathlon at the Vancouver Games, but a few folks will no doubt turn their attention from Helena Jonssons quest for gold to the UEFA Champions League, which resumes Tuesday.

title: Dick Francis, Jockey and Writer, Dies at 89
description: Dick Francis, whose notable but blighted career as a champion steeplechase jockey for the British royal family was eclipsed by a second, more brilliant career as a popular thriller writer, died on Sunday in the Cayman Islands, where he had a home. He was 89.

title: Mozart Served Up With Tasty Side Dishes From All Over
description: For many classical musicians, you presume, programming works by Mozart comes as naturally as breathing and requires about as much conscious thought. By no means is this meant to slight Mozart, whose greatest works are unassailable and as vital to healthy living as, well, oxygen. But encountering concerts in which Mozarts music is investigated within an enlightening context happens less frequently than you might think.

title: Inviting In a Brash Outsider
description: Visit CNN.com these days and you might come across a video about Liberia in which a regular-looking guy, about as far from a dashing foreign correspondent as you can get, is walking through a swamp and interviewing a Liberian warlord named General Butt Naked. (Hes called that because he leads his fighters wearing nothing more than a bad attitude.)

title: Five Musicians on Nine Instruments in New Carter Woodwind Score
description: As a soloist and chamber music player, the clarinetist Charles Neidich has played plenty of Elliott Carters music over the years, and like many of this composers advocates, he has been intent on coaxing more music from Mr. Carter in recent years, as he passed his 100th and then, last December, 101st birthday.

title: A Newsrooms Salute to Its Departed
description: Newspapers occasionally publish ads congratulating themselves for various achievements. But a most unusual ad appeared last week in The Star Tribune of Minneapolis with a less upbeat message, honoring  and naming  newsroom employees who had left the newspaper in wave after wave of staff cuts.

title: Under Fire in Marja
description: U.S. Marines and Afghan Army soldiers face Taliban gunfire, rockets and mortars.

title: In Japan, Unmakable Contract Decides Title
description: At the NEC Bridge Festival, which ended Sunday in Yokohama, Japan, the winners of the NEC Cup were Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Antonio Sementa from Italy. (Maria Teresa Lavazza and Guido Ferraro were also on the team but did not play in the final.) Over 64 boards they defeated Pierre Zimmermann and Franck Multon from France, Cezary Balicki and Adam Zmudzinski from Poland and Fulvio Fantoni and Claudio Nunes from Italy by 129 international match points to 127.5.

title: Love Songs With Power, Not Heartache
description: Although jazz and pop-soul singing have always been stylistic first cousins, the line between them has never been fuzzier than it is today. In the voice of Nicole Henry, the gifted Florida singer who during the past year has become one of the top attractions at the Metropolitan Room, the two are practically synonymous.

title: For New Leader of Disney Parks, a Little Improv
description: Thomas O. Staggs, the Walt Disney Companys new theme parks chairman, hopped onto a circular stage built to resemble an enormous can of tuna on Thursday. Ladies and gentlemen, he said to the audience gathered at Epcot in Florida, the worlds largest structure of canned food!

title: N.B.A.s Glamour Weekend Carries Air of Labor Gloom
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Opposition Chief Is Named Victor of Ukrainian Vote
description: MOSCOW  Ukraines Central Election Commission certified Viktor F. Yanukovich as the winner of the Feb. 7 presidential election on Sunday, even as his opponent, Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, vowed to challenge the decision in court.

title: Do These Pants Make Me Look Fast?
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The day before the mens snowboard cross competition on Monday, the snowboarder Nate Holland was talking fashion.

title: Haiti Mourns Its Dead
description: The nation emerges from its shock to memorialize individual victims of the earthquake.

title: Sideman as Benevolent Leader
description: Bill Stewart allowed himself just one fully unaccompanied drum solo in his first set at Smoke on Friday night. As he must have known, one was enough. Not because Mr. Stewart lacks the resources or imagination to sustain an audiences interest  far from it  but because his true specialty is making a good band sound inexplicably better. And the band he had here, with the bassist Peter Washington and two saxophonists, Steve Wilson and Seamus Blake, was playing extremely well to begin with.

title: An Officer Shoots, a 73-Year-Old Dies, and Schisms Return
description: HOMER, La.  For the past year, many residents of this tiny town in the northern Louisiana hill country have waited in anger.

title: End of the Run for 47-Year-Old Luger?
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The luger Ruben Gonzalez is one of the Vancouver Olympics more interesting stories.

title: Cities Prepare for Life With the Electric Car
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If electric cars have any future in the United States, this may be the city where they arrive first.

title: McMurray Wins Daytona; Nascar Has to Dig Out of a Hole
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A double-overtime finish, a furious sprint to the checkered flag and a near-win by Dale Earnhardt Jr. almost saved Nascar from a stunning failure in the showcase event of the Sprint Cup season.

title: Its Not All for Sale
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: German Wins Gold on Shortened Luge Course
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  As flags flew at half-staff in honor of the luge competitor from the Republic of Georgia who died training here last week, Felix Loch of Germany became the youngest man to capture the gold medal in the singles luge Sunday.

title: Cubs Open Ticket Line Early for Fans Willing to Pay Extra
description: Pitchers and catchers report to spring training in a few days, which means diehard fans are gearing up for an annual ritual: the start of ticket sales for individual games.

title: Want to See Olympic Flame? Bring a Ladder
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  With its harbor and mountain backdrop, the Olympic caldron is an impressive sight  on television.

title: Nation and Region-Building in Afghanistan: The British, Pakistani, Soviet (& American) Experience
description: A major new operation has been launched in the Taliban stronghold of Marja  an area reshaped 50 years ago to be  model villages under an Afghan and American scheme to rejuvenate the Helmand River Valley.

title: Analyst Informed by Saddest Experience
description: John Morgan, NBCs bobsled analyst, did not sleep well Friday night. He had gone on the air that afternoon to talk about the death of the Georgian luger Nodar Kumaritashvili on the Olympic sliding track, displaying the authority he had gained from a lifetime in the sliding sports.

title: U.S. Women Rout China in Hockey Opener
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  To the surprise of no one, including dozens of cheering, flag-waving Chinese fans, the American womens hockey team, in its first game of these Olympics, breezed to a 12-1 victory over China on Sunday.

title: Politicians as News Analysts Raise Questions on Their Goal
description: Sarah Palin. Mike Huckabee. Newt Gingrich.

title: Expecting a Surge in U.S. Medical Schools
description: Peter Allen applied to 30 medical schools after graduating from the University of Pittsburgh last year. Twenty-eight said no.

title: Older and Better, Chinese Couple Dominates Pairs Short Program
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Shen Xue and Zhao Hongbo, pairs figure skaters from China, did not have to be at these Olympic Games.

title: Local TV for Devices on the Move
description: Who has time to sit on the couch and watch TV anymore? In the last 10 years, broadcasters have lost 25 percent of their audience. So to win back some viewers, the industry has a plan to grab their attention while they are on the move.

title: Weather and Luck Turn Bad for Bjorndalen
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Ole Einar Bjorndalen pushed out of the start for his fifth Olympics, his arms and skis working in hard-wired harmony, and the announcer at Whistler Olympic Park made sure everyone knew who was on the course: The king of biathlonnnnn!

title: Learning to Climb New York Citys Trees
description: In New York, a city where tree climbing in public parks is officially considered disorderly conduct, the art of hauling yourself skyward, branch by branch, may be endangered for children and adults alike. Add the modern diversions of mobile gadgets and video games and, as Idiongo Okoro said, you never really notice the trees.

title: Scratch-Off Hopes Come in a New Aesthetic: Black
description: As an advertising executive, Leo Mamorsky has promoted instant scratch-off tickets for two decades. But last spring, when New Yorks lottery commissioner requested a campaign for a sleek, jet black $5 ticket, the ad man found himself at a loss.

title: Knicks Said to Renew McGrady Bid, but Math May Not Work
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Four days before the N.B.A.s trading deadline, the Knicks have renewed efforts to acquire the former All-Star Tracy McGrady from the Houston Rockets, according to two people close to the talks.

title: A Map of Olympic Medals
description: A breakdown of medals that countries have won in Olympic Games.

title: U.S. Housing Aid Winds Down, and Cities Worry
description: ELKHART, Ind.  Over the next six months, the federal government plans to wind down many of its emergency programs for housing. Then it will become clear if the market can function on its own.

title: China Grooms Team to Become a Powerhouse
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  As Wang Meng, Chinas champion short-track speedskater, breezed through her first heat of the 500 meters Saturday night, she stayed well ahead of a crash that wiped out a competitor, set an Olympic record, then walked dismissively past waiting Chinese reporters.

title: Taking a Texas Primary Ever Further to the Right
description: HOUSTON  Some days it is hard to be a neophyte far-right candidate in a governors race, even in Texas, where Republicans vying for the partys nomination try to outdo one another to prove their conservative credentials.

title: Snowboarders Report Poor Halfpipe Condition
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  As snowboarders used phrases like pretty horrible to describe the condition of the halfpipe after days of warm weather and rain, Olympic officials said Sunday night that they had deemed the conditions at Cypress Mountain unsafe for some spectators. As a result, they canceled 8,000 tickets for the snowboard cross events scheduled for Monday and Tuesday.

title: Editors Note
description: In a number of business articles in The Times over the past year, and in posts on the DealBook blog on NYTimes.com, a Times reporter appears to have improperly appropriated wording and passages published by other news organizations.

title: Johnson Retains His Title With Birdie on Final Hole
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  After a long, hard slog around Pebble Beach on Sunday, five and a half hours of taking the lead and giving it away in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, it all came down to whether one of the longest hitters in golf could win with his short game.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the increasing costs of Internet connectivity and entertainment may have left an incorrect impression about the cost of a subscription to Xbox Live. It is $50 a year, not a month.

title: Though Absent, Apple Permeates Barcelona Fair
description: The biggest gathering of the global mobile phone industry begins on Monday in Barcelona, and much of the talk will be about the company that is not there: Apple.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a critical audit of the mens basketball program at Binghamton University misstated the year the team moved up to Division I. And the Sports of The Times column on Friday, also about the report, gave another incorrect year for the move. Binghamton became a Division I school in 2001  not in 1991 or in 2006.

title: The Making of a Euromess
description: Lately, financial news has been dominated by reports from Greece and other nations on the European periphery. And rightly so.

title: Despite Budgets, Some Newsrooms Persist in Costly Fight for Records
description: Last fall Hearst, the big media company that owns newspapers, magazines and television stations, filed a lawsuit against the Texas governors office, seeking access to a clemency report in the case of Cameron Todd Willingham, who was executed in 2004 but whose guilt is now in doubt.

title: In Wake of a Beating That Guards Watched, Seattle Tries to Mend Its Image
description: SEATTLE  It was just a few months ago that no one would have been in the Downtown Seattle Transit Tunnel at 7:14 on a weeknight. Surveillance video would probably have shown a station platform empty after having just closed, instead of the brutal beating that has left this city scrambling to repair its kind, caring image.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Friday with an article about New Yorks decision to keep parts of Broadway closed to vehicular traffic misidentified the photographer. The picture of people along a stretch of the pedestrian plaza in Times Square was taken by Damon Winter of The Times, not by Ozier Muhammad.

title: U.S. Hockey G.M.  Burke Balances Grieving and the Games
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Brian Burke, the general manager of the United States mens hockey team, stood in front of a large group of reporters after the teams introductory news conference Sunday and faced the question he knew would come.

title: Charges in Web Video Bring Unusual Rebuttal From F.D.I.C.
description: WASHINGTON  All week long, officials at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation watched with growing dismay as a YouTube video ricocheted around the Internet. In 4 minutes 26 seconds, the clip asserted that the agencys sale last year of the assets of the failed bank IndyMac to a group of private investors was a sweetheart deal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a family forced apart by immigration law misspelled the name of the city in Ecuador where the United States consulate denied the man a visa, saying the couple, Elizabeth and Segundo Encalada, had a marriage of convenience. It is Guayaquil, not Guyaquil.

title: Links Between Charity and State Senators Staff
description: This article is by Nicholas Confessore, William K. Rashbaum and Ray Rivera.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Thursday, about life on a snowy winter day in northern Westchester, misspelled, in some copies, part of the name of a deli in Chappaqua. It is Langes Little Store and Deli, not Langs.

title: Seven Paragraphs
description: There are times when governments fight to keep documents secret to protect sensitive intelligence or other vital national security interests. And there are times when they are just trying to cover up incompetence, misbehavior or lawbreaking.

title: With the Stroke of a Pen, Honoring the Little Known, if Only for a Day
description: They honor stickball tournaments and dance teachers, doughnut-store openings or New Yorkers reaching the century mark. They spread good will, honor bravery and service, and cement political alliances.

title: Fleming Slightly Hurt After Accident in Biden Motorcade
description: Update | 11:12 p.m. VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Figure skating great Peggy Fleming and the former bobsled champion Vonetta Flowers received minor injuries when a van carrying them in Vice President Joe Bidens motorcade was involved in a traffic accident at the Olympics on Sunday.

title: Anger Leads to Apology From Google About Buzz
description: Google moved quickly over the weekend to try to contain mounting criticism of Buzz, its social network, apologizing to users for features that were widely seen as endangering privacy and announcing product changes to address those concerns.

title: Wait Ends as Canada Wins Gold at Home
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Three men stood in the sea of red at Cypress Mountain on Sunday, their chests bare except for paint. Euphoria surrounded them, men and women, young and old, who waved Canadian flags and clanged cowbells and danced to the Black Eyed Peas.

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Sports Briefing column on Feb. 4 about a horse racing bankruptcy filing in New Jersey misidentified the entity that filed for Chapter 11 protection. It was Ahmed Zayats Zayat Stables, not Ahmed Zayat personally.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about the hiring of John A. Thain as chairman and chief executive of the CIT Group misstated the role of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in his selection. While the F.D.I.C. was consulted by CIT about Mr. Thains hiring, it did not clear the appointment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about United States lugers who used the San Diego Air & Space Technology Centers Low Speed Wind Tunnel to test drag on their suits misstated the speed of the wind-generating fans blades. They spun at up to 800 rotations a minute, not a second.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE
