title: Haiti Emerges From Its Shock, and Tears Roll
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Will anyone remember that 17-year-old Angelania Ritchelle, a parentless high school student who wanted to be a fashion model, died of fright two days after the earthquake and ended up in a mass grave on the outskirts of this city?

title: A Fine Line When Ads and Children Mix
description: When an arts and crafts company placed an ad in Discovery Girls magazine for Tulip Glam-It-Up iron-on crystals, it hardly seemed controversial. The ad, which ran last summer, showed a young girl wearing a T-shirt swirled with paint and crystals. I glam rock it up, the girl was saying.

title: Opposition in Iran Meets a Crossroads on Strategy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Many of Irans opposition supporters expected last Thursday to be a moment of climactic triumph, with calls for a vast street protest on the 31st anniversary of the countrys Islamic Revolution.

title: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Getzlafs 4-Point Night Proves Hes Fit for Canada
description: Six games on Sunday, the last day of N.H.L. games before the league goes on hiatus for the Olympics. The biggest news comes all the way West in Anaheim, where Ryan Getzlaf returned to action after an ankle injury that left him doubtful for Canada at the Winter Games. Home teams listed first:

title: Lottery Numbers
Modest Beginning Propels Czech Victory in Speedskating
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The long-track speedskater Martina Sablikova grew up training on a frozen pond in southern Moravia, which many of her peers from other countries found endlessly amusing. At the elite level, it was virtually unheard of, like a basketball team preparing for an N.B.A. game by practicing on outdoor asphalt courts.

title: Rabbi Bernard Lander, the Founder of Touro College, Is Dead at 94
description: Rabbi Bernard Lander, the founder and only president of Touro College, a Jewish-sponsored institution of higher learning that began four decades ago in Manhattan with a class of 35 and today educates thousands of students in 29 locations around the world, died on Monday in Flushing, N.Y. He was 94 and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Obama Stays Course, but the Winds Change
description: In an interview, Barack Obama declared: I am a pro-growth, free market guy. I love the market. I think it is the best invention to allocate resources and produce enormous prosperity for America or the world thats ever been designed.

title: The Year in Foreclosures
description: Last week offered some sobering news on the housing market: Even with broad government support for housing, data from the National Association of Realtors showed that the median price of single-family homes continued to decline in 2009. RealtyTrac, an online marketer of foreclosed properties, said foreclosure filings rose by 15 percent in January compared with a year ago.

title: 7-Year-Old Samba Queen Raises Adult Concerns
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Monica and Marco Lira had joked that, one day, their third-grade daughter would dance her heart out as a drum corps queen in Rios annual Carnaval samba competition, which is seen by tens of thousands of paradegoers and millions more television viewers.

title: Obama Stays Course, but the Winds Change
description: In an interview, Barack Obama declared: I am a pro-growth, free market guy. I love the market. I think it is the best invention to allocate resources and produce enormous prosperity for America or the world thats ever been designed.

title: Australian Men Sentenced for Terrorism Plot
description: HONG KONG  An Australian court on Monday sentenced five Muslim men to prison terms of 23 to 28 years for conspiracy to commit acts of terror, according to reports from ABC Radio and news agencies.

title: A Separate Label for Aspergers
description: To the Editor:

title: Waste Land on the East Side? Eliot Did Read It There
description: To the Editor:

title: TB in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Recorders in Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: What a Church Is Not for: Violent Fighting
description: To the Editor:

title: A Music Industry Case
description: To the Editor:

title: 9/11 From Above
description: In the days and weeks immediately after Sept. 11, there was, in many people, a deep hunger to see and see again what happened as the World Trade Center towers burned and then fell, a hunger fed by disbelief and shock. But as the years have passed, 9/11 has resolved itself into a collection of core images  photos, impressions, memories  whether you were in Manhattan that day or not.

title: Respect for Women in Uniform
description: The Pentagons decision to begin making so-called morning-after emergency contraception available at military bases around the world marked welcome, if overdue, progress in meeting the health needs of women serving the United States in the military.

title: Lets Make a Deal
description: High-profile summit meetings flop more often than they succeed. But Barack Obamas promised health care conference with Republican leaders, if it actually comes off, promises to be a particularly depressing exercise in grandstanding and gamesmanship.

title: George Washingtons Tear-Jerker
description: CIVILIAN control of the military is a cherished principle in American government. It was President Obama who decided to increase our involvement in Afghanistan, and it is Congress that will decide whether to appropriate the money to carry out his decision. It is the president and Congress, not the military, that will decide whether our laws should be changed to allow gays and lesbians to serve in our armed forces. The military advises, but the civilian leadership decides.

title: Seeking to Save a Gym That Saved Young Lives
description: When Frankie Garriga talks about what the Morris Park Boxing Club has meant to him, he takes on the air of Marlon Brandos slightly punchy Terry Malloy in On the Waterfront. Boxing, he hopes, will make him a somebody.

title: Leader Raises Eyebrows by Following His Muse
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, the Indonesian president, recently released a new album of pop music titled Im Sure Ill Get There. Though well received, the album  his third since becoming president  has not lifted him from the political doldrums.

title: Obstructed View
description: Canadians and tourists journey to the Olympic torch, and are disappointed.

title: A Comeback for Credit Card Come-Ons
description: After three quarters of near-paralyzing caution, credit card issuers last quarter increased the number of offers they were sending out to American households. But last quarters volume is still small compared with the final quarter of 2008, when issuers sent out 668.1 million offers, according to Synovate, a market research company that gathered the data using a representative, rotating monthly panel of 3,500 households.

title: Clinton Pleads for Patience at U.S.-Islamic World Forum
description: DOHA, Qatar  Nine months after President Obama held out the promise of a new beginning for the United States and the Muslim world, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton came to this Persian Gulf emirate on Sunday to plead for patience, conceding that the Obama administration had not yet delivered on some of its signature foreign-policy goals.

title: Approval of Airline Deal Puts Pressure on Europe
description: PARIS  The approval by United States regulators of a deal to expand the alliance between British Airways and American Airlines puts added pressure on Europes new antitrust boss to follow suit before a new round of trans-Atlantic aviation talks on the so-called Open Skies agreement, analysts said Sunday.

title: After 9/11 Trial Plan, Holder Hones Political Ear
description: WASHINGTON  Last winter, when Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. called the United States a nation of cowards for avoiding frank conversations on race, President Obama mildly rebuked him in public.

title: Holder Interview Excerpts
description: On Tuesday, February 9, The Times's Charlie Savage and Jodi Kantor interviewed Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in preparation for a profile of him. The following are excerpts:

title: Looking Ahead
description: A HOLIDAY WEEK Markets, government offices and many businesses are closed in the United States in observance of Presidents Day (Monday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes an aution of four-week bills on Wednesday and an auction of new three- and six-month bills next Monday.

title: Forecast: The Downhill, Hopefully
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Rain poured on the Alpine ski courses. The first freestyle skiing event took place on a swatch of snow moved there by snowplows, trucks and helicopters. On Sunday, Vancouver was substantially warmer (52 degrees Fahrenheit, or 11 Celsius) than Dallas (41 Fahrenheit, or 5 Celsius).

title: Smarter Sensors Start Going to Work
description: In the last couple of years, the research laboratories at companies like Hewlett-Packard and Intel have been working on the next generation of digital sensors. They are smarter, smaller, consume less energy, and they can communicate wirelessly.

title: Prabal Gurung: In Fashion's Spotlight
description: After attending Parsons and working for Bill Blass, Prabal Gurung started his own line. He discussed his fall 2010 collection, shown at New York Fashion Week, with The Times's Eric Wilson.

title: At Shared Offices, How Green Is My Work Space
description: Hunched over their computers on a recent afternoon, two brothers were sketching plans to build a green roof for an elementary school in Brooklyn. One row and three desks away, a woman was working on an environmentally friendly fashion project, a little black dress that can be worn 365 ways.

title: Boys Leg Is Severed in Tunnel on N Line
description: A teenagers leg was severed by a train while he was in a Brooklyn subway tunnel on Saturday night, planning to paint graffiti with two other boys, the authorities said.

title: No Standing-Room Access to Snowboard Cross
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Olympic organizers canceled 8,000 standing-room tickets for the mens and womens snowboard cross after heavy rains turned viewing areas into sinkholes.

title: East Wins by 2, but the Biggest Number Is 108,713
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Before the floodlights flickered on, before the speakers boomed and the building echoed with oohs, the first gawking spectators entered Cowboys Stadium on Sunday afternoon.

title: James as a Knick Wont Help MSG
description: The formidable skills of LeBron James probably wont reach the stock market. Speculation is rampant he could soon be headed to the New York Knicks basketball team, whose owner is now trading on the Nasdaq.

title: Phillip Martin, Who Led His Tribe to Wealth, Is Dead at 83
description: Phillip Martin, a former chief of the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians, who guided his tribe from grinding poverty in the red clay hills of east central Mississippi to become proprietor of one of the states leading business empires, died Feb. 4 in Jackson, Miss. He was 83 and lived in Philadelphia, Miss.

title: Three Nominees for Whos Next
description: Joseph Altuzarra is a Swarthmore-educated Paris-bred son of an American mother and a French father. Prabal Gurung grew up in Katmandu and trained at Bill Blass. At 25, Alexander Wang is the hitmaker of contemporary urban fashion, his $25-million business already surpassing that of many established designers.

title: Bidens Motorcade in  Accident; Peggy Fleming Hurt
description: The Timess Rings blog has word of an accident involving Vice President Joseph R. Bidens motorcade in Vancouver, which injured the former skating star Peggy Fleming.

title: For the Well (and Amply) Dressed Guy
description: In a cab, on the way to the Rag & Bone show, the off button on the Taxi TV wasnt working, thereby subjecting this passenger to repeated viewings of that annoying commercial for the Barneys Warehouse sale.

title: Extreme Clutter Hampers Firefighters in Fatal Harlem Blaze
description: One person died Sunday night in Harlem when a fire swept through an apartment and firefighters were delayed because of debris inside, the Fire Department said.

title: Neighborhoods, Up Close and Personal
description: Each time the city sits for its portrait, census figures reveal an ever-changing metropolis.

title: Kenyan President Blocks Prime Ministers Suspension of 2 High-Ranking Officials
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya seemed headed for another political tangle on Sunday after the prime minister suspended two high-ranking ministers recently implicated in multimillion-dollar corruption scandals and the president immediately annulled the suspensions.

title: News Quiz | February 15, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Swider-Peltz Is Standing by Her Daughter
description: Nancy Swider-Peltz Jr. took her first lap around an Olympic oval when she was 13 months old. She was in the arms of her mother, who became the first American to qualify for four Winter Games when she made the United States team that competed in the 1988 Calgary Olympics in between feeding her daughter.

title: For High-Profile Coach, Its All About the Quadruple Jump
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Yevgeny Plushenko, the reigning Olympic champion, has snubbed reporters since arriving last week, saying he would not speak until the mens short program on Tuesday.

title: Behind the Scenes: The Sorrow of Section 60
description: Larry Downing and his wife, Angelica, first visited Arlington National Cemetery together last Memorial Day. As they walked around Section 60, they saw Laura Youngblood place flowers on the gravestone of Petty Officer Third Class Travis L. Youngblood and then lie down on the ground next to it. Mr. Downing raised his point-and-shoot camera and made a single frame, just as she reached out and brushed the word husband with the tip of her finger.

title: Oh Yoko!
description: "The Plastic Ono Band fell together in 1969 when John Lennon and Yoko Ono wanted to record. It was the loose aggregation that knocked out 'Give Peace a Chance' in a Montreal hotel room," Jon Pareles writes. "Ms. Ono's vocals  discordant yips and shrieks  were more avant-garde than most Beatles fans preferred, and she turned to more conventional songwriting as she continued to make albums. She left behind the Plastic Ono Band moniker in the mid-1970s but reclaimed it in the 2000s as she re-emerged." Ms. Ono has since convened a new Plastic Ono Band and for the concert "We are Plastic Ono Band," at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the lineup includes Sean Ono Lennon, Yuka Honda from Cibo Matto and two Japanese electronic musicians, Haruomi Hosono (from the Yellow Magic Orchestra) and Cornelius as well as performances by unnamed original members of the 1960s group  an appearance by Eric Clapton has been rumored. The show on Tuesday is already sold out, but tonight go listen to a special "dress rehearsal" beginning at 8 p.m.

title: Monday at the Met
description: Thank the presidents for giving the Metropolitan Museum of Art an excuse to stay open on a Monday. Today, spend some time with one of the smaller exhibitions that might on a normal day get overlooked. For instance, "Cinnabar: The Chinese Art of Carved Lacquer," which runs through Feb. 21. "The exhibition's approximately 50 carved lacquer dishes, platters, boxes, vases and other domestic objects  including a spectacular folding screen  are as engrossing for their formal beauty as for their amazing craftsmanship," writes Ken Johnson. The pigment cinnabar gives them a rich, dark red color, and intricate patterns, ornamental animals and pastoral vignettes carved and incised into their lustrous surfaces make every object a pleasure to behold."

title: Olympics Fever
description: O Canada! Our usually modest neighbors to the north are trying to boost national pride with a serious hunt for gold  the country's spent $118 million to enhance the performance of Canadian athletes, or "syrup suckers" in the words of Stephen Colbert. Head to Van Diemens in Murray Hill to see how that investment is paying off. The bar is televising the Vancouver Olympic games through Feb. 28 and offering $12 pitchers and $18 buckets of signature Canadian brews like Molson and Labatt Blue. Check out the Canadian Association of New York for hockey schedules and more events.

title: U.S. Figure Skaters Making Olympic Commute
description: The American figure skaters Rachael Flatt and Mirai Nagasu are planning to stay in Vancouver for just a few days, long enough to get their Olympic gear and to speak to reporters.

title: Clinton Raises U.S. Concerns of Military Power in Iran
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The United States fears that Iran is drifting toward a military dictatorship, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Monday, with the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps seizing control of large swaths of Irans political, military and economic establishment.

title: No Hotel, No Fur
description: Johnny Weir, the three-time United States national champion, had considered staying in a hotel during the Vancouver Games after a bad experience in the athletes village in Turin, Italy, four years ago.

title: Indonesia: Obama Statue Moved From Public Park
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A statue of President Barack Obama as a 10-year-old boy was transferred Monday from a public park here to an elementary school that Mr. Obama attended as a child. The removal of the statue came after criticism of its placement by Indonesian users of Facebook.

title: Half of Towns Taliban Flee or Are Killed, Allies Say
description: NAD ALI, Afghanistan  As heavy fighting in the insurgent stronghold of Marja carried into its third day, the number of Taliban fighters in the area has dropped by about half, American and Afghan commanders said Monday.

title: A Many-Splendored Thing
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have been generous in sharing their definitions of love  from the moving to the mawkish.

title: Trains Collide Head-On in Belgium
description: PARIS  A head-on collision between trains outside Brussels during the morning rush on Monday killed at least 18 people and injured 80, a police spokesman said, in Belgiums deadliest railroad accident in more than 25 years.

title: Beyond Controversy at Tates Ofili Exhibition
description: Chris Ofili, the artist best known for colorful pieces that incorporate unusual elements like elephant dung, is being honored with an exhibition at Tate Britain, through May 16  45 paintings that survey his work from the mid-90s to the present day.

title: Intel and Nokia Team Up on Mobile Software
description: BARCELONA, Spain  If the wildest dreams of Intel and Nokia come true, well be talking about the market-shaping might of NokTel for years to come.

title: Back Home With Hillary
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Onward and  | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: The Dresden Debate Wont Die
description: Todays idea: Sixty-five years after the bombing of Dresden and other German cities during World War II, debate festers over whether the intention was to kill as many civilians as possible.

title: State of the Cardinals: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Military Brings 43 Alleged Rebels to Court in Manila
description: MANILA  The Philippine military, stung by new criticism over reported human rights abuses, brought to court on Monday the 43 health workers it arrested 10 days ago, insisting they were members of the communist New Peoples Army who were being trained to make bombs.

title: Snowboard Cross: What to Expect
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The soft snow on the snowboard cross course could make Mondays mens competition even more exciting than usual. The American favorite Nate Holland predicted a rough-and-tumble set of races, which will culminate in a four-man chase for the gold medal.

title: He Drives to Compete, So He Files Suit
description: Last year, the Albany legislature levied a new tariff on most of the businesses in the New York City region. The Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Mobility Tax  requires employers to set aside 34 cents for every $100 in payroll costs, and hand the money over to a battered, barely breathing patient on the states fiscal operating table: the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: College Students, the New Cash Cows
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: More Shoppers Go Online, Hungry for Deals
description: If online shoppers do not get a deal and free shipping, they are unlikely to make a purchase.

title: Not Yet Rivals, Gillibrand and Ford Wage Shadow Attack Campaigns
description: ALBANY  At times, it seems that Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand and her potential rival in the Democratic primary, former Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., have two different relationships.

title: The Early Word: Washingtons Birthday
description: Its the 278th anniversary of President George Washingtons birthday, a federal holiday for most workers.

title: Mammograms and Severe Dementia
description: Im trying, with some difficulty, to imagine myself as a woman in her 80s, someone with such advanced cognitive impairment that I can correctly answer fewer than a third of the questions on a commonly used test. I might not know who the president is, or what day or date it is; I might not be able to remember a few nouns the test giver just recited. Asked the question, What is the object used to cut paper? I might not be able to come up with the word scissors.

title: Rethinking My Meeting Strategy
description: I recently implemented a formal set of procedures to evaluate key business metrics. We are using an Excel spreadsheet to capture the data that is then funneled into an executive dashboard that gives me a snapshot view of what is happening at any point in time. I look forward to seeing how this tool scales and evolves as we grow.

title: Rules, Glorious Rules
description: Do not attempt to mess with documentarians. They will seek out the truth or make an entertaining account of trying. Ditto the Academys documentary branch, a particular stickler for rules when it comes to choosing the best film of the year.

title: Its Pizza Oscar for Bianco, Says Rachael Ray
description: A tough loss for New York pizza supremacy, as Pizzeria Bianco of Phoenix has been awarded the title Best Pizza in America by the magazine Every Day With Rachael Ray, according to Lois Najarian ONeill, a publicist for the television personality. Ms. Ray commissioned the Serious Eats founder Ed Levine and his Slice blog compatriot Adam Kuban to conduct the competition, which involved their eating at some 64 pizzerias across the United States.

title: Gains in Global Wind Capacity Reported
description: The Global Wind Energy Council, a trade association based in Brussels, estimates that wind power capacity grew by 31 percent worldwide in 2009, with 37.5 additional gigawatts installed, bringing global wind power capacity to 157.9 gigawatts.

title: What Matters Most?
description: Ecoartspace, an organization that focuses on addressing environmental issues through the visual arts (the image below, from a 2009 exhibition, is by Nils-Udo), got in touch with me recently about a planned spring exhibition of small works on paperdevoted toa simple question: What matters most?

title: Pope Meets Irish Bishops to Discuss Clergy Abuse
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVI began meeting individually with 24 serving Irish bishops on Monday to discuss a clerical abuse scandal that has rocked the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland.

title: JW Marriott Opens in Downtown Los Angeles
description: Downtown Los Angeles continues its renaissance from urban blight to tourist site with todays opening of the JW Marriott Hotel Los Angeles, featuring 878 luxurious rooms, a rooftop bar and three floors of ballrooms.

title: WWS 543: Class notes, 2/15/10
description: The political economy of trade policy, here.(pdf)

title: Microsoft Starts Over in Phone Software
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The frenetic pace of the mobile phone industry has forced some of the technology worlds largest players to make a break with the past.

title: Nascars Good Ol Days, and the Tracks That Provided the Charm
description: My first Daytona 500 was in 1973, when I drove down from Indianapolis with Donald Davidson, who is today the historian for the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. We came home with a pile of stock car racing souvenirs, a bushel of jumbo navel oranges, a country ham and a savvy selection of barbecue sauces.

title: Can You Keep a Child Too Safe?
description: In the City section of The Times yesterday, my colleague Ariel Kaminer describes childproofing her apartment now that her 13-month-old daughter has learned to walk.

title: How Wall Street Helped Mask Europes Debt
description: Wall Street tactics akin to the ones that fostered subprime mortgages in America have worsened the financial crisis shaking Greece and undermining the euro by enabling European governments to hide their mounting debts, The New York Timess Louise Story, Landon Thomas Jr. and Nelson D. Schwartz reported on Sunday.

title: Will Steady Resolve Land Lysacek the Gold?
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  When the figure skating coach Frank Carroll first saw Evan Lysacek perform, he marveled at him.

title: Bedford to Once Again Direct, Don a Dress in Earnest
description: The actor Brian Bedford will direct a new Broadway production of Oscar Wildes comedy The Importance of Being Earnest next season for Roundabout Theater Company, while also donning a dress and wig to play the domineering Lady Bracknell in the show.

title: Fertilizer Maker to Buy Terra for $4.1 Billion
description: A Norwegian fertilizer producer, Yara International, agreed on Monday to buy Iowa-based Terra Industries for $4.1 billion to increase its presence in the United States, as rivals look to join forces to gain size and reach, Reuters reported.

title: Ask About the History of Complaining in New York
description: This week, Matthew Bakkom, the editor and creator of New York City Museum of Complaint, a collection of 132 letters written to the mayor of New York from 1751 to 1969, will responded to readers questions about communiqus of dissatisfaction over the course of the citys evolution.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: F.D.I.C. Pushes Back at Charges in YouTube Video
description: All week long, officials at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation watched with growing dismay as a YouTube video ricocheted around the Internet. In 4 minutes 26 seconds, the clip asserted that the agencys sale last year of the assets of the failed bank IndyMac to a group of private investors was a sweetheart deal.

title: Bharti Airtel Bids for Zains African Phone Customers
description: Bharti Airtel, the largest Indian mobile phone company by subscribers, confirmed on Monday that it is in talks to buy the African assets of the Kuwaiti telecom company Zain for about $10.7 billion, The New York Timess Heather Timmons reported on Monday.

title: Bayh Decides Against Re-election Bid
description: Update | 2:38 p.m.  Senator Evan Bayh, the Indiana Democrat, said today that he would not seek a third term in Congress, a move that gives Republicans yet another opportunity to pick up a Senate seat and gives Democrats some fresh anxiety about whether they are losing the partys center.

title: Greek Statistician Is Caught in Limelight
description: As the head of a once obscure Greek agency churning out government data, Manolis Kontopirakis never sought the limelight that has suddenly come his way, after his countrys financial woes touched off a global storm that threatens to tear the euro zone apart, The New York Timess Dan Bilefsky and Niki Kitsantonis reported on Sunday.

title: Jamie McMurray Wins Daytona 500 as Track Crumbles
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr. nearly won the Daytona 500  dream scenario for Nascar, right?  before he ran out of track, and Jamie McMurray claimed victory.

title: Greece Pressed to Take Action on Economic Woes
description: BRUSSELS  New questions emerged Monday about the reliability of Greek statistics  this time over its austerity package  prompting the European Union to call for further measures to ensure that Greece pulls out of its budget crisis.

title: Less Is More
description: During your post-Valentines Day hangover, its only appropriate to learn that the producers of the Oscars, Adam Shankman and Bill Mechanic, act like an old married couple. Strangers when Mr. Mechanic called Mr. Shankmans agent to offer the shared assignment last fall, the two producers, for the record, are now finishing each others sentences, Michael Cieply wrote this weekend. And the two dont always agree about what theyre saying.

title: Now Screening | Diane Von Furstenberg
description: The fall 2010 collection from Diane Von Furstenberg.

title: Echoes of a Past Expulsion Fight in Monserrate Case
description: As legal scholars and state legislators debate the constitutionality of expelling Hiram Monserrate from the State Senate last week, there is a similar case worth noting, both for the legal precedent it established and the political lessons it holds.

title: Helping Governments Deceive
description: In the aftermath of the Enron crisis, we learned that Wall Street firms had been helping Enron deceive investors by lending money to it through convoluted structures that were intended to let Enron claim they were not really loans, and that the company was therefore less indebted than it was. In return, Enron paid interest rates that were higher than it would have faced on a normal loan.

title: Adri Elaborates on El Bullis Future
description: After shocking the food world on Friday by telling  The New York Times that in 2014 El Bulli would become a foundation for culinary study, and not a restaurant, the avant-garde Catalan chef Ferran Adri now says that the public may have more opportunities for meals at El Bulli than he had indicated at first.

title: NBC: Death Unites Luge Community
description: As the games get underway, the death of Georgian luger Nodar Kumaritashvili is bringing members of the luge community together in a way they couldn't have expected.

title: Monday Puzzle: The Case of the Carnival Cups
description: Welcome to the season of wild and crazy celebrations. From Valentines Day yesterday, we pass on to Mardi Gras (or Carnival) tomorrow. In some countries like Brazil, Carnival is already well under way. Now the word carnival in the United States is also used to denote a traveling assemblage of entertainments, rides and games, like a country fair (or as it is called in other parts of the world, a funfair or fte). Todays puzzle story is set in such a scene. Both the puzzle and the storyline are original contributions of our All-Star puzzle solver, Tom Enrico from Sandy, Utah. Here is Toms story:

title: Bucking a Trend, Grizzlies Hit the Offensive Boards
description: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com.

title: Bernstein on the Mystery Behind the Music
description: Imagine this: you drop onto the sofa on a Sunday afternoon, switch on the TV and see a dapper young man with a baton standing before an orchestra and demonstrating the patterns conductors use to lead music in different meters  two, three, four and five beats to the bar. He directs his players in a few examples, bits of Beethovens Ninth and Schuberts Eighth Symphonies, Prokofievs Peter and the Wolf, Waldteufels Skaters Waltz. Then he ups the ante, showing how these simple gestures, with subtle modification, are used to coax a fluid, lyrical performance; a playful reading; or an urgently dramatic interpretation from an orchestra.

title: F.C.I.N.O.
description: Initialism for Fiscal Conservative in Name Only, applied to Senatorial candidate Tom Campbell (R-CA).

title: The Future Bailouts of America
description: As Washington spins its wheels on financial reform, its becoming painfully clear that the problem of entities that are too interconnected or too politically powerful to fail is also too hard for our policy makers to tackle, The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest column.

title: Self-Promotional Blather
description: We interrupt this blog for a moment of shameless self-promotion. Two things coming up that I thought I should mention. First is that this Thursday, Feb. 18, at 9:30 pm, HBO will show a documentary about me, called Reporter. It was filmed during my 2007 win-a-trip journey to Congo and looks at such larger issues such as how we can get American audiences to care about distant tragedies. The documentary was made by Eric Metzgar, and exec-produced by Ben Affleck. I stayed out of the decision-making, since I dont know a thing about film, but it came out very well. It gives you a chance to tag along on my reporting, including the opportunity to join a dinner I had with a warlord in the bush. It conveys the texture of the kind of reporting I often do.

title: Overcome the Fear of Frying
description: Health-conscious people have a fear of frying  certainly I have felt the aversion. You have to use fat to fry, and many of us think of fat as a root cause of poor health.

title: Wall Street and Greece: Shades of Enron
description: From Floyd Norris on Notions on High and Low Finance:

title: Fighting to Keep Guns Off Campuses
description: Are guns allowed on your campus?

title: NBC Video: Gretzky Lights Olympic Way
description: Canada's Wayne Gretzky speaks with Today's Matt Lauer about lighting the Game's Cauldron at the Opening Ceremony and previews Olympic hockey.

title: Lily Tomlin and Jane Wagner Climb Aboard Pink Carpet
description: The gay power-couple Lily Tomlin and Jane Wagner are climbing aboard the theatrical presenter bandwagon: They have joined the producing team of the coming Off Broadway show My Trip Down the Pink Carpet, written by and starring Leslie Jordan.

title: Missionaries Go to Haiti, Followed by Scrutiny
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Their holy books vary widely and so does their disaster apparel. Devotees of Supreme Master Ching Hai, a Vietnamese spiritual leader, wore fluorescent yellow vests on their way into quake-damaged Haiti. Mormons wore their trademark white shirts and ties. And an array of others  Scientologists, Presbyterians, Lutherans, Jews and Muslims  each printed T-shirts of a different hue declaring which faith had inspired them to help save Haiti.

title: Unlikely Swiss Wins Gold in Downhill
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Less than a week ago, Didier Defago did not know if he would qualify for the mens Olympic downhill. He had not yet earned one of Switzerlands four spots in the field. Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway, the defending World Cup overall champion, had not won a downhill for nearly a year. That was better than Bode Miller. He had not won a downhill in almost two years.

title: Freeing Quarks and Gluons
description: Physicists melted protons and neutrons in the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in an effort to create quark-gluon plasma.

title: Mavericks Surf Contest Is a Lesson in Natures Power
description: If Saturdays Mavericks Surf Contest taught us anything, it was that everyone involved must be prepared. For anything.

title: Happy Now? to Be Extended
description: The Off Broadway production of Lucinda Coxons play Happy Now? at Primary Stages will be extended for two weeks, through March 21, executives of the not-for-profit theater company announced on Monday. The production of the new play, about a professional London woman dealing with the pressures of life, received generally positive reviews, with Charles Isherwood of The Times calling it a trenchant comedy with a skilled, appealing cast. The production is running at the 59E59 Theaters in Manhattan.

title: Photos of the Moment | Diane von Furstenberg
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: NBC Video: Ohno Savoring Olympic Journey
description: Once the brash young kid who captured the world's attention in Salt Lake City, Apolo Anton Ohno has grown into his role as the elder statesman of the American short track team.

title: The Case for Slow Money
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November. A version of this post originally appeared on Mr. Richards site.

title: A Models Prospects: Slim and None
description: I dont do nudes, I dont do semi-nudes, I dont do cigarette shots, Coco Rocha was saying on Sunday evening before the Diane Von Furstenberg show at the Bryant Park tents. It took me a long time in the business to realize I didnt have to do everything people told me I should if I wanted a career.

title: Trafficking Charges for Adviser to Jailed Americans in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As the 10 Americans imprisoned in Haiti for trying to remove children from the country awaited a decision on their fate Monday, the legal woes of the man who falsely portrayed himself as the groups lawyer mounted.

title: Cool Tools | Alessis Essentiel de Patisserie
description: Chefs tools are technical. I want to make them simple for the home cook and to have fewer of them, said Matali Crasset, the French industrial designer. Crasset, who worked with Philippe Starck for five years before starting her own studio in 1998, got the opportunity to put her ideas to work when she met with Alberto Alessi, the Italian design impresario. When Alessi learned that she had once collaborated on a cake knife with Pierre Herm, the famous Parisian pastry chef, he knew immediately that the three of them had to work on a collection of patisserie tools. Alessi, an accomplished cook, has a passion for pastry. (His favorite recipe is one for torta de panna, a cake made with old bread. You add milk to soften it, then mix in raisins, eggs, chocolate, amaretti and a little grappa. Then you bake it, he instructed.)

title: Bernstein on the Blues
description: A set of instructional appearances Leonard Bernstein made in the 1950s on "Omnibus," a television program about science and the arts, has just been released on DVD.

title: First Look: Carolina Herrera
description: Backstage views of Carolina Herrera's Fall 2010 collection at New York Fashion Week.

title: Bernstein on Opera
description: A set of instructional appearances Leonard Bernstein made in the 1950s on "Omnibus," a television program about science and the arts, has just been released on DVD.

title: Inside the Rings
description: The delays that have wreaked havoc with the Alpine schedule in Whistler may aid Lindsey Vonn's quest for gold.

title: Not Even James Can Assist Madison Square Garden Inc.
description: The formidable skills of LeBron James probably wont reach the stock market, Reuters Breakingviews argues.

title: Barbara Walters Ending Oscar-Night Specials
description: Barbara Walters is calling an end to her annual Oscars interview show. Ms. Walters, 80, said Monday on The View that this years Barbara Walters Special would be her last. Her celebrity sit-downs have been a staple of Academy Awards nights since 1981.

title: Marines Push Ahead on Taliban Stronghold
description: NBC's Sebastian Rich embedded with the Marines during the assault on Marja, Afghanistan, one of the war's largest battles to date.

title: Dancing the Forr
description: Forr, a rustic country dance from northeastern Brazil, has fired the romantic imaginations of Parisians young and old. BizzArt, a club in Paris, hosts a weekly gathering devoted to the Brazilian dance. .

title: Scoring the Olympics | The Olympic Catwalk
description: For anyone expecting the spectacle and precision seen at the Birds Nest in Beijing in 2008, the scene at BC Place Stadium Friday night was positively underwhelming. If Beijing was Michael Bay, Vancouver is Yasujiro Ozu, as understated as Beijing was flashy.

title: Air Liquide Cools Speculation It Will Bid for Airgas
description: PARIS  For now, it appears that the takeover battle between Air Products and Chemicals and Airgas will remain a two-company affair.

title: Pondering N.F.L. Retirement at a Younger Age
description: There seem to be an unusual number of young/middle-aged players contemplating retirement. In all cases, injuries are a factor. Here is a list.

title: NBC Video: Luge Track Changes Needed?
description: Three-time Olympic luger Duncan Kennedy speaks with Today's Meredith Vieira about the deadly luge accident that prompted officials to modify the track for safety reasons.

title: Never Been to El Bulli? Youre Not Alone
description: So El Bulli, as weve all heard by now, will close.

title: In Pelada, Pickup Games Around the World
description: If the director Martin Scorsese can do a horror flick, then next months South by Southwest film festival can serve as the world premiere for a soccer film, Pelada. Right?

title: Photos of the Moment | LnA After-Party
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Greg Kadel.

title: Bras and Cancer
description: Q. Is there any truth to the Internet rumor that the incidence of breast cancer is more than 100 times greater in women who always wear bras than in women who never wear bras?

title: This King-Size Frog Hopped With Dinosaurs
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  Now appearing in the lobby of Stony Brook University Medical Center: a frog that lived in the era of the dinosaurs and is as big as a beach ball. Scientists believe it to be the largest frog ever.

title: Wanted: Volunteers, All Pregnant
description: The woman sent by government scientists visited the Queens apartment repeatedly before finding anyone home. And the person who finally answered the door  a 30-year-old Colombian-born waitress named Alejandra  was wary.

title: Scorecard | Richard Chai Love Wins!
description: Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week opened on Thursday on a tragically somber note. Yet, as they say in show business, the show[s] must go on  so, as ever, Scorecard is here keeping tabs on all the critic talk for you. Amid the eulogies to Alexander McQueen, Erin Wassons magic carpet ride failed to transport, while Richard Chais exquisite tailoring had the fashion cognoscenti feeling that all is love.

title: The Convention Crashers
description: Convention industry insiders disdainfully call them outboarders  those vendors who set up shop in a hotel suite near a trade show site to promote their products.

title: Imitators That Hide in Plain Sight, and Stay Alive
description: In the summer of 1859, an Englishman named Henry Walter Bates returned home after 11 years of roaming the vast Amazon jungle with specimens of more than 14,000 species he had collected.

title: Bigelow to Direct HBO Pilot
description: Charismatic, self-destructive, brilliantly talented: Which Broadway composer does this sound like to you?

title: Competing for Students Who Can Pay
description: My colleagues at the Economix blog have put up an interesting post by an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst exploring the increasing competition for students who can help a schools bottom line.

title: 36 Hours in Vieques
description: THE mascot of Vieques seems to be the coqu, a tiny frog whose image adorns everything from T-shirts to hot sauce bottles. Yet, given the islands rapid metamorphosis from Navy testing ground to upscale beach resort, perhaps a tropical butterfly would be better suited. Since the United States Navy ceased military operations in 2003, this small island just off the east coast of mainland Puerto Rico has seen a boom in restaurants, galleries and hotels, including a new W resort expected next month. Its a testament to the islands natural beauty, with its white-sand beaches, coral reefs and bioluminescent bay.

title: Surgery for Obese Children?
description: HOUSTON  One callous question turned Brittany Caesar into a medical pioneer: Why do you eat so much? Its not normal.

title: Just Looking | Young at Art
description: Leslie Camhi has written about art for numerous publications, including The New York Times and Vogue. She is currently working on a book about the world of Yves Saint Laurent.

title: Hamas Arrests British Journalist in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  A British journalist has been arrested by Hamas authorities in Gaza and detained for 15 days of questioning, Hamas officials said on Monday, citing suspicion of unspecified security offenses.

title: Backstage Beauty | Alexander Wang and Joseph Altuzarra
description: Polished perfection was out, and strung-out was pretty at Alexander Wang and Joseph Altuzarra. Models who looked like theyd partied until just before arriving backstage were given a free pass. I would rather my girls look like they had just left the club than like they were leaving a beauty salon, said the makeup artist (and Este Lauders new Creative Makeup Director) Tom Pecheux at Altuzarra.

title: Barbara Walters Ending Oscar-Night Specials
description: Barbara Walters is calling an end to her annual Oscars interview show. Ms. Walters, 77, said Monday on The View that this years Barbara Walters Special would be her last. Her celebrity sit-downs have been a staple of Academy Awards nights since 1981. Read more on ArtsBeat

title: Arrest Warrant for Floyd Landis
description: PARIS  The United States cyclist Floyd Landis was stripped of his 2006 Tour de France title after testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs, but the fallout from his doping case has lingered.

title: Televisa to Buy 30% Stake in Nextel de Mexico
description: Grupo Televisa, the Mexican broadcaster, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in the Mexican telecommunications unit of NII Holdings for $1.44 billion in cash, Michael J. de la Merced reports in The New York Times.

title: Two Pianos, Four Hands, Many Twists
description: In the 19th century orchestral and chamber works were often transcribed for piano duet so that those who couldnt attend concerts might still hear the latest symphony or opera. These duets were considered more suitable for the parlor than the concert hall, where two virtuoso egos would be uncomfortably squashed together on one piano bench. Four-hand two-piano works had more appeal for the reigning superstars, even allowing them to indulge in some lively onstage one-upmanship.

title: Doctor-Patient Divide on Mammograms
description: Confusion reigned late last year after the United States Preventive Services Task Force changed its recommendations on mammography, suggesting that most women start routine scans at age 50 rather than 40 and reduce the frequency to every two years, from once a year.

title: Empathys Natural, but Nurturing It Helps
description: My grandson Chasen was on a first-grade bus trip when a classmate got carsick. The other children quickly moved away, mumbling words of disgust. Chasen went over, put his arm on the boys shoulder and asked, Are you O.K.?

title: Wotherspoon Can End Olympic Gold Shutout
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  As if Jeremy Wotherspoon needed a reminder, he awoke Monday to a full-page ad placed by Canadas Olympic network in the countrys national daily, The Globe and Mail, featuring a large action photograph of him with the headline: ONE LAST CHANCE.

title: After Surviving Cancer, a Focus on True Manhood
description: Ive trudged through Stage 3 prostate cancer and its treatment in good shape. Nearly two years after learning I had cancer, Im an active 52-year-old, I exercise regularly, my blood tests are where they need to be and my oncologist wants to see me only twice a year.

title: Iran Defends Human Rights Record Before U.N. Council
description: GENEVA  Brushing aside allegations that it has resorted to torture, executions and mass detentions to crush political opposition, Iran made a defiant appearance before the United Nations human rights body here on Monday, saying that it promoted and defended human rights and that Western critics were exploiting the issue for political ends.

title: Model-morphosis | Diane von Furstenberg
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Georgina Stojiljkovic from Women Management, before (above, bottom) and after makeup by James Kaliardos and hair by Orlando Pita. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: The Claim: Counting Sheep Helps You Fall Asleep
description: THE FACTS The reason people count sheep, as opposed to bluebirds or sailboats, is uncertain; some authorities think it may have to do with a tallying system devised by shepherds in ancient Britain. But there is no question that the phrase has entered the language. And its meaning is clear enough  the sheer monotony of the task is meant to lull you to sleep.

title: The Tea Party: A Movement in Ferment
description: The Tea Party movement has become a sprawling rebellion that incorporates a range of anti-establishment activists.

title: R.B.S. Is Said to Lose 3 More Senior Bankers
description: Three senior bankers have left the Royal Bank of Scotland in recent days, likely headed for jobs elsewhere, as scrutiny builds on the size of bonuses the partly nationalized bank will pay this year, Reuters reports.

title: Weight Loss Surgery for Teens
description: In todays Science Times, Laura Beil reports on the increasing popularity of weight loss surgery for obese teenagers.

title: Women Resolve to Keep Getting Mammograms
description: Women are balking at new mammography recommendations and want to continue annual mammograms, even against their doctors advice, a new report shows.

title: India Worries as China Builds Ports in South Asia
description: HAMBANTOTA, Sri Lanka  For years, ships from other countries, laden with oil, machinery, clothes and cargo, sped past this small town near India as part of the worlds brisk trade with China.

title: As Girls Become Women, Sports Pay Dividends
description: Almost four decades after the federal education law called Title IX opened the door for girls to participate in high school and college athletics, a crucial question has remained unanswered: Do sports make a long-term difference in a womans life?

title: After Surviving Cancer, a Focus on True Manhood
description: Ive trudged through Stage 3 prostate cancer and its treatment in good shape. Nearly two years after learning I had cancer, Im an active 52-year-old, I exercise regularly, my blood tests are where they need to be and my oncologist wants to see me only twice a year.

title: Ikea Fires 2 Officials in Russia Bribe Case
description: MOSCOW  Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer, has dismissed two senior executives in Russia for allowing a contractor to pay a bribe, the company said Monday in a statement, calling the payment totally unacceptable.

title: Canada Grabbed its Moment to Exhale
description: When Canada celebrated its first Olympic victory on home soil yesterday, one could sense a nationwide sigh of relief. Expectations here have been over the top, only to be thwarted by a series of mishaps. From loss of life on the luge run, to a series of challenges including uncooperative weather; an opening ceremony malfunction during the lighting of the Olympic torch and finally, a traffic accident involving Vice President Joe Bidens motorcade which sent U. S. Olympic icons Peggy Fleming and Vonetta Flowers to the hospital with whiplash. Organizers here have been wondering when they would get a break.

title: As Girls Become Women, Sports Pay Dividends
description: Almost four decades after the federal education law called Title IX opened the door for girls to participate in high school and college athletics, a crucial question has remained unanswered: Do sports make a long-term difference in a womans life?

title: Another Public Figure Succumbing to Lust
description: Keeping track of the saints and the sinners is pretty easy in Shakespeares Measure for Measure, because there is nary a saint in sight. Consider that Isabella, the apparent exemplar of moral perfection and the plays chief cheerleader for purity, prefers to see her beloved brother beheaded rather than surrender her prized virginity. With angels like that, who needs demons?

title: The Scene: Day Five
description: Scenes around the tents at Bryant Park and backstage during New York Fashion Week.

title: Inside the Rings: After Hype, Injury and Delays, Vonn Set to Ski
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Last Friday, after another womens downhill training session was canceled, the Canadian Alpine skier Emily Brydon finished her course inspection early and spent a few minutes at the bottom of the course talking to reporters. She joked that she was the fastest that day, able to survey the turns and dips of the slope quicker than her competitors, including the gold medal favorite Lindsey Vonn.

title: Revisiting the 1950s on Foot
description: The choreographer Anna Sokolow, who would have turned 100 last Tuesday, died in 2000, after a life long enough to see New York go through unbelievable changes. At times the city of her youth must have seemed all but vanished.

title: Best in Show | Hitler vs. Eli Broad: A Comedy
description: Best in Show follows the peregrinations of the critic and novelist Linda Yablonsky, author of The Story of Junk, and a front-line chronicler of exhibitions and art-world events.

title: Adding Rocket Man to His Rsum
description: HAWTHORNE, Calif.  The coming debate over the future of the American space program will, in no small part, revolve around this question: Should the United States hire Elon Musk, at a cost of a few billion dollars, to run a taxi service for American astronauts?

title: A Royal Feast for Clinton in Saudi Arabia
description: RAWDAT KHURAYIM, Saudi Arabia  The king of Saudi Arabia had Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton over for a friendly lunch Monday here at his desert camp, northeast of Riyadh. In a gesture of informality, King Abdullah reached for his remote control and switched on a giant flat-screen TV as soon as they sat down to eat at the vast horseshoe-shaped table.

title: Tallulahs Back in Town, Still Famous for Her Infamy
description: Tallulah Bankhead, the sandpaper-voiced actress who pronounced darling dahling and threw in a few extra syllables to boot, made only about a dozen movies, a number of them silent. Though she triumphed onstage, at least two generations have been born since her name last graced a marquee. And her appearances on television, mostly as herself, can be found on YouTube but have never inspired so much as a DVD package.

title: Reading Nicely Edited Tea Leaves
description: As the Bagger winds her way through the final weeks before the big show, whose outcome increasingly seems a fait accompli (raise your hand if youre betting against Jeff Bridges and MoNiqueyeah, still typing comments with both left and right, just as we thought) there are still pats on the back to be delivered from various influential guilds. Conventional wisdom holds that an editing nomination is a must for an eventual best-picture winner  when Up in the Air didnt garner one, veteran awards-watchers concluded that its chances werenil  so the results of the American Cinema Editors Eddie awards on Sunday were closely watched. And the winners are: The Hurt Locker (best drama); Up (best animated); The Cove (best documentary); and The Hangover (best comedy).

title: Now Screening | Thakoon
description: The fall 2010 collection from Thakoon.

title: On Crete, New Evidence of Very Ancient Mariners
description: Early humans, possibly even prehuman ancestors, appear to have been going to sea much longer than anyone had ever suspected.

title: Its a Plot! No, Its Not: A Debunking
description: The principle of Occams razor suggests that the simplest hypothesis is usually the correct one  or as the character Gil Grissom in CSI: Crime Scene Investigation succinctly puts it, if you hear hoofbeats, think horses, not zebras.

title: Americans in Space (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mastering the Fickle Winds (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Photos of the Moment | Faces of Fashion
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Poppy de Villeneuve.

title: 3-D Motion Sickness (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dealing With Speech Delays (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Protection Zones Help Predators, Too
description: A marine conservation zone that is closed to commercial fishing helps save the targeted fish species, or so one would hope. But what about birds or other top predators that dine on those species?

title: Senator Evan Bayh Won't Seek Re-election
description: During his remarks, the moderate Indiana Democrat expressed frustration at what he described as an increasingly polarized atmosphere on Capitol Hill. (Video: NBC)

title: Teaching Pet-Friendly Homes New Cleaning Tricks
description: IN Dog Whisperer with Cesar Millan, now in its sixth season on the National Geographic Channel, several episodes have featured vacuum cleaners that send dogs into a barking frenzy. With tactics like placing their food bowls next to vacuums that are not in use, Mr. Millan helped reverse the behavior.

title: Too Many Chefs Spoil the Dream
description: Two weeks ago, I had a chef. Was happy as a clam.

title: Meditating with an Ex-NFL Tight End
description: Putting some muscle into its mind-body program, the Westin Kierland Resort & Spa in Scottsdale, Ariz. has teamed up with the former NFL tight end Damian Vaughn to offer guided meditation sessions.

title: N.J. Plane Crash Kills All Five Aboard
description: Five people were killed when a small plane crashed Monday afternoon at a private airport in central New Jersey, law enforcement authorities said.

title: Hazards: Are Pipe and Cigar Users Blowing Smoke?
description: Pipe and cigar smokers may say they dont inhale, but a new study suggests otherwise.

title: Opposition Grows in Germany to Bailout for Greece
description: BERLIN  As European finance ministers refused Monday to name specific measures to rescue Greece and the Continents common currency, opposition grew among Germans to bailing out what they call spendthrifts to the south after years of belt-tightening by workers at home.

title: 26 Works, New and Old, to Aid Relief in Haiti
description: In its natural state, the Metropolis Ensemble is a chamber orchestra that specializes in new music, mostly by young composers. But for Love Letters to Haiti, its Sunday evening concert at Le Poisson Rouge, Metropolis was really an umbrella group that brought together instrumental soloists, chamber ensembles, singers and a few composers for a benefit performance for Partners in Health, a nonprofit organization that provides medical care in Haiti (and elsewhere), and is currently working with victims of the Haitian earthquake.

title: Regimens: Pungent Pills
description: Some people with Type 2 diabetes say theres something fishy about their medication: its smell.

title: Vonn Quells Doubts, Wins Training Run
description: Lindsey Vonn is apparently bouncing back just fine from her injured shin, finishing with the best time Monday in a training run for the super combined at Whistler Mountain, United States ski team officials said.

title: Girls Health: Kits to Aid in Menstrual Health May Cut School Absenteeism in Kenya
description: Tackling a problem that is widespread but rarely discussed, a new American-backed charity in Kenya has begun making and giving away kits containing washable sanitary pads, underwear and soap.

title: Iran Rejects Familys Charge That Protester Was Tortured
description: The prosecutor general in Tehran on Monday dismissed accusations by the wife of an opposition leader who said her son was arrested and tortured while in detention, the semiofficial ILNA news agency reported.

title: Six Assured Singers Harmonizing on a Trip Back to 1641 and Monteverdis Venice
description: Classical music loves to celebrate its own, with performers seizing upon any artists birthday or major works debut to which a milestone number can be added and staging a party. Chopin and Schumann at 200 are much in the air this season, as is Barber for his centenary. Monteverdi, too, has attracted his share of attention: 2010 is the 400th anniversary of his Vespro Della Beata Vergine, a landmark liturgical collection more widely known as the 1610 Vespers.

title: McCain Challenger Makes It Official
description: Former Representative J.D. Hayworth made his long-discussed and long-expected primary challenge to Senator John McCain in Arizona official today.

title: Backstage Grooming | Male Makeup at Gary Graham
description: To celebrate the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Finalist Gary Grahams first foray into mens fashion on Saturday, the designers longtime friend and makeup maverick Mike Potter whipped up some striking looks for the male models. Potters woodsy mechanic meets alien visage mirrored the dark, complex yet ethereal feel of Grahams collection, which was inspired by the wild woods of upstate New York and his memories of unearthing his grandmothers husbands World War II souvenir trunk as a young boy. Graham said that his mens designs are not as romantic as the womens looks.

title: Gawker Makes Its First Acquisition
description: Gawker Media, the eight-year-old online publishing heavyweight founded by Nick Denton, announced its first acquisition on Monday: the New York boldface name guide CityFile.

title: Tomlin and Wagner Join Pink Carpet
description: The power couple Lily Tomlin and Jane Wagner are climbing aboard the theatrical-presenter bandwagon. They announced on Monday that they have joined the producing team of the coming Off Broadway show My Trip Down the Pink Carpet, written by and starring Leslie Jordan, who is best known for playing the closeted Republican socialite Beverley Leslie on the NBC series Will and Grace, for which he won an Emmy Award for guest actor in 2006. Among other celebrities who have embraced shows to boost publicity and, hopefully, ticket sales are the couple Elton John and David Furnish (the coming Broadway production of Next Fall) and Jay-Z and Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith (Fela!). My Trip Down the Pink Carpet, which will be directed by David Galligan, is to run for 12 weeks at the Midtown Theater, with preview performances beginning on April 14 and an opening night set for April 19.

title: Footnotes
description: Kathryn Bigelow, an Academy Award nominee for best director for The Hurt Locker, has signed on to direct The Miraculous Year for HBO, a drama pilot written by John Logan (Gladiator, the coming Broadway play Red) about a self-destructive Broadway composer and his family, according to Variety. ... Following generally positive reviews, the Off Broadway production of Lucinda Coxons play Happy Now? at Primary Stages will be extended for two weeks, through March 21.

title: Casting for The Kid
description: The New Group has announced additional casting for its coming Off Broadway musical The Kid, based on the book by Dan Savage about his experience adopting a child with his boyfriend. Joining Christopher Sieber, a two-time Tony Award nominee for the musicals Spamalot and Shrek the Musical, who has previously been announced to play Dan, are Jill Eikenberry (Uncommon Women and Others, NBCs L.A. Law) as Dans mother; Jeannine Frumess as the childs birth mother; Lucas Steele as Dans boyfriend, Terry; and Michael Wartella as the childs birth father. Susan Blackwell, Ann Harada and Brooke Sunny Moriber will be featured in the ensemble. Directed by Scott Elliott, the artistic director of the New Group, the musical is to begin previews on April 10 and open on May 6.

title: Brian Bedford to Direct Earnest on Broadway
description: The actor Brian Bedford will direct a new Broadway production of The Importance of Being Earnest next season for the Roundabout Theater Company. Mr. Bedford, above, will also don a dress and a wig to play the domineering Lady Bracknell in the play, the Roundabout announced on Monday. Mr. Bedford performed the same double duties in a 2009 production at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival; Charles Isherwood, in his review in The Times last summer, called that revival splendid and deemed Mr. Bedford superb. Additional casting and a creative team are to be announced shortly. Mr. Bedford, who turns 75 on Tuesday, has been nominated six times for the Tony Award for best actor in a play, the last three for Roundabout productions: Tartuffe (2003), London Assurance (1997) and The Molire Comedies (1995). He won a Tony in 1971 for his performance as Arnolphe in Molires School for Wives.

title: In Brookhaven Collider, Scientists Briefly Break a Law of Nature
description: Physicists said Monday that they had whacked a tiny region of space with enough energy to briefly distort the laws of physics, providing the first laboratory demonstration of the kind of process that scientists suspect has shaped cosmic history.

title: Barbara Walters to End Oscar-Night Specials
description: Barbara Walters, below, is calling an end to her annual Oscars interview show. Ms. Walters, 80, said on Monday on The View that this years Barbara Walters Special would be her last. Her celebrity sit-downs have been a staple of Academy Awards nights since 1981. ABC has asked me to keep doing these specials as they have been so successful  and Im thrilled we have such great stars and have such a wonderful show  but to be honest, I feel like Ive been there, done that, Ms. Walters said. The shows ratings have held steady for the past several years, with about 12 million tuning in last year. This years installment will be on March 7. ABC said Ms. Walters would continue hosting her other annual special, The 10 Most Fascinating People. The network, meanwhile, has another Oscars preview lined up: Oprah Winfrey will host a celebrity interview hour in prime time on March 3.

title: Winter Olympics Win Ratings Gold
description: NBCs coverage of the Winter Olympics in Vancouver lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday. According to Nielsens estimates, NBCs four hours of prime-time coverage drew an average of 26.3 million viewers, easily leading the night, but down from an impressive 32.6 million who tuned in to the opening ceremony on Friday, the most for a non-United States Winter Olympics since the 1994 opening ceremony (the year of Tonya Harding and Nancy Kerrigan). CBS was runner-up on Sunday, earning its best ratings at 9 for its new series Undercover Boss, which made its debut last week after the Super Bowl. The reality show delivered 15.3 million viewers, the nights largest non-Olympic audience. The rest of CBSs lineup, including 60 Minutes at 7 (8.2 million), The Amazing Race at 8 (9.1 million) and Cold Case at 10 (8.7 million), drew lower but still solid ratings. Fox ranked third over all with its animated comedy lineup, while ABC struggled in fourth place, with six million viewers for a two-hour installment of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition, from 9 to 11.

title: Director Takes on Airline Over Seating
description: The film director Kevin Smith (Clerks, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back) was removed from a Southwest Airlines flight on Saturday because he was too overweight to fit in one seat, in accordance with Southwests Customer of Size policy, according to statements from Southwest and Mr. Smith. In its statement Southwest said that Mr. Smith, right, originally bought two seats for a flight from Oakland, Calif., to Burbank  as hes been known to do when traveling on Southwest  but went standby on an earlier flight, where only a single seat was available. The pilots decided that Mr. Smith needed more than one seat, according to Southwest and Mr. Smiths postings on Twitter; Mr. Smith said he was ejected and put on a later flight. Mr. Smith denied the airlines statement that he regularly purchases two seats. On Twitter Mr. Smith said, Im way fat, but Im not there just yet, and also posted a picture of himself onboard with his cheeks puffed out, along with this comment: If you look like me, you may be ejected from Southwest Air. Southwest, in a blog posting on Sunday titled Not So Silent Bob (blogsouthwest.com), said that its policy had existed for more than 25 years, and that the pilots were simply adhering to it. The post also said that the airline had apologized to Mr. Smith by phone and had given him a $100 voucher.

title: Around the Redwoods, the Fog Is Dissipating
description: Fog may come on little cat feet and sit on silent haunches before moving on, as the poet Carl Sandburg wrote, but in central and Northern California it plops its bulk down on the states redwoods and makes itself quite comfortable.

title: Fjords Contribute to Melting of Glaciers
description: Greenlands glaciers are melting faster than they used to, contributing to the rise of sea levels worldwide. While warmer atmospheric temperatures thin all the glaciers from above, scientists have wondered if warmer waters are also melting the many glaciers that flow into the fjords.

title: For Oscar Hopefuls, a Season Stretched
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Traces of awards fatigue, faint but undeniable, crept into the annual luncheon for Oscar nominees on Monday in a Hollywood prize season that has been stretched by two weeks to avoid having Academy Awards night collide with the Vancouver Olympics.

title: Now Screening | Zac Posen
description: The fall 2010 collection from Zac Posen.

title: Bayh
description: Just the obvious point: whatever his real reason for suddenly dropping out  everyone is still wondering  by dropping out with no warning, leaving his own party unable to stage a proper primary, Bayh was behaving selfishly and irresponsibly.

title: A Visit From the Priestess of Waste-Free Living
description: MY neighbor Bea produces no garbage. I am serious. None.

title: Euroskeptic, Me
description: Reading the comments on todays column, I was startled to find a number of commenters assuming that I have switched my position on the euro. Some cited this piece, while others assumed that my criticism of the euro was somehow inconsistent with the good things Ive had to say about European social insurance.

title: A Passionate Tradition Is Made Livelier Through Irreverence
description: Has someone tried making a flamenco soap opera? Often the world of flamenco appears to be a nexus of rival clans: everyone has worked with, or is related to, or is at daggers drawn with, everyone else. Heres hoping there were no hostilities among the artists performing in this years New York Flamenco Festival, which got under way last week, but certainly its interconnections were apparent from the biographical notes in City Centers program.

title: If Its Tuesday, This Must Be  Copenhagen
description: For a while there, the Copenhagen fashion scene convinced itself (and attempted to convince everyone else) that the city would be the fifthfashion capital. This season, however, was as close as youre going to get to an all-out admission that, well, its just not going to happen. With a smaller-than-usual show roster and largely lackluster runway displays, the three-and-a-half-day Copenhagen fashion week that wrapped up on Saturday evening, felt like an unintentional homage to defeat. But not all was lost  indeed, there were a few gems that made it all worthwhile:Spon Diogo is the sartorial love child of a couple-turned-design-duo, and together they create refined, modernist looks  read: structured, well-cut frocks  lush, perfectly tailored coats and sheer, feminine blouses. And hallelujah for their use of thick woolens and luxe leathers  a sophisticated breath of fresh air amid a sea of commercial shows where the nylon-polyester blends practically screamed keep away from flame.

title: Now Screening | Calvin Klein
description: The fall 2010 collection from Calvin Klein.

title: Gawker Makes Its First Acquisition: CityFile
description: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

title: At Olympics, an N.H.L. Rink, but Not an N.H.L. Style
description: The mens hockey tournament at the Vancouver Games will be the first Olympic competition played on a narrow rink of N.H.L. dimensions, but that hardly means it will devolve into the N.H.L.-style crash-and-bash fest many have predicted.

title: Marja: From USAID to U.S. Marines
description: NAD-I-ALI, Afghanistan  American, other NATO and Afghan forces are attacking into the canal-laced region of Marja, a Taliban stronghold that, as Stephen Farrell wrote last week, was built from scratch with American money and resources in the late 1950s.

title: Mets Get an Early Dose of Koufaxs Wisdom
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The popular thinking surrounding the Mets is that a good start is essential for a successful 2010 campaign. So what better way to start than to have Sandy Koufax surveying the early proceedings?

title: You, Too, Can Soon Be Like Tom Cruise in Minority Report
description: Hollywood imitates life. And sometimes life imitates Hollywood.

title: Actually, I Wont Be in the Middle East
description: As I mentioned in my last post, Im supposed to be flying tonight to the Middle East. But we had a health problem  my son injured himself at a wrestling match over the weekend, and the injury became badly infected  and so Ive had to postpone the trip. Priorities! I had some great things planned, and Ill definitely go later, probably in the late spring. Stay tuned.

title: Weir Considers Adding Quad to His Free Skate
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After weeks and months of conversation about the Russian skater Yevgeny Plushenkos quadruple jump and the Swiss skater Stphane Lambiels quadruple jump, another skater added his name to the list of top contenders here who are likely to try the risky move at these Olympics: Johnny Weir, the three-time United States national champion.

title: Fit and Folklore
description: Looking at the Carolina Herrera and Zac Posen shows, held back-to-back on Monday, you couldnt help thinking they were mother-and-daughter collections. Both designers were into fur, asymmetrical pleating and tailored dresses so tight they looked pasted on. Mr. Posens were a little shorter.

title: China Ends Russian Winning Streak in Pairs With a One-Two Punch
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On the night the Russians failed to uphold a 46-year winning streak in the Olympic pairs figure skating event, the Chinese stole the moment.

title: Turning Her Fear Upside Down
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Hannah Kearney, who claimed Americas first gold medal of these Games by winning the moguls Saturday, suffers from a considerable liability for someone in her sport. She hates being upside down, and for years avoided learning the back flips that are now standard for most moguls skiers.

title: Jobs Is Said to Assist With Book on His Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A handful of presumptive biographers have, over the years, tried to tell the remarkable story of Steven P. Jobs: the youthful visionary who, after being ousted from Apple, the company he helped to found, triumphantly returned to lead a new era of high-tech innovation.

title: U.S. Gets Additional Complaints of Crashes of Toyotas
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators said on Monday that they had received complaints alleging that 34 deaths were caused by unintended acceleration in Toyota vehicles.

title: Olympic Voices: Riding the Pipe
description: Five snowboarding halfpipe medal contenders talk about their sport, their first tricks and the music they listen to.

title: Student Suspended for Facebook Page Can Sue
description: MIAMI  A South Florida teenager who sued her former principal after she was suspended for creating a Facebook page criticizing a teacher can proceed with her lawsuit, a federal judge has ruled.

title: Talk of Selling an Empty House Has Boise Buzzing
description: BOISE, Idaho  J. R. Simplot was an Idaho potato titan who knew his way to water. Irrigation made his famous potatoes grow and later it made the sprawling slope beneath his estate here green. When the 1,982 sprinkler heads pop up each summer through the expansive Kentucky bluegrass, the high-desert heat meets its match.

title: Despite Fast Track, Skeleton and Bobsled Must Stay the Course
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  As the Olympic sliding sports schedule moves from luge to skeleton to bobsled, a constant remains: The competitors will hurl themselves down the icy chute of the Whistler Sliding Centre, billed as the fastest track in the world, where a luge athlete from the Republic of Georgia was killed last week in a training crash.

title: A Chance to Finally Forgive Mom for Throwing Out That Card
description: For nearly as long as kids, mostly boys, have collected baseball cards, mothers have figured as the culprits in tossing out boxes or drawers full of those pieces of cardboard.

title: The Common Cold Stirs Fear in Winter Olympians
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  At the Winter Olympics, medals are won by centimeters and fractions of a second  margins of victory so slight, something that seems as innocuous as a cough or sniffle can unravel plans a lifetime in the making.

title: Dutch Fishermen Join Their Catch on Endangered List
description: NUMANSDORP, the Netherlands  Doede Vissers eyes grow misty when he recalls eating eel as a child.

title: How to Watch the Banks
description: Washington

title: Granderson Fitting In With Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Curtis Grandersons wardrobe is still filled with Tigers paraphernalia, a matter resolved Monday morning when the Yankees outfitted him with all sorts of team gear. He is eager to settle another issue very soon: meeting his teammates.

title: In the Citys Vital Statistics, So Many Ways to Die by Accident
description: In a city where homicides have fallen to a record low, it may be overlooked that there are numerous ways to be killed in New York  and those who die by accident have done so in numbers remarkably constant over the years.

title: Vonn Fights Through the Pain on an Unfriendly Course
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  After days of rain and Lindsey Vonns pain, the womens downhillers finally got in their Olympic training run Monday.

title: At Westminster, Passing Time Before Passing the Judge
description: As the dogs waited to be judged in four groups Monday night at the 134th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, another sort of show broke out.

title: Granderson Gives the Yankees an All-Star Without Pretension
description: TAMPA, Fla.
