The day he signed his $30.25 million contract extension with Detroit, the new Yankees outfielder Curtis Granderson celebrated with a double cheeseburger from the dollar menu at McDonalds. Because of its cheap nonstop flights, his favorite airline is Southwest. When a Michigan auto dealership told him two years ago that it would ship down a sporty Corvette for him to use during spring training, he said thanks, but a Malibu would be just fine.

title: Struggling Over a Rule for Brokers
description: While most of the debate about financial overhaul legislation has focused on the impact on how big banks do business, one piece that would affect consumers directly has received little public notice: a requirement that stock and insurance brokers act in their customers best interest.

title: Mexican Broadcaster Buys 30% Stake in Telecom Unit
description: Grupo Televisa, the Mexican broadcaster, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in the Mexican telecommunications unit of NII Holdings for $1.44 billion in cash.

title: Where Money (Maybe Yours) Goes Begging
description: On the federal holiday commonly known as Presidents Day, some in New York were keenly interested in dead presidents  the ones found on money. Washington, Lincoln and Jackson held a measure of appeal. Grant did even more so. Naturally enough, people had their hearts set on a nonpresident, the one on the Benjamins.

title: In Nascars Top Race, One Memorable Pothole
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  No one would dismiss Augusta National, home of the Masters, as little more than a nicely mowed lawn. Nor is a racetrack merely an oval road.

title: Gawker Acquires a Guide to Big Names in the City
description: Gawker Media, the eight-year-old online publishing heavyweight founded by Nick Denton, left, announced its first acquisition on Monday: the New York boldface name guide CityFile. Mr. Denton would not disclose the sale price of the Web site. He indicated in a memorandum that he had looked at other acquisition targets in recent months, but reiterated the companys belief that it was usually more effective to build than buy. Remy Stern, the editor and publisher of CityFile, will become the editor of the companys flagship blog, Gawker, next week. Mr. Stern formerly worked at Gawker and Radar magazine.

title: Secret Joint Raid Captures Talibans Top Commander
description: WASHINGTON  The Talibans top military commander was captured several days ago in Karachi, Pakistan, in a secret joint operation by Pakistani and American intelligence forces, according to American government officials.

title: Home Fires: Womens Work
description: Maybe I shouldve been a soldier in Israels army. As of 10 years ago, that countrys women have been allowed to serve in the Israeli Defense Force (I.D.F.) in any capacity that male soldiers serve, including combat units. They can serve in the infantry or mechanized units, or any other combat occupation. They make up a third of the I.D.F., and are treated as equals with males. This CNN segment features footage of Israeli female soldiers who can and do serve in any capacity.

title: Democrats Reel as Senator Says No to 3rd Term
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election, sending a wave of distress over his fellow Democrats and focusing new attention on the view that unyielding partisanship had left Congress all but paralyzed.

title: At Bronx Vocational School, Concern Over Plan for Charter
description: Citing academic failures, the city has proposed closing the construction trade program at Alfred E. Smith Career and Technical Education High School, a 78-year-old vocational school in the South Bronx.

title: For Wescott, Saving Victory for Final Moment
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Seth Wescott did not seem overly worried when he found himself in the fourth and final spot partway down the winding snowboard cross course.

title: Speedskating Delayed by Ice Resurfacing Problems
description: Update | 12:37 a.m. RICHMOND, British Columbia  To all the other woes of these Winter Olympics, one can add malfunctioning ice resurfacing machines. At the Richmond Olympic Oval on Monday night, two machines broke down while smoothing the ice midway through the first round of the mens 500 meters, causing a delay of over an hour.

title: Mardi Gras
description: Celebrate Fat Tuesday tonight Brooklyn-style. A Mardi Gras affair, presented by L Magazine and Southern Comfort, features a parade with a marching band and burlesque dancers beginning at 7 p.m. at McCarren Park and Driggs. Costumed revelers and bicyclists are invited to join. The parade will then proceed down Driggs, up Bedford and over to Wythe Avenue, arriving at Brooklyn Bowl around 8 p.m., where prizes await the best bicycle float. The event will be topped off with a performance by the 22-year-old noise-pop artist Nathan Williams  who performs under the alias Wavves (the second "v" is silent). He'll be performing off his second self-titled album, "dissonant but sparkly, a collection of shimmering synthesizers, distorted vocals and twittering drums," writes Amanda Petrusich, along with MNDR.

title: You Call This Roughing It?
description: Calling all Wilderness Girls and those who love them. As any baby of the 80's will tell you, "Troop Beverly Hills" is a welcome addition to the pantheon of cult films. The 1989 movie stars Shelly Long as a "spoiled, princessy character forced to rough it, in this case as the troop leader commanding a group of equally spoiled little scouts," writes Janet Maslin in her original review. Go to the Bell House on Tuesday night to watch, sing, dance and quote along to the film. Look out for a very young Tori Spelling and Jenny Lewis as well as Ms. Long who, while "tossing her carrot-colored hair and modeling a succession of fabulously awful outfits by Theadora Van Runkle, makes the story's predictable moves in a refreshingly trim, buoyant way." Join your fellow scouts beginning at 7:30; the director, Jeff Kanew, is scheduled to be there too. Dressing up encouraged.

title: Defying Gravity
description: "I always feel sorry for the parts of the stage that aren't being used," Trisha Brown once said. "I have in the past felt sorry for the ceilings and the walls. It's perfectly good space, why doesn't anyone use it?" It's been 40 years since the choreographer founded her company and broke boundaries by dangling dancers off city rooftops and walls. "Stepping back in time with her art is a wild ride" writes Gia Kourlas, "not just because of how the work has held up, but also because of how wittily relevant it remains." As part of a yearlong celebration of that work, Ms. Brown and her dancers will present a series of talks about her career and breakthrough pieces. Tuesday night, Ms. Brown, Diane Madden and Julie Martin discuss the creation of "Opal Loop" in 1980, and its recent reconstruction at 7:30 p.m. at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Its Not Political, but More Canadians Are Lefties
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  What is the difference between a Canadian and an American? The old question is coming up again here at the Olympics, with answers involving eagerness for war, ketchup, the pronunciation of toque or the ability to identify poutine and the Tragically Hip.

title: A Hand in a House of Cards
description: With all the hand-wringing over the role of Wall Street banks in the financial crisis, one group of key players in the mess has been keeping  and undoubtedly enjoying  a relatively low profile: the rating agencies.

title: A Difficult Stretch in a Telecom Deal
description: Bharti Airtel, Indias largest cellphone operator, may be about to realize its dream of becoming an emerging market telecom giant. The company has made a $10.7 billion nonbinding offer to buy most of the African assets of its Kuwaiti rival, Zain. The deal would add 40 percent to Bhartis current enterprise value.

title: With a Laugh and a Smile, Jagr Makes a Nod to Time
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Jaromir Jagr skated off the ice after the Czech Republics practice Monday, smiling on his 38th birthday, his shaggy hair spilling out from under his helmet, as it did during his early years with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: U.S. Encounters Limits of Iran Engagement Policy
description: WASHINGTON  For two days this month, Gen. James L. Jones, President Obamas national security adviser, and Manouchehr Mottaki, the Iranian foreign minister, were in the same place at the same time, attending a high-level security conference in Munich with a number of high-ranking officials from around the world. And yet the two made no plans to meet with each other.

title: Soldiers Keep Up Push in Taliban Stronghold
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  Ten minutes after walking out of the small outpost on Monday morning, the Marines of Company K were ambushed again.

title: Over the Years, the Rules Have Changed
description: 1934 Congress passes the Securities Exchange Act, creating the Securities and Exchange Commission and giving it authority to oversee brokerage firms. Brokers, which the act defines as those conducting securities transactions for others, must generally be registered with the S.E.C., though the commission has delegated much of the rule-making to a self-regulatory organization, now called the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority. The authority, known as Finra, requires brokers to adhere to a suitability rule, which says that a broker must make recommendations that are suitable for customers based on their financial situation, needs and goals.

title: He Clips Hair, Not Conversation
description: VAILS GATE, N.Y.  For something like the 300th time, Mike Jaffe settled into Anthony Mancinellis chair on a recent Saturday for another haircut and another conversation.

title: Bloggingheads: Broken Congress
description: Lawrence Lessig, left, of Harvard Law School and Ezra Klein of The Washington Post discuss reforming Congress.

title: In California, Exhibit A in Debate on Insurance
description: LOS ANGELES  When Bernhard Punzet opened the dreaded envelope from Anthem Blue Cross one recent Saturday, it ruined his weekend.

title: Travel Sites or Guidebooks: Why Not Dip Into Both?
description: WHERE do you turn when youre looking for reliable, practical travel information? A printed guide with a well-established brand and a $19.95 price tag? An online review site with millions of opinions, mostly anonymous? Or an online site that hires reporters who visit hotels and post hundreds of photos?

title: Inside the Rings
description: A moment of hubris cost Lindsey Jacobellis an Olympic gold medal four years ago Turin.  In Vancouver, she'll have to navigate a treacherous snowboard cross course to redeem herself.

title: Drug Firms Apply Brand to Generics
description: Some prestigious brand-name pharmaceutical companies that once looked askance at the high-volume, low-cost business of generic drugs are now becoming major purveyors of generic medicines.

title: Spam
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This looks like a debut puzzle for Paul Hunsberger. Congratulations!

title: Remnants of Spitzers Plan for Universities Are in Peril
description: During Eliot Spitzers campaign for governor, he often wondered why New York lacked a public university on a par with Berkeley, the University of Californias flagship. Once elected, he seemed poised to raise the profile of the states two huge systems  the State University of New York and the City University of New York  and maybe even create a couple of Berkeleys in the process.

title: The Flight Is a Smooth One? He Disagrees
description: IM a mess when I fly. Actually, there was a time that I convinced myself I never would set foot on a plane. That is, unless the airplane stayed on the ground and taxied along Route 80.

title: Giving In to Emotion, Miller Gets a Bronze
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  So what do we make of Bode Miller now?

title: 5 Men Sentenced in Australian Terrorism Plot
description: HONG KONG  An Australian court on Monday sentenced five Muslim men to prison terms of 23 to 28 years for conspiracy to commit acts of terrorism, according to reports from ABC Radio and news agencies.

title: Afghan Suicide Attacks Seen as Less Effective
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Talibans suicide bombers have been selling their lives cheaply of late.

title: A Timely Jolt for the F-35
description: Fixing the Pentagons dysfunctional procurement system takes more than just killing off anachronistic projects like the now-terminated F-22 jet fighter. It also requires rescuing vitally needed programs from poor military management and private sector cost overruns.

title: When Politicians Hand Out Money
description: For years, lawmakers in New York City and Albany could toss out money like Mardi Gras trinkets in their districts. Some of this discretionary money  known as member items  went for ball fields and senior centers. But too much of it has gone astray.

title: Justice Kennedy on Prisons
description: Justice Anthony Kennedy spoke out against excessive prison sentences this month in California, criticizing the states deeply misguided three-strikes law. It was a welcome message, delivered with unusual force. Much of the blame for the law, however, lies with the Supreme Court, which upheld it in a decision on which Justice Kennedy cast the deciding vote.

title: The Power of Art
description: As it turns out, the very rich did feel the pain of the global financial crisis  just not for long.

title: Junk Food in School
description: To the Editor:

title: The Violence in Congo
description: To the Editor:

title: Shunning Toyota
description: To the Editor:

title: Corn and Fuel Groups Weigh In on Ethanol
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lean Years
description: Financial crises stink. In their wake, public debt explodes. Nations default. Economic growth falters. Taxes rise. Unemployment lingers.

title: Whats Wrong With Us?
description: Harrisburg, Pa.

title: For Those Countries With N.H.L. Talent, Team Chemistry Is a Luxury
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Olympic hockey teams are not last-minute operations. Most teams held camps last summer  except for the Czechs, whose coach, Vladimir Ruzicka, does not believe in them.

title: Winter Coats No Longer the Fashion for Fig Trees
description: Stavros Pando will tell you that the ideal spot to plant a fig tree in New York City is in the corner of a walled-off backyard where the walls serve as buffers from the cold winter winds. But he lives in Astoria, Queens, and finding such a spot there can be challenging. Though the neighborhood has plenty of backyards, few are walled and many have been paved to make room for parking, a prized commodity.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the failure of states to use computerized scanning to check for possible cheating on standardized education tests misspelled the given name of the Georgia superintendent of schools and misidentified her political affiliation. She is Kathy Cox, a Republican  not Cathy Cox, a Democrat, who was Georgias secretary of state from 1999 through 2007.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about Germanys continuing efforts to come to terms with its divided past in sports, including then-East Germanys state-sponsored system of doping athletes, misspelled the given name of a figure skater in some editions. She is Mandy Wtzel, not Mendy. The article also misstated, in some editions, the country for which Wtzel and Ingo Steuer skated in 1995. It was Germany  not East Germany, which was reunified with West Germany in 1990.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Friday about a tribute show for the composer Joe Maneri, at the Irondale Center in Brooklyn, misidentified the guitar player who performed with Mike Rivard on sintir, Tom Halter on trumpet and John Medeski on melodica. He is Keith Yaun  not Joe Morris, who had been scheduled to appear at one point.

title: Tea Party Lights Fuse for Rebellion on Right
description: SANDPOINT, Idaho  Pam Stout has not always lived in fear of her government. She remembers her years working in federal housing programs, watching government lift struggling families with job training and education. She beams at the memory of helping a Vietnamese woman get into junior college.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Critics' Picks: 'Jules and Jim'
description: A. O. Scott looks at Franois Truffaut's meditation on love, friendship and sexualtiy.

title: In Canada, a Gold Medal and a Commemorative Stamp
description: While most Canadians were relieved that their country finally broke its curse and won an Olympic gold medal while hosting the games, Alexandre Bilodeaus moguls victory on Sunday must have brought particular relief to officials at Canada Post.

title: After One Triumph, Hamlin Coolly Eyes Another
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The time has passed when the only pressure Erin Hamlin felt was G-force as she careened down the luge track. She preferred to stay in the background and try to surprise the field.

title: Snow Giveth; Snow Could Taketh Away
description: The cold temperatures that accommodated a smooth mens downhill at Whistler on Monday after two days of weather delays could jeopardize Tuesdays super combined and throw havoc into the Alpine schedule again.

title: A Doctor Who Can Feel Whats Going On
description: Dr. Stanley F. Wainapel, the clinical director of rehabilitation medicine at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, is also a classical pianist and can speak with authority about acupuncture and Charles Dickens. At age 8, he received a diagnosis of choroideremia, a rare retinal disorder that causes blindness. At 23, he graduated from medical school at Boston University. Now, at 63, he treats about 200 patients each month at Montefiore, where he has worked off and on for 20 years.

title: Worry at Stuyvesant Town as Foreclosure Draws Near
description: The lenders at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village are expected to begin an uncontested foreclosure action on Tuesday against the owner of Manhattans largest residential complex, according to bankers and real estate executives.

title: After a Shooting, Colleagues Try to Regain Footing
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  When after many months of careful tending, Sarah Cseke reached a milestone in her graduate student research, she went straight to the office of the busy chairman of the biology department at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, Gopi Podila, to share the triumphal moment.

title: Lottery Numbers
Excise Tax Loses Support Amid White House Push
description: WASHINGTON  An agreement to tax high-cost, employer-sponsored health insurance plans, announced with fanfare by the White House and labor unions last month, is losing support from labor leaders, who say the proposal is too high a price to pay for the limited health care package they expect to emerge from Congress.

title: United Arab Emirates: Suspects in an Officials Death
description: Dubais police chief said Monday that an 11-person team of trained killers with European passports carried out the mysterious assassination of a senior Hamas official last month in a Dubai hotel. The chief, Lt. Gen. Dahi Khalfan al-Tamim, provided names and photographs of the suspects, along with a detailed account of how they tracked the Hamas official, Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, and suffocated him within minutes of his arrival on Jan. 19 at Al Bustan Rotana hotel, near the international airport. The suspects, who disguised themselves with wigs and fake beards, left Dubai immediately after the killing on separate airlines, the chief said. He also said that two Palestinian suspects in the case were arrested in Jordan and extradited to Dubai, where they are now in custody. Mr. Mabhouh played a role in the kidnapping and killing of two Israeli soldiers in 1989. Hamas has accused Israel of his killing, and has vowed to retaliate.

title: Russia: Premier Congratulates Winner of Ukraine Vote
description: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia congratulated Viktor F. Yanukovich on Monday for winning Ukraines presidential election, well after many other world leaders had done so. But Mr. Putin may have had his reasons for delaying. In 2004, he was accused of meddling in Ukraines affairs by making a similar call to Mr. Yanukovich while the presidential election results were still being contested. Mr. Yanukovichs campaign was accused of fraud, the election was thrown out and the Orange Revolution happened. This time, Mr. Putin waited until Mr. Yanukovichs victory was certified.

title: Doug Fieger Dies at 57, Singer of My Sharona
description: Doug Fieger, the lead singer and rhythm guitarist of the band the Knack, whose enduring 1979 hit My Sharona has become an emblem of the new wave era in rock and a prime example of the brevity of pop fame, died on Sunday at his home in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 57.

title: Times Reporter Held by Taliban Is Among Polk Award Winners
description: A correspondent held captive by the Taliban for more than seven months and journalists who exposed inhumane treatment of inmates in a supermax prison and criminality in a state child-care program were among the winners of 13 George Polk Awards for 2009 announced Monday by Long Island University.

title: Ralph McInerny, Scholar and Mystery Novelist, Dies at 80
description: Ralph McInerny, a scholar of Roman Catholicism who taught at the University of Notre Dame for more than half a century and a prolific novelist whose books included the Father Dowling mystery series, died Jan. 29 in Mishawaka, Ind., near South Bend. He was 80.

title: Pearce Must Learn to Walk Again
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Many thought that the snowboarder Kevin Pearce would be here, preparing for Wednesdays Olympic competition in the halfpipe. But a severe head injury sustained while practicing on Dec. 31 has left him struggling to walk.

title: Parade of Ice Machines Overshadows Speedskating
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  To all the other woes of these Winter Olympics, one can add malfunctioning ice resurfacing machines. At the Richmond Olympic Oval on Monday night, two Olympia machines broke down while smoothing the ice midway through the first round of the mens 500 meters, causing a delay of over an hour.

title: Goal for NASA: To Mars, or Not Quite?
description: To the Editor:

title: Word of the Day | bedraggled
description: bedraggled\bi-dra-gld; be-\ adjective

title: Womens Lugers Adjust to an Altered Course
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The womens singles lugers did their best to adjust to an abbreviated course and entrance curve. Some experienced difficulties, bobbing through the curve as though they were in turbulent waters. Others mastered it with more craft and were among the leaders after the days two runs. The event concludes with two more runs Tuesday.

title: News Quiz | February 16, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: In New York, Fashion of a Different Breed
description: The 134th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden, with awards handed out for best hound, toy, nonsporting and herding.

title: Over the Years, Rules for Brokers Have Changed
description: One piece of the financial overhaul legislation that is currently being hotly debated is a requirement that stock and insurance brokers act in their customers best interest.

title: Is Zain Deal a Stretch for Bharti?
description: Bharti Airtel, Indias largest cellphone operator, may be about to realize its dream of becoming an emerging market telecom giant. The company has made a $10.7 billion nonbinding offer to buy most of the African assets of its Kuwaiti rival, Zain. The deal would add 40 percent to Bhartis current enterprise value.

title: Jobs Is Said to Assist With Book on His Life
description: A handful of presumptive biographers have, over the years, tried to tell the remarkable story of Steven P. Jobs: the youthful visionary who, after being ousted from Apple, the company he helped found, triumphantly returned to lead a new era of high-tech innovation.

title: Deutsche Bank Said to Force Bonus Deferrals
description: Deutsche Bank has introduced a sliding scale that limits the amount of bonus paid out to top staff, Bloomberg News reported Monday, citing unnamed sources.

title: Barclays Reports Profit Doubled in 2009
description: Barclays said on Tuesday that its top two leaders would forgo bonuses for a second year in a row, even as the bank reported that its profit more than doubled last year, Julia Werdigier reports in The New York Times.

title: Another World
description: WHO performed on the original We Are the World? WHO performed on the remake?

title: Struggling Over a Rule for Brokers
description: While most of the debate about financial overhaul legislation has focused on the impact on how big banks do business, one piece that would affect consumers directly has received little public notice: a requirement that stock and insurance brokers act in their customers best interest.

title: What Are the Attitudes Toward Cheating and Plagiarism Among Your Peers?
description: Last week we asked teachers about how they handle cheating and plagiarism, and reading their responses made us want to ask students about the same issue. What do you consider cheating, and how much of it do you see in your school? Why do you think students cheat? Do you think attitudes about plagiarism, specifically, have changed for your generation because of the whirring flood of information available on the Internet and through other kinds of new media?

title: The Correlation Between Art and Banking
description: As it turns out, the very rich did feel the pain of the global financial crisis  just not for long, The New York Timess Eduardo Porter writes in the newspapers Editorial Notebook column.

title: Turkish Brewer Spurns Takeover Approaches
description: Anadolu Efes Biracilik & Malt Sanayii, Turkeys dominant beverages company, said it spurned approaches from some of the worlds biggest beer makers amid speculation that the brewer might become a takeover target.

title: Perforated Cities
description: Conurbations left to crumble into feral wastelands as a consequence of falling birthrates.

title: Obama Bank Proposal Stirs Resistance in EU
description: If President Barack Obamas plan to ban proprietary trading at some banks was applied in the European Union, it could be problematic for the blocs universal banks, an E.U. document obtained by Reuters said.

title: How Pairs Broke Free From Russias Grip
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  One of sports towering winning streaks ended Monday night when gold medals were awarded in Olympic pairs skating and not placed around the necks of a couple from the former Soviet Union or Russia.

title: Quintiles Expands Stake in Big Pharma
description: Pharmaceutical companies previously did all their own research and testing and submitted the results to the Food and Drug Administration for approval to put a medication on the market. The agencys review was devised to settle concerns about the drug makers vested interest in showing a pill was safe and effective.

title: Gala Coral Lenders Said to Eye Cash Infusion
description: Lenders to Gala Coral, a British gambling group, have tentatively agreed to pump 175 million ($274 million) into the troubled company, in a bid to restructure its debt, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with talks.

title: J.P. Morgan Announces Deal for Parts of RBS Sempra
description: J.P. Morgan  confirmed Tuesday that it would buy certain assets of the energy and commodities trader RBS Sempra for $1.7 billion.

title: Cozi Logs $5 Million in Financing
description: Cozi, a site where families can build and manage their own shared blogs, calendars and journals, has nabbed $5 million in financing, PaidContent reported.

title: Urban Airship Lands $1.1 Million
description: Urban Airship, whose products are aimed at helping developers build mobile applications, has corralled $1.1 million in a round of financing led by True Ventures, VentureBeat reported.

title: British Arms Companies in Takeover Dispute
description: Babcock International of Britain has made a 1.14 billion ($1.79 billion) bid for a defense services company, the VT Group, potentially stopping VTs own bid for an infrastructure services firm, Mouchel, Reuters reported.

title: You, Too, Can Soon Be Like Tom Cruise in Minority Report
description: From Jennifer 8. Lee at Bits:

title: Clinton Issues Another Warning to Iran
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The confrontation with Iran over its nuclear program appeared to deepen Tuesday as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton escalated her verbal assault during a Persian Gulf visit and Russia joined the United States and France in bluntly questioning Irans ultimate intentions in enriching uranium.

title: India Condemns Attack by Maoists That Killed 24 Police Officers
description: NEW DELHI  Indias top domestic security official strongly condemned on Tuesday a brazen attack by Maoist rebels in which gunmen on motorcycles and pickup trucks killed 24 police officers during a daylight ambush against a paramilitary camp in the state of West Bengal.

title: Benihana Heirs to Fight Merger Terms, Report Says
description: A battle is reportedly brewing over how Benihana will be sliced up.

title: University and Pickens Sue Over Fund-Raising Plan
description: Oklahoma State University and T. Boone Pickens, an alumnus and one of its largest donors, have sued a life insurance company over a fund-raising plan that took out policies on alumni with the aim of raising hundreds of millions of dollars for the university, The New York Timess Stephanie Strom reported.

title: Money for Nothing  for N.F.L. Owners in 2011?
description: Seth Wickersham recently wrote an excellent article for ESPN The Magazine in which he explains the N.F.L.s labor issues and the ramifications for 2010. In short, the uncapped year was initially installed as an incentive to extend the collective bargaining agreement before 2010. It was thought that failure to do so would lead to a spending free-for-all. As it turns out, the opposite is true. The free-agent market is thin; many unrestricted free agents have become restricted free agents. Teams have strict limits on what they can spend in free agency.

title: A New Madrid Art Fair Goes Small
description: ARCO, Madrids international art fair that runs from tomorrow through Sunday, has dominated the Spanish art scene for 29 years, offering artists, collectors, galleries and institutions from around the world a sophisticated and widely diverse showcase.

title: SuperGroup Presses Ahead With I.P.O.
description: SuperGroup, the British company behind the Superdry brand worn by celebrities like David Beckham said it planned to join the stock market, despite a decision last week by three much larger firms to abandon plans for listings, Reuters reported.

title: Sorkin: A Hand in a House of Cards
description: The failed legal pursuit of some intrepid investors is a lesson in how difficult it will be for those trying to punish ratings agencies, which played key roles in the financial crisis, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Tough to Find Good Help at Nose Tackle
description: Quality nose tackles will be tough to find this off-season. ESPN is reporting that the San Francisco 49ers will put a $7 million franchise tag on Aubrayo Franklin.

title: The Post-Text World
description: Todays idea: Since written language is merely a technology for storing and transferring information, its likely to be replaced by a newer technology that performs the same function more effectively, a futurist says.

title: ABInBev Said to Be in $13 Billion Refinance Talks
description: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the worlds largest brewer, is talking to close relationship banks about refinancing $13 billion of loans, Reuters reported, citing banking sources.

title: State of the 49ers: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: U.S. Group Said to Bid $3 Billion for Daewoo Firm
description: A United States consortium wants to buy the South Korean builder Daewoo Engineering & Construction for about $3 billion, a local newspaper reported Tuesday, sending Daewoos shares up as much as 8 percent.

title: Phibro Boss Said to Seek Cash for Hedge Fund
description: The former Citigroup trader Andrew Hall, whom The New York Times once called the banks $100 million man, has hung his own hedge fund shingle, according to The Financial Times.

title: He No Longer Loves Congress
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Children Moving Back Home and the Construction Industry
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: F.S.A. Deals Largest Fine Ever for Insider Trading
description: Britains securities regulator, the Financial Services Authority, said Tuesday that it was fining Mehmet Sepil, head of the Turkish oil company Genel Enerji, 967,005 ($1.5 million) for insider trading, the most an individual has ever been fined.

title: KTOs Said to Eye Investment in H.F. Start-Ups
description: KTOs Capital Partners plans to raise and invest 30 billion yen ($333 million) this year in new Asian hedge funds, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Sampler: Whither the Fog, and the Sierra Club Gets a New Director
description: Church Shooting Victims Cooperate | The police said that two teenage brothers were cooperating to help identify the three hooded men who walked into a Richmond church Sunday during a packed service and opened fire, hitting the two brothers, who are 14 and 19. Last week, another daytime shooting claimed the life of a 23-year-old woman. We are very concerned about the brazen level of these daytime attacks, said Sgt. Bisa French. Nat Bates, a Richmond city councilman, said he would try to reinstate a local ordinance allowing the police to randomly search vehicles for weapons. [The San Francisco Chronicle, Richmond Confidential]

title: Russian Tycoon Said to Consider Another I.P.O.
description: Russian oligarch Oleg V. Deripaska is reportedly mulling a move to list in Hong Kong an electric power generating company he controls.

title: Plushenko May Be Better Than Ever
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: Critics Picks Video: Jules and Jim
description: Though the candy has been eaten and the flowers delivered, love is still in the air with A. O. Scotts pick this week, Franois Truffauts Jules and Jim. Mr. Scott says the film, about a love triangle, celebrates love, which turns out to be contradictory, complicated and even dangerous. Please share your thoughts on Jules and Jim and where you rank it among the films of the French New Wave.

title: Paulson: How to Watch the Banks
description: Henry M. Paulson Jr., the secretary of the Treasury from 2006 to 2009, and the author of On the Brink: Inside the Race to Stop the Collapse of the Global Financial System, writes in an Op-Ed piece in The New York Times that it is critical to learn from the financial crisis and put in place reforms to avert a repeat of 2008 or something even worse.

title: Simon Bids $10 Billion for General Growth Properties
description: Update | 10:39 a.m. Simon Property Group on Tuesday made an unsolicited $10 billion bid for General Growth Properties, a rival mall operator that is trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection.

title: Portuguese Official Endorsed for Central Bank Post
description: FRANKFURT  A crucial decision by European Union finance ministers on Tuesday has helped clear the way for an inflation-fighting German to become the next president of the European Central Bank.

title: The Early Word: Back to Work
description: Washington itself looks to be on the road to recovery from the recent heavy snows that blanketed the region, though the federal government will again have a delayed opening today.

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Feb. 16
description: Highlights from media coverage in The New York Times:

title: Our Sharona
description: In an obituary for Doug Fieger, the lead singer and rhythm guitarist of the Knack, who died of lung cancer on Sunday, Ben Sisario praises the bands best-known song, My Sharona. An inescapable hit of the summer of 1979, he writes, it was built on a simple riff that was as perky as it was sexy as it celebrated teenage lust in unabashed terms.

title: Samsung Enters Solar Deal in California
description: Samsung, the Japanese South Korean conglomerate best known to Americans for its televisions and cellphones, is jumping into the American solar business.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: Travel Sites or Guidebooks: Why Not Dip Into Both?Where do you turn when looking for reliable, practical travel information  online or in print? The answer is all of the above, because one complements the other.

title: Tracking Accidental Deaths, With Eyes on Prevention
description: In a city where homicides have fallen to a record low, it may be overlooked that there are numerous ways to be killed in New York  and those who die by accident have done so in numbers remarkably constant over the years.

title: Another Options Backdating Defeat
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Equality (and Self-Praise) for All
description: The Academys nominees luncheon seems like a perfectly nice occasion for all the contenders to meet and greet, congratulate each other and have their photo taken. At least, thats what its been in previous years. This year, it was broadcast live on the Academys Facebook page, which meant it was also an experiment in social media. Between 1,000 and 1,200 people, including the Bagger, watched the stream, which focused not on the stars tables  where all the good gossip that doesnt take place in the smoking area happens  but on the speeches delivered by the Academy president, Tom Sherak, and the telecasts producers, Bill Mechanic and Adam Shankman.

title: Whats The Buzz on Peaches Jesus Christ Superstar? Canceled.
description: Heres another lesson from the teaches of Peaches: Dont attempt to perform Jesus Christ Superstar as a one-woman show, because Andrew Lloyd Webber wont allow you to do it. The Guardian reported that Peaches, the provocative electro-rock artist whose song titles mostly cant be published here, planned to perform that biblical musical in its entirety at the Hebbel-Theater Berlin, March 25 to March 27. In those performances, its organizers said, Peaches will sing all roles including: Jesus, Maria Magdalena, the disciples and the pharisees.

title: As Saudi Women Meet Clinton, No Talk of Rights

title: Estimates of Quake Damage in Haiti Increase by Billions

title: After London Layover, Broadway Gets La Bte Revival
description: Britain has certainly been generous in sharing its theatrical talents with its former American colonies lately, as it plans to send plays like Red and Enron  not to mention the Royal Shakespeare Company  Stateside in the months ahead. Now add to that list a new production of David Hirsons Molire-style comedy La Bte, which is headed to Broadway in September after it runs in London this summer. On Tuesday, publicists for the trans-Atlantic production of La Bte, said that it will star David Hyde Pierce (as Elomire, the high-brow playwright), Mark Rylance (as Valere, the low-brow street entertainer) and Joanna Lumley (as the princess who comes between them). The play, to be directed by Matthew Warchus (a Tony Award-winner for God of Carnage and Boeing-Boeing, which also starred Mr. Rylance) will be presented at the Comedy Theater in London from June 26 to Aug. 28, before it heads to an as-yet-undetermined Shubert theater in the fall. La Bte was previously performed on Broadway at the Eugene ONeill Theater in 1991, where its cast included Michael Cumpsty, Tom McGowan and Dylan Baker. The revival will be produced by Scott Landis & Sonia Friedman Productions, Roger Berlind, Robert Bartner and Roy Furman.

NME.com, the Web site of the British music magazine New Musical Express, reported that Aerosmith will be among the headliners at the Download Festival, which will take place June 11 to June 13 at Donington Park in Leicestershire, and will also feature bands like Rage Against the Machine and AC/DC. If Aerosmith roadies arent already excitedly tying scarves to Mr. Tylers microphone stand, that may be because hes been feuding with his band mates for months, and a lawyer for the singer recently warned the group against attempting to replace him. The Aerosmith guitarist Joe Perry said in November that Mr. Tyler had quit the band, then reunited with him at a concert a few days later. Mr. Tyler entered a rehabilitation facility in December to treat an addiction to prescription painkillers.

title: Inside Out | Restfully Rumpled

I cant stand its lack of decoration a minute longer. I have never been any good at sleeping within white walls and this (cell-like) room has been pitifully neglected since I moved in a year ago. Well, not for much longer! I have chosen the wallpaper, a fantastic allover fuchsia design from one of my favorite companies, Twigs, in L.A.; Ive ordered window shades inspired by Hamish Bowless Paris apartment; and I am about to order a headboard covered in that fabulous, classic zebra-print linen from Brunschwig & Fils. It is strange how you can do nothing for so long, and then all of a sudden, you have to have everything, instantly.

title: In Focus | Richard Misrach
description: Richard Misrachs large-scale photographs now on view at PaceWildenstein are stunning examples of landscape photography, but not for the reason you might think. These are not the ominous aerial views of beaches or the desert vistas weve come to know as his work. Instead, all of the images in this show have been inverted to resemble enormous color negatives. While the environments are still recognizable, many of the photos  like one in which a lone figure appears like a specter in the distance  seem almost supernatural. Misrach shot most of these landscapes and seascapes with an advanced digital camera and then reversed the positive captures to transform them into strange and incongruous settings. The bluish rocks strewn along a craggy shoreline look more like icebergs. Not only does the series continue Misrachs probing exploration of the natural world, but it also reminds us of the rapid demise of analog photography  this is, after all, Misrachs first showing of digital prints. At a time when more and more photographers are embracing digital technologies, its nice to see work that bridges the mediums past and present.

title: An Anchovy Spree
description: A while ago I wrote about eating Spanish smoked anchovies in London. And on a more recent trip my wife, Jackie, and I were reminded of how frequently these salty little fish  generally the traditional unsmoked ones we find in cans  turn up on traditional and not-so-traditional English menus. Since my student days in the 1970s Id been dimly aware of this: soon after my arrival, my friend Tom introduced me to a brownish substance called Patum Peperium  The Gentlemans Relish (see here), which came in a lovely ceramic tub (now plastic except for special presentation packs) and which consisted of anchovies, butter and seasonings. Spread on toast, it tasted just as its ingredients would suggest: to me at that age, weird. But now that I get the point of anchovies, not so weird.

title: Broadway Shakes Off the Mid-Winter Chill
description: Broadway box offices rebounded robustly last week after three weeks of modest ticket sales during the traditional mid-winter chill for plays and musicals. Over all, Broadway productions grossed $15.8 million last week, up from $12.9 million the previous week and the highest total since mid-January. Among the shows with the greatest proportional increase in sales were the musicals In the Heights, which added $287,605 for a weekly total of $740,580, and Chicago, which shot up about 70 percent to $578,407. Both shows still earned less than two-thirds of their maximum possible potential grosses, however. The musical revival Hair, which has also seen a decline  in ticket sales recently, also increased its grosses by $111,744, to $593,128, though swaths of seats still went empty at some performances. Most other plays and musicals did better at the box office as well, in part because of Presidents Day vacation schedules, but the performance was still notable given the fears about ticket falloff because of a snowstorm across the New York City area last Wednesday.

title: Will You Be My Fiduciary?
description: I wrote an article for the paper on Tuesday about the legislative proposals that would require stock and insurance brokers to put their clients interests ahead of their own.

title: Antipodal Tipples
description: Touched down yesterday in San Francisco and went through the usual battles with the rental car agency:

title: Huckabees Daughter to Manage Arkansas Campaign
description: The daughter of former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas has signed on to be campaign manager for Representative John Boozmans 2010 Senate bid in Arkansas.

title: WWS 543: Class notes, 2/17/10
description: Nineteenth-century trade policy, here. (pdf)

title: Judge Rules Against Cyclists
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Tuesday ruled that the City of New York did not violate the constitutional rights of cyclists by requiring them to file for parade permits when they rode in groups of 50 or more. The ruling is a blow to organizers of the Critical Mass bike protests in Manhattan.

title: As Garment Industry Moves Out, Theater and Arts Move In
description: South of 42nd Street in Manhattan, the bright lights of Broadway start to fade and give way to the trimmings shops, fabric stores and designers ateliers of the garment district. But in recent years, much of the clothing trade has moved overseas, leaving vacant factory spaces that have lured growing numbers of theater and arts groups to the area.

title: Bartok and Ravel, Ohio Style
description: Conductors like to think that when they direct an orchestra, it takes on a sound that reflects their own musical personalities, and for better or worse, most get their wishes. Paavo Jarvi has directed the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra since 2001, and what he appears to have sought above all else is flexibility and efficiency.

title: What Were Reading
description: 1.) A new study, based on online dating data, finds that a 5-foot-9-inch man needs to make $30,000 more than a 5-foot-10-inch one to be as successful in the dating pool.

title: White House Hints at New Health Bill
description: With the House and the Senate still at loggerheads over their health care bills, the White House hinted on Tuesday that President Obama might post his own bill on the Internet before the bipartisan health care summit he is planning at Blair House next week.

title: In Des Moines, Downtown Revival Is a Team Effort
description: DES MOINES  It took Wellmark Blue Cross and Blue Shield only about a year in 2007 to locate, assemble and buy a 6.6-acre parcel of land from nine owners for its new headquarters in this citys downtown.

title: Blast From My Past
description: So Vitor Constancio is going to be the next vice president of the ECB. Hey, I know that guy!

title: Sites That Do Your Fare Digging
description: HOW do you find the best airfare? Click. Click again. Click again. Then click some more.

title: Sabathia Talks LeBron, Pitching
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One of C.C. Sabathias favorite pastimes last spring training was taking teammates to Orlando Magic games, and he has the same intention this year. What with practice and all, he probably cant get away with going on Sunday afternoon, when the Cleveland Cavaliers and LeBron James, his good buddy (and avowed Yankees fan), come to town.

title: Fiat Chief: Alfa Romeo Could Be in U.S. by 2012  or Not
description: Dont hold your breath, but Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Fiat and Chrysler, gave the strongest indication yet that Alfa Romeo would be returning to the United States in two years.

title: Revisions Announced in Alpine Race Schedule
description: 3:32 p.m., revised scheduled |Update

title: The Emptiness of Evan Bayh
description: Before he decided not to run for re-election, Evan Bayh was an unpopular figure in the liberal blogosphere. Now hes straightforwardly reviled. Normally, this would incline me to find something positive to say about him, but after meditating on the Bayh record, such as it was, I find myself basically agreeing with Michael Tomasky:

title: Addiction in Cambodia
description: Reports from human rights activists say drug addicts in Cambodia's rehabilitation system are routinely subjected to physical, emotional and sexual abuse.

title: From Finland, Northern Lights and a Clarinet
description: Some new-music ensembles have attracted attention lately for staging concerts in trendy nightclubs and other offbeat spaces. Others have remained faithful to the old standbys: conventional concert halls and churches. Axiom, an exacting, exciting Juilliard student group, has chosen to have it both ways this season: the ensemble has presented concerts of works by a single composer or a few related composers at the schools Peter Jay Sharp Theater, followed by complementary events featuring the same composers at Le Poisson Rouge, a bustling Bleecker Street nightclub.

title: Central Park, 2 P.M.
Western Union: Debating Benefits and Challenges of EU Membership
description: Overview | How do countries join the European Union, and what are the benefits and challenges of EU membership? With a shared currency, the euro, how does the economy in one EU country impact those of other EU nations? In this lesson, students research the European Union and the criterion and ramifications of membership and hold a conference to debate the admittance of other potential EU countries.

title: Should D.U.I. Checkpoints Trap Unlicensed Drivers?
description: In The New York Times on Sunday, an article and a blog post about the treatment of unlicensed drivers nabbed in sobriety checkpoints elicited more than 100 comments  the most in the short history of the Bay Area blog.

title: Where Even First-Stringers Get Benched
description: He goes by Bugsy, even though his show name is Draggonfly Call Me Your Sugar. The chocolate-and-black English toy spaniel Blenheim and Prince Charles entered Madison Square Garden at 6:30 a.m. Monday morning and did not use the bathroom the rest of the day.

title: Should Coke Talk About Heart Health?
description: Soft drink makers increasingly are being accused of contributing to the nations obesity epidemic. Now a consumer advocacy group is questioning whether Coca-Cola should be allowed to sponsor a national heart health campaign.

title: For the Moment | Juliet Kinsman of Mr. & Mrs. Smith
description: Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr. & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London  but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New Yorks Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insiders view on whats driving gallivanters now.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Feb. 16
description: Another snowstorm. Another opportunity for photographers. Tuesdays show closes with a picture by Librado Romero (Slide 14) that looks  does this sound too stuffy?  quite painterly. Thats not a coincidence. Mr. Romero is, in fact, a painter as well as a staff photographer for The Times. (Behind the Scenes: The Canvas as Lens, Dec. 17, 2009.)

title: A Pizza Place Grows Up
description: THERE was a television crew in Motorino in Williamsburg a couple of weeks ago, Michelle Park from NY1 shooting a segment with the restaurants chef, the elegant young Mathieu Palombino. He smiled shyly in chefs whites.

title: Riding the City in Search of Food
description: Major Taylor, the great American track cyclist who challenged the race barrier at the turn of the last century, wrote a list of a dozen donts for aspiring competitive cyclists. Number six is, Dont eat cheap candies.

title: Viewing the Mouse Tracks You Leave Behind
description: If youve ever wondered about the flow of your mouse around your computer screen, a free downloadable application, called mouse pointer track, can help you follow these esoteric movements and turn them into a fascinating blur between art and information.

title: Icahn Wants to Raise Lions Gate Stake to Nearly 30%
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn wants to raise his stake in Lions Gate Entertainment to nearly 30 percent and he is willing to spend about $79 million to do so.

title: James Patterson to Create Comic Books
description: Having conquered the best-seller lists with prose novels, James Patterson, the blockbuster thriller writer, wants a new audience: comic book fans.

title: When the Moon Hits Your Eye
description: My restaurant review this week is of Motorino, the Brooklyn and East Village pizza churches owned and run by the chef Mathieu Palombino. Of the two, I prefer the Brooklyn location because its larger and more comfortable, but jeepers the pizzas good at both.

title: City Now Vaccinating Raccoons for Rabies
description: After a rash of rabies cases among the raccoons of Central Park and environs  39 cases in Manhattan already this year  the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced on Tuesday the start of a mass raccoon-vaccination effort. Wildlife experts have begun trapping raccoons around Central, Morningside and Riverside parks, vaccinating them, tagging them and releasing them in the same location.

title: Photos of the Moment | Strike a Pose
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Hanuk.

title: HBO Prepares Site That Will Offer Shows and Movies
description: HBO looks to be on the verge of unveiling its Internet streaming service in a wider way.

title: A (Very) Young Mother
description: In response to the discussion here last week about the best age to become a parent, I received a guest post from Meagan Francis, who knows what its like to start early. She is 32 years old and has five children, the oldest of whom is 12. True, her definition of early  todays definition of early  would not have startled our grandmothers, but it certainly brought a lot of double takes for Francis over the years.

title: Trans-Siberian Railway Views, a Click Away
description: If, like me, you have been thinking for decades that it would be great to travel the entire 5,752-mile route of the Trans-Siberian Railway from Europe to Asia one day, but are starting to suspect that you just might not ever actually get around to it, you may be glad to hear that there is now a virtual alternative.

title: For Vonn, Only Race Will End Suspense
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  It has been nearly a week since Lindsey Vonn disclosed she had a severely bruised right shin, but it is still not clear how the injury will affect her medal chances in the Olympics, which begin for her Wednesday with the womens downhill. Even Vonns mother, Linda Krohn, in a chance meeting in the Whistler village over the weekend, acknowledged that she knew little about the injury.

title: Energy Company Mergers Are Expected to Rise
description: Energy companies are on the prowl again.

title: Odd Juxtapositions in Tarantino Land
description: I love your show, Joan Collins said to Adrian Grenier the other day, at a lunch in an art-filled town house on the Upper East Side.

title: Love, Curses and Delusion, From an Epic
description: You dont need to be an expert in Sanskrit aesthetics to enjoy the Magis Theater Companys imaginatively staged production of Shakuntala and the Ring of Recognition at La MaMa E.T.C. The director, George Drance, understands that at its core, Shakuntala is about enchantment.

title: American Goalies Helmets Run Afoul of I.O.C. Rules
description: The mens Olympic hockey tournament opened on Tuesday on the kind of note that makes people scratch their helmets.

title: The Possessed
description: Babel in California

title: Tolstoy & Co. as Objects of Obsession
description: Early in Elif Batumans funny and melancholy first book, The Possessed, she describes her disillusionment, as a would-be novelist, with the transcendentalist New England culture of creative writing. The problem with creative writing programs, she says, is their obsession with craft.

title: Inside the Rings: Lindsey Jacobellis, Style and Substance
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Is Lindsey Jacobellis really in search of redemption? Does she need it? The Olympic snowboard cross champion but for a moment of hubris four years ago, Jacobellis didnt win the silver medal in Turin, she lost gold.

title: Musings on Gay Identity, Then and Now
description: Theres something to be said for a love that dare not speak its name, at least when it comes to dramatic tension. In the opening scene of The Pride, Alexi Kaye Campbells seriously sentimental play at the Lucille Lortel Theater, two men meet for the first time at the house one shares with his wife, and the room is stifling with the heat of the unsaid.

title: Energy Company Mergers Are Expected to Rise
description: Energy companies are on the prowl again.

title: Dickens Shows the Brutality of a Gentle Age
description: Hard Times does not make many lists of Charles Dickenss best novels  its too preachy, too harsh in its vision of a society that trades joy or individuality for materialism and mass production. Yet, as the excellent Pearl Theater Company production that opened at City Center on Sunday night shows, those very qualities make it well suited to the stage.

title: Obama Selects Heads of His Deficit Panel
description: President Obama is going to name Alan K. Simpson, a former Republican senator from Wyoming, and Erskine Bowles, former chief of staff in the Clinton White House, as the co-chairmen of a bipartisan commission to recommend how to reduce high deficits that are building the national debt to perilous levels, according to a senior administration official.

title: Snickers Takes to the Road for Next Installment of Campaign
description: A popular commercial for Snickers that made its debut during the Super Bowl on Feb. 7 is already getting a sequel.

title: Philharmonic Offers Plans and Weighs Renovation
description: Esa-Pekka Salonen, the composer and conductor, will lead a three-week festival, and the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will be artist in residence at the New York Philharmonic next season, the orchestra said on Tuesday in announcing its programming for 2010-11.

title: Mysteries and Hopes Converge on a Shrine
description: Moving between heaven and hell, or perhaps just sky and earth, the pilgrims who walk and tremble and are sometimes pushed through Lourdes in wheelchairs are usually seen at a remove. One exception is Christine, a young woman with multiple sclerosis who is played by the French actress Sylvie Testud. Tucked into a wheelchair, her limbs immobile and hands tightly curled, Christine looks around her  at the other visitors, the helpful aides, the strange locale  with a gaze that seems at once incurious and beatific.

title: A Not-So-Innocent Abroad Does Riffs on the French
description: The Paris portrayed in Ftes de la Nuit is filled with rude waiters, sexual frankness, cigarettes, wine, balloons and, of course, an accordion. With the wide-eyed sentimentality of someone on a junior year abroad, Charles L. Mee, a wildly uneven pastiche artist with a devoted following, has cobbled together a tourists fantasy rooted in an impressively exhaustive collection of cultural stereotypes.

title: Now Showing | The Park, Episode 3
description: Its been 18 years since Home Alone 2, when we last saw Macaulay Culkin make mischief in Central Park. Plus a change ? Log on each Monday for more of The Park, directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and starring New Yorks mostly green dream machine, Central Park.

title: Aerosmith Plans Show With Steven Tyler
description: An intramural fight involving the members of Aerosmith hasnt prevented the group from committing to a coming summer festival at which promoters say Steven Tyler will definitely be appearing with the band. NME.com, the Web site of the British music magazine New Musical Express, reported that Aerosmith will be among the headliners at the Download Festival, which will take place June 11 to 13 at Donington Park in Leicestershire and will also feature bands like Rage Against the Machine and AC/DC. If Aerosmith roadies arent already excitedly tying scarves to Mr. Tylers microphone stand, that may be because hes been feuding with his band mates for months, and a lawyer for the singer recently warned the group against trying to replace him. The Aerosmith guitarist Joe Perry said in November that Mr. Tyler had quit the band, then reunited with him at a concert a few days later. Mr. Tyler entered a rehabilitation center in December to treat an addiction to prescription painkillers.

title: No Fans of Family Guy
description: The good news for Seth MacFarlane is that Sarah Palin has at least heard of Family Guy, but she is hardly a fan of him or his animated show. In a post on Facebook, Ms. Palin, the former Republican governor of Alaska and 2008 vice-presidential nominee, wrote that a recent episode of Family Guy felt like another kick in the gut. In the episode, shown Sunday on Fox, the teenage son Chris Griffin courts a female classmate named Ellen who has Down syndrome. During a date with Chris, Ellen tells him, My dads an accountant, and my mom is the former governor of Alaska. The joke appeared to be a swipe at Ms. Palin, whose son Trig also has Down syndrome. On Facebook, Ms. Palins daughter Bristol wrote: If the writers of a particularly pathetic cartoon show thought they were being clever in mocking my brother and my family yesterday, they failed. All they proved is that theyre heartless jerks. Representatives for Mr. MacFarlane and Fox did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

title: 'The Park' | Episode 3
description: It's been 18 years since "Home Alone 2," when we last saw Macaulay Culkin make mischief in Central Park. Plus a change...?

title: Tariff Laffer Logic
description: How is it that I never knew about this? It turns out that in the 19th century, Republicans believed in the Laffer curve, just as they do today  except that they used it as an argument to raise taxes, to get rid of an unwanted surplus. Seriously. Heres Doug Irwin:

title: Ratings Gold for NBC
description: An Olympics lineup that included pairs figure skating and mens snowboard cross overpowered The Bachelor as NBCs coverage of the Winter Games easily topped the ratings on Monday. NBC won the night over all as its Olympics broadcast earned an average of 25.5 million viewers. ABC was runner-up as The Bachelor delivered an average of 11.5 million viewers, down from last weeks audience of 12.4 million but still the top-rated non-Olympic program in prime time. CBS placed third with repeats of its comedies and CSI: Miami, and Fox was fourth as 24 (8.4 million) took a tumble opposite the Winter Games.

title: Patterson Hopes to Conquer Comics
description: Having conquered the best-seller lists with prose novels, James Patterson, the writer of blockbuster thrillers, wants a new audience: comic book fans. In a deal with IDW Publishing, Mr. Patterson, the author of the popular Alex Cross and Maximum Ride series, will offer two series of comic books based on previously published books as well as an original comic based on a story concept, Beer Belly and Fat Boy, that he developed for a video game. The first volume in one of the comic series to be published by IDW will be set in the world of Witch and Wizard, a young adult novel published last year by Little, Brown. It will be released in May. IDW also plans to adapt The Murder of King Tut, a thriller published last September and written in collaboration with Martin Dugard, as a comic series. Ultimately our goal is to try and reach as many people as we can with our material, and Mr. Patterson has proved beyond any expectations that he knows how to reach a reader, said Ted Adams, chief executive of IDW. Steve Bowen, president of James Patterson Entertainment, said Mr. Patterson was interested in expanding his audience and attracting more attention from movie studios. Hollywood really looks at comic books and graphic novels as a major source of inspiration, Mr. Bowen said. And this is a medium that Jim has not been in.

title: London, Then Broadway for La Bte Revival
description: Britain has certainly been generous in sharing its theatrical talents with its former American colonies lately, as it plans to send plays like Red and Enron  not to mention the Royal Shakespeare Company  stateside in the months ahead. Now add to that list a new production of David Hirsons Molire-style comedy La Bte, which is headed to Broadway in September after it runs in London this summer. On Tuesday, publicists for the trans-Atlantic production of La Bte, which is performed in rhymed verse, said that it will star David Hyde Pierce, top right (as the high-brow playwright Elomire, whose name is an anagram for Molire); Mark Rylance, center right (as Valere, the low-brow street entertainer); and Joanna Lumley, right (as a princess who comes between them). The play, to be directed by Matthew Warchus (a Tony Award winner for God of Carnage), will be presented at the Comedy Theater in London from June 26 to Aug. 28 before it heads to an as-yet-undetermined Shubert theater in the fall. La Bte was previously performed on Broadway at the Eugene ONeill Theater in 1991, where its cast included Michael Cumpsty, Tom McGowan and Dylan Baker. The revival will be produced by Scott Landis & Sonia Friedman Productions, Roger Berlind, Robert G. Bartner and Roy Furman.

title: CW Renews 5 Shows, Including Gossip Girl
description: Fans of Gossip Girl, 90210 and The Vampire Diaries rest easy: CW announced early season renewals for its three best-known dramas on Tuesday. The network also said that it had renewed the reality competition Americas Next Top Model, as well as the five-year-old drama Supernatural. Notably missing from the renewal list was Melrose Place, the soap opera that CW resurrected last fall. The network also remained mum on the fates of Smallville, One Tree Hill and the new series Life Unexpected. The network is adding two reality shows, Fly Girls and High Society, to its schedule in March.

title: Report Says Abbey Road Is for Sale
description: Abbey Road Studios, the London recording complex immortalized by the Beatles, may be up for sale. The Financial Times, citing anonymous sources, reported late on Monday that EMI, the troubled record label that has owned it for decades, had put the studio on the market and could raise tens of millions of pounds from the sale. A spokeswoman for EMI declined to comment on Tuesday. EMI, which was bought by the British private equity firm Terra Firma in 2007 for $8 billion, had a net loss of $1.6 billion in its last fiscal year and has been struggling under a heavy debt load. The Abbey Road facility, in a 19th-century Georgian town house in north London, has been used as a recording studio since 1931. The Beatles held most of their sessions there, and on the cover of their 1969 album Abbey Road, above, the band members are pictured walking single-file through a pedestrian crossing outside the studio. Other groups that have recorded at Abbey Road include Pink Floyd, Radiohead, Oasis and Blur.

title: Former American Idol Contestants Join Hair
description: Ace Young and Diana DeGarmo, who both developed fan followings as contestants on the television show American Idol, will play the characters Berger and Sheila in the new cast for Broadway musical revival of Hair, the shows producers announced on Tuesday.

title: Grass Fed | Mardi Gras Edition
description: Happy Mardi Gras 2010! Since its Fat Tuesday, lets talk New Orleans.

title: Money for Moynihan Station, but Futures Still Murky
description: The long-delayed plan to build a grand annex to Pennsylvania Station beside the existing underground warren received $83.3 million in federal stimulus funds on Tuesday. But the billion-dollar projects long-term prospects remained decidedly murky.

title: Colossi, Both Kitschy and Compelling
description: Viola Freys giant ceramic sculptures of men and women are among the underappreciated wonders of late-20th-century art. Rising 11 feet and higher, wearing business suits and ties and nondescript dresses, they have a spookily imposing physical presence and a clunky, cartoonish ugliness.

title: What Buffett Sold to Pay for His Railroad
description: Warren E. Buffett really wanted to own the worlds largest train set. His company, Berkshire Hathaway, sold a fair portion of its stakes in Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble late last year in order to help pay for its acquisition of Burlington Northern Santa Fe.

title: U.S. Opens With a Victory and Makes a Case for Hope
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It was convincing but hardly a blowout, and proof that a team composed mostly of players from European hockey leagues is more than a challenge for a group of elite N.H.L. players and that Team USA is a real contender for an Olympic medal.

title: In Boston, a New Focus on the Local
description: BOSTON  Before Peter DuBois even began his duties here in 2008 as artistic director of the Huntington Theater Company, the citys largest, he had dinner with one of the areas most prominent young playwrights, Lydia R. Diamond, to discuss ways of fostering relationships between the Huntington and local writers.

title: A Duplex in Torontos Financial District
description: In stark contrast to the sagging residential markets of most cities, the Toronto skyline is a gallery of giant cranes in action.

title: Coney Island Rides Again
description: Coney Islands iconic Cyclone roller coaster sat dormant under a thick layer of snow Tuesday afternoon. The Boardwalk was silent but for the distant crash of waves.

title: House Hunting in ... Toronto
description: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-AND-A-HALF-BATH APARTMENT IN DOWNTOWN TORONTO

title: Three Firms Quit Climate Lobby
description: Three influential multinational corporations have decamped from the United States Climate Action Partnership, a 3-year-old lobbying group. They cited mounting concerns over the direction of climate change legislation, particularly concessions to the politically influential coal sector.

title: Prominent Taliban Commander Captured
description: The Times's Scott Shane discusses the capture of prominent Taliban commander Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, who was captured in Karachi, Pakistan, after a secret joint raid by American and Pakistani forces.

title: Now Screening | Derek Lam
description: The fall 2010 collection from Derek Lam.

title: Vonn and Mancuso, the Best of Rivals
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Rivals since they were 12, Lindsey Vonn and Julia Mancuso have long been the yin and yang of American ski racing. They are Olympic teammates now for the third time, and little has changed since they were preteens.

title: NBC Winter Games Commercials Show Extended Reach
description: NBC Universal is wasting no time letting advertisers  and potential advertisers  know about data that show strong responses to commercials appearing during its coverage of the Vancouver Winter Games.

title: United in Italy; Real in Trouble
description: Few people would confuse Wayne Rooney with a rocket scientist, but the increasingly deadly and dangerous Manchester United striker used his head not once, but twice, as the Red Devils nearly crushed A.C. Milans hopes of advancing in the UEFA Champions League with a 3-2 win in the first leg of their home-and-home, total-goals series at the San Siro on Tuesday.

title: Backstage Beauty | Este Lauders First Foray Into Fashion Week
description: The eyes had it on Derek Lams runway this morning, with Tom Pecheux, Este Lauders recently appointed creative makeup director, testing the companys fall eye shadow formulations to dramatic effect. He painted the girls upper lids a deep, rich blue and contrasted it with a shimmery terra copper just below the lower lash line. Lips were glossed with Este Lauder Pure Color Crystal Lipstick in Crystal Beige, and skin was made perfectly matte with Este Lauder Double Wear Light Foundation. Nails were given a calculated slick of one of the companys yet-unnamed fall shades by the manicure artist Jin Soon Choi. Surprisingly, the Lauder-sponsored look was the the first fashion-week outing in the beauty brands 64-year history.

title: Bandleader Kevin Eubanks Will Leave Jay Lenos Tonight Show
description: The changes keep coming for NBC in late night. The latest: Kevin Eubanks, the longtime bandleader for Jay Leno, is leaving that partnership.

title: Fox Business Hires Reporter From CNBC
description: The Fox Business Network hired Charlie Gasparino, the veteran financial reporter, on Tuesday, in an attempt by the struggling unit of the News Corporation to improve its standing.

title: Big Donors Call for Stricter Campaign Laws
description: If anyone knows the burdens of political fund-raising, it is the biggest political donors  the rich partisans who field the constant calls from elected officials pressing for checks to fill their campaign coffers.

title: Bomb Explodes at Athens Office of JPMorgan
description: A bomb exploded Tuesday outside the Athens office of JPMorgan Chase, but the police and the company told Reuters that it caused no injuries and only minor damage.

title: Jacobellis Exits in Snowboard Cross Semifinal
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Lindsey Jacobellis will not get the chance to showboat in the snowboard cross finals this time.

title: Even Before Filming, Kennedy Series Stirs Anger
description: A new mini-series about John F. Kennedys presidency that is being prepared by the History channel does not yet have a cast or a premiere date. Not a frame of footage has been shot. It does, however, have prominent critics who want it brought to a halt.

title: Hillary Clinton Hops a Ride With Petraeus
description: Traveling as secretary of state is normally a privileged affair, with the Air Force providing a Boeing 757 with a cabin and rollout bed. But when youve got mechanical trouble, you might as well be any air traveler stuck at OHare or LaGuardia, as Hillary Rodham Clinton discovered when her plane was grounded in Saudi Arabia with a faulty fuel valve tonight.

title: Pitching Napa
description: Facing declining sales and oversupply, different wineries are pursuing different strategies.

title: A Comeback for Nuclear Power?
description: The Obama administration has approved a $8 billion loan guarantee to support the construction of two nuclear reactors in Georgia. If the project goes forward, the plants would be the first built in the United States since the 1970s.

title: New Muscles and Pounds Boost an American Ice Dancers Outlook
description: ASTON, Pa.  The American ice dancer Tanith Belbin looks at photographs of herself from the 2006 Turin Olympics and wants to hide her eyes.

title: Indiana Fallout Over Bayh
description: With Senator Evan Bayh abandoning his re-election bid, the new focus in Indiana is on who will be running for his newly vacant seat. Both parties are in full maneuvering mode and national Democrats appear to have sidestepped what was  at least from their perspective  a political landmine.

title: Properties for $350,000
description: Homes in Alameda, Calif., Cambridge, Mass., and Little Rock, Ark.

title: What You Get for ... $350,000
description: ALAMEDA, CALIF.

title: Record Number of Journalists Killed in 2009
description: UNITED NATIONS  At least 71 journalists were killed across the globe in 2009, the Committee to Protect Journalists announced Tuesday, the largest annual toll in the 30 years the group has been keeping track.

title: What Grant Achatz Saw at El Bulli
description: When Ferran Adri announced last week that El Bulli would not reopen at the end of a two-year hiatus in 2014or, if it did reopen, it would not be in anything like its present form  we wrote to Grant Achatz for his reaction. Mr. Achatz worked at El Bulli for a few weeks in 2000, and what he saw there shaped his career. Now the chef at Alinea in Chicago, Mr. Achatz wrote back with this reflection, based in part on an excerpt from his forthcoming memoir Life, On the Line.

title: American Style, Way Up High
description: Thirty minutes before the start of the Marc Jacobs show, the models were lined up and waiting. Mr. Jacobs, in a formal mood, was wearing a three-piece suit but had removed the jacket. Out front, where the floor and specially built walls were covered with brown cardboard, giving the aura of a giant box, guests milled around. The photographers, without celebrities to snap (none had been invited) were like chickens idly pecking around a barnyard.

title: Judging Stimulus by Job Data Reveals Success
description: WASHINGTON

title: Dining Calendar
description: Fighting Hunger

title: Ted Conovers Roadside Attractions
description: In cities, roads turn into streets. To burn Brazilian rain forests, and thereby raise cows and soybeans, you had to have a market, and to have a market, you had to have a road. For these and other aphorisms, please voyage through the pages of Ted Conovers Routes of Man: How Roads Are Changing the World and the Way We Live Today. Despite the subtitle, which might have been tacked on by the marketing department, this book offers no general theory of roads, and most of you are unlikely to say, at any given page, Yes, this is exactly how I live today, unless you are involved in any or all of the following:

title: Live Blog: Follow the Mens Short Program
description: Join us throughout the evening for updates on the mens short program, with analysis provided by three-time Olympian Todd Eldredge, watching from his home in Florida, and live, on-site coverage from Times reporters Juliet Macur and Jere Longman from Vancouver.

title: The President and the Prosecutor
description: Is anyone still fixated on the escapades of Linda Tripp and her motives for ratting out Monica Lewinsky? Or on what Lewinskys high-powered lawyers advised her to do with the semen-stained blue dress? (Dont give it to Goodwill.) Or on whether Vincent Foster, the deputy White House counsel, actually committed suicide? (Yes, he did.)

title: Annus Periculosus
