description: Barack Obamas worst day is a sugary cakewalk compared with what the Roman consul Marcus Tullius Cicero endures in Conspirata, a portrait of ancient politics as a treasonous blood sport in which more  much more  than health care reform is on the line.

title: Life With Death
description: Among his many practical maxims, La Rochefoucauld included this: Death and the sun are not to be looked at steadily. If writers subscribed to a similar belief, civilization would have been deprived of many a masterwork, starting with the Iliad. Death, like love, is the writers currency. Religion and sex are where we dash to deny it.

title: The Widow in Winter
description: Its hard to give movement to a story about stasis. Grief, as all those immersed in it are chillingly aware, causes a numbness, an arrest  a formal feeling, as Emily Dickinson put it. To tell it straight is to tell of a persons repeated, futile reaching for the absent loved one, the insistent return to the original moment of loss. Combating this circularity is the narrative challenge the accomplished Canadian writer Lisa Moore faces in her new novel. Moore has canvassed the melancholy territory of grief before, in her first novel, Alligator, but in February its the heart of her concern.

title: Avatar on the West Bank
description: As The Lede has noted before, there are weekly demonstrations against the security barrier Israel is building near the West Bank village of Bilin. In part because they are so regular, these protests tend not to generate much news coverage.

title: The Rose Did Caper on Her Cheek
description: If Emily Dickinson had wanted to make a spectacle of herself, she could have wandered solo into a disreputable rum resort to sit on the lap of a not-so-gentlemanly scholar, as Jerome Charyn has her do in his daring novel about the Emily who might have been. As we know, she chose a spectacle of a quieter sort, writing poems that never fail to sparkle, prick and unnerve.

title: Its Not All Black; There Was Some Snow
description: Donna Karan became famous in the 1980s for creating a wardrobe made of seven easy pieces. In the 2010s, she will more likely be known as a designer of seven complicated personalities.

title: Of Gold and Bondage
description: Its astonishing to think that there was once a time when news from California could reach Hong Kong long before it came to the attention of the president of the United States, but thats exactly what happened when gold was discovered in the winter of 1848. California wasnt even a state when the developer of a sawmill took a morning stroll and noticed a nugget gleaming in a stream, a discovery that was to transform America.

title: My Life as a French Movie
description: A young woman introduces herself to a young man at a lavish party on Christmas Eve on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He is instantly smitten. The woman, Clara, is beautiful, forward, witty, adept at wordplay, often nasty. She has a transcendent singing voice. The narrator, whose name we never learn, is painfully self-aware, given to obsessively questioning his own motives and trying to discern Claras to an extent that often leaves him paralyzed and mute. Will the two sleep together? Begin a relationship? Andr Aciman raises these questions in the first moments of Eight White Nights, his ambitious second novel, and keeps us guessing until the very last, which occurs eight nights later.

title: If You Cant Take the Heat, Dont Read Me on Twitter
description: NEW YORK CITYS restaurant world has never been cuddly, but last week may have seen its first shouting match prompted by a Twitter post.

title: Lessons in Simplicity at an Arizona Bistro
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.

title: Front Page, Back Story
description: Lorraine Adamss first novel, Harbor, skillfully imagined the lives of a small circle of illegal Arab immigrants adrift in America just before 9/11. Inspired in part by her reporting for The Washington Post, the book followed a young Algerian, Aziz Arkoun, who flees the civil war in his country and stows away on a boat to Boston. There he falls in with a constantly shifting group of strivers and scammers who live in low-rent apartments, cruise nightclubs in search of casual sex and turn to means both honest and dishonest to keep themselves afloat. Eventually, several of Aziz associates draw the attention of the F.B.I.s counterterrorism division, whose agents make no distinctions as they move in to make their arrests. Adamss book was a vivid portrayal of innocents swept up by forces beyond their control, the alienation of immigrant life and the ambiguities of the war on terror.

title: Joy to the World
description: Economists, especially those who cross the disciplinary boundary into psychology, have recently begun informing us about what makes people happy. The American political system, as Thomas Jefferson memorably declared, seeks among its three objectives the pursuit of that very thing. The conclusion seems self-evident: Apply what psychology teaches us to the way the system works and the achievement of a good society will be one step closer.

title: Takin It to the Streets
description: The story of pop music is usually told as a story of records, and records are poor witnesses. They can make day-work seem like divine whispers, or fail to explain why a musician found his stride in such a place at such a time.

title: Iran Policy Now More in Sync With Clintons Views
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  If Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed especially fired up in criticizing Iran during her visit to the Persian Gulf this week, there was good reason for it: President Obamas Iran policy is beginning to look a lot like candidate Clintons Iran policy.

title: A Blessing and a Burden
description: Gerald M. Boyds memoir, My Times in Black and White: Race and Power at The New York Times, opens with the author waking from a dream. Heart racing, he reflects on a life  a remarkable Horatio Alger-like rise from stifling poverty to a senior post among the newspapers succession of greats, ending with a swift fall  whose meaning eludes him. This book, published posthumously, is an attempt to come to terms with that life, and particularly with the role race played in it.

title: The Enemy Within
description: As the rubble begins to be cleared in Baghdad and the clamor of reporting moves on to Afghanistan, its time to take a step back to appraise the regional panorama. Whither the Middle East? Lee Smith asks. Why is the region so assailed by the intractables of political dysfunction and religious violence? How can the United States navigate vested interests (including its own oil dependency) and address a deep seam of anti-Americanism amid a complex network of frenemies?

title: Two Phillies, Two Viewpoints on the W.B.C.
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  A year ago, spring training camps opened early as players prepared for the World Baseball Classic. The next W.B.C. is not until 2013, and at the Phillies camp on Tuesday, two pitchers reflected on their experiences in vastly different ways.

title: Romans
description: 243 DeKalb Avenue (Vanderbilt Avenue), Fort Greene, Brooklyn; (718) 622-5300.

title: Do Not Pass
description: This may come as a shock to you, especially if you look at whiteness as a boon and blackness as a burden, but I have never once wished to be white. If a fairy godfather came to me and said I could switch races, Id open the window and make him use it. I think 99 percent of black people would do the same. Thats not a knock on whiteness  it seems to be working out well for many people  its that I love blackness, even if passing would allow me to unhook myself from the heavy anchor called racism. Its cool: Ive learned how to be as quick as a Brer Rabbit, even with the anchor attached. Still, you might argue, wouldnt switching from a disadvantaged race to the dominant one be as liberating as a winning lottery ticket? Well, for those whove been able to complete the sociopolitical fantasy trip and become racial transvestites, it usually ends badly.

title: Up Front: Jennifer Egan
description: Jennifer Egan, reviewing Andr Acimans novel Eight White Nights this week, has good reason to notice the books allegiance to Proust: One of my great reading pleasures over the past few years, she said in a recent e-mail message, has been revisiting In Search of Lost Time with a group of friends and arriving at the end of the novel for the first time.

title: Paperback Row
description: NINE LIVES: Mystery, Magic, Death, and Life in New Orleans,  by Dan Baum (Spiegel & Grau, $15.) In this splendid book, as our reviewer, Thomas Mallon, called it, Baum follows the lives of nine New Orleans residents, among them a gynecologist turned coroner; a former football player and family man turned transsexual bar owner; a well-connected young lawyer who is Rex, king of carnival; a Mardi Gras Indian; a streetcar track repairman; and a cop. We dont hear about Hurricane Katrina until the books last third; Brownie never appears. Instead, with telling detail and emotional resonance, the nine stories wind around one another, illuminating the life of the city.

title: In Dagestan, Laugh Track Echoes Across Mountains
description: MAKHACHKALA, Russia  A funny thing happened to Magomedkhan M. Magomedkhanov, an ethnographer from the Russian republic of Dagestan, on a recent visit to the United States. Surrounded by distinguished colleagues at Harvard University and sensing that there was only one way to put everyone at ease, he dusted off a favorite joke about a Jew in a pit full of wild animals.

title: Raouls
description: 180 Prince Street (Sullivan Street), SoHo; (212) 966-3518, raouls.com.

title: Purging Loyalists, Chvez Tightens His Inner Circle
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  News travels fast in this city, and rumors even faster. So when a billionaire banker named Ricardo Fernndez Barrueco learned that his home had been searched by agents from the feared secret intelligence police, he might have suspected that the rumors of a purge of magnates loyal to President Hugo Chvez were true.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: An Organic Brittle to Chirp About
description: It may look like what youd buy for a bird feeder, but the new organic brittle from Angelica Kitchen is nothing short of addictive. Its the first packaged product made by this vegan restaurant in its 34 years.

title: A Destination for Latin Flavors in Hoboken
description: Maricel Presilla, above, a cookbook author, chef and scholar of Latino food and cooking, has her culinary fiefdom in Hoboken, N.J. She and her partner, Clara Chaumont, have two restaurants. And now, next door to one of them, Zafra, they have added Ultramarinos, an inviting, well-stocked, reasonably priced market for products and prepared foods from Spain, Portugal, Mexico and Central and South America.

title: For a Bloody Mary to Make You Pucker
description: Taking his spicy pickles as the starting point, Bob McClure has concocted a real eye-opener of a Bloody Mary mix. Its relatively thin, definitely not sweet and seriously but not overpoweringly spiced. The base is pickle brine. It has abundant minced garlic bits; theyre the white flecks that you would suppose were horseradish, but there is none of that common component, and the mix does not need it.

title: Ice Cream Makers Embracing Their Soft Side
description: When Jennie Dundas and Alexis Miesen opened Blue Marble, a shop selling homemade ice cream on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, back in 2007, their checklist included organic ingredients, 16 percent butterfat and a child-friendly setting. Soft-serve ice cream was not in the picture there or at their second shop, in Prospect Heights. It didnt seem to have a quality connotation, Ms. Dundas said. Then she tasted the version that Billy Barlow was churning out at Bonita, in Fort Greene, which has since closed.

title: Take a Napkin and Wipe That Grin Off
description: SO El Bulli, as weve all heard by now, will close.

title: Try the Red: Napa Learns to Sell
description: NAPA, Calif.

title: Behind JPMorgans Deal With RBS Sempra
description: Control, not politics, may have been the biggest factor in why JPMorgan Chase chose not to acquire the the North American gas and power trading operations owned by a joint venture of the Royal Bank of Scotland and Sempra Energy of California. Sempra seemed unwilling to surrender full control of those operations and JPMorgan did not want to share a large chunk of the business with Sempra, according to several people familiar with the negotiations who asked not to be identified because of the sensitivity of the talks.

title: Alaskan Road Trip, 500 Feet Up
description: IT was a windy, snow-whipped morning in early winter, and as I stood on a spit of land jutting into Kachemak Bay in the Alaskan town of Homer, I was surrounded by natural wonders. Or so I was told. The Harding Icefield, rugged mountaintops ensconced in interconnected glaciers, was just off to the northeast. Ten miles away were rivers where in spring phalanxes of brown bears stand paw deep in the water, practically posing for photos as they snap up spawning salmon midleap.

title: U.S. Skeleton Team Wants to Erase Ghosts of Turin
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  At their news conference last week, the United States Olympic skeleton team recounted their past haunts, their need for redemption and their motivation for retribution.

title: Paterson Aides Quick Rise Draws Scrutiny
description: David W. Johnson has worked for Gov. David A. Paterson for much of his adult life. He began as a young, ambitious intern from Harlem when Mr. Paterson was a state legislator. He rose to be Mr. Patersons driver, serving as a kind of protector and scheduler.

title: Elders of Wall St. Favor More Regulation
description: Put aside for a moment the populist pressure to regulate banking and trading. Ask the elder statesmen of these industries  giants like George Soros, Nicholas F. Brady, John S. Reed, William H. Donaldson and John C. Bogle  where they stand on regulation, and they will bowl you over with their populism.

title: Iraqi Women Are Seeking Greater Political Influence
description: BAGHDAD  For women in Iraq, the coming national elections offer both a promise and a reminder of the difficulty of change in this male-dominated culture.

title: Americans Bemoan Luge Changes as Germans Take Two Medals
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Between runs in their medal event, the American lugers Julie Clukey and Erin Hamlin discussed the start change that reshaped their routes and possibly their mindsets.

title: Slow Trip Across Sea Aids Profit and Environment
description: It took more than a month for the container ship Ebba Maersk to steam from Germany to Guangdong, China, where it unloaded cargo on a recent Friday  a week longer than it did two years ago.

title: Zuckerman Unbound
description: Mort Zuckerman, owner of The New York Daily News and U.S. News and World Report, is said to be pondering a run for the United States Senate from New York. If he makes the transition to politics, The New York Times noted in reporting his ruminations, he will be following the path of a close friend and fellow media executive, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Vonn Draws Good Start for Downhill
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The American gold medal hopeful Lindsey Vonn drew the 16th spot out of 45 in the start order for the womens downhill Wednesday during the customary coaches meeting held the night before the race.

title: A Conference Keen on Finding Open Communication
description: BARCELONA, Spain  In the world of mobile phone applications, Apple, Google, Nokia and their competitors seem to have only their differences in common.

title: The Citys Best Pizza
description: Where is the best pizza in New York? For many of this city's residents the question takes on proportions that are nothing less than existential. Thankfully, for the moment, at least, foodie rabbi Sam Sifton has an answer. Motorino "serves the city's best pizza," he writes. The restaurant, which has locations in Brooklyn and the East Village, has attracted culinary celebrities like Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, who run the Frankies's restaurants, and Rachel Ray. Made to the chef Mathieu Palombino's specifications and "cooked in the tempering heat of a wood fire, his crust emerges from the oven as a Neapolitan fantasy of crispness that is also pillowy and soft, sweet but not sugared, tangy without too much salt." Multiple visits to the restaurants conform: "Motorino pies are great hot out of the oven, five minutes later, 10. You can order too much, watch a pie go cool on the plate, eat it anyway and discover: terrific. You can order pizzas to take out, drive them across the boroughs in freezing conditions, get home and reheat the pies: still terrific. Even a slice in the morning, fridge-cooled mozzarella over tangy red sauce, exhibits the pliancy and flavor of bread, not cardboard."

title: The Art of Viola Frey
description: "Viola Frey's giant ceramic sculptures of men and women are among the underappreciated wonders of late-20th-century art," writes Ken Johnson. "Rising 11 feet and higher, wearing business suits and ties and nondescript dresses, they have a spookily imposing physical presence and a clunky, cartoonish ugliness." These massive, mysterious sculptures are on view at "Bigger, Better, More: The Art of Viola Frey" through May 2 at the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle. A few more by Frey can also be seen at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery in Chelsea through Saturday. Unlike the museum, the gallery provides the kind of space the pieces deserve, but both exhibits showcase the work of "a true original," whose pieces, "because of their size and their blank or seemingly angry expressions, may remind you of what it was like to be a child among grown-ups troubled by incomprehensible problems."

title: Finland and More Finland
description: Finland has yet to win a medal at the Olympic games in Vancouver, but that doesn't mean the country is not well represented elsewhere. Wednesday night, the Juilliard new music ensemble Axiom performs works by the Finnish composers Kaija Saariaho, Magnus Lindberg as well as their countryman, Esa-Pekka Salonen. Ms. Saariaho and Mr. Lindberg helped to establish the Ears Open Society to foster awareness and appreciation of modern music in Finland. Go to hear it performed by the group, which Steve Smith calls "exacting" and "exciting" at Le Poisson Rouge, beginning at 7 p.m.

title: Party Gridlock in Washington Feeds Fear of a Debt Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Evan Bayhs comments this week about a dysfunctional Congress reflected a complaint being directed at Washington with increasing frequency, and there is broad agreement among critics about Exhibit A: The unwillingness of the two parties to compromise to control a national debt that is rising to dangerous heights.

title: As Knicks Resume Play, McGradys Still in Houston
description: CHICAGO  Nate Robinson was back in New York with a stomach virus and Tracy McGrady was said to be home in Houston awaiting developments. Amid speculation that a trade would bring them McGrady before the N.B.A. trading deadline Thursday, the Knicks resumed play after the All-Star Game with the same roster responsible for a 19-32 record before the break.

title: Taliban Arrest May Be Crucial for Pakistanis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans arrest of the top Taliban military commander may be a tactical victory for the United States, but it is also potentially a strategic coup for Pakistan, officials and analysts here and in Afghanistan said.

title: Redemption, but Not for Jacobellis
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  This time, the finish line in sight, Lindsey Jacobellis landed the big jump and sailed cleanly to the end. But there was no joy in not making the same mistake twice.

title: Pressure Rises on Greece to Explain and Fix Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  European officials told Greece on Tuesday that it must immediately explain how the government used complex financial tactics engineered by Wall Street to mask its rising debt, and warned that they might widen their inquiry to other countries that use the euro.

title: A Well-Trained Eye, and a Singular Focus
description: Mary Bloom, her camera around her neck and her brown curls framing her face, can be found each year at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show kneeling at the edge of the breeding rings, sometimes crawling to follow certain dogs, to record the best images.

title: Forecasting a Snowfall: The Bigger the Better
description: It has become a fixed feature of the television news landscape: hype at 6, slightly more educated hype at 11, followed by team coverage of the weather event of the moment. A northeaster one day, Snowmageddon another. There may be significant developments in Congress or Haiti or a shooting in Brooklyn or the Bronx, but first, the weather.

title: Big Crowds for Snowboarding Events Are Reduced to Puddles
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On Tuesday, Olympic organizers finally abandoned all hope for standing-room admission to the snowboarding events. The monthlong meltdown at Cypress Mountain has left about 28,000 disappointed spectators and will reduce the Vancouver Games ticket revenue by 1.5 million Canadian dollars, or $1.4 million.

title: Averbuch: Pias Valuable Message and Uncommon Delivery
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team last week by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog before, during and after her trip to Portugal.

title: In a Challenge to Rangel, an Echo of His Rise
description: A 40-year-old challenger wages a grass-roots Democratic primary campaign against a popular Harlem congressman who has been entrenched for decades and for whom he once worked. The upstart says the incumbent, who has been dogged by a Congressional ethics investigation, is still living in the realm of his past accomplishments and that distractions have left the 15th District unrepresented.

title: With Big Takeover Bid, Simon Aims to Control 30% of U.S. Malls
description: After months of speculation, the Simon Property Group on Tuesday finally made an unsolicited $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties, its bankrupt rival. But General Growth quickly rebuffed the approach, calling the bid too low.

title: In Phillies Camp, an Ace and a Little Insurance
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  A fresh season yawned to life Tuesday at Bright House Field. It was breezy outside, in the low 40s, and there were no formal workouts for the Philadelphia Phillies pitchers and catchers.

title: Reyes Is Revved Up and Ready to Run
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the first time since May, a familiar banter and accompanying smile spread through the Mets players stretching and running. Jose Reyes, sidelined since May 20 with a torn hamstring tendon and later a tear in a muscle in his right leg, was back on the field Tuesday, exhibiting his signature energy  perhaps a tad more than usual for this time of year.

title: Cotto-Foreman Bout May Move to Yankee Stadium From Garden
description: Louis-Schmeling. Ali-Norton. Cotto-Foreman?

title: Big Games With an Eye on March
description: Wednesdays best matchups will have a bearing come Selection Sunday.

title: When Cell Doors Wont Close
description: As of Tuesday afternoon, New York State had about 5,000 empty beds in its 67 prisons. Even if the state werent flat broke, this would be an expensive proposition. Just turning on the lights in the morning costs money. Correction officers must be on duty 24 hours a day, year round, even when there are only a handful of inmates to watch.

title: Stimulus Jobs on States Bill in Mississippi
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  Scott Phillips had to close his small plumbing company after the housing bubble burst and his business dried up. Roshonda Bolton lost her job when the garment and uniform factory where she had worked for 16 years shut down last August.

title: 3 Companies Quit Group Over Moves on Climate
description: Three large corporations are quitting the Climate Action Partnership, a group in Washington that has sought to find common ground among corporations and environmental groups in battling global warming.

title: Nail on a Branch
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  A circle of circles represents a sphere in this very clever puzzle by Elizabeth A. Long. An English city, an American state and a Eurasian country show the effects of GLOBAL WARMING. This theme strikes a personal chord for me. In my youth, I spent part of every summer in the Canadian Rockies. Last year I visited some of the same regions I had explored so often. Majestic glaciers of the recent past are disappearing quickly. What happens when the Columbia Icefield melts? I have no idea but its scary to contemplate.

title: Times Business Reporter Accused of Plagiarism Is Said to Resign
description: A New York Times reporter accused of plagiarizing portions of several articles resigned from the newspaper on Tuesday, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Taking Charge of a Tour in Flux
description: As the ninth commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour, Michael Whan, 44, has taken the reins of an organization in flux. Its last commissioner, Carolyn Bivens, left after a player revolt at last years United States Womens Open over sponsor defections, some of them caused as much by Bivenss autocratic management style as by the slumping economy.

title: Federal Reserve Officials, Often Tight-Lipped, Openly Voice Deficit Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  Wading deeply into fiscal policy is not normally the domain of the Federal Reserve, but several central bank officials have begun speaking out in forceful terms about the dangers of the expanding deficit.

title: Washington States Rink of Dreams
description: FEDERAL WAY, Wash.  At Pattisons West Skating Center on Monday afternoon, three college students toted ice skates into a roller rink.

title: Race Officials Bungle Two Pursuit Starts
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  A problematic opening week at the Vancouver Olympics continued Tuesday when errors by biathlon officials caused unprecedented mistakes to be made in the starting procedures at the mens and womens biathlon pursuit races.

title: Top Two Barclays Executives Forgo Bonuses for a Second Year in a Row
description: LONDON  Barclays top two leaders will forgo their bonuses for a second year in a row, the bank said on Tuesday, even as it reported a huge jump in its profit last year.

title: Crackdown Provokes Fears for Sri Lankas Democracy
description: NEW DELHI  In a part of the world better known for the interruption of democracy than its stubborn endurance, Sri Lanka has always been something of an oddity. A small country that suffered through one of the worlds nastiest recent wars, it nevertheless remained for the most part a vibrant multiparty democracy.

title: Hey, Ryan? You Mean Me?
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  All the Ryans will be in the hallway, Dave Fischer, the senior press officer for the United States mens ice hockey team, said Monday before a news conference at Canada Hockey Place.

title: Czechs and Slovaks to Meet on the Ice
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Call it the Velvet Derby.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the odd circumstance that a majority of Canadian hockey players shoot left-handed while a majority of American players shoot right-handed misstated the surname of a Montreal Canadiens goalie from the 1940s who played ambidextrously. He was Bill Durnan, not Dunham.

title: Candy Makers Cut the Calories, by Cutting the Size
description: M&MS, the Mars Snackfood brand, has stirred up the candy dish in recent years, introducing the M&M Premiums line with flavors like chocolate almond, mint chocolate and mocha as well as a Web site, Mymms.com, where customers can personalize the candies with words, logos and pictures.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with continuation of an article about an increase in new medical schools in the country misstated the given name of a student at the Commonwealth Medical College in Scranton, Pa. She is Jennifer Sidari, not Jessica.

title: General Says 2 Iraq Politicians Have Ties to Iran
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Ray Odierno, the senior American commander in Iraq, said Tuesday that two influential Iraqi politicians now involved in blocking candidates in the parliamentary election next month had close links to Iran, which the general said was trying to undermine the vote.

title: Clijsters Returns to Garden, but Shes All Grown Up
description: Kim Clijsters was 17, practically a child, in November 2000 when she played her first and only tournament at Madison Square Garde. Now, nearly 10 years later, she will bring along her own child in her first time back to the Garden since then.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about military and civilian prosecutions of suspected terrorists misidentified the administration that sent back to civilian courts one of two terrorism suspects that the Bush administration had initially shifted to the military justice system. It was the Obama administration, in March 2009  not the Bush administration  that transferred the case of Ali al-Marri, one of the suspects, back to civilian courts. (The other defendant, Jose Padilla, was transferred during the Bush administration.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a new study linking childhood obesity to a higher risk of death before age 55 misstated a finding. The study, which appeared in The New England Journal of Medicine, reported that adults who had the highest blood glucose levels as children were 73 percent more likely than those with the lowest levels to have died prematurely  not 73 percent as likely.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a womans recollection of a date she had with J.D. Salinger in 1946 misstated part of the title of one of his short stories. The story is A Perfect Day for Bananafish  not a Bananafish.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Itineraries pages on Tuesday about efforts to discourage unofficial exhibitors at trade shows misstated the size of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. It involved 1.4 million square feet of exhibit space; it did not attract 1.4 million attendees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about complaints that Googles new Gmail-based social networking service violates privacy misidentified the publication that employs Evgeny Morozov, who criticized the service in a blog post. It is Foreign Policy, not Foreign Affairs.

title: Officers Wont Face Federal Charges in Sean Bell Killing
description: Citing insufficient evidence, federal authorities said Tuesday that they would not bring a civil rights case against the New York City police officers involved in the killing of Sean Bell, a 23-year-old black man who was shot by the police outside a strip club in Queens on his wedding day.

title: Booking a Flight the Frugal Way
description: It used to be so simple. You wanted to go to Paris, so you called a travel agency, gave them your dates and budget, and with any luck, you soon had in your hands a real paper ticket with a real dollar value. Even in the early days of the Internet, it was easier. You went to one of the few booking sites  Travelocity or Expedia, most likely  searched for your route, paid with a credit card and that was it. Maybe you even got a paper ticket in the mail. Those were the days!

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Feb. 6, about the bitterness that marked the first Super Bowls because they featured champions from rival leagues, misidentified the opponent in the preseason game in 1967 in which the Detroit Lions Alex Karras said he would walk home if his team lost. The Lions, a National Football League team, lost by 13-7 to the Denver Broncos, an American Football League team; they did not lose to the A.F.L.s Kansas City Chiefs. (Nor did Karras walk home.)

title: Daviss Withdrawal Prompts Questions
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  Shani Davis, who qualified for the Vancouver Games in five individual events, pruned his Olympic schedule a month ago because he wanted to really bloom in his best events.

title: Corrections
description: A Theater entry in the Week Ahead report on Sunday about the opening of The Pride, at the Lucille Lortel Theater in the West Village, misstated the phone number of the box office. It is (212) 279-4200.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Muslim Son, a Murder Trial and Many Questions
description: MEMPHIS  When Monica Bledsoe spoke to her younger brother late last May, he seemed his old upbeat self. He had just led his first sightseeing tour of Little Rock, Ark., for their fathers new tour bus company and all went well. The tips had flowed.

title: Defense Tries to Undercut Prosecution Witness as Officers Brutality Trial Wraps Up
description: Lawyers defending three police officers accused in a brutality case sought on Tuesday to blunt damage done by a fellow officer who had testified that he saw Officer Richard Kern jab a baton between the buttocks of Michael Mineo, a 24-year-old body piercer who had been smoking marijuana outside a Brooklyn subway station.

title: Harboring Hopes for an American First in Cross-Country Skiing
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After Kikkan Randall competed in the 2002 Olympics in the Nordic sprint, her maternal grandfather, Lew Haines, advised her to retire.

title: Boy, 11, Left Alone, Dies in Coney Island Fire
description: An autistic 11-year-old boy died on Tuesday from a fire that investigators believe he set himself after his grandmother left him home alone in Coney Island, Brooklyn, according to the authorities.

title: Upsets Are Always Lurking in Match Play
description: TUCSON  The 64 highest-ranked players in the world  minus No. 1 Tiger Woods and No. 2 Phil Mickelson  have gathered in the desert for the annual shootout that is the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship, and the nervous anticipation that accompanies incipient disaster was hanging in the thin air.

title: Living Up to Its Billing, Scottie Is Best in Show
description: Sadie, a four-year-old Scottish terrier, broke the losing streak for favorites at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night when she was named best in show.

title: Take the Ferrari, Prosecutors Tell a Judge, but a Stockbroker Gets to Keep His Coupe
description: It is not often that prosecutors ask that a Ferrari be included in a bail package. Then again, the criminal case of Steven Mandala is nothing if not unusual.

title: Canada Routs Norway in Its Opener
description: VANCOUVER  It took a little while for Team Canada to get on track against unheralded Norway, but once it did and completed an 8-0 rout on Tuesday evening, the Olympics had finally begun for most Canadians.

title: New Look at Killing of Brother of Professor
description: BRAINTREE, Mass.  Amy Bishop, the Harvard Ph.D. accused of killing three colleagues at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, could have been charged with assault in connection with the shooting death of her brother in 1986, law enforcement authorities here said Tuesday.

title: Corporate Debt May Be Safer Bet
description: When the going gets tough, investors generally get going to debt issued by sovereign governments, whose default is for the most part considered unthinkable. Greeces situation this year is changing the perception. In some cases, the debt of stable multinational companies has become a safe-haven substitute.

title: Airlines Vie to Serve Haneda Airport
description: Delta Air Lines, American Airlines, United Airlines and Continental Airlines, the four largest carriers in the United States, asked regulators for clearance to fly to Haneda Airport in Tokyo.

title: Tax Question Arises Over Sale of an A.I.G. Unit
description: The American International Groups efforts to sell one of its biggest life insurance companies to pay back its rescue loans are snagged on a tax issue that may require a special ruling by the Internal Revenue Service, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: U.S. to Take On Turkey and Czech Republic in World Cup Warm-Up
description: Wednesday, Feb. 17, 1:19 p.m. |Update

title: Judge Rules Bike Groups Must Get Parade Permits
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Tuesday dealt a blow to organizers of group bicycle protests, ruling that the City of New York did not violate the constitutional rights of cyclists by requiring them to get parade permits.

title: Insanity Plea Likely in Boys Death
description: The lawyer for a Manhattan woman accused of murdering her 8-year-old autistic son indicated Tuesday that he planned to use a psychiatric defense.

title: Global Weirding Is Here
description: Of the festivals of nonsense that periodically overtake American politics, surely the silliest is the argument that because Washington is having a particularly snowy winter it proves that climate change is a hoax and, therefore, we need not bother with all this girly-man stuff like renewable energy, solar panels and carbon taxes. Just drill, baby, drill.

title: Showcase: A Thought for Your Penny
description: Paved with gold? The streets of New York arent even paved with copper. It took three days of walking to find a single penny on the sidewalk, in this case at West 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue. At that rate, you could make $1.21 a year. At that rate, even with its astronomical odds, the lottery starts to look better and better, though its hard to read much eager anticipation in the face of this player emerging from a magazine store in Chinatown  unless thats a penthouse blueprint tucked under his left arm.

title: 3 Polish Visitors Among Dead in New Jersey Plane Crash
description: A father, his son and a nephew visiting from Poland were among the five people killed when a twin-engine Cessna crashed at Monmouth Executive Airport in Wall Township, N.J., the authorities said Tuesday. The pilot and the owner of the plane, both from New Jersey, were also killed.

title: A Welcome, if Partial, Fix
description: Hi. Im the C.E.O. of (Fill in the Blank) Corporation, and I approved this message. If Senator Charles Schumer and Representative Chris Van Hollen have their way, youll be hearing those sorts of disclosures in political ads for Novembers Congressional elections.

title: With Stakes This High
description: Disclosures of isolated errors and exaggerations in the 2007 report from the United Nations panel on climate change do not undermine its main finding: that the planet has been warming gradually for more than a century and that human activity is largely responsible. But the misstatements have handed climate skeptics a public relations boost.

title: Westchesters Word
description: Six months ago, New Yorks Westchester County agreed to spend slightly more than $50 million in the next seven years to build at least 750 units of affordable housing  more than 600 of them in towns and villages where the black population is 3 percent or less and the Hispanic population is less than 7 percent.

title: Whats Hot on This BBC Podcast? The Siege of Munster (1534-35)
description: The Frankfurt School of philosophers emigrated from Nazi Germany and became dyspeptic critics of American culture. Several landed in Southern California where they were disturbed by the consumer culture and the gospel of relentless cheeriness. Depressive by nature, they focused on the disappointments and venality that surrounded them and how unnecessary it all was. It could be paradise, Theodor Adorno complained, but it was only California.

title: Sizing Up the Bipartisan Health Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: McCains Karma: A Challenge From the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Survivors of Polio
description: To the Editor:

title: An Order of Prosperity, to Go
description: Dallas

title: Crime by the Numbers
description: A RECENT survey of retired New York Police Department personnel strongly implies that the polices reporting of crime statistics in New York City has been skewed for years, with precinct commanders and others downgrading crimes to make their results look better. According to the surveys authors, criminologists John Eterno and Eli Silverman, and to spokesmen for the Captains Endowment Association, the pressures exerted by the departments CompStat crime-tracking program forced commanders and their subordinates to manipulate statistics to protect themselves from abuse at CompStat meetings, where their results were discussed. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: G.O.P. Hopes for Senate Control Face Hurdles
description: WASHINGTON  The retirement of Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana has raised Republicans hopes of capturing a significant number of Democratic Senate seats in November. Some Republicans and analysts are even suggesting that the party might take control of the Senate.

title: Push Begins for 2nd Stop on No. 7 Subway Extension
description: More than two years ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the city concluded that there was enough money for only one new station on the extension of the No. 7 line, at 34th Street and 11th Avenue.

title: Lottery Numbers
Study Finds Public Discontent With Colleges
description: Most Americans believe that colleges today operate like businesses, concerned more with their bottom line than with the educational experience of students, according to a new study. And the proportion of people who hold that view has increased to 60 percent, from 52 percent in 2007.

title: U.S. Blocks $70 Million for Rail Line in Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Federal Transit Administration pulled $70 million in stimulus money from a planned expansion of the commuter rail service here Tuesday after it found that the local rail agency had not appropriately studied the projects impact on low-income and minority residents.

title: Colorado: Man Freed by DNA Evidence Settles Suit
description: A Colorado man who was wrongfully imprisoned for murder for nearly a decade will be paid $4.1 million by Larimer County to settle a lawsuit he filed. The man, Tim Masters, was sent to prison in 1999 for the 1987 slaying of a woman who was found dead in a field near his Fort Collins home when he was 15. He was freed after DNA evidence pointed to another suspect. Mr. Masterss suit charged the authorities with framing him in their zeal to close the case, which remains unsolved. Larimer Countys Board of Commissioners approved the settlement on Tuesday. I would gladly pay $10 million, or whatever it took, if I could get those years of my life back, Mr. Masters said.

title: Judge Sylvia Pressler, Who Opened Little League to Girls, Dies at 75
description: Sylvia B. Pressler, whose 1973 ruling as a hearings officer with the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights opened the door for girls to play Little League baseball, and who later rose to be the presiding administrative judge of the states Appellate Division, died Monday at a family cottage in Sparta, N.J. She was 75, and her primary residence was in Englewood, N.J.

title: Plushenko, Once Untouchable, Faces Competition
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Yevgeny Plushenko was untouchable four years ago, but he returned to the Olympics on Tuesday to find something he might not have recognized: competition for the gold medal.

title: Word of the Day | abominable
description: abominable\-bm-n-bl, -b-m-\ adjective

title: France: Report Says Army Exposed Troops to Radiation
description: PARIS  The French military deliberately exposed enlisted men to nuclear radiation in the Sahara Desert in 1961 in order to study resulting physical and psychological effects, according to a classified 1998 report published Tuesday by a French daily, Le Parisien.

title: Lucille Clifton, Poet Who Explored Intricacies of Black Lives, Dies at 73
description: Lucille Clifton, a distinguished American poet whose work trained lenses wide and narrow on the experience of being black and female in the 20th century, exploring vast subjects like the indignities of history and intimate ones like the indignities of the body, died on Saturday in Baltimore. She was 73 and lived in Columbia, Md.

title: Knicks Said to Be Close on a Deal for McGrady
description: While the Bulls were routing the Knicks at the United Center on Tuesday night, the Knicks were close to securing a bigger victory over Chicago off the court.

title: China: Gay Pageant Contestant Wins a Prize
description: A 25-year-old Muslim man from China was the third runner-up in the Worldwide Mr. Gay pageant, which ended Sunday in Oslo. The man, who is known publicly by his nickname, Xiao Dai, entered the contest despite the fact that Chinese authorities last month canceled Mr. Gay China, a smaller pageant in Beijing that would have been the first of its kind. After the cancellation, contestants and organizers quietly selected Xiao Dai to represent China in Oslo.

title: Scottie Captures the Crown
description: Day 2 of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, from preparations to best in show.

title: Howard Lotsof Dies at 66; Saw Drug Cure in a Plant
description: Howard Lotsof was 19, addicted to heroin and searching for a new high in 1962 when he swallowed a bitter-tasting white powder taken from an exotic West African shrub.

title: News Quiz | February 17, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Two-Peating the Gold
description: WHO is Seth Westcott? WHO did he beat to win the gold medal in the Mens Snowboard Cross Final?

title: Elders of Wall St. Favor More Regulation
description: Put aside for a moment the political pressure to regulate banking and trading. Ask the elder statesmen of these industries  giants like George Soros, Nicholas F. Brady, John S. Reed, William H. Donaldson and John C. Bogle  where they stand on regulation, and they will bowl you over.

title: Fortress Buys Logan Circle, a Bond Investor
description: Fortress Investment Group, the private equity and hedge fund investor, said Tuesday that it had struck a deal to acquire Logan Circle Partners, which manages about $12 billion in bond investments, from Guggenheim Partners.

title: Raucous Play as Russia Tops Latvia
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On a day of mostly lopsided games at Canada Hockey Place, Russia ran over Latvia, 8-2, on Tuesday.

title: Astra Pays Up to $1.2 Billion for Arthritis Drug
description: AstraZeneca waded into the competitive rheumatoid arthritis market on Tuesday by buying rights to Rigel Pharmaceuticals next-generation drug R788 for up to $1.245 billion, Reuters reported.

title: West Says Hershey Trust Poses No Obstacle
description: David West, chief executive of Hershey, does not think the charitable trust that has the controlling vote at the largest American chocolate maker stops him from running the company the way it should be run, Reuters reported.

title: Year-Old Finance Microblogger Sees Boom
description: Howard Lindzon, founder of a start-up called StockTwits, may have something hot, peHUB writes.

title: How Involved Are Your Parents in Your Life?
description: President Obama schedules meetings and trips around his family commitments. Do your parents make family time, and your activities, a priority? Do they face challenges and obstacles that prevent them from doing so?

title: General Growth to Simon: Thanks, but No Thanks
description: After months of speculation, the Simon Property Group on Tuesday finally made an unsolicited $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties, its bankrupt rival. But General Growth quickly rebuffed the approach, calling it too low, The New York Timess Michael J. de la Merced reported.

title: In Wake of Merger, Merck Beats Forecasts
description: Merck posted quarterly revenue above analysts estimates on Tuesday, helped by strong sales of its diabetes and allergy drugs, Reuters reported.

title: Retailer Express Eyes $200 Million I.P.O.
description: The owner of Express, the retail apparel chain, said Tuesday it is planning to go public, The Associated Press reported.

title: On the IndyMac-F.D.I.C. Kerfuffle
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is on the defensive thanks to imperfect disclosure. A Web video critical of the agencys sale of the failed IndyMac Bancorp last year has elicited a defensive clarification, Reuters Breakingviews says. The F.D.I.C. could have been clearer when the deal was done, Breakingviews suggests.

title: U.N. Rejects Militarization of Afghan Aid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Senior United Nations officials in Afghanistan on Wednesday criticized NATO forces for what one referred to as the militarization of humanitarian aid, and said United Nations agencies would not participate in the militarys reconstruction strategy in Marja as part of its current offensive there.

title: Shares Gain as Merck Reports Strong Results
description: Stocks posted their biggest daily percentage gain in three months on Tuesday after strong revenue from the drug maker Merck and positive regional manufacturing data instilled confidence in the economic outlook.

title: Investors Pool $16 Million for TidalTV
description: TidalTV, an online video advertising network, has raised $16 million in a second round of funding, VentureBeat reported.

title: Coca-Colonization
description: Term used to characterize Americanization.

title: Chesapeake Midstream Plans $345 Million I.P.O.
description: Chesapeake Midstream Partners said Tuesday that it is planning to raise up to $345 million in an initial public offering, The Associated Press reported.

title: Tax Question Arises Over Sale of an A.I.G. Unit
description: The American International Groups efforts to sell one of its biggest life insurance companies to pay back its rescue loans are snagged on a tax issue that may require a special ruling by the Internal Revenue Service, The New York Timess Mary Williams Walsh and Michael J. de la Merced  reported, citing people briefed on the matter.

title: Take the Ferrari, Prosecutors Tell Judge in Mandala Case
description: It is not often that prosecutors ask that a Ferrari be included in a bail package. Then again, The New York Timess John Eligon writes, the criminal case of Steven Mandala is nothing if not unusual.

title: Will Morgan Stanley Hand Over Hotel Keys?
description: Morgan Stanley may hand creditors the keys to its $2.4 billion investment in a chain of Japanese hotels, when the debt becomes due in April, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: At Paris Museum, a Table in the Sky
description: When Electrolux, the Swedish electrical appliance maker, proposed a project called Art Home (pronounced aroma inFrench) to the Palais de Tokyo (13, avenue du Prsident-Wilson) late last year, the result was a partnership as close to heaven as the contemporary art museum could get. Conceived by the award-winning artist Laurent Grasso, the rectangular, purple-hued, glass-and-steel box, which sits atop the museum, houses Nomiya, a conceptual dining space for 12, orchestrated by the experimentalist chef Gilles Stassart.

title: State of the Seahawks: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Another Win for BNP Paribas, Another Loss for ING
description: The diverging fortunes of Europes biggest banks were evident Wednesday as the largest French bank, BNP Paribas, reported another strong quarterly profit, while its Dutch rival, the ING Group, booked a larger-than-expected loss to repay government bailout funds, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

title: How the Supreme Court Helped Balance the Budget
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Case Named Chairman of Exclusive Resorts
description: AOLs co-founder, Steve Case, was named chairman of Exclusive Resorts, a luxury vacation membership club.

title: The Dawn of Neurocapitalism
description: Todays idea: Were becoming a neurocapitalist world, an essay says. The demands of performance-driven, self-enhancing societies will expand markets for neuro-psychotropic drugs beyond those for depression, dementia and attention deficit disorder. And they will cost our health care systems dearly.

title: Goodbye to All That: Is Abbey Road for Sale?
description: Abbey Road, the London recording studio immortalized by the eponymous multimillion-selling Beatles album, has reportedly been put up for sale by its owners.

title: Busy Buffett Ends an Annual Meeting Tradition
description: Theres only one Warren E. Buffett to go around, and non-U.S. investors will get less of him this year.

title: Soros Doubles Down on Gold
description: George Soross hedge fund more than doubled its bet on the price of gold during the fourth quarter, as the firm reported total U.S.-listed equity holdings of $8.8 billion at the end of 2009, Reuters reported.

title: Man Group Rises on BlackRock Deal Chatter
description: 1:15 p.m. | Updated BlackRock is not in talks to buy the Man Group, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by David Goodwillie
description: David Goodwillie is the author of the forthcoming novel American Subversive, and the memoir Seemed Like a Good Idea at the Time.

title: American Idol: Choosing the Top 24, Part 1
description: Should you ever find yourself in the later stages of Hollywood Week on American Idol and you make it to the round where singers are segmented into several empty hotel conference rooms, dont just sit on the ground and mope. Look around. Observe the competition. In each room is a blatant tell, someone whos a sure thing for the next round, or a sure thing to go home. Identify that person. (N.B.: These rules also work for viewers, who if they successfully do this can skip an entire hour of Idol programming.)

title: Goldman-Greece Currency Swap Went Unmentioned
description: Goldman Sachs Group managed $15 billion of bond sales for Greece after arranging a currency swap that allowed the government to hide the extent of its deficit, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Sampler: Vallejo Seeks Policing Help, and an Oakland Student Leader Wants Tougher Courses
description: School Should Be Harder, Student Leader Says | Wesley Sims, a senior at the East Oakland School of Arts and a representative on the Oakland School Board, said that his high school had not prepared him for college even though he had earned good grades. I woke up to take my SAT, and me being a 4.4-G.P.A. student, Im like, all right, SATs, lets go, Im ready, he said. I opened my book and knew, lets say, 25 percent of the things that were going on in the book. [The Oakland Tribune]

title: Poll Shows Mayor Slipping Somewhat
description: Hows he doing? Not too badly, which is to say, steadily worse.

title: At Governors Side, an Aide With a Past
description: David W. Johnson has worked for Gov. David A. Paterson for much of his adult life. He began as an intern and is now one of the most senior people in the administration, paid $132,000 a year. He is described as Mr. Patersons closest confidant and has a designated room for overnight stays in the Executive Mansion and a broadening role in areas like campaign strategy, government initiatives and management of the governors staff.

title: Walgreen to Buy Duane Reade for $1.1 Billion
description: Update | 4:30 p.m. Walgreen, the national pharmacy chain, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Duane Reade Holdings, whose drugstores occupy many a New York City corner, for about $1.1 billion.

title: Analysts Put Bank Reform Costs at $221 Billion
description: Top banks will need an extra $221 billion of capital and their annual profits will slump by $110 billion if all proposed regulations to reform the industry are brought in, leading analysts said on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

description: Video | Airport security that crosses hearts and hopes not to die:

title: Bidders Undeterred by Stuyvesant Town Foreclosure
description: A couple of potential bidders interested in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village were apparently unconcerned by a foreclosure action by lenders on Tuesday against the owner of Manhattans largest residential complex, The New York Post reported.

title: Shares Improve on Growing Signs of a Recovery
description: Wall Street investors, buoyed by signs of stability in the housing and manufacturing sectors, seemed optimistic about the speed of economic renewal on Wednesday as worries about mounting debt burdens abroad began to subside.

title: Lost Watch: The Magic Numbers
description: Mike Hale is off this week. The spoilers are still here.

title: Part 2: A Scientists Defense of Greenhouse Warming
description: Heres the second (and final) installment from Andrew A. Lacis of NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies providing more detail on his view of the evidence showing a human warming influence on the climate. [Part one is here.] This post builds on his earlier efforts here to challenge arguments of skeptics of human-driven warming. (Ive added a link or two to Web sites explaining some of the acronyms.)

title: Lacis at NASA on Role of CO2 in Warming
description: Andrew A. Lacis, the NASA climatologist whose 2005 critique of the United Nations climate panel was embraced by bloggers seeking to cast doubt on human-driven climate change, has sent in two more commentaries on the state of climate science.

title: You Call That a Taxi?
description: Ford is on a mission to show that its Transit Connect has all kinds of transportation potential.

title: Feldsteins Euro Holiday
description: Today, Martin Feldstein suggests that Greece make a temporary return to the drachma, so as to regain cost competitiveness. In terms of the macroeconomics, this actually does make sense. But its also impossible; Feldstein needs to read Barry Eichengreen. Heres Eichengreen on euro exit:

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Feb. 17
description: Highlights from media coverage in Wednesdays New York Times:

title: Fed Board Diverged on Timing of Policy Shift, Minutes Show
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the Federal Reserves policy-making arm generally concurred that the central bank should eventually tighten monetary policy, but they disagreed on how to raise interest rates and reduce the balance sheet, according to minutes of last months meeting.

title: Video Ad Start-Up YuMe Raises $25 Million
description: Who will be the Google of video advertising  inserting ads into the ever-expanding torrent of video on the Web?

title: Fashion as Food
description: As I bounded over a snowbank yesterday near 531 West 36th Street, thinking one false step and Ill end up in New Jersey, some magazine editors were debouching from their cars in nice clothes with platforms and stiletto suede boots. The snow was blowing up the street. Who doesnt know that feeling of being one-upped by someone elses ability to look utterly fabulous in all weathers? Its too incredible to deplore. I climbed the stairs for the first showing of the Row, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsens line, wishing I had my fuzzy slippers.

title: All the Globes a Stage, Now for Female Playwrights, Too
description: After more than 400 years, there were still a few milestones that Shakespeares Globe Theater in London had not yet reached. Now hold onto your jerkin, because for the first time since the doors of the original Globe opened in 1599, the theater plans to present a play by a female author. The Guardian reported that the playwright Nell Leyshon will have her play Bedlam, about the notorious London mental hospital, the Bethlem, performed at the Globe as part of its coming season.

title: High Schools to Offer Plan to Graduate 2 Years Early
description: Dozens of public high schools in eight states will introduce a program next year allowing 10th graders who pass a battery of tests to get a diploma two years early and immediately enroll in community college.

title: Questioning the Way Colleges Are Managed
description: Ninety percent of parents believe it is likely that their children will attend college, and most of them believe that any student can get the loans or financial aid required. But a new survey, reported on by my colleague, Tamar Lewin, finds that parents dont have a lot of confidence in the way colleges are managed.

title: Bits Scan: Wednesdays Tech News Roundup
description: Your morning roundup of technology news:

title: Brooklyn Boy, 4, Is Killed by School Bus
description: Updated, 11:18 a.m. | A yeshivas school bus struck a 4-year-old boy in Borough Park, Brooklyn, on Wednesday morning, claiming his life, the authorities said.

title: A Must Read for Anyone Who Wants to Sell a Business
description: When I discovered The Offer, a series by the veteran entrepreneur and Inc. columnist Norm Brodsky, I think I must have gasped audibly.

title: The Trifecta Comes to Town
description: On Tuesday night at Caf Grumpys Greenpoint location (193 Meserole Avenue, 718-349-7623), a handful of coffee professionals and a few unwitting customers witnessed the surreptitious New York debut of the Trifecta, a high-tech single-cup coffee machine from Bunn.

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: What Are Those Blue Lines?
description: Doug Lewis is a two-time Olympian (1984 and 1988) and world championship bronze medalist in the downhill. He is the voice of Alpine skiing at the 2010 Olympics for the Vancouver Organizing Committee and works as the Alpine analyst for Universal Sports.

title: I Read You: Cameron Plans Avatar Novel
description: For fans of James Cameron who have always believed that the best thing about his work is the writing, youll be delighted to know that hes got a book in the works  and not just any book, but a novel that will serve as a prequel to his money-minting 3-D science-fiction film Avatar. In an interview with MTV.com, Jon Landau, who produced Avatar with Mr. Cameron, said that the novel (whose printed words will presumably exist in boring old 2-D) will give a foundation for the story told in the film, providing back stories for characters like Jake Sully (played by Sam Worthington), Grace Augustine (Sigourney Weaver) and Colonel Quaritch (Stephen Lang).

title: Wearing Pajamas to School
description: What do you wear to school? I mean your childs school.

title: Trendspotting | Layers
description: For fall 2010, grunge returned with a vengeance to the New York runways in the form of a multitiered orchestration of garments.

title: A Lot of the Biathlon
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: The Winter Olympics are under way in Canada. They showed a lot of the biathlon, a combination of cross country skiing and shooting, which, to Sarah Palin, is called commuting.

title: He Celebrated Quietly
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know who is a crazy guy? That Kim Jong-il. North Korean dictator. Hes 68 years old today. Happy birthday to Kim Jong-il. He celebrated quietly at the mansion with his twin girlfriends.

title: Rescuing the Halfpipe With Shovels and Buckets
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The halfpipe is a massive structure, about 550 feet long, with walls 22 feet high.

title: Grunge Gets Respectable
description: Grunge used to be a dirty word in fashions lexicon, but it functioned this week as a kind of code for the elaborate layering that Marc Jacobs made his signature nearly two decades ago. For fall 2010, grunge returned with a vengeance to the New York runways in the form of a multitiered orchestration of garments so seemingly random it boggled the eye.

title: McCartney Hopes Abbey Road Plan Will Come Together
description: One of Abbey Road Studios most famous clients hopes that the facility, which has reportedly been put up for sale, can be saved. Paul McCartney, speaking to the BBCs Newsnight television show on Tuesday, said there have been efforts to save Abbey Road by a few people who have been associated with the studio for a long time, although he did not name those people or include himself among them.

title: Out With the Old Commissioners, In With the New
description: At the time, it seemed like a bold pledge: replacing 15 out of the citys 40 agency commissioners. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made it anyway, in October 2009 as he was campaigning for re-election, saying it was important to constantly reinvigorate government with new blood.

title: Getting Geeked for Glee
description: If youre yearning for a television series where religious attention to picayune details isnt mandatory (and which isnt Gossip Girl), the folks at Fox have provided this preview of coming episodes of Glee, which returns to the networks schedule in April. Youll get teases of a Madonna-themed episode, and make sure you are still around until the end to see Sue Sylvester inoh, we just cant spoil it for you.

title: The 7th Annual Great Performers in Film  2009
description: Stars and on-screen couples, five actresses who broke through and nine days on the road with Jeff Bridges.

title: Dueling Stimulus Ads on Obamas Jobs Plans
description: On the anniversary of President Obamas stimulus package, Democrats and Republicans have been throwing grenades online at one another.

title: Now Screening | Marc Jacobs
description: The fall 2010 collection from Marc Jacobs.

title: Running the (Exhausting) Oscar Circuit
description: There will not be any three-way shootouts or close-ups of shoes in the final installment of the Baggers series Lunch With Quentin Tarantino in a Mansion with Intimidating Art. (Yeah, still working on the titles.)

title: Photos of the Moment | Rodarte
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: The Olympics? Dont Tell Me.
description: At 6:24 last night, more than an hour and a half before NBC began its tape-delayed coverage of the Winter Olympics, The Times reported on its home page that Lindsey Jacobellis, a popular American, had veered off course in the semi-finals of the snowboard cross and was eliminated from medal contention.

title: Only David Gergen Can Save Us Now
description: Speaking of Evan Bayh and the inside-the-Beltway consensus, how long do you suppose it will before his name starts showing up in pieces like this one by Edward Luce, this one by Steve Clemons or this one by Leslie Gelb  all of which argue that only a sudden infusion of Washington wise men can save the Obama administration from itself? (In Matt Yglesiass pithy phrase, each one effectively urges Obama to fire all his friends, and bring my friends on board to run the country.) I can already see the Bayh-for-chief-of-staff constituency gathering steam

title: Changes at Gawker Fire the Imagination
description: On Monday, Gawker Media announced that it was buying CityFile, a relatively small Manhattan site known for its database of bios of A-listers. But the plot thickened a bit when it was revealed that Gabriel Snyder, the editor of Gawker, would be replaced by Remy Stern, the editor and publisher of CityFile.

title: Trans-Siberian Railway Views, a Click Away
description: If, like me, you have been thinking for decades that it would be great to travel the entire 5,752-mile route of the Trans-Siberian Railway from Europe to Asia one day, but are starting to suspect that you just might not ever actually get around to it, you may be glad to hear that there is now a virtual alternative.

title: Creamy Polenta With Sausage
description: You can put almost anything on a bed of polenta, but few things are better than a simple sausage. And theres no excuse not to make polenta, whose difficulties are overstated by a factor of ten. Learn how in this weeks Minimalist column.

title: Tesla Motors Executives Are Believed Dead in Plane Crash
description: Update 11:54 Pacific Time | Three executives of Tesla Motors, the electric car company, are believed to be dead after the small plane they were in crashed in East Palo Alto, Calif., shortly after taking off in thick fog Wednesday morning, according to the car Web site Jalopnik, which said it received confirmation from a Tesla representative.

title: Now Screening | Vera Wang
description: The fall 2010 collection from Vera Wang.

title: Airfare Price Tracking Gets Easier
description: Starting today, Yapta.com, the airfare tracking service, will offer broader search capabilities thanks to a partnership with Kayak, the meta-search site.

title: Young Mens Fashion
description: Who says Europe gets to have all the fun? When it comes to exciting new themes in mens fashion, New York Fashion Week is doing pretty well  our designers perspective is tempered by a more realistic understanding of what guys will actually wear. Its better to be ahead of the curve, so start placing your fall orders now.

title: The M.L.K. of Fatties
description: A fans description of the film-maker Kevin Smith, after Smith protested his removal from a flight on the grounds of his weight.

title: Behind the Scenes: Childs-Eye View of Haiti
description: They sweep through the streets of Haitis fourth-largest city, Jacmel, photographing the evolving daily life of a nation as it rebuilds. Moving quickly, they capture the resurfacing of a bustling market or a family settling into its new home inside a brightly colored canvas tent. Sometimes they meet resistance from residents, who worry that their tragedy might be exploited.Other times, they breeze through areas unnoticed, candidly photographing subjects who are acclimating to their new environments.

title: A Cartoon Depiction of Real Iranian Life
description: On Friday, First Second Books will begin publishing a serialized Web comic about Iran, exploring social, political and human rights issues there. The strip, called Zahras Paradise, described as real-time historical fiction, will blend current events with fictional composites of actual Iranians.

title: A New Olympic Pride
description: Pride House is believed to be the first house at the Olympics for gay and lesbian athletes and their friends and families and is seen as a new effort to tackle homophobia in sports.

title: Easing the Tics of Tourettes Syndrome
description: Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about Tourettes syndrome, a mysterious ailment that causes odd tics, sudden jerking movements and strange vocalizations. Here, Dr. Leckman and Dr. King respond to readers asking about medications, psychotherapy and experimental treatments for Tourettes.

title: Positive Views of Israel, Brought to You by Israelis
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government, deeply worried about the countrys declining international image, began a campaign on Wednesday to turn every Israeli  and ultimately every Jew  into a traveling public relations agent.

title: When Black Ice Strikes, Whos to Blame?
description: The streets seemed to shimmer last night as if glazed, the days snow melting and refreezing into treacherous patches of slick white and invisible black ice.

title: Act I, Scene I: The Cellphone Must Not Go On
description: THE producer David Richenthal was at a performance of The King and I in the late 1990s when a cellphone rang. Its owner, sitting near him in the audience, answered. He remembers her saying, in a heavy New Yawk accent, I cant talk right now, the king is dying.

title: Please, No More Mr. Bad Guy Roles! (But Creepy Is Fine)
description: AFTER four decades of playing almost every sort of sociopath imaginable, Christopher Walken laid down the law a couple of years ago with his agent about the scripts she kept sending him.

title: Toyotas President Softens on Speaking to Congress
description: DETROIT  Any company looks to its chief executive for leadership, especially in a time of crisis.

title: Are Store Brands Just as Good?
description: As in past recessions, consumers, including me, are buying more generic store brands.

title: U.N. Criticizes U.S. Restrictions on Aid for Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  United Nations officials intensified their criticism of the American government on Wednesday, saying that Washington was imposing impossible conditions on aid deliveries for Somalia and holding up tens of millions of dollars of desperately needed food based on unfounded accusations that it would be diverted to terrorists.

title: Geri Wang to Lead ABC Sales
description: Geri Wang, who has served in a key post in the sales and marketing operations for the ABC Television Network unit of ABC, is being promoted to the top spot.

title: Play It Again, Broadway, and Again
description: TODD HAIMES, the Roundabout Theater Companys artistic director, was in London in 2008 when a producer invited him to a revival of La Cage aux Folles. Having seen the 2004 Broadway revival, Mr. Haimes went only out of a sense of duty. There was just no reason to see it again, he recalls thinking. But by the end of the show I was crying, and I said: I understand why theyre redoing it. This deserves to be seen.

title: News Flash: Some Adobe Software Works on the iPad
description: As Stephanie Clifford wrote Tuesday, Wired magazine unveiled an iPad application with a fair amount of fanfare, including a demo of what a mashed-up future of old media and new might look like. It was a cool demo, but it left some of us confused. During the announcement of the iPad, much was made of the fact that it didnt work with Flash, the software from Adobe that animates much of the video on the Web. And yet, the Wired app was clearly built with Flash. What gives?

title: Settlement in Salvation Army Suit on Proselytizing
description: Updated, 4:14 p.m. |To settle a longstanding suit alleging that the Salvation Army preached Christianity in the course of its government-financed social services work, an agreement has been reached to ensure that it does not do so, the New York Civil Liberties Union announced Wednesday.

title: A Portrait of a Film Lover
description: Finally, there is something that all the Oscarologists, movie fans and industry folks can agree on (aside from the fact that the awards season is too long). Chris Joness profile of Roger Ebert in the March issue of Esquire has been making the rounds as a must-read, and it is: emotionally challenging, richly detailed and open, a portrait of a film lover who has done as much to promote cinema as any director, and a man who still has his voice even though its been nearly four years since he lost his lower jaw and ability to speak. The Bagger interviewed Mr. Ebert years ago, back when he was still flaunting his thumbs on television, and he was generous and savvy about how the media industry was changing. Now he is a first-rate blogger and Twitterer, and still an inspiration.

title: Drama! Music! Financial Shenanigans!
description: LONDON

title: Showtime | Dog Days of Fashion
description: It was sort of like Fashion Week.

title: Officials to Resume Search for Air France Wreckage
description: PARIS  Frances chief air accident investigator expressed cautious optimism Wednesday that the wreckage of an Air France jet that crashed in the Atlantic last June would be found when search efforts resume next month.

title: Barnes & Noble Rebuffs Approach by Burkle
description: Barnes & Noble has rejected a request by the major shareholder and Los Angeles billionaire Ronald Burkle to raise his stake in the book retailer, The Associated Press reports.

title: Napas Wineries Look to the Internet to Reach Customers
description: For the first time in 16 years, California wine shipments have fallen and Napa wineries are suffering, with sales of wine $25 a bottle and above down by 30 percent, according to an article in The New York Times.

title: Now Screening | Rodarte
description: The fall 2010 collection from Rodarte.

title: TLC and  Jon Gosselin Settle Lawsuits
description: Jon Gosselin is back in the TLC family nest.

title: With Lawsuits Settled, Jon Gosselin Could Return to TLC
description: Jon Gosselin is back in the TLC family nest.

title: China Intensifies Tug of War With India on Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  For years, Nepal never bothered too much with policing its northern border with China. The Himalayas seemed a formidable-enough barrier, and Nepals political and economic attention was oriented south toward India. If Nepal was a mouse trapped between elephants, as the local saying went, the elephant that mattered most was India.

title: Controlling Phones With the Body Electric
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Evolution has been so cruel, burdening us with fingers. Thank heaven there are engineers hard at work making sure we can live without them.

title: Vringo Seeks to Make Ring Tones More Social
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Creative marketing minds can make just about anything social these days. The start-up Vringo, for example, is giving what executives describe as a Facebook-like personal touch to ring tones, of all things.

title: Backstage Beauty | Just Plain Pretty at Marc Jacobs
description: Last season, Marc Jacobss girl was a dancer who had just left the cabaret with post-performance hair and makeup. This season, shes a chic, unfussy 70s French sophisticate sitting at a cafe in Saint Germain des Pres. Its very about an individual kind of woman, very untortured and at ease, said the hairstylist Guido Palau. Jacobs wanted new faces that would capture that kind of feeling, so he assembled a casting of over 150 new models and selected an interesting-looking group that included the unknown brunette Tati Cotliar, who opened the show.

title: Michael Shannon Is Next Stage Manager of Our Town
description: If youve seen Michael Shannons creep-tastic work in films like Revolutionary Road, the news that he is headed to your town may both delight and horrify you. So someone pass the word along to the good people of Grovers Corners: Mr. Shannon will be joining the cast of the Barrow Street Theaters long-running production of Our Town, playing the omniscient stage manager of that Thornton Wilder play.

title: Obama and Republicans Clash Over Stimulus Bill, One Year Later
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama defended his year-old economic stimulus package on Wednesday, as Republicans and Democrats took to the Internet and the airwaves to wage a furious partisan battle over whether the bill was a monumental waste of taxpayer money or had rescued the economy from catastrophe.

title: Why Househusbands Are the Future
