description: Gail Collins: David, when I was reading your column about the plight of male workers in our current hard times, I recalled a conversation I had with a friend about the TV series Cougar Town.

title: Karine Plantadit, Dancer
description: In a cramped studio on West 42nd Street in Manhattan the dancer Karine Plantadit moves to the center as Sinatras record of Thats Life swells in the background. She breaks free from a male dancers embrace, her fists clenched, her arms flexed; all of the songs force embodied in her movement. Wearing a skimpy brown blouse open down to there, shes a bit reckless, a little wild and impossible not to watch.

title: For the Moment | Trust Issues
description: Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London  but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New Yorks Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insiders view on whats driving gallivanters now.

title: Nottinghams Soulful Side?
description: NOTTINGHAMS crooked reputation doesnt stop at Robin Hoods penchant for pilfering. Indeed, for the past several decades, the citys name was synonymous with gun violence, earning it the nickname Shottingham. And Hockley, a neighborhood adjacent to the citys famed Lace Market, had particularly suffered, as factories shut their doors. So many people were out of work, said Daryl Gaskill, a Nottingham-based property manager. The Lace Market, and Hockley, which borders it, were filled with degenerates. You just didnt go there.

title: In Vietnam, Traveling an Unlikely Beer Trail
description: THE setting could have been any typical Central European beer garden. There were long rows of wooden tables stained in dark, rich hues; half- and full-liter beer mugs hanging from metal racks; and two beautifully crafted brass decoction tanks used for mashing traditionally brewed beer. But on this warm afternoon in November, I wasnt in Plzen, or Munich, or Bruges. I was at the Hoa Vien Bruhaus in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

title: Patrick Breen and Patrick Heusinger, Actors
description: It was a moment of rehearsal life imitating art for the two actors who portray the gay couple  Adam, an atheist, and Luke, deeply Christian  at the center of Next Fall, Geoffrey Naufftss critically lauded play. Like their characters, Patrick Breen, right above, and Patrick Heusinger interrupted each other amiably as they spoke about the transfer of the production from a small Off Broadway stage to the Helen Hayes Theater, where it opens on March 11.

title: Security at the Games and Its Cost Are Heavy
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  While the Vancouver Olympics have generally stayed within budget, the security costs have risen far beyond initial estimates of $175 million Canadian, or $167.5 million American, with the final tally widely expected to go beyond $1 billion Canadian.

title: Nina Arianda, Actor
description: Diligently preparing for the audition that would change her life, Nina Arianda, 25, ran lines for days, bought new clothes and worked on building her confidence. The role she was trying out for in David Ivess twisty new play, Venus in Fur, might have had something to do with that: the character of a frazzled young actor desperate to impress a director was something she understood all too well.

title: Trekking With Wolves
description: WINTER strips the wilderness of color: white snow, gray ice, the Dalmatian spots of paper birches. The somber green of pine and spruce and claret stems of red osier are vivid in comparison. Simple forms stand in high relief: a black pool of open water flanked by snow, daggers of ice plunging from slaty rocks, low sun, long shadows. The effect is striking, as austere and beautiful as an Ansel Adams print.

title: First Look: Tory Burch
description: Views from backstage at Tory Burch's Fall 2010 collection.

title: Tony Vincent, Actor
description: Tony Vincent has a soft Mohawk-like haircut, a big voice and a past in pop music. So its not entirely surprising that Mr. Vincent, one of the stars of American Idiot, the coming Broadway show based on a Green Day album, would list among his influences some of rocks most theatrical leading men: Freddie Mercury of Queen, David Lee Roth of Van Halen, Robert Smith of the Cure.

title: Ellen Fairey, Playwright
description: Im a person who doesnt like summer or sunshine, said Ellen Fairey, playwright and self-proclaimed melancholic. Speaking with all the cautionary exuberance of Eeyore, she was discussing her play Graceland, which received rave reviews in Chicago last year and is the occasion of her New York debut in May. I mean, she added, I feel like its all downhill from here.

title: Stanley Tucci, Director
description: It is much easier to make somebody cry than to make them laugh, Stanley Tucci observed. As an actor he has been doing both in movie theaters recently.

title: High Court in Ukraine Weighs Appeal on Election
description: MOSCOW  A high court in Ukraine began Wednesday to consider Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenkos request to overturn the results of the countrys presidential election, which she narrowly lost.

title: Camp Oscar
description: With their hair rolled and fluffed, their lips glossy and eyes smoldering in the direction of the photographers (egad!), the models at Oscar de la Renta today hinted of espionage. Or maybe a dangerous affair! O.K., how about lunch at La Grenouille. Mr. de la Renta was very much in a luxe-glam zone, now with a leaner silhouette than recent seasons, below-the-knee skirts in tweed embroidered at the hem and finished with a nutria band, and a palette that included magenta, lapis blue and emerald paired with black. Evening clothes were predominantly in black, silvery gray and champagne.

title: Mourning a Diner Man, if Not His Mustache
description: Maybe it was the handlebar mustache that kept them coming back. The perfect curlicues framed an ever-present smile and gave everyone, new customers and old, a conversation piece and a reason to remember Pete of Petes Cafe.

title: To Be Topical in a Time Out of Joint
description: THE theater critics for The New York Times, Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, looked at the spring seasons offerings and found a number of productions that addressed pressing issues. Are political shows making a comeback? They discussed this and other aspects in an e-mail conversation excerpted below.

title: Mississippians Go to Church the Most
description: Compared with residents of other states, people in Mississippi go to church most frequently, according to new survey data from Gallup. Vermonters, on the other hand, report going to church the least often.

title: Would-Be Teammate Criticizes Daviss Withdrawal
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The speedskater Shani Davis has once again landed at the center of controversy after his decision to pull out of the Olympic 500 meters midway through the event, two days before he was to try to defend his 1,000 meters crown on Wednesday.

title: Concrete-Testing Company Guilty in Partial Verdict
description: A concrete testing company and its owner were convicted on Wednesday of filing false test reports on various projects throughout New York, including the new Yankee Stadium, the Freedom Tower and the Second Avenue subway line.

title: Model-morphosis | Peter Som
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Irina Kulikova from IMG Models, before (above, top) and after makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Laurent Philippon for Bumble and bumble. (Drag the orange bar down to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Airport Traffic Lowest Since 2004
description: Fewer travelers used the major airports in and around the city last year than in any year since 2004, according to statistics released on Wednesday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Three Tesla Employees Dead in California Plane Crash
description: Update | 3:39 p.m.

title: BofA and S.E.C. Say Settlement Needs No Changes
description: From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

title: Travel Deals: Amtrak Discounts to Canada and the Midwest
description: Amtrak is offering a weekend getaway package from New York City to Montreal, for $85 round trip on the Adirondack line. Children under 15 travel for half price.

title: Defying Injury, Vonn Wins Gold in Downhill
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Standing next to the start house, Lindsey Vonn heard the radio crackle. She lifted it to her ear.

title: Tech Industry Catches Its Breath
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The technology industry has sucked in a deep breath and paused for a rare moment of reflection.

title: Prosecutor Asks Mineo Jury to Focus on Blood
description: Updated, 5:29 p.m. | The summations are finished and the case has gone to the jury. However, deliberations are over for the day. Theyll resume tomorrow.

title: Washington Theater to Christen New Home  With Albee Festival and Ruined
description: The Washington theater company Arena Stage on Wednesday announced productions for its 2010-11 season that coincide with the grand opening of its new campus. The complex, the Mead Center for American Theater, will include three theaters, rehearsal and shop space, and offices and will bring every part of Arena Stage under the same roof for the first time.

title: The Significance of the Janikowski Contract
description: After making Sebastian Janikowski the only kicker of his generation to be a first-round draft choice, the Oakland Raiders have now made him the highest-paid place-kicker in the game. Janikowskis four-year, $16 million contract carries $9 million in guarantees.

title: Why Ravens Are Giving Donte Stallworth a Chance
description: The Baltimore Ravens are signing wide receiver Donte Stallworth to a one-year, $900,000 contract. Before his year-long suspension for pleading guilty to D.U.I. manslaughter, Stallworth specialized in one-year tenures.

title: The Morning Skate: U.S. Team Not at Its Best in Opener
description: Ever the contrarian, Mike Milburys remarks after the U.S. Olympic teams victory over Switzerland (video at around the 1:20 mark) hardly overflowed with glowing praise. It was all right. They got the win, Milbury told the USA Networks postgame audience. The best thing you can say about these guys is they put the two points in the bank and its behind them. But they have to be a lot better than that going forward. They were careless with the puck. I thought they made some decisions that were questionable on pinches, and they gave away far too many opportunities.

title: Some Surprises in Terras Deal With Yara
description: Terra Industries has made a surprising decision to sell itself to Yara International of Norway for $4.1 billion. Only a month ago, Terra successfully fended off a hostile bid by CF Industries Holdings. And during Terras yearlong fight against CF Industries, it had failed to obtain any other interest, making its rejection of CFs advances perilous and leaving its shareholders clamoring for returns equivalent to those CF offered. Terras announcement of a deal with Yara is a clear vindication of that just say no strategy.

title: Tourists, Tourists Everywhere
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has just released its major report on tourism. And as those of us who work near Times Square may suspect, the United States appears to have the highest international tourism receipts:

title: Now Showing | Ute Mahlers G.D.R. Chic
description: The German photographer Ute Mahler became one of the G.D.R.s fashion visionaries, her work a testament to the subversive role fashion can assume as a mode of expression in an authoritarian state. Mahler was focused not on extreme fantasy but on a heightened sense of reality. She presented women as strong individuals, concerned more with style than with the latest fashions (which werent available anyway to citizens of the G.D.R). Her work is the subject of a show at Berlins Galerie fr Moderne Fotografie until March 10. She sat down for a fascinating conversation and shed some light on a rarely discussed period of fashion history.

title: Utility Executives Like Nuclear Power. Climate Science, Not So Much.
description: American utility industry executives see nuclear energy as the most promising carbon-free power source, are skeptical of climate change science, and are uncertain about the future, according to a report to be issued Thursday by Black & Veatch, the engineering and consulting giant.

title: Catwalk or Catalog?
description: Lingerie stole the shows in Paris. Will Fredericks have the last laugh?

title: A New Conservative Outline
description: On the eve of the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, known as CPAC, several well-known Republicans, includingEdwin Meese III, the former attorney general, have signed a new document called the Mount Vernon Statement.

title: Scientists Decode Genomes of Five Africans, Including Archbishop Tutu
description: The complete genomes of five southern Africans have been decoded, almost doubling the number of published human DNA sequences. The Africans include four Bushmen hunter-gatherers, known as !Gubi, G/aqo, D#kgao and !Ai, the odd symbols representing different clicking sounds in Bushmen languages. The fifth person, a Bantu, is none other than Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

title: A Decade of Favorites
description: Another thing that most film buffs can agree on: The New York Times Magazines close-ups with leading actors are pretty cool. (Admittedly, were biased, and not just because those magazine assignments are pretty plum gigs.) This year, Jake Gyllenhaal, Julianne Moore, George Clooney, Vera Farmiga and Zoe Saldana reveal their favorite performances of the last decade. Our vote would have to include Sandra Bullocks wig.

title: New Surroundings for the Flame
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The caldron of many legs holding the Olympic flame is still imprisoned. But changes made by Olympic organizers on Tuesday night have at least placed it within a more aesthetically pleasing form of captivity.

title: Backstage Beauty | Girlish Ghosts at Rodarte
description: Last season, the beauty look at Rodarte matched the warrior-like clothes, with tribal tattoos, strong makeup colors and severe hair. This season, the hair and makeup were as romantic as the clothes. The makeup artist James Kaliardos said he was inspired by desaturated photos, nighttime visions and spirits.

title: Who Wins in a McGrady Trade? Maybe Utah
description: If the Knicks and the Houston Rockets consummate their proposed deal for Tracy McGrady, the winner will probably be the Utah Jazz.

title: One Year Anniversary of the Stimulus
description: The Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg discusses President Obama's speech on the first anniversary of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, the $787 billion stimulus package.

title: Tesla Employees Killed in Plane Crash
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A small plane crashed into a residential neighborhood in East Palo Alto Wednesday, killing three employees of Tesla Motors, the California electric car company, and causing widespread power disruptions, officials said.

title: Attila and Muti in Debuts at the Met
description: WHEN Riccardo Muti ruled Teatro alla Scala in Milan from 1986 to 2005, a telephone caller to the opera houses business offices was greeted in style: the first sound on the line was a gorgeously arching melody played by the full orchestra. Opera fans could probably identify the composer  Giuseppe Verdi  but they might have had trouble placing the tune. It comes from the brief prelude to his seldom performed opera Attila, which finally receives its Metropolitan Opera premiere on Tuesday. Leading the performance will be Mr. Muti in his own Met debut.

title: BBC Host Admits Killing Ailing Partner
description: LONDON  The revelation seemed to slip out, almost as an aside. In the midst of narrating a television program about end-of-life decisions, the documentary maker Ray Gosling departed from the prepared script and declared, his voice shaking with emotion, I killed someone once.

title: Paul Taylor: Return of the Beloved Renegade
description: Its tempting  wrong, but tempting  to take the choreographer Paul Taylor for granted. He will be 80 this year. He has been choreographing since the 1950s. While the fortunes of other one-choreographer troupes have risen and fallen, his company has had an annual season at New York City Center Theater almost every year since 1977. (Its Feb. 24 to March 14 this year.) Several of the biggest American ballet companies dance some of his best-loved works.

title: The Care and Feeding of Kids: Finding Information on Nutrition and Fitness
description: Overview | How healthy are children in America? Why did first lady Michelle Obama introduce a new health initiative aimed at reducing childhood obesity? In this lesson, students reflect on their knowledge of health, nutrition and exercise. Then they review New York Times articles, videos and other features on issues related to childrens health and diet, either by playing a bingo game or by running through the issues from A to Z. Finally, students create a personalized calendar to encourage them to make healthy choices.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Feb. 17
description: In what appears at first to be a picture of a group of Marines, Tyler Hicks of The Times has in fact created five distinctive portraits of individuals; men who are collecting themselves after the death of one comrade in a Taliban ambush and the wounding of two others. It is well worth time to use the Full Screen button above, to the right of the slide counter, and study Slide 1. Look at each face. Observe each mans posture. They have paid a price. They are not defeated.

title: Feb. 21  27
description: Pop

title: Buzzing, Tweeting and Carping
description: Funny, isnt it? The people who review gadgets generally arent the people who buy them.

title: Tax Forms That Come Already Filled Out
description: Hate filling out your tax form? If youre a resident of California and meet other qualifications, you can actually get a tax return prefilled with information that the state government already has about you, and similar programs may show up in other states one day.

title: Palin Again Criticizes Fox Show, This Time on Fox
description: Though they share a corporate parent, Sarah Palin continued her criticism of her Fox sibling Seth MacFarlane, the creator of Family Guy, in an appearance on The OReilly Factor that drew support from the programs host, Bill OReilly.

title: Bail Set for Father in Terror Case
description: Federal prosecutors said on Wednesday that they had agreed on bail provisions for a Colorado man who has been charged with obstructing an investigation into a terrorist bombing plot.

title: Oscar-Watching, in Style
description: Forget the Kodak Theater. On March 7, New Yorkers with an outsize share of local pride  which is to say, most of us  can head to Alice Tully Hall for the citys first-ever official Oscar-watching party. The event, organized by NYC & Company, the tourism bureau, will include a cocktail reception and music by the Juilliard Jazz Ensemble, which will play songs from Oscar-winning films. Tickets are $150 and $225 and available here.

title: Sponsorship Woes Threaten Future of U.S. Formula 1 Team
description: A bottle of Champagne sits in an otherwise empty trophy case that greets visitors in the lobby of the new USF1 headquarters in Charlotte, N.C. It is a gift for the team founders, Ken Anderson and Peter Windsor, to be opened March 14, when the first Formula One team based in the United States since the 1970s lines up on the starting grid in Bahrain for the opening race of the season.

title: Theater Talkback: Spring Is in the Air
description: Sundays Arts & Leisure issue includes a special look at the spring theater season. In this article, Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, the Timess theater critics, discuss whether or not political shows are making a comeback.

title: BofA Merrill Names Global Corporate Banking Head
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that it had named Paul M. Donofrio as the head of its global corporate banking business.

title: Reactions to Baradars Arrest
description: As Carlotta Gall and Souad Mekhenet report in todays Times, Pakistans arrest of the top Taliban military commander, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, may be a tactical victory for the United States, but analysts also see it as a potential strategic coup for Pakistan, which has been signaling its interest in participating in any mediation efforts between the West and the Taliban.

title: House G.O.P. Leaders Seek a Jobs Summit
description: Open forums seem to be the latest fad in Washington.

title: Places, Everyone! Take the Usual Places.
description: WEVE always been into mythology, but now were into alchemy, Gabi Asfour, of the design collective ThreeASFOUR said before his show on Tuesday evening. Mr. Asfour meant that literally. Lately these resolutely noncommercial designers have been looking into eons-old philosophies that sought wisdom, the elixir of longevity and the ability to transform base metals into gold.

title: Financing Offered for Delayed Airbus Plane
description: BERLIN  The German government is prepared to offer up to 1.2 billion euros in cash and loan guarantees to help Airbus pay for cost overruns on the A400M military transport plane, a person involved in the negotiations said Tuesday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Head Shots
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: National Trust Considers Buying Abbey Road Studios
description: The National Trust, a British preservation charity, has emerged as a possible buyer for Abbey Road Studios in London.

title: A New York Relationship Gets More Complicated
description: In the 50 years since it named itself for the side streets closest to its first store, Duane Reade has had a singular relationship with New York. Complicated, unavoidable, convenient, annoying  whatever that relationship was, even Duane Reade seemed to understand how deeply it had worked its way into the municipal psyche.

title: Woods to Address His Past and His Future on Friday
description: MARANA, Ariz.  And everyone thought Tiger Woods would not be showing up at the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship this week. But he was here in spirit, dominating the airwaves shortly after noon on Wednesday when ESPN broadcast the announcement that Woods plans to break his lengthy silence and end his self-imposed exile from the game at a televised Friday event in Florida.

title: Wright Is Upbeat, an Early Sign of Spring
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  In the months after the disappointing 2009 season, Mets fans watched carefully to see how the front office would respond. The team signed Jason Bay and made additions to the pitching staff, but that did not seem to satisfy the loyal fan base, which has grown more agitated and despondent by the day, with more forecasts of another season of gloom at Citi Field.

title: The Olympic Art of Tweeting
description: In between training, eating, sleeping and competing, Olympians are finding time to let their fingers do some talking in Vancouver  via Twitter.

title: Short Stroll to the Wild Side From the Safe Side at Home
description: Congratulations, Travis Baker, on writing a play with gratuitous everything in it. Theres nudity, of course, but also sex, rape, anal rape, assault, blood, something like oral sex performed on a gun barrel, and more. Perhaps its not surprising that Mr. Baker didnt have much room for things like believability and back story.

title: The Case Against (Self) Torture
description: Because of the economy, I have really been watching expenses and doing a cost-benefit analysis on all nonessential spending. I recently had to question whether I should go to the international picture-frame trade show  yes, there is one  in Italy, as I have every year for 15 years. I import half of the frames I sell from Italy and Spain, which has allowed me to sell wholesale to other frame shops nationally. But I decided to skip the show this year. Cutting expenses has taken precedence over looking for opportunities to improve my business.

title: Answers About the History of Complaining
description: Following is the first set of responses from Matthew Bakkom, the editor and creator of New York City Museum of Complaint, a collection of 132 letters written to the mayor of New York from 1751 to 1969.

title: How to Create an Advisory Board
description: Jim Bourdon, chief executive of Accounting Management Solutions in Waltham, Mass., said his advisory board persuaded him to be more aggressive about jettisoning ineffective consultants and replacing them with star performers. The result? His clients report that his companys consultants are either meeting or exceeding the standards set by Mr. Bourdon and his team.

title: Sades Comeback Succeeds With Quiet Application of Old-School Approach
description: How do you make it to No. 1 on the Billboard chart? Sades strategy: take a decade off and remain mysterious.

title: App of the Week: Finding Vines and Fine Wines
description: After being snowbound for two weeks, most of the mid-Atlantic could stand to put down the shovels, get out of the house and to have a relaxing glass of wine (or five).

title: Should Chargers Trade Antonio Cromartie?
description: ESPN is reporting that the Chargers are looking into  shopping cornerback Antonio Cromartie for a running back. With LaDainian Tomlinsons career all but over and with Darren Sproles facing free agency, San Diego is in dire need of a featured back. But theyd be taking a slight gamble by dealing Cromartie. Yes, the former first-round pick has had two inconsistent seasons since his 10-interception breakout campaign.

title: Stirring the Late Romantics Libido
description: Dissolute, drugged out and, dare I say, horny, was how the pianist Steven Blier, from the Merkin Concert Hall stage on Tuesday, described the late romantic works in the New York Festival of Songs Voluptuous Muse.

title: An Elite Squadron, Before It Was Airborne
description: Black Angels Over Tuskegee, Layon Grays sturdy drama about trailblazing African-American fighter pilots entering the European theater in World War II, gets by on the charm of the cast and a commitment to the rules of the uplifting inspirational melodrama.

title: Berlin Takes Film Fest, and Fringe, in Stride
description: BERLIN  At the Berlin International Film Festival every year large-format photo portraits of visiting stars line the stairs of the cavernous Berlinale Palast. A paparazzi encampment can often be seen outside the Grand Hyatt Hotel, where the press conferences are held.

title: Fisher-Price Takes (On) a Leap
description: Fisher-Price has been showing its new iXL Learning Systems (pronounced I excel), an $80 touch-screen edu-game platform for preschoolers coming in June.

title: Artifacts | Banks Violette
description: Banks Violette is one artist who lives for the idea that nothing is ever lost or destroyed, only transformed. His blackouts/blackholes (and all the things between)/for DS 7.13.09, the massive three-part sculpture he just unveiled at the Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea (and dedicated to the late Dash Snow), looks like a shiny black pyramid frozen in midcollapse. Or the remains of the stage at an arena rock show disrupted by stampeding fans. Or the walls of a nightclub after a bombing. Its made of high-gloss fiberglass, and the much-tattooed Violette, 37, stomped the glossy black material till it buckled, then erected it on steel scaffolding weighted by absurdly small black sandbags. Reflected in the walls surface is throne, a chandelier of fluorescent tubes that resembles an umbrella clothes dryer trailing long tendrils of black wires to a common instrument case. Both works simultaneously pay homage to, and thumb their noses at, Minimalist sculptures by Dan Flavin and Robert Smithson, while proving there is light in darkness, and in grief, redemption.

title: Top Judge Sets Liberal Course for New York
description: Gov. David A. Paterson nominated Jonathan Lippman to head the New York Court of Appeals in January 2009, making him the chief judge of the state. The choice was a gamble: The judge, a longtime court administrator, did not have a long history of deciding cases, and there was almost no record of his political views.

title: Filmmakers With Shared Grit
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  One night in the early 1990s Nash Edgerton, about 20 years old and struggling as an electrical-engineering student, awoke with an inspiration.

title: Top Chef Goes Tuscan in North Hollywood
description: If Top Chef has given the world anything, its a string of upstart restaurants started by the shows telegenic alums. The latest is from Fabio Viviani, the charming fan-favorite from Season 5 in New York City, who recently opened Firenze Osteria in North Hollywood, Calif.

title: Israelis Share Suspicions in Hamas Leaders Killing
description: JERUSALEM  The initial nods, winks and pats on the back here over the assassination last month of a senior Hamas official in Dubai are turning to puzzlement and concern as mounting evidence, including extensive surveillance videos, points to a remarkably clumsy operation many Israelis deem unworthy of their intelligence service, Mossad.

title: Rabbit Legs with Peas, Collards and Country Ham
description: 1 cup Sea Island red peas, from Anson Mills, or substitute pigeon peas

title: Trade Commission, Citing Deception, Sues Seven Job Placement Operators
description: WASHINGTON  After eight months without work, Cathy Willburn spotted a classified ad last June offering a full-time job operating a forklift in a warehouse for $14 to $19 an hour, with benefits.

title: Sewer Hookup Drags Queens Hamlet Into 20th Century
description: It is a day they thought would never come, down here in the Land of the Lost: No more flushing of toilets into Hook Creek. No more running of dishwater and bathwater into Jamaica Bay.

title: The Cheat: A Bunny Hop
description: It isnt easy to cook restaurant food at home. Chefs dont have kitchens like ours for the same reason that Jeff Koons doesnt have a studio like your Aunt Hildies up in the attic. Chefs have enterprises to run, not children to feed. They have bustling shops filled with skilled staff members charged with particular duties. Chefs have systems. We have a stove, a refrigerator and a sink, not enough counter space and a dog lying somewhere inconvenient. (Hey, a dishwasher!)

title: Nabors Looks to Sell $2 Billion in Energy Assets
description: Nabors Industries, the oil and gas driller, is looking to dispose of about $2 billion in energy assets worldwide as it moves to slim down its operations after several quarters of anemic growth.

title: Quote Unquote | Leggo My Ego
description: Paulina Porizkova on how being recognized by an Olsen made her feel better about being snubbed by Anna Wintour. Beggars cant be choosers!

title: Bill Clinton Is Back at Work
description: Former President Bill Clinton, who underwent a heart procedure last week, pronounced himself fit and glad to be back doing some work earlier Wednesday afternoon.

title: Ohno Takes Aim at History
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In Wednesdays Times, we explored Apolo Ohnos roller skating roots. Tonight, here at the Pacific Coliseum, he takes aim at history, the American Winter Olympics version.

title: Colicchio & Sons Goes Prix Fixe
description: At Colicchio & Sons, his new makeover of Craftsteak near the meatpacking district, Tom Colicchio has changed his menu format. He has just replaced the a la carte menu in the main dining room with a prix fixe dinner menu at $78, for three courses plus canapes and petits fours. Theres also a $125 8-course menu.

title: Verizon Will Carry HBOs Streaming Service
description: HBO took the wraps off its Internet streaming service, called HBO GO, on Wednesday, and announced that Verizon FiOS would be its first distribution partner.

title: Scorecard | Thakoon Wins!
description: Will we all be monsters next fall? As Scorecard can tell you, Sundays lineup was a veritable bestiary, full of wild and woolly coats, sweaters made of human-hair-like goat hair (and sweaters made of actual human hair!) and other things that go bump in the night. With Thakoon leading the wild rumpus, it seems the only potential faux pas was playing it pretty safe.

title: Shopping With Mart Guix
description: A Catalan designer sought out tableware with character.

title: A Collector of Road Trips, Just Passing Through
description: There is one important kind of path that cannot be found in Ted Conovers globe-spanning adventure book about roads: the one that would run all the way through The Routes of Man and give it thematic consistency and purpose.

title: The Routes of Man
description: The Road Is Very Unfair

title: Resetting the Table
description: IT has been nearly a decade since Mart Guix began calling himself an ex-designer as a way to express his disdain for traditional approaches to design.

title: Part Traditionalist, Part Naturalist, Part Dissident
description: THE artist Yun-Fei Ji was riding his electric bike through Beijing last October, snapping pictures of the elaborate parades honoring the 60th anniversary of the Peoples Republic of China. Suddenly, he said, among the white-uniformed soldiers holding bouquets of red flowers and the rows of bright blue military tanks, everywhere I looked, I saw either a volunteer guard with a red armband or a policeman or a soldier.

title: Taking a Chance on an M.R.I.
description: Heres the problem: The M.R.I. has become the gold standard in medical imaging; doctors use it routinely to diagnose problems in joints, brains, hearts. After age 65, a person is twice as likely as before to have an imaging scan, research shows.

title: Snipers Imperil U.S.-Led Forces in Afghan Offensive
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  In five days of fighting, the Taliban have shown a side not often seen in nearly a decade of American military action in Afghanistan: the use of snipers, both working alone and integrated into guerrilla-style ambushes.

title: Dont Worry, Aerobics Are Optional
description: FASHION retailers, as battered as theyve been over the last couple of years, have been pretty upbeat about the fall collections. One reason is the popular layering trend, in which designers have shown jackets over vests over sweaters over dresses, and putting together those looks in their stores will logically require customers to make multiple purchases.

title: Idol Beats the Olympics, But by a Smaller Margin Than Usual
description: The power of American Idol as a television attraction was reaffirmed Tuesday night when the singing competition on the Fox network convincingly beat the snow-and-ice competition on NBC.

title: Turning Patents Into Invention Capital
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  Nathan Myhrvold wants to shake up the marketplace for ideas. His mission and the activities of the company he heads, Intellectual Ventures, a secretive $5 billion investment firm that has scooped up 30,000 patents, inspire admiration and angst.

title: Finland Defeats Belarus in Mens Hockey
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Fans sometimes forget that Finland was the 2006 Olympic mens hockey silver medalist, having lost the final to Sweden by 3-2 on a goal with 10 minutes to play. The Finns are not among the favorites here, even though their roster features several veteran N.H.L. stars and perhaps three of the worlds best goalies.

title: Modern and Quirky
description: Monolithic from the outside, a Dutch dream home contains lots of quirkiness.

title: The Plastic Ono Band, Reunited
description: Yoko Ono and Sean Lennon reunited the band, an informal group put together by John Lennon, for a performance at Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Idol Outdraws Winter Olympics
description: It was no contest when American Idol squared off against NBCs coverage of the Winter Olympics on Tuesday. Ratings for Idol easily topped the night, according to Nielsens estimates, as a two-hour installment of the Fox reality show delivered an average of 23.6 million viewers, as its first set of semifinalists were revealed. NBCs Winter Games coverage, including figure skating, speed skating and snowboarding, averaged 20.4 million for the night over all. CBS placed third on the night with reruns, while ABC was fourth with new episodes of Lost (9.8 million) and The Forgotten (5.1 million).

title: HBO Go, the Best Online Video Service I Cannot Use
description: HBOs latest venture, HBO Go, looks like a great new product, streaming more than 600 hours of HBO-specific programming online. Its a shame that I wont be able to use it.

title: A Cartoon Depiction of Real Iranian Life
description: A serialized Web comic about Iran, exploring social, political and human rights problems there, makes its debut on Friday. The publisher, First Second Books, describes the strip, called Zahras Paradise, as real-time historical fiction, blending current events with fictional composites of actual Iranians. The first story line, above, begins in June 2009 during the turmoil surrounding the contested presidential election. Mark Siegel, the editorial director of First Second, said in a statement that Zahras Paradise is not merely a work of observation, adding, Art becomes a player, a participant, a voice adding to the chorus of voices in the streets and on the rooftops of Iran. The Web comic is written by Amir, a human-rights activist, and illustrated by Khalil. First Second Books is keeping their last names confidential to protect their safety. The comic can be read at zahrasparadise.com beginning Friday.

title: Our Town and Hair Get New Cast Members
description: If youve seen Michael Shannons creep-tastic work in films like Revolutionary Road, the news that he is headed to your town may both delight and horrify you. So someone pass the word along to the good people of Grovers Corners: Mr. Shannon will be joining the cast of the Barrow Street Theaters long-running production of Our Town, playing the omniscient stage manager of that Thornton Wilder play. Press representatives for Our Town said that Mr. Shannon will start in the production on Tuesday, following in the footsteps of Stephen Kunken (whos headed to Enron on Broadway) and David Cromer, who directed the Our Town revival in New York and at the Hypocrites Theater in Chicago. Mr. Shannon was nominated for an Academy Award for his performance in Revolutionary Road. ... Ace Young and Diana DeGarmo, former contestants on American Idol, will play the characters Berger and Sheila in the new cast for Broadway musical revival of Hair, the shows producers announced on Tuesday. Kyle Riabko, above right, with Mr. Young and Ms. DeGarmo,  will also join the cast, as Claude. The current cast, led by Will Swenson as Berger and Gavin Creel as Claude, is heading to London to open a West End production of Hair, with preview performances starting April 1. The new cast of the Broadway Hair will take over on March 9.

title: McCartney Expresses Hopes for Abbey Road
description: One of Abbey Road Studios most famous clients hopes that the facility, which has reportedly been put up for sale, can be saved. Paul McCartney, speaking to the BBCs Newsnight television program on Tuesday, said there have been efforts to save Abbey Road by a few people who have been associated with the studio for a long time, although he did not name those people or include himself among them. I have so many memories there with the Beatles, he added. It still is a great studio. So it would be lovely for someone to get a thing together to save it. The Financial Times, citing anonymous sources, has reported that EMI, the longtime owner of the studio, in North London  home to most Beatles sessions  had put the building on the market. The National Trust, nationaltrust.org.uk, a British preservation charity, said on its Web site, that it would consider buying the complex.

title: TLC and Jon Gosselin Settle Suits
description: Jon Gosselin is back in the TLC family nest. He had strayed from the cable channel, which showcased his super-sized family last year on the show Jon and Kate Plus Eight. But dueling lawsuits between Mr. Gosselin and the channel have been settled, TLC confirmed on Wednesday, potentially reopening the door to more reality TV from the famous family. The whole Gosselin family remain under contract with TLC, the channel said in a statement. The settlement terms are confidential. Jon and Kate took an ugly turn last spring when the marriage of Jon and Kate Gosselin  collapsed, culminating in an on-camera separation announcement in June. When TLC tried to reduce Mr. Gosselins role and rename the show Kate Plus Eight, a war of words ensued. He called for an end to filming and declared that the show had hurt his family. TLC filed a lawsuit against him in October for breach of contract. He countersued a month later. Production of the new show was suspended, but a separate show with Ms. Gosselin  but not her children  is moving forward, with a scheduled debut in the spring, TLC said.

title: After 400 Years, Globe to Stage Womans Play
description: After more than 400 years, there were still a few milestones that Shakespeares Globe Theater in London had not yet reached. Now hold onto your jerkin, because for the first time since the doors of the original Globe opened in 1599, the theater plans to present a play by a female author. The Guardian reported that the playwright Nell Leyshon will have her play Bedlam, about the notorious London mental hospital, the Bethlem, performed at the Globe as part of its coming season. In fairness to the Globe, it presented no plays at all from the time it was shut down by the Puritans in 1642 and when performances resumed in the reconstructed theater in 1997, but Ms. Leyshon still appreciates the honor. I wanted to prove that women can do conflict, she told The Guardian, that they can write big structures, big stories because Ive heard it too many times that women arent as good at that. The new season is to begin on April 23 and will also include productions of Hamlet, Henry IV parts 1 and 2 and Henry VIII.

title: Amid All That Experience, Innocence
description: In some ways Yoko Ono is still an amateur. At We Are Plastic Ono Band, mixing concert and tribute at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night, her voice could be shaky and her stage patter giggly and unplanned. She looked genuinely surprised when the audience interrupted her and sang Happy Birthday. (She turns 77 on Feb. 18.) Shes also untamed. She can still let loose the bleats, wails, yips, howls and shrieks that alienated Beatles fans in the 1960s and inspired avant-rockers soon afterward.

title: R.B.S.s Shining Star in Connecticut
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  The Royal Bank of Scotland may be one of Britains most bailed-out banks. But at its American headquarters here, there is hardly a whisper of distress.

title: On Anniversary of Stimulus Law, Pelosi Comes Home to Tout Its Merits
description: Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, returned to her home district of San Francisco Wednesday to tout the success of the $787 billion economic stimulus package that Democrats passed into law exactly a year ago.

title: The Scene: Day Seven
description: Scenes around the tents at Bryant Park and backstage during New York Fashion Week.

title: Skype in a Struggle to Be Heard on Mobile Phones
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Josh Silverman, the chief executive of Skype, the voice-over-Internet phone service, could tick off the names of mobile phone operators that block his companys service.

title: An Extra Week of Pride
description: The Off Broadway production of The Pride, about a fraught love triangle in 1958 and a stormy gay relationship in the present day, will extend for an additional week to March 28 because of audience demand, the producers announced on Wednesday.

title: A Dutch Home With Some Serious Whimsy
description: AMSTELSCHEG, the Netherlands

title: Invisible Hand in MoMA Shows
description: In hundreds of exhibitions over the last three decades the names of a stunning number of curators and artists have entered the institutional memory of the Museum of Modern Art. But behind nearly all of these shows there has been a constant, a man whose name rarely surfaces anywhere except in invoices.

title: An Illuminating Swan, Then a Pure-Dance End
description: At last! After months of concentrating on full-length narrative ballets, New York City Ballet is closing its winter season with three programs of the pure-dance works that are central to its legend. In the Balanchine double bill that opened on Tuesday night, the choreography suggested not less plot than the story ballets but more, and the company again looked itself  though not in invariably good ways in the opening ballet, Liebeslieder Walzer. In the closing ballet, Tschaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2, Ashley Bouder, branding her steps onto the music, swept through the lead role with the kind of quietly precise blaze that exemplifies how this troupe can be at its best.

title: Safe Travels for You and Your Data
description: Youre a smart traveler. You pack sunscreen and Pepto, locks for your luggage and a pouch to hide cash under your clothes. But what digital precautions do you take?

title: Crafting a Party
description: The warehouse parties that have roved Brooklyn for more than a decade have become ever-more-refined environments.

title: Signs of Rebound in Antiques Market
description: LAST months series of major antiques shows and sales in New York City signaled growing strength in a market that was hit hard over the previous year, according to dealers, show managers and others in the field. But good buys still abound, especially in 18th- and 19th-century English and American furniture.

title: Up to Date on Facebook
description: Up to Date

title: Homework for Hiring a Broker
description: TO vet a prospective broker, you have several choices, although no single approach will give you all the answers.

title: Judge Releases Eight Americans Jailed in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A Haitian judge on Wednesday ordered the release of 8 of the 10 Americans arrested here on child abduction charges but decided that two members of the group, including its leader, would remain in jail for additional questioning.

title: Readers Sound Off on Cellphone Manners
description: Last week Ben Brantley, The New York Timess chief theater critic, wrote about the aftermath of having a companions cellphone go off during a performance of Gatz at the American Repertory Theater in Boston.

title: New Rum Campaign Has a Sophisticated Tone
description: The raucous, party-hardy image of rum is not for the rum distillers of Puerto Rico. They are taking another tack in a campaign that is now under way.

title: Navigating the Shifting Tax Landscape
description: THIS is the year of tax uncertainty, and what might seem like temporary tax benefits could turn into tax traps.

title: Mattia Bonettis Loud Furniture
description: MATTIA BONETTI is a soft-spoken, Swiss-born, Paris-dwelling designer who makes very loud furniture: lozenge-shape tables and consoles of lacquered fiberglass that resemble ribbon candy; a patinated bronze chair with a furry Drano-blue hide seat; a suite of hand-carved Louis chairs gilded in pink, green and silver that would fit nicely in Sofia Coppolas sugar-plum Versailles.

title: The Spotless Garden
description: THERES a Beyond Thunderdome quality to Rob Torcellinis greenhouse. The 10-by-12-foot structure is undistinguished on the outside: he built it from a $700 kit, alongside his familys Victorian-style farmhouse in Eastford, Conn., a former farming town 35 miles east of Hartford. What is going on inside, however, is either a glimpse at the future of food growing or a very strange hobby  possibly both.

title: Rex Nettleford, Jamaican Scholar and Educator, Dies at 76
description: Rex Nettleford, a Jamaican scholar, educator and choreographer who devoted his life to studying postcolonial Caribbean culture and in the process helped shape it, died in Washington on Feb. 2, one day before his 77th birthday.

title: Simpler Green Cleaning
description: To the Editor:

title: View the Print, Own a Copy
description: Graphic Heroes, Magic Monsters: Japanese Prints by Utagawa Kuniyoshi from the Arthur R. Miller Collection opens at the Japan Society in Manhattan on March 12. The show includes more than 130 works by Kuniyoshi (1797-1861), a master of color woodblock prints  among them, vivid images like that of a warrior stabbing himself in the mouth with a sword and a boy grappling with a giant carp. Thirty-six of those prints, including the one above of a Buddhist monk hiking on a snow-covered mountain, can be purchased as very high-quality digitalized prints, even before the show opens. Although, as Joe Earle, the director of the Japan Society Gallery, noted: The prints you buy are not the actual size of the ones in the show  some are bigger than the original, and some are smaller. This is to prevent anyone from passing them off as original prints. Available online, in three sizes, framed (in black, gold or espresso wood frames) or unframed, for $75 to $500. Information: japansociety.org/mfaprints.

title: The Sectional as Sexy Sculpture
description: For some, the sectional sofa brings back bad memories of a giant glossy vinyl remote-control swallower circa 1982. Patrick Jouins Item, above, elegantly reimagines the often not-so-stylish sectional genre.

title: Decorating the Night in Brooklyn
description: IT was Valentines Day at the House of Yes, an old ice warehouse turned event space in Bushwick, Brooklyn: The three-story skybox was swathed in red satin and velvet, and red aerialists silks hung from the circus truss that spanned the ceiling. Kae Burke, 23, who runs House of Yes with her high school pal Anya Sapozhnikova, twined her way up and down the silks, while Marcie Grambeau, a 23-year-old New York University student wearing a red satin mini-cheongsam, fishnet stockings and stilts, played Tainted Love on her violin. Rhiannon Erbach-Gruber, 30, resplendent in a red satin petticoat and bustier, was singing from a perch halfway to the ceiling.

title: Architecture in Dinnerware
description: Stefano Seletti describes his kitchen as big but nice chaos, with open shelves that hold plates of various shapes and sizes. When Mr. Seletti, the president of Seletti, the Italian home furnishings company, challenged the designer Alessandro Zambelli to come up with a solution for hiding dinnerware in plain sight, the Palace Collection was Mr. Zambellis solution. At first glance, the pieces look like porcelain renditions of Renaissance palaces in Florence, but each building is actually made up of a stack of six plates (dinner or dessert size) or bowls (cereal or soup) with a roof that, when turned over, becomes another usable dish. The small dessert plate and bowl sets (top left, and far left) are $98 each; the soup bowl and large plate sets (the latter shown in part, above right) are $130 each. Available in late April; for information or to order: (800) 913-0071 or aplusrstore.com.

title: Bundle Up for a Bargain
description: The Company Stores white sale runs through March 10 (Hampton blankets, originally about $40 to $70, are about $35 to $62); information: (800) 323-8000 or thecompanystore.com.

title: Reviving Two Chairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Jonathan Adler Designs for Junior
description: Jonathan Adler is known for whimsical designs that might appeal just as easily to youngsters as to adults. Many assumed he had a collection for the younger set all along, but in fact, his first official collection for children, Jonathan Adler Junior, was introduced at the recent New York Gift Fair. It includes everything from furniture and lighting to accessories like clocks and throw pillows. Mr. Adlers 5-year-old nephew acted as a focus group of one. Hes so creative and great and honest  maybe too honest sometimes, Mr. Adler said of his young critic. Prices will range from $48 for a piggy bank with pink or blue polka dots to $1,950 for the Junior Lampert, a tufted sofa. (The Junior Templeton Chair, below, is $1,195.) Available in May, in stores and at jonathanadler.com.

title: Nanny Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Scenes: Reclaiming a Lost Past
description: Lance Cpl. Edwin Marrero is no longer missing in America.

title: Estate Taxs Unclear Fate Challenges Heirs
description: IN the final weeks of 2009, as the repeal of the estate tax on Jan. 1 approached, financial advisers speculated that heirs would reap a windfall if wealthy relatives died in 2010 and Congress took no action to restore it.

title: Saying No Thanks to a Bequest
description: TURNING down an inheritance may seem to be an alien concept. But with the estate tax in flux, this process, called disclaiming, can provide needed flexibility.

title: Less Risk, but Staying in Stocks
description: EVEN after a modest stock market rebound last year, the downturns of the last decade have left portfolios bruised.

title: Lending a Helping Hand, but With Restrictions
description: YOU are the family success story, respected in your business or profession and the larger community as well. So do not be surprised in todays bruising economy, the worst since the Great Depression with 14.8 million people unemployed, if you get a desperate call from a less fortunate relative.

title: Garage Sales, So to Speak, but With Cachet
description: PAUL DEAN, an investment banker based in Westport, Conn., lives in rooms bulging with art he has collected from an unusual source. Many, if not most, of his collections of paintings, woodblock prints, bronze sculptures and Oriental rugs have come from museums that sold their works through the auction houses he frequents.

title: Broker? Adviser? And Whats the Difference?
description: THE Great Recession has intensified a long-running debate: who is better able to look out for your money, a broker or an independent adviser?

title: What Were Reading
Feeling Guilty About Your Purebred Dog?
description: This week, as Sadie, the Scottish terrier, strutted to the podium to accept her best in show award at the the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, two women held up placards that read: Mutts Rule and Breeders Kill Shelter Dogs Chances.

title: Getting Todays Politicians to Think About Tomorrows Problems
description: My colleague Jackie Calmes has an article today on the political gridlock in Washington over how to address the nations long-term fiscal challenges. The response from the White House has been to form a blue ribbon commission that will propose spending and/or taxation changes to address future deficits.

title: British Team Reaps Benefits of a Sacrifice
description: The teams that did not qualify for the knockout stage of the NEC Cup in Yokohama, Japan, last week competed in a Swiss team event for the Yokohama Cup. It was won by David Kendrick, Brian Senior, Jonathan Cooke and Martin Garvey from England. They finished 11 victory points ahead of a team from China, with Australia third.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Fraud Case Against Merkin
description: From Diana B. Henriques, a DealBook colleague:

title: What You Need to Know About Google Buzz
description: UPDATE February 18, 7:45 a.m.: Clarified some passages to reflect ongoing changes made by Google to Buzz.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: The Buzz on Buzz
description: In this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein discussesBuzz from Google with Miguel Helft, the Times reporter who followed how Googles foray into social networking fell afoul of privacy concerns and generated the wrong kind of buzz.

title: Lufthansa Pilots Approve Four-Day Strike
description: FRANKFURT  Pilots for Lufthansa, the largest airline in Germany, and two of its subsidiaries voted Wednesday to hold a four-day strike next week, raising the prospect of delays and cancellations for passengers.

title: Newly Released Books
description: How many ways are there to tell a story? Among this months new books, there are motifs  the disintegrating family, the sexually obsessed writer, the minister who is not as godly as he might seem  that might seem familiar. (The name Dimmesdale gets dropped in one of these books.) The authors of two of these volumes have gone so far as to borrow their narrative strategies outright from the classics. Evolution or devolution? Dear reader, you decide.

title: Scenes From the Berlinale
description: Images of films and stars at the Berlin Film Festival.

title: Cross-Country Skiing Seeks Some X-citement With Sprints
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  While no one disputes the difficulty of cross-country skiing, even some of its participants acknowledge that it leans toward the geeky end of the sports spectrum.

title: To Vazquez and Yankees, Labels Dont Matter
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It is how things are done in baseball: starting pitchers are viewed as aces and innings eaters and everything in between. They are given labels like No. 2 starter or No. 4 starter, and such perceptions can change  and often do  from month to month.

title: Inside the Rings
description: What snowboard riders call progression has taken the sport to new heights and flips and twists.

title: Environmental Advocates Are Cooling on Obama
description: WASHINGTON  There has been no more reliable cheerleader for President Obamas energy and climate change policies than Daniel J. Weiss of the left-leaning Center for American Progress.

title: Allez Canada!
description: Confession: When I was 17 one of my best friends, now a police officer, molded a few scraps of official-looking paper with camera-booth photos, and just like that we turned 21  old enough to drink, and Canadians as well.

title: Report Cited by Obama on Hospitals Is Criticized
description: For much of the past year, President Obama lavished praise on a few select hospitals like the Mayo Clinic for delivering high-quality care at low costs, but a pointed analysis published Wednesday in an influential medical journal suggests that the presidents praise may be unwarranted.

title: A Trickle of Live Streams on the Web
description: NBC Universals television coverage of the Winter Olympics in Vancouver this month is exhaustive, as viewers have come to expect.

title: Judges Free Inmate on Recommendation of Special Innocence Panel
description: Acting at the recommendation of a special state innocence commission  the only one of its kind in the nation  a panel of North Carolina judges ruled Wednesday that a man was wrongfully convicted of murdering a prostitute in 1991 and freed him after 16 years in prison.

title: Simon Warns General Growth Its Offer Wont Last
description: The war of words between the Simon Property Group and General Growth Properties continued late Wednesday, as Simons chief executive sent off a sharply worded missive in the wake of General Growths rejection of an unsolicited $10 billion bid. (Read the letter after the jump.)

title: Back in Camp, McGwire Tries to Look Forward
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The time for tears has apparently passed for Mark McGwire, even as he admitted that the need for remorse will be forever. Saying that he is ready to turn his recent steroid confession into a positive thing, McGwire suited up with the St. Louis Cardinals on Wednesday morning for the first time since his retirement in 2001.

title: Plan Pushed on Lending to Students
description: The Obama administration on Wednesday sought to bolster support for its plan to overhaul student lending, attacking banks that oppose it for enjoying a free ride from taxpayers for too long.

title: Errors and Weather Obscure Results
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Every few hours, it seems, attention is diverted from Olympic competition to the organizers, who have had to explain a series of foibles, accidents and miscalculations. The Vancouver Games have not reached their midpoint, but there is a sense that they will be remembered in part for a baffling number of blunders and for the unseasonably warm weather that has scrambled skiing and snowboarding events here at Cypress Mountain and about 90 minutes north at Whistler.

title: Toyota Uses Olympic Ads to Seek Redemption
description: AMID the halfpipes, triple axels and doubled triple lutzes of the Vancouver Games, viewers are being treated to quite a feat: a corporate bend-over-backward.

title: With Title in Hand, Girardi Is Free to Focus on Repeating
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A clear indication of how different this spring is likely to be for Joe Girardi came 28 minutes into his first news conference. It took that long Wednesday for anyone to pose a question about Alex Rodriguez. There are no controversies, no steroid-related distractions that require Girardis immediate and consistent attention.

title: Barbaros Brother Finishes Second in Florida
description: Lentenor, a full brother of Barbaro, finished second Wednesday as the odds-on favorite in a mile-and-an-eighth turf race at Gulfstream Park in South Florida, leaving his Kentucky Derby prospects uncertain.

title: Aggressive Skiing Pays Off for Injured Vonn
description: Lindsey Vonn soared down Whistler Mountain, taking the most aggressive line of all the top skiers and defying the pain in her bruised shin, winning gold in the womens downhill competition.

title: Marchesa: Courtesan Chic
description: I admit I didnt know much about the life and loves of Eliza Rosanna Gilbert, known by her stage name Lola Montez, who was the inspiration for an enchanting Marchesa presentation today. The designer Georgina Chapman and her partner, Keren Craig, seemed to find Montez a rich subject. The collection had a strong element of performance, with short feathered dresses in blush pink and sky blue, a gorgeous one-shoulder minidress in embroidered teal, and a gown in black embroidered organza with overlapping pinwheels of tulle. The 3-D effects were quite successful, though it was hard not to love a silver bugle-beaded gown with a tight sheer bodice embroidered in silver. Gorgeous.

title: Pelosi Says Republicans Were Slow on Jobs
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi is firing back at House Republican leaders, saying they were slow to take interest in legislation to create jobs. The Republicans on Wednesday demanded an open forum on the jobs issue, months after House Democrats approved a $154 billion package with not a single Republican vote in favor of it.

title: It Wont Line a Bird Cage, but Its Still News
description: It seemed like the end of an era to loyal readers when yet another venerable publication, a Connecticut political journal, bit the dust this month.

title: Senator Retires, and Voters, Too, Grow Dismayed
description: HAMMOND, Ind.  Brent Kruse, a retired railroad conductor, says he is an independent-minded, loosely affiliated Democrat who votes for the man, not the party. In the last presidential election, he said, he flirted with the idea of casting a ballot for a Republican, Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, before throwing his support behind Barack Obama.

title: Fats No Longer a Punch Line
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Hijinks and Low Comedy in Champions League
description: The coincidences during Wednesdays UEFA Champions League games were simply too delicious to go without notice.

title: American Idol Beats Olympics and Endures as Gold Standard
description: The power of American Idol as a television attraction was reaffirmed Tuesday night when the singing competition on Fox convincingly beat the snow-and-ice competition on NBC.

title: Concrete Testing Company and Owner Are Convicted of Falsifying Work
description: The leading concrete testing company in New York and its owner were convicted on Wednesday of falsifying the test results of different concrete mixes that were eventually used in some of the most prominent projects in the city.

title: On Plushenkos Heels, and Standing Strong
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On the eve of the mens free skate, one that promises to be one of the closest, most exciting in Olympic history, the top six skaters practiced together Wednesday.

title: U.S. Cracks Down on Contractors as a Tax Dodge
description: Federal and state officials, many facing record budget deficits, are starting to aggressively pursue companies that try to pass off regular employees as independent contractors.

title: Have a Tattoo or Walk With a Limp? The Police May Know
description: He was discovered by the police around 8 p.m. Tuesday, lying in the snow in Harlem, unresponsive. The police did not know who he was or how he got there.

title: Follow That Rabbit to the Makeup Aisle
description: TIM BURTON, the director of Disneys 3D movie Alice in Wonderland, which opens next month, is no stranger to over-the-top visuals (remember Edward Scissorhands?). Lewis Carrolls classic tale is the perfect excuse for Mr. Burton and his crew to go gangbusters once again. Makeup aficionados will especially appreciate the Queen of Hearts vivid blue lids and heart-shaped lips, and the Mad Hatters green eyes, ringed with azure, fuchsia and brick-red eye shadows and what looks to be white mascara.

title: Bar Mitzvah May Complicate Plans for a Bout in the Bronx
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, has seen his share of great fighters: Muhammad Ali, Ken Norton, Manny Pacquiao. He can add Jonathan Ballan to that list.

title: The Salt Air, the Sea! (No, Forget the Sea)
description: THE mayor of New York may think that salt is the enemy, but Ron Rof, the founder and president of Halo Air/Salt Rooms, New Yorks first salt therapy center, cant seem to get enough of it.

title: Tiptoeing Around Tibet
description: President Obama and the White House have mentioned Tibet in the last year, but they have done so very carefully.

title: Spanish Premier Insists Economic Recovery Is Near
description: MADRID  With Spain having spent weeks in the cross hairs of jittery world markets, Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero went on the offensive on Wednesday, defending the countrys solvency and saying his government had the will to reduce its fast-growing deficit.

title: Retirees Trade Work for Rent at Cash-Poor Parks
description: ROMA, Tex.  A cold wind whipped down the Texas plains on the night last month that Sharon Smith, 68, and her husband, Bill, 73, arrived here to be work-campers.

title: Abbott Is Still Looking to Make the Most of Free Skate
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Jeremy Abbott, the reigning United States national champion in mens figure skating, did not want to think about what happened in the short program on Tuesday night.

title: Going All Lengths for Lashes
description: ABOUT a year ago, a prescription eye-drop formula for glaucoma made beauty history by repackaging itself as an eyelash serum. Now long, thick lashes can be obtained with a prescription to Latisse (about $120 a month). Allergan, the maker of Latisse, has exclusive rights to bimatoprost, the Food and Drug Administration-approved ingredient behind lash growth, but that hasnt stopped other makers of eyelash serums from claiming that their products also may strengthen eyelashes. This month, a new drugstore version, Concentrated Lash Boosting Serum by LOral Paris, which includes centella asiatica, a plant extract, and arginine, an amino acid found in keratin, made its debut for $14.95.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 973 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Womens Hockey Endures Growing Pains
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In another one-sided womens hockey match, Canada beat Sweden on Wednesday, 13-1. At 11-0, Canadian television stopped showing the game. The Canadians outshot the Swedes, 52-13, and the final scoresheet looked like an accountants ledger.

title: Finlands Selanne Ties Olympic Scoring Mark
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Teemu Selanne, starting play in his fifth Winter Games, tied the Olympic career scoring record by registering an assist in Finlands 5-1 victory over Belarus in both teams opener Wednesday.

title: Under Indonesias Surface, an Intricate Quilt of Faiths
description: YOGYAKARTA, Indonesia  As if on cue, the two Buddhist monks in saffron robes appeared one late afternoon recently, seemingly out of nowhere, to complete the picture of Indonesias religious past and present.

title: For Customers Who Really Shop
description: So J-Woww made it to Fashion Week, after all.

title: Dre Day
description: If you needed a reason to "sit back, relax and strap on your seatbelt," here it is: Dre Day 2010. In celebration of the birth of Andre Young, a k a Dr. Dre and his great contribution to hip-hop, pepper your conversation with all your favorite lyrics and then head tonight to the Music Hall of Williamsburg for a party in his honor. The record producer, rapper, executive and Dr. Pepper commercial star, who introduced acts like N. W. A., 50 Cent, Snoop Dogg and Eminem, turns 45 today. Bring your West Coast G-Funk swagger and listen to Nick Hook, Egg Foo Young and Project Matt pay tribute.

title: Scavenging for Style
description: "Every respectable closet in New York has one or seven items bought in haste at a Barneys New York Warehouse Sale," Jon Caramanica writes. "For decades, the sale has been feeding the helpless as much as those in the know, probably more so. But while watching the schlubby can make for fun sport, it doesn't hold a candle to the dandy trainspotting: hip-hop hipsters checking out plaid-accented Pendleton down vests; model boys rummaging through the bins of tiny-waisted jeans, hoping for a score; European tourists fiddling with iridescent Dior and Lanvin shoes; dyed-in-the-wool sartorial conservatives looking to buy dark suits, plastic-wrapped shirts and striped ties en masse in preparation for another 12 months of doing battle with a Bloomberg terminal." Leave your pride at the door and scrounge like the rest of them for hidden treasures like angora sweaters from Marc by Marc Jacobs, discounted Alexander McQueen shirts, Gucci jeans and Dries Van Noten blazers. "This scavenger hunt is held twice a year  the current one runs through Feb. 28  with absolutely no guarantees: Success here comes only with tenacity, tolerance and luck."

title: Race in America
description: Tonight a bunch of very smart people will gather at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine for a conversation about race in America and its influence on public and private lives. The program, titled "Enter the Conversation," will feature Gwen Ifill, moderator and managing editor of "Washington Week" on PBS, as well as one of our favorite "Daily Show" guests, and Michele Norris, host of NPR's "All Things Considered." William F. Baker, president emeritus of WNET.org, will be serving as moderator, beginning at 8 p.m.

title: Agreement Is Near on New Overseer of Banking Risks
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate and the Obama administration are nearing agreement on forming a council of regulators, led by the Treasury secretary, to identify systemic risk to the nations financial system, officials said Wednesday.

title: Airport Efforts to Detect Explosives Expand
description: WASHINGTON  Airport security screeners are expanding the use of equipment to detect residues of explosives, swabbing the hands of passengers as well as their carry-on items, the Transportation Security Administration said Wednesday.

title: Pakistani Backs Down in Conflict With Judge
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari backed down from a confrontation with this countrys powerful top judge on Wednesday, defusing a potential judicial crisis that threatened to destabilize the government.

title: Davis Earns Repeat Gold and Validation
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The first time Shani Davis won an Olympic gold medal in the 1,000 meters, he skated a victory lap while hugging a teddy bear. On Wednesday night, after becoming the first man to successfully defend his title in the event, Davis held an American flag to his chest, a gesture rich in symbolism.

title: Grinnell Chooses New President
description: Grinnell College in Iowa announced Wednesday that Dr. Raynard S. Kington, deputy director of the National Institutes of Health, would become its 13th president, on Aug 1. Dr. Kington is a physician who specializes in research on the intersection of health and social factors.

title: Iranians Protest Bill on Rights of Women
description: In what appeared to be the first burst of activism in months not related to the disputed presidential election, about 1,200 Iranians signed a statement against a bill that would further curb womens rights, the feminist Web site Change for Gender Equality reported.

title: Voices of a Mississippi Jobs Program
description: Workers reflect on their experiences with a program in Mississippi that is taking a direct approach to creating jobs.

title: A Look That Doesnt Need to Introduce Itself
description: When your name is Thom Browne, it might not be the best idea to use your initials as a logo.

title: Navy to Investigate Murthas Care
description: The Navy is reviewing the medical care given to Representative John P. Murtha, the Pennsylvania Democrat who died last week after complications from gallbladder surgery at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. A Navy spokesman said Wednesday that the review, first reported by CNN, was standard in cases of unexpected death after surgery. Gov. Edward G. Rendell announced that a special election to fill Mr. Murthas term, which ends in January, would be held May 18.

title: Vonn and Mancuso Knew They Would Push Each Other Down the Mountain
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Lindsey Vonn and Julia Mancuso, the gold and silver medalists in Wednesdays womens Olympic downhill, seemed to sense on the eve of the race that their showdown was coming.

title: Russia: Military Pact With Abkhazia
description: Russia has moved to bolster its military presence in Abkhazia, signing an agreement on Wednesday to establish a Russian military base in the separatist territory, a focal point of Russias war with Georgia in August 2008. President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia announced the agreement at a news conference in Moscow with Abkhazias president, Sergei V. Bagapsh. It calls for the base to house about 1,700 Russian troops for a minimum of 49 years, the Interfax news agency reported. Russia recognized the independence of Abkhazia and another separatist enclave, South Ossetia, shortly after the war, vowing to support them economically and militarily. Georgia has called deployment of Russian troops in the enclaves a violation of the French-brokered peace treaty that ended the war.

title: Online Bookmakers Warm to Winter Games
description: The American figure skater Evan Lysacek was virtually tied with Yevgeny Plushenko of Russia after the mens short program, but Lysaceks odds are a generous 6-1 to win the gold medal on the global wagering site Betfair.com. English bookmakers at William Hill gave Lysacek, the reigning world champion, 4-1 odds on winning the free skate Thursday.

title: The Mets by the Numbers: Nothing Ever Adds Up to 3
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With Yankees championship No. 27 safely behind him, Joe Girardi is now putting No. 28 on his back, gimmicky as that might seem. He has not worn the official pinstriped version yet, but on Wednesday the new digits were already visible, stitched in subtle fashion onto the blue Yankees pullover he was wearing.

title: What Does Taste Have to Do With It?
description: ITS where my mother took me to get a proper suit in high school, and where Benjamin Bixby oxfords and plaid shirt-smocks from Chlo Sevigny for Opening Ceremony go to die.

title: U.N. to Review Falklands Dispute
description: Argentina will take its dispute over plans by British oil companies to explore for oil off the coast of the Falkland Islands to the United Nations next week, where Argentina will assert its longstanding claim to sovereignty over the islands, the countrys government press agency, Telam, reported Wednesday. Foreign Minister Jorge Taiana will demand that Britain abide by General Assembly resolutions urging the two countries to begin negotiations on the future of the Falklands, known as the Malvinas in Argentina, the news agency said. Although Britain took control of the islands by force in 1833, Argentina has never given up its claims to them. The countries waged a war over the islands in 1982, after the military junta then governing Argentina invaded, with Britain emerging victorious.

title: Walgreen to Buy Duane Reade for $618 Million
description: Walgreen may already be the nations biggest drugstore chain, but its $618 million purchase of Duane Reade will put it on seemingly every Manhattan street corner.

title: The Great Pangram Debate
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I can imagine young Caleb Madison staring at his computer keyboard as he tries to come up with his next puzzle theme. Concentrate, concentrate  Eureka!

title: New Yorkers Ponder Sale of Duane Reade to Walgreen
description: In the 50 years since it named itself for the side streets closest to its first store, Duane Reade has had a relationship with New York City. Complicated, unavoidable, convenient, annoying  whatever that relationship was, even Duane Reade seemed to understand how deeply it had worked its way into the municipal psyche.

title: Bank of America Opposes Judges Proposal for an Outside Pay Consultant
description: Bank of America says it is opposed to a judges proposal to appoint an outside compensation consultant as part of a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 6 about the political pressures in Europe caused by the highly indebted members of the group of nations that use the euro as their common currency misstated an economic comparison of Greece, one of the weakest members of that group, and Germany, one of the strongest. The comparison, of each countrys ratio of public debt to gross domestic product, showed Greeces is higher than Germanys, not no higher than Germanys.

title: A Profit at BNP, a Loss at ING and a Cut in Bonuses at Both
description: PARIS  The largest French bank, BNP Paribas, reported another strong quarterly profit, while its Dutch rival ING Group booked a larger-than-expected loss to repay government bailout money.

title: Forsberg Plays as Sweden Stops a Determined Germany
description: UPDATE: 11:20 p.m.

title: Corrections
