description: A picture last Thursday with an article about Palestinian efforts to halt the construction of the Center for Human Dignity  Museum of Tolerance by the Simon Wiesenthal Center because it would occupy part of a centuries-old Muslim cemetery in Jerusalem was published in error. The photograph showed several graves in a section of the cemetery that will not be affected by the construction. The photo has since been removed from the Web site.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 30 about an exhibition celebrating an abandoned tenement on East Third Street and the squatters who made it their home in 1986 included an erroneous account from one squatter about his involvement. The squatter, Andrew Castrucci, who had said that he was present on the first day that squatters explored the building and that he used a sledgehammer to enter a rear doorway, now says he recalls being at the building sometime after squatters first broke in, but not on the first day, and that someone else first used the sledgehammer on the rear doorway of the tenement, at 292 East Third Street.

title: U.S. Team Not at Its Best in Opener
description: Ever the contrarian, Mike Milburys remarks after the U.S. Olympic teams victory over Switzerland (video at around the 1:20 mark) hardly overflowed with glowing praise. It was all right. They got the win, Milbury told the USA Networks postgame audience. The best thing you can say about these guys is they put the two points in the bank and its behind them. But they have to be a lot better than that going forward. They were careless with the puck. I thought they made some decisions that were questionable on pinches, and they gave away far too many opportunities.

title: Working Out With Gretchen Bleiler
description: The snowboarder and member of the United States Olympic team shares the gym routine she uses to prepare for the halfpipe.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Tuesday about a lawsuit challenging a state commuter tax in New York misstated the location and part of the name of an outlet mall served by both the Metro-North Railroad and the Hampton Luxury Liner, whose owner sued the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It is Woodbury Common, not Commons, and the mall is in Orange County, not Westchester.

title: Never Too Cool for a Hard Workout
description: PARK CITY, Utah

title: Devastated by a Blaze, Merchants See New Loss
description: There were a Russian liquor seller, an Ecuadorean manicurist and a Dominican barber. There was Thomas Kourakos, 83, who is from Greece and who opened his shoe-repair shop in 1956. And there was Maria Solano, 54, who is from Peru and who opened her party-favor store in 2006.

title: In Ponzi Case, Judge Denies a Motion to Dismiss
description: A state court judge has refused to dismiss civil fraud charges filed by the New York attorney general against a hedge fund manager whose clients, including Yeshiva University and New York University, lost more than $1 billion in Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: Boy, 4, Is Killed by School Bus in Borough Park
description: A yeshivas school bus struck a 4-year-old boy in Borough Park, Brooklyn, on Wednesday morning, killing him, the authorities said.

title: Toyota Announces Steps to Restore Confidence on Safety
description: TOKYO  Toyotas president, Akio Toyoda, offered several steps Wednesday aimed at restoring trust in the embattled Japanese automaker, including installation of a new brake-override systems in future models and quicker disclosure of defects.

title: Bail Set for a Man Caught Up in His Sons Terrorism Case
description: Federal prosecutors said Wednesday that they had agreed on bail provisions for a Colorado man who has been charged with obstructing an investigation into a terrorist bombing plot.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Wednesday about the American Shani Daviss withdrawal from another speedskating event at the Vancouver Games so he could focus on his best events misstated the surname of the athlete who took his spot in the 10,000 meters. He is Jonathan Kuck, not Kruk.

title: Lost Memories, Found
description: On Feb. 4, David Gonzalez related the touching story of two photo albums, entrusted by one Marine buddy to another in Vietnam 40 years ago, that had yet to be returned to their owner. The pictures within offered a sweet and telling glimpse of life in the Bronx in the late 1960s. Now weve found the owner, Edwin Marrero, who will claim the albums in a few months when he visits his mother in Puerto Rico and pays his respects at the grave of the buddy who saved so much Marrero family history.

title: Corrections
description: A picture from The Associated Press on Wednesday with an article about the Philadelphia Phillies off-season acquisitions was published in error. It showed pitcher Philip Barzilla, a nonroster invitee with the Seattle Mariners in 2008  not Phillippe Aumont, a top pitching prospect acquired from the Mariners in December.

title: Knicks Revolving Door Is Starting to Spin Faster
description: The night began with a survey of lockers, specifically the empty ones. Nate Robinsons was devoid of personal belongings, save for a jar of Vaseline. Darko Milicic still had a name plate, but little else to attest to his Knick existence.

title: Corrections
description: A theater entry in the listings on Friday erroneously included a production on the list of long-running shows. Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps ended its Broadway run on Jan. 10 and is reopening off Broadway, at New World Stages, on March 25. The error appeared the four previous Fridays, dating to Jan. 15.

title: Bloggingheads: Iran Impasse
description: Flynt Leverett of the New America Foundation and journalist Barbara Slavin debate who is responsible for the stalemate over Irans nuclear program.

title: Espadas Bill on Rent Limits Draws Criticism From Tenant Groups
description: Pedro Espada Jr., the State Senate majority leader, introduced a housing bill on Wednesday that he described as a major lifeline to New Yorkers with lower incomes, and that a tenants group denounced as a Trojan horse.

title: Judge Denies a Dismissal in a Suit Against MBIA
description: A New York judge refused on Wednesday to dismiss a lawsuit that claims MBIA took illegal steps to cut the chances that it would have to pay off on bond insurance policies.

title: Jurors Begin Deliberations in Police Sexual Abuse Case
description: The prosecutor grabbed a baton, the symbol of the police brutality case that has unfolded over the past month in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, to show how quickly Michael Mineo could have been sodomized, as he said he was in the Prospect Park subway station on Oct. 15, 2008.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Frederick C. Weyand, the commander of American forces in Vietnam in the final year of the war, misstated the year General Weyand succeeded Gen. Alexander M. Haig as Army vice chief of staff. It was 1973, not 1974. The obituary, using information from the family, also misidentified the city in California where General Weyands brother, Robert, lives. It is Orinda, not El Cerrito. And a picture caption misstated, in some editions, the date of the ceremony depicted, which officially ended the role of United States forces in Vietnam. It was March 1973, not March 1972.

title: Top-Earning U.S. Households Averaged $345 Million in 07
description: The 400 highest-earning households in the United States averaged nearly $345 million in 2007, up 31 percent from a year earlier, data from the Internal Revenue Service shows.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Feb. 7 about the psychologist Jack Block referred imprecisely to a study he conducted with his wife, Jeanne Humphrey Block, and Per F. Gjerde. While the study, which credited Ms. Block, was indeed published in 1986, it had been conducted years earlier. (As the obituary noted, Ms. Block died in 1981.)

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lottery Numbers
Eight States Have Shortchanged Pensions, Pew Study Finds
description: Eight states have been given failing scores for their pension management under a new grading system developed by the Pew Center on the States, which also found a $1 trillion gap between what all 50 states have promised their workers and what they have set aside.

title: Apples Prices for E-Books May Be Lower Than Expected
description: Maybe e-book prices wont be rising so much after all.

title: White Spins, Flips and McTwists His Way to Halfpipe Gold
description: 11:56p.m. |Update

title: Barrels in Reserve but Harder to Get
description: With oil majors given the cold shoulder in many developing countries, it is no mean feat that Exxon Mobil managed to replace 100 percent of last years production with new reserves. Even so, not all energy is equal. The stuff Exxon is using to fill its pipeline will be harder to extract and of lower value to investors.

title: California: Mayor Seeking New Post
description: Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco took a first step toward a run for lieutenant governor on Wednesday, filing a ballot statement with the secretary of state saying he was in the race and was fired up and ready to change state government. Mr. Newsom, a Democrat who cannot seek re-election next year because of term limits, abandoned a run for governor last year after his fund-raising lagged.

title: A Night of Big East Muscle, and an Upstart
description: While some Big East teams are playing for a better N.C.A.A. seed, others are still looking to get in the tournament door.

title: The Mullah and the Marja Campaign
description: Good news from Pakistan is rare. So it was a particular relief to hear of the capture in Karachi of the Talibans top military commander, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar. The joint raid by American and Pakistani intelligence forces is a sign that President Obamas investment in better relations with Pakistan is bearing fruit. It is also a reminder of how much more could be done if the Pakistanis fully committed to the fight against the extremists.

title: A Reasonable Bet on Nuclear Power
description: President Obamas decision to commit $8.3 billion in loan guarantees to help build two nuclear reactors in Georgia and restart the American nuclear power industry makes good sense.

title: Listen to the Task Force
description: Gov. David Patersons juvenile justice task force rightly urged him to phase out the practice of placing low-risk young offenders in failing institutional facilities and replace them with community-based programs that cost less and reduce recidivism rates.

title: Closing the Carp Highway
description: The Asian carp, a large and ravenous invasive species, has been making a so-far-unstoppable migration up the Mississippi River. It now has come to within a few miles from the Great Lakes. Unless serious measures are taken  soon  it looks as though the carp will likely break through, using canals that connect the river to Lake Michigan.

title: What the Tea Party Movement Wants
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas About the Medicare of the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay: A Home 8,000 Miles Away
description: 2:38 p.m. | Updated An explanation of the transliterations used in this post, following the article, has been expanded.

title: Just Dont Call It Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: An Episcopal Divide Over Gay Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Party Like Its 1854
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference begins Thursday in Washington. Glenn Beck is scheduled to give the keynote speech. Stephen Baldwin is slated to preside over a special nighttime youth event. As always, the right wing is great at producing hot talk shows and terrible at attracting hot actors.

title: Do We Really Want the Status Quo on Health Care?
description: If you found a suspicious lump in your neck, youd never put off dealing with it with the excuse: This is the loveliest neck in the world, and I dont want to tinker with it.

title: Empty Skies Over Afghanistan
description: Washington

title: No Fault of Their Own
description: Los Angeles

title: Wealth Gap for Schools in New Jersey Is the Highest
description: Nearly one in five public schools in New Jersey has almost no poor students, the highest percentage of any state, according to a new report.

title: Some Mets Numerology
description: The Timess David Waldstein has a little fun in Thursdays paper, wondering why Mets Manager Jerry Manuel doesnt switch to No. 3 this season in order to inspire the team to its third World Series championship. After all, it worked for Joe Girardi last season, when he wore No. 27, and Girardi will try on No. 28 this year in the hopes of yet another Yankees title.

title: White Cements His Status With 2nd Gold
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The quest to successfully defend his gold medal might have begun the moment that Shaun White won the halfpipe competition at the 2006 Turin Olympics.

title: Word of the Day | jettison
description: jettison\je-t-sn, -zn\ verb

title: Report from a Pashtun Teen
description: Sher Bano is a 17-year-old Pashtun girl from Pakistan who spent last year as an exchange student in Evanston, Illinois, as part of the Youth Exchange and Study (YES) Program. She is now back in the city of Peshawar in the northwest of Pakistan, but is unable to attend formal school because of insecurity there. As a guest blogger, shell be writing about life in Pakistan from the perspective of a teenage girl who has spent time in the West.

title: Fed Board Diverged on Timing of Policy Shift
description: Members of the Federal Reserves policy-making arm generally concurred that the central bank should eventually tighten monetary policy, but they disagreed on how to raise interest rates and reduce the balance sheet, according to minutes of last months meeting, Sewell Chan and Javier C. Hernandez report in The New York Times.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day, Feb. 17
description: A roundup of Olympic highlights, including victories by Lindsey Vonn, Shaun White and Shani Davis.

title: News Quiz | February 18, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Malicious Software Infects Computers
description: A malicious software program has infected the computers of more than 2,500 corporations around the world, according to NetWitness, a computer network security firm.

title: Survival of the Fittest
description: At the annual Mobile World Congress in Spain, the tech industrys innovation engine is in idle.

title: New Yorkers Ponder Sale of Duane Reade to Walgreen
description: In the 50 years since it named itself for the side streets closest to its first store, Duane Reade has had a relationship with New York City. Complicated, unavoidable, convenient, annoying  whatever that relationship was, even Duane Reade seemed to understand how deeply it had worked its way into the municipal psyche.

title: Dale Hawkins Dies at 73; Rockabilly Author of Susie Q
description: Dale Hawkins, a songwriter and singer whose rockabilly repertory included the 1957 hit Susie Q, a bandstand classic for generations of rockers, died on Saturday in Little Rock, Ark. He was 73.

title: Donald E. Welsh, a Creator of Magazines, Dies at 66
description: Donald E. Welsh, a publishing entrepreneur who helped found Arthur Frommers Budget Travel, Budget Living and many childrens magazines, died on Feb. 6 in Tortola, the British Virgin Islands. He was 66 and lived in Boston Corner, N.Y.

title: Agreement Is Near on New Banking Risk Overseer
description: The Senate and the Obama administration are nearing agreement on forming a council of regulators, led by the Treasury secretary, to identify systemic risk to the nations financial system, officials said Wednesday, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: R.B.S.s Shining Star in Connecticut
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland may be one of Britains most bailed-out banks. But at its American headquarters here, there is hardly a whisper of distress, Louise Story writes in The New York Times.

title: Vringo Seeks to Make Ring Tones More Social
description: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

title: Tesla Employees Killed in Plane Crash
description: A small plane crashed into a residential neighborhood in East Palo Alto on Wednesday, killing three employees of Tesla Motors, the California electric car company, and causing widespread power disruptions, The New York Timess Claire Cain Miller reported.

title: Best in Show
description: WHO is Sadie? WHO is her handler?

title: After Securing Bronze, American Snowboarder Doesnt Hold Back
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Near the bottom of the halfpipe at Cypress Mountain, the American snowboarder Scotty Lago dedicated his bronze medal to friends and family and his New Hampshire town. It was less of an interview and more of an awards speech.

title: Should Kids Head to College Early?
description: Starting next year, a new program will enable high school sophomores to enter community college after passing a set of exams. What do you think the benefits and drawbacks are of such a program? Are you interested in it for yourself?

title: Corrections
description: The Front Row column last week, about Cynthia Rowleys plans to sell quick reproductions of her own designs, misidentified the rights that fashion designers are seeking for their work. It is a copyright, not a trademark.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Emily Ford, whose husband, Harold E. Ford Jr., is considering running for the United States Senate from New York, misspelled the surname of an actress for whom Ms. Ford was once a stylist. She is Rene Zellweger, not Zellwegger.

title: HIV Phobia
description: A psychological condition, reported in China, whereby individuals are convinced they have HIV despite negative test results.

title: Judge Denies a Dismissal in Suit Against MBIA
description: A New York judge refused on Wednesday to dismiss a lawsuit that contends MBIA took illegal steps to reduce the likelihood that it would have to pay off on bond insurance policies.

title: Plea in Case of Stolen Code From Goldman
description: A former Goldman Sachs computer programmer pleaded not guilty Wednesday to charges he stole code from the banks lucrative high-frequency trading platform before leaving for another company last year, Reuters reported.

title: N.H.L. Stars Thrill as Czechs Defeat Slovaks
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It was a thrilling, nonstop celebration of hockey amid a festive atmosphere that felt like a holiday in Prague or Bratislava, and it provided a glimpse of why this Olympic tournament is expected to be the greatest in the history of the game.

title: Shares Improve on Growing Signs of a Recovery
description: Wall Street investors, buoyed by signs of stability in the housing and manufacturing sectors, seemed optimistic about the speed of economic renewal on Wednesday as worries about mounting debt burdens abroad began to subside.

title: Japan Telecom Backed by Carlyle Files for Bankruptcy
description: The Japanese wireless company Willcom, 60 percent owned by the private equity firm Carlyle Group, said Thursday it was filing for bankruptcy protection in Tokyo, Chris V. Nicholson and Hiroko Tabuchi report in The New York Times.

title: Lobbyist Turns Crime Buster
description: Several years ago, Greg Whisenant unsuspectedly opened the door of his apartment building for a burglar, who then ripped off several of his neighbors.

title: Socit Gnrale Reports $303 Million Profit
description: A day after BNP Paribas reported its latest profit in a streak, Socit Gnrale came out with its quarterly and full-year earnings showing it was also in the black.

title: Turning Patents Into Invention Capital
description: Nathan Myhrvold wants to shake up the marketplace for ideas. His mission and the activities of the company he heads, Intellectual Ventures, a secretive $5 billion investment firm that has scooped up 30,000 patents, inspire admiration and angst, The New York Timess Steve Lohr writes.

title: Is the London Hedge Fund Exodus a Myth?
description: The dire warnings of a London hedge fund exodus due to plans by the British government to levy heavier taxes on the industry may be overdone  at least, according to a Reuters report.

title: Shirin Neshat Turns Toward Laos in Madrid Exhibition
description: The provocative photographer and filmmaker Shirin Neshat has been exploring identity through her art for more than 30 years. Though she is based in New York, her main focus has been her native Iran, especially the situation of Iranian women  until now. In Games of Desire, an exhibition at La Fbrica Galera (Calle Alameda, 9; 34-91-360-1325; lafabricagaleria.com) that runs through March, Ms. Neshat turns from the Middle East to Laos.

title: Analysts Weigh In on Arrow I.P.O.
description: Australias  Arrow Energy said Tuesday that it planned to sell 20 percent of its overseas assets in an Asian initial public offering, and Deutsche Bank is betting that the I.P.O. could net the gas producer as much as 310 million Australian dollars ($278 million), Bloomberg News reported.

title: State of the Lions: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: A.I.G. Said to Plan to Keep $500 Billion in Derivatives
description: Nearly two weeks after reports emerged that the American International Group had struck a deal with Barclays to keep profiting from certain complex derivatives, The Financial Times said Thursday that the bailed-out American insurer had plans to keep a portfolio of the securities worth as much as $500 billion.

title: Whistler Auction: A Parable of Our Times?
description: With the Fortress Investment Group reportedly behind on a $524 million loan payment for the company that owns the Whistler ski resort, home of some of the Winter Olympics competitions, creditors have scheduled a Friday auction smack-dab in the middle of the Olympic games, The Associated Press said.

title: The Crime Waves in Our Heads
description: Todays idea: Even though crime rates have consistently declined over the years  even in this recession  most Americans believe they are rising. Blame cognitive biases that are prone to political manipulation.

title: American Idol': Who Wont You Be Voting For This Year?
description: Paige Miles, thats who. Thats not an order so much as an inevitability. Paige is one of 12 young women in this seasons top 24, though you could be forgiven for not knowing who she was before Wednesday nights American Idol, in which the remaining semifinalists were revealed. Apart from a glimpse of her group round performance  underwhelming, at that  shed had effectively zero screen time thus far before being gifted a spot on the show.

title: Swiss Re Prepares to Repay Buffett
description: Swiss Re can apparently see the light of the end of the tunnel when it comes to repaying a costly convertible loan from Warren E. Buffett, Reuters reported.

title: Iraq Suicide Bomber Strikes in Anbar
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber struck near the government headquarters in the capital of Iraqs Anbar Province on Thursday, the latest in what Iraqi and American officials warned would be a wave of violence before next months parliamentary elections.

title: Goldman Sues 7 Executives Now at Credit Suisse
description: Goldman Sachs sued seven of its former private wealth management division executives for abruptly leaving the company to join rival Credit Suisse early this month, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

title: 25 Afghan Police May Have Joined Taliban
description: JALREZ, Afghanistan  A group of about two dozen Afghan national police officers may have defected to the Taliban, according to American and Afghan officers here in Wardak Province.

title: Capital Controls Are In Again
description: Simon Johnson is an economics professor at M.I.T.s Sloan School of Management and a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

title: Europeans Summon Israeli Envoys in Dubai Murder Probe
description: LONDON  Britain and Ireland called on the Israeli ambassadors to their countries on Thursday to explain what they knew about the use last month of false British and Irish passports by the suspected assassins of a leading Hamas figure who was in Dubai.

title: Bundles of Anxiety
description: Video | When theyre not wired, they get pretty wired:

title: Calpers: Firms Mum on Placement Agents
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the biggest U.S. public pension fund, released late on Wednesday a list of 11 firms with which it has invested that did not reply to its request for information on their use of placement agents, who are at the center of a probe of New Yorks pension fund, Reuters reported.

title: In Blow to Taliban, 2 More Leaders Are Arrested
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two senior Taliban leaders have been arrested in recent days inside Pakistan, officials said Thursday, as American and Pakistani intelligence agents continued to press their offensive against the groups leadership after the capture of the insurgencys military commander last month.

title: Czech Court Bans Far-Right Party
description: PRAGUE  A Czech court has banned the far-right Workers Party, the first time a political party has been outlawed since the Czech Republic was founded in 1993.

title: Actavis Relies on Deutsche for Ratiopharm Bid
description: Actavis has severed ties with Swedens EQT in a bid for German drug maker Ratiopharm, Reuters reported.

title: The Patent Litigation Dilemma: Free Riders
description: I wrote an article in Thursdays New York Times about Intellectual Ventures, the giant patent fund and invention company, which pointed out that most of its revenue to date has come from defensive license deals with a small number of large technology and telecommunications companies.

title: Paulson and Buffett Split on SunTrust
description: It seems that John Paulson and Warren E. Buffet are having a difference of opinion on SunTrust.

title: Capital Controls Are In Again
description: From Simon Johnson at Economix:

title: The Drunkest City
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Citi Said to Face Objections in Sale of Real Estate Unit
description: Buyers, be patient. Even as American International Group considers keeping its derivatives portfolio, Citigroup is said to face obstacles auctioning off it real estate asset management unit, sources told Reuters.

title: Video: Tiptoeing on Tibet
description: President Obamas delayed meeting with the Dalai Lama today is notable for how delicate it is diplomatically. It has already angered Chinas leadership who regard Tibet as an internal problem, and the Obama administration is trying to minimize the focus on it. Theyre keeping the media away and only plan to release a summary of the meeting, as well as an official photograph.

title: Long Before Kerik, Top Cops Went Wrong
description: On Thursday, Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner who was briefly poised to lead the Department of Homeland Security, is expected to be sentenced to two to three years in prison following his guilty plea to eight felony charges, including tax fraud and lying to White House officials.

title: Honoring Mickey Thompson, First American to 400 M.P.H.
description: Mickey Thompson, the great racing superstar, did not limit himself to one motorsports arena. He built cars for the Indianapolis 500 and funny cars for drag racing, and he put together trucks for off-road competition. But he may be best known for his many land-speed achievements.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, Feb. 18
description: Highlights from Thursdays media coverage in The New York Times:

title: Profit Rises at Wal-Mart, but Outlook Is Clouded
description: Wal-Mart, the giant retail discount chain, posted a record profit on Thursday for the fourth quarter, which included the all-important holiday shopping season.

title: Newsom Inches Toward a New Campaign
description: Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco has given the strongest indication thus far that he will run for lieutenant governor of California.

title: From Beethoven to Britney | Gonzaless Joes Pub Residency
description: I relish being compared to a dictator, said the musician Gonzales, whose piano-based albums  which range from rap to classical to soft rock  have been compared to Maos cultural revolution. The goal itself is not to surprise people. Its really just a way to keep myself amused. That is why I am the most powerful man ever!

title: A Day of Gains, Then a Shift in Mood
description: Wall Street rode a three-day winning streak on Thursday, but an unexpected move after the close to raise a crucial interest rate sent a wave of pessimism through the market.

title: Finding That Perfect Match, in a Police Database
description: He was discovered by the police around 8 p.m. Tuesday, lying in the snow in Harlem, unresponsive. The police did not know who he was or how he got there.

title: Judges Should Reward Best All-Around Skater
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: Higher Energy Costs Lift Producer Prices
description: With interest rates at low levels, inflation hawks have warned that price increases may be around the corner. While a government report on Thursday heightened those concerns, economists said inflation still remained largely in check.

title: The Early Word: The Deficit and the Dalai Lama
description: President Obama meets with a set of somewhat disparate guests at the White House this morning  welcoming Alan K. Simpson and Erskine Bowles, the co-chairmen of the new bipartisan commission on fiscal responsibility, before sitting down with the Dalai Lama.

title: Bomb at Pakistan Mosque Kills Dozens
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A bomb blast at a mosque in the Khyber tribal area killed at least 30 people and wounded more than 70 others on Thursday, residents and security officials in the region said.

title: U.N. Climate Chief Quits, Deepening Sense of Disarray
description: UNITED NATIONS  The sense of disarray in the global effort to address climate change deepened Thursday with the resignation of Yvo de Boer, the stolid Dutch bureaucrat who led the international climate change negotiations over four tumultuous years.

title: Betty White on Her SNL Supporters: They Just Dig Old Ladies
description: Were sure this was exactly the kind of story Diane Sawyer was hoping to break when she was named the anchor of a network newscast.

title: Fairfax to Buy Zenith National for $1.3 Billion
description: Fairfax Financial Holdings, a Canadian insurer, said on Thursday that it has agreed to buy Zenith National Insurance, a workers compensation insurance specialist, for about $1.3 billion in cash.

title: Concerns Raised Over Gas Flaring in Uganda
description: Environmental advocates are expressing concern over the potential impact of oil discoveries in western Ugandas Lake Albert region, thought to total as much as 1.7 billion barrels.

title: Airport Rankings Are In
description: Looking for a good airport? Try Detroit.

title: S.B.A. Prepares, Again, to Lose Stimulus Support
description: With the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act measures that have been subsidizing Small Business Administration loan programs scheduled to conclude by the end of the month, the S.B.A. announced Tuesday that it was finalizing plans for an orderly transition back to loans with higher fees and lower guarantees.

title: The Perils of Oscar Season Eating
description: What do you serve at a dinner party for Food, Inc., the Oscar-nominated documentary about the evils of agri-business? Especially when its hosted by Martha Stewart? A healthy buffet and eco-friendly cocktails, apparently, along with pigs-in-blankets for the likes of the restaurateur Drew Nieporent, who turned up at the party at the Monkey Bar, along with the documentary filmmaker Albert Maysles and others on Tuesday night.

title: A Gloomy January for Hedge Funds
description: Hedge funds suffered a tough January, with most posting minimal gains to moderate losses for the month, according to two reports released late Wednesday.

title: Weekly Popcast: Yeasayer, Jaheim and VV Brown
description: This week: reviews of CDs from the Brooklyn band Yeasayer and the R&B star Jaheim. Also, VV Brown, the British soul singer, performs live in the studio. Sia Michel is the host.

title: The Lessons of the 80s
description: Barack Obamas recent interview with BusinessWeek  the one where he made the mistake of saying nice things about Jamie Dimon and Lloyd Blankfeins bonuses  inspired Reihan Salam to dig up the presidents interview with the same magazine back in the summer of 2009. When I suggested yesterday that whatever problems the White House is having start at the top, heres an example of what I have in mind:

title: Union Jobs Hang On in the Recession
description: One aspect of New Yorks economy that the financial crisis and recession did not shake is the relatively strong grip labor unions have in the state.

title: Rowling Denies Plagiarism Charge
description: If theres a magic spell that can keep J. K. Rowlings name out of lawsuits  Litigio Impedimenta, maybe?  the Harry Potter author hasnt mastered it yet. On Thursday, Ms. Rowling said a plagiarism lawsuit filed against her by the estate of another author was unfounded and absurd after Ms. Rowlings name was added to the case as a defendant, Reuters reported. The estate of Adrian Jacobs, an author who died in 1997, began proceedings against Ms. Rowling and the publisher Bloomsbury, which releases the Harry Potter novels in Britain, saying that Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the fourth novel in Ms. Rowlings series, was plagiarized from Jacobss 1987 book, The Adventures of Willy the Wizard  No 1 Livid Land. In a statement, Ms. Rowling said she was saddened that yet another claim has been made that I have taken material from another source to write Harry.  She said she had not heard of the Jacobs book before the accusations were made by the estate, and never read it, adding: We will be applying to the court immediately for a ruling that the claim is without merit and should therefore be dismissed without delay.

title: More on Wall Streets Euro Deals
description: Derivatives, trickiest of securities, have been in the news a lot since Greek debt, and all the ways that Greece tried to hide it, have made the headlines, with The New York Times running an extensive piece as recently as this weekend.

title: C.I.C. Said to Ready $1.5 Billion for Buyouts
description: After a year of buying stakes in many of the most well-known listed companies in the United States, China Investment Corp. is turning its attention to private equity deals, according to The Financial Times.

title: Will Carriers Offer a Better Way to Get Voice Mail?
description: Last week, I got the most surprising piece of e-mail. It came from Saul Einbinder, a marketing executive at a company called uReach.

title: Of National Security and Climate Change
description: The video above was released by the Pew Project on National Security, Energy and Climate  a project of the Pew Charitable Trusts that, according to its Web site, brings together science and military experts to examine new strategies for combating climate change, protecting our national security, increasing our energy independence and preserving our nations natural resources.

title: Off the Menu: The Mark Restaurant by Jean-Georges
description: Jean-Georges Vongerichtens latest, in the newly redone Mark Hotel, is something of a multiplex.

title: Sampler: Runner Is Ticketed in a Closed San Jose Park, and Walnut Creek Polishes Its Brand
description: Mayor Moves Toward Run for Lieutenant Governor | On Wednesday, Gavin Newsom, the San Francisco mayor, filed a ballot statement with the Secretary of States office to indicate his interest in seeking the lieutenant governors post vacated when John Garamendi won a seat in Congress. Mayor Newsom has not made a final determination if he will run and has until March 12 to decide, said an adviser. Still, his statement sounded like he was throwing his hat in. Im running for Lieutenant Governor because its time for us to finally shake up Sacramento and reform state government, read the opening lines. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: AnOther Cotillard Cover
description: Hot in here? In this video  previewed exclusively here on T  Marion Cotillard steams it up for the British fashion photog Craig McDean. Everyone fell in love with her on the shoot, says Jefferson Hack, the editor in chief of AnOther Magazine, who slapped Cotillard on the cover of his new spring/summer issue. As an actress, Marion Cotillard is the consummate performer. A dream to work with  almost too good to be true. Told you so.

title: Special Section on Wealth and Personal Finance
description: A number of consumer-focused articles appeared in a recent special section on wealth and personal finance. Here are some of the highlights.

title: Will Carriers Offer a Better Way to Get Voice Mail?
description: Last week, I got the most surprising piece of e-mail. It came from Saul Einbinder, a marketing executive at a company called uReach.

title: All at Sea, Surrounded by Red Herrings
description: Shutter Island takes place off the coast of Massachusetts in 1954. Im sorry, that should be OFF THE COAST OF MASSACHUSETTS! IN 1954! since every detail and incident in the movie, however minor, is subjected to frantic, almost demented (and not always unenjoyable) amplification. The wail of strangled cellos accompanies shots of the titular island, a sinister, rain-lashed outcropping that is home to a mental hospital for the CRIMINALLY INSANE! The color scheme is lurid, and the camera movements telegraph anxiety. Nothing is as it seems. Something TERRIBLE is afoot.

title: Update: Wednesdays Olympics Coverage Tops Idol
description: After six years, the competition has finally figured out how to beat American Idol in the ratings: have Americans produce thrilling and emotional victories in the Olympics.

title: Comics Creators Gain New Executive Superpowers
description: 2:30 p.m. | Updated Meanwhile, back at the Hall of Justice: DC Comics, the longtime home of Batman and Superman, gained a new executive team on Thursday, one that places some of the comics publishers best-known talents in key positions.

title: Should Doctors Prescribe a Drink a Day?
description: Dr. Mark L. Willenbring, the former director of the Treatment and Recovery Research Division of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, previously responded to reader questions about alcohol use in A New View of Alcoholism. Here, he addresses one readers question about the health benefits of drinking.

title: Safe Travels for You and Your Data
description: There are common-sense measures you can take to keep your data secure when using your computer on the road. Read the full story.

title: Mariano Rivera: Closer and Philosopher
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Whenever I listen to Mariano Rivera, for some reason I think about a great image from September 2008 that Tyler Kepner described thusly: As rain pelted Fenway Park, Rivera stepped out of the visitors clubhouse for a soft-serve chocolate-and-vanilla twist ice cream cone from a concession stand. It cost $4.25, but he got it for free. Being the greatest closer in history has its perks.

title: Update: Ginsberg to Join Time Warner
description: Gary Ginsberg, a politically connected former top adviser to Rupert Murdoch, is joining Time Warner.

title: Mineo Jury Asks for Evidence and Readbacks
description: Jurors in the Michael Mineo police brutality trial asked Thursday morning to review all the physical evidence in the case, and to receive readbacks of the testimony of two officers called by prosecutors to support their charge that Mr. Mineo was sexually abused by police officers at a subway station in Brooklyn in October 2008.

title: E.U. Countries Vie to Meet Renewable Goals
description: The European Union as a whole will meet its goal of 20 percent renewable energy by 2020, according to an analysis by the European Wind Energy Association  though some individual countries will fall short of their individual production targets, while others now report they will exceed them.

title: Down and Down and Down
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: President Obama has announced that hes approving construction of two new nuclear reactors. And George W. Bush immediately stood up and screamed, Its nucular!

title: Glaxo Plans to Remove Zinc From Poligrip Denture Adhesive
description: GlaxoSmithKline said on Thursday that it would stop making and distributing three versions of its popular denture adhesive Poligrip until it removed zinc from the products because of concerns about health risks.

title: Toyota Chief Agrees to Testify Before House Panel
description: DETROIT  The president of Toyota, Akio Toyoda, agreed on Thursday to appear before Congress next week to discuss the recall of millions of vehicles for sudden acceleration problems. The move puts him squarely in position for the first time as the companys chief advocate in Washington.

title: How Simon Built Its War Chest
description: The Simon Property Groups unsolicited $10 billion offer for General Growth Properties didnt come as a surprise to industry analysts, who saw the nations biggest mall operator storing up cash and raising equity over the past year.

title: Bolstering the Knicks Now, and in July
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On a day of furious deal-making, with players scattered across the continent, the most important name was the one that never passed through the transaction wire, or through the lips of Knicks officials.

title: After a Cruelest Month, Oxford Resumes Search for Poetry Professor
description: Oxford University opened nominations on Thursday for the position of professor of poetry, The Guardian reported, less than a year after embarrassing scandals caused one prominent poet to withdraw his candidacy and a second to resign shortly after she assumed the post. In May, the Nobel Prize winner Derek Walcott, top left, withdrew from an election for the professorship after anonymous packages were sent to Oxford academics, containing copies of pages from The Lecherous Professor, a book that described decades-old acts of sexual harassment that he allegedly committed. Days later, Ruth Padel, above bottom, became the first woman in over 300 years to win the seat. But she quickly resigned after it was learned she sent e-mail messages alerting reporters about The Lecherous Professor.

title: Haiti Frees 8 of 10 Detained Americans
description: Eight of the 10 American missionaries jailed last month for trying to take children out of the country were freed Wednesday.

title: Success in Marja Will Hinge on Civilian Surge
description: While the Battle of Marja has so far displayed how the ongoing troop surge in Afghanistan has given Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal additional flexibility in manpower by pushing into Taliban-held territories, the forthcoming months will indicate if the proposed complementary civilian surge was merely a talking point or an actual enabler.

title: CPAC Speakers Mock Obamas Teleprompter
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference opened Thursday morning in Washington, and one leitmotif has emerged as an early favorite: noting that President Obama likes to use a teleprompter when delivering a speech. It was mentioned by David Keene, the head of the American Conservative Union, in his introductory remarks; by Stephen Baldwin, of the famous Baldwin brothers, as part of an attack on Mr. Obama; and by Marco Rubio, the Tea Party-backed candidate who is challenging Gov. Charlie Crist for the Republican senatorial nomination in Florida. Mr. Rubio is clearly a star of the gathering here.

title: F1 Testing Continues, Questions Remain
description: In the two full days now that Formula One testing has resumed in Spain, the predicted bad weather has again made it impossible to tell who is really on top. Yesterday Sebastian Vettel, Lewis Hamilton and Felipe Massa were first, second and third fastest in what seemed to carry some sense of logic to it. But today, Reubens Barrichello in the Williams and Vitaly Petrov in the Renault were first and second fastest and Vettel was third fastest. Massa was down to fifth fastest and Hamilton was lost at the bottom of the time sheets. So still no conclusions, thanks largely to the mixed weather conditions.

title: Q&A: Traveling Alone in Mexico
description: Q.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Seeking to Privatize, Hutchison Delays Earnings
description: Hutchison Telecommunications International, the company run by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, said Thursday that it would postpone reporting its annual results.

title: Ex-UBS Executive to Settle Insider Trading Charges
description: 12:09 p.m. | Updated The New York Timess Lynnley Browning has more here.

title: Ticketmaster Settles With F.T.C. Over Springsteen Tickets
description: The Federal Trade Commission has settled with Ticketmaster over complaints that Ticketmaster used deceptive tactics to steer Bruce Springsteen fans to expensive scalped tickets last year. As part of the settlement, the company will pay refunds and, in a move that could have a wide impact on the multibillion-dollar resale business, make disclosures about the availability of the tickets it resells.

title: Answers About Freelancers and Taxes: Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: True to Its Savory Roots
description: Chelsea Market, on the ground floor of an 11-story building in the shadow of the High Line, is a smorgasbord of food and other shops that came by its tasty mission naturally. For decades, the structure was part of the Nabisco bakeries, churning out Fig Newtons, Animal Crackers, Oreos and Mallomars. The cookies are gone, but the indoor market, occupying the block from 9th to 10th Avenues and 15th to 16th Streets, has stayed true to its food-focused heritage, offering a sprawling set of restaurants and kitchenware stores as well as a refuge from the seasons cold snaps.

title: U.S and Europe Clear Microsoft-Yahoo Search Deal
description: Microsoft and Yahoo have received clearance from regulators in Washington and Europe to proceed with a search partnership intended to challenge Google, The Associated Press reports.

title: McQueen Label Will Continue
description: Robert Polet, the president and chief executive of Gucci Group, announced on Thursday that the Alexander McQueen label will continue, in response to questions about its future since the designers death last week.

title: Kerik Is Sentenced in Corruption Case
description: WHITE PLAINS  Bernard B. Kerik, a former New York police commissioner who rose to national prominence, was sentenced to four years in prison on Thursday after pleading guilty to eight felony charges, including tax fraud and lying to White House officials.

title: Not in Front of the Children?
description: Josh Tyson is now a father of two. He and his wife, Nicole, welcomed a second son, Arius, about a month ago, making Elias a big brother. Josh has written for Motherlode before about merging the old and the new, the person you were before children with the person who is raising children, the child you once were with the parent you are becoming.

title: Bits Scan: Thursdays Tech News Roundup
description: Your morning roundup of technology news:

title: Getting Up Pretty Early in Pursuit of Untouched Powder
description: WARREN, Vt.

title: Designed to Help Uplift the Poor
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A Look Back at 20 Years of Photoshop
description: Its remarkable when a product stays on top of its game for 20 years, and Adobe Photoshop had done just that. The first version of Photoshop shipped on Feb. 19, 1990, at a price of $895. Today its the go-to tool for professional photographers and graphic designers, and it is used by 10 million people around the world, according to Adobe.

title: Im Here, New York, Please Rob Me
description: I was going to write something elegiac about the sale of Duane Reade, an emotionally complicated New York institution, but then it seemed as if most everything had been said already. It remains to be seen whether the sushi and the Delish brand will stay, or what will happen to the much-derided new logo. But I never did feel as passionately about the place pro or con as the blogger behind I Hate Duane Reade seems to. I mean, have you been to a Rite Aid?

title: How to Take Better Low-Light Photos
description: I recently spoke with the Scottish photojournalist Harry Benson, who is known for his images of world leaders, Hollywood icons, rock stars and everyday Glaswegians. (He is, as I found out, also an amiable character and a charming raconteur.) Mr. Bensons photos, particularly his early black-and-white images, are masterly studies in the use of natural light, and I wanted to ask him for tips on shooting in low-light situations. Heres what he had to say.

title: Obama Sets Up Debt Panel
description: President Obama officially created an 18-member commission to propose ways by Dec. 1 to reduce the growing national debt. He named its Republican and Democratic co-chairmen as Congressional Republican leaders agreed, reluctantly, to participate in the effort.

title: A Florida Town Where Turtles, and Even Humans, Can Relax
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.

title: The Resort at Isla Palenque
description: WHAT Private-island residential resort.

title: Sony to End OLED Sales in Japan
description: For those travelers hoping to purchase a Sony OLED television in Japan and cart it home, cancel those plans.

title: Making Computer Science More Enticing
description: The top 10 companies in Silicon Valley employed a lower percentage of Hispanics, African-Americans and women in 2005 than they did a decade ago, according an article earlier this week.

title: Now Screening | Narciso Rodriguez
description: The fall 2010 collection from Narciso Rodriguez.

title: Is It O.K. to Cheat on Your Taxes?
description: Is it O.K. to cheat on your income taxes?

title: Japans Central Bank Stands Pat on Rates
description: Japans central bank held interest rates just above zero Thursday and held off on new policy steps, resisting growing government pressure to escalate the fight against deflation, The Associated Press reported.

title: Seeing Things | The Art of the Billboard
description: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

title: I, Snooki: Is a Jersey Shore Memoir in the Works?
description: Nicole Polizzi, the diminutive reality star who will be known for time immemorial as Snooki, may be shrewder than audiences give her credit for: according to documents published by TheSmokingGun.com, Ms. Polizzi, the Jersey Shore cast member, has filed the paperwork to trademark the name Snooki for future uses that may include a book project. In a Feb. 7 filing with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, representatives for Ms. Polizzi  who, by the way, resides in New York and not New Jersey  asked to trademark her nickname for entertainment in the nature of personal appearances by a television personality and printed matter, namely books. (Ms. Polizzis other handle, Snickers, is already in use by someone else.) Earlier this month, TheSmokingGun.com published documents showing that Ms. Polizzis Jersey Shore cast mate Mike Sorrentino has sought a trademark for the Situation, a nickname that he uses for himself and his abdominal muscles.

title: At 20, a Dane Prepares for Biggest Stage
description: Even attired in the soft pink tones of the Palermo uniform, Simon Kjaer cuts an intimidating figure on a soccer field.

title: CPAC Speaker Bashes Obama, in Racial Tones
description: How can conservatives win the youth vote that overwhelmingly went for Barack Obama in 2008? At the Conservative Political Action Conference, apparently, some are betting on using racial stereotypes.

title: Manhattan District Attorney Names Economic Crimes Chief
description: Manhattans district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., has created a major economic crimes bureau to help combat financial fraud, Reuters reported Thursday.

title: Answers to Your Tax Questions
description: Q.  I bought a rental house with tenants in January 2009. The tenants moved out in May 2009, and I then renovated it and sold it this month. Am I eligible for long-term capital gains tax treatment?

title: Dick Cheney Stuns CPAC Crowd
description: A last-minute surprise appearance at the Conservative Political Action Committee: Dick Cheney. The former vice president was introduced by his daughter Liz after she gave a speech.

title: Papa Loves Baby, but Even That Is in Dispute
description: The words are splayed in silver scribble all over the city, anchoring lampposts, adorning mailboxes, greeting subway riders: Papa Loves Baby.

title: NBC Video: Woods to Come out of Hiding
description: Tiger Woods will end months of silence Friday when he speaks publicly for the first time since his middle of the night car crash and shocking revelations of infidelity.

title: Quick-Change Artist | Abbey Lee
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York fashion week. Here, the model Abbey Lee of Next gets reinvented seven times. For previous models, click here.

title: Intrawest Auction Is Said to Be Delayed 1 Week
description: The Winter Olympics look like theyll go on without interruption.

title: Marines Sweep for Taliban Fighters in Marja
description: United States Marines and Afghan National Army soldiers seized bomb-making materials, documents and weapons.

title: 'ReEntry'
description: Joseph C. Harrell performs an excerpt from Emily Ackerman and K.J. Sanchez's play about Marines returning home from Iraq and Afghanistan. (Video courtesy of Alex Koch)

title: The Writers Sad Lot in Hollywood
description: Novelists are like oil in Hwood: they drill us, pipeline us, pump us and then burn us.

title: Restaurant Review: Restaurante de la Calle in Aranjuez, Spain
description: Mention Aranjuez to your average Spaniard, and its a safe bet that two things will leap to his or her mind: strawberries and asparagus. Since the 16th century, this palatial city, located in a fertile bend between the Tagus and Jarama rivers some 30 miles south of Madrid, has been known for its bountiful produce. Which is why it makes perfect sense that the young chef Rodrigo de la Calle would choose Aranjuez as the location for his delicious experiment in what he calls gastrobotany.

title: Now Screening | Proenza Schouler
description: The fall 2010 collection from Proenza Schouler.

title: Toyota Owners Complain, This Time About the RAV4
description: Last August, Toyota said it was studying complaints from owners of 20013 RAV4s about expensive automatic transmission failures, trying to determine whether an extended warranty was needed. Now those owners have the answer: No.

title: Vonn Crashes, but Mancuso Rolls On
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Watching from the bottom of the race course Thursday afternoon, Maria Riesch and Julia Mancuso turned to look at Lindsey Vonn, the leader at the midpoint of the womens super combined. It was another tense Olympic moment, with a gold medal hanging in the balance. Except this time Vonn clipped a gate and tumbled, the suspense ending with the downhill winner sitting on the snow.

title: Virginia Files Challenge to E.P.A. Greenhouse Gas Regulation
description: Virginias attorney general, Ken Cuccinelli, filed a petition Tuesday asking the Environmental Protection Agency to reconsider its finding that global warming poses a threat to people.

title: Another Extension for Venus in Fur
description: The critically praised production of the new play Venus in Fur will extend for a second time, for three additional weeks, becoming the longest-running play in the 42-year history of the Off Broadway theater company the Classic Stage Company, the troupes leaders announced on Thursday afternoon.

title: A Dutch Town That Nurtures Its Quirks
description: ONSTAGE at ACU, a bar and music club in Utrecht, Noam Cohen stopped briefly to address the crowd. Theres so much room! Mr. Cohen, the lead singer of the hardcore band This Routine Is Hell, yelled into his microphone, surveying the gap between the band and the crowd, clad mostly in black. So he did something about it. Backed by the aggressive one-two thrum of the band, he jumped from the stage, belting out slogans, punching shoulders, launching himself bodily at listeners to draw them closer to the stage and into the show.

title: Police Stops Hit Record in 2009
description: One Police Plaza reported last week that 2009 would likely break the record for the annual number of street stops carried out by city officers  so-called stop and frisks. The total is important because, in a city of 8.4 million people, it is a rough reflection of how many citizens are stopped, questioned and sometimes frisked in encounters that can lead to their being arrested or given a summons. (Some citizens can be stopped more than once in a year.)

title: A Revival in Istanbul
description: UNTIL only recently, the 90-year-old Deniz Palas (Sea Palace in Turkish) in Istanbuls Sishane neighborhood was a perfect symbol of the citys faded glory. Originally a grand apartment building that catered to the areas once large Greek-speaking community, the edifice  and the surrounding neighborhood  slowly slid into a state of decay over the decades, as political and economic turbulence drove the areas original residents away. Now, though, the building symbolizes nothing less than the citys cultural resurgence.

title: Hotel Review: Renew in Honolulu
description: THE BASICS

title: On Asimovs Tail
description: Out here in Napa Valley the thermometer hit 80 degrees yesterday. I put the top down on the baby-blue Mustang and lit out, care free, whizzing by the mustard flowers blooming a brilliant yellow between the rows of healthy vineyards. Slushy New York seems far, far away at the moment.

title: Readers Picks for Mexico City
description: Selected reader suggestions for visiting Mexico City, compiled from user comments on the Travel sections Web site.

title: Obama Meets Dalai Lama, and China Is Quick to Protest
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama met with the Dalai Lama on Thursday, welcoming the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader to the White House for a low-profile meeting that nonetheless raised the hackles of China.

title: Before Games, Luger Filed Warnings
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  An Olympic luge athlete injured in a crash at the Whistler Sliding Centre in November warned Canadian officials about safety hazards at the track months before a competitor was killed last week at the Vancouver Games in an accident on the same course.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Istanbul
description: The 36 Hours column on Feb. 7, about Istanbul, described the fortress Rumelihisari on the Bosporus incorrectly. The fortress is Ottoman, not Byzantine. (It was built in 1452 by the Ottoman sultan Mehmed II and used a year later as a major staging ground for the conquest of Constantinople, the Byzantine capital.)

title: Correction: Into the Wild in Lush Guyana
description: A picture caption on Feb. 7 with an article about eco-tourism in Guyana referred imprecisely to a bird shown at the Iwokrama research center. While it is mostly red, as described, it is actually a red-and-green macaw, and is also known as the green-winged macaw.

title: Setting the Stage for Oscar
description: Bigger, shinier and with more moving parts: those could be the key words for this years Oscars. They certainly apply to the telecasts set, which was revealed on Wednesday by the designer, David Rockwell. With a quarter-moon curtain made of 100,000 Swarovski crystals, three revolving platforms, multiple rotating L.E.D. panels, architecture metal work and mirrors, the set is more complex than ever, according to the shows producers, Adam Shankman and Bill Mechanic. Mr. Rockwell, who also designed the stage last year, was inspired by his childhood in Mexico, as well the optimism of modernism in L.A. and the heyday of Hollywood, he said, according to The Los Angeles Times. The design is meant to encompass the basic elements of moviemaking  light and movement  as well as frame the hosts, Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin, and involve the audience in the theater. But capturing it for the audience at home wont be easy.

title: How Vacations Affect Your Happiness
description: Vacations are a chance to take a break from work, see the world and enjoy time with family. But do they make you happier?

title: Inflation Wont Solve Our Debt Problems
description: Lately I have seen a few suggestions, here and there, that the United States should consider inflating its way out of its rising debt burden.

title: Up Close With Keir Dullea and Marsha Mason
description: Theatergoers who want to see the actors Keir Dullea (2001: A Space Odyssey) and Marsha Mason (The Goodbye Girl) show their stuff up close will have an opportunity when they play the parents in the coming Off Broadway revival of I Never Sang for My Father at the 99-seat Clurman Theater at Theater Row.

title: Answers About the History of Complaining, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of responses from Matthew Bakkom, the editor and creator of New York City Museum of Complaint, a collection of 132 letters written to the mayor of New York from 1751 to 1969.

title: Brown Tees Up Romney at CPAC
description: Another CPAC surprise: Scott Brown.

title: In Plane Crash Coverage, Networks Use the Word Terrorism With Care
description: The early bulletins from Austin, Tex., were chilling: small plane into a building.

title: Man Crashes Plane Into Texas I.R.S. Office
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Leaving behind a rant against the government, big business and particularly the tax system, a computer engineer smashed a small aircraft into an office building where nearly 200 employees of the Internal Revenue Service were starting their workday Thursday morning, the authorities said.

title: Judge Hears Arguments on Google Book Settlement
description: The federal judge overseeing the proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit filed against Google by groups representing authors and publishers heard from a handful of supporters and a parade of objectors to the deal at a hearing Thursday in Manhattan.

title: Rubenstein: No $10 Billion L.B.O.s Anytime Soon
description: 2:45 p.m. | Updated While David M. Rubenstein thinks happy days for private equity are coming again, he says one shouldnt bet on seeing the mega-buyouts of yesteryear return anytime soon.

title: Small Plane Crashes into Texas Office
description: A small plane crashed Thursday into a multistory office building in Austin, causing a fire and sending black smoke billowing from the seven-story structure, NBC reports.

title: Eagles Quarterback Muddle and Mystery
description: Speculation is rampant about Philadelphias quarterback situation. The latest news: no contract extension for Kevin Kolb (and probably none soon, as hell be a restricted free agent in 2011); Michael Vick might not be traded until the preseason (it would cost the Eagles $1.5 million in roster bonus money to keep him that long); and Donovan McNabb may or may not be dealt (nothing new here).

title: A.I.G.s Ex-Top Lawyer Gives Her Side of Pay Dispute
description: Anastasia D. Kelly, who was general counsel of the American International Group during the financial crisis, explained to Fortune why she quit her job over pay restrictions handed down by the governments pay czar.

title: Breaking Down Barriers, and Putting Some Up
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  After the speedskater Shani Davis of Chicago charged from fifth place to first in a gutsy, unyielding finish Wednesday to win his second career Olympic gold medal, his mother could be seen smiling on the arenas jumbo television screen.

title: Photos of the Moment | Lights! Camera! Fashion!
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Bryan Bedder/Getty Images.

title: Europes Top Monetary Official Moves to New Role
description: Just as European Union institutions come under fire for not detecting problems earlier in Greeces finances, the official most responsible during the last five years, Joaqun Almunia, slipped out of that job this month and straight into another, as E.U. antitrust chief, The New York Timess James Kanter reports.

title: Jamal Lewis and His Legacy
description: The Cleveland Browns surprised no one by releasing running back Jamal Lewis this week. The 30-year-old workhorse said last season that he would retire in 2010. However, in a recent statement, Lewis said, I plan to evaluate my future and have not made a final determination on whether I will be playing football next season.

title: Crashes Continue as Bobsled Training Begins
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Shortly after the Olympic luge events ended on Wednesday, the sliding sports changed, but the crashing at the Whistler Sliding Centre did not. There were eight crashes during the first day of two-man bobsled training.

title: Greek Press Names a Speculator
description: The Greek press has started naming names as it looks for the culprits betting against its debt and the euro, and its accusation has been taken up by the blogosphere.

title: Drones at War
description: Video | For comedy with a message, call tech support:

title: Mineo Jury Requests More Readbacks
description: After asking a judge for hours worth of testimony readbacks and physical evidence Thursday morning, the jury in the Michael Mineo police brutality trial asked for a witness list and for medical testimony from both defense and prosecution witnesses to be read back Thursday afternoon.

title: What Were Reading
7 Secrets of the Emergency Room
description: Whats the worst thing you can say to the nurse in an emergency room?

title: Honoring a Homegrown, Forgotten Freedom Fighter
description: When David Ruggles, an Underground Railroad conductor in Manhattan who is said to have opened the nations first black bookstore and black-owned printing press, died in 1849, the antislavery advocate and publisher William Lloyd Garrison lauded his contributions to the abolitionist movement.

title: Where the Orchestras Played and the Mice Presided
description: MICKEY MOUSE has left the building. That is, left the marquee over the World of Disney Store on Fifth Avenue at 55th Street, where he, Minnie and Pluto guarded the entrance for well over a decade. They were removed earlier this year, after Disney moved out.

title: Vanishing Cranes
description: The housing start numbers released on Wednesday showed that we were approaching a milestone that would have been thought impossible a year or two ago.

title: Tainted Record or Not, La Russa Remains Impressed
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Tony La Russa is not ready to declare Mark McGwires 70-homer season in 1998 a sham but he conceded on Thursday that McGwires steroids confession in January had changed his perception of the achievement  sort of.

title: Big Musical Questions, and Some Answers
description: The topic was weighty: how music can save the world.

title: For the Moment | Value Propositions
description: Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London  but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New Yorks Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insiders view on whats driving gallivanters now.

title: Why Were Not Hiring Right Now
description: The recession has been devastating to businesses of all kinds. But we at SRC just learned how its effects, which have already forced everyone in our company to make some tough decisions, might linger longer than wed hoped. Let me explain.

title: On the Scene: Analyzing Scenes in Film and Literature
description: Overview | What are the elements of a scene? How does deconstructing scenes reveal meaning? In this lesson, students start to think like film directors by storyboarding an experience from their lives. They then examine the Times Movies feature Anatomy of a Scene and develop their own analyses of scenes from film and literature.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A hot-air balloon flies near the Ramesseum temple on the west bank of Luxor, Egypt.

title: Screed Against I.R.S. Was Posted Online Before Two Fires in Texas
Former UBS Banker Settles Insider Trading Claims
description: A former senior executive at the Swiss banking giant UBS has agreed to pay a $2.75 million settlement to resolve claims of insider trading in auction-rate securities, the New York attorney generals office saidThursday.

title: Shrinking the Screen
description: Parenthood, on NBC, is the latest television series to be adapted from a film. A look at previous examples.

title: History Lesson in Abstraction, Cutting Across the Americas
description: NEWARK  Art museums are in the business of sorting out history. And it often falls to our smaller institutions to tackle the initial, broad-stroke cuts. Over the years the Newark Museum has taken on this path-clearing role with relish, particularly when the histories are transcultural in scope. It does so again in Constructive Spirit: Abstract Art in South and North America, 1920s-50s, the capstone exhibition of the museums centennial.

title: Reed Business Information to Hold On to Variety
description: Reed Elsevier on Thursday disclosed that it will hold on to the Hollywood trade magazine Variety instead of selling it, Folio reports, citing the British publishers 2009 investor presentation.

title: Tweet My Ride: Fords Tech-Savvy Fiesta
description: Are you interested in reserving one of the 2011 Ford Fiestas, which will appear in dealerships this spring? You need go no further than your iPhone or BlackBerry  just text the word reserve to 4Ford. A few clicks at Fiestamovement.com will get you there, too.

title: Judge Keeps His Word to Immigrant Who Kept His
description: The judge and the juvenile had grown up on the same mean streets, 40 years apart. And in fall 1996, they faced each other in a New York court where children are prosecuted as adults, but sentenced like candidates for redemption.

title: Model-morphosis | Anna Sui
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Rose Cordero from Supreme Model Management, before (above, top) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Garren. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Some Think Cheating on Taxes is O.K.
description: About 13 percent of Americans think its O.K. to cheat on income taxes, a slight increase from the previous year, according to a new survey from the Internal Revenue Service Oversight Board covered in this Economix blog post.

title: Oscar Pool Intelligence
description: Aside from the technical categories  sound editing and the like  foreign-language and short films are often the downfall of most peoples Oscar pools. Well, the Bagger is looking out for you. Before you place your bets, well help you do a little self-education (or point you to others with the same impulse). At the In Contention blog, Kris Tapley breaks down the foreign-language films, which are somehow ripe for upset every year (last years winner was the little-seen Japanese film Departures).

title: Alexander McQueen Line to Continue
description: The Gucci Group announced on Thursday that it would continue to produce fashion collections and accessories under the Alexander McQueen label after the suicide of the avant-garde designer last week.

title: Pirates Ross Ohlendorf Exercised Brain With Federal Internship
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In some ways, Ross Ohlendorf is a lot like other players at spring training. He drives a sport utility vehicle and listens to baseball talk on the radio. He took his golf clubs to camp and watches American Idol with his three Pittsburgh Pirates roommates. He wants to perfect a changeup.

title: Pranksters May Want to Give This Brand a Hand
description: Remember an online prank last fall from a Manhattan restaurant, generating real-looking receipts that were offered up as a way to pad expense accounts? Some of the folks behind it are back with a Web site that generates realistic-seeming hand scans.

title: Local Airports Are Unloved, Survey Says
description: Updated, 4:22 p.m. | All three major airports that serve the New York City area ranked at or near the bottom of a customer-satisfaction survey released Thursday.

title: Cautious Optimism for the Pirates
description: It is a small note on the major league landscape on Thursday, but discouraging just the same. Joel Hanrahan, a reliever for the Pittsburgh Pirates, has a flexor-pronator strain in his right elbow and will start the season on the disabled list.

title: Movie Listings
description: MOVIES

title: Quirky Buyers Wanted
description: CYNTHIA CRANE, a cabaret singer and Greenwich Village fixture of sorts, has a show scheduled for next month titled John Denver, Bernie Madoff and Me. What she and John Denver, or more literally Mr. Denvers estate, have in common is that they were both fleeced by Mr. Madoff.

description: Werewolf Star Transforms

title: Spotlight on Tiger Woodss Strategy
description: Tiger Woodss live scripted mea culpa on Friday at 11 a.m. Eastern time, from the T.P.C. Sawgrass clubhouse in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., will inevitably be compared with two forms of the modern celebrity apology: one made famous by Mark McGwire and Alex Rodriguez and the second by politicians like Eliot Spitzer and Mark Sanford.

title: Ristretto | A New Twist on Espresso
description: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why its never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

title: Vote of Confidence for Womens Hockey
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Womens hockey will continue in future Olympics, although measures may be taken to modify the one-sided nature of the tournament, Ren Fasel, president of the International Ice Hockey Federation, said Thursday during a news conference at Canada Hockey Place.

description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Barrick to Spin Off 4 African Gold Mines
description: Barrick Gold said Thursday that it planned to spin off its African gold mines into a separate publicly traded company, The Associated Press reports.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Feb. 18
description: Marines continued their operation in southern Afghanistan, conducting a sweep to clear the Taliban from the Marja area. At least four Taliban fighters were killed in the operation, which began before daybreak on Thursday. (Slides 1 and 2)

title: In Surprise Move, Fed Signals Pivot to Normal Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Taking a step to normalize lending after holding interest rates to extraordinary lows for more than a year to prop up the financial system, the Federal Reserve on Thursday raised the interest rate it charges on short-term loans to banks.

title: The Other Kind of Fog Visits the Bay Area and Stays
description: The comedian Eddie Izzard described the San Francisco fog: Busy, busy, busy! It could be late to get in someones face somewhere! It runs down the road, doesnt it?

description: Attendees were anxious about the direction of the country under President Obama, but hopeful that public discontent would be a route back to political power for Republicans.

title: Inspectors Say Iran Worked on Warhead
description: WASHINGTON  The United Nations nuclear inspectors declared for the first time on Thursday that they had extensive evidence of past or current undisclosed activities by Irans military to develop a nuclear warhead, an unusually strongly worded conclusion that seems certain to accelerate Irans confrontation with the United States and other Western countries.

title: The Presidential Field
description: The conservative activists have differing views of who should be seen as leading contenders for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination.

description: Web Travel Tycoon

title: In Mets Camp, a Little P.& R.
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Oakland Raiders use Commitment to Excellence as a team slogan, and at Notre Dame football players go out to the field under a sign imploring them to Play Like a Champion.

title: True to Its Savory Roots
description: Chelsea Market, on the ground floor of an 11-story building in the shadow of the High Line, is a smorgasbord of food and other shops that came by its tasty mission naturally. For decades, the structure was part of the Nabisco bakeries, churning out Fig Newtons, Animal Crackers, Oreos and Mallomars. The cookies are gone, but the indoor market, occupying the block from Ninth to 10th Avenues and 15th to 16th Streets, has stayed true to its food-focused heritage, offering a sprawling set of restaurants and kitchenware stores as well as a refuge from the seasons cold snaps.

title: Home Is Where the Soul Aches
description: A scary, splendid clarity radiates from the terminally confused kinfolk who are running wild at the Acorn Theater. Thats where the New Group revival of A Lie of the Mind, Sam Shepards gorgeous play from 1985 about families in meltdown, opened Thursday night in a production that connoisseurs of precision acting will be savoring for years to come.

title: Challenge From the Right
description: The notion of a third party - beyond Democrats and Republicans - does not seem desirable or even feasible to these activists, although it still proves worrisome to the ultimate goal of advancing a conservative agenda.

title: House G.O.P. Leader Promises Bipartisan Change
description: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader who has an eye on the speakers gavel, says things will be different if he, rather than current Speaker Nancy Pelosi, is in charge come 2011.
