title: Trendspotting | Hoods
description: Many of the models sauntering along the runways during New York Fashion Week were shrouded in hoods, a look as pervasive in the fall 2010 collections as it is on the streets and at the gym.

title: Money for Nothing
description: News Parody | From The Onion:

title: Raising the Hood
description: WERE they off to some assignation? Taking cover from the flashbulbs? Or just trying to disguise a bad hair day? Many of the models sauntering along the runways during New York Fashion Week were shrouded in hoods, a look as pervasive in the fall 2010 collections as it is on the streets and at the gym.

title: A Vote for the Best, Not for Modesty
description: The best pitcher in the National League East, according to Johan Santana, arrived at Mets camp on Thursday.

title: The Brain Mistrust
description: Republicans are feeling buoyant these days, having managed to cut their deficit in the Senate down to 18 seats, which means they can now be a genuine irritant to the Democrats who run the country. And yet there are still those glass-half-empty Republicans who insist on reminding their colleagues that the party is beset by serious problems. It has no discernible governing agenda, for one thing. The partys chairman, Michael Steele, makes Howard Dean look like a model of reticence, and its most charismatic leader is a former governor of a small state  unless you count the caribou  who seems more interested in celebrity than in policy. And its establishment is under siege from furious activists who seem to regard all government as tyranny. And so this month a cadre of conservative donors and policy makers  they include the former Minnesota senator Norm Coleman and the economist Douglas Holtz-Eakin  stepped forward with an answer to all this: a brand-new think tank. Actually, the American Action Network, as Coleman described it to The Timess Jackie Calmes, is supposed to be a think-and-do tank, meaning that its mission is not only to synthesize the Republican argument but to aggressively market it as well.

title: Revenue Rose but Profit Dropped for Dell
description: Still struggling to keep up with its competitors, Dell said on Thursday that its profit fell 5 percent in the fourth quarter, breaking with what has been a strong earnings season for technology companies.

title: Olympics Tops Idol
description: After six years, the competition has finally figured out how to beat American Idol in the ratings: have Americans produce thrilling and emotional victories in the Olympics. Based on the overnight ratings, NBCs coverage of the Winter Olympics on Wednesday night did not just beat Idol on Wednesday night  it trounced that previously unbeatable singing competition. It was the first time that the formidable Idol lost to any show on television in almost six years, ending a winning streak of an amazing 222 editions of Idol. The victory for NBC was clearly fueled by early news reports Wednesday that Lindsey Vonn, above, the star American skier, had staged an exciting comeback run on the downhill course despite a shin injury. The coverage of the race proved the highlight of NBCs night, and it was placed dead against Idol in the 9 p.m. hour. In the overnight national ratings, the Olympics averaged 30.1 million viewers in the hour between 9 and 10 p.m., by far the biggest night of the games so far, and an increase of 47 percent over the same night four years ago in Turin, Italy. Idol had a still potent but distant second-place total of 18.4 million viewers. Over all, NBCs Olympics coverage on Wednesday night averaged 29.4 million viewers, the best total of the games so far.

title: Dodd to Unveil Bill on Financial Regulations
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, plans to unveil his bill to overhaul the nations financial regulations next week after months of negotiations with Republicans, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Dullea and Mason Pair; Venus in Fur Extended
description: Theatergoers who want to see the actors Keir Dullea (2001: A Space Odyssey) and Marsha Mason (The Goodbye Girl) show their stuff up close will have an opportunity when they play the parents in the coming Off Broadway revival of I Never Sang for My Father at the 99-seat Clurman Theater at Theater Row. The actor Matt Servitto (The Sopranos) will join them as the son who yearns for a closer relationship with his father. The play, which was written by Robert Anderson, was first produced on Broadway in 1968, starring Lillian Gish, Hal Holbrook and Alan Webb. This new revival, by Keen Company, will be directed by Jonathan Silverstein (The Temperamentals) and is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 23 and open on April 4. A limited engagement, it is scheduled to end on May 1. Ms. Mason, above right, a four-time Oscar nominee, last appeared on Broadway in Impressionism last season and Off Broadway in A Feminine Ending at Playwrights Horizons in 2007. Mr. Dullea, above left, last starred Off Broadway in Mary Rose at the Vineyard Theater in 2007. ... The critically praised production of the new play Venus in Fur will extend for a second time, for three additional weeks, becoming the longest-running play in the 42-year history of the Off Broadway theater company the Classic Stage Company, the troupes leaders announced on Thursday. Starring Nina Arianda and Wes Bentley as an actress and a playwright whose wordplay during an audition turns erotic, Venus in Fur is now scheduled to run through March 28. Venus, a limited engagement, was originally scheduled to end this Sunday, but was first extended to March 7 because of demand and to accommodate producers considering the show for regional productions and for New York and London.

title: J. K. Rowling Denies Plagiarism Charge
description: If theres a magic spell that can keep J. K. Rowlings name out of lawsuits  Litigio Impedimenta, maybe?  the Harry Potter author hasnt mastered it yet. On Thursday Ms. Rowling, right, said a plagiarism lawsuit filed against her by the estate of another author was unfounded and absurd after Ms. Rowlings name was added to the case as a defendant, Reuters reported. The estate of Adrian Jacobs, an author who died in 1997, began proceedings against Ms. Rowling and the publisher Bloomsbury, which releases the Harry Potter novels in Britain, saying that Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the fourth novel in Ms. Rowlings series, was plagiarized from Jacobss 1987 book, The Adventures of Willy the Wizard  No 1 Livid Land. In a statement Ms. Rowling said she was saddened that yet another claim has been made that I have taken material from another source to write Harry. She said she had not heard of the Jacobs book before the accusations were made by the estate, and never read it, adding, We will be applying to the court immediately for a ruling that the claim is without merit and should therefore be dismissed without delay.

title: Oxford Resumes Search for Poetry Professor
description: Oxford University opened nominations on Thursday for the position of professor of poetry, The Guardian reported, less than a year after an embarrassing scandal caused one prominent poet to withdraw his candidacy and a second to resign shortly after she assumed the post. In May the Nobel Prize winner Derek Walcott withdrew from an election for the professorship after anonymous packages were sent to Oxford academics, containing copies of pages from The Lecherous Professor, a book that described decades-old acts of sexual harassment that he allegedly committed. Days later, Ruth Padel became the first woman in more than 300 years to win the seat. But she quickly resigned after it was learned she had sent e-mail messages alerting reporters about The Lecherous Professor. Oxford will take nominations for the professorship, a prestigious position with a salary of less than $11,000 a year, through May 5, after which its graduates can vote for a favorite. The Guardian said Geoffrey Hill and Anne Stevenson were possible candidates, but Andrew Motion, a former British poet laureate, has said he does not want to be considered.

title: I, Snooki: Jersey Shore Memoir in the Works?
description: Nicole Polizzi, the diminutive reality star who will be known for time immemorial as Snooki, may be shrewder than audiences give her credit for: according to documents published by TheSmokingGun.com, Ms. Polizzi, the Jersey Shore cast member, has filed the paperwork to trademark the name Snooki for future uses that may include a book project. In a Feb. 7 filing with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, representatives for Ms. Polizzi  who, by the way, resides in New York and not New Jersey  asked to trademark her nickname for entertainment in the nature of personal appearances by a television personality and printed matter, namely books. (Ms. Polizzis other handle, Snickers, is already in use by someone else.) Earlier this month TheSmokingGun.com published documents showing that Ms. Polizzis Jersey Shore cast mate Mike Sorrentino has sought a trademark for the Situation, a nickname that he uses for himself and his abdominal muscles.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: In San Francisco, Eats and Beats
description: What do you get when you combine San Franciscos booming food-cart scene and local D.J. culture? A monthly party called Dirty Dishes.

title: Fed Raises Interest Rate That It Charges Banks
description: The Federal Reserve, taking its first step to normalize lending after more than two years of extraordinary actions to prop up the economy, on Thursday raised the interest rate it charges banks on emergency loans, Sewell Chan of The New York Times reports from Washington.

title: Dance Listings
description: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

title: Tribune Gains More Time for Reorganization Plan
description: The Tribune Company on Thursday won approval from a federal bankruptcy judge for more time to prepare its reorganization plan, The Associated Press reports.

title: Charitable Doubt
description: I am the assistant to the president of a general-contracting company. Although I have no authority to hire subcontractors, several seem eager to cultivate my good will. This past fall when I participated in a charity race, I added a line to my e-mail signature describing my involvement and linked it to a Web site where people could donate to this worthy cause. Several subcontractors did so, and the charity automatically alerted me. Was I wrong to solicit money this way? KELLY VERDIN, AUSTIN, TEX.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

title: Scorecard | Marc Jacobs Wins!
description: Psst  want a little tip on improving your Scorecard average? Dont show on the same day as Marc Jacobs. If you do, even if you clock shift your show by an entire 12 hours and trade in the whole five-piano circus for some perfectly lovely austerity chic, the Wiz who likes to show over at the Armory will take his pared-down dissertation on Americana over the rainbow and upstage you.

title: What Olympic Events and Athletes Are You Watching?
description: Did you watch Shaun White, Lindsey Vonn or Shani Davis win the gold in their events at the Winter Olympics on Wednesday night? How closely are you following the coverage this year? What are your favorite Olympic sports and athletes? Why?

title: British Austerity
description: So Ive seen the economists letter opposing premature fiscal tightening in Britain, and hear it will be published tomorrow. I fully agree with the writers position.

title: Palace in Niger Is Attacked by Soldiers
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Soldiers in Niger assaulted the presidential palace in a coup attempt on Thursday while the government was meeting inside, according to officials and diplomats.

title: Capitol Steps
description: The satirical comedy troupe the Capitol Steps, above, is fittingly based in Washington, where it performs regularly, and with the number of targets for spoofing there youd think it would never have occasion to leave the capital. Thankfully, though, members of the company will be at Town Hall on Friday night to share their spirited form of mockery; in addition to skits, they rewrite the words to well-known songs, lampooning various public figures or situations.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Five Questions About ReEntry
description: What happens when a soldier comes back from combat is the subject of Emily Ackerman and K. J. Sanchezs play ReEntry, now playing at Urban Stages.

title: Mineo Jury Told That Officer Had Prior Charges
description: Updated, 6:23 p.m. | Jurors have gone home for the evening. The juror who sent the note apparently wants to stay on the trial. Lawyers for the defendants are expected to discuss the situation with their clients on Thursday evening. The judge plans on interviewing the juror before deciding whether to allow deliberations to continue.

title: Brooklyn Inventgenuity Festival
description: Dont be alarmed if your children tell you they want to spend the weekend inside the Invisible Dog. They dont need a trip to the therapist  just to Brooklyn.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100218

title: In the Bronx, a Place to Glide, and Fall, on the Ice
description: The skating rink is small, ringed by hay bales and dwarfed by walls of brick and windows. Prometheus - unbound or otherwise - is absent.

title: Simon Seeks Partners for Joint General Growth Bid
description: 7:50 p.m. | Updated The Simon Property Group is in preliminary talks with the Blackstone Group and sovereign wealth funds about making a potential joint bid for General Growth Properties after the bankrupt mall operator rejected Simons unsolicited $10 billion offer, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

title: $3.5 Billion in Revenue at CBS in Quarter
description: CBS, which is regularly the countrys highest-rated broadcast network, said on Thursday that revenue and profits at its flagship television business improved in the fourth quarter.

title: Tesla Motors: Tight-Knit, Passionate and Grieving
description: For Tesla Motors, the airplane crash in East Palo Alto, Calif., that killed three of its employees Wednesday morning was like a death in the family.

title: Now Screening | Michael Kors
description: The fall 2010 collection from Michael Kors.

title: Dont Think of It as Another Film Festival, Think of It as a Sampler
description: Berlin is wrapping up. Cannes looms on the horizon, and the rest of the calendar is stuffed with more film festivals than even the most dedicated frequent-flying cinemaniac could list, much less attend. But for the last 10 years Film Comment Selects, a program hosted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, has provided both a diversion from that relentless schedule and a distillation of it. A visit to the Walter Reade Theater from Friday through March 4 offers a chance to sample a kind of tasting menu of the festival circuit.

title: Letters: The Scene in Santa Fe
description: To the Editor: The Art of Being Santa Fe (Feb. 7) by Henry Shukman neglected to mention ART Santa Fe (artsantafe.com), an international art fair celebrating its 10th anniversary. The fair will be held July 15 to 18, 2010, at the new Santa Fe Convention Center and will once again present great contemporary art from around the world. With over 5,000 visitors expected, this is a significant event for Santa Fe and its arts community, and should certainly be included in any list of upcoming events.

title: Soundtrack of Their End: Romance Curdles Onstage
description: Around 9 on Wednesday night Stew and his band had just finished Leave/Believe, a terse, mopey number that stops cold in the middle of a sad feeling and never resumes, or redeems. Wordlessly the group left the stage. The St. Anns Warehouse house lights didnt brighten. The audience waited expectantly for a couple of minutes, and got nothing.

title: A Musician, Machines and Room to Breathe
description: Acoustic information goes a long way in Four Tets electronica. Kieran Hebden, an English musician whose solo electronic project is Four Tet, brought a laptop and a table full of other devices to Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday night, and there was no question that he was making electronic music, with layer upon layer of loops and programmed drumbeats. But those layers were often filled with sounds that had been made physically rather than electronically: percussion, guitar, a human voice. They make Four Tets music breathe, even though its a computer product.

title: U.S. Mens Hockey Win Stirs Questions
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Norway, a team without any N.H.L. players on its roster, battled to a standoff for long stretches of Thursdays game against the all-N.H.L. roster of the United States.

title: Taking the Podcast Back to a Simpler Time
description: The podcast is the ultimate symbol of modernity, a hipster alternative to the creaky, top-down formalism of conventional television. So its piquant, to say the least, that The Ricky Gervais Show, a new animated series which begins on HBO on Friday, echoes the early days of radio and television.

title: A Woman and Her Band Commune With a Legend
description: Introducing her Billie Holiday tribute, To Billie With Love  A Celebration of Lady Day, on Wednesday evening at the Allen Room, the singer Dee Dee Bridgewater declared that the standard image of Holiday as a tragic figure shrouded in sadness was only partly true. Holiday was also a very funny woman who could curse like a sailor and loved to cook for her fellow musicians, Ms. Bridgewater insisted. She went on to sing a program of Holiday-associated songs, many of which she and her phenomenal band infused with an epic sense of expressive possibility.

title: A Dutch Orchestra Plumbing the Depths
description: When Mariss Jansons took over the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam in 2004, he quickly set about muting the bright sound cultivated by his predecessor, Riccardo Chailly, and restoring the warmth and depth for which this great Dutch orchestra has long been revered. When he visited New York with the ensemble in 2006 and 2008, that restoration seemed just about complete.

title: Youthful Intensity, Onstage and in the Program
description: A surprising number of seats were empty at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night for the concert by the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra, the first of two programs. The performance was the first chance for New York audiences to hear this impressive orchestra under its exciting new music director, Yannick Nzet-Sguin, now in his second season. Born in Montreal in 1975, Mr. Nzet-Sguin, who succeeded Valery Gergiev at Rotterdam, recently had a notable success in his Metropolitan Opera debut for the new production of Bizets Carmen.

title: Tinges of Electro-Pop and Some Ives, Too
description: Among the ways to pin down Kneebody, a resolutely unpin-downable band, a few come rooted in plain fact. The group uses a common jazz instrumentation  trumpet, saxophone, rhythm section  to make a somewhat less common amalgam of urban-signifying genres, from electro-pop to punk-rock to hip-hop. Four of its five members met in the late 1990s at the Eastman School of Music. Its most recent album, Twelve Songs by Charles Ives (Winter & Winter), featuring the vocalist Theo Bleckmann, was nominated for a Grammy this year, in the category of best classical crossover album.

title: The Torrent That Flowed in Picassos Final Years
description: The post-World War II years were a particularly prolific period for Picasso. He began spending most of his time in the south of France surrounded by bullfighters and poets, master craftsmen and fellow artists like Matisse.

title: A Wish List of Features for the Next Round of Cellphones
Writer for Hire Is a Wanted Man
description: The darkly brooding sky that hangs over much of The Ghost Writer, the latest from Roman Polanski, suggests that all is grim and gray and perhaps even for naught. But this high-grade pulp entertainment is too delectably amusing and self-amused, and far too aware of its own outrageous conceits to sustain such a dolorous verdict. The world has gone mad of course  this is a Polanski film  so all we can do is puzzle through the madness, dodging the traps with our ironic detachment and tongue lightly in cheek.

title: Toffees Honor Donovan
description: So far, Landon Donovans limited engagement with Everton of the English Premier League has been nothing short of smashing, as they might say on the other side of the pond.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jeremy Scott
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: Under a Strange, Soulful Spell
description: In 1960, one year after Nina Simones first album, Little Girl Blue, was released, the poet Langston Hughes struggled to put the appeal of Simones music and presence  that dusky voice, that unblinking gaze  into words. She is strange, Hughes wrote in The Chicago Daily Defender. So are the plays of Brendan Behan, Jean Genet and Bertolt Brecht. She is far out, and at the same time common. So are raw eggs in Worcestershire.

title: Take This Museum and Shape It
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is capping the 50th birthday festivities for its Frank Lloyd Wright building with some navel gazing. Still, there are worse navels to consider. Wrights spiral rotunda, in fact, could be thought of as the greatest belly button in modern architecture: an innie and an outie all in one.

title: Princess Noire
description: Prologue

title: Academy Gives Art Some Wiggle Room
description: The 2010 Whitney Biennial, which opens next week, is one of the leanest in recent memory. So by its own standards is the National Academy Museums 185th Annual: An Invitational Exhibition of Contemporary American Art  down to 65 artists from the usual 120 or so. Reduced finances are to blame, in both cases.

title: Do-It-Yourself Comes to Collector Publishing
description: As museums have slashed budgets for publications about their antiques in recent years, collectors are picking up the slack. In the last few months a half-dozen scholarly books have been released about narrow categories of objects, with texts and sometimes funding provided by obsessed owners.

title: Art in Review
description: ECSTATIC PEACE POETRY JOURNAL, ISSUE #10

title: Bridge Will Close on Schedule
description: The producers of the hit Broadway revival A View From the Bridge told cast members on Wednesday night that the play, by Arthur Miller, would close as scheduled on April 4 after a proposed move from the Cort Theater to the Neil Simon Theater fell through because of matters of costs and actor availability, according to two executives involved in the production.

title: More Shake-Ups at the Ailing Philadelphia Orchestra
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra, facing severe financial problems and searching for a music director, received some mixed news this week.

title: Audrey Saunders Leaves the Tar Pit
description: Two months after opening the tiki-themed Tar Pit bar in Los Angeles with the chef Mark Peel, Audrey Saunders has left, citing differences of opinion regarding the overall vision and direction and fundamental differences regarding the marketing strategy.

title: Photographs From The Routes of Man
description: Images captured by Ted Conover, from his globe-spanning book about.

title: Video: Ten Minutes With CPAC Attendees
description: With efforts for midterm elections intensifying and the next presidential campaign already quietly underway, what is the mood among conservatives?

title: Theater Listings: Feb. 19  25
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Big Ethanol Producer in Brazil to Buy a Rival
description: ETH Bioenergy, a large ethanol producer in Brazil, announced Thursday that it was acquiring its debt-laden rival Brenco for an undisclosed price.

title: Forget Those Games in Vancouver. We Havent Finished Analyzing the Super Bowl Ads.
description: Madison Avenue continues to pore over the results of the polls and surveys showing how consumers responded to the commercials that ran during Super Bowl XLIV on CBS on Feb. 7.

title: National Enquirer Is Deemed Eligible to Compete for Pulitzer Prizes
description: The Pulitzer Prize administrators have decided that the National Enquirer is eligible to compete for the awards, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Family Guy Voice Actor Says Palin Does Not Have a Sense of Humor
description: Since it was shown on Sunday, an episode of the Fox animated comedy Family Guy has drawn the repeated condemnation of Sarah Palin, the former Republican governor of Alaska and 2008 vice-presidential nominee.

title: A Town Torn Asunder by Racial Killing in 70
description: Jeb Stuarts Blood Done Sign My Name scrupulously examines a page from the recent history of the South  a racially charged murder that took place in Oxford, N.C., in 1970. The details of the case resemble those of many similar events that took place across the region at the height of the civil rights movement. A black man, Henry Marrow, was brutally killed and his accused murderers, members of a family of white business owners, were acquitted by an all-white jury as the town seethed and its leaders panicked. There were peaceful marches to the state capital, and also acts of looting, vandalism and arson.

title: Inside the List
description: SCANDAL SHEETS: Political gossip continues to own the podium this week, with Game Change hanging on to the hardcover nonfiction gold, followed by The Politician and Jenny Sanfords Staying True.

title: In Performance: 'A Lie of the Mind'
description: Maggie Siff performs an excerpt from the revival of Sam Shepard's play.

title: The Case For Prison Reform, Again
description: It cant be made often enough. In a grim New York Review of Books essay on prison rape, the authors zero in on sexual abuse at juvenile detention centers:

title: In Mens Figure Skating, Quad Not Needed to Win
description: An analysis suggests that the risk of trying a quadruple jump in figure skating is not worth the reward.

title: So Many Identities, So Little Time
description: In the first minutes of Palestine, her one-woman show at the Fourth Street Theater, Najla Said announces, I grew up as a Jew in New York City. Except that she didnt. Ms. Said is a hyphenated-hyphenate, a Palestinian-Lebanese-American Christian. And, oh yes, shes the daughter of Edward W. Said.

title: Does Education Make You Happy?
description: Ignorance isnt bliss. Rather, education is.

title: Home No More
description: In impoverished parts of Milwaukee and many other cities, evictions of renters are so common that they have become part of the texture of life.

title: Lincoln Center to Stage an Almodvar Musical
description: The new musical Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, based on the 1988 Pedro Almodvar film, and the acclaimed British production of the play War Horse will be two of the major shows of the 2010-11 season at Lincoln Center Theater, executives there said on Thursday.

title: Investor Will Leave New York Times Board
description: A leader of the investment team that bought a large stake in The New York Times Company two years ago, only to see it lose much of its value, will not seek re-election to the board, the company said Thursday.

title: Sex and Money and High Rollers (Memories Were Made of This)
description: Yuppie scum is a term that may not be heard much nowadays, but it applies to the shallow, boorish stock traders at Morgan & Morgan, the fictional New York investment bank in Julio DePietros acidic romantic comedy, The Good Guy. Shown last year at the Tribeca Film Festival just a few months after the economys near-collapse, the movie may feel a little behind the curve. But it is fresh enough to provide the voyeuristic kick of glimpsing the frenzied lifestyle of aspiring masters of the universe at a time when unlimited greed was rewarded with unlimited opportunity. An alternate title might have been Wall Street, Junior.

title: Its All Downhill From Here
description: Back in the 70s, when I was at Brown University playing on the only womens college ice hockey team in the U.S., I called my brother, a varsity hockey player at Colby College, and asked him to get some girls out onto the ice for us to play. He did, and one of them was our friend Linda Krohn. Weeks later, Lindas mother found out and insisted that Linda stop playing hockey so she wouldnt lose her teeth or something. Now I smile with glee that Lindas daughter, Lindsey Vonn, races down mountains at world-class speeds and that womens ice hockey is in the Olympics, too. Portsmouth, R.I.

title: On Edge
description: Michael Sokoloves story about Shani Davis reminded me of one of my sons favorite sayings. When we lectured him as a middle-school student about the value of being a team player, we told him, tritely, Theres no I in team.  He looked at us slyly and came right back with, Thats right; but there is a me! Good luck, Shani!

title: The Ethicist: Should the Sex Offender Be Invited?
description: In response to a reader who asked whether to invite to a reunion a classmate who is a registered sex offender, Randy Cohen said to do nothing in order to not be catering to prejudice. Is the dissemination of public-record information about a person who has proved to be a danger, perhaps to children, now deemed equivalent to denying a woman equal pay based on her gender or denying an African-American a loan based on the color of his skin?

title: James Patterson Inc.
description: In Jonathan Mahlers profile of James Pattersons writing empire (Jan. 24), Mahler compares the prolific Patterson to other best-selling authors like John Grisham, Dan Brown and Stephen King. Why not make the most obvious comparison to the prolific Nora Roberts? True, Roberts publishes just four to five novels each year, compared with Pattersons nine, but because Roberts has sometimes outearned Grisham and King  according to The New Yorker, 27 of Robertss books are sold each minute  Mahlers focus on less-successful male authors to emphasize Pattersons success smacks a bit of myopia.

title: In No Excuse Campaign, Bad Drivers Offer Excuses
description: WEYMOUTH, Britain  One after the other, the motorists were caught blatantly violating the law. One after the other, they tried to talk their way out of it with elaborate diversionary narratives.

title: Is There an Ecological Unconscious?
description: The answer to this question posed by Daniel B. Smith (Jan. 31) is yes, and for some time now science has had far more than anecdotal or folkloric bases for it. The anthropological science of cultural ecology was established in the 1950s, and the logical presumption that an ecological sense is rooted in human evolutionary biology was supported by subsequent studies. Good evidence that a natural setting . . . has restorative benefits was provided by the landscape architect Roger S. Ulrich in his influential article, View Through a Window May Influence Recovery From Surgery, published by Science in 1984; his and E. O. Wilsons subsequent work have important implications for understanding the apparently universal cultural expressions of human interconnections with nature. Their work can inform such disparate phenomena as the soothing effects of pale shades of blue and green; urban dwellers romanticization of nature, as evidenced in the medieval concept of the wild man; and the success of Romantic poetry during the British Industrial Revolution.

title: N.H.L. Commissioner Lists Reasons for Failing to Commit to 2014
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Commissioner Gary Bettman on Thursday offered the most publicly detailed list of reasons yet for the National Hockey Leagues longstanding position not to commit to participation in the 2014 Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

title: A Tired Old Bridge Gets a New Look. No, Four of Them.
description: Updated, 12:47 p.m. | (See video-game-like simulation of a drive across one of the proposed bridge designs here.)

title: CPAC Gets Under Way
description: Adam Nagourney reports on the gathering of the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington.

title: The Big New Idea Is Modesty
description: Behind every good man is a good woman, the saying goes. After the last day or so of the New York fall shows, American designers might want to amend that: Behind every good collection is Phoebe Philo.

title: Leave the Driving to Us? Thief Thinks Otherwise
description: A question that doesnt come up all the time but does come up every now and then is: What do you do once youve stolen a bus?

title: Enquirer Is Eligible for Pulitzer
description: The Pulitzer Prize administrators have decided that The National Enquirer is eligible to compete for the awards, a person briefed on the matter said Thursday.

title: A Sight All Too Familiar in Poor Neighborhoods
description: MILWAUKEE  Shantana Smith, a single mother who had not paid rent for three months, watched on a recent morning as men from Eagle Moving carried her tattered furniture to the sidewalk.

title: 3 Known for Creativity Will Oversee DC Comics
description: Meanwhile, back at the Hall of Justice: DC Comics, the longtime home of Batman and Superman, gained a new executive team on Thursday, one that places some of the comics publishers best-known creative talents in crucial positions.

title: 3 New Yorks, 2 Tennessees and 1 Senator
description: Those of us at the upper reaches of the baby boomer scale remember the country and gospel singer Tennessee Ernie Ford and his signature song, 16 Tons. It is a coal miners lament that Ford recorded in 1955 and rode to the top of the charts.

title: Blackstone and Other Funds Said to Weigh Bid With Simon for Malls
description: The Simon Property Group is in preliminary talks with the Blackstone Group and sovereign wealth funds about making a potential joint bid for General Growth Properties, the bankrupt mall operator, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: In an Ever-Changing New York, Falling in Love May Be the Only Constant
description: Many scenes in Harvey Wangs Last New Yorker were shot in the kind of mom-and-pop stores around Manhattan that have become an endangered species in the age of the franchise. To the films 70-something protagonist, Lenny Sugarman (Dominic Chianese), places like Eisenbergs Coffee-Sandwich Shop, at 174 Fifth Avenue; Moulded Shoe Company, at 10 East 39th Street; and Global International Mens Clothing, at 62 Orchard Street, are lingering vestiges of the less impersonal city of his youth, or so he imagines.

title: Vehicle Tests on Emissions Were Faked
description: Dozens of auto repair shops and service stations in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County faked the results of emissions tests, giving nearly 21,000 cars and light trucks passing grades, state environmental officials said Thursday.

title: Mexico Exonerates Suspect in Killing of U.S. Journalist
description: MEXICO CITY  The man accused of killing a New York City journalist as he videotaped street clashes in Oaxaca in 2006 was released from jail on Thursday after an appeals tribunal declared that there was no evidence against him.

title: Conservatives of All Stripes Gather, Emboldened but Far From Unanimous
description: WASHINGTON  For 30 minutes on Thursday, Mitt Romney, a likely Republican candidate for president in 2012, offered a systematic indictment of what he described as the failed presidency of Barack Obama. A little earlier, a crowd of conservatives whooped in delight as a speaker made coy allusions to Mr. Obamas youthful experimentation with cocaine.

title: 2 China Schools Said to Be Tied to Online Attacks
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A series of online attacks on Google and dozens of other American corporations have been traced to computers at two educational institutions in China, including one with close ties to the Chinese military, say people involved in the investigation.

title: Germany: Teacher Killed by Ex-Student, Police Say
description: A 58-year-old teacher was killed by a former student at a vocational school in Ludwigshafen, near Mannheim, on Thursday, the police said. The student, 23, was armed with a knife and a starter pistol, Chief Prosecutor Lothar Liebig said. The student told the police that he was angry that the teacher had given him poor grades.

title: Ticketmaster Reaches Settlement on Complaints of Deceptive Sales
description: The Federal Trade Commission has reached a settlement with Ticketmaster over complaints that the company used deceptive tactics to steer Bruce Springsteen fans to more expensive tickets through its own reseller last year.

title: China: Wife of Dissident Denies Officials Claims
description: Geng He, the wife of Gao Zhisheng, a prominent Chinese dissident who disappeared in February 2009, said late Wednesday that she had not heard from her husband even though Chinese officials told a human rights group recently that Mr. Gao, left, who is presumably being detained by security forces, had been in touch with his wife. Ms. Geng made her comments in a written statement after the Dui Hua Foundation said last weekend that the Chinese Embassy in Washington had told the group that Mr. Gao was working in the Xinjiang region and that he had been in touch with Ms. Geng, who fled to the United States a year ago.

title: Judge Approves Extension for Tribune Reorganization Plan
description: A federal judge on Thursday gave the Tribune Company more time to file a reorganization plan for exiting Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Malawi: Prosecutors State Case Against Gay Couple
description: Prosecutors concluded their case on Thursday against two men charged with unnatural acts after they conducted an engagement party on Dec. 26 in the city of Blantyre. Homosexuality is a crime in Malawi, punishable by up to 14 years in prison. A police detective, Justine Magreta, testified that the defendants, Tiwonge Chimbalanga and Steven Monjeza, admitted to having had sex with each other. Their lawyer said the couple signed statements only after being beaten. The defense has until March 4 to argue why the charges should be dropped.

title: The Many Shades of Family Dysfunction
description: In Happy Tears, a comedy about the unhappy topic of family dysfunction, the writer and director Mitchell Lichtenstein (Teeth) struggles to find the humor in a host of horrors, including encroaching parental dementia. Unfortunately, to judge from the many awkwardly handled passages, Mr. Lichtenstein does not possess the requisite filmmaking skill or certainly the delicacy, to balance the different, often jarringly contrasting moods, jokes and intimate revelations squeezed into this erratic, belabored movie.

title: Expecting a Surplus, Britain Posts a Deficit
description: LONDON  Britain provided another glimpse of the extent of its deteriorating public finances on Thursday, when a shortfall in tax receipts led to the countrys first budget deficit in January in at least 17 years.

title: Google and Mountain View Recast Company-Town Model
description: It is no secret that Silicon Valley is one long string of company-dominated towns. Hewlett-Packard and Palo Alto. Intel and Santa Clara. Apple and Cupertino.

title: NBC Microphones Pick Up More Than They Hoped For
description: NBC got the best  and worst  of intimate commentary during its coverage of the Olympics on Wednesday night, thanks to some strategically placed microphones.

title: Past Clouds Future of Europes New Antitrust Chief
description: BRUSSELS  When the financial crisis erupted more than a year ago, Joaqun Almunia, as the European Unions economics and monetary affairs commissioner, projected an air of competence and seriousness, helping to calm markets.

title: Olympic Stars Give NBC Victory Over Idol
description: NBCs Olympic skiers took down the American Idol singers Wednesday night, something no other form of programming has been able to do in the last six years of the popular Fox network show.

title: Documenting a Quarrelsome Marriage
description: Whenever the filmmaker Cindy Kleine pondered her parents quarrelsome, 59-year marriage, her most frequent thought was, What are they doing together? Hoping that movie audiences would be equally inquisitive, Ms. Kleine embarked on a 12-year journey through photographs and home movies, love letters and long-kept secrets to produce Phyllis and Harold, an impossibly self-involved portrait of a union far more commonplace than its offspring seem to believe.

title: Bay Area Smokers Beware; a Crackdown Is in the Air
description: It was a typical photo of teenage mischief, posted on MySpace last fall, featuring four cheerleaders from California High School in San Ramon at a party. The event did not happen on campus or during class hours, but when the coach saw the picture, her reaction was swift: two-week suspensions from the squad.

title: Ruling May Dilute Drug Policy in N.F.L.
description: In a ruling that could spell trouble for the N.F.L. and its antidoping policy, a Minnesota judge said Thursday that two players on the Vikings could sue the league in state court for violating parts of Minnesotas drug-testing laws.

title: Judge Halts Deliberations in Police Case
description: A Brooklyn judge halted deliberations Thursday in a police brutality trial after one of the jurors told the others that Officer Richard Kern, the main defendant, had previously been accused of misconduct  allegations that were not introduced during the trial and that the judge described as misinformation.

title: In-Law or in the Way?
description: My boyfriend wants to ask me to marry him, but hes hesitating because he thinks my mother doesnt approve. He seems to expect some grand gesture like: My daughter is so lucky to have you. Im thrilled that youre a part of her life.

title: Daimler Reports Loss and Cancels Dividend
description: FRANKFURT  Daimler, the maker of Mercedes cars and Freightliner trucks, posted an unexpected fourth-quarter loss on Thursday and canceled its dividend for the first time in more than a decade.

title: Checkpoint Scrutiny
description: An article on Sunday from the Investigative Reporting Program at the University of California, Berkeley, on the practice of using police checkpoints for drunken drivers to impound the vehicles of unlicensed drivers  many of them illegal immigrants  and then charge more than $1,000 in fines and fees to release the vehicle, provoked more than 100 comments. Excerpts from two of them follow.

title: Diversity Lower Among Silicon Valleys Top 10 Companies
description: Silicon Valleys Top 10 companies employed lower percentages of women, African-Americans and Hispanics in 2005 than in 1999, a recent analysis by The San Jose Mercury News showed.

title: Federal Judge Rejects Claim That Terrorist Was Beaten
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has denied a request by a Saudi terrorist convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Kenya to suppress statements he made after his capture because of newly raised questions about whether he was beaten during interrogation.

title: Newsom Flirting With Run for Office
description: Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco has given the strongest indication thus far that he will run for lieutenant governor.

title: Nets Will Play in Newark for the Next Two Seasons
description: The Nets will call the Prudential Center in Newark their home for the next two seasons as part of a deal announced Thursday by Gov. Christopher J. Christie. After that, the team plans to move to Brooklyn, where an arena is being built.

title: Tumblr 4 Ya
description: If Twitter's 140-character max limits expression and long-form journalism no longer holds the attention spans of most Internet users, then is Tumblr the happy medium of the World Wide Web? Fans of the platform, not to mention sites like Awkward Family Photos, This Is Why You're Fat, Cake Wrecks and Pets Who Want to Kill Themselves, certainly think so. Tonight, members of the Tumblr community will be at Housing Works for an open bar and live performance to "celebrate writing, reading, and the art of the second draft." Writers Julie Klausner, Choire Sicha, Meaghan O'Connell, Will Leitch, Emily Gould, Matthew Gallaway, Edith Zimmerman, Bailey Kennedy, Halle Kiefer, Melissa Gira Grant, Foster Kamer, and Diana Vilibert will all be there to share their work.

title: Hitting Home
description: "If you were to talk about it in terms of cars, it's like an old, broken-down Buick that you kind of hold together to just get down the road. All of the characters are in a fractured place, broken into pieces, and the pieces don't really fit together. So it feels kind of rickety to me now," Sam Shepard said in a recent interview about his 1985 play "A Lie of the Mind," about families in meltdown, which opened in its first off-Broadway revival on Thursday. The author and actor might have a few kinder words for that old Buick now. In his review of the show, Ben Brantley writes that "a scary, splendid clarity radiates from the terminally confused kinfolk who are running wild at the Acorn Theater." Go tonight to see the eight-member ensemble, directed by Ethan Hawke, give "crystalline, individual forms to a blurred collective sense of self that anyone who has been part of a family is going to identify with" in a production that "connoisseurs of precision acting will be savoring for years to come" and makes the case for "'A Lie of the Mind' as Mr. Shepard's richest and most penetrating play, a 20th-century masterwork of a family portrait to be compared with Eugene O'Neill's 'Long Day's Journey Into Night' and Harold Pinter's 'Homecoming.' "

title: Shaq in the Paint
description: Apparently being an NBA superstar, actor, author, Ph.D. student, platinum-selling rapper, reserve police officer and U.S. Deputy Marshal was not enough for Shaquille O'Neal. Now the 7-foot-1-inch Cleveland Cavalier is venturing into the art world as a gallery curator. His first exhibition, "Size Does Matter," opens today at the Flag Art Foundation in Chelsea. The show, which runs through May 27, explores "the myriad ways that scale affects the perception of contemporary art" and includes works by Chuck Close, Cindy Sherman, Jeff Koons, Kehinde Wiley, Lisa Yuskavage and others. And if that wasn't enough to get your attention, a catalog with an essay by Cleveland native James Frey will accompany the exhibition.

title: Ski Cross Enters the Vancouver Games With Aches and Quirks
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  You think Lindsey Vonn is hurting? A little over a month ago Casey Puckett, an American ski cross racer, dislocated his shoulder in a World Cup race. It was surgically repaired Jan. 13, and two weeks later  possibly a little early, he concedes  he tried skiing again and reinjured himself.

title: Katie Robbins and Philip Swift
description: KATIE ROBBINS never met a political event she didnt want to join or organize.

title: The Urban Winery: A Dream Relocated
description: Michael Brill looked tired last week as he ducked into his cavernous winery in eastern San Francisco to answer what he described as a staggering number of e-mail messages. They were customers passionate responses to Mr. Brills decision, announced only a few days before, to move Crushpad, the participatory winery he founded in 2004, from its home in San Francisco to the vineyards of Napa Valley.

title: Equality at Issue for MBIA
description: All insurance policyholders are equal. But some are more equal than others.

title: Citys Affordable Housing Program Faces Trouble Finding Buyers
description: For all the booms and busts he has lived through, Vincent Riso never thought it would come to this: Offering free 42-inch, flat-screen televisions to lure buyers into government-subsidized homes.

title: Corals Partner Up With Heat-Resistant Algae
description: Corals around the world, already threatened by pollution, destructive fishing practices and other problems, are also widely regarded as among the ecosystems likely to be first  and most  threatened with destruction as earths climate warms.

title: The Great Goldman Sachs Fire Sale of 2008
description: In an interview last week, President Obama said he didnt begrudge Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorganChase, and Lloyd Blankfein, the head man at Goldman Sachs, their 2009 bonuses of $17 million and $9 million, respectively. He said that while $17 million was an extraordinary amount of money, there are some baseball players who are making more than that and dont get to the World Series either, so Im shocked by that as well.

title: Mets Japanese Pitchers Trying to Fit In Together
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Sometime last June, unbeknownst to the coaching staff of the Yakult Swallows, relief pitcher Ryota Igarashi started throwing a major league baseball during his bullpen sessions in Japan.

title: We Interrupt This Event for a Word From Woods
description: MARANA, Ariz.  As the sun was sinking toward the Mexican border in this Old West town north of Tucson on Thursday, the pristine landscape of the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club was figuratively littered with the sun-bleached bones of the four top seeds. Only 16 golfers were left standing in he W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship, and only four are from the United States.

title: Coded to Obey Law, Lights Become Marlboro Gold
description: When it comes to new rules for marketing so-called light cigarettes, tobacco companies plan to honor the letter of the law  but to shade the truth, critics say.

title: Bipartisan Commission Is Established to Cut Debt
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday officially established a bipartisan commission to propose ways by December to rein in the growing national debt, despite reluctance in both parties to tackling the politically charged issue in a midterm election year.

title: Fed Move May Signal End to Easy Bank Profits
description: Federal Reserve to Wall Street: The days of easy money  and, just maybe, easy profits  are numbered.

title: Cats on Camera
description: Few wild animals are more charismatic than tigers and other big cats. And few are more threatened by habitat loss, poaching and other problems.

title: In Pakistan Raid, Taliban Chief Was an Extra Prize
description: WASHINGTON  When Pakistani security officers raided a house outside Karachi in late January, they had no idea that they had just made their most important capture in years.

title: Top Pitching Prospect Hopes to Leave Behind a Season of Growing Pains
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andrew Brackman traveled around Spain last October. He visited seaside towns along the Mediterranean coast. He explored the cathedrals and parks of Barcelona, his new favorite city. Another vacation is in the early planning stages.

title: Bobsled Contender Questionable After Crash
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The Switzerland pilot Beat Hefti, a favorite to medal in the two-man bobsled competition, was held out of training runs Thursday after crashing a day earlier, leaving his status questionable for the event.

title: Bleak Economy Pushing Health Insurers to Raise Rates, Analysts Say
description: Health insurers lately seem more afraid of Wall Street than of Washington.

title: As Campaign Nears, Paterson Is Seen as Increasingly Remote
description: This article was reported by Danny Hakim, Serge F. Kovaleski and Nicholas Confessore and written by Mr. Hakim.

title: States Consider Medicaid Cuts as Use Grows
description: WASHINGTON  Facing relentless fiscal pressure and exploding demand for government health care, virtually every state is making or considering substantial cuts in Medicaid, even as Democrats push to add 15 million people to the rolls.

title: Mets Takahashi Takes No. 47, for Now
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets pitcher Hisanori Takahashi was given Tom Glavines old No. 47 jersey, which is probably not a coincidence because he is a veteran left-hander who doesnt throw very hard.

title: Tax Law Was Cited in Software Engineers Suicide Note
description: In his suicide note, the computer software engineer who flew a small plane into a building with Internal Revenue Service offices in Texas on Thursday cited a 1986 tax law as a major motivation for his action.

title: That Unmistakable Streepness
description: FROM the moment it was announced on Feb. 2, Meryl Streeps 16th Oscar nomination  best performance by an actress in a leading role for Julie & Julia, in case your attention has been otherwise occupied  seemed both richly merited and a bit redundant. Of course she would! How could she not?

title: From Spectacular Crash to Bronze Medal for Paerson
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Anja Paerson awoke Thursday morning unsure if she could walk down the hallway to the bathroom.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 978 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day, Feb. 18
description: A roundup of Olympic highlights, including crashes on snow and ice, and a good day for Maria Reisch of Germany.

title: Another Cable Helping for Food Lovers
description: FOR the upfront season of advance television advertising sales, Scripps Networks has something new to share with clients: a second 24-hour cable channel for food lovers and the advertisers who love them.

title: Wal-Mart Dispels Inflation Fears
description: Fears of deflation in the United States have abated, replaced by worries that rampant inflation could take hold. But the experience of Wal-Mart Stores, the worlds largest retailer, is a reminder that, for now, the battle on the ground is still against corrosive falling prices, not rising ones.

title: Obama to Offer Health Bill to Ease Impasse as Bipartisan Meeting Approaches
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will put forward comprehensive health care legislation intended to bridge differences between Senate and House Democrats ahead of a summit meeting with Republicans next week, senior administration officials and Congressional aides said Thursday.

title: Male Gopher
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Were getting close to the start of another American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. Patrick Merrell and I are both there so say hi if you see us wandering the halls of the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott.

title: Judge Is Skeptical in Monserrates Suit to Return to Senate
description: A federal judge who is weighing whether to block the first expulsion of a member of the New York State Legislature in nearly a century appeared unmoved on Thursday by arguments that the removal was unlawful.

title: Police Misconduct to Go to Board
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Thursday that some police officers accused of misconduct would not be prosecuted by the Police Department but by an independent panel that investigates police-abuse allegations.

title: Golf Writers to Boycott Todays Talk
description: Objecting to the ground rules for Fridays scripted and highly managed live television statement by Tiger Woods, the Golf Writers Association of America announced a boycott of the event Thursday. The ground rules originally allowed close proximity to Woods for three pool reporters who would agree not to ask him questions.

title: Bass Fishing Tour Is a Life Journey for Takahiro Omori
description: COLUMBIANA, Ala.  The rap of knuckles on the car window could come at any time of the night. A hotel security guard would discover Takahiro Omori asleep in the back seat of the worn Chevrolet Suburban and there was no sympathy for an angler in a pinch.

title: Lysacek Wins Gold
description: Todd Eldredge, the three-time Olympian, will provide analysis from his home in Florida, and Times reporters Juliet Macur, Karen Crouse and Jer Longman will send updates and insights from Vancouver.

title: Obama Heads Out West to Stump for Two Senators
description: DENVER  President Obama dipped into two hotly contested Senate races on Thursday, flying out West to raise money and rally the Democratic troops for two struggling lawmakers: Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, who faces a challenge from within his party, and Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, who wields power in Washington as his partys leader but is vulnerable back home.

title: A Diploma in 10th Grade?
description: Updated, Feb. 19, 4:45 p.m. | Michael Goldstein, founder of MATCH Charter Public School in Boston, joins the discussion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about retirees who volunteer to work in parks, campgrounds and wildlife sanctuaries, usually in exchange for camping space, misstated the effect budget cuts in California have had on parks there the past year. Cutbacks have caused partial closures or deep reductions in the hours of operation at nearly 60 state parks, but no park has been shut completely.

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
description: An article on Monday about environmentally focused start-up companies sharing green co-working spaces misstated the rental fee charged by Green Desk, one such venture, whose fee was compared with the cost of Green Spaces, another start-up company. While Green Spaces charges $550 for a single desk with 24-hour access, Green Desk charges $299  not $199  for comparable space and access.

title: Pacts Signed to Help River and Salmon
description: SEATTLE  What supporters are calling the largest river and salmon restoration effort in American history took a critical step forward on Thursday, when formal agreements were signed to remove four dams and revise how water is shared in the Klamath River basin in southern Oregon and Northern California.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the issuing of an arrest warrant in France for the United States cyclist Floyd Landis in connection with a computer data hacking case from 2006 misstated the suspicions of investigators after a security breach at the French antidoping lab that tested Landiss urine samples from the 2006 Tour de France. Investigators found that an e-mail message sent to another lab in an apparent effort to discredit the Chtenay-Malabry antidoping lab  the message included nonpublic documents from Landiss Tour testing, the first indication that the French lab had been hacked  had originated from the same Internet Protocol address used by Arnie Baker, then Landiss coach; they did not conclude that a Trojan horse program used to download files remotely from the lab could have originated from an e-mail message sent from Bakers computer. (In fact, a French computer specialist, Alain Quiros, has confessed to the hacking.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Topps Companys promotion to give away a million baseball cards, using information from the company, misstated the year it first issued baseball cards It was 1951  not 1952, the year of Toppss first complete baseball card set.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Tuesday about a performance of two premieres by the Israeli choreographer Deganit Shemy at Danspace Project referred incorrectly to Tei Blow, the sound designer. Tei Blow is a man.

title: Corrections
description: A classical entry in the listings last Friday omitted the first initial of the composer of estuary (for quintet and electronics), a world premiere that was part of the Perlman Music Program performance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday. He is D. Edward Davis, not Edward Davis.

title: Corrections
description: A theater entry in the listings last Friday gave outdated casting information for the revival of West Side Story at the Palace Theater. The role of Tony is now played by Matthew Hydzik and by Jeremy Jordan  not by Matt Cavenaugh.

title: Knicks Magic Number Is Smaller but More Magical
description: Write down this figure: $21,571,737.

title: DNA Match Leads to Arrest in Rapes From 2000 and 03
description: He broke in through a back door of a Queens home, raping an 11-year-old girl in her bedroom just before she was to wake up for school. Before he left, he threatened to kill her if she told anyone what had happened, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Elon Musk, the founder of the private spaceflight company SpaceX, referred incorrectly to railroad cars that the company refurbished for use at its leased site at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida. They were originally used by NASA to transport helium, not hydrogen.

title: Chill Descends Over Russia as Olympic Medals Prove Elusive
description: MOSCOW  The Olympics are not even half over, but Russia seems to be suffering a collective panic attack over the lackluster performance of its athletes.

title: With Steel and Asphalt, Bridge Helps Seal Baghdads Division
description: BAGHDAD  On a bend in the Tigris where caliphs summered when Baghdad was the City of Peace, the pontoons came first. Steel and asphalt followed. Now, two years on, the Greihat Bridge, a gesture of wartime expediency, has become permanent, traversing the river, joining two Shiite Muslim neighborhoods and, some fear, going too far.

title: Keep Calm and Never Mind, Britain Says in Its X-Files
description: If youve ever been kidnapped by aliens from outer space, dont complain to the British Ministry of Defense.

title: Obama to Seek Ratification of Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Thursday that it would ask the Senate to ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, more than a decade after President Bill Clinton failed to convince the treatys opponents that the American arsenal could deter adversaries without ever setting off nuclear explosions.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Torah Bright Wins Womens Halfpipe
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The night before the Australian snowboarder Torah Bright won the gold medal in the halfpipe, her parents hid in the closet.

title: Gareth Wigan, Who Urged Hollywood Abroad, Dies at 78
description: LOS ANGELES  Gareth Wigan, whose six-decade career in the film industry ranged from helping to shape seminal movies like Star Wars to forging Hollywoods production strategy overseas, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 78.

title: Kathryn Grayson, Operatic Film Star, Dies at 88
description: Kathryn Grayson, the petite singer and actress whose operatic voice and campus-sweetheart beauty embodied the glamour of Hollywood movie musicals in the 1940s and 50s, died Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: Bloggingheads:  Iran Regime Change?
description: Steven Clemons, left, of the New America Foundation and David Frum of FrumForum debate the stability of the Iranian regime.

title: For the Tea Party Movement, Sturdy Roots in the Chicago Area
description: Sitting in a Starbucks last week, a few blocks from his Lakeview home, Eric Odom mused about the irony of the ever-intensifying Tea Party movement.

title: The Lesson of Anthem Blue Cross
description: Clients were understandably furious when Anthem Blue Cross, the largest for-profit health insurer in California, announced huge rate increases for people who buy their own insurance: an average increase of 25 percent, and a 35 percent to 39 percent rise for a quarter of the purchasers. The move also provided a textbook example of why the nation badly needs comprehensive health care reforms.

title: Greece Inches Back
description: After weeks of denial, the European Union has begun grappling with Greeces debt crisis and the dangers it poses for the 15 other nations using the euro.

title: Lingering Questions About Stop-and-Frisk
description: The New York Police Department says its stop-and-frisk program  under which officers investigating crimes, or working to prevent crimes, briefly detain or pat down people on the streets  has played a pivotal role in driving down crime levels to record lows.

title: Chinas Tiger Farms
description: One of the most intractable problems in species protection is the Chinese appetite for traditional medicines. That appetite has only grown as China has grown more prosperous. Despite bans  by Chinas government and international agreements  on the sales of some materials and the near extinction of many of the animals used in traditional medicine, prices for animal parts continue to rise, and so do the incentives for poachers and sellers.

title: A Senator and a Dysfunctional System
description: To the Editor:

title: Mini-Series About J.F.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Is a Human Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Worth of A.P. Courses
description: To the Editor:

title: California Death Spiral
description: Health insurance premiums are surging  and conservatives fear that the spectacle will reinvigorate the push for reform. On the Fox Business Network, a host chided a vice president of WellPoint, which has told California customers to expect huge rate increases: You handed the politicians red meat at a time when health care is being discussed. You gave it to them!

title: The Power Elite
description: One of the great achievements of modern times is that we have made society more fair. Sixty years ago, the upper echelons were dominated by what E. Digby Baltzell called The Protestant Establishment and C. Wright Mills called The Power Elite. If your father went to Harvard, you had a 90 percent chance of getting in yourself, and the path upward from there was grooved in your favor.

title: Stop at Start
description: Washington

title: Not Grass-Fed, but at Least Pain-Free
description: St. Louis

title: Ranking as Sports Hero Takes More Than Talent
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Rabbi Is Charged With Trying to Extort $4 Million From a Hedge Fund
description: An Orthodox rabbi who runs a respected Jewish day school in Brooklyn was charged on Thursday with trying to extort $4 million from a Connecticut hedge fund.

title: Health Care Experts Must Face What Politicians Wont
description: Austan Goolsbee, a wiry and droll economic adviser to President Obama, was addressing a private Chicago dinner last week when he entered the Death Valley of American politics: health care.

title: Out-of-State Transfer for Target of Mayor
description: Just weeks after being the target of a curt expletive from Mayor Richard M. Daley, Rolando Rodriguez, a Wal-Mart executive, has been transferred out of the state.

title: An Ally in 2007, but No Longer
description: The afterglow of victory was brief for the self-styled reformers of Chicagos 32nd Ward.

title: Taking Head Start Into the Home
description: With unemployment high, the staff of an Early Head Start program based in Evanston noticed that some hard-hit families were removing their children from child care and support programs that focus on child care centers. As a result, Early Head Start teachers were losing their ability to help at-risk children.

title: Crosbys Shootout Goal Saves Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  While millions of Canadians held their breath, Sidney Crosby scored the lone goal of an overtime shootout to enable the Canadian hockey team to survive a scare Thursday night with a 3-2 victory over Switzerland.

title: Word of the Day | duress
description: duress\du-res also dyu-\ noun

title: Lysacek Wins the Gold With Style
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On what was perhaps the longest night of his life, Evan Lysacek had to wait.

title: At Halfway Point, Topalov Leads at Linares
Working Without a Standard Playbook, the Fed Plans Its Moves on Rates
description: WASHINGTON  In raising the interest rate it charges banks for short-term loans, the Federal Reserve set the stage on Thursday for the day when the recovering economy will lead it to begin a broader campaign to tighten monetary policy.

title: Google Programs Company Town 2.0 and Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: Googleplex, the City | As Silicon Valley companies grew, they tended to stay within their own clean campuses, with the cities around them little more than an incidental item on their stationery. But it is different with Google and Mountain View, where the search-engine giant is recreating the 19th-century company town with a 21st-century accent. The union has produced the same mix of plans, dreams and frustration, of civic-corporate boosterism and local concern about the giant in their midst that Henry Ford might have found familiar. For Google, Mountain View is part home and part beta-testing ground. For the city, Google is part economic engine, part benefactor and a soon-to-be real-estate developer with an opportunistic eye for underused assets  like the landing strip at Moffett Field, where jets of Google executives now come and go.

title: News Quiz | February 19, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Where Theres Smoke, Theres Ire
description: It is one of the more infamous scenes in locally anchored cinema: The Basic Instinct murder suspect portrayed by Sharon Stone sits in a San Francisco police station, picks up a cigarette and is quickly told she cant light up.

title: Nearly Flawless, Lysacek Skates to Gold
description: Evan Lysacek edged Russia's Yevgeny Plushenko, the defending Olympic champion, to win the men's figure skating gold medal.

title: How Lysacek Defeated Plushenko
description: Evan Lysacek beat Yevgeny Plushenko basically by doing a modern program that took advantage of the new judging system.

title: Carl Kaysen, Nuclear Test Ban Negotiator (and Much More), Dies at 89
description: Carl Kaysen, who wove a tapestry of expertise through economics, foreign policy, sociology, environmentalism and the law, but whose pre-eminent achievement was probably his role as President John F. Kennedys behind-the-scenes negotiator of the groundbreaking nuclear test ban treaty with the Soviet Union in 1963, died Feb. 8 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.

title: General Growth Said to Eye Public Capital-Raising
description: General Growth Properties is looking to raise $1 billion to $2 billion from public markets to fund an independent exit from bankruptcy, a source familiar with the situation told Reuters on Thursday.

title: The Dalai Lama Meets Obama
description: WHO is the Dalai Lama?

title: Asia Leads the Global End to Cheap Money
description: The United States Federal Reserve kick-started its cautious exit from unprecedented emergency lending measures on Thursday  but the process has been going on for months in the Asia-Pacific region, underscoring the two-speed path of the global recovery, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Fed Move May Signal End to Easy Bank Profits
description: Federal Reserve to Wall Street: The days of easy money  and, just maybe, easy profits  are numbered, Graham Bowley and Eric Dash report in The New York Times.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about a proposed casino for Point Molate in Richmond mischaracterized a group involved in the debate. Stand Up for California is a statewide organization that monitors casinos, card rooms and other gambling places. It is not an antigambling.

title: Norris: Equality at Issue for MBIA
description: All insurance policyholders are equal. But some are more equal than others.

title: Fed Rate Move Rattles Stocks
description: The Federal Reserves decision to raise the interest rate it charges on short-term loans to banks reverberated in the financial markets Friday, sending overseas stock indexes lower and giving fresh momentum to a recent rise in the dollar.

title: The Great Goldman Sachs Fire Sale of 2008
description: From William D. Cohan at Opinionator:

title: Rabbi Charged For Extorting a Hedge Fund
description: An Orthodox rabbi who runs a respected Jewish day school in Brooklyn was charged on Thursday with trying to extort $4 million from a Connecticut hedge fund.

title: Lewis Was Briefed Twice on Merrill Disclosure
description: Kenneth D. Lewis, the former Bank of America chief executive, said he was briefed twice on his companys decision not to disclose rising losses at Merrill Lynch before the banks takeover of Merrill was put before shareholders, Reuters reports.

title: Clicker, a Guide to Internet TV, Raises $11 Million
description: Clicker, which says it is the complete guide to Internet Television, has landed $11 million in a fresh round of funding, PaidContent reported.

title: Slovakia Upsets Russia in Shootout
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaIn a second consecutive shootout at Canada Hockey Place on Thursday, Slovakia upset the Russians 2-1 in a game that was fast, physical and, if you didnt mind the absence of goals-scoring, the most thrilling of the tournament so far. It took 14 penalty shots to settle the outcome, with Pavol Demitra, a local favorite who plays for the Vancouver Canucks, finally lifting a shot over the outstretched pad of Ilya Bryzgalov, in goal for the Russians, and sending the Slovak fans home in ecstasy.

title: Wakaresaseya
description: A Japanese term  the splitter upper or separator  used to describe professionals employed to end relationships.

title: Senate Said to Mull Watered Down Volcker Rule
description: Senate Banking Committee members are considering a watered down version of the so-called Volcker Rule unveiled last month by the Obama administration to curb risk-taking by banks, Reuters reported, citing sources familiar with the panels thinking.

title: Philippines Bracing for the Worst in Drought
description: MANILA  A drought in the Philippines has destroyed millions of dollars worth of crops, reduced the countrys water supply and is threatening widespread blackouts as power companies contend with low water levels in hydroelectric dams, officials said Friday.

title: Niger Capital Is Calm After Coup
description: COTONOU, Benin  The military junta that overthrew the president of Niger began asserting its authority on Friday, amid signs of public support within the country and condemnation from abroad.

title: A Look at Fashion Week 2010
description: Eric Wilson looks at the trends that have emerged from the Fall 2010 collections in Bryant Park.

title: Harbingers Man at Times Co. Exits Board
description: An activist shareholder who joined The New York Times Companys board of directors two years ago will relinquish his seat at the end of April, The Associated Press reported.

title: Schlumberger in Talks to Buy Smith, Report Says
description: Schlumberger, the oil services company, is in advanced talks to acquire another major industry player, Smith International, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Chrysler Near Deal to Buy Detroit-Area Plant
description: Chrysler Group is poised to acquire the Sterling Heights, Mich., assembly plant for $20 million from the company that has managed the automakers remaining assets since its emergency from bankruptcy last year, The Associated Press reported.

title: Hedge Fund Said to Oppose Benihana Plan
description: It appears that resistance is growing to a plan by the managers of Japanese steakhouse Benihana to raise money through a share sale.

title: Pulling Back the Curtain on French Freemasonry
description: A once mysterious fraternal society continues to put itself in the public eye with the opening of the completely renovated Museum of Freemasonry, which opened in a newly renovated location in Paris last week. The Grand Orient de France, the oldest and largest Masonic organization in the country, has been collecting items dating from as far back as the 1720s, around the time that Freemasonry was established in France. It now has 10,000 objects in total, including a collection of 18th-century earthenware that was recently purchased with the help of the French government.

title: State of the Packers: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Blippy Asks, What Are You Buying?
description: Facebook and Twitter have prodded people to broadcast just about anything, from what they ate for lunch to what movie theyre going to see. Now a new site wants to unearth more  by asking people to automatically reveal things they buy.

title: GLG Boosts Assets, but Books a Loss
description: Despite booking $723 million in client inflows, GLG Partners still posted a loss in the fourth quarter of 2009, The Financial Times reported.

title: Goldman Buying Metals Warehouser Metro
description: Goldman Sachs plans to buy U.S.-based warehouse and logistics company Metro International Trade Services, a Goldman Sachs spokesman told Reuters on Friday, without revealing how much the deal was worth.

title: The Morality of Web War Footage
description: Todays idea: Do gruesome amateur Iraq war videos on YouTube represent what Susan Sontag called our right to look, or something worse?

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber Eyes Abbey Road
description: Will Andrew Lloyd Webber be the one to watch over Abbey Road Studios?

title: Natixis in Talks to Sell P.E. Assets to Axa
description: Natixis, the French investment bank, is in exclusive talks with Axa to sell its French private equity business, after Axas buyout unit made a 507 million euro ($685 million) bid for the assets.

title: Traders Said to Get Scared on European Bets
description: As officials in Europe begin to scrutinize, and criticize, the positions some financial players are making by shorting the euro and certain nations bonds, some hedge funds are getting nervous and shifting their bets, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Carlyles Japanese Adventures
description: The Carlyle Group is currently holding a mixed bag when it comes to its investments in Japan, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Olbermann vs. Chipmunk
description: Video | Non-fans lampoon the self-dramatizing special effects of Keith Olbermann on MSNBC:

title: Audio of Tesla Plane Crash May Help in Determining Cause
description: Investigators looking into the cause of the airplane crash that killed three Tesla employees on Wednesday have been given an unusual clue, audio recordings made on the ground of the last few seconds of the flight.

title: Cuts Behind Them, Salaries Said to Rise in London
description: Its shaping up to be another sellers market for British financiers, and even bailed-out banks are coming out of a season of cutbacks to beef up their teams again.
