title: Sampler: An Arrest in the Richmond Church Shooting and the Lives of the Tesla Employees Killed in the Plane Crash
description: A Bid to Tax Medical Marijuana | To help close its $14 million budget shortfall this year, the Berkeley city manager has unveiled a plan to tax three medical marijuana dispensaries at a rate of $10 per square foot of the space they occupy. The dispensaries pay the city $20,000 a year in business license fees based on sales. Taxing sick peoples medicine is not the best way to make up their financial shortfall, said Erik Miller, manager of the Patients Care Collective, who opposes the tax. Last year, Oakland voters approved a sales tax on the citys medical marijuana dispensaries and now collects $18 for every $1,000 in sales. [The Oakland Tribune]

title: Once More, Health Care Cost Control
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Obama Announces Aid for Homeowners
description: LAS VEGAS  President Obama will announce a modest housing initiative during an appearance in Las Vegas on Friday, according to senior administration officials who say the White House has decided to release $1.5 billion from bank bailout funds to help struggling homeowners in five states  Nevada, California, Arizona, Michigan, Florida  that are hardest hit by the housing crisis.

title: Virtue and Moir Get First Home Dance
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: EveryScape Takes in $6 Million
description: EveryScape, a start-up that builds 3-D, street-level images of big cities for local businesses, has raised $6 million in a third round of financing, MocoNews reports.

title: Asked & Answered | Matthew Ames
description: Throughout the last few seasons, the 30-year-old designer Matthew Ames has steadily piqued interest in an increasingly tumultuous fashion climate. Gaining esteem for his austere but no less luxurious frocks, the Washington, D.C.-born, Antwerp-trained and New York-based Ames has championed a new minimalism in the face of maximalist hype. T spoke with a curiously calm Ames moments before his fall 2010 presentation at Milk Studios, and later at his garment-district showroom overlooking Bryant Park.

title: The Early Word: Out West
description: President Obama finishes off his swing out West today, holding a town hall meeting and giving a speech to the Chamber of Commerce in Nevada.

title: Missile Kills Militants Brother in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A missile believed to have been fired Thursday from an American drone killed the younger brother of a top militant commander in the North Waziristan tribal area, according to several Pakistani security and intelligence officials, residents in Waziristan and a friend of the commanders family.

title: U.S. Inflation Report Gives Fed Breathing Room
description: Consumer prices were flat in January, the Labor Department said Friday, easing concern that the Federal Reserve will have to raise interest rates to ward off inflation soon.

title: Photos of the Moment | Party On
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Hanuk.

title: Agreement Reached on Klamath River
description: Four hydroelectric dams on the Klamath River in Oregon and Northern California will be removed under an agreement that ends decades of fighting between fishermen, farmers, environmental and Native American groups over water and fishing rights.

title: Those Close to Paterson Cant Reach Remote Governor
description: When a plane crashed outside Buffalo about 10:20 on a Thursday night last year, killing 50 people, aides to Gov. David A. Paterson could not find him for more than three hours, and it was nearly five hours before his office released any statement about what was the deadliest air disaster in the nation since 2001. Mr. Paterson later had difficulty explaining the delay and suggested that when trying to reach him, an aide had been calling the wrong telephone.

title: Daytime Media Ready to Ride the Tiger
description: Memo to the IT department: expect the grid to sag a bit around 11 a.m. today.

title: The Times Announces New Roles for Two Senior Editors
description: The New York Times on Friday named Richard L. Berke, an assistant managing editor, to be the papers next national editor, replacing Suzanne M. Daley, who will return to being a reporter as a correspondent writing about Europe.

title: Bits Scan: Fridays Tech News Roundup
description: Your morning roundup of technology news:

title: A View From the Back Seat: The Early Days of TV on the Road
description: THE quest to combine two of Americas passions, automobiles and television, goes back at least six decades. But making it happen was not cheap: a 12-inch screen in the back seat of a 1951 Cadillac was installed for the princely sum of $1,000  the equivalent of $8,251 today.

title: Parents Say the Darnedest Things
description: There are two lines you find yourself crossing when you become a parent. The first is when you start saying things you swore you would never say, things that make you sound just like your own parents  if all your friends jumped off the Brooklyn Bridge   comes to mind.

title: Television That Streams, Even if Traffic Doesnt
description: LIVE traffic reports  even weather updates  are available on the navigation screens of many new cars. And its easy enough to turn a minivan into a roving Wi-Fi hot spot with Internet access for everyone on board. Unlocking a car from 1,000 miles away? A simple task for a smartphone.

title: A Digital Disaster With a Dated Look
description: WHAT WAS IT? 1978-89 Aston Martin Lagonda

title: Unrequited Longing for the 67th Volvo
description: SAN ANSELMO, Calif.

title: A Widescreen View of the Outside World
description: TORRANCE, Calif.

title: Sound Logic
description: The Hurt Locker is a bomb movie that mutes its booms. It derives suspense by withholding the expected boomala, boomala, as an Iraqi kid puts it in the film while taunting an American bomb-squad soldier about the cool soundtrack of Hollywood war.

title: Speed Read for Friday, Feb. 19
description: Here are some highlights from the Friday edition of The New York Times:

title: Great Performers
description: Despite the economic downturn, 2009 was a record-shattering year at the movies. The megahits were noisy, special-effects-driven films like Transformers 2. When the studios focus is on creating international blockbusters, in which violence is the universal language, great performances are not a priority. Yet most filmmakers understand that people are infinitely more captivating than bellicose robots. Avatar, the biggest moneymaker of all time, utilized technology to enhance storytelling as well as spectacle. For all of the movies 3-D innovations, its director, James Cameron, counted on actors for the films emotional core. Without Sam Worthington and Zo Saldana, he would have created a magnificent void.

title: A Second Food Network
description: Scripps says its Food Network is drawing so many advertisers that its starting a new Cooking Channel to soak them up. Lucky them. When company officials first considered starting the second network, they thought it would have programs that actually taught viewers to cook, but then they came to their senses.

title: The Boston Pops Plans a Kennedy Tribute
description: Where else but Boston could a musical homage to the Kennedys have its debut? Keith Lockhart, the Boston Pops Orchestra and the Tanglewood Festival Chorus, as well as celebrity narrators, will honor the brothers John, Robert and Edward M. Kennedy with a new work called The Dream Lives On: A Portrait of the Kennedy Brothers as part of the Pops coming season, it was announced. The work, written by Peter Boyer (Ellis Island) with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens (Ragtime), will be performed from May 18 through 22, press representatives for the Pops said in a news release. Its full season runs from May 4 through June 20, and opens with a concert featuring Idina Menzel and Doc Severinsen. Other artists this season include Ozomatli, John Williams, Maureen McGovern, Dave Brubeck, Kelli OHara and Arlo Guthrie. More information is at bostonpops.org.

title: Gordon Lightfoot Lives!
description: If you could read Gordon Lightfoots mind right now, what a tale his thoughts would tell. On Thursday, the Canadian news media (not to mention the general population of the Twitterverse) was abuzz with apparent news that Mr. Lightfoot, 71, the smooth-voiced singer-songwriter of Sundown and Carefree Highway, had died while on tour. But like the man sang in The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald, the legend lives on: Reuters reported that Mr. Lightfoot called into Torontos CP24 news station to say he was very much alive. It seems like a bit of a hoax, Mr. Lightfoot said. I was quite surprised to hear it myself. He added: I feel fine.

title: Olive Oil vs. Trans Fats
description: The Greeks, always happy to put in a good word for olive oil, have conducted a few tests that show olive oil is a great substitute for shortenings filled with trans fat in commercial recipes.

title: Placing Consistency Above the Big Trick
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Evan Lysacek of the United States took the gold medal in Olympic mens figure skating Thursday, winning an event that was as much a philosophical debate as an athletic contest.

title: Espresso to Go, Anywhere
description: On the Moment blog, Oliver Strand tests out the $160 hand-held Twist  espresso maker from Mypressi. It works with a blast of nitrous oxide. He likes it a lot. The coffee, not the nitrous oxide.

title: Graphic Book Best Sellers: By Odins Beard!
description: There are two new books on our lists this week and both involve visitors from the realm of fantasy. On our hardcover list, the third volume of the new Thor series lands at No. 8. It features the latest twist in the saga that finds the fabled city of Asgard hanging over Oklahoma. Other less godly legends are present in volume 13 of Fables, which attains No. 1 on our softcover list. Storybook characters including the likes of Snow White and the Big Bad Wolf are under siege by a group called the Literals, one of whom can erase their tales forever.

title: Complaint Box | Workout Miscreants
description: This weeks Complaint Box features two views on workout annoyances, from Linda Carlson and Raul A. Reyes.

title: Reassured About Inflation, Investors Push Shares Higher
description: Stocks were slightly higher Friday as investors saw signs that inflation remained subdued in the United States. That eased anxiety over the Federal Reserves decision to increase an important interest rate.

title: Clueless in Hollywood and Washington
description: When Armando Iannucci, the director and a screenwriter of In the Loop,  heard the news that it had been nominated for an Oscar for best original screenplay, he was in London, about to have lunch with some friends. He never lifted a fork.

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Photographic Memories of Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD Mohammed Kasim cast a hesitant glance down at the rickety benches in Baghdads Shahbandar Cafe. He was a big man, after all, looking more like a linebacker than an artist. But a few awkward contortions later, he shoehorned himself behind an equally tattered table, sticky from countless spills of sweet tea, and ordered his own.

title: Meet Karl Pilkington, the Stealth Star of The Ricky Gervais Show
description: In a review of The Ricky Gervais Show, which has its debut on HBO on Friday night, Alessandra Stanley initially sets her sights not on the animated series title personality or his co-star, Stephen Merchant, but on their lesser-known third wheel, Karl Pilkington. She describes Mr. Pilkington as a performer whose persona is a cross between the deadpan comedian Steven Wright and Cliff Clavin of Cheers  transposed to a Manchester pub, with an accent that to an American ear sounds a little like Ringo Starr under water.

title: Is That Techno Jeep? Well, Turn It Up
description: Lots of cars have inspired classic pop songs, like Little GTO, Brand New Cadillac and Hot Rod Lincoln, but not many cars have performed songs themselves.

title: Plans for Real Growth at City Hall
description: A garden on the White House lawn is one thing, but organic vegetables growing outside New Yorks City Hall? That could be a much tougher sell.

title: Greek Spy Agency Said to Identify More Speculators
description: The National Intelligence Service of Greece, cooperating with officials from several other countries in an investigation over speculation against Greek bonds, has identified additional players shorting the troubled countrys debt, according to TO BHMA, an Athens daily.

title: Apologizing, Woods Sets No Date for Return to Golf
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  In his first public appearance after the November head-on collision of his squeaky clean image and an unsavory secret life, Tiger Woods was somber in expressing remorse, stern in scolding the news media for stalking his family and reporting untruths, and spiritual in saying he had drifted from the Buddhist principles he was taught as a child.

title: Now Screening | Calvin Klein, Womens Collection
description: The fall 2010 womens collection from Calvin Klein.

title: Shake Shack Drops Plans for NoLIta
description: This just in from David Swinghamer,  Shake Shacks chief executive, about the proposed Shake Shack in NoLIta, the first to face serious community opposition:

title: What to Do if You Suspect Learning Disability
12 in Allied Forces Die in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twelve NATO service members, including at least eight Americans, have died in the first week of the offensive in Marja, with more than half the fatalities occurring on Thursday and Friday.

title: Reactions to Climate Group Departures
description: Environmental organizations that belong to the U.S. Climate Action Partnership are downplaying the departure this week of BP, Caterpillar and ConocoPhillips, saying the high-profile alliance will continue to make its presence felt as lawmakers fine-tune the climate change bills in the House and the Senate.

title: Testing a Child for Learning Disabilities
description: In todays Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman explores the financial implications of a childs learning disabilities. She writes:

title: When a Weight-Obsessed Partner Keeps You Fat
description: Previously on the Consults blog, Dr. Kathryn Zerbe, professor of psychiatry at Oregon Health and Science University, took readers questions on a binge eating, anorexia and other eating disorders. Here, Dr. Zerbe responds to a man who wrote that his former wife, who suffered from bulimia, was trying to keep me fat.

title: An Island Cocktail Lounge, Manhattan Island
description: If you like pia coladas, free hot dogs and a live-and-let-live approach to life, Painkiller, a tiki bar due to open on the Lower East Side this spring, may be your cup of rum.

title: In the Future, El Bulli May Serve 60 Meals a Year
description: Ferran Adri talked to Time about his plans to transform his restaurant El Bulli into a culinary foundation for young chefs. He provided a few more details:

title: Mineo Juror Replaced
description: The morning after a wrench was thrown into jury deliberations at the Michael Mineo police brutality trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, a juror who made allegations about the lead defendant was removed from the jury and deliberations resumed.

title: Fewer People Late Paying Mortgage
description: Even as the Obama administration stepped up efforts to aid homeowners facing foreclosure, data released Friday indicated that the housing crisis might finally have stopped getting worse.

title: Crickets Warn Young Before Birth of Dangers of Wolf Spiders
description: If an expectant mother knew that dangerous creatures lurked around her, and knew also that she wouldnt be around to take care of her young, she might be stressed.

title: Jalen Rose on Jeter,  the Basketball Player
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The state of Michigan has produced some pretty fair basketball players. Magic Johnson is a Lansing native. Shane Battier hails from Birmingham. George Gervin, the Iceman, is from Detroit. So are Chris Webber and Jalen Rose, who were teammates on the Wolverines and, before that, on an A.A.U. team that also featured the future N.B.A. players Voshon Lenard and Howard Eisley.

title: Photos of the Moment | LWren Scott
description: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Elle Muliarchyk.

title: School Accused of Using Webcam to Photograph Student at Home
description: In a lawsuit filed in federal court, a school district in suburban Philadelphia has been accused of using a Webcam embedded in a school-issued laptop to covertly photograph a 15-year-old student in his home.

title: My Bags Are Packed for Portugal
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team last week by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog before, during and after her trip to Portugal.

title: Sharing Your Wifes Eating Disorder
description: Over at the Consults blog, Dr. Kathryn Zerbe, professor of psychiatry at Oregon Health and Science University, responds to a man who believes his former wife, who suffered from bulimia, was trying to keep me fat.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Your Business and Health Insurance Costs
description: As health care reform continues to twist in the wind, the problems of the current system continue to become more apparent. It is not hard to find anecdotal evidence of small businesses whose insurance rates have jumped 20 or 30 percent. Heres an article about small-business rate increases from October. Heres an article from todays paper about the recent explosion in insurance rates, especially in California but in other states as well.

title: Inimitable Guitarist
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeff Beck: A Fans Remembrance
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekend Competition: Overheard
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the pearls of wisdom (or swines of ignorance) they have eavesdropped overheard.

title: That Unmistakable Streepness
description: Meryl Streeps Oscar nomination  for portraying a pitch-perfect Julia Child in Julie & Julia  surprised absolutely no one (that was Sandra Bullocks territory). In this Sundays Arts & Leisure, A.O. Scott considers the Streepness of the woman he calls the best screen actress in the world and finds that she is in some ways a late bloomer as a star, and that this makes her all the more appealing.

title: Now Screening | Ralph Lauren
description: The fall 2010 collection from Ralph Lauren.

title: Discovering Alaskan King Salmon
description: I ate Alaskan troll-caught king salmon three times this week and wondered why Id waited so long. There is no better finfish.

title: A Conductor Whose Worship Stands Apart
description: MANY works in the classical music canon were written for the greater glory of God, but performers these days generally reflect little of that religious devotion.

title: Using a Lawyers Words Against a Client
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch

title: Choreography Inspired by Coltrane
description: THE choreographer Lar Lubovitch is nothing if not aware of his own predilections. I do this very old-fashioned thing, he said, as the lines around his eyes crinkled affably over breakfast in Chelsea. I design the music visually. And at my age and after all the years Ive spent doing it, Im not embarrassed to lay claim to it.

title: Investigation of Nearly 500,000 Toyota Corollas and Matrixes
description: Possible steering problems in about 487,000 Toyota Corolla and Matrix models are being investigated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Now, Cellphones for the Defense, Too
description: Come April 1, the federal courthouse in Manhattan will become a much friendlier place for defense lawyers.

title: Touring Italy With a High-Tech Treasure Hunt
description: Do you find walking tours too passive, like sitting through a boring lecture. Wish they were more like The Amazing Race, the popular CBS reality show?

title: Burning Down the Tax Man
description: Some coverage today of Andrew Joseph Stack III, the man who crashed a plane into an I.R.S. office in Texas has focused on his complaints about part of the 1986 tax reform act. That is fair, although it is hard for some of us to feel great sympathy for those who must have taxes withheld like nearly everyone else.

title: NBC Video: Woods Apologizes
description: Tiger Woods admitted to his repeated marital infidelities, acknowledged that he has been in therapy and will immediately return to that treatment.

title: Redesigning the Kosciuszko Bridge
description: A behind-the-wheel simulation of a trip on one of the state's proposed replacement designs for the Kosciuzsko Bridge.

title: California Solar Startup and German Industrial Giant Forge Partnership
description: The German industrial giant Ferrostaal will use solar technology from the California startup eSolar in power plants to be built in Europe, the Middle East and South Africa.

title: Full Transcript of Tiger Woodss Statement
description: A transcript of Tiger Woodss remarks at the TPC Sawgrass Clubhouse in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. on Friday.

title: Stray Questions for: Justin Taylor
description: Justin Taylor is the author of a story collection, Everything Here Is the Best Thing Ever.

title: Judge Denies Monserrates Bid to Stay in Senate
description: A federal judge on Friday denied [pdf] former State Senator Hiram Monserrates petition to block his expulsion and halt the special election called for next month to select his replacement.

title: Rift Grows as U.S. and China Seek Differing Goals
description: BEIJING  When President Obama met with the Dalai Lama in the White House on Thursday, he was following a tradition that all recent American presidents had dutifully honored.

title: Professor Has No Memory of Shootings, Lawyer Says
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.  The neuroscientist charged with killing three colleagues at the University of Alabama in Huntsville last week does not remember what happened, her lawyer said Friday.

title: The Case of the Fraudulent Pinot Noir
description: In the case of the fraudulent pinot noir, a group of French wine brokers were convicted of selling to E. & J. Gallo 3.57 million gallons of red wine from the Languedoc that it falsely called pinot noir but in fact was made from a much less expensive grape, Decanter.com reported. Gallo then sold the wine as pinot noir under its Red Bicyclette brand.

title: Backstage Beauty | A Strong Face Forward at Proenza Schouler
description: Sparked by the grunge spirit of the 90s, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough  both children of Generation X  presented a collection full of cropped, ribbed turtlenecks (very Kate Moss) and psychedelic-print flannels on a girl with messy, natural hair and a strong face. As the makeup artist Diane Kendal explained, Being younger designers, they find it inspiring how the girls looked then. But like the sharp tailoring and feminine thigh-high stockings in the show, their interpretation is a bit more sophisticated and polished.

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber Interested in Abbey Road Studios
description: Two more potential buyers for Abbey Road Studios have emerged: Andrew Lloyd Webber and his longtime lyricist Tim Rice. In apparently unrelated statements to the British news media, the two men have both expressed interest in buying the studio, which has reportedly been put for sale by EMI.

title: Vook, Maker of Multimedia E-Books, Raises $2.5 Million
description: Brad Inman wants to bring books into the 21st century. His year-old start-up, Vook (which weve written about here and here), mashes and mixes videos and photos with text to create multimedia books for devices like the iPhone and, soon, the iPad.

title: Senator Lautenberg Learns He Has Cancer
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, has a cancerous stomach tumor but expects to make a full recovery and continue working during treatments, his office and one of his doctors said on Friday.

title: The Reading Life: A Chinese Writers Poetics, and Politics
description: The Chinese poet Bei Dao, born in Beijing in 1949, has long been mentioned in the West as a potential Nobel laureate, but its been hard to get to know his work well: curiously, theres been no career-spanning volume of his poetry available in English. That situation is rectified now with the publication of The Rose of Time: New & Selected Poems (New Directions, $16.95), edited by the critic and translator Eliot Weinberger.

title: Conspirata
description: Chapter 1

title: The Big Cheese
description: Your once-quiet life as a congressman from Wisconsin was forever altered at the House Republican retreat in Baltimore last month, when President Obama singled you out as a pretty sincere guy and gave a shout-out to your Road Map for Americas Future 2.0, your plan to balance the federal budget.  He brought up my plan and I thought for a moment, Wow, this could be a sincere olive branch.

title: A Family Affair
description: New Jersey native and Olympic ice dancer Allison Reed will be skating for the Republic of Georgia; her siblings will be competing against her for Japan.

title: Oh, So Polite
description: Diplomacy can be fun to watch because diplomats often seem to be trained to say negative things in the most polite and convoluted ways, presumably so as not to offend.

title: Eight White Nights
description: First Night

title: The Room and the Chair
description: Chapter 1: We Are Shadow

title: What Were Reading
Three Siblings Carry Two Different Flags
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Walking around the Olympics in her Georgian team jacket, Allison Reed often gets an acknowledging nod, a pat on the back or words of sympathy, like sorry for your loss.

title: Palestinian Rights Advocates to Protest Performance by the Israel Ballet
description: Advocates for Palestinian rights have called for a boycott of the Israel Ballet, which is performing Sunday at Brooklyn College. The advocates say there will be protests at the colleges Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts to denounce what they call Israels apartheid and colonial policies, part of a broader call by some critics of Israels treatment of Palestinians for a boycott of Israel in cultural and academic circles. The protest was announced on Friday by the group Adalah-NY: The Coalition for Justice in the Middle East. Israels Batsheva Dance Company faced similar protests during an American tour last year.

title: Ellsworth to Run for Indiana Senate Seat
description: 3:13 p.m. | Updated  Representative Brad Ellsworth, an Indiana Democrat, announced on Friday that he will go after the Senate seat being vacated by Democrat Evan Bayh.

title: Calls in Egypt for ElBaradei to Seek Presidency
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of people across Egypts political spectrum greeted the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Mohamed ElBaradei on his arrival at the airport here on Friday and called on him to run for president, a daring political gesture in a country where unauthorized political demonstrations are illegal.

title: Off the Menu: No. 7 Sub
description: Luring the team behind No. 7, the highly regarded restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to open a sub shop in the Ace Hotel in Manhattan took time.

title: The Strong Horse
description: Introduction: The Clash of Arab Civilizations

title: Narcissisms Discontents
description: To the Editor:

title: Thanking the Academy
description: To the Editor:

title: My Leningrad
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Choice
description: THE THREE WEISSMANNS OF WESTPORT,  by Cathleen Schine (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) In Schines novel, two sophisticated Manhattan sisters, one wildly emotional, one smartly sensible, come to the aid of their beloved aging mother.

title: Age 22 and the Achievement Gap
description: At age 22, women and whites are more likely to be on a track leading toward higher educational achievement than men and racial minorities are, according to new data from the Labor Department.

title: Myths Obscure Voodoo, Source of Comfort in Haiti
description: Barely 18 hours after an earthquake devastated Haiti on Jan. 12, the Rev. Pat Robertson supplied a televised discourse on the nations history, theology and destiny. Haiti has suffered, he explained, because its rebellious slaves swore a pact with the devil to overthrow the French two centuries ago. Ever since, he went on, they have been cursed by one thing or another.

title: U.S. Strongly Favors Leniency for a Madoff Aide
description: Prosecutors expect to recommend extraordinary leniency for Frank DiPascali Jr., who has admitted being Bernard L. Madoffs crucial lieutenant in historys largest Ponzi scheme, according to documents made public in federal court in Manhattan on Friday.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Gabbis Gourmet Hot Sauce
description: We have Californias Orange County to thank for many things: the Josh Schwartz creations Ryan Atwood and Seth Cohen; the real housewives Vicki Gunvalson and Lynne Curtin; the semi-real celebrities Lauren Conrad and Kristin Cavallari; and hot sauce.

title: The Wisdom and Wit of an Irregular Library Regular
description: Perhaps the most regular visitor to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts is Greg Sloane, who can be seen nearly every day among the dancers, musicians, actors and culture-mongers who flock to this gem at Lincoln Center.

title: Rebates for Veterans
description: Q.

title: Whats At Stake? Mapping Causes and Effects of Developments in Iran
description: Overview | Why is Secretary of State Clinton urging an uprising in Iran? What is at stake under Irans current leadership  for the Iranian people and the rest of the world? In this lesson, students immerse themselves in the complicated issues that have brought growing alarm to the international community. They trace and research the issues, and then create a concept map that connects each issues causes and effects. Finally, they write an open letter to Secretary Clinton.

title: Parking Perils in a Condo
description: Q.

title: A Threat to Their Sovereignty
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: President Obama in Washington today met with the Dalai Lama, despite strong objections from the Chinese government. China considers the Dalai Lama a threat to their sovereignty and warned that if Obama met with him, it would damage U.S.-Chinese relations. Theyve even threatened to stop sending us poisonous toys.

title: Short-Term Rentals in Stabilized Building
description: Q.

title: Look Out for the Phillies
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: Spring training started. And the Phillies, look out for the Phillies. They get this guy, Roy Halladay, the best pitcher in all of baseball. But listen to this, the Mets, very competitive. You know who they signed? They signed that guy who threw the shoes at President Bush.

title: Children: Rate of Chronic Health Problems Rises
description: Childhood rates of chronic health problems, including obesity, asthma and learning disabilities, have doubled in just 12 years, a new study reports  to 1 in 4 children in 2006, up from 1 in 8 in 1994.

title: U.S. Favors Extraordinary Leniency for Madoff Aide
description: Prosecutors expect to recommend extraordinary leniency for Frank DiPascali Jr., who has admitted being Bernard L. Madoffs crucial lieutenant in historys largest Ponzi scheme, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques reports, citing documents made public in federal court in Manhattan on Friday.

title: Woods Has Long Road Ahead, Study Suggests
description: The denizens of Madison Avenue, like the residents of so many other streets and avenues around the country, are riveted by Tiger Woods, particularly because of all the money related to his endorsement deals and advertising campaigns.

title: Some Security for a Tenant
description: Q.

title: Pets in Airline Cabins Pose Allergy Risk, Doctors Say
description: First peanuts. Now pets.

title: Buddies Cracking Jokes and Heads
description: NEARLY three decades ago 48 Hrs. arrived in theaters with a bang. That 1982 movie, in which a gruff white detective partners with a smooth-talking black convict to hunt down a killer, took in $78 million at the North American box office on a $13 million budget, transformed a young comedian turned actor named Eddie Murphy into a Hollywood megastar and gave wings to a cinematic tradition as emblematic of the 80s multiplex as John Hughess teenage dramedies: the interracial buddy-cop movie.

title: Test Drive the New Kosciuszko!
description: In addition to releasing four proposed designs for a replacement for the crumbling Kosciuszko Bridge, the State Department of Transportations Division of Video Games and Special Effects (we made that up) has produced drivers-eye-view simulations of trips across each version of the bridge (we didnt make that up).

title: Another Big Night for the Olympics (Greys Anatomy, Not So Much)
description: First the would-be singers, now the sexy doctors: nothing is standing up to NBCs coverage of the Winter Olympicsnot the way several competitors did four years ago, anyway

title: Answers About Freelancers and Taxes: Part 3
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: At CPAC, Rallying Against Moderates
description: For all the bold talk at the conservative confab here about taking back Congress in November, one Republican who lost when the majority shifted last time worried that his party might not deserve it.

title: Housings Crystal Ball
description: HOME buyers heading into real estates busy spring season face a tricky question: should they buy soon, before mortgage rates increase, or wait a few months, when housing prices are finally expected to hit rock bottom?

title: 'Constructive Spirit'
description: Images from the Newark Museum's exhibit of early 20th-century abstract art.

title: Illinois Senate Candidate Raises Iran Threat
description: CHICAGO  Representative Mark Steven Kirk of Illinois, a Republican who is running for President Obamas old Senate seat, said the United Nations report on Iran gave a clear and ominous message that the country was trying to develop a nuclear bomb.

title: Secondary Offerings Post a Solid Rebound
description: While overall deal activity has been relatively sluggish this year, a large number of secondary offerings and cross-border mergers and acquisitions have managed to keep some investment bankers busy.

title: Answers About the History of Complaining, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of responses from Matthew Bakkom, the editor and creator of New York City Museum of Complaint, a collection of 132 letters written to the mayor of New York from 1751 to 1969.

title: Pawlentys Principles: Gods in Charge
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference heard from another likely presidential candidate for 2012 on Friday  Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota. Mr. Pawlenty offered a series of what he called principles for the conservative movement that have become familiar here: Reducing the size of government, opposing President Obamas health care plan, denouncing Mr. Obamas handling of terrorists.

title: Tenor More Like a 5
description: Audio | His voice was all it was cracked up to be. Who, when and where unknown:

title: Real Estate Looks Risky, but Less So for Bargain Hunters
description: EVEN a cursory glance at recent events in commercial real estate would make you think the next big collapse is upon us.

title: A Shift in the Export Powerhouses
description: IN the first decade of the 21st century, world exports boomed and then fell sharply. And there was a restructuring of the major manufacturing nations of the world.

title: Short in Time, Long on Wit and Daring
description: In small proportions we just beauties see, wrote Ben Jonson, the Elizabethan poet. And in short measures life may perfect be. Short films may lack the scale and sweep of their feature-length siblings, but the best of them offer a Jonsonesque promise of perfection in miniature, and a reminder that cinema is often an art of patience, precision and detail.

title: The Morning Skate: Loose Defense Troubles U.S., Canada Even in Victories
description: Late Thursday afternoon, after the United States Olympic hockey teams 6-1 victory over Norway (Jeff Z. Kleins Times article), the lingering impression of its efforts from media observers and from within boiled down to this: Despite the flattering five-goal spread, achieved with three third-period goals, this game wasnt the rout the scoreline indicated. And if the Americans were to play the same freewheeling style Sunday, the powerful Canadians would slaughter them.

title: Las Vegas Officials Get an Apology  Sort Of
description: LAS VEGAS  City officials here have been demanding an apology from President Obama for two weeks now, ever since the presidents off-hand remark during an appearance in New Hampshire that You dont blow a bunch of cash in Vegas when youre trying to save in college.

title: Freezing Tuition to Attract Students
description: In an effort to increase enrollment, the Minneapolis College of Art and Design is freezing tuition for one year, Minnesota Public Radio reports.

title: Old-Car Picnic Waits to Hear if It Should Hit the Road
description: In 1988, Jimmy OKeefe, a native San Franciscan, a car aficionado an a gardener at Golden Gate Park, decided to throw himself a birthday party at Golden Gate Parkand invited other car enthusiasts to join him. That first year, Jimmys Old Car Picnic attracted around 40 cars to the parks Speedway Meadow. Over the last 21 years, the event has grown substantially, drawing most recently at the October 2009 picnic 800 cars manufactured before 1972.

title: Book Review Podcast: Ted Conover
description: This week: Ted Conover, author of The Routes of Man; The Timess Richard L. Berke revisits Clinton vs. Starr; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Vook, an E-Book Start-Up, Raises $2.5 Million
description: From Brad Stone at Bits:

title: Book Review Podcast: Ted Conover
description: This week: Ted Conover, author of The Routes of Man; The Timess Richard L. Berke revisits Clinton vs. Starr; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Loose Defense Troubles U.S. and Canada, Even in Victories
description: Late Thursday afternoon, after the United States Olympic hockey teams 6-1 victory over Norway (Jeff Z. Kleins Times article), the lingering impression of its efforts from media observers and from within boiled down to this: Despite the flattering five-goal spread, achieved with three third-period goals, this game wasnt the rout the scoreline indicated. And if the Americans were to play the same freewheeling style Sunday, the powerful Canadians would slaughter them.

title: Travel Deals: Harry Potter Theme Park Package
description: The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, a theme park set to open this spring at Universal Orlando Resort, announced its first vacation packages for travel starting May 28.

title: Iranian Supreme Leader Denies Nuclear Arms Push
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Speaking from the deck of a newly unveiled naval destroyer, Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, derided Western claims about his countrys nuclear program, saying Iran did not believe in nuclear weapons and was not seeking to develop them.

title: Party Central | The Vienna Opera Ball
description: Alles walzer! With these words, declared by the debutantes at the Vienna Opera Ball, the ballroom floor of the Vienna State Opera house became a colorful mess of swirling gowns and shimmering rhinestones as ballgoers raced for their spot to boogie alongside the newest inductees to Viennese high society.

title: Recession Slows the Increase in Rents in the Region
description: The long recession that has driven the unemployment rate above 10 percent has been painful for residents of the metropolitan area in many ways. But it has had at least one side benefit: a break in the upward spiral of rents.

title: Goldman Drops Suit Against Former Employees
description: Goldman Sachs has dropped its lawsuit against seven former executives at its private wealth management division who resigned this month to join Credit Suisse, Bloomberg News reports, citing court records.

title: No Outside Food or Drink Allowed
description: Its a familiar sight in many casual restaurants: the sign warning patrons against bringing in outside food or beverages. Some offer an explanation  the health code requires you to consume only those items bought in the restaurant in which you are sitting. (Ah, the cleansing power of money.)

title: Can Condoms Help Save Polar Bears?
description: An environmental group is distributing hundreds of thousands of free condoms with hopes that it will educate the public about the impact of human overpopulation on endangered species.

title: David Spade: Happily Sold on Selling Out
description: IF you think David Spade is no different from Russell, the smart-alecky lothario he plays on the CBS comedy Rules of Engagement, or the skirt-chasing wisenheimer he played on Just Shoot Me, or the similarly smarmy characters he played in any number of Saturday Night Live sketches of yore, you could not be more mistaken. For one thing, Mr. Spade called in to conduct this interview at the exact time for which it was scheduled and explained that he is a more considerate person than people realize.

title: Japan Plans to Ignore Any Ban on Bluefin Tuna
description: PARIS  Japan will not join in any agreement to ban international trade in Atlantic bluefin tuna under the United Nations treaty on endangered species, the countrys top fisheries negotiator said.

title: F.B.I., Laying Out Evidence, Closes Anthrax Case
description: WASHINGTON  More than eight years after anthrax-laced letters killed five people and terrorized the country, the F.B.I. on Friday closed its investigation, adding eerie new details to its case that the 2001 attacks were carried out by Bruce E. Ivins, an Army biodefense expert who killed himself in 2008.

title: Up From the Underground, Into the Light
description: WITH bright midafternoon sun streaming into a photographers studio in Midtown Manhattan, Holly Miranda was glammed up from head not quite to toe as she posed for a magazine spread recently to promote her new album. In a black, catwalk-ready cut-out dress by Marc Jacobs, her auburn hair curled and zhooshed just so, she was, for the most part, appropriately groomed for a young woman whose music has attracted the likes of Kanye West and Scarlett Johansson.

title: Just Who Is Fighting in Marja?
description: Last Saturday evening, as the first day of fighting in Marja between the Taliban and the Marines of Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines was ceasing with the approach of darkness, two Marine platoons converged for the night on a small Afghan compound. The platoons took cover behind the mud walls. The company manned its guns for the night and began to plan its missions for the next day.

title: Beyond French Fries
description: Theres no question that frying adds calories to food, but healthful eating doesnt have to mean abandoning fried foods altogether, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Must See: Dropping the Masks
Pettitte Can Empathize With Damon
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The longer Johnny Damon remains unsigned, the more Andy Pettitte can empathize with his soon-to-be-former teammate. Pettitte was in a similar situation last off-season as Damon, rejecting a one-year contract from the Yankees because the money ($10 million, a $6 million pay cut) was not acceptable.

title: Feinstein to Propose Federal Supervision of Insurance Rates
description: Moved to action by the proposed Anthem Blue Cross premium increases, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said Friday that she would introduce legislation to create a national Medical Insurance Rate Authority to prevent unfair rate increases by private insurers.

title: A Card Fee Still Hides in the Luggage
description: Starting Monday, your credit card company will have to follow a long list of new rules.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Meryl Streep, Christopher Walken, Riccardo Muti and More
description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Svindal Grabs Super-G Gold From Miller
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Andrew Weibrecht was the third racer down the Olympic mens super-G course Friday, and he posted the fastest early time. Eight racers later, his teammate Bode Miller barreled down the course 0.03 of a second quicker.

title: An Urban Theorist Questions the Gospel of St. Jane
description: Sharon Zukin has a thought or five about what has become of New York City, and her verdict is not great news if you are a lover of cities, and of this one in particular.

title: Teacher Q | How Should the Traditional High School Be Reinvented?
description: This week The Times reported on a new program in which public high schools in eight states will allow 10th graders who pass a battery of tests to get a diploma two years early and immediately enroll in community college.

title: Party Central | Calvin Klein Fashion Week After-Party
description: What: Another New York fashion week well and done.Calvin Klein celebrated its womens and mens fall 2010 runway collections with a post-show bash.

title: Obama to Las Vegas: Love You, Always Have
description: LAS VEGAS Well, he didnt exactly apologize. But President Obama did offer an explanation for his recent controversial remarks about Las Vegas, as well as atidbit of family news:his mother-in-law is a frequent visitor tothe city.

title: Urban Bicycling: Is It Becoming Safer?
description: In the winter months, with more darkness and creepy fog, I obsess about bike lights, reflecting strips and bike flags, which I use for my childrens bicycle trailer. If I could encase my biking operation in neon, I would to do it, even to the point of looking ridiculous. Anything to increase my visibility on the road to drivers. Im on the hunt for battery-operated Christmas lights to wind up the bike flags.

title: A Visual Tool to Track Olympic Tweets
description: As Twitters user base continues to grow, the signal-to-noise ratio can become increasingly difficult to sift through. Twitters new media team has been working to solve this problem  particularly during major current events like the Super Bowl, the Oscars, and the State of the Union address  by creating data visualizations based on the chatter and keywords popping up on the social networking service.

title: Return Engagement| Gone AWOL
description: With two wars on and a recent surge, military flourishes were all but axiomatic on the spring runways, leaving unenlisted designers looking less like conscientious objectors than ostriches in a state of denial. Balmains Christophe Decarnin led the charge with camouflage patchwork smothered in gold sequins; Haider Ackermann had cargo pants and epaulet-tipped jackets in washed leather.

title: Their Corner of the World
description: ITS hardly unusual for Americans to display items from other traditions, as a decorating choice or to remind themselves of their travels. But for some people, cultural ties run so deep that their living spaces have become far more than an aesthetic expression: They have recreated their homeland at home.

title: Top Terror Prosecutor Is a Critic of Civilian Trials
description: He was the lead prosecutor 15 years ago in one of the countrys biggest terrorism trials: a group of men led by a blind Egyptian sheik had plotted to blow up the United Nations, the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and other city landmarks.

title: Once More Around the Sandbox
description: JASON KATIMS, the creator of NBCs new series Parenthood, had been at his son Sawyers first practice for just five minutes when he realized T-ball had been a mistake. A ground ball went through his legs, and he ended up in the dugout in my arms, weeping, Mr. Katims said. Worst idea ever.

title: Film in Brief
description: Images and trailer links for the films appearing in the compilation of Academy Award-Nominated Shorts.

title: Correction: Between a Castle and a Cottage
description: The In the Region article in Westchester and Connecticut copies on Jan. 31, about Westport developers driven by the market to downsize luxury homes they build on speculation, misstated the time it took to sell a 13,000-square-foot colonial on Clapboard Hill Road in Westport. It sold six months  not 18 months  after completion.

title: Old Cars Add Character to Science-Fiction Series
description: Recently, I checked out the new science-fiction series Caprica, the spin-off to the hugely popular Battlestar Galactica on the now-dubbed SyFy channel. And I noticed the interesting selection of prop cars: a Jaguar Mk2 and a Citron DS.

title: A New School Hopes to Learn From the Charters
description: One of the main arguments for charter schools is that they will improve the school system as a whole by introducing innovations that traditional schools then adopt. But charter school critics charge that this is not happening  and they say that charters on the whole are weakening the schools around them by siphoning off their resources.

title: How Teams Fared at the Trade Deadline
description: This month I reviewed the teams that were slightly over the luxury tax threshold, or slightly under having the ability to make a maximum free agent offer. Now that the trade deadline has passed, lets take another look to see how these teams fared.

title: Is the Tiger Woods Brand Beyond Repair?
description: Tiger Woodss golf game may recover, an advertising executive believes, but it may take his brand a long time to do so  if it ever does.

title: The Magnificent Seven
description: Coming soon to a saloon (or brasserie) near you:

title: UBS Defers Part of Bonuses for High-Paid Employees
description: After an unprofitable year and to reduce its immediate compensation costs, the Swiss bank UBS is awarding deferred stock bonuses for senior employees whose total pay for 2009 exceeded $250,000, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Theyre Big and Ready to Eat Florida
description: Flying into Florida for a winter vacation? If you look out the plane window once youre near your destination and the ground seems to be writhing, its because the entire state is covered with pythons. Checking out the bathtub in your hotel room? Python. Looking in the back seat of your roller-coaster car at Walt Disney World? Python. Rental-car trunk? Restaurant toilet? Rest-stop trash can? Curbside mailbox? Python, python, python, python.

title: Do You Pay Foreign Transaction Fees on Your Cards?
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the foreign transaction (also known as currency conversion) fees that banks levy on credit and debit cards.

title: Stuart Thompson to Receive Award for Theatrical Production
description: The Broadway producer Stuart Thompson (God of Carnage, Proof) will be the 2010 recipient of the Commercial Theater Institutes annual award for outstanding achievement in commercial theater producing, according to the Broadway League and the Theater Development Fund, which oversee the institute.

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Feb. 19
description: A common theme among the photojournalists covering the aftermath of the earthquake in Haiti has been a frustration that their pictures cannot capture the immensity of the devastation  its scope, its feel, its smells, its sounds. Perhaps no single photograph could ever be expected to do that. But in his picture of the dump near Cit Soleil, Todd Heisler has conveyed something viscerally. After some moments of reflection, you may find yourself thinking youre looking at a medieval scene. And in a sense you are. There is an uncanny kinship to Bruegel. Specifically, The Triumph of Death.

title: Kathryn Bigelows London Love
description: Critical love is never-ending for Kathryn Bigelow, who won the best director award for The Hurt Locker from the London Critics Circle on Thursday, again besting two of her Oscar opponents, James Cameron and Jason Reitman. Neither of their films, Avatar and Up in the Air garnered any awards, though other Academy front-runners, including MoNique and Christoph Waltz, continued to rack up the statuettes  MoNique for her performance in Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire and Mr. Waltz for his in Inglourious Basterds. (By this point in the season, the Bagger wishes she had invented some kind of keyboard shortcuts for these statements  maybe a sassy apostrophe for MoNique and a stern but sexy  for Mr. Waltz. Ms. Bigelow would get a new symbol which would immediately become shorthand for killer-lady-director.)

title: Afghan Push Went Beyond Traditional Military Goals
description: WASHINGTON  Before 10,000 troops marched through central Helmand Province to wrest control of a small Afghan town from a few hundred entrenched Taliban fighters, American officials did something more typical of political than military campaigns: they took some polls.

title: A Contrarians Lament in a Blitz of Gentrification
description: SHARON ZUKIN had come to Greenwich Village and the Shrine of St. Jane not as a pilgrim but to wax sardonic.

title: An Apartment Away From the Truck
description: Kim Ima, a transplant from California who has given the city one of its most beloved purveyors of street food, the Treats Truck, lives in a West Village apartment.

title: The Moviegoer | Talking With Ewan McGregor
description: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

title: Lawyer Calls Woodss Remarks Counterproductive
description: One of the harshest critics of Tiger Woodss remarks on Friday morning is L. Lin Wood, a lawyer with Bryan Cave Powell Goldstein.

title: Her Second Home, the One Without Wheels
description: BACK in the 1970s, a staple of starter apartments in New York was a poster advertising rye bread, an image that featured a member of a distinctly non-Jewish ethnic group with the tagline, You dont have to be Jewish to love Levys. ...

title: Gavin Newsom, the Twitter Prince
description: If only the Twitterverse had polling places. Forget this lieutenant governor business  @gavinnewsom could run for president.

title: Lysacek Enjoys Golden Whirlwind
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After a stressful yet joyous 24 hours at the Olympics, Evan Lysacek said his head was still spinning on Friday, when he began enjoying the fruits of being an Olympic champion.

title: Roots Rock and the Funk of the Firmament
description: Galactic

title: The Godfathers Ghost Speaks French
description: FRENCH cinema has produced some notable gangster characters and crime films over the years. During their long careers Jean-Paul Belmondo, Alain Delon and Jean Gabin portrayed underworld figures with swagger, world-weariness or elegance, and even after 50 years Jacques Beckers Night Watch still stands as one of the most memorable psychological dramas ever set in a prison.

title: Agrium Puts More Pressure on CF to Accept Bid
description: The Canadian fertilizer maker Agrium said Friday that it was extending  once again  its unsolicited offer for CF Industries Holdings, arguing that the announced merger of its rivals, Terra Industries and Yara International of Norway, makes striking a deal more compelling.

title: Swap Till You Drop
description: If the new barter economy means that you can trade a Dries Van Noten winter coat for last summers Marni sandals, things cant be that bad. ReFashioner, a new invitation-only Web site, lets you swap your unwanted designer and vintage clothes for other couture castoffs. Kate Sekules, a New York writer, editor and Comme des Garons addict, said the site was created for women who love good designers and good design  and who like turnover. No money is exchanged, though a $5 fee is charged per trade. And while you wait to receive an invite from Anna Wintour, you can window-shop at refashioner.com.

title: A Unique Film Selection
description: Images from some of the films in the Film Comments Selects series.

title: Hughes the Man, Joba Too
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Maybe we should settle the fifth starters competition another way, Phil Hughes was saying. Like whoever can do the most sit-ups. Or trivia  The Office for Hughes, Nebraska football for the devoted Huskers fan Joba Chamberlain. There should be a meter for every pitcher, Hughes added, that would rise and fall based on his daily performance.

title: An Auction for the Upscale Beach Bum
description: A HOUSE facing the ocean is the holy grail of Hamptons real estate. And Peter Brown, a public relations executive (and former Beatles manager), has been renting one for 27 years.

title: Israeli Embassy Deletes Joke About Dubai Hit From Twitter
description: On Thursday, the same day that Israels ambassador to Britain was asked to tell the British government if he knew anything about the apparent use of cloned British passports by suspects in the assassination of a Hamas official in Dubai last month, his embassys official Twitter feed posted a joking reference to the killing.

title: Conan OBriens Next Appearances Could Be on Stage
description: When and where will the world next see Conan OBrien?

title: Police Fighting Crime in a Parking Lot. Theirs
description: YONKERS  The Bronx had Fort Apache, the police precinct that Paul Newman immortalized in the classic film that pitted lonely cops against ruthless gangs.

title: For the Moment | East vs. West
description: Juliet Kinsman is the editor-in-chief of Mr & Mrs Smith, a London-based company that books high-end hotels and travel experiences for a global membership of travel connoisseurs. In addition to publishing a series of guidebooks and tending to the needs of members, Kinsman regularly writes about travel and interior design for newspapers and magazines on both sides of the Atlantic. She lives in London  but her Canadian passport can attest to extended stays in Athens, North Africa, India and on New Yorks Lower East Side. This week, from a laptop somewhere in the world, Kinsman shares her insiders view on whats driving gallivanters now.

title: Showcase: Too Busy for Leisure
description: It wouldnt be difficult to make fun of old people cheerleading in sequined leotards.

title: Homicidally Unhinged, but for a Cause
description: IT may come as a shock, but the fanboys reveling in the eviscerations, explosions and Car Wash of Death scene contained in the director Breck Eisners new take on The Crazies will also be contributing to socially progressive cinema. Perhaps even to the public good. With any luck, they wont notice.

title: Have You Seen the Closets?
description: FOR most of her time at New York University School of Law, Mari K. Bonthuis lived in a postwar high-rise co-op on 14th Street near First Avenue. Her parents bought the alcove studio for her in 2003 for $250,000. About two years ago, when I was no longer a broke law student, Ms. Bonthuis said, she bought them out for the same price.

title: The Toe-Tapping Starts at the Podium
description: The balletic movements and springy step of David Robertson as he led the New York Philharmonic in works by Ravel, Debussy, Ginastera and George Benjamin on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall seemed appropriate for the dance theme that permeated the program.

title: From Out of the Mouths of Babes  Come New Commercials
description: Remember the expression Kids say the darnedest things? (One clue of how far back it goes is the use of darnedest.) The second phase of a campaign for Ally Bank will continue to feature kids  er, children, in the formal locution of the newspaper that operates this blog  and the things they say in the face of what are meant to be idiotic adult activities.

title: Players See Sincerity, but Many Just Prepare to Play
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Members of the news media far outnumbered players at the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club here when Tiger Woods issued his televised public apology Friday.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Northern Minnesota is usually populated by canoeists. But as writer Greg Breining discovers, it becomes a lonelier place in the winter, a wilderness to explore on snowshoes, where the only company is often four-legged.

title: Living in Matawan, N.J.
description: Matawan, N.J., appeals to a wide variety of residents for its excellent transportation network and its wealth of natural resources.

title: Roy Halladay: Good Ol Country Hardball Player
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Phillies fans, Charlie Manuel knows how youre feeling. He loved Cliff Lee, too. But hes also excited about putting Roy Halladay atop his rotation.

title: In the Depression, a Couple Undone
Exploring the Topography of John Zorns Continent
description: If the output of any prolific composer can be likened to a world, then John Zorns Masada is a sprawling continent, with its own richly varied climate and topography, its own regional twists on a governing tongue. Since the early-1990s, which saw the formation of the first Masada band  with Mr. Zorn on alto saxophone, Dave Douglas on trumpet, Greg Cohen on bass and Joey Baron on drums  the concept has broadened and stabilized, becoming ever sturdier and less surprising.

title: Nice Way to Fold the Tents
description: Tommy Hilfiger had the last word at Fashion Week, closing the collections on Thursday night with a high-booted display of sportswear before a throng of garment industry executives and front row star-of-the-moment Zo Saldana, as 18 years of fashion under the tents in Bryant Park came to an end.

title: Short on Time, Long on Wit and Daring
description: Remember how we were going to help you arm yourself against those usual Oscar pool-defeaters, the short film categories? Now we dont have to, because theyre playing at a theater near you (if youre in New York, anyway). This weekend the IFC Center presents the Academy-nominated animated and live-action shorts. Among the latter, many feature children in peril, the quickest route to an audiences emotions, as A.O. Scott writes.

title: 2 Lakes, the Shore and a Train to the City
description: NOT long after moving to Matawan, Elizabeth Renners children, Nicholas and Maria, found their local park in bad shape and decided to do something about it. With playmates, they circulated a petition, ran a lemonade stand and raised $169, which they handed over at a Borough Council meeting, urging the officials in attendance to fix the park.

title: Scorecard | The Row Wins!
description: Heres another tip for playing the Scorecard rankings game: if youre not part of the less-is-more camp, avoid showing post-Marc (not when the formerly skort-wearing designer puts on a suit for his totally discourse-altering collection, anyway). Or at any rate, be advised that the critical community may just have a little less patience for (hauntingly lovely) floral chiffon-plaid-crochet collaged deconstructionist explorations of liminal states.

title: U.N. Report to Quantify the Environmental Impact of Major Companies
description: A United Nations report to be released this spring finds that the worlds top 3,000 companies cause $2.2 trillion in environmental damage per year, according to the consulting company commissioned to write the report.

title: Robert I. Toll
description: Mr. Toll, 69, is the chairman and chief executive of Toll Brothers Inc., one of the countrys largest builders of luxury homes. Toll Brothers was founded by Mr. Toll and his brother, Bruce, in 1967 and became a public company two decades later. The company develops residential communities in 21 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Conan OBriens Next Appearances Could Be Onstage
description: With his separation deal from NBC preventing Conan OBrien from appearing anywhere on television until after Sept. 1, the comedians representatives have for several weeks been formulating a plan to get him back in front of the public in a show that would have some elements of his television work combined with new stage elements. More on Media Decoder

title: From a Dreamy World to a Citys Tough Streets
description: New York City Ballets current season has been dedicated to its full-length story ballets. But Jerome Robbins, the companys truest storyteller, didnt augment the repertory with a Swan Lake or Sleeping Beauty.

title: Dry Your Eyes and Lower the Price
description: NEVER in all his 17 years selling real estate has Mark Seiden gone through as many boxes of tissues as he has in the past 12 months.

title: Biology Rappers Return
description: The science rappers from Stanford are back. If you liked their take on regulatin genes, check out their new number on how the body converts food into energy. The song is performed by Derrick Davis, a student at Stanford, and Tom McFadden, an instructor in the human biology program there. Mr. McFadden (hes the one wearing sunglasses and a plaid shirt in the video above) explained the project to me:

title: Requiem for a Jumble of Artworks
description: DON ARGOTT was never one of those Philadelphians besotted with the Barnes Foundation, the museum of late-19th- and early-20th-century art tucked away in the suburbs.

title: Model-morphosis | Derek Lam
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Anja Rubik from Next Model Management, before (above, top) and after makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Orlando Pita. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Judge Weighs Delay in Galleon Civil Trial
description: A federal judge reserved ruling on Friday on requests to suspend the civil trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group hedge funds founder, and other defendants on insider-trading charges in order to give a criminal trial precedence, Reuters reports.

title: On the Street | In Stride
description: The standout look during New York Fashion Week was the long leg covered or (a bigger surprise) a revival of the nude leg amid leggings, high boots and impossibly high shoes.

title: Remembering the 1970 N.B.A. Finals
description: The lasting image of the 1970 N.B.A. finals is a hunched over Willis Reed limping onto the floor at Madison Square Garden during the warmups before Game 7. Reed, who tore a thigh muscle in Game 5, had sat out Game 6 and his status for the deciding game was up in the air until the minute that he came out of the tunnel. Even the Lakers stopped warming up to watch Reed, whose appearance in uniform drove the Garden faithful crazy.

title: CSI: Egypt, Complete With DNA Tests of Mummies
description: King Tutankhamens reign lasted about nine years, and you may feel as if youre living all of it in real time if you watch the plodding first half of King Tut Unwrapped, Sunday on Discovery. Things pick up in Part 2 on Monday, though, with revelations about malaria in the royal family and other juicy tidbits.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 19
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Four for the Price of One
description: WHEN it comes to selling or buying a house, multiple minds can be better than one. At least thats what some agents would like sellers and buyers to think.

title: Hot Breath of Saharan Rock Blows in From Africa
description: Tinariwen is a more worldly band now than it was in 2001, when a performance at the Festival of the Desert in Mali introduced its resolute, hypnotic Saharan rock to an audience that carried its reputation beyond Africa. Since then Tinariwen has been on the world-music circuit, performing for audiences who dont speak its main language, Tamashek. Wearing white robes and head scarves, the band members have made themselves emissaries. One of the bands leaders, Abdallah Ag Alhousseyni, has a catchphrase onstage: Welcome to the desert.

title: Bridge Revival Will Close on Schedule
description: The producers of the hit Broadway revival A View From the Bridge told cast members on Wednesday night that the play, by Arthur Miller, would close as scheduled on April 4 after a proposed move from the Cort Theater to the Neil Simon Theater fell through because of matters of costs and actor availability, according to two executives involved in the production. Starring Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson, above, A View From the Bridge received rave reviews and is on track to recoup its initial investment thanks to strong audience demand, said the executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized by the producers to share details about the closing. The producers had been exploring wrapping up at the Cort, where the revival of August Wilsons Fences is set to start preview performances on April 14, and then re-opening at the Neil Simon, which has been vacant since the revival of the musical, Ragtime, closed in January.

title: Disinflation
description: So the core CPI  consumer prices excluding food and energy  fell for the first time since 1982. But that could be just a blip. Also, core CPI has been behaving erratically lately, making me doubt whether its still a good guide to underlying inflation (by which I mean the trend in prices that, unlike commodity prices, have a lot of inertia).

title: Boycott Is Sought Against Israel Ballet
description: Advocates for Palestinian rights have called for a boycott of the Israel Ballet, which is performing Sunday at Brooklyn College. The advocates said that there would be protests at the colleges Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts to denounce what they call Israels apartheid and colonial policies, part of a broader call by some critics of Israels treatment of Palestinians for a boycott of Israel in cultural and academic circles. The protest was announced on Friday by the group Adalah-NY: The Coalition for Justice in the Middle East. Israels Batsheva Dance Company faced similar protests during an American tour last year.

title: Olympics Skate to Easy Win
description: The Winter Olympics continued to dominate the ratings on Thursday as an average of 25.3 million viewers tuned in to NBCs prime-time coverage, according to Nielsens estimates. The networks coverage, which included the mens figure skating free-skate finals and Evan Lysaceks victory for the United States, led during every time slot of the night. CBS ranked a distant second with repeats of The Mentalist (8.8 million) and CSI (7.9 million) following a new installment of Survivor (11.9 million) at 8 p.m. ABC placed third for the night, getting a lift from Greys Anatomy at 9 (10.2 million) but earning smaller audiences at 8 for The Deep End (4.3 million) and at 10 for Private Practice (7.6 million). Fox finished fourth with a repeat of Bones at 8 (5.7 million) followed by Past Life at 9 (3.5 million).

title: Gordon Lightfoot Lives!
description: If you could read Gordon Lightfoots mind right now, what a tale his thoughts would tell. On Thursday, the Canadian news media (not to mention the general population of the Twitterverse) was abuzz with apparent news that Mr. Lightfoot, right, 71, the smooth-voiced singer-songwriter of Sundown and Carefree Highway, had died while on tour. But like the man sang in The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald, the legend lives on: Reuters reported that Mr. Lightfoot called into Torontos CP24 news station to say he was very much alive. It seems like a bit of a hoax, Mr. Lightfoot said. I was quite surprised to hear it myself. He added: I feel fine. The mistaken report of Mr. Lightfoots death, which appears to have originated on Twitter, was carried by the Canwest News Service as well as the Web sites of the Vancouver Sun, Ottawa Citizen, and Calgary Herald newspapers, all of which have since corrected their stories.

title: More Interest in Abbey Road Studios
description: Two more potential buyers for Abbey Road Studios, above, have emerged: Andrew Lloyd Webber and his longtime lyricist Tim Rice. In apparently unrelated statements to the British news media, the two men have each expressed interest in buying the studio, which has reportedly been put up for sale by EMI. According to The Daily Telegraph, the BBC and others, a spokesman for Mr. Lloyd Webber said he is very interested in buying Abbey Road Studios, and added: He first recorded there in 1967 with Tim Rice. Andrew has since recorded most of his musicals there, from Jesus Christ Superstar to his new musical, Love Never Dies. EMI has not confirmed reports that Abbey Road is for sale, but since word first surfaced on Monday night Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, has spoken about the need to save the studio, and National Trust, a British preservation charity, has said that it would consider buying the property, which is said to be worth as much as $45 million. In an interview, Mr. Rice told The Telegraph that he would consider joining a group to save Abbey Road but that he had not discussed it with Mr. Lloyd Webber.

title: Spirit of 76 Lives On, and On
description: IN the practical sense, of course, it matters little what architectural label is slapped on a house in a real estate listing. A Cape Cod called a Cotswold cottage or a center-hall colonial has its list of attributes and drawbacks, regardless. Nor does its property tax bill go up or down based on its description.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 19
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include a Chinese New Year celebration, a tree-climbing class in Bronx Park, and a neighborhoods loss to a fire in Queens.

title: Spring and Summer Theater Listings
description: A select list of forthcoming shows. Dates are subject to change.

title: Abroad in the U.S.
description: For some people, cultural ties run so deep that their living spaces have become far more than an aesthetic expression: They have recreated their homeland at home.

title: Scotty, the Warp Drive Needs Some Dilithium Crystals
description: My friend Jason loves Star Trek Online. Jason, a 36-year-old technology manager who lives in my Brooklyn neighborhood, has been a Trekkie for decades. Not as fanatical as some, Jason still certainly knows his Klingons from his Cardassians.

title: Dancers Compelled by Words of a Poet
description: Its not a great sign when a company comes to town, performs for two hours and leaves you more confused than confident about its point of view. The Kosoko Performance Group, a Philadelphia interdisciplinary ensemble under the artistic direction of Jaamil Olawale Kosoko, appeared at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday evening and delivered a long-winded program that touched on dance-theater, political dance and even a bit of pure dance, but didnt make a show of any of it.

title: Heroes of DC Comics Get Ready for Closeup
description: You dont have to possess the cold, calculating heart of Lex Luthor to appreciate the valuable place that comic-book companies occupy in the master plans of media companies.

title: Yes, Two Guitar Idols Are Better Than One
description: At 10:30 on Thursday night, the Eric Clapton-Jeff Beck concert at Madison Square Garden woke up. After playing individual sets, the guitarists faced each other on stage for a final stretch.

title: Inside the Rings
description: The United States may not have much success in some of the most traditional of winter sports, but American fans don't have to look too far down the medal list to soothe their sporting psyches.

title: Fried Chickpeas With Chorizo
description: Mark Bittman prepares a traditional Spanish dish that he made up.

title: A Dinner Date With India and Spain
description: CHICKPEAS are often cooked with spinach, from India to the New World. But in southern Spain, they are mostly made with chorizo. Combine these ideas, and you have a rich, deep, full-flavored stew perfect for a fast dinner on a cold night.

title: Deft Deductions at New England Knockout
description: The most successful players at the New England Knockout Team Regional in Cromwell, Conn., which ended last Monday, were Debbie and Michael Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Andrew Rosenthal and Aaron Silverstein of New York. They won three events and lost in the final of a fourth. They each amassed 111.86 master points, 24.55 ahead of Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn., who is this years president of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Babble on? Babylon? Next Question, Please
description: Alex Escalantes subjects in The 25th Frame include the barrage of words and visions to which we are submitted by news (and the consequent breakdown of serious meaning), the intensely commercial nature of our society (in which you pay for both tranquillity and art) and the connections among politics, money, war, employment and propaganda. The title refers to the subliminal effect of fleeting film images. I attended Thursdays performance at the Kitchen.

title: Now Screening | Tommy Hilfiger
description: The fall 2010 collection from Tommy Hilfiger.

title: Lehman Paid Bankruptcy Advisers $642 Million
description: Lehman Brothers, which is being liquidated in bankruptcy, has paid its lawyers and other advisers $641.9 million in the 16 months since it collapsed in September 2008, according to a regulatory filing late Friday, Bloomberg News reports.

title: The Return of the Ski Bum
description: Aspen, Colo.

title: For Texas Pilot, Rage Simmered With Few Hints
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  He arrived, as so many do, from California, graying and open-faced, working in the computing industry, quietly nursing strong feelings about the government and moonlighting with a rock band.

title: Netflix Does Dash
description: Dash, the desktop Internet viewer introduced in January by Sony at the Consumer Electronics Show, has added a dedicated application that allows paid subscribers of the Netflix movie service to access an online library of about 12,000 movies and television episodes.

title: She Always Cooks With Onions
