description: You know youre getting old when you look up and Judy Collins is 70. The singer-songwriter, who released her first album in 1961 at age 22, still performs, almost constantly. She will appear at Town Hall on March 5 and is booked for six weeks at the Carlyle Hotel beginning May 4; her new CD,  Paradise,  is scheduled for release in May. She is also working on a memoir. Ms. Collins and her husband, Louis Nelson, 74, an industrial designer, live in an Upper West Side apartment with three Steinway pianos and three Persian cats.

title: Bloomberg Shifts $5 Billion Out of Friends Firm
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has decided to remove his fortune from a private equity firm founded by his longtime friend, 10 months after that firm became embroiled in a scandal involving the state pension fund.

title: Art Forms Pioneer; Achievers Incubator
description: Max Neuhaus died a year ago, but his voice still reverberates in Times Square. It is, as he once described it, a sonorous, harmonic tone resembling the after-ring of large bells. It arises from beneath a subway grating where he installed a sound sculpture in 1977, when Times Square was a very different place.

title: This App Is Made for Watching
description: While live, mobile broadcast TV is still a few months from coming to market, you can use your iPhone to watch live TV today. However, the content might at times be something youd rather not see.

title: For the Visually Impaired, Money Talks
description: While theres little doubt that United States paper currency has gotten prettier, that doesnt matter much for the blind and vision-impaired. If you cant see the bill, you still cant tell whether youre holding a one or a one hundred.

title: Apple to Replace Bad Hard Drives
description: Apple, meet Toyota.

title: Sezmi Says Open!
description: Do you dislike your cable or satellite provider? Then Sezmi wants to talk to you.

title: Re-Energized Conservatives
description: Representative Pence was among Republican leaders riding the enthusiasm wave as they face increasing prospects of sizable gains in the midterm elections.

title: Bipartisan Chances and Future Plans
description: Congressman Pence acknowledged that Republicans and Democrats do need to find common ground to break gridlock. The Indiana lawmaker also talked -- just a little -- about his own plans for the future.

title: Sony Introduces First Receiver Ready for 3-D
description: Plasma and LCD television sets capable of 3-D have yet to hit the market, but the accessories one needs to complete the experience are starting to trickle out.

title: An Eye-Opening Show. Eye-Closing, Too.
description: The voice of Whoopi Goldberg, rich and powerful, filled the planetarium.

title: God Said Multiply, and Did She Ever
description: WHEN Yitta Schwartz died last month at 93, she left behind 15 children, more than 200 grandchildren and so many great- and great-great-grandchildren that, by her familys count, she could claim perhaps 2,000 living descendants.

title: Bloomberg Shifts Money Out of Quadrangle
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has decided to remove his fortune from the Quadrangle Group, the private equity firm founded by his longtime friend Steven Rattner, just 10 months after that firm became embroiled in a scandal involving the state pension fund, The New York Timess Louise Story and Michael Barbaro report.

title: Let the Games Be Stylish
description: THE question that some Olympics fans who happened to be in town for Fashion Week found themselves asking was, Where did all the bad taste go?

title: Before Takeoff, a Cozy, if Boozy, Spot for a Pizza Pie
description: Catering to the wheels-up-in-an-hour crowd, this no-nonsense Mediterranean restaurant in the basement food court at La Guardia Airport is light on atmosphere and heavy on preflight boozers. It can nonetheless feel cozy at the dark end of a February snowstorm  especially when packed with delayed travelers, including two identically dressed white-shirted businessmen from the Midwest.

title: Thursday's Health Care Summit
description: With President Obama's bipartisan summit on health care this coming Thursday, Republicans have staked out a path of resistance against Democratic proposals.

title: Talking Fashion With Charlie Rose
description: Thanks, everyone, for some terrific comments on the blog during Fashion Week, and I will return to them in a day or so as the action moves to London and Milan. The first shows in Milan are next Thursday. Meanwhile, I had the pleasure today to be on The Charlie Rose Show with Narciso Rodriguez, Mickey Drexler, the chief executive of J. Crew, and Robbie Myers, the editor of Elle. We discussed all things fashion from our different perspectives of the industry. The show will be on the air tonight at 11.

title: Tips From a Maestro of the Spray Can
description: FAIRFIELD

title: A Bit Slower, but Still Throwing Lethal Punch Lines
description: AFTER World War II, a generation of comics emerged from the clubs ready to challenge the conventions of the day. Among the best known were Dick Gregory, who mocked racial attitudes; Jerry Stiller and his wife, Anne Meara, who satirized assumptions about marriage; and Irwin Corey, who punctured academic pretense.

title: A Rivalry Born Behind the Lens
description: Youve probably heard of three of the four characters in Kim Merrills Exposure Time, a promising but sometimes incoherent drama now being given its world-premiere production by the New Jersey Repertory Company.

title: Childhood, Then and Now
description: It is not easy to organize a historical loan exhibition on an extremely limited budget. That is the ambitious task that the Hofstra University Museum set itself with Childrens Pleasures: American Celebrations of Childhood, a show of about 50 works of art.

title: Obama Invites G.O.P. Lawmakers Health Care Ideas
description: LAS VEGAS  Days before a high-profile summit meeting that could determine the future of his health care overhaul, President Obama made an impassioned appeal for the legislation here on Friday, challenging Republicans to come to the table with their own ideas.

title: Offering Face Time With History
description: GREENWICH

title: Simons Dueling Newlyweds Return
description: Barefoot in the Park, Neil Simons 1963 comedy, has certainly not wanted for attention over the years. Robert Redford and Jane Fonda immortalized those tediously dueling newlyweds Paul and Corie Bratter in the 1967 film. In 1970, ABC started a television series based on the play, and in 1982 it was HBOs turn with a telecast starring Richard Thomas as Paul.

title: City Critic | Fashion for Everyone!
description: Ariel Kaminer straps on stilettos and heads to the tents at Bryant Park to see if an outsider can get in to the New York Fashion Week shows.

title: I Was the One Reading Andrew Marvell. You Were . . .
description: Art is the sex of the imagination, said the drama critic George Jean Nathan, and no one can deny that creativity and carnality are closely linked. Perhaps there is a sexual charge placed in every artwork at its making; perhaps the mere act of looking at art itself is erotic. The following poems about the romantic effects of art (and artists) were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

title: F.C.C. Opens an Inquiry for a Game Show on Fox
description: LOS ANGELES  The Federal Communications Commission is looking into whether the producers of the planned Fox game show Our Little Genius gave potential contestants the answers to some questions before taping episodes of the program last year.

title: Agency Proposes U.S.-Paid Research on Stem Cells
description: The National Institutes of Health is proposing to expand its definition of human embryonic stem cells, enabling the university researchers it finances to work with cells derived from a very early human egg.

title: Two Editors at The Times Are Appointed to New Roles
description: Richard L. Berke, an assistant managing editor at The New York Times, was named on Friday to be the papers next national editor, replacing Suzanne M. Daley, who will return to reporting as a correspondent writing about Europe.

title: Americans Trying to Mend Fences
description: Olympic gold has a way of transcending issues and in Vancouver, Americas stellar and growing medal count is helping heal the wounds of a United States Olympic Committee on the mend. Americas athletes, performing with dignity and acting with humility, are helping polish its image. U.S.O.C. President Larry Probst, a newcomer to the Olympic world, has been working tirelessly since declaring he was all in with the effort to build new bridges with the international Olympic community.

title: Senior Counsel, Very Senior Counsel
description: THE question has raged for as long as there has been law: When is the right time for lawyers to turn in their cards, for judges to pack up their robes?

title: In the West, Monument Is a Fighting Word
description: DENVER  In much of the nation, monument is an innocuous word, conjuring up images of historical figures cast in bronze or road-side plaques few stop to read.

title: Surcharge Designed to Aid Cubs Upsets Rivals
description: Not everyone apparently thinks the Chicago Cubs are lovable losers deserving of sympathy  and tax dollars.

title: To Halladay, Phillies Look Like October at Last
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Roy Halladay goes to bed before his two young children, and he reports to the Philadelphia Phillies clubhouse at 5:45 each morning. He does not waste time. He has done that enough already.

title: Learning to Live With Tape Delay
description: Every Olympics brings the predictable, biennial complaint: Why does NBC tape-delay events?

title: Drones Are Playing a Growing Role in Afghanistan
description: When American and allied forces pushed into the Taliban stronghold of Marja, in southern Afghanistan, last week, they had the advantage of knowing where dozens of roadside bombs had already been planted. And when some troops came under fire, they called in help from a weapon that has quietly become one of the militarys most versatile tools on the Afghan battlefield: the drone.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 980 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Inside the Rings: If It Wasnt for Those Medaling Americans
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Canada spent almost $120 million in an effort to win more medals than any other country at the Vancouver Games. After the first week of the Olympics, the Own the Podium Program has received a mixed return on its investment. Though Alexandre Bilodeau won Canadas first gold medal on home soil in mens moguls, the home country is fourth in the medals standings with seven. Thats more than $14 million a medal; presumably though gold and silver are worth more than bronze.

title: The Stars of Hockey Play Here, and There
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Canadians poured into the streets of Vancouver to celebrate after Martin Brodeurs save on Martin Plss won Thursday nights game for Canada. But the fact remains: it was a shootout victory by the barest of margins against Switzerland.

title: On and Off the Ice, Ohno Is Positioned for Success
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The evolution of Apolo Anton Ohno unfolded in ice rinks, on television, over 12 years and three Winter Olympics. It involved a single father and singular short track speedskating focus, a torturous trainer and dancing with stars.

title: Jury in Police-Abuse Trial Restarts Its Deliberations
description: A juror who told others on the panel that a police officer accused of sexually abusing Michael Mineo had been previously accused of brutality was dismissed Friday morning, more than a day after the jury had started deliberating.

title: Conservatives Get a Look at Possible Candidates
description: WASHINGTON  For all the talk of Sarah Palin these days, there are two Republicans who are already laying the groundwork to run for president in 2012  Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota and Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts.

title: Mission: Impossible  Dubai
description: Wanna see the best spy thriller of the year? Heres the trailer:

title: Vulnerability in a Disciplined Performance
description: If Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina had delivered Tiger Woodss ironclad apology instead of a lovelorn cri de coeur about his Argentine love nest, his soon-to-be-ex-wife, Jenny, might not have published a book about her marital woes.

title: Slovenia Considers a Lawsuit
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Petra Majdic was awarded Slovenias Golden Order of Services for winning her countrys first medal in cross-country skiing after suffering injuries during a warm-up crash.

title: Indiana: Congressman Enters Race for Bayhs Senate Seat
description: Representative Brad Ellsworth said Friday that he would seek his partys nomination for the United States Senate seat in Indiana that Senator Evan Bayh is vacating. Mr. Bayhs announcement Monday that he would not run, on the eve of filing deadlines, gave the states Democrats no time to qualify for a primary. Under state law, the Democratic Party will pick the nominee. On the Republican side, Dan Coats, who left the Senate in 1999, is seeking to retake the seat.

title: Steelworkers Say Reactors Will Create Overseas Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  The United Steelworkers union has complained that a government-backed plan to build two nuclear reactors in Georgia will create jobs overseas that should go to American workers.

title: Feasting on Memories, Serving the Future
description: Perhaps more than any other work on display at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, The Brown Sisters by Nicholas Nixon captures the essence of the institutions 75th anniversary celebration. The work is a set of 35 photographic portraits, made annually since 1975, of the artists wife and her three siblings standing in the same order. The museum acquired the artwork in 2000, and, as of now, there is no official end date to this act of creation.

title: Judge Declines to Reverse Monserrates Expulsion From the State Senate
description: A federal judge on Friday refused to reinstate former Senator Hiram Monserrate, the first member of the New York State Legislature removed from office since the 1920s, rejecting Mr. Monserrates claims that his expulsion was unconstitutional.

title: Report Faults 2 Authors of Bush Terror Memos
description: WASHINGTON  After five years of often bitter internal debate, the Justice Department concluded in a report released Friday that the lawyers who gave legal justification to the Bush administrations brutal interrogation tactics for terrorism suspects used flawed legal reasoning but were not guilty of professional misconduct.

title: Beyond Twitter: An App That Lets You Truly See City
description: The view of the South Bronx and East Harlem seen from the window of a Metro-North train heading south can at times challenge the commuters sense of place. Impenetrable-looking brick buildings loom off in the distance, boarded-up windows flash closer by. The citys stories seem sealed off, remote, silenced by the sound of wheels moving on tracks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about troubled efforts to control the national debt misidentified the organizations that issued a recent report addressing the problem. Choosing the Nations Fiscal Future, was by the National Research Council and the National Academy of Public Administration  not by the National Academy of Sciences, which is the research councils parent organization.

title: Rewards Cardholders Face a Higher Price for Perks
description: Rewards cardholders take note: the price of perks is about to go up.

title: U.S. Formula One Team Struggling to Reach Start Line
description: One year after announcing grand plans to build a Formula One race team in the United States, Ken Anderson conceded on Friday that it would not be able to make the grid for the 2010 season opener March 14 in Bahrain because of financial problems.

title: Trade Puts Knicks on the Clock With Lee
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Tracy McGradys arrival on Thursday may lead directly to David Lees departure in July. The issue is salary-cap rules.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about federal and state officials efforts to collect taxes from companies that illegally pass off regular employees as independent contractors gave an incorrect middle initial, in some copies, for the vice president, whose Middle Class Task Force helped orchestrate the campaign. He is Joseph R. Biden, not Joseph A.

title: Want Inside the Tents? Lose the Pose
description: Halfway through Fashion Week, the streets were ankle-deep in slush, but the people arriving for the ThreeASFOUR runway show in West Chelsea were impeccably attired. Most precious of all was the wisp of a man with a Pierrot haircut and a white origami coat that extended through to jeweled finger gloves, who was overseeing the guest list. Im not on your list, I began nervously. Im just a nobody fan. But its a snowy night, so maybe a few people didnt show up. Is there any chance I could just, you know, sneak in?"

title: An Accidental Leader Stirs Hopes in Nigeria
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  The circumstances of Acting President Goodluck Jonathans accession to power are so odd that even he looks bewildered as he takes a self-effacing bow in this boiling, fractious nation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a campaign trip by President Obama on behalf of two Democratic senators misidentified, in some editions, the beneficiary of a fund-raiser he attended in Las Vegas on Thursday. The event raised money for the Democratic National Committee, not for Senator Harry Reid of Nevada.

title: For Female Ski Jumpers, Chance to Compete Remains Elusive
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Coach Jochen Danenberg was walking toward the bottom of the jumping hill at the Whistler Olympic Park on Friday when he spotted a familiar face across the fence. Alissa Johnson, an American ski jumper who holds 10th place in the world rankings for women, was standing on the side reserved for spectators.

title: Corrections
description: A Pop entry in the Week Ahead report on Page 2 this weekend about the Tibet House benefit concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday erroneously includes several performers among the musicians who are to appear. David Bowie, Moby, Paul Simon, Sheryl Crow, R.E.M., Rufus Wainwright, Baaba Maal, Vampire Weekend and The National are not on the program. (They previously appeared at Tibet House benefit concerts.)

title: Generics Face Longer Wait for Approval
description: NAPLES, Fla.  American consumers are waiting nearly a year longer for government regulators to approve new lower-priced generic drugs than they did in 2005.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the actress and singer Kathryn Grayson referred incorrectly to the opera singer Grace Moore, whom Ms. Grayson portrayed in the 1953 film So This Is Love. Ms. Moore was not paralyzed. The obituary also erroneously attributed a distinction to Ms. Graysons on-screen performance of the song Smoke Gets in Your Eyes. Irene Dunne sang it in the 1935 film Roberta, 17 years before Ms. Grayson sang it in Lovely to Look At; Ms. Grayson did not introduce movie audiences to the song.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: Fashions Military Invasion Rolls On
description: AS he mulled the themes that would color his fall line, Marcus Wainwright of Rag & Bone had a minor epiphany. You cant really improve on a field jacket, he said. It is a silhouette thats going to be cool forever.

title: Investor to Step Down From Times Co. Board
description: A leader of the investment team that bought a large stake in The New York Times Company two years ago, only to see it lose much of its value, will not seek re-election to the board, the company said Thursday.

title: Ukraine: Premier Presses Case of Fraud
description: Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, seeking to overturn her loss in the presidential election, urged judges on Friday to scrutinize evidence that she said showed voter fraud. Ms. Tymoshenko is challenging the Feb. 7 election, which the opposition leader, Viktor F. Yanukovich, won by 3.48 percentage points. The Higher Administrative Court in Kiev is expected to rule in the next few days. Mr. Yanukovichs inauguration is scheduled for Thursday.

title: Russia: Life Term for a Former Officer
description: A former police major who went on a shooting rampage last year at a Moscow supermarket, killing two people and wounding others, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday, a spokesman for the Moscow City Court said. Denis Yevsyukov, the former major, confessed to killing one of the victims, but said he could not remember much of the episode. The shooting provoked widespread anger in Russia, where video of Mr. Yevsyukov stalking the supermarket aisles, firing at fleeing customers, has been played repeatedly on television. His lawyers said they would appeal the sentence.

title: U.S. Asks Justices to Review Tobacco Company Ruling
description: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court on Friday to review a 2006 federal fraud racketeering conviction against the tobacco industry and to authorize the district judge in the case to require tobacco companies to give up as much as $280 billion in ill-gotten gains.

title: Blackstone Reaches Deal to Cut Hiltons Debt
description: The Blackstone Group has reached a deal to reorganize the big debt load of Hilton Hotels, shoring up the finances of one of its crown jewels, a person briefed on the matter said Friday night.

title: Up Against Michigans Basketball Elite, Jeter Was Less So
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The state of Michigan has produced some pretty fair basketball players. Magic Johnson is a Lansing native. Shane Battier hails from Birmingham. George Gervin, the Iceman, is from Detroit. So are Chris Webber and Jalen Rose, who were teammates at the University of Michigan and, before that, on an A.A.U. team that also featured the future N.B.A. players Voshon Lenard and Howard Eisley.

title: Research Ties Diabetes Drug to Heart Woes
description: Hundreds of people taking Avandia, a controversial diabetes medicine, needlessly suffer heart attacks and heart failure each month, according to confidential government reports that recommend the drug be removed from the market.

title: The Breast Whisperer
description: AMY BRILL, a writer who lives in Windsor Terrace, survived nine months and six days of pregnancy, then 40 hours of labor. But after a few days of nursing, she was in excruciating pain, crying every time her baby latched on. Ms. Brills pediatrician wrote out a phone number as if it were a prescription. Call this woman, he said. Shes seen every new mom in Brooklyn.

title: Top Driver of Bobsled Pulls Out After Crash
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Safety concerns at the Whistler Sliding Centre arose again Friday when Beat Hefti of Switzerland, the top-ranked bobsled driver in the world, announced that he would not compete in the two-man race after he sustained a concussion crashing during a training session run on Wednesday.

title: Davis and Hedrick Seem to Move Past Turin Friction
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  They sat on the interview podium about a foot apart, the United States long-track speedskaters Shani Davis and Chad Hedrick appearing much closer than they were four years ago, when nine-hundredths of a second separated them in the 1,500 meters at the Turin Olympics.

title: Poor Sanitation in Haitis Camps Adds Disease Risk
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As hundreds of thousands of people displaced by last months earthquake put down stakes in the squalid tent camps of this wrecked city, the authorities are struggling to address the worsening problem of human waste. Public health officials warn that waste accumulation is creating conditions for major disease outbreaks, including cholera, which could further stress the ravaged health system.

title: Not Bogged Down Over Cranberries
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Richmond is perhaps best known as the location of Vancouvers airport. Now the city, which is home to the speedskating oval, hopes the Olympics will leave its name forever associated with cranberries.

title: Exposure Warning
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Paula Gamache is a remarkably diverse constructor. Her last seven published puzzles cover six different weekdays, Monday through Saturday. Todays is the Saturday, and its suitably difficult. Its so tough that only a few top solvers in the world will slice through it quickly, and theyre all in Brooklyn today at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

title: Manuel Is in Midseason Form
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  One day before the first official workout of the spring, Jerry Manuel held his first news conference of the year and had some interesting things to say  besides presenting his plan to move Jose Reyes into the third spot in the batting order.

title: Blackstone Group Refinances Debt at Hilton Hotels
description: The Blackstone Group has reached a deal to reorganize the debt load of Hilton Hotels, shoring up the finances of one of its crown jewels, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday. The deal would cut Hiltons debt burden to about $16 billion from $20 billion. Under the terms of the agreement, Blackstone will inject an additional $800 million of capital to buy back Hiltons debt at a discount, this person said. The maturities of some of Hiltons debt will also be pushed back. A Blackstone spokesman declined to comment. Blackstone agreed to acquire Hilton in 2007 for $26 billion. Negotiations with Hiltons lenders have been going on for months. One complication is that several billions of dollars of Hilton debt is held by an unusual entity: the Federal Reserve, which assumed loans to Hilton made by Bear Stearns when it helped rescue the investment bank almost two years ago. News of the deal was first reported by The Wall Street Journal online.

title: No Bias Here, Locals Say, Just Very Few Black People
description: After last weeks blizzard, neighbors helped neighbors dig out their snowbound cars. An icy wind blew off Long Island Sound, snapping American flags and jangling wind chimes that hung from squat bungalows. Posters stapled to lampposts told of St. Patricks Day bingo games at the firehouse and a pot ogold party for the children.

title: Baked Treats of Portugal
description: Even if you havent been to Teixeiras Bakery in Newark, theres a good chance youve eaten one of its crusty Portuguese rolls. Teixeiras (pronounced tay-SHARE-uhs) supplies supermarkets and restaurants in New Jersey, New York, Philadelphia and parts of Delaware with breads and pastries.

title: A Gentle Introduction to Syrian Cuisine
description: WHEN I made a reservation at Aleppo, a year-old Syrian restaurant in the heart of the thriving Middle Eastern bazaar that is Patersons south side, the soft and courtly female voice at the other end asked when wed be arriving. Seven oclock? I offered. Inshallah, she replied  God willing.

title: Lottery Numbers
Power to Prosecute Police Goes to Civilians. Again.
description: On Thursday, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly gave lawyers from the Civilian Complaint Review Board, the independent agency that investigates allegations of police abuse, authority to prosecute police officers in cases now handled exclusively by the departments lawyers. But it was not the first time such powers have been proposed.

title: Key West Style, Far to North
description: An arrow out front indicates the way to Key West, 1,551 miles south, where this pale blue beach-style shack would look very much at home. The flagstone patio, decorated by a lobster pot, a few buoys and a weathered flamingo, also suggests warmer climes. Yet Blue Sky Foods, which was established in 1994, is very much a local business, one that remains open throughout the winter.

title: Now (Possibly) Batting Third, Jose Reyes
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jose Reyes has made 3,651 plate appearances in his seven-year career and, according to Baseball Reference.com, not one of those has come as the No. 3 hitter in the batting order.

title: Bus and Subway Ridership Falls for the First Time Since 2003
description: Ridership on New York Citys buses and subways declined last year for the first time in six years, apparently a victim of the economic downturn.

title: Assorted Links
description: Why health care reform wont prevent premium increases.

title: Where Who Dat Nation Can Feel Right at Home
description: NEW ORLEANS cuisine is the product of a lively fusion of cultures: African, Caribbean, European and Native American. So perhaps its not surprising that the shorelines lone offering of that cuisine, Creative Cooking New Orleans Restaurant, is the brainchild of a man whose culinary influences are just as diverse.

title: Family Guy, Palin and the Limits of Laughter
description: Family Guy, the Fox animated comedy series, is either irreverent or crass, depending on your tolerance for unmannerly humor. Viewers come for its pop-cultural free associations and flatulence gags, not necessarily to debate pressing issues of the day.

title: Just in From Sicily
description: Paolo Pilano remembers all the tastes of Agrigento, Sicily, where he was raised. Although he immigrated to New York in 1971, when he was 21, you wouldnt know it from his thick accent, the way he tears up when he talks about his hometown or his culinary biases, which are readily apparent at Pane and Gelato, a cafe he opened in November.

title: A Cafe With a Family Touch
description: Theres a homemade flavor at the two-year-old MoJoe Coffee Caf in Mineola that extends to the dcor. One of the owners, Christian Crespo, 30, of Mineola, hung a painting of Don Quixote by his grandfather on the wall; his grandmother knitted the caddies that hold the Trivial Pursuit cards on the tables.

title: For Knicks, a Spry McGrady Would Be a Bonus
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Without a stage or a microphone, an official introduction or a contrived jersey presentation, Tracy McGrady gently slipped into his new life as a Knick early Friday afternoon.

title: The Oceans Bounty, With Touches of Odessa
description: THE Buccaneer Crab House sailed into Freeport late last summer, landing not on the Nautical Mile with most of the other seafood restaurants but in the center of downtown on Merrick Road.

title: Spirit Quest
description: I recently met a young woman who was just back from a monthlong Costa Rican vacation. She said that she had gone in part to connect with her spiritual self, to shed the moral strictures of her youth and to find her place of peace as an adult. In her mind at least, it had been a successful trip. She was a new woman, spiritually awakened.

title: Making a Mission Out of Comfort Food
description: IS this the same place? my daughter asked.

title: A Top Womens Ski Jumper Watches From the Sideline
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Coach Jochen Danneberg was walking toward the bottom of the jumping hill at the Whistler Olympic Park on Friday when he spotted a familiar face across the fence. Alissa Johnson, an American ski jumper who holds 10th place in the womens world rankings, was standing on the side reserved for spectators.

title: Some Phone Calls, 2 Big Checks, and Rabbi Is Charged
description: Rabbi Milton Balkany, the director of a Brooklyn Jewish day school, was on the phone last month with a proposition for a man he had never met, the president of a giant Connecticut hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Fran Lee, Whose Work Led to Pooper-Scooper Law, Is Dead at 99
description: Fran Lee, a preternaturally outspoken consumer advocate whose ardent campaign against dog waste helped bring about New York City's pooper-scooper law in 1978, died on Feb. 13 at her home in Jerusalem. She was 99.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the transformation of former auto-related operations in the Detroit area misspelled the name of one of the companies that is investing in a mothballed Ford plant in Wixom, Mich. It is Xtreme Power, not Extreme Power.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Westminster Dog Show referred imprecisely to its coverage on Animal Planet. While the show was indeed shown on that channel, the coverage was only in Canada; USA Network and CNBC carried the show in the United States.

title: Lautenbergs Cancer Is Curable, Doctor Says
description: Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, the second-oldest member of the United States Senate, has a curable form of stomach cancer and will undergo chemotherapy, his office and doctor said on Friday.

title: New York Fashion Week: The Last Word
description: Cathy Horyn looks back at the fall 2010 collections.

title: Battle Gear
description: For much of the last year, interpretations of battle gear have infiltrated the style world.

title: Bar Mitzvah Conflict Is Resolved for Bout
description: The Yankees settled one fight so they could book another. On Friday, the team said that it had reached an agreement with Jonathan Ballan, whose son, Scott, is scheduled to have his bar mitzvah at Yankee Stadium on June 5, the same day the Yankees want to host a boxing match between Miguel Cotto and Yuri Foreman.

title: Bloggingheads: Hooray for Obstruction?
description: Peter Beinart, left, of The Daily Beast and Jonah Goldberg of National Review debate the popularity of G.O.P. obstructionism.

title: Truth and Fiction on the Stimulus Bill
description: It was a pleasure to see President Obama come out swinging this week and win a round in the long-running fight with Republicans over the $787 billion stimulus bill.

title: Bringing Back the Fixers
description: New York Citys freshly elected comptroller, John Liu, announced this week what he called major reforms in the way the citys pension fund works. He offered several good ideas, particularly his decision not to accept political contributions from anybody doing business with the citys $100 billion pension fund. But one of his major reforms is a worrying step backward.

title: Who Can Relax This Way?
description: It looked like a casting call for a Sam Pekinpah shoot-em-up: 100 or so gun enthusiasts showed up at the Buckhorn Grill in Walnut Creek, Calif., this month with revolvers strapped on their hips. Were not politically involved, the restaurant manager declared as he agreed to serve the supporters of Open Carry, a group that goes around flaunting gun owners right  under a benighted California law  to pack weapons in public.

title: The Revolution Has Gone Mobile
description: By mid-2010, there will be 6.8 billion humans on this planet. According to United Nations estimates, there also will be five billion cellphone subscriptions. These are astonishing numbers. What is still more astonishing, and hopeful, is the breadth of change this number reflects.

title: Revisiting Nuclear Power: A Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Airstrikes and Civilian Casualties in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Costs, Politics and Health Care in America
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tea Party Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pope and the Clerical Abuse of Irish Children
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wages of Rages
description: Today, our topic is: strange stories about Republican presidential hopefuls. Would you rather start with the one about Mitt Romney and the rapper, or Tim Pawlenty?

title: Falling Further Behind
description: Harrisburg, Pa.

title: WhoseTube?
description: Melbourne, Australia

title: Sending a Message in 12,000 Bottles
description: ABOARD THE PLASTIKI

title: Keeping the Plates Spinning
description: NORWICH, Conn.

title: The Vatican: Australian Saint Approved
description: Pope Benedict XVI approved sainthood on Friday for Mary Helen MacKillop, who will become Australias first Roman Catholic saint. Sister Mary of the Cross, as she was known, founded the Congregation of the Sisters of Saint Joseph of the Sacred Heart in Australia. Since 1866, the order has built schools, orphanages and centers for the homeless and the needy in Australia and New Zealand.

title: Russians Lead After What May Be Final Compulsory Dance
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In what could be the final performance of the compulsory dance in the Olympics, the Russian ice dancing team of Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin performed the tango romantica  just as the other 22 couples in Fridays competition. But, according to the judges, their version was the best.

title: Munching to the Future
description: TRY this, Marcus Samuelsson said, cramming a fragrant morsel of fried chicken into his guests mouth. Good, right?

title: Chugging, No. Canoodling, O.K.
description: Its all in a name: Baddies, the cavelike lounge attached to the West Village restaurant Kingswood, does make one think that something deliciously naughty is going to happen.

title: Lionel Jeffries, British Character Actor, Dies at 83
description: Lionel Jeffries, a mustachioed, bald-pated British character actor who excelled in rubber-faced comedic roles like Grandpa Potts in the musical fantasy adventure Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, and who directed The Railway Children and several other family-oriented films, died Friday. He was 83.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday about isolated, but politically potent, missteps by the United Nations panel on climate change misidentified the journal that published Ralph J. Cicerones editorial on credibility and climate science. It was Science, not Nature.

title: Editors Note
description: An Op-Ed essay on Thursday, about air strikes in Afghanistan, included a quotation from a Marine officer under fire in an Afghan village. The essay should have made clear that the quotation came from a news article by McClatchy Newspapers.

title: Signs, Wonders and Fates Fulfilled
description: THE first time I saw Frdric, he was wearing a long monastic habit and carrying a battered teapot. Would you like some tea? he asked in English tinged with a French accent.

title: A Digital Doomsday Simulation
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: N.F.L. Will Be Playing Tag on Thursday
description: Thursday is one of the most important days of the N.F.L. off-season. Its the deadline for teams to prevent the departure of key unrestricted free agents by using their franchise and transition tags. In previous years, teams could use one tag or the other. In this uncapped year, they can use both tags or two transition tags (but not two franchise tags).

title: A Tale of Two Skiing Styles
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Cross-country skiers generally fall into one of two camps. Some prefer the classical technique, which uses skis waxed to grip and glide on the snow. Others favor the freestyle (or skate) technique, which is faster on the flats and uses skis only waxed for glide.

title: Live Evil Webcast Loop
description: Video | Theres a moral for technology in here somewhere:

title: An Eventful Games for Hedrick
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  Since the XXI Winter Olympics have begun, Chad Hedricks 11-month-old daughter, Hadley, has said Da-Da for the first time and taken her first steps.

title: Classic Ads: Audis Ski Jump Sedans
description: Motor sports arent part of the Winter Olympics  not yet, anyway  but that didnt keep Audi from using a ski jump to show off the climbing power of its quattro four-wheel drive system.

title: Ukraine Leader Drops Vote Challenge
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko of Ukraine effectively conceded the presidential election on Saturday by withdrawing her legal challenge, saying that she did not believe that she would get a fair hearing.

title: More on Disinflation
description: First, a tale of dueling headlines:

title: Video: Ten Minutes With Rep. Mike Pence
description: Conservatives have swarmed the nations capital in the last few days, generating enthusiasm among the Republican base and offering a campaign platform for many elected officials with higher ambitions and fund-raising needs.

title: They Hate Me, They Really Hate Me  Still
description: Steve Pearlstein.

title: Is the Fed Getting Ready to Tighten?
description: Officials say no. But theres a lot of speculation that the rise in the discount rate presages further action. Lets hope that this is wrong.

title: The Bankruptcy Boys
description: William Galston, writing about Republican refusal to join a deficit-reduction commission, catches something I missed: the WSJ editorial page is now against means-testing on entitlements programs, because it

title: Wheels Down in Portugal
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

title: Every Channel Except the Food Network
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Im kind of embarrassed to say, I actually, and Im not kidding, I wish I was, set my alarm last night to make sure I was up in time for Tiger Woods apology. It was covered on pretty much every channel except the Food Network, I think. And the excitement surrounding this historic event could hardly be contained. Less than three hours before Tiger Woods speaks. Hes going to speak in exactly a minute and a half. Tiger Woods set to walk out now in about 40 seconds. I guess this is like the closest thing we get to the thrill of a space launch now that we cant afford NASA anymore.

title: Those Were Hilarious
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Show With David Letterman on CBS: You know who loves the Winter Olympics? You wouldnt guess this. Former Vice President Dick Cheney. He loves it. He thinks that snowboarding is waterboarding but colder.

title: Defying Critics, Paterson Opens His Campaign
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Gov. David A. Paterson returned to his boyhood hometown on Saturday and defiantly proclaimed his candidacy for election, portraying himself as a champion of New Yorkers struggling with discrimination and economic hardship.

title: Alexander M. Haig Jr., 1924-2010
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., a former Army general who became White House chief of staff during the Watergate scandal and was secretary of state during the Reagan administration, died at age 85.

title: Marines Do Heavy Lifting as Afghan Army Lags in Battle
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  As American Marines and Afghan soldiers have fought their way into this Taliban stronghold, the performance of the Afghan troops has tested a core premise of the American military effort here: in the not-too-distant future, the security of this country can be turned over to indigenous forces created at the cost of American money and blood.

title: Cryptic Homeric Saga
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Were used to seeing Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon on the byline of the acrostic puzzles, but theyre masters of several puzzle forms, including cryptics. Their collection of puzzles for The Atlantic is available in book form and they now have a new cryptic published every four weeks in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Texas Senator Now a Challenger Lagging in Polls
description: DALLAS  Just a year ago, many Republican leaders considered Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison to be the odds-on favorite to become the next governor of Texas. A popular lawmaker from the old-guard Republican establishment, she was seen as someone who could widen the partys appeal after the setbacks it suffered during the 2008 national election.

title: Another Reliever, Another Shoulder Problem
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jay Marshall, a left-handed reliever the Mets claimed off waivers from the Oakland Athletics last month, did not report to camp because of a sore shoulder.

title: Letters: Too Close to Home and Someone Elses Rumor
description: Here are additional reader letters in response to Too Close to Home and to Someone Elses Rumor.

title: Dutch Government Collapses Over Its Stance on Troops for Afghanistan
description: BERLIN  A last-ditch effort to keep Dutch troops in Afghanistan brought down the government in the Netherlands early Saturday, immediately raising fears that the Western military coalition fighting the war was increasingly at risk.

title: Alexander M. Haig Jr. Dies at 85; Was Forceful Aide to 2 Presidents
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., the four-star general who served as a confrontational secretary of state under President Ronald Reagan and a commanding White House chief of staff as the Nixon administration crumbled, died Saturday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, according to a hospital spokesman. He was 85.

title: Letters to the Editor: An Apology, for What Its Worth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Turmoil, Sunni Party in Iraq Calls for Vote Boycott
description: BAGHDAD  The Sunni political party whose two most prominent leaders were disqualified from next months parliamentary elections in Iraq because of supposed ties to Saddam Husseins Baath Party called Saturday for a boycott of the vote, raising fears of worsening sectarian tensions in an already volatile campaign.

title: No Olympics for Female Ski Jumpers
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Jochen Danneberg was walking toward the bottom of the jumping hill at Whistler Olympic Park on Friday when he spotted a familiar face across the fence. Alissa Johnson, an American ski jumper who holds 10th place in the womens world rankings, was standing on the side reserved for spectators.

title: Up Next! On Live TV! A Battle Over ... Health Care?
description: WASHINGTON  When he jousts with Congressional Republicans over health care policy during a televised meeting on Thursday, President Obama will seek to portray his adversaries as sharing many of the broad goals of his legislation and also strive to unify Congressional Democrats to press ahead and adopt a bill, senior White House officials and leading Democrats say.

title: A Prediction That Lives in Infamy
description: PLANT CITY, Fla.  My first spring training was 20 years ago, and I am reminded of it whenever I drive east from Tampa on Interstate 4.

title: Testing Ends in Jerez, as Bigger Tests Continue for USF1
description: The final week of testing ended in Jerez with the second day in a row of dry track running of the week, and some very interesting results, as car strengths begin to look a little clearer.

title: Tiger Woodss Game, Not His Life, Is Focus of Tour Players
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Now that Tiger Woods has made his apologies and begun to mend his fences, the focus on the PGA Tour shifts to what he left unsaid in his carefully crafted and brilliantly delivered mea culpa on Friday: When will he return to competition?

title: U.S. to Face Canada in Mens Hockey
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Sundays Olympic mens hockey matchup between Canada and the United States is not the end of the world  not quite.

title: Woods Had His Say, and Now Conversation Should Shift
description: The nation is fighting wars overseas.

title: The Boys of Winter
description: Reporter John Branch spends some down time with the American men's curling team as they explore Vancouver.

title: Filipino Politicians Wield Private Armies, Despite Ban
description: REINA REGENTE, the Philippines  Tata Uy and a dozen members of his militia were milling around their base, a bullet-pocked mosque on a hill overlooking forests and farmland here in the southern Philippines. Mr. Uy pointed to a spot a couple of miles away where gunmen loyal to his uncle were holed up.

title: The Neighborhood Curling Team
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  From the house on 13th Street where John Shuster grew up, along one edge of Chisholm, Minn., it was only a few blocks to where Jason Smith lived. And if you headed out of town a ways, out toward Biwabik, you would find the house of Jeff Isaacson.

title: For Professor, Fury Just Beneath the Surface
description: Not long after Amy Bishop was identified as the professor who had been arrested in the shooting of six faculty members at the University of Alabama in Huntsville on Feb. 12, the campus police received a series of reports even stranger than the shooting itself.

title: Red Sox Are Strong on Mound, but Theres a Power Vacuum
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: At Cornell, the Team That Lives Together Wins Together
description: NEWTON, Mass.  To illustrate the Ivy Leagues seemingly unwavering rhythms, Cornell Coach Steve Donahue pointed to the bedroom in his hotel suite on Thursday and said, half kidding, that he had slept in that room every Friday night at this juncture in February for the past 10 years.

title: Glint of Gold Never Left Orsers Eyes
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  As Kim Yu-na of South Korea skates her sassy Olympic short program Tuesday night, her coach, Brian Orser, is certain to pantomime his own James Bond routine along the boards.

title: Doubts Raised on Books Tale of Atom Bomb
description: A new book about the atomic destruction of Hiroshima has won critical acclaim with its heartbreaking portrayals of the bombs survivors and is set to be made into a movie by James Cameron.

title: A Loyal Tony La Russa Remains Mark McGwires Biggest Booster
description: JUPITER, Fla.  There is eternal defiance in 65-year-old Tony La Russa, from the tenor of his voice to the fountain-of-youth tint of his still-modish mane to the steroid taint of his new hitting coach that he steadfastly refuses to concede.

title: Teams Are World Apart, but Bound by Excellence
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan  Order seems restored to the baseball world  actually, two worlds  as training camp begins with the most hallowed franchises in the United States and Japan as champions.

title: After James, the Choices Arent Easy
description: Donnie Walsh, the president of the Knicks, has finally done it. He has cleared enough money to sign not one but two superstars in this summers potential free-agent extravaganza. For Knicks fans, who have watched their team flounder, often losing to teams they should have beaten, and often in embarrassing fashion, that possible shopping spree cannot arrive soon enough.

title: Prime Number
description: 345: The average amount, in millions of dollars, earned by the 400 highest-earning households in the United States in 2007, according to Internal Revenue Service data reported by Tax.com. The number is up from $263 million in the previous year, an increase of 31 percent. Each of the top-earning 400 households paid an average tax rate of 16.6 percent, the lowest since the I.R.S. began tracking the data in 1992. The top 400 earned a total of $138 billion in 2007, up from $105.3 billion a year earlier.

title: Quotation of the Week
description: Im free for dinner. Im sure we could work something out.

title: Xeroxs New Chief Tries to Redefine Its Culture
description: Orlando, Fla.

title: With Fear and Crashes on Rise, Rogge Vows Action
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  As more bobsleds were crashing at the Whistler Sliding Centre on Saturday, the president of the International Olympic Committee said he would do everything in my power to prevent another accident like the one that killed an Olympic luge athlete on the same track last week.

title: Correction: A Sin We Sip Instead of Smoke?
description: An article last Sunday about taxing soda misstated the timing of a proposal by Gov. David Paterson of New York to impose a tax on soda. He proposed the tax in the state budget plan he unveiled on Jan. 19; he is not planning to propose such a tax.

title: Will Airlines and Passengers Call a Truce?
description: WHEN weather forecasters predicted severe winter storms across the country in the last few weeks, airlines sent their customers a steady stream of e-mail and text messages, giving them a chance to change their itineraries ahead of the bad weather.

title: Vonn Slips, Too, but Not Off the Podium
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Five of the first 11 racers Saturday in the womens super-G crashed or skied off course to save themselves. And that was in the first 700 yards of a deceptive course draped in shadows.

title: Astros Extend Contract of General Manager Ed Wade
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  After their first workout of spring training Saturday, the Houston Astros made clear that the future of General Manager Ed Wade would not hover over the team. Drayton McLane, the teams owner, extended his contract through 2012, giving Wade time to see through the changes he is making to the organization.

title: Millions of Unemployed Face Years Without Jobs
description: BUENA PARK, Calif.  Even as the American economy shows tentative signs of a rebound, the human toll of the recession continues to mount, with millions of Americans remaining out of work, out of savings and nearing the end of their unemployment benefits.

title: The Art of the Public Apology
description: The art of the apology, like every art, has its connoisseurs and professional critics; and almost all of them have weighed in on last weeks big show: Fridays televised mea culpa by Tiger Woods.

title: Erin Kotheimer and Pepijn Helgers
description: Erin Elizabeth Kotheimer and Pepijn Marijn Helgers were married Saturday in Washington at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle. The Rev. John Hurley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Andariese, Ady Wright
description: Emily Cecilia Andariese and Adrian Peter David Wright were married Saturday evening at the Water Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Henry Fehren, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Michael Grover and Nunzio Lupo
description: Michael McInally Grover and Nunzio Michael Lupo were married in Boston Tuesday evening at the W Boston hotel. Jane W. Grover, a sister of Mr. Grover, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Christy Monier, Charles Nixon
description: Christy Ann Monier and Charles Andrew Nixon were married Saturday in Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. Maxwell Grant, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Honu Kitchen and Cocktails, an event space.

title: A Left-Hander Hopes to Stick With Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Realistically, D. J. Mitchell hopes to begin this season at Class AA Trenton. Then he hears the tale of Boone Logan, whose locker is 25 feet away from his in the Yankees clubhouse. And then he thinks that it can be done.

title: Building a Better Mailbox
description: WHEN Vanessa Troyer and Chris Farentinos first hit on the idea that would change their lives, they were thinking big  a little too big, actually.

title: Audrey Hohman, William Miller Jr.
description: Audrey Judith Hohman and William James Miller Jr. were married Saturday in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor performed the ceremony at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, where he is pastor.

title: Goodbye to All That
description: Providence, R.I.

title: Why Im Leaving the Senate
description: BASEBALL may be our national pastime, but the age-old tradition of taking a swing at Congress is a sport with even deeper historical roots in the American experience. Since the founding of our country, citizens from Ben Franklin to David Letterman have made fun of their elected officials. Milton Berle famously joked: You can lead a man to Congress, but you cant make him think. These days, though, the institutional inertia gripping Congress is no laughing matter.

title: Emily Mitchell and Stephen Fleming
description: Emily Fong Mitchell and Stephen Samuel Fleming were married Saturday on the Island of Maui in Hawaii. Judge Joel E. August of Hawaiis Second Circuit in Maui officiated at the Olowalu Plantation House in Lahaina.

title: Liz Rubincam, Andrew Naysmith
description: Elizabeth Reid Rubincam and Andrew John Naysmith were married Saturday at 25CPW, an art gallery in Manhattan. Everett Bradley, a friend of the couple who is a minister with Universal Ministries, officiated.

title: The Birth of Cheap Communication (and Junk Mail)
description: WOULD you pay a full days earnings just to receive an e-mail message from me? On those terms, I bet you wouldnt welcome hearing from me very often.

title: A Small Price for a Large Benefit
description: FORECASTS involving climate change are highly uncertain, denialists assert  a point that climate researchers themselves readily concede. The denialists view the uncertainty as strengthening their case for inaction, yet a careful weighing of the relevant costs and benefits supports taking exactly the opposite course.

title: Alison Epstein, Jeffrey Brenner
description: Alison Cori Epstein and Jeffrey Jay Brenner were married Saturday evening in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai, with Rabbi Uri Goren participating.

title: Lyndsay Steuber, Philip Norman
description: Lyndsay Ann Steuber, the daughter of Marilyn Doerr Steuber and David W. Steuber of Laguna Beach, Calif., was married Tuesday to Philip Douglas Norman, a son of Jacqueline Batten Norman and Stephen Peckham Norman of Rye, N.Y. Blanca Martinez of the Office of the City Clerk officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Feb. 21
description: A new offensive in southern Afghanistan and the captures of several Taliban operatives may set off a debate on the Sunday talk shows about whether the United States is winning the war in Afghanistan.

title: Elizabeth Scott, Kris Barber
description: Elizabeth Scott and Kris Barber were married Saturday at the First United Methodist Church in Golden, Colo. The Rev. Ross Kershaw, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Educator to the World
description: I ATTENDED a one-room schoolhouse in rural Minnesota in the 1950s. My grandparents, who were German immigrants, had no formal schooling, and my father had only an eighth-grade education. Education was the path up for my brother, sister and me. My father excused me from the dairy chores on our farm so I could concentrate on school.

title: Class notes for Feb. 22
description: The interwar trade decline. (pdf)

title: Polly Samuels and Andrew McLean
description: ON Feb. 5, 2005, Polly Samuels and Andrew McLean were married in Alta, Utah, at Our Lady of the Snows Chapel, the perfect place for them: It was dog-friendly (the couples Labrador and Bernese, Brooklyn and Greta, roamed through the crowd) and avalanche-proof.

title: At CPAC, Gingrich Calls for Principled Bipartisanship
description: After a rock-star-like entrance to the cheering of thousands of conservatives, Newt Gingrich, who led the Republican revolution in 1994, threw plenty of red meat to his audience in a short speech Saturday afternoon.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday, about the marriage of Alicia Llosa and Christopher Chang, contained an outdated reference to the officiant. After the section went to press, the Rev. Rolando Cabrera replaced Msgr. Jude ODoherty, who was ill.

title: Health Care: Game On
description: Well, this certainly sounds like its a go. Thats the style, Mr. President!

title: Romo and Polian: Quotable and Notable in the N.F.L.
description: In what has been a quiet past few days in the N.F.L., here are three quotations that made a little noise.

title: When There Were Arts Olympians
description: Probably few of the millions slumping in front of the flat-screen this week, skipping the gym to watch their bodily betters perform hair-raising feats of athletic prowess in the Vancouver slush, are aware that in the first half of the 20th century, the modern Olympics also included arts competitions.

title: Whistler Mayor Revels in Olympic Spotlight
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Ken Melamed, the mayor of this resort town, where the Olympic Alpine and sliding events are taking place amid bad weather, controversy and an athletes death, is a ski bum turned politician who voted against bringing the Games here.

title: Burmese Refugees Persecuted in Bangladesh
description: BANGKOK  Stateless refugees from Myanmar are suffering beatings and deportation in Bangladesh, according to aid workers and rights groups who say thousands are crowding into a squalid camp where they face starvation and disease.

title: The Long, Long Shadow of Early Missteps in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq  Fittingly, it was Order No. 1.

title: States Have Not Yet Seen the Worst of Economic Times, Governors at Meeting Say
description: WASHINGTON  Although the national economy has begun to bounce back, governors said Saturday that the worst was yet to come at the state level, where revenues are still falling short of projections.

title: Canadian TV Switch Displeases Americans
description: DETROIT  It was an instinctual move, honed through years of watching the Olympics on television. Tom August, a resident of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., changed channels to see what was on CBC, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Its an option available to many American border cities like Detroit, Buffalo and Seattle, and a secret escape for Americans who do not want to watch NBC.

title: Are the Lakers  Gasp  Better Without Kobe?
description: Joseph Treutlein is the co-owner of Hoopdata.com and the assistant director of scouting for DraftExpress.com.

title: Potter Adept at Handling Hockey Stick, and Children
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  She had not been consistent, and Jenny Potters 3-year-old son, Cullen, called her on it. You didnt score, Mommy, he said. Why?

title: The Surreal World of Chatroulette
description: Nothing can really prepare you for the latest online phenomenon, Chatroulette.

title: Phenoms Cautionary Tale Takes Bright Turn
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Thomas Greilinger cuts a trim figure on the ice for Germany at these Olympics: 5 feet 11 inches, 194 pounds, the leading scorer in his countrys top league, the Deutsche Eishockey Liga.

title: A Case for Tenure That Some See as Falling Short
description: Neurobiologists say Amy Bishop did not actually have an exciting new idea for treating degenerative nervous system diseases like multiple sclerosis or Alzheimers. And her invention of a better petri dish did not seem like something that is needed or wanted in research laboratories.

title: Health Executive to Lead N.A.A.C.P.
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Saturday announced the selection of its first new board leader in more than a decade.

title: U2 Guitarists Plans Dont Find Green Harmony
description: MALIBU, Calif.  The house that the U2 guitarist longs to build here would have a copper roof, fashioned to resemble fluttering leaves. Boulders that dot the property would be left in place and assigned charming names like Dinosaur Vertebrae and Cistern. The dirt dug up to build would be reused, when possible.

title: Prize on the Battlefields of Marja May Be Momentum
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Any historian, or any general, would tell you the same: Lose the initiative on the battlefield, and its awfully hard to get it back.

title: Arrest of Prosecutor in Turkey Exposes Tensions Between Secular and Religious Turks
description: ISTANBUL  The arrest of a state prosecutor on orders from another prosecutor last week, and the power struggle in the Justice Ministry that has followed, has once again exposed the continuing battle between Turkeys staunchly secular establishment and its religiously inspired government.

title: Saving Sabathias Bullets
description: TAMPA, Fla.  This time of year, how well C.C. Sabathia looked in his 35-pitch bullpen session Saturday morning hardly matters. Joel Sherman of The New York Post may have put it best when, in a tweet, he wrote that writing who looks good throwing at this point of camp is like writing who looks good in a layup line. Sabathia, like Andy Pettitte and A.J. Burnett, is easing into his throwing routine. He feels strong and is on track to start the Yankees second Grapefruit League game, March 4 against the Phillies in Clearwater. (Look for some of the fifth-starter candidates, then, to start the March 3 opener against Pittsburgh.)

title: Does Washington Need Fixing?
description: WASHINGTON  Even in the midwinter mess of 2010, its not hard to imagine a Washington that works. It wouldnt even seem to require that much change.

title: Organizers Give Midterm Report
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  At the midway point of the Winter Olympics, Vancouver organizers on Saturday addressed everything from the death of a luge athlete to the sale of mittens.

title: Political Standoff Puts Kenyans Rage in Focus
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyans are once again waiting anxiously to see whether their president and prime minister will do something that may seem elemental: sit down and talk to each other.

title: Cries for Help via Text Messages Are Used to Direct Aid to Haiti
description: MIAMI  From his makeshift workstation, Ryan Bank spends hours sifting through thousands of electronic cries for help from Haitian earthquake victims, many detailing the horrors of dead family members, hunger and homelessness.

title: Letter: Rating Greek Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: NASAs Room With a View
description: Ten years after astronauts first moved into the International Space Station, they finally installed a picture window last week to take in the neighborhood.

title: Ski Resorts Thrive, Despite Recession Pain
description: Even when the Olympics isnt shining a spotlight on it, skiing is a robust industry. Ski resorts in the United States have shown steady increases in revenue over the last five years, according to the research firm IbisWorld.

title: In Wyoming, Debate Swirls on Taxing Wind Industry
description: With currents of powerful wind gusts whipping across its plains and plateaus, Wyoming has become a new frontier for the wind industry  the latest energy development for a state that only recently experienced a natural gas boom.

title: From the White House
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  The New York Times crossword is known for its erudite sense of humor. Youd never see a Sunday puzzle filled with crazy puns, each one a bigger groaner than the one before.

title: Letters: Not Just the Middle
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilpon Says Mets Are Still a Family Business
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets held their first official workout in advance of the 2010 season Saturday, and the teams owner, Fred Wilpon, used the occasion to finally personally dispel a report from last year that he would be forced to sell the team because of financial distress.

title: Letters: Beyond the Dollars in Government Bailouts
description: To the Editor:

title: In Practice, Stock Formulas Werent Perfect
description: A QUANT may sound like the name of a science fiction creature, but it refers to a class of human beings who came to dominate global financial markets during the past decade.

title: Early in the Year, and Already Surprised
description: AFTER last years stunning rally in global stock markets, many investors thought they knew what to expect in 2010. Among their bets were that the worst of the credit crisis was over, that the global economy would continue to expand and that the dollar would remain weak as economies abroad were expected to grow faster than that of the United States.

title: A Midstream Switch to Teaching
description: ALMOST three years ago, I started teaching seventh-grade English. Before that, I was an account manager in public relations in the Boston area.

title: Should I Hire You? Ill Ask the Receptionist
description: This interview with Jana Eggers, chief executive of Spreadshirt, a maker of personalized clothing, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Ron Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
description: And the winner is  Ron Paul.

title: On Capitol Hill, a Tradition of Condemning Washington
description: Condemning Washington as a broken, ruined, irretrievably lost place is a favorite pastime of the people who run it.

title: New Plan on School Selection, but Still Discontent
description: After years of complaints from parents, the San Francisco Unified School District has just taken a serious step toward revamping its well-meaning but labyrinthine student-assignment system, which decides the educational homes for tens of thousands of children.

title: The Lottery in Winter
description: Iowa City

title: Mets Sign Rod Barajas
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets have agreed to a deal with the free-agent catcher Rod Barajas. Although the team has not announced it yet, a person familiar with the negotiations says the deal has been agreed to. FoxSports.com first reported the deal, saying it was worth $1 million with another $1 million in incentives.

title: Sleep, the Snake and Solving the Worlds Ills
description: Josh Kornbluth, 50, is a one-man show. A writer and performer of comic monologues, he will present his latest  Andy Warhol: Good for the Jews?  at the Jewish Theatre San Francisco in April and May. He lives in Berkeley with his wife, Sara, a first-grade teacher, their son, Guthrie, 12 and Snakey, a corn snake. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: St. Helenas Version of Hatfields vs. McCoys
description: Cindy Warren has lived in the wine country town of St. Helena for more than 20 years, raised three children there and served on the school board since 2005. So it came as something of a shock when, one day after church, she bumped into a longtime acquaintance at the grocery store who gave her an ice-cold reception.

title: Beck Wows the CPAC Crowd
description: Glenn Beck, the hero of the political right and the closing speaker of a three-day conservative conference, ripped the roof off a Washington hotel Saturday with a sweeping denunciation of progressivism.

title: Snowbirds Come Home to Roost
description: Detroit

title: Have Keyboard, Will Travel
description: YOU can tell when a print journalist has lost his full-time job because of the digital markings that suddenly appear, like the tail of a fading comet. First, he joins Facebook. A Gmail address is promptly obtained. The Twitter account comes next, followed by the inevitable blog. Throw in a LinkedIn profile for good measure. This online coming-out is the first step in a daunting, and economically discouraging, transformation: from a member of a large institution to a would-be Internet brand.

title: Life Underwater
description: Atlanta

title: Johnny Damon Agrees to One-Year Deal With Tigers
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When the Detroit Tigers reached the 2006 World Series, three of their best players, Ivan Rodriguez, Kenny Rogers and Magglio Ordonez, had one thing in common. All were represented by the agent Scott Boras.

title: The U.S. Economy, Four Reports
description: The Federal Reserve on Feb. 18 raised interest rates, signaling its confidence in our economic recovery. But are Americans feeling as confident? The Op-Ed editors asked four writers from around the country to provide quarterly snapshots of their local economies. Here are their final dispatches.

title: Obama and the Dalai Lama
description: China-U.S. relations are on a downhill slide this year, and so its inevitable that critics will ask whether it was really necessary for President Obama to meet the Dalai Lama at the White House. Its a fair question, and the answer is: Yes, it was necessary.

title: Inside the Rings
description: There's no bigger game before the gold medal game than when Canada plays its neighbor in the host country's national sport.

title: On the Trail of the Anthrax Killers
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past. This article originally appeared on November 10, 2001, after the F.B.I. began investigating the origins of anthrax-laced letters that killed five people. The F.B.I. closed its investigation on Friday, Feb. 19, 2010.

title: Some Calls, 2 Big Checks, and a Rabbi Is Charged
description: Rabbi Milton Balkany, the director of a Brooklyn Jewish day school, was on the phone last month with a proposition for a man he had never met, the president of a giant Connecticut hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, The New York Timess Alan Feuer reports.

title: Alpine Skiing, From Technical Turns to Tucks and Speed
description: The different techniques required by each of four alpine skiing events.

title: The Pulse: Trying to Bridge a Gap in Bridgeport Neighborhood
description: Times are changing in the South Side enclave of Bridgeport, the longtime power base of the Daley family. Elderly men who gathered to klatch over Dunkin Donuts each morning have migrated to the Bridgeport Coffee House. The younger crowd frequents the old neighborhood tavern in the blue-collar area once known as Hardscrabble.

title: Malaria: A Scourge as Old as King Tut
description: In death if not in life, a bond unites King Tut, Egypts boy pharaoh, with the multitudes high and especially low through human history. Palace walls could not shield him from the enemy without: the anopheles mosquitoes infesting the Nile Valley with malaria parasites. A post-mortem on Tutankhamens mummy, scientists reported last week, shows that malaria was one of the most probable agents of his death at age 19, in the 14th century B.C.

title: Putting New Perspective on Illinois Corruption
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: For Many Latina Teens, Gang Life Adds to Stress
description: Sitting at a wobbly table in the back room of Enlace Chicago, a privately funded violence prevention agency in Little Village , 13-year-old April slumped in her chair and buried her face in her hands. A curtain of jet-black bangs fell across her knuckles. Her nails were bitten to nubs. She said nothing.

title: An Actress Who Prefers the Stage to Red Carpets
description: Amy Morton has a role in Up in the Air, one of the years most lauded films, sharing the screen  and her characters wellspring of acerbity  with none other than George Clooney.

title: Modest Wont Do It
description: Nearly a year ago, as the Obama administration issued a first draft of its plan to reform the financial system, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner forcefully  and correctly  declared that anything less than a total overhaul would be inadequate. Our system failed in fundamental ways, he told Congress. To address this will require comprehensive reform. Not modest repairs at the margin, but new rules of the game.

title: Still Needed
description: Here is another chilling indicator of how Americans are struggling in the recession: In June 2009, some 46.9 million people were enrolled in Medicaid programs throughout the country, nearly 3.3 million more than in the previous June. That is the biggest one-year increase ever, according to a survey just released by the Kaiser Family Foundation. This years Medicaid enrollments are almost certain to rise even higher and faster.

title: Congress Parties With the Big Money
description: Critics who accuse Congress of doing nothing are wrong. Lawmakers are hard at work raising money. The Capitols ever-booming industry has never been bigger, or shabbier, as incumbents grasp beyond campaign kitties to amass huge treasuries in the name  but hardly the spirit  of charity and do-gooding.

title: Behind the House
description: For the spring semester, I am renting a small house in Claremont, Calif., a modest ranch in a modest neighborhood. Like most of the houses on the block, its facade pays a dutiful, if glib, homage to the street, but the houses real attention  its gaze  is directed toward the carefully fenced backyard, where an orange tree grows and there is shelter from the sun under the long, wide roof of the porch.

title: Other Voices: Reporters Allegiances
description: Re Too Close to Home (Feb. 6):

title: Climate, Weather and Weirdness
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Finance Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Prosecutors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Meeting in Washington About Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fat Lady Has Sung
description: A small news item from Tracy, Calif., caught my eye last week. Local station CBS 13 reported: Tracy residents will now have to pay every time they call 911 for a medical emergency. But there are a couple of options. Residents can pay a $48 voluntary fee for the year, which allows them to call 911 as many times as necessary. Or theres the option of not signing up for the annual fee. Instead they will be charged $300 if they make a call for help.

title: I Cost More, but Im a Specialist
description: Our health care has been memorably compared, by Jonathan Rauch of The National Journal, to the airline system. That made me wonder: What if the news industry were like our unreformed health care system ... ?

title: Our Low-Tech Tax Code
description: Washington

title: Touched by Stories, Readers Open Purses to Help Change Lives
description: I just want a steady job, Telmo Cerezo, 31, a developmentally delayed Ecuadorean immigrant, said in November. With money from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Mr. Cerezo had bought business attire for job interviews. But after an article about him ran in The Times, Mr. Cerezo got his wish: After sorting through an outpouring of job offers, he accepted a position as a maintenance worker at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Gingrich and Beck Galvanize Conservatives
description: WASHINGTON  Glenn Beck, a hero of the political right and the closing speaker at a conference of political conservatives here, offered a sweeping denunciation of progressivism on Saturday, calling it a cancer that must be cut out of the nations political system.

title: New Plan on School Selection Process and Highlights From Sundays Bay Area Pages
