description: Discontent Despite New School Plan | The San Francisco Unified School District is taking a serious step toward revamping its well-meaning but complex student-assignment system, which decides where tens of thousands of children attend school. The current system has aggravated parents to a point at which efforts to manipulate it have become endemic. But even with a new plan, no one seems happy.

title: Allan Kornblum, Counsel to F.B.I., Is Dead at 71
description: Allan Kornblum, who helped steer the F.B.I. into the post-J. Edgar Hoover era by drafting guidelines for its surveillance operations in the 1970s, and whose testimony helped convict the murderer of a black man in a celebrated civil rights case revived nearly 40 years after the event, died Feb. 12 in Gainesville, Fla. He was 71.

title: Switzerlands Ammann Wins Fourth Gold
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Simon Ammann soared to victory in the mens large hill ski jump on Saturday, becoming the first person to win four individual gold ski jumping medals.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about some of the largest auditoriums in New York City by seating capacity, using information from the Department of Education, omitted two of the largest venues. They are the Metropolitan Opera House, with 3,800 seats, and the Paradise Theater on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, with 3,700 seats.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in some copies last Sunday of Compulsion, about the writer Meyer Levin, at Yale Repertory Theater, referred incompletely to the productions of Mr. Levins play about Anne Frank. Besides being performed for the Israeli Army in the 1960s, it was produced at least one other time  at Brandeis University, in 1972.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article last Sunday about the sports agent David Falks long-held view that the National Basketball Association and its players would be worlds apart as they started to negotiate a new labor deal misstated, in some editions, the reason Billy Hunter, the president of the players union, missed Commissioner David Sterns All-Star address last Saturday. He declined to attend; it was not because he was not invited.

title: Bobsled Crashes and I.O.C. Comment on Luge
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  As more bobsleds were crashing at the Whistler Sliding Centre on Saturday, the president of the International Olympic Committee said he would do everything in my power to prevent another accident like the one that killed an Olympic athlete on the same track last week.

title: Corrections
description: A Pop entry in the Week Ahead report on Page 2 this weekend about the Tibet House benefit concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday erroneously includes several performers among the musicians who are to appear. David Bowie, Moby, Paul Simon, Sheryl Crow, R.E.M., Rufus Wainwright, Baaba Maal, Vampire Weekend and The National are not on the program. (They previously appeared at Tibet House benefit concerts.)

title: Hoping to Show the G.O.P.s Role
description: Some high-level Democrats are betting that the outcome of President Obamas health care summit meeting this week could hinge on the extent to which they prove to the American public that they have already incorporated Republican ideas into the Democrats health care legislation.

title: Team Effort Produces Two Medals for Sweden
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The temperature was certainly warm enough for cycling when the men lined up for Saturdays 30-kilometer pursuit cross-country ski race. So it was perhaps appropriate that the Swedish team took first and third place by deploying tactics normally used at the Tour de France.

title: From Pregnancy to the Olympic Ice in Under a Year
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Even after nearly 20 years of skating and traveling the world with his ice dance partner Isabelle Delobel, Olivier Schoenfelder was never expecting the phone call he received from her last winter.

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Big Push From Canada Is Not Panning Out
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Dean and Holly Pirozzini were prepared to wait in line for six hours at the Royal Canadian Mint pavilion on Saturday morning simply for the chance to touch an Olympic medal.

title: Weekend of Fun and Friends Between Battles on the Board
description: The highlight of the year for many players is Washingtons Birthday weekend, when four amateur team championships are held across the country.

title: Damon Moves to Tigers for a Year
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When the Detroit Tigers reached the 2006 World Series, three of their best players  Ivan Rodriguez, Kenny Rogers and Magglio Ordonez  had one thing in common. All were represented by the agent Scott Boras.

title: If Your Comments Were Like Health Care
description: then Id have to pay for them, more each year. But thats not the case, so I welcome your thoughts on my Sunday column, which explores what would happen if journalism were like health care. I got the idea from other parallel efforts, such as Jonathan Rauchs brilliant essay comparing health with airlines.

title: The Pulse: Critical Week Ahead for City School Reform
description: Chicago Public Schools controversial process of closing, consolidating and turning around schools will receive new scrutiny this week.

title: Ohno Wins Bronze and Sets Record
description: Updated | 11:13 p.m. Apolo Ohno won the bronze medal in the 1,000-meter short-track speedskating final Saturday night. It was his seventh Olympic medal, a record for an American athlete at the Winter Games.

title: Davis Is Again Denied Gold in the 1,500
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The 1,500 meters is designed to separate the king from his court, the distance a melding of speed, endurance and nerve that long-track speedskaters describe as the purest measure of ability.

title: McGrady Wins Over Fans, but Knicks Lose Game
description: It took Tracy McGrady just a few purposeful steps to earn an ovation, a few minutes to find his balance and one half of a basketball game to win the unadulterated adulation of a star-hungry fan base.

title: N.C.A.A. Ends Hearing About U.S.C. Infractions
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  The University of Southern Californias three-day hearing before the N.C.A.A.s committee on infractions ended Saturday night with little indication of what is ahead for the Trojans football and mens basketball programs.

title: Georgelle Hirliman, Writer in the Window, With Answers, Is Dead at 73
description: Q. Dear Writer in the Window: If life is a stage, why do we take it so seriously?

title: Poulter in Final, Awaiting Opponent
description: MARANA, Ariz.  When a nasty winter storm blew across the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club at Dove Mountain on Saturday, it was as if a bit of Scotland had descended upon the Sonoran Desert.

title: Ohno Stakes Claim as U.S. King of Winter
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  As Apolo Ohno skated slowly around the rink at Pacific Coliseum, he held both the American flag and seven fingers above his head.

title: Vows: Liz & Andrew
description: Elizabeth Rubincam and Andrew Naysmith met when they travelled to South Africa to visit their respective siblings, who were dating at the time and had since gotten married.

title: Tactical Tweaks for U.S.-Canada Hockey Game
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The coaches of Team Canada and Team USA offered a glimpse into some of the tactical gambits they will try ahead of their clash in the Group A mens hockey finale on Sunday at Canada Hockey Place.

title: For Figure Skating Favorite, a Familiar Rival
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  South Koreas Kim Yu-na, the gold-medal favorite in womens figure skating, had been in a pre-Olympic bubble for about two months before arriving here on Friday. She trained at a rink in Toronto, tuning out distractions and refusing all interview requests.

title: 2 Are Critically Injured in Bronx Fire
description: Two people were hospitalized with critical injuries after a fire in a Bronx apartment building Saturday evening.

title: How to Write an Incendiary Blog Post
description: Incoming | From Chris Clarke in The Boston Globe:

title: 50 Impressions, 50 Seconds
description: Video | Take his succinctness, please:

title: The Arts, From A to Z, at Hong Kong Festival
description: Hong Kong has a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to its arts scene, so when it puts on a festival, it sometimes overcompensates by throwing in everything including the kitchen sink. The lineup at this years Hong Kong Arts Festival, which starts on Thursday, Feb. 25, and runs through March 28, is a testament to that, but no matter  the upside is, there is something for everyone.

title: The Lineage of a View
description: The International Space Stations new cupola has windows reminiscent of Captain Nemos submarine and the Millenium Falcon.

title: Vernon Davis the Curler
description: The Olympics have kept us busy in the Times sports department. Andy Benoit of NFLTouchdown.com has kept the Fifth Down afloat during this period, and we thank him for that.

title: Februarys Poli-Book Best Sellers
description: Game Change, the 2008 campaign tell-all book by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin, takes over the No. 1 rank on our list of top political books, while Going Rogue by Sarah Palin slips to No. 5.

title: Inflation Perceptions
description: Ive recently put up several posts on disinflation, and was struck by how many of the comments were along the lines of Get real  the cost of everything like food and gas has gone way up over the past two years. So I thought Id look at the BLS average price data.

title: Democrats Target Independents in Colorado and Virginia
description: Democrats are ramping up their efforts to woo those fickle independent voters, beginning by deploying volunteers from the considerable Obama campaign army now known as Organizing for America.

title: The Case of Phil Hughes and the American Flag
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Its a mystery straight out of the Encyclopedia Brown series: The Case of the Random Flag. Or something like that. On Sunday morning, a security guard handed Phil Hughes a frame containing an American flag and a letter from Stephen T. Ayers, the Acting Architect of the Capitol. At the request of Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, the flag was flown over the Capitol on Hughess birthday in 2008, June 24. Hughes was grateful for the gift but wasnt quite sure of its origins.

title: Pakistan  Fashion Week
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Security for Lahore Fashion Week was, inevitably, tight.

title: Dan Feyer is the New A.C.P.T. Champion
description: Congratulations to Dan Feyer, the new king of crosswords. Two years ago, he won the C Division. Last year, he easily took the B. This year, he won it all, beating out Howard Barkin and Anne Erdmann on the big board.

title: Vancouver Worries About Too Much Revelry
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  As the Olympics have progressed and the warm and dry weather has continued, boisterous crowds have continued to grow late at night downtown. So much so that the Vancouver police are becoming alarmed.

title: Dutch Pull-Out From War Expected After Government Collapse
description: BERLIN  A day after his government collapsed, Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende said Sunday that he expected Dutch troops to come home from Afghanistan before the end of the year.

title: Two Stars Hope Teams Turn Things Around
description: Most BracketBusters games arent busting any brackets, arent adorning any marquees, arent even on television.

title: Bicoastal Dissonance at Unsurprising Writers Guild Awards
description: Despite being held simultaneously on both coasts to add drama, there were few surprises for statuette-counters at the Writers Guild Awards on Saturday night. Up in the Air, The Hurt Locker and The Cove, favorites all season long, won for best adapted screenplay, best original screenplay and best documentary, respectively, and the winners gave variations on the speeches theyve been giving all season long. In Los Angeles, Jason Reitman, of Up in the Air, thanked his father, Ivan; his co-writer, Sheldon Turner, thanked other writers. And The Hurt Locker writer Mark Boal thanked Kathryn Bigelow, the director, for believing in an unpopular project about an unpopular war. In New York, the Baggers pal Anthony Mackie rushed over from his curtain call at A Behanding in Spokane on Broadway to accept the award on Mr. Boals behalf, doing a not-very-convincing impression of him.

title: Military Bases as Wildlife Havens
description: In recent years, U.S. military lands have become safe areas for endangered species.

title: A Base for War Training, and Species Preservation
description: FORT STEWART, Ga.  Under crystalline winter skies, a light infantry unit headed for Iraq was practicing precision long-range shooting through a pall of smoke. But the fire generating the haze had nothing to do with the training exercise.

title: EMI Says Abbey Road Studios Not for Sale
description: After nearly a week of public outcry over reports that Abbey Road Studios in London was up for sale, its owner, the financially troubled British record label EMI, has finally spoken. In a statement issued Sunday, EMI denied that the studio was being put on the market but confirmed that it was seeking financial help to save it.

title: Mother of Top Canadian Figure Skater Joannie Rochette Dies
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Two days before the Canadian figure skater Joannie Rochette was to compete here on home soil and contend for an Olympic medal, her Olympics took a tragic turn. Her mother, Therese, died on Sunday in a hospital here, Skate Canada president Benoit Lavoie said. She was 55. The cause of death has not been announced.

title: Ski Cross Makes Its Debut
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The newest Winter Olympics sport, ski cross, made its debut Sunday at Cypress Mountain.

title: Miller Wins Gold in the Super Combined
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  During a United States ski team training camp last November in Colorado, Bode Miller spent an entire lunchtime finding fault with the way his teammates had skied that morning.

title: Live Analysis: United States vs. Canada
description: In-game analysis from United States-Canada hockey game at the Vancouver Games on Sunday night. Jeff Z. Klein and Jeffrey Marcus were ice-side in Vancouver. Richard Sandomir, who covers sports media and business for The Times, and Stu Hackel of The Timess Slap Shot blog offered commentary from New York.

title: Shutter Island Soars at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  The gamble worked: Shutter Island, yanked from the fall release schedule by a cost-cutting Paramount Pictures, arrived in theaters on Friday and was a strong No. 1 at the North American box office.

title: For Nats, Everythings Sunny With Strasburg on the Mound
description: VIERA, Fla.  This time of year, with workouts just beginning in Florida, optimism is as plentiful as palm trees. Every bad team knows what went wrong and has taken the right steps to correct it. Every crop of prospects oozes potential. Yet somehow, when you add up all the teams records at the end of the season, there are exactly as many wins as losses.

title: U.S. Commander Describes Marja Battle as First Salvo in Campaign
description: Gen. David H. Petraeus, the head of the United States Central Command, said Sunday that the battle being fought in the Taliban stronghold of Marja was the initial salvo in a military campaign that could last 12 to 18 months.

title: Vazquez and Posada Re-establish Connection
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The first time he played for the Yankees, Javier Vazquez made an instant connection with Jorge Posada. Both are natives of Puerto Rico and Vazquez, having never worked with a veteran catcher, loved pitching to Posada.

title: Repeating Modern Classics
description: Photos and reviews of revivals of "Ragtime," "A View From the Bridge" and "Present Laughter."

title: A Globalization Puzzle
description: Im devoting tomorrows class to the big decline in world trade that took place between the two world wars. Its a familiar proposition to international economists: globalization isnt an inexorable trend. In fact, it took until around 1970 before world goods markets were as closely integrated as they had been in 1913, and it wasnt until very recently that we returned to anything like Edwardian levels of capital-market integration.

title: After Outcry, EMI Says Abbey Road Isnt for Sale
description: After nearly a week of public protest over reports that Abbey Road Studios, the London recording complex made famous by the Beatles, had been put up for sale, its owner, the financially troubled British record company EMI, has finally spoken. In a statement issued Sunday morning, EMI denied that the studio was being put on the market but confirmed that it was seeking financial help to save it.

title: Indie-Rock on a Quest, With Woodwinds, Brass and Strings
description: Dirty Projectors 2005 album, The Getty Address, is far more a contemporary chamber opera than indie-rock. It uses woodwinds, brass, strings and orchestral percussion; its music has dissonances and complexities galore, and only fitfully settles into a steady beat. Lincoln Centers American Songbook series is a natural place for it, and on Friday night at the Allen Room, Dirty Projectors performed The Getty Address, backed by the chamber ensemble Alarm Will Sound. It was arranged for the concert by Matt Marks and conducted by Alan Pierson.

title: A Fresh Look at a Familiar Violin Concerto
description: During the two concerts that the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra presented at Avery Fisher Hall last week, all eyes were fixed on the orchestras music director, Yannick Nzet-Sguin, a strikingly gifted young Canadian conductor whose international career has lately assumed a meteoric velocity. But on Friday night, in the second of the orchestras New York events, the Russian violinist Viktoria Mullova proved equally worthy of consideration during an uneven but fascinating account of Brahmss Violin Concerto.

title: Lyrics Still Inspire Mistiness Even After All These Years
description: Once upon a time in America, a skinny blue-eyed crooner from Hoboken, N.J., sang the following words: Now in a cottage built of lilacs and laughter/I know the meaning of the words ever after/And Ill always see polka dots and moonbeams/When I kiss the pug-nosed dream.

title: Women Can Only Test the Hills
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Ski jumping and the related sport of Nordic combined are the only events at the Winter Games that bar women from competing. And yet before any man takes flight during competition, a woman has probably cleared the way.

title: An Erotic Encounter Further Charged by Voyeurism
description: Marguerite Durass strange, sinewy tale The Man Sitting in the Corridor begins with a man peering through an open door: Hes looking at a woman lying a few yards away on a path made of stones.

title: The Gangs All Here: Mimi, Rodolfo and Zeffirelli
description: Typically the Metropolitan Opera takes a fill-in-the-blanks approach to casting Puccinis Bohme. Both the opera and the Mets lavish 1981 Franco Zeffirelli production are so popular that audiences will come no matter who is singing.

title: Interplay of Antiquity With Some Modernity
description: For anyone interested in Japans distinctive musical culture, Music From Japan has been a valuable resource since 1975, presenting concerts and festivals of traditional and contemporary works, and maintaining a valuable archive and database devoted mostly to modern Japanese composers.

title: Could a Start-Up Competition Help Haiti?
description: Could a nation still lacking basic resources and infrastructure and still reeling from a devastating earthquake benefit from entrepreneurial education and cash grants for small businesses? Startup Weekend, a nonprofit organization based in Seattle, thinks so.

title: Men Dancing vs. Male Centrality
description: Before the 19th century ballet was dominated by men. The British Parliament, not known for balletomanic tendencies, canceled one session so that everyone could watch one such dieu, Gatan Vestris, and his no-less-phenomenal son Auguste, perform in 1781. Who knows? Male dancers could effect another takeover of the art; they may be doing so now. In many ballet performances today the male role is much more fully delivered than the female.

title: Blending Tea and Hearts
description: On the first page of the first chapter of her first novel, Major Pettigrews Last Stand, Helen Simonson invites her readers to experience love at first sight. A starchy retired British Army officer named Maj. Ernest Pettigrew has just learned of his brother Berties death. Distracted by grief, he happens to be wearing a red, flowery housecoat when he answers a ring at his front door. He opens the door and casts a tearful eye on the dignified, elegant, foreign-looking woman who will win his heart.

title: New CDs
description: JOANNA NEWSOM Have One on Me (Drag City)

title: Division and Its Discontents
description: Theres a narrative line that runs through arithmetic, but many of us missed it in the haze of long division and common denominators. Its the story of the quest for ever-more versatile numbers.

title: 17 Across: Bakery Fixture
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I was thinking of writing this post as if Ive just returned from the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in Brooklyn, but the fact is I received the puzzle Friday morning and am writing it before I leave. (Being a judge at the tournament, I didnt want to be distracted from my unofficial duties of hanging out until all hours of the night with the other constructors and contestants talking about puzzles and  and, well, Im sure we talk about other things, but nothings coming immediately to mind.)

title: Top Defense by Top Pair in Cromwell
description: The New England Knockout Team Regional in Cromwell, Conn., which ended last Monday, also had some pair events. The winners of the Friday Open Pairs were Art Brodsky of Huntington Station, N.Y., and Bob Heitzman of Suffern, N.Y. Over the two sessions they scored 70.25 percent and won by five and a half boards.

title: In Canada, an Artwork With Its Own Barkeeps
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  This city is not just temporary home to the Olympics, its a hotbed of conceptual art and conceptual artists. There are also a lot of bars here, some so crowded during the Games that people have been spilling out onto the streets. Fittingly, a new installation on the third floor of the Playwrights Theater Center on Granville Island, the touristy, artsy part of town, examines the subtle conceptual difference between drinking and drinking and between the bar as mere watering hole and as self-activating performance space.

title: Cheering Team USA on NBCs Olympics
description: Curling is a favorite Olympic guilty pleasure, but so is churling, a home game that consists of sneering at the triumphalism and bathos of NBCs coverage. (Hurling is its X Games equivalent.)

title: Film Honors All Over
description: Awards season is in full swing at home and abroad. The filmmakers of the Oscar hopefuls The Hurt Locker and Up in the Air got some practice giving acceptance speeches this weekend when they won awards from the Writers Guild of America and the British Academy of Film and Television Arts. On Saturday the Writers Guild honored Mark Boal for best original screenplay for The Hurt Locker, and Jason Reitman and Sheldon Turner for best adapted screenplay for Up in the Air, based on Walter Kirns novel. On Sunday the British Academy repeated those honors for both films. The Hurt Locker also won best film. MoNique and Christoph Waltz repeated their Golden Globe wins for best supporting roles at the Bafta awards. Up won the British prizes for best animated film and A Prophet for best foreign film. In other categories at the Writers Guild awards, ABCs Modern Family won for best new television series, and the playwright Edward Albee was honored with the Evelyn F. Burkey Award for contributions bringing honor and dignity to writers everywhere. ... At the 60th Berlin International Film Festival a Turkish-German drama with no soundtrack and a minimal plot, Honey, by Semih Kaplanoglu, above, won the Golden Bear for best picture, Reuters reported. The Silver Bear for best director went to Roman Polanski for The Ghost Writer. Other winners included Florin Serbans Romanian film If I Want to Whistle, I Whistle and How I Ended This Summer, a Russian film by Alexei Popogrebski.

title: Racy Memoir for the French National Library
description: The French National Library has bought itself a belated valentine in the form of manuscript pages by the hand of the worlds most famous lover, Giacomo Casanova, Reuters reported. The 3,700-page purchase includes Casanovas memoir, LHistoire de Ma Vie (The Story of My Life), below, which was thought to have been destroyed at the end of World War II; it was discovered in boxes that had been transferred to a bank safe in Leipzig, Germany, in 1945 a few days before Allied bombing raids. The library paid more than $9 million for the pages, which were being sold by the heirs of a German publisher who had acquired them in the 19th century. They were in good shape, Marie-Laure Prvost, curator of the Bibliothque Nationale de France, told Reuters TV. The work is expected to be exhibited in 2011. Casanova began documenting his sexual exploits in 1789 while working as a librarian, and continued to revise his stories until he died in 1798.

title: In the Wings
description: To celebrate the 80th birthday of the playwright Mara Irene Forns, the New York troupe Intar and the English department at New York University have put together a festival of readings of her plays, including Fefu and Her Friends, as well as lesser-known works like Dr. Kheal and Tango Palace. The readings will be presented at various theaters in New York City from March 25 to April 5. ... The Amoralists theater troupe has announced its 2010 Off Broadway season, which will include two plays written and directed by Derek Ahonen and a third from the Obie Award winner Adam Rapp, to run at Theater 80 St. Marks. Mr. Ahonens world premiere of Happy in the Poorhouse is set to run March 11 to April 5 and his Amerissiah is scheduled for June 3 to 27. The New York premiere of Mr. Rapps Ghosts in the Cottonwoods, which he is also directing, will run Nov. 11 through Dec. 5. Information at theatre80.org. ... Additional casting for the Broadway production of Lucy Prebbles play, Enron, has been announced. Joining the previously cast leads, Norbert Leo Butz and Stephen Kunken, will be Noah Weisberg, Rightor Doyle, Ian Kahn, Mary Stewart Sullivan, Madisyn Shipman and January LaVoy. Previews are to begin on April 8, with an opening on April 27 at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Classic Sting via the Royal Philharmonic
description: The British rocker Sting, left, and the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra are pairing up for a North American tour beginning this summer, the promoter Live Nation announced. The tour will feature Sting tunes like Fields of Gold as well as hits by his former band, the Police, including Roxanne and Every Breath You Take. Those songs will be arranged for the 54-piece orchestra, to be conducted by Steven Mercurio and accompanied by a quartet that includes a guitarist, a multipercussionist, another vocalist and a bassist. In an e-mail message on Sunday, Sting said he was inspired by a 2008 performance with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. It was both exciting and a bit daunting working up orchestral versions of some of my most successful songs, he wrote, adding, I certainly enjoyed the experience, as did the audience and most importantly so did the orchestra, who I believe were very relieved that they werent reduced to sawing whole notes behind a pop ballad. The tour will begin on June 2 in Vancouver and continue on to Denver, Los Angeles and the Ravinia Festival near Chicago. Additional dates in New York, Boston, Toronto and elsewhere are yet to be announced. Tickets go on sale March 8. Details are at livenation.com.

title: Owen Wilson Goes Woody Allen
description: Owen Wilson, top right, known mostly for his slacker characters in movies like Wedding Crashers and The Royal Tenenbaums, is taking on the king of neurotics: hes been cast in Woody Allens latest movie, Reuters reported. The films story line, characters and title are not being revealed, as is typical with Mr. Allens movies, but filming is set to begin this summer. In November, Frances first lady, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, bottom right, said she had also been cast in the movie, though Mr. Allens production company would not confirm that. Mr. Allens newest film, You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger, starring Antonio Banderas, Josh Brolin, Anthony Hopkins and Naomi Watts, is set for release in the fall.

title: Good Defenses Make Good Neighbors
description: It takes a special vision, both clear and cockeyed, to see the present as if it were the past. Half a century separates the two acts of Bruce Norriss Clybourne Park, a spiky and damningly insightful new comedy set in 1959 and 2009. In both parts of this production, which opened Sunday night at Playwrights Horizons, Mr. Norris is examining his subjects through the same merciless telescope, with a historians distance and an ethnographers detachment.

title: New Schools, to Train New Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: For Women, Redefining Marriage Material
description: Women have outpaced men in acquiring education for a few decades now, with 185 women earning college degrees at age 22 for every 100 men, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And more women are now employed because men are more likely to work in industries that are declining or cyclical. An essay by Don Peck in The Atlantic reported that in November nearly a fifth of all men between the ages of 25 and 54 did not have jobs, the highest figure since 1948.

title: Theater Talkback: Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood Answer Readers Questions
description: As an online companion piece to their Arts & Leisure discussion about political plays, The Timess theater critics answered readers questions about the spring season and other theatrical topics.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: On Radio, Experts Mix Fun With Games
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  When Maylin Hausch of Germany took the ice for the Olympic pairs short program, the briefs of her costume seemed to be made of tin foil.

title: For U.S.C. Football, the Squirming Begins
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  With the knot of his light purple tie loosened from his neck and the jacket from his stylish khaki suit long removed, Lane Kiffin left the University of Southern Californias hearing with the N.C.A.A.s committee on infractions.

title: For Chip Makers, the Next Battle Is in Smartphones
description: The semiconductor industry has long been a game for titans.

title: A Vision of Iceland as a Haven for Journalists
description: ICELAND, where the journalists run free.

title: How the G.O.P. Can Fix Health Care
description: In a bid to reopen the debate over health care reform, President Obama has arranged a televised bipartisan meeting this Thursday. Republican leaders in Congress have been invited to bring their best ideas for slowing the growth of health care expenditures and expanding the number of insured Americans. The Op-Ed editors asked five conservative thinkers to outline what they believe those ideas should be.

title: Unusually Talented College Basketball Coach Is Set for a Record
description: PHILADELPHIA  Along his road to the top of college basketballs career list for victories while coaching at Philadelphia University, Herb Magee has engaged bus drivers in games of Trivial Pursuit on long trips, bathed in beer after wins and been led onto the court in handcuffs by a police officer as a joke. He has had his mustache mimicked by fans, and he met his second wife, Geri, when she tended bar at the Yankee Doodle Inn.

title: How to Tame Inflation as the Chinese Spend More
description: In the Chinese year of the tiger, inflation is the beast to worry about. Rapid increases in bank loans could be spurring higher prices. But so could a decline in savings by Chinas fabled hoarders.

title: Mea Culpa, at Arms Length
description: Long before his public image became as badly dented as the Cadillac Escalade he was driving on Thanksgiving weekend, Tiger Woods wondered aloud about the appetite of the media.

title: For Job as Mets Starting Catcher, Caracas Will Have Been Worth It
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Josh Thole bought his fiance a box of Frosted Flakes, a jar of peanut butter and a loaf of bread, kissed her and walked out of the Best Western hotel in Caracas, Venezuela, for a three-day trip.

title: Lawmakers Consider an Animal Abuse Registry
description: SAN FRANCISCO  California may soon place animal abusers on the same level as sex offenders by listing them in an online registry, complete with their home addresses and places of employment.

title: Honoring Citizen Journalists
description: Anonymity is a privilege in journalism extended to sources and sometimes even to award winners.

title: Global Crisis Leads I.M.F. Experts to Rethink Long-Held Ideas
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund has long preached the virtues of keeping inflation low and allowing money to flow freely across international boundaries. But two recent research papers by economists at the fund have questioned the soundness of that advice, arguing that slightly higher inflation and restrictions on capital flows can sometimes help buffer countries from financial turmoil.

title: 2 Men Charged in Texas Church Fire
description: Two men were charged Sunday morning with setting fire to a church in east Texas and federal authorities said the men may face charges in nine other church fires.

title: Niger Junta Gives Assurances on Democracy Plans
description: NIAMEY, Niger  The military junta that deposed Nigers longtime leader last week sought to assure visiting diplomatic delegations on Sunday that it would soon restore democracy, as more signs emerged that the violent overthrow had been widely welcomed in this impoverished West African desert nation.

title: Reasons for Miller to Smile, but Not for Him to Change
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  What has long mattered most to Bode Miller is living and skiing his way. This was not negotiable, and even now in this sunlit place, as even his family members speak of redemption, and with Miller possessing everything a normal ski racer could crave, he insists that it is much more about the method than the medals.

title: Obama Will Propose Federal Oversight of Rate Increases
description: President Obama will propose on Monday giving the federal government new power to block excessive rate increases by health insurance companies, as he rolls out comprehensive legislation to revamp the nations health care system, White House officials said.

title: Enquiring Minds
description: This year, for the first time in its colorful history, The National Enquirer will be in the running for a Pulitzer Prize.

title: Obama to Urge Oversight of Insurers Rate Increases
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will propose on Monday giving the federal government new power to block excessive rate increases by health insurance companies, as he rolls out comprehensive legislation to revamp the nations health care system, White House officials said Sunday.

title: Hacking Inquiry Puts Chinas Elite in New Light
description: SHANGHAI  With its sterling reputation and its scientific bent, Shanghai Jiaotong University has the feel of an Ivy League institution.

title: Afghans Voice Their Fears Amid Marja Campaign
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  Since the American-led offensive into the last large Taliban enclave in Helmand Province began nine days ago, local Afghans have faced a dangerous and uncertain world.

title: A Model of Harmony Is Found in a Flashpoint City for Iraqi Sectarian Fighting
description: SAMARRA, Iraq  Busloads of Iranian pilgrims arrive every day at this citys Askariya Shrine, one of Shiite Islams holiest places, which was badly damaged by a bombing four years ago that prompted reprisal killings and pushed the country to the brink of civil war.

title: Gay Soldiers Dont Cause Disruption, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  A comprehensive new study on foreign militaries that have made transitions to allowing openly gay service members concludes that a speedy implementation of the change is not disruptive. The finding is in direct opposition to the stated views of Pentagon leaders, who say repealing a ban on openly gay men and women in the United States armed forces should take a year or more.

title: An Astor Juror Says Her Fear Dictated Vote
description: A holdout juror in the trial of Brooke Astors son has told defense lawyers that she voted to convict him and an estate lawyer for crimes she did not believe they committed out of fear for her safety.

title: Michaels in the Studio: Unfamiliar, but Not a First
description: Al Michaelss best-known Olympic experience  calling the Miracle on Ice victory at the Winter Games 30 years ago Monday  occurred through a process of elimination.

title: Heres the Story of a Lovely Lady...
description: Tonight "The Brady Bunch" alum and Internet entrepreneur Florence Henderson is hosting "Broadway Backwards 5." The annual cabaret show at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, which benefits Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS and The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center, features Broadway stars singing songs originally written for the opposite gender, with often hilarious results. Go to listen to Gary Beach, Mario Cantone, Len Cariou, Ral Esparza, Tony Goldwyn, Ann Harada, Aaron Lazar, Michele Lee, Julia Murney, Tonya Pinkins, Lee Roy Reams, Lea Salonga, Douglas Sills, Bruce Vilanch and more. The curtain rises at 8 p.m.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the impact of eviction on low-income black women, often single mothers, misstated, in some editions, the name of a company that is familiar on Milwaukees impoverished North Side. It is Eagle Moving, not Eagle Movers.

title: After Skating, a Unique Olympic Event: Crying
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  For sheer spectacle, the Olympics offer the opening ceremony, the closing ceremony and dozens of medal ceremonies in between. For sheer awkwardness, they offer the kiss-and-cry area.

title: Riding a Bus Into South Africa's Future
description: A new rapid transport system exposes lingering divisions in a city where much is seen through the prism of race.

title: A History of Streep
description: Images from the varied film roles of Meryl Streep.

title: In Their Words
description: If you missed Susie Essman's recent stint at Carolines on Broadway tonight you have another chance to see the stand-up queen in action. Ms. Essman, who is best known for playing Susie Green, Jeff Garlin's obscene, "perpetually scolding wife" on "Curb Your Enthusiasm," will be appearing tonight as part of "Celebrity Autobiography: In Their Own Words." The comedy evening, which features actors reading verbatim from other actors' memoirs, will also include performances by Craig Bierko, Mario Cantone, Rachel Dratch, Eugene Pack, Dayle Reyfel, Michael Riedel, Brooke Shields, Sherri Shepherd, Alan Zweibel and more.

title: Feel Your Shame
description: "Sexy, Clean, Cool, Fun, Healthy, Young, Large Underpants." Sarah Haskin's brilliant online videos "Target Women" on current.com hilariously dissect the way marketers advertise to women. "So much of women's advertising these days is built around the construct of a new, modern superwoman who can work, run the household, raise kids, do yoga and still be a sexbot at home," Ms. Haskins recently told Time Out. "No one can do all those things perfectly  but the fear that you're slipping at any of these roles is what advertisers target." You can hear more insights from Ms. Haskins and others tonight at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe during the program "That Not-So-Fresh Feeling: Marketing Embarrassing Products to Women." The panel discussion presented by DoubleX, Slate's section for women, will also feature Susan Kim, author of "Flow," and Allison Silverman, a former executive producer of "The Colbert Report." Hanna Rosin, the co-editor of DoubleX and contributing editor at The Atlantic Monthly, will serve as moderator at the event, which begins at 7 p.m.

title: A Roller Coaster Chase for a Cure
description: PHILADELPHIA  His patient, a spunky Italian-American woman in her 60s, was waiting in an exam room down the hall for the answer: Was the experimental drug stopping her deadly skin cancer?

title: Persistent Unemployment, Without Lingering Pain
description: CDIZ, Spain  Beyond its pink-hued Atlantic light and the distinction of being the oldest city in Europe, this Andalusian outpost is best known for two things: its famous carnival, which wraps up Monday after two raucous weeks, and its chronic unemployment.

title: A Patient, a Pioneer
description: After surgeries and chemotherapies failed, the last hope for Sam Spero, a cancer patient, is an experimental drug with high promise. The first in a series.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 10 about a White House campaign against childhood obesity described incorrectly programs that affect producers of high fructose corn syrup, a sweetener. Farm programs subsidize the production of corn, and other programs also affect the supply and the cost of corn, sugar and related commodities. But the Agriculture Department itself does not directly subsidize high fructose corn syrup.

title: Dutch Gold Is Latest Disappointment for Canada
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The band at the Richmond Olympic Oval launched into a brassy rendition of pop musics victory anthem and pretty soon many in the crowd joyfully joined in, singing, We are the champions  my friends. And well keep on fighting  till the end. ...

title: A Bus System Reopens Rifts in South Africa
description: SOWETO, South Africa  Since the days of apartheid, when blacks were required to live in distant townships like this, Susan Hanong, a 67-year-old maid, has commuted to the wealthy northern suburbs of Johannesburg, one of the spectral figures trudging through darkened streets on long trips to wash white peoples clothes and mind their children.

title: With the Senate Set to Vote on Jobs Bill, Governors Say They Still Need Assistance
description: WASHINGTON  With the Senate poised to take a first test vote on a jobs bill, governors said Sunday that they still needed assistance from the federal government but urged Congress to focus more on creating jobs in the private sector.

title: Oil Servicer to Buy Rival in $11 Billion Agreement
description: Schlumberger, the giant oilfield-services company, announced on Sunday that it would acquire Smith International in an all-stock transaction valued at $45.84 a share.

title: Textbooks That Professors Can Rewrite Digitally
description: Readers can modify content on the Web, so why not in books?

title: Momentum of Hit on Jagr Propels Russia to a Victory
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It will go down as one of the most memorable plays in Olympic hockey history, a thunderous mid-ice collision in which one superstar leveled another.

title: Climate Change
description: Yvo de Boers resignation on Thursday after nearly four tumultuous years as chief steward of the United Nations climate change negotiations has deepened a sense of pessimism about whether the world can ever get its act together on global warming. Mr. de Boer was plainly exhausted by endless bickering among nations and frustrated by the failure of Decembers talks in Copenhagen to deliver the prize he had worked so hard for: a legally binding treaty committing nations to mandatory reductions in greenhouse gases.

title: Accounts, People and Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: A Campaign to Leaven the Mood
description: ALMOST 75 years ago, the fashion editor Diana Vreeland began captivating, puzzling and amusing a Depression-weary nation with a column in Harpers Bazaar magazine called Why Dont You ...  She offered suggestions that were breezy  Why dont you tie black tulle bows on your wrists?  or profligate  Why dont you turn your old ermine coat into a bathrobe?

title: Rochette's Mother Dies
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Just hours after learning that her mother had died of a heart attack here, the Canadian figure skater Joannie Rochette was on the practice ice Sunday. In front of the near-empty stands at the Pacific Coliseum, Rochette  one of the favorites to win an Olympic medal  was sniffling as she warmed up, then ran through her short program, hitting jump after jump. Her father, Normand, was there to watch her and wiped tears through the practice.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include the Case-Shiller home price index for December and the Conference Boards consumer confidence index for February (Tuesday); new-home sales for January (Wednesday); durable goods orders for January (Thursday); and the revised fourth-quarter gross domestic product, the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for February and existing-home sales for January (Friday).

title: Waking Its Neighbors, U.S. Upsets Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  With a hard-earned, thrilling victory Sunday, the United States surprised Canada, both the hockey team and the nation.

title: Limited Share-a-Cab Test to Begin Soon
description: Share a cab, stranger?

title: An Entertaining and Bloody Debut for Ski Cross
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  When ski cross made its Olympic debut Sunday, competitors careened downhill, four men and eight skis jumping and turning at one time.

title: Shuttles Mission Ends Smoothly
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Endeavour arrived home late Sunday, dropping out of a partly cloudy night sky to a smooth touchdown, leaving the International Space Station behind in orbit with a new life support module and a bay window observation deck.

title: Knicks Newcomers Could Bring Buzz Back to Garden
description: Tracy McGrady should have been sore Sunday. Sore, fatigued, creaky, something that suggested overexertion in the line of duty. There had to be a price to pay for 32 minutes of inspiration after 12 months of relative inactivity.

title: Open the Door
description: Victims of employment discrimination are increasingly finding the courthouse door closed, as conservative judges twist the law to throw out civil rights suits on technicalities. The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in a discrimination case that African-American applicants to the Chicago Fire Department won on the merits only to have the suit thrown out on the ground that they had complained too late.

title: Failing Grade
description: At least one in five adult workers in New York City lacks a high school diploma. New York State has the highest failure rate for adults who want to get an equivalent credential by taking the General Educational Development Test, or G.E.D. For the sake of these workers  and New Yorks economy  the city and state need to work together to rebuild the failing system that is supposed to prepare people for the G.E.D.

title: Above the Past
description: From time to time, New Yorkers are reminded of the age of this city and the way the past penetrates the present. You see it in the grid of streets, the fabric of buildings  especially the oldest buildings that, for a moment, seem to loom out of some distant year and then recede into the light of the day youre rushing through.

title: A Second Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Stamps in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece and the Banks: What Went Wrong?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bankruptcy Boys
description: O.K., the beast is starving. Now what? Thats the question confronting Republicans. But theyre refusing to answer, or even to engage in any serious discussion about what to do.

title: Networks Wary of Apples Push to Cut Show Prices
description: If Apple cut the price of each TV episode in half  to 99 cents, from $1.99  would sales on iTunes increase enough to offset the price drop?

title: Nationals Strasburg Resumes Work of Living Up to Expectations
description: VIERA, Fla.  Five pitchers were throwing in the bullpen by the Space Coast Stadium practice fields at 10:45 on Sunday morning. It was Jim Rigglemans job to watch them all, to ignore the magnetic pull toward the one in the middle.

title: A New Exit to Space Readies for Business
description: UPHAM, N.M.

title: A Protein That Fuels Cancer, and a Drug to Fight It
description: The Cancer

title: Selling a Celebrity Look
description: The paparazzi tracked down Angelina Jolie and four of her children in Venice last week, snapping photos of them eating ice cream. Her fans analyzed the photos, looking for the presence of Brad Pitt, at her new blond highlights and for clues to what she was wearing.

title: For Teenagers, Messaging on the Go
description: Sending text messages from cellphones has shot past instant messaging from computers as a way for teens to communicate, according to Mediamark Research and Intelligence, a market research company.

title: Topalov Closes In on Linares Title
Toyota Cited $100 Million Savings After Limiting Recall
description: Toyota estimated that it saved $100 million by negotiating with regulators for a limited recall of 2007 Toyota Camry and Lexus ES models for sudden acceleration, the same problem that has since prompted it to recall millions of cars, documents turned over to a Congressional committee showed Sunday.

title: Obama to Propose New Reading and Math Standards
description: WASHINGTON  In a proposed change to the No Child Left Behind law, the Obama administration would require states to adopt new academic standards to qualify for federal money from a $14 billion program that concentrates on impoverished students, the White House said Sunday.

title: Tough Day for a Land Where Hockey Is a Religion
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The third game on what the Canadians were calling Super Sunday  a three-course menu of outstanding hockey matchups  originally seemed fated to be watched mostly by night owls and insomniacs. It did not start until midnight Eastern time, and it was between Finland and Sweden, two teams that had flown a bit under the radar here, overshadowed by the Russians and the Canadians.

title: Showcase: Leisure as a National Mirror
description: We always recommend using the Full Screen feature to view photographs on Lens. But the work of Simon Roberts practically demands you do so. The button is above, to the right of the slide counter.

title: Trial in Agents Killing Is Marked by Tensions
description: After about four weeks of testimony from nearly 40 witnesses, the trial of the personal assistant accused of murdering her boss, Linda S. Stein, a well-known real-estate agent who once managed the Ramones, is poised to go to the jury by Monday or Tuesday.

title: On Avenue A, a Quirky Slice of Faux Frontier Past
description: Somewhere among the stuffed animals and fire logs, the bellows, copper kettles, hatchets and adzes, the powder horn, horse skull, snowshoes, sleds, razor strop, ox-yoke chandelier and crank-operated washing machine are Rob Schleifers 21st-century necessities.

title: Report Seeks Sole Agency to Rebuild War Zones
description: The government agency responsible for monitoring American reconstruction work in Iraq has proposed the creation of a single organization to oversee future rebuilding to avoid the fraud and waste that have marred this work in the past.

title: Sam D. Hamilton, Wildlife Service Director, Is Dead at 54
description: Sam D. Hamilton, who turned a Southern youths love of fish and waterfowl into a 30-year career with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, becoming the services director last year, died Saturday on a ski trip in Colorado. He was 54.

title: Panorama: A Cabin in Manhattan
description: Rob Schleifer turned his Manhattan apartment into a rustic cabin.

title: ATP Receives  Boost From a Beer Sponsor
description: The ATP will announce Monday that Corona Extra will become the new premier sponsor for the ATP World Tour, filling a vacancy created when Mercedes-Benz let its deal with the mens tennis tour expire at the end of 2008.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Ice Dancing Tilts Toward North America
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  With only one segment of the ice dancing competition left at these Olympics, three North American teams find themselves in an unprecedented position: all are in reach of a medal  with some even close to the gold.

title: Readers Digest and Life in These United States
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: In Barajas, Mets Buy Some Time
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets were still waiting for Rod Barajas to arrive at camp Sunday and take his place as their primary catcher.

title: Citys New Plan on Affordable Housing: Build Less, Preserve More
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has changed the blueprint of his affordable housing plan to preserve more such homes but build fewer of them, a shift that nonetheless will still cost the city $1 billion more than originally anticipated.

title: This Time, Poulter Lets His Game Speak Boldly
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Up until now, Ian Poulters trademarks have been bold outfits, brash statements and brazen behavior. To all those, British golf hero can be added. On a cool Sunday in the all-England final of the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship, Poulter took his countryman Paul Casey down early and never let him up, winning by 4 and 2 and further fueling a British golf surge.

title: Word of the Day | truncate
description: truncate\trN-kat, trn-\ verb

title: Paterson, Before Meeting Obama, Hones Message
description: WASHINGTON  Arnold Schwarzenegger bounded over to David A. Paterson and placed a reassuring hand on his shoulder.

title: Citys Public Hospitals Fear Huge Loss in Subsidies
description: The citys public hospital system, the largest in the nation, is facing a fiscal crisis because New York State is threatening to cut its financing for the care of poor patients at a time when the number of uninsured patients has soared, city officials said Sunday.

title: After Years of Poor Conditions, a Night of Sudden Repairs
description: There was trouble at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Rehabs long before a rat ate Chi-Chi the canary.

title: Hit and Run in Brooklyn Leaves One Brain-Dead
description: An employee of the mayors office was declared brain-dead on Sunday morning after she and another woman were struck by a hit-and-run driver while crossing Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Lottery Numbers
China Car Dealer Zhongsheng Said to Near I.P.O.
description: Zhongsheng Group Holdings, a Chinese automobile dealer, today started testing demand for a Hong Kong initial public offering that could raise as much as $1 billion, three people with knowledge of the planned sale told Bloomberg News.

title: Computer Engineer Barbie
description: WHO chose Barbies new career?

title: News Quiz | February 22, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Carpetbagger: Oscar Fashion 101
description: Melena Ryzik travels coast to coast to peek inside the world of Oscar fashion.

title: Bharti Said to Line Up $9 Billion for Zain Africa
description: Bharti Airtel of India has lined up $9 billion in loans from foreign and local banks for its planned acquisition of the African assets of Kuwaits Zain, The Economic Times reported on Monday.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day, Feb. 21
description: What was billed as Super Sunday in Canada turned out to be a day for Americans to celebrate.

title: Selling a Celebrity Look With a Click
description: The paparazzi tracked down Angelina Jolie and four of her children in Venice last week, snapping photos of them eating ice cream. Her fans analyzed the photos, looking for the presence of Brad Pitt, at her new blond highlights and for clues to what she was wearing.

title: Germanys Lange Secures Fourth Bobsled Gold
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Andre Lange of Germany became the most decorated bobsled pilot in Olympic history, winning his fourth gold medal in the two-man event Sunday at the Whistler Sliding Centre.

title: NATO Airstrike Kills Afghan Civilians
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An airstrike launched Sunday by United States Special Forces helicopters against what international troops believed to be a group of insurgents ended up killing as many as 27 civilians in the worst such case since at least September, Afghan officials said Monday.

title: Schlumberger Buying Smith in $11 Billion Deal
description: Schlumberger, the giant oilfield-services company, announced on Sunday that it would acquire Smith International in an all-stock transaction valued at $45.84 a share, Mary Williams Walsh reports in The New York Times.

title: 2 Japanese Banks May Call Off Deal, Report Says
description: A plan to merge two Japanese banks backed by American investors is on the rocks, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Soros: Greece Not The Only Test for Eurozone
description: The euro zone, while it may succeed in saving Greece, faces far larger problems because of more fundamental flaws, George Soros, the hedge fund billionaire, writes  Monday in The Financial Times.

title: Dai-ichi Mutual Life Plans $11.7 Billion I.P.O.
description: Dai-ichi Mutual Life Insurance, Japans second-largest life insurer, said it would sell about 1.07 trillion yen ($11.7 billion) of shares in the countrys largest initial public offering in more than a decade, Reuters reported.

title: How Important Is Your Spiritual Life?
description: Op-Ed Columnist Charles Blow writes that, according to two new reports, many young adults seem to be moving away from organized religion while simultaneously trying desperately to connect with their spirituality. Does this describe you?

title: Ireland Pushes Back Bad Bank Deadline
description: Ireland will transfer the first loans to the National Asset Management Agency, a bad bank, by the end of March, missing its latest deadline of late February, Finance Minister Brian Lenihan said Monday.

title: Chinas Stock Market Struggles
description: Mainland Chinas stock market, open for the first time since the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday, slipped on Monday, while markets elsewhere in the region rallied as investors digested the impact of recent moves by the United States and Chinese central banks, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: R.B.S. Chief Is Said to Forgo Bonus
description: Royal Bank of Scotlands chief, Stephen Hester, intends to decline his bonus for 2009, making him the third major British banking executive to do so, a person with knowledge of the matter told The Associated Press on Sunday.

title: British Premier Struggles to Repaint Blotched Image
description: LONDON  Can anything be done about Prime Minister Gordon Browns personality problem?

title: Reliance Said to Bid $14.5 Billion for Lyondell
description: Reliance Industries, owner of the worlds largest oil-refining complex, raised its offer for the bankrupt LyondellBasell Industries to about $14.5 billion, two people with knowledge of the offer told Bloomberg News.

title: Hedge Funds Bet on Greek Debt Default
description: Hedge funds have increased their bets this month on Greeces economic woes by shorting its bonds or buying default protection, although anecdotal evidence suggests some have cashed in after recent gains, Reuters reported.

title: Nathaniel Rothschild Calls for Ban on Sovereign Default Swaps
description: Nathaniel Rothschild, the heir of the British branch of the family and former co-chairman of Atticus Capital, told Les Echos that he thought credit default swaps, or C.D.S.s, for sovereign debt should be banned.

title: In Practice, Stock Formulas Werent Perfect
description: A quant may sound like the name of a science fiction creature, but it refers to a class of human beings who came to dominate global financial markets during the past decade, The New York Timess Harry Hurt III writes.

title: After Outcry, EMI Says Abbey Road Isnt for Sale
description: After nearly a week of public protest over reports that Abbey Road Studios, the London recording complex made famous by the Beatles, had been put up for sale, its owner, the financially troubled British record company EMI, has finally spoken.

title: Ex-Treasury Secretaries Back Volcker Rule
description: Five former Treasury secretaries urged Congress on Sunday to bar banks that receive federal support from engaging in speculative activity unrelated to basic bank services, Reuters reported.

title: Editorial: Bringing Back the Fixers
description: New York Citys freshly elected comptroller, John Liu, announced this week what he called major reforms in the way the citys pension fund works. He offered several good ideas, particularly his decision not to accept political contributions from anybody doing business with the citys $100 billion pension fund, The New York Timess editorial board says. But, The Times argues, one of his major reforms is a worrying step backward.

title: Iran to Build More Enrichment Plants
description: PARIS  Iran will build 10 more nuclear-fuel enrichment plants  two within the next year  and has identified close to 20 sites for such facilities, a senior Iranian official said Monday.

title: Orange and T-Mobile Deal Said to Near Approval
description: European regulators are set to approve a plan to combine France Telecoms Orange and Deutsche Telekoms T-Mobile as early as this week, creating Britains largest mobile operator, newspapers reported.

title: Dropped Eaves
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared the gems they have overheard.

title: BlackRock Said to Plan Asian Hedge Fund
description: BlackRock is adding to Asian offerings with plans to start a a hedge fund to trade corporate bonds in the region, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Candid Photos From Auschwitz on Display in Rome
description: Photographs of men and women lying in the sun, amusing themselves in front of a camera, having lunch outside in shirtsleeves. Nothing shocking there. But these images were taken at Auschwitz-Birkenau, while thousands were dying in the notorious German death camp.

title: Gender Trade-Offs
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: 2 Veteran Fund Managers Said to Team Up
description: Stanley Fink, the former chief executive of Man Group, and the American hedge fund manager Larry Hite are teaming up to start a new fund, The Financial Times reported.

title: Citi Says Europes Banks May Need $327 Billion Yearly
description: Twenty-four European banks may need to issue about 240 billion euros ($327 billion) annually for the next three years to fund existing and new businesses, as well as to meet the new Basel stable funding requirements, Citigroup said.

title: Bryant McKinnie Had No Business Being in Pro Bowl
description: After being booted from the N.F.C. Pro Bowl squad for skipping most of the team practices and obligations, Vikings left tackle Bryant McKinnie has been ordered to reimburse the N.F.L. $4,285 for expenses in Miami that week. He also forfeited his $22,500 game check.

title: Why So Many Terrorists Are Engineers
description: Todays idea: From the underwear bomber to Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, students of engineering or applied science become terrorists because they have a greater intolerance of uncertainty, an Israeli analyst argues.

title: I.M.F. Questions Freedom of Capital Flows
description: The International Monetary Fund has long preached the virtues of keeping inflation low and allowing money to flow freely across international boundaries. But two recent research papers by economists at the fund have questioned the soundness of that advice, arguing that slightly higher inflation and restrictions on capital flows can sometimes help buffer countries from financial turmoil, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Congress Returns to Confront Jobs Bill
description: Congress returns from a blizzard-lengthened two-week break Monday, and the will Senate immediately face a crucial test vote on a stripped-down jobs measure.

title: Government Is Broken
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Speed Read for Monday, Feb. 22
description: Here are some highlights from Mondays edition of The New York Times:

title: Crisis Over, Geithner Is Going Vogue
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, after helping to steer the United States through its worst economic crisis in decades, is seeing his role in Washington clipped because of popular upset at the financial bailout, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Randy Moss Already Looking Beyond Patriots
description: Patriots wide receiver Randy Moss rarely speaks to the news media. When he does, he tends to choose honesty or discretion. At former Patriot Heath Evanss charity softball event in Jupiter, Fla., Moss talked with reporters about the final year of his contract in 2010.

title: Submit Your Funny Caption
description: Uniform? | Tell us whats going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned images were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Goldman Said to Take New Steps to Polish Image
description: On Wall Street, Goldman Sachs is as feared and envied as ever. But in mainstream America, the firms image remains mired in loathing and disdain  and that apparently is starting to worry firm insiders and clients.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Says 1990 Bill Could Have Prevented Toyota Problems
description: Almost 20 years ago, Congress missed a chance to require automakers to prevent computer malfunctions that could cause problems such as unintended acceleration.

title: Finding Love on Metro-North, and Other Stories
description: This month, the Metro-North Railroad, best known for spiriting New York suburbanites on their daily quests, presented an additional service: dating tips.

title: Media Equation: Despite Apology, Its Still Tiger Rules
description: In this Mondays Media Equation column, David Carr takes a look at the Tiger Woods apology drama and finds that the ultimately uncomfortable relationship between the golf superstar and the media continues in full force. Why do they have to know everything? a 14-year-old Tiger asked a reporter many years ago. Why indeed, Mr. Carr asks?

title: Sampler: Take a Gun to a National Park, and More People Dial 211 for Help
description: A California Animal Abuser Registry | A proposal to create an online registry of animal abusers, complete with home addresses and places of work, was introduced last week in the State Senate by Dean Florez, the majority leader. It would be the first of its kind in the country. We know theres a link between those who abuse animals and those who perform other forms of violence, said Stephan Otto, the director of legislative affairs of the Animal Legal Defense Fund, a group that helped to draft the bill. Presumably if were able to track animal abusers and be able to know where they live, there will be less opportunity where those vulnerable to them would be near them. [The New York Times]

title: European Press Links Israelis to Dubai Killing
description: Updated, 4:19 p.m. | As Israels foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, prepared to meet his British and Irish counterparts on Monday, press reports from Britain and Germany linked Israelis to the assassination of a Hamas official in Dubai last month.

title: Video: Oscar Fashion 101
Arming Both Sides: The Perils of Ammunition Leakage in the Afghan War
description: In a previous post, and an article last year, The New York Times examined the question of how Taliban fighters obtain their small-arms ammunition. The limited data available  gleaned from captured Taliban weapons and magazines, or from spent casings collected from Taliban firing positions after firefights  pointed to Afghan security forces as a significant source.

title: Im a Poet
description: And other unexpected stuff, in this profile.

title: Man Beating Mother With Skillet Is Killed by Police
description: Updated, 1:35 p.m. | Police officers in the Bronx burst in on a man who was beating his mother with a frying pan Sunday night and fatally shot him, the police said.

title: Philly Papers One Year Into Bankruptcy Fight
description: For the newspapers of Phildelphia, Monday is a not-so-happy anniversary, one year after The Daily News, The Inquirer and philly.com all asked for bankruptcy protection.

title: Sitting Pretty
description: Before he was the creative director and founder of Acne, Jonny Johansson knocked around as a musician. So its no surprise that the Swedish fashion labels first furniture collection takes its cues from the place where music and fashion meet: the remix. Take the Nya Berlin, a 1920s sofa designed for that citys Swedish embassy by the modernist Carl Malmsten. Johansson stretched and contorted the sofas no-nonsense curves to arrive at five new variations, built in the south of Sweden and upholstered in cupcake shades of denim. Johansson says of his latest release: I have all these architect and designer friends who are inspired by fashion. I thought, Why not look at it the other way around?

title: Yankees Add Chan Ho Park to Bullpen
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One of my favorite quotations from last season came from the player who is the newest Yankee. Pitching for the first time in a month, Chan Ho Park retired Manny Ramirez, Matt Kemp and Casey Blake in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series at Dodger Stadium. Asked afterward when the last time he pitched that well was, Park replied, An hour and 20 minutes ago.

title: The Dangers of Baby Walkers
description: Q.

title: The Oil Bubble Controversy, Revisited
description: One of the curious things about economic debate in the later Bush years was the conviction among many on the right that there wasnt a bubble in housing, but that there was one in oil.

title: The Early Word: Another Health Care Plan
description: President Obama plans to offer up his own health care proposal on Monday, a few days ahead of the health care summit hes hosting on Thursday, which will be televised. Details of the presidents proposal will be posted online at WhiteHouse.gov at 10 a.m.

title: Wall Street Exchanges Turn Lower in Closing Minutes
description: Volatility returned to Wall Street on Monday, ending a four-day winning streak for stocks, as worries over the energy sector overshadowed hopes that banks would continue to bring in generous profits.

title: In Washington, Paterson Expresses Confidence
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger bounded over to David A. Paterson and placed a reassuring hand on his shoulder.

title: Hotel Trappings Without the Hotel
description: One of the big trends in peddling products is known as experiential marketing  that is, giving a consumer an experience a company can brand as its own.

title: Cold Comfort for Hurt Locker in London
description: The Baftas, a.k.a. the British Oscars, should provide some cold comfort to awards-season watchers. On the one hand, The Hurt Locker, this years hard-charging underdog, swept the prizes on Sunday, picking up six of its eight races, including best picture, best director and best original screenplay. On the other, the British cinephiles have predicted the eventual best picture Oscar winner only three times in the nine years since their little show has been held before the Academy Awards. So as Harvey Weinstein would like to remind you, it aint over yet for Inglourious Basterds (no matter how seemingly unlikely).

title: White House Preparing to Roll Out New Health Plan
description: All eyes will be on the White House this morning as officials prepare to roll out President Obamas own comprehensive health care proposal, which is be posted on the White House Web site.

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide attack on a military vehicle in the Swat Valley has killed at least six people, including two soldiers, according to a Pakistani security official and local news outlets.

title: After Genzymes Stumbles, a Struggle for Its Control
description: In the biotechnology business, where executives or even entire companies can come and go in an instant, Henri A. Termeer has been a constant.

title: Former Top Generals Detained in Turkish Coup Inquiry
description: ISTANBUL  In one of the toughest actions against the powerful Turkish military in the history of modern Turkey, the police detained three of the countrys highest-ranking former generals on Monday as part of a vast investigation into a shadowy ultranationalist movement accused of planning to overthrow the Islamist-inspired government.

title: Airgas Rejects Air Products Tender Offer
description: Updated Includes Air Products response.Airgas on Monday formally rejected (PDF) Air Products and Chemicals tender offer, setting the stage for a monthslong battle for control of the producer of industrial packaged gas.

title: Make Science-Fiction Movies More Scientific, Says Scientist
description: Those preposterously unscientific moments in science-fiction movies  laser guns that emit visible beams, spaceships that explode in flames, pretty much anything that happened in The Day After Tomorrow  that disrupt our glimpses into the future could soon be a thing of the past if a professor at Emory University has his way.

title: Ask Chuck Scarborough
description: This week, the Emmy award-winning anchor and correspondent Chuck Scarborough will be responding to readers questions about his career as an author and broadcast journalist, his job as co-anchor of New York Nightly News at 7 P.M., and other related matters.

title: The Morning Skate: U.S.-Canada a Tremendously Tremendous Game
description: It is hard to imagine that there have ever been two better consecutive games of international hockey than the first two games Sunday at the Vancouver Games.

title: Icahn Seeks 4 Seats on Genzyme Board
description: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn is seeking a seat for himself and three associates on the board of Genzyme, posing a new challenge to the management of the embattled biotechnology company, The New York Timess Andrew Pollack reports.

title: House Panel Says Toyota Misled Public on Safety
description: WASHINGTON  Leading Democrats on the House Energy and Commerce Committee said Monday that Toyota relied on a flawed study in dismissing the notion that computer issues could be at fault for sticking accelerator pedals, and then made misleading statements about the repairs.

title: Four Dead in Queens Murder-Suicide, Police Say
description: A family of four were found dead with gunshot wounds to the head at a home in southeast Queens on Monday in what was believed to be a murder-suicide, the police said.

title: Taking Tax Questions From Same-Sex Couples
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Bits Scan: Tracking Adobe Stock, Google Hackers and Sexy iPhone Apps
description: Monday mornings roundup of technology news:

title: The Party of AARP
description: Going through a Pew survey on the Millennial generations political tilt, Daniel Larison (as is his wont) finds long-term bad news for the Republicans:

title: The First Celebrity to Appear on Sesame Street
description: According to the official Twitter feed of Sesame Street, the first celebrity was a shaven-headed James Earl Jones (then prepping for his role in the 1970 film The Great White Hope) reciting the alphabet, and it was spooky:

title: In Europe. Lying in Bed. Soccer on TV. A Game in the Mud. Life Is Good.
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

title: Obamas Health Bill Plan Largely Follows Senate Version
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday issued his own blueprint for a health care overhaul, challenged Republicans to come forward with their ideas and laid the groundwork for an aggressive parliamentary maneuver to pass the legislation using only Democratic votes if this week brings no progress toward a bipartisan solution.

title: All Officers Acquitted in Mineo Trial
description: Updated, 11:02 a.m. | Police Officer Richard Kern has been acquitted on all counts of sexually abusing Michael Mineo on a Brooklyn subway platform in 2008. Two fellow officers accused of covering up the crime were also acquitted.

title: White House Releases Health Care Plan
description: After more than a year of people talking about President Obamas health care plan, the president actually has offered his own detailed proposal. And its now posted on the White House Web site.

title: Monday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: U.S. Tempers Expectations While Canada Re-evaluates
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Americans skated onto the Canada Hockey Place ice on Sunday with a sense of purpose. They wore 1960 replica sweaters, commemorating the United States first gold medal in Olympic hockey, 50 years ago at Squaw Valley. They knew where they stood and what might come to be.

title: Supermen Dont Leave: Will Comic-Con Seek a New Home?
description: The hordes of obsessives who gather in San Diego each summer dressed as hobbits, Star Wars stormtroopers and classic gray Iron Man from his debut appearance in Tales of Suspense No. 39 (March 1963) may soon have to find another place to do it, at least if they want to do so in the company of thousands of like-minded fans.

title: Afghan Warlord With Many Enemies, and Possibly One Notorious Ally, Killed by Suicide Bomber
