description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Hajji Zaman Ghamsharik, the Afghan warlord accused of helping Osama bin Laden escape from the Americans at Tora Bora, had so many enemies that his assassination on Monday came as no particular surprise.

title: Officers Acquitted in Mineo Trial
description: A Brooklyn jury found three police officers not guilty on Monday of abusing a suspect in the Prospect Park subway station during a 2008 arrest, in a case that recalled some of the citys most notorious police brutality episodes but never generated as much public outcry or departmental change.

title: Monday Puzzle: Getting Something From Nothing
description: Weve had a lot of quite sophisticated mathematical puzzles recently, like last weeks Case of the Carnival Cups, and the Toiling Antomatons and Stashing Llamas before that. Today we go on to something different, and far grander. I must announce that I have solved all the worlds problems. Ive found the secret of making unlimited money with a simple scheme, and Ive also figured out how to generate unlimited energy with my new invention, the papaya battery. Both these are based on the successful application of one of the deepest human principles of all time  getting something for nothing! To understand the papaya battery requires some physics, so lets consider the money solution first.

title: Judge Accepts S.E.C.s Deal With Bank of America
description: In a ruling that freed Bank of America from some legal problems, a federal judge wrote on Monday that he had reluctantly approved a $150 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Dcor Couture
description: Four terrific ways to blend in with the wallpaper.

title: White House Releases Health Care Plan
description: After more than a year of people talking about President Obamas health care plan, the president actually has offered his own detailed proposal, writes The Timess David M. Herszenhorn. Read about the plans details, view a searchable copy of the bill and find additional context on Prescriptions, the Timess health care blog.

title: Judge Accepts S.E.C.s Settlement With BofA
description: In a ruling that freed Bank of America from some of its legal problems, a federal judge on Monday reluctantly approved a $150 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, The New York Timess Louise Story reports.

title: A Broken Economic Law
description: Remember Okuns Law?

title: Zazi Pleads Guilty in Plot to Bomb Subways
description: Updated, 3:50 p.m. | Najibullah Zazi, the Afghan immigrant who was a key player in what the federal authorities have said was one of the most serious threats to the United States since the 9/11 attacks, pleaded guilty on Monday to terrorism charges after admitting to a plot to blow up the subways.

title: Tax Tips for Same-Sex Couples
description: Gay couples have complicated financial lives, and preparing tax returns is no exception.

title: Luck Helps Jimmie Johnson Land a Win at the Auto Club 500
description: Jimmie Johnson, the four-time Sprint Cup champion, was fortunate to be in pit row as the yellow flag came out with 20-some laps to go.

title: Featured Recipe: Spinach Lasagna
description: This vegetable lasagna is as close to a one-pot (or one-pan) dish as you can come for a big family dinner. It takes some work to put together, but the benefit comes with the sides, which can be very simple. Think about marinated olives, a green salad, a good bread  you dont need much more.

title: Pelosi Taking a Long Look at Presidents Plan
description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has issued a statement saying that she looks forward to reviewing President Obamas proposal for compromise health care legislation, and reiterated the need to revamp the health system.

title: Obama Pitches Education Proposal to Governors
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama kicked off a drive Monday to upgrade American education, unveiling a plan requiring states to adopt new reading and mathematics standards and committing his administration to breaking down some of the barriers to reform.

title: A New Ezio for the Premiere of a New Attila
description: One day before the debut of Pierre Audis much anticipated new production of Verdis Attila at the Metropolitan Opera, the Met announced a substitution in one of thekey roles. Carlos lvarez, the Spanish baritone who was to sing the role of Ezio, will not perform in Tuesday nights premiere because of illness, the Met said in a news release on Monday. Taking Mr. lvarezs place will be Giovanni Meoni, who will be making his Met debut. Mr. Meoni hassung at the Teatro la Fenice in Venice and the Teatro dellOpera in Rome and has sung the role of Ezio in Bari, Italy, the Met said. RiccardoMuti, the former music director and conductor of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan, will be making his own Met debut with this production, as will the opera itself.

title: Cuomo Keeps Everyone Guessing
description: Whats the worst-kept secret in Albany? That Andrew M. Cuomo, the states popular attorney general, is going to run for governor against the unpopular incumbent, David A. Paterson.

title: School Choice in San Francisco: Is it Working?
description: Jesse McKinleys article in The New York Times on Sunday put a spotlight on the San Franciscos new school assignment plan, which gives more weight to matching a student with a school near his or her home.

title: Running Into Your Therapist in Public
description: What happens if you run into your therapist in public? Do you introduce him or her to your friends? Or do you pretend you dont know each other?

title: What Obamas New Health Care Plan Means for Small Businesses
description: The White House, in advance of a televised summit meeting aimed at reviving revive stalled health care legislation, posted a proposal this morning that is meant to bridge the differences, in the words of Dan Pfeiffer, White House communications director, between the House and the Senate bills. The White House basically follows the Senate bill, except that in a handful of key instances it weighs in with a Solomonic compromise. We view this as the opening bid for the health meeting that will be televised live this Thursday, said Mr. Pfeiffer.

title: A Day Dedicated to the Weird and Wondrous
description: Most online travel guides focus on the obvious  the Eiffel Tower, say, or the Pyramids of Giza. Not Atlas Obscura. The seven-month-old Web site has the opposite goal: highlighting the oddest places the world has to offer: places that are evocative of wonder, that provoke ones sense of curiosity and that might be under-appreciated or under-celebrated, said Joshua Foer, a co-founder of the site.

title: Chiie
description: A misspelling of Chile, mistakenly stamped on thousands of Chilean 50-peso coins.

title: Obama Biography Is Coming From New Yorker Editor
description: 1:44 p.m. | Updated  David Remnick, editor of The New Yorker, who has already written extensively about President Obama in the pages of his own magazine, will soon have another platform to do so. The Alfred A. Knopf imprint of Random House said Monday that it had acquired a biography of Mr. Obama by Mr. Remnick and would publish it on April 6.

title: The New Staples
description: Introducing The New Staples, a column by Merrill Stubbs of Food52 that highlights ingredients making their way into restaurants and refrigerators, plus recipes from top chefs to help you put them to use.

title: Boehner: White House Plan Cripples Summit Prospects
description: Ever since President Obama floated the idea of a big televised forum on health care legislation, he has said that he first wanted to resolve differences between the bills already adopted by the House and the Senate so Democrats would have a single plan as a starting point in their discussion with Republicans.

title: Tufts, Please Pick Me
description: For the first time, Tufts University has invited aspiring students to submit short videos with their applications.

title: House Trained
description: Keeping track of fashions rotating cast of characters can be more challenging than playing six degrees of separation with inbred European nobility.

title: Judge Dismisses Ferriter Suit Against William Morris Endeavor
description: The lawsuit by John Ferriter, the former head of reality television at the William Morris Agency, against Ari Emanuel and his new William Morris Endeavor Agency, is over, at least for the moment. Judge Elizabeth A. Grimes of Los Angeles Superior Court dismissed the suit at a hearing on Monday in Santa Monica and sent it to arbitration.

title: House Trained
description: You may have never heard of them, but Marco Zanini, Peter Copping and Rodolfo Paglialunga are three new names to watch. Having worked with some of the best designers around, their new mission is to revitalize three of the oldest and chicest French fashion houses  Rochas, Nina Ricci and Vionnet. Will they succeed? More

title: Off the Menu: Torrisi Italian Specialties
description: Starting March 9, Torrisi Italian Specialties, the clever little NoLIta food shop owned by Richard Torrisi and Mario Carbone that sells sandwiches and prepared items made with Italian ingredients from well-sourced domestic producers, will serve dinners every night except Mondays from 6 to 11.

title: To Impress, Tufts Prospects Turn to YouTube
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  There are videos showing off card tricks, horsemanship, jump rope and stencils  and lots of rap songs, including one by a young woman who performed two weeks after oral surgery, with her mouth still rubber-banded shut.

title: Insurer Warns Against Politicized Federal Oversight
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association is hammering back at President Obamas proposal to give the federal government new power to review, and potentially block, health insurance premium increases.

title: Behind Schlumbergers Smith Deal: A Big Gas Bet
description: Schlumbergers $11 billion takover of a smaller rival, Smith Industries, seems to be a big bet on unconventional natural gas production in the United States.

title: Eddie Comes to The City
description: I have a high school buddy named Eddie who has lived his entire life a block away from the Massapequa Park station of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: The Times Gets a New Styles Editor
description: Stuart Emmrich, the travel editor of The New York Times, was named on Monday as editor of the Sunday and Thursday Styles sections, replacing Trip Gabriel, who is returning to reporting as an education writer. Bill Keller, executive editor, made the appointments, which will take effect at the end of February.

title: Horrid Job Number Coming
description: It snowed this month in much of the United States. And that may create unnecessary fears that a double-dip recession is upon us.

title: Countless Lost Limbs Alter Life in Haitis Ruins
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Dont cut off my leg! Fabienne Jean screamed repeatedly as she was carried through the gates of the General Hospital here after the earthquake. Im a dancer. My leg is my livelihood. Please, dont take my leg.

title: Wal-Mart vs. Whole Foods
description: Ed Schneidersent this link to a piece by Corby Kummer, which reports on the increasing attempts by Wal-Mart to sell local produce. He then gathers a crew to compare the Wal-Mart food to that from Whole Foods (which I dont think is apt, but then again, Im hardly a Whole Foods fan), which turns out to be if not a toss-up, then surprising. In any case, the efforts on Wal-Marts part are fascinating.

title: Now Showing | The Park, Episode 4
description: The sign reads Lunch Poems. $1. But a harried journalist (Tammy Blanchard) gets more than she bargained for in the latest installment of The Park. Log on next Monday for the final episode of our original Web series, directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and starring New Yorks mostly green dream machine, Central Park.

title: A New Twist: The Application Video
description: For most applicants, writing the college essay is challenging enough. Now, applicants to Tufts University are also sending in videos about themselves, my colleague Tamar Lewin reports.

title: RBNY to Use RFID at the Turnstiles
description: Thousands of soccer fans passing through the turnstiles at Red Bull Arena will never hear these words: Tickets, please.

title: Dreaming of the Derby in the Dead of Winter
description: So here we are after a late Saturday in February, trying to divine what may happen on the first one in May when the best 3-year-olds in the nation line up for the 136th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Obamacare
description: OK, the plan is out. Basically, it splits the difference between the House and Senate bills, with a set of measures that can be passed through reconciliation. Igor Volsky has a nice table doing the comparison. Since the House bill is better than the Senate bill, and the Senate bill is much better than nothing, this should be a go.

title: Remembering the 1970 N.B.A. Finals (Part 2)
description: Continuing Off the Dribbles look at the 1970 N.B.A. Finals, an event often remembered for Willis Reeds dramatic appearance but one that was important in many other ways.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article erroneously stated that Luther S. Luedtke is chairman of Education Development Center.

title: Why Balance Is More Important Than Returns
description: The act of planning for your financial future is all about making trade-offs. Its essentially a question of dealing with the constant tension between living for today and saving for some future event.

title: Delusions of Bipartisanship
description: Great catch by Matt Yglesias, who quotes some all-too-typical centrist Obama-bashing from The Economist:

title: Israels Plans for 2 Sites Stir Unrest in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Scores of Palestinians clashed with Israeli forces in the West Bank city of Hebron on Monday, a day after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, announced plans to include two hotly contested sites  a Hebron shrine and a tomb in another West Bank city  on a list of Israeli national heritage sites.

title: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Combating Worry
description: Mr. Cassone, whose son Richard is serving as a sergeant in Afghanistan, contributed a post in December appealing for a little compassion for parents of active-duty service members during the holidays. Below, he writes about a recent check-in with his son and the worry that lingers after each call.

title: Some Readers Sweat the Small Stuff at Gyms
description: At the gym, its a survival of the fittest.

title: Behavior: Napping Can Prime the Brain for Learning
description: Bring back the siesta.

title: 'The Park,' Episode 4
description: A harried journalist (Tammy Blanchard) gets more than she bargained for in the latest installment of "The Park."

title: Lenos Guest List to Include Palin, Vonn and Jersey Shore Cast
description: Jay Leno will return to The Tonight Show next Monday with a guest list loaded with names intended to bring back the kind of audience lead he enjoyed on the NBC show before his ill-fated side trip to prime time.

title: Spike in Iraq Violence as Vote Nears
description: BAGHDAD  A series of bombings, beheadings and shootings rippled through Iraq on Monday, leaving at least 23 people dead, including 9 children, and intensifying concern about a spike in violence with less than two weeks until national elections.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Tracey Brown, senior vice president for client services and account management at Rapp, part of the Omnicom Group, was named managing director for the Dallas office. Jim Lyons, president at Rapp, had been handling those duties on an interim basis since Becca Weigman became chief marketing officer at Rapp U.S.

title: Share-a-Ride
description: A public service announcement created by NYC Media, the city's online and broadcast arm, for the share-a-cab program.

title: University of North Carolina Greensboro to Offer 3-Year Degree
description: The University of North Carolina at Greensboro is announcing today that it will allow highly motivated students to graduate in three years, beginning with the freshman class that will be seated this fall.

title: Murky Path in Deciding on Care at the End
description: Aggressive treatment at the end of life  frantic CPR for a brain-dead accident victim, inserting a feeding tube in a dying Alzheimers patient  has become a staple of the health care debate. Critics argue that vast resources are squandered on care that is obviously futile.

title: Any Way Its Sliced, Appeal of Social Media Grows
description: Youve heard of Meetup, the online social networking portal? A couple of consumer marketers are bringing out campaigns that could be called meatups.

title: Crist Defends Decision to Accept Stimulus Funds
description: Under fire from the right at home, Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida went to the White House on Monday and expressed no regrets for embracing both President Obama and his antirecession spending program. He dismissed the criticism as mattering not one iota.

title: What the Credit Card Act Means for You
description: On Monday, banks had to start complying with many provisions of the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act that are intended to protect consumers from unfair credit card billing practices.

title: Keeping Housemates Fed and Green at a Berkeley Student Co-op
description: Its 6 p.m., and that means crunch time in the kitchen at my student co-operative in Berkeley.

title: Wal-Mart Adds Its Clout to Movie Streaming
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sure, you took the plunge and bought that expensive high-definition television. But does it connect to the Internet?

title: The Claim: To Cut Calories, Eat Slowly
description: THE FACTS

title: Profile in Style | Diane Keaton
description: Were all aware that Diane Keaton is a wonderful actress. But did you know that shes also a photographer, clotheshorse, design enthusiast and overall aesthete? In our latest Profile in Style, Keaton gives us exclusive access into her polymath universe.

title: Police Identify Suspect in Brooklyn Hit-and-Run
description: Detectives are searching for a 31-year-old Bronx woman who they believe struck two young women with her car early Sunday in Brooklyn, leaving one of them brain-dead, and fled the scene, the police said.

title: Intramural Squabbling at The L.A. Times
description: There is trouble in Oscar pundit land. The Bagger knows youll be shocked (shocked!) to find that there is a brouhaha over something Harvey Weinstein-related, namely his campaign to get Inglourious Basterds into the conversation for best picture.

title: Utilities Finding Peer Pressure a Powerful Motivator
description: National Grid, the electricity and gas provider to several Northeastern states, last week announced the expansion of its Home Energy Report program, which delivers energy-use statements to homeowners showing how they stack up against their neighbors in similar-size homes.

title: Vegetarian Dishes From a Greek Holiday
description: In Greece, Clean Monday is a public holiday that marks the first day of Lent on the Greek Orthodox calendar. At Molyvos in New York on that day  which this year fell on Feb. 15  the chef, James Botsacos, collaborating with the cookbook author Diane Kochilas, prepared a plant-based feast as a fund-raiser for the Gennadius Library in Athens, which houses a collection of Greek arts and letters that was invaluable to Ms. Kochilas when she was researching her prize-winning cookbook, The Glorious Foods of Greece.

title: Breaking Down LeBron Jamess Suitors (Part I)
description: The first of two parts looking at teams that will have the ability to offer LeBron James a maximum contract. This part discusses the Cavaliers and the Knicks; on Tuesday, the remaining teams with enough salary-cap room to sign James.

title: Napping to Boost Brain Power
description: New research shows what power nappers have believed all along: napping is good for your brain.

title: Quote Unquote | Shes a Lady
description: Janice Dickinson on her former boss, Tyra Banks. No wonder she was fired.

title: Anti-Bullying Activist Wants British Leaders Office to Be a Stress-Free Environment
description: Entering a debate in Britain about accusations that Prime Minister Gordon Brown has lost his temper with staff at times, the leader of the British National Bullying Helpline, Caroline Pratt, told the BBC on Monday that she has reason to believe that the leader of Britains office is not a safe and stress-free environment.

title: Pricing of TV Shows on iTunes Prompts a Debate
description: In Mondays New York Times, I reported about Apples pitch for lower TV prices on iTunes. Apple apparently believes that if TV episodes were sold for 99 cents, rather than $1.99, the increased sales volume would offset the lower price.

title: A New Social Contract, but Which One?
description: Paul Krugman writes today about starving the beast  the idea, popularized under President Reagan, that depriving the government of tax revenue would force it to shrink.

title: Travel Deals: Double-Decker Sightseeing Tours of New York
description: Gray Line New York, which runs a double-decker sightseeing tour, is offering a two-for-one promotion for residents of the tristate area, allowing city slickers to be tourists in their own city.

title: How Flexible Is Delaware Law?
description: I am teaching mergers and acquisitions this semester. In my last class, I made a particular point of highlighting the remarkable flexibility of Delaware corporate law, the law governing the majority of American public companies. Depending upon the type of consideration offered, the structure of the deal (tender offer, merger or the asset sale) or the acquiring party, different Delaware standards, voting and appraisal requirements apply.

title: British Airways Cabin Crews Vote to Back a Strike
description: The Associated Press is reporting that cabin crew members for British Airways voted in favor of striking over jobs and working conditions, union leaders said Monday, in the latest action in a long-running dispute between the airlines management and workers.

title: Joe Drapes Derby Contenders
description: In Tuesdays Times, Joe Drape examines the Derby contenders after last weekends prep races and, in the chart below, ranks his early Derby favorites. The odds are drawn from the Kentucky Derby Future Wager. Then watch Lookin at Luckys gritty victory in the Rebel Stakes. Will last years Juvenile champion capture a fourth Derby victory for trainer Bob Baffert? Share thoughts in the comments section below.

title: Flight Data Show Rendition Planes Landed in Poland
description: BERLIN  Two human rights groups released government flight logs Monday that showed aircraft linked to the Central Intelligence Agencys program for secretly detaining, moving and housing terrorism suspects had landed in Poland.

title: Bloomberg Doesnt Want to Talk About His Money
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has never been shy about talking about how his staggering wealth, now estimated at somewhere in excess of $15 billion, has enabled him to lead a fortunate life.

title: Rare Antiquities from Italy on Loan to the Met
description: It might still be winter, but theres been a warm Italian breeze wafting through the Metropolitan Museum of Art in recent days. As part an agreement reached with the Italian government in 2006, in return for the repatriation of several antiquities from the museums collection that were thought to have been looted, Italy has recently loaned a small trove of rare works from its own public collections.

title: Off the Menu: The Castello Plan
description: Mimis Hummus, the popular Middle Eastern restaurant, continues to expand its enclave in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn. It recently opened a well-edited food shop, Market, next door and on Friday it will open the Castello Plan, a wine bar with more than 120 selections, and light food. Its a handsome room done in reclaimed wood, bare brick and iron.

title: Photos of the Moment | Cameron Smith
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Cameron Smith.

title: Wal-Mart Is Buying Vudu Movie Service
description: 5:46 p.m. | Updated Wal-Mart Stores confirmed late Monday that it is buying Vudu.

title: Doing an About-Face on Overmedicated Children
description: Picture a cupped hand. A capsule and a pill lie in the palm. The hand is extended toward a small child. The caption reads, Take your vitamins.

title: What Were Reading
Womens Work
description: Hardly a Tweet had been sent after the Whitney Museum of American Art released the names of the 55 artists selected for its 75th biennial before it was already known as the womens biennial. Thats crazy, says Francesco Bonami, the chief curator of the exhibition, now on view through the end of May. To be the womens biennial, 55 of the artists would have to be female.

title: Ted Bundys VW Beetle Is Now a Museum Piece
description: The ratty, rusted 1968 Volkswagen Beetle in faded beige that was owned by the serial killer Ted Bundy has become a museum display in Washington.

title: Domingo to Undergo Surgery
description: 4:43 p.m. | Updated

title: Paterson Still Welcome at White House
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. David A. Paterson, who has been encouraged by the White House not to seek election this year, was seen exchanging pleasantries on Sunday night with Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff.

description: Brooklyn high and low on the blogs today.

title: Fruit and Fermentation
description: Q. Must you eat fruit on an empty stomach, so it wont mix with other foods and cause fermentation and rot?

title: Mobile Broadcast TV: New Options and New Headaches
description: As I pointed out in an article in last Mondays Times, broadcasters are looking forward to the imminent availability of new mobile devices that can pick up broadcast television while on the move.

title: Polyvore Hires Former Google Executive as Chief
description: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, Googles former president of Asia-Pacific and Latin America operations, is taking on a new challenge. She will become chief executive of Polyvore, an online shopping and fashion start-up.

title: Samurai Shopper | Pink Think
description: In these parlous times, its prudent to shop your closet. Its also self-serving  in the best possible way  to shop your colors, too. As spring fashion appears to be mainly a mash-up of beige and other exquisitely subtle hues (zzzzzz), Ive concluded a): my closet is a wonderland and b): ghostly taupe lipstick will never appeal to anyone with a pulse.

title: Christopher Wheeldon Leaves Dance Company He Created
description: The choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, three years after forming the Morphoses company to much excitement in the dance world, is walking away from the ensemble amid apparent friction with his executive director.

description: Jon Nolting, the sports education manager for Alpine for the US Ski and Snowboard Association, uses a Web channel called Dartfish.tv to help train the next generation of ski racers.

description: When Rolling Stones site went down on Monday, some people on the Web and on Twitter suggested that it had neglected to renew its domain name  a big and elementary error in the Internet world.

description: WASHINGTON

title: Whaling Compromise Proposed, and Panned
description: An ad hoc group within the International Whaling Commission has offered a proposal that would sanction some commercial whaling for the first time in decades while reducing the amount of whaling taking place through what amount to end runs around a longstanding whaling moratorium  like Icelands expanding hunt of fin whales (video above) and Japans research whale hunts in the ocean near Antarctica.

title: Triggering a Supernova
description: An animation showing a supernova from a merger of two white dwarfs.

title: From the Clash of White Dwarfs, the Birth of a Supernova
description: How many ways can a star go kaboom!? It might depend on what kind of galaxy the star lives in, astronomers said last week.

title: At Met, Less Zeffirelli, Pricier Tickets
description: Peter Sellars is in, Franco Zeffirelli is out  again.

title: In Biathlon, Concerns About Russias Program
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  One of the most charismatic and controversial characters in the sport of biathlon will not be found racing the cross-country trails here. Alexander Tikhonov, a celebrated biathlete from the Soviet era, instead works the sidelines, shaking hands with old friends and passing out photo cards that show him draped in colorful medals from his past.

title: Reply Inc. Files With S.E.C. for Initial Public Offering
description: Reply Inc., which runs an auction service for local Web advertising, said on Monday that it was planning an initial public offering, The Associated Press reports.

title: Training the Next Generation of Ski Racers
description: On many slopes across the country, there are young ski racers hoping and training to become the next Lindsey Vonn or the next Bode Miller.

title: Forgetting, With a Purpose
description: Just why the brain erases certain memories has long been a topic of interest to scientists.

title: Evidence That Little Touches Do Mean So Much
description: Psychologists have long studied the grunts and winks of nonverbal communication, the vocal tones and facial expressions that carry emotion. A warm tone of voice, a hostile stare  both have the same meaning in Terre Haute or Timbuktu, and are among dozens of signals that form a universal human vocabulary.

title: A Grand Showplace Seen From All Angles
description: In their new work, Armory Show, Brennan Gerard and Ryan Kelly pay homage to a place, though its setting  the Park Avenue Armory, where the production was seen on Saturday night  really represents something far more grand. For the directors of the interdisciplinary company Moving Theater, the performance, marking the culmination of an 18-month residency in the space, incorporates dance, text, live music and video to offer a dreamlike portrait of the armorys social and military history.

title: Pinstripes to Tiger Stripes for Damon
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Blue and orange paw prints decorate the carpet of Johnny Damons new home clubhouse. There are no motivational slogans on the walls at Joker Marchant Stadium, no roaring Tampa highway behind the practice fields. Damon is a Detroit Tiger now, an Old English D replacing the interlocking NY on his cap.

title: Iceland Asks U.S. to Help Ensure It Gets Loans
description: Iceland is seeking the help of the United States to ensure that Britain and the Netherlands do not use a dispute over aid to depositors of its collapsed banks to hold up international loans, Prime Minister Johanna Sigurdardottir said Monday in Parliament, The New York Timess David Jolly reports.

title: Just Google It? Developing Internet Search Skills
description: Overview | Do Internet search engines point us to the information that we need or confuse us with irrelevant or questionable information? How can Internet users improve their searches to find reliable information? What are some ways to perform effective searches? In this lesson, students conduct Web searches on open-ended questions, and draw on their experiences to develop guides to searching effectively and finding reliable information online.

title: Harold Prince to Receive Achievement Award
description: The Broadway director and producer Harold Prince, who has won 21 Tony Awards, more than anyone else, will receive the Eugene ONeill Theater Centers annual award for achievement in the theater, leaders of the center said on Monday.

title: 'Strange Attractors' by Aki Sasamoto
description: Aki Sasamoto discusses her contribution to the Whitney Biennial.

title: A Revolutionary Returns, Embracing Subtle Change
description: When the English conductor Roger Norrington accepted an invitation to become the first music director of the Orchestra of St. Lukes in 1990, he came to the post with a revolutionarys repute.

title: How Miraculous Was the Miracle?
description: Carlton J. Chin, a fund manager, and Jay P. Granat, a psychotherapist, wrote Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.

title: Beltran Arrives With No Hard Feelings
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Carlos Beltran arrived in Mets camp on Monday saying that his surgically repaired right knee was recovering on schedule and that his feelings from the time of the operation had healed as well.

title: Puzzle Solved: How a Fatherless Lizard Species Maintains Its Genetic Diversity
description: More than 40 years ago, Bill Neaves, then a young Ph.D. student, discovered how an all-female, asexual species of the whiptail lizard came to be. He found that the lizard was a cross between the female species of one type of lizard and the male species of another.

title: A Look at the Womens Figure Skating Contenders
description: Womens figure skating, often the marquee event of the Winter Olympics, begins Tuesday with the short program. Thirty skaters will have a maximum of 2 minutes 50 seconds to deliver a routine that has eight required elements, including jumps, spins and spirals. The short-program session is from 7:30 p.m. to midnight, Eastern time. NBC will have some live coverage on the East Coast from 8 p.m. to midnight.

title: Medical Paper Trail Takes Electronic Turn
description: As far back as I can remember, medical care has been paper-driven. When you see a new doctor or return to one you havent seen for a while, you are asked to complete a written medical history that includes every illness or condition you have ever had (along with operations and their dates), every drug and over-the-counter medication and supplement you take, the major illnesses and causes of death of members of your family, and perhaps other medical facts of possible interest to the doctor.

title: Everythings Breaking. Is It the Weekend Yet?
description: MY daughter Clementine was the first to notice that everything breaks when my husband is out of town.

title: A Push to Start the School Week Without Meat
description: Cafeteria offerings on Monday in the citys public schools included turkey-bacon strips, hamburger patties and teriyaki chicken. But if a national effort being pushed locally by Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, gains traction here, students may find themselves starting the week with more garbanzo beans, green peas and eggplant.

title: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Feb. 22
description: In photographs transmitted today from Afghanistan, Tyler Hicks of The Times conveys both the intensely personal face of peril (Slide 4) and the chilling abstraction of a perilous landscape (Slide 3). In Slide 13, Paul White of The Associated Press can be seen following in the footsteps  quite literally  of Shannon Stapleton of Reuters (Pictures of the Day, Feb. 11, (Slide 12).

title: Presidents Proposal Lacks Sufficient Detail for Analysis, Budget Office Says
description: The director of the Congressional Budget Office, Douglas W. Elmendorf, said on Monday that the White House had not provided enough detail about President Obamas health care plan for the C.B.O. to make a full analysis.

title: Funds and Goldman Deny Acting Improperly on Greece
description: Several hedge funds named last week in the Greek press have denied shorting the countrys debt, while others declined to comment.

title: Enchantment in a Race Against the Clock
description: CHICAGO  What a pleasure it is to see an American ballet company dancing Frederick Ashtons full-length Cinderella. The Joffrey Ballet, which acquired it a few years ago, has already toured it this season to Los Angeles and now is presenting it in Chicago, its home city. At each of the three performances I attended on Saturday and Sunday, you could hear both children and grown-ups laughing happily at its jokes, and cheering its conclusion. The Chicago friend, a painter, who came along on Saturday night, had never seen full-blown classical ballet before; he said afterward that he had found it the ideal introduction and would love to watch it again soon.

title: Newborns: Training in Birth Basics May Save Lives
description: Simple lessons for midwives and other birth attendants in how to help a newborn start breathing and how to keep it warm could save one million babies a year, according to a study published last week.

title: A Murder Suspects Worth to Science
description: Amy Bishop, neuroscientist, inventor, murder suspect, has become bigger than life, a symbol for those who think that genius is close to madness, or that women cannot get ahead in science, or that tenure systems in universities are brutalizing  or even that progress against fatal diseases is so important that someone like Dr. Bishop should be set free to pursue cures.

title: Genius, Madness and Tenure
description: In todays Science Times, Gina Kolata explores the fascinating public reaction to the case of Amy Bishop, the university neuroscientist accused of going on a shooting rampage after failing to win tenure.

title: Guilty Plea Made in Plot to Bomb New York Subway
description: The Afghan immigrant at the center of what the authorities described as one of the most serious threats to the United States since 9/11 pleaded guilty Monday to terrorism charges in what he said was a Qaeda plot to detonate a bomb in the New York subway.

title: M.L.S. Labor Talks Get Hot
description: The protracted labor negotiations between Major League Soccer and the union that represents the leagues players over a new collective bargaining agreement, conducted under a cone of silence and extended twice since the original Jan. 31 deadline, burst into public view over the weekend.

title: Aloft Hotels Tests Keyless Check In
description: Call it convenient, even antisocial, but Aloft Hotels  a Starwood brand that targets younger business travelers  is testing a new key card system that allows registering guests to bypass the front desk and head straight for their rooms.

title: Sheens Circle, From Son to Father
description: LOS ANGELES  In a dressing room at the Mark Taper Forum here, some 46 years in the life of Martin Sheen seemed to disappear. He was discussing the play The Subject Was Roses, both his breakout performance on Broadway as the son in 1964 and his current role as the father in the production that opened at the theater on Sunday.

title: Harold Prince to Receive ONeill Theater Award
description: The Broadway director and producer Harold Prince, below, who has won 21 Tony Awards, more than anyone else, will receive the Eugene ONeill Theater Centers annual award for achievement in the theater, leaders of the center said on Monday. Stephen Sondheim, some of whose best-known musicals were directed or produced by Mr. Prince (Company, Follies, Sweeney Todd), will present the award at a gala dinner on April 5. Mr. Prince, 82, is preparing to direct, with Susan Stroman, a new musical in London. The show, Paradise Found, starring Mandy Patinkin, Shuler Hensley and Judy Kaye, is scheduled to begin performances in May at the Menier Chocolate Factory before a possible New York production. This is the 10th year that the ONeill Center, a 46-year-old hub for the development of new plays and musicals, will present its Monte Cristo Award, given to recognize a distinguished career that, according to the centers Web site (theoneill.org), exemplifies its standard of excellence and pioneering spirit. Past recipients include Kevin Spacey, Edward Albee, Brian Dennehy and Wendy Wasserstein.

title: Nazis, Basterds and Haiti Relief
description: While were on the topic of the campaign for Inglourious Basterds  which, in an extra long awards season with extra few surprises, seems to be the only one with any drama, which is why everyone is talking about it  lets take a closer look at some of the promos that the mad geniuses of the Weinstein Company have been running. Saturdays New York Times featured a full-page ad in the Arts section for an exhibit of reimagined Inglourious movie posters, created by some street-cred-y graphic designers, autographed by Quentin Tarantino and sold to benefit earthquake relief in Haiti. Natural connection, right? The movie that reminds you why you love movies has inspired others to create and give back, blares the ALL-CAPS copy above a series of stylized images of Hitler, screaming eagles, swastikas and Brad Pitt.

title: Obama Biography by The New Yorkers Editor
description: David Remnick, right, editor of The New Yorker, who has already written extensively about President Obama in the pages of his own magazine, will soon have another platform to do so. The Alfred A. Knopf imprint of Random House said on Monday that it had acquired a biography of Mr. Obama by Mr. Remnick and would publish it on April 6. In an interview on Monday, Mr. Remnick said that the biography, The Bridge: The Life and Rise of Barack Obama, would not be simply a pumped up version of a 12,000-word article about the Obama campaign that he wrote for the November 2008 issue of The New Yorker. Mr. Remnick, who won the Pulitzer Prize for his book Lenins Tomb, said the biography would include considerable material about the president that was not in the article, as it follows Mr. Obamas life in Hawaii and Chicago and ends at the door of the White House on Inauguration Day.

title: Olympics Lift NBC
description: NBCs coverage of the Olympics continued to find ratings gold on Sunday, although with an average audience of 22.4 million viewers during prime time it was one of the lower-rated nights so far for these Winter Games, according to Nielsens estimates. NBCs coverage on Sunday, much of it taped in advance, provided little air time for the United States hockey victory over Canada. That game was carried live on NBCs cable-news channel, MSNBC, although NBC did interrupt its coverage of bobsledding and ice dancing on the night for the final half-minute of the hockey match. CBS ranked second on the night, continuing to earn strong ratings for Undercover Boss (13.6 million viewers). ABC placed third, while Fox finished fourth.

title: Attila Premiere at Met Loses a Baritone
description: One day before the debut of Pierre Audis much-anticipated new production of Verdis Attila at the Metropolitan Opera, the Met announced a substitution in a key role. Carlos lvarez, the Spanish baritone who was to sing the role of Ezio, will not perform in Tuesday nights premiere because of illness, the Met said in a news release on Monday. Taking Mr. lvarezs place will be Giovanni Meoni, who will be making his Met debut. Mr. Meoni has sung at the Teatro la Fenice in Venice and the Teatro dellOpera in Rome and has sung the role of Ezio in Bari, Italy, the Met said. Riccardo Muti, the former music director and conductor of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan, will be making his own Met debut with this production, as will the opera itself.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Talent Agency
description: The lawsuit by John Ferriter, former head of reality television at the William Morris Agency, against Ari Emanuel and his new William Morris Endeavor Agency, is over, at least for the moment. Judge Elizabeth A. Grimes of Los Angeles County Superior Court dismissed the suit at a hearing on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif., and sent it to arbitration. Judge Grimes said she would retain jurisdiction over the case if all issues were not resolved by an arbitrator. But for now Mr. Ferriters far-ranging suit  which had alleged contractual violations and defamation connected with the merger of Morris and Endeavor  will not result in an open-court battle.

title: Palin and Vonn on Lenos List
description: Jay Leno, left, will return to The Tonight Show on Monday with a guest list loaded with names intended to bring back the kind of audience he enjoyed on the NBC show before his ill-fated side trip to prime time. Sarah Palin will appear on Mr. Lenos second night back. It will be her first interview on a late-night talk show, and it will be on the one that happens to compete with David Letterman, with whom she has engaged in a longstanding feud. Mr. Leno will have the skiing star Lindsey Vonn on his first night back, followed by the cast of Jersey Shore on Wednesday. His second-week guests include Simon Cowell and Kim Kardashian.

title: Will Comic-Con Seek a New Home?
description: The hordes of obsessives who gather in San Diego each summer dressed as hobbits and Star Wars storm troopers may soon have to find another place to do it, at least if they want to do so in the company of thousands of like-minded fans. The San Diego Comic-Con International, the 40-year-old event that has evolved into a required pit stop for film studios, television networks and comics publishers who are preparing geek-friendly projects, could leave its longtime home base after 2012, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported. The contract between the San Diego Convention Center and the organizers of the convention, which brings 126,000 attendees and millions of dollars to the city, ends after 2012. Though the corporation that runs the convention hall recently sent a proposal to the organizers seeking to extend their agreement through 2015, the growing number of convention-goers and the finite space of the convention center could spell trouble. The city of Anaheim, which is closer for Hollywood-based executives and talent, has made a competing bid to become the conventions new home. In response, The Union-Tribune said, three waterfront hotels in San Diego have offered 300,000 square feet of their meeting space to the convention free of charge for 2013 through 2015. A decision by the Comic-Con board is expected in the coming weeks.

title: Chic in Review | McQueen Label will Live On
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: An Apology With Echoes of 12 Steps
description: In the long, self-lacerating statement that he read to a nationwide audience last week, Tiger Woods never used the words sex addiction. Yet by publicly apologizing for his infidelity, saying he was returning to his religious faith and admitting that he has work to do, he appeared to be carrying out several steps of a common 12-step treatment for just that.

title: When It Comes to Salt, No Rights or Wrongs. Yet.
description: Suppose, as some experts advise, that the new national dietary guidelines due this spring will lower the recommended level of salt. Suppose further that public health officials in New York and Washington succeed in forcing food companies to use less salt. What would be the effect?

title: Ask the Experts: Sex Addiction
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, the health writer Donald McNeil Jr. explores the world of sex addiction, a controversial and often misunderstood condition that has most recently garnered news media attention because of the travails of the golfer Tiger Woods.

title: Loan Guarantee for a Big Solar Power Plant
description: The United States Energy Department on Monday offered a $1.37 billion loan guarantee to a company planning to build a large-scale solar power plant in the Southern California desert.

title: New Roles for Two Editors at The Times
description: Stuart Emmrich, the travel editor of The New York Times, was named Monday as editor of the Thursday and Sunday Styles sections, succeeding Trip Gabriel, who is returning to reporting as an education writer. Bill Keller, executive editor, made the appointments, which will take effect at the end of February.

title: Birding in Badakhshan
description: Heres yet another example that Afghanistan is a good place to hide. One of the rarest birds on Earth, the Large-billed Reed Warbler, has apparently found refuge in Afghanistans northeastern Badakhshan Province. Scientists recently announced that they had discovered a breeding ground for the rare warbler, a species that was last seen in 2006, Afghan Analysts Network points out.

title: Police Order Downsizing of Parades
description: Everyone may love a parade, but the New York Police Department would like them a bit smaller, if you please. The department notified parade organizers throughout the city on Monday that starting April 1, their processions must cover 25 percent less distance and may no longer exceed five hours in duration.

title: Domingo to Undergo Surgery After Suffering Abdominal Pain
description: Plcido Domingo, the peripatetic tenor, conductor and opera house impresario, suffered severe abdominal pain while performing in Tokyo last week and will undergo preventive surgery, his spokeswoman said on Monday.

title: Transplants That Do Their Job, Then Fade Away
description: Jonathan Nuez was 8 months old when a liver transplant saved his life. Three years later, his body rejected the transplant, attacking it so fiercely that it wasted away and vanished, leaving barely a trace.

title: Anti-Abortion Group Opposes Increased Oversight of Premiums
description: The National Right to Life Committee, which opposes abortion rights, on Monday criticized President Obamas proposal to give the federal government new authority to review and potentially block premium increases by private health insurers.

title: The Comfortable Delights of Ski Jumping, With or Without Cowbells
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Ski jumping could use more cowbell. But that might wake the children.

title: New Gay Theater Has More Love Than Politics
description: A new breed of plays and musicals this season is presenting gay characters in love stories, replacing the direct political messages of 1980s and 90s shows like The Normal Heart and Angels in America with more personal appeals for social progress.

title: U.S. Women Reach Gold Medal Hockey Game
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It took four years, but the United States womens hockey team finally avenged a semifinal defeat they suffered against Sweden at the 2006 Turin Games by trouncing the Swedes, 9-1, in a semifinal Monday at Canada Hockey Place.

title: Millipores Shares Jump on Report of Takeover Bid
description: Shares of Millipore climbed 22.4 percent on Monday after Bloomberg News reported that Thermo Fisher Scientific had made an unsolicited takeover offer of about $6 billion for the company.

title: Excuse Me, Is This Seat Taken?
description: FLYING in coach is never comfortable, but its getting downright awkward for bigger passengers as airlines increasingly single out customers they deem too fat to fly.

title: A Huge Night for Olympic Hockey
description: The Winter Olympic numbers keep piling up for NBC: even hockey was a hit.

title: Wheeldon Quits Dance Troupe He Created
description: Three years after forming the Morphoses company to much excitement in the dance world, the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is walking away from the ensemble amid apparent friction with his executive director.

title: State of the Bears: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Lone Athlete Is the Face of San Marino
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  First, the hair. The curls that stick out from under his ski helmet and fall to his shoulders are natural. So is the color, tinged with gold. Sun and salt, he said. He uses conditioner once a week. Women like it.

title: Two Corrections
description: My column today on the National Enquirer included two errors. One was a brain-cramp: I referred to John Ensign as a Senator from Arizona, rather than Nevada. The other was more serious: I remarked that todays media almost seems more uncertain about when and whether to probe into politicians private lives than it was in the days when The Miami Herald cheerfully ran a photograph of Donna Rice sitting side-saddle on Gary Harts lap, which missed the rather important point that the photo in question first appeared in  the National Enquirer. The Herald broke the story on Hart, after famously staking out his Washington townhouse. But it wasnt the first to publish the scandals defining image. That distinction belongs (as such things often do) to the Enquirer.

title: Dalai Lama Now Knows Who Tiger Woods Is
description: As readers of our sports section will know, when The Associated Press used an audience with the Dalai Lama on Saturday to ask for a comment on the infidelities of Tiger Woods, the news agency discovered that the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader had never heard of the golfer.

title: Officials Seek Permanent Market at Seaport
description: Four years ago, when the people behind the New Amsterdam market started talking about creating a public market that could be a civic institution in the manner of Seattles Pike Place Market, they sounded sweet, sincere but unrealistic.

title: Blue Bottle Coffee to Open in Williamsburg
description: Once all proper permits are in place, Blue Bottle Coffee will open a roaster and coffee bar in Williamsburg, possibly as early as Wednesday.

title: The Afghan Side of War
description: Last fall the Afghan reporter Najibullah Quraishi was surprised to find himself operating as an embedded journalist. He was not tagging along with the United States Marines or some other coalition force  he was on the other side of the war, riding in minivans and walking through dusty fields with a small unit of militants in Baghlan Province, north of Kabul.

title: How Sex Addiction Is Treated
description: Golfer Tiger Woods is believed to be undergoing therapy for sex addiction at a Mississippi clinic called Gentle Path. But what, exactly, does treatment involve?

title: California Agency Expands With Acquisitions
description: The Phelps Group, an independent advertising agency based in Santa Monica, Calif., has made a pair of acquisitions for undisclosed financial terms.

title: Turning Back History: Reuniting Styles Long Divided
description: Historical memory can linger in music, sometimes for centuries. The Flamenco Festival concert on Saturday night at Town Hall, by the singer Marina Heredia and the Chekara Arab-Andalusian Orchestra of Ttouan, reunited two Andalusian styles: flamenco from Spain and Arab-Andalusian music from Morocco.

title: On Idol, Shifts in Power, Not Talent
description: Effectively, this season of American Idol, the ninth, is the shows last. Simon Cowell, its godfather figure, responsible for dashing the ambitions of untold singers and for being the most visible advocate for music criticism in this country, will leave after this years finale, in May, to prepare for the United States debut of his own singing competition, The X Factor, next year.

title: Womens Work
description: Hardly a Tweet had been sent after the Whitney Museum of American Art released the names of the 55 artists selected for its 75th biennial before it was already known as the womens biennial. Thats crazy, says Francesco Bonami, the chief curator of the exhibition, now on view through the end of May. To be the womens biennial, 55 of the artists would have to be female.

title: U.S. Mens Hockey Victory Only a Bit Player on NBC
description: The United States mens hockey teams 5-3 victory over Canada on Sunday night existed in the type of parallel television universe that can only be created by a news media giant during the Olympics.

title: A Face-Off on the Safety of a Drug for Diabetes
description: Three years ago, Dr. Steven E. Nissen, a cardiologist at the Cleveland Clinic, conducted a landmark study that suggested that the best-selling diabetes drug Avandia raised the risk of heart attacks. The study led to a Congressional inquiry, stringent safety warnings, a sharp drop in the drugs sales and a plunge in the share price of GlaxoSmithKline, Avandias maker.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Chinatown'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Roman Polanski's meditation on evil.

title: Shopping With Ghislaine Vias
description: The Manhattan interior designer shopped for turquoise accents to brighten up a room.

title: Are There Secular Reasons?
description: In the always-ongoing debate about the role of religion in public life, the argument most often made on the liberal side (by which I mean the side of Classical Liberalism, not the side of left politics) is that policy decisions should be made on the basis of secular reasons, reasons that, because they do not reflect the commitments or agendas of any religion, morality or ideology, can be accepted as reasons by all citizens no matter what their individual beliefs and affiliations. So its O.K. to argue that a proposed piece of legislation will benefit the economy, or improve the nations health, or strengthen national security; but its not O.K. to argue that a proposed piece of legislation should be passed because it comports with a verse from the book of Genesis or corresponds to the will of God.

title: In a Turquoise Mood
description: IF there is one color that deserves extra attention in 2010, it is turquoise  at least according to Pantone. The company has declared it the color of the year, citing its serene yet invigorating qualities, and Ghislaine Vias, for one, couldnt be happier with the choice.

title: Thirsty for Revenue, White House Reaches for Black Liquor
description: It sounds like a fight over a bottle of Johnnie Walker.

title: The People We Pay to Look Over Our Shoulders
description: At this very moment analysts at the National Security Agency some 30 miles north of the White House are monitoring countless flashpoints of data  cellphone calls to hot numbers, an e-mail message on a suspicious server, an oddly worded tweet  as they carom around the globe like pinballs in cyberspace.

title: Blame Game for Team Canada Seems to Spare Babcock
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Canada is suffering.

title: Scorecard | Michael Kors Wins!
description: As the Tents folded on Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week for the very last time, the race was on for a new vision of pared-down American chic. With Calvin, Isaac, Ralph, Michael and Tommy all in a heat, who came out ahead? As Scorecard can tell you, Calvin Kleins womens-wear designer Francisco Costa took his minimalist vision to the max, yet it was Michael Kors who took the gold for his streamlined yet sensual sportswear. See you at Lincoln Center  and London!

title: Pairings: Sauted Whiting With Lemon Cream Sauce
description: Its hard to imagine what I wouldnt want to serve with delicious pale Belgian-style ales. With acidity to spare, they might inspire a trip to Alsace, to flatter foods like choucroute or stinky Muenster. Southeast Asian hot pots would be another worthwhile adventure. The ales also deliver body and complexity that can stand up to hearty meat stews and casseroles like vegetable lasagna, or mac and cheese.

title: Sauted Whiting With Lemon Cream Sauce
description: 2 shallots, finely minced

title: A Delicious Free-for-All
description: A GOOD selection of Belgian-style ales is like the very best kind of buffet, offering an assortment of flavors, aromas, styles, strengths and types. You want strong ale, sour ale, sweet ale, dry ale, golden, dark, wheat, fruity and malty. When we set out to draw a stylistic standard for a planned tasting of Belgian golden ales, it seemed as if wed taken on an impossible task. But glory does not come to those who quit easily.

title: Computers Turn Flat Photos Into 3-D Buildings
description: Rome wasnt built in a day, but in cyberspace it might be.

title: Critics Picks Video: Chinatown
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks at Roman Polanskis 1974 film noir Chinatown. Mr. Scott calls the film, which explores corruption in 1930s Los Angeles, much more than the sum of its parts. He says that Mr. Polanski pushes beyond the conventions of the genre to give us a stark encounter between a powerless individual and monstrous evil. Please share your thoughts on Chinatown.

title: G.M.s Sale of Saab Seen Likely to Close This Week
description: General Motors is expected this week to close its sale of Saab Automobile of Sweden to Spyker Cars of the Netherlands, two executives involved with the deal told Bloomberg News.

title: Tasting Belgian Golden Ales
description: After a week in California wine country, thoughts turn naturally to beer. Well, of course. As the saying goes, it takes a lot of beer to make a little wine, meaning that more than a few winemaker regimens include copious amounts of beer. I doubt, though, that many winemakers are heading off after work to drink Belgian golden ales, the subject of my column this week.

title: With G.O.P. Help, Senate Advances Jobs Bill
description: In a rare bipartisan breakthrough, the Senate pushed a $15 billion measure intended to spur job creation over a crucial preliminary obstacle Monday night after five Senate Republicans broke ranks to back consideration of the Democratic leadership initiative.

title: In a Gilded World, Theirs Is but to Quip and Sigh
description: The first thing you hear is laughter, and it freezes the blood. The loud peals of offstage merriment that begin Mr. & Mrs. Fitch, the shrill new comedy by Douglas Carter Beane that opened on Monday night, are made by its title characters, an urbane husband and wife who are terribly, terribly amused by each other.

title: Wheeldon Says Morphoses Scheduling Prompted His Departure
description: The choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, who has decided to leave Morphoses/The Wheeldon Company, the dance troupe he created three years ago, said Monday afternoon that the reasons for his departure had been misrepresented by Lourdes Lopez, the executive director of the company. He said in an e-mail relayed by a publicist that neither Ms. Lopez nor the board asked him to give more time to the company. She only brought it up as a problem after I decided to leave, he said, also contending that he had made himself available for 17 weeks, not 10, but that the company lacked bookings for some of the weeks he was free.

title: Doctor Training Aided by Drug Industry Cash
description: More than half of the nations medical residency programs to train doctors in internal medicine accepted financial support from the drug industry, even though three-fourths of the programs directors said accepting the aid was not desirable, a survey found.

title: A Script, or Woodss Road to Recovery?
description: The best thing I heard from Tiger Woods the other day was that he is not coming back anytime soon.

title: The Future of Spaceflight? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Empathizing With Others (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Adolescents and Surgery (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Make Adjustments to Bobsled Track
description: Officials from bobsleds international governing body removed ice from some of the corners at the controversial Whistler Sliding Centre in hopes of curtailing speed and crashes.

title: Now Showing | Burberry in 3D
description: Those of you who have followed fashion long before the advent of Twitter, may remember that fairly lame attempt back in the mid-90s to beam the shows to New York live from Europe via satellite. (Yes, you heard it right, satellite!) What seemed at the time like a glimpse at the future was, in retrospect, the video conferencing equivalent of two tin cans connected together with string. But if you had told us that someday we would be watching the shows on our mobile phones we would have sent you a fax to tell you just how nuts you were. Well, some 15 years later, the future is finally up to speed. Tomorrow Burberry will stream its fall 2010 Prorsum show to around the world live and in 3D no less. Thats Lily Donaldson walking right at you folks. And lest you think Anna would be caught dead in a pair of square paper specs with blue and red cellophane lenses (okay, maybe thats not the best example because Anna will no doubt be watching the show live and in 3D from her regular perch in the front row in her regular black sunglasses) Burberry will be handing out these not-to-shabby wrap-arounds. We may just dash off to Avatar and make it a double-feature.

title: Can Obama Bypass Republicans on Health?
description: On Monday, President Obama outlined a legislative plan to overhaul health care. His blueprint, which tilts toward the Senate bill, is unlikely to win support from Republicans, or even be used as the basis for a compromise. Representative John Boehner of Ohio, the House Minority Leader, called the plan a back room deal that doubles down on the same failed approach that will drive up premiums, destroy jobs, raise taxes and slash Medicare benefits.

title: Police Are Criticized in 86 Shooting
description: QUINCY, Mass.  The authorities who investigated a 1986 shooting missed an opportunity to order a psychiatric evaluation on a neuroscientist now charged with killing three colleagues at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, a congressman who served as the local district attorney said Monday.

title: Bloggingheads: Say It Aint So, Tiger
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate Tiger Woods as a role model.

title: Foe of Iran Government Calls for Referendum
description: Defying a harsh crackdown on political protesters in Iran, one of the countrys most outspoken opposition leaders on Monday called for a national referendum to gauge the popularity of the government.

title: M.T.A. Plans to Lay Off Subway Agents
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is looking to lay off hundreds of New York City subway station agents, revising an earlier plan under which they would have been allowed to retire, according to two people with knowledge of the plans.

title: Murthas Widow Not Running
description: The widow of Representative John P. Murtha will not seek to complete her husbands unfinished term in the House.

title: Keyed In | Robert Geller Pop-Up Shop
description: Robert Geller, one of mens fashions cult ringleaders, has officially joined in on the fun of the pop-up shop. Arguably made popular by Comme des Garons guerrilla stores, a pop-up store (a good one, at least) is more like an art exhibition than a traditional retail experience  a sort of traveling circus making a pit stop in town. So ladies and gentleman, boys and girls, come in and get Gellers personal curation of the pieces from the runway that dont always make it to the stores.

title: Tomlinson Is Available, but How Much Does He Have Left?
description: LaDainian Tomlinson called his release from the Chargers a long time coming. No. 8 on the career rushing list, he hits a flimsy free-agent market as a 30-year-old who, statistically speaking, is coming off a third year of decline.

title: Take a Step Closer for an Invitation to Shop
description: LIKE many retailers, the North Face has been having trouble luring shoppers into its stores. The company, which sells outdoor apparel and gear, is about to try a new tactic: sending people text messages as soon as they get near a store.

title: Another Recession Casualty: Cuban Cigars
description: Cuban cigars  that quintessential emblem of high living, celebration and excess  have not weathered the downturn well, according to The Associated Press.

title: Scorecard (Mens Edition) | Calvin Klein Wins!
description: Dont worry, boys, Scorecard hasnt forgotten you. Today, we check in with a recap of all thats new in New York mens fashion (militaria, outsize proportions, raccoon pelts). While Calvin Kleins womens wear may have failed to square the circle, in his New York mens-wear homecoming, Italo Zucchelli scored one for the team with his quiet take on techno tailoring  relatively speaking.

title: Salt Wars
description: To salt or not to salt? To regulate right away or conduct more research first? My Findings column takes a skeptical look at the case for salt reduction. (You can also check out my colleague Jane Brodys recent column on salt.) The salt wars can be vicious, pitting what I call the salt reformers against skeptics who say there isnt enough evidence yet to justify public policies restricting salt levels. The reformers want immediate action; the skeptics want to see a randomized clinical trial. Your opinions are welcome.

title: Tip Helped Lead to Arrests in Texas Fires
description: HOUSTON  Footprints left at the scenes of fires and an anonymous tip from a caller to a federal hot line led investigators to two young men who have been arrested in connection with fires that destroyed 10 churches in East Texas, according to affidavits released in court Monday.

title: New Season, More Vocalists for Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: Voices  from jazz, blues, cabaret and gospel  dominate Jazz at Lincoln Centers 2010-11 season, its 24th, to be announced on Tuesday by that organization.

title: Straining to Define Itself, Russian Opposition Tests Limits
description: MOSCOW  For a few days this month, Moscow political circles were transfixed by a rather exotic spectacle: the leader of an opposition party was criticizing Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Leaving the Trash Behind
description: The aviation industry is often criticized for contributing to global warming through airplane exhaust. But waste of a different kind also has the potential to create environmental problems.

title: U.S. Offers Solar Project a Crucial Loan Guarantee
description: The United States Department of Energy offered a $1.37 billion loan guarantee on Monday to a California company planning to build a large-scale solar power plant in the Southern California desert.

title: Recession Tightens Grip on State Tax Revenues
description: The recession can now claim another troublesome record: state tax collections shrank at the end of 2009 for a fifth consecutive quarter, the longest period of continuing state revenue declines since at least the Great Depression, according to a new report.

title: Terrorism and Free Speech
description: Congress has made it illegal to provide material support to foreign terrorist groups  a sensible means of combating terrorism but one that carries the risk of being applied in ways that infringe on Americans freedom of expression. The Supreme Court has a chance to draw the line where it should be between banning aid to terrorists and undermining civil liberties.

title: Astor Juror Disputes Claim of Intimidation
description: After she screamed at a fellow juror in the trial of Brooke Astors son, Yvonne Fernandez said, she and the other woman made up, hugged and cried together in the bathroom. Even after the trial, Ms. Fernandez added, that fellow juror, Judi DeMarco, left her a pleasant voice-mail message.

title: Daring to Think Private Jet Again
description: HAPPY days are not quite here again in the business aviation industry, but at least there are some breaks in the clouds.

title: U.S.-Canada Game Sets Record for Viewers
description: The United States mens hockey teams 5-3 victory over Canada on Sunday night was the most watched sports program ever shown on Canadian TV. The average of 10.6 million who watched on six networks, including CTV, exceeded the 10.3 million for Canadas gold-medal-winning game over the Americans at the Salt Lake Games eight years ago.

title: Distant Wars, Constant Ghosts
description: SINCE the two recent NATO-led military strikes that accidentally killed dozens of Afghan civilians, I have been thinking a great deal about the psychic toll that killing takes on soldiers.

title: Lawmakers Ties to Toyota Questioned at Start of Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress prepares to open hearings on Tuesday into Toyotas rash of safety problems, government watchdog groups are questioning whether the deep financial and personal connections between lawmakers and the carmaker could taint the inquiries.

title: Whos Next to Be Next in Line?
description: Return with us briefly to 2006. By February of that year, the would-be governor Eliot Spitzer had announced that he wanted David A. Paterson as his lieutenant governor. Mr. Spitzer, all but hailed as the Savior by fellow Democrats, knew in his bones that he would win the November election, so why not fill the No. 2 spot nice and early?

title: Destroying C.I.A. Tapes Wasnt Opposed, Memos Say
description: WASHINGTON  At a closed briefing in 2003, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee raised no objection to a C.I.A. plan to destroy videotapes of brutal interrogations, according to secret documents released Monday.

title: The Presidents Plan
description: Perhaps if Senator Edward Kennedy had lived longer, or the election to choose his successor had turned out differently, President Obamas decision to have Congress take the lead on health care reform would have looked like a political masterstroke. It didnt turn out that way.

title: Hurdles Hinder Counterterrorism Center
description: WASHINGTON  The nations main counterterrorism center, created in response to the intelligence failures in the years before Sept. 11, is struggling because of flawed staffing and internal cultural clashes, according to a new study financed by Congress.

title: As Damon Moves on Again, Its the Nature of the Business
description: LAKELAND, Fla.

title: Last Chances, First Responses
description: What happens when a new science delivers on its promise? As terminal cancer patients begin to respond to an experimental drug, new hopes and challenges emerge. The second in a series.

title: Tasting Menu
description: You may have just missed the Berlin Film Festival, which ended Sunday, but you can still feel like a jet-setting movie star without leaving the city by paying a visit to Film Comment Select. The program, hosted by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and running through March 4, "offers a chance to sample a kind of tasting menu of the festival circuit," writes A.O. Scott. The series at the Walter Reade "seems committed above all to being interesting and to calling the attention of the cognoscenti and the merely curious to movies they might otherwise have missed." Tonight, go to see "Be Good," Juliette Garcias's directorial debut about a woman with a false identity married to a man in a rural French village.

title: Attila and Muti at the Met
description: The opera "Attila" is based on a German romantic play about Attila the Hun's attacks on Western civilization. The premise may not be everyone's idea of a fun night out, but just trust us on this one. Tonight, Riccardo Muti, the former music director and conductor of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan, will make his long-awaited debut at the Metropolitan Opera, conducting the Verdi work. "I find 'Attila' a very mysterious but exquisitely defined score," Mr. Muti said in a recent interview. "In the prologue, as the Roman general Ezio plots with Attila to divide up the empire between them, Ezio sings, 'Avrai tu l'universo, resti l'Italia a me!' 'You can have the universe, leave Italy for me!' One can just imagine the effect that line must have had in 1846, delivered by the baritone over his full octave-and-a-half range. The first performance stopped dead and the audience went absolutely crazy." This will be the company's first production of the early opera, directed by Pierre Audi, and it's worth going just to see the sets and costumes, designed by Herzog & de Meuron and Miuccia Prada.

title: Raindrops on Roses ...
description: "I do this very old-fashioned thing," the choreographer Lar Lubovitch said in a recent interview. "I design the music visually." In honor of his company's two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater, beginning tonight, Mr. Lubovitch has returned to his roots with a premiere, "Coltrane's Favorite Things," the final dance in an all-jazz program. "For the Coltrane piece," Gia Kourlas writes, "Mr. Lubovitch found inspiration in a 1963 live recording from a Copenhagen performance of the saxophonist's effervescent interpretation of Richard Rodgers's 'My Favorite Things.' " "I've known the piece of music for a long time," Mr. Lubovitch said. "It was only recently that I felt I could manage it. I like to imagine that I am not doing anything that's exactly to the music. I'm trying to write the visual line of the score that capitulates to everything but doesn't copy it." Mr. Lubovitch never studied jazz dance, but jazz is where he feels at home; the sound, as he put it, "assaults my solar plexus and causes a response in the rest of my body."

title: Pakistani Reports Capture of a Taliban Leader
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In another blow to the Taliban senior leadership, Pakistani authorities have captured Mullah Abdul Kabir, a member of the groups inner circle and a leading military commander against American forces in eastern Afghanistan, according to a Pakistani intelligence official.

title: Winn Hopes for Another Magical Run
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One year out of high school, Randy Winn had a marvelous view of college basketball at its best. He was sitting on the Santa Clara bench the night in 1993 when the 15th-seeded Broncos, fueled by a scrappy guard named Steve Nash, upset second-seeded Arizona in what remains one of the greatest upsets in N.C.A.A. tournament history. Huntsman Center in Salt Lake City pulsated with energy.

title: All Kidding Aside, Yankees Pick Park for Relief
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Pitching last October for the first time in a month, Chan Ho Park retired Manny Ramirez, Matt Kemp and Casey Blake in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series between the Philadelphia Phillies and the Los Angeles Dodgers. Asked afterward the last time he pitched that well, Park replied, An hour and 20 minutes ago.

title: Flatt Is the Picture of Efficiency, on Ice and Off It
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In the life of Rachael Flatt, the figure skater, not one minute is wasted.

title: Healing the Great Lakes
description: The Obama administration on Sunday unveiled an ambitious plan to rescue and repair the Great Lakes after a century of environmental neglect and abuse. The plan calls for spending more than $2 billion over five years on a wide range of restoration programs carried out by federal agencies, state and local governments and tribal and private groups under the guidance of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Americas Elite, and the Discontented
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Policy Analysis
description: To the Editor:

title: Teetering Pillars
description: To the Editor:

title: Unlicensed Drivers: A View From California
description: To the Editor:

title: Into the Mire
description: Barack Obama came to Washington with the nations hope for change riding on his shoulders. He promised to reform the health care system. He hired many of the countrys top experts who had written brilliantly about how to do reform.

title: Where the Bar Ought to Be
description: Deborah Kenny talks a lot about passion  the passion for teaching, for reading and for learning. She has it. She wants all of her teachers to have it. Above all, she wants her students to have it.

title: What Does It Take to Aid a Terrorist?
description: Newark

title: Beltran Says His Feelings Have Healed
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Whatever lingering resentments that might have remained in the wake of Carlos Beltrans knee operation last month were not on display as an upbeat Beltran arrived at Mets camp on Monday vowing that he had put the episode behind him.

title: After Long Fight, Drug Gives Sudden Reprieve
