description: For the melanoma patients who signed on to try a drug known as PLX4032, the clinical trial was a last resort. Their bodies were riddled with tumors, leaving them almost certainly just months to live.

title: Excess Skepticism on Schlumberger?
description: Schlumbergers shareholders have been in a state since news leaked last week of the companys bid for Smith International, its rival in the oilfield services sector. Skeptical investors have since stripped more than $5 billion from the value of Schlumberger, the industry leader, a powerful slap in the face of its chief, Andrew F. Gould. Such punishment appears excessive.

title: Balanced on a Skaters Blades, the Expectations of a Nation
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Officially, Kim Yu-na of South Korea will be judged only for her jumps and spins when the Olympic womens figure skating competition begins Tuesday. But there will be important political and cultural elements to her programs as well.

title: Its All Sweetness and Light, Until the Snowballs Fly
description: I lost it. In the middle of Ancient Playground by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with toddlers and parents and the art and wisdom of ages looking on, I completely lost it.

title: Banks Apply Pressure to Keep Fees Rolling In
description: For many households trying to improve their finances, tossing out pitches from the bank has become almost automatic. But in recent weeks, Chase has been fanning special letters out to consumers with an offer that it urges them not to refuse.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about the stage shows inspired by the actress Tallulah Bankhead misidentified a drag act named for her. It is the Dueling Bankheads  not the Dueling Tallulahs.

title: 49 Across: Like Most Promgoers
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This puzzle most likely sets a record, but one Im sure nobody is keeping track of  the most highlighted squares in a weekday puzzle. Online they have circles, in print theyre gray, with the print version definitely winning on style points.

title: F.C.C. Takes a Close Look at the Unwired
description: For many Americans, having high-speed access to the Internet at home is as vital as electricity, heat and water. And yet about one-third of the population, 93 million people, have elected not to connect.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the play La Bte, which is transferring to Broadway in September after a run in London this summer, erroneously included a play among those for which the director of the play, Matthew Warchus, was awarded a Tony. While Mr. Warchus received a Tony for directing God of Carnage, he did not win for directing Boeing-Boeing, though he was nominated.

title: In Passage of Jobs Measure, a Glimpse of Bipartisanship
description: WASHINGTON  Five Republican senators broke ranks with their party on Monday to advance a $15 billion job-creation measure put forward by Democrats, a rare bipartisan breakthrough after months in which Republicans had held together to a remarkable degree in an effort to thwart President Obamas agenda.

title: Where Scott Brown Is Coming From
description: In just 48 hours, Scott Brown would be sworn in as the newest member of the United States Senate, stepping into the shoes (and office suite) of Edward M. Kennedy and the world of woe on Capitol Hill. But as he zipped down a Massachusetts highway on an early February night, he wasnt focused on the issues he campaigned on and the problems he would soon confront: a gargantuan federal deficit; terrorism; health care reform, which his election may well have killed. He was fixated on Saturday Night Live. And how the actor Jon Hamm nailed him in a recent skit.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about various theater plans in New York, including new cast members for Enron, which is to start previews on April 8 at the Broadhurst Theater, referred incorrectly to that work. Although it includes a few songs and dances, its author, Lucy Prebble, considers it a play, not a musical.

title: Laying Out Olympic Ski Courses for Friend and Foe
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  If the coaches who set the Olympic ski courses are indeed Picassos of the snow, their artwork does not last for long.

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Tuesday about the Metropolis Ensembles Love Letter to Haiti concert at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village misspelled the surname of an artist who designed T-shirts for the event. She is Jennifer Salomon, not Solomon.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Feb. 3 about conflict within the band Aerosmith misstated the date of its most recent show. It was Nov. 1 in Abu Dhabi  not Aug. 5 in Sturgis, S.D.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz entry in the listings on Friday misidentified the drummer who is performing with the saxophonist Lou Donaldson, the organist Pat Bianchi and the guitarist Randy Johnston at Birdland on Wednesday and Thursday. He is McClenty Hunter  not Fukushi Tainaka, who had previously been scheduled to play.

title: Dr. Albert M. Kligman, Dermatologist, Dies at 93
description: Dr. Albert M. Kligman, a dermatologist who invented the widely used acne medication Retin-A but whose experiments involving prisoners raised ethical questions that dogged his career, died Feb. 9 in Philadelphia. He was 93.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Feb. 12 with a film review about October Country omitted a distributor. In addition to Wishbone Films, the movie was also released by International Film Circuit.

title: Apple Bans Some Apps for Sex-Tinged Content
description: Apple has started banning many applications for its iPhone that feature sexually suggestive material, including photos of women in bikinis and lingerie, a move that came as an abrupt surprise to developers who had been profiting from such programs.

title: Like Players, Hockey Announcer Gives His All
description: Mike Emrick announced two Olympic mens hockey games Sunday  Russias defeat of the Czech Republic and the United States win over Canada  then relaxed with his wife, Joyce, in their hotel room to watch Sweden shut out Finland.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Friday about the exhibition Contemplating the Void: Interventions in the Guggenheim Museum misstated the name of the creator of Art/Trap, a work on view. The creator is the Seoul-based firm Mass Studies, not Art Mass.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit in the Escapes pages on Friday with the continuation of an article about the Sugarbush ski resort in Warren, Vt., misspelled the photographers surname. As noted in another credit with the article, he is Brian Mohr, not Mohn.

title: Who Decides Where Gates Are Placed on Ski Course? Sometimes Its Dad
description: Imagine if Phil Mickelsons father got to select the pin placements at Augusta National before the final round of the Masters. Slight advantage for Phil, right?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an obituary about the British actor Lionel Jeffries misstated the name of the other actor shown with him in a scene from the movie The Spy With a Cold Nose. He is Eric Sykes, not Skyes.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Duane Reade and Its Road to Health
description: Good thing Duane Reade is in the pharmacy business.

title: President of San Francisco Fed Sees Slow Recovery, Especially in Jobs
description: The United States faces the prospect of a jobless recovery, with painfully slow employment growth and the economy not operating at its full potential until 2013, a top Federal Reserve official said Monday.

title: Ministers Speak on Forged Passports Linked to Killing
description: The European Union said Monday that it strongly condemns the use of forged European passports by the suspected assassins of a Palestinian leader, but it avoided any direct criticism of Israel, which has been accused of carrying out the attack. The declaration came as foreign ministers from some of the nations whose passports were counterfeited met individually with their Israeli counterpart, Avigdor Lieberman, who was in Brussels for a series of meetings. The police in Dubai have accused Israels intelligence agency, Mossad, of using fake European passports and credit cards to help plan the murder of Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, a founder of Hamass armed wing, in a hotel in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in January.

title: Nepal: Royalist Strikers Close Shops and Schools
description: Advocates of restoring the deposed monarchy waged a general strike on Monday that paralyzed the capital, Katmandu, by closing shops and schools and halting most vehicle traffic. Royalists are demanding a public referendum to decide whether to reinstate the monarchy, a move rejected by other political parties as well as the countrys Maoists. Nepal abolished the monarchy in 2008 and is now struggling to approve a new constitution.

title: On a Night to Savor Knicks Glory, the Present Disappoints Again
description: The film, as grainy as it was familiar, played on the center scoreboard. Willis Reed, hobbling, emerged from a tunnel and sent Madison Square Garden into an emotional frenzy. As the fans in the 1970 video rose and roared, the crowd watching them stood in solidarity  two generations of Knick fans connected by one poetic moment in time.

title: Ukraine: Losing Candidate Reiterates Fraud Charge
description: Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko of Ukraine, who conceded the presidential election on Saturday when she withdrew her legal challenge, reiterated her accusation on Monday that the winner, Viktor F. Yanukovich, prevailed only through fraud. In a speech, Ms. Tymoshenko said that she would not resign her post and that she would instead build a new coalition in Parliament in order to prevent Mr. Yanukovich from ousting her. A president who came to power through deception will not last long, she said. The inauguration of Mr. Yanukovich, who won by 3.5 percentage points in an election on Feb. 7 that monitors described as fair, is planned for Thursday.

title: Pakistan: 6 Killed in Suicide Bombing in Swat Valley
description: A suicide attack on a military vehicle in the Swat Valley killed at least six people, including two soldiers, according to a Pakistani security official and local news outlets. The bomber, who the official said was on foot, attacked a vehicle in central Mingora, the Swat Valleys main town. Dozens of people were reported to have been injured in the attack.

title: With Unemployment a Possibility, Manuel Can Still Laugh
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla  Jerry Manuels job security may be tenuous, but he sure has a good sense of humor about it. During an interview with reporters Monday, Manuel, a resident of Sacramento, was discussing Sandy Koufaxs visit to the Mets training camp early that morning.

title: The Presentation? That Was the Easy Part
description: I WAS asked to design stadiums for two cities, Natal and Rio Branco, both of which were bidding to host the 2014 World Cup games in Brazil. One of these cities, Rio Branco, is in northwestern Brazil.

title: Ilona Copen, a Founder of Dance Competition, Dies at 70
description: Ilona Copen, a founder of the New York International Ballet Competition and a champion of the exchange of ideas among dance companies around the world, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

title: Democrats Take Aim at G.O.P. on Stimulus Aid
description: After months of being on the defensive over stimulus spending, Democrats think they have finally been getting some offensive traction with their efforts to show that many Republicans who had nothing good to say about the economic stimulus bill were still very eager for its money to be steered to their districts.

title: Lufthansa Pilots to Continue Flying
description: PARIS  Lufthansa pilots agreed late Monday to return to work temporarily, suspending a walkout that had grounded hundreds of flights. But further strikes by French air traffic controllers and British Airways cabin crews also threatened to throw European air travel into chaos.

title: As a Career Ends, Hoping for a Title
description: Patrick Behan is a 6-foot-8 senior on the Bucknell basketball team. He is also an English major and an aspiring sportswriter. As he did last season, he will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

title: High Above Subway Repairs in Queens, but Deafened Anyway
description: The exhaust fans occupy a squat building that stands at an angle on 50th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, in a narrow lot surrounded by brush and an iron fence, behind an elegant high-rise building half a block from the East River.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 986 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans since Friday:

title: Police Kill Man Beating Mother With Pan
description: Police officers fatally shot a man in a Bronx apartment late Sunday after he refused to stop beating his mother with a frying pan, officials said on Monday.

title: E.P.A. Plans to Phase in Regulation of Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  Facing wide criticism over their recent finding that greenhouse gases endanger the public welfare, top Environmental Protection Agency officials said Monday that any regulation of such gases would be phased in gradually and would not impose expensive new rules on most American businesses.

title: Lottery Numbers
Discrimination Case Raises Old Issues
description: WASHINGTON  When the Supreme Court took up a race discrimination case on Monday brought by black firefighters from Chicago, the justices were alert to the precedential shadows cast by two of their recent decisions.

title: Assistant Hid Murder Signs, Prosecutors Say
description: Dissecting Natavia S. Lowerys every action on Oct. 30, 2007  down to a peek she took toward the cuff of her cargo pants  a prosecutor told jurors on Monday that Ms. Lowery murdered her boss in cold blood, and went to great lengths to cover it up.

title: Applications for Help on Heat Bills Rise by 15%
description: The number of households applying for home heating assistance has climbed to record levels for the third straight year, rising by 15 percent to a projected 8.8 million this winter, state energy officials said Monday. This compares with almost 7.7 million recipients last year and 5.7 million in 2008.

title: James Wieghart, Editor of Daily News, Dies at 76
description: James G. Wieghart, a former editor of The Daily News in New York who toggled between reporting on public servants and being one, writing political analysis on one side of the divide and, on the other, contributing to the final report of the independent counsel on the Iran-contra affair, died Sunday in Clare, in central Michigan. He was 76 and lived in nearby Lake City, Mich.

title: Showcase: Exiled by Weather
description: Updated | 5:45 p.m., Wednesday, March 10. Jan Grarup has responded at length, in comment No. 17, to questions and criticisms raised by readers since this post was published. In keeping with Times policy, his comment has not been edited for spelling, grammar and punctuation.

title: Word of the Day | beholden
description: beholden\bi-hol-dn, be-\ adjective

title: Canadians Secure Ice Dancing Gold
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In front of a packed arena, filled with thousands of their countrymen and hundreds of Canadian flags, it took about four minutes Monday for the Canadian ice dancers Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir to finish their free dance and make history.

title: Queens Man Kills His Family and Himself, Police Say
description: Back in November, Dionne Coy-Bailey, an assistant principal, moved out of her Queens home for a few weeks because she found her husbands gun under their bed and feared for her safety, a law enforcement official said.

title: City Orders Reductions in Lengths of Parades
description: Few events are as quintessentially and flamboyantly emblematic of New York as its parades. From Macys skyscraper-scraping balloons to the bombast of Puerto Rican Day to the feathered splendor of the West Indian American Day Carnival to the exhibitionism of gay pride, parades help New Yorkers reclaim their streets by the tens of thousands, and do what they do best: preen and strut.

title: Bringing a Rarity to Real Estate: Patience
description: Haley S. Bullock, 23, is a real estate associate at Halstead Property and executive assistant to one of its top agents, Brian Lewis. She came to New York in 2007 for her masters degree in African-American studies, planning to work in the development of poor urban neighborhoods, but a sudden illness spurred a change in course.

title: City Reconsiders Approach to Bronx Vocational School
description: City officials said Monday that they were scrapping a controversial plan to replace some vocational programs at a Bronx high school with a troubled 18-month-old charter school.

title: One Dead in Queens Double Shooting
description: One man died and another was hospitalized after a double shooting on Monday in Jamaica, Queens, the police said. Three men who fled the scene were later arrested and charges were pending.

title: Student Killed in Faculty Apartment on Manhattanville Campus
description: A student at Manhattanville College in Westchester County was found dead on Monday in a faculty apartment on campus, and the police said they were investigating the death as a homicide.

title: Big Surprises in Europe
Iran Says Capture of Rebel Is Blow to U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iranian officials on Tuesday hailed the capture of a Sunni rebel leader as a major antiterrorist coup, and sought to portray his arrest as a victory over Britain, the United States and Israel, saying those countries had supported the insurgent group.

title: News Quiz | February 23, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Avatar Director Emphasizes Environmental Message
description: I was asked to sort of tone it down, the director James Cameron said on Monday evening.

title: Excess Skepticism on Schlumberger?
description: Schlumbergers shareholders have been in a state since news leaked last week of the companys bid for Smith International, its rival in the oilfield services sector. Skeptical investors have since stripped more than $5 billion from the value of Schlumberger, the industry leader, a powerful slap in the face of its chief, Andrew F. Gould. Such punishment appears excessive, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Daring to Think Private Jet Again
description: Happy days are not quite here again in the business aviation industry, but at least there are some breaks in the clouds, Joe Sharkey writes in The New York Times.

title: Canada Wins Ice Dancing Gold
description: The Canadian team of Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir won the gold medal in ice dancing, becoming the first non-European team to win gold in the sports Olympic history.

title: Brookfield Said to Challenge Simons Takeover Bid
description: Brookfield Asset Management of Canada is preparing to bid for a large stake in the No. 2 United States mall owner, General Growth Properties, aiming to outbid Simon Property Group, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

title: BofA Brings 2 Merrill Executives Back to the Fold
description: Its a sign of the changing times at Bank of America: Two Merrill Lynch executives who fled the company are back.

title: Duane Reade and Its Road to Health
description: Last week, Duane Reade agreed to be sold to its giant rival Walgreen for a whopping $1.1 billion, including debt  an earthshaking deal for Manhattan that even topped the local evening newscasts, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: A Spot in Hockey Lore
description: WHO won a gritty 5-3 victory against WHOM in Olympic hockey Sunday night?

title: Polyvore Taps Ex-Google Executive as Chief
description: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

title: Equinix to Offer $500 Million in Senior Notes
description: Equinix, a data center service provider, said Monday it plans to offer $500 million in senior notes due 2018, The Associated Press reported.

title: Details Out on Bank C.D.O.s That Sank A.I.G.
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner took a little heat last month at the hearing of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, but details about the securities that led to American International Groups bailout slipped through without much notice.

title: Deal Seen for Stake in China Investment Bank
description: 11:22 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess David Barboza reports that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and TPG Capital have tentatively agreed to pay close to $1 billion to acquire Morgan Stanleys 34 percent stake in Chinas leading investment bank, according to people who have been briefed on the deal.

title: Distant Wars, Constant Ghosts
description: SINCE the two recent NATO-led military strikes that accidentally killed dozens of Afghan civilians, I have been thinking a great deal about the psychic toll that killing takes on soldiers.

title: Wal-Mart Says It Plans Deals in Japan
description: The Japanese unit of Wal-Mart Stores, the worlds largest retailer, said Tuesday that it would actively seek opportunities for mergers and acquisitions as a way to grow.

title: Commerzbank Deep in the Red
description: Commerzbank, Germanys second-largest lender after Deutsche Bank, posted a wider-than-estimated fourth-quarter loss after writing down investments related to bond insurers and setting aside money for bad loans, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Wall Street Exchanges Turn Lower in Closing Minutes
description: Volatility returned to Wall Street on Monday, ending a four-day winning streak for stocks, as worries over the energy sector overshadowed hopes that banks would continue to bring in generous profits.

title: Kangatarians, Vegeroos & Cameltarians
description: Vegetarians who eat kangaroo (or camel) meat.

title: Genzyme Chief May Not Go Gently
description: In the biotechnology business, where executives or even entire companies can come and go in an instant, Henri A. Termeer has been a constant.

title: Do You Get Enough Sleep?
description: A new study reports that napping can improve the brains ability to absorb new information. Do you ever have the opportunity to nap? Do you get enough sleep overall?

title: Merrills Fickle Fancy?
description: At least one legacy of the old Merrill Lynch is thriving at Bank of America, Breakingviews says: the kiss-off then embrace-back.

title: Religare Takes Stake in Northgate Capital
description: Religare Enterprises, the Indian financial services firm, has snapped up a majority stake in Northgate Capital as part of a plan to invest much as $1 billion buying up stakes in asset managers, Reuters reported.

title: Bicycle Rigged as Bomb Kills 7 in Afghan Provincial Capital
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  A few miles away from where Marines battled sporadically with Taliban insurgents hidden in protected bunkers, a bicycle rigged as a bomb exploded in a bazaar here in the capital of Helmand Province, killing 7 people and wounding 14.

title: U.S. Offers Solar Project a Crucial Loan Guarantee
description: The United States Department of Energy offered a $1.37 billion loan guarantee on Monday to a California company planning to build a large-scale solar power plant in the Southern California desert, The New York Timess Todd Woody reported.

title: Out of Africa, Zain Concentrates on Middle East
description: Zain, the Kuwaiti telecoms firm selling its African assets to Indias Bharti Airtel, will focus on the Gulf and Middle East region and is open to new investments, its chief executive said Tuesday, according to Reuters.

title: Greek Bourse Starts Trade Despite Protest
description: Greek shares began trading on time on Tuesday, unaffected by a trade union protest that sought to disrupt the session by blocking the entrance to the Hellenic Exchanges building.

title: Receiver Wants Stanford Political Donations Back
description: The court-appointed receiver of R. Allen Stanfords empire is suing Democratic and Republican party organizations for the return of $1.6 million in political contributions made by the jailed financier, The Associated Press reported.

title: Cantor Plans Futures Exchange For Film Buffs
description: Traders will soon be able to place possibly the surest bet around: the one on the next James Cameron film.

title: Intel Plans $2 Billion Fund, Report Says
description: Intel is planning to set up a $2 billion fund to invest in exclusively U.S. companies, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Buffett-Backed Chinese Automaker in Export Push
description: BYD, the Chinese auto maker backed by  billionaire Warren E. Buffett, aims to sharply boost its car exports this year, banking on improving demand as the global economy recovers, an executive told Reuters.

title: Apollo Seeks Stake in Zale, Report Says
description: Apollo Management is interested in taking a slice of Zale, the struggling jewelry chain that the private equity firm once held a minority stake in, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Sugar and Spice in Mumbais Desserts
description: An evening stroll through Mumbai is the perfect time to sample the citys signature desserts, many of which come in liquid form. Tucked away near tourist hot spots, youll find family-run stands that have been serving up local favorites for generations.

title: When States Become Dependent on Federal Aid
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.Last week, the Department of Health and Human Services gave another $4.3 billion to state governments by reducing the amount they will have to pay the federal government to offset the cost of Medicare coverage for prescription drugs.

title: Kabel Deutschland Plans I.P.O.
description: The owners of Kabel Deutschland are planning to sell a stake in Germanys largest cable operator in an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Benihana Shareholders Approve Share Issue
description: Benihanas shareholders refused to put the kibosh on a planned share issue, delivering a defeat to the heirs of the restaurant chains late founder, Rocky Aoki, and the hedge fund Coliseum Capital, The New York Post reported.

title: Love Stories
description: A look at modern gay plays, from Angels in America to a revival of Boys in the Band.

title: State of the Broncos: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: News Corp. Makes Mideast Push With Rotana
description: Rotana, the Saudi-based entertainment firm, said Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to sell a 9.09 percent stake in the Rotana Group to the News Corporation, run by Rupert Murdoch, for $70 million, Reuters reported.

title: Lloyds Chief Becomes Latest to Waive Bonus
description: Eric Daniels, the chief executive of the bailed-out Lloyds Banking Group, has waived his right to a 2009 annual bonus of more than 2 million, bowing to growing pressure on bank bosses, Reuters reported.

title: Its Getting Harder to Hate Wal-Mart
description: Todays idea: Its getting harder to hate Wal-Mart, recent articles suggest. Its shift to locally grown organic crops now yields produce to rival Whole Foodss, one says, while another says the chains stores may help curb obesity in poor neighborhoods.

title: As Deadline Nears, Hummer Deal in Trouble
description: Hostility from Chinese regulators and bank financing problems have raised two potentially insurmountable obstacles to plans by an obscure Chinese machinery company to buy General Motorss Hummer division, people close to the negotiations said on Tuesday, Keith Bradsher reported in The New York Times.

title: Goldmans P.R. Chief as Whipping Boy?
description: Goldman Sachss spokesman Lucas Van Praag, it seems, has gone from gatekeeper of the story to the story itself.

title: Morgan Stanley Sees Debt Problem Looming
description: Morgan Stanley analysts are looking at the mountain of debt held by European banks that will mature this year and next  more than 1 trillion euros  and they see a problem.

title: Sampler: Fund-Raiser for Defenestration and Palo Alto Pilots May Change Route
description: Local Fed Says Full Recovery in 2013 | Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said that the United States would continue to see a jobless recovery with the economy operating at its full potential in 2013. Speaking at the University of San Diego on Monday, Ms. Yellen predicted that the national unemployment rate, now at 9.7 percent, would drop to 9.25 percent by the end of the year and drop to 8 percent by the end of 2011. [The New York Times]

title: Speed Read for Tuesday, Feb. 23
description: Here are some highlights from Tuesdays edition of The New York Times:

title: In Iraq, Campaigning 101
description: BAGHDAD  With Iraqs short election campaign already under way, eight candidates met in a hotel conference room the other day for a late primer on something that is still a novelty here: getting themselves elected.

title: Broadway Box Office Hums a Little Louder
description: The hit Broadway revival of A Little Night Music was missing one of its stars, Catherine Zeta-Jones, to the tune of $431,825 last week  the box-office amount that Night Music dipped from the previous week,largely because ofMs. Zeta-Joness scheduled vacation.

title: With Dominance, Kim Carries the Most Pressure
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: Toyota Remains Third in Consumer Reports Brand Ranking
description: In spite of all the recalls, Toyota was ranked third in the annual spring auto issue of Consumer Reports, the same rank the carmaker had last year.

title: Cold Rush
description: How the sleepy ski town of Geilo, Norway, became one big holiday on ice.

title: Baruch College Gets a New President
description: Mitchel B. Wallerstein, the dean of the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, was named president of Baruch College on Monday.

title: Wall Street Bonuses Said to Rise 17% in 2009
description: One year after the finance industry received its massive government bailout, Wall Street firms paid out 17 percent more in bonuses, amounting to more than $20 billion, New York States comptroller said on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press and Reuters.

title: Toyota Official Says Recall May Not Fully Solve Safety Problem
description: WASHINGTON  In the first of many Congressional hearings into Toyotas extensive recalls, a senior company executive told the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Tuesday that the repairs prescribed by the company might not totally solve the problem of unintended sudden acceleration in its vehicles.

title: Variety Cold Cuts
description: News Parody | From The Onion:

title: Earth to Museum
description: Sight Gag | Correspondence included in a lighthearted book, The Pluto Files, by Neil deGrasse Tyson, director of the Hayden Planetarium at the Museum of Natural History. The letter (found here) is from a boy who noticed Plutos demotion from planetary status at the museums Rose Center for Earth and Space:

title: The Early Word: Setting the Stage
description: Both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue were pretty active on Monday, setting the stage for what could be a busy week on the health care and jobs fronts.

title: Milestones: Scott P. Brown
description: An interactive timeline of the Republican senator's life and career.

title: Air Traffic Controllers Strike Begins in France
description: The Associated Press is reporting that air traffic controllers across France began a four-day strike on Tuesday, which will cut back on half of the flights in and out of Paris Orly airport and one in four at Charles de Gaulle amid staffing shortages caused by the walkout.

title: M.T.A. to Lay Off Hundreds
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is looking to lay off hundreds of New York City subway employees, including station agents and members of the authoritys administrative and managerial staff, revising an earlier plan under which they would have been allowed to retire, according to two people with knowledge of the plans.

title: London: Body Snatchers
description: Ive been scanning the London shows and reading the reviews before I head downtown this morning to watch Burberrys live stream in 3-D, and its plain, as Sarah Mower noted in her review of the Central Saint Martins M.A. show, that the female silhouette isbeing revisualized. If some of the shapes in the Saint Martins show had not been so effective  one students renderings of jackets and bottoms were so flat as to appear perfectly steamrolled  you might have been tempted to dismiss the work as fascinating experiments. But with computer programs reshaping design, with fabrics able to hold forms or seemingly mutate, the clothes dont elicit ordinary responses.

title: For European Theater Chain, Alice in Wonderland Plans Are Off
description: As a certaincat told Alice on a visit to Wonderland: Were all mad here.

title: Despite a Price Gain in December, Signs of Worry on Housing
description: The wobbly state of the housing market was made clear on Tuesday with the release of data showing that home prices managed a modest increase in December even as many more Americans owed more on their properties than they were worth.

title: Brad DeLongs Foolishness
description: Brad looks at John Cochrane asserting that fiscal expansion does nothing but shift money around, and tries to figure out Cochranes model. Its a hopeless quest.

title: The End of the Excise Tax?
description: Ive been surprised at the blitheness with which liberal health care writers have greeted the White Houses proposal to postpone the excise tax on high-value health care plans till 2018  eight years and a political eternity away. Theres not a lot of policy news in the presidents new health-care plan, writes Ezra Klein, adding that the real story of the bill is as its always been. Jonathan Cohn digs into the excise tax issue a bit more, but concludes that the change is cosmetic: It doesnt mean sacrificing the taxs projected ability to control costs, which is what economists, including the ones who work at the Congressional Budget Office, care about.

title: White House in New Push for Changes on Wall St.
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration redoubled its efforts on Tuesday to overhaul the nations financial regulations, saying it would not back down from its efforts to restrict the trading activities of banks and to create a consumer agency to regulate financial products.

title: Surviving the Awards Season Homestretch
description: What day is today? Mark Boal asked the Bagger in a late-night phone call from London. It was Monday, and Mr. Boal had arrived in London on Sunday, just in the nick of time to receive his Bafta award for best original screenplay for The Hurt Locker, less than 24 hours after receiving an award in the same category from the Writers Guild of America in Los Angeles. We know: tough life.

title: Frill Seeker
description: If fashion is all about performance, then Chantal Thomass is a master player. Anyone familiar with the French designer instantly associates her with blunt-cut jet fringed hair, crimsonlips and a strict black and white wardrobe with an enticing bit of lingerie coyly on display. There may or may not be a corset in the mix, and a satin whip or feathered tickler might be tucked away somewhere in a tufted boudoir. The look is equal parts dominatrix and I can have it all workingwoman.

title: Evicted Artists Protest After Attack in Beijing
description: BEIJING  Nearly two dozen artists protesting the forced demolition of their homes and studios marched through the ceremonial heart of the capital before the police intervened and prevented them from reaching Tiananmen Square, the artists said Tuesday.

title: Deal Seen for Stake in China Investment Bank
description: SHANGHAI  Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and TPG Capital have tentatively agreed to pay close to $1 billion to acquire Morgan Stanleys 34 percent stake in Chinas leading investment bank, according to people who have been briefed on the deal.

title: Too Many Chefs Spoil the Dream, Part 2
description: In Part 1, negotiations with the chef and manager of Almond Bistro had reached an impasse, so, on an impulse, the author called Rick Moonen, seafood superstar, in Las Vegas.

title: Reconciliation and the Presidents Proposal
description: How viable is the reconciliation scenario? Our colleagues at Room for Debate have published some interesting perspectives on the issue. The blogger Megan McArdle of The Atlantic, for one, argues that its not possible to do any sort of comprehensive, rational overhaul of the Senate health bill via reconciliation. Find the full discussion here.

title: Bits Scan: Inside Google, the Future of Gaming and Data Breaches
description: Tuesday mornings roundup of technology news:

title: Breaking Down LeBron Jamess Suitors (Part II)
description: The second of two parts looking at teams that will have the ability to offer LeBron James a maximum contract. Mondays segment looked at the Cavaliers and the Knicks; today covers the remaining teams with enough salary-cap room to sign James.

title: Python Fill-In
Slow Eating Cuts Calories
description: Several studies now show that the pace at which you eat can influence how many calories you consume, an issue explained in todays Really? column by Anahad OConnor.

title: Toyotas Latest Legal Headache: Federal Subpoenas
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Today in Business Travel
description: Daring to Think Private Jet AgainBusiness travelers are venturing back into private aircraft after the battered economy and a public outcry against corporate jets walloped the sector in 2008.

title: Hummer Deal in Trouble
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: At F.D.I.C. , Bracing for a Wave of Failures
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is bracing for a new wave of bank failures that could cost the agency many billions of dollars and further strain its finances.

title: Scale Back Their Evil Ways
description: Monologue |  Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Do you know why it is a good day today? Ill tell you why. Because the new credit card regulations start today. Thats good news if you have credit card debt, like me. I racked up 50 grand on bedazzlers.

title: Judge Wont Turn Off Juice of MTVs Jersey Shore, For Now
description: Stephen Izzo Jr. tried, but today he stands as living proof that one man cannot halt the tide of history  or, at least, prevent the DVD release of the first season of Jersey Shorefor the time being. Mr. Izzo, 26, had gone to a New Jersey court on Monday seeking a temporary restraining order to block the DVDs release, The Asbury Park Press reported.

title: Lawmakers Erred on Raises for Judges, Court Finds
description: ALBANY  The states highest court ruled on Tuesday that New Yorks governors and legislators had violated the State Constitution by refusing to authorize pay raises for state judges for more than a decade.

title: Inside the Rings
description: Kim Yu-na of South Korea is the prohibitive favorite and Joannie Rochette, the silver medalist at the 2009 world championship, will skate days after the death of her mother.

title: Tuesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Q & A: Clinical Trials for Cancer
description: This week, Amy Harmon, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Times, is answering readers questions about her series on experimental trials for a new drug to treat melanoma. Parts 1 and 2 were published Monday and Tuesday; Part 3 was published Wednesday.

title: Mayhem on the Playground
description: In her Big City column, Susan Dominus writes about how a nice day at the playground with her 3-year-old twins turned ugly in Its All Sweetness and Light, Until the Snowballs Fly.

title: Fifty-Seven Trombones?
description: So parades, by order of the New York Police Department and to free up $3.1 million per year for more essential policing duties, were commanded Monday to shrink by 25 percent.

title: Correction
description: An earlier version of this article stated incorrectly that 500 institutions had been added to the troubled-lender list in 2009. It also erred in reporting that the collective bank profit in the fourth quarter was an improvement over the previous quarter.

title: Scan Artists
description: Question: Whats on the cover of almost every magazine, from Artforum to The National Enquirer? Clue: Its also on every book, soda can, FedEx package and airline boarding pass. Bigger clue: Black stripes.

title: Putting In a Good Word for Algae
description: A European lobbying group weighed in Tuesday on a fierce debate over the environmental value of using algae to produce biofuels for vehicles.

title: Scan Artists
description: Question: Whats on the cover of almost every magazine, from Artforum to The National Enquirer? Clue: Its also on every book, soda can, FedEx package and airline boarding pass. Bigger clue: Black stripes.

title: Iran Letter Repeats Nuclear Swap Terms Rejected by West
description: PARIS  Iran offered a formal, written response Tuesday to a Western-backed plan to defuse the crisis surrounding its nuclear ambitions, but Tehrans reply was couched in terms the United States and its allies have already dismissed, according to Iranian accounts and diplomats.

title: The Concert That Couldnt Entertain a Dead Rat
description: Whitney Houstons first Australian performance in 12 years may not have provided the comeback moment that the singer was hoping for, but it did at least yield some fantastically vituperative responses from disappointed concertgoers.

title: Ferraris Armchair Critic
description: The Ferrari Formula One team has published an odd critical column on its web site, tearing about the efforts of new teams to enter the series. In a column on the official Ferrari web site titled, The Horse Whisperer  for whom the bell tolls it criticizes the battles the new teams like USF1 and Campos are having to try to enter the sport. And it says that the FIA, which has encouraged these teams to enter the series, should have done more to keep the car manufacturers instead.

title: New Yorks Nooks Are a Challenge to Census Takers
description: One River Place blends easily into the dense forest of Manhattan skyscrapers, its vanity address camouflaging its precise location. Still, even in New York City, a 40-story tower containing 900 apartments should be difficult to miss.

title: Abbey Road Studio Is Given Protected Status
description: The long and winding road of Abbey Road news continued with an announcement on Tuesday that the British government had granted that north Londonstudio protected status as a historic building.

title: Feuding Kenyan Leaders Meet
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  After a week of playing political hard-to-get that put this country on edge and caused Kenyas stock market and currency to slide, Kenyas feuding president and prime minister finally met Tuesday.

title: Ford Polls New Yorkers on Himself and Gillibrand
description: Former Representative Harold E. Ford Jr. of Tennessee has dug into his own pocket to pay for a detailed poll, conducted over the last few days, intended to test the viability of a Senate run in New York, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Bristol Palin Will Appear on The Secret Life of the American Teenager
description: Though she and her mother may not be on the best terms with Hollywood these days, Bristol Palin plans to make her acting debut in the ABC Family series The Secret Life of the American Teenager, ABC News reported on Tuesday.

title: Teixeira Happy for Spring Continuity
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In 2007, Mark Teixeira showed up to Texas Rangers spring training in Surprise, Ariz. In 2008, he reported to the Braves facility in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. A midseason trade to the Angels presented the possibility of his returning last spring to the Cactus League. But he signed a long-term deal with the Yankees, and for the first time in three years, Teixeira has continuity.

title: List of Troubled Banks at 16-Year Peak, F.D.I.C. Says
description: After weathering the nations worst run of bank failures in nearly two decades, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced Tuesday that it had added 450 institutions to its list of challenged lenders in 2009 and warned that the industry was likely to remain under stress, The New York Timess Eric Dash reports.

title: Advice From Students Who Have Been Through It
description: As Nicole and I walked down the long, narrow aisle of her high school auditorium one recent evening, she darted to sit with a friend while I went for a seat up close. It was College Night  a chance for all interested students and parents to get the lowdown directly from seven high school seniors  and I didnt want to miss a word.

title: Philadelphia Firm Selected to Design U.S. Embassy in London
description: 1:16 p.m. | Updated The Philadelphia architecture firm Kieran Timberlake has been selected to design the new United States Embassy in London, the State Departments announced on Tuesday.

title: Tracking Congressional Hearings on Toyota
description: The Lede is following Congressional hearings in Washington this week on Toyotas safety problems. We will provide updates on the questioning of witnesses during a House Energy and Commerce Committee hearing on Tuesday. The star witness will be James E. Lentz III, the president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. My colleague Micheline Maynard is providing frequent updates on the hearings on her Twitter feed, from the room where it is taking place.

title: Inside Out | How to Serve a Wild Martini
description: Mieke ten Have The martini basics.

title: More on the Party of AARP
description: A further note in the same vein as my last post on this subject: When Reihan Salam and I co-authored Grand New Party, our book about conservative domestic policy, we didnt spend a lot of time talking about entitlements. Thats because we felt that the Republican Party had roughly the right ideas on Medicare and Social Security: Some combination of means-testing and raising the retirement age, presumably, to keep the programs from swallowing the budget in the short run, with a shift toward a voucherized system as the long-term (though possibly unachievable) goal for Medicare reform. Essentially, our view was that the G.O.P. needed to think much more creatively about discretionary spending, with a particular eye toward the challenges facing working class families, while continuing to take a pretty firm limited-government line on the question of how big we should allow our entitlement system to get.

title: Spyker Completes Deal for Saab
description: While the Hummer deal crumbles a world away, General Motors announced that it had completed a deal for at least one of its divisions.

title: War of Words Over Health Care Plans
description: Open the windows: the war of words is heating up.

title: Convictions Overturned in Bronx Firefighter Deaths
description: A Bronx judge on Tuesday overturned the convictions of the owner and former owner of a building where two firefighters died in 2005 after leaping from a window to escape the flames.

title: Rare Superman Comic Sells for $1 Million
description: Up, up and away! The comics blogosphere has been buzzing over the auction Monday of a copy of Action Comics No. 1, the first appearance of Superman. The price: $1 million.

title: Barbara Kingsolver and Lorrie Moore Among PEN/Faulkner Prize Finalists
description: Its the literary showdown that readers have been clamoring for: in one corner, Barbara Kingsolver,author of The Lacuna, the best-selling 2009 novel about art, McCarthyism, and post-World War II America; in the opposing corner, Lorrie Moore,author of last years widely praised post-9/11 novel A Gate at the Stairs. And in the three remaining corners of this five-cornered ring, the authors Sherman Alexie (War Dances); Colson Whitehead(Sag Harbor); and Lorraine M. Lpez(Homicide Survivors Picnic and Other Stories). These are the five finalists for the 2010 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, its organizers announced on Tuesday. They wereselected from nearly 350 submissions bymore than 90 publishers. The winner, to be announced in a ceremony on March 23, will receive a$15,000 prize; the four runners-up receive $5,000 each.

title: Greek Yellow Split Pea Pure
description: If youve ever been to Greece, youre probably familiar with the delicious yellow split pea puree called fava. Its served in tavernas all over the country and is standard fare on the Lenten table. Its important to cook the split peas for a very long time, slowly, until they disintegrate into a pure. Greeks use much more olive oil than this recipe calls for, and they top their fava with chopped onion, sometimes caramelized and mixed with fresh herbs. I prefer a drizzle of olive oil. Yellow split peas are easy to find in Mediterranean and Indian markets, as well as many supermarkets.

title: State Revenues Fall Further
description: State tax revenues continued to plummet in the last quarter of 2009, aggravating states budget shortfalls and potentially increasing their dependence on federal aid.

title: Counting Conundrums
description: Map of the hard to count census tracts in New York City.

title: Last Tony-Winning Billy Sets Final Performance
description: Trent Kowalik, one of three actors to win the Tony Award for his performance as the title character in Billy Elliot: The Musical, will leave the show after his March 7 performance, its publicists said on Tuesday. Mr. Kowalik originated the role in the musicals Broadway production with Kiril Kulish, who left the show in October, and David Alvarez, who left in January. Michael Dameski, Alex Ko, Liam Redhead and Dayton Tavares will continue to perform the role in rotation.

title: Afghan Leader Asserts Control Over Election Body
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  To the dismay of his political opponents and many of his international backers, President Hamid Karzai has moved to ensure that he can handpick members of an electoral monitoring commission, removing significant United Nations oversight of future elections.

title: Quote Unquote | Dont Hem Her In
description: Carey Mulligan on turning down Anna Wintours advice. We knew we liked her for a reason.

title: New Disclosure Rules for Free Credit Reports
description: 2/24/10 | Updated to note Experian comment

title: Hiring Freezes Hamper Weatherization Plan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas plan to create jobs and rein in energy costs through a steep increase in money for weatherizing the homes of low-income Americans has so far borne little fruit, with many of the biggest states meeting less than 2 percent of their three-year goals to date, the Department of Energys inspector general said in a reportTuesday.

title: Penguin Press Rushes Tony Judt Book to Stores
description: Just weeks after the historian Tony Judt put the finishing touches on the manuscript for Ill Fares the Land, a book based on a lecture about social democracy that Mr. Judt delivered at New York University in the fall, the book will be in stores starting March 18. The manuscript was rushed into print by Penguin Press. Mr. Judt, who hasLou Gehrigs disease, is also the host ofan invitation-only seminar at New York UniversitysRemarque Institute, where he is the director, with a gathering of international scholars in April.

title: Q&A: Two Weeks in Peru (Ecuador Must Wait)
description: Q.

title: Frances Air Traffic Controllers Are Latest to Strike
description: PARIS  French air traffic controllers began a five-day strike on Tuesday, causing thousands of travelers to be stranded across the country the day after a walkout by Lufthansa pilots had forced the cancellation of hundreds of flights in neighboring Germany.

title: Fewer Jobs, Fewer Commuters
description: Yet another casualty of the recession: commuters. The Associated Press reports:

title: Chinas Han Flock to Theme Parks Featuring Minorities
description: MANZHA, China  Tucked away in Chinas steamy tropical southwest are the villages of the Dai people, famous throughout the country for a raucous annual tradition: a water-splashing festival where the Dai douse one another for three days in the streets using any container they can get their hands on  buckets, wash basins, teacups, balloons, water guns.

title: No Brownies at Bake Sales, but Doritos May Be O.K.
description: Nine months after effectively banning most fund-raising food sales in city schools, a city panel will vote Wednesday on an amended regulation that will allow student groups to sell items like Pop-Tarts and Doritos during the school day, but not brownies, zucchini bread or anything else homemade.

title: What Were Reading
Yale Drama Series Prize Awarded
description: Virginia Grise, a writer, performer and teacher, has won the Yale Drama Series $10,000 playwriting prize for blu, a work about how a Mexican-American family copes with the death of its eldest son, a soldier in Iraq. The English playwright David Hare, who chose Ms. Grises drama out of 960 submissions, said in the announcement of the award that, Virginia Grises writing is blazingly talented and resonant and the play stays with you long after youve read it. The prize, which is jointly sponsored by Yale University Press and Yale Repertory Theater and funded by the David C. Horn Foundation, also means that blu will be published and will havea reading at Yale. The runners-up are Siona MacDuff by Mary Hamilton and Nineteen Kinds of Peril by Tom Lavignino.

title: Back to Basics on Climate and Energy
Young Swiss Stays Cool and Takes Giant Slalom
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  On the Swiss Alpine team, they call Carlo Janka the Iceman, something Janka finds amusing.

title: House Hunting in ... Hungary
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE ON LAKE BALATON

title: Full Court Press
description: Jeff Schers video captures the commotion surrounding a lawyer for Najibullah Zazi, the Afghan immigrant who eventually pleaded guilty to terrorism charges in Brooklyn.

title: Washington Sends Delegation to Moscow, via Silicon Valley
description: MOSCOW  Call it geek diplomacy.

title: Correction: In Vietnam, Traveling an Unlikely Beer Trail
description: A picture caption on Feb. 21 with an article about tasting local and regional beers in Vietnam misidentified the type of beer shown being delivered in Hanoi in the top photograph. It is Bia Ha Noi, as labeled on the boxes  not bia hoi, Hanoi's local draft beer.

title: Intel Was Attacked at the Same Time as Google
description: 7:20 p.m. | Updated  Adding update from Intel spokesman about the possibility of other similarities between the Google and Intel attacks.

title: Correction: Offering Whatever Floats Your Boat
description: An article on Feb. 14 about whats new in cruising in 2010 misstated the itinerary of the new Queen Elizabeths maiden voyage this fall. The ships maiden voyage, departing Oct. 12, sails from Southampton, England, to the Canary Islands in the Atlantic  not to the Mediterranean. Its second voyage, departing Oct. 25, sails from Southampton through the Mediterranean to Naples, Italy. And a picture caption misidentified the river on which a Viking River Cruises vessel is shown sailing as it passes the Schloss Johannisburg in Aschaffenburg, Germany. It is the Main, not the Danube.

title: Brides on Parade
description: It wasnt quite a six-hour celebration, but the procession through the streets of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Monday featuring African drums and dozens of women in white dancing through the doors of a baptist church sure was festive. What it was, in fact, was a wedding, filmed for the TLC nuptial round-robin show Four Weddings. Check out the whole story, with slideshow, at our sister blog The Local.

title: Elsewhere: Fashion Buzzwords
description: The Global Language Monitor has designated Lady Gaga as the top fashion buzzword for the forthcoming season.

title: Republican Senators: Well Be There
description: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, has announced the Senate Republican delegationthat he will lead to the health care summit meeting on Thursday. They are:

title: French Ad Shocks, but Will It Stop Young Smokers?
description: PARIS  A new French antismoking advertisement aimed at the young that plays off a pornographic stereotype has gotten more attention than even its creators intended, and critics suggest that it offends common decency and creates a false analogy between oral sex and smoking.

title: A Strange Sequel to the Astor Trial
description: Everyone following the Astor trial, in which the now elderly son of the philanthropist Brooke Astor was accused of looting his mothers fortune, knew the case wasnt really over when the jury rendered its resounding guilty verdict in October.

title: Republican Senators: Well Be There
description: At our sib-blog, Prescriptions, colleague David M. Herszenhorn is following the lead-up to Thursdays summit on health care. The latest? The list of G.O.P. senators planning to attend. Read the full post.

title: Photos of the Moment | Vivienne Westwood
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Cameron Smith.

title: Ukraines New President to Visit Brussels Before Russia
description: MOSCOW  President-elect Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, who tried during the campaign to shed his reputation as an obedient Kremlin ally, intends to make his first foreign trip after taking office to Brussels, not Moscow, officials said on Tuesday.

title: Tips to Jazz Up Your Oscar Party
description: When you think Oscars, you think Bingo!, right? The Academys reaching-out-to-the-youth campaign continues with snazzy party-planning tips on its Web site, including a downloadable card for Oscar bingo, with squares for Crying, Winner Accepts Oscar in a Foreign Language and, mystifyingly, Lauren Bacall. (Spoiler?!)

title: You Can Park Your Bike, but at What Price?
description: When the city adopted a new law to allow bicycle access to office buildings  under certain conditions  advocates celebrated the move as a positive  if imperfect  step toward even greater bicycle commuting.

title: Bay Enters Camp With a Fresh Perspective
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Bay parked his Toyota S.U.V. in his new designated parking spot, got out of the vehicle and searched for an entrance to the clubhouse. He stopped, looked around a bit more, then spotted a group of photographers standing 50 yards away awaiting his arrival.

title: Madonnas Publicist Leaving Warner Brothers After 39 Years
description: Madonnas longtime publicist, Liz Rosenberg, a 39-year veteran of Warner Brothers Records, will leave the label to start her own firm at the end of February, the company announced on Tuesday. Some of the artists she works with at Warner Brothers, including Michael Bubl and Cher, will move with her to the new agency, Liz Rosenberg Media.

title: Answers About Same-Sex Couples and Taxes: Part 1
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Excerpts From an Interview With Mario Batali and Mark Morris
description: When the choreographer Mark Morris is not rehearsing his company, the Mark Morris Dance Group, or creating new works for ballet or opera houses, he can often be found eating, both at home and in restaurants around the world, including those of his fellow Washington state native, the celebrity chef Mario Batali. Since the two met 10 years ago, they have become fans of each others work. Over a boozy dinner at Mr. Batalis Del Posto, they talked about art and ice skating, the work of their colleagues, Michelle Obama and much more, often in language too blue for a family newspaper. They will continue the conversation in a discussion at BAM on Thursday at 6 p.m. as part of the Morris companys engagement there, which will include the world premiere of Socrates Wednesday. Here are excerpts from their dinner interview.

title: Jumble Fever
description: Matchy-matchy is so last decade. More

title: The Palin Roundup
description: It may only be Tuesday, but it has already been a busy week for the Palin family of Wasilla, Alaska.

title: The Snackbot at Work
description: A demonstration of the Snackbot, a robot developed at Carnegie Mellon University that is one of a growing number of robots designed to serve and cook food. (Video courtesy of Carnegie Mellon University.)

title: Cheney Sustained Mild Heart Attack
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney sustained a minor heart attack but was expected to be released from the hospital within a day or two, according to a statement released by his office.

title: Full Court Press
description: I walk past the United States District Court building in Brooklyn almost every day. One sunny morning a few months ago, the courthouse entrance was swarming with the news media. The light was handsome, and the scale of the event was intriguing, so I joined in, even though I had no idea what was going on.

title: New Hotel Search For Disabled Travelers
description: Searching for a hotel for disabled travelers just got easier.

title: Salingers Quote-Me-Not Letters Going on View
description: This months decision by the Morgan Library and Museum to lift restrictions on a cache of letters, written by the late J.D. Salinger to his longtime friend, Mike Mitchell, has fans of the reclusive author clamoring for a peek.

title: A Conversation With Mark Morris and Mario Batali
description: When the choreographer Mark Morris is not rehearsing his company, the Mark Morris Dance Group, or creatingworks for ballet or opera houses, he can often be found eating, both at home and in restaurants around the world, including those of his fellow Washington State native, the celebrity chef Mario Batali. Since the two met 10 years ago, they have become fans of each others work. Over a boozy dinner at Mr. Batalis Del Posto in Chelsea, they talked about art and ice skating, the work of their colleagues, Michelle Obama and much more, often in language too blue for a family newspaper. They will continue the conversation in a discussion at the Brooklyn Academy of Musicon Thursday at 6 p.m. as part of the Morris companys engagement there, which will include the world premiere of Socrates tonight. Here are excerpts from their dinner interview.

title: BofA Shareholders Approve TARP Payback Plan
description: Shareholders of Bank of America on Tuesday approved an increase in the banks common shares to finance its repayment of government bailout money, The Associated Press reports.

title: London Sips a Different Cup
description: IF the Nuova Simonelli espresso machine on the counter at Present, an airy mens clothing store in East London, seems a little extra shiny, thats because its a trophy: Gwilym Davies won it at last years World Barista Championship.

title: Hot Plates | Aspen Eating
description: As perennial host to the Food & Wine Classic, Aspen, Colo., is no stranger to good food. Or, for that matter, big names in the restaurant business. But this season, the ski town is giddily bingeing on a new crop of restaurants, with a trio of Italian openings leading the way.

title: Restart, Acorn Edition
description: As has been widely reported, Acorn is straining and possibly dissolving as a national organization as state chapters distance themselves from the beleaguered community organizing outfit amid a wave of negative press and Congressional pressure.

title: Just Like Mombot Used to Make
description: PITTSBURGH

title: Mission District Merchants Say No to Sunday Metered Parking
description: As San Francisco considers requiring people to pay for metered parking on Sundays, Mission Local reporters canvassed 131 Mission District businesses last week and found that 80 percent were against the proposed meter extension.

title: N.H.R.A. to Investigate Crash That Led to Fans Death
description: The National Hot Rod Association and Don Schumacher Racing say they have begun investigating the circumstances that led to an accident that resulted in the death Sunday of a female spectator at the Arizona Nationals at Firebird International Raceway in Chandler, Ariz., a suburb of Phoenix.

title: Fire Marshals Say Blaze at Philadelphia Record Studio Was Deliberately Set
description: A fire broke out on Sunday morning at Philadelphia International Records, where Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff perfected the Philadelphia sound of smooth R&B for singers like Teddy Pendergrass and Patti LaBelle, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The fire swept through the labels office area, melting gold and platinum records and destroying much of its memorabilia, but it spared the historic studio and the labels tape library, according to the newspaper.

title: Dysfunction Function: Charting the Ideal and Real Legislative Process
description: Overview | How does the way Congress was designed to function differ from how it actually operates? How do bills really become laws? What factors contribute to Congressional gridlock? In this lesson, students chart the basic process of how a bill becomes a law, and then consider Senator Evan Bayhs criticisms of the Senate. They then dig into a current piece of legislation and create a detailed flow chart showing the complexity of the real process. Finally, they create political trees for members of Congress, showing key relationships, connections and interests.

title: InterContinental Takes a Chance With a New Hotel
description: Boutique and high-style hotels have sprung up in New York in recent years, their lounges studded with celebrities and their restaurant menus developed by famous chefs. But big hotels that cater to tourists and business travelers have come along only rarely.

title: White House Urges Repeal of Insurers Antitrust Exemption
description: 4:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Roger Eberts Voice, Lost and Found
description: Film critic Roger Ebert is best remembered sitting in a theater seat, delivering a sharp, witty review of the latest movie. But in recent years, cancer of the thyroid and salivary glands left him without a lower jaw, and he can no longer eat or speak.

title: Feeding a Fad
description: Virtually unknown outside the Amazon two decades ago, aa is now an international celebrity, thanks to the antioxidant craze.

title: The Morning Skate: TV Ratings Soar for U.S.-Canada Game
description: MSNBCs audience for Sundays United States-Canada preliminary-round Olympic mens hockey game, 8.22 million viewers, was the second highest in the history of that network, only slightly behind its ratings on election night in 2008, when 8.23 million watched.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Feb. 23
description: The payoff for weeks of preparation by the photographer Doug Mills (described in Up for the Downhill on Lens) can be seen in Slide 12 of Tuesdays presentation, showing Bode Miller making his way through a gate at the Winter Olympics.

title: Clybourne Park Extended Until March 21
description: After strong reviews from theater critics on Monday, Playwrights Horizons announced on Tuesday that its Off Broadway production of the new play, Clybourne Park, would extend its run by two weeks and is now scheduled to close on March 21.

title: ABC News to Cut Hundreds of Staff Members
description: In what it called a fundamental transformation, ABC News said Tuesday that it was seeking to substantially reduce its staff, possibly by up to 25 percent.

title: Reader Response: Traffic and the Recession
description: In response to our post noting the decline in riders on the Metro-North line, a reader named Tucker Morgan writes:

title: Top Legal Officer Stepping Aside at Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley said Tuesday that its chief legal officer, Gary G. Lynch, was stepping aside to concentrate on his duties as vice chairman in London, working with regulators overseas.

title: A Hawk For All Seasons
description: You might think it would be hard to be an inflation hawk, demanding monetary tightening now now now, in the current environment. For one thing, theres no inflation. And theres also mass unemployment. Based on historic Fed behavior, the combination of these two factors should mean a Fed funds rate of around -6 percent; since the Fed cant do that, it ought at least to keep rates near zero for a long time, probably at least the next two years.

title: The Washington Area Primps as Northrop Grumman Shops for a New Home
description: WASHINGTON  The announcement last month that Northrop Grumman would move its headquarters to the Washington area after 72 years in Los Angeles has set off a feverish competition among local governments to land the company, one of the nations largest military contractors.

title: Sound (and Fury), Signifying Oscar
description: In the Baggers continued quest to help you win your Oscar pool, we present  finely tuned drumroll, please  a primer on the sound awards. (If you need a background of false information on the technical stuff, watch this video about foley artists.) The nominees this year for sound editing and sound mixing are Avatar, The Hurt Locker, Inglourious Basterds and Star Trek for both categories; Up rounds out the group for editing and Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen for mixing.

title: A Home Outside of Budapest
description: A five-bedroom house on Lake Balaton, about 130 kilometers (80 miles) southwest of Budapest, is on the market for 280,000 euros ($355,000).

title: Bathroom Rule Rankles Vendors
description: More than 20 street vendors gathered outside the headquarters of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday to protest a policy that bans vendors from leaving their carts, even for bathroom breaks.

title: Deep in Vogue | The September Issue DVD
description: The fashion worlds favorite new parlor game  watching The September Issue, R.J. Cutlers hilarious documentary about the making of Vogues bumper 2007 issue  just got even more entertaining. Todays DVD release contains 90 minutes of extra footage, including a side-splitting cover-line meeting; Anna Wintour admonishing Olivier Theyskens, then at the helm of Nina Ricci, for rescheduling one of his shows (Youll never do that again, Wintour proclaims); and plenty of gems from the films accidental breakout vedette, Grace Coddington. Sadly, no bonus clips of Andr Leon Talley playing tennis.

title: N.H.L.s Stance on Olympics Faces Challenge
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Gary Bettman could be finding himself boxed into a corner, his position that N.H.L. participation in future Olympics may not be worth the sacrifice rendered untenable by the big television audience last Sunday for the game between Canada and the United States.

title: From President Charles Logan to Kenneth Lay
description: Gregory Itzin, who played one of the most memorable baddies on television in recent years  the Nixonian president of the United States, Charles Logan, in the Fox series 24  has been cast in the role of Enron chairman Kenneth L. Lay in the forthcoming Broadway production of Lucy Prebbles play Enron.

title: Fashion Week | Mens Roundup
description: The womens fall shows have just begun (London, Milan and Paris are still to come), but the mens circuit, which has a different calendar, ended with New York. A lot of the trends from Paris and Milan were confirmed here: extreme layering, lots of fur, knit pants and rugged explorer boots. Here is a roundup of some of the standout mens looks from New York fashion week.

title: A Three-Dimensional Business Card
description: Jrg Ebers decided that instead of looking for an architecture job, he would construct a building of his own.

title: How the Summit Will Be Organized
description: President Obama says he is eager for substantive negotiations when he convenes Democrats and Republicans for a bipartisan health summit at Blair House on Thursday. But before those negotiations, there are other negotiations  talks about who sits where, who gets to talk and precisely what the agenda will be.

title: The Obama Treatment
description: Ever since his days as a community organizer, President Obama has believed that by listening and appealing to reason, he can bring people together to get results. But will his gentle, consensus-building style be enough to pass health legislation?

title: Australian Bobsled Team Pulls Out
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The Australian bobsled team withdrew from the four-man competition on Tuesday, as two of its athletes recover from injuries sustained during crashes in the two-man competition.

title: Gates Calls European Mood a Danger to Peace
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, who has long called European contributions to NATO inadequate, said Tuesday that public and political opposition to the military had grown so great in Europe that it was directly affecting operations in Afghanistan and impeding the alliances broader security goals.

title: Broken Hearts, Bleeding Psyches
description: A couple of highball glasses were shattered, by actors and ostensibly by accident, the night I saw the Transport Groups site-specific revival of The Boys in the Band. And the awareness of dangerous shards on the floor of the Chelsea penthouse where this production is performed surely increased the audiences already palpable unease.

title: In Berlin, Filling a Gap
description: In 1999, Jrg Ebers was 30 years old, living in Berlin and finishing his architectural degree. But instead of looking for an architecture job, he decided to construct a building of his own. I was hoping for something I could both live in and use as a kind of three-dimensional business card, said Mr. Ebers, 40, who now has his own architecture company, Ebers Architekten.

title: Outlook for All Points West Festival in Jersey City This Summer Is in Doubt
description: It may be only February, but for the concert industry the summer is already here, with artists completing their tour schedules and festivals releasing their lineups. Bonnaroo, in Tennessee in June, has announced most of its 100-plus acts, and blogs have been buzzing for weeks about who is expected for Lollapalooza in Chicago in August.

title: Miguel Tejada: Im a New Man
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Few players have been involved in as many uncomfortable issues as Miguel Tejada, who reported to Baltimore Orioles training camp here on Tuesday.

title: Last-Minute Winter Getaways
description: WELL, O.K., maybe you miscalculated. You thought youd be able to tough out a New York winter without getting away. But now, with the cold, dreary weather  not to mention blizzards  dragging on, you find yourself craving a hit of warmth and sunshine. What you need is a quick, last-minute, long-weekend escape, to get you over the final hump of winter.

title: 'The Nose'
description: William Kentridge talks about his new production of Shostakovich's opera. (Video courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera)

title: 36 Hours in Telluride, Colo.
description: TELLURIDE almost begs comparisons with Aspen. A Colorado mining town affixed to a world-class ski resort; rugged locals brushing elbows with the occasional celebrity; white tablecloth restaurants serving up foie gras next to taco dives. Its like Aspen was back in the 70s, but less pretentious, said Bo Bedford, a self-described Aspen refugee who is a manager at the New Sheridan Hotel. It hasnt gone Hollywood yet. There is, of course, a certain star-studded film festival. And Telluride does count Jerry Seinfeld and Tom Cruise among its regulars. Yet, the town stays true to its hardscrabble roots. Dogs roam off-leash, folks rummage for freebies at a so-called Free Box, and residents zip up in flannel instead of fur coats.

title: Social Change and the Oscars
description: If ever you doubted the greater good of an Oscar nomination  if ever you thought this whole awards season stuff was just a bunch of razzle-dazzle designed to give people who already hold themselves in pretty high regard even more cause for self-congratulation, not to mention giving them more money, more glamorous stuff to wear, parties to attend and free stuff to paw through  then perhaps you should talk to a Burmese monk.

title: Make Your Beer and Drink It, Too
description: BY 8:30 a.m., Glen Nile was elbow-deep in a bucket of Cascade hops, pulling apart the dry pods and releasing the lupulin, a resinous substance that plays a crucial role in the creation of beer. Meanwhile, Errol Chase, who goes by Butch, was pouring pints of oatmeal stout.

title: Israel With a Russian Accent (and Pork)
description: MARINA from Belarus and Ida from Ukraine were selling jewelry on fold-up tables by the beach, alongside Malka from Georgia. On the way over, I had met Natalya from Russia and Igor from Uzbekistan, who were holding hands as they strolled around a hilltop park, sunning themselves on a sparkling winter afternoon. Should it have been any surprise that Yana, the saleswoman at the nearby mall, grew up in Azerbaijan?

title: White House Still Committed to Strict Volcker Rule
description: The Obama administration said Tuesday that it was still committed to the Volcker Rule, its proposal to ban risky trading by banks, although Congress looks increasingly unlikely to adopt as strict a rule as the White House wants, Reuters reports.

title: Art Takes Root in Fertile Soil in Spain
description: FOUR years ago I would have told you that none of this would be possible here in Murcia, said Jos Martinez Calvo, a native of this province in the southeast corner of Spain and a respected art dealer who owns the Madrid gallery Espacio Mnimo. When my colleagues here told me what they were planning, I told them all to have a Plan B because this was just never going to happen.

title: Magazine Ranks Most Bike-Friendly Cities
description: In its March issue, National Geographic Traveler ranks the most bike-friendly cities in the United States for visitors. Topping the list, predictably, is Portland, Ore., which boasts dozens of bike rental shops, 75 miles of bike paths and guided bike tours along its waterfront and nearby gorges.

title: Where Puccini Might Shop in Rome
description: OVER the years, an impressive array of artists  Fellini, Picasso, Stravinsky, Puccini  have lived, found inspiration and created masterpieces on the Via Margutta, a tiny street in Rome barely the width of an SUV and tucked just away from the Spanish Steps.
