Then Joe Bradley moved in. Gregory Pecks character in Roman Holiday had a flat there, and apparently nothing elevates an address in the public consciousness better than Audrey Hepburn lilting, Via Margutta, 51. Presto: a real estate star was born.

title: Stretching Winter: 5 North American Spots for Spring Skiing
description: MOUNTAIN folks know that spring is often the best time to ski. The snow base is deep, with a winters worth of accumulation. Bluebird days are more plentiful. And as the temperature rises, the crowds and high-season prices melt away. Here are five of the top North American spots for spring skiing.

title: Yankees Looking to Avoid a Championship Hangover
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There are usually so many ancillary issues surrounding the Yankees that one of General Manager Brian Cashmans favorite (and more optimistic) sayings  Camp Quiet  goes unspoken. What passes for noise around these parts (aside from Nick Swisher) is the contract status of Joe Girardi, Mariano Rivera and Derek Jeter, who on Wednesday morning will address the non-issue for the first and only time this season.

title: A Trade School Where Ideas Are Currency
description: On Sunday evening, 16 people gathered in a cramped Lower East Side storefront for a class on making irrational decisions. One woman was between jobs and apartments and wanted help thinking things through; the artist sitting next to her wanted to shut off the part of her brain that impedes creative thinking. No money changed hands. Instead, the teacher asked everyone to pay for the class by bringing ideas  an example of a good decision made in the last two weeks, and one made in the last five years.

title: Hotel Review: Shattuck Plaza Hotel in Berkeley, Calif.
description: THE BASICS

title: Toyota Sees Growing Anger From Suppliers in Japan
description: KARIYA, Japan  As Toyotas president Akio Toyoda faces American lawmakers on Wednesday, his company will be facing something else here in Japans auto manufacturing heartland: an unprecedented level of opprobrium.

title: Off the Menu: The Lion to Be A Throwback to Delmonicos
description: John DeLucie, the executive chef and a partner at The Waverly Inn in Greenwich Village, will wear a second toque come spring, when he opens The Lion, a new restaurant in the space on West Ninth Street that was Village. Through his publicist, Mr. DeLucie said that he has no plans to leave The Waverly Inn, apart from a brief hiatus of several weeks while he gets The Lion up and running.

title: Book Review: The Routes of Man: How Roads Are Changing the World and the Way We Live Today
description: The symbolic value of the road may be as crucial for civilization as its ancient function in easing the transport of goods and soldiers. Poets have long viewed the ups and downs of a tortuous path worn smooth over time as a potent metaphor for the course of life itself. To young Americans after World War II, the highway promised escape and happy fortuity, while for less mobile societies it has been as much a source of trouble as a way out of it  the means by which the destructive stranger, novelty or virus comes to town.

title: Protected Status for Abbey Road Studio
description: The long and winding road of Abbey Road news continued with an announcement on Tuesday that the British government had granted that north London recording studio protected status as a historic building. Margaret Hodge, the culture minister, said in a statement that Abbey Road, made famous by the Beatles, had been granted Grade II status, which does not prohibit changes to the building but stipulates that care must be taken to ensure that any alterations with respect to its character and interest are fully considered. The decision was made on the advice of English Heritage, a government preservation agency, the statement said. Its a testament to both the importance of music in peoples lives as well as the passion this kind of issue stirs up, that so much interest has been generated by the perceived threat to the future of Abbey Road, Ms. Hodge said, alluding to the public outcry over reports last week that EMI, the studios longtime owner, had put it up for sale. EMI has denied those reports and said that it was seeking financial support to revitalize Abbey Road.

title: Penguin Press Rushes to Publish Tony Judt
description: Just weeks after the historian Tony Judt put the finishing touches on the manuscript for Ill Fares the Land, based on a lecture about social democracy that Mr. Judt delivered at New York University in the fall, the book will be in stores starting March 18. The manuscript was rushed into print by Penguin Press. Mr. Judt, who has Lou Gehrigs disease, will also be the host of an invitation-only seminar at New York Universitys Remarque Institute, where he is the director, with a gathering of international scholars in April.

title: Supermans Debut Comic Sells for $1 Million
description: Up, up and away! The comics blogosphere has been buzzing over the sale on Monday of a copy of Action Comics No. 1, the first appearance of Superman, right. The price: $1 million. Interest in the sale generated enough traffic to bring down the Web site of the seller, Comic Connect, which posted a note explaining, Due to the exceedingly high volume of traffic, the site has been temporarily replaced with this news article about the record selling comic. The sale breaks the record of $317,200 from last March when Comic Connect sold another copy of Action No. 1, but in a lower-grade condition. Only 100 copies of Action No. 1 are believed to still exist. Comic books are now in the same realm as fine art, one-of-a-kind jewels and antiques, Vincent Zurzolo, chief operating officer and co-owner of Comic Connect, said. If you look at the impact that a piece of fine art has on the world, compared to the impact that Superman has had, I think you would have to say more people know Superman. A big question among comics fans is, Who made the purchase? Alas, both customers want to retain their secret identities, Mr. Zurzolo said of the buyer and seller.

title: Kingsolver and Moore: Pen/Faulkner Finalists
description: Its the literary showdown that readers have been clamoring for: in one corner, Barbara Kingsolver, top left, author of The Lacuna, the best-selling 2009 novel about art, McCarthyism and post-World War II America; in the opposing corner, Lorrie Moore, top right, author of last years widely praised post-9/11 novel A Gate at the Stairs. And in the three remaining corners of this five-cornered ring, the authors Sherman Alexie, above right (War Dances); Colson Whitehead, above left (Sag Harbor); and Lorraine M. Lpez (Homicide Survivors Picnic and Other Stories). These are the five finalists for the 2010 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, its organizers announced on Tuesday. They were selected from nearly 350 submissions by more than 90 publishers. The winner, to be announced on March 23, will receive a $15,000 prize; the four runners-up receive $5,000 each.

title: ABC Teenager Show Lands Bristol Palin
description: Though she and her mother may not be on the best terms with Hollywood these days, Bristol Palin plans to make her acting debut in the ABC Family series The Secret Life of the American Teenager, ABC News reported on Tuesday. On that ABC Family show, about an unwed teenage mother dealing with the consequences of her pregnancy, Ms. Palin will play a fictionalized version of herself, who meets the shows lead character at a music program for teenage moms. Ms. Palin, 19, a daughter of the Republican vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin, revealed that she was pregnant during the 2008 campaign and gave birth to a son, Tripp, on Dec. 27 of that year. She and her mother recently came into conflict with the Fox network when they criticized its animated show Family Guy for a joke they believed was about Sarah Palins son Trig, who has Down syndrome.

title: Charlie Sheen Enters Rehabilitation Center
description: Charlie Sheen, right, the star of televisions most popular sitcom, Two and Half Men, has entered a rehabilitation center, his spokesman said on Tuesday afternoon. Calling the time in rehabilitation a preventative measure, the spokesman, Stan Rosenfield, said in a statement that Mr. Sheen would take some time off from the series, but did not comment on the length of time or the kind of rehabilitation Mr. Sheen was undergoing. Earlier this month Mr. Sheen was charged with felony menacing after a Christmas Day dispute with his wife, the actress Brooke Mueller. Warner Brothers, which produces Two and a Half Men, had no immediate comment about how the shows production schedule would be affected by Mr. Sheens absence. Two and a Half Men is the cornerstone of CBSs Monday-night comedy lineup and averages about 16 million viewers a week.

title: Last Original Billy Sets Final Performance
description: Trent Kowalik, one of three actors to win the Tony Award for his performance as the title character in Billy Elliot the Musical, will leave the show after his March 7 performance, its publicists said on Tuesday. Mr. Kowalik originated the role in the musicals Broadway production with Kiril Kulish, who left the show in October, and David Alvarez, who left in January. Michael Dameski, Alex Ko, Liam Redhead and Dayton Tavares will continue to perform the role in rotation.

title: More Guilty Verdicts in Trial of Concrete-Testing Firm
description: The president and vice president of a prominent concrete-testing company in New York were convicted on Tuesday of a scheme that involved falsifying steel test reports for a major construction project.

title: Charlie Sheen Enters Rehabilitation Center
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated Production of Two and a Half Men will be temporarily suspended while Charlie Sheen is in rehabilitation, according to a joint statement from Warner Brothers, CBS and Chuck Lorre, the shows executive producer.

title: Rep. Steve King and the I.R.S.
description: Representative Steven A. King, Republican of Iowa, has drawn criticism in recent days after news reports indicated that he expressed empathy for Andrew Joseph Stack III, the disgruntled computer engineer who crashed a small plane into an office building last week, killing himself and an employee of the Internal Revenue Service. Mr. Stack left behind a rambling suicide note that expressed anger at the I.R.S., which had 190 employees in the building.

title: Feeling at Sea on the Roads of New China
description: American travel writers over the past century have taken special delight in describing the intricacies, and the lunatic comedy, of driving etiquette in foreign countries. Some enterprising publisher is bound to scoop up the best of these observations and issue a queasy-making anthology: Carsick: A Global Reader.

title: Theatrically Gory Rappers and Their Family, the Fans
description: Every summer for the past 10 years, theres been a Gathering of the Juggalos. Novi, Mich.; Pataskala, Ohio; Cave-In-Rock, Ill.: theyve all had a turn hosting the event, organized by Psychopathic Records, the Michigan-based label of the shock rap group Insane Clown Posse, purveyors of fully committed white working-class kabuki.

title: Eagles Release Brian Westbrook
description: The Eagles released running back Brian Westbrook on Tuesday. Westbrook, a versatile veteran, has battled injuries in recent years, including two concussions. An ankle injury sidelined him for eight games last season. Heading into 2009, Westbrook was already showing signs of decline. Given that hell be 31 in September, its doubtful hell be on a roster for Week 1.

title: In a Name, Unleashed and Intense
description: In Shakespeare the big scenes stir your blood, yet its the small moments that can steal your heart. Thats never more apparent than in the balcony scene of Romeo and Juliet at the Baruch Performing Arts Center, a co-production of the Acting Company and the Guthrie Theater.

title: Case Study | Single Chair Ale
description: The aprs-ski crowd clumps into the 19th Hole bar at Mad River Barn in Waitsfield, Vt., red-cheeked from afternoon runs and shedding all manner of performance plumage. Nearly everyone in the place is holding a beer glass. Behind the bar is a single tap. But if youre from the area, that tap speaks volumes. It is the Single Chair Ale, a locals-only secret that Magic Hat Brewery has been producing for 15 years, ever since Mad River Glen Ski Area became a nonprofit cooperative. People up here tend to do things their own way, and such is the case with both the ski co-op and the beer, which is addictively quaffable yet only selectively available  and only on tap. Due to the liaison, what could be just another quirky regional brew became a celebrated cause and has long since nestled comfortably into a niche as a destination beer.

title: Clothes Retailer Arrested on Labor Charges
description: The owner of seven budget clothing stores in Lower Manhattan was arrested on charges of underpaying his workers and falsifying business records, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said.

title: App of the Week: Spot Spring on the Wing
description: As the snowbanks begin to recede, it is possible to look with hope for signs of spring. The first harbinger in the Mid-Atlantic would be the return of the Purple Martins, which, like retirees, head south before winter strikes. To follow the Martins progress returning north, I turn to BirdsEye, a relatively expensive iPhone app that takes a different approach to bird watching than most ornithological applications.

title: Home Improvement Retailers See Glints of Rebound
description: After more than a year of not spending money on their homes, consumers began refurbishing their kitchens and painting their living rooms in what appears to be the early stages of a comeback for the home improvement industry.

title: Kingstons Mega-Drive Is a Cram Course in Data
description: Its larger than the hard drive on many computers, but significantly smaller than a Snickers bar.

title: Guilty Verdict in Murder of Real Estate Broker
description: Updated, 5:52 p.m. | A Manhattan jury convicted Natavia S. Lowery of second-degree murder Tuesday evening in the 2007 bludgeoning death of the celebrity real estate broker and former punk-rock manager Linda S. Stein. It was the top charge against Ms. Lowery; she faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.

title: Franklins Electronic Dictionary: Worth the Price?
description: Theres always something lost when a new technology becomes an accepted part of the culture. The Internet has brought the worlds knowledge to any room equipped with a computer, but the experience and convenience do not substitute for the pleasure of strolling through a university librarys stacks, randomly searching through volumes of books whose titles look interesting.

title: Samsungs High-Performance Compact Camera
description: Samsung just announced four new point-and-shoot cameras, and the most interesting by far is the TL500, a high-performance compact camera that has a very bright f/1.8 lens and a comparatively large image sensor. These two features should make it much easier to get good shots in low-lighting conditions.

title: Immigrant Detention Centers
description: Federal immigration authorities operate a nationwide network of detention centers.

title: The TV Numbers Game
description: A slew of television sales reports were released yesterday and, as expected, the results can be spun in a number of ways.

title: Kerri Does New Orleans
description: (Kerri and Nawlins go way back, and ever since Ive known her  20 years or so  shes made the pilgrimage when she could. Heres her report from this year. MB)

title: Pettitte Warms Up to a Different Routine
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte threw his first bullpen session of the spring Tuesday, an event so unremarkable that Yankees Manager Joe Girardi did not bother to watch. He was off making sure the catchers didnt go all out the first day they threw to the bases.

title: Idol Winners: Not Just Fame but Big Bucks
description: LOS ANGELES  It is doubtful that any of the remaining 24 contestants on American Idol hope that they will be playing the Teen Angel in a touring production of Grease in Milwaukee three years from now.

title: A Winning Trip to New England
description: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team. As he did last season, Jon will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season. You can also follow him on Twitter.

title: A New Fort, er, Embassy, for London
description: LONDON  The State Departments announcement on Tuesday that it had selected a design by the Philadelphia firm KieranTimberlake for its new embassy in London was not exactly uplifting news.

title: Greenspan Bemoans Crisis, but Who Is to Blame?
description: Talk about a bad time to bring up the Great Depression. Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman, argued Tuesday that the world was coping with by far the greatest financial crisis globally ever, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Stand Up While You Read This!
description: Your chair is your enemy.

title: A Woman of Many Talents and Bands
description: As with many things in indie rock of late, the quality of the performances at the Mercury Lounge on Sunday night was directly tied to the placement of Frankie Rose.

title: Properties for $880,000
description: Homes for sale in Woodstock, N.Y., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Seattle.

title: Cat-and-Mouse for a Trashy Trailer
description: LOS ANGELES  Theyre not the kind of things people say in polite society, or even impolite society. Saying them, even in jest, can get a drink tossed in your face and the glass with it.

title: What You Get for... $880,000
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.

title: Oppenheimer Settles Auction-Rate Securities Lawsuit
description: Oppenheimer & Company on Tuesday became the latest firm to settle a lawsuit by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York over auction-rate securities, agreeing to buy back $31 million worth of the instruments from investors.

title: Brazilian Street Meets the Stage
description: If there is a heaven for b-boys, it must look something like Bruno Beltros H3.

title: Flamenco Kept Simple, but Fun
description: It was an all-male affair Sunday night at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University, when the 10th annual New York Flamenco Festival wrapped up with a 90-minute performance by Compaa Israel Galvn. Joined by the vocalist David Lagos and his brother, the guitarist Alfredo Lagos, Mr. Galvn presented La Edad de Oro (The Golden Age), a strikingly austere production but one with pockets of welcome humor.

title: Is Medicating Your Child a Cop-Out?
description: I have found that many people think they understand depression because they have been sad, a mother of a boy diagnosed with high-functioning autism, sensory-integration issues and obsessive-compulsive behavior tells Judith Warner in the early pages of her new book, Weve Got Issues: Children and Parents in the Age of Medication.

title: Microchip Technology Wins Michigan Business Challenge
description: The University of Michigans Zell Lurie Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies held the finals for its annual all-student business plan competition, the Michigan Business Challenge, over the weekend. From 85 initial applications, a record number for the school, four advanced to the finals, and the winner was Ambiq Micro, which took $27,000 in cash grants.

title: Next Week on Letterman: Romney, Seinfeld and Matt Damon
description: So how does David Letterman counter Jay Lenos big bookings on his first week back on The Tonight Show, highlighted by the first Tonight appearance by the Republican presidential hopeful Sarah Palin?

title: New Look at Bach, 21st-Century Composer
description: Bach has long proved irresistible to artists drawn to reconstructing his music through a contemporary prism. Busoni and Liszt transcribed his works, and Leopold Stokowski orchestrated them. More recently, jazz performers like Uri Caine, Jacques Loussier and Dave Brubeck and the classical pianist Gabriela Montero have reinterpreted Bach with idiosyncratic twists.

title: Presenting a Shiny Gem in an Unusual Setting
description: The flutist Carol Wincenc is celebrating the 40th anniversary of her concert debut with three performances spread through the season, each at a different hall. The programs put a spotlight on the breadth of Ms. Wincencs repertory, with special attention to her passion for contemporary music.

title: Financial Investing for Film Buffs
description: Worried about keeping your retirement nest egg in your home, the S.& P. 500 or Treasury bills, but obsessed with Avatar?

title: Dutchman Loses Gold and a Record
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  After 25 laps around the Richmond Olympic Oval, Sven Kramer of the Netherlands crossed the finish line Tuesday and raised his arms in triumph, having secured  or so he thought  his second Olympic record and gold medal of these Winter Games.

title: Rockaway Ferry to Sail Into Sunset
description: Commuter ferry boats. Everybody likes them, but nobody wants to pay for them.

title: Canada Calms Panic With a Rout of Germany
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Canada crushed lightly regarded Germany, 8-2, in an elimination game Tuesday, and its reward was another elimination clash on Wednesday, against Alex Ovechkin and the Russians.

title: Canos Golden Glove?
description: Someday, Robinson Cano may win a Gold Glove award at second base. According to his manager, Cano should have won it last season. Then again, Tigers Manager Jim Leyland probably feels the same way about the actual winner, Placido Polanco.

title: Senators Propose Big Corporate Tax Cut
description: Calls to cut taxes on large corporations may seem odd given that the nation faces a $1.55 trillion budget shortfall for the coming fiscal year. But that is exactly what a couple of senators, one Republican and one Democrat, would like to see happen. They jointly introduced a bill in Congress on Tuesday that would cut the corporate income tax rate to a flat 24 percent from 35 percent by eliminating some tax breaks.

title: 3 Democrats Named to Deficit Panel
description: Senator Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, on Tuesday named three senior Democratic senators as his choices for President Obamas 18-member bipartisan commission to reduce the national debt, including one colleague who opposed the commission as a threat to Social Security.

title: Obama Dines With Business Leaders
description: He may be at odds with big business on a number of matters, but that doesnt mean he cant eat with them. President Obama invited some of the countrys top business executives to dinner at the White House on Tuesday night.

title: Getting a Little Help to Go Out All Alone
description: THE self-written solo performance has reached such ubiquity in New York that its easy to forget how recently the genre became, well, a genre. Five years ago solo show wasnt even marketed as a separate category at the summer New York International Fringe, the citys biggest theater festival. In 2006 submissions of solo works jumped to 125, a 20 percent increase over the previous year. The spring SoloNova festival, dedicated entirely to the genre, recorded an even sharper rise: up more than a third to 109 submissions last year, from 75 in 2008. Even without a festival there were at least 15 solo shows in New York last week, from the revelatory (Palestine) to the masturbatory (The Accidental Pervert).

title: Fearing Obama Agenda, States Push to Loosen Gun Laws
description: When President Obama took office, gun rights advocates sounded the alarm, warning that he intended to strip them of their arms and ammunition.

title: Hes Had Work: Preserving the Face of a Revolution
description: ITS an old Soviet joke.

title: Aa, a Global Super Fruit, Is Dinner in the Amazon
description: CAMET, Brazil

title: Too Many Olympic Events, or Not Enough?
description: NBCs coverage of the Winter Olympics has dominated the ratings, drawing  29.4 million viewers when Shaun White won the gold medal in the mens halfpipe competition. The networks success might be attributed to ever faster, riskier events that have been added in recent years like snowboard cross, halfpipe, aerial skiing, mogul skiing, ski cross and skeleton. The number of events has gone up from 38 in the 1980 Lake Placid games to 86 in the Vancouver games.

title: The F.D.I.C. Mission to Face Problem Banks Early
description: Killing zombies isnt just a job for horror movie heroines. Its also the primary task of Sheila C. Bair, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: For WWS 543, Feb 24
description: Import-substituting industrialization.

title: That Triple Salchow Was Great. Now for More Ads.
description: SINCE the Vancouver Winter Games began on Feb. 12, the networks of NBC Universal have presented hundreds of hours of coverage  and thousands of commercials. Here is a look at some of the highlights, sidelights and lowlights of the spots so far.

title: Progress Slow in City Goal to Fire Bad Teachers
description: The Bloomberg administration has made getting rid of inadequate teachers a linchpin of its efforts to improve city schools. But in the two years since the Education Department began an intensive effort to root out such teachers from the more than 55,000 who have tenure, officials have managed to fire only three for incompetence.

title: Wall Street 09 Bonuses Increase 17%
description: Its about as official as it gets: the big money is back on Wall Street.

title: Better Bread With Less Kneading
description: WHEN I started making bread back in the 1970s, whether an establishment loaf from James Beards Beard on Bread or a countercultural one from The Tassajara Bread Book, it was a hands-on workout, kneading a stiff, elastic dough for what felt like a very long 10 to 15 minutes.

title: A Yankee Bleacher Creature Takes a Little Off the Top
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Before Justices, First Amendment and Aid to Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON  The line between speech protected by the First Amendment and aid to terrorists appeared elusive at the Supreme Court on Tuesday, and the justices lively questioning complicated rather than clarified matters. They discussed travel to Cuba, the Communist and Nazi Parties, Tokyo Rose, treason and whether it is a crime to teach a terrorist how to play the harmonica.

title: A $3.5 Billion Effort Aims to Help Tech Start-Ups
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Technologists have been worrying aloud for years that America is losing its competitive edge as other countries invest more heavily in technology education and innovation.

title: In Field Trialing, Bird Dogs Call Shots and Humans Follow
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn.  The competitors arrived at the historic Ames Plantation in pickup trucks with built-in dog kennels, pulling gooseneck trailers hauling saddle horses. After a year of crisscrossing the country, the holy grail of their sport was at last in reach for the owners of 39 of the best bird-hunting dogs in North America.

title: ABC News to Cut Hundreds of Staff
description: ABC News will sharply reduce its news-gathering staff through buyouts and possible layoffs, the company said on Tuesday. ABC employees said they expected the cutbacks would affect 300 to 400 people, or roughly 25 percent of the news divisions work force.

title: Sidewalks, and an Identity, Sprout in Jordans Capital
description: AMMAN, Jordan  It might be too much to call it a miracle, but the government of this ancient metropolis that rolls out over seven sun-burned hills has managed something that until now seemed impossible. It built sidewalks that are easy to walk on.

title: Ministers Question Status of Washington House
description: A group of ministers has sent a complaint to the Internal Revenue Service saying that a town house on Capitol Hill that provides inexpensive lodging and meals for conservative Christian members of Congress is not a church and should no longer be granted the tax-exempt status afforded a house of worship.

title: Variations on a Beloved Theme
description: THE heart wants what it wants, and so, I believe, does the mouth.

title: H.P., Tech Powerhouse, Stumbles in Smartphones
description: Hewlett-Packard is one of the worlds most successful makers of desktop computers, laptops, servers and printers. It owns a powerful consumer brand, and it is a growing provider of services for businesses. In the first quarter, the companys sales rose 8 percent.

title: New Amputees Face Challenges
description: More than a month after the earthquake, thousands of new amputees in Haiti are facing the stark reality of living with disabilities in a country whose terrain and culture have never been hospitable to the disabled.

title: Illness Hinders Plans to Close Immigration Jail
description: When Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials announced last month that they would close New York Citys only immigration jail and relocate its roughly 300 detainees to New Jersey, they described the step as part of a larger overhaul to improve health care and cost-effectiveness in the nations detention system.

title: Baohaus
description: IS there room in this town for another pork bun?

title: Dining Calendar
description: Savory Festival

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Landlords Convictions Overturned in Deaths of 2 Firefighters
description: A Bronx judge on Tuesday overturned the convictions of the owner and former owner of a building where two firefighters leapt to their deaths from a fourth-floor window to escape advancing flames.

title: Bloom Energy Claims a New Fuel Cell Technology
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  A Silicon Valley company is claiming a breakthrough in a decades-old quest to develop fuel cells that can supply affordable and relatively clean electricity. Google, Bank of America, Wal-Mart and other large corporations have been testing the devices, which will be formally introduced on Wednesday.

title: As Deadline Nears, G.M.s Sale of Hummer Faces Several Big Obstacles
description: HONG KONG  Hostility from Chinese regulators and financing problems are increasingly likely to scuttle plans by an obscure Chinese machinery company to buy the Hummer division from General Motors, people close to the negotiations said on Tuesday.

title: Herbsaint Returns to Its Original Formula With a Stronger Kick
description: When Prohibition ended in 1933, absinthe could not be imported. So in New Orleans, J. Marion Legendre concocted his own version, without wormwood. The federal government made him take the word absinthe off the label. He renamed it Herbsaint.

title: Health Care: Toward the Big Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Questions Still Linger on Eve of Health Care Meeting
description: Three years ago this month, a presidential candidate  John Edwards, as a matter of fact  started a debate on health reform by announcing a plan to cover the uninsured. Since then, weve had an election, town hall meetings, speeches, Congressional hearings and a special election in Massachusetts.

title: The Discreet Charm of Robots
description: A simple rule of robotic personality seems to be: dont make things the most efficient way, said Magnus Wurzer, the man who started Roboexotica, when, for my article on robots who cook and serve food, I asked him how you go about the tricky business of making a machine not just adept  but likeable.

title: Yahoo Gets Closer to Twitter
description: Yahoo is announcing a partnership with Twitter on Wednesday that will bring the services of both companies closer together.

title: Back Home, U.S. Snowboarder Finds Solace
description: SEABROOK, N.H.  One country and three time zones from Vancouver  where he had planned to be this week  Scotty Lago sat perched on a bar stool Monday night in this small seaside town, wearing a Team USA jacket and cap, his bronze medal hanging from his neck.

title: Toyota Chief in Trial by Fire Before Congress
description: WASHINGTON  There are no crown princes at the Ford Motor Company, its late chief executive, Henry Ford II, was fond of saying about the family business.

title: Bust the Health Care Trusts
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: More Satellites Will Act as Eyes for Troops
description: OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb.  Across the unforgiving terrain of Afghanistan, American combat forces have come to rely on satellites as well as their rifles and body armor to carry out missions effectively, and to stay alive.

title: Tanoreen
description: SATURDAY night in the neighborhood that once gave America fever, a Brooklyn that looks to itself for employment and has little time for the glittering island to the north. A bridge rises out of it, a silver ramp, and you can see ocean beneath it, darkness running all the way to Portugal, and from there down the Mediterranean to the Middle East. Dinner time.

title: Water-Cooler Effect: Internet Can Be TVs Friend
description: Remember when the Internet was supposed to kill off television?

title: Would Ya Just Watch the Hair?
description: This weeks restaurant review is of Tanoreen, a Bay Ridge fixture that recently moved into a larger room on Third Avenue. Its a terrific neighborhood restaurant, a gem in the Kings County crown. It also occupies a psychic space a great distance from Manhattan. Its a long way from the city center, and as a result seems a long way from the city centers concerns. Thats welcome, sometimes. Have you been to the new Tanoreen? Did you go to the old one? Do you have favorite restaurants in places that dont concern themselves with the business and culture of Manhattan? Watch the trailer for Saturday Night Fever, the 1977 disco classic that takes place in Bay Ridge, and post a comment below. Keep it clean!

title: 2 Generals Wary About Repealing Gay Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The top generals from the Army and the Air Force expressed deep concern on Tuesday about moving rapidly to lift the ban on openly gay service members, saying it could make it harder for their forces to do their jobs while fighting two wars.

title: Brimming Buns
description: Ligaya Mishan asks: "Is there room in this town for another pork bun?" The answer is yes if the bun is from Baohaus, which opened on the Lower East Side in December. Their specialty is gua bao, or Taiwanese hamburgers. "For $4, you get a lily-white bun  the bao  brimming with Niman Ranch pork belly, glossy with fat and topped with the classic Taiwanese condiments: peanuts pulverized to a powder and tossed with red sugar; suan cai (pickled mustard greens), and a fistful of cilantro." The buns, which have eccentric names  Chairman Bao is named after Mao Zedong, who is said to have loved red-cooked pork belly, and Uncle Jesse is packed with tofu  are the creation of Eddie Huang, the 27-year-old son of Taiwanese immigrants who is also a street-wear designer and a former lawyer. "Mr. Huang cooks everything himself and is prone to whipping up new dishes on the spot. For Chinese New Year, he devised an eight-course menu. But he says he wants to focus on his gua bao. After all, less is more."

title: Past and Present
description: " 'Clybourne Park,' " writes Ben Brantley, "concerns, to borrow from Raymond Carver, what we talk about when we talk about race." The play by Bruce Norris, which opened Sunday night at Playwrights Horizons, "focuses on the evasions, euphemisms and tongue-tied paralysis that afflict such discussions and comes to the conclusion that talk  at least among the all-American solipsists he portrays  is worse than cheap: it's valueless." Half a century separates this "spiky and damningly insightful new comedy," which is set in 1959 and 2009. Clybourne Park was the all-white Chicago neighborhood "on which a hopeful African-American Southside family set its sights in 'A Raisin in the Sun,' Lorraine Hansberry's 1959 epochal drama. The house in the play is the dream house that Hansberry built, the place her upwardly mobile Younger family was planning to inhabit. In the first act the Youngers haven't arrived yet. In the second they're long gone, and Clybourne Park has become a very different, predominantly black neighborhood. And it is now a white family that wants to move into an area that shows every promise of being thoroughly regentrified." In both parts of this production, "Mr. Norris is examining his subjects through the same merciless telescope, with a historian's distance and an ethnographer's detachment."

title: Your Longstreth Fix
description: If you missed the show at the Allen Room, don't despair: you can listen to a world premiere by the composer David Longstreth, the band's guitarist and lead singer, tonight. His piece is one of four world premieres that will be presented by Bang on a Can All-Stars at the 2010 People's Commissioning Fund Concert at Merkin Concert Hall. As part of the program, the chamber ensemble will also perform works by the Swiss ambient-funk-pianist-composer Nik Brtsch, the British electro-acoustic composer Oscar Bettison and the Boston composer-inventor Christine Southworth. There will also be a recent work by Michael Nyman for a film by the photographer Paul Strand and a selection from the group's live arrangement of Brian Eno's "Music for Airports."

title: Regional Group Leaves Out U.S. and Canada
description: MEXICO CITY  Leaders from Latin America and the Caribbean agreed Tuesday to form a new regional group that brings Cuba into the fold but excludes Canada and the United States.

title: French Air Traffic Controllers Start 5-Day Strike
description: PARIS  French air traffic controllers began a five-day strike on Tuesday, leaving thousands of travelers stranded across the country the day after a walkout by Lufthansa pilots had forced the cancellation of hundreds of flights in neighboring Germany.

title: Assistant Is Convicted of Murdering Realty Agent
description: The personal assistant of Linda S. Stein, who had managed the Ramones and was a real estate agent for celebrities, was convicted on Tuesday of second-degree murder in the bludgeoning death of Ms. Stein in October 2007.

title: Gentle White House Nudges Test the Power of Persuasion
description: WASHINGTON  Tempers were fraying in the White House Cabinet Room as night turned into morning on Jan. 15. President Obama had been cloistered nearly all day with House and Senate Democrats, playing marriage counselor, an aide said, as he coaxed, cajoled and prodded them on a health care overhaul.

title: The First Tea-Party Terrorist?
description: Joseph Stack had barely finished flying his airplane into a Texas office building when the battle over his legacy began.

title: Man Connected to Americans in Haiti Makes His Case
description: MEXICO CITY  Jorge Torres  a k a Jorge Puello, a k a the self-described lawyer who advised the 10 Americans arrested in Haiti last month  certainly has unusual habits for a man on the run. A fugitive of the modern age, he fires off e-mail messages on the lam, defends himself on Web sites against the charges looming over him and grants media interviews even as law enforcement agencies pursue him.

title: New Complaints Filed Against Google in Europe
description: Google faces European antitrust scrutiny after three companies filed complaints about what they consider unfair competition.

title: Canadian Wins Gold in Womens Ski Cross
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Here at womens ski cross, otherwise known as crash central, Ashleigh McIvor of Canada won gold Tuesday, in large part by doing something that sounds relatively simple. She stayed upright.

title: Meet a Met Who Can Curl
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Bay may not be the best hitter the Mets have ever acquired, but he may be the best curler.

title: The Initial Health Summit Promise
description: A campaign appearance in Nevada, Iowa on December 27, 2007.

title: Time Running Out for Some U.S. Players
description: For a majority of the 20 players on the roster, Wednesday nights international friendly match against El Salvador is likely to be their last opportunity to wear the red, white and blue for a while.

title: Bay Walks Into Crucible and Relaxes
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Bay parked his Toyota S.U.V. in his new designated parking spot, got out of the vehicle and searched for an entrance to his new clubhouse.

title: Look for Comebacks and Nail-Biters
description: Xavier (19-7, 10-2 Atlantic 10) at Saint Louis (18-8, 9-3)

title: U.S. Completes a Step Forward With a Silver Medal in Nordic Combined
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The lead changed four times in the last half of the relays final leg Tuesday. The American stepped past the Austrian on the uphill portions, and the Austrian glided past the American on the downhill portions.

title: Serbia: Police Raid Home of Fugitives Family
description: The Serbian police staged a dawn raid on Tuesday at a Belgrade home belonging to the family of Gen. Ratko Mladic, Europes most wanted war crimes fugitive. Serbian officials close to the operation said that the police found a cache of Swiss francs worth $73,000, as well as euros and dollars that they believe were used to pay for food and protection for General Mladic. Serbia has been warned that it cannot join the European Union before the government has arrested and handed over General Mladic to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

title: 60 Across: Austrias Capital, to Austrians
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  In honor of the Winter Olympics, Kenneth Berniker has performed four triple homonyms in his 1515 program today. Nearby reactions from the nontheme space-fillers range from ITS OK to OH MY!

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Alexander M. Haig, the former secretary of state and White House chief of staff, referred incorrectly to the 241 victims of a bombing at a Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983 and misstated the timing of that attack in relationship to Mr. Haigs tenure at the State Department. Eighteen sailors and three soldiers were among the dead; they were not all Marines. And the bombing was 16 months after Mr. Haig was dismissed as secretary of state, not in the immediate aftermath of his departure. The obituary also misstated part of the name of the Army post in Virginia where a Mass was planned for Mr. Haig. It is Fort Myer, not Fort Myers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the reported capture in Pakistan of Mullah Abdul Kabir, a senior Taliban military commander, misspelled the name of the city in North-West Frontier Province where a senior Pakistani intelligence official said Mullah Kabir had been detained. It is Nowshera, not Nawshera.

title: A Terrorist in Court? Life Goes On
description: It could have been any late-winter afternoon in Downtown Brooklyn: the sun bright, people grabbing lunch from hot-dog carts, traffic rolling along Tillary Street. But it happened to be Monday of this week, and inside the federal courthouse at Cadman Plaza, a man was led into a courtroom. His name was Najibullah Zazi, and last summer he was caught in the act of getting ready to bomb the subways.

title: Baseball Plans to Test for H.G.H. in Minors
description: Major League Baseball, which had long been skeptical about a viable test for human growth hormone, now plans to implement blood testing for the substance in the minor leagues later this year, according to an official in baseball with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about Freda Rosenfeld, a New York lactation consultant who helps mothers who are having trouble breast-feeding, misidentified, using information from a mother of twins, the consultant who the mother said had misinformed her about her sons anatomy and prescribed exercises that did not work. The mother, who was not identified in the article, was speaking about another lactation consultant whom Ms. Rosenfeld had recommended because she was too busy  not about Ms. Rosenfeld herself.

title: When Rebuilding, Beware of What Is Discarded
description: The redoubtable legends reunited in New York at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, making the news media rounds, repeating the old war stories they can by now recite in their sleep and soaking in well-earned ceremonial love.

title: Questions Surface After Haitian Airlift
description: PITTSBURGH  It was widely billed as the first uplifting story in the aftermath of the earthquake that devastated Haitis capital: two young American women rescued 54 Haitian orphans in an airlift organized by Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania and supported by top Obama administration officials.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in some editions last Wednesday about the dominance of the weather as a top story on local newscasts misstated the name of the airline whose plane was being de-iced at Kennedy International Airport. It is Alitalia, not Air Alitalia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the scrutiny of two Chinese educational institutions to which researchers have traced online attacks on American companies misstated the location of Duke Universitys planned campus in China and the date that plans for that campus were announced. The campus will be in Kunshan, near Shanghai, not in Shanghai itself, and the plans were announced on Jan. 22, not last year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article in some editions on Monday about the United States 5-3 victory over Canada on Sunday in Olympic mens hockey described the action incorrectly in some copies. The photograph of three Americans shown hugging after a goal was taken during the first period, after one of Brian Rafalskis two goals; it was not after Ryan Keslers empty-net goal with 45 seconds left in the game. The article also omitted the final score in some editions.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day, Feb. 23
description: Highlights included biathlon skiing, alpine skiing, ski jumping and even a few sports that dont use skis at all.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the Olympic television coverage available to Americans living near the Canadian border misidentified the owner of CTV, which is broadcasting the Vancouver Games in Canada. It is CTVglobemedia, not Rogers Communications.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the announcement that the tenor Plcido Domingo would undergo surgery after experiencing severe abdominal pain last week referred imprecisely to plans for the production of Tamerlano scheduled for next month at the Royal Opera House in London. While Mr. Domingos performances have been canceled, the production of Tamerlano has not been. (Kurt Streit will replace Mr. Domingo in the opera.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Martin Sheen, who is performing in the play The Subject Was Roses in Los Angeles, misidentified the Tony Award for which he and Jack Albertson were nominated when they were in the 1964 Broadway production of the play and which Mr. Albertson won. It was for best featured actor in a play, not best actor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the success of Sades new album, Soldier of Love, which topped the Billboard chart in its first week with 502,000 copies sold, erroneously included a pop star among those whose latest albums did not do as well in their debut weeks. While Sade did outsell Jay-Z and U2, she did not surpass Britney Spears, whose Circus sold 505,000 copies in its first week.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Downsize a Parade, Diminish New York?
description: Not everyone loves a parade. Lana Einsmann, who runs the Claudia Ciuti shoe boutique on Madison Avenue near East 75th Street, does not shout from the sidelines. She does not wave at the floats or hum along with the bands. She worries about lost business.

title: Knicks Fall to Celtics in a Battle of Changes
description: BOSTON  On a night of reunions and readjustments, the Knicks turned to Tracy McGrady, their recently anointed new star and asked him, sore knee and all, to save them.

title: Uncharted Waters, Fragile Hopes
description: As many of the trial participants experience dramatic recoveries, patients and doctors face the uneasy task of managing expectations in this new scientific frontier. The third in a series.

title: Inside the Rings
description: Some athletes fight gravity, others battle friction at the Winter Games.

title: Albany Erred by Tying Up Judges Raises, Court Rules
description: ALBANY  New Yorks highest court ruled on Tuesday that governors and legislators had violated the State Constitution by trying to tie pay raises for state judges to unrelated legislation, including bills to raise lawmakers own salaries.

title: Lottery Numbers
Settlement Reached in Suit Against Working Families Party
description: The Working Families Party, perhaps the states most influential third party, has settled a lawsuit by agreeing to greatly distance itself from its for-profit subsidiary, a much respected and much criticized company that provided campaign services.

title: A Drug Trial Cycle: Recovery, Relapse, Reinvention
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  On a sunny afternoon last June, Dr. Keith Flaherty stood before a large room packed with oncologists from around the world and described the extraordinary recovery of the melanoma patients in the experimental drug trial he was leading.

title: Owner of Car Linked to Crash Says Her Sister Was Driving
description: The owner of the car that hit two young women in Brooklyn on Sunday, leaving one of them brain-dead, said through her lawyer on Tuesday that her sister was driving it when the accident occurred, the police said.

title: Zuckerman Courts G.O.P. While Ford Polls Voters
description: As they weigh whether to make a bid for the Senate seat held by Kirsten E. Gillibrand, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher of The Daily News, is quietly reaching out to state Republican leaders, and Harold E. Ford Jr., a former congressman, has conducted a poll of New York voters, people told of the moves said.

title: Budget Beauty: Manicured Without Getting Clipped
description: As the needle went into my skin, somewhere between the two biggest toes on my left foot, I felt an almost electrical joltmy metatarsal bones pulsed with energy, like a muscle cramp but completely painless. It was as if my entire foot were a neon sign that had never been switched on before.

title: Questions for Mr. Toyoda
description: In the weeks since Toyotas safety problems have become international news, Akio Toyoda, the companys president, has apologized repeatedly. When he testifies on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, he is expected to apologize again and, according to a prepared statement, admit that his companys priorities became confused in its quest for growth over the last decade. It isnt enough.

title: Power Grab
description: After his brazen bid to steal his re-election, Afghanistans president, Hamid Karzai, swore that he would do better  and the Obama administration swore it would ensure that he did. He hasnt. It didnt.

title: Five Republican Votes
description: After a year of partisan gridlock, it was heartening to see five Republican senators break ranks on Monday to advance a $15 billion jobs bill. The 62-to-30 vote clears the way for the bills final passage this week.

title: Moynihan Station, Finally?
description: Almost two decades after the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan began pressing for it, there is real hope of replacing the gloomy Pennsylvania Station with a newer, grander entranceway to New York City.

title: New York Crime Statistics: What the Researchers Say
description: To the Editor:

title: An International Medical Corps, to Aid in Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqs Known Unknowns, Still Unknown
description: From the very beginning of the U.S. intervention in Iraq and the effort to build some kind of democracy there, a simple but gnawing question has lurked in the background: Was Iraq the way Iraq was (a dictatorship) because Saddam was the way Saddam was, or was Saddam the way Saddam was because Iraq was the way Iraq was  a collection of warring sects incapable of self-rule and only governable with an iron fist?

title: Extending Our Stay in Iraq
description: Washington

title: Canadian Sets Bobsled Track Record, Takes Lead
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Kaillie Humphries of Canada blistered through the Whistler Sliding Centre, establishing a track record in her second run of womens bobsled and taking a 0.13 seconds lead over the American pilot Erin Pac entering Wednesdays medal event.

title: Live Blog: Kim Yu-na Dominates Short Program
description: Todd Eldredge, the three-time Olympian, provided analysis from his home in Florida, and the Times reporters Jer Longman and Katie Thomas sent updates from Vancouver. Joanne C. Gerstner and Lynn Zinser contributed insight as well.

title: Papers Link Husband of Professor to 93 Threat
description: BOSTON  The husband of the neuroscientist accused of killing three colleagues at the University of Alabama in Huntsville told a witness he wanted to harm a Harvard professor who was later mailed a pipe bomb in 1993, according to newly released federal documents.

title: Showcase: Its a Grand Old Crosswalk
description: New Yorkers may not think so. Other Americans certainly dont think so. But just about everyone else in the world thinks that New York is the most American of cities. After all, as the writer Alfred Kazin observed, No other country in the world could have created New York.

title: John Babcock, Last Canadian World War I Veteran, Dies at 109
description: John Babcock, who joined the Canadian Army at 15 and ultimately became the symbol of an embattled generation as Canadas last known veteran of World War I, died Thursday at his home in Spokane, Wash. He was 109.

title: G.O.P. Expects Little From Health Forum
description: WASHINGTON  Republican Congressional leaders on Tuesday rejected President Obamas challenge to come up with a single comprehensive proposal to achieve his goal of guaranteeing health insurance for nearly all Americans.

title: Democrats Seek to Push Ahead $15 Billion Jobs Bill, With More Steps to Come
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Democrats say the House is preparing to quickly pass a $15 billion job-creating measure once it is approved by the Senate, illustrating new urgency on the part of Democrats to show they are taking steps to improve the national employment picture.

title: Word of the Day | replicate
description: replicate\re-pl-kat\ verb

title: Pressure Is No Problem for Kim Yu-na
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In a black, bejeweled dress and her hair pulled back into a neat bun, South Koreas Kim Yu-na skated on Tuesday as if she knew she would win the short program at these Olympics.

title: Cheney Had Heart Attack, His Fifth
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Dick Cheney had a minor heart attack but was expected to be released from the hospital within a day or two, according to a statement released Tuesday by his office.

title: A Vote to Fire All Teachers at a Failing High School
description: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.  A plan to dismiss the entire faculty and staff of the only public high school in this small city just west of the Massachusetts border was approved Tuesday night at an emotional public meeting of the school board.

title: Corrections
description: A review last Wednesday about the Motorino pizzerias misidentified the location in Brooklyn of Frannys, one of the first upscale pizza restaurants in New York City. It is in Prospect Heights, not Park Slope.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday about a brittle sold by the restaurant Angelica Kitchen in the East Village misstated the number of years the restaurant has been in business. It is 34, not 24.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 991 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Tuition Rises at Yale
description: Yale University said undergraduate tuition, room and board will increase 4.8 percent to $49,800 for the 2010-11 school year. Next years cost will be $52,900, including $3,100 for books and personal expenses, a spokesman said Tuesday. Financial aid will increase more than 10 percent, with an average Yale scholarship totaling more than $35,000, the university said in a statement.

title: News Quiz | February 24, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: If They Perform Their Best, or Their Worst
description: A look at the top 10 skaters best and worst long program scores offers a glimpse into what the final results could look like after Thursday's long program.

title: Executives in the Hearing Room
description: Some shifted the blame. Others refused to answer questions. And as corporate executives called to testify in some of the biggest Congressional investigations, almost all were on the defensive.

title: White House in New Push for Wall St. Changes
description: The Obama administration redoubled its efforts on Tuesday to overhaul the nations financial regulations, saying it would not back down from its efforts to restrict the trading activities of banks and to create a consumer agency to regulate financial products, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Colorado: Middle School Students Shot
description: Two students were wounded outside a suburban Denver middle school Tuesday afternoon by a gunman wielding a high-powered rifle, the police said. The victims, seventh and eighth graders at Deer Creek Middle School, were wounded as students were leaving school for the day, said Mark Techmeyer, a spokesman for the Jefferson County Sheriffs Office. The gunman was tackled and disarmed by two school staff members, who held him until deputies arrived. The two students, a boy and a girl, were hospitalized in stable condition after surgery. Investigators did not yet know the connection  if any  between the gunman, identified as Bruco Strongeagle Eastwood, 32, and the victims, Mr. Techmeyer said. The school is just a few miles from Columbine High School, where one of the nations deadliest school shootings occurred in 1999.

title: Rapping About Science
description: WHO are the rappers in this video?

title: Obama's Health Care Push
description: Economics Columnist David Leonhardt discusses the upcoming health care meeting.

title: The Big Moneys Back in Town
description: Its about as official as it gets: the big money is back on Wall Street, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

title: China Tells Banks to Restrict Loans
description: Chinas banking regulator has told commercial lenders to restrict new lending they provide to the financing arms of local governments, the latest move by the Chinese authorities to slow bank lending in a bid to head off inflation and limit the risks of potential loan defaults, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Rescue Teams Continue Search After Indonesia Mudslide
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Local villagers and government rescue teams, using sniffer dogs and farm tools, searched Wednesday for workers on an Indonesian tea plantation who were buried by a mudslide estimated to be 35 feet deep.

title: Amicas Urges Vote for Thoma Bravo Bid
description: Amicas rejected a buyout offer from Merge Healthcare. and told shareholders to vote instead for a competing $217 million bid from Thoma Bravo, The Associated Press reported.

title: Best Political Medicine for Democrats? Passing a Bill, Menendez Says
description: As chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey bears the heavy burden of defending the Democrats majority in a brutally challenging mid-term year.

title: Kim Yu-na Dominates Short Program
description: South Korea's Kim Yu-na, the reigning world champion, skated with the confidence and skill to match her expectations to win the short program.

description: From Richard S. Chang at Wheels:

title: Date Night in the Senate: A Primer on Budget Reconciliation
Are You Watching American Idol This Season?
description: Even if youre not, apparently many others are: An article from Feb. 17 headlined American Idol Beats Olympics and Endures as Gold Standard pointed out that absolutely nothing on any other channel has beaten an edition of Idol in almost six years. (Though the Olympics went on to beat it the next night after all.) Are you a fan? Are you watching the show this season? Why or why not?

title: Old Mutual Considers Sale of U.S. Unit, Report Says
description: Old Mutual has appointed JPMorgan Chase to look at a possible sale of its American life insurance business, among other options, people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Tuesday.

title: Carlyle Starts Renminbi Fund in China
description: Carlyle Group, one of the worlds biggest private equity firms, said Wednesday that it had formed a partnership with one of the largest nonstate-owned Chinese conglomerates to invest in China and around the world, David Barboza reports in The New York Times.

title: President Returns to Nigeria, but Not to Work
description: NIAMEY, Niger  While President Umaru YarAdua of Nigeria returned home on Wednesday after three months of medical treatment in Saudi Arabia, a spokesman indicated that he would not immediately seek to reclaim the powers that Parliament transferred to his deputy two weeks ago.

title: F.D.I.C. Needs to Do Some Zombie Hunting
description: Killing zombies isnt just a job for horror movie heroines. Its also the primary task of Sheila C. Bair, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: Through Grief and Tears, a Triumph on the Ice
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Finally, it could not be put off any longer. Joannie Rochette of Canada slapped her coachs hands, took a few deep breaths and circled the ice, no doubt wondering along with everyone else whether her emotions would overcome her or inspire her.

title: Corriente Said to Profit on Europe Debt Bets
description: Accusations and denials have flown between Greece and the investors it says are betting against its debt, but now reports are coming from another quarter.

title: HSBC Said to Shop Its $3 Billion Leasing Company
description: HSBC has launched the 2 billion sale ($3.1 billion) of its British rolling stock leasing company, with financial investors seen as the most likely buyers, several people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: New Bank Tries to Steer Deals in Media
description: Code Advisors bills itself as a next-generation investment bank, but what it really wants to be is the deftest traffic cop at the raucous intersection of technology and media, The Associated Press writes in a profile of the new boutique firm.

title: Balancing Act for India as Talks With Pakistan Resume
description: NEW DELHI  The resumption of diplomatic talks between India and Pakistan on Thursday comes at a critical moment, with the United States hoping that even a modest improvement in relations between the nuclear-armed neighbors could help the broader American military effort in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: Bloom Energy Claims a New Fuel Cell Technology
description: A Silicon Valley company is claiming a breakthrough in a decades-old quest to develop fuel cells that can supply affordable and relatively clean electricity. Google, Bank of America, Wal-Mart and other large corporations have been testing the devices, which will be formally introduced on Wednesday.

description: Images of the artist and his sculptures.

title: Citi Said to Hold Talks to Sell Business
description: SkyBridge Capital is in advanced talks to buy Citigroups $4 billion hedge fund business, The Wall Street Journal reported.

description: Monday announcement by Reply Inc., which runs an auction service for local Web advertising, that it was planning an initial public offering, apparently gave The San Jose Mercury Newss Chris OBrien pause.

description: Microchip Technology on Tuesday sweetened its bid for Silicon Storage, aiming to thwart an 11th-hour rival offer from Cerberus Capital Management, The Associated Press reported.

description: From Ben Sisario at ArtsBeat:

title: Tengzhong Seeks Private Equity Solution for Hummer
description: The planned purchase of General Motors Hummer brand by a Chinese heavy equipment maker appears stalled by regulators, but that hasnt stopped investors from setting up a fund to invest in the deal, The Associated Press reported.

description: R.R. Donnelley & Sons, the printing services company, said Tuesday it has agreed to acquire Bowne & Company, a shareholder and marketing communications services company, for about $481 million in cash, The Associated Press reported.

title: Blockbuster Said to Tap Restructuring Advisers
description: Blockbuster has hired a law firm and an investment bank to explore how the video rental company can cut its $1 billion debt load, The Wall Street Journal reported.

description: American banks and investment firms transferred their political contributions to Republicans in 2009 as Democrats in Washington put the focus on big bonuses, huge profits and tight lending, The Washington Post reported.

title: A Green and Gold Gem in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kongs Diamond Hill was once home to a mix of gamblers, thugs and movie stars. Over the last 20 years, the government cleared away much of the squalor (and history) to make way for a subway stop, generic high-rise housing developments and the cacophonous Hollywood Plaza shopping center. But the city did manage to tuck a giant hidden gem into the neighborhood: the Nan Lian Garden.

title: Are We Overpaying Grandpa?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: HSBC Said to Cancel Raise for C.E.O.
description: HSBC Holdings is likely to back down on plans to give its chief executive officer, Michael Geoghegan, a pay increase of as much as 40 percent in 2010 after investors opposed the plan, a person briefed on the discussions told Bloomberg News.

title: Icahn v. Trump: Casino Fight Heads to Court
description: Donald Trump, the larger-than-life real estate developer, and Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, took their contentious fight for the Atlantic City hotel-casinos bearing Mr. Trumps name to U.S. bankruptcy court on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

description: Top executives at two of the five largest United States airlines said on Tuesday they are open to a merger, adding that the airline industry needs to consolidate to return to profitability, Reuters reported.

title: The U.S. Militarys German Fetish
description: Todays idea: American military thinkers have a German fetish, an ex-officer writes. They view war less as a man-made disaster than as a creative science and art, a la Karl von Clausewitz.

title: Short-Sale Curb May Apply to Market Makers
description: Securities regulators are considering new short-sale restrictions with no exemptions for market makers, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the regulators plans.

description: 8:45 a.m. | Updated Erin Callan, who briefly worked as Lehman Brothers chief financial officer months before the investment banks collapse, has left her position at Credit Suisse, Fox Business reported on Tuesday.

title: The Goldman Fleece
description: Nickname for the deals made by Goldman Sachs which reportedly helped Greece obscure its debt.

description: Geoffrey Becker is the author of the story collections Dangerous Men and Black Elvis, and the novels Bluestown and Hot Springs.

title: Dow Jones Seeks to Buy Rest of SmartMoney
description: Dow Jones is in talks to acquire the half of SmartMoney magazine that it doesnt already own from the Hearst Corporation, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

title: Greece Trots Out the Real Culprits: Nazi Occupiers
description: Deputy Prime Minister Theodoros Pangalos of Greece, responding to criticism from Germany, said historically, Berlins actions had disqualified it from attacking Athens for its budget difficulties.

title: Wynn Moves to Take Control of Philly Casino
description: Stephen A. Wynn has signed a letter of intent with investors in Foxwoods Casino Philadelphia that would see the casino mogul take over as managing general partner of the project, which has been floundering, The Philadelphia Daily News reported.

title: A.I.G. Was Blindsided by Backlash, Ex-Spokesman Says
description: The American International Group is now firmly ensconced in the nations and probably the worlds mind as an object of scorn, the company that nearly took the global financial system down before its more than $180 billion bailout.

title: Sampler: San Francisco Is Not Liable for Killings in a Family, and the Effects of the Cosco Busan Oil Spill
description: Charges Dropped Against Vietnamese Student | Phuong Ho, 21, a Vietnamese student at San Jose State University, will not face charges, Santa Clara County prosecutors said. Mr. Hos arrest, which was secretly videotaped by a roommate with a cellphone, appeared to show the police striking him with batons and using a Taser as he pleaded for his glasses. He was arrested for resisting arrest and brandishing a deadly weapon, both misdemeanors. The videotape heightened tensions between the San Jose police and minority communities. I think I can finally concentrate on my schoolwork, said Mr. Ho, who is studying to become an actuary. Im a free man in a free country. [The San Jose Mercury News]

title: Speed Read for Wednesday, Feb. 24
description: Here are some highlights from Wednesdays editions of The New York Times:

title: Waste-to-Ethanol Venture Attracts Investors
description: In a deal announced on Wednesday, Enerkem Inc., a Quebec waste-to-ethanol processor, has raised $51.5 million from a syndicate of investors that includes the landfill and garbage-hauling giant Waste Management of Houston.

title: The Internet Turns Out to Be Televisions Friend
description: The Internet, which many feared would draw viewers away from television, appears to be having exactly the opposite effect  at least when it comes to coverage of major events.

title: Tories and Republicans
description: I spent some time in London last week, talking to British political observers about their upcoming election, which is scheduled (to the extent that U.K. elections ever are) for the first week in May. Its a subject Ill hopefully return to at greater length as the David Cameron-Gordon Brown showdown draws closer, but given my recent gripes about the Republicans and entitlements, its worth pointing out that Camerons Tories are facing a similar problem: Theyre trying to promise the cuts the British welfare state desperately needs (their deficit problem is worse than ours, remarkably) while simultaneously pledging to ring-fence (that is, leave untouched) spending on the National Health Service.

title: Video: Health Summit Preview
description: Ahead of Thursdays highly anticipated bipartisan health summit at Blair House, the Presidents negotiating style is something to watch closely.

title: Still Has the Pipes
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Survivors, Celebrated on Film, Now Departed
description: Harvey Wang has explored New York people and places in photographs and on film for years, but his latest love letter to his home town, The Last New Yorker, which opened at the Quad Cinema on Friday, vividly epitomizes one characters lament about gentrification.

title: Greeks Strike for 2nd Time Against Steps to Cut Deficit
description: ATHENS  Flights at Greek airports were canceled, public transportation was halted and schools closed Wednesday as public-sector employees and private-sector workers walked off their jobs in the second 24-hour strike in two weeks against austerity measures.

title: The Early Word: The Business of Jobs
description: The Senate is set to pass a $15 billion jobs bill on Wednesday, with the House expected to quickly follow suit, setting the stage for President Obama to sign legislation into law on his top domestic priority.

title: Next Stop, Bread Crumb Square
description: Video | Pigeon homes in on commuting in the big city:

title: Now Showing | Deyns Debut
description: Agyness Deyn is the latest model trying to make the transition to acting, but shes doing it via the art gallery rather than Hollywood. In Mean to Me, a visually sumptuous 12-minute film noir written and directed by David McDermott and Peter McGough, Deyn trades her gamine look for raven-hued finger waves and crimson lips  all the better to deliver a blow to the head of her lover (the Law & Order star Linus Roache), wrestle him into the bathtub, tie him up and extort a sizable check. Set in the Great Depression and named for a popular song of the era, the artist duos first scripted film chronicles the disastrous end of an affair. McDermott and McGough began collaborating 30 years ago, and capturing the essence of a time past has always been part of their work, so recreating the 1930s proved no challenge. Period-perfect down to its wallpaper, telephone and radio, McGoughs Art Deco Manhattan apartment provided the set. Deyns costumes, by Zac Posen, might as well be of that vintage. The Shalimar perfume and pearls, around which crucial plot points turn, were courtesy of Guerlain and Mikimoto, which underwrote the project. Deyn got the gig at the suggestion of McGoughs pal Louie Chaban, director of Women Management. Peter asked for a girl who wanted to act, Chaban says. And can she? McGough proclaims: A star is born.

title: Millipore Confirms Exploring Strategic Alternatives
description: Millipore, a maker of tools and services for bioscience companies, confirmed late on Tuesday that it was examining strategic alternatives, including a potential sale of the company.

title: Martin Wolf Makes Me Look Like Pollyanna
description: Quite a depressing column:

title: Investors Cheer as Federal Reserve Eases Anxiety Over Monetary Policy
description: A pledge from the chairman of the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low helped galvanize the equity markets on Wednesday, soothing concerns that the economy would be deprived of a critical crutch as it struggled to recover.

title: Unexpected Beauty
description: One of the things that never ceases to amaze me is the pleasure I take in the sweep of the Raritan River past New Brunswick, as seen from New Jersey Transit heading south. A surprise lift to the spirit  in a very odd place for that to happen  after a day in the big city.

title: Lost Watch: Go Ask Alice
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Mercedes-Benz F 800 Style Concept to Showcase Green Technologies
description: Would you buy a 136-horsepower Mercedes-Benz? What if it were powered by hydrogen fuel cells? Are you so committed to green-car technology that, besides the six-figure price tag, you would put up with zero-to-60 times of more than 11 seconds?

title: Big Bonuses Are Back
description: The big money is officially back on Wall Street.

title: Pregnancy, Depression and Acupuncture
description: Two studies released in the past few days address the the prevalence and treatment of depression during and after pregnancy.

title: How Many Successful Businesses Can One Owner Run?
description: There are many events that prompt the sale of a business, including retirement, health issues and burnout. There is another reason for selling that is not quite as common. Every once in a while I meet an entrepreneur who has started two  sometimes even three  businesses within a short period of time and needs to jettison one of them to avoid financial or emotional peril, or both.

title: Deal Grab Bag: Airgas, Schlumberger, A.I.G. and More
description: It has been an eventful week so far in the world of mergers and acquisitions.

title: Bernanke Expects Extended Low Rates
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress on Wednesday that the central bank did not intend to start raising short-term interest rates anytime soon, saying the economic recovery would remain halting for many more months.

title: In Every $10 Fine, a Tribute to Holzman
description: The greatest team in Knicks history left an indelible impression, but not enough DNA to provide a blueprint for future generations. Descendants have failed to replicate its success or its spirit, although a few occasionally came close.

title: American Idol': Ladies of the Top 24
description: And so it begins: Ellen DeGeneres on one end of the judges table and Simon Cowell on the other. By now the tension between them, imagined or real, is part of the narrative of this season of American Idol.After the first performance, Mr. Cowell didnt even know he was supposed to speak first. Where his slight cluelessness used to be a marker of power, now hes just looking marginalized.

title: An Apology From Toyotas Leader
description: WASHINGTON  Akio Toyoda, the president of Toyota, was billed as the main attraction at a House hearing Wednesday into the companys recalls of millions of cars  recalls for which he profusely apologized and took personal responsibility.

title: Jeter Says He Expects to Re-Sign With Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter said Wednesday that he has never envisioned playing anywhere else and that he expects to re-sign with the Yankees when his contract expires after this season.

title: New-Home Sales Plunged to Record Low in January
description: The sickly housing market was socked with another dose of bad news on Wednesday when the Commerce Department reported that new home sales fell in January to the lowest level since record-keeping began in 1963.

title: Former Jobs Czar Lands at Think Tank
description: Van Jones, the charismatic advocate for environmental jobs who resigned from a White House post last September over a number of controversial past statements, has found a new job with the Center for American Progress in Washington.

title: Bernanke Reaffirms Extended Period of Low Rates
description: 12:23 p.m. | Updated  Ben S. Bernanke, making his first appearance before Congress since the Senate confirmed him last month to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, reaffirmed on Wednesday that short-term interest rates would remain exceptionally low  near zero  for an extended period, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: Catching the Wave
description: In the 1940s, the investor, diplomat and art collector William A.M. Burden and his wife, Margaret Livingston Partridge Burden, commissioned Wallace K. Harrison - the architect who was involved in the design of iconic works like Rockefeller Center, the Museum of Modern Art (of which Mr. Burden was president in the 1950s and '60s) and the United Nations headquarters - and the artist Isamu Noguchi to design a summer house off the Maine coast.
