The house, which was completed in 1947, became a 20th-century landmark, literally as well as figuratively - it is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places - as well as a remarkable example, after a devastating fire, of how to restore a Modernist dwelling.

title: Volvo Looks at New Way of Lightening Batteries Without Losing Power
description: Among the biggest challenges for hybrid and battery cars are the size, weight and cost of their battery packs. A new joint project involving Volvo and the Imperial College London is attempting to address all three simultaneously by supplementing the battery with ultracapacitors that can quickly store and discharge energy. That part isnt new  a number of companies are working on ultracaps for battery vehicles  but this portion of the $4.5 million research program, funded by the European Union, is unique in that its energy storage doubles as part of the car.

title: Domesticities
description: Catching the Wave, the story of a house designed in the 1940s by Wallace K. Harrison and Isamu Noguchi for a breathtaking site off the coast of Maine, is the first article in our new series, Domesticities, in which T looks at the design of notable new and classic houses and interiors. More

title: Wednesday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: British Prime Minister as Animated Antihero
description: Apple Daily, a news and gossip site in Taiwan and Hong Kong known for blurring the distinction between the two by supplementing its online articles with computer-animated videos that treat rumor as fact, produced a video this week that imagines Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain as the boss from hell.

title: Antonin Scalia, Script Doctor
description: 12:51 p.m. | Updated  Like countless aspiring screenwriters who spend their days typing away in home offices and coffee shops and their evenings waiting plaintively for responses from anyone who can make their dreams come true, Daniel Turkewitz sent his original script out into the world and, surprisingly, got a response. More surprisingly, that response was from Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia.

title: Drone Attack Reported in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least eight militants were killed in the North Waziristan region on Wednesday by three missiles fired from an American drone, according to a Pakistani security official and residents.

title: Vaccine Approved for Child Infections
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved Prevnar 13, an expanded version of a vaccine to protect children against more forms of bacterial infections that can cause meningitis, pneumonia and other diseases.

title: Answers From Chuck Scarborough
description: Following is the first set of answers from Chuck Scarborough about his career as an author and broadcast journalist, his job as co-anchor of New York Nightly News at 7 P.M., and other related matters.

title: Akio Toyoda Meets Congress
description: Everything thus far seems to have been prologue to the Congressional hearings on Toyotas sudden unintended acceleration problems, which began Tuesday. On Wednesday at 11 a.m., Akio Toyoda, president of Toyota and grandson of the companys founder, will testify in front of the House Committee on Oversight and Reform.

title: Bits Scan: Apple TV, an Improved Xbox and a Week Without Google
description: Wednesday mornings roundup of technology news:

title: Whats in a Name, Hurt Locker Edition
description: If intellectuals had a say in the Oscar race, The Hurt Locker would surely win, judging from the crowd that turned up at a party at the Monkey Bar celebrating the publication of the movies shooting script on Tuesday night. Not to say that Academy members arent intellectuals; theyre just not public about it. Or  O.K., were getting out of this before we start a Hollywood elite versus New York elite flame war. (It would be fought entirely with donations to eco-charities.)

title: Health Executive Defends Premiums
description: WASHINGTON  A top health insurance company executive told a Congressional committee on Wednesday that higher premiums were justified by soaring medical costs, and warned that pending legislation could make the problem worse, further driving up costs for young, healthy people.

title: Updates on Toyota Hearings in Congress
description: The Lede is following Congressional hearings in Washington this week on Toyotas safety problems. On Wednesday, we will provide updates on the questioning of witnesses during a House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform hearing. The star witness will be Akio Toyoda, grandson of the companys founder who now runs it. My colleague Micheline Maynard is providing frequent updates on the hearings on her Twitter feed.

title: Volunteers at Whistler Do the Grunt Work, and Love It
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  When his daughter won a gold medal last week, Karl Ricker was on a different mountain, being a Weasel. It is a term of affection.

title: It Was a Fun Day
description: Monologue |  Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: It was a fun day for the head of Toyota U.S.A. today. He had to appear in front of Congress to be yelled at by men who dont do anything.

title: A Secretive Start-Up Raises the Curtain
description: In The New York Times on Wednesday, I wrote about Bloom Energy, the once-secretive Silicon Valley start-up that has apparently made a big breakthrough in developing a fuel cell that can generate electricity at competitive prices while minimizing greenhouse gas emissions.

title: The Other Debt Story: U.S. Treasuries and China
description: Its when you need to borrow money that you find out who your friends are. China sold $34 billion worth of United States Treasury securities in December, and The Daily Telegraph of London thinks this is no coincidence.

title: You Shall Know His Velocity: Speedy Gonzales Gets a Movie
description: When you have been accused for decades of being a cheap caricature and resorting to ethnic humor for easy laughs, does an endorsement from George Lopez help or hurt your cause?

title: Pan-Fried Chickpeas
description: The pan-fried chickpeas described in this weeks Minimalist column are worth making alone, separately from the main dish, because the process turns the normally mealy legume into something you can happily snack on. Combine those with chorizo and spinach and you have a fantastic dinner dish.

title: Senate Approves $15 Billion Jobs Bill
description: WASHINGTON  In what Democrats hope is the first in a series of legislative victories, the Senate on Wednesday easily approved a $15 billion plan to spur job creation, a vote that lawmakers hoped would show that they were taking steps to improve the nations employment outlook.

title: Q. and A. With the Kabul Bureau
description: Will Operation Moshtarak, the campaign under way in Marja, Afghanistan, reshape the war? How are civilians in the area handling the campaign? How long will it take for a local Afghan government to begin functioning in the area? What is the role of the government of President Hamid Karzai in the ongoing campaign? Are the recent arrests of Taliban leaders in Pakistan related to the campaign in Marja?

title: Burberry: Fly Girls
description: The shearling jackets were so ample, fluffy and round, the trousers and narrow skirts so spindly that at times on Tuesday the Burberry show resembled a lane of dandelions gone to seed. To be sure, Christopher Baileys outerwear for the British label was especially strong, with those romantic flight jackets spreading or curling at the collar and the pomp of officer coats.

title: Brooklyn Borough Chief Is Deposed in Bias Suit
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not the only city official who has been forced recently to answer questions about employment discrimination.

title: A Maker of Fuel Cells Blooms in California
description: Our colleague Todd Woody on the Green Inc. blog has an interesting blog post about Bloom Energy, a secretive fuel-cell start-up that was also the subject of an article Wednesday in The New York Times.

title: Free In-Room Hotel Workouts
description: No more excuses. The Hotel Networks, a television programming company based in New York that delivers on-demand channels to hotels, has teamed up with ExerciseTV to provide free workout videos in more than 1.1 million hotel rooms across the United States.

title: Maria Cornejo Plays All the Angles
description: IVE had a music book sitting out for the last month, for the purpose of staring at a Tom Copi portrait of Miles Davis, photographed sometime in the early 1970s. Mr. Davis is onstage, wearing a lace-up suede Robin Hood shirt and enormous square Jackie O sunglasses. He is scowling, apparently taking a momentary break between lung blasts, and holding his trumpet straight up.

title: Mountain Men
description: Snow Canvas With the Leica may not be the most exciting of book titles, but the author Stefan Kruckenhauser knew how to capture the drama and beauty of skiing in the Austrian Alps in the 1930s. He was known as the pope of skiing, and he trained many instructors on the finer points of the sport. While you might not understand or care for all the terminology, the images he took are glorious  something right out of an Arnold Franck mountain film. Skikamerad Toni/Winterfahrten inGarmisch-Partenkirchen by Dr. Paul Wolf is another bland title (loose translation: My Ski Comrade Tony/Winter Sports in Garmisch-Partenkirchen) but offers gorgeous moments of the sport as well as the aprs-ski scene in Austrians fanciest resorts.

title: As Plain as the Nose on His Stage
description: MANAGING pandemonium is not easy, especially when you must create it first. The South African artist William Kentridge has set himself this task with the very young Dmitri Shostakovichs first opera, The Nose. Based on the story by Nikolai Gogol, the absurdist tour de force tells of Platon Kuzmich Kovalev, a civil official of the eighth rank who wakes up one morning in status-mad St. Petersburg short one nose. To his mounting dismay, the missing body part is eventually discovered gallivanting through the capital in the guise of a snooty official of the fifth rank.

title: Before the Glitter, Plenty of Bruises
description: WHETHER flying through the air looking weightless or spinning so fast that they turn into a blur, figure skaters at the Olympics often make their sport look easy.

title: Hedge Fund Moves on Stuyvesant Town
description: A hedge fund that has acquired a significant portion of the debt on the troubled Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes in Manhattan is seeking to take control of them.

title: Snow Day at the Hospital
description: Ah, the unexpected pleasure of a snow day. School is canceled and work may be canceled, too. Life suddenly becomes all about hunkering down in your domestic space and making do with what you have.

title: General Growth to Split Itself in Two
description: 1:45 p.m. | Updated General Growth Properties officially announced its plan. Read it here. Read the term sheet here.

title: Anthem Executive Blames Premium Increases on Rising Medical Costs
description: A top insurance executive told a Congressional panel on Wednesday that higher premiums were justified by soaring medical costs, and she warned that pending legislation could make the problem worse, further driving up costs for young, healthy people.

title: S.E.C. Moves to Put Limits on Short-Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted on Wednesday to limit short-selling of stocks that are falling rapidly in price.

title: Luo Hun
description: A Chinese term naked wedding or naked marriage  used to describe economy no frill nuptials.

title: S.E.C. Moves to Put Limits on Short-Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted on Wednesday to limit short-selling of stocks that are falling rapidly in price, The New York Timess Floyd Norris reports. The rule was adopted on a 3-to-2 vote, with the two Republican members saying that no case had been made to justify any further action against short-selling.

title: Pride of Canada and Grandmas
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The line stretched out the door of the Vancouver Curling Club on Monday afternoon, the entrance blocked by a bouncer, befitting the rock-star status of the man inside.

title: Avatar Wins 3-D Shocker
description: Hey, so are things beginning to seem a little predictable? If youre just tuning in to awards season, maybe not  but for most prognosticators, the favorites seem clear.

title: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall Offices? Walk, Walk.
description: Carnegie Halls $200 million renovation is entering a new phase that will cause the displacement of most of its administrative staff. Some 175 employees will vacate the building in May and take up residence at 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, through at least the end of 2012, said Clive Gillinson, Carnegies executive and artistic director. Stagehands and a few other employees will remain at the hall, where performances and box office operations will be unaffected, he said. E-mail and postal addresses will stay the same, along withphone numbers. The work, which began in the summer and is expected to last four or five years, will createroom for education programs and offices, as well as renovate the backstage area and other spaces. The plan will expand Carnegies footprint into the studios in two towers once rented by artists, residents and others.

title: London Fashion Week | An Audience With Queen Viv
description: Vivienne Westwood stopped for a chat after her AW10 Red Label show to tell us about buying clothes, colony collapse disorder and her plans for media domination.

title: Montreal Bagels, Now South of the Border
description: New Yorkers interested in seeing how Montreals famous bagels stack up against their citys finest can now taste-test for themselves.

title: Nets Chief Executive Looks Forward to Turning the Page
description: For Brett Yormark, the chief executive of the Nets, next season cannot come soon enough. With just five wins, the team is on track to set a league record for losses.

title: Not Necessarily a Lost Decade for Savers
description: A recent study by Fidelity offers some more evidence that the past 10 years may not have been a lost decade for steadfast savers.

title: G.M. Vice Chairman May See Retirement on Horizon
description: LOS ANGELES  Bob Lutz, a vice chairman of General Motors, addressed a breakfast meeting of automotive writers here on Tuesday, ostensibly to talk about the companys improving fortunes. But Mr. Lutz, 78, sounded like he was launching his farewell tour.

title: At the Met, a Hun Who Struggles to Conquer His Doubts
description: Attila was the ninth of Verdis 28 operas, an early work, coming right before Macbeth. Most opera buffs, if they know Attila at all, would rank it pretty far down the list. I would have agreed  that is, before Tuesday night, when Riccardo Muti, making his absurdly overdue Metropolitan Opera debut, conducted Attila in a Met premiere production by the noted director Pierre Audi.

title: Chronic Disease Straining Medicare Budgets
description: The growth in health care spending for Medicare beneficiaries is increasingly due to treatment for lifestyle-related chronic conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol, according to a study recently published online by the journal Health Affairs.

title: How to Find Out if Your Bank Is Healthy
description: With the news Tuesday from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that it is bracing for a new round of bank failures and has placed 702 lenders on its list of problem banks, the most since 1993, you may be wondering about the long-term prospects of your own bank.

title: Idol Returns to Form and Beats the Olympics
description: The natural ratings order returned on Tuesday night, which meant that even though the Winter Olympics continued to attract big audiences for NBC, American Idol was by far the dominant show on television.

title: Sade Remains Atop the Billboard Charts
description: Sades Soldier of Love (Epic) holds at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a second week with sales of 190,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. With no major new releases, the Top 10 is only slightly reshuffled from last week. Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 144,000, and the Black Eyed Peas The E.N.D. (Interscope), with 65,000,climbed five spots to No. 3.

title: Vonns Crash Winds Up Hurting Mancuso, Too
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  In another twist to an already complicated relationship, the longtime skiing rivals Lindsey Vonn and Julia Mancuso were linked in a new way during one bizarre minute of the womens giant slalom Wednesday morning. It did not turn out well for either of them.

title: Violence That Art Didnt See Coming
description: When Ezra Pound declared in 1934 that artists are the antennae of the race, and Marshall McLuhan 30 years later called them people of integral awareness, both were using modern terms to update the ancient belief that works of the imagination might actually require a talent not only for invention but for attunement  for picking up signals already in the air. This is why the most forceful narratives and dramas seem less made up than distilled. They clarify events and experiences taken directly from the actual world.

title: Can Nummi Be Saved?
description: The Bay Area is bracing itself for the March 31 closure of the New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., known as Nummi, in Fremont as officials work to try to soften the blow.

title: Where Shoddy Construction Could Mean Death
description: An analysis of damage that would be caused by a major earthquake in Istanbul.

title: Now Reserving | Azar in Marrakesh
description: After fending off miscellaneous marauders for centuries, Marrakeshs ramparts now stand guard over one of the worlds great dream machines.

title: The Obligations of Pundits
description: Jonathan Chait, echoed by Jonathan Cohn, responds to David Brooks column on the disappearing excise tax and my own post on the subject with a critique of conservative punditry:

title: Where That Is It and Rewrite History Still Resonate
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The United States is not the only land whose hockey team made its citizens believe in miracles. Other countries have had their defining moments on the rink, when a victory became a communal celebration of nationhood its people will never forget.

title: Menendez Aims New Jobs Attack at Republicans
description: Hes withstood high-profile retirements, a staggering loss in Massachusetts and a spate of heavy criticism for his record so far as chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. But Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey called it wishful thinking for Republicans to think they have a shot at recapturing a majority this year.

title: S.E.C. Restricts Short-Selling and Addresses a Global Accounting Shift
description: A sharply divided Securities and Exchange Commission voted on Wednesday to restrict selling stocks short when they are falling rapidly, with the majority voicing hopes the action would improve investor confidence and the dissenters saying there was no evidence that any action was needed.

title: Solving a Mystery Covered by 137 Years of Paint
description: They went with a shade close to the second generation color  not the original brown from 1873 and not the blue from the 1970s, but a creamy off-white.

title: Millennials More Pro-Government Than Older Americans
description: Speaking of generational divides: the Pew Research Center today released a giant report on the Millennial generation, a k a Generation Y, a k a Americans born after 1980.

title: Neighbors Opens Its Doors to Theater Critics
description: The Public Theaters production of Neighbors, a new play about race and family that uses theatrical devices like blackface and minstrelsy, will run for an additional week and be opened to theater critics for review, artistic leaders of the Public said on Wednesday.

title: S.E.C. Moves Toward Use of Global Accounting Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it still hoped to approve the move of American companies to international accounting standards by the end of 2011, but it laid down a series of conditions before it would approve the shift, The New York Timess Floyd Norris reports.

title: Kramer Is More Forgiving Than Dutch Press
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The collapse of the Dutch coalition government over the question of extending the Netherlands military presence in Afghanistan was knocked off the front pages Wednesday by another catastrophe: the Dutch speedskating star Sven Kramers Olympic disqualification in his signature event, the 10,000 meters.

title: A Shop of Her Own and Good, Clean Dirt
description: ANDES, N.Y.

title: Suggestions to Improve the Combine
description: The meat market known as the Combine starts in Indianapolis this week. You can view the workout schedule (and every other piece of Combine information) here. Or, for the N.F.L.s semiprivate Combine page, click here.

title: Bites That Kill: Creating Informative Exhibits on Malaria
description: Overview | What do King Tut and impoverished people living in tropical zones have in common? In this lesson, students reflect on malaria through the ages and then create an installation exhibit to educate their peers about the science, health issues and history of malaria.

title: Travel Deals: 20 Percent off Eurostar
description: Rail Europe, which sells train tickets throughout Europe, is offering 20 percent off fares aboard the Eurostar, a high-speed train that services the Britain, France and Belgium.

title: Pistol Packing Fashion Icon
description: ONE thing you may not have known about Elvis Presley and his peculiar fashion choices is that he never liked wearing jeans. Another is that, evidently, he considered a gun to be an accessory.

title: Boy Meets Girl
description: We have had decades of fusion food. Now, at last, we have fashion fusion. For gender bending  a vestige of feminism and gay pride  substitute gender blending, as designers unite drape and straight and meld a womanly softness with masculine confidence. The concept of women dressing like men to shatter the glass ceiling hung around throughout the 1980s. But that attitude has been replaced by a new aesthetic: take any elements from either sex and piece them together.

title: Signs of Life, and Change, in Climate Inquiry
description: There are signs that climate research (and the efforts to communicate it) could emerge bruised but intact, and better off in the long run, in the wake of all the various Xxxxx-gates propounded in the climate debate over the last three months. They are preliminary signs, mind you, but they seem significant.

title: Painted Ladies | Lady Gaga and Cyndi Lauper
description: Barely discernible makeup may be the beauty trend du jour, but those mavens of maquillage Cyndi Lauper and Lady Gaga never got the memo. I have a huge suitcase full of the stuff, said Lauper, who is composing the music for the coming Broadway adaptation of the movie Kinky Boots. I am just sorry I only have one face to put it all on. Its an addiction shared by her stylistic heiress. I am a glamour girl through and through, Lady Gaga said. See, she added, pointing to welts on her left arm, I burned myself with a curling iron. Glamour, girl! Little wonder, then, that M.A.C. has tapped them to be the latest mouthpieces for its VIVA Glam campaign. In addition to appearing in the companys new advertisements, they have each created a lipstick. (Laupers is a light coral red, and Gagas is a bubble-gum pink; $14.) All proceeds go to the M.A.C. AIDS fund. Who said glamour was only for the shallow?

title: After Shooting Chimp, a Police Officers Descent
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Everybody here knew Travis the Chimp, whose owners drove him around in a tow truck, and Police Officer Frank Chiafari, on the job for 25 years, remembered playing with him when their paths would cross.

title: CBS Extends Contract for Moonves to 2015
description: Leslie Moonves will continue to lead the CBS Corporation until early 2015, the company announced Wednesday after extending his employment agreement.

title: Witnessing Kashmirs Invisible War
description: India and Pakistan last went to war over Kashmir in 1999. But the violence continues, mostly invisible to outsiders.

title: In the Shoes of Olympians Parents
description: For most of my life I watched the Olympics and identified with the athletes (if identified is not too lofty a word, sitting on my couch with my remote) wondering how it must feel to go that fast, jump that high, perform at that level, stand on that podium. I wanted to be Dorothy Hamill. Kristi Yamaguchi looked like she was having so much fun.

title: Midcentury Modernized
description: An architect was challenged to create a contemporary feel in a 1940s housing tower, and on a tight budget.

title: An Unfortunate Oops: That Was Not Rochettes Dad
description: NBC had the most heart-rending of stories to tell when the Canadian skater Joannie Rochette competed in the short program Tuesday night, only days after her mother, Therese, died from a heart attack after arriving in Vancouver.

title: Va. Republican Leader Takes on Boucher
description: For the first time since 1984, Representative Rick Boucher of Virginia will face a serious Republican challenge, possibly jeopardizing his 28-year Democratic stronghold on the Appalachian district and sending his office into campaign mode earlier than ever before.

title: A New Report Card on Stimulus
description: It could have been worse may not be the worlds catchiest slogan, but its the best selling point that stimulus supporters have.

title: Prevention: Older Women Are Not Likely to Benefit From Cervical Cancer Vaccine
description: Women older than 40 are unlikely to get much benefit from the vaccine for the virus that causes cervical cancer, a new study reports.

title: Pregnancy: Some Depression Relief, Without Drugs
description: Up to a quarter of all women suffer from depression during pregnancy, and many are reluctant to take antidepressants. Now a new study suggests that acupuncture may provide some relief during pregnancy, even though it has not been found to be effective against depression in general.

title: Concrete-Testing Company Guilty of Enterprise Corruption
description: A prominent concrete-testing company and its two top executives were convicted on Wednesday of enterprise corruption, the last remaining and most serious charge levied in the case.

title: Turkey Unsettled by Officer Arrests
description: ISTANBUL  Tensions between Turkeys powerful military and the government have escalated sharply as a court has ordered the formal arrests of 20 former and current officers on charges they had plotted a coup.

title: A Match All About the Sicilian
Making the Golden Fuel Cells in Silicon Valley
description: An article in The New York Times and a post by our colleagues at the Green Inc. blog delve into the story behind Bloom Energy, a Silicon Valley company. At a news conference in San Jose on Wednesday, Bloom officials announced the company had developed fuel cells that they said could supply affordable and relatively clean electricity.

title: What Can the Bagger Do for You?
description: Longest Oscar season ever, one awards-watcher complained on Twitter recently, and his discontent wasnt merely hyperbole.The telecast was indeed pushed back two weeks to make room for Olympics coverage, so it doesnt just feel longer than normal. People have been making this lament to the Bagger for a while now, but since we have nothing to compare it to  this being our first Oscar season  weve kept mum.

title: Acting Early to Clear Redness
description: At birth, port-wine stains are well-defined, flat pink to red lesions. In time, they thicken and darken and may grow little bumps that bleed.

title: Vitiligo: Ignoring What Is Painfully Obvious
description: THREE million Americans have vitiligo, an autoimmune disorder that causes patches of skin to lose pigment. The darker the skin, the more prominent the paler patches. But for people of every shade, vitiligo can cause distress as strangers gawk and job interviews become sidetracked.

title: Charges Filed in Katrina Inquiry
description: NEW ORLEANS  On Sept. 4, 2005, with floodwaters of Hurricane Katrina still standing in much of the city, Lt. Michael J. Lohman of the New Orleans Police Department arrived at the Danziger Bridge in eastern New Orleans. A group of police officers had rushed there just ahead of him in response to a radio call for assistance.

title: Yelp Is Sued After Dispute Over a Review
description: 4:14 p.m. | Updated  Removing reference to earlier lawsuit at the end. Yelp says it was no longer a defendant when that case was settled.

title: Boy Meets Girl
description: We have had decades of fusion food. Now, at last, we have fashion fusion. For gender bending  a vestige of feminism and gay pride  substitute gender blending, as designers unite drape and straight and meld a womanly softness with masculine confidence. The concept of women dressing like men to shatter the glass ceiling hung around throughout the 1980s. But that attitude has been replaced by a new aesthetic: take any elements from either sex and piece them together.

title: At the Summit, an Unexpected Guest and a Republican Truth Squad
description: The White House has made an unexpected addition to the guest list for Thursdays big health care summit meeting, adding Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who is the author of a prominent bipartisan health care proposal.

title: Vermont Senate Votes to Close Nuclear Plant
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  In an unusual state foray into nuclear regulation, the Vermont Senate voted 26 to 4 Wednesday to block operation of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant after 2012, citing radioactive leaks, misstatements in testimony by plant officials and other problems.

title: Corzine Sees Envy Behind Anger at Goldman
description: Jon S. Corzine, the former governor of New Jersey, has mostly kind things to say about another place he once led: Goldman Sachs.

title: Inquiry Grows in Dubai Assassination
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Dubai police released the names of 15 more suspects on Wednesday in the killing of a senior Hamas operative in a Dubai hotel room last month, expanding the range of an investigation that has already fostered diplomatic tensions between several European countries and Israel, whose intelligence service is widely suspected of planning the assassination.

title: Clear Trend in Pocket Projectors
description: New technology follows a certain cycle. When a new category bursts out  the VCR, the MP3 player, the netbook  the first models are crude, expensive and underpowered. Several months later, me-too companies rush in, bringing the prices down and the refinement up. A few years later, the VCR, MP3 player or netbook reaches its final form, with only minor refinements in the years to come.

title: Along the Watchtower, Paring Down and Peeling Back
description: More change in the constantly changing city.

title: Packaging the Cage-Free Trend
description: Hellmanns mayo is using cage-free eggs. Real change or marketingtrend? You make the call.

title: On Saturday, Bagels Fresh From Montreal
description: On Saturday mornings, Mile End Deli, a new Canadian-themed venture in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has bagels freshly delivered from the St.-Viateur Bagel bakery in Montreal.

title: Obama Defends His Policies to C.E.O.s
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama rejected assertions on Wednesday that his domestic program amounted to big-government socialism.

title: Answers About Same-Sex Couples and Taxes: Part 2
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Next Stop for Maazel: Munich?
description: The Munich Philharmonic Orchestra is wooing Lorin Maazel as chief conductor, according to German news reports. Mr. Maazel, 79, who ended a term as music director of the New York Philharmonic last season, declined to comment on the reports, a spokesman said Wednesday. The Web site of the Sueddeutsche Zeitung said Munichs mayor, Christian Ude, confirmed that negotiations were under way. Mr. Maazel is well known in Munich, having led the Bavarian Radio Symphony there from 1993 to 2002. In an interview last June Mr. Maazel said he was done with permanent posts. After the New York Philharmonic, one doesnt take positions, he said.

title: Republicans: Hey, Wheres Stupak?
description: Firing his latest zinger at the White House ahead of Thursdays big forum on health care policy, the House Republican leader, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, urged President Obama to invite Representative Bart Stupak, a Michigan Democrat who authored tight restrictions on insurance coverage for abortions that were added to the House health care bill before it was adopted in November.

title: G.M. to Close Hummer After Sale Fails
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Wednesday that it would shut down Hummer, the brand of big sport utility vehicles that became synonymous with the term gas guzzler, after a deal to sell it to a Chinese manufacturer fell apart.

title: Evita Revival Planned for Broadway
description: The theater producers Hal Luftig and Scott Sanders are aiming to mount the first Broadway revival of the musical Evita in the next year or two, with the Argentine actress Elena Roger inthe title role, which she played to acclaim in London in 2006, an executive involved with the production said on Wednesday.

title: G.M. to Close Hummer After Sale Collapses
description: General Motors said Wednesday that it was shutting down Hummer, the brand of big sport-utility vehicles that became synonymous with the term gas guzzler, after a deal to sell it to a Chinese manufacturer fell apart, The New York Timess Nick Bunkley reports from Detroit.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Feb. 24
description: The demonstrators fist in Slide 1, which has just dealt a surprisingly effective blow to a riot police officer in Athens, is just the first of a remarkable gallery of hands in Wednesdays show. Yes, hands; in all their expressive power. You can read the unleashed fury in the first picture. In Slide 4, a victims clenched hand speaks of the awful desperation of death under a landslide. Hands comfort in Slide 5 and they heal in Slide 7. They are said to be playing in Slide 10, but there is an undeniably haunting quality to that hand in the center of the frame.

title: The Argument for Boxed Wine
description: The issue of alternative packaging came up repeatedly at the Symposium for Professional Wine Writers, which I attended in Napa Valley last week. While opinion was mixed on whether this would be an important issue to follow over the coming year, the moaning was collective when the subject of boxed wines came up.

title: Hummer Deal Falls Through
description: DETROIT  Hummer, the brand of big sport-utility vehicles that became synonymous with the term gas guzzler, is being shut down after a deal to sell it to a Chinese manufacturer fell apart, General Motors said Wednesday.

title: Large Coalition of Religious Groups Urges Passage of Health Bill
description: An unusually broad array of religious groups sent a letter to President Obama and members of Congress on Wednesday calling on them to pass a comprehensive health care bill [pdf].

title: France Hopes Visit by Sarkozy Will Improve Ties to Rwanda
description: PARIS  Nicolas Sarkozys visit to Rwanda on Thursday, the first by a French president since the 1994 genocide there, is intended to improve the fraught relations between the countries.

title: Netherlands Sled Withdraws from Bobsled, Citing Safety
description: Netherlands pilot Edwin van Calker withdrew his four-man sled from Olympic competition Wednesday, citing a loss of confidence in navigating through the Whistler Sliding Centre. He said it stemmed from his crash in two-man bobsled, the death of a Georgian luger at the track and family pressure.

title: Toyota to Foot Bill for Recalls
description: Toyota has agreed to provide free pickup and return of recalled cars, free rental cars or taxi reimbursement for the owners of the half million or so Toyotas in New York State that are being recalled, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday. Soon after, a Toyota executive, Yoshimi Inaba, told a Congressional hearing that the company planned to offer the benefit nationwide.

title: Takahashi Makes a Good First Impression
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Most of the buzz surrounding the two Japanese pitchers in Mets camp involves Ryota Igarashi, the right-hander with the two-year guaranteed contract. The cagey left-hander on the minor league deal gets less attention.

title: Water-Cooler Talk About the Water-Cooler Effect
description: In Wednesdays New York Times, I write about the online water-cooler effect that television executives are crediting in part for record ratings for big-ticket events like the Super Bowl and the Olympics.

title: Choosing a Marketing Plan: Traditional or Social Media?
description: EPC CIGAR COMPANY manufactures and distributes cigars that are hand-rolled in the Dominican Republic from Ecuadorean, Nicaraguan and Dominican tobacco. It has been in business since April, although the family that owns it previously ran a successful cigar company that was sold to Swedish Match in 1999.

title: Stealing Kisses Before Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: A delightful first act gives way to a muddled Act II in Yank!, a musical about a gay romance during World War II. But if the overall package doesnt quite work, this stuffed-to-the-brim show certainly goes out of its way to include something for everybody: two tap numbers, a ballet, rousing songs of camaraderie, sentimental ballads, bare backsides, guys in formal gowns. With all thats going on, you hardly even notice the accidental topicality.

title: Unsecured Creditors Question General Growth Plan
description: Hours after General Growth Properties introduced its reorganization plan, which would split the company in two and make Brookfield Asset Management one of its largest investors, the mall operators unsecured creditors committee has raised concerns about the plan.

title: Vonn Declines to Fire Back after Mancuso Comments
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Lindsey Vonn was asked Wednesday about some mildly disapproving comments her teammate Julia Mancuso said in a recent interview with Sports Illustrated. Mancuso lamented the popularity contest aspect of their relationship and Vonns impact on the team dynamic.

title: If Douglas Sirk and Milton Walked Into a Bar and Started Trading Yarns
description: This Buds for you, John and Doug. Thats the poet John Milton and the filmmaker Douglas Sirk, the main sources of inspiration for Whatever, Heaven Allows, the latest act of cultural deconstruction (or do I mean demolition?) from the rowdy Radiohole, an experimental theater company that breaks out the beer when its time for a toast.

title: Lawmakers Find S.E.C.s Short-Sale Rule Lacking
description: Some lawmakers are disappointed by the scope of the Securities and Exchange Commissions decision to put limits on short-selling, arguing that an alternative uptick rule does not go far enough to protect investors like the original uptick rule that reined in traders from 1938 to 2007.

title: Showcase: In Asia, Hope for Haiti
description: Is it possible for any land to recover from a calamity as tremendous as the earthquake in Haiti? Those who dare to hope so point to what happened in the Indonesian province of Aceh after it was devastated by the tsunami of 2004.

title: Disaster Awaits Cities in Earthquake Zones
description: ISTANBUL  As he surveys the streets of this sprawling mega-city, Mustafa Erdik, the director of an earthquake engineering institute here, says he sometimes feels like a doctor scanning a crowded hospital ward.

title: A Scorpion From Iraq Trying to Sting in America
description: The Iraqi metal band Acrassicauda, named after a black scorpion, looked at cross-purposes before it started to play on Tuesday night: both hesitant and ready to rip. But the singer and rhythm guitarist Faisal Talal Mustafa pushed ahead, beginning the ceremony. This songs called ...  he barked, Message! From! Baghdad!

title: Did EPC Cigar Pick the Right Marketing Campaign?
description: We just published a case study of EPC Cigar Companys new marketing campaign. The article, written by Jane L. Levere, explains how the company chose between traditional media and social media to introduce its new brand. Below are the analyses of four business owners and executives with related experience:

title: Barajas Finds There Are Few Guarantees These Days
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  After hitting 19 home runs and a career-high 71 runs batted in for the Toronto Blue Jays last year, Rod Barajas assumed he would get another contract without much problem, even at age 34 and with a career .238 batting average.

title: Analysis: United States Beats Switzerland, 2-0
description: Analysis of Wednesdays United States-Switzerland mens hockey quarterfinal. The Timess Jeffrey Marcus was at the arena providing updates, and Stu Hackel, a contributor to the Timess Slap Shot blog, provided analysis throughout the game.

title: Hurt Locker Takes a Hit
description: The Hurt Locker, which has been riding high on the strength of its many, many award wins and plaudits from intellectual bigwigs, lost a little altitude on Wednesday because of a guest article in Newsweek.

title: Jackpot | Winners from the Mens Trade Shows
description: Ive just returned from Las Vegas, where I checked out the Fall/Winter 2010 mens trade shows. A lot of the offerings were inspired by traditional fall favorites: Fair isle, flannel and fleece. (Pardon the alliteration.) In general, the mood signaled a return to backwoods basics.

title: Dress Codes | Channeling Those Crazy 80s Kids
description: The last year saw rumblings of a return of club-kid finery and the kinds of madcap outfits that were a mainstay of the 1980s and early 1990s nightclub scene  looks like these.

title: Putin Questions Dealings of Russian Oligarchs
description: MOSCOW  Four of Russias wealthiest businessmen were criticized by Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday, accused of failing to properly invest in the countrys energy sector.

title: The Fight Is On: Berkeleys Bread Garden Criticizes Peets Pastries
description: Berkeleyside has a scoop on a budding Berkeley bakery battle.

title: Watch How You Hold That Crayon
description: NOAH LASCANO, 8, had a problem: His teachers couldnt read his handwriting. His homework became a frustrating exercise in writing once, and then, at the teachers request, writing again, just for legibility.

title: Waterworld
description: Yuppies from Chinas boom cities arrive by the busload to take part in a wild frenzy of dousing and dunking and drenching at a site called the Dai Minority Park.

title: A Tie-Up Between Intel and TSMC Fizzles
description: About this time last year, Intel and TSMC announced a groundbreaking deal. Intel, which loves to make its own chips, tapped TSMC, which loves to make chips for other companies, to make variants of its Atom processor.

title: British Panel Condemns Media Group in Phone Hacking Case
description: LONDON  A parliamentary committee on Wednesday accused News International of having exhibited collective amnesia in an inquiry about how its News of the World tabloid hacked into the telephones of members of the royal family, celebrities and other public figures.

title: A Megacity Girds for a Major Quake
description: I have an article running in The Times on efforts to move away from what the psychologist Paul Slovic calls gut thinking, which tends to make people discount long-term threats even if science has delineated them with crystal clarity. The focus is great earthquakes that, without any doubt, will someday hammer great cities. The case study is Istanbul, but it could just as easily be Lima or Katmandu or Karachi or a host of other fast-growing urban centers in developing countries.

title: February Snow Showers Bring Bright Flowers
description: Three to six inches of wet snow are forecast for Thursday, 50-mile-an-hour winds are coming Friday, and the sun may not shine till Sunday, but theres always the orchid show at the New York Botanical Garden. Entitled Cuba in Flower, it opens Saturday and promises, among its thousands of brilliantly colored flowers, an oasis of beauty, fragrance and the intrigue of the tropical island nation. The exhibits designers, the gardens Web site says, have recreated the charm of the city of Havana, infused with Caribbean rhythm and romance. Plus, its indoors.

title: Works Begins on Veselka II
description: Construction has started on a new outpost of Veselka, the Eastern European institution in the East Village, famous for its dumplings, soups and Old-World-meets-art-world-vibe.

title: As India Sells Assets, Political Tensions Rise
description: MUMBAI, India  In the last 10 months, India has raised $3.5 billion selling off pieces of state-run companies, more than such sales brought in during the previous four years.

title: Is Sex Addiction an Excuse?
description: Recently, a panel of experts joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about sex addiction. One reader, responding to reports of golfer Tiger Woodss sex addiction, wondered if the sex addiction claim was just to save face and release all personal responsibility for his actions.

title: Lantern Cracker Jack
description: 8 cups freshly popped popcorn (from about 1/3 cup raw kernels)

title: Field Report: Plow Shares
description: Who brought their own wheelbarrow? Rob Jones asked the group of 20-somethings gathered on a muddy North Carolina farm on a chilly January Sunday. Hands shot up and wheelbarrows were pulled from pickups sporting Led Zeppelin and biodiesel bumper stickers, then parked next to a mountain of soil. We need to get that dirt into those beds over there in the greenhouse, he said, nodding toward a plastic-roofed structure a few hundred feet away. The rest of you can come with me to move trees and clear brush to make room for more pasture. Watch out for poison ivy.

title: Cheekily Defying Expectations
description: The choreographer Mark Morris works hard, well and successfully to elude categorization throughout his triple bill at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. By stretching his range, he also stretches our ideas of what dance theater can be and do.

title: A D.I.Y. Versailles
description: The Hart familys ornate 25,500-square-foot mansion in Las Vegas.

title: Five-Spice Powder
description: 2 tablespoons black peppercorns

title: Going Gaga
description: SOME people come to New York to achieve fabulousness; some come and find fabulousness thrust upon them.

title: Lions Head Meatballs
description: 10 dried black mushrooms (available at Asian markets)

title: Masking the Shades of Vitiligo
description: Todays Skin Deep column explores treatment options for vitiligo, an autoimmune disorder that causes patches of skin to lose pigment. New York Times reporter Catherine Saint Louis writes:

title: Cheney and Bush, Together Again
description: Now that former Vice President Dick Cheney has been released from a Washington hospital earlier today, hell at least get to have coffee with his old boss on Thursday.

title: The New Makeup
description: In accordance with our earlier promise  equal coverage for all the major horses in the major horse race  lets take another stroll through James Cameron-land. Put on your galoshes!

title: Deal Said to Be Reached on Deutsche Bank Building
description: At least one of the many disputes over the demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero is coming to an end.

title: Another Historian Criticizes The Kennedys
description: Add David Talbot to the list of authors who are pre-emptively criticizing The Kennedys, a planned mini-series that the producer and 24 co-creator Joel Surnow is preparing for the History channel.

title: Concert Still Shines a Light on Tibetan Culture
description: In 1988 when Tibet House US, a cultural organization in New York, held its first benefit concert, things were not looking good for the Tibetan homeland. It had been under Chinese occupation for four decades, and the Dalai Lama, its spiritual leader, had been in exile for three.

title: A.I.G. Unit Accused of Sex Discrimination in Suit
description: The American International Groups derivatives unit, which brought the insurer to the brink of failure, was sued by two former vice presidents who said a boys club culture discriminated against older women, Bloomberg News reports.

title: C.I.A. and Pakistan Work Together, Warily
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Inside a secret detention center in an industrial pocket of the Pakistani capital called I/9, teams of Pakistani and American spies have kept a watchful eye on a senior Taliban leader captured last month. With the other eye, they watch each other.

title: Charter Schools Get Less Money Per Student, Study Says
description: Charter schools in New York City get slightly less government funding per pupil than traditional public schools when the charter school is located in a public school building, and 18 percent less per student when the charter rents private space, according to a study released Wednesday by the citys Independent Budget Office.

title: Nintendos Newest Portable Gaming System
description: Big news  literally  from Nintendo. On Sunday, March 28 (Nintendo is not known to be sloppy on ship dates), a swollen-looking DS, called the DSi XL, will arrive in the United States.

title: Second Run of Womens Giant Slalom Is Postponed
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The Olympic womens giant slalom could not be completed today because of poor weather. The second run was rescheduled for tomorrow, weather permitting.

title: Regional Shift Helps Darfur, Amid Doubts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The preliminary peace treaty signed Tuesday night between the most powerful rebel movement in Darfur and the Sudanese government is the culmination of a shift in regional politics that could help bring Darfurs sputtering conflict to an end, Sudan observers say.

title: Shakespeares Lovers via Berlioz, via Russia
description: Valery Gergiev appears to be everywhere, all the time  running the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, leading the London Symphony as its principal conductor, conducting at the Metropolitan Opera or as a guest of the New York Philharmonic, directing festivals in Russia, the Netherlands, Finland and Israel.

title: As the Ball Bounces, Bleakly
description: I had a sort of, maybe, what should have been a grand idea.

title: Please Be Seated
description: The seating chart for the health care meeting is all set. And the folks on the dais are hardly a surprise: President Obama at the center, with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. immediately to his right and the secretary of health and human services, Kathleen Sebelius, sitting to his left.

title: Sade Stays on Top
description: Sades Soldier of Love (Epic) holds at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a second week with sales of 190,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. With no major new releases, the Top 10 is only slightly reshuffled from last week. Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 144,000, and the Black Eyed Peas E.N.D. (Interscope) climbed five spots to No. 3, with 65,000. Lady Gagas Fame (Interscope) rose three to No. 4 with 63,000, and Lil Waynes Rebirth (Cash Money/Universal) fell one spot to No. 5 with 58,000.

title: Carnegie Hall Offices Heading to Broadway
description: Carnegie Halls $200 million renovation is entering a new phase that will cause the displacement of most of its administrative staff. Some 175 employees will vacate the building in May and take up residence at 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, through at least the end of 2012, Clive Gillinson, Carnegies executive and artistic director, said. Stagehands and a few other workers will remain at the hall, where performances and box-office operations will be unaffected, he said. E-mail and postal addresses will stay the same, along with phone numbers. The work, which began in the summer and is expected to last four or five years, will create room for education programs and offices and renovate the backstage area and other spaces. The plan will expand Carnegies footprint into the studios in two towers once rented by artists and others.

title: Evita Revival Planned for New York Stage
description: The producers Hal Luftig and Scott Sanders are aiming to mount the first Broadway revival of the musical Evita in the next year or two, with the Argentine actress Elena Roger, right, in the title role, which she played to acclaim in London in 2006, an executive involved with the production said Wednesday. Plans for the revival, reported in The New York Post on Wednesday, call for a Broadway opening during the 2011-12 season, and the show could start performances as late as the spring of 2012, said the executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the producers had not permitted details to be made public. While the producers have faith in Ms. Roger to deliver a star turn as Eva Pern in the Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim Rice musical, the executive said, they are also looking for a household name to play Che Guevara. An offer had been made to the singer and actor Ricky Martin, but he had not accepted as of Wednesday afternoon, the executive said. Michael Grandage, the artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse in London, directed the 2006 revival starring Ms. Roger, and he has signed on to direct the Broadway production as well. The London production received strong reviews and ran for about a year before closing at a busy time for musicals in the West End. The Tony-winning Broadway production of Evita, which opened in 1979, starred Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin.

title: Idol Trumps Olympics
description: After American Idol, on Fox, trailed in its time slot last week for the first time in more than 200 episodes, it returned to form in the ratings on Tuesday night with its first live broadcast of the season, outperforming NBCs coverage of the Winter Olympics. According to Nielsens estimates, 24 million viewers tuned in to the two-hour Idol from 8 to 10 p.m., compared with the 20.8 million who watched NBC during the same time period. NBC did lead during the 10 oclock hour, improving its average for the night (21.2 million), but Fox still won the night over all. CBS ranked third with reruns of NCIS (11.5 million), NCIS: Los Angeles (8.6 million) and The Good Wife (7.1 million). ABC was fourth.

title: The Koons Collection
description: JEFF KOONS, at 55, is one of the worlds most famous living artists. And every night before drifting off to sleep in his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, he is able to survey the salmon-pink walls of his bedroom and commune with a small pantheon of the most famous artists of centuries past.

title: A Devil Who Takes the Side of Angels
description: One morning Ignatius Perrish, the bedeviled hero of Joe Hills Horns, wakes up to find that he has been transformed overnight. Suddenly there are knobby little horns growing out of his head. When he talks to people they dont recoil at them, but they do feel impelled to fall into trances and voice their most unspeakable thoughts.

title: London Fashion Week | Its a Wrap!
description: A lot can happen in London on a tight schedule. But do not try forge a coherent story line when you are running jet-lagged from a fashion show in a deluxe tent streamed worldwide live and in 3-D (Burberry) to an improvised catwalk in a parking garage (Peter Pilotto) to a Serpentine Gallery art and fashion mlange (Pringle) to a leather and flower feast in a cement bunker basement (Christopher Kane) to an East London home studio visit (Meadham Kirchhoff) to a star-studded Russian Loveball caviar and vodka dinner.

title: Remembering Mosi Tatupu, Patriots Fan Favorite
description: 11:49 p.m. | Updated Andy Barall, who writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down, sends in an appreciation of Mosi Tatupu, who died Tuesday at age 54:

title: Sandras Sources | Destination Shopping
description: Trust the folks from Project No. 8, one of the citys more thoughtfully hip boutiques, to curate an out-of-the ordinary hotel shopping experience for travelers. Elizabeth Beer and Brian Janusiak conceived No. 8a  in Manhattans hopping Ace Hotel  as a place to find useful objects and unusual souvenirs. Forget bad books, phone chargers and tacky swimsuits. Instead, youll find underpinnings from Falke, Schiesser and VPL, the cult skin-care line In Fiore, accessories from the likes of Maison Martin Margiela, Christian Wijnants, Bless and Natalia Brilli, and a continuing project called Mementos, an amusing collection of New York ephemera (think Chinatown Soccer Club mugs, Statue of Liberty night lights and Krink graffiti markers) gathered by the designers Josee Lepage and Tobias Wong. Theres also a mini-outpost of Kiosk, a downtown shop that regularly mounts themed exhibitions of objects.

title: Old Hand Tries New Approach to Jazz Festival
description: The concert promoter George Wein, now 84, has been getting out to clubs lately.

title: Where Wit and Genre Filmmaking Collide
description: Four features and a handful of shorts: that hardly qualifies as a mini-festival, let alone a luxuriously titled retrospective of a major international filmmaker. Yet thats what Monsters and Murderers: The Films of Bong Joon-ho is. Beginning Thursday night at the BAMcinmatek in Brooklyn, this five-day series will present the entire output of Mr. Bong, a Korean writer-director who is one of the most seriously entertaining film artists around.

title: At Voos, a Talent Show
description: Photos of a Friday night gathering celebrating young designers, held at the Brooklyn furniture store Voos.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: The Future of Cellphones
description: In this weeks episode of Tech Talk, Bettina Edelstein talks to Ashlee Vance, the New York Times technology reporter who just returned from the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain, the worlds biggest trade show for cellphones and other mobile devices. The discussion on the podcast includes Microsofts new Windows Phone 7 operating system for cellphones and Intels and Nokias joining forces on a new open-source OS called Meego.

title: Turning Tapes Into Discs
description: Turning Tapes

title: In Rivalry, One-Sided Hockey Win for Canada Over Russia
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  We want gold! We want gold! the Canada Palace crowd chanted, roaring like a jet engine as the seconds counted down in Canadas astonishingly easy 7-3 quarterfinal victory over Russia on Wednesday.

title: Locked or Unlocked? Today, That Is the Money Question
description: Offered two identical phones, one for $400 and the other for $150, which would cost you less?

title: Getting Rid of Bad Teachers
description: Updated, March 3, 6:00 p.m. | Steve Perry, principal of Capital Preparatory Magnet School in Hartford, joins the discussion.

title: Playmakers Paradise
description: A look at the basketball Hall of Fame player Walt Fraziers home on the island of St. Croix.

title: Bloggingheads:  Health Care Bungle?
description: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether President Obama botched his case for health care reform.

title: London Fashion Week | Burberrys Christopher Bailey
description: For the second season running, Burberry showed its Prorsum collection at the end of London fashion week. Its quite fun, all things considered  all the big editors come out, Rachel Zoe turns up, and a bit of quality and excitement gets injected into proceedings. And people harass Christopher Bailey, too. Seriously, the whole of London has a whale of a time with it. Its probably not so much fun for him, but hed never let on.

title: Descartes Letter Found, Therefore It Is
description: It was the Great Train Robbery of French intellectual life: thousands of treasured documents that vanished from the Institut de France in the mid-1800s, stolen by an Italian mathematician. Among them were 72 letters by Ren Descartes, the founding genius of modern philosophy and analytic geometry.

title: Bilton on ABC: Facebook, Farmville and Foursquare
description: The Bits blogger Nick Bilton sat down with the anchor of ABC World News, Diane Sawyer, to discuss the online virtual game Farmville, the unending growth of Facebook and the use of Foursquare as a game and information-sharing tool.

title: Scorecard | Matthew Williamson Wins!
description: Twitter-ific tees, slutty Second Life avatar models and Where the Wild Things Are horned headgear, oh my! Toto, we arent in New York anymore. Well, not quite. As Scorecard can tell you, critics at London fashion weeks opening weekend grappled with what to make of the bright young things designer Matthew Williamsons new darkly Almodvarian vision. That is, until they saw the stripped-down sculptural silhouettes emerging from the Central Saint Martins class of 2010 graduation presentation Sunday night  and all became light.

title: The Films of Bong Joon-ho
description: A look at the films appearing in the retrospective of Bong Joon-ho at BAM.

title: Madoff Investors Sue SIPC Chief Over Claims
description: Three investors in Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme filed a lawsuit on Wednesday accusing the president and directors of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation of fraud for failing to reimburse them for their losses, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Larger Threat Is Seen in Google Case
description: ROME  Three Google executives were convicted of violating Italian privacy laws on Wednesday, the first case to hold the companys executives criminally responsible for the content posted on its system.

title: As Senate Majority Shifts, So Does View of a Procedural Power Play
description: WASHINGTON  It is tempting to think that the authors of the 1974 federal budget law were feeling mischievously ironic when they chose reconciliation as the name for a particularly arcane process the bill established.

title: Court Says Miranda Rights Dont Bar Requestioning
description: WASHINGTON  The police can take a second run at questioning a suspect who has invoked his Miranda rights, but they must wait until 14 days after the suspect has been released from custody, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

title: Analysis: Canada Defeats Russia, 7-3
description: Analysis of Wednesdays Canada-Russia mens hockey quarterfinal. The Timess Jeffrey Marcus was at the arena providing updates and analysis of Canadas 7-3 victory over Russia in a quarterfinal matchup.

title: At Saks and TJX, Luxuries and Discounts Rebound
description: Consumers were more willing in recent months to treat themselves to things they did not need, like baubles and little black dresses. But only if those indulgences could be had for recession-friendly prices.

title: Video Mad Libs With the Right Software
description: It is April 1945. In his underground bunker, Hitler huddles over a map with his top generals. The room is insufferably tense. Members of the German high command, sweating in their uniforms, wonder who will dare to break the terrible news to Der Fhrer.

title: Disqualified Dutch Speedskater Kramer Grabs the Headlines at Home
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The collapse of the Dutch coalition government over the question of extending the Netherlands military presence in Afghanistan was knocked off the front pages Wednesday by another catastrophe: the Dutch speedskating star Sven Kramers Olympic disqualification in his signature event, the 10,000 meters.

title: At the Algarve Cup, Its All About the Jersey
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

title: A $1 Billion Hangover From an Olympic Party
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Josie Lombardi came downtown this week for a taste of the Olympics accompanied by a friend rather than her husband, because he is on an Olympics boycott.

title: A Lot to Lose for Jeter if He Leaves the Yanks
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Bradley Logs Miles Before World Cup
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Niger: Junta Pledges to Restore Democracy
Whos That Grl? Svedka Vodka Brings a Mascot to TV
description: THERE are all sorts of strange characters pitching products on television, among them a jovial giant, as green as the vegetables he peddles; a bald man in a white T-shirt, obsessed with cleanliness; and an insurance-loving lizard with a Cockney accent. Now their ranks are being joined by a sensual female robot from the future who adores vodka.

title: A Las Vegas Mansion, Glue-Gunned to Perfection
description: LAS VEGAS

title: The Transition Game
description: Christiansted, V.I.

title: Old Suit, New Seats
description: WHEN February gets to be too much and you need a little fun, you could do worse than hop over to Voos, a furniture store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The designers there think so far outside the box that very little is squared, so good luck finding a familiar-looking place to sit down. But the gallery is guaranteed to make you smile.

title: A Little Cutie to Rub Your Feet and Serve a Martini
description: Massage chairs, with their bulk and hulk, tend to be the elephants in the room  if you can imagine a selfless elephant that didnt need to be fed, enjoyed living in a one-bedroom apartment and kept animal rights activists off your back while massaging it. The Inada Cube ($800), which is made by the Family Inada massage chair company of Japan and was presented at the recent Las Vegas Market furniture show, is a different beast entirely: a massaging chair that, when not in use, folds into an 18-by-19-by-21-inch cube. Cliff Levin, the 44-year-old president of Inada USA, spoke to us from his home in Boulder, Colo., about the Cube.

title: Furniture and Flooring for Less
description: HBF, a contract furnishings company, is having a sale on office furniture through March 1, with some conference tables and chairs discounted by as much as 90 percent (the Linea casegoods office, originally $12,960, is $1,500); 200 Lexington Avenue (32nd Street), (212) 686-3142 or hbf.com.

title: A Sticky Little Lizard Inspires a New Adhesive Tape
description: KEEP your eye on the shelves of your local hardware store, where in the next few years you may be able to find new tape from an unlikely source: the gecko.

title: Pushing Korean Design Into the Future
description: Contemporary Korean Design, a show of more than 30 pieces of tableware and home furnishings by five Korean designers and ceramicists, opens March 1 at the R 20th Century gallery in TriBeCa.

title: In Brooklyn, Only the Best Parts of Life in the 1940s
description: THE Park Slope brownstone, with its carved decorative panels and inviting stoop, may be many peoples idea of New York charm, but it is not Hilary Boteins. It was a beautiful apartment, but so oppressive and dark, she said of the one-bedroom on Second Street in Brooklyn that she owned for seven years. I could never go back to it.

title: May You Bloom and Glow
description: It couldnt have come at a better time: The Infiore pendant lamp, recently introduced by Estiluz, a Spanish company, is an ebullient reminder of springs impending arrival. Created by Lagranja, a design collective in Barcelona, the hanging lamp is 10 1/4 inches high and 21 5/8 inches in diameter, with large polycarbonate petals. The inside of each petal is white, to reflect the light; the outside is green (below), gray or white. The fixture comes wired either for a halogen bulb ($976) or a compact fluorescent one ($1,116), and is available in table- and floor-lamp models. For information: (201) 641-1997 or estiluz.com.

title: Newcomers Flock to Curling Clubs
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

title: A Flower Designer Who Uses the Vase as Her Canvas
description: Bella Meyers foray into floral design began a decade ago, when she made a wedding canopy for a friend. Since then, she has dabbled with the subject, but earlier this year she made it official and opened Fleurs Bella, a store in the East Village. The colors and textures of flowers were more exciting than anything else, she said.

title: Cozy Kitchens
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Will Climb Ladder, but How High?
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In the first year of the new Yankee Stadium, its tenants won the World Series. In its second, Alex Rodriguez could hit his 600th home run. In its third, Derek Jeter should notch his 3,000th hit. More milestones will follow, and Rodriguez and Jeter will almost certainly be chasing them together.

title: The Missionary Impulse
description: From out of the ordered suburbs of Idaho to the grim chaos of Haiti came 40-year-old Laura Silsby  fleeing creditors who had foreclosed on her home and ex-employees stiffed of their wages.

title: Built With Ideals
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke in Talks to Buy U.S. Unit of Its Biggest Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Company is in talks to buy the North American operations of its largest bottler, according to a person briefed on the matter, reversing a 24-year-old strategy of separating its bottling operations from its main soft drink business.

title: Conan OBrien Joins Twitter With a Humorous Plea: Somebody Help Me
description: Conan OBrien, the unemployed former host of The Tonight Show, has ventured into the twittersphere.

title: Campaign Goes After Opponents of Gay Marriage
description: ALBANY  Angered by the defeat last year of a bill that would have allowed same-sex couples to marry, a group of well-financed gay rights advocates has started a political action committee to take aim at state senators who have opposed same-sex marriage.

title: Bribes Let Tomato Vendor Sell Tainted Food
description: Robert Watson, a top ingredient buyer for Kraft Foods, needed $20,000 to pay his taxes. So he called a broker for a California tomato processor that for years had been paying him bribes to get its products into Krafts plants.

title:
Question of Influence
in Abuse Case of Paterson Aide
description: This article is by William K. Rashbaum, Danny Hakim, David Kocieniewski and Serge F. Kovaleski.

title: Hedge Fund Moves on Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village
description: A hedge fund that has acquired a significant portion of the debt on the troubled Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes in Manhattan moved in court this week to take control of them.

title: Love and Baseball
description: Its here again. Position players report to spring training this week (pitchers and catchers started workouts last week, in keeping with tradition), and as always there is a high level of excitement and anticipation among the players. Maybe this is the year they can bring home a World Series title  or make the team for the first time.

title: Denver Woman Sentenced in Hepatitis Infection Case
description: DENVER  A former hospital technician and admitted heroin addict was sentenced Wednesday to 30 years in prison for swapping drug-filled syringes intended for patients with used syringes whose needles were contaminated with the deadly hepatitis C virus.

title: City and Teachers Union Near Contract Mediation
description: The Bloomberg administration is seeking significant changes in the citys next contract with teachers, including a 50 percent cut in sick days, the ability to tie teacher pay more closely to performance and the power to lay off teachers whose classroom jobs have been eliminated.

title: Amazing Grace
description: There are apparently 90 minutes of unseen footage on the just-released DVD of "The September Issue." A few extra clips from the documentary by R. J. Cutler about Vogue's biggest issue have been posted on New York Magazine's Web site, including additional appearances by the movie's breakout star, Grace Coddington, and they leave us wanting more. Tonight, thankfully, Ms. Coddington, the magazine's creative director, will oblige. She and another fashion favorite, Vogue editor-at-large Andre Leon Talley, will be at Barnes & Noble to discuss the film. Go in your best fashion-week-inspired outfit and ask about "Catwalk Cats," the rumored animated feature in the works about Ms. Coddington's famous feline family.

title: Socratic Method
description: " 'Socrates,' Alastair Macaulay writes, "though not simple, is simply beautiful: the most sensuously attractive new choreography that I have seen by Mark Morris in more than 10 years." The new work is one of three pieces being performed by the Mark Morris Dance Group at BAM through Saturday. The other two are "Behemoth" and "Looky," which is having its New York premiere, but the new piece is generating the most excitement. "The work is set to Erik Satie's cantata 'Socrate.' Its movement idiom is one of deliberate neo-Classicism  in the first of the three sections, the dancers keep crossing the stage right to left, largely in flattened profile, like a Grecian bas-relief passing before our eyes  that seems to melt in later sections into its own, less obviously antique but more three-dimensional Classicism." Prior to the performance, Mr. Morris will be in conversation with the celebrity chef Mario Batali, a fellow foodie and Washington State native. Judging from a recent interview, it should be a lively discussion.

title: Down to the River
description: Barb Jungr, Stephen Holden writes, is a revelatory British interpreter and jolly iconoclast, who dramatically reinvents every song she touches. Tonight, Ms. Jungr inaugurates a new late-night series at the Cafe Carlyle with performances through March 6. Songwriters featured in her new show, "River," include Bruce Springsteen, Hank Williams, Bob Dylan, Kern and Hammerstein, Leonard Cohen and many others. Simon Wallace accompanies on piano. The show begins at 10:45 p.m.

title: At Closing Plant, Ordeal Included Heart Attacks
description: The first to have a heart attack was George Kull Jr., 56, a millwright who worked for three decades at the steel mills in Lackawanna, N.Y. Three weeks after learning that his plant was closing, he suddenly collapsed at home.

title: Dutch Pilot Withdraws Over Safety Concerns
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The Netherlands four-man bobsled team has a motto: Drive fast, take chances. The Whistler Sliding Centre provided an abundance of opportunity to do both. Too much, in fact, for the Dutch pilot Edwin van Calker.

title: Banks Bet Greece Defaults on Debt They Helped Hide
description: Bets by some of the same banks that helped Greece shroud its mounting debts may actually now be pushing the nation closer to the brink of financial ruin.

title: Acquitted in a Police Abuse Trial, but Still Under a Legal Cloud
description: After he was acquitted on Monday of sexually abusing a suspect in a subway station, Officer Richard Kern said he had simple goals: a good nights sleep and a quick return to patrolling Brooklyn.

title: Job Loss Can Lead to Health Problems
description: Michael Luo of The New York Times discusses the long-term health effects of stress upon people who get laid off.

title: In an Iraqi City, the Real Ballot Contest Is for Shiite Leadership
description: NASIRIYA, Iraq  This city along the Euphrates River, whose shabby appearance belies residents pride in it, has become the forefront of what may be the pivotal struggle in Iraqs election for Parliament: which of the countrys myriad Shiite parties will claim leadership of its empowered majority.

title: American Women Know Canadas Biggest Advantage
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The United States hockey player Julie Chu stood in the bowels of the arena on Wednesday afternoon, discussing the next days gold-medal game with Canada.

title: Missing Element in Obamas Ties With G.O.P. Leaders: Good Chemistry
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Representative John A. Boehner, the House Republican leader, share a love of golf. But the prospect of the two men hitting the links together would seem as likely as, say, the president and Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, exchanging a hearty bro hug before Thursdays meeting on health care.

title: Coke Acquires North American Unit of Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Company confirmed Thursday morning that it had agreed to acquire the North American operations of its largest bottler, reversing a 24-year-old strategy of keeping its bottling operations separate from its main soft-drink business.

title: Reform Plan Rocks Troubled School
description: Teachers at a high school in Rhode Island say that if they lose their jobs, the town loses its glue.

title: Mall Operator Plans to Split Company to Exit Bankruptcy
description: The mall operator General Growth Properties said on Wednesday that it would split into two companies as part of a plan to lift itself out of one of the largest real estate bankruptcy cases in corporate history. Under the plan, Brookfield Asset Management, a large real estate investment firm, would invest $2.63 billion.

title: The McGrady Effect: More $ Than Ws
description: A week after trading for Tracy McGrady, the Knicks are still waiting for a transformation. Or, at a minimum, a victory.

title: A Long Season of Disappointment in the Pac-10
description: LOS ANGELES  In the waning minutes of a crosstown rivalry last week, U.C.L.A. guard Michael Roll  one of the Pacific-10 Conferences leading 3-point shooters  was left unattended by Southern California defenders after inbounding the ball. Roll received a quick return pass from an alert teammate and attempted a 3-pointer. It missed, but two Trojan big men who were all alone under the basket  Alex Stepheson and Leonard Washington  bumped into each other and knocked the ball out of bounds.

title: Carlyle Group Forms Partnership With Chinese Conglomerate
description: SHANGHAI  The Carlyle Group, one of the worlds biggest private equity firms, said Wednesday that it had formed a partnership with one of the largest Chinese conglomerates to invest in China and around the world.

title: U.S. Men Advance in Hockey with Patience, Persistence and Some Luck
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After its upset victory over Canada on Sunday, the United States mens hockey team was supposed to have landed itself on the easy side of the bracket leading to the gold medal.
