While the two favorites, Russia and Canada, faced each other Wednesday in a game of epochal significance for both countries, the Americans had to deal with the ostensibly easier Swiss.

title: Once Mighty Party Falls, and Worries Grip Japan
description: TOKYO  What does a political party built on power and patronage, with few philosophical or ideological underpinnings, do when it is defeated and driven into the opposition? In the case of Japans once formidable Liberal Democratic Party, it implodes like an old Las Vegas hotel being demolished.

title: A Jumble of Strong Feelings After Vote on a Troubled School
description: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.  Like many other teenagers in this troubled city, Sheila Gomes said she found a surrogate family outside her home at Central Falls High School.

title: 11 Down: Happy Hour Order
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Rebus themes, where more than one letter goes in a square, come three ways: 1. rebus squares are symmetrically placed; 2. entries containing rebus squares are symmetrically placed; or 3. entries containing rebus squares are placed in symmetrical areas of the grid.

title: Medal Ambiences Are Miles Apart
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After receiving his bronze medal Monday for cross-country skiing, Nikolay Morilov was leaving the Whistler Olympic Medals Plaza with five other Russian athletes. All around them, people were pulsing to the live music of Devo, the old New Wave band.

title: Hockey Familys Fulfillment Wasnt Without Its Stresses
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In most households, family bulletin boards are repositories of items like school-lunch menus, report cards, doctors notes and class photos. But when Kacey Bellamy was growing up, her parents also made a point of posting their monthly bank statements.

title: Citi Field Could Become Venezuela North
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  In a far corner of the Mets spring training clubhouse, a group of players laughed and talked Spanish, and words like chamo and pana floated beyond the grasp of some of the other Spanish-speaking players nearby.

title: Hyundai to Recall Some 2011 Sonatas
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The Hyundai Motor Company said on Wednesday that it would recall 46,000 new Sonata sedans in South Korea and 1,300 in the United States, becoming the latest global carmaker to issue recalls.

title: At Moment of High Drama, NBC Makes Mistake
description: NBC had the most heart-rending of stories to tell when the Canadian skater Joannie Rochette competed in the short program Tuesday night, only days after her mother, Therese, died from a heart attack after arriving in Vancouver.

title: ESPN Sets Sights on Different Way to Show Olympics
description: With 25.2 million viewers watching the Winter Olympics in prime time, NBC Universal feels vindicated by a strategy that features tape delay of some events and shows nothing live in the Mountain and Pacific time zones.

title: Preparing for Health Debate, and Its TV Audience
description: WASHINGTON  In convening Thursdays bipartisan health session, President Obama is angling to recreate the kind of spontaneous, unscripted debate that gave him a decided advantage when he took questions on live television at a House Republican retreat in Baltimore last month.

title: Catching Kim Wont Be Easy
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  South Koreas Kim Yu-na, the woman to beat in the free skate Thursday, has been in this position.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 15 about connections between State Senator Malcolm A. Smiths staff and officials of a nonprofit group in Queens that is under federal investigation misidentified, in some editions, Gov. David A. Patersons leadership position when he was a state senator and employed Joan Flowers, now counsel to Mr. Smith. Mr. Paterson was minority leader at the time, not majority leader.

title: Some Teams Live and Die by the 3 More Than Others
description: Zach Lowe writes for CelticsHub.com.

title: As U.S. Aid Grows, Oversight Is Urged for Charter Schools
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to significantly expand the flow of federal aid to charter schools, money that has driven a 15-year expansion of their numbers, from just a few dozen in the early 1990s to some 5,000 today.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day, Feb. 24
description: A look at the day in Olympic sports including poor conditions on the ski slopes and plenty of action on the ice.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column in some editions on Tuesday about the Washington Wizards victory over the Chicago Bulls on Monday referred incorrectly to Andray Blatches history with the Wizards. He joined the team in 2005; he did not come to Washington as part of a recent deal in which his teammates Antawn Jamison and Caron Butler were traded away.

title: Death Penalty Is Thrown Out in Texas Murders
description: A Texas court threw out the death sentence on Wednesday of a man whose double murder conviction gained international attention because of revelations that the judge and prosecutor had had an extramarital affair.

title: Sweden Cruises Despite Northugs Big Finish
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Petter Northug, a cross-country skier from Norway, is known for his high-speed finishes. On Wednesday, during the mens 4-by-10 kilometer relay race, Northugs speed was good enough for only second place.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the college basketball coach Herb Magee described incorrectly a career record he pursued recently. Magee, the coach at Philadelphia University for 43 years, was on track to break a tie with Bob Knight for most N.C.A.A. mens basketball victories, not for most wins in mens basketball at four-year colleges. (Magee got his 903rd career victory on Tuesday night, and now has the most N.C.A.A. wins among mens coaches.)

title: Radiation Errors Reported in Missouri
description: A hospital in Missouri said Wednesday that it had overradiated 76 patients, the vast majority with brain cancer, during a five-year period because powerful new radiation equipment had been set up incorrectly even with a representative of the manufacturer watching as it was done.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the $1 million sale of a copy of the comic book in which Superman first appeared referred incorrectly to the transaction. The comic was offered for sale on a Web site for a fixed price of $1 million; it was not auctioned.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about the Eric Clapton-Jeff Beck concert at Madison Square Garden misstated the size of the orchestra that played with Mr. Becks group. It had 22 members, not 12.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Newly Released books column last Thursday about the novel Model Home, by Eric Puchner, in which a character listens to the music of the band Hsker D, misidentified the state where the band was formed. It is Minnesota, not California.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Carl Kaysen, who helped negotiate the 1963 nuclear test band treaty, misstated the year he began teaching at Harvard. It was 1950, not 1947. (He was a junior fellow in Harvards Society of Fellows from 1947 to 1950.)

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: The Torture Lawyers
description: Is this really the state of ethics in the American legal profession? Government lawyers who abused their offices to give the president license to get away with torture did nothing that merits a review by the bar?

title: Correction
description: The Critical Shopper column on Jan. 14, about Lily et Cie, a vintage fashion store in Los Angeles, misstated the age of an Herms coat. It dates from the 2007-8 season, not from the 1970s. This error was pointed out by Rita Watnick, the stores owner, in an e-mail message received Feb. 16.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,369 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 992 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: Loan-Sharking Inc.
description: The Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act, signed into law last spring, was supposed to put an end to many of the deceptive practices that allowed credit card issuers to bleed customers dry. The most important provisions went into effect earlier this week, but credit card companies have already found ways to evade the law. Congress and federal regulators need to do a lot more.

title: More Calls for Review of Gay Policy
description: The top officers for the Navy and the Marine Corps added their voices Wednesday to those of the Army and Air Force chiefs in calling for careful review before repealing the ban on openly gay service members. Adm. Gary Roughead, the chief of naval operations, and Gen. James T. Conway, commandant of the Marine Corps, told Congress that they supported a plan by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates to take up to a year to study the issue. General Conway expressed his worries that a swift repeal could hurt the militarys ability to carry out its national security mission.

title: Dutch Retreat
description: After the collapse of its coalition cabinet, the Netherlands is set to withdraw its 2,000 troops from Afghanistan by the end of this year. That decision is an embarrassment to the Netherlands, to NATO, and to Washington at a moment when President Obamas counterinsurgency strategy faces a crucial test.

title: Sago, Four Years Later
description: It took the 2006 Sago mine catastrophe, and the loss of 12 lives, before Congress deigned to reform inspection procedures that for decades put coal company profits ahead of workers safety. Since then, deaths in mining accidents  34 last year  have dropped to their lowest in a century under a tighter regimen that has increased citations for violators by a third and fines eightfold.

title: Science, Ethics and Factory Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Terrorists Be Tried in Civilian Courts?
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Companies Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Eco-Friendly in California?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Self-Involved Society and the Wish for Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Toxins Cause Autism?
description: Autism was first identified in 1943 in an obscure medical journal. Since then it has become a frighteningly common affliction, with the Centers for Disease Control reporting recently that autism disorders now affect almost 1 percent of children.

title: Like Rome Before the Fall? Not Yet
description: Cambridge, England

title: Short-Track Speedskating After Ohno
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On Wednesday evening at Pacific Coliseum, two young American short-track speedskaters gave hope to those concerned with the programs post-Apolo Ohno future.

title: New Job for Ex-White House Adviser
description: Van Jones, the advocate for environmental jobs who resigned from a White House post in September over several controversial past statements, has found a job with the Center for American Progress in Washington. Mr. Jones served in the Obama administration after years as a community organizer and green jobs activist in the San Francisco Bay Area. He will lead the centers Green Opportunity Initiative, which will help promote investment and employment in clean energy and environmental restoration projects, officials at the center said. On Friday, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will honor Mr. Jones with its Presidents Award at its annual Image Awards ceremony, the group said.

title: New Charges Are Expected for Others in Terror Plot
description: In his guilty plea to conspiracy charges, Najibullah Zazi often referred to other unnamed people in their plan to set off explosives on the New York subway system. Yet thus far, federal authorities have revealed virtually nothing about who, exactly, Mr. Zazi was conspiring with.

title: Todays Reversal vs. Dot-Com Bust
description: The recent financial crisis was the worst in a generation  unless you were an American investment banker. Wall Street certainly took its lumps: some banks failed and the survivors slashed thousands of jobs. Even with the collapses of Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers, though, the finance industry laid off fewer people than it did after the dot-com crash.

title: For Donors to Governors Associations, Cash Buys a Seat at the Table
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic governors came here last weekend to meet with the president about health care. First, though, they had a date with their corporate sponsor: the drug maker Pfizer.

title: Bronx Courts Thrown Into Chaos by Ruling on Merger
description: Nearly every level of the Bronx criminal justice system was racing on Wednesday to deal with the ramifications of an appellate court decision that declared the 2004 merger of the boroughs Criminal Court and Supreme Court unconstitutional.

title: Public Advocate Wants to Shine a Light on Earmark Funds
description: New Yorks public advocate, Bill de Blasio, determined to make the scandal-plagued process of doling out discretionary city funds more transparent, plans to create a searchable database that would disclose pertinent details about all applications for such funds.

title: Testing Company Officials Guilty on Top Count
description: The first batch of guilty verdicts came a week ago, but those counts were not the most serious. On Tuesday, Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, and its principals were again slapped with convictions, but the jury remained deadlocked on the most serious charge.

title: Lottery Numbers
Deal on Payment for Removal of Deutsche Bank Building
description: At least one of the many disputes over the demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero is coming to an end.

title: Despite Bad News, Subway Chief Hopes to Hold Line on Fare
description: For the struggling Metropolitan Transportation Authority, it remains the absolute last resort: raising fares and tolls more than planned to help offset a budget shortfall of nearly $800 million.

title: A Bit More on Autism
description: My Thursday column argues that as long as were looking at reforming the clinical health system, we should also examine public health interventions  including greater scrutiny of chemicals that may be having harmful effects on us. In particular, I look at autism (for more information about autism, check out the site of the Autism Society of America).

title: New Directors/New Films Series Sets Lineup
description: The premiere of a documentary about Bill Cunningham, a photographer for The New York Times, will open New Directors/New Films, the annual series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, the society and the museum announced. The documentary, called Bill Cunningham New York, follows Mr. Cunningham on his assignments for the Styles sections of The Times and chronicles his life and work over eight decades. It is directed by Richard Press and produced by Philip Gefter, a former staff member of The Times, and will be presented on March 24 at MoMA.

title: On Assignment: Syria Changes, to a Point
description: Ed Kashi is a photojournalist and filmmaker. He spoke with Lens last summer about Three, his book of triptychs. (Kashi, Kashi, Kashi, June 19, 2009.) His other books include Curse of the Black Gold: 50 Years of Oil in the Niger Delta and Aging in America: The Years Ahead. His work often appears in National Geographic. The interview, by James Estrin, has been condensed somewhat and edited for clarity.

title: Word of the Day | consign
description: consign\kn-sin\ verb

title: Selma G. Hirsh, Humanitarian, Dies at 92
description: Selma G. Hirsh, a humanitarian and an author who was associated with the American Jewish Committee for many years, died on Feb. 1 at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 92.

title: Transcript of Womans Testimony About David W. Johnson
description: An audio recording and transcript of the womans testimony in Family Court in the Bronx on Nov. 2, 2009, when she was granted an order of protection. The hearing was held two days after the woman said she was assaulted by David W. Johnson, a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: Finance Bill Compromise Appears Likely
description: WASHINGTON  As part of an effort to save a financial regulation bill, the Obama administration is prepared to agree that an existing agency, rather than a new agency, could take responsibility for consumer protections as long as the regulators have substantive powers.

title: Raymond Mason, Sculptor Who Focused on Street-Level Drama, Is Dead at 87
description: Raymond Mason, a British sculptor whose teeming street scenes and narrative tableaux evoked an animated world of ordinary people caught up in the drama of daily life, died on Feb. 14 at his home in Paris. He was 87.

title: China: I.M.F. Post for a Banker
description: The International Monetary Fund on Wednesday named Zhu Min, deputy governor of the Peoples Bank of China, special adviser to its managing director, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, effective May 3. China has gradually increased its influence at multilateral institutions, and the fund, traditionally led by a European but dominated by the United States, has tried to engage Asia more as it helps coordinate the global economic recovery.

title: Britain: Fallout From Bullying Claims
description: An anti-bullying hot line whose director claimed it had been contacted by distressed staff members at 10 Downing Street shut down and said it did not know if it would operate again. Four patrons of the charity, the National Bullying Hotline, resigned in anger after the director, Christine Pratt, went public with her claims. The charity said that competitor anti-bullying charities, individuals with an axe to grind and a few others have forced our hand.

title: News Quiz | February 25, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Australian Edges Chinese in Womens Aerials
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Jing Feng stood in the front row at Cypress Mountain, holding a giant red and yellow sign. She moved here from Beijing recently, and on Wednesday night at the womens aerials event, she banged the handmade collared drum the Chinese play for celebrations.

title: Player Unions Wary of H.G.H. Test
description: The disclosure that Major League Baseball will begin testing for human growth hormone in the minor leagues this year prompted the player unions for baseball and the N.F.L. to issue statements Wednesday that they remained skeptical about the efficacy of current testing but were open to the possibility of successful tests in the future.

title: Finance Bill Compromise Seems Likely
description: As part of an effort to save a financial regulation bill, the Obama administration is prepared to agree that an existing agency, rather than a new agency, could take responsibility for consumer protections as long as the regulators have substantive powers, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: Todays Reversal vs. Dot-Com Bust
description: The recent financial crisis was the worst in a generation  unless you were an American investment banker, Breakingviews says.

title: Domo Arigato, Mr. Roboto
description: WHO are inventing robots, like the one in this photo, who can prepare or serve food?

title: Hedge Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Securities Fraud
description: A hedge fund manager in Florida who bilked millions of dollars from investors, then briefly disappeared as investigators closed in, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to securities fraud, The Associated Press reported.

title: Grassley Asks Goldman to Explain Build America Fees
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa has asked Goldman Sachs to clarify how much it has collected in underwriting fees as states and cities issue so-called Build America Bonds to raise money for infrastructure projects and create jobs.

title: In First Step, India and Pakistan Resume Talks
description: NEW DELHI  India and Pakistan took a first step toward rebuilding confidence on Thursday after a wide-ranging meeting between high-level diplomats of both countries that included discussions on terrorism, the Mumbai attacks, the disputed border region of Kashmir and competing water claims.

title: PeerPong Swallows $2.8 Million
description: PeerPong, a social search start-up, has taken $2.8 million in a fresh round of funding, PaidContent reported.

title: Kodak Prices $500 Million Note Placement
description: Eastman Kodak said Wednesday it priced a private placement of $500 million worth of 9.75 percent senior secured notes due 2018 to qualified institutional buyers, The Associated Press reported.

title: On Visit to Rwanda, Sarkozy Admits Grave Errors in 1994 Genocide
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France admitted Thursday that his country had made grave errors of judgment in the 1994 Rwandan genocide but stopped short of offering a formal apology for his nations failure to prevent the mass killings.

title: Banks Bet Greece Defaults on Debt They Helped Hide
description: Bets by some of the same banks that helped Greece shroud its mounting debts may actually now be pushing the nation closer to the brink of financial ruin, Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash report in The New York Times.

title: Can You Sell Cookies at School?
description: The New York City school system has rules restricting the types of foods that can be sold in school fund-raisers. Does your school have rules governing food sales? What are they?

title: Thank You Cam
description: A backstage camera at the Academy Awards which will record the roll calls of Oscar-winner gratitude  thereby, it is hoped, making the acceptance speeches pithier.

title: Mashery Nabs $5.5 Million from Cisco
description: Mashery, a start-up that helps software companies manage their application programming interfaces, has landed $5.5 million in a round led by Cisco Systems, the worlds largest maker of computer networking equipment, TechCrunch reported.

title: Turkeys Leaders Seek to Defuse Crisis
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys prime minister, president and military chief gathered Thursday in an emergency meeting aimed at defusing a political crisis that is threatening the stability of the country.

title: Deal Reached on Deutsche Bank Building
description: From Charles V. Bagli at City Room:

title: Swiss to Put Revised UBS Tax Deal to Parliament
description: The Swiss government confirmed on Wednesday that it would place a settlement made between the giant bank UBS and the U.S. authorities in an investigation of tax evasion before the countrys Parliament in a bid to overcome objections raised by a Swiss court, The New York Timess Matthew Saltmarsh reported.

title: Anthera Pharmaceuticals Defers Its Debut
description: The lone initial public offering scheduled for this week, Anthera Pharmaceuticals, did not start trading Wednesday as expected by I.P.O. market trackers, The Associated Press reported.

title: Investors Cheer as Fed Eases Anxiety Over Rates
description: A pledge from the chairman of the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low helped galvanize the equity markets on Wednesday, soothing concerns that the economy would be deprived of a critical crutch as it struggled to recover, The New York Timess Javier C. Hernandez reported.

title: Pushing for H.G.H. Testing in the N.F.L.
description: You can throw human growth hormone testing into the heap of issues that N.F.L. owners and the players union are squabbling about in the latest collective bargaining negotiations. As has long been expected, testing for H.G.H. is becoming more sophisticated. The British rugby player Terry Newton recently became the first athlete to be suspended for a positive H.G.H. test.

title: Obama Defends His Policies to C.E.O.s
description: President Obama rejected assertions on Wednesday that his domestic program amounted to big-government socialism, The New York Timess Peter Baker reported.

title: Alongside Volvo Deal, Geely to Acquire Zhongyu Auto
description: The parent company of Geely Automobile Holdings said Thursday that it planned to buy the Chinese special vehicle maker Zhejiang Zhongyu Automobile as it moved to expand its product portfolio, Reuters reported.

title: Appaloosa Moves on Stuyvesant Town
description: From Charles V. Bagli at City Room:

title: State of the Chiefs: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: A Popular Tourist Spot in Prague to Close
description: The ancient Prague Castle complex, the Czech Republics most visited tourist attraction, will close one of its top draws for a yearlong renovation. The Golden Lane, a narrow alley lined with candy-colored one-room houses from the 16th century, will be off limits to tourists starting May 1, according to Frantisek Kadlec, director of Prague Castles tourism department.

title: Hedge Funds Slam Short-Sale Rule
description: It seems that the Securities and Exchange Commission cant please anybody when it comes to their efforts to put limits on short-selling.

title: As India Sells Assets, Political Tensions Rise
description: In the last 10 months, India has raised $3.5 billion selling off pieces of state-run companies, more than such sales brought in during the previous four years.

title: S.&P. Raises Outlook on 3i Group
description: A credit ratings agency upgraded its outlook on 3i Group, saying the British private equity firm has significantly reduced its net debt levels, The Associated Press reported.

title: Mack Questions Politics of Reform
description: John J. Mack seems to find President Obamas financial reforms a little too political for his taste.

title: Lehman Settles Collateral Claims With JPMorgan
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings has agreed with JPMorgan Chase to settle about $7.68 billion in collateral obligations that were pending after Lehmans bankruptcy filing in 2008, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

title: A 19th-Century Idea for Health Reform
description: Todays idea: To get healthy young Americans into the insurance pool, pay such low-risk individuals bonuses if it turns out theyre correct in their belief that they wont get sick, say two academics.

title: American Idol': In First Look, the Men Underwhelm
description: There were no winners  no survivors, even  on American Idol on Wednesday, when this seasons top 12 men took to the stage for the first time. It was, politely, a blood bath, certainly the least promising group ever selected by the judges. It was bad enough to raise the question: Simon sabotage?

title: In Taibbis Latest, More Shots at Goldman
description: In a signature polemic, Matt Taibbi, columnist for Rolling Stone, takes on his favorite target, Goldman Sachs, accusing Wall Streets most profitable investment bank of setting the stage for the countrys next crisis hardly more than a year after it was on the brink of collapse.

title: Fidelity Fires 2 in Hong Kong for Ethics Breaches
description: Fidelity International said on Thursday it had fired two of its Hong Kong-based fund managers for what it said were ethical breaches, an embarrassment as the giant fund manager raises its exposure to fast growing Asia, The New York Timess Bettina Wassener reported.

title: K.K.R. Reports Profit for Quarter
description: K.K.R. & Company Guernsey, the listed unit of the private equity firm run by Henry Kravis and George Roberts, reported a fourth-quarter profit as it reaped gains from some investments and made new deals, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Please Rob Me: Site Chides Location Messages
description: As more people reveal their whereabouts on social networks, a new site has sprung up to remind you that letting everyone know where you are  and, by extension, where youre not  could leave you vulnerable to those with less-than-friendly intentions, The Associated Press writes. The sites name says it all: Please Rob Me.

title: Olympics Fever
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: When Is It Sex Addiction?
description: Recently, a panel of experts joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about sex addiction. Here, several experts address the question of differentiating between bad behavior and sex addiction.

title: Coke to Take Over North American Bottling Unit
description: The Coca-Cola Company confirmed Thursday morning that it had agreed to acquire the North American operations of its largest bottler, reversing a 24-year-old strategy of keeping its bottling operations separate from its main soft-drink business.

title: Speed Read for Thursday, Feb. 25
description: Here are some highlights from Thursdays edition of The New York Times:

title: Westfield to Join General Growth Bidding Fray?
description: And then there were three?

title: R.B.S. Lifts 2009 Bonuses Despite Yearly Loss
description: Royal Bank of Scotland, which is majority-owned by the government after a 2008 bailout, said Thursday it had set aside more money to pay bonuses to its investment banking staff after reducing its losses last year, The New York Timess Julia Werdigier reports.

title: Sampler: Judge Defends Beleaguered Colleague, and Museum Ants Escape
description: A Suit Against Oakland Goes Forward | A federal judge in San Francisco said in a ruling this week that a wrongful-death lawsuit against the city of Oakland could go forward. The suit arose from the death of Jerry Amaro, who was arrested in 2000 in East Oakland and died a month afterward after claiming he had been beaten by the police. Judge William Alsup of Federal District Court wrote that misleading statements and conduct by the police made soon after Mr. Amaros death discouraged his mother, Geraldine Montoya, from filing a wrongful death lawsuit. The family filed a lawsuit in 2009, but the city had argued that the statute of limitations had passed. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a separate inquiry into whether or not the police covered up the circumstances surrounding Mr. Amaros death. [The Oakland Tribune]

title: The Early Word: Health Care Meeting
description: President Obamas health care meeting begins at 10 a.m.

title: Time to Press China on Its Exchange Rate
description: Simon Johnson is a professor at M.I.T.s Sloan School of Management and a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.This morning the bipartisan United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission holds a hearing on U.S. Debt to China: Implications and Repercussions. Im on the first panel, which will discuss in part the perception that Chinas large dollar holdings confer upon that country some economic or political power vis--vis the United States. In particular, Ill talk about whether Chinese reserves prevent us from putting pressure on that countrys authorities to revalue (i.e., appreciate) the renminbi.

title: Barbershop Politics in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  We are brothers in this barbershop, Sadiq al-Jaff, a barber, said when I showed up for a haircut and, this being election season, a sampling of the voters mood.

title: Blackstone Earns $329 Million Profit
description: The Blackstone Group, the giant private equity firm, reported a $329 million fourth-quarter profit on Thursday as the credit and stock markets continued to rally, helping lift the leveraged buyout industry.

title: Greek Debt and a Weak Job Sector Weigh on Investors
description: A tense day for Wall Street ended with a tinge of hope, as a rise in commodity prices helped temper anxiety about Greek debt and the American jobs market.

title: Combat Ready
description: When two trends  lingerie and military  go to war, fashion deploys for action. Forward march!

title: Major Winter Storm Disrupts Flights in New York Area
description: According to Bloomberg News, The National Weather Service announced a winter storm warning for New York starting this morning, as the city braces for as much as a foot of snow, making travel very hazardous or impossible, the service said. The service expected 7 to 13 inches, or 18 to 33 centimeters, of snow.

title: New Full-Body Scanners for Two Airports
description: According to the Associated Press, the first of 150 full-body scanners planned for U.S. airports will be installed in Boston next week, officials said Tuesday. Three machines are to be installed at Logan International Airport, a Homeland Security official said. In the next two weeks, officials plan to install another machine at Chicagos OHare International.

title: Porsche to Unveil a Cayenne Hybrid S.U.V. at Geneva Auto Show
description: The definition of what a Porsche can be continues to be rewritten. The German sports car manufacturer shook up loyalists when it introduced an S.U.V., the Cayenne, in 2002; last year, it was a sedan, the Panamera. Next, the company will introduce a gas-electric hybrid, at the Geneva auto show on March 2.

title: A Call From the Governor, and a Call for an Inquiry
description: Last fall, a woman went to court in the Bronx to testify that she had been violently assaulted by a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson, and to seek a protective order against the man.

title: Durable Goods Orders Rise; Unemployment Claims Climb
description: A lackluster report on durable goods on Thursday resurrected doubts about the sustainability of a recovery for manufacturing. In addition, the number of people filing unemployment claims touched a three-month high, and a barometer of home prices unexpectedly fell.

title: Another Madoff Aide Faces Fraud Charges
description: A senior executive who worked for Bernard L. Madoff for more than 30 years was arrested Thursday on federal fraud and conspiracy charges, including claims that he had helped Mr. Madoff survive a cash crisis that almost derailed the gigantic Ponzi scheme five years ago.

title: The Christian Tories
description: For anyone interested in reading more about the state of British conservatism, I highly recommend this big Financial Times piece on the influence of evangelical Christians  and particularly Tim Montgomerie, the founder of the prominent ConservativeHome website  in David Camerons Tory Party. Its thick with heavy breathing about the perils of religious influence on politics, but mostly that comes from old-guard Conservative apparatchiks quoted sniping at Montgomerie, rather than from the authors own editorializing. Overall, the story strikes me as a fair-minded look at the attempt to forge a distinctively Christian approach to right-of-center politics  and to do so in a country where religious believers are a distinct minority, and evangelicals are particularly marginal. There are echoes of the religious right and Bush-esque compassionate conservatism in what Montgomerie and Co. are up to, but also striking differences as well. And as with Cameronism writ large, I think that there are ways in which American conservatives  and social conservatives, obviously, in particular  might profit from their example.

title: Framing the Debate
description: President Obama and Congressional Democrats square off against Congressional Republicans today at the highly anticipated health care forum at Blair House. And as the two sides prepare to make the case for and against comprehensive legislation to overhaul the system, no one is expecting a major breakthrough.

title: China Warns U.S. Against Selling F-16s to Taiwan
description: BEIJING  A top Chinese military official reaffirmed Chinas resolve to punish the United States over its decision to sell weapons to Taiwan and suggested on Thursday that there would be even greater consequences should Washington fulfill a longstanding request by Taiwan for advanced fighter jets.

title: Another Way to Watch
description: There will be a plethora of ways to follow the health care meeting today and talk back live  from cable television and C-Span to live blogs and social networking sites. But there is a new entry into the media cacophony that hopes to offer something a little different.

title: Obsessions | Tramp Stamps
description: Please, stop the tramp stamp.

title: Paterson Refuses to Discuss Role in Aides Abuse Case
description: Gov. David A. Paterson said on Thursday that he learned only in the past day about a womans allegations that she was violently beaten by one of his closest aides.

title: The Olympic Ties That Bind
description: Donna de Varona, who won two gold medals in swimming at the 1964 Olympics, is a writer, producer and an Emmy Award-winning broadcaster. She is currently a member of the International Olympic Committees Women and Sport Commission.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Former Madoff Aide
description: 1:25 p.m. | Updated A senior executive who worked for Bernard L. Madoff for more than 30 years was arrested Thursday on federal fraud and conspiracy charges, including claims that he helped Mr. Madoff survive a cash crisis that almost derailed the gigantic Ponzi scheme five years ago, The New York Timess Diana B. Henriques reports.

title: The Oscars, by the Numbers
description: Almost as much as athletes or American Idol fans, Oscar watchers are obsessed with stats  that 51 of the 82 best actress winners in Oscar history won for a film that was nominated for best picture, for example. This handy chart, even breaks down some more unexpected figures related to the Academys big night  like the cost to create a little gold man ($500), the amount the average person wins in an Oscar pool ($50), the average age of the winners of best actor (44) and actress (36) and the number of streakers to interrupt the ceremony (only one, sadly).

title: The Senate Offers Small Businesses a Little Relief
description: Small business has at least a little to gain from the stripped-down, $15 billion jobs bill that passed the Senate Wednesday.

title: Lessons of a Cleft Lip
description: Meera and Raul Oliva expect to bring their son, Elan, home from the hospital today. His operation  the third hes had in his six months of life  went well, and his parents are glad it is over. This leaves the boy one operation away from being cured of the cleft lip and palate that doctors found on his sonogram before he was born.

title: Bits Scan: Googles Accountability and Nintendos E-Reader
description: Thursday mornings roundup of technology news:

title: Kim Yu-na Looks Poised for Gold
description: Todd Eldredge is a three-time Olympian (1992, 98 and 2002) and former world champion who also won six national championships and was inducted into the U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame in 2008. Eldredge, 38, will be providing analysis for Rings throughout the Olympic figure skating competition in Vancouver.

title: Why Cant PCs Work More Like iPhones?
description: Back in the dark ages of personal computing, if you wanted to look through the programs on your machine and, say, open a Microsoft Word document from the floppy drive, you would need to type a list of arcane commands that went something like this:

title: Blogging the Health Care Summit
description: 6:28 p.m. |Wrap Up

title: Fewer Tourists Heading to Cuba
description: According to Reuters, The Cuban tourism season got off to a rough start in 2010, with arrivals down 4.9 percent in January from the same month of last year, according to a government report due to be released this week. Tourism and related businesses make up about 20 percent of Cubas foreign exchange income.

title: Firefighters Face Charges in Bar Brawl
description: Updated, 4:30 p.m. | Two firefighters were charged on Thursday in connection with a brawl at a Brooklyn bar in January that left three people severely injured, according to the authorities.

title: Thursday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Big Flakes, Small Storm?
description: This stuff was truly huge. Did it remind anyone else of Oobleck?

title: Depressions Upside
description: The Victorians had many names for depression, and Charles Darwin used them all. There were his fits brought on by excitements, flurries leading to an uncomfortable palpitation of the heart and air fatigues that triggered his head symptoms. In one particularly pitiful letter, written to a specialist in psychological medicine, he confessed to extreme spasmodic daily and nightly flatulence and hysterical crying whenever Emma, his devoted wife, left him alone.

title: Bernanke Defends Feds Ability to Supervise Banks
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, urged Congress on Thursday not to strip the central bank of its power to regulate banks, warning that to do so would be a grave mistake.

title: Race in the South in the Age of Obama
description: SEVERAL DAYS A WEEK, a tall, broad-shouldered African-American Methodist preacher named James Fields drives his black pickup truck toward the quiet Alabama city of Cullman. An hour into the red-dirt hills above Birmingham, Cullman is the seat of a farming county where the strongest legal drink you can buy at the pool hall is Pepsi; the kegs at the annual Oktoberfest hold only root beer. Welcome to Mayberry! strangers are greeted. And then, We all do have bathrooms and wear shoes! With its steeples, grain elevators, striped barber poles, fireflies and wisteria, Cullman has the faraway feel of a small Southern town untroubled by time. Sweet Cullman! Fields sometimes says when hes on his way in. Its home!

title: Sally Quinns Column Dropped in Print Editions of The Washington Post
description: Just three months after it started, Sally Quinns weekly column on entertaining and social mores has been dropped from The Washington Posts printed editions, after complaints about Ms. Quinns using it to air a dispute within her extended family.

title: He Came to Apologize
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Today, Congress held more hearings with the executives of Toyota. Akio Toyoda, the president of the company and great-grandson of the company founder, came in from Japan to testify. This is a big deal, because this guy is a notoriously private person. He rarely checks his Facebook account. Hes very private.

title: What Were Reading
Paterson, Still in Race, Will Mull His Future
description: Updated, 7:40 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson said late Thursday that he would continue with his election bid, despite calls for him to suspend or end his campaign in the wake of reports that he and the State Police intervened in a domestic-assault case against a senior aide. But he said he would seek the opinions of other elected officials before deciding his long-term future.

title: When He Shot That Lawyer
description: Monologue |  Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Its a great day for former Vice President Dick Cheney, who was released from the hospital today. Hes doing well. Doctors say hell be up and shooting lawyers in no time.

title: Class Dismissed
description: According to the unwritten constitution that governs ordinary American life and makes possible a shared pop culture that even new immigrants can jump right into after a few movies and a trip to the mall, the senior year of public high school is less a climactic academic experience than an occasion for oafish goofing off, chronic truancy, random bullying, sloppy dancing in rented formalwear and interludes of moody, wan philosophizing (often at sunrise while still half-drunk and staring off at a misty river or the high-school parking lot) about the looming bummer of adulthood. In films like Ferris Buellers Day Off, Dazed and Confused and High School Musical 3, senior year is a do-little sabbatical from what is presented as the long dull labor of acquiring knowledge, honing skills and internalizing social norms. Its a spree, senior year, that discharges built-up tensions. Its an adolescent Mardi Gras. And its not an indulgence but an entitlement. Remember that line in your yearbook? Seniors rule! And they rule not because theyve accomplished much, necessarily (aside from surviving to age 18 or so and not dropping out or running away from home), but because its tradition, and seniors crave tradition. They crave it because they know, deep down, theyre lost, and tradition helps them hide this fear. From juniors.

title: Discovering Teenagers' Risky 'Game' Too Late
description: The patient was already on the operating room table when the other transplant surgeons and I arrived to begin the surgery that would remove his liver, kidneys, pancreas, lungs and heart. He was tall, with legs that extended to the very end of the table, a chest barely wider than his 16-year-old hips, and a chin covered with pimples and peach fuzz.

title: Many Doctors Unaware of the Choking Game
description: A few years ago the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sounded the alarm about the choking game, a bizarre adolescent ritual which involves intentionally trying to choke oneself to create a brief high. Deaths from the game, it appears, are on the rise.

title: Math Is Hard
description: What was it like to spend nine years trying to persuade the Securities and Exchange Commission that Bernard Madoff was a fraud, only to learn that the agency thought he was perfectly reputable?  For nine years I was the S.E.C.s doormat.

title: New Indictments in Subway Bomb Plot
description: Two men already in custody were indicted on Thursday on charges of participating in an Al Qaeda plot to detonate explosives on the New York subway system.

title: Womens Free Skate Q.& A. With Juliet Macur and Jer Longman
description: Urs Kluyver for The New York Times Times Olympics reporter Jer Longman.

title: Thom Yorke Names His New Band
description: Last fall, when Thom Yorke of Radiohead introduced his new band  featuring Flea of Red Hot Chili Peppers and the longtime Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich  it had no name. For the groups official debut in Los Angeles, the marquee outside the Orpheum Theater simply had six question marks.

title: President Urges Focus on Common Ground
description: WASHINGTON  If there was any question about how deeply divided Republicans and Democrats are about how to reshape the American health care system, consider that they spent the first few hours of President Obamas much-anticipated health care forum on Thursday arguing over whether they were in fact deeply divided.

title: In Greeces Crisis, Fed Studies Wall St.s Activities
description: Greeces problems deepened on both sides of the Atlantic as the Federal Reserve disclosed it was investigating Goldman Sachs and other banks that helped the country mask its debts, and investors grew increasingly leery of lending any more money to a nation flirting with default.

title: Webinar
description: Webinar (Web + seminar) seems like a fine neologism for a seminar offered online. A blend of two common terms, its immediately understood by most people. Ive been taking Webinars lately; I like them and appreciate having a handy word for them  even though Im often inclined to object to linguistic innovations.

title: Yes to Pop-Tarts! Panel Approves Bake-Sale Rules
description: By the time the Panel for Educational Policy was ready to vote over bake sales during the monthly meeting on Wednesday night, it was after 11:30. By then, there was just was one mother, Elizabeth Puccini, waiting to speak out against the new policy, which bans most bake sales but allows students to sell premade items including Pop-Tarts and Doritos.

title: Switzerland to Change Course on Tax Evasion
description: Switzerlands finance minister, Hans-Rudolf Merz, said on Thursday that the countrys federal council, the Bundesrat, had decided to adopt a basic change in its relation to international banking, although it rejected the automatic exchange of information that other states had sought.

title: Rules to Write By
description: The Guardian of London published a two-part series last week on Ten Rules for Writing Fiction solicited from writers including Elmore Leonard, Margaret Atwood, Jonathan Franzen, Neil Gaiman, Roddy Doyle and Richard Ford.

title: Parsley as Puree
description: My wife, Jackie, and I tend to keep our refrigerator a bit colder than the manufacturer recommends  better safe than sorry  and we got back from a recent trip to find a semi-frozen bunch of parsley in the vegetable bin. Normally, I would have just thrown it away, but I tasted a leaf and found it pretty flavorful. But frosty: rinsed, dried and chopped, it would probably have had an unpleasant consistency. So, looking ahead to the evenings spaghetti-with-leeks dinner, I tossed the whole bunch into a pot of boiling salted water, just for 30 seconds, then drained it and pureed it in a blender, along with a couple of tablespoons of the cooking water  just enough to give the blender a chance to do its work.

title: Inside the Rings
description: Kim Yu-na and Mao Asada are favorites to stand atop the podium, but there's great drama in the competition to see who else will medal.

title: Fed Reviewing Goldmans Moves on Greek Debt
description: The Federal Reserve is examining the financial stratagems devised by Goldman Sachs and other big banks to help Greece mask its ballooning debt over the last decade, The New York Timess Nelson D. Schwartz reports.

title: Oranjes Opportunistic Wing
description: Eljero Elia is a tricky wing player who can take advantage of the slightest leeway from a defender and turn it into a goal-scoring opportunity  making something from nothing. After just five games with the Dutch national team, he may already have snatched a spot in its World Cup squad.

title: High and Dry
description: The sartorial forecast this spring calls for ruffles with a chance of flowers and prints. But whats in store for your romantic get-up when the seasonal rains roll in? Instead of ruining it with a frumpy discount umbrella, raise it to new heights with couture coverage from Parasolerie Heurtault. Obsessed with umbrellas since childhood, the French artisan Michel Heurtault opened this Parisian atelier-boutique in 2008 after 20 years of working as a costume designer and corset maker for film, theater and fashion. Through the windows of the vaulted shop, clients can watch him construct made-to-measure umbrellas and parasols using waterproofed and UV-protected silk, taffeta, linen and cotton, then hand-finish them with button fixtures instead of snaps. Umbrellas have been vulgarized as disposable objects, says Heurtault, whos committed to creating silhouettes as sturdy as they are stylish. When beautifully designed, they can give instant allure and attitude to a chic ensemble while providing ultimate protection and comfort. Go to parasolerieheurtault.com.

title: Buy, Buy, Buy: Johnny Cash Song Is iTuness 10 Billionth Download
description: 2:23 p.m. | Updated  And we have a winner! Apple announced on Thursday that Louie Sulcer of Woodstock, Ga., clicked the Buy button at an opportune time, downloading the 10 billionth song from the companys iTunes Store since the site went active in April 2003. The fortuitous purchase makes Mr. Sulcer the winner of the iTunes Countdown to 10 Billion Songs, and hell receive a $10,000 iTunes gift card.

title: Fainting Spells
description: The middle-aged woman perched on the edge of a plastic chair as the doctor explained his thoughts on why her son was having persistent headaches. Suddenly, she toppled forward, collapsing onto the linoleum floor. Dr. Philip Ledereich hurried over to the woman. Call 911, he shouted to his nurse. The patients mother has fainted.

title: Q&A: If Its Spring, It Must Be Naples and Amalfi
description: Q.

title: The Dude Plumbs His Weary Soul
description: AT some point on the road to screen immortality, in between pining for Cybill Shepherd in The Last Picture Show and hurting for Maggie Gyllenhaal in Crazy Heart, Jeff Bridges transformed from an all-American pretty boy with effortless charm to a weathered veteran with bottomless soul. It has been a gradual metamorphosis, sweet and bitter and eagerly observed by critics, who, as the years passed, kept angling for audiences (and studio executives) to get up to speed. He is still waiting for the big hit that will finally transform his career, Newsweek declared of Mr. Bridges in 1984, upon the release of Starman, in which he played an extraterrestrial. A decade later, and the one after that, he was still waiting.

title: Framing Childhood
description: American children in 2010 have a bright, clear reason for being. They exist to furnish subjects for digital photographs that can be corrected, cropped, captioned, organized, categorized, albumized, broadcast, turned into screen savers and brandished on online social networks.

title: The Baby-Sitter Contract
description: Last fall my wife and I hired a young woman to care for our two children two days a week. Wed been left in the lurch before, so we insisted that she commit for the school year. We felt similarly committed to her. I now find that Ill lose my job in April, so we wont need day care. I want to lay her off, likening my situation to her having a medical emergency that renders her unable to work. My wife says we must pay her through June. You? NAME WITHHELD, TACOMA, WASH.

title: Perseverance in a Hunt for a Tricky Bomber
description: In New Yorks cold-case crime files, few have as firm a grip on the collective psyche of city law enforcement officers as the so-called zip-gun bomber.

title: Acquired Taste
description: One rainy afternoon this past December, while visiting my cousin Martin in Ecuador, I found myself surrounded by eight grinning, scantily clad members of the Shuar, an Amazonian tribe with the distinction of having shrunk its last human head during the Reagan administration. I wasnt in any kind of danger  just the opposite, in fact  but Id have given almost anything to escape.

title: Mayors Housing Offer Sets Off Row in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  The mayor of Jerusalem is offering 120 Palestinian families in a jumble of houses scheduled for demolition a deal he believes they cant refuse: new apartments atop shops and restaurants, a day care center, boutique hotels and a huge park. Tourists and income will flow. It is  as the mayor likes to say  win-win.

title: Boligarchs & The Bolibourgeoisie
description: Wealthy Venezuelans who have prospered (thus far) under Hugo Chvezs reign.

title: Founding Father?
description: Its easy to scoff at a state that would consider letting a dentist determine its history curriculum. But what do we expect, given the poor quality of history instruction in our schools? In science and math classes, we give students a series of puzzles to solve. But we present history as a set of facts rather than as a set of debates and arguments about them.

title: At the Toyota Hearing, Remembering the Pinto
description: During the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform hearings on Toyotas sudden acceleration problem, lawmakers displayed a slide titled, From Recall to Recovery that listed some of the major recalls of the last 30 years, including 31 million Tylenol bottles in 1982, four million General Motors pickups in 2004 and 1.5 million Ford Pintos in 1978.

title: Don Pardo: Live From New York, Still
description: The cast members, writers and the overall quality of Saturday Night Live may change from season to season but one constant has remained mostly in place for 35 years.

title: Dissent on American Embassy Design
description: Two prominent British members of the jury charged with selecting a design for the new American Embassy in London strongly opposed the choice of the Philadelphia firm KieranTimberlake, the Guardian of London reported on its Web site Tuesday.

title: How to Tell if a Good Savings Rate Will Last
description: I recently moved my savings from one bank to another to take advantage of a 1.55 percent annual yield. But within days, the rate had dropped to around 1.4.

title: M.T.A. Switches Firms for Transit Advertising
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York has ended its contract with Titan Worldwide, which had sold the advertising space on buses and commuter trains since January 2007, and shifted the assignment to the CBS Outdoor unit of the CBS Corporation.

title: Leak in Shark-Filled Aquarium in Dubai Mall
description: One day after an orca at Sea World in Orlando dragged a female trainer into his tank by her ponytail, causing her death, a crack appeared in a huge aquarium in a Dubai mall filled with hundreds of sharks.

title: Bernanke Defends Feds Ability to Supervise Banks
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, urged senators on Thursday not to strip the central bank of its authority to supervise the countrys largest banks, warning that to do so would pose a grave risk, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

title: Answers From Chuck Scarborough, Part 2
description: Following is the second set of answers from Chuck Scarborough about his career as an author and broadcast journalist, his job as co-anchor of New York Nightly News at 7 P.M., and other related matters.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: Wanderlust | Aspen in the Bag
description: Aspen, Colo., the quintessential winter getaway for Goldie, Posh and Mariah, has been generating fresh buzz recently for its latest crop of shops that provide a perfect contrast against the traditional mountain-town aesthetic.

title: The Snowboarder Supported by Grocers
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Canadian snowboarder Alexa Loo will compete in the parallel giant slalom Friday at Cypress Mountain. The Kin brothers will watch that event for the first time.

title: Photoshop and Photography: When Is It Real?
description: In the March issue of Popular Photography magazine, the editors note, by Miriam Leuchter, is called What Is a Photograph?

title: Photoshop and Photography: When Is It Real?
description: In the March issue of Popular Photography magazine, the editor's note, by Miriam Leuchter, is called "What Is a Photograph?"

title: Last-Minute Campaign Tricks Turn Nasty
description: With just a few days to go before Oscar ballots are due, all the scuttlebutt is coming out. Last Friday, Nicolas Chartier, the producer who put up the financing for The Hurt Locker, sent out an e-mail message asking people to vote for his indie film over a certain multimillion-dollar behemoth. If everyone tells one or two of their friends, we will win and not a $500M film, he wrote in the e-mail message, which Pete Hammond reprinted in a Los Angeles Times blog. Though Mr. Chartier didnt mention Avatar by name, the reference seemed pretty clear, and a violation of the Academys rules. Mr. Hammond thought a fitting punishment would be to revoke an Oscar seat or two.

title: JPMorgan Names New Tech M.&A. Head
description: JPMorgan Chase has named Anwar Zakkour, a veteran deal-maker, as its new head of technology mergers and acquisitions, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: A Utility Will Help Homeowners Go Solar
description: TXU Energy, a Texas utility with two million customers, is making it possible for homeowners in the Dallas area to lease or buy rooftop solar-power systems in one of the first programs of its kind.

title: Frozen Vines (and Fingers) Yield a Sweet Reward
description: Beamsville, Ontario

title: Will This Jobs Bill Do Any Good?
description: The Senate passed a jobs bill on Wednesday that, among other things, would give employers a temporary exemption from payroll taxes for hiring people who had previously been out of work for at least 60 days.

title: Great Read-Alouds From The New York Times
description: Update: March 1, 2012: This post is so popular and so large that we have permanently moved whats here to our new page, Great Read-Alouds From The New York Times. Please bookmark that as well continue to update it with more ideas and resources.

title: Investigator Says Killer of Rights Worker Identified
description: MOSCOW  A lead investigator in the murder of Natalya Estemirova, a human rights worker who was abducted and shot to death in Chechnya last July, said on Thursday that the authorities know who shot her but that they have been unable to arrest the suspect.

title: A Neighborhood Evolves, History Intact
description: Once considered the badlands, Bedford-Stuyvesant is slowly gentrifying and now features refurbished brownstones, vintage clothing stores and bakeries that produce a bumper crop of red velvet cakes and other treats. This central Brooklyn neighborhood is also a bastion of the African diaspora, a place where, as Black History Month winds down, a visitor can get a King Curtis Sweet Soul album or a dish of navy bean pie.

title: Aerosmith Back in the Saddle
description: The internal squabbles plaguing Aerosmith appear to have subsided, at least long enough for the band to announce dates for a European tour. And Steven Tyler  who reportedly quit the band and then entered a rehabilitation center to treat an addiction to prescription painkillers late last year  will be holding the microphone. I just auditioned, and I got the gig, Mr. Tyler said in a video on the bands Web site. Were coming your way and rocking your world.

title: Blogging the Health Care Summit
description: 2:46 p.m. | Updated  At our sib-blog, Prescriptions, colleague David M. Herszenhorn has been offering frequent updates to President Obamas health care session with Republican and Democratic leaders.

title: Teen Moodiness, or Borderline Personality Disorder?
description: When The Timess Personal Health columnist Jane Brody wrote about borderline personality disorder in An Emotional Hair Trigger, Often Misread, hundreds of readers had questions about the diagnosis and treatment of the troubling condition, characterized by impulsive behaviors, shifting moods and often frequent thoughts of suicide.

title: Gun Advocates to Make a Point at the Presidio This Weekend
description: Gun advocates plan to continue the fine Bay Area tradition of protest this weekend in San Francisco when members of Bay Area Open Carry take advantage of a new federal law allowing firearms in federal parks. On Saturday, the group will meet for a picnic and pick up trash at the Presidio, which is part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area, one of the most popular destinations in the National Park system.

title: 2010s Best Are All Men
description: Female writers and editors have noticed that the guest editors (and one introduction writer) selected last week by Houghton Mifflin to put together the publishers Best American anthologies for 2010 are all white men. The blog She Writes, by Kamy Wicoff, reported that Barbara Jones, the editorial director of Hyperion Books and Voice (an imprint of books for women), had sent an e-mail message with the subject line women are apparently not fit to judge this year. The anthologies, in one form or another, have been published since 1915.

title: Italian Court Action Gives One Victory to Premier
description: ROME  In a political victory for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, Italys Supreme Court on Thursday threw out a case in which his former lawyer was sentenced for taking a bribe to lie under oath in order to protect the prime minister.

title: Two More Men Charged in Plot to Bomb Subways
description: Two men already in custody were indicted on Thursday on new charges of participating in a Qaeda plot to detonate explosives in the crowded New York subway system, and federal prosecutors suggested that more people would be charged in the case.

title: Patti LuPone Asks Fans to Name Her Book
description: Im Ready for My Close-Up.

title: Photos of the Moment | Backstage at Milan
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Martino Lombezzi/Contrasto.

title: For Theater Chain, Alice in Wonderland Plans Are On Again
description: It looks as if Alice will make her very important date in a chain of European theaters.

title: On Jonathan Golds Los Angeles
description: Todays Internet brings us news of the publication, in LA Weekly, of Jonathan Golds 99 Things to Eat in L.A. Before You Die. It is an epic read, a 15-click Los Angeles fever dream that starts with blowfish at Urasawa in Beverly Hills and ends with maple-bacon biscuits at Huckleberry in Santa Monica.

title: The Muti Era Takes Shape in Chicago
description: Riccardo Muti will open his term as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra with a concert in Millennium Park on Sept. 19, the orchestra said on Thursday in announcing its 2010-11 season. In other highlights, his opening subscription concerts will feature Berliozs Symphonie Fantastique and Llio, with the actor Grard Depardieu as narrator, and Mr. Muti will lead concert performances of Verdis Otello in Chicago and at Carnegie Hall in April 2011. The violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will play the Beethoven violin concerto for the first time in nearly two decades with the orchestra at the orchestras gala, the Symphony Ball, on Oct. 2. Mr. Muti will spend 10 weeks with the orchestra.

title: Those Little Black Gum Dots, Busted
description: Of the many great mysteries of the city street, perhaps none is more ubiquitous and more perplexing than the presence of so many black dots.

title: Nikki Apicha Jawelo Johnson and Raymond S. Johnson
description: Photos from the wedding of Nikki Apicha Jawelo Johnson and Raymond S. Johnson.

title: Idol Again Beats the Olympics (With an Interesting Backstory)
description: NBC chose discretion over valor Wednesday night in the final face-off between the Vancouver Olympics and the American Idol power sweep: It punted for an entire half-hour.

title: Artist Converts Hummer Into Horse-Drawn Carriage
description: On Wednesday, General Motors announced that the planned sale of its Hummer brand to an obscure Chinese machining company had fallen through and that G.M. would end operation of the division. As if to punctuate Hummers demise, Jeremy Dean, an artist, is rolling out a work based on a Hummer H2. The gas-guzzling engine has been removed, and the S.U.V. can be pulled by horses.

title: Nikki Johnson and Raymond Johnson
description: NIKKI JOHNSONS wedding took place in her minds eye long before she met the man.

title: Iraq to Rehire 20,000 Hussein-Era Army Officers
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government said Thursday that it would reinstate 20,000 army officers who served under Saddam Hussein, a surprising move given that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has focused his campaign in the coming parliamentary elections around denouncing the former Baath government.

title: Snow Days
description: Today was a snow day for my younger son (video evidence below) and tens of thousands of other kids in the Northeast  all part of the remarkably snowy winter experience in much of the United States, Europe and a variety of other places in the Northern hemisphere, even as parts of Greenland have been balmy and rainy (one reason is that the Arctic Oscillation is once again in one of its extreme negative phases).

title: Lawyer Challenges a Paterson Claim in Abuse Case
description: The lawyer for the woman who had sought court protection from one of Gov. David A. Patersons top aides disputed on Thursday the governors claim that it was the woman who had initiated a telephone conversation with Mr. Paterson the day before she was due back in court.

title: A Neighborhood Evolves, History Intact
description: Once considered the badlands, Bedford-Stuyvesant in central Brooklyn is slowly gentrifying and now features refurbished brownstones, vintage clothing stores and bakeries that produce a bumper crop of red velvet cakes and other treats. The neighborhood is also a bastion of the African diaspora, a place where, as Black History Month winds down, a visitor can get a King Curtis Sweet Soul album or a dish of navy bean pie.

title: The Latest Pico Projectors
description: The latest in a new generation of projectors: The LG Expo, a cellphone with an (almost) built-in projector, and the Aaxa, which uses lasers for clearer images.

title: After Conviction, Concrete Executive Tried to Kill Himself
description: The owner of Testwell Laboratories, once the leading concrete testing company in New York, tried to kill himself last week, two days after he was convicted of falsifying concrete mix reports, according to court documents.

title: Banking by Text Message
description: In another sign that mobile banking may be the way of the future, Wells Fargo recently announced that its text banking service is now available to all customers, even those who arent enrolled in online banking.

title: More Clashes Over Israeli Claim to Shrine
description: HEBRON, West Bank  Dozens of Palestinian youths clashed with Israeli forces for a fourth day on Thursday at various locations in this volatile city over the inclusion of a hotly contested religious shrine here, the Cave of the Patriarchs, in a list of places earmarked for renovation as Jewish heritage sites.

title: Press in Tow, McCains Challenger Demands Debates
description: PHOENIX  In terms of major as United States Senate candidate J. D. Hayworth billed his announcement here outside the McCain 2010 headquarters, lets give it a feh. But as political theater goes, it wasnt bad.

title: JPMorgan Shows Its Concern About New Bank Rules
description: James E. Staley, JPMorgan Chases investment banking chief, acknowledged Thursday that regulatory changes being considered in Congress had influenced the banks acquisition strategy, in a sign that the bank may be growing more concerned about the impact of tougher rules for financial firms.

title: The Lost Children of Haiti
description: Even before the earthquake, one option for Port-au-Prince's homeless children was Restavek, an underground system that some call foster care, and others call child slavery.  Now their numbers swell.

title: The Morning Skate: Is Canada vs. U.S. II in the Forecast?
description: A clash of two onrushing forces is taking shape in the mens hockey tournament at the Vancouver Games. Like the winter storm currently enveloping the Northeast United States, nothing is certain; nothing is given. Formidable obstacles could intervene and alter this forecast. But a second Canada-United States game  this one for the gold medal  could be just a shot away.

title: Storm Covers Northeast With Another Wet Blanket
description: Thousands of people were without power and dozens of school districts  including all New York City public schools  were shut down on Friday morning as a lumbering late-February blizzard roosted over New York and lashed the region with driving snow.

title: The Health Care Forum
description: At a highly anticipated meeting at Blair House, President Obama and Congressional Democrats squared off against Congressional Republicans on legislation to overhaul the health care system.

title: Middlebury Students Rap About Vermont Cheddar, Flannel and Nalgene
description: The latest in a growing list of a videos paying homage to particular colleges comes from a troupe of students at Middlebury in Vermont. But unlike Thats Why I Chose Yale  which originated in the Yale admissions office and appeared to take some cues from High School Musical  Midd Kid is a rap that is proudly unauthorized by the college. That is not least because of some risque inferences and language that is more Jay-Z than Jay Leno, although the lyrics are mostly tame. (A sample: Im a Midd Kid/I roll my jeans up high/With my Teva strap tight and my flannel so fly.

title: Meanwhile, in Madrid
description: Balenciagas Nicolas Ghesquire is currently one of the worlds most influential designers, but when it comes to Spanish fashion,its Cristobal Balenciaga who casts a long shadow. At the 51st edition of Cibeles Fashion Week, which wrapped up this week in Madrid, many of the citys most celebrated designers found inspiration in an ultrastructured, old-school couture ideal  a point of reference that was about as relevant to 2010 as it sounds. Luckily, there were plenty of other distractions including a buzzing scene at the Feria de Madrid site and an array of eccentric bold-face names who could have walked out of an Almodovar film.Much of the excitement on the runways came courtesy of the top-tier models who skipped London, where few designers can afford to pay fees, in favor of Madrid. Iris Strubegger, Marina Peres, Eniko Mihalik, Egle Tvirbutaite, Denisa Dvorakova, Michaela Kocianova Diana Farkhullina, Daiane Conterato and Charlotte di Calypso added some super appeal to the calendar.

title: Video: Olympic Pictograms Through the Ages
description: The designer Steven Heller traces the evolution of the tiny symbols for each Olympic sport since their appearance in 1936.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Men celebrate Lathmar Holi, also known as the festival of colors, at Nandgaon village near Mathura, India. This tradition heralds the beginning of spring.

title: Questions? The Baggers Got Answers
description: On Wednesday the Bagger put forth a call for Oscar-season help and  thank God  our dear readers responded. If we had known our desperate plea would generate such good questions, we wouldve groveled long ago. Heres the first installment of our answers:

title: A Two-Time Winner
description: WHO Ron McKenna, 63

title: 3-Point Artist Hopes W.N.B.A. Is in Her Range
description: UNION, N.J.  Melissa Beyruti was so quiet when she first arrived at Kean University that her basketball coach, Michele Sharp, made her stop by her office just to see if Beyruti was doing all right. Sharp said the visits came to be known as Melissa meetings.

title: Embattled Peanut Vendor Fails Inspection
description: The city still has one fewer peanut vendor on the sidewalks today.

title: In Only Bar of Its Kind in City, Haven (or a Hideout) for Smokers
description: The first sign that the place is different is out front: Arriving customers do not walk the gantlet of exiled smokers that greets them at the doors of other bars. Here, those people are all inside.

title: Murthas Widow Endorses a Candidate
description: John P. Murthas widow may not be looking to succeed her late husband in the House  but she is weighing in on who she thinks that replacement should be.

title: Tile by Tile, a Mural Is Saved
description: Tile by Tile,

title: Art in Review
description: CHARLES W. HUTSON

title: Dispute Shows Argentinas Lack of Oil Exploration
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The diplomatic jousting between Argentina and Britain over drilling for oil off the coast of the disputed Falkland Islands may be less about rubbing salt in old wounds than about exposing new ones of the Argentine governments own making, political analysts and energy consultants said.

title: Blinky Palermos American Tour
description: There are artists whose work is much loved in Europe but barely noticed in this country. Martin Kippenberger, the German painter who died in 1997, fell into this category until last year, when the Museum of Modern Art presented a major retrospective. Suddenly his canvases started turning up at auctions in New York, where they brought prices that were higher than anticipated. Now another European name  the German abstract painter Blinky Palermo  is getting his posthumous American moment.

title: Preferring Girls Over Boys
description: For generations, boys have been preferred to girls in Asian culture, but there is at least one study that hints that in at least one country this bias is changing.

title: Verizons $18.5 Million Goodbye to Ex-President
Perella Weinberg Hires Restructuring Banker in London
description: Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank, said on Thursday that it had hired a London-based banker as a managing director for its restructuring and bankruptcy group.

title: A Burial Ground and Its Dead Are Given Life
description: Cemeteries are at least as much for the living as the dead. They are the locus of tribute and memory; they affirm connections to a place and its past.

title: Trendspotting
description: Pigtails  statement lips smudged eyes disappearing brows bare cheeks. More

title: In Defense of Dead Trees
description: Dave Eggers, the fledgling press baron behind The San Francisco Panorama, the much-ballyhooed (and drop-dead gorgeous) newspaper released in December by the McSweeneys gang, has been making the rounds with his full-throated argument that the future of the news business can be written not just in pixels but with old-fashioned paper and ink.

title: France May Make Mental Violence a Crime
description: PARIS  Frances National Assembly approved Thursday night a proposal to add psychological violence to a law intended to help victims of physical violence and abuse, despite doubts that the law is specific enough to have much impact.

title: Chefs on the Move: Scott Peacock Leaving Watershed
description: My chef friend Scott Peacock called today to confirm that he has resigned from Watershed restaurant in outside Atlanta to pursue new projects.

title: Movie Listings
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Houlihan Lokey Hires Executive for Southeast M.&A.
description: Houlihan Lokey said on Thursday that it had hired a veteran deal-maker to head its mergers and acquisitions business for the Southeastern United States.

title: Man Killed by Falling Branch in Central Park
description: Updated, 5:59 p.m. | A 46-year-old man was killed in Central Park when a snow-sodden tree limb fell on him just before 3:30 p.m. Thursday, the authorities said.

title: Olympic Icons: An Animated Appraisal
description: You know those little symbols that represent each Olympic sport? They get redesigned for every Olympics, and it doesnt always go well.

title: Party Central | Whitney Biennial Party
description: Scenes from the Whitney Biennial afterparty at the Tommy Hilfiger flagship store.

title: Experts Assail Call as Claimed Between Paterson and Aides Accuser
description: In the world of lawyers and advocates who specialize in domestic violence and family law, a moment-to-moment concern is that a woman who has made an accusation  or gone to court for protection  will be intimidated by even the slightest pushback, whether it comes from the man she has taken action against or from his family, his friends or his co-workers.

title: Hofstra Lacrosse Hopes Its Canadian Connection Pays Off
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Snow was ringing the field and sitting in the aisles at Shuart Stadium.

title: Air Sprite, Feral Creature, Rapturous Love and Other Sorcery
description: As you take your seat at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater, where the Bridge Project production of The Tempest opened Thursday night, you can spy Stephen Dillane, the lanky British actor who plays Prospero, sitting quietly among the musicians already assembled on the stage.

title: Work by the People and for the People
