description: Bang on a Can, the composer-run new-music organization, has always had a populist streak, as its name implies. Its Peoples Commissioning Fund taps into that spirit: contemporary-music fans are encouraged to contribute a few dollars each toward a handful of new works.

title: Inflections: Proustian and Jazzy
description: Many composers have considered the piano and violin natural soul mates, but Ravel deemed them essentially incompatible. He said that instead of reconciling their differences in his Sonata for Violin and Piano, he would emphasize their independence.

title: John Grisham to Pen Childrens Books
description: John Grisham, the best-selling author of more than 20 books, is writing a new series for children centered on a precocious amateur lawyer.

title: Trading in a Bugatti Veyron for a Corvette
description: For car enthusiasts who cant get enough newness, theres a very familiar expression: taking a hit, a euphemism for losing a lot of money. But a trade-in at All American Chevrolet in Midland, Tex., gives new meaning to that phrase.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Feb. 25
description: For the second day in a row, Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press has filed a surprising and offbeat view of life in Pakistan. Todays picture (Slide 12) shows a 14-year-old balloon vendor on the outskirts of Islamabad; or, rather, it shows a bunch of ballons on the outskirts of Islamabad sprouting from a little pair of legs. Yesterdays roadside entrepreneur, above right, was not quite so Winnie the Pooh. (Click here or on the image for the full Wednesday show.)

title: Judge Expanded Review on Terrorism Suspect
description: When a federal judge in Manhattan ordered prosecutors to search Justice Department records concerning a terrorism suspect, he granted a broader review than the government wanted to undertake, a newly released court opinion shows.

title: For a Drugstore, Nice Isnt a Panacea
description: WYNNEWOOD, Pa.

title: Answers About Same-Sex Couples and Taxes: Part 3
description: Ask an Expert is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

title: Two Young Pianists, Forging Connections
description: Most young classical musicians feel pressure to stand out. If handled right, though, this pressure can be a productive force in an emerging artists life.

title: Workers File Suit Against Waldorf-Astoria
description: Nine former Waldorf-Astoria employees filed suit against the luxury hotel on Thursday, saying management skimmed their tips.

title: Theater Listings: Feb. 26  March 4
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Paying for Innovation
description: Who pays for innovation? Around the world, the leader is the United States. And within the United States, the leader is private industry.

title: President of Goldmans Power Unit Is Retiring
description: Larry Kellerman, president of Goldman Sachss wholly owned electric power asset business, Cogentrix, and a partner at the firm, is retiring, a Goldman spokesman told DealBook on Thursday.

title: The Fallback Option
description: Ill be writing more about the health care summit over the weekend, but I just want to make one quick point on policy. The big news leading into the event was the Wall Street Journals report this morning that the White House has prepared a more modest, fallback health reform plan in the event it becomes clear comprehensive reform is going nowhere. Or perhaps I should say the big news, since Ezra Klein quickly came out with a post saying that nobody in Obamaland is seriously considering the proposal at the moment. (It certainly wasnt mentioned at the summit.)

title: Are Trade Shows a Waste of Time?
description: I just got back from the international framing show in Italy. Yes, there are trade shows for picture framing. Last month, I went to the national frame and art show in Las Vegas. Both shows have gotten smaller over the years, and several other shows have been discontinued. From what I have seen and heard, attendance has been declining at most trade shows in most industries. There are numerous reasons, including fewer small businesses, more reluctance to travel and more information on the Internet.

title: A Little Twilight for Oscar Night
description: Waaaay back at the beginning of Oscar season, when the Bagger was green  greener  and Adam Shankman was just a choreographer-turned-newbie Oscar producer, not one-half of the Academys most famous odd couple, he suggested on Twitter that people like Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart might be a part of the show.

title: Haitian Tradition Is Criticized as Child Slavery
description: After Haitian authorities arrested 10 Americans last month for trying to bring 33 Haitian children to an orphanage outside of the country, it emerged that several of the children were not, in fact, orphans.

title: Wired for Sound, and Everything Else
description: Everything gleamed when Black Eyed Peas performed at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. On shiny metallic stage sets, Will.i.am, Fergie, Taboo and Apl.de.ap wore silvery metallic costumes, flanked by dancers in head-to-toe robot gear or Op-Art bodysuits. Video screens flashed to announce song titles and segments of the show like computer programs booting up. Anything not reflective was likely to light up with LEDs.

title: Fidelity Fires 2 Managers for Violating Ethics Code
description: HONG KONG  Fidelity International said on Thursday that it had fired two fund managers based in Hong Kong for what it said were ethical breaches.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: At a Biennial on a Budget, Tweaking and Provoking
description: In what felt like a pre-emptive effort at damage control, the Whitney Museum of American Art did everything to underpitch its 2010 Biennial. With 55 artists, we were advised, it would be half the size of the 2006 show. Unlike the 2008 version, which spilled over into the Park Avenue Armory, this one would be confined to the museums premises. No frills. Tight belts. Were doing our best. Dont shoot.

title: After the Annuals and Biennials, the Perennials
description: When the Whitney Biennial ends, where does all the art go? Some of it gets sold, quietly or not so quietly, to collectors, foundations and other museums. Some pieces stay with the artists, or their dealers. But a few wind up sticking around, in the Whitney collection.

title: London Fashion Week | Meadham Kirchhoff
description: Edward Meadham and Benjamin Kirchhoff just showed the fourth season of their Meadham Kirchhoff brand under the New Gen new talent initiative in London. Theyve got themselves a bit of reputation for being all moody and slouchy and gothic, but this season they did something more exciting than most of the other stuff being churned out in London: Riot Grrrls and gowns that were almost like couture and veils and tinsel tiaras made in collaboration with millinery wunderkind Nasir Mazhar. It was an unexpected breath of fresh air. Theyre still good for a right old rant, though.

title: Learning to Read, Murder, Survive
description: Near the end of A Prophet, one of those rare films in which the moral stakes are as insistent and thought through as the aesthetic choices, theres a scene in which the lead character, Malik, travels to Paris to kill some men. The scene reverberates with almost unbearable tension but is briefly punctured by a seemingly throwaway image: Seconds before he begins shooting, thereby sealing his fate, you see him catch sight of a pair of mens shoes showcased like jewels in a boutique window in a rich Parisian quarter. He does a double take, a reaction that might mirror that of the anxious viewer who wonders why he doesnt just get on with it.

title: Falklands Oil Dispute Escalates
description: The war of words continues between Britain and Argentina over Britain's oil exploitation off the coast of the contested Falkland Islands, France24 reports.

title: James Van Der Back?
description: He spent six years on his own creek and, in-between, struggled through some varsity blues and obeyed a few rules of attraction. Now, after a bit of time outside the spotlight, James Van Der Beek has returned to screens both large and small. He has the starring role in a current film (Formosa Betrayed), a supporting role in a coming film (Stolen) and a recurring role on the television hospital drama Mercy. He answered a few questions about his recent projects, as well as the effects of growing up Dawson.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: A Slice of 19th-Century  Brooklyn
description: To walk down the four blocks of MacDonough Street in the Stuyvesant Heights Historic District of Brooklyn is to travel from 1860s villa-style mansions to 1890s mass-produced brownstones.

title: Who Needs the Whitney? They Have Their Own Show
description: If the 2010 Whitney Biennial is too lean, clean and demure for your taste, you might try an alternative, the Brucennial in SoHo, which features 420 artists from 911 countries working in 666 disciplines, and is, for good measure, the most important survey of contemporary art in the world. Ever.

title: American Idol': Who Will Be the First to Say Goodbye?
description: A sleepless night of research, phone calls, and meetings with lawyers has failed to yield results: Turns out there is no way to wipe the American Idol semifinalist slate clean and start over with a new group of 24. Given that, its worth considering that this is at least an implicit part of the shows plan: some contestants are just there to fill space while the favorites gain strength and confidence. Having served their purpose, they begin to fall off during the early voting rounds, like outmoded appendages.

title: Photos of the Moment | Glamour Girls
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Davide Monteleone/Contrasto.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Anger and Angst, Explored With Animation
description: The Museum of Modern Arts William Kentridge: Five Themes amounts to a split decision. Combining film and film installations with prints and drawings, it lays out the strengths and weaknesses of this prominent South African artists work with a forthrightness that is almost touching.

title: Photographers Hurry Up and Wait for Long Program
description: The womens long program is one of the premier events of these Winter Olympics, with photographers from all over the world wanting to have an ice-level position to capture every jump and spin. But the first-come, first-served nature of securing one of these positions left photographers who arrived by 9 a.m., eight hours before the event, out of contention for a spot.

title: A Poet of the Body, Bending All the Rules
description: If you want to learn just how differently dance can be set to music  and how dance can reveal different aspects of music  then there is no better place to be than in New York this weekend. Three companies are all showing first-class examples: New York City Ballet in George Balanchines Jewels at the David H. Koch Theater; the Mark Morris Dance Group in a program of works by Mr. Morris at the Brooklyn Academy of Music; and the Paul Taylor Dance Company in a series of triple bills of Mr. Taylors work at City Center, where the troupe opened its season on Wednesday. (At such times, New York is the envy of the dance world.)

title: Thom Yorke Names New Band
description: Last fall, when Thom Yorke of Radiohead introduced his new band  featuring Flea of Red Hot Chili Peppers and the longtime Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich  it had no name. For the groups official debut in Los Angeles, the marquee outside the Orpheum Theater simply had six question marks. Now the band has a name and a bunch of tour dates. In a brief note posted on Radioheads Web site (radiohead.com), Mr. Yorke announced that groups name, Atoms for Peace, and that it would play a series of American shows leading up to the Coachella festival in California on April 18. Hope you like the name, Mr. Yorke wrote. It seemed bleedin obvious. (Atoms for Peace is the title of a track from his 2006 solo album, The Eraser, which the band plays in its entirety.) First up: the Roseland Ballroom in New York on April 5 and 6.

title: Letter: Cruising for Everyone
description: To the Editor: Re Offering Whatever Floats Your Boat, Is This How Cleopatra Felt? and Cruise Bargains Harder to Find: Nowhere in these three articles in The Cruise Issue 2010 (Feb. 14)  one of which includes a list of 29 different cruise line companies, was there a mention of cruises that cater to the gay and lesbian community (Atlantis, RSVP or the very family-friendly R Family Vacations, for example).

title: Manifesto From the Battle for the Barnes Collection
description: Money, power, race, a mansion stuffed with treasure, a city plagued by scandal  about all thats missing from The Art of the Steal, a hard-hitting documentary about a high-cultural brawl, is a hot woman with a warm gun. At the heart of the movie, energetically directed and argued by Don Argott, is the celebrated Barnes Foundation, which houses a private collection in suburban Philadelphia (here, a city of brotherly love and loathing) groaning with European masterworks, African sculptures, Asian prints, American Indian ceramics, among other items. The foundation even owns a farmhouse furnished with decorative arts, and its surrounding 12-acre arboretum is filled with rare flora from around the globe.

title: 10 Billionth Download for iTunes
description: And we have a winner! Apple announced on Thursday that Louie Sulcer of Woodstock, Ga., clicked the Buy Song button at an opportune time, downloading the 10 billionth song from the companys iTunes Store since the site went active in April 2003. Mr. Sulcer will receive a $10,000 iTunes gift card for his fortuitous purchase of Johnny Cashs Guess Things Happen That Way. Mr. Sulcer, a 71-year-old retired real estate broker, said in an interview that he learned about his achievement when Steve Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, called on Wednesday night. On Thursday he heard from Rosanne Cash, Johnny Cashs daughter, who thanked him for buying one of her fathers tunes. She then put her husband, the musician John Leventhal, on the phone to play the winning song. Mr. Sulcer said he hadnt had much time to think about how he would spend the winnings. Thats the $10,000 question, he said, though he said he expects that his three children and nine grandchildren would most likely benefit. I dont think Ill have to worry about buying birthday and Christmas presents anytime soon.

title: OBrien Speaks via Twitter
description: Conan OBrien, below, the unemployed former host of The Tonight Show, has a fervent online fan base. Now he is reaching out to his supporters. In his first public comment since exiting NBC last month, Mr. OBrien wrote on Twitter on Wednesday night: Today I interviewed a squirrel in my backyard and then threw to commercial. Somebody help me. Twitter verified that the account, with the username @ConanOBrien, is operated by the comedian. In his short biography Mr. OBrien describes himself thusly: I had a show. Then I had a different show. Now I have a Twitter account. By Thursday morning Mr. OBrien had amassed more than a quarter-million followers, making him one of Twitters most popular users.

title: Aerosmith Back in the Saddle
description: The internal squabbles plaguing Aerosmith appear to have subsided, at least long enough for the band to announce dates for a European tour. And Steven Tyler  who reportedly quit the band and then entered a rehabilitation center to treat an addiction to prescription painkillers late last year  will be holding the microphone. I just auditioned and I got the gig, Mr. Tyler said in a video on the bands Web site, aerosmith.com. Were coming your way and rocking your world. The bands troubles began after Mr. Tyler fell from a stage during a concert in South Dakota in August. It escalated earlier this month when Mr. Tylers lawyer sent a letter to the bands management warning them of legal action if another front man was brought in. The 11-show run, the Cocked, Locked and Ready to Rock tour, will begin in Sweden on June 10 and end in Italy on July 3. Tickets will go on sale March 5.

title: Patti Lupone Enlists Fans to Write Title for Her New Book
description: Im Ready for My Close-Up. Dont Cry for Me, Argentina. Put Your Camera Away! These are just three possible titles for the actress Patti LuPones forthcoming book about her life in the theater, offered in the spirit of a new contest that Ms. LuPone  a two-time Tony Award winner for Evita and Gypsy  is running on her official Web site, pattilupone.net. Writes Ms. LuPone, above: Dolls, Ive been busy writing the story of my theatrical life and need your help to find a suitable and fabulous title. If your entry is selected youll win an autographed copy of the book, two tickets to my next Broadway show (or major show in a city near you), and Ill congratulate you personally at the theater. Contest ends March 30, 2010. Important note: Travel and accommodations are not included. Good luck! The first two title suggestions are memorable lines of Ms. LuPones as Norma Desmond in Sunset Boulevard and Eva Pern in Evita. The third is a bit of speculative mind-reading based on Ms. LuPones reputation for occasionally diva-slamming folks she sees using electronic devices during a performance.

title: Grisham to Write for Children
description: John Grisham, the best-selling author of 24 legal thrillers, is writing a new series for children centered on a precocious amateur lawyer. The first in the series, which will be published in May by Penguin Young Readers Group, is Theodore Boone: Kid Lawyer and features the 13-year-old title character, the son of two lawyers in a Southern town. Mr. Grisham has sold North American rights for the first two books to Penguin, a move that takes him away from his longtime publisher, the Doubleday imprint of Random House. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Doubleday will still publish Mr. Grishams new legal thriller for adults, an untitled work scheduled to be released in October. David Gernert, Mr. Grishams literary agent, said Mr. Grisham wanted to explore other publishers as he entered a new genre. Childrens publishing is totally different from adults, Mr. Gernert said. Stuart Applebaum, a spokesman for Random House, said Random Houses Childrens Books division made an offer and expressed our keen interest. Don Weisberg, president of Penguin Young Readers Group, said the books would be aimed at 8- to 12-year-olds. The title character, he said, is delightful, and the kind of character you would like the opportunity to develop over time.

title: Muti Era Takes Shape in Chicago
description: Riccardo Muti, below, will open his term as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra with a concert in Millennium Park on Sept. 19, the orchestra said on Thursday in announcing its 2010-11 season. In other highlights, his opening subscription concerts will feature Berliozs Symphonie Fantastique and Llio, with the actor Grard Depardieu as narrator, and Mr. Muti will lead concert performances of Verdis Otello in Chicago and at Carnegie Hall in April 2011. The violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will play the Beethoven violin concerto for the first time in nearly two decades with the group at the orchestras gala, Symphony Ball, on Oct. 2. Mr. Muti will spend 10 weeks with the orchestra.

title: Idol Beats Olympics, Again
description: For the second time this week, Foxs American Idol beat NBCs coverage of the Olympics. Wednesdays episode of Idol drew 22.8 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., almost 3 million more than the Winter Games on NBC in the same time period, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox led the night over all, while NBC was a close runner-up, averaging 19.4 million viewers. CBS was third with reruns of Criminal Minds (7.3 million) and CSI: NY (7.9 million), following repeats of the networks sitcoms The New Adventures of Old Christine at 8 (4.4 million) and Gary Unmarried at 8:30 (3.4 million). ABC placed fourth with an all-repeat lineup of comedies.

title: Two Jury Members Opposed Pick for U.S. Embassy Design
description: Two prominent British members of the jury charged with selecting a design for the new American Embassy in London strongly opposed the choice of the Philadelphia firm KieranTimberlake, The Guardian of London reported on its Web site (guardian.co.uk) on Tuesday. The British architect Richard Rogers and Peter Palumbo, a British arts patron and chairman of the Pritzker Prize, submitted a minority report in which they told the United States State Department  which commissioned the project  that the design was not world class and was unfit to represent the U.S. in Britain. KieranTimberlakes design for the billion-dollar project features a glass cube covered in plastic panels. Mr. Rogers declined to comment, The Guardian said; Mr. Palumbo could not be reached. The Guardian said the two had favored the design by another contender, Thom Mayne of Morphosis in Los Angeles. The New York architects Richard Meier and Pei Cobb Freed & Partners also submitted schemes. In an e-mail message, the State Department said it would not comment on the individual jury members design choices.

title: Grooming for the Vancouver Olympics
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  General Motors provides the official cars, trucks and S.U.V.s that keep the Vancouver Winter Olympics going. But when it comes to snow events, the true official vehicle is the PistenBully 400.

title: More Soul for the Money
description: CHRISTOPHER HYLAND, a Manhattan designer and the owner of a high-end fabric house in the Decoration and Design Building on Third Avenue, has listed his 4,000-square-foot apartment in Chelsea for $22.45 million. He said he hoped that by doing so, he could also send a message. Namely: If youre going to charge a fortune for housing in this city, you have to give people something that has a sense of soul, said Mr. Hyland, as he led a tour of the condominium, which his friends call The Manor House of Chelsea.

title: A Nation 400 Million Strong
description: At 7:46 a.m. on Oct. 17, 2006, precisely the moment that the Census Bureau estimated that the American population would reach 300 million, Emanuel Plata was born in a public hospital in Queens. His parents were Mexican immigrants. The doctor who delivered him was from Argentina. One nurse was from Russia, another from India. The anesthesiologist came from Bulgaria. As that benchmark birth demonstrated, in 2006 the United States was a very different country than it had been less than 40 years earlier, when the number of Americans topped 200 million. (The population passed 100 million five decades earlier in 1915.)

title: Where Black  Is Blacklisted
description: PRACTICALLY everyone wears black in  Men in Black  and  The Addams Family,  films directed by Barry Sonnenfeld. But in the 2,270-square-foot condominium loft that he and his wife, Susan Ringo, just sold in the financial district for $1.8 million, its all about white.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

title: When Opportunity  Comes Knocking
description: SOMETIMES $10 million town houses on the Upper East Side sell without ever being put on the market.

title: Dance Listings
description: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

title: Needs Work, and Art
description: WHEN Caral Gimbel Lebworth, an heiress to the Gimbel Brothers department store chain, died in 2008 at age 93, she left behind an impressive art collection and an 11-room apartment on Park Avenue. Christies sold the artwork, including works by Matisse and Mir, last year. And her estate recently sold the apartment for $5.5 million.

title: Canada Is Back. A Challenge, Anyone?
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Canadas dissection of Russia in Olympic mens hockey on Wednesday was more than just a reason for scores of Canadians to hop in their cars and drive around the city, waving flags and honking horns. It also drastically altered the medal landscape.

title: The Buddy-Police Recipe: Take Guns, Add Some Wisecracking, Stir
description: Jimmy and Paul are a carefully mismatched pair of New York City detectives who have endured nine years of partnership, which should put the ordeal of anyone who buys a ticket to Cop Out in some perspective. You will spend less than two hours in their wisecracking, undisciplined company, and that should be more than enough.

title: On Wall Street, a Romance With Curling
description: Wall Street trading is often described as a blood sport. But inside the great investment houses, the sport of the moment is, of all things, curling  that oddball of the Olympics that is sort of like shuffleboard on ice.

title: Mancuso Falls Short in the Giant Slalom
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Julia Mancuso skied fast in the womens giant slalom Thursday, though not nearly fast enough to catch the 20-year-old gold medalist Viktoria Rebensburg of Germany. That Mancuso would fail to retain her Olympic title in the event had been an obvious outcome since a series of random circumstances forced her into an unenviable do-over of her first run Wednesday.

title: Geffen Buys Fifth Avenue Co-op for $14 Million
description: David Geffen, the Brooklyn-born record and film producer, just bought a 17th-floor apartment with sweeping Central Park views at 785 Fifth Avenue for $14.17 million.

title: In Tax Law, an Overdue Overhaul a Step, With Miles to Go
description: What is the most outrageous section of American tax law?

title: Prada: Old Dears
description: Miuccia Pradas fall collection tonight dealt with women oblivious of fads, brands, red carpets and warnings about taking the extra helping. The figure she imagined was voluptuous, her bust delineated with darts and dimply ruffles, her waist where it naturally belongs and her hips somewhere under pleats.

title: The Ailey Extension
description: On a dancing scale of 1 to 10, with the low end occupied by the spastic Elaine on Seinfeld and the high end by Michael Jackson, I consider myself a solid 6.

title: More Answers From the Bagger
description: Its time for another installment of You Ask, Bagger Answers. In this round: Is the cost of hair and makeup part of the cost of doing business in Hollywood? How do Academy members distinguish between best actor/actress and best supporting actor/actress categories? And whither the Twitter campaign?

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: An Architectural Encyclopedia, Vols. 1860-1890
description: TO WALK down the four blocks of MacDonough Street in the Stuyvesant Heights Historic District of Brooklyn is to travel from 1860s villa-style mansions to 1890s mass-produced brownstones  and no farther. But the 21st century is now intruding, as two brownstones have narrowly escaped the wrecking ball.

title: Scorecard | Christopher Kane Wins!
description: The British Fashion Council-sponsored fashion week(end) is over, and the stilettoed set is now setting up camp in Milan, but today Scorecard asks, Who won among the final shows? From the business-of-fashion angle, its clear that the shearling spectacular from Burberrys creative director, Christopher Bailey, pressed a five-point offensive, but it was another Christopher  Kane  who carried the day with his ironic pastiche of his whole nymphet thing. Only in London, kids!

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO  (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series Dora the Explorer and Go, Diego, Go! have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diegos Animal Rescue Center and Doras Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street , (212) 721-1223, cmom.org; free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.20100225

title: Willie Mays, the Say Hey Kid
description: A long time ago in America, there was a beautiful game called baseball. This was before 30 major-league teams were scattered in a blurry variety of divisions; before 162-game seasons and extended playoffs and fans who watched World Series games in thick down jackets; before the D.H. came to the American League; before AstroTurf on baseball fields and aluminum bats on sandlots; before complete games by pitchers were a rarity; before ballparks were named for corporations instead of individuals; and long, long before the innocence of the game was permanently stained by the filthy deception of steroids.

title: Up Front: Pete Hamill
description: Pete Hamill roots for the Mets these days, but he hasnt really been much of a baseball fan since the steroid scandals, and the impunity that engulfs them, he said in an e-mail message.

title: Kabul Bureau Chief Answers Readers Questions on Marja
description: The New York Timess Kabul bureau chief, Alissa J. Rubin, is answering readers questions about the military campaign in Marja, Afghanistan. As the operation in Marja continues, other reporters in the bureau will respond as well.

title: Highlights From the Health Care Summit
description: The six hours of talking, boiled down to 4 minutes.

title: In Richard Bauschs Stories, Peril and Temptation
description: An older man is on his fourth wife. Shes much younger; in fact, she happens to be his former student. And now hes apparently walked out on her too. Thats the setup for the story The Harp Department in Love. But if it seems to promise a walk down some familiar literary lane  telling, say, a tersely lyrical tale of the wreckage caused by restless, self-defeating men, or depicting a grand tragedy of never-satisifed masculine desire  rest assured that because its a Richard Bausch story it will attend to the predicaments of the American male with insight and flair, even as the struggles of his female counterpart are treated with an equally interested eye.

title: On the Phone, Alienated and Indulging
description: There is a lot of dirty talk in Easier With Practice, an intimate drama about a fledgling author with a sensitive soul, a fondness for romance novels and an imagination that skews toward the raw. You learn about those feverish thoughts soon after that soul, Davy Mitchell (Brian Geraghty), enters the picture. With his brother, Sean (Kel ONeill), Davy is tooling around on a book tour, reading his unpublished prose to listeners who can barely rouse themselves to lift their hands in applause. One night after a particularly forlorn reading, he answers the motel phone and encounters the woman of his wet dreams, Nicole (Kathryn Aselton), who soon benefits from his affection for books in which throbbing is the verb of choice.

title: BAMkids Film Festival
description: Childrens moviegoing is often a passive experience, except, of course, for the vigorous chewing of popcorn and candy. But the BAMkids Film Festival strives to turn it into a more active one.

title: National Medal of Arts Winners Include Bob Dylan, Clint Eastwood and Maya Lin
description: The White House continues to pay tribute to Bob Dylan in every way it knows how  whether or not Mr. Dylan is there to receive the honor. On Thursday, two weeks after the singer appeared at the East Room as part of a concert to commemorate Black History Month, Mr. Dylan was named one of 12 recipients of the National Medal of Arts, only this time the Blowin in the Wind balladeer was not in attendance.

title: Gilbert Sorrentinos Last Novel
description: The title of Gilbert Sorrentinos last novel comes from Henry Jamess story The Middle Years: It was the abyss of human illusion that was the real, the tideless deep. Sorrentino, who died in 2006 at the age of 77, was a cleareyed observer of human illusion and the frailties and follies of the species. He was also a very funny writer. When asked in an interview about the apparent contradiction in his work between the hilarity of his style and the bleakness of his subject matter, he said, by way of explanation, A writer seizes on a particular aspect of the culture, and I believe that life is basically ridiculous, then went on to gloss this ridiculous quality as being potentially tragic or comic, light or dark, laughter- or sob-provoking, or all of the foregoing, depending on circumstance.

title: Photos of the Moment | Vive le Maquillage
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Marcello Bonfanti/Contrasto.

title: Red Highways
description: If Chinas first urban planners had persevered, Peter Hesslers road trip from east of Beijing to the Gobi Desert would have taken place on top of the Great Wall instead of alongside it. Never mind that the Great Wall is actually many walls and that it extends for more than 5,000 miles. Thinking big was both the curse and the blessing of 20th-century China, and that hasnt changed in the 21st. The Great Wall road may never have materialized, but plenty of others are being carved through the countryside to accommodate what Hessler calls the largest migration in human history, with nearly one-tenth of the nations billion-plus people moving from rural areas to cities and factory zones. Despite its late entry into the car culture, China aims within the next decade to have more highway miles than the United States. And almost everybody on the road will be a rookie driver.

title: Tracking the Toyota Investigation
When the Language of Diplomacy Includes Kapow!
description: Formosa Betrayed, set mostly in Taiwan (but filmed in Thailand) in 1983, has dual agendas that collide more readily than they mesh. Focusing on an F.B.I. investigation into the murder of Henry Wen (Joseph Forunda), a Taiwanese economics professor in Chicago, the film is partly a tutorial on the tense relations among Taiwan (the island of Formosa), the Chinese mainland and the United States, and partly a clumsy cloak-and-dagger political thriller.

title: Now Playing | Attila at the Met
description: Whats big, bad and draped in a black Prada overcoat? Think less the Matrix and more the early Middle Ages. Attila, aka Attila the Hun, one of the most fearsome rulers in history, is the central character in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera. True to the fate of a grand Italian operatic divo, Attila is depicted not so much as a brute barbarian as a man with a soft spot for women and dashing attire. Whether or not youre a stickler for period costumes and a strict interpretation of history, this devil looks great in Prada.

title: Video: The Health Care Session in 4 Minutes
description: Didnt make it through all six hours of the health care session at Blair House? Here are the highlights in video.

title: M.L.S. Negotiations at an Impasse
description: Major League Soccer and its players union appeared unlikely to reach a new labor agreement before the current deal expired at midnight Thursday, raising the possibility of a strike.

title: Beyond the Jimi Hendrix Experience
description: THIS year marks the 40th anniversary of the death of Jimi Hendrix, and, predictably, that event will be commemorated with the release of a new CD, the freshening up of his classic titles, a tribute tour and the makers of the video game Rock Band say they are currently in discussion to bring more of his music to our platform. He will be a hard figure to avoid, as viewers of the Super Bowl who heard his song Fire on a commercial promoting Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains have already learned.

title: Julianne of the Spirits
description: In  A Single Man,  you play Charlotte, a wealthy, aging English glamour girl who is attached to, and may be in love with, her gay best friend, George. Their complicated relationship is one of the centerpieces of Tom Fords movie, which chronicles a day in the life of a grieving professor in 60s Los Angeles. Your character is reminiscent of Ann-Margret in  Carnal Knowledge   did that influence you?

title: The Day the Music Died
description: Rock n roll is old. The music of youth and sex and rebellion, the sound that would never die, has now entered its seventh decade, and the business that has sustained it is limping and shrunken. Its had a good long run, which means that its story can finally be told as a proper epic, from birth to death.

title: Obama Gives Cheney a Call
description: Updated: President Obama called former Vice President Dick Cheney at home to wish him a speedy recovery from his latest heart attack, a rare truce in the fiery, arms-length debate the two have been having about national security over the last year.

title: On a High School Lacrosse Team, Opposites Attract and Attack
description: If Toe to Toe were a young-adult novel, it would be embraced and argued about in classrooms and eagerly read by thoughtful teenage girls. The films observations about race, class and friendship are clear and accessible without being overly didactic, and its sometimes harsh candor about female sexuality would not be unfamiliar to devotees of contemporary adolescent literature. But because it is a movie  the first nondocumentary feature film by the writer and director Emily Abt  Toe to Toe is likely to languish in art-house limbo, far from the eyes of its ideal audience.

title: Take Five: Singing Annie Tunes and Taking in Orchids
description: Wondering what to do this weekend? We have you covered:

title: Nightmare on Easy Street
description: The best American writing has always been regional, Flannery OConnor said  but what counts as a region, anyway? California, perhaps alone among the states, is big enough and misunderstood enough to qualify. Easily dismissed for its most hackneyed attributes  its frivolity, its celebrities  it is damned as the cauldron where all that is ephemeral and crass in the culture is brewed. But the heart of the California experience is a wild, touching and unruly thing, as polymorphic and perverse as the states ever diversifying population. In his first novel, Model Home, Eric Puchner cannily trades on the very characteristics that have come to define a recognizable California experience in order to blast them apart, revealing the uncertainty and terror beneath the glossy postcard version we cling to and dismiss.

title: Wal-Mart Unveils Plan to Make Supply Chain Greener
description: Wal-Mart, the nations largest retailer, announced on Thursday that it would cut some 20 million metric tons of greenhouse gas emissions from its supply chain by the end of 2015  the equivalent of removing more than 3.8 million cars from the road for a year.

title: Murder by the Drop
description: At the beginning of Deborah Blums Poisoners Handbook, a murderer named Frederic Mors gets off virtually scot-free after confessing to multiple killings by poison, then disappears without a trace. Though Blum leaves the reader with the impression that Mors  whose adopted surname means death in Latin  will return, she never comes back to his story. But death moves throughout her latest book via myriad poisons administered by impatient heirs, unhappy spouses and psychopaths  or innocently ingested, because the science of forensic toxicology has not yet caught up with these deadly chemicals.

title: Canadian Authorities Detain U.S. Bobsledder
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  A United States Olympic bobsledder was detained and released by the Canadian authorities late Wednesday, according to the U.S. Bobsled and Skeleton Federation chief executive Darrin Steele.

title: What Were Reading: Patents, E-Books and Spy Software
description: Thursdays highlights from our What Were Reading feature, in which New York Times technology journalists point out interesting articles they have spotted on the Web:

title: Nina Simone, Diva Out of Carolina
description: I will never be your clown, Nina Simone shouted at a restless nightclub audience in Cannes in 1977. The mostly French-speaking crowd was either unable or unwilling to join her in a singalong, and she took it as a personal affront. God gave me this gift  and I am a genius. I worked at my craft for six to 14 hours a day, I studied and learned through practice. I am not here just to entertain you. But how can I be alive when you are so dead? Her speech only prompted more requests for her to SING! She managed to get through some songs before delivering her parting words. You owe me, she railed. I dont wear a painted smile on my face, like Louis Armstrong.

title: Three Loners on a Road Leading to One Another
description: The adage that you cant make a silk purse out of a sows ear certainly applies as much to actors and the roles they inhabit as it does to the materials used in making accessories. In The Yellow Handkerchief, the gifted William Hurt, who specializes in playing high-strung, upscale neurotics, brings his formidable skills to the character of Brett, an itinerant oil rigger with a criminal record who, as the story begins, is released from a Louisiana prison after serving six years for manslaughter. The circumstances of the crime are only revealed in a flashback late in the film.

title: Its Spring, and All Is Right With Perez
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Perez threw live batting practice for the first time and elicited raves from Jerry Manuel, who said the reports he received from the coaches were exceptional.

title: Subcontinental Tour
description: In recent years, many travel books have languished in the doldrums. There are exceptions, of course  by well-established adventurers like Jonathan Raban, Pico Iyer and Paul Theroux. Its interesting, though, to note that even their travel books have tended to evolve into other things  histories, recollections, investigations  rather than linear journeys traced on a map. Back in the mid-1970s, Theroux contributed to the resurgence of travel writing with The Great Railway Bazaar, lifting a flagging genre out of its isolated niche and giving it a nagging, tangy voice that sent it wandering through a weird variety of human experiences. But in recent years his most successful excursions have been fictional.

title: A Horror Show
description: The problem with The Crazies? Not crazy enough.

title: Middle of the Journey
description: Dani Shapiro has a problem: Things are going really well. After two failed marriages, she has a husband she adores. Her son, who suffered from a rare and life-threatening seizure disorder, is fine at 10, saved by early medical intervention and his parents unstinting care. She has the acclaim shes sought for years, a Connecticut home straight out of a Nancy Meyers movie and, in her mid-40s, a delicate, undiminished beauty.

title: Dimon Decries Washingtons Treatment of Banks
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, says he believes Washington has become increasingly erratic and unfair in its treatment of the banks over the last few months, and he now has some regrets about participating in the governments Troubled Asset Relief Program.

title: Family Dynamics
description: Leaping from Helena, Mont., to Split, Croatia  by way of Old Hollywood  Kimberly Reeds compelling documentary, Prodigal Sons, is filled with revelations.

title: Pakistani Newspaper Attributes Mystical Powers to Diplomat
description: In advance of talks in New Delhi on Thursday between Indian Foreign Secretary Nirupama Rao and her Pakistani counterpart, Salman Bashir  which touched on a number of sensitive issues  a Pakistani newspaper suggested that Mr. Bashirs delegation included a secret weapon: a diplomat who can read the faces of people and predict what they are actually thinking and feeling  an art known as physiognomy.

title: Children of Exile
description: Peter Akintis first novel, Forest Gate, is about broken bodies and a broken country. Titled after a deprived district in East London, the novel begins with a double suicide attempt: a hanging that leaves a young Somalian refugee dead and his British friend James still alive, collared with bruising, his trachea embedded with rope.

title: Telecom Italia Delays Results Because of Money-Laundering Scandal
description: ROME  Telecom Italia has delayed the release of its 2009 results after the authorities seized 300 million euros from its Sparkle subsidiary in connection with a money-laundering scandal that has rocked the Italian business establishment.

title: The Bluest Eye
description: Theres a reason many great social justice novels are written as historical fiction or contain elements of fantasy or allegory: This builds a certain crucial distance into their storytelling. Heidi W. Durrow is the daughter of an African-American serviceman and a white Danish mother, and her first novel was, according to her publisher, inspired by true events. On the face of it, the story of a biracial girl growing up in 1980s America, grappling with confusion over both her identity and a complicated, mysterious family history, couldnt be more timely or important. But in the moments when Durrows novel seems to tackle its big themes most self-consciously  when it appears written for the Age of Obama  it can be predictable, even dull. Its when it approaches the questions of identity and community more subtly and indirectly that The Girl Who Fell From the Sky can actually fly.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Narrows Loss and Adds to Bonuses
description: LONDON  Royal Bank of Scotland, which is majority-owned by the British government as a result of a 2008 bailout, said on Thursday that it had set aside more money to pay bonuses to its investment banking staff after reducing its loss last year.

title: Mexican Drug Kingpin Sentenced to 25 Years in Secret Hearing
description: HOUSTON  One of the most brutal and feared drug kingpins in Mexican history was sentenced this week to 25 years in prison during a highly secretive hearing here that was closed to the public to protect the lives of everyone involved, according to a court transcript unsealed Thursday.

title: U.S. Finishes 1-2 in Nordic Combined
description: Despite exceptionally poor weather, Bill Demong and Johnny Spillane gave the United States first- and second-place finishes in the mens long-hill, 10-kilometer Nordic combined event Thursday.

title: Op-Chart: On the Timing and Duration of Sleep
description: To introduce All-Nighters, a new series that examines our sleeping habits and troubles, Ben Schott gathers proverbs and data about our nocturnal life.

title: Under Fire, Administrator Defends NASAs New Direction
description: WASHINGTON  Maj. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, faced skeptical, sometimes hostile questioning on Thursday from members of a key House committee who said they opposed the Obama administrations plans to revamp the nations human spaceflight program.

title: High-Wire Act
description: When Allan Kaprow wrote, in his 1966 guidelines for happenings, that the line between art and life should be kept as fluid, and perhaps indistinct, as possible, he could not in his wildest dreams have predicted James Franco. Last year, the Spider-Man star appeared on General Hospital in the role of an artist named Franco. Then he unmasked the character as a piece of performance art and announced that the fictional Franco would exhibit at the real Deitch Projects.

title: Wal-Marts Green Mandate to Suppliers
description: Wal-Mart has announced an initiative that aims to achieve major reductions in greenhouse-gas emissions from its supply chain. As Stephanie Rosenbloom reports for The New York Times, the company said it would cut 20 million metric tons of emissions by the end of 2015 by focusing on popular product categories with the highest embedded carbon  milk, bread, meat, clothing. It said it would lean on its suppliers to rethink the sources, manufacturing processes, packaging and transportation of their goods.

title: Sam Sullivan, Ambassador to the Paralympics
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Sam Sullivan, the former mayor of Vancouver, who twirled and waved the Olympic flag from his wheelchair at the 2006 Turin Games, will serve as Canadas ambassador for the Paralympics.

title: California Education: Tallying Cuts and Costs
description: A new round of rallies are planned for next week to protest the budget cuts in higher education and the resulting layoffs, furloughs and fee increases. Here are some numbers  from state and nonprofit sources  that describe education in public schools and colleges.

title: Red Hottie
description: There are people who expect me to have a Chanel breast pump, said Dasha Zhukova last December as she emerged from a suite at the Chateau Marmont hotel in Los Angeles, where she had been nursing her two-week-old son. For the record, I dont, but there are definitely some bizarre preconceptions about me out there.

title: Familiar Turn After Acquittal of Officers
description: Predicting what a jury might do is always risky, but its pretty easy to guess what will happen once the verdict is in: The winners will glow about the criminal justice systems being a gem, and the losers will glower that its a sham.

title: Analysis: Kim Yu-na Triumphant in Long Program
description: Todd Eldredge, the three-time Olympian, provides analysis from his home in Florida, and the Times reporter John Branch is sending updates from Vancouver. Joanne C. Gerstner and Lynn Zinser contributed insight as well.

title: Coke Adopts a Move It Scorned
description: The chief executive of Coca-Cola, Muhtar Kent, threw cold water on its archrival PepsiCos decision to acquire its bottling subsidiary last year. So it came as some surprise this week to see Coke copying the transaction, with a takeover bid of about $13 billion announced for Coca-Cola Enterprises North American bottling operations.

title: Democrat Seeks Part of Spotlight in Florida Senate Race
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Representative Kendrick B. Meek, the leading Democratic candidate for Floridas open Senate seat, listened quietly last week to tales of woe: a college student who nearly ended up homeless because her mother had lost her job; a laid-off mother who paid for health care with credit cards; an electrician struggling to get unemployment benefits.

title: A Thousand and One Sleepless Nights
description: In Ernest Hemingways short story Now I Lay Me, Nick Adams, the writers alter ego, stays up at night listening to the silk worms feeding on mulberry leaves outside his army tent in Italy. During World War I, Hemingway had himself developed insomnia so severe that he was afraid to go to bed with the lights out. And he struggled with sleeplessness the whole rest of his life, although this issue was often hard to separate from his other ailments  including severe depression, chronic alcoholism and diabetes. I myself did not want to sleep, he writes, because I had been living for a long time with the knowledge that if I ever shut my eyes in the dark and let myself go, my soul would go out of my body.

title: Coke Confirms Purchase of a Bottling Unit
description: The Coca-Cola Company confirmed on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the North American operations of its largest bottler.

title: Despite Pressure, China Still Resists Iran Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  Despite intense public and private pressure by the Obama administration, China has not yet shown any sign that it will support tougher sanctions against Iran, leaving a stubborn barrier before President Obamas efforts to constrain Irans nuclear ambitions.

title: Two Worlds of Sliding Sports, for the Haves and the Have-Nots
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Felix Loch took his first luge run as a 5-year-old and now trains year-round at one of Germanys four world-class tracks with his father, Norbert, the Olympic luge coach. Loch, 20, won the Olympic gold medal in mens singles last week.

title: California Deputy Is Killed in Gun Battle
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A California sheriffs deputy was fatally shot and two other officers were wounded Thursday morning when a fire investigation in rural Fresno County turned into a gun battle and standoff between law-enforcement authorities and an unidentified suspect.

title: Intentions of Whale in Killing Are Debated
description: MIAMI  Homicide investigators in Orlando said Thursday that the death of a trainer at SeaWorld on Wednesday occurred when the theme parks largest male Orca whale grabbed the trainer by her hair while she stood in shallow water, and dragged her into a deep pool.

title: Inquiry Poses a Quandary for Cuomo
description: It had to have been one of the more awkward phone calls that either man had ever experienced.

title: On Wall Street, Romancing the (Curling) Stone
description: Wall Street trading is often described as a blood sport. But inside the great investment houses, the sport of the moment is, of all things, curling  that oddball of the Olympics that is sort of like shuffleboard on ice.

title: U.S. Weighs Requiring Lenders to Consider Changes Before Foreclosures
description: The Obama administration, under intense pressure to help millions of people in danger of losing their homes, is considering a ban on foreclosures unless they have first been examined for potential modification, according to a set of draft proposals.

title: Phoebe Philos Third Act
description: It wasnt the best way to start the day. When I was leaving the house this morning, my husband saw what I was wearing and said, What do you think youre doing, you complete freak?  recalls Phoebe Philo with a laugh. He said that skinny jeans, a sweatshirt, a Crombie coat and loafers are the uniform of the British National Party. And he has a point.

title: Hey, Look! Shes Naked! But Its Art, So Its All Right.
description: One after the next, they trudged through the horizontal-blowing snow on Thursday, most focusing more on the icy sidewalk than on the body of a naked woman, who stood in a gallery window in Greenwich Village.

title: Paterson's Appearance in New York
description: Following allegations against one of his aides, Gov. David A. Paterson, held a brief news conference on Thursday.

title: Preparing Side by Side to Bolster U.S. Hockey Teams
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  What do Angela Ruggiero and Chris Drury have in common?

title: Disabled Man Assaulted at Hospital, Police Say
description: A custodian in Kings County Hospital Centers psychiatric unit, which was recently placed under federal monitoring after a series of troubling incidents, was arrested on Thursday on charges of sexually assaulting a deaf, mute and mentally disabled patient.

title: Mets Lineup Takes Shape
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Each day Jerry Manuel gives more indications of how he would like his batting order to shape up. Thursday he said he wants Daniel Murphy to bat sixth, which means Jeff Francoeur would bat seventh, and the catcher eighth. Using Murphy there helps split up the right-handed bats.

title: Anticipating Hockey Victory, With Excitement and Dread
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Of the 86 gold medals being awarded at the Winter Olympics, none are as anticipated here as the final one.

title: Paterson Weighs Race as Top Aide Quits in Protest
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Patersons administration on Thursday faced new revelations about its intervention in a domestic violence episode involving a chief aide, and growing dismay among fellow Democrats about the governors political future.

title: Radiation Bills Raise Question of Supervision
description: MELBOURNE, Fla.  To help ensure that medical radiation is safe, Medicare insists that certain highly technical cancer treatments be administered only when a patients radiation oncologist is present or nearby.

title: Rodriguez Stands Alone, and Thats a Good Thing
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Housing Dispute in Jerusalem
description: An offer of new housing from the mayor of Jerusalem to a group of Palestinian families is stirring disagreements over matters of ownership and the demographics.

title: Canadian Women Take Gold in Hockey Final
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In the gold medal game on Thursday, the Canadian and American womens hockey teams finally found worthy opponents: each other. But in the end, one woman made the biggest difference.

title: Merrill Lynch Guaranteed Ford Annual Pay of at Least $2 Million
description: As he flirts with a challenge to Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the Democratic primary, Harold E. Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, has been dogged by questions about his compensation on Wall Street, a sensitive issue because of taxpayer-financed bailouts of big banks during the financial crisis.

title: Concert for Tibet
description: "The Tibetans are like the Na'vi," Robert A. F. Thurman, a professor of Indo-Tibetan studies at Columbia University who helped found Tibet House, said recently in an interview. "They're hanging in there. Maybe not fighting with bows and arrows, but they are staying connected to nature, and we think they will prevail." For the past two decades, Mr. Thurman and his organization have hosted concerts, held at Carnegie Hall since 1994, to draw attention to the Tibetans' cause. These celebrity-filled events, Ben Sisario writes, "have developed into an institution of their own, shining a light each year on the urgency of preserving Tibetan culture and offering music fans starry, varied lineups." This year is no different. Tonight, the Tibet House Benefit Concert, which is curated by Philip Glass, will feature performances by Iggy Pop, Patti Smith, Gogol Bordello, Regina Spektor and many more.

title: Whitney Biennial on a Budget
description: It's always a challenge to sift through all the art at the Whitney Biennial, and this year is especially difficult because of a no-frills selection. Thankfully, we have Holland Cotter to point out what to skip and what to see. "The show has dead spots," Mr. Cotter writes, "mainly where it reflects the retrenched art-about-art spirit of the day. But it also has strong work (particularly in video) that speaks of life beyond the art factory." Head to a group of snap-shot-style family photographs by Nina Berman, part of a series Ms. Berman made of American soldiers who returned home wounded from Iraq. "You have to get up close to the pictures to see what's going on. And the shock they generate, due in part to the exploitive vibes they give off, ripples through everything around them." Another set of photographs, by the photojournalist Stephanie Sinclair of women in Afghanistan who immolated themselves to escape punishing marriages, is also a highlight. "Like much painting at present (and if you don't believe there's a ton of it around, just spend an afternoon in Chelsea), the work is clean, cool, classy, retro-modernist, labor-intensive."

title: Swing Goth
description: The ubiquitous posters and trailers for Tim Burton's "Alice in Wonderland" make us want to smear on a lot of white face paint, dark lipstick and take on the Red Queen. Tonight, the party promoters Swing Goth are offering a chance to do so with "Wonderland: A Tim Burton Ball." The dance party at Don Hill's will celebrate "the offbeat and macabre." Seattle's Abney Park will perform and there will also be swing dancing and lessons. Costumes are encouraged.

title: Uniting Democrats Is Challenge at Health Forum
description: WASHINGTON  After more than six hours of extraordinary debate on Thursday over health care policy, President Obama had not won over any of the Republicans, and he seemed to end the day largely where he started, with little choice but to try to rally his Democrats to act on their own.

title: Clearing the Air at American Ports
description: The Teamsters union and environmental activists have formed an unlikely and outspoken alliance aiming to clear the air in American ports, and perhaps bolster the Teamsters ranks in the process.

title: The Paterson Bombshell
description: 4:02 p.m. | Updated  This post has been updated to reflect Gov. David Patersons announcement today that he would end his election campaign.It turned out to be a bombshell after all, the scoop that derailed the political career of Gov. David Paterson of New York.

title: Mets Return and Start to Work Out Their Problems
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It was an unseasonably cold day, with a chilling north wind blowing in over the Mets first full workout Thursday. It was reminiscent of April or October, depending on ones level of optimism.

title: Bringing Groups Together to Revamp an Industry
description: ONE of the best-known slogans from the Mad Men era of advertising was for Certs, which declared itself to be Two, two, two mints in one  a breath mint as well as a candy mint, that is. Decades later, the successors to Don Draper and Roger Sterling are trying to combine two prominent industry conferences into one big event.

title: Parties Jousting With Dire Warnings
description: The Democrats told insurance company horror stories, including a tale of an old woman forced to wear her dead sisters dentures. The Republicans countered with scary metaphor, likening the Democratic health care bill to the ailing auto industry.

title: Missing the Tea Party
description: The real surprise of the Supreme Courts decision in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, which magnified the ability of corporations to spend money in political campaigns, is how widely disliked the ruling is across the ideological spectrum. After more than a month, the storm set off by the Citizens United ruling is still raging.

title: Pepsi Charity Contest Trips Over Its Own Submission Rules
description: Pepsi is planning to give more than $20 million to charities through a contest called Pepsi Refresh, the most ambitious so far among a number of similar contests that have used social networks on the Internet to raise money and recognition for nonprofit groups and social causes.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 993 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: Traction for Banking Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  The prospect of a financial regulatory overhauls passing Congress brightened on Thursday, as representatives of the banking industry left a meeting with the Treasury secretary saying that they had agreed on the need to get a bill through Congress this year.

title: Taking a Gamble
description: When Amitabh Bachchan, Bollywoods perennial Mr. Big, gets a meaty role, he digs into it with such gusto that everyone around him starts to look a bit underfed.

title: C. R. Johnson, X Games Medalist in Free Skiing, Dies at 26
description: C. R. Johnson, an innovative figure in the young professional sport of free skiing and a medal winner in X Games competitions, died Wednesday while skiing on treacherous terrain at Squaw Valley resort in California. He was 26 and lived nearby in Truckee, Calif.

title: Plan to Seek Use of U.S. Contracts as a Wage Lever
description: The Obama administration is planning to use the governments enormous buying power to prod private companies to improve wages and benefits for millions of workers, according to White House officials and several interest groups briefed on the plan.

title: Four South Koreans Detained in North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Friday that it has apprehended four South Koreans, the latest in a series of detentions of foreigners whom the North has charged with illegal entry.

title: 21 Across: Lewis Carrolls Birthplace
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Solving themeless puzzles isnt just a matter of knowing who, what, where, when and why. The ability to see letter patterns and word possibilities, combined with a dash of general knowledge, is often the secret to unlocking answers. Thats the beauty of a crossword  its a test where one often knows more after taking it than before.

title: Bunning Blocks Jobless Aid in Senate
description: 12:06 a.m. | Updated The Senate clash over the unemployment benefits ended just before midnight Thursday with Senator Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky, refusing to lift his objection, meaning the jobless aid  for however short a time  will run out Sunday night unless a deal is reached Friday.

title: Mystical Form of Islam Suits Sufis in Pakistan
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  For those who think Pakistan is all hard-liners, all the time, three activities at an annual festival here may come as a surprise.

title: Yes to Pop-Tarts! Panel Approves Bake-Sale Rules
description: By the time the Panel for Educational Policy was ready to vote on bake sales during its monthly meeting on Wednesday night, it was after 11:30. By then, just one mother, Elizabeth Puccini, was waiting to speak out against the new policy, which bans most bake sales but allows students to sell premade items including Pop-Tarts and Doritos.

title: A Hospital in Harlem Is Studying Its Future
description: Thirty years ago, it was the great hope for the future of health care in Harlem, a new private hospital, opened at a time when public hospitals were seen as failing.

title: Blast Rocks a Prominent Hotel in Afghan Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Several suicide bombers attacked a prominent hotel and the surrounding area in the center of Kabul early Friday, the police said. One of the bombers detonated his vest, according to the police, who were still fighting the attackers 90 minutes later.

title: Bloggingheads: Ron Paul 2012?
description: Matt Welch, left, of Reason and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate Ron Pauls CPAC straw poll victory.

title: How to Protect the Children of Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Admonishes Rangel for Taking Trips as Gifts
description: The House ethics committee said on Thursday that it had admonished Representative Charles B. Rangel for violating Congressional gift rules by accepting corporate-sponsored trips to the Caribbean in 2007 and 2008.

title: Union Election Further Complicates a Tangled City Budget
description: When the ballot counters at Local 1021 of the Service Employees International Union announce the results of the unions bitter leadership election Saturday, the news will be felt keenly in two quarters.

title: Tallying Cuts and Costs
description: More rallies are planned for next week to protest the budget cuts in higher education and the resulting layoffs, furloughs and fee increases. Here are some numbers  from state and nonprofit sources  that describe education in public schools and colleges.

title: Hurricane but No Gold for Peterson in Aerials
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Jeret Peterson came here to attempt the Hurricane, a daring, innovative, borderline foolish mens aerials maneuver. No one in the world except Peterson can land it. No one else has tried.

title: Paterson Gets Some Sobering Advice on His Political Future
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson said Thursday night that as he weighed his political future, he was seeking counsel from elected officials across the state. But the first few hours of that listening effort offered some sobering advice.

title: Coming to Terms With a Street Food Boom
description: Sevilla Granger swerved her black Volvo station wagon into a parking lot near the San Francisco Design Center and ran over to Liba, a falafel truck. It was 1:57 p.m. Liba closes at 2.

title: After the Summit
description: The main lesson to draw from Thursdays health care forum is that differences between Democrats and Republicans are too profound to be bridged. That means that it is up to the Democrats to fix the countrys dysfunctional and hugely costly health care system.

title: Gov. Paterson Faces Reality
description: It has been clear for many months that Gov. David Paterson should not try persuade New Yorkers to elect him to a job he never really wanted, got only because his predecessor had to resign over his disgraceful personal behavior and has not done terribly well. Now, Mr. Paterson has reached that conclusion himself and announced Friday that he plans to give up his election campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 19 about the mass graves in Haiti for victims of the Jan. 12 earthquake misstated the average life span in Haiti. It is 61 years, not 44. (The lower figure, according to the World Health Organization, is for a category known as healthy life expectancy, which represents the average number of years that a person can expect to live in full health by taking into account years lived in less than full health because of disease and/or injury.) When the number was questioned shortly after the article was published, editors at The Times determined that a correction was not needed, but reconsidered after additional reporting.

title: The Voters Will Pay
description: It was bad news for the voting public when Election Systems and Software, the nations largest voting machine company, announced last fall that it was acquiring the elections division of Diebold, the nations second-largest voting machine company.

title: Goodbye, Hummer
description: The world might be saved: It looks as if the Hummer is destined for the junkyard. The plan by General Motors to sell the muscular brand to a Chinese company went up in a puff of exhaust smoke on Wednesday after government officials in China said that they had never received the necessary application for approval and thus couldnt grant it.

title: Finding the Recipe for a Successful School
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: On Your Public Radio Dial: Serious Offerings
description: To the Editor:

title: Afflicting the Afflicted
description: If were lucky, Thursdays summit will turn out to have been the last act in the great health reform debate, the prologue to passage of an imperfect but nonetheless history-making bill. If so, the debate will have ended as it began: with Democrats offering moderate plans that draw heavily on past Republican ideas, and Republicans responding with slander and misdirection.

title: Not as Dull as Expected!
description: Going in, I was as cynical as everybody else about the Blair House health care forum. I was planning to watch for a half-hour and then write about something else.

title: Talking-Cure Diplomacy
description: Tel Aviv

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Our Towns column on Thursday, about the Nutmeg Curling Club in Bridgeport, Conn., which is drawing new interest because of the Olympics, misidentified the location of a New Jersey club. The club, the Plainfield Curling Club, is in South Plainfield, not Plainfield.

title: 2 Bite-Size Eateries Too Popular for Their Neighbors Good
description: It is the sandwich that ate the neighborhood.

title: Lottery Numbers
Robert J. Myers, Actuary Who Shaped Social Security Program, Dies at 97
description: Robert J. Myers, an actuary who helped to create the Social Security program and to set Americas official retirement age at 65, died Feb. 13 at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 97.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in some editions last Friday about sluggish sales at some developments participating in the citys affordable-housing program misidentified the location of Waters Edge at Arverne, a project in Queens that is offering free 42-inch, flat-screen television sets to lure condominium buyers. It is in Arverne, not Far Rockaway. (Both communities are part of the Rockaways.)

title: Man Is Killed in Central Park by the Falling Branch of a Snow-Laden Tree
description: A 46-year-old man was killed on Thursday as he was walking through Central Park when a large tree branch, weighed down by snow, snapped off and struck him, the police said.

title: New Wrinkle in Old Hitting Drill
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  This year the 80-pitch opposite field batting practice drill has been modified a bit. Now its 40 pitches off a curveball machine, and the players are asked to hit to all fields.

title: Kermit Tyler, Player of a Fateful, if Minor, Role in Pearl Harbor Attack, Dies at 96
description: They were only four words, but they made him a footnote figure in a catastrophic day for America and shadowed him the rest of his long life: Dont worry about it.

title: Corrections
description: The DealBook column on Tuesday, about the sale of the Duane Reade drugstore chain, misstated the location of the first store. It was on Broadway between Duane and Reade Streets  not on the corner of Duane and Reade, which run parallel. The column also gave an incomplete name for the private equity firm that took the chain private in 2004 and misidentified the location of that firm. It is Oak Hill Capital Partners, not Oak Hill Partners, and it is based in New York, not Chicago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Coca-Cola Companys negotiations to buy the North American operations of its largest bottler misstated the number of years that the company has kept its bottling operations and soft drink business separate. It has been a 24-year-old strategy, not a 14-year-old one.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the first run of the womens giant slalom at the Vancouver Games on Wednesday misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the races referee. He is Atle Skaardal, not Arle.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 18 about the singer and songwriter Dale Hawkins referred incorrectly to Kicks, the publication for which he discussed the creation of his song Susie Q. It was a magazine, not a newsletter.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: For U.S. Speedskater, a Bumpy Path Back to Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Of all the places in the world, Simon Chos speedskating ambitions led him here. He finds that amusing and symmetrical, because those ambitions started here, too, 14 years ago in a muddy field.

title: Nancy Sweezy, Savior of Jugtown Pottery, Dies at 88
description: In the rolling Piedmont hills of North Carolina, potters were turning out fine work before the American Revolution. But by the 20th century, the tradition had faltered. Two passionate women, a half-century apart, saved it.

title: Showcase: Empty, but Occupied
description: In the stillness of empty buildings, Magda Biernat finds human traces. While cropping out location and context, she looks for the soul in the modern built environment.

title: M.L.S. Labor Talks Hit an Impasse
description: Major League Soccer and its players union appeared unlikely to reach a labor agreement before the current deal expired at midnight Thursday, raising the possibility of a strike. The two sides vowed to keep talking, and the league said it would not lock out the players if a collective bargaining agreement was not reached before the season opened March 25.

title: Prices Rise for Cubs, but Loyalty Wins Out
description: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Looking to Taxes as Solution to a Crisis
description: With a fiscal crisis looming in Illinois, some influential people concerned about the dismal condition of the states finances are proposing that lawmakers increase the individual income tax rate by two-thirds and the corporate rate by one-third.

title: As Fighting Eases, Afghans Plant Flag and Their Hopes in Marja
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  The black, red and green flag of Afghanistan was hoisted over the center of this onetime Taliban stronghold on Thursday, as Afghan officials symbolically claimed control after a major American-led military offensive.

title: Word of the Day | plasticity
description: plasticity \pla-sti-s-te\ noun

title: After a String of Political Victories, a Union Has Clout to Spare
description: As the debate intensifies over what to do about Springfields $13 billion budget deficit, a powerful labor union has given Gov. Patrick J. Quinn another big number to take into account: $1.7 million.

title: Now at Northwestern, Ethics 101, Taught by, Well, Go Figure
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Pakistan Agrees in Principle to Hand Over Taliban Deputy to Afghans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan officials said Thursday that Pakistans Interior Ministry had agreed in principle to hand over the No. 2 Taliban leader, Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, whom the Pakistani intelligence services captured in Karachi in January.

title: North Korean Military Parts Were Intercepted, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  Two shipping containers loaded at a Chinese port and bound on a ship for the Congo Republic carrying what the manifest called bulldozers were found to be transporting North Korean tank parts and other military equipment in violation of international sanctions, diplomats at the United Nations said Thursday.

title: Kim Yu-na Wins Gold in Figure Skating
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia - After months of playing it cool, saying the pressure to win the Olympic gold medal had not weighed on her, Kim Yu-na of South Korea finally let her emotion show on Thursday.

title: Iran Leader Concedes No Ground to Rivals
description: Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, dismissed the possibility of compromise with opposition leaders on Thursday, saying in harsh language that they had no right to participate in politics, the official IRNA news agency reported.

title: The Tempest
description: Scenes from Sam Mendess production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Feb. 25
description: As the games enter their final days, there was plenty of drama on the snow and ice in Vancouver.

title: News Quiz | February 26, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed essay on Thursday, about the decline of nations, misidentified the source of the observation that Britain had lost an empire without finding a role. It was Dean Acheson, not Adlai Stevenson.

title: Guesthouses Used by Foreigners in Kabul Hit in Deadly Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A complex suicide and car-bomb attack in the heart of Kabul on Friday showed the continued ability of the Taliban to stage sophisticated operations in the heavily guarded capital, with the aim of undermining international support for the Afghan war.

title: A Toast to Hockey Gold, but at What Cost?
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  For nearly two weeks, the Canadian womens hockey team had been on the outside looking in as inebriated fans spilled out of the bars and restaurants here like so much beer out of a keg.

title: Golden Night for South Korea's Kim
description: After months of playing it cool, South Korea's Kim Yu-na finally let her emotions show after her program.

title: Traction for Banking Regulation
