description: The prospect of a financial regulatory overhauls passing Congress brightened on Thursday, as representatives of the banking industry left a meeting with the Treasury secretary saying that they had agreed on the need to get a bill through Congress this year, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

title: As Kim Raises the Bar, South Korea Delights
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Dressed in azure, accompanied by Gershwin, Kim Yu-na of South Korea seemingly floated to the clouds with her soaring jumps and airy elegance Thursday night, winning an Olympic gold medal and her rightful place as one of the greatest womens figure skaters of any era.

title: Labor Fights Impact on Budget Fight, and Other Highlights From Fridays Bay Area Report
description: One Tough Fight Deserves Another | The results of the sharp-edged election within Local 1021 of the Service Employees International Union will be announced on Saturday. But the backdrop of this fight is less the personality-driven politics of that local union than the impact that that rough contest will have on an even rougher one: the negotiations over San Franciscos budget for the next fiscal year. Gerry Shihs article in Fridays Bay Area Report explores the links between the two bitter and intractable fights, explaining how each exacerbates the other. The trend lines laid out by city economists describe a government with a shrinking capacity to deliver vital services or to underwrite new initiatives, particularly if pension obligations keep expanding. And then there is the $522 million deficit for the coming fiscal year.This is the toughest year that anyone has seen in recent history, said David Chiu, the president of the Board of Supervisors, in large part because last year we cut to the bone, and this year, were cutting bone.

title: In Tax Law, Overdue Overhaul Is Just One Step
description: Senators are cooperating on a bipartisan effort to overhaul the tax code as the need to pass a new bill grows more urgent, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.

title: MoneyGram Pays $80 Million to Settle Suit
description: MoneyGram International, the payment services provider, said on Thursday that it had agreed to settle a federal lawsuit filed by investors for $80 million.

title: Oyster Patrol on the Arcachon Bay
description: As thefts climb in the region, French gendarmes have stepped up surveillance to protect the diminished 2010 crop of oysters.

title: Broke, Homeless and Now a Culinary Star
description: When Ike Shehadeh opened his eponymous sandwich shop on Oct. 31, 2007, he was prepared to be overwhelmed with customers. After all, it was Halloween night in San Franciscos Castro neighborhood  an event that traditionally attracted hundreds of thousands.

title: A Day at the Round Table
description: WHO called the Democrats health proposal a dangerous experiment? WHO said that Democrats and Republicans are not really that far apart on health care reform?

title: Who Is the Best Teacher You Ever Had? Why?
description: Many are convinced that what matters most in making schools successfulmore than class size or curriculum is excellent teaching. Do you agree? Who is the best teacher youve ever had, and what made him or her so memorable and effective?

title: Schott Op-Chart: On the Timing & Duration of Sleep
description: A collection of proverbs, advice and facts to introduce All-Nighters  a new Opinionator series that explores the habits and troubles of sleep.

title: China Said to Run Currency Stress Tests for Exporters
description: China is conducting stress tests in the countrys labor-intensive export sectors to see how much appreciation in the renminbi the firms can withstand, Reuters reported, citing an article in the Chinese daily 21st Century Business Herald.

title: Mog.com Gets $10 Million in Financing, Report Says
description: Mog.com, a subscription-based music service, has landed around $10 million in a round co-led by a previous backer, Menlo Ventures, and a new investor, Balderton Capital, PaidContent reported, citing sources.

title: Fortress Assets Shrink
description: The Fortress Investment Group, one of the worlds largest publicly traded alternative asset managers, said its assets under management shrank by almost 1 percent during the fourth quarter as client redemptions totaled more than $1 billion.

title: Greek Debt and U.S. Job Sector Weigh on Investors
description: A tense day for Wall Street ended with a tinge of hope, as a rise in commodity prices helped temper anxiety about Greek debt and the American jobs market.

title: White Birch Paper Files for Bankruptcy
description: The newsprint manufacturer White Birch Paper Company has filed for bankruptcy protection, citing declining demand for newspapers and the strength of the Canadian dollar, The Associated Press reported.

title: Sirius XM Posts Profit, Its First Since Merger
description: Sirius XM Radio, the satellite radio company, posted its first quarterly profit since its merger and said it expected to add 500,000 new subscribers in 2010 as the recovery in the car market increased demand.

title: Coke Adopts a Move It Scorned
description: The chief executive of Coca-Cola, Muhtar Kent, threw cold water on its archrival PepsiCos decision to acquire its bottling subsidiary last year. So it came as some surprise this week to see Coke copying the transaction, with a takeover bid of about $13 billion announced for Coca-Cola Enterprises North American bottling operations, Reuters Breakingviews says.

title: At Merrill Lynch, Harold Ford Received at Least $2 Million
description: As he flirts with a challenge to Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in the Democratic primary, Harold E. Ford Jr., the former congressman from Tennessee, has been dogged by questions about his compensation on Wall Street, a sensitive issue because of taxpayer-financed bailouts of big banks during the financial crisis.

title: Mengagement Rings
description: Engagement rings for men.

title: A Sport With Delusions of Grandeur
description: Figure skaters and judges increasingly seem more focused on the sports technical aspects at the expense of its lyrical qualities.

title: A Glimpse Into the Heart of SAC Capital
description: Steven A. Cohen, who runs the $12 billion hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, usually doesnt have much to do with investors, let alone journalists, but he gave Bloomberg Markets magazine rare access for a profile coming out in the publications April issue.

title: Judge Fines Ex-Chief of Kmart $10 Million
description: A federal judge ordered a former chief executive of the Kmart Corporation, Charles Conaway, to pay more than $10 million for misleading shareholders about the retailers prospects before its 2002 bankruptcy.

title: 100 Years Later, Revisiting a Paris Flood
description: One hundred years after a major flood swept through Paris, temporarily transforming the city and causing widespread damage, two exhibitions take a look back at the extraordinary event. After months of unusually wet weather in 1909, January 1910 brought even heavier rainfall that, combined with faulty engineering, swelled the waters of the Seine. The river eventually rose to 26 feet above normal levels, flooding the streets and squares of central Paris. For a time, Paris looked more like Venice: famous boulevards turned into canals, and boats replaced the flooded Mtro tunnels as the preferred mode of transportation. This novel and strangely beautiful urban landscape drew the attention of artists and photographers from around the world.

title: State of the Chargers: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: Whither Wall Streets Banished?
description: From moviemaking to architecture, the shamed and banished chief executives of the 2008 credit crisis have opted for some unusual career paths, either by choice or necessity, Reuters writes.

title: Harrahs Moves to 4th-Quarter Profit
description: Harrahs Entertainment, the casino company run by two private equity firms, moved to a profit in the fourth quarter even as its revenue continued falling, The Associated Press reported.

title: Is Your Mutual Fund a Hedge Fund in Disguise?
description: While many regard hedge funds as a speculative realm of the wealthy, from a strategic standpoint, many of these investing refuges of the rich are more conservative than the average mutual fund, The Associated Press writes.

title: JPMorgans Dimon Wary of Potential Negatives
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief of JPMorgan Chase, said he is in no hurry to raise the banks dividend because of an economy that he warned could still be threatened by a double dip recession, Reuters reported.

title: In Casino Fight, Trump Gets His Day in Court
description: Donald Trump, the celebrity real estate developer hoping for a casino comeback, took the stand in U.S. bankruptcy court on Thursday to fight for control of the three Atlantic City hotel-casinos bearing his name, Reuters reported.

title: Shouting Yoo-Hoo! to the Cosmos
description: Todays idea: Is it time to take a more active approach and systematically advertise our existence to the cosmos? Some searchers for extraterrestrial intelligence say yes. Others suggest its a rash, nave idea.

title: Blackstone Said to Attract Investors for China Fund
description: Blackstone Group has nailed down three commitments so far to its landmark renminbi-denominated fund for China, with the countrys national pension fund expected to be a major investor, Reuters reported.

title: G.M. Said to Revisit Previous Bids for Hummer
description: General Motors is going back to the pool of original bidders for its Hummer unit, after plans to sell the brand to Chinas Sichuan Tengzhong Heavy Industrial Machinery fell through, according to press reports.

title: Lloyds Shrinks Loss in 2009
description: Lloyds Banking Group, Britains largest retail bank, shrank its losses in 2009, despite a 24 billion ($37 billion) hit from loans that soured, mostly assets inherited from last years takeover of rival HBOS, Reuters reported.

title: Stray Questions for: Don Lattin
description: Don Lattin is the author of four nonfiction books, including most recently The Harvard Pschedelic Club.

title: Icesave Talks Break Down, and Referendum Looms
description: The Icelandic Finance Ministry said on Thursday that talks broke down with Britain and the Netherlands over the nearly $6 billion those countries say Reykjavik owes them on deposits lost when Landsbanki collapsed in 2008.

title: Big Hedge Funds Said to Bet Against Euro
description: Apparently, the euro has some hedge-fund heavies on its tail.

title: No School. Honest.
description: Updated 7:52 a.m. | No school. No. School. No school for New York City public school students. This is not a joke.

title: V.C.s: No Longer Brothers in Arms?
description: Some venture capital firms are losing interest in pooling their funds for start-up investments, leading to some messy break-ups, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: A Government Takeover of Health Care?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Madoff Whistle-Blower Slams S.E.C. in New Book
description: Few parties came out clean in the mess that was the Bernard L. Madoff Ponzi scheme  certainly not the regulators who missed multiple chances to stop the financial fraud earlier on.

title: Many Without Power as Storm Pounds Northeast
description: A dangerous winter storm that walloped the Northeast overnight, leaving hundreds of thousands of winter-weary residents without power from New Jersey to Maine and disrupting travel at New York airports, stalled obstinately over the region on Friday.

title: New Fund Rules for Disclosure of Systemic Risks
description: The International Organization of Securities Commissions published on Thursday the data that hedge funds will be required to disclose as of September, The Telegraph reported.

title: Sampler: Taxi Company Balks at Providing Drug Test Results, and the Future of an Orca
description: Telecasting Prop. 8s Closing Arguments May be Back on the Table | Federal judges in the Bay Area are again proposing to allow cameras in the courtroom, which may mean the closing arguments of the lawsuit challenging Californias ban on same-sex marriage will be broadcast beyond the courthouse. As the trial began in January, the United States Supreme Court ruled that the proceedings could not be shown on YouTube. The justices noted that witnesses testifying for same-sex marriage opponents expressed fear of intimidation. The United States District Court in San Francisco has now posted the same proposal to its Web site, allowing judges to take part of a pilot program that would allow telecasting of a nonjury trials proceedings. The closing arguments would not involve any witness appearances. They will be set after the final round of briefs in the case is delivered on Friday. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

title: CKE Restaurants to Sell Itself to THL for $619 Million
description: CKE Restaurants, the owner of fast-food chains like Hardees and Carls Jr., agreed on Friday to sell itself to the private equity firm THL Partners for $619 million in cash as the leveraged buyout industry continues to revive.

title: GMAC I.P.O. at Least a Year Away, Official Says
description: An initial public offering of GMAC Financial Services, the U.S. auto loan company that was bailed out by the government, is probably at least a year away, a senior U.S. Treasury official told the Congressional Oversight Panel Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: Whose Woods These Are I Think I Know
description: Mine, actually, a few minutes ago. I think I could appreciate the beauty a bit more, however, if Robin didnt have to get to NYC, somehow, and it wasnt urgent that I make it over to my parents.

title: Speed Read for Friday, Feb. 26
description: Here are some highlights for a snowy day from Fridays edition of The New York Times:

title: You Know What Would Be Great Right Now?
description: A hot chocolate. That would be awesome, a cup of heat and velvet to counteract this awful snow. And while we dont know about you, we here at Diners Journal would like to have it here at home, since its not as if were going to be mushing our way to Le Pain Quotidien any time soon, and the kids are stuck home from school besides.

title: Financing Package Takes Shape for More 3-D Screens
description: Details of a prospective financing package for the deployment of 14,000 new digital theater screens are beginning to emerge. The long anticipated build-up by the Digital Cinema Implementation Partners  a consortium operated by the AMC, Cinemark and Regal theater chains  will allow theaters to increase the number of 3-D screens beyond the 5,100 total that has been projected by this years end.

title: A.I.G. Posts $8.9 Billion 4th-Quarter Loss
description: The American International Group on Friday reported an $8.9 billion loss for its fourth quarter, an improvement over the staggering $61.7 billion loss it disclosed one year ago after its government-financed rescue.

title: A.I.G. Posts Loss of $11 Billion on Higher Claims
description: The American International Group said on Friday that it lost about $11 billion last year, surprising analysts and showing the long-term risks inherent in the types of large, complex insurance coverage that the company once pioneered.

title: Vain Glorious | Martin Margielas First Fragrance
description: Who: Martin Margiela

title: The Early Word: Post-Summit
description: More than six hours of debate, zero breakthroughs.

title: January Existing Home Sales Drop Despite Tax Credit
description: Existing home sales fell in January, a real estate trade group reported on Friday, suggesting that a government tax credit meant to help prop up the market is having limited success.

title: South African Hotel Industry Expects Vindication on Prices
description: The South African Tourism Ministry has ordered an investigation into allegations that World Cup hotel prices are unreasonably high. But hotel operators and others in the tourism sector expressed confidence on Tuesday that an independent investigation would clear them.

title: Nine to Know: Jeters Milestones
description: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow Chuck on Twitter.

title: Video of Firefight in Afghan Capital
description: As my colleague Alissa Rubin reports from Afghanistan, police officials in Kabul said that at least 18 people, many of them Indian nationals, were killed on Friday in suicide and car bomb attacks on two guesthouses popular with foreigners in the center of the Afghan capital.

title: Batmans First Appearance at a Bruce Wayne Price
description: Despite their long history as super-friends, comic book fans have been known to debate: Who would win in a fight? The all-powerful Superman or the ever-ingenious Batman? This week, we may have gotten the answer.

title: A Brief Guide to an Administration in Crisis
description: Heres a primer on Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: Art Imitating Crash in London
description: The death of J.G. Ballard, the British novelist, last year vaulted him seemingly overnight from a cult taste into the mainstream. The authors bizarre sensibility appears at its most extreme in Crash, the 1973 novel in which its protagonists reenact celebrity car crashes. (One sentence reads: The crushed body of the sports car had turned her into a being of free and perverse sexuality, releasing within its dying chromium and leaking engine-parts, all the deviant possibilities of her sex.)

title: Study Finds Stents Effective in Preventing Strokes
description: Surgery on blocked neck arteries has long been considered the best procedure for preventing a stroke. Now a large North American study has found that a less invasive approach may be just as safe and effective, but other researchers are not so sure.

title: Nudging Schools to Help Students With Learning Disabilities
description: WHEN it comes to special education, Becky McGee and her 19-year-old son, Kyle, feel as if theyve seen it all.

title: Union Square Greenmarket Snowed Out
description: The Union Square Greenmarket is closed today. Driving conditions are too hazardous for the farmers. This happens rarely folks! tweet thefolks at The Council on the Environment of New York City, which runs the market. Apologies all around for those hoping for some warm apple cider, fresh bread and winter squash.

title: Resources for Parents of Students With Learning Disabilities
description: Parents should do their homework so they can contribute to an individualized learning plan for a student with a learning disability.

title: Core Logic
description: Since Im taking a break from shoveling, I thought I might take a few minutes to address an issue that seems to confuse many people: the idea of core inflation. Why do we need such a concept, and how should it be measured?

title: Kias Economic Stimulus Package
description: KIA would never admit it, even if executives in Seoul imbibed too much soju one night. But they have to be thinking that maybe this recession isnt such a bad thing.

title: With a Coupe as Its Curveball, Kia Tosses a Strikeout
description: THE mission, should you choose to accept it: Find a car with good looks and a soupon of sport for less than 20 grand. Preferably, one that doesnt self-destruct.

title: Thai Court Seizes $1.4 Billion From Ex-Premier
description: BANGKOK  Thailands Supreme Court on Friday confiscated $1.4 billion in frozen assets from the nations fugitive former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, after finding him guilty of illegally concealing his ownership of a family company and abusing his power to benefit the companies he owned.

title: The Wired Repo Man: Hes Not As Seen on TV
description: BUSINESSES of every sort have been sucker-punched by the recession, but at least one enterprise has continued to grow through the downturn: auto repossession.

title: Its Entertainment, Folks, and a Long Way From Reality
description: ITS a cartoon, said Rodney Myers, dismissing the portrayal of his profession on television reality shows about repossessing cars.

title: Le Cirque
description: Capelets! fishnet! ruffles! see The Seasons daring fashion dos! Step right up!

title: Italian Flair for Genevas Show
description: WITH the unveiling of new concept cars at the Geneva auto show this week, Pininfarina and other Italian carrozzerie plan to allay some of the concern over the future of the countrys famed design houses.

title: The Dude Plumbs His Weary Soul
description: At some point on the road to screen immortality, Manohla Dargis writes in this Sundays appraisal of Jeff Bridges, that Oscar-nominated actor transformed from an all-American pretty boy with effortless charm to a weathered veteran with bottomless soul.

title: Dissecting the Profits in a Private Equity Deal
description: March 1, 11:41 a.m. | Corrected What are the returns of private equity firms? This is not as easy to answer as you might think.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Strange Visitors From Another Planet
description: The second volume of All-Star Superman lands at No. 3 on our paperback list this week. The All-Star line from DC Comics was conceived as a way for creators to tell stories about Superman and Batman that were free of the years of continuity that come with the characters, and All-Star Superman, written by Grant Morrison and illustrated by Frank Quitely, was embraced as one of the best Superman titles in years. In this volume Superman faces his backward foe Bizarro; meets two survivors from his home planet, Krypton; and deals with his own mortality.

title: An Attack on Foreigners in Kabul
description: Suicide and car bomb attacks on two guesthouses in the center of Kabul, Afghanistan, appeared to focus on foreigners.

title: Move Your Body, Power Your Cellphone
description: It may not seem like it, but even the laziest of couch potatoes is a human dynamo. The act of breathing  of moving the ribs to draw air into the lungs and expel it  can generate about a watt of power. And if the potato actually gets up off the couch and walks briskly across the room, each heel strike can produce even more power, about 70 watts worth.

title: If This Be Victory
description: Via Edward Hugh, The Economist is portraying Latvia as a success story. Hey, the peg against the euro is still holding, and further debt downgrades are on hold.

title: Bits Scan: Facebooks Patent, Nokias Woes and Phishing on Twitter
description: Facebook Granted Patent on the News FeedAs we noted Thursday, Facebook has been granted a patent for the its central feature, the news feed. ReadWriteWeb spotlights the discussion in the blogosphere on the topic, with many questioning if Facebook actually invented the algorithm-driven newsfeed. Bloggers also ask if the company will enforce its patent against other services, including Google Reader and Google Buzz, or if the move is just defensive.

title: Hello, Jerry: Seinfeld Returns to Television With The Marriage Ref
description: Twelve years ago Jerry Seinfeld walked away from his wildly successful NBC sitcom, never planning to be back on television regularly again. Then he got married and had kids, had an argument with his wife that inspired a new series, yada yada yada  he returns to NBC this weekend. Sort of.

title: The Week Ahead | Feb. 28  March 6
description: Dance

title: Q.& A. With K.H.L. President Alexander Medvedev
description: K.H.L. President Alexander Medvedev was not in the happiest mood when he met with a small group of reporters on Thursday, one day after Canada trounced Russia, 7-3, and eliminated the Russians from the Vancouver Olympics at the quarterfinal stage.

title: A Week Where Juries Took Center Stage
description: It has been a crazy week and a half for juries in New York.

title: Citi to Reshape Its Board as 3 Directors Stand Down
description: Citigroup on Friday said it planned to reshape its board, nominating the former Mexican president Ernesto Zedillo as a director as three others declined to seek re-election.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Spring Theater listings last Sunday misidentified the role that Al Pacino played in the movie The Merchant of Venice and is reprising in a theatrical production being presented as part of the Public Theaters Shakespeare in the Park season. He is reprising the role of Shylock, the moneylender  not Antonio, the title character of the play.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The Evolution of Depression
description: According to evolutionary theory, nature selects for those heritable traits that make us more likely to survive and reproduce. So how, then, does one explain the widespread prevalence of depression?

title: Revivals: A Plea for New Playwrights
description: To the Editor:

title: Interracial Duos: The Role of I Spy
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: BofA Merrill Hires New Head of Houston Office
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Friday that it had hired Oscar Brown, a veteran Lehman Brothers energy banker, as the new head of its Houston investment banking office.

title: Hip Replacement vs. Hip Resurfacing
description: Jane Brody, the Timess Personal Health columnist, recently reported on less invasive techniques for hip replacement that reduce complications and speed recovery. Dr. Patrick A. Meere, an orthopedic surgeon at New York University who specializes in hip and knee arthritis surgery, joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions. Here, Dr. Meere responds to several readers who asked about hip replacement versus hip resurfacing. In addition, see Dr. Meeres many responses in the Comments section of Improving on the Hip Replacement; additional responses will be posted in the coming days, so check back for updates.

title: Paterson to Drop Out of Race for Governor
description: Gov. David A. Paterson is set to announce that he will not seek election in the wake of reports that he and the State Police intervened in a domestic-assault case against a senior aide, according to a person told about the plans.

title: ArtsBeat: Seinfeld Returns to NBC
description: Whos down on NBC? Not Jerry Seinfeld. In a conversation about his new show The Marriage Ref, which has its premiere on NBC on Sunday, Mr. Seinfeld discusses his loyalty to the maligned network and why he thinks now would be a hilariously ironic moment to produce a new hit show for it. Everythings so wrong. Thats what I love about it, he said. That to me  when I see everything is wrong, that feels right to me. Read more at ArtsBeat

title: Are Grandparents Making Kids Fat?
description: Finally, something that isnt the mothers fault.

title: David Neumanns All-American Meal
description: ITS possible you know the infamous David Hasselhoff video that hit YouTube a while back, the one with him on a floor, too drunk to eat a hamburger effectively, weathering an earnest lecture from one of his teenage daughters.

title: Now Accessorizing | Give Him the Boot
description: As far as boots go, the Greenwich is pretty strapping. Built by the Massachusetts-based cobbler Alden exclusively for Leffot, a stylish downtown mens shoe store, the boots upper is fashioned from oiled nubuck and its flexible soles are completely waterproof. Although inspired by the spirit of Greenwich Village hipsters and bohemians, they cost a decidedly unbohemian $475 a pair. 10 Christopher Street; (212) 989-4577.

title: Video Shows SeaWorld Trainer With Orca Moments Before Her Death
description: Updated | 1:16 p.m. A local news station in Florida has obtained video shot by a tourist from New Hampshire at SeaWorld in Orlando on Wednesday moments before an orca dragged a trainer under water by her hair, leading to her death.

title: The String Quartet, Reinvented
description: CREDIT for inventing the string quartet tends to be laid at the feet of Joseph Haydn, that industrious, fecund genius whose lifes work counts among the crowning achievements of the 18th-century Austrian Empire. Haydn was not the first composer to write pieces for two violins, viola and cello. But his efforts established the intimacy, flexibility and expressiveness that made the string quartet a medium capable of encompassing his own congeniality and craft, Beethovens stormy spirit, Shostakovichs hidden turmoil and Elliott Carters fearsome concatenations.

title: College Campaign for Star Wars Mascot Is Fully Operational
description: For a character who makes only a passing appearance in the original Star Wars trilogy, things are going swimmingly for Admiral Ackbar, a bit player from Return of the Jedi. Ackbar, the squidlike leader of the Rebel Alliances assault on the Death Star who vocally declares that his forces have stumbled into a trap, has lately been ensnared by the popular culture: hes received shout-outs on television programs from Robot Chicken to The Daily Show to The Colbert Report. And if things go his way, he could even end up the new mascot of the University of Mississippi.The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that the students of Ole Miss voted on Tuesday to seek a new mascot to replace the schools Colonel Reb, who was deemed too evocative of the Old South and potentially offensive. Among the leading candidates to replace the Colonel? The Admiral, whos been getting a boost from student Web sites like notatrap.org, which declares: He led the Galactic Rebellion, and he knew he needed to be with the Ole Miss Rebels.

title: The Story of PLX4032: A Berkeley Companys Cancer Therapy
description: Plexxikon, Inc. is a small biotechnology company in Berkeley. Its creation, PLX4032, a melanoma drug tailored to a gene mutation known as B-RAF, played a central role in Amy Harmons three-part series in The New York Times about targeted therapy.

title: A Super Bowl at the Meadowlands?
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Get your long johns ready. Arizona has dropped out of the bidding for the 2014 Super Bowl  the one to be awarded in May  which leaves the new stadium at the Meadowlands as the clear front-runner to get the game.

title: Obama Names 4 More to Debt Panel
description: President Obama on Friday named the final four of his six choices to serve on a bipartisan commission to recommend ways to reduce the national debt, including two corporate leaders, one of whom is a Republican.

title: The Toughest Soldiers in Moviedom
description: On the heels of the discussion, here and elsewhere, of whether Jeremy Renners character in The Hurt Locker is an authentic soldier or merely a rogue plot device, Break Media has provided a roundup of the toughest soldiers in moviedom (only they use a word thats more Internet-appropriate). From Charlie Sheen in Platoon to Jack Nicholson as a Marine in A Few Good Men to some guy who fights werewolves, here are 16 video clips to help you power through this snow day.

title: Hey, Waiter! Just How Much Extra Do You Really Expect?
description: Do you need change?

title: Judge Rejects Settlement in Honda Fuel-Economy Lawsuit
description: A federal judge in California has rejected a proposed settlement of a class-action suit between Honda and Civic Hybrid owners who felt they were misled about fuel economy. The judge agreed with consumer advocates, including 26 attorneys general, who argued it wasnt a good deal for the owners.

title: An Ode to the Overdraft Fee
description: In response to our story earlier this week about banks efforts to persuade customers to opt in to overdraft coverage on their checking accounts, a reader named Tim Torkildson of Ban Phe, Thailand, sent in the poem that appears below. Wed love to publish a response (in verse) from a banker. If you have one, please send it to yourmoney@nytimes.com.

title: The White Houses Call to Populism
description: Those arguing that the Obama administration has put the interests of Wall Street above those of Main Street should check out the first Annual Report of the White House Task Force on the Middle Class, released today. It appears to be among the most straightforwardly populist policy packages issued by the White House to date.

title: Friday Reading
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Bush Reunites With Staff
description: Former President George W. Bush is here in Washington, D.C., officially for a Marine Corps University Foundation awards dinner, but he also presided over a breakfast reunion on Friday with members of his administration.

title: American Wasteland
description: The mountain that John DAgata is ostensibly concerned with in his slim but powerful new book, About a Mountain, is Yucca Mountain, located approximately 100 miles north of Las Vegas. And hes not the only one interested in it: since the mid-1980s, the United States government has been doing back flips to bury the countrys entire reservoir of spent nuclear waste  some 77,000 tons of apocalyptic yumminess  deep inside Yucca. In the summer of 2002, the summer after DAgata helped his mother move to a Vegas suburb, Congress was proceeding with plans to make the mountain a nuclear dump. Also that summer, 16-year-old Levi Presley jumped to his death from the observation deck of a third-rate Vegas hotel. These subjects, disparate though they are, animate DAgatas sprawling narrative.

title: Murder Most Global
description: Henning Mankell is perhaps the second-most-famous modern Swedish cultural figure, after Ingmar Bergman  which seems appropriate since hes married to one of Bergmans daughters. And since portions of Sweden remain winterbound for more than seven months a year, it seems equally appropriate that much of these countrymens work is enshrouded in gloom. Bergman wrote of a virulent, terrifying evil within us all. Mankell asks, Why does barbarism always wear a human face? If striations of optimism can be found in their work, maybe thats just the Northern Lights.

title: Seen Much Better Days: Rolling Stones Return to Main Street
description: If, after listening to all 18 tracks and 67 minutes of the Rolling Stones Exile on Main Street youve ever thought to yourself, Boy, I could really do with a few more scuzzy, skeevy, down-and-dirty Stones tracks from those same recording sessions, your ship has just come in. (And we think thats Keith Richards dangling perilously from the crows nest.)

title: Under Fire, Paterson Ends His Campaign for Governor
description: Gov. David A. Paterson ended his campaign for election on Friday amid crumbling support from his party and an uproar over his administrations intervention in a domestic violence case involving a close aide.

title: Phoebe Philos Third Act
description: It wasnt the best way to start the day. When I was leaving the house this morning, my husband saw what I was wearing and said, What do you think youre doing, you complete freak?  recalls Phoebe Philo with a laugh. He said that skinny jeans, a sweatshirt, a Crombie coat and loafers are the uniform of the British National Party. And he has a point.

title: Myanmar Denies Dissidents Appeal
description: BANGKOK  The Supreme Court in Myanmar refused an appeal on Friday to abbreviate the current term of house arrest of the countrys long-detained leading dissident, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: I Was a Teenage Illiterate
description: At the age of 26, when I returned to New York after an inglorious stab at graduate work in medieval history on the frozen steppes of Chicago, I had a horrifying realization: I was illiterate. At least, I was as close to illiterate as a person with over 20 years of education could possibly be. In my stunted career as a scholar, Id read promissory notes, papal bulls and guidelines for Inquisitorial interrogation. Dante, too. Boccaccio. . . . But after 1400? Nihil. I felt very, very stupid among my new sophisticated New York friends. I seemed very, very stupid, too. Actually, lets face it, I was stupid, and it was deeply mortifying, as so many things were in those days. But I have since come to realize that my abject ignorance was really a gift: to be a literarily inclined illiterate at age 26 is one of the most glorious fates that can befall mortal girl.

title: Devils Island
description: Its only a story. Its only a story. Its only. . . . But the sense of immediacy Mark Mills brings to THE INFORMATION OFFICER (Random House, $25) is so intense that this breathtaking novel reads more like a memoir than a wartime thriller. Its May 1942 on the Mediterranean island of Malta, pounded by Axis forces because its the lone Allied outpost in a hostile Nazi-controlled sea. Were told that twice the tonnage of bombs dropped on London during the worst 12 months of the blitz has rained down on the islands inhabitants in the last two months, the enemys final preparation for an invasion thats expected any day.

title: Turkish Leader Defends Inquiry Into Possible Plot
description: ISTANBUL  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan weighed in on Turkeys worsening political crisis on Friday, declaring that an investigation into alleged coup preparations was for the benefit of the people, while the Turkish police detained 18 more current and retired military officers and arrested two others.

title: Music Chronicle
description: MISS ODELL  My Hard Days and Long Nights With the Beatles, the Stones, Bob Dylan, Eric Clapton, and the Women They Loved.  By Chris ODell with Katherine Ketcham.  Touchstone, $26.

title: E.V. Companies Tell Senate They Need Federal Help
description: Although it was overshadowed by the Toyota drama taking place in the House of Representatives, the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee for Energy and Water Development held a hearing on Electric Vehicles in the Light Duty Auto Sector this week, and the Senators heard a fairly unified message from players in the electric vehicle community. There could be a significant early gap between E.V. demand and E.V. supply, they said, and we need help getting these green cars off the ground.

title: Eurostar to Restore Service to Brussels
description: The international high-speed rail operators Eurostar and Thalys said Friday that full service into and out of Brussels would be restored on Monday, two weeks after a fatal collision of two commuter trains forced the closure of a section of track outside the Belgian capital.

title: A Loo for Ladies on All Nippon Flights
description: Tired of putting the toilet seat down every time you walk into an airplane bathroom? Beginning March 1, Japans All Nippon Airways will offer women-only bathrooms on most international routes.

title: Inside the List
description: ICE SWARM: The Norwegians may have won the Scandinavian medal count in Vancouver, but the Swedes own the best-seller list. This week, Henning Mankells Man From Beijing enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 6, joining The Girl Who Played With Fire, currently at No. 11, by his fellow Swedish mysterian Stieg Larsson.

title: No Tiptoeing Necessary
description: Q.

title: Now Screening | Prada
description: The fall 2010 collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week.

description: Q.

title: Share a Cab? Not in This Snow!
description: Of the many thousands of events canceled by the snow, it might have been convenient if Fridays scheduled rollout of the great New York share-a-taxicab-with-a-stranger experiment of 2010 were not among them.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE ROUTES OF MAN: How Roads Are Changing the World and the Way We Live Today,  by Ted Conover (Knopf, $26.95.) Conovers globe-spanning travelogues can be fascinating in themselves, and his meditations on highways are thoughtful, temperate and generous.

title: Projecting Jeters and Rodriguezs Ascent
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter said his contract status would not prevent him from doing what he always does, focusing on the current Yankees season. General Manager Brian Cashman said he was concentrating solely on how to improve the 2010 team. And Alex Rodriguez, as he says, is just taking it one day at a time.

title: When Tenants Dont Pay the Rent
description: Q.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE VAGRANTS,  by Yiyun Li (Random House, $15.) In Muddy River, a town 700 miles from Beijing, 80,000 people live in overcrowded shacks set among small factories. Many are illiterate, and they scheme and steal to stay alive. This novel opens in 1979 as a 28-year-old woman, a former Red Guard who repudiated her past, is about to be executed. A year later, leaflets about her case begin to circulate, and townspeople learn of a democratic wall in Beijing. Li, who was born in China, writes in English; our reviewer, Pico Iyer, praised her grieving and unremitting first novel.

title: Science and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Orwell Studies
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: PBS to Broadcast Sondheim Concert
description: Musical theater fans unable to make it to Avery Fisher Hall for Sondheim: The Birthday Concert on March 15 and 16 can breathe a sigh of relief. Great Performances will broadcast the New York Philharmonic show, Playbill.com has reported. The exact dates for the telecast have not yet been determined, but representatives for that PBS program told Playbill that it would most likely be shown in the fall. The star-studded, sold-out show, directed by Lonny Price and hosted by David Hyde Pierce, is scheduled to include performances by Patti LuPone, Bernadette Peters, Audra McDonald, Laura Benanti, Matt Cavenaugh, Michael Cerveris, Victoria Clark, Jenn Colella, Jason Danieley, Joanna Gleason, Nathan Gunn, George Hearn, Marin Mazzie, ,John McMartin, Donna Murphy, Gillian Murphy, Laura Osnes, Mandy Patinkin, , Ethan Stiefel, Elaine Stritch, Jim Walton and Chip Zien. Mr. Sondheim celebrates his 80th birthday on March 22.

title: Two Schools of Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: Photos of the Moment | Prada
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Correction: Best Sellers
description: An entry on the hardcover fiction best-seller list on Jan. 31 for The Swan Thieves, by Elizabeth Kostova, referred incorrectly to a misdeed committed by one of the characters. While he tried to slash a canvas in the National Gallery, he did not succeed in doing so. The error was repeated on Feb. 7, Feb. 14 and last Sunday.

title: Navigating the Special Education System
description: In the second part of a series exploring the costs associated with learning disabilities, Patient Money columnist Walecia Konrad today offers advice for navigating the special education system for children with learning disabilities.

title: In F.C.C. Report, Family Guy Tops a Bad-Taste Chart
description: Sarah Palin isnt the only one who has taken issue with Family Guy lately. According to a report from the media research firm SNL Kagan, that Fox animated series is responsible for more that 190,000 indecency complaints that have been filed and and are still pending at the Federal Communications Commission, with Fox shows accounting for half of the Top 50 complaints.

title: Another Puzzle After Iran Moves Nuclear Fuel
description: WASHINGTON  When Iran was caught last September building a secret, underground nuclear enrichment plant at a military base near the city of Qum, the countrys leaders insisted they had no other choice. With its nuclear facilities under constant threat of attack, they said, only a fool would leave them out in the open.

title: Group Hug | Milan Fashion Week
description: Milan fashion week has only just begun, but it was interesting to see how some key themes in the mens-wear shows, which took place here in January, have carried into the womens. At D&G, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana reprised last months ski motif, complete with the seasons ubiquitous alpine knits. What a shame that the Vancouver Olympics are nearly over! Wouldnt it be fun if Lindsey Vonn had worn glittery D&G goggles? Or if the medalists had sashayed onto the podium wearing massive furry leg warmers?

title: Whats Happened to Cultural Discourse?
description: David Brooks: Dick, thanks a million for filling in for Gail while she takes a vacation. As you know, over the past few months, Gail has published a book and done a book tour all while writing a witty and wise column twice a week, so she deserves a few weeks off so she can attend conferences on how to save the public option.

title: When Special Delivery Meant Deliverance for a Fugitive Slave
description: The box that arrived in Philadelphia that day was the plain-looking sort typically used to transport dry goods. Just over 3 feet long, it was 2 feet 8 inches deep and not quite 2 feet wide. Written on the side were the words this side up with care.

title: An Ode to Fiscal Responsibility
description: In response to our post earlier today, An Ode to the Overdraft Fee, a Bucks reader named Lee Elliott wrote in (with impressive speed we might add) with the following retort:

title: A Bit of Boasting in Bank of Americas Filing
description: Anyone who actually makes it through Bank of Americas 750-plus page Form 10-K (including exhibits), filed earlier Friday, might be surprised by some of the language that the annual financial statement used to describe the bank. Thats because it reads more like a marketing piece or an advertisement instead of the dry legalese that most of us have come to expect from cumbersome Securities and Exchange Commission filings.

title: President Urges Focus on Common Ground
description: At a highly anticipated forum, President Obama and Congressional Democrats squared off against Congressional Republicans on comprehensive legislation to overhaul the health care system.

title: Answers About Same-Sex Couples and Taxes: Part 4
description: In anticipation of tax season, we have turned to a series of experts who focus on specialized areas of tax finance. In our first series, we focused on freelancers. In our second installment, were looking at same-sex couples and the unique issues they face.

title: Feast Like the Greeks
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five meat-free dishes commonly eaten in Greece during religious holidays, when observant Greeks abstain from most animal products.

title: University of Pennsylvania Tries Outreach Based on Sexual Orientation
description: The Web site Inside Higher Ed reports that the University of Pennsylvania admissions office is expanding the boundaries of its so-called affinity outreach  a Penn engineering student might reach out to a high school senior interested in engineering, a black alumnus might call on a potential applicant who is black  to include applicants who might be gay. The writer of the article, Scott Jaschik, explains:

title: Lunch Break at the Met, 12:45 p.m.
The Stakes in Spain: A Little Exaggerated
description: Everyone knows Spain, with one of the largest economies in the eurozone, is in trouble: its housing bust, budget deficit, swelling debt and lingering recession have been in the news and seen as a few more signals that the euro will take a slide.

title: Narrating Canadas Quest for Gold in Mens Hockey
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Like platooning goaltenders, the Canadian hockey announcers Chris Cuthbert and Gord Miller are taking turns behind the microphone, their voices providing the English soundtrack for Canadas Xanadu production.

title: Must See: Fragile Hopes in Fighting Cancer
Voices From the Crisis: Investigating Local Effects of Unemployment
description: Overview | Who are the new poor, and why do some labor experts believe that many unemployed Americans will spend years waiting for new jobs? In this lesson, students consider the scope and personal impact of the unemployment crisis, as well as some ideas for fighting joblessness. They then interview people in the community about the local effects of unemployment and produce written, audiotaped or videotaped interviews to share with the larger community.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Musicians Give Up Raises and Agree to Hiring Freeze
description: Members of the financially ailing Philadelphia Orchestra have made key concessions in pay and pensions, the orchestra said Friday. Donors often look favorably on such cooperation, so the development gives management a better position to raise funds from individuals and foundations. The orchestra said it had raised $8 million toward a $15 million emergency fund needed to stabilize its finances.

title: Rangel Responds
description: Congressman Charles B. Rangel challenged a Times article. This graphic presents a point-counterpoint between Mr. Rangel and The Times.

title: Deaths Rising for Lack of Insurance, Study Finds
description: As members of the Obama administration and Congress met on Thursday to try to find common ground on health care, a new report warned that without comprehensive legislation, more than 275,000 adults nationwide will die over the next decade because of a lack of health insurance. Nearly 14,000 of those deaths would occur in New York State.

title: Coming-of-Age Filmgoers: Youre Not in Kansas Anymore
description: One of the most intriguing features in the New York International Childrens Film Festival is all about Oz. But this place has no Dorothy, no wizard, no Emerald City. And its even farther from Kansas.

title: I.M.F. Chief Suggests Look at New Reserve Currency
description: WASHINGTON  The chief of the International Monetary Fund said Friday that the organization should reorient itself to better detect systemic risks to the global economy and quickly step in with emergency loans when financial crises emerge.

title: Another Madoff Defendant From the Fringes
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues related to white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: David Soyer, Guarneri Cellist, Has Died
description: David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet, died on Thursday at his apartment in New York, a day after his 87th birthday. The news comes from Frank Salomon, a co-administrator of the Marlboro Music Festival, with which Mr. Soyer had a long association.

title: Franchise Tags Hit the Nose
description: The market for nose tackles became officially barren this week after the Packers and the Patriots applied franchise tags to Ryan Pickett and Vince Wilfork. The two could still receive long-term deals with their clubs, but at the very least, theyll play under a lucrative one-year contract in 2010. Veteran NT Casey Hampton was also kept off the market; the Steelers agreed to a three-year deal with their nine-year star. The move guaranteed Hampton $11 million and allowed Pittsburgh to use its franchise tag on kicker Jeff Reed.Also franchised was Raiders defensive lineman Richard Seymour.

title: Plaza Sweet, and Hot
description: They timed it perfectly. The Plaza started offering hot chocolate in a colorful Thermos just as the first snowflakes started falling. For $19, you can buy 15 ounces of steaming hot chocolate flavored with cinnamon, orange and port, and the container is yours to keep. Ten percent of the price goes to the Central Park Conservancy. They have it ready to go, so you need only to go to the bartender in the Oak Bar and request it.

title: Book Review Podcast: A Biography of Willie Mays
description: This week: James S. Hirsch on his biography of the baseball legend Willie Mays; the Book Reviews Alida Becker on driving in China; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Paterson to Drop Out of Governor's Race
description: In anticipation of the announcement he will end his campaign for governor, The Times's Carolyn Ryan and Jane Bornemeier discuss Paterson's decision.

title: Off the Menu: Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream
description: Ben Van Leeuwen; his wife, Laura ONeill; and his brother, Peter Van Leeuwen, are no longer simply roaming the city with their five butter-yellow trucks, dispensing ice cream churned from Hudson Valley milk and cream, along with coffee and pastries. They have a new storefront, and Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is the lucky recipient.

title: Now Accessorizing | Heavenly Gate
description: What happens when you cross the scion of a storied jewelry company with a chic nomad? In the case of Mario Buccellati and Carla Forte, its a unique jewelry line called Prediletto, which means favorite in Italian. Their first collection  all of it handmade in Italy  is full of references to Fortes far-flung travels. There are necklaces inspired by the views from a window at Versailles or from an open portico in a Palladian villa outside Venice, and earrings that recall the chandeliers in an ornate dining room from her childhood. Other pieces, like this $6,500 gold, sapphire and diamond gate pendant, are simply tiny sculptures of architectural elements the designer finds beautiful. Call (914) 218-8207 for information.

title: Riesch Wins Slalom; Vonn Misses a Gate
description: Lindsey Vonns Olympics, which started so triumphantly with a gold medal in the womens downhill, sputtered to a close on Friday as she missed a gate on the slalom course at Whistler Mountain and failed to finish for the third time in five races.

title: Whitney Biennial 2010
description: Images from the Whitney Museum of American Arts signature show.

title: 'William Kentridge: Five Themes'
description: Photos from the exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Another Foreclosure Alternative
description: HOMEOWNERS on the verge of foreclosure will often seek a short sale as a graceful exit from an otherwise calamitous financial situation. Their homes are sold for less than the mortgage amount, and the remaining loan balance is usually forgiven by the lender.

title: U.S. Renews Travel Alert for Mexico
description: Mexican beach resorts may get fewer college students from the United States this spring break. This week, the State Department renewed its travel advisory alert for Mexico, singling out the states of Michoacan, Coahuila, Durango and Chihuahua, along the United States-Mexico border, as especially dangerous for United States travelers.

title: New Rules Aimed at Increasing Retirement Savings
description: The United States Department of Labor announced two new rules Friday intended to help better protect, and increase, workers retirement savings.

title: Snowmageddon Still Has Time to Kill Health Care Reform
description: Washingtons Snowmageddon may have already passed. But the storm still has the power to kill Washingtons health care reform talks, perhaps for good.

description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting face-savers  the words and phrases we turn to at awkward moments.

description: Some may have noticed this week an unusual number of Facebook friends in the city becoming fans of something called Secret New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Games Not Yet Done, but Oscar Is on Horizon for Madison Avenue
description: As the parade of so-called big events on television continues  brought to you by, as the saying goes, a lengthy list of blue-chip advertisers  the marketer line-up for the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on March 7 is coming into focus.

title: Axe Cop
description: Animation | Adventure supposedly dreamt up by a 5-year-old. Or it could have been a studio mogul. Hard to tell which:

title: Its the Traffic, Stupid
description: When the economy was in crisis mode last year, the National Traffic Scorecard, published by Inrix, showed a 30 percent drop in traffic, compared with 2008.

title: Academy to Address Oscar Shenanigans
description: So. All of the close Oscar-watchers of the world are aflutter about an e-mail message that a producer of The Hurt Locker sent asking people to vote for his indie movie over another, bigger-budget contender. (Everyone else is sorta like, Oh, yeah, the Oscars. Is curling still on?)

title: Moving House, Radio-Style
description: To the Editor:

title: New Leader for Rent Guidelines Board
description: Opting for a familiar face to navigate one of the most contentious processes in city government, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Friday that he had elevated a member of the citys Rent Guidelines Board, Jonathan L. Kimmel, to be its chairman.

title: Not the Way It Was
description: To the Editor:

title: When It Comes to Content, Amazons Kindle Wont Be Undersold
description: On Jan. 27, Steven P. Jobs was still standing on a stage in San Francisco, presenting Apples new iPad, when the phones started ringing. Senior managers from Amazon.com were calling newspaper, magazine and book publishers trying to glean any information possible about the deals Apple was offering them to supply content for its new reading device.

title: Pelosi Defends Rangel on Ethics Ruling
description: At a Friday news briefing, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi defended Representative Charles Rangel in light of a new ethics panel ruling that admonished him for corporate-financed trips to the Caribbean.

title: Bourne Team Takes a Chance With Iraq War
description: NO one doubts that Green Zone comes with what Adam Fogelson, the chairman of Universal Pictures, calls an action movie pedigree. The film, which opens across the country on March 12, stars Matt Damon and reunites him with Paul Greengrass, the director who brought a propulsive visual style to The Bourne Supremacy and The Bourne Ultimatum. And television ads and trailers promise plenty of suspense, firepower and, of course, fighting in close quarters.

title: Storm Cripples Northeast
description: The third major snowstorm of the winter hit the Northeast, causing power outages and travel delays for area residents.

title: Cardozo Lived Here
description: To the Editor:

title: A Show About Something: Marriage
description: BACK when he was single Jerry Seinfeld helped create a pretty successful comedy series. And now that hes been married for 10 years, he thinks he may have found an idea for a worthy successor.

title: Ask the Expert: Parental Support and the Law
description: Craig Reaves, immediate past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, fields legal questions from New Old Age readers on occasion. You may submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your inquiries to general legal issues; Mr. Reaves cannot offer personal legal advice.

title: Vote Ratings Show Partisan Divide
description: Washington has been full of talk recently about the lack of cooperation between Republicans and Democrats. And, according to the newly released Congressional vote ratings from the National Journal, theres good reason for that.

title: Book Review Podcast: A Biography of Willie Mays
description: This week: James S. Hirsch on his biography of the baseball legend Willie Mays; the Book Reviews Alida Becker on driving in China; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Drinking Blood: New Wonders of Alices World
description: INSTEAD of Wonderland, its Underland. Instead of Alice as a bored but clever child, we get Alice as a 19-year-old rebel and warrior, dispatching the monstrous Jabberwocky with a magic sword. Disneys second rendering of Lewis Carrolls fantasy, in other words, is a world apart from both its 1951 cartoon version and the original Victorian-era text.

title: Associated Press to Create Pay Service for iPad
description: The Associated Press will create paid subscriptions through the Apple iPad for itself and other news organizations, the companys leader said Friday, in the latest step of its campaign for the battered news business to control and profit from the electronic use of its work.

title: At the Combine: Union Will Watch Teams Spending
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The players union chief, DeMaurice Smith, said Friday at the scouting combine that the union would be monitoring team spending in the uncapped year very closely when free agency opens next Friday.

title: Defender of Waterboarding Hears From Critics
description: Theres nothing unusual about partisans of the Bush administration defending waterboarding as a useful form of enhanced interrogation. Others will go even further, calling the technique torture, but saying it may be a necessary evil. What is a bit unusual is the case being made by Marc A. Thiessen, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush.

title: Can You Be Addicted to Your Wife?
description: Recently, a panel of experts joined the Consults blog to answer readers questions about sex addiction. Here, two of those experts respond to one wife who is concerned that her husband may be a sex addict who is addicted to her.

title: Time Is Now for Astros Mills to Stand on His Own
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  It was the morning of the first practice of the first spring training for Brad Mills, major league manager. Mills leaned on a fungo bat near the bullpen mounds at Osceola County Stadium. He knew the sound bite the reporters wanted, about realizing a dream that was decades in the making. But he could not bring himself to give it.

title: Visual Learning: The Passion Play Poster
description: There were probably several very unhappy flower girls in Richmond, Va., the day Noah Scalin walked into a local flower shop and bought every rose petal in sight.

title: What Were Reading
Another Trippy Rabbit Hole
description: THE home video market is awash in versions of Alices Adventures in Wonderland this week, all evidently intended to capitalize on the publicity surrounding Tim Burtons new 3-D interpretation of the classic Lewis Carroll book, set to be released on Friday by Walt Disney Studios.

title: Answers From Chuck Scarborough, Part 3
description: Following is the third and final set of answers from Chuck Scarborough about his career as an author and broadcast journalist, his job as co-anchor of New York Nightly News at 7 p.m., and other related matters.

title: Health Economists Urge Passage of Reform
description: Obviously, not all economists are in favor of the current proposals in Congress. But a pretty impressive group of health economists and other policy experts has released a letter making the following argument:

title: One Big Upshot
description: Monologue |  Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: President Obama today hosted a bipartisan health care summit in Washington, D.C. He invited Democrats and Republicans together to debate the health care proposal. They met for a little more than six hours, which, coincidentally, happens to be exactly the average wait time at the emergency room if you were to go in with something bleeding.

title: Finally, That Herms Horse-Drawn Carriage
description: Theres a hot new ride parked beside the Maybachs at the tony Les Airelles ski resort in the French Alps: a horse-drawn carriage by Herms. The Moment was curious and tracked down the carriages fur-hatted, liveried coachman, Fred Molinas, who grew up on a farm near Avignon. Fred was lovely, if not exactly loquacious, but he did tell us (through a translator) that he has worked as a carriage driver at some of the most beautiful resorts in France, and Les Airelles  nestled in the spectacular Tarentaise Valley  is his absolute favorite. But wouldnt anything look beautiful from such a prestigious perch? With wheels like these  his coachmans seat is done up in Herms ebony bull-calf leather, and his passengers keep warm inside the brick-leather interior with a pair of luxurious Herms blankets  Freds smart to toe the company line. Au trot!

title: Travel Deals: Winter Winery Weekends
description: Finger Lakes Wine Country, a tourism company in upstate New York, has extended its Winter Wine Weekends package through April 30. Though temperatures may be freezing, visiting in the off-season also means lower prices and fewer crowds.

title: New Developments in the Health Care Debate
description: 6:15 p.m. | Updated  More from Economix: A new Gallup poll sheds light on why young people dont buy health insurance. And at Media Decoder, the White House says it served up millions of live streams for the summit yesterday.

description: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

description: The Timess Jeffrey Marcus, who is at Canada Hockey Place, and Stu Hackel, a contributor to The Timess Slap Shot blog, will be providing live analysis during the mens semifinal hockey game between the United States and Finland.

title: A Split Decision in Ratings Battle Between Olympics and Idol
description: Finally some real throw-down competition in the last few days of the Olympics.

description: Chapter 1

title: Rubio to Reimburse G.O.P. for Flights
description: Marco Rubio, the former Florida House speaker who has proven to be a stiff challenger to Gov. Charlie Crist for the G.O.P.s Senate nomination, said in statements on Friday that he would reimburse his party for about $3,000 in travel expenses.

title: Photos of the Moment | Milan lan
description: Scenes from Milan Fashion Week photo diary from the photographers of Contrasto.

title: Something Is Out There
description: Immigration

title: White House Social Secretary Resigns
description: Desire Rogers, the White House social secretary, is resigning her position just a few months after she was roundly criticized for a security lapse that led to uninvited guests crashing the presidents first state dinner.

title: New Yorkers React
description: Three New Yorkers share their views on the news Gov. Paterson will end his election campaign.

title: Banks Out of the Woods? Maybe Not
description: MORE than $1 in every $10 that American banks have outstanding in loans is lent to a troubled borrower, a ratio far higher than previously seen in the quarter-century that such numbers have been compiled.

title: The Man From Beijing
description: The Epitaph

title: In France, Gendarmes Are on Patrol Against Oyster Rustlers
description: GUJAN-MESTRAS, France  On a recent wintry evening, Thierry Deuet, known as Titi, and two fellow gendarmes put Ernea II, a 10-meter boat, into the dark waters of Arcachon Bay. Their mission was to patrol the oyster parks to ensure that the bulging sacks of mollusks just below the surface of the shallow waters were not winched away by thieves.

title: Switzerland Unruffled by Qaddafis Call for Jihad in Wake of Its Ban on New Minarets
description: PARIS  The Swiss government reacted blandly on Friday to the latest rhetorical sally from the eccentric Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who called on Thursday for a jihad against Switzerland. The two countries have been sparring since the Swiss arrested one of Colonel Qaddafis sons and his wife in 2008 on suspicion of beating their servants.

title: When the Mets Had Mettle
description: The Mets have come under fire from fans and sports commentators this winter for not acting boldly enough to improve the team. Aside from Jason Bay, General Manager Omar Minaya has signed primarily castoffs and reclamation projects.

title: The Online Private Sale Trend Packs Its Bags
description: Private-sale sites like Gilt,Rue La La andOne Kings Lane have sprouted across the Web, offering big discounts on brand-name goods to members  anyone who wants go through the simple step of registering for these free services.

title: A Go-To Guy, if You Want a Do-Nothing
description: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.

title: Making Mischief Along With the Melodies
description: Paul Motian, Chris Potter, and Jason Moran

title: With Bridgess Voice Silenced for Oscar Night, Hyundai Turns to the Rest of Hollywood
description: Hyundai Motor America is recruiting a bakers half dozen of Hollywood stars to pinch-hit for its long-time voice-over announcer, Jeff Bridges, for the automakers commercials that will appear during the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on March 7.

title: For Your Consideration: An Anti-Scarface
description: For people looking to fill out their Oscar ballots in the foreign-language category the honest way, by watching the movies, instead of the usual way  by picking the film whose title most makes it seem as if its about the Holocaust  there is a new screening opportunity starting on Friday. A Prophet, a French entry that has already nabbed some big prizes globally, including the Grand Prix at Cannes, is one of those rare films in which the moral stakes are as insistent and thought through as the aesthetic choices, writes Manohla Dargis in The New York Times.

title: Preparing for the Inevitable Bursting Bubble
description: Financial bubbles are a way of life now. They can upend your industry, send your portfolio into spasms and leave you with whiplash. And then, once youve recovered, the next one will hit.

title: New Yorkers React to Patersons Decision
description: On a blustery day in Times Square, three New Yorkers shared their views on Gov. David A. Patersons decision to end his campaign for governor. Emily B. Hager reports.

title: How Are You Preparing for the Next Bubble?
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I give some tips for reorganizing your financial life if you believe that well see more bubbles (and more severe ones) in the future.

title: An Olympic Victory for Shutter Island
description: Most of the big winners from the Vancouver Olympics are easy to point out: Lindsey Vonn, Bode Miller, Shani Davis, Evan Lysacek, Leonardo DiCaprio.

title: Police a No-Show at Workshop
description: Updated 5:42 p.m., March 2 | We have published an update post with comment from the head police spokesman, Paul W. Browne.

title: Artifacts | Jamie Isensteins
description: At first glance, Jamie Isensteins Dancing Pop-Up Fishing Sculpture appears to be a lumpen patchwork pod with fake human limbs. Oh hey, you might think. Thats pretty funny. Then its foot twitches and its hand trembles, and your amusement turns to dismay.

title: For Health Care Meeting, a Large Online Audience
description: The White House says it counted nearly four million live streams of its health care summit meeting on Thursday.

title: What BofAs Lewis Earned in 2009
description: 4:34 p.m. | Update Bank of Americas former chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, received about $4.2 million for 2009, comprised largely of an appreciation in the value of his pension benefits, news reports said on Friday, citing a regulatory filing.

title: MGM Mirage Strikes Deal to Extend Debt Deadline
description: MGM Mirage, the Las Vegas casino operator, said on Friday that it had reached an agreement with lenders to extend the deadline for repaying $3.6 billion of debt to February 2014, The Associated Press reported.

title: War and Conscience
description: Readers who commented on Shannon P. Meehans post, Distant Wars, Constant Ghosts, wrote about dealing with the effects of war and the psychic toll that killing takes on soldiers. Excerpts from a few are below.

title: Setting Mealtime Rules
description: Kate Buckley is a stay-at-home mother of two raucous sons (the adjective is hers) who live in Adelaide Hills, Australia. She has a blog, Eating the Daisies, which she began after the family moved from the city to the suburbs and the boys kept trying to munch on the flowers.

title: Paterson's Announcement in New York
description: Caught up in a whirlwind of allegations about his administration's intervention in a domestic violence episode, Gov. David A. Paterson announced that he was ending his election campaign at his Manhattan office.

title: Broadcast May Be Intended to Undercut Support for Obama in Iran
description: State-run television in Iran showed what it said was a televised confession on Thursday by Abdolmalek Rigi, the recently captured leader of Jundallah, a militant group that claims to be defending Sunni Muslims in Irans southeast and has killed hundreds of Iranian soldiers and civilians since 2003.

title: Toyota Accused of Withholding Data
description: DETROIT  The chairman of a House committee that questioned Toyota executives this week about the carmakers recall accused the company on Friday of withholding documents while fighting lawsuits filed by crash victims.

title: Ski Week | Slope Style
description: Whether you take your ski fashion cues from Gstaad or Sugarloaf, heres something special for the slopes.

title: Why Regulations Might Actually Create Jobs
description: That, anyway, is the provocative claim from Barry Lynn, who runs the Markets, Enterprise, and Resiliency Initiative at the New America Foundation, a center-left research group. But hes not talking about the health or safety or labor regulations that drive small-business owners nuts. Rather, he means the regulations that once kept companies from becoming so big that they dominate the market.

title: Chrysler to Repair 300,000 Minivans for Air Bag Problem
description: Chrysler has agreed to repair about 312,000 minivans because the front air bags might not deploy in a crash.

title: Health Care and Moral Urgency
description: Jon Chait responds to my qualified praise for the idea of a scaled-back health care bill:

title: Excerpt: 'The Marriage Ref'
description: The hybrid reality game show, produced by Jerry Seinfeld, aims to arbitrate marital disputes.

title: Scorecard | Prada Wins!
description: When sexy is the critical buzzword of the day, you know Scorecard must be in Milan. Thursdays shows opened with a girl-with-the-band party like usual at Just Cavalli, and even Miuccia Prada put angels on the runway  yet hers was no Victorias Secret glittery campfest. Leave it to the reigning queen of ugly chic to make dcolletage discreet and quietly subversive.

title: Seventh Avenue and 118th Street, 1:30 P.M.
description: Yes, we know its really called Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem, but that didnt fit in the headline. Hope the guy beat the bus.

title: Managing Peak Demand With Water Heaters
description: Most programs for reducing peak electricity demand involve air-conditioners or (in farm states) irrigation. In Idaho, for example, the main power company pays homeowners to allow their air-conditioners to be cycled on and off in 15-minute intervals during some summer afternoons, and farmers are paid to turn off their water pumps during those times.

title: Essential Recordings by the Kronos Quartet
description: STEVE REICH: DIFFERENT TRAINS

title: Once Upon a Time, as Told by 2 Composers
description: For the second week of his visit with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, David Robertson led a program that began and ended with symphonic settings of fairy tales, Ravels Ma Mre LOye Suite and Bartoks Wooden Prince. Both works make substantial demands on an orchestra and test a conductors interpretive ingenuity. But they could hardly be more different.

title: Sending Signals With Songs, Struts and Static
description: Storms like the miserable, windy mess that hit New York on Thursday make it easy to cancel evening plans. Is it really worth getting cold and wet to see another show?

title: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Feb. 26
description: After two especially upsetting pictures from Afghanistan, by Ahmad Massoud and Brennan Linsley of The Associated Press, two photographs follow (Slides 3 and 5) that show people fleeing Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and waiting for food rations in Islamabad, Pakistan. A portrait of someone whose eyes gaze upward is such an efficient way to convey supplication that it forever verges on the clich. But Todd Heisler of The Times and Muhammad Muheisen of The Associated Press show how poignantly it can be done.

title: Committee Monitoring Use of Unauthorized Video
description: YouTube, Justin.tv, and Ustream are among the 150 sites worldwide being monitored by the International Olympic Committee to squelch the spread of illicitly uploaded video of the Vancouver Games.

title: Next Problem: Governing New York
description: After reports that he intervened to protect an aide in a domestic violence case, Gov. David A. Paterson of New York announced on Friday that he would not seek election.

title: Think Banks Are Out of the Woods? Maybe Not
description: More than $1 in every $10 that American banks have outstanding in loans is lent to a troubled borrower, a ratio far higher than previously seen in the quarter-century that such numbers have been compiled, The New York Timess Floyd Norris writes in his Off the Charts column.

title: An Action Hero Low on the Bond Factor
description: Its unfair, perhaps, to compare the new Masterpiece Classic version of The 39 Steps with the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock film. But Hitchcocks lighthearted thriller has been the only screen version of the story  there are at least four, with another on the way  that matters. And it still is.

title: Photos of the Moment | Che Bellezza!
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: On Assignment: Nine Eyes on the Prize
description: Update, March 1, 8:25 p.m. | Bruce Bennett answers a readers question about how photo agencies are picked for the privilege of having their cameras in or over the net.

title: Hughes and Chamberlain Are in the Running
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After pitching live batting practice Friday afternoon, Phil Hughes stuck around as Joba Chamberlain prepared to throw. Was Hughes sizing up his competition? Nope.

title: Boy Is Ensnared in 19th-Century Papal Politics
description: For nearly 30 years the scrappy Dicapo Opera Theater has presented a healthy number of contemporary works by Barber, Menotti, Britten and, last season, Tobias Picker (Emmeline). On Thursday night this small company took a big step with the premiere of its first commissioned work: Il Caso Mortara (The Mortara Case), by Francesco Cilluffo, a 31-year-old Italian composer.

title: Military Announces New Social Media Policy
description: Many months behind schedule, the Department of Defense on Friday issued a new policy that, on the surface, seems likely to expand access to popular social networking sites like YouTube, Facebook and Twitter by troops using military computers.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 26
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Sunday Preview
description: Tired of the snow? Find yourself craving a bit of warmth and sunshine to get over the final hump of winter? In this Sundays Travel section, Jane Margolies offers some last-minute getaways, from an upscale surf lodge on the Gulf Coast of Florida, to a three-day cruise to the Caribbean. And for those who arent sick of the snow,Cindy Hirschfeld picks five of the top North American resorts for spring skiing.

title: Pay Attention to the Man Behind the Camera
description: OVER a year ago a producer for National Public Radios Fresh Air interviewed me about whether my book, Victor Fleming: An American Movie Master, would be worth the host Terry Grosss time. The result was a mildly farcical call and response. Fleming, I said, molded as many great stars as any director in Hollywood, including Clark Gable, Gary Cooper, Spencer Tracy, Judy Garland and Jean Harlow. The producer responded, Then why havent I heard of him? I explained that he was not a self-promoter, hired no publicist and left no diaries or journals.
