But he did direct pictures that defined movies for generations of Americans, smash hits like Gone With the Wind, The Wizard of Oz, Captains Courageous and A Guy Named Joe.

title: Rosters for United States vs. the Netherlands
description: Less than 24 hours after the United States mens national team rallied to defeat El Salvador by 2-1 in an international friendly match, Coach Bob Bradley announced his 20-man roster that will be in Amsterdam for Wednesdays match against the Netherlands. The date, March 3, is the last official international date on the FIFA calendar before the start of the 2010 World Cup in South Africa in June.

title: Furor Over Canada Womens Team Celebration Fizzles
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Canadian womens hockey team pulled out traditional celebratory props after its gold medal win on Thursday: cigars, beer and champagne.

title: One on One: Esther Dyson, Health Tech Investor and Space Tourist
description: This week, I sat down with Esther Dyson, who began her career as a journalist, moved to Wall Street, wrote a popular technology newsletter and is now investing in health technology and training to be a space tourist.

title: Big Olympics For Demong Now Includes Engagement
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It apparently wasnt enough for Bill Demong to become the first American in history to win a gold medal in Nordic combined Thursday, or to be selected as the flag bearer for the United States Olympic Team in the closing ceremony.

title: Senator Asks NBC to Explain Internet Restrictions
description: Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, called on NBC Universal on Friday to explain why it has limited access to some Internet video from the Vancouver Games to subscribers of the cable, satellite and telephone companies that have Olympic deals with NBC.

title: Celebrating 75 Years of Grooves in Village
description: A warm sense of occasion surrounds this weeks Village Vanguard engagement by the saxophonist Joe Lovano. The club just commemorated its 75th anniversary, another mile marker in a storied and still vital history.

title: The 3 Glittering Tales Balanchine Tells
description: Few artists have believed quite so firmly in beginnings, middles and ends, in exits and entrances, and in presenting everything to the audience as did the choreographer George Balanchine. His curtains do not rise on characters who are already in the middle of something, as happens in Shakespeare ( King Lear) or Mozart (Figaro). And when the curtains fall, we do not wonder how long the characters will be able to sustain this newly achieved state of things (as happens in comedies from Shakespeares Loves Labours Lost to almost anything by Alan Ayckbourn, and with Mozarts Cos fan Tutte, the most discussed example).

title: Night Out With Andr Leon Talley
description: Andr Leon Talley heads to Sugar Bar on the Upper West Side with Whoopi Goldberg for the bar's open mic night.

title: Film: Rotterdam@BAM
description: Pedro Gonzlez-Rubios ALAMAR depicts the oceanic idyll of Jorge, a Mexican fisherman and his 5-year-old son, Natan, whom Jorge takes to a coral reef where he teaches him the ways of the sea, before the boy goes to live with his mother, Roberta, in Italy. The movie opens the Rotterdam@BAM program from the International Film Festival Rotterdam at BAMcinmatek on Wednesday.

title: Now Screening | Alberta Ferretti
description: The fall 2010 collection from Alberta Ferretti at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Salmon-Roe-Topped Baked Potatoes With Crme Frache
description: 4 large russet potatoes (10 to 12 ounces each), scrubbed well

title: Audio Books With a New York Accent
description: In one room, Meade Esposito, the Democratic boss from Brooklyn, was tightening his grip on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Justice Dept. Reveals More Missing E-Mail Files
description: WASHINGTON  Large batches of e-mail records from the Justice Department lawyers who worked on the 2002 legal opinions justifying the Bush administrations brutal interrogation techniques are missing, and the Justice Department told lawmakers Friday that it would try to trace the disappearance.

title: Too Many Choices: A Problem That Can Paralyze
description: TAKE my younger son to an ice cream parlor or restaurant if you really want to torture him. He has to make a choice, and thats one thing he hates. Would chocolate chip or coffee chunk ice cream be better? The cheeseburger or the turkey wrap? His fear, he says, is that whatever he selects, the other option would have been better.

title: Twice-Baked Potatoes: The Classy Side of the Family
description: IF I hadnt really trusted the friend who sent me the link to a recipe for twice-baked stuffed potatoes, I certainly never would have clicked on it. Those supersize tubers have always scared me. Growing up Id see them at food courts in a mall  microwaved until soggy, heaped with sour cream until sloppy, littered with neon orange cheese.

title: Screen Test | Julianne Moore
description: The actress on her acting, her influences and Tom Ford.

title: Rain or Shine, Where Sea Lions Go, Tourists Follow
description: The hype is for real.

title: On the Street | Cold Call
description: Fur and all its imitations were worn by many guests attending the recent New York Fashion Week, no doubt prompted at least in part by the bitter cold and snow.

title: Driving the Young From the Insurance Pool
description: Better health doesnt seem to explain why so many young people forgo health insurance. Rather, income does, according to new survey data released by Gallup.

title: A Medal for Dylan From the White House
description: The White House continues to pay tribute to Bob Dylan, right, in every way it knows how  whether or not Mr. Dylan is there to receive the honor. On Thursday, two weeks after he appeared in the East Room as part of a concert to commemorate Black History Month, Mr. Dylan was named one of 12 recipients of the National Medal of Arts, only this time he was not in attendance. Other winners who were announced in an afternoon ceremony and awarded their medals by President Obama and his wife, Michelle, included the designer Milton Glaser, the artist and architect Maya Lin, the singer and actor Rita Moreno, the soprano Jessye Norman, the artist Frank Stella, the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas, the composer and conductor John Williams, and Joseph P. Riley Jr., the mayor of Charleston, S.C. The actor and director Clint Eastwood was also named a medalist but not present at the ceremony (though were sure the distinction made his day). The Oberlin Conservatory of Music and the School of American Ballet were awarded medals as well. The annual award is managed by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Batman Beats Superman in the Marketplace
description: Despite their long history as super-friends, comic book fans have been known to debate: Who would win in a fight? The all-powerful Superman or the ever-ingenious Batman? This week we may have gotten the answer. On Monday the $1 million sale of a copy of Action Comics No. 1, which features the first appearance of Superman, set a record for the sale of a comic book. But it was short-lived. On Thursday a copy of Detective Comics No. 27, the first appearance of Batman from 1939, sold for $1,075,500. Take that, Man of Steel! Heritage Auctions, which sold the Batman comic, has a video presentation on this copy of Detective Comics No. 27, that includes a closer look at its cover, above, and some of the interior panels. Like the buyer of Action Comics No. 1  and Superman and Batman  the new owner of Detective Comics No. 27 would like to keep his identity secret.

title: T Exclusive | Marina Abramovic
description: Marina Abramovic discusses performance art.

title: Rolling Stones Return to Main Street
description: If, after listening to all 18 tracks and 67 minutes of the Rolling Stones Exile on Main Street, youve ever thought to yourself, Boy, I could really do with a few more scuzzy, skeevy, down-and-dirty Stones tracks from those same sessions, your ship has just come in. (And we think thats Keith Richards dangling perilously from the crows nest.) Universal Music said that it would re-release Exile on Main Street, the 1972 Rolling Stones double album. The new version, which will get a United States release on May 18, will include 10 new tracks, with titles like Plundered My Soul, Dancing in the Light, Following the River and Pass the Wine. It will also feature alternate versions of songs like Soul Survivor and Loving Cup. A deluxe edition of the album will also include a DVD of a new Rolling Stones documentary, Stones in Exile.

title: Philadelphia Musicians Forgo Raises
description: Members of the financially struggling Philadelphia Orchestra have made crucial concessions in pay and pensions, the orchestra said on Friday. Donors often look favorably on such cooperation, so the development puts management in a better position to raise funds from individuals and foundations. The orchestra said it had raised $8 million toward a $15 million emergency fund needed to stabilize its finances. The players agreed to give up a 4.8 percent raise next season, accept a freeze in pension contributions from the orchestra and allow a hiring freeze, although principal-player openings may be filled, management said. The savings could add up to about $4.5 million next year, in addition to a similar amount from concessions last season, the orchestra said. Orchestra musicians around the country have been making similar concessions since the recession, which shrunk endowments and donations. A Philadelphia performers minimum salary this season is $124,800, although all make more than that  and some two or three times that amount. That minimum ranks sixth among the major orchestras; a freeze next year would drop it a notch to seventh, according to current contract figures.

title: Olympians Top Idols
description: After a night of lackluster performances from its Top 12 male contestants, American Idol lost once again to NBCs coverage of the Olympics in their Thursday night matchup. According to Nielsens estimates, 17.8 million viewers tuned in to see four contestants eliminated from Idol at 8 p.m., fewer than the 19.2 million who watched the Winter Games at that hour. Although Idol was the nights top-rated broadcast among viewers 18 to 49, NBC led the night in total viewers, averaging 22.5 million over prime time as a whole. Fox ranked second, drawing 7.7 million viewers for Kitchen Nightmares, while CBS was third with a lineup that included Survivor (11.5 million). ABC was fourth with The Deep End (3.9 million) and reruns of Greys Anatomy (4.6 million) and Private Practice (3.6 million).

title: Mark P. Boisi
description: As of March 1, Mr. Boisi, 56, will become the chairman for the New York region of Cassidy Turley, a new commercial real estate company made up of eight firms, including four former Colliers affiliates that merged into a holding company over a year ago.

title: Out With the Colonel, in With the Admiral?
description: For a character who makes only a passing appearance in the original Star Wars trilogy, things are going swimmingly for Admiral Ackbar, a bit player from Return of the Jedi. The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that the students of the University of Mississippi voted on Tuesday to seek a new mascot to replace the schools Colonel Reb, above, who was deemed too evocative of the Old South and potentially offensive. Among the leading candidates to replace the Colonel? The Admiral, a squidlike leader of the Rebel Alliance, whos been getting a boost from student Web sites like notatrap.org. While a student committee to propose a new mascot is still in the early stages of formation, Lucasfilm, which produced the Star Wars movies, has given a (tongue-in-cheek) endorsement to Ackbars candidacy. In a statement the studio said: Lucasfilm is flattered that our Star Wars fans at the University of Mississippi are considering electing Admiral Ackbar as their mascot. The last time we checked in with Admiral Ackbar he was leading the Rebel Alliance Fleet on a critical mission so it will be difficult for him to show up for the games!

title: In Long Island, a Home for All Generations
description: EARLY this month, three generations of the Delfino family moved into the 3,400-square-foot stone and stucco home they designed for themselves in Port Jefferson Station.

title: After Plea, Top Builder Awaits His Fate
description: RICHARD R. GIROUARD made his fortune speculating on the living tastes of the affluent. From the ridges of Avon to the village lanes of Old Greenwich, Mr. Girouards building company, Girouard Associates, spent 15 years wooing and winning the corporate elite with stately stone manors and dormered colonials.

title: Teacher Q | How Did Your Teachers Shape Who You Are as an Educator?
description: This week we were inspired by Bob Herberts column about a school in Harlem to ask kids Whos the best teacher you ever had? Why?

title: In New Jersey, No Consensus on Foreclosure Problem
description: IN gauging the severity of the foreclosure problem in New Jersey, the experts could hardly be farther apart. Some see the state as relatively unscathed at this point, with the situation about to improve; others see worsening conditions that may turn downright severe.

title: A Hunter Finds Gleaming Skyline, by the Windowful
description: ALINUR SALUR came to the United States from Turkey in 1980 with his wife-to-be, the pianist Meral Guneyman. The two lived first on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, then moved to Riverdale in the Bronx, then to the Jersey Shore. Mr. Salur worked in the import-export business and owned a restaurant.

title: Home at First Sight
description: WHEN the towers fell, Amy Gottlieb was in the kitchen of her familys Battery Park City apartment, serving breakfast to her twin daughters, not yet a year old. Ms. Gottlieb, a special education teacher, and her husband, Terry McElroy, an artist, had rented the apartment only three months earlier, attracted by the complexs child-friendly vibes; just the previous morning, Ms. Gottlieb had begun sharing a babysitter with another mother of twins who lived nearby.

title: The Psychology of Moving
description: IN the nine years since he came to New York with $500 in his pocket, Martin-Christopher Harper estimates that he has moved at least 40 times.

title: Off the Grid, but on the Radar
description: KEW GARDENS is compact  flanked on one side by Forest Park, on the other by Maple Grove Cemetery. A walk from the greenery on one side to the greenery on the other isnt very far at all, as long as you dont get lost.

title: Gatorade Ends Its Relationship With Tiger Woods
description: Gatorade officially cut its ties to Tiger Woods on Friday, one week after he admitted to extramarital affairs and said he was unsure when he would return to golf.

title: Fish Use UV Patterns to Tell Species Apart
description: If youve seen one damselfish, youve seen them all.

title: An Open Mike for Andr and Whoopi
description: DAMARA LYNN GREENE was pinup-girl gorgeous in a tight black bodysuit and feather-fringed boots as she shimmied across the stage at Sugar Bar. She pouted. She twirled. She kicked her leg so high she nearly nicked a man in the front row with her heel. When she launched into a kinetic rendition of the Janet Jackson anthem What Have You Done For Me Lately? the crowd roared, one voice booming above the rest.

title: In Plants, Yeast Raises Temperatures
description: Yeast is good for a lot more than just baking bread or brewing beer. Yeasts, which are single-celled fungi, are everywhere in nature and can perform many ecological functions, like breaking down dead plant tissue and encouraging root growth.

title: In Figure Skating World, Winning Leaps Over Art
description: From experience, three things happen the moment that you let it slip that you used to be a figure skater: there is an incredulous pause, a sharp Really? and laughter. The order of the first two can change, but the exchange always ends in laughter.

title: Deadly Germs Largely Ignored By Drug Firms
description: Gram-negative bacteria are practically built to withstand drugs, which is one reason few drug makers have rushed to pursue treatments.

title: Rising Threat of Infections Unfazed by Antibiotics
description: A minor-league pitcher in his younger days, Richard Armbruster kept playing baseball recreationally into his 70s, until his right hip started bothering him. Last February he went to a St. Louis hospital for what was to be a routine hip replacement.

title: Julianne of the Spirits
description: A Single Man, you play Charlotte, a wealthy, aging English glamour girl who is attached to, and may be in love with, her gay best friend, George. Their complicated relationship is one of the centerpieces of Tom Fords movie, which chronicles a day in the life of a grieving professor in 60s Los Angeles. Your character is reminiscent of Ann-Margret in Carnal Knowledge  did that influence you?

title: On Top of the Happiness Racket
description: HERE we are, already at the end of February. Its been weeks since our scant New Years resolutions fell under the bed, joining the resolution dust bunnies of yesteryear.

title: From One Island to Another
description: Amy Gottlieb and her family were living in Battery Park City on Sept. 11, 2001. Not long thereafter, she moved to City Island in the Bronx.

title: Iraqi Sunnis Pin Their Hopes on Elections
description: BAQUBA, Iraq  Here in Diyala, a quarter of provincial council members, all Sunnis, have warrants against them. Most dont show up for votes, fearing they will be jailed. The leading Sunni candidate was arrested this month on what supporters call trumped-up terrorism charges. Crushing poverty is the norm. So is mistrust of a central government and the Shiite-dominated security forces.

title: At the Whitney, Busting Out Quietly
description: ITS a lot cheaper to get a new wig than a new wife, the art collector Mera Rubell said at the gala on Tuesday for the opening of the Whitney Biennial. Peering out from beneath a spiky platinum Warhol wig, the dark-haired Ms. Rubell gazed up at her husband, Don, a former obstetrician turned art mogul, and added that she had another look for the after-party.

title: The Week in Pictures for February 26
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a rustic cabin in Manhattan, an acquittal for a police officer, and a curling club.

title: Soulful Music at Its Heart
description: THE first thing a person notices after entering Tillmans, the soul music lounge on West 26th Street in Manhattan, is that it contains one of the most diverse crowds in New York. And that does not mean the typical Manhattan mingling of model plus banker with a sprinkling of trust fund hipster.

title: Letting Loose
description: A night out at the Sugar Bar in Manhattan with Andre Leon Talley and Whoopi Goldberg.

title: Now Screening | Gianfranco Ferr
description: The fall 2010 collection from Gianfranco Ferr at Milan Fashion Week.

title: When British Building Began With Compass and Ruler
description: Sometimes the shows at the Yale Center for British Art  always scholarly, with a focus on Britain and its former colonies  are as fascinating as they are informative. The tribute last year to Charles Darwin, which was organized in association with the Fitzwilliam Museum at the University of Cambridge to coincide with the 200th anniversary of the scientists birth, was among the highlights of the exhibition season in the region.

title: Processing Alex Katz, From Sketch to Finish
description: Alex Katz is one of those artists who have enjoyed tremendous commercial and museum success but whose art historical importance remains an open question. He is not a bad painter, just not original enough  or even good enough  to suggest that his will be a lasting contribution to American art. Critics tend to complain that his colorful portraits of friends and family are flat, static and unremarkable.

title: High-Wire Act
description: When Allan Kaprow wrote, in his 1966 guidelines for happenings, that the line between art and life should be kept as fluid, and perhaps indistinct, as possible, he could not in his wildest dreams have predicted James Franco. Last year, the Spider-Man star appeared on General Hospital in the role of an artist named Franco. Then he unmasked the character as a piece of performance art and announced that the fictional Franco would exhibit at the real Deitch Projects.

title: It Took Tools to Build a Revolution
description: NEW HAVEN  At first glance, the handsome galleries of a newly mounted exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art might seem to portray a contemplative world of measure, calm and consistency. There is an enormous 18th-century compass  a drawing instrument familiar to high school geometry students (though this one seems designed for a standing adult rather than a sitting child). There is also Queen Elizabeths decorously refined astrolabe from 1559, along which a visitor may align a gaze (though without the hope, indoors, that this star-sighting instrument might provide any information about time and place).

title: Trailer: Heavy Rain
description: The murder mystery, developed by FindQuantic Dream for the Sony PlayStation 3, takes its inspiration from noir films.

title: Lifes Hard, but Hopeful
description: Its been a bad season for Neil Simon. Although Broadway critics said good things about the Brighton Beach Memoirs revival last fall, it closed after a week. Broadway Bound, which was to be Part 2 of The Neil Simon Plays, a major theatrical event, never opened. The ticket-buying public, it seemed, just didnt care.

title: A Tragedy of Freedom and Humanity Denied
description: IN 1856, Margaret Garner, a slave from Kentucky, fled with seven members of her family to Ohio, where they were recaptured  and where she made the horrific decision to kill her children rather than see them live in captivity.

title: Toyota Extends Assistance for Owners of Recalled Cars
description: Toyota is going nationwide with an assistance program previously offered to New York State owners of Toyota and Lexus vehicles affected by recent safety recalls.

title: Chic in Review | Christian Dior, the Musical
description: BirkinsBeing destroyed left, right and center. Blasphemy!

title: Yakisoba: Leeway Among the Noodles
description: YAKISOBA is one of those dishes with roots in several countries. Although its from Japan, it is Chinese influenced, similar to chow mein and lo mein. However you define it, there are thousands of ways to make yakisoba, many of them good. All contain noodles and vegetables, and usually some protein. The dish is always fried in a pan and finished with a somewhat sweet sauce that is put together quickly, from condiments. All of this provides plenty of leeway.

title: Discobus: Where Beer and Spirits Are Free
description: Frivolity reigns on the party bus from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to a club on the Lower East Side.

title: Yakisoba
description: Mark Bittman recreates an everyday Japanese fast food recipe.

title: Now Online | T Womens Fashion Spring 2010
description: We love a bit of drama at T. Which is just as well, as this season its all about the spirit of performance, as embodied by our redoubtable cover star Julianne Moore, who acts out the complex theater of feminine personae for the photographer Raymond Meier. Elsewhere, Chantal Thomass, wearable furniture, combat-ready fashion, tribal brights, monster mania, D.I.Y couture and the-model-turned-actress Agyness Deyn take center stage. We profile the art-world provocateuse Marina Abramovic, who is in the spotlight more than ever now that performance art is the new black. Linda Yablonsky surveys the female artists in the Whitney Biennial; we meet Dasha Zhukova, the art worlds quiet achiever; and introduce a troika of ex-assistants who are at the helm of three venerable French labels. Bravo!

title: Weekend Readings
description: The Reformations end?

title: A Tip on Slavery, Holocaust Talk
description: Its time for this little refresher to our friends on Capitol Hill.

title: Paterson Drops Out of Governor's Race
description: Gov. David A. Paterson of New York dropped his bid for re-election Friday, citing an "accumulation of obstacles" that had made it difficult to campaign and attend to the state's needs.

title: Sharing a Sixth Sense in Musical Collaboration
description: LIKE ships passing in the night, the violinist Joshua Bell and the pianist Jeremy Denk missed each other by a year at Indiana University. By the time Mr. Denk entered, in 1990, Mr. Bell had already graduated and was on his way to becoming one of the leading soloists of his generation.

title: Experiencing Iranian Culture Through a Masters Films
description: Jonathan Demme first encountered the films of Bahman Farmanara,the Iranian filmmaker, at Lincoln Centers 2007 retrospective of his work. I was completely knocked out, Mr. Demme said recently by telephone.

title: What Were Reading: Art Fraud, Steve Jobs and Citibank
description: Fridays highlights from our What Were Reading feature, in which New York Times technology journalists point out interesting articles they have spotted on the Web:

title: The DArtagnan Anniversary Party
description: (Daniel attends the big deal culinary event of the season, or at least the month  MB)

title: Murderers Young Prey; A Fathers Torment
description: The big storm has been raging for days. The winds around the eaves make me lonely, melancholy, and yet my guilt forces me forward in search of redemption.

title: Defying Global Slump, China Has Labor Shortage
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Just a year after laying off millions of factory workers, China is facing an increasingly acute labor shortage.

title: Elegant Yet Modern, and What a View!
description: STEP into the Polytechnic ON20 Restaurant, an excellent, earth-toned eatery on the 20th floor of the Hartford Steam Boiler Building, and two thoughts occur simultaneously. Why havent I heard more about this place? And, what do I have to do to get one of those window tables?

title: U.S.-UBS Deal Is Undermined by Swiss Ruling
description: ZURICH  A Swiss court ordered tax officials to drop two more cases involving account holders of the banking giant UBS, adding urgency to the governments effort to find a political solution that would preserve a data-sharing agreement with American regulators.

title: The Curious Case of the Hurt Locker Attacks
description: Timing counts in everything but horseshoes, as the saying doesnt go, and some awards-watchers are finding the timing and placement of several Oscar-related stories mighty suspicious. This matter has the distinct smell of awards-season dirty tricks, S.T. Vanairsdale writes in Movieline, about a Los Angeles Times article reported from Baghdad, Los Angeles and Washington  in which veterans and military personnel criticize The Hurt Locker as inaccurate and disrespectful. (It also smells pretty familiar.)

title: Luring Diners Out of Their Dens
description: As groundhogs stir, the fourth annual Hudson Valley Restaurant Week will be tempting diners from their own winter sleep. With more than 130 restaurants participating  twice the number that first signed on in 2007  the 14-day event, this year from March 15-28, has blossomed into something of a prix-fixe-palooza.

title: Mexican Remedies for Snow Shoveling
description: ON a dark icy night, Don Emilios windows radiate a rosy glow onto Chappaquas gray main thoroughfare and promise warmth within. Thats delivered by hospitable, affable Don Emilio Martinez himself. The welcome begins early at the front bar, with happy hour, which packs in, on weeknights in particular, a convivial bunch that clearly enjoys the crush. This place is fun.

title: U.S. Eyes New Target: Heartland of Taliban
description: WASHINGTON  Even as it presses its campaign to run insurgents out of the Taliban stronghold of Marja in Afghanistan, the United States military is looking ahead toward taking the fight to Kandahar, the Talibans spiritual and political heartland, White House officials said Friday.

title: New Reds for Famiglia
description: Although the Diliberto Winery and its adjacent three-acre vineyard are in Jamesport, they are nourished spiritually by Italy. Salvatore A. Diliberto, who owns the winery with his wife, Maryann, has family roots in the Campania region. When you walk into the casual tasting room, you are famiglia.

title: A New Entry True to Its Italian Roots
description: VERACE translates as true, and the Islip restaurant by that name, which opened in January, is true to its Italian roots. The newcomer is owned by the Bohlsen family, which also runs Tellers Chophouse next door, Prime in Huntington, H2O Seafood Grill in Smithtown and Beachtree Cafe in East Islip.

title: A Family Talks a Lot but Says Too Little
description: LOS ANGELES  Communication is definitely a problem in the household of The Subject Was Roses, Frank D. Gilroys 1964 drama about disappointed lives in the Bronx in the aftermath of World War II.

title: Oreos in the (Pancake) Mix
description: When Stacks Pancake House and Cafe opened in Hoboken in December, the response was overwhelming, according to Scott Handler, one of the owners.

title: Where Vegetables Serve as More Than Sides
description: GLADSTONE TAVERN is a destination for vegetable skeptics. Beautiful on the plate and unfailingly delicious, the well-prepared orbs, cubes and leaves hold their own against upscale meats  short ribs, duck, chicken, steak, lamb  and a couple of seafood picks in a pleasant lodge-style setting.

title: For 7-Level Contract in Russia, 7 Trumps Prove Sufficient
description: What is highly unusual about the diagramed deal?

title: Without a Single Throw, Tebow Rules the Combine
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Heisman Trophy and two national championships probably prepared Tim Tebow for moments like this, but when Tebowmania finally made it to the scouting combine Friday, the N.F.L. had a rare commodity: a player who is unlikely to be picked in the first round morphing into the weeks biggest star.

title: U.S. Bobsledder Beats 50-50 Curve
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The bobsleds came and they spilled over, one after another at the same treacherous curve in a recycling of pileups. The occupants left as breaths exhaled, departing with bruised body parts and egos.

title: Gov. Patersons Next Steps
description: Gov. David Paterson of New York served up one of the great political understatements on Friday when he talked about the accumulation of obstacles to his campaign for election. He did the right thing  the only thing  by dropping out of the race, but that is not going to make his troubles go away.

title: Medal of Underage Chinese Gymnast Revoked
description: After an investigation that lasted more than a year, the International Gymnastics Federation announced on Friday that a Chinese gymnast from the 2000 Olympics had been too young to compete.

title: The Accidental Lieutenant
description: Albany

title: Dissidents Death Ignites Protest Actions in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY  The death of a jailed Cuban dissident this week after a long hunger strike has led to a surge of criticism of the Cuban government and prompted several other dissidents to announce that they will begin forgoing food to press for political change in a nation that allows little public dissent.

title: White House Social Secretary to Resign
description: On Thursday evening, the White House social secretary, Desire Rogers, presided over yet another glittering event, with luminaries like Sarah Jessica Parker sipping sparkling wine while Rita Moreno, star of the film West Side Story, danced to the Marine orchestras rendition of the score.

title: Milan Goes in All Directions
description: Like it or not, much about a Prada show feels brave and responsible. Miuccia Prada is singularly open about women. She is wise about their ways of being. A great deal about physical beauty and sexual attractiveness fascinates her, but as an intelligent woman she also readily acknowledges a feeling of repulsion.

title: David Soyer, Cellist, Is Dead at 87
description: David Soyer, the founding cellist of the Guarneri String Quartet and a link to the legendary cellists Pablo Casals and Emanuel Feuermann, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Germanys Export Prowess Weighs on Euro-Zone
description: FRANKFURT  Glasbau Hahn could easily be mistaken for one of the auto repair shops or plumbing supply outlets that characterize a former factory district a few miles from Frankfurts banking quarter.

title: On a Day of Surprises, U.S. Speedskating Teams Rule the Track
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The American women pulled off a miracle on ice Friday, eclipsing the world-record holders from Canada by five-hundredths of a second in a head-to-head quarterfinal race in the team speedskating pursuit to eliminate the Canadians.

title: Ernst Beyeler, Top Dealer of Modern Art, Dies at 88
description: Ernst Beyeler, one of the worlds foremost dealers of modern art, who established a jewel-like small museum, the Fondation Beyeler, to display his private collection of important works by Monet, van Gogh, Picasso, Giacometti and others, died on Thursday at his home in Riehen, Switzerland, outside Basel. He was 88.

title: Buying Milk and Meat, With Plastic
description: To think of food stamps is to conjure up images of coupons printed with the faces of presidents and the seal of the Agriculture Department. But since 1999, New Yorkers who qualify for food stamps have used Electronic Benefit Transfer cards, which look and act like debit cards.

title: Panel Clears 7 Lawmakers in Lobbying Scandal
description: WASHINGTON  The House ethics committee cleared seven members of Congress on Friday of official charges of wrongdoing in a lobbying scandal despite a separate, independent investigation that cast a harsh spotlight on the pay-to-play culture in Washington.

title: In a Shake-Up, Citigroup to Add Ernesto Zedillo to Its Board
description: Bracing for more criticism over its enormous bailouts, Citigroup shook up its board on Friday and is preparing a marketing campaign to revamp its image with Washington and Wall Street.

title: In Need of Allies, Governor Walks Alone
description: In the end, what was most striking was his isolation.

title: For Cuomo, Spotlight Suddenly Grows Hotter
description: For months, Andrew M. Cuomo has silently inhabited a world of grand assumptions: that he was by far the strongest Democrat to run for governor of New York; that his poll numbers were not merely overwhelming but durable; that his fund-raising prowess would turn his inevitable campaign into a juggernaut.

title: A Chin Guard Is Lost at the Wrong Time
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The vast majority of slalom skiers attach a chin guard to their helmet to protect their face during races and training. Modern slalom technique requires racers to ski directly at the flexible slalom gates, slamming them backward with the racers shins and with hand guards affixed to ski poles.

title: Cellphones Let Shoppers Point, Click and Purchase
description: Shoppers will soon be able to stand outside the designer Norma Kamalis boutique in Manhattan, point a phone at merchandise in the window and buy it  even late at night when the store is closed.

title: We Wail With You, Haiti
description: ON Jan. 13, the day after the earthquake that upended Haiti, Garry Pierre-Pierre, editor and publisher of The Haitian Times, moved the center of operations for his weekly newspaper from Brooklyn to a tent in the backyard of a damaged apartment building in Port-au-Prince. If he was going to cover one of the most transformative events in the history of the country and its diaspora, he knew there was only one place for him to be.

title: U.S. Routs Finland, but Questions and Canada Remain
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  How good is the United States mens hockey team, really? The American record so far consists of some workmanlike but not overwhelming preliminary games, an amazing upset against the Canadians (assisted immeasurably by Ryan Millers spectacular goaltending and Martin Brodeurs miscues) and now an easy recreational cruise past the Finns.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE ROOSEVELT ISLAND TABLE TENNIS PROGRAM was the idea of George Braithwaite, who has lived on the island for 35 years and was inducted into the Table Tennis Hall of Fame in 1989. Mr. Braithwaite, 64, known as  The Chief,  played on the United States team that fostered Ping-Pong diplomacy with China in 1971. This month, he used his diplomatic skills to broker an agreement to create a Ping-Pong program at Sportspark, a gym near the tram. When Mr. Brathwaite, who has a taste for dapper warm-up suits, walked into the gym on Wednesday night, the clack-clacking from a half-dozen games stopped, and the players watched reverently as he showed off his deadly serve, vicious volleys and fast-twitch top-spin returns (video is online at nytimes.com/cityroom). We want to see what kind of talent we have on this island, he said.

title: On a Bus From Brooklyn, the Party Rolls
description: WE were somewhere around Manhattan on the edge of the river when the beers began to take hold.

title: House Inquiry on Trips Is Criticized as Weak
description: WASHINGTON  A Congressional inquiry that cleared five House Democrats and lightly admonished Representative Charles B. Rangel for accepting free trips to the Caribbean drew harsh criticism on Friday from some ethics lawyers who said it showed that Congress was still loath to police itself.

title: As a Derby Favorite Soars, His Owner Stumbles
description: Ahmed Zayat was the nations leading thoroughbred owner two years ago, and many of his 200-plus horses frequently visit the winners circle in the nations biggest races. In fact, one of his colts, Eskendereya, is the early favorite to win the Kentucky Derby after running away with the $250,000 Fountain of Youth Stakes in Florida last Saturday.

title: A Ping-Pong Diplomat Back at the Table
description: A member of the U.S. table tennis team known for visiting China in 1971 and fostering Ping-Pong Diplomacy starts a Ping-Pong league on Roosevelt Island.

title: Blocked by Jeter, a Backup Finds Other Work
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Literally and figuratively, Mick Kelleher was once in Ramiro Penas position. As a shortstop in the St. Louis Cardinals organization in the late 1960s and early 70s, Kelleher played four years in the minors behind the incumbent, Dal Maxvill. The day after Maxvill was traded to Oakland, Kelleher was promoted, and he started the rest of the 1972 season.

title: Mets' Wright Trusts His Work Ethic, and His Sandwich
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Last month the Mets held a media event in the clubhouse at Citi Field, and David Wright made the trip to speak about the coming season.

title: For the Madoffs Not Related to Bernie, Life Suddenly Got More Complicated
description: Bernard L. Madoffs relatives are not the only people suffering indignities for bearing the Madoff name.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the TV Watch column on Friday about President Obamas televised health care forum on Thursday misidentified, in some editions, the political party of Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, who defended malpractice suits. He is a Democrat not a Republican.

title: Spitzer, Paterson and a Cult of Faux Piety
description: Eliot Spitzer still has enough political DNA to avoid piling on.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of military deaths on Thursday misidentified the country where Chief Warrant Officer Billie J. Grinder was killed in combat. It was Iraq, not Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Bloomberg News article on Feb. 18 about the income of the 400 highest-earning households in the United States misstated their earnings. As the headline correctly stated, $345 million was the average income of those households, not the total for all 400.

title: Seeing POD People? Its No Sci-Fi Film
description: PODs are the sleeper cells of public health, assuming a different shape and observing different local mores each time a crisis emerges. When hepatitis A was diagnosed in a bartender at the Manhattan nightclub Socialista two years ago, POD people were on hand to vaccinate patrons, including some guests at Ashton Kutchers birthday party. In the case of a bioterrorism attack, they might turn up in your neighborhood dispensing anthrax antidote. On Feb. 18, they were in Anshe Sfard Hall in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, rolling up the sleeves of Hasidic Jews. Thats a long way from Ashton Kutcher.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Olympic curler Kevin Martin and his popularity in Canada misidentified the town in Alberta where he grew up. It was Lougheed  not Killam, a town about 14 miles to the west, where he was born. (Because of that error, the reference to the population of his town having hovered around 200 should have been to Lougheed, not Killam.)

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Her Games at an End, Vonn Looks Ahead to 14
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Lindsey Vonn completed her last race of the 2010 Vancouver Olympics with shoulders slumped, slowly sliding sideways on the snow after missing a gate in the womens slalom Friday. It was a far cry from the Vonn who had been a streaking blur nine days earlier in the downhill, when she crossed the finish line with arms raised, the first American woman to win the event.

title: Dreams of a Unified Northwest Are Halted at the Border
description: BLAINE, Wash.  The Winter Olympics have made for strange days here in what many call Cascadia.

title: A Family Label, Ungarbled
description: WHEN I was pregnant for the first time, my biggest fear was not whether I would love the baby but whether I could. Whether I was capable of loving another human being at all.

title: In New Yorks Parks, a Snowy Day of Beauty and Caution
description: It looked like a typical snow day on Friday in Central Park. With schools closed, children took to the hills, armed with their sleds and their laughter. But there were signs of the dangers from above, dangers that many New Yorkers accustomed to the power failures and minor inconveniences of snowstorms tend to overlook: fallen tree limbs, cordoned off by police tape.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Lottery Numbers
Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: Tyler Perrys Crack Mothers
description: MoNique is a favorite to win an Oscar next Sunday for her powerful and disturbing portrayal of an abusive mother in the movie Precious.

title: How Do You Feel About That?
description: A friend of mine is open about her conversations with her therapist, who seems to dispense terrible advice. For instance, my friend has dated a man who has stood her up a few times. At her therapists suggestion, she has made a date with him  just to blow him off for revenge. I said, Why not talk to him directly about his behavior? But my friend takes everything her therapist says to heart. Should I express my concerns?

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Private Equity Firm Buys a Fast-Food Operator
description: CKE Restaurants, the owner of fast-food chains like Hardees and Carls Jr., agreed on Friday to sell itself to the private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners for $619 million in cash. Under the terms of the deal, the equity firm will pay $11.05 a share, a 24 percent premium to CKEs closing share price of $8.91 on Thursday. It will also assume about $309 million of CKEs debt.

title: Patersons Driver Problem
description: Robert Penn Warren knew what he was doing when he practically opened All the Kings Men, a meditation on power and politics, with a description of the driver. Sugar-Boy, a menace on the road and the chauffeur to the governor of some unnamed Southern state, shows up on Page 3 of my own copy, along with the .38 special which rode under his left armpit like a tumor.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: T Exclusive | Elle Muliarchyk
description: The photographer and filmmaker Elle Muliarchyk brings her brand of sinister glamour to "The Last Poet," an elegiac new fashion video, shot exclusively for T.

title: To Court Blacks, Foes of Abortion Make Racial Case
description: ATLANTA  For years the largely white staff of Georgia Right to Life, the states largest anti-abortion group, tried to tackle the disproportionately high number of black women who undergo abortions. But, staff members said, they found it difficult to make inroads with black audiences.

title: Recalling Mothers Advice, Rochette Chose to Skate
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  So many times in the days before the womens figure skating final on Thursday, Joannie Rochette wanted to pack up and go home.

title: Aide Asked State Police to Contact His Accuser
description: ALBANY  David W. Johnson, a top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson, reached out to the commander of the governors State Police detail the day after an altercation with his girlfriend and asked the commander to call the woman, according to a person briefed on the commanders actions.

title: 9 Across: Film About the Statue of Liberty?
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ah, I can hear the furor already. Not What is OH SNAP? or How am I supposed to remember who Laverne and Shirleys landlord was? but KETCHUP on a hot dog!?

title: Ex-Jihadist Defies Yemens Leader, and Easy Labels
description: ADEN, Yemen

title: Health Cares Clash of the Titans
description: Its a long way from Vancouver, but there there was an Olympian clash at the White House guest cabana Thursday, and despite the cloudy outlook, conditions didnt result in a debilitating outbreak of bipartisanship. So, who were the big winners and losers of Health Care Brouhaha of 2010? Lets first focus on the man in the middle of it all:

title: California Campus Sees Uneasy Race Relations
description: SAN DIEGO  It began, as so many racial flare-ups on campus do, with a prank that some called malicious, others insensitive.

title: Bloggingheads: Climate: Whom to Believe?
description: Mark Kleiman, left, of U.C.L.A. and Will Wilkinson of the Cato Institute debate climate change uncertainty.

title: Bill to Extend Jobless Benefits Hits a Partisan Roadblock
description: WASHINGTON  A partisan impasse in the Senate will cause unemployment benefits to run out for thousands of Americans beginning next week after the Senate was unable on Friday to temporarily extend the jobless pay.

title: Manhattan Highs and Your Permanent Record
description: Manhattan Highs

title: On Patrol and Almost Undercover
description: Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: Young Lust and Anxiety Inspired by a Classic
description: In Barry Wyners musical Calvin Berger, now onstage at George Street Playhouse, the endearingly neurotic title character has a problem. Burdened with an outsize nose, Calvin, played with great charm by Noah Weisberg, has been saving up for a facial circumcision fund since he was 10.

title: A Play-and-Nap Day. For My Son, Too.
description: Morgan Spurlock, 39, spent a month eating at McDonalds in Super Size Me," rode camels in the Middle East for Where in the World Is Osama bin Laden? and worked as a coal miner for the FX television series 30 Days. He recently directed and hosted The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special: In 3-D! On Ice! When Mr. Spurlock, who lives in Fort Greene, is not traveling, he spends Sundays with his 3-year-old son, Laken.

title: Democrats to Press Health Bill With Simple Majority
description: WASHINGTON  Seeing no prospect of a bipartisan agreement on health care, Congressional Democrats said Friday that they would make another effort to pass sweeping health care legislation on their own.

title: In the Bronx, Noodle War Takes Aim at a Growing Population
description: In a Bronx neighborhood of Puerto Rican barbershops, Mexican taco stalls and Irish bars, an unlikely noodle war has begun.

title: India and Pakistan (Barely) Talk
description: Low expectations for the first talks between India and Pakistan since the 2008 bombings in Mumbai were disappointingly on the mark. After the two sides met Thursday, Foreign Secretary Nirupama Rao of India said that she agreed only to keep in touch with her Pakistani counterpart, Salman Bashir. No future discussions were scheduled.

title: Clueless in Kentucky
description: Kentucky has lost about 60,000 jobs since the end of 2008. In December, its unemployment rate stood at 10.7 percent, the highest since 1983. So what exactly is going on in the minds of Kentuckys two Republican senators, Mitch McConnell and Jim Bunning?

title: The Man in White
description: Theres a dark and a troubled side of life. Theres a bright and a sunny side, too, and the trick  if youre an artist of any depth  is not to get stuck on one side or the other. That can be hard to do, harder if youre dying.

title: What Happened at the Health Forum?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemicals and Illness: The Personal and the General
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Teachers, Great Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stimulus and the Highways
description: To the Editor:

title: Paterson on the Brink
description: Its not like David Paterson had a choice. His decision to give up on a bid for election to governor in his own right was a decision to scrap a campaign that had no real support and absolutely no chance of succeeding. The bottom had completely fallen out of his election bid, and the question now is whether the same is true about his governorship.

title: Putting the Coast Guard Out to Sea
description: Washington

title: Let the S.E.C. Help Itself
description: Rochester

title: Council Seeks to Crack Down on Process Servers Who Lie
description: In a proposal aimed at unscrupulous debt collectors, the City Council is considering legislation that would require process servers to use global positioning systems to show that they have actually visited consumers homes or workplaces to deliver notices of collection proceedings.

title: At Hearing on Radiation, Calls for Better Oversight
description: WASHINGTON  A dozen witnesses, including representatives of virtually all of the leading professional groups in medical radiation, told a House subcommittee during a hearing Friday that more needed to be done to make sure that radiation continues to help, not harm, patients.

title: Versace Runway Show
description: The fall 2010 Versace collection as presented at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Rebecca Paterson and Douglas Hart
description: Rebecca Lynn Paterson and Douglas Gourley Hart were married Saturday in San Francisco. The Rev. Edward Seton Fittin, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Sir Francis Drake Hotel.

title: Cindy Hwang and Jay Ping Chiang
description: Cindy Hwang and Jay Ping Chiang were married Saturday at the Athenaeum, a club on the campus of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. David Chiu, the president of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, officiated after being appointed a deputy marriage commissioner for this event.

title: Olympics Pictures of the Day: Friday, Feb. 26
description: A look at the day in Olympic action, including highlights from hockey, Alpine skiing and curling events.

title: Hali Feldman and Benjamin Friehling
description: Hali Tara Feldman and Benjamin Lawrence Friehling were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky officiated at the W Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Marisa Rose, Robin van Bokhorst
description: Marisa Stephanie Rose, the daughter of Christina Rose and Allan V. Rose, both of New York, was married Saturday evening to Robin Alexander van Bokhorst, the son of Willem van Bokhorst, of Curaao, the Netherlands Antilles, and the late Felice van Bokhorst da Costa. The Rev. David J. Robb, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed an interfaith ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Marne Loveman, Matthew Friedman
description: Marne Joy Loveman and Matthew Bennett Friedman were married Friday evening at the Central Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman performed the ceremony. On March 6, Rabbi Stuart A. Gertman is to lead a second ceremony, at which the couples Jewish marriage certificate is to be signed, at the Ritz Carlton Rose Hall in St. James, Jamaica.

title: Rebecca Shaw, Michael Kelly
description: Rebecca Blackwood Shaw and Michael Loughran Kelly are to be married Sunday in an outdoor ceremony at Caneel Bay resort on St. John in the Virgin Islands. Deborah McDonald, a minister with New Horizon Ministry, is to officiate.

title: Meredith Radow, Herschel Thompson
description: Meredith Lynn Radow and Herschel Wayne Thompson were married Saturday evening at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi Sharon G. Forman officiated.

title: As Clock Ticks, Nuclear Plant Searches for Leak
description: VERNON, Vt.  At Vermont Yankee, a nuclear reactor on the ropes, the search for a tritium leak that may doom the plant is proceeding as quickly as possible  which is to say, at a painstaking pace.

title: Case Revives Debate Over Protection Orders
description: How protective is an order of protection? The short answer is: It depends.

title: Gina Ciraldo, Daniel Stabile
description: Gina Yolanda Ciraldo and Daniel Tramel Stabile were married Saturday at St. Patrick Church in Miami Beach. Msgr. John Vaughan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Lydio Tomasi taking part.

title: Disqualified in 500, Ohno Wins 8th Medal
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Over the past two weeks, Apolo Ohno danced with danger, evading crashes, employing strategy and adding two Winter Olympics medals to the most expansive collection in United States history. Sometimes he seemed forever fortunate.

title: Leslie Streeter and Scott Zervitz
description: Leslie Gray Streeter and Scott Mitchell Zervitz are to be married Sunday in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Paul Underhay, a Methodist minister, is to officiate at the Colony Hotel.

title: Stephanie Bressler, Blake Weissberg
description: Stephanie Rene Bressler and Blake Weissberg were married Saturday evening at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J. Rabbi Dennis Tobin officiated.

title: Samantha Greenes, Jeffrey Goldstein
description: Samantha Reig Greenes, the daughter of Jessica Redel and Steven Greenes, both of New York, is to be married Sunday to Jeffrey Alan Goldstein, the son of Patricia Goldstein of New York and the late Jack Goldstein. Rabbi Dr. Robert N. Levine is to officiate at the Standard Hotel, also in New York.

title: Sarah Burley, Douglas Reid
description: Sarah Elizabeth Burley and Douglas Gordon Reid were married on Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Michael J. Godderz, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: The Hague: Srebrenica Trial
description: The trial of a Bosnian Serb general accused of playing a key role in the 1995 massacre in Srebrenica, Bosnia, opened at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague on Friday. Gen. Zdravko Tolimir, 61, faces charges of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. Prosecutors said he was a right-hand man of Gen. Ratko Mladic, commander of the campaign to drive non-Serbs out of large areas of Bosnia and the tribunals most wanted fugitive. The trial of General Tolimir, who has been in custody since 2007, had been delayed because of his poor health. Unless General Mladic is arrested and handed over, this may be the last new case to come to trial in The Hague dealing with the 1990s wars in the former Yugoslavia.

title: North Korea: Four Detained
description: North Korea said Friday that four South Koreans charged with entering the North illegally were being detained. The South Koreans had crossed the border recently and were under interrogation, the state-run Korean Central News Agency said in a dispatch. It provided no further details.

title: Gaza War Inquiries Demanded
description: The General Assembly renewed its demand on Friday that Israel and the Palestinians conduct credible, independent investigations into possible war crimes during the Gaza war, to be completed within five months. The Goldstone report, issued by the United Nations Human Rights Council last fall, said there was evidence that both sides, but Israel in particular, committed war crimes and crimes against humanity during the three-week war in the winter of 2008-09. The resolution, which passed 98 to 7 with 31 abstentions, echoed a similar demand passed last November. Riyad Mansour, the ambassador representing the Palestinian Authority, which sponsored the resolution, said the vote indicated that the great majority of humanity is asking for the Goldstone report to be implemented. But other ambassadors suggested that repeated resolutions with little effect was more likely to be a sign of the reports slow, bureaucratic death.

title: Canada Advances, but Struggles With Slovakia
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  For Canada, it came down to a single play in the final moments. If the puck went one way, it meant a trip to Sundays Olympic gold-medal game against the United States. If it went the other, it meant a trip to overtime and possible humiliation against Slovakia.

title: Dodd Proposes Financial Protection Agency
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee on Friday proposed creating a Bureau of Financial Protection inside the Treasury Department to regulate mortgages, credit cards, payday loans and other consumer products.

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday with the Streetscapes column about 711 Fifth Avenue, a building that over time has housed NBC and the World of Disney store, erroneously included a reference to NBCs peacock logo. The logo was created in 1956, 23 years after NBC left the building, in 1933; therefore the Fifth Avenue building was not where the peacock nested.

title: License Plate Software Stirs Privacy Concerns
description: THE notion of roving cameras snapping pictures of license plates conjures up television shows like Foxs counterterrorism series, 24.

title: Classic Ad: Hummer H2
description: General Motors announced this week that, having failed to sell Hummerto a Chinese manufacturing company, it would begin shutting down the brand.If no other suitors mount an 11th-hour rescue, a quiet end seems likely for the purveyor of gas-guzzling behemoths, which unabashedly cultivated an aggressive my way on the highway ethos during the fatter parts of the last decade.

title: A One-Word Riddle
description: Video | Startling insight into English:

title: Conans Tweets
description: Incoming | With time on his hands, Conan OBrien joins Twitter. His first three tweets:

title: S.B.A. Stimulus Extension Lives, Then Dies, in Congress
description: Among the victims of Republican Senator Jim Bunnings move to stall a jobless benefits bill Thursday are small-business owners who hoped to take advantage of stimulus provisions to increase Small Business Administration lending.

title: Performance Cover Art | You Be The Judge
description: In the spirit of performance, the theme of this Sundays T Womens Spring Fashion 2010 issue, readers receive one of two covers: Julianne Moore au naturel, or Julianne Moore highly theatrical. Do you like one better than the other? Pray tell!

title: The Saturday Word: Revisiting Health Care
description: Democrats and Republicans continued the political battle over health insurance reform in their weekly addresses in an extension of Thursdays 7-hour health care summit  which was, if anything, divisive.

title: Updates on the Earthquake in Chile
description: As my colleagues Alexei Barrionuevo and Liz Robbins report, an 8.8 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Chile on Saturday morning, setting off a tsunami warning across much of the Pacific. The Lede is tracking reports of the damage. Readers are encouraged to share first-hand accounts of the earthquake or preparations for the potential tsunami with us, or point to any eyewitness video, photographs or text accounts they see on the Web, by writing in the comments thread below.

title: A Strong-Willed Storm
description: Monologue |  Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: What is being called a strong-willed storm blasted through New York and New England today. Millions of people were unable to get where they used to work.

title: Redesigning the Penny
description: Monologue |  Friday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: The U.S. Mint has announced theyre redesigning the penny. The pennys going to have Abraham Lincoln on the front and a shield on the back. And Im thinking, Lincolns probably thinking, Oh, sure, now you give me a shield. Its probably too soon to say that.

title: Van Jones to Glenn Beck: I Love You, Brother
description: Van Jones is back on the scene for a second act, and hes got a peculiar affection for the Fox TV host whose persistent attacks helped bring down the curtains on his post with the Obama administration.

title: When You Cant Say It With Roses
description: Video | You cant make this up:

title: Earthquake in Chile
description: An 8.8-magnitude earthquake rocked Chile, toppling buildings and triggering tsunami warnings across the Pacific Ocean.

title: Now Screening | Giorgio Armani
description: The fall 2010 collection from Giorgio Armani at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Now Screening | Jil Sander
description: The fall 2010 collection from Jil Sander at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Photos of the Moment | Party On, Milan
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary from the photographers of Contrasto.

title: Reform And Premiums, Explained
description: So the big factual debate in the health summit was over whether insurance premiums would rise or fall under the Democratic plan. The answer is that they would fall  but Republicans successfully threw up dust by pointing to the CBO conclusion that average payments to insurance companies would rise.

title: Unlikely Activist Who Got to the Tea Party Early
description: SEATTLE  Keli Carender has a pierced nose, performs improv on weekends and lives here in a neighborhood with more Mexican grocers than coffeehouses. You might mistake her for the kind of young person whose vote powered President Obama to the White House. You probably would not think of her as a Tea Party type.

title: Crocidolite Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  I made a discovery while solving this puzzle thats going to sound ridiculous  using a pencil. I do almost everything in pen these days, from solving puzzles to sketching to writing, even writing puzzles. But for me, an acrostic takes a bit more guessing than a crossword, and it finally occurred to me that a pencil might be a better choice given the limited space in the Times layout. It was.

title: Chile Earthquake Leads to Tsunami Warnings
description: A powerful 8.8-magnitude earthquake struck Chile early Saturday, shaking the capital of Santiago for 90 seconds and sending tsunami warnings along much of the Pacific basin, including Hawaii. Follow updates at nytimes.com and the Lede blog.

title: Conflict in Senate Could Get Messier
description: In the original Star Trek series, a popular episode centered on two planets that fought a bloodless war through computer simulation but then delivered real casualties. The partisan conflict in the Senate has been waged in a similar fashion.

title: Olympic Glory, Led by Stars Hardly on the Team
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  No gold is awarded to the nation that takes home the most medals at the Vancouver Games, yet for a few countries, the battle to rack up the most golds, silvers and bronzes can be one of the most competitive sports at the Olympics.

title: District May End N.C. Economic Diversity Program
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  When Rosemarie Wilson moved her family to a wealthy suburb of Raleigh a couple of years ago, the biggest attraction was the prestige of the local public schools. Then she started talking to neighbors.

title: Youre So Vain
description: Jonathan Chait and Robert Waldmann, in slightly different ways, highlight a crucial dynamic in American political debate: the extent to which public figures are punished for actually knowing what theyre talking about.

title: Now Screening | Versace
description: The fall 2010 collection from Versace at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Good News About The WSJ
description: Brad DeLong and Felix Salmon both point to evidence that the Murdoch effect is degrading the Journals news coverage. Indeed.

title: At Binghamton, Concern That Sports Still a Focus
description: VESTAL, N.Y.  In the weeks since an audit faulted Binghamton Universitys leadership for allowing its mens basketball program to spin out of control, the university has experienced a crisis of confidence. Interviews with students, administrators and faculty members revealed just how corrosive the trade-offs were in Binghamtons pursuit of athletic glory.

title: W. E. Gordon, Creator of Link to Deep Space, Dies at 92
description: William E. Gordon, an electrical engineer who conceived, designed, built and operated the worlds largest radio telescope, which has been described as Earths ear to outer space, died on Feb. 16 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 92.

title: L.P.G.A. Tour Will Put a Stop in Malaysia
description: The L.P.G.A. Tour plans to announce Monday that it will hold a title-sponsored event in Malaysia to replace a previously scheduled event in China.

title: Decision Could Allow Anonymous Political Contributions by Businesses
description: The Supreme Court decision last month allowing corporations to spend unlimited money on behalf of political candidates left a loophole that campaign finance lawyers say could allow companies to pay for extensive political advertising while avoiding the disclosure requirements the court appeared to leave intact.

title: States Move to Revoke Charities Tax Exemptions
description: Faced with steep declines in tax revenue, an increasing number of states and localities are considering eliminating various tax exemptions for nonprofit groups.

title: Underwater Plate Cuts 400-Mile Gash
description: The magnitude 8.8 earthquake that struck off the coast of Chile early Saturday morning occurred along the same fault responsible for the biggest quake ever measured, a 1960 tremor that killed nearly 2,000 people in Chile and hundreds more across the Pacific.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At Algarve Cup, a Win and More Chocolates
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Womens Professional Soccer in the leagues first season. Now, Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, is on the roster of the United States womens national team as it prepares for the Algarve Cup tournament in Portugal. She was named to the team by Coach Pia Sundhage after a January training camp in Carson, Calif. Averbuch will be filing to the Goal blog during her trip to Portugal.

title: Cramped Quarters Define Struggles of Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  When Wathiq Htaib talks about the crisis in Iraq, he does not mean politics or sectarian strife. On a recent afternoon, Mr. Htaib, 31, sat on the floor of a small, bare room where six family members sleep each night.

title: Changing Face in Poland: Skinhead Puts on Skullcap
description: WARSAW  When Pawel looks into the mirror, he can still sometimes see a neo-Nazi skinhead staring back, the man he was before he covered his shaved head with a skullcap, traded his fascist ideology for the Torah and renounced violence and hatred in favor of God.

title: Irans Leader of Opposition Assails Cult of Rulers
description: One of Irans opposition leaders, Mir Hussein Moussavi, said Saturday that a dictatorial cult was ruling Iran  one of his most critical statements against the countrys rulers since disputed elections last summer.

title: In Yemens South, Protests Could Cause More Instability
description: ADEN, Yemen  Less than an hours drive outside this dilapidated port town, the Yemeni governments authority is scarcely visible, and a different flag appears, that of the old independent state of South Yemen.

title: Buffetts Bargain Shopping Spree
description: Americas most famous investor, Warren E. Buffett, struck a confident note in his annual letter to the shareholders of his holding company on Saturday, as he described in characteristically colorful terms how his businesses had largely ridden out the calamity of the financial crisis.

title: Wary Centrists Posing Challenge in Health Care Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The future of President Obamas health care overhaul now rests largely with two blocs of swing Democrats in the House of Representatives  abortion opponents and fiscal conservatives  whose indecision signals the difficulties Speaker Nancy Pelosi faces in securing the votes necessary to pass the bill.

title: Maps of the Chile Earthquake
description: Initial reports of damage from the 8.8-magnitude earthquake that struck central Chile early Saturday.

title: The Winter Games With the Summery Smile
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  It is hard to imagine a more beautiful, welcoming and diverse city hosting the Olympics  the Summer Olympics.

title: Where Home Prices Are Still Falling
description: What do Tampa and New York have in common?

title: For a Moment of Glory, Mastering a Million Details
description: NORWICH, Vt.

title: Now Screening | Bottega Veneta
description: The fall 2010 collection from Bottega Veneta at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Ripples of H.G.H. Test in England Are Being Felt Across the U.S.
description: Terry Newton, a professional rugby player with a thick chest and a tattoo of a star on his left knee, has played on three teams over the last 11 years and in the parlance of the rugged sport has often played hooker, a versatile playmaker positioned in the middle of the front row.

title: Prince Shows Support for Citis Pandit
description: Kingdom Holdings Prince Walid bin Talal, left, expressed support for Citigroups chief executive, Vikram Pandit, on Saturday.

title: Powerful Earthquake Hits Chile
description: A 8.8-magnitude earthquake hit Chile and triggered tsunami warnings across the Pacific Ocean. (Video via MSNBC.)

title: Buffetts Bargain Shopping Spree
description: Americas most famous investor, Warren E. Buffett, struck a confident note in his annual letter to the shareholders of his holding company on Saturday, as he described in characteristically colorful terms how his businesses had largely ridden out the calamity of the financial crisis, The New York Timess Graham Bowley reports.

title: After Race, Miller Says His Career May Go On
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Bode Millers last race of the Vancouver Olympics lasted less than 10 seconds as he missed an early gate and skied out of the first run of Saturdays mens slalom. But afterward, Miller said his multiple medal experience at the 2010 Winter Games had made it likely he would continue his ski racing career after this season.

title: Analysis of C.T.A. Data Reveals No Bias
description: Though critics of the Chicago Transit Authoritys recent cuts in service contend that the reductions disproportionately affect low-income and minority areas, a Chicago News Cooperative analysis of transit, racial and economic data paints a more even-handed, and milder, picture.

title: Hawaii Exhales as Tsunami Warning Is Canceled
description: KAUAI, Hawaii  Tsunami waves arrived in Hawaii on Saturday afternoon, as predicted, causing erratic surges in the sea, but the impact was not nearly as great as had been feared. The rising water did not appear to cause significant property damage, officials said, and a tsunami warning was canceled.

title: Fit for a Rezko, a Home Goes on the Market
description: For a man known for his shady political and business dealings, Tony Rezkos home life seems to have been more than sufficiently illuminated.

title: The Dish: A Report on Pitchers by a Catcher to the Stars
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  On the last play of his college career, at Southern California in 1996, Chad Moeller tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee in a collision at the plate against U.C.L.A. It was an omen.

title: Prime Number
description: 30: The percentage of millennials (Americans ages 18 to 29)who say having a successful marriage is one of the most important things in their lives, according to a survey by the Pew Research Center. Perhaps that may have something to do with the fact that only about 6 in 10 were raised by both parents. Just about 20 percent of millennials are married, half the number of their parents generation at the same stage of life. But 34 percent of millennials are parents, according to Pew. Whats most important to millennials? Fifty-two percent said, being a good parent.

title: Tackling Challenges of Memory and History
description: Six years ago, the playwright Emilie Beck was home with a colicky baby and a mounting sense of disconnection from the rest of the world when she read about an exchange between President George W. Bush and Bob Woodward, the author and journalist.

title: Protests and Promises of Improvements at Schools
description: Josephine Norwood, a Bronzeville mother of three Chicago public school students, has rebounded from two rounds of school closings that displaced her children from their schools. As she watched the Board of Education approve another set of schools for closing or turnaround last week, Mrs. Norwood had a simple question: Can Chicago Public Schools officials promise that the new schools will be better?

title: A Mongolian Dzud Hits Herders Hard
description: Think your winter has been bad? Try livingin Mongolia. Over 2.7 million livestock animals have perished there after persistent heavy snows covered up sparse grazing areas, the United Nations reported. Another three million animals may die. Mongolians are no strangers to tough winters. But this one has been particularly harsh because of a phenomenon known as dzud, which occurs when deep snows and bitter cold are preceded by dry summers that limit grazing. To help Mongolians, a third of whom depend on herding and agriculture, a cash-for-work program run by the United Nations will pay 60,000 herders to clear away dead animals and bury them.

title: Quotations of the Week
description: It is like drinking merlot.Douglas A. Kass, the president of Seabreeze Partners, on the sport of curling.

title: Senator Pushes His Plan to Overhaul Health Care
description: To many California political insiders, the idea of the state adopting a Canadian-style health plan  run by the government with care delivered by private doctors and hospitals  seems fanciful.

title: Reading File
description: Why Snowboarders Should Salute Sherman Poppen

title: In a Country of Monopoly Newspapers, Palo Alto Is Awash in Competition
description: People in Palo Alto, Calif., frequently call Dave Price a contrarian. While they typically mean it as a slam, Mr. Price, the co-founder and editor of the Palo Alto Daily Post, considers it a badge of honor.

title: A Spiritual Connection to the Ships
description: Martin Davis works on the mooring repair crew at the San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park on the Hyde Street pier. Mr. Davis, who was transferred to the park museum in 1999 after the Oakland Naval Supply Center closed, repairs mooring lines and does maintenance work. The park preserves ships from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The first time Mr. Davis, 58, climbed into the hold of the Balclutha, a three-masted ship launched in 1886, he thought of the slaves confined in ships lower decks during their transport to America before the Civil War. He lives in Berkeley with his family. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

title: Prudential P.L.C. Closes In on Deal for A.I.G. Unit
description: Updated | Feb. 28, 5:15 p.m.Prudential P.L.C. is close to clinching a deal to acquire the American International Groups Asian life insurance unit for about $35.5 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday. Read more here.

title: How to Improve the Olympics
description: A Room for Debate forum on Tuesday discussed the growth in events at the Winter Games, with the addition of riskier sports like snowboard cross, halfpipe, aerial skiing, mogul skiing, ski cross and skeleton. Many readers sent in ideas for sports to add or cut, and more generally, for making the games more entertaining. Here are excerpts from their comments.

title: For Buyout Kingpins, the TXU Utility Deal Gets Tricky
description: IN the fall of 2007, nerves were fraying on Wall Street. Billions of dollars promised to private equity firms to finance an epic acquisition spree were threatened, and banks wanted dealmakers to share the pain. Renegotiate the loans, the banks said. The private equity firms disagreed: a deal, they argued, is a deal.

title: 1.5 Million Displaced After Chile Quake
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A strong aftershock struck Chile on Sunday, a day after a destructive 8.8-magnitude earthquake left hundreds of people dead and a long swath of the country in smoky rubble.

title: 6 Months, $90,000 and (Maybe) a Great Idea
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.

title: For a Legally Blind Cross-Country Skier, a Triumphant Perspective
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  To spend any time around the Canadian cross-country skier Brian McKeever, who is legally blind, is to pity all the people who do not see as well as he does.

title: Opinion Polling: A Question of What to Ask
description: W. H. Auden couldnt have had public opinion polls in mind when he wrote that to ask the hard question is simple.

title: Curlers Form Close-Knit Community of Camaraderie and Competition
description: CHILLIWACK, British Columbia  If you ask Canadians about the appeal of curling  a game that to Americans seems to be about pushing around bizarre, tea kettle-shaped rocks and then yelling Whoa! and Hurry up! at them  what they say most often is that people here, especially those who live on the prairie, need something to do to keep from going stir-crazy during long winters.

title: We Cant Wish Away Climate Change
