description: It would be an enormous relief if the recent attacks on the science of global warming actually indicated that we do not face an unimaginable calamity requiring large-scale, preventive measures to protect human civilization as we know it.

title: The Free-Appropriation Writer
description: Heres an exercise: Think of almost any kind of cultural endeavor and then use the word we to describe its creation. The communal pronoun trips easily off the tongue when talking about the world of contemporary arts and entertainment, where things are often the product of teams, workshops, studios or institutions, where collaboration and idea-swapping are the norm. But now try applying it to creative writing, especially to fiction and poetry, and it can sound absurd: We worked for years on the character development and the voice, and when we finally nailed the subtle epiphany, we cracked open a bottle of Champagne to celebrate.

title: A Strategy for Keeping Girls in African Schools
description: Last September I posted about the increasingly widespread belief in the global development community that one way to help high school girls in poor countries stay in school is to help them manage menstruation. Theres anecdotal evidence that girls stay home during their periods (because of a lack of hygiene products and underwear, as well as embarrassment, cramps and taboos). Then they get further and further behind and eventually drop out. If thats true, then interventions to address this would be a cost-effective way of keeping girls in school.

title: A.I.G. Chairman Critiques Pay Caps
description: The chairman of the American International Group wrote in a letter (PDF) to the insurers shareholders that the firm has sometimes been hurt by government-imposed compensation limits, yet anticipates being supported by the government for some time.

title: Wilson and Babcock Excel, but in Different Contexts
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Although both coaches for Sundays gold medal game, Ron Wilson of the United States and Mike Babcock of Canada, are respected N.H.L. bench bosses, they carry somewhat different reputations.

title: Paterson Scandal Scars a Piece of Harlem History
description: David A Paterson was the great hope of Harlems Gang of Four. He was the instrument by which an extraordinary political quartet nurtured since professional infancy by the legendary Democratic leader J. Raymond Jones would impart their legacy to a younger generation of New York politicians.

title: Music Festivals Are Siblings, Invisibly Bonded
description: The British-born electronic composers Kieran Hebden, who performs as Four Tet, and Natasha Barrett are both in San Francisco for concerts. Although Mr. Hebden is closely identified with the indie-pop scene, and Ms. Barrett with the contemporary classical world, they could easily be on the same bill. These musicians, creators of spiraling musique concrte-infused compositions that veer between sound art and trance, allow us to pick out tiny textural details in their work while basking in the musics overall ambience.

title: So Far, E-Books Arent Making Sales Waves
description: The publishing industrys alarm over the electronic book isnt based on current use. Last year, less than 2 percent of all books sold were e-books, according to Bowker, which tracks the industry.

title: No News Is Good News on Antidoping Testing at Olympics
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  With the Vancouver Games nearly over, officials here are breathing a sigh of relief that no major doping scandals have overshadowed the events. Still, they say, it would be nave to think that every athlete who competed here did so with natural talent alone.

title: U.S. and Canada in Fight for Olympic Hockey Gold
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Looking ahead to Sundays gold medal game, the Canadian coach, Mike Babcock, said of the Americans: We know them and they know us. There wont be a lot of surprises.

title: The Jobless in the New Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Thrill Ride, Mostly on 4 Wheels
description: SQUAMISH, British Columbia  Highway 99, the sole direct road between the Olympic host communities, is a route of many names. On its signs, it is the Sea-to-Sky Highway. In the past, many British Columbians called it the death highway. And its propensity to be blocked by massive rockslides leads some to call it the Sea-to-Slide.

title: Patersons Ability to Lead Is Questioned
description: When Gov. David A. Paterson ended his candidacy on Friday, he pledged to cooperate with an inquiry into his administrations handling of a domestic violence case and vowed to concentrate on his job.

title: Coin Tosses at the Combine
description: Because the Bears and the Jaguars finished 7-9, had identical strengths of schedule and did not play head-to-head, their draft position was determined by a coin flip at the combine Friday. The Jaguars won, earning the 10th pick. Chicagos No. 11 spot goes to Denver as part of the Jay Cutler trade (one could say the Bears 11th pick was intercepted by the Broncos).

title: Cuts to Public Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: When American and European Ideas of Privacy Collide
description: WASHINGTON  On the Internet, the First Amendment is a local ordinance, said Fred H. Cate, a law professor at Indiana University. He was talking about last weeks ruling from an Italian court that Google executives had violated Italian privacy law by allowing users to post a video on one of its services.

title: What We Owe Leonard Bernstein
description: To the Editor:

title: Error-Prone Coach Returns, but Cant Shake His Blunder
description: RICHMOND, British Columbia  The Dutch speedskating coach Gerard Kemkers was back on the ice Saturday for the Netherlands bronze medal bid in the mens team pursuit, skating back and forth with the lap counter but remaining essentially stuck in one place.

title: The Cost of Doing Nothing on Health Care
description: Hands off my health care, goes one strain of populist sentiment.

title: Ireland Defeats England, So France Is Alone at Top in Six Nations Rugby
description: LONDON  The closing game of the third weekend of the Six Nations rugby tournament produced two winners. One was an Irish team, which spent 80 minutes tackling huge Englishmen in the rain and the mud. The other was France, which had done its hard work the day before in Cardiff.

title: Redrawing the Route to Online Privacy
description: ON the Internet, things get old fast. One prime candidate for the digital dustbin, it seems, is the current approach to protecting privacy on the Internet.

title: Jordan Takes Control of Charlotte Bobcats
description: Michael Jordan may have retired from pro basketball years ago, but the N.B.A. legend is jumping back in the game in a different way.

title: Energy Scoreboards, Designed for the Home
description: UTILITIES are gradually installing smart meters that can tell homeowners the price of the electricity theyre using at the time, including discounts for off-peak hours.

title: Free Assistance (Well, for 90 Days)
description: IN this episode, the Haggler starts with a gripe of his own, and its not about some misdeed by a rogue corporation. No, ladies and gentlemen, it is about you. Well, not you, exactly. Its about your complaints. Not all of them, but many.

title: The Axis of the Obsessed and Deranged
description: No one knows what history will make of the present  least of all journalists, who can at best write historys sloppy first draft. But if I were to place an incautious bet on which political event will prove the most significant of February 2010, I wouldnt choose the kabuki health care summit that generated all the ink and 24/7 cable chatter in Washington. Id put my money instead on the murder-suicide of Andrew Joseph Stack III, the tax protester who flew a plane into an office building housing Internal Revenue Service employees in Austin, Tex., on Feb. 18. It was a flare with the dark afterlife of an omen.

title: Learning From the Sin of Sodom
description: For most of the last century, save-the-worlders were primarily Democrats and liberals. In contrast, many Republicans and religious conservatives denounced government aid programs, with Senator Jesse Helms calling them money down a rat hole.

title: Georgia Republican to Leave House
description: Another House Republican, Representative John Linder of Georgia, is stepping down at the end of this session, making him the 19th to do so. He announced his decision Saturday morning in his district outside Atlanta.

title: Two Markets: One to Blame, One to View as Normal
description: Todays Times has two articles that caught my eye. Both, in their own way, reflect views of markets.

title: A Familys Vision
description: MY fathers father, Bartolom Poma, was born in Barcelona and worked as a specialized car mechanic in Paris at the beginning of the 20th century.

title: How the G.O.P. Goes Green
description: It is early evening on Capitol Hill, and I am sitting with Senator Lindsey Graham, the South Carolina Republican, who, along with John Kerry and Joe Lieberman, is trying to craft a new energy bill  one that could actually win 60 votes. What is interesting about Graham is that he has been willing  courageously in my view  to depart from the prevailing G.O.P. consensus that the only energy policy we need is drill, baby, drill.

title: Writing a Rsum That Shouts Hire Me
description: ITS tempting to think of a rsum as a low-maintenance aspect of your job search. Just list where you worked, what you did and where you went to school, attach that to each application and press the button.

title: Talk to Me. Ill Turn Off My Phone.
description: This interview with Tachi Yamada, M.D.,  president of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundations Global Health Program, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Frustrated Strivers  in Pakistan Turn to Jihad
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Umar Kundi was his parents pride, an ambitious young man from a small town who made it to medical school in the big city. It seemed like a story of working-class success, living proof in this unequal society that a telephone operators son could become a doctor.

title: Turning a 10-Cent Comic Book Into a Million Bucks
description: This is a lesson for all those parents who threw away their childrens comic books: Last Monday, a copy of Action Comics No. 1, in which Superman first appeared in 1938, sold for a record $1 million. That price was eclipsed on Thursday by the $1,075,500 auction of a copy of Detective Comics No. 27, where Batman made his premiere in 1939.

description: Washington

title: Ease-E Does It
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Todays theme uses the reliable and oft-amusing letter substitution ploy, in this case changing an ea word into an ee word in eight phrases. The pronunciations stay the same, but the meanings dont.

description: CORPORATE insiders are sending fairly positive signals about the market.

title: Penultimate Day of Final Winter Testing
description: So what is the meaning of this? The penultimate day of winter testing ended in Barcelona today with the Mercedes of Nico Rosberg setting the fastest time, and at a very respectable 1:20.6 seconds.

title: Fixing Something That Wasnt Broken
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On the day pitchers and catchers reported to camp almost 10 days ago, General Manager Omar Minaya was asked about the teams approach to its two new Japanese pitchers. Minaya said it was important to allow them to do what they do best because they are familiar with it.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Buried Treasure in Your TV Dial
description: HERES a list of national domestic priorities, in no particular order: Stimulate the economy, improve health care, offer fast Internet connections to all of our schools, foster development of advanced technology. Oh, and lets not forget, wed better do something about the budget deficit.

title: Sochi Embraces Zorbs, Whatever They Are
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The handover from one host city to the next is a revered ritual of the Olympic closing ceremony, and the details are often a closely guarded secret until the event begins.

title: Sabathia vs. Halladay on Thursday
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joe Girardi announced the Yankees pitching setup for the first 11 days of spring training games, and from the outset we have a real treat. After the three long-shot No. 5 starter candidates  Chad Gaudin will start, followed by Sergio Mitre and Alfredo Aceves  pitch in Wednesdays Grapefruit League opener against Pittsburgh, C.C. Sabathia faces Philadelphia on Thursday  opposite Roy Halladay.

title: Its Time for Swaps to Lose Their Swagger
description: USING these instruments in a way that intentionally destabilizes a company or a country is  is counterproductive, and Im sure the S.E.C. will be looking into that.

title: Google and Brazil in Tourism Deal
description: Google is making another connection with Brazil.

title: Cross-Country Skier Bjoergen Adds to Medal Haul
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Whatever the distance, whatever the conditions, Marit Bjoergen of Norway emerged with a medal from every cross country ski race she entered at these Olympics.

title: A Players Attacks Pay Off, Even When They Shouldnt
description: Computer chess programs are so popular, and so good, that almost anybody can use one to figure out where a player went wrong  when the game is over. But at the board, competitors can rely only on their brains and wits (unless they are cheating) and are bound to make mistakes, especially when they are under pressure.

title: And the Orchestra Played On
description: The other day, I found myself rummaging through a closet, searching for my old viola. This wasnt how Id planned to spend the afternoon. I hadnt given a thought to the instrument in years. I barely remembered where it was, much less how to play it. But I had just gotten word that my childhood music teacher, Jerry Kupchynsky  Mr. K. to his students  had died.

title: Dont Count on Escobar
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Kelvim Escobar appears to be out of the running to be the eighth-inning setup man, or anything else for that matter, early in the season.

title: Closing the Gap Without Winning a Medal
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Olympic medal ceremony for womens figure skating brought the rarest of sights. For the first time, the South Korean flag was raised, in the gold medal position. And for the first time since 1964, the flag of the United States was not raised at all.

title: An Olympic Musical
description: When Usain Bolt left the field far, far behind in the 200 meters at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Amanda Cox and her colleagues in The Timess graphics department thought it would be interesting to demonstrate the massive winning margin in an auditory way. Two years later, Amanda has applied the concept to the events at the Vancouver Games that have often been determined by fractions of a second.

title: Proposal Would Change Playoffs Overtime Rules
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The N.F.L. could take the first steps toward changing its controversial overtime rules when the competition committee considers a rule that would give both teams a possession in overtime unless the team that receives the ball first scores a touchdown on the opening drive.

title: Shutout in Slalom Fails to Dim U.S. Mood
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  Near the end of the 2006 Turin Olympics, Hermann Maier, the Austrian ski star, mocked the United States ski teams celebrated pre-Olympics goal of Best in the World.

title: Earthquake and Aftershocks Shake Chile
description: More than 200 are confirmed dead after the magnitude-8.8 temblor toppled homes, buckled roads and triggered dozens of aftershocks. NBC's George Lewis Reports. (Video: MSNBC)

title: A Yankee With Ice in His Blood
description: TAMPA, Fla.  According to Yankees outfielder Jamie Hoffmann, no proper tour of his hometown, New Ulm, Minn., would be complete without a visit to the August Schell Brewing Company. The next stop, he is not so sure about. Maybe an outing to the Minnesota Music Hall of Fame or, if processed cheese is your thing, a drive past the Kraft Foods plant.

title: New Think and Old Weapons
description: Every four years the White House issues a nuclear posture review. That may sound like an anachronism. It isnt. In a world where the United States and Russia still have more than 20,000 nuclear weapons  and Iran, North Korea and others have seemingly unquenchable nuclear appetites  what the United States says about its arsenal matters enormously.

title: Germany Survives a Crash
description: It looked like the U.S. women were bound for the gold-medal race Saturday in the team pursuit when the last skater for Germany, their semifinal foe, crashed to the ice on the final curve.

title: The F.B.I.s Anthrax Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has issued a report that is supposed to clinch the case that a lone scientist mailed anthrax-laced letters in 2001, terrorizing a country already traumatized by the 9/11 attacks. The agency cites voluminous circumstantial evidence that is largely persuasive, but its report leaves too many loose ends to be taken as a definitive verdict.

title: Relieve the Chairman of His Gavel
description: Congressman Charles Rangel was far from humbled after the ethics committee admonished him for taking corporate-paid Caribbean junkets in violation of the House ethics code. Rather, the New York Democrat berated the panels leaders on the House floor.

title: White Knuckles and Gold for U.S. Bobsled Team
description: WHISTLER, British Columbia  The sports switch did not worry Steve Holcomb. When his son, Steven, changed winter sports allegiances from Alpine skiing to bobsled, he knew both were inherently dangerous and vastly time consuming and offered little return.

title: Nigeria Hires New Coach
description: Nigeria has hired the Swedish coach Lars Lagerback to lead the Super Eagles at the World Cup. Nigeria fired its head coach, Shaibu Amodu, after the team came in third during the African Cup of Nations. Lagerback resigned as Swedens coach in October after his team failed to qualify for the World Cup.

title: Djokovic Leads in Dubai
description: The defending champion Novak Djokovic led Mikhail Youzhny, 7-5, 2-0, before the Dubai Championship final was postponed because of rain. Djokovic, the No. 2 seed, was serving at 30-15 in the third game of the second set when rain forced the final to be rescheduled for Sunday.

title: Chelseas Streak Ends
description: Chelsea had two players sent off and Manchester City ended the English Premier League leaders 38-match unbeaten home streak by winning, 4-2. Chelsea missed a chance to extend its 1-point lead over the defending champion Manchester United. Third-place Arsenal closed the gap on Chelsea to 3 points by rallying to beat Stoke, 3-1.

title: Ferguson Boycott a Problem
description: Manchester United will be punished by the English Premier League if its manager, Alex Ferguson, keeps boycotting the British Broadcasting Corporation in the upcoming season.

title: Bradford Says Hes On Track
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Oklahoma quarterback Sam Bradford did not meet with reporters Friday as he was scheduled to do, in large part because the medical exam on his right shoulder took hours longer than anybody elses. Such is the life of the best quarterback in the draft and perhaps the top overall pick.

title: Muslims Wont Play Together
description: London

title: The Newest Met Malady
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Francisco Rodriguez went to a local eye doctor who confirmed his case of conjunctivitis. It doesnt stop Rodriguez from doing his work, but the Mets have semi-quarantined him.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the Malibu Journal article, about local resistance to development plans by David Evans, better known as U2s guitarist the Edge, misidentified, in some copies, the man shown walking with Mr. Evans along Mr. Evanss property above Malibu, Calif. He is Steven Billings, a landscape architect, not Jason Kinney of California Strategies.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Boston Red Sox chances of winning the American League East this season misstated a batting average for one of their off-season acquisitions. Outfielder Jeremy Hermida batted .259 for the Florida Marlins last season, not .301.

title: A Senators Frustration With a Partisan Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Alternatives to Jailing Children
description: To the Editor:

title: McGrady Exits as Knicks Fall to the Grizzlies
description: The exhilaration and intrigue surrounding Tracy McGradys arrival in New York has given way to a more familiar sensation: concern.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about Yitta Schwartz, a Satmar Hasid from Kiryas Joel, N.Y., who left perhaps 2,000 living descendants at her death last month at 93, was published in error. It showed Faige Teitelbaum, the widow of Joel Teitelbaum, the Satmar grand rabbi  not Mrs. Schwartz. (A picture of Mrs. Schwartz is at nytimes.com/nyregion.)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Sharon Zukin, a Brooklyn College sociology professor and critic of gentrification who argues for stronger government regulation of rents and zoning, referred incorrectly to the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, which Ms. Zukin cited as an example of inexorable gentrification. It is a project, not a place, and city officials did not in fact rezone the property to allow the development.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about airline fees misstated the amount that major airlines collected in baggage and other fees last year. It was $3.8 billion, not million. The article also misstated Virgin Atlantics policy on fees for choosing specific seats. While a fee applies to exit-row seats, the airline says it does not charge for other aisle seats.

title: Pictures of the Day: Saturday, Feb. 27
description: Images from the final Saturday of the Vancouver Games, including bobsled, curling, Alpine skiing and speedskating.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the Boss feature last Sunday about Luther S. Luedtke of the Education Development Center misstated one of his titles. He is president and chief executive, not chairman and chief executive.

title: McCoy Feels the Brees
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Texas quarterback Colt McCoy, who suffered a nerve injury that drove him from the national championship game, said he wasnt able to throw for about three weeks after the injury, but now he feels great. McCoy, who lost feeling in his arm during the game, said the feeling returned a few days later, but while he rested his arm, he worked on his footwork. He said there is nothing structurally wrong with his shoulder.

title: Odds and Ends From Port St. Lucie
description: Hisanori Takahashi threw another impressive bullpen session Saturday and drew raves from Rod Barajas, who was laughing trying to track his breaking ball. Takahashi is scheduled to pitch the first spring training game March 2, but may not be able to if his work visa doesnt come through by then. If it does, he could start that game.  As of Saturday the Mets still did not consider themselves close to attaining the left-handed reliever Joe Beimel. But Beimel told The Denver Post that he was weighing the offer.  As part of the Mets efforts to get their pitchers to throw more strikes, they are playing a DVD on the clubhouse televisions of Mets pitchers throwing strike one.

title: Your Comments on my Evangelicals Column
description: Im bracing myself for comments about my Sunday column about religion. Theres a tendency for liberals to devote lots of ink to decrying conservative Christians, because of their positions on social issues. I disagree strongly with typical evangelical positions on gay marriage, abortion, abstinence only education  but I also think that liberals dont appreciate the impact of the arrival of evangelicals into humanitarian space or give sufficient credit for that change. The United States is doing far more for Africa today than a decade ago largely because evangelicals became a strong constituency for the Pepfar AIDS program and the PMI malaria program. Liberals were always in favor of such ventures, and what changed was that conservatives pushed for them as well  and of course the Bush White House listened to them in a way it did not listen to liberals. And dont minimize those programs: Pepfar and PMI are saving millions of African lives.

title: Final Piece of Puzzle for Canadian Curler Martin
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  At Saturdays gold medal curling match, Canadas Kevin Martin won the one championship that has eluded him. We profiled Martin earlier this week.

title: The Thunder Is Rolling
description: Last season, the Oklahoma City Thunder finished with a 23-59 record, third worst in the Western Conference.

title: Rangers Get a Goalie
description: The Rangers have found the veteran backup goalie they have been looking for, claiming Alex Auld off re-entry waivers from Dallas. The 29-year-old Auld was 9-6-3 with a 3.00 goals-against average in 21 games this season with the Stars.

title: Williams Wins in Acapulco
description: Venus Williams came from a set down to defend her Mexican Open title with a 2-6, 6-2, 6-3 victory over Polona Hercog in Acapulco. It was Williamss second consecutive WTA title after winning a week ago in Dubai and pushed her career total to 43 WTA titles, the most by an active player.

title: Late Gold Rush Lifts Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Who needs the podium when you have the penthouse?

title: Canada Wins Mens Olympic Curling Gold
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The mens curling gold medal match started with noise: foot-stomping, head-splitting, ground-shaking noise.

title: John Reed, Master of Gilbert and Sullivans Patter Songs, Dies at 94
description: John Reed, a silver-tongued Gilbert and Sullivan singer renowned for urbanity, verbal inanity, touching humanity, antic insanity and (a noteworthy trait in a world-famous player quite used to performing for crowned heads of state) a singular lack of theatrical vanity, died in Halifax, England, on Feb. 13, his 94th birthday.

title: Harvick Is First in Las Vegas
description: Kevin Harvick overcame a pair of horrendous pit stops to win the Nationwide Series race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. Harvick led 83 of the 200 laps, but had to rally after his crew cost him several spots.

title: High-Profile Demotion of Thabeet Has Future Ramifications
description: Instead of making his Madison Square Garden debut Saturday night, Hasheem Thabeet, the No. 2 overall pick in the 2009 N.B.A. draft, came off the bench Friday night for the Dakota Wizards of the N.B.A.s Development League in a game in Erie, Pa.

title: Vows: Rebecca & Mike
description: Rebecca Shaw and Mike Kelly met at a mutual friend's party in 2005 and then went on their first date in Grand Central. They have travelled all around the world and each trip has brought them closer.

title: Now Screening | The Last Poet
description: The photographer and filmmaker Elle Muliarchyk brings her brand of sinister glamour to The Last Poet, an elegiac new fashion video, shot exclusively for T. I made it with a look that doesnt really exist these days,  says Muliarchyk of her latest offering, which was shot at more than 20 New York skyscrapers and inspired by Wings of Desire, the Wim Wenders film. Its not black and white exactly, but the richest tones of gray, giving the effect of ghosts emerging and disappearing in a storm cloud. Scary, Mary.

title: Doubles on Court, Twins at Home
description: Gigi Fernandez and her doubles partner, Natasha Zvereva, are among the International Tennis Hall of Fames 2010 inductees, to be announced at the Billie Jean King Cup on Monday at Madison Square Garden. Fernandez peaked at No. 17 in singles, yet won 2 Olympic gold medals and 17 Grand Slam titles in doubles. Fourteen of those Grand Slam championships were with Zvereva, the second-highest team total of the Open era behind that of Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver.

title: Coach Has 923 Wins, and Thats Easy Part
description: Herb Magee, the coach at Division II Philadelphia University, received accolades last week for passing Bob Knight on the N.C.A.A. mens basketball career list with his 903rd victory.

title: Filling Dome and Basket, Syracuse Routs Villanova
description: SYRACUSE  With Orange luminaries like Pearl Washington, Derrick Coleman and Lawrence Moten dotting courtside seats and with fans at the Carrier Dome seemingly stretched to Rochester, Syracuses game with Villanova on Saturday was more of an event.

title: Syracuse Star Is Hurting, but Still Smiling
description: SYRACUSE  The Syracuse star Wes Johnson is in a funk.

title: Officials Breathe Sigh of Relief as Tsunami Passes
description: TOKYO  The threat of lethal tsunami waves from the earthquake in Chile forced more than 1.5 million people to higher ground in countries on the other side of the Pacific Ocean on Sunday, but in the end small waves left only minor damage.

title: Get on the Bus
description: A bus "tricked out with a dance floor, moody lighting, a D.J. and free alcohol," with "Judas Priest blasting and cigarette smoke billowing." This is the scene on the Rusty Knot party ride from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to the Rusty Knot, a campy nautical-theme bar in the West Village. Begun last month by the owners of the bar, Taavo Somer and Ken Friedman, the shuttle "was at first nothing more than a way to fill their bar on Monday nights in the dead of winter," writes Alex Williams. But "with its minimal supervision (you must be 21 or older), the ride is a reminder of the days when New York nightlife seemed to have no rules." The free trip takes about 60 minutes and includes free Budweisers, and not surprisingly it results in a "cocoon of debauchery." "But even with music that can be punk-club loud, on the sidewalk nothing is heard but a muffled rumble. It is of New York, but separate from New York." Pick-up locations and times can be found on the bar's Web site and by following the Rusty Knot on twitter @therustyknot.

title: Army of Me
description: It's no secret that the Icelandic singer Bjork likes to experiment with different musical genres, so we suspect she would appreciate Bjorkestra. The group, led by the saxophonist and pianist Travis Sullivan, recasts the music of the quirky songstress for a modern-spirited big band. "For this one-night stand," Nate Chinen writes, "the group welcomes several accomplished guests: the tenor saxophonist Donny McCaslin, the keyboardist Rachel Z and the drummer Clarence Penn." Show times are at 8 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. at Blue Note.

title: Take a Chance
description: Is Chatroulette another Internet fad that will disappear in the next six months? Probably, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't make the most of the live-video-chat Web site while the trend lasts. "Entering Chatroulette is akin to speed-dating tens of thousands of perfect strangers  some clothed, some not," writes Nick Bilton. The site connects visitors through Webcams to a random, fathomless succession of strangers from across the globe. The experience is "very strange, and not just because you are parachuting into someone else's life (and they yours), a kind of invited crasher. It is also the eerie thrill of true randomness  who, or what, will show up next?" Tonight, Union Hall in Brooklyn is inviting New Yorkers to a Chatroulette night beginning at 7:30.

title: 30 Years Later, Same Dedication to Gold
description: Donna de Varona, who won two gold medals in swimming at the 1964 Olympics, is a writer, producer and an Emmy Award-winning broadcaster. She is currently a member of the International Olympic Committees Women and Sport Commission.

title: It Would Pay for Itself
description: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below. To allow others to recommend your jokes, send them one per comment, please:

title: Cat Elevator
description: Video | Landing on all fours just got a lot easier:

title: A Hometown Hero
description: Hannah Kearney, the first American gold medalist of this year's Winter Olympics, returned home to Norwich, Vt., to great fanfare.

title: State of the Raiders: What the 2009 Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: A Jazz Impresarios Return to Istanbul
description: Along with vibrant cultural and night-life scenes, another thing New York and Istanbul share in common is the talent of the saxophonist and impresario Ilhan Ersahin. Born in Stockholm, Mr. Ersahin now lives in New York, where in 2002 he opened Nublu, a small downtown club known for its eclectic programming and general good times (he also runs a small record label with the same name). He has recorded extensively in New York and Istanbul.

title: Rene Fleming Rocks Out
description: The soprano Rene Fleming is no stranger to venturing beyond her standard operatic domain. But even admirers who have followed her adventurous forays into jazz (as on her 2005 CD Haunted Heart) or heard her sing in an invented Elvish tongue for Howard Shores Lord of the Rings film scores may not have anticipated Dark Hope, a forthcoming CD from Decca on which Ms. Fleming will apply her skills in songs by iconoclastic rock acts (Leonard Cohen, Peter Gabriel) and current indie-rock darlings (Arcade Fire, Death Cab for Cutie).

title: Readers Photos: Chile Earthquake
Whats In a Name? Great Success (and Confusion) for U.S. Team
description: As General Manager Brian Burke built the United States Olympic roster, he intentionally passed on aging stars for younger, faster players. Coincidently, he managed to compile an impressive group of Ryans.

title: Howard Adds to His Milestones
description: Being the key player on a team that finished with more than 50 victories in each of the last two seasons was apparently not enough for center Dwight Howard of the Orlando Magic. Nor were his four trips to the All-Star Game, his slam-dunk contest title in 2008 or his Defensive Player of the Year award in 2009. On Wednesday, he did something that had not been done since the 1968-69 season, scoring 30 points, grabbing 16 rebounds and not missing a field goal. The player whose accomplishment he matched: Wilt Chamberlain.

title: Mario Andretti Turns 70  Goes to Bahrain
description: Happy birthday to Mario Andretti, who turns 70 today. And the party will continue to the first race of the F1 season as Andretti will go to Bahrain to be part of the celebrations of the 60 years of the Formula One World Championship, and he will be joined by a bunch of other champions and his Lotus 79 in which he won the 1978 title.

title: Frantic Rescue Efforts in Chile as Troops Seek to Keep Order
description: LIMA, Peru  With frantic rescue efforts under way, a rising death toll and isolated outbreaks of looting, the Chilean president on Sunday issued an order that will send soldiers into the streets in the worst-affected areas to both keep order and speed the distribution of aid.

title: The Sunday Word: Health Care Wars
description: With the White House preparing to usher another version of the health care legislation through a divided Congress and Congressional leaders talking reform on the Sunday television shows, President Obama has a doctors appointment of his own.

title: Food Flight: A Postcard from South Beach
description: If you live on the East Coast, went out to eat in a celebrity chefs restaurant on Friday or Saturday night, and are unsure whether he or she had a hand in your meals cooking, I can tell you, with enormous confidence and no rigorous fact checking whatsoever, that the answer is most likely no.

title: A Conversation With Paul Greengrass
description: Paul Greengrass is a former journalist who came late in life to the business of directing big-budget Hollywood action films, but he is responsible for two of the most successful thrillers of recent years, The Bourne Supremacy and The Bourne Ultimatum.

title: Federal Investigation Links N.F.L. Players to Use of Doping Drugs
description: Federal authorities investigating a Canadian doctor have uncovered information tying several N.F.L. players to the use of performance-enhancing drugs, according to several people who have been briefed on the investigation.

title: James Fields, the Visible Man
description: James Fields is an African-American Democratic state legislator in a nearly all-white Alabama county that voted overwhelmingly against Barack Obama. Is he an anomaly or the future?

title: Winter Testing Ends in Barcelona
description: The first eight cars are within half a second. As this is the last day of winter testing, that is it, now we are beginning to see what this winter testing has proven: We are almost certainly looking at a very, very tight grid starting in Bahrain in two weeks today. And the drivers are likely to make a difference. With Michael Schumacher consistently in around the sixth position, but now only .2 seconds behind the fastest car, that of Lewis Hamilton at McLaren, Im just thinking of how his racecraft and experience can make an exciting difference over a race. Im looking forward to this!

title: Evidence in Africa: Dance Troupe as Ambassadors
description: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa  Saturday was the first working day in South Africa for members of the Evidence Dance Company, one of three troupes (Urban Bush Women and ODC/Dance are the others) chosen for a series of monthlong tours to different continents, all funded by the State Department. DanceMotion USA, as its called, is the first time in decades that dance has played a major role as an official instrument of cultural exchange; the State Department is dedicating $1 million to this program, and plan for it to continue, according to Maura Pally, the acting assistant secretary at the Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs. This administration is very keen on people-to-people diplomacy, Ms. Pally said by telephone. The scope of audiences we can reach with this kind of programming is unparalleled, but its a personal connection too.

title: A.C.P.T. Vignettes
description: Before the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament fades into the sunset, here are a few glimpses Id like to share from behind the scenes:

title: Echoes of Mamula in Impressive Combine Performance
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Remember Mike Mamula? He was the workout warrior who wowed the 1995 scouting combine, running and lifting so well that he went from a third-round prospect to a top-10 pick, only to turn into a cautionary tale about putting too much stock in performance at combine drills. The Eagles traded up to take Mamula seventh over all, passing up Warren Sapp, the defensive tackle who anchored Tampa Bays defense and is almost certainly on his way to the Hall of Fame.

title: Spain Says It Arrested Basque Militant Leader
description: PARIS  The ranking leader of the armed Basque separatist group ETA was arrested in northern France early Sunday, officials said, with Spains interior minister saying that the group had been preparing an attack inside Spain.

title: Coach Wins 923 Games, and Thats the Easy Part
description: Herb Magee, the coach at Division II Philadelphia University, received accolades last week for passing Bob Knight on the N.C.A.A. mens basketball career list with his 903rd victory.

title: Park Arrives, Hoping for a Ring
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Greg Golson was originally given No. 61. Then one day, his number changed. It was all part of the Yankees plan to accommodate their newest player, Chan Ho Park, who finally appeared in camp on Sunday morning. Park, wearing his customary No. 61, called it an honor to wear pinstripes.

title: Now Screening | Marni
description: The fall 2010 collection from Marni at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Photos of the Moment | Color and Texture
description: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary from the photographers of Contrasto.

title: Now Screening | DSquared2
description: The fall 2010 collection from DSquared2 at Milan Fashion Week.

title: President in Excellent Health, Routine Checkup Finds
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is in excellent health and likely to remain able to carry out his duties for the rest of his term, his doctor said Sunday after completing Mr. Obamas first routine medical checkup since he took office.

title: Evidence in Africa: Dance in the Township of Joza
description: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa  Most South African towns have a kind of parallel city close by; the township, where thousands of people live in tiny, close-packed houses or self-made shacks, often several families to the one room that constitutes the house. Yesterday, as part of their U.S. State Department tour, the Evidence Dance Company spent the day in the township of Joza, a short drive away from the wide, tree-lined streets and Victorian houses of Grahamstown, where they are based for several days.

title: Video of Earthquake Damage in Chile
description: As my colleagues Alexei Barrionuevo and Marc Lacey report, more than 2 million have been displaced by Saturdays 8.8 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Chile. The countrys president said the death toll now stands at 708 and is expected to rise. My colleague Martin Fackler reports from Japan that there was widespread relief around the Pacific that the earthquake did not cause a deadly tsunami, as a larger earthquake off Chile did in 1960.

title: 2 Million Displaced After Chile Quake
description: After an 8.8-magnitude earthquake, residents of Santiago are seeking refuge where they can. Park benches have become beds, and cars have become bedrooms.

title: Documenting the Damage in Chile
description: Readers are sharing their photographs from the Chile earthquake.

title: European Union Moves Toward a Bailout of Greece
description: LONDON  Greece, in the midst of a financial crisis, is planning a bond deal this week that depends on a lot of things going right.

title: Moving Fast in the 40
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Chris Johnsons combine 40-yard dash record of 4.24, set in 2006, appears to be safe this year, but not by much. On Sunday morning, Clemson receiver Jacoby Ford, who is listed at 5-foot-9 and 186 pounds, was unofficially clocked running the 40 in 4.28 and 4.27 seconds. Thats blazing fast, but the official times are usually a few ticks slower.

title: Does Anybody Want to Throw?
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Quarterbacks work out at the scouting combine Sunday. If, in fact, any of them were planning to do anything. Most of the big-name quarterbacks do not plan to throw here, preferring to wait for their colleges pro days, when they can throw to familiar receivers. Thats understandable for quarterbacks like Sam Bradford, Jimmy Clausen and Colt McCoy, all of whom are recovering from injuries. But the decision by others hasnt pleased many coaches and general managers, who wanted to see quarterbacks  the healthy ones, at least  throw on neutral ground. (Central Michigans Dan LeFevour irked them in particular, because he is healthy and, unlike Tim Tebow, is not revamping his throwing motion.)

title: Dynamos Cruz: A Curious Route to M.L.S.
description: For most young American soccer players, the road to the pros  whether in Major League Soccer or abroad  usually begins as a precocious sprout, jersey reaching past his knees in the beehives of youth soccer. From there, it is on to club soccer, soccer in high school and either a pit stop in college or, for the elite, perhaps a tryout with a European, M.L.S. or Mexican club.

title: 15 Hurt When Ice Shatters Glass in Sony Building
description: Fifteen people were injured on Saturday night at a Midtown Manhattan high-rise after the ceiling of a glass atrium was shattered by falling ice, the authorities said Sunday.

title: Aftermath of the Earthquake in Chile
description: Residents in Chile took stock of a devastating 8.8 earthquake that flattened homes and took more than 300 lives.

title: Oz and Beyond
description: A look back at the films of Victor Fleming.

title: Industrial Nostalgia
description: About an hour ago, coming home. Not anymore, Im afraid. (It used to be a major ceramic center).

title: Revisionist History
description: So, on the This Week panel today I didnt get a chance to weigh in on the biggest whopper from Sen. Lamar Alexander, who told Elizabeth Vargas that reconciliation  I dont have the exact transcript  had in the past been used for small things and to reduce the deficit.

title: The Churning Insides of a Quiet Revolution
description: Amazing, isnt it, what could be hidden behind those sober jackets and ties that made American men look all but interchangeable in the early 1950s. The Temperamentals, Jon Maranss eminently likable docudrama about gay identity in the age of Eisenhower, begins with a classic vision of mid-20th-century uniformity: five guys in off-the-peg suits, as anonymous as the standard-issue, metal-frame chairs on which theyre seated.

title: Exotic Creatures and the Humans Who Chase Them
description: In her first book, the memoir Falling Through the Earth, Danielle Trussoni wrote of a rough-and-tumble childhood and a father who was irreparably damaged by his experiences as a tunnel rat in the Vietnam War. She also wrote that her mothers diary assigned numerical values to each family member, using a system by which Danielles sister rated a nine while Danielle rated only a four.

title: Storms in France Kill at Least 48
description: PARIS  A strong winter storm with powerful winds and heavy rain killed almost 60 people in at least five European countries over the weekend, with at least 48 of the dead in France, officials said Monday.

title: Finding Untainted Jurors in the Age of the Internet
description: WASHINGTON  When Enron collapsed in 2001, thousands of employees at its Houston headquarters lost their jobs and savings, and the citys economy reeled. Much of the publics anger was directed at Jeffrey K. Skilling, the companys former chief executive.

title: Both Sides Stand Their Ground on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Three days after an extraordinary forum moderated by President Obama to bridge the gulf between Democrats and Republicans over a health care, leaders of both parties drew clearer lines in the sand on Sunday.

title: Theyre Glad They Didnt Stop at Three
description: First, look at only the West hand and the auction. What would you have led against six no-trump?

title: Shes So Under the Gun, She Cant Leave Her Desk
description: LOS ANGELES  A warning really should be appended to the cellphones-off announcement at the Geffen Playhouse here, where Joanna Murray-Smiths rancid farce The Female of the Species recently opened in a production starring Annette Bening.

title: In a Bleak Era, Trying to Stay Connected Through Art
description: A lot of talent and some fine voices are on display in Signs of Life, a musical about Theresienstadt, the camp in Czechoslovakia where the Nazis put Jewish artists and performers in an effort to create a false image of life under Hitler. But, as might be expected, its a grim theatrical journey. This is not a show you come out of feeling entertained.

title: Mind Games
description: My insomnia always begins with me falling asleep. Ive been reading the same paragraph for the last five minutes  the text is suddenly impossibly dense  and I can feel the book getting heavier and heavier in my hands. Gravity is tugging on my eyelids.

title: Big Times for Buddies, Partying in Atlantic City
description: Extinction is the sort of play youve seen before  in nearly everything by Neil LaBute, in Stephen Belbers Tape, in Sam Shepards True West. Still, theres something intriguing going on here. After all, just because the story uses many of the same moves doesnt mean it cant pack a punch.

title: Village Attack Leaves 11 Dead in Philippines
description: MANILA  Eleven people, at least three of them children, were killed in an attack believed to have been carried out by the militant group Abu Sayyaf in retaliation for the recent arrests and deaths of several of its members, officials said Sunday.

title: Philharmonic in Red, White and Blue? Not Quite Yet
description: One expectation arising from Alan Gilberts appointment as music director of the New York Philharmonic was that, by instinct and experience, this native New Yorker would foster the creation and performance of works by American composers.

title: Now Letting His Guitar Do the Talking
description: The defining document of the John Mayer Implosion Era will not be the Q.&A. in the current issue of Playboy magazine, in which he made flip and unfortunate use of a racial epithet. That will survive, for better and worse, mostly in Twitter-bursts and sound bites and only fully in the outlets where that slur is reprintable.

title: As They Were Saying ... (Network Dramas Return)
description: Where are my shows?

title: New CDs
description: DANNY GOKEY My Best Days (19/RCA Nashville)

title: Prank
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This is an odd puzzle, for several reasons.

title: Oscar E-Mail Message Attracts Scrutiny
description: Oscar watchers are aflutter over an e-mail message from a producer of The Hurt Locker asking friends and colleagues to vote for his independent movie over bigger-budget competitors, an indirect dig at Avatar. The producer, Nicolas Chartier, has already sent an e-mail apology for his original plea, which apparently violated the rules of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on direct-mail campaigning and criticizing competitors. The academy wont respond officially until after Tuesday, when Oscar ballots are due. Most members have sent in their ballots already; voting closes at 5 p.m. Pacific time on Tuesday.

title: Aftra and S.A.G. Link Over Next TV Contract
description: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, or Aftra, said its national board of directors had approved plans to negotiate jointly with the Screen Actors Guild toward its next prime-time television contract. The vote, taken on Saturday, ended a split between those actors unions, which in the last round bargained separately after a disagreement over strategy but had previously joined in making deals with the major television production companies. Current contracts with the two unions do not expire until June 2011, but the unions are expected to begin an early negotiating session with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers in October. The talks are aimed at averting the sort of uncertainty that occurred when S.A.G. failed to reach a deal with the production companies in 2008 and worked for nearly a year without a contract, though Aftra had settled separately.

title: A $200,000 Grant for Soho Rep Theater
description: The Soho Rep theater in TriBeCa has been awarded a $200,000 grant by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the theaters publicists announced. According to a statement from the companys artistic director, Sarah Benson, the money will help support the companys over the next several seasons. SoHo Reps productions have included a critically acclaimed version of Sarah Kanes Blasted last season and Young Jean Lees Lear this season.

title: Rene Fleming Ventures Into Rock n Roll
description: The soprano Rene Fleming, below, has ventured beyond her standard operatic domain before. But even admirers who have followed her forays into jazz (as on her 2005 CD Haunted Heart) or heard her sing in an invented Elvish tongue for Howard Shores Lord of the Rings film scores may not have anticipated Dark Hope, a coming CD from Decca on which Ms. Fleming will perform songs by Leonard Cohen, Peter Gabriel, Arcade Fire and Death Cab for Cutie. The project was the brainchild of Peter Mensch and Cliff Burnstein from the management firm Q Prime, whose roster includes Metallica, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Josh Groban. Would Peter Gelb, now the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera but still remembered as the crossover-friendly head of the Sony Classical record label, consider presenting Ms. Flemings new project at the Met? Sure, Mr. Gelb said through a spokesman, without elaborating.

title: Brown Professor Wins History Prize
description: The historian Gordon S. Wood won the American History Book Prize last week for Empire of Liberty: A History of the Early Republic, 1789-1815, an account of how Americas leaders created the countrys democratic institutions. The award, presented by the New-York Historical Society, comes with a $50,000 prize, an engraved medal and the title of American Historian Laureate. Mr. Wood, professor emeritus at Brown University, beat out 129 other nominees. He will formally pick up the award on March 26.

title: Shutter Island Stays Afloat at No. 1
description: Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio, below, weathered a storm of critics and snow for the second week in a row, landing their Shutter Island (Paramount Pictures) at No. 1 at the weekend domestic box office. According to the Screenline box-office report, the film took in $22.2 million (for a total of just over $75 million). In their debut weeks the Warner Brothers buddy comedy Cop Out was No. 2, with a little more than $18.5 million, and the Overture thriller Crazies was No. 3, with $16.5 million. They pushed Avatar (20th Century Fox) to fourth place with $14 million in its 11th week ($706.9 million total domestically). Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (Fox) took the fifth spot, earning $9.8 million in its third week (total so far: $71.2 million).

title: Buyer of Giacometti Sculpture Is Revealed
description: The Giacometti sculpture Walking Man I, which sold for a record $104.3 million at Sothebys last month, above, was bought by the billionaire Lily Safra, according to Bloomberg News. The news service said that two dealers who declined to be identified had confirmed the identity of the buyer. The Brazilian-born Ms. Safra, widow of the banker Edmond J. Safra, is based in London, where the statue was part of a sale of Impressionist and modern art. Sothebys has not identified the buyer, who made the bid by phone to Philip Hook, an expert at the auction houses Impressionist and modern art department. The sale broke the world-record price for a work of art at auction.

title: British Firm Said to Consider $30 Billion Deal With A.I.G.
description: Prudential P.L.C., the British financial services company, is in talks with the American International Group over a potential deal for A.I.G.s big life insurance business in Asia that could be worth more than $30 billion, people briefed on the matter said Saturday.

title: New Shrek to Open TriBeCa Film Festival
description: Shrek Forever After, the final chapter in the adventures of Shrek, the beloved ogre, and the first of the series to be presented in 3-D, will have its premiere on April 21, the opening night of this years Tribeca Film Festival, DreamWorks and festival officials announced. The familiar voices of Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy, Cameron Diaz and Antonio Banderas will be heard in the new story, which features the grumpy green hero as a domesticated family man longing for a little adventure. The film will be released in theaters nationwide on May 21.

title: Sharing Affinity for Haydn
description: According to the superb pianist Andras Schiff, Haydn is the most underrated of the great composers, his piano music relatively neglected because many of the renowned pianists of the 19th and 20th centuries did not perform it. Haydn, whose bicentennial was celebrated last year, certainly has a powerful champion in Mr. Schiff, who gave a revelatory recital at the 92nd Street Y on Thursday, the first in a series of Haydn events that end on Monday.

title: Mets Waiting on Takahashi
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Japanese left-hander Hisanori Takahashi was tentatively scheduled to start the first spring training game on Tuesday, but visa issues prompted the Mets to change the plan.

title: Loosening the Reins on Composers After Stalin
description: When the American Symphony Orchestra is firing on all cylinders, its concerts can be immensely gratifying. The ensemble has strong principal players and consistently delivers creditable performances. Few programmers mine hidden corners of the orchestral repertory as avidly and shrewdly as Leon Botstein, the orchestras music director and conductor. No one contextualizes better.

title: In City Ballets Season One Jewel Still Sparkles
description: George Balanchines Cortge Hongrois is not one of the masters greatest ballets, whereas his Liebeslieder Walzer is. Yet as New York City Ballets winter season ended Sunday, I found myself forgetting the one performance I did see of this seasons only Liebeslieder cast but pining to have seen one particular cast change in Cortge.

title: A Look Back: The Defining Performances
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Unlike my colleagues who offer their views in the video above about the athlete who will leave the most lasting impression from these Games, Im no expert. When safely back in my base in Ottawa, I cover Canada generally, not sports specifically, for The Times.

title: Boisterous Bliss in Celebration of an Iron Tiger Year
description: You dont see much stage-diving at Carnegie Hall, but a stage-dive was exactly what the shirtless Iggy Pop did as he started I Wanna Be Your Dog on Friday night. Backed by the Patti Smith Band and the Scorchio String Quartet, he was headlining the 20th annual benefit concert for Tibet House US, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving Tibetan culture. And if I Wanna Be Your Dog seemed like a punky, unruly song for a concert that always starts with the sacred chanting of Tibetan Buddhist monks, Mr. Pop pointed out what d-o-g spells backward.

title: Live Analysis: Canada Beats the U.S. for Gold Medal
description: In-game analysis from the New York Times reporters Jeff Z. Klein, Charles McGrath and Greg Bishop at Canada Hockey Place in Vancouver, and insights from The Timess Slap Shot blog contributor Stu Hackel. Richard Sandomir, who covers sports media and business for The Times, shared thoughts about the broadcast. Post your thoughts about the game in the comment section below.

title: Taking the Bait: Chefs and Stars
description: This chef business is heating up. Readers seem frustrated with the process, with me, with the concept of chefs as stars instead of chefs earning stars. It could be a reaction to the Food Network, or it could just be impatience with my micromanaging. Whatever. As I tell myself every day: If you cant stand the hire, get out of the kitchen.

title: Chilean Quake a Warning to U.S. Northwest
description: Im dealing with a disaster of microscopic dimensions, being among the 200,000 households in the Northeast still lacking electricity, heat and flushing toilets three days after an astonishing dump of snow.

title: Now Screening | Missoni
description: The fall 2010 collection from Missoni at Milan Fashion Week.

title: For WWS 543, March 1
description: Readings. (doc)

title: Now Screening | Gucci
description: The fall 2010 collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.
